.

<START>

Inc.
said

expects

to
remain
steady
at
about
1,200
cars
in
1990
.
<END>
<START>
The
luxury
auto
maker
last
year
sold
1,214
cars
in
the
U.S.
<END>
<START>

,

and

anticipates

,

.

10

.

Feb.

.

has
n't

.

,

,

.

<START>
Investors
are
appealing
to
the
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
not
to
limit
their
access
to
information
about
stock
purchases
and
sales
by
corporate
insiders
.
<END>
<START>
A
SEC
proposal
to
ease
reporting
requirements
for
some
company
executives
would
undermine
the
usefulness
of
information
on
insider
trades
as
a
stock-picking
tool
,
individual
investors
and
professional
money
managers
contend
.
<END>
<START>
The
proposed
changes
also
would
allow
executives
to
report
exercises
of
options
later
and
less
often
.
<END>
<START>
``
Apparently
the
commission
did
not
really
believe
in
this
ideal
.
''
<END>
<START>
Currently
,
the
rules
force
executives
,
directors
and
other
corporate
insiders
to
report
purchases
and
sales
of
their
companies
'
shares
within
about
a
month
after
the
transaction
.
<END>
<START>
But
about
25
%
of
the
insiders
,
according
to
SEC
figures
,
file
their
reports
late
.
<END>
<START>
The
SEC
will
probably
vote
on
the
proposal
early
next
year
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Not
all
those
who
wrote
oppose
the
changes
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
some
estimates
,
the
rule
changes
would
cut
insider
filings
by
more
than
a
third
.
<END>
<START>
The
SEC
's
Mr.
Lane
vehemently
disputed
those
estimates
.
<END>
<START>
The
rules
will
eliminate
filings
policy-making
divisions
,
such
as
sales
,
marketing
,
finance
and
research
and
development
,
Mr.
Lane
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
proposed
rules
also
would
be
tougher
on
the
insiders
still
required
to
file
reports
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Companies
would
be
compelled
to
publish
in
annual
proxy
statements
the
names
of
insiders
who
fail
to
file
reports
on
time
.
<END>
<START>
Many
investors
wrote
asking
the
SEC
to
require
insiders
to
report
their
purchases
and
sales
immediately
,
not
a
month
later
.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Lane
said
that
while
the
SEC
regulates
who
files
,
the
law
tells
them
when
to
do
so
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
who
want
to
change
the
required
timing
should
write
their
representatives
in
Congress
,
he
added
.
<END>
<START>
The
SEC
would
likely
be
amenable
to
legislation
that
required
insiders
to
file
transactions
on
a
more
timely
basis
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
nation
's
largest
pension
fund
,
which
oversees
$
80
billion
for
college
employees
,
plans
to
offer
two
new
investment
options
to
its
1.2
million
participants
.
<END>
<START>
The
Teachers
Insurance
and
Annuity
Association-College
Retirement
Equities
Fund
said
it
will
introduce
a
stock
and
bond
fund
that
will
invest
in
``
socially
responsible
''
companies
,
and
a
bond
fund
.
<END>
<START>
Both
funds
are
expected
to
begin
operation
around
March
1
,
subject
to
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
approval
.
<END>
<START>
For
its
employees
to
sign
up
for
the
options
,
a
college
also
must
approve
the
plan
.
<END>
<START>
Some
4,300
institutions
are
part
of
the
pension
fund
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
``
social
choice
''
fund
will
shun
securities
of
companies
linked
to
South
Africa
,
nuclear
power
and
in
some
cases
,
Northern
Ireland
.
<END>
<START>
Also
excluded
will
be
investments
in
companies
with
``
significant
''
business
stemming
from
weapons
manufacture
,
alcoholic
beverages
or
tobacco
.
<END>
<START>
Sixty
percent
of
the
fund
will
be
invested
in
stocks
,
with
the
rest
going
into
bonds
or
short-term
investments
.
<END>
<START>
The
bond
fund
will
invest
in
high-grade
or
medium-grade
bonds
,
mortgages
or
asset-backed
securities
,
including
as
much
as
15
%
in
foreign
securities
.
<END>
<START>
The
fund
also
might
buy
and
sell
futures
and
options
contracts
,
subject
to
approval
by
the
New
York
State
Insurance
Department
.
<END>
<START>
The
investment
choices
offered
by
the
pension
fund
currently
are
limited
to
a
stock
fund
,
an
annuity
and
a
money-market
fund
.
<END>

``

.

<START>
Richard
Stoltzman
has

.
<END>
<START>
Just

<START>
But

.
<END>
<START>
He
believes

,

.
<END>
<START>
His
recent

at
the

Museum
,
dubbed
``
A
Musical
Odyssey
,
''
was
a
case

.
<END>
<START>
It
felt
more

a

,
or
a

with

,

a

.
<END>
<START>
He
launched
into
Saint-Saens
's
``
The
Swan
''
from
``
Carnival
of
the
Animals
,
''
a
favorite

piece
for
cellists
,
with
lovely
,

and
no

.
<END>
<START>
And

went

:
an

of
pieces
,
none

,

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Stoltzman
introduced

:
Bill
Douglas
,

and
an
old
buddy
from
Yale
,

Eddie
Gomez
.
<END>
<START>
Bach
's
``
Air
''

.
<END>
<START>
``
Deep
Peace
''
also

a

show
of
lovely

images
of
clouds
,

,

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
That
went

permissible
line
for

.
<END>
<START>
Was

?
<END>
<START>
Or

Collins

's

''

.

<END>
<START>
Mr.

:
He

''

:

<START>
Ms.
Waleson
is
a
free-lance
writer
based
in
New
York
.
<END>
<START>
One
of
Ronald
Reagan
's
attributes
as
President
was
that
he
rarely
gave
his
blessing
to
the
claptrap
that
passes
for
``
consensus
''
in
various
international
institutions
.
<END>
<START>
In
fact
,
he
liberated
the
U.S.
from
one
of
the
world
's
most
corrupt
organizations
--
UNESCO
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
the
U.N.
group
that
managed
to
traduce
its
own
charter
of
promoting
education
,
science
and
culture
.
<END>
<START>
Ever
since
,
the
remaining
members
have
been
desperate
for
the
United
States
to
rejoin
this
dreadful
group
.
<END>
<START>
Now
UNESCO
apologists
are
lobbying
President
Bush
to
renege
on
President
Reagan
's
decision
to
depart
.
<END>
<START>
But
we
can
think
of
many
reasons
to
stay
out
for
the
foreseeable
future
and
well
beyond
.
<END>
<START>
The
U.S.
,
along
with
Britain
and
Singapore
,
left
the
agency
when
its
anti-Western
ideology
,
financial
corruption
and
top
leadership
got
out
of
hand
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
M'Bow
was
an
extreme
case
,
but
even
his
replacement
,
the
more
personally
genial
Spanish
biochemist
Federico
Mayor
,
has
had
little
success
at
achieving
reforms
.
<END>
<START>
Several
ridiculous
projects
continue
,
including
the
``
New
International
Economic
Order
,
''
which
means
redistributionism
from
the
West
to
pay
for
everyone
else
's
statism
.
<END>
<START>
UNESCO
somehow
converted
the
founding
U.N.
ideals
of
individual
rights
and
liberty
into
``
peoples
'
rights
.
''
<END>
<START>
Million-dollar
conferences
were
held
to
chew
on
subjects
such
as
``
ethical
responsibilities
of
scientists
in
support
of
disarmament
''
and
``
the
impact
of
the
activities
of
transnational
corporations
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
agency
was
so
totally
subverted
from
the
high
principles
of
its
founding
that
even
the
Soviets
now
wonder
about
an
agency
that
seemed
so
congenial
to
them
.
<END>
<START>
Glasnost
may
be
partly
responsible
,
but
Soviet
Foreign
Minister
Eduard
Shevardnadze
last
year
admitted
,
``
The
exaggerated
ideological
approach
undermined
tolerance
intrinsic
to
UNESCO
.
''
<END>
<START>
UNESCO
is
now
holding
its
biennial
meetings
in
Paris
to
devise
its
next
projects
.
<END>
<START>
He
has
n't
been
able
to
replace
the
M'Bow
cabal
.
<END>
<START>
Of
the
agency
's
2,750
staff
members
,
230
are
in
the
field
working
on
actual
projects
,
such
as
literacy
and

research
.
<END>
<START>
The
position
of
the
United
States
,
which
once
contributed
25
%
of
the
budget
,
is
that
nothing
has
changed
.
<END>
<START>
This
has
n't
much
bothered
the
UNESCO
delegates
,
who
last
week
could
n't
even
agree
to
raise

by
selling

French

the

.

<START>
Other

,
including
West
Germany
,
may

.
<END>
<START>
We
see

even
stronger

against
UNESCO
than
its

failure
to

.
<END>
<START>
This
is

shows

We

.
<END>
<START>
Researchers
at
Plant
Genetic
Systems
N.V.
in
Belgium
said
they
have
developed
a
genetic
engineering
technique
for
creating
hybrid
plants
for
a
number
of
key
crops
.
<END>
<START>
The
researchers
said
they
have
isolated
a
plant
gene
that
prevents
the
production
of
pollen
.
<END>
<START>
The
gene
thus
can
prevent
a
plant
from
fertilizing
itself
.
<END>
<START>
Such
so-called
male-sterile
plants
can
then
be
fertilized
by
pollen
from
another
strain
of
the
plant
,
thereby
producing
hybrid
seed
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
generation
of
plants
will
possess
the
flourishing
,
high-production
trait
known
as
``
hybrid
vigor
,
''
similar
to
that
now
seen
in
hybrid
corn
.
<END>
<START>
On
a
commercial
scale
,
the
sterilization
of
the
pollen-producing
male
part
has
only
been
achieved
in
corn
and
sorghum
feed
grains
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
because
the
male
part
,
the
tassel
,
and
the
female
,
the
ear
,
are
some
distance
apart
on
the
corn
plant
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
labor-intensive
process
,
the
seed
companies
cut
off
the
tassels
of
each
plant
,
making
it
male
sterile
.
<END>
<START>
They
sow
a
row
of
male-fertile
plants
nearby
,
which
then
pollinate
the
male-sterile
plants
.
<END>
<START>
The
first
hybrid
corn
seeds
produced
using
this
mechanical
approach
were
introduced
in
the
1930s
and
they
yielded
as
much
as
20
%
more
corn
than
naturally
pollinated
plants
.
<END>
<START>
The
vast
majority
of
the
U.S.
corn
crop
now
is
grown
from
hybrid
seeds
produced
by
seed
companies
.
<END>
<START>
A
similar
technique
is
almost
impossible
to
apply
to
other
crops
,
such
as
cotton
,
soybeans
and
rice
.
<END>
<START>
The
anthers
in
these
plants
are
difficult
to
clip
off
.
<END>
<START>
At
Plant
Genetic
Systems
,
researchers
have
isolated
a
pollen-inhibiting
gene
that
can
be
inserted
in
a
plant
to
confer
male
sterility
.
<END>
<START>
The
sterilizing
gene
is
expressed
just
before
the
pollen
is
about
to
develop
and
it
deactivates
the
anthers
of
every
flower
in
the
plant
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Leemans
said
this
genetic
manipulation
does
n't
hurt
the
growth
of
that
plant
.
<END>
<START>
The
researchers
also
pulled
off
a
second
genetic
engineering
trick
in
order
to
get
male-sterile
plants
in
large
enough
numbers
to
produce
a
commercial
hybrid
seed
crop
.
<END>
<START>
They
attached
a
second
gene
,
for
herbicide
resistance
,
to
the
pollen-inhibiting
gene
.
<END>
<START>
Both
genes
are
then
inserted
into
a
few
greenhouse
plants
,
which
are
then
pollinated
and
allowed
to
mature
and
produce
seed
.
<END>
<START>
The
laws
of
heredity
dictate
that
half
of
the
plants
springing
from
these
greenhouse-produced
seeds
will
be
male
sterile
and
herbicide
resistant
and
half
will
be
male
fertile
and
herbicide
susceptible
.
<END>
<START>
The
application
of
herbicide
would
kill
off
the
male-fertile
plants
,
leaving
a
large
field
of
male-sterile
plants
that
can
be
cross-pollinated
to
produce
hybrid
seed
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Leemans
said
the
hybrid
rapeseeds
created
with
this
genetic
engineering
yield
15
%
to
30
%
more
output
than
the
commercial
strains
used
currently
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
the
company
is
experimenting
with
the
technique
on
alfalfa
,
and
plans
to
include
cotton
and
corn
,
among
other
crops
.
<END>
<START>
In
recent
years
,
demand
for
hybrid
seeds
has
spurred
research
at
a
number
of
chemical
and
biotechnology
companies
,
including
Monsanto
Co.
,
Shell
Oil
Co.
and
Eli
Lilly
&
Co
.
<END>
<START>
One
technique
developed
by
some
of
these
companies
involves
a
chemical
spray
supposed
to
kill
only
a
plant
's
pollen
.
<END>
<START>
But
there
have
been
problems
with
chemical
sprays
damaging
plants
'
female
reproductive
organs
and
concern
for
the
toxicity
of
such
chemical
sprays
to
humans
,
animals
and
beneficial
insects
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
Paul
Johanson
,
Monsanto
's
director
of
plant
sciences
,
said
the
company
's
chemical
spray
overcomes
these
problems
and
is
``
gentle
on
the
female
organ
.
''
<END>
<START>
Biosource
Genetics
Corp.
,
Vacaville
,
Calif.
,
is
developing
a
spray
containing
a
gene
that
spreads
from
cell
to
cell
and
interferes
with
the
genes
that
are
responsible
for
producing
pollen
.
<END>
<START>
This
gene
,
called
``
gametocide
,
''
is
carried
into
the
plant
by
a
virus
that
remains
active
for
a
few
days
.
<END>
<START>
Robert
Erwin
,
president
of
Biosource
,
called
Plant
Genetic
's
approach
``
interesting
''
and
``
novel
,
''
and
``
complementary
rather
than
competitive
.
''
<END>
<START>
``
There
is
a
large
market
out
there
hungry
for
hybrid
seeds
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
because
pollination
,
while
easy
in
corn
because
the
carrier
is
wind
,
is
more
complex
and
involves
insects
as
carriers
in
crops
such
as
cotton
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
one
thing
to
say
you
can
sterilize
,
and
another
to
then
successfully
pollinate
the
plant
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Nevertheless
,
he
said
,
he
is
negotiating
with
Plant
Genetic
to
acquire
the
technology
to
try
breeding
hybrid
cotton
.
<END>
<START>
A
bitter
conflict
with
global
implications
has
erupted
between
Nomura
Securities
Co.
and
Industrial
Bank
of
Japan
,

world
's

.
<END>
<START>
The

's

.
<END>
<START>

;

.
<END>
<START>

,

.

<START>

.
<END>

's

.

.

Canada
's

rose

,

as

growth

,

.
<END>
<START>

August

2.4
%
from

.
<END>
<START>
GDP
is

's

.
<END>
<START>

Canada
said

in
August
rose
0.4
%
from
July
.
<END>
<START>
Output
of
goods-producing
industries
increased
0.1
%
.

.

.

,

.

.

,

.

.

<START>

.

.

.

.

,

.

.

.

<START>
A

.
<END>
<START>

.

,

.

.
<END>
<START>
Here
are

on

's

,
as

close
of
1969
equaling
100
.
<END>
<START>
The
percentage
change
is
since

.
<END>
<START>
French
consumer
prices
rose
0.2
%
in
September
from
the
previous
month
and
were
up
3.4
%
from
a
year

,
according

from
the
National

.
<END>
<START>
The
state
agency
's
figures
confirm
previous
estimates
and
leave
the
index
at
178.9
,
up
from
178.5
in
August
and
173.1
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
The
index
is
based
on
1980
equaling
100
.
<END>
<START>
A
breakdown
showed
that
food
prices
were
the
most
active
part
of
growth
with
a
rise
of
0.6
%
.
<END>
<START>
An
official
linked
the
gain
essentially
to
higher

for

and

.
<END>
<START>
He
said
summer

that
had
hit
several
southern
agricultural
regions
had
stopped
being
a
major
source
of

pressure
in

.
<END>
<START>
Japan
's
index
of
leading
indicators
rose
to
63.6
in
August
,
above
the
so-called
boom-or-bust
line
of
50
for
the
first
time
since
May
,
the
Economic
Planning
Agency
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
leading
index
recovered
from
July
's
revised
level
of
36.6
on
strong
performances
in
consumer
durables
and
machinery
orders
,
among
other
factors
,
according
to
an
agency
spokeswoman
.
<END>
<START>
The
index
is
intended
to
measure
future
economic
performance
.
<END>
<START>
A
figure
above
50
indicates
the
economy
is
likely
to
expand
;
one
below
50
indicates
a
contraction
may
be
ahead
.
<END>
<START>
Metromedia
Co.
said
its
Metromedia
Long
Distance
unit
has
been

Long
Distance
,
reflecting

from
ITT
Corp.
,
which
licenses
its
name
to
closely
held

.
<END>
<START>
Metromedia
said
its
unit
is
the

provider
of

communications
service
in
the
U.S.
,
with
projected
1989
revenue
of
more
than
$
550
million
.
<END>
<START>
Metromedia
,
headed
by
John
W.

,
has
interests
in

,

painting
,
computer
software
,

and

.

<START>

to

released
by

two

agencies
,

consumer
and

prices
each
rose
by
0.2
%
in

from

previous
month
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,

for
the
first
10
months
of
1989
surged
by
5
%
and

by
1.3
%
.

<START>
The
South
Korean
government
had
been

5
%

price
increase
for
the
entire
year
.
<END>

,

,

.

<END>
<START>
Yields
on
savings-type
certificates
of
deposit
dropped
slightly
in
the
week
ended
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
yield
on
a
six-month
CD
of
$
50,000
or
less
was
7.90
%
,
compared
with
7.94
%
a
week
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
one-year
savings-type
CD
was
down
to
7.99
%
from
8.01
%
,
according
to
Banxquote
Money
Markets
,
a
New
York
information
service
that
tracks
CD
yields
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
week
was
uneventful
for
the
CD
market
,
''
said
Norberto
Mehl
,
chairman
of
Banxquote
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
major
banks
have
n't
even
reacted
to
sharp
rises
in
the
three-month
Treasury
bill
rates
''
in
the
past
two
weeks
.
<END>
<START>
Banks
that
adjusted
payouts
on
CDs
in
the
most
recent
week
made
only
fractional
moves
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
CD
trend
runs
counter
to
the
direction
of
short-term
interest
rates
at
the
Treasury
bill
auction
Monday
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
six-month
bill
was
sold
with
a
yield
of
8.04
%
,
up
from
7.90
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
three-month
issue
rose
to
8.05
%
from
7.77
%
.
<END>
<START>
Typically
,
banks
offer
CD
yields
higher
than
those
on
Treasury
bills
,
which
are
considered
the
safest
short-term
investments
;
banks
need
a
competitive
edge
to
sell
their
products
.
<END>
<START>
But
when
market
interest
rates
move
up
rapidly
,
increases
in
bank
CD
yields
sometimes
lag
.
<END>
<START>
Most
yields
on
short-term
jumbo
CDs
,
those
with
denominations
over
$
90,000
,
also
moved
in
the
opposite
direction
of
Treasury
bill
yields
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
six-month
yield
on
a
jumbo
CD
was
at
7.90
%
,
down
from
7.93
%
,
Banxquote
said
.
<END>
<START>
For
longer-term
CDs
,
yields
were
up
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
two-year
and
five-year
jumbos
were
up
0.02
of
a
percentage
point
to
7.91
%
and
7.96
%
,
respectively
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
CDs
sold
through
major
broker-dealer
networks
were
up
slightly
almost
across
the
board
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
six-month
CD
in
that
category
added
0.05
percentage
point
to
8.35
%
,
for
example
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Mehl
attributed
the
rise
specifically
to
the
Treasury
bill
increase
.
<END>
<START>
Among
the
major
banks
surveyed
by
Banxquote
in
six
regions
of
the
country
,
8.33
%
is
the
highest
yield
available
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
offered
by
the
flagship
banks
of
New
York
's
Manufacturers
Hanover
Corp.
in
the
one-year
maturity
only
.
<END>
<START>
The
yield
is
offered
across
a
range
of
maturities
at
San
Francisco
's
BankAmerica
Corp.
and
Wells
Fargo
&
Co
.
<END>
<START>
Just
two
weeks
ago
,
BankAmerica
's
yields
in
many
of
those
maturities
was
8.61
%
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
on
average
,
the
major
California
banks
have
the
highest
yields
on
CDs
,
according
to
Banxquote
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
yield
there
on
six-month
issues
is
8.32
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
man
with
the
clipboard
represented
a
halfhearted
attempt
to
introduce
a
bit

<START>
Norway
's

October

3.6
%
,

September
but

.

.

,

non-family
shareholder
.
<END>
<START>
His
new

would

in

of

,
which
receive
higher

but
have

only
in

.
<END>
<START>
The
Aga
Khan
owns
10
%
of

's

,
while

owns
23
%
.
<END>
<START>
Its

will

to
232.4
billion
lire
-LRB-
$
172.5
million
-RRB-
from

current
204.3
billion

.
<END>
<START>
IFI

,

.

<START>

,

.

<START>
Congressional
Democrats
and
the
Bush
administration
agreed
on
a
compromise
minimum-wage
bill
,
opening
the
way
for
the
first
wage-floor
boost
in
more
than
nine
years
.
<END>
<START>
The
agreement
ended
a
long
impasse
between
the
congressional
leaders
and
the
White
House
over
the
wage
issue
.
<END>
<START>
The
compromise
was
a
somewhat
softened
version
of
what
the
White
House
had
said
it
would
accept
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
agreement
with
the
House
and
Senate
leaders
,
the
minimum
wage
would
rise
from
the
current
$
3.35
an
hour
to
$
4.25
an
hour
by
April
1991
.
<END>
<START>
White
House
officials
were
delighted
that
the
compromise
includes
the
concept
of
a
training
wage
,
which
Mr.
Bush
has
fought
for
throughout
the
year
.
<END>
<START>
White
House
aides
said
that
although
they
made
a
small
compromise
on
the
length
of
a
training
wage
,
the
final
minimum-wage
increase
will
meet
the
standards
set
by
Mr.
Bush
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
compromise
,
the
$
4.25
level
would
be
reached
nine
months
earlier
,
while
the
training
subminimum
would
be
shorter
,
unless
it
is
tied
to
a
training
plan
.
<END>
<START>
Democrats
had
been
negotiating
with
some
Republican
congressional
leaders
on
a
compromise
lately
.
<END>
<START>
Republicans
have
been
imploring
the
White
House
to
compromise
on
the
wage
issue
.
<END>
<START>
The
House
is
scheduled
to
vote
this
week
on
the
compromise
,
as
a
substitute
to
a
new
Democratic
bill
,
itself
watered
down
from
last
spring
's
version
.
<END>
<START>
The
Senate
will
probably
vote
not
long
afterward
.
<END>
<START>
Some
Democrats
thought
they
might
have
compromised
too

.
<END>
<START>
Gerald
F.
Seib
contributed
to
this
article
.

Armstrong
World
Industries
Inc.
agreed
in

its

operations
to
Shaw
Industries
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
The
price
was
n't
disclosed
but
one
analyst
estimated
that
it
was
$
150
million
.
<END>
<START>
Armstrong
,
which
has
faced
a
takeover
threat
from
the
Belzberg
family
of
Canada
since
July
,
said
that
disposing
of
the
carpet
business
would
improve
``
total
financial
performance
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
move
also
would
allow
the
company
to
concentrate
on
core
businesses
,
which
include
ceramic
tile
,
floor
coverings
and

.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,

a
sale
could
help
Armstrong
reassure
its

and
deter
the
Belzbergs
,
who
own
a
9.85
%

in
the
Lancaster
,
Pa.
,
company
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
expect
Armstrong
to
use
proceeds
of
the
sale
to
reduce
debt
,
buy
back
stock
or
perhaps
finance
an
acquisition
.
<END>
<START>
The
carpet
division
had
1988
sales
of
$
368.3
million
,
or
almost
14
%
of
Armstrong
's
$
2.68
billion
total
revenue
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
has
been
manufacturing
carpet
since
1967
.
<END>
<START>

it
upgraded
its
plants
so
that

could
make

products
with
higher
quality

.
<END>
<START>

,

.

<START>

14

.
<END>
<START>

,

.

,

.

.

<START>
An
imaginative
novelist
writing
a
thriller
about
amateur
spy-chasing
might
invent
a
Clifford
Stoll
,
but
it
's
unlikely
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
also
unnecessary
.
<END>
<START>
Amateur
spy-chaser
Clifford
Stoll
is
a
real
person
,
or
as
he
might
waggishly
put
it
,
a
surreal
person
.
<END>
<START>
He
is
37
,
an
astronomer
with
impressive
credentials
,
and
something
of
a
genius
at
making
computers
do
his
bidding
.
<END>
<START>
He
also
is
an
entertaining
writer
,
combining
wisecracks
and
wordplay
with
programmatic
detail
and
lucid
explanations
of
how
computers
work
.
<END>
<START>
One
of
them
,
25-year-old
Markus
Hess
of
Hannover
,
allegedly
used
the
international
telecommunications
network
to
break
into
more
than
30
high-security
computers
in
the
U.S.
,
searching
for
secrets
.
<END>
<START>
They
promised
yet
more
for
really
good
stuff
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Stoll
draws
his
title
from
the
cuckoo
's
habit
of
laying
eggs
in
the
nests
of
other
birds
,
making
them
surrogate
parents
.
<END>
<START>
The
computer
spy
had
discovered
that
a
popular
editing/electronic
mail
program
called
Gnu-Emacs
could
do
tricks
with
the
widely
used
Unix
operating
system
created
by
AT&T
.
<END>
<START>
Using
Gnu-Emacs
,
the
spy
could
substitute
a
bogus
``
atrun
''
program
for
the
one
that
routinely
cleans
up
the
Unix
system
every
five
minutes
.
<END>
<START>
Once
his
cuckoo
's
egg
was
laid
,
he
could
enter
Unix
and
become
a
``
super-user
,
''
with
access
to
everything
.
<END>
<START>
He
discovered
a
75-cent
discrepancy
in
the
charges
made
to
various
departments
for
computer
time
and
traced
it
to
a
user
named
``
Hunter
,
''
who
had
no
valid
billing
address
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Stoll
suspected
the
intruder
was
one
of
those
precocious
students
who
has
fun
breaking
into
computers
.
<END>
<START>
But
after
much
tracking
,
it
became
evident
to
Mr.
Stoll
,
through
various
clues
,
that
the
hacker
was
not
on
the
Berkeley
campus
or
even
in
California
.
<END>
<START>
Finding
him
became
an
obsession
for
Mr.
Stoll
.
<END>
<START>
He
made
a
midnight
requisition
of
all
the
printers
he
could
lay
hands
on
so
that
he
could
monitor
all
the
telephone
lines
coming
into
the
lab
's
computers
.
<END>
<START>
Some
nights
he
slept
under
his
desk
.
<END>
<START>
His
boss
complained
about
neglect
of
other
chores
.
<END>
<START>
The
White
Sands
missile
range
and
CIA
contractor
Mitre
Inc.
were
among
the
targets
.
<END>
<START>
When
the
hacker
moved
,
Mr.
Stoll
moved
too
,
calling
up
other
systems
managers
to
alert
them
but
keeping
his
own
system
open
to
avoid
arousing
suspicion
.
<END>
<START>
The
FBI
initially
showed
little
interest
,
and
he
had
the
impression
other
federal
security
agencies
were
tangled
up
in
legal
red
tape
.
<END>
<START>
The
CIA
told
him
it
does
not
do
domestic
counterespionage
.
<END>
<START>
One
learns
a
lot
from
this
book
,
or
seems
to
,
about
crippling
federal
bureaucracy
.
<END>
<START>
``
Seems
to
''
because
it
's
possible
that
the
CIA
and
the
National
Security
Agency
were
more
interested
than
they
let
on
to
Mr.
Stoll
.
<END>
<START>
Finally
,

got
help
.

<START>

is
a

.
<END>

,

.

.

.

.

<START>
Mips
Computer
Systems
Inc.
today
will
unveil
a
new
general-purpose
computer
that
will
compete
with
more
expensive
machines
from
companies
such
as
Sun
Microsystems
Inc.
and
Digital
Equipment
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
The
closely
held
Sunnyvale
,
Calif.
,
company
also
will
announce
an
agreement
to
supply
computers
to
Control
Data
Corp.
,
which
will
sell
Mips
machines
under
its
own
label
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
Mips
machine
,
called
the
RC6280
,
will
cost
$
150,000
for
a
basic
system
.
<END>
<START>
The
computer
processes
55
million
instructions
per
second
and
uses
only
one
central
processing
chip
,
unlike
many
rival
machines
using
several
processors
.
<END>
<START>
The
machine
employs
reduced
instruction-set
computing
,
or
RISC
,
technology
.
<END>
<START>
At
that
price
,
an
analyst
familiar
with
the
machine
said
,
the
computer
offers
up
to
10
times
the
performance
of
similar
machines
.
<END>
<START>
``
In
the
price
range
it
's
a
tremendously
high-performing
product
,
''
said
Sandy
Gant
,
an
analyst
at
the
market-research
firm
InfoCorp
.
<END>
<START>
The
machine
is
part
of
an
effort
by
Mips
to
establish
itself
as
a
supplier
of
computers
,
not
just
of
integrated-circuit
technology
.
<END>
<START>
Mips
also
wants
to
wedge
into
markets
other
than
traditional
RISC
applications
such
as
engineering
;
Mips
said
the
new
machine
will
also
be
used
by
businesses
and
for
communications
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
clearly
demonstrates
that
Mips
is
a
systems
company
rather
than
just
a
chip
company
,
''
said
Mips
Vice
President
John
Hime
.
<END>
<START>
RISC
technology
speeds
up
a
computer
by
simplifying
the
internal
software
.
<END>
<START>
For
Mips
,
which
expects
revenue
of
$
100
million
this
year
,
big-name
allies
such
as
Control
Data
are
essential
to
attract
software
developers
to
the
company
's
RISC
architecture
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
thing
it
says
about
Mips
is
that
they
're
on
a
roll
right
now
,
''
said
Ms.
Gant
at
InfoCorp
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
're
getting
some
major
wins
,
''
she
added
.
<END>
<START>
Last
month
,
for
example
,
Mips
agreed
to
supply
its
computers
to
Nixdorf
Computer
AG
of
West
Germany
and
France
's
Groupe
Bull
.
<END>
<START>
Today
's
agreement
gives
Control
Data
a
machine
to
compete
against
Digital
and
other
general-purpose
computer
makers
,
said
John
Logan
,
a
computer-market
analyst
at
Aberdeen
Group
Inc.
of
Boston
.
<END>
<START>
The
machine
is
essentially
a
mainframe
computer
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
Suddenly
CDC
-LRB-
Control
Data
-RRB-
has
a
competitive
product
to
fight
back
against
the
VAX9000
,
''
a
machine
Digital
announced
last
month
,
he
added
.
<END>
<START>
Nixdorf
,
Bull
and
others
will
also
sell
versions
of
the
machine
,
said
Mips
President
Robert
Miller
.
<END>
<START>
Mips
will
start
shipping
its
new
machine
in
the
first
quarter
of
1990
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
machine
uses
a
single
processor
,
which
makes
it
easier
to
program
than
competing
machines
using
several
processors
.
<END>
<START>
The
computer
can
process
13.3
million
calculations
called
floating-point
operations
every
second
.
<END>
<START>
The
machine
can
run
software
written
for
other
Mips
computers
,
the
company
said
.
<END>
<START>
Another
fight
is
brewing
between
Congress
and
the
Bush
administration
over
how
to
pay
for
the
savings-and-loan
bailout
without
adding
to
the
federal
budget
deficit
.
<END>
<START>
Officials
of
the
Resolution
Trust
Corp.
have
said
privately
that
such
a
plan
was
the
most
likely
alternative
to
raise
short-term
cash
for
the
bailout
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
,
the
GAO
and
the
Congressional
Budget
Office
said
,
the
RTC
should
consider
using
Treasury
debt
,
which
is
less
expensive
and
subject
to
oversight
by
Congress
.
<END>
<START>
The
spending
could
be
exempted
from
meeting
deficit-reduction
targets
in
the
Gramm-Rudman
budget
law
.
<END>
<START>
The
RTC
has
projected
that
it
will
require
between
$
50
billion
to
$
100
billion
in
temporary
working
capital
.
<END>
<START>
The
borrowing
to
raise
these
funds
would
be
paid
off
as
assets
of
sick
thrifts
are
sold
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
S&L
law
allows
the
RTC
to
issue
notes
for
as
much
as
85
%
of
the
value
of
the
assets
it
holds
.
<END>
<START>
But
higher
interest
rates
paid
on
off-budget
debt
could
add
billions
to
the
bailout
costs
,
and
would
n't
be
subject
to
congressional
scrutiny
,
Ways
and
Means
members
argued
.
<END>
<START>
The
RTC
will
have
to
sell
or
merge
hundreds
of
insolvent
thrifts
over
the
next
three
years
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
S&L
bailout
law
allows
$
50
billion
to
be
spent
to
sell
or
merge
sick
S&Ls
and
their
assets
,
but
that
is
a
net
cost
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
meantime
,
the
agency
must
raise
cash
to
maintain
assets
,
such
as
real
estate
,
until
they
can
be
sold
.
<END>
<START>
Then
the
short-term
debt
is
paid
off
through
the
proceeds
of
selling
the
assets
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
worst
possibility
would
be
raising
no
working
capital
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
working
capital
financing
is
not
provided
,
''
he
said
,
``
the
RTC
may
have
to
slow
-LCB-
S&L
sales
-RCB-
or
dump
acquired
assets
through
fire
sales
.
<END>

,

Healthcare
International
Inc.

with

affiliate
calling
for
Healthcare
to
pay
HealthVest
$
5
million
right
away
and
additional
amounts
in
the
future
.
<END>
<START>
In
return
,
HealthVest
agreed
that
it
wo
n't
exercise
its
rights
and
remedies
against
Healthcare
during
the
120-day
period
.
<END>
<START>
Healthcare
has
given
HealthVest
a
12
%
note
for
that
overdue
amount
,
to
be
repaid
over
three
years
.
<END>
<START>
Because
Healthcare
actually
owes
HealthVest
$
4.2
million
in
rent
and

each
month
,
the
amount
due
above
the
amount
paid
will
be
added
to

three-year
note
.
<END>
<START>

should
help

a
cash
bind
at
HealthVest
,
which
has
been
unable
to
pay
its
debts
because
Healthcare
has
n't
made
complete
rent
and
mortgage
payments
since
July
.
<END>
<START>
A
spokesman
said
HealthVest
has
paid
two
of
the
three
banks
it
owed
interest
to
in
October
and
is
in

with
the
third

.
<END>
<START>
The
loan
is
backed
by
Healthcare
's
5.4
%

in
HealthVest
and
interest
in
certain
facilities
.

<START>

<START>
The
local
American

.
<END>
<START>
As
the
judge
marched
down
the
center
aisle
in
his
flowing
black
robe
,
he
was
heralded
by
a

.
<END>
<START>
To
many
,
it
was
a

more
befitting
a
king
than
a
rural
judge
seated
in

.
<END>
<START>
But
then

O'Kicki
often
behaved
like
a
man
who
would
be
king
--
and
,

say
,
an

and

.
<END>
<START>
While
his
case
may
be
extreme
,
it
reflects
the
vulnerability
of
many
small
communities
to
domineering
judges
.
<END>
<START>
The
allegations
,
ranging
from
theft
and
bribery
to
coercion
and
lewdness
,
paint
a
disquieting
picture
.
<END>
<START>
One
former

charged
that
the
judge
double-crossed
him
by
reneging
on
a

of
a

job
after
pocketing
a
$
500
bribe
.
<END>
<START>
Some

.
<END>
<START>
Two
former
secretaries
told
the
grand

were

to

's

on
separate

to

,

in

.
<END>
<START>
One

that
the
judge
once
called

to

office
while

nothing
at
all
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
do
n't
know

toes
I
've

on
,
''
says
the
judge
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
'll
find
out
,

,
who
pushed
the
state
police
buttons
into
action
.
''
<END>
<START>
Even

allegations
stand
up
,
however
,
they
provide
ample
testimony
to
the
awesome
power
of

in
rural
communities
.
<END>
<START>
That
power
can
sometimes
be
abused
,
particularly
since
jurists
in
smaller
jurisdictions
operate
without
many
of
the
restraints
that
serve
as

in

.
<END>
<START>
Lawyers
and
their
clients
who
frequently
bring
business
to
a
country
courthouse
can
expect
to
appear
before
the
same
judge
year
after
year
.
<END>
<START>
Judge
O'Kicki
,
a
stern
and
forbidding-looking
man
,
has
been
a
fixture
in
the
local
legal
community
for
more
than
two
decades
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
also
in
law
school
that
Mr.
O'Kicki
and
his
first
wife
had
the
first
of
seven
daughters
.
<END>
<START>
He
divorced
his
first
wife
three
years
ago
and
married
the
daughter
of
his
court
clerk
.
<END>
<START>
Last
year
,
Pennsylvania
Supreme
Court
Justice
John
P.
Flaherty
called
Mr.
O'Kicki
one
of
the
finest
judges
``
not
only
in
Pennsylvania
but
in
the
United
States
.
''
<END>
<START>
Clearly
,
the
judge
has
had
his
share
of
accomplishments
.
<END>
<START>
After
practicing
law
locally
,
he
was
elected
to
his
first
10-year
term
as
judge
in
1971
;
in
1981
,
he
was
effectively
re-elected
.
<END>
<START>
Six
years
ago
,
Judge
O'Kicki
was
voted
president
of
the
Pennsylvania
Conference
of
State
Trial
Judges
by
the
state
's
400
judges
.
<END>
<START>
He
has
been
considered
several
times
for
appointments
to
federal
district
and
appellate
court
vacancies
in
Pennsylvania
.
<END>
<START>
And
when
he
ran
unsuccessfully
for
a
state
appellate
court
seat
in
1983
,
the
Pennsylvania
Bar
Association
rated
him
``
one
of
the
best
available
,
''
after
interviewing
local
lawyers
.
<END>
<START>
``
He
's
sharp
as
a
tack
.
<END>
<START>
He
could
grasp
an
issue
with
the
blink
of
an
eye
.
''
<END>
<START>
For
more
than
a
decade
,
virtually
no
one
complained
about
Judge
O'Kicki
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
only
a
banker
or
a
lawyer
had
spoken
out
years
ago
,
the
judicial
process
would
n't
be
under
the
taint
it
is
today
.
''
<END>
<START>
Officials
with
the
Pennsylvania
Judicial
Inquiry
and
Review
Board
,
the
arm
of
the
state
that
investigates
judicial
misconduct
,
counter
that
they
had
no
inkling
of
anything
amiss
in
Ebensburg
.
<END>
<START>
``
Nobody
told
us
;
nobody
called
us
,
''
says
an
official
close
to
the
case
who
asked
not
to
be
named
.
<END>
<START>
``
Nobody
had
the
guts
to
complain
.
''
<END>
<START>
Certainly
not
the
lawyers
.
<END>
<START>
Johnstown
attorney
Richard
J.
Green
Jr.
shelled
out
$
500
in
loans
to
the
judge
over
five
years
,
he
said
in
testimony
to
the
grand
jury
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
judge
never
made
a
pretense
of
repaying
the
money
,
''
said
Mr.
Green
.
<END>
<START>
Eventually
,
Mr.
Green
testified
,
he
began
ducking
out
of
his
office
rather
than
face
the
judge
when
he
visited
.
<END>
<START>
When
Mr.
Green
won
a
$
240,000
verdict
in
a
land
condemnation
case
against
the
state
in
June
1983
,
he
says
Judge
O'Kicki
unexpectedly
awarded
him
an
additional
$
100,000
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Green
thought
little
of
it
,
he
told
the
grand
jury
,
until
the
judge
walked
up
to
him
after
the
courtroom
had
cleared
and
suggested
a
kickback
.
<END>
<START>
``
Do
n't
you
think
I
ought
to
get
a
commission
...
or
part
of
your
fee
in
this
case
?
''
Mr.
Green
said
the
judge
asked
him
.
<END>
<START>
Appalled
,
Mr.
Green
never
paid
the
money
,
he
testified
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
did
n't
complain
to
the
state
's
Judicial
Inquiry
and
Review
Board
,
either
,
saying
later
that
he
feared
retribution
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
O'Kicki
said
he
will
respond
to
Mr.
Green
's
allegation
at
his
trial
.
<END>
<START>
Like
most
of
Cambria
County
's
lawyers
and
residents
who
had
dealings
with
the
judge
,
Mr.
Green
declined
to
be
interviewed
for
this
article
.
<END>
<START>
And
no
one
with
a
complaint
about
the
judge
would
allow
his
name
to
be
printed
.
<END>
<START>
Says
another
lawyer
:
``
The
practice
of
law
is
a
matter
of
biting
one
's
lip
when
you
live
in
a
small
community
.
<END>
<START>
One
had
best
not
dance
on
top
of
a
coffin
until
the
lid
is
sealed
tightly
shut
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
judge
was
considered
imperious
,
abrasive
and
ambitious
,
those
who
practiced
before
him
say
.
<END>
<START>
He
sipped
tea
sweetened
with
honey
from
his
high-backed
leather
chair
at
his
bench
,
while
scribbling
notes
ordering
spectators
to
stop
whispering
or
to
take
off
their
hats
in
his
courtroom
.
<END>
<START>
The
judge
,
they
say
,
was
fiercely
proud
of
his
abilities
and
accomplishments
.
<END>
<START>
``
My
name
is
judge
,
''
Judge
O'Kicki
told
a
car
salesman
in
Ebensburg
when
he
bought
a
new
red
Pontiac
Sunbird
in
October
1984
,
according
to
the
grand-jury
report
.
<END>
<START>
The
dealership
dutifully
recorded
the
sale
under
the
name
``
Judge
O'Kicki
.
''
<END>
<START>
Yet
,
despite
the
judge
's
imperial
bearing
,
no
one
ever
had
reason
to
suspect
possible
wrongdoing
,
says
John
Bognato
,
president
of
Cambria
County
's
150-member
bar
association
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
arrogance
of
a
judge
,
his
demeanor
,
the
way
he
handles
people
are
not
a
basis
for
filing
a
complaint
,
''
says
Mr.
Bognato
.
<END>
<START>
``
Until
this
came
up
and
hit
the
press
,
there
was
never
any
indication
that
he
was
doing
anything
wrong
.
''
<END>
<START>
State
investigators
dispute
that
view
now
,
particularly
in
light
of
the
judge
's
various
business
dealings
in
Cambria
County
.
<END>
<START>
The
judge
came
under
scrutiny
in
late
1987
,
after
the
state
attorney
general
's
office
launched
an
unrelated
investigation
into
corruption
in
Cambria
County
.
<END>
<START>
The
inquiry
soon
focused
on
the
judge
.
<END>
<START>
Even
his
routine
business
transactions
caused
trouble
,
according
to
the
grand
jury
report
.
<END>
<START>
The
dealership
took
the
extra
step
of
having
all
the
paper
work
for
the
transaction
pre-approved
by
Ebensburg
's
local
lender
,
Laurel
Bank
.
<END>
<START>
But
when
the
judge
received
his
payment
book
,
he
disavowed
the
deal
.
<END>
<START>
Later
,
the
judge
went
a
step
farther
.
<END>
<START>
After
Laurel
Bank
tried
to
repossess
the
car
,
a
vice
president
asked
him
to
intervene
in
an
unrelated
legal
dispute
involving
a
trust
account
.
<END>
<START>
The
judge
wrote
again
.
<END>
<START>
``
Perhaps
if
my
personal
matters
can
be
resolved
with
Laurel
bank
in
the
near
future
,
I
may
be
inclined
to
reconsider
your
request
...
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
judge
now
says
it
was
``
unfortunate
''
that
he
chose
to
write
the
letter
but
says
``
there
was
certainly
no
intent
to
extort
there
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
bank
acquiesced
.
<END>
<START>
The
incident
was
n't
the
only
time
the
judge
got
special
treatment
from
his
local
bank
.
<END>
<START>
Two
years
later
,
he
wrote
to
complain
that
the
interest
he
was
paying
on
an
unsecured
$
10,000
loan
was
``
absolutely
onerous
.
''
<END>
<START>
Paul
L.
Kane
,
Laurel
's
president
at
the
time
,
quickly
responded
.
<END>
<START>
The
bank
,
he
wrote
back
,
was
``
immediately
''
lowering
the
rate
by
3.5
%
,
``
as
a
concession
to
you
.
''
<END>
<START>
His
seven-bedroom
cedar
and
brick
house
outside
of
Johnstown
is
up
for
sale
to
pay
for
his
lawyers
.
<END>
<START>
The
judge
says
he
is
confident
he
will
return
to
his
old
bench
.
<END>
<START>
Already
,
he
notes
,
the
76
charges
originally
filed
against
him
have
been
trimmed
to
27
.
<END>
<START>
Most
of
the
allegations
no
longer
pending
were
ethics
charges
withdrawn
by
state
prosecutors
as
part
of
a
pre-trial
agreement
.
<END>
<START>
The
heart
of
the
case
--
``
official
oppression
''
--
remains
intact
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
I
lose
,
I
lose
my
position
,
my
career
,
my
pension
,
my
home
and
my
investments
,
''
says
the
judge
.
<END>
<START>
``
My
God
and
I
know
I
am
correct
and
innocent
.
<END>
<START>
Many
thanks
for
Alexander
Cockburn
's
comic
masterpiece
-LRB-
``
U.S.
.
Economy
:
A
House
Built
on
Junk-Bond
Sand
,
''
Viewpoint
,
Oct.
19
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
It
should
be
a
scream
.
<END>
<START>
William
S.
Smith
<END>
<START>
By
contrast
,
the
Los
Angeles
Times
,
for
example
,
uses
83
%
recycled
paper
.
<END>
<START>
The
Wall
Street
Journal
is
an
excellent
publication
that
I
enjoy
reading
-LRB-
and
must
read
-RRB-
daily
.

<START>
Virginia
M.W.
Gardiner
<END>
<START>
The
following
were
among
yesterday
's
offerings
and
pricings
in
the
U.S.
and
non-U.S.
capital
markets
,
with
terms
and
syndicate
manager
,
as
compiled
by
Dow
Jones
Capital
Markets
Report
:
<END>
<START>
Continental
Cablevision
Inc.
--
<END>
<START>
$
350
million
of
senior
subordinated
debentures
,
due
Nov.
1
,
2004
,
was
priced
at
par
to
yield
12
7/8
%
.
<END>
<START>
Beatrice
Co.
--
<END>
<START>
$
251
million
of
notes
,
due
Nov.
1
,
1997
,
was
priced
in
a
two-part
offering
through
underwriters
at
Salomon
Brothers
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
The
size
of
the
issue
was
scaled
back
from
an
originally
planned
$
350
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
first
part
,
consisting
of
$
151
million
of
13
3/4
%
senior
subordinated
reset
notes
,
was
priced
at
99.75
.
<END>
<START>
The
rate
on
the
notes
will
be
reset
annually
to
give
the
issue
a
market
value
of
101
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
the
maximum
coupon
at
which
the
notes
can
be
reset
is
16
1/4
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
minimum
coupon
is
13
3/4
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
second
part
,
consisting
of
$
100
million
of
senior
subordinated
floating-rate
notes
,
was
priced
at
99
3/4
to
float
4.25
%
above
the
three-month
London
interbank
offered
rate
.
<END>
<START>
The
initial
coupon
on
the
floating-rate
notes
will
be
12.9375
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
issue
is
rated
single-B-3
by
Moody
's
and
single-B-plus
by
S&P
.
<END>
<START>
New
Jersey
Wastewater
Treatment
Trust
--
<END>
<START>
$
75.1
million
,
two-part
offering
of
bonds
apparently
was
won
by
a
Merrill
Lynch
Capital
Markets
group
.
<END>
<START>
The
group
's
bid
for
$
40.9
million
of
wastewater
treatment
insured
bonds
,
Series
1989
A
,
produced
a
7.0826
%
true
interest
cost
.
<END>
<START>
The
Series
1989
A
bonds
are
insured
and
rated
triple-A
by
Moody
's
and
S&P
.
<END>
<START>
The
group
's
bid
for
$
34.2
million
of
wastewater
treatment
bonds
,
Series
1989
B
,
produced
a
7.0808
%
true
interest
cost
.
<END>
<START>
The
Series
1989
B
bonds
are
uninsured
and
rated
double-A
by
Moody
's
and
S&P
.
<END>
<START>
Both

1989

were

to
yield
from
6
%
in
1991
to
7.15
%
in
2008-2009
,
according

official
.

,

--

.

.

.

.

.

<START>

-LRB-

<START>

<START>
EG&G
Inc.
said

Laboratorium
Prof.
Dr.
Berthold
,

.

Terms

.
<END>

,

,

.

.

to

,

,

8

140

.

,

.

,

,

.

.

,

.

.

.

,

.

.

<START>
The
Tax

n't

rule

early

.
<END>
<START>
Japan
has
found
another
safe
outlet
for
its
money
:
U.S.
home
mortgages
.
<END>
<START>
An
increasing
number
of
big
Japanese
investors
are
buying
up
U.S.
home
mortgages
that
have
been
pooled
and
packaged
for
sale
as
interest-bearing
instruments
known
as
mortgage-backed
securities
.
<END>
<START>
That
may
not
come
as
a
surprise
to
Americans
who
have
watched
the
Japanese
snap
up
properties
in
the
U.S.
from
golf
courses
to
a
stake
in
Rockefeller
Center
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
marks
a
big
change
for
the
Japanese
,
who
shunned
mortgage
securities
after
getting
burned
by
a
big
downturn
in
interest
rates
a
few
years
back
.
<END>
<START>
``
Interest
is
a
great
deal
higher
than
it
was
a
year
ago
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
steady
growth
of
the
mortgage
securities
market
in
the
U.S.
has
even
triggered
talk
of
building
up
a
similar
market
here
.
<END>
<START>
Evidence
of
the
growing
Japanese
demand
for
mortgage
securities
abounds
.
<END>
<START>
Earlier
this
year
,
Blackstone
Group
,
a
New
York
investment
bank
,
had
no
trouble
selling
out
a
special
$
570
million
mortgage-securities
trust
it
created
for
Japanese
investors
.
<END>
<START>
``
Last
year
,
there
were
only
several
big
investors
who
were
interested
,
''
says
Kinji
Kato
,
a
vice
president
at
the
international
arm
of
Nomura
Securities
Co
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
year
,
some
investors
are
changing
their
policies
and
investing
a
lot
.
''
<END>
<START>
Ultimately
,
he
says
,
strong
demand
could
help
to
drive
down
interest
rates
on
mortgage
securities
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
moment
,
Nomura
is
the
only
Japanese
institution
authorized
to
act
as
a
primary
seller
of
Fannie
Mae
instruments
.
<END>
<START>
But
other
Japanese
institutions
say
privately
that
they
are
considering
asking
to
join
the
59-dealer
selling
group
.
<END>
<START>
These
securities
are
attractive
to
Japanese
investors
for
three
reasons
.
<END>
<START>
First
,
they
are
safe
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
U.S.
Treasury
bonds
are
still
the
dollar-denominated
investment
of
choice
for
long-term
Japanese
investors
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
Second
,
they
are
liquid
.
<END>
<START>
The
secondary
market
in
federally
backed
mortgage
securities
now
exceeds
$
900
billion
,
or
nearly
half
of
the
$
2.2
trillion
in
U.S.
residential
mortgages
issued
.
<END>
<START>
Third
,
they
offer
high
yields
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
moment
,
some
offer
as
much
as
1.6
to
1.8
percentage
points
over
Treasury
securities
of
similar
maturities
.
<END>
<START>
But
there
is
a
risk
,
which
the
Japanese
discovered
when
they
first
dipped
their
toes
into
the
market
nearly
five
years
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Since
most
mortgages
can
be
prepaid
or
refinanced
at
any
time
,
issuers
of
mortgage
securities
retain
the
right
to
buy
back
their
bonds
before
maturity
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
a
headache
for
long-term
investors
,
since
it
forces
them
to
reinvest
their
money
--
usually
at
lower
rates
than
the
original
mortgage
securities
carried
.
<END>
<START>
``
Two
or
three
years
ago
,
the
problem
was
that
people
did
n't
understand
the
prepayment
risk
,
''
says
Nomura
's
Mr.
Kato
.
<END>
<START>
``
So
they
were
surprised
and
very
disappointed
by
prepayment
.
''
<END>
<START>
Compounding
the
trouble
to
Japanese
investors
,
mortgage
securities
pay
interest
monthly
,
since
most
mortgages
require
homeowners
to
make
monthly
payments
.
<END>
<START>
But
Japanese
institutional
investors
are
used
to
quarterly
or
semiannual
payments
on
their
investments
,
so
the
monthly
cash
flow
posed
administrative
problems
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
Japanese
investors
steered
clear
of
the
mortgage
securities
.
<END>
<START>
But
they
did
n't
lose
touch
with
the
U.S.
issuers
.
<END>
<START>
And
Japanese
investors
took
up
nearly
all
of
two
$
200
million
Real
Estate
Mortgage
Investment
Conduits
,
a
kind
of
collateralized
mortgage
obligation
,
that
were
offered
to
foreigners
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Freddie
Mac
for
years
has
offered
a
so-called
participation
certificate
that
guarantees
it
wo
n't
be
prepaid
for
a
set
number
of
years
and
offers
semiannual
payments
.
<END>
<START>
As
Georgia-Pacific
's
bid
for
Great
Northern
Nekoosa
has
shown
,
uninvited
takeovers
are
still
alive
despite
premature
reports
of
their
demise
.
<END>
<START>
Therefore
,
the
debate
about
poison
pills
will
continue
to
rage
in
the
boardrooms
of
corporations
and
the
halls
of
academia
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
these
discount
purchase
rights
may
generally
be
redeemed
at
a
nominal
cost
by
the
corporation
's
directors
if
they
approve
of
a
bidder
.
<END>
<START>
Recent
studies
by
Georgeson
&
Co.
conclude
that
corporations
with
poison
pills
have
experienced
greater
stock-price
appreciation
than
corporations
without
poison
pills
during
the
past
few
years
.
<END>
<START>
Critics
of
poison
pills
argue
that
they
harm
shareholders
by
letting
corporate
management
defeat
takeover
bids
at
premium
prices
and
by
deterring
premium
bids
from
ever
being
made
to
shareholders
.
<END>
<START>
These
critics
are
backed
by
several
academic
studies
showing
that
the
adoption
of
poison
pills
reduces
shareholder
values
not
merely
in
the
short
run
,
but
also
over
longer
periods
.
<END>
<START>
Institutional
investors
that
must
evaluate
poison
pills
on
a
regular
basis
are
interested
less
in
this
general
debate
than
in
the
answers
to
specific
questions
about
the
corporation
issuing
the
pill
.
<END>
<START>
Does
this
corporation
have
a
high-quality
management
team
with
a
good
track
record
?
<END>
<START>
Does
this
team
have
a
viable
strategy
for
improving
shareholder
values
,
and
does
this
strategy
require
implementation
over
an
extended
period
?
<END>
<START>
Will
the
adoption
of
this
particular
form
of
a
poison
pill
significantly
improve
the
chances
for
management
to
carry
out
this
strategy
?
<END>
<START>
If
the
answers
to
these
questions
are
affirmative
,
then
institutional
investors
are
likely
to
be
favorably
disposed
toward
a
specific
poison
pill
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
the
problem
is
that
once
most
poison
pills
are
adopted
,
they
survive
forever
.
<END>
<START>
Although
the
current
management
team
may
be
outstanding
,
who
will
be
the
CEO
in
10
years
?
<END>
<START>
Although
the
five-year
strategy
may
be
excellent
,
what
will
be
the
strategy
in
25
years
?
<END>
<START>
The
solution
to
this
problem
is
a
time-limited
poison
pill
.
<END>
<START>
The
limit
could
range
from
three
years
to
seven
years
,
depending
on
the
composition
of
the
management
team
and
the
nature
of
its
strategic
plan
.
<END>
<START>
One
rare
example
of
a
time-limited
poison
pill
is
the
shareholder
rights
plan
adopted
by
Pennzoil
last
year
after
it
received
a
huge
litigation
settlement
from
Texaco
.
<END>
<START>
Pennzoil
's
poison
pill
covers
five
years
in
order
to
give
current
management
enough
time
to
put
these
proceeds
to
work
in
a
prudent
manner
.
<END>
<START>
Another
interesting
example
is
the
poison
pill
adopted
recently
by
Pittsburgh-based
National
Intergroup
Inc.
,
a
diversified
holding
company
.
<END>
<START>
The
State
of
Wisconsin
Investment
Board
,
which
owned
about
7
%
of
the
company
's
voting
stock
,
worked
with
management
to
devise
a
time-limited
poison
pill
.
<END>
<START>
This
pill
automatically
expires
after
three
years
unless
continued
by
a
vote
of
the
shareholders
.
<END>
<START>
More
widespread
time
limits
on
poison
pills
would
allow
shareholders
to
evaluate
a
specific
poison
pill
within
the
context
of
a
specific
management
team
's
strategy
.
<END>
<START>
Such
concrete
analysis
is
likely
to
lead
to
more
fruitful
dialogue
between
management
and
shareholders
than
the
abstract
debate
about
poison
pills
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Pozen
is
the
general
counsel
and
a
managing
director
of
Fidelity
Investments
in
Boston
.
<END>
<START>
Michael
Blair
,
former
president
and
chief
executive
officer
of
Enfield
Corp.
,
failed
to
win
election
to
the
company
's
board
at
a
special
shareholder
meeting
.
<END>
<START>
Holders
at
the
meeting
elected
a
full
slate
of
Canadian
Express
nominees
to
Enfield
's
11-member
board
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Blair
and
Hees
have
been
feuding
for
months
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
's
election
was
a
sequel
to
Enfield
's
annual
meeting
in
June
when
Mr.
Blair
disallowed
proxies
in
favor
of
two
Hees
nominees
.
<END>
<START>
The
Ontario
Supreme
Court
overturned
Mr.
Blair
's
decision
.
<END>
<START>
He
later
resigned
from
his
executive
positions
with
Enfield
,
saying
that
actions
by
its
board
``
amounted
to
-LCB-
my
-RCB-
dismissal
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Blair
said
his
libel
suit
seeks
10
million
Canadian
dollars
-LRB-
US$
8.5
million
-RRB-
from
Canadian
Express
and
Hees
executives
Manfred
Walt
and
Willard
L'Heureux
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
his
suit
against
Enfield
seeks
two
years
severance
pay
,
equivalent
to
C$
720,000
.
<END>
<START>
Hees
and
Canadian
Express
executives
could
n't
be
reached
for
comment
.
<END>
<START>
Enfield
is
a
holding
company
with
interests
in
manufacturing
concerns
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
38.5
%
owned
by
Canadian
Express
,
another
holding
company
.
<END>
<START>
Hees
is
a
merchant
bank
controlled
by
Toronto
financiers
Peter
and
Edward
Bronfman
.
<END>
<START>
All
the
concerns
are
based
in
Toronto
.
<END>
<START>
But
in
another
sense
,
the
$
846
million
purchase
is
uncharacteristically
nervy
,
industry
analysts
say
.
<END>
<START>
Officials
of
Rockefeller
Group
and
Mitsubishi
Estate
prefer
to
focus
on
the
affinities
,
nearly
dismissing
the
threat
of
a
backlash
from
the
U.S.
public
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
think
there
will
be
positive
as
well
as
negative
reactions
,
''
says
Raymond
Pettit
,
senior
vice
president
and
chief
financial
officer
of
Rockefeller
Group
.
<END>
<START>
``
On
balance
,
we
think
it
will
be
positive
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
some
Japanese
government
officials
and
businessmen
worry
that
the
prominent
purchase
is
just
the
sort
of
deal
that
should
be
avoided
for
the
time
being
.
<END>
<START>
In
particular
,
they
criticize
the
timing
,
coming
as
it
does
on
the
heels
of
Sony
Corp.
's
controversial
purchase
of
Columbia
Pictures
Entertainment
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
``
Officially
,
yes
,
we
encourage
the
free
flow
of
direct
investment
,
''
says
a
Foreign
Ministry
official
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
they
did
n't
have
to
choose
this
particular
moment
.
''
<END>
<START>
During
the
past
year
,
government
officials
and
leading
business
organizations
have
repeatedly
urged
Japanese
companies
to
refrain
from
flashy
real
estate
purchases
in
the
<END>
<START>
Altogether
,
annual
Japanese
investment
in
U.S.
commercial
real
estate
grew
from
about
$
1.3
billion
in
1985
to
about
$
7.1
billion
in
1988
.
<END>
<START>
Many
Japanese
companies
have
taken
the
warnings
by
the
country
's
leaders
to
heart
and
sought
development
partnerships
rather
than
landmark
properties
.
<END>
<START>
Critics
say
Mitsubishi
Estate
's
decision
to
buy
into
Rockefeller
reflects
the
degree
to
which
companies
are
irritated
by
the
pressure
to
act
for
the
good
of
Japan
.
<END>
<START>
But
to
Mitsubishi
Estate
,
the
acquisition
has
just
the
elements
that
should
win
support
from
both
sides
.
<END>
<START>
First
of
all
,
it
is
a
friendly
acquisition
in
which
Rockefeller
sought
out
Mitsubishi
Estate
and
asked
it
to
buy
a

.
<END>
<START>
Secondly
,

two
companies
found
a
similarity
in

business
and
development

and
intend
to

in
a

of

from
real

to

.
<END>
<START>
Finally
,

Estate
has
no

to
interfere
with
Rockefeller
's
management
beyond
taking
a

on

board
.
<END>
<START>
Rockefeller
may
well
have
found
its
match
in
Mitsubishi
Estate
,
a
company
of
long
history
,
strong
government

and
sound
resources
.
<END>
<START>
In
asset
terms
,
Mitsubishi
Estate
is
the
largest
real

firm
in
Japan
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
time
,
Japan
had
just
opened

doors
to
the
world
after
about
250
years
of
isolation
and
needed
a
Western-style
business
center
.
<END>
<START>
Mitsubishi
built
the
government
's
dream
development
,
the
story
goes
,
in
exchange
for
the
official
decision
to
locate
Tokyo
's

station
there
.
<END>
<START>
Mitsubishi
Estate
is
one
of
the

of

in
today
's
Mitsubishi
group
.
<END>
<START>
For

latest

,

's
net

jumped
a
robust
19
%
to
35.5
billion
yen
-LRB-
$
250.2
million
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
``
Japanese

need
to

overseas

,
''

Yoshio
Shima
,

-LRB-

-RRB-

.

.
<END>

.
<END>

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

,

.

,

<START>
In

,

``
further

.
''
<END>
<START>
Sony

.

<START>

,

.

.

<START>
Southern
Co.
's

.

<START>

.
<END>

,
''

.

.
''

.
<END>

,

.
<END>

``

plead
-LRB-

-RRB-

is

.
<END>
<START>
And

will

to

,

.
''
<END>

.

.

.

<START>
`
Frequent
Drinker
'
Offer
Stirs
Up
Spirited
Debate
<END>
<START>
TO
GRAB
a
bigger
piece
of
the
declining
scotch
market
,
Seagram
Co.
has
launched
a
controversial
``
frequent
drinker
''
promotion
for
its
Chivas
Regal
brand
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
program
,
dubbed
Chivas
Class
,
customers
who
send
in
two
labels
from
Chivas
bottles
will
receive
an
upgrade
in
seating
class
on
some
Trans
World
Airlines
flights
.
<END>
<START>
Repeat
customers
also
can
purchase
luxury
items
at
reduced
prices
.
<END>
<START>
But
at
a
time
of
mounting
concern
over
alcohol
abuse
,
some
liquor
marketers
consider
Seagram
's
frequent
buyer
promotion
risky
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
'm
surprised
they
're
doing
this
,
''
says
Penn
Kavanagh
,
president
of
Schieffelin
&
Somerset
Co.
,
which
markets
Johnnie
Walker
scotches
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
would
be
very
leery
of
anything
that
says
if
you
drink
more
,
you
get
more
.
''
<END>
<START>
Others
question
the
impact
on
Chivas
's
upscale
image
of
a
promotion
that
has
customers
soaking
off
labels
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
really
bizarre
,
''
says
Albert
Lerman
,
creative
director
at
the
Wells
Rich
Greene
ad
agency
.
<END>
<START>
``
Chivas
has
an
image
of
something
you
would
savor
,
rather
than
guzzle
.
''
<END>
<START>
Chivas
Class
is
n't
the
first
such
promotion
.
<END>
<START>
Last
year
,
J&B
Scotch
offered
500
TWA
frequent
flier
miles
in
exchange
for
a
label
.
<END>
<START>
And
Dewar
's
gave
discounts
on
Scottish
merchandise
to
people
who
sent
in
bottle
labels
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
scope
of
Seagram
's
Chivas
promotion
sets
it
apart
.
<END>
<START>
The
current
campaign
is
just
the
first
leg
of
an
aggressive
three-to-five-year
direct
marketing
plan
.
<END>
<START>
Seagram
says
the
promotion
is
designed
to
build
brand
loyalty
rather
than
promote
heavy
drinking
.
<END>
<START>
Seagram
asks
customers
to
buy
only
two
or
three
bottles
over
a
12-month
period
,
says
Richard
Shaw
,
vice

U.S.
direct
marketing
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're
not
asking
them
to
save
up
50
proof-of-purchases
.
<END>
<START>
We
're
not
saying
drink
more
,
we
're
saying
trade
up
.
''
<END>
<START>
Goya
Concocts
a
Milk
For
Hispanic
Tastes
<END>
<START>
MOST
FOOD
companies
these
days
are
trimming
the
fat
and
cholesterol
content
of
their
products
to
appeal
to
health-conscious
consumers
.
<END>
<START>
But
Goya
Foods
Inc.
believes
it
can
milk
some
sales
by
bucking
the
trend
.
<END>
<START>
The
Secaucus
,
N.J.
,
company
has
formed
a
joint
venture
with
a
distributor
called
La
Lecheria
to
market
a
higher-fat
milk
targeted
at
Hispanic
consumers
.
<END>
<START>
To
give
Leche
Fresca
the
creamier
taste
Goya
says
Hispanics
prefer
,
the
new
brand
has
a
butterfat
content
of
3.8
%
.
<END>
<START>
That
compares
with
3.5
%
butterfat
for
whole
milk
.
<END>
<START>
A
spokesman
for
Borden
Inc.
,
the
nation
's
largest
milk
producer
,
concedes
Goya
may
be
on
to
something
.
<END>
<START>
Borden
sells
considerably
more
whole
milk
than
reduced-fat
milks
in
southern
and
Hispanic
markets
,
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Borden
even
tested
a
milk
with
4
%
butterfat
in
the
South
,
but
decided
the
market
was
too
small
.
<END>
<START>
Goya
is
selling
Leche
Fresca
in
nearly
500
grocery
stores
and
bodegas
in
New
York
and
parts
of
New
Jersey
.
<END>
<START>
And
it
's
adding
15
to
20
new
outlets
a
day
,
says
Greg
Ricca
,
sales
director
at
La
Lecheria
.
<END>
<START>
Because
of
Leche
Fresca
's
success
,
he
says
,
the
joint
venture
is
developing
other
dairy
products
tailored
to
Hispanic
tastes
.
<END>
<START>
Jewelry
Makers
Copy
Cosmetics
Sales
Ploys
<END>
<START>
FOR
YEARS
,
costume
jewelry
makers
fought
a
losing
battle
.
<END>
<START>
Jewelry
displays
in
department
stores
were
often
cluttered
and
uninspired
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
merchandise
was
,
well
,
fake
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
marketers
of
faux
gems
steadily
lost
space
in
department
stores
to
more
fashionable
rivals
--
cosmetics
makers
.
<END>
<START>
But
lately
,
retailers
say
,
fake
has
become
more
fashionable
.
<END>
<START>
And
jewelry
makers
are
beginning
to
use
many
of
the
same
marketing
tricks
honed
in
the
aggressive
world
of
cosmetics
.
<END>
<START>
Last
year
,
the
total
women
's
fashion
jewelry
business
topped
$
4.9
billion
,
says
Karen
Alberg
,
editor
of
Accessories
magazine
.
<END>
<START>
And
it
's
growing
fast
,
with
annual
sales
gains
of
more
than
10
%
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
've
started
trying
just
about
anything
to
keep
sales
moving
in
the
stores
,
''
says
Kim
Renk
,
a
Swank
vice
president
.
<END>
<START>
But
there
are
limits
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Renk
says
retailers
nixed
a
promotion
for
pins
with
animal
motifs
.
<END>
<START>
Her
idea
:
bring
in
live
zoo
animals
.
<END>
<START>
Trifari
,
whose
national
ads
earlier
this
year
included
paper
cutouts
of
its
costume
finery
,
takes
a
tamer
approach
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
focuses
on
the
how-to
aspects
,
says
Andrew
E.
Philip
,
president
.
<END>
<START>
Trifari
now
trains
sales
help
to
advise
customers
on
the
best
earring
styles
.
<END>
<START>
But
cosmetics
firms
still
have
one
big
marketing
edge
:
They
motivate
sales
people
with
commissions
.
<END>
<START>
Jewelry
makers
rarely
pay
commissions
and
are
n't
expected
to
anytime
soon
.
<END>
<START>
Odds
and
Ends
<END>
<START>
DESPITE
GROWING
interest
in
the
environment
,
U.S.
consumers
have
n't
shown
much
interest
in
refillable
packages
for
household
products
.
<END>
<START>
Procter
&
Gamble
Co.
recently
introduced
refillable
versions
of
four
products
,
including
Tide
and
Mr.
Clean
,
in
Canada
,
but
does
n't

East
.
<END>
<START>
Sidley
will
maintain
its
association
with
the
Hashidate
Law
Office
in
Tokyo
.
<END>
<START>
THE
UNITED
AUTO
WORKERS
said
it
will
seek
a
rehearing
of
a
U.S.
appellate
court
ruling
against
the
union
's
claim
that
the
state
of
Michigan
engages
in
wage-discrimination
against
female
employees
.
<END>
<START>
A
three-judge
panel
of
the
court
in
Cincinnati
made
the
ruling
Saturday
.
<END>
<START>
The
UAW
is
seeking
a
hearing
by
the
full
14-judge
panel
.
<END>
<START>
The
union
sued
the
state
in
November
1985
,
alleging
that
it
intentionally
segregated
job
classifications
by
sex
and
paid
employees
in
predominantly
female
jobs
less
than
males
in
comparable
jobs
.
<END>
<START>
The
UAW
also
charged
that
the
state
applied
its
own
standards
for
determining
pay
in
a
discriminatory
manner
.
<END>
<START>
In
November
1987
,
a
district
court
judge
in
Detroit
ruled
against
the
UAW
.
<END>
<START>
The
union
is
the
bargaining
representative
for
more
than
20,000
Michigan
state
employees
.
<END>
<START>
NEW
JERSEY
MERGER
:
<END>
<START>
Norris
McLaughlin
is
a
general-practice
firm
that
has
expanded
recently
into
such
specialties
as
banking
,
labor
and
environmental
work
.
<END>
<START>
The
merged
firm
will
carry
Norris
McLaughlin
's
name
.
<END>
<START>
DRUG
WARS
:
<END>
<START>
A
Texas
legislator
proposes
color-coding
drivers
'
licenses
of
some
drug
offenders
.
<END>
<START>
The
bill
would
authorize
courts
to
order
the
licenses
as
a
condition
of
probation
.
<END>
<START>
State
Senator
J.E.
``
Buster
''
Brown
,
a
Republican
who
is
running
for
Texas
attorney
general
,
introduced
the
bill
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
an
altered
license
would
be
an
``
embarrassment
''
to
teenagers
and
young
adults
and
would
act
as
a
deterrant
to
drug
use
.
<END>
<START>
Debate
on
the
legislation
,
which
faces
a
veto
threat
from
President
Bush
,
is
to
continue
today
.
<END>
<START>
In
1983
,
Texas
Air
's
Continental
Airlines
filed
for
bankruptcy
.
<END>
<START>
Earlier
this
year
,
Texas
Air
's
Eastern
Airlines
filed
for
bankruptcy
.
<END>
<START>
For
years
,
a
strict
regimen
governed
the
staff
meetings
at
Nissan
Motor
Co.
's
technical
center
in
Tokyo
's
western
suburbs
.
<END>
<START>
Employees
wore
identification
badges
listing
not
only
their
names
but
also
their
dates
of
hire
.
<END>
<START>
No
one
could
voice
an
opinion
until
everybody
with
more
seniority
had
spoken
first
,
so
younger
employees
--
often
the
most
enthusiastic
and
innovative
--
seldom
spoke
up
at
all
.
<END>
<START>
In
recent
years
,
Nissan
has
instituted
flex-time
work
schedules
and
allowed
employees
to
dress
casually
,
even
in
blue
jeans
.
<END>
<START>
A
rule
forbidding
staffers
to
own
competitors
'
cars
has
been
lifted
,
and
now
many
designers
drive
foreign
cars
to
get
useful
ideas
.
<END>
<START>
Nissan
's
decades-old
corporate
song
filled
with
references
to
Mount
Fuji
has
been
scrapped
in
favor
of
a
snappy
tune
sung
by
a
popular
Japanese
vocalist
.
<END>
<START>
And
in
a
Japanese
corporate
first
,
Nissan
recently
opened
the
first
coed
company
dormitory
for
single
employees
at
the
suburban
Tokyo
technical
center
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
had
lots
of
internal
debate
about
this
one
,
''
concedes
Tadahiko
Fukuyama
,
a
senior
public-relations
official
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
in
the
end
,
top
management
decided
to
follow
the
voice
of
the
younger
generation
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
company
's
turnaround
is
far
from
complete
;
many
crucial
tests
are
just
beginning
.
<END>
<START>
But
its
surprising
progress
so
far
holds
important
lessons
for
companies
in
trouble
.
<END>
<START>
The
big
one
:
A
company
's
culture
ca
n't
be
radically
changed
unless
top
management
first
admits
that
things
have
gone
badly
awry
and
then
publicly
leads
the
charge
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
a
time
of
self-criticism
to
discover
what
is
wrong
with
us
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Yutaka
Kume
,
who
took
the
helm
as
Nissan
's
president
in
June
1985
,
added
simply
,
``
I
am
deeply
disappointed
.
''
<END>
<START>
No
wonder
.
<END>
<START>
Nissan
's
market
share
in
Japan
had
been
dropping
year
by
year
since
the
beginning
of
the
decade
.
<END>
<START>
Its
U.S.
sales
sagged
,
partly
because
of
price
increases
due
to
the
rising
yen
.
<END>
<START>
Worst
of
all
,
Nissan
was
preoccupied
with
management
infighting
,
cronyism
and
corporate
rigidity
.
<END>
<START>
Consider
the
experience
of
Satoko
Kitada
,
a
30-year-old
designer
of
vehicle
interiors
who
joined
Nissan
in
1982
.
<END>
<START>
At
that
time
,
tasks
were
assigned
strictly
on
the
basis
of
seniority
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
oldest
designer
got
to
work
on
the
dashboard
,
''
she
recalls
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
next
level
down
did
doors
.
<END>
<START>
If
a
new
person
got
to
work
on
part
of
the
speedometer
,
that
was
a
big
deal
.
''
<END>
<START>
This
system
produced
boring
,
boxy
cars
that
consumers
just
were
n't
buying
.
<END>
<START>
Desperately
hoping
to
spark
sales
,
Nissan
transferred
5,000
middle
managers
and
plant
workers
to
dealerships
.
<END>
<START>
Some
town-watching
excursions
were
downright
comic
.
<END>
<START>
One
group
of
middle-aged
manufacturing
men
from
the
company
's
Zama
plant
outside
Tokyo
was
supposed
to
check
out
a
trendy
restaurant
in
the
city
.
<END>
<START>
But
when
they
arrived
at
the
door
,
all
were
afraid
to
go
in
,
fearing
that
they
would
be
out
of
place
.
<END>
<START>
Other
trips
were
more
productive
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Kume
himself
visited
Honda
's
headquarters
in
Tokyo
's
upscale
Aoyama
district
.
<END>
<START>
He
liked
the
well-lighted
lobby
display
of
Honda
's
cars
and
trucks
so
much
that
he
had
Nissan
's
gloomy
lobby
exhibit
refurbished
.
<END>
<START>
Later
,
Nissan
borrowed
other
Honda
practices
,
including
an
engineering
``
idea
contest
''
to
promote
inventiveness
.
<END>
<START>
One
engineer
developed
a
``
crab
car
''
that
moves
sideways
.
<END>
<START>
Such
sudden
cultural
shifts
may
come
across
as
a
bit
forced
,
but
they
seem
to
be
genuine
--
so
much
so
,
in
fact
,
that
some
older
employees
have
resisted
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
the
pain
of
adjusting
,
the
cultural
revolution
has
begun
to
yield
exciting
cars
.
<END>
<START>
Since
then
,
Nissan
also
has
launched
new
versions
of
the
$
13,249
240SX
sporty
coupe
and
300ZX
sports
car
.
<END>
<START>
The
restyled
300ZX
costs
as
much
as
$
33,000
and
is
squared
off
against
the
Porche
944
,
which
begins
at
$
41,900
.
<END>
<START>
Besides
new
styling
,
the
new
Nissans
have
more
powerful
engines
and
more
sophisticated
suspension
systems
.
<END>
<START>
All
three
new
models
are
outselling
their
predecessors
by
wide
margins
.
<END>
<START>
In
its
home
market
,
Nissan
has
grabbed
attention
with
limited-production
minicars
featuring
styling
odd
enough
to
be
cute
.
<END>
<START>
One
is
the
Pao
,
a
tiny
coupe
with
a
peelback
canvas
top
and
tilted
headlights
that
give
it
a
droopy-eyed
look
.
<END>
<START>
Nissan
initially
planned
to
sell
just
10,000
Paos
,
but
sales
have
passed
50,000
,
and
there
's
a
one-year
waiting
list
for
the
car
.
<END>
<START>
Then
,
there
's
the
S-Cargo
,
an
offbeat
delivery
van
with
a
snail-like
body
that
inspired
its
name
.
<END>
<START>
Nissan
helped
develop
a
Tokyo
restaurant
with
both
vehicles
as
its
design
theme
.
<END>
<START>
The
chairs
are
S-Cargo
seats
,
and
a
gift
shop
sells
such
items
as
alarm
clocks
styled
like
the
Pao
's
oversized
speedometer
.
<END>
<START>
All
these
vehicles
have
sharply
improved
Nissan
's
morale
and
image
--
but
have
n't
done
much
for
its
market
share
.
<END>
<START>
Nissan
had
29
%
of
the
Japanese
car
market
in
1980
before
beginning
a
depressing
eight-year
slide
that
continued
through
last
year
.
<END>
<START>
Nissan
concedes
that
it
wo
n't
recoup
all
its
market-share
losses
in
Japan
until
at
least
1995
,
and
even
that
timetable
might
prove
optimistic
.
<END>
<START>
``
Everyone
else
is
going
to
catch
up
''
with
Nissan
's
innovative
designs
,
says
A.
Rama
Krishna
,
auto
analyst
at
First
Boston
-LRB-
Japan
-RRB-
Ltd
.
<END>
<START>
Nissan
's
pace
of
new-model
hits
will
slow
,
he
adds
,
just
as
arch-rival
Toyota
unleashes
its
own
batch
of
new
cars
.
<END>
<START>
Likewise
,
in
the
U.S.
,
Nissan
has
grabbed
5.2
%
of
the
car
market
so
far
this
year
,
up
from
4.5
%
a
year
ago
.
<END>
<START>
But
even
that
brings
Nissan
only
to
the
share
it
had
in
1987
,
and
leaves
the
company
behind
its
high
of
5.5
%
in
1980
and
1982
.
<END>
<START>
Why
?
<END>
<START>
So
far
,
Nissan
's
new-model
successes
are
mostly
specialized
vehicles
with
limited
sales
potential
.
<END>
<START>
In
compact
and
subcompact
cars
,
the
bread-and-butter
sales
generators
for
Japanese
auto
makers
,
Nissan
still
trails
Toyota
and
Honda
.
<END>
<START>
Nissan
hopes
that
that
will
start
to
change
this
fall
,
with
its
new
version
of
the
Stanza
compact
sedan
.
<END>
<START>
The
Stanza
has
been
a
nonentity
compared
with
Honda
's
hugely
successful
Accord
and
Toyota
's
Camry
.
<END>
<START>
But
this
year
,
Honda
has
revamped
the
Accord
and
made
it
a
midsized
car
.
<END>
<START>
Accord
prices
start
at
$
12,345
.
<END>
<START>
Nissan
's
risk
is
that
its
low-base-price
strategy
might
get
lost
amid
the
highly
publicized
rebates
being
offered
by
Detroit
's
Big
Three
.
<END>
<START>
Even
if
the
new
Stanza
succeeds
,
Nissan
will
remain
behind
in
the
subcompact
segment
,
where
its
Sentra
does
n't
measure
up
to
the
Honda
Civic
and
Toyota
Corolla
.
<END>
<START>
Nissan
will
introduce
a
completely
revamped
Sentra
next
fall
.
<END>
<START>
Nissan
started
advertising
Infiniti
fully
eight
months
before
the
cars
hit
American
showrooms
.
<END>
<START>
The
ads
featured
fences
,
rocks
and
pussy-willow
buds
--
almost
anything
but
the
cars
themselves
.
<END>
<START>
The
ads
have
generated
some
laughs
but
also
plenty
of
attention
because
they
are
so
unlike
any
other
U.S.
auto
advertising
.
<END>
<START>
On
the
other
hand
,
Nissan
's
sales
goals
for
Infiniti
are
modest
compared
with
Toyota
's
targets
for
Lexus
.
<END>
<START>
Nissan
will
build
only
about
3,500
of
the
$
38,000
Infiniti
Q45
sedans
each
month
,
sending
about
2,000
of
them
to
the
U.S.
and
keeping
the
rest
for
sale
in
Japan
.
<END>
<START>
Toyota
wants
to
sell
about
49,000
Lexus
LS400
sedans
next
year
in
the
U.S.
alone
.
<END>
<START>
``
When
I
saw
the
Lexus
sales
projections
,
I
got
worried
,
''
confesses
Takashi
Oka
,
who
led
the
Infiniti
development
team
.
<END>
<START>
But
on
reflection
,
Mr.
Oka
says
,
he
concluded
that
Nissan
is
being
prudent
in
following
its
slow-startup
strategy
instead
of
simply
copying
Lexus
.
<END>
<START>
``
Infiniti
is
Nissan
's
big
business
move
for
the
21st
century
,
and
we
're
in
no
hurry
to
generate
large
profits
right
away
,
''
Mr.
Oka
says
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
plans
to
add
two
new
Infiniti
models
next
year
,
bringing
the
total
to
four
,
Infiniti
wo
n't
show
profits
for
at
least
five
years
,
he
adds
.
<END>
<START>
These
days
Nissan
can
afford
that
strategy
,
even
though
profits
are
n't
exactly
robust
.
<END>
<START>
Nissan
has
increased
earnings
more
than
market
share
by
cutting
costs
and
by
taking
advantage
of
a
general
surge
in
Japanese
car
sales
.
<END>
<START>
But
Nissan
expects
to
earn
only
120
billion
yen
in
the
current
fiscal
year
,
a
modest
increase
of
4.7
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
big
reason
:
For
all
its
cost-cutting
,
Nissan
remains
less
efficient
than
Toyota
.
<END>
<START>
In
its
last
fiscal
year
,
Nissan
's
profit
represented
just
2.3
%
of
sales
,
compared
with
4.3
%
at
Toyota
.
<END>
<START>
To
help
close
the
gap
,
Nissan
recently
established
a
top-level
cost-cutting
committee
.
<END>
<START>
Nissan
is
the
world
's
only
auto
maker
currently
building
vehicles
in
all
three
of
the
world
's
key
economic
arenas
--
the
U.S.
,
Japan
and
Europe
.
<END>
<START>
That
gives
it
an
enviable
strategic
advantage
,
at
least
until
its
rivals
catch
up
,
but
also
plenty
of
managerial
headaches
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
Nissan
's
U.S.
operations
include
10
separate
subsidiaries
--
for
manufacturing
,
sales
,
design
,
research
,
etc.
--
that
report
separately
back
to
Japan
.
<END>
<START>
And
in
July
,
Nissan
's
Tennessee
manufacturing
plant
beat
back
a
United
Auto
Workers
organizing
effort
with
aggressive
tactics
that
have
left
some
workers
bitter
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
are
in
a
transitional
phase
from
being
a
Japanese
company
to
becoming
an
international
company
based
in
Japan
,
''
says
Mr.
Muramatsu
,
the
executive
vice
president
.
<END>
<START>
He
promises
that
Nissan
will
soon
establish
a
holding
company
overseeing
all
U.S.
operations
,
just
as
it
's
doing
in
Europe
.
<END>
<START>
Perhaps
the
biggest
challenge
,
however
,
will
be
to
prevent
a
return
to
its
former
corporate
rigidity
as
its
recovery
continues
.
<END>
<START>
Already
,
personnel
officials
are
talking
about
the
need
for
a
``
Phase
Two
''
cultural-reform
effort
of
some
sort
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
are
still
only
half
way
through
the
turnaround
of
this
company
,
and
there
are
many
more
things
to
do
,
''
President
Kume
says
.
<END>
<START>
He

,

,

``
the

.

<START>

,

Bros
.

.

.

.

,

<START>
President
Bush
and
Soviet

Mikhail
Gorbachev
will

an

meeting
in
early
December
,
a
move
that
should
give
both
leaders
a

boost
at

.
<END>
<START>
The

is

a

so
that
there
wo

any

or

.
<END>
<START>

will

,

of

.
<END>
<START>
The

wo

a

meeting
next
spring

,
at

is

.
<END>
<START>

,

that

``

.
''
<END>
<START>

,

``

''
and

.
<END>
<START>
Despite

to

,

could
pay

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Gorbachev
badly
needs

from

and

.

.

''

<START>

.

<START>

.

<START>
Hardly
a
day
passes
without
news
photos
of
the
police
dragging
limp
protesters
from
some
building
or
thoroughfare
in
one
of
our
cities
.
<END>
<START>
Maybe
he
did
n't
start
it
,
but
Mohandas
Gandhi
certainly
provided
a
recognizable
beginning
to
non-violent
civil
disobedience
as
we
know
it
today
.
<END>
<START>
The
Mahatma
,
or
``
great
souled
one
,
''
instigated
several
campaigns
of
passive
resistance
against
the
British
government
in
India
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
difficult
,
however
,
to
justify
civil
disobedience
,
non-violent
or
not
,
where
citizens
have
full
recourse
to
the
ballot
box
to
effect
change
.
<END>
<START>
There
may
be
a
few
cases
where
the
law
breaking
is
well
pinpointed
and
so
completely
non-invasive
of
the
rights
of
others
that
it
is
difficult
to
criticize
it
.
<END>
<START>
The
case
of
Rosa
Parks
,
the
black
woman
who
refused
to
sit
at
the
back
of
the
bus
,
comes
to
mind
as
an
illustration
.
<END>
<START>
But
most
cases
of
non-violent
civil
disobedience
are
not
nearly
so
benign
.
<END>
<START>
The
public
has
a
tendency
to
equate
lawful
demonstrations
with
non-violent
civil
disobedience
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
true
that
both
are
non-violent
,
but
there
is
a
fundamental
difference
between
them
.
<END>
<START>
Civil
disobedience
,
violent
or
non-violent
,
is
intentional
law
breaking
.
<END>
<START>
The
subject
of
this
discussion
is
non-violent
civil
disobedience
;
but
,
before
we
get
on
with
that
,
let
me
make
just
a
few
tangential
remarks
about
lawful
demonstrations
.
<END>
<START>
They
are
useful
to
call
public
attention
to
grievances
,
but
they
have
little
value
in
educating
anyone
about
the
issues
in
dispute
.
<END>
<START>
The
delight
of
television
in
dramatic
confrontation
encourages
overuse
of
slogans
chanted
through
bullhorns
,
militant
gestures
,
accusatory
signs
and
other
emotionally
inspired
tactics
.
<END>
<START>
Civilized
discourse
and
an
environment
where
compromise
can
begin
are
lost
in
a
hostile
posture
abetted
by
superficial
media
interviews
.
<END>
<START>
At
best
,
demonstrations
are
overused
and
boringly
uninformative
;
at
worst
,
they
can
become
the
stimuli
that
lead
to
law
breaking
.
<END>
<START>
Demonstrations
are
particularly
apt
to
degenerate
into
criminal
conduct
when
they
leave
the
site
of
the
grievance
and
become
mobile
.
<END>
<START>
Soon
the
whole
purpose
of
the
demonstration
is
lost
in
mob
mania
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
better
ways
to
promote
a
cause
.
<END>
<START>
Where
non-violent
civil
disobedience
is
the
centerpiece
,
rather
than
a
lawful
demonstration
that
may
only
attract
crime
,
it
is
difficult
to
justify
.
<END>
<START>
Some
find
no
harm
in
the
misdemeanors
of
trespass
,
minor
property
destruction
,
blocking
traffic
and
the
like
.
<END>
<START>
They
say
these
are
small
prices
to
pay
for
galvanizing
action
for
the
all-important
cause
.
<END>
<START>
The
crimes
may
appear
small
,
but
the
prices
can
be
huge
.
<END>
<START>
Here
are
two
cases
to
illustrate
.
<END>
<START>
Assume
a
neighborhood
demonstration
to
protest
speeding
on
a
certain
road
or
a
careless
accident
involving
a
police
car
.
<END>
<START>
The
protesters
lie
down
in
the
street
,
blocking
traffic
,
and
will
not
move
until
the
authorities
carry
them
away
.
<END>
<START>
Assume
that
someone
caught
in
the
jam
has
a
heart
attack
.
<END>
<START>
There
is
no
way
to
get
an
ambulance
in
quickly
to
move
him
to
a
hospital
.
<END>
<START>
He
dies
.
<END>
<START>
The
demonstration
was
non-violent
and
involved
only
a
simple
misdemeanor
,
but
its
impact
on
that
individual
was
violent
and
terminal
.
<END>
<START>
Assume
that
a
TV
network
is
airing
a
celebrity
interview
program
with
a
live
audience
.
<END>
<START>
The
politician
appearing
is
highly
controversial
and
has
recently
generated
a
good
deal
of
rancor
amid
certain
groups
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
planned
protest
against
his
appearance
,
several
members
of
the
studio
audience
chain
themselves
in
front
of
the
TV
cameras
in
such
a
way
that
the
program
can
not
continue
.
<END>
<START>
The
network
must
refund
money
to
the
advertisers
and
loses
considerable
revenue
and
prestige
.
<END>
<START>
The
demonstrators
have
been
non-violent
,
but
the
result
of
their
trespasses
has
been
to
seriously
impair
the
rights
of
others
unconnected
with
their
dispute
.
<END>
<START>
Or
maybe
the
TV
network
would
lose
nothing
.
<END>
<START>
Geraldo
or
Phil
would
probably
pull
up
another
camera
and
interview
the
chained
protesters
.
<END>
<START>
Let
us
look
for
a
moment
at
another
type
of
non-violent
civil
disobedience
that
only
harms
other
people
indirectly
,
yet
does
irreparable
damage
to
the
nation
as
a
whole
.
<END>
<START>
I
am
referring
to
those
young
men
who
chose
to
disobey
their
country
's
call
to
arms
during
the
Vietnam
war
and
fled
to
Canada
or
some
other
sanctuary
to
avoid
combat
.
<END>
<START>
Even
more
at
fault
are
those
leaders
in
and
out
of
government
who
urged
and
supported
their
defections
,
thereby
giving
great
help
and
comfort
to
the
enemy
propagandists
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
amazing
that
the
ensuing
mass
executions
in
Vietnam
and
Cambodia
do
not
weight
more
heavily
on
minds
so
morally
fine-tuned
.
<END>
<START>
Worse
,
it
remained
to
a
well-meaning
but
naive
president
of
the
United
States
to
administer
the
final
infamy
upon
those
who
fought
and
died
in
Vietnam
.
<END>
<START>
Finally
,
I
think
it
important
to
point
out
the
extraordinarily
high
visibility
of
non-violent
civil
disobedience
in
these
days
of
intensive
media
coverage
.
<END>
<START>
Give
television
a
chance
to
cover
live
any
breaking
of
the
law
,
and
no
second
invitation
will
be
required
.
<END>
<START>
This
brings
into
question
the
motives
of
those
who
lead
civil
disobedience
demonstrations
.
<END>
<START>
Do
they
want
the
spotlight
for
themselves
or
for
their
cause
?
<END>
<START>
Here
is
a
good
rule
of
thumb
:
If
the
movement
produced
the
leader
,
the
chance
that
he
is
sincere
is
much
greater
than
if
the
leader
produced
the
movement
.
<END>
<START>
In
either
case
,
ask
yourself
whether
you
have
become
better
informed
on
the
issues
under
protest
by
watching
the
act
of
civil
disobedience
.
<END>
<START>
If
you
have
not
,
it
is
probable
that
a
thorough
airing
of
the
dispute
by
calm
and
rational
debate
would
have
been
the
better
course
.
<END>

.

.

.

.
