<START>
Despite
continuing
problems
in
its
newsprint
business
,
Kimberly-Clark
Corp.
posted
a
20
%
gain
in
third-quarter
net
income
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
rose
6.2
%
to
$
1.45
billion
from
$
1.37
billion
.
<END>
<START>
After
a
flat
second
quarter
tied
largely
to
lower
newsprint
earnings
,
Kimberly-Clark
attributed
the
gain
to
improved
results
in
its
consumer
businesses
in
North
America
,
Brazil
and
Korea
.
<END>
<START>
Those
gains
came
from
higher
prices
,
particularly
for
disposable
diapers
and
tissue
products
,
and
from
increased
sales
,
primarily
for
feminine-care
products
,
the
company
said
.
<END>
<START>
Newsprint
results
continued
to
be
depressed
,
the
company
added
,
because
of
industrywide
price
discounting
.
<END>
<START>
The
quarter-to-quarter
comparison
was
also
enhanced
by
charges
taken
in
the
year-earlier
period
,
including
$
11
million
related
to
the
modernization
of
a
pulp
and
newsprint
mill
in
Alabama
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
1989
period
also
,
interest
expense
and
tax
rates
were
lower
than
a
year
ago
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
first
nine
months
,
profit
rose
10
%
to
$
313.2
million
,
or
$
3.89
a
share
,
from
$
283.9
million
,
or
$
3.53
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
rose
6.7
%
to
$
4.27
billion
from
$
4
billion
.
<END>
<START>
In
New
York
Stock
Exchange
composite
trading
,
Kimberly-Clark
closed
at
$
66.50
a
share
,
up
$
1.50
.
<END>
<START>
INTENSIVE
AUDITS
are
coming
to
55,500
taxpayers
as
research
guinea
pigs
.
<END>
<START>
The
last
Taxpayer
Compliance
Measurement
Program
survey
covered
1985
returns
.
<END>
<START>
The
1988-return
project
starts
Jan.
1
and
is
to
be
done
by
May
31
,
1991
.
<END>
<START>
Specially
trained
IRS
agents
will
look
for
under-reported
income
and
unsupported
deductions
and
credits
.
<END>
<START>
The
agents
will
make
more
than
routine
inquiries
about
such
items
as
marital
status
and
dependents
;
they
want
to
look
at
living
standards
and
business
assets
.
<END>
<START>
But
they
also
are
to
see
that
taxpayers
get
all
allowable
tax
benefits
and
to
ask
if
filers
who
sought
IRS
aid
were
satisfied
with
it
.
<END>
<START>
Courts
have
ruled
that
taxpayers
must
submit
to
TCMP
audits
,
but
the
IRS
will
excuse
from
the
fullscale
rigors
anyone
who
was
audited
without
change
for
either
1986
or
1987
.
<END>
<START>
Rewards
have
been
suggested
--
but
never
adopted
--
for
filers
who
come
through
TCMP
audits
without
change
.
<END>
<START>
PENALTY
OVERHAUL
is
still
likely
,
congressional
sources
say
.
<END>
<START>
Long-debated
proposals
to
simplify
the
more
than
150
civil
penalties
and
make
them
fairer
and
easier
to
administer
are
in
the
House
tax
bill
.
<END>
<START>
But
they
were
stripped
from
the
Senate
bill
after
staffers
estimated
penalty
revenue
would
fall
by
$
216
million
over
five
years
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
congressional
aides
say
penalty
reform
is
a
strong
candidate
for
enactment
,
even
if
not
this
time
around
,
although
some
provisions
may
be
modified
.
<END>
<START>
He
would
ease
the
proposed
penalties
for
delayed
payroll-tax
deposits
and
for
faulty
Form
1099
and
other
reports
that
taxpayers
correct
voluntarily
.
<END>
<START>
The
General
Accounting
Office
urges
Congress
to
ensure
that
all
penalties
retain
their
force
as
deterrents
.
<END>
<START>
TAXPAYERS
'
RIGHTS
are
defined
by
a
growing
number
of
states
.
<END>
<START>
The
1988
tax
act
created
a
federal
bill
of
rights
spelling
out
IRS
duties
to
protect
taxpayers
'
rights
in
the
assessment
and
collection
of
taxes
.
<END>
<START>
States
are
following
suit
.
<END>
<START>
California
enacted
a
rights
law
in
1988
.
<END>
<START>
And
taxpayer
groups
are
urging
legislation
in
many
other
states
.
<END>
<START>
One
group
is
the
Committee
on
State
Taxation
,
which
comprises
330
multistate
corporations
and
advises
the
Council
of
State
Chambers
of
Commerce
.
<END>
<START>
The
group
also
seeks
uniformity
among
states
in
provisions
for
taxpayers
'
rights
.
<END>
<START>
This
week
,
New
York
City
announced
a
10-point
policy
patterned
on
the
federal
bill
of
rights
for
taxpayers
.
<END>
<START>
Also
unaltered
:
12
cents
for
charitable
activities
and
nine
cents
for
medical
and
moving
costs
.
<END>
<START>
IRA
BALANCES
could
be
used
to
qualify
for
bank
services
under
a
bill
entered
by
Reps.
Chandler
-LRB-
R.
,
Wash
.
-RRB-
and
Andrews
-LRB-
D.
,
Texas
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
The
bill
would
thwart
a
recent
Labor
Department
opinion
that
investing
individual-retirement-account
funds
to
earn
free
checking
violates
the
law
.
<END>
<START>
HUGO
FELLED
vast
timberlands
.
<END>
<START>
South
Carolina
's
congressional
delegation
has
entered
Senate
and
House
bills
to
provide
special
casualty-loss
treatment
and
other
tax
relief
for
timber
growers
in
the
hurricane
disaster
areas
.
<END>
<START>
HE
RODE
HIS
HOBBY
,
but
he
could
n't
milk
it
,
the
Tax
Court
says
.
<END>
<START>
The
court
often
weighs
deductions
of
sideline-business
costs
:
Do
they
stem
from
a
profit-seeking
activity
or
a
nondeductible
hobby
?
<END>
<START>
But
it
's
rare
to
see
both
functions
in
one
case
.
<END>
<START>
He
claimed
losses
totaling
$
42,455
--
and
the
IRS
denied
them
all
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
he
took
little
businesslike
care
with
his
cattle
:
He
had
no
prior
experience
and
did
n't
seek
business
counsel
about
them
.
<END>
<START>
The
judge
said
Givens
may
deduct
his
$
30,180
of
losses
from
horse
breeding
,
but
rejected
the
$
12,275
in
deductions
from
the
cattle
operation
.
<END>

:

1988

E.

to
the

post
of
inspector

,
which

for
the
IRS
...
.
<END>
<START>
The
U.S.
and
Finland
signed
an
income-tax
treaty
,
subject
to
ratification
.
<END>
<START>
An
arbitrator
awarded
Eastern
Airlines
pilots
between
$
60
million
and
$
100
million
in
back
pay
,
a
decision
that
could
complicate
the
carrier
's
bankruptcy-law
reorganization
.
<END>
<START>
Eastern
,
a
unit
of
Texas
Air
Corp.
,
said
it
is
examining
the
ruling
to
determine
if
it
can
appeal
.
<END>
<START>
All
Eastern
's
previous
court
efforts
to
head
off
the
pilots
'
demands
have
failed
.
<END>
<START>
An
Eastern
spokesman
said
he
does
n't
expect
that
the
arbitrator
's
ruling
``
will
have
any
overall
material
effect
on
the
company
's
strategic
plan
.
''
<END>
<START>
Bankruptcy
experts
said
the
law
is
n't
clear
on
how
such
an
arbitration
ruling
can
affect
a
company
's
case
.
<END>
<START>
Like
any
other
creditor
,
the
pilots
will
have
to
apply
to
the
court
for
payment
of
their
claim
.
<END>
<START>
That
may
leave
a
lot
of
leeway
for
U.S.
Bankruptcy
Judge
Burton
R.
Lifland
to
decide
what
,
if
anything
,
the
pilots
actually
collect
.
<END>
<START>
In
August
,
he
issued
the
ruling
that
let
the
pilots
pursue
their
back-pay
grievance
before
the
arbitrator
.
<END>
<START>
The
pilots
'
contract
with
Eastern
calls
for
a
mutually
acceptable
private
arbitrator
to
resolve
such
grievances
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
statement
to
employees
,
Eastern
said
the
company
was
disappointed
by
the
ruling
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
obligation
is
totally
unwarranted
,
''
the
statement
said
.
<END>
<START>
James
Linsey
,
a
lawyer
for
the
Air
Line
Pilots
Association
,
said
the
pilots
were
extremely
pleased
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
a
blow
not
only
to
Eastern
but
to
the
creditors
committee
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Eastern
and
its
creditors
are
in
the
final
,
delicate
stages
of
negotiating
a
second
reorganization
plan
to
pay
off
the
airline
's
debts
.
<END>
<START>
An
earlier
plan
,
which
had
received
the
creditors
'
approval
in
July
,
fell
apart
when
Eastern
changed
its
business
plan
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
n't
known
whether
the
pilot
claim
was
figured
into
either
plan
.
<END>
<START>
The
dispute
between
Eastern
and
its
pilots
is
over
a
``
pay
parity
''
clause
in
the
pilots
'
contract
.
<END>
<START>
The
clause
was
part
of
an
agreement
in
which
pilots
accepted
a
substantial
pay
cut
as
long
as
no
other
labor
group
got
a
raise
.
<END>
<START>
Shortly
after
Texas
Air
took
control
of
Eastern
,
some
Machinists
union
supervisors
received
a
20
%
pay
raise
.
<END>
<START>
The
pilots
argued
that
this
triggered
a
pay
raise
for
them
.
<END>
<START>
Eastern
has
disputed
the
claim
,
but
a
federal
district
court
,
an
appeals
court
and
now
the
arbitrator
have
all
sided
with
the
pilots
.
<END>
<START>
The
two
sides
do
n't
even
agree
about
how
much
money
is
at
issue
.
<END>
<START>
The
pilots
put
the
amount
as
high
as
$
100
million
,
the
company
at
$
65
million
.
<END>
<START>
Another
arbitrator
is
hearing
another
pay
parity
case
between
Eastern
and
its
pilots
,
resulting
from
a
similar
set
of
circumstances
involving
a
separate
pay
raise
granted
another
union
.
<END>
<START>
A
decision
on
that
case
is
n't
expected
before
mid-November
.
<END>
<START>
Ironically
,
many
of
the
pilots
involved
have
left
Eastern
or
are
still
striking
the
carrier
,
which
filed
for
bankruptcy
protection
March
9
.
<END>
<START>
About
800
have
crossed
the
picket
lines
and
returned
to
work
.
<END>
<START>
Few
people
in
the
advertising
business
have
raised
as
many
hackles
as
Alvin
A.
Achenbaum
.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
after
beating
them
,
Mr.
Achenbaum
is
joining
them
.
<END>
<START>
Backer
Spielvogel
Bates
Worldwide
named
Mr.
Achenbaum
,
62
,
vice
chairman
of
professional
services
,
reporting
directly
to
Carl
Spielvogel
,
chairman
and
chief
executive
officer
.
<END>
<START>
He
joins
Nov.
13
,
dissolving
his
consulting
firm
,
Canter
,
Achenbaum
Associates
.
<END>
<START>
In
years
past
,
the
ad
industry
's
most
distinguished
executives
did
n't
hesitate
to
excorciate
Mr.
Achenbaum
.
<END>
<START>
But
industry
executives
also
believe
hiring
Mr.
Achenbaum
is
a
shrewd
move
for
Backer
Spielvogel
,
a
unit
of
Saatchi
&
Saatchi
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Achenbaum
has
counted
among
his
clients
some
of
the
most
visible
blue-chip
advertisers
in
the
country
,
including
Nissan
,
Toyota
,
Seagram
and
Backer
Spielvogel
clients
Hyundai
and
J.P.
Morgan
.
<END>
<START>
His
client
contacts
,
meanwhile
,
could
prove
a
gold
mine
for
an
agency
that
has
had
few
new
business
wins
of
late
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
consultant
,
he
has
given
seminars
at
agencies
including
Ogilvy
&
Mather
on
how
to
win
new
business
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Spielvogel
said
he
hopes
Mr.
Achenbaum
will
do
some
strategic
consulting
at
the
agency
for
``
non-clients
,
in
hopes
that
they
become
clients
.
''
<END>
<START>
At
Backer
Spielvogel
,
Mr.
Spielvogel
's
hallmark
has
been
personal
involvement
with
all
major
clients
.
<END>
<START>
He
pampers
them
;
he
invites
them
to
fabulous
parties
;
he
strokes
them
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Achenbaum
,
too
,
delves
into
his
clients
'
business
.
<END>
<START>
``
Carl
has
a
much
higher
degree
of
intimacy
with
his
clients
than
is
ordinary
for
an
agency
his
size
.
<END>
<START>
And
with
Al
's
record
of
being
a
delver
and
a
detail
guy
,
you
can
see
how
the
two
fit
,
''
said
Alan
Gottesman
,
an
analyst
with
PaineWebber
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Achenbaum
's
move
follows
the
announcement
last
month
that
his
consulting
partner
,
Stanley
Canter
,
66
,
would
retire
.
<END>
<START>
When
the
announcement
came
out
,
``
I
picked
up
the
phone
and
said
,
`
Why
do
n't
you
come
to
us
?
'
''
Mr.
Spielvogel
said
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Achenbaum
,
who
had
been
considering
paring
down
his
firm
or
merging
it
with
another
small
consulting
outfit
,
soon
agreed
.
<END>
<START>
The
two
men
are
longtime
friends
and
tennis
partners
,
having
met
about
25
years
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Before
becoming
a
consultant
in
1974
,
Mr.
Achenbaum
was
a
senior
executive
at
J.
Walter
Thompson
Co
.
<END>
<START>
He
spent
most
of
his
career
formulating
marketing
strategies
,
but
became
best-known
for
chipping
away
at
ad
agency
compensation
.
<END>
<START>
Ad
agencies
typically
earned
a
straight
15
%
commission
;
if
a
client
spent
$
100
million
on
TV
time
,
the
agency
made
$
15
million
.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Achenbaum
pioneered
negotiated
fees
,
which
often
worked
out
to
less
than
15
%
.
<END>
<START>
More
recently
,
he
negotiated
``
indemnification
''
clauses
in
which
an
ad
agency
in
some
cases
must
pay
a
client
if
it
drops
the
account
.
<END>
<START>
He
ultimately
became
so
well-known
for
cutting
compensation
,
however
,
that
clients
did
n't
seek
him
out
for
anything
else
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
was
very
frustrated
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
fact
of
the
matter
is
,
I
am
a
marketer
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
another
reason
-LCB-
for
the
Backer
Spielvogel
job
-RCB-
.
<END>
<START>
It
struck
me
as
a
way
to
get
back
to
what
I
really
want
to
do
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Spielvogel
added
pointedly
:
``
The
pressure
on
commissions
did
n't
begin
with
Al
Achenbaum
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Spielvogel
said
Mr.
Achenbaum
will
work
with
clients
to
determine
the
mix
of
promotion
,
merchandising
,
publicity
and
other
marketing
outlets
,
and
to
integrate
those
services
.
<END>
<START>
He
will
concentrate
on
,
among
others
,
J.P.
Morgan
and
Hyundai
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Achenbaum
helped
Morgan
in
its
recent
agency
search
,
and
he
has
a
long
relationship
with
Hyundai
,
which
is
having
severe
troubles
,
including
declining
sales
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
trail
of
revenue
is
increasingly
going
away
from
pure
advertising
,
and
going
towards
other
services
,
''
Mr.
Spielvogel
said
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
of
being
just
an
ad
agency
,
he
said
:
``
We
have
redefined
our
mission
here
.
<END>
<START>
Our
mission
is
to
help
our
clients
grow
,
and
to
use
every
tool
of
marketing
communications
to
accomplish
that
.
''
<END>
<START>
Industry
executives
are
wishing
Mr.
Achenbaum
well
.
<END>
<START>
Leonard
Matthews
,
then-president
of
the
American
Association
of
Advertising
Agencies
,
called
Mr.
Achenbaum
a
``
quisling
''
in
an
incendiary
1987
speech
.
<END>
<START>
And
much
better
at
that
than
at
-LCB-
the
price-cutting
-RCB-
he
's
been
doing
recently
.
''
<END>
<START>
Cotton
Inc
.
Campaign
<END>
<START>
Cotton
Inc.
,
the
fiber
company
that
represents
cotton
growers
,
will
begin
a
new
ad
campaign
,
developed
by
Ogilvy
&
Mather
,
Thanksgiving
Day
.
<END>
<START>
J.
Nicholas
Hahn
,
Cotton
Inc.
's
president
and
chief
executive
,
was
an
outspoken
critic
of
WPP
Group
's
acquisition
of
Ogilvy
Group
earlier
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
During
the
takeover
,
Mr.
Hahn
said
he
would
put
his
account
up
for
review
if
WPP
's
bid
were
successful
,
but
he
did
n't
.
<END>
<START>
Cotton
Inc.
's
new
$
9
million
campaign
calls
cotton
the
``
Fabric
of
Our
Lives
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
campaign
replaces
its
``
Take
Comfort
in
Cotton
''
ads
and
marks
the
end
of
its
national
cooperative
advertising
efforts
.
<END>
<START>
With
the
new
TV
spots
,
Ogilvy
&
Mather
has
opted
for
a
family
style
with
lots
of
laughter
,
hugs
and
tears
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're
making
a
fairly
obvious
plea
for
some
emotional
reaction
,
''
says
Tom
Rost
,
creative
director
at
Ogilvy
&
Mather
.
<END>
<START>
Frank
Mingo
Dies
at
49
<END>
<START>
Frank
L.
Mingo
,
one
of
the
pioneers
of
advertising
targeted
at
black
audiences
,
died
at
the
age
of
49
after
a
stroke
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Mingo
was
chief
executive
officer
of
the
Mingo
Group
,
which
he
founded
in
1977
and
which
created
ads
for
the
black
market
.
<END>
<START>
Clients
include
Miller
Brewing
Co.
and
General
Motors
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Mingo
was
hospitalized
Sept.
23
and
died
Monday
,
according
to
Samuel
J.
Chisholm
,
the
agency
's
president
and
chief
operating
officer
.
<END>

Ad
Notes
...
.

<START>
EARNINGS
:
<END>
<START>
Revenue
increased
20
%
to
$
246.6
million
from
$
204.8
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
66-year-old
Mr.
Lee
recently
spent
an
hour
discussing
the
state
of
Asia
and
the
world
with
two
Journal
reporters
in
his
plainly
furnished
,
wood-paneled
office
.
<END>
<START>
The
interview
did
not
touch
on
Singapore
's
domestic
affairs
.
<END>
<START>
Excerpts
follow
:
<END>
<START>
On
China
's
turmoil
:
``
It
is
a
very
unhappy
scene
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Rebuilding
that
team
,
Mr.
Lee
predicted
,
will
take
another
10
years
.
<END>
<START>
On
similarities
between
China
and
the
Soviet
Union
:
``
In
important
particulars
,
the
Soviets
are
different
from
the
Chinese
.
<END>
<START>
They
are
already
industrialized
...
.
<END>
<START>
Their
problem
is
one
of
inefficiency
of
an
industrial
economy
.
<END>
<START>
The
Chinese
problem
is
much
greater
--
it
's
how
to
industrialize
to
begin
with
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mikhail
Gorbachev
,
he
said
,
is
ahead
of
China
's
leaders
in
his
awareness
of
the
world
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
I
think
the
Soviet
peoples
are
more
introverted
than
the
Chinese
.
''
<END>
<START>
Regardless
,
he
said
,
he
still
believes
the
Soviet
Union
,
while
falling
far
short
of
the
efficiency
of
a
Western
economy
,
may
well
manage
to
improve
considerably
.
<END>
<START>
In
such

,
``
all
benefit
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
And
if
the
Europeans
come

,
they
benefit

.
<END>
<START>
It
's
not
a
zero-sum
game
.
''
<END>
<START>
An
Asian
bloc
is
n't
intended
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
That
's
not
possible
.
''
<END>
<START>
On
U.S.-Japan
relations
:
``
I
'm
encouraged
.
<END>
<START>
I
think
the
earlier
strident
notes
struck
by
-LCB-
U.S.
Commerce
Secretary
Robert
-RCB-
Mosbacher
and
-LCB-
U.S.
Trade
Representative
-RCB-
Carla
Hills
have
been
more
rounded
.
<END>
<START>
I
believe
the
U.S.
is
becoming
more
patient
and
circumspect
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
the
total
relationship
that
is
important
.
''
<END>
<START>
Japan
's
recent
political
turbulence
,
Mr.
Lee
said
,
may
mean
Japan
will
slow
market
adjustments
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
'll
be
more
timorous
in
tackling
their
own
voters
,
like
opening
up
more
to
agricultural
imports
from
America
,

their

.
''
<END>
<START>
We
are
willing
to
share
the
political
burden
of
being
host
to
America
,
an
imperial

.
<END>
<START>
We
think

is
n't
such
a
great
burden
,
that
it
carries
no
stigma
,
and
we
are
prepared
to
do
it
.
''
<END>
<START>
On
U.S.-Philippine
relations
:
``
It
's
such
a
mixed-up
relationship
going
back
into
history
...
.
<END>
<START>
I
really
do
not
understand
how
it
is
that
Filipinos
feel
so
passionately
involved
in
this
father
figure
that
they
want
to
dispose
of
and
yet
they
need
.
<END>
<START>
I
just
do
n't
understand
it
.
<END>
<START>
My
relationships
with
the
British
are
totally
different
.
<END>
<START>
They
lorded
it
over
me
.
<END>
<START>
They
did
me
some
good
.
<END>
<START>
They
did
themselves
even
more
good
.
<END>
<START>
They
let
me
down
when
the
Japanese
came
down
-LCB-
during
World
War
II
-RCB-
...
.
<END>
<START>
I
do
n't
feel
down
or
done
in
because
I
show
British
serials
on
my
television
network
or
read
their
books
.
<END>
<START>
I
mean
it
is
a
normal
adult
relationship
.
<END>
<START>
The
occasional
Englishman
tries
to
put
on
airs
but
we
let
it
pass
...
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
just
comic
when
they
try
to
pretend
they
're
still
the
master
race
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lee
added
that
the
Filipinos
are
``
making
it
very
difficult
''
for
the
U.S.
military
presence
to
last
beyond
five
or
10

.
<END>
<START>
On
military
alternatives
if

:
``
The
Soviets
already
are
present
.
<END>
<START>

suppose
sooner

later
,
the
Japanese
would
have
to
fill
up
a
large
part
of
the
gap
on
the
naval
side
.
<END>
<START>
Maybe
the
Chinese
,
maybe
even
the
Indians
.
''
<END>
<START>
Asked
why
so
few
nations
seem
to
share
his
views
of
America
,
he
said
,
``
Many
people
see
it
that
way
.
<END>
<START>
But
they
have
just
taken
it
for
granted
.
''
<END>
<START>
Is
the
trouble
over
?
<END>

Sihanouk
and

Sen

?

ca

.

What

?

To

as

.

,

to

.

<START>

's

.

Chinese
can
not

seen
to
have
made
use
of
the
Khmer
Rouge
and
then
discard

.
''
<END>
<START>
Ms.
House
is
vice
president
of
Dow
Jones
International
Group
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Wain
is
editor
of
The
Asian
Wall
Street
Journal
.
<END>
<START>
Everything
looked
good
as
neurosurgeon
Walter
Levy
and
colleagues
carefully
cut
away
a
woman
's
spinal
tumor
at
the
Cleveland
Clinic
in
1978
.
<END>
<START>
Using
small
electrical
shocks
applied
to
her
feet
,
they
were
able
to
monitor
sensory
nerves
.
<END>
<START>
The
shocks
generated
nerve
impulses
that
traveled
via
spine
to
brain
and
showed
up
clearly
on
a
brain-wave
monitor
,
indicating
no
damage
to
the
delicate
spinal
tissue
.
<END>
<START>
Then
,
says
Dr.
Levy
,
``
she
woke
up
paralyzed
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
damage
was
to
her
motor
nerves
,
which
could
n't
be
monitored
along
with
the
sensory
nerves
,
he
explains
.
<END>
<START>
The
tragedy
,
he
adds
,
``
galvanized
me
''
to
look
for
a
way
to
prevent
similar
cases
.
<END>
<START>
Dr.
Levy
's
answer
may
come
with
a
new
kind
of
magnetic
brain
probe
,
a
device
that
he
and
dozens
of
U.S.
researchers
are
studying
with
great
hope
.
<END>
<START>
Besides
holding
the
promise
of
safer
spinal
surgery
,
the
probe
could
improve
the
diagnosis
of
brain
and
nerve
disorders
such
as
strokes
and
multiple
sclerosis
.
<END>
<START>
Perhaps
most
exciting
,
the
device
is
thrusting
open
a
window
to
the
workings
of
the
brain
.
<END>
<START>
The
probe
,
which
is
painless
,
non-invasive
and
apparently
harmless
,
employs
strong
magnetic
fields
to
induce
small
whirlwinds
of
electricity
within
the
brain
.
<END>
<START>
If
positioned
over
the
brain
's
motor-control
area
,
the
hand-held
electromagnets
generate
nerve
impulses
that
zip
down
motor
nerves
and
activate
muscles
,
making
,
say
,
a
finger
twitch
.
<END>
<START>
In
principle
,
they
will
enable
doctors
to
check
the
body
's
motor
system
the
way
an
electrician
tests
a
home
's
electrical
circuits
by
running
current
through
them
.
<END>
<START>
``
All
we
could
do
was
tell
a
patient
,
`
squeeze
my
fingers
as
hard
as
you
can
'
or
`
raise
your
arm
.
'
<END>
<START>
``
Under
the
best
circumstances
such
tests
are
subjective
;
when
a
patient
is
unconscious
,
they
do
n't
work
at
all
.
<END>
<START>
Magnetic
brain
tweaking
started
in
the
early
1900s
,
when
researchers
produced
flashes
of
light
in
the
visual
field
with
magnets
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
1960s
,
Mayo
Clinic
researchers
developed
magnetic
devices
to
stimulate
motor
nerves
in
the
hand
and
other
limbs
.
<END>
<START>
The
field
took
off
in
1985
after
scientists
at
Britain
's
Sheffield
University
developed
a
handy
,
compact
magnet
for
brain
stimulation
.
<END>
<START>
Since
then
,
at
least
two
commercial
versions
have
been
put
on
the
U.S.
market
,
and
an
estimated
500
have
been
sold
.
<END>
<START>
In
August
,
a
Chicago
conference
on
such
devices
attracted
more
than
100
researchers
,
who
reported
studies
on
everything
from
brain
mapping
to
physical
therapy
.
<END>
<START>
A
problem
,
he
adds
,
is
that
anesthetized
brains
are
more
resistant
to
magnetic
stimulation
than
awake
ones
.
<END>
<START>
The
devices
could
help
indicate
when
surgery
would
help
,
says
Charles
Tator
,
a
University
of
Toronto
neurosurgeon
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
paralyzed
car-crash
victims
occasionally
have
some
intact
spinal
tissues
that
,
if
preserved
by
emergency
surgery
,
enable
partial
recovery
.
<END>
<START>
But
such
operations
typically
are
n't
performed
because
there
is
no
sign
right
after
an
injury
that
surgery
would
be
beneficial
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
cost
-LCB-
of
magnetic
stimulators
-RCB-
would
seem
like
peanuts
if
we
could
retrieve
limb
function
''
in
such
people
,
Dr.
Tator
says
.
<END>
<START>
Scientists
caution
there
is
a
chance
the
magnet
technique
might
spark
seizures
in
epileptics
.
<END>
<START>
But
no
significant
problems
have
been
reported
among
hundreds
of
people
tested
with
the
devices
.
<END>
<START>
One
apparent
side
effect
is
a
minor
increase
in
a
brain
hormone
.
<END>
<START>
And
some
doctors
who
have
conducted
hours
of
tests
on
themselves
report
temporary
headaches
.
<END>
<START>
At
least
two
companies
,
Cadwell
Laboratories
Inc.
of
Kennewick
,
Wash.
,
and
Novametrix
Medical
Systems
Inc.
of
Wallingford
,
Conn.
,
now
sell
versions
of
the
magnetic
devices
.
<END>
<START>
Researchers
can
apply
for
permission
to
use
the
probes
for
brain
studies
.
<END>
<START>
Similarly
,
a
Purdue
University
team
led
by
heart
researcher
W.A.
Tacker
hopes
to
develop
ways
to
magnetically
induce
cardiac
muscle
contractions
.
<END>
<START>
The
devices
might
someday
serve
as
temporary
pacemakers
or
restarters
for
stopped
hearts
,
says
Dr.
Tacker
,
whose
prototype
was
dubbed
the
``
Tacker
whacker
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
devices
'
most
remarkable
possibilities
,
though
,
involve
the
brain
.
<END>
<START>
Probing
with
the
stimulators
,
National
Institutes
of
Health
scientists
recently
showed
how
the
brain
reorganizes
motor-control
resources
after
an
amputation
.
<END>
<START>
Similar
studies
are
expected
to
reveal
how
stroke
patients
'
brains
regroup
--
a
first
step
toward
finding
ways
to
bolster
that
process
and
speed
rehabilitation
.
<END>
<START>
Scientists
also
are
exploring
memory
and
perception
with
the
new
machines
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
State
University
of
New
York
at
Brooklyn
,
researchers
flash
two
groups
of
different
letters
on
a
computer
screen
in
front
of
human
guinea
pigs
.
<END>
<START>
Between
flashes
,
certain
areas
in
subjects
'
brains
are
jolted
with
a
magnetic
stimulator
.
<END>
<START>
When
the
jolt
is
timed
just
right
,
the
subjects
do
n't
recall
seeing
the
first
group
of
letters
.
<END>
<START>
``
Where
does
that
first
stimulus
go
?
''
exclaims
SUNY
neurologist
Paul
Maccabee
.
<END>
<START>
``
Trying
to
answer
that
is
suggesting
all
kinds
of
theories
,
''
such
as
precisely
where
and
how
the
brain
processes
incoming
signals
from
the
eyes
.
<END>
<START>
He
and
others
say
that
the
machines
are
weak
enough
that
they
do
n't
jeopardize
the
memory
.
<END>
<START>
Both
the
SUNY
team
and
researchers
at
the
National
Magnet
Laboratory
in
Cambridge
,
Mass.
,
are
working
with
more
potent
magnetic
brain
stimulators
.
<END>
<START>
Among
other
things
,
the
stronger
devices
may
be
able
to
summon
forth
half-forgotten
memories
and
induce
mood
changes
,
neurologists
say
.
<END>
<START>
Du
Pont
Co.
,
Hewlett-Packard
Co.
and
Los
Alamos
National
Laboratory
said
they
signed
a
three-year
,
$
11
million
agreement
to
collaborate
on
superconductor
research
.
<END>
<START>
The
collaboration
will
include
at
least
25
researchers
and
will
be
aimed
primarily
at
developing
thin
films
of
high-temperature
superconductors
for
use
in
electronics
,
the
companies
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
materials
,
discovered
during
the
past
three
years
,
conduct
electricity
without
resistance
and
promise
smaller
,
faster
computers
and
other
new
technologies
.
<END>
<START>
Joint-research
programs
have
proliferated
as
U.S.
companies
seek
to
spread
the
risks
and
costs
of
commercializing
new
superconductors
and
to

,

.
<END>
<START>
The
latest
research
pact
bolsters
Du
Pont
's
growing

of

in

.
<END>
<START>
The
Wilmington
,

,

previously

with

and

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
Hewlett-Packard
is
a
Palo
Alto
,

,

maker
.
<END>
<START>
J.C.
PENNEY
Co.
,
Dallas
,
said
it
issued
$
350
million
of
securities
backed
by

.
<END>
<START>
The

was

with

8.95
%

at
99.1875
%
to
yield
9.19
%
.
<END>
<START>
The

said

are
expected

be
rated

by
Standard
&
Poor
's
Corp.
and
Aaa
by

's

Service
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
They

only
for
115

,

.
<END>
<START>
The
expected

of

10

,

in

,

.
<END>
<START>
First
Boston
Corp.
is

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
J.C.

will

.

<START>
Shaken
by
tumbling
stock
prices
and
pessimistic
projections
of
U.S.
economic
growth
,
currency
analysts
around
the
world
have
toned
down
their

of
the
dollar
's
near-term
performance
.
<END>
<START>
Opinion
is
mixed
over
its
three-month
prospects
.
<END>
<START>
Half
of
those
polled
see
the
currency
trending
lower
over
the
next
three
months
,
while
the
others
forecast
a
modest
rebound
after
the
New
Year
.
<END>
<START>
A
month
ago
,
a

survey
predicted
the
dollar
would
be
trading
at
1.8690
marks
and
139.75
yen
by
the
end
of
October
.
<END>
<START>
Sterling
was
trading
at
$
1.5805
,
down
from
$
1.5820
late
Monday
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
of
estimates
of
the
10
economists
polled
puts
the
dollar
around
1.8200
marks
at
the
end
of
November
and
at
141.33
yen
.
<END>
<START>
By
late
January
,
the
consensus
calls
for
the
dollar
to
be
trading
around
1.8200
marks
and
near
142
yen
.
<END>
<START>
Those
with
a
bullish
view
see
the
dollar
trading
up
near
1.9000
marks
and
145
yen
,
while
the
dollar
bears
see
the
U.S.
currency
trading
around
1.7600
marks
and
138
yen
.
<END>
<START>
A
number
of
those
polled
predict
the
dollar
will
slip
as
the
Federal
Reserve
eases
interest
rates
.
<END>
<START>
Fed
funds
is
the
rate
banks
charge
each
other
on
overnight
loans
;
the
Fed
influences
the
rate
by
adding
or
draining
reserves
from
the
banking
system
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
White
also
predicted
a
half-point
cut
in
the
U.S.
discount
rate
in
the
near
future
.
<END>
<START>
The
discount
rate
,
currently
7
%
,
is
the
rate
the
Fed
charges
member
banks
for
loans
,
using
government

as

.
<END>
<START>
He

``
because
of

,

.
''

14

.

<START>
The

.

<START>

.

.

.

whom

tried
to
keep
,
did
n't
return
calls
for
comment
.
<END>
<START>
Separately
,
Chemical
confirmed
that
it
took
an
undisclosed
charge
in
the
second
quarter
for
losses
on
forward-rate
agreements
involving
foreign
currency
written
by
its
branch
in
Frankfurt
,
West
Germany
.
<END>
<START>
A
Chemical
spokeswoman
said
the
second-quarter
charge
was
``
not
material
''
and
that
no
personnel
changes
were
made
as
a
result
.
<END>
<START>
The
spokeswoman
said
the
Frankfurt
situation
was
``
totally
different
''
from
problems
in
the
interest-rate
options
unit
.
<END>
<START>
These
complex
products
require
close
monitoring
because
each
must
be
valued
separately
in
light
of
current
market
conditions
.
<END>
<START>
In
an
interest-rate
options
contract
,
a
client
pays
a
fee
to
a
bank
for
custom-tailored
protection
against
adverse
interest-rate
swings
for
a
specified
period
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
forward-rate
agreement
,
a
client
agrees
to
an
exchange
rate
on
a
future
currency
transaction
.
<END>
<START>
Some
competitors
maintain
the
interestrate
option
loss
,
in
particular
,
may
have
resulted
more
from
Chemical
's
taking
large
and
often
contrarian
positions
than
a
valuation
problem
.
<END>
<START>
Started
three
years
ago
,
Chemical
's
interest-rate
options
group
was
a
leading
force
in
the
field
.
<END>
<START>
From
1987
to
1988
,
the
value
of
Chemical
's
option
contracts
outstanding
mushroomed
to
$
37
billion
from
$
17
billion
.
<END>
<START>
More
importantly
,
the
volume
of
options
written
exceeded
those
purchased
by
almost
2-to-1
.
<END>
<START>
With
such
a
lopsided
book
of
options
,
traders
say
,
Chemical
was
more
vulnerable
to
erroneous
valuation
assumptions
.
<END>
<START>
The
Chemical
spokeswoman
said
the
bank
has
examined
its
methodologies
and
internal
controls
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
consider
our
internal
controls
to
have
worked
well
,
''
she
said
,
adding
that
some

have
been

.
<END>
<START>
Its
valuation
methodologies
,
she
said
,
``
are
recognized
as
some
of
the
best
on
the
Street
.
<END>
<START>
Not
a
lot
was
needed
to
be
done
.
<END>
<START>
When
Thomas
W.
Wathen
went
big
league
last
year
,

acquired
a

of
Americana
along
with

ailing

:

.
<END>
<START>
Then

,

.
<END>
<START>
But

three
,

's

.
<END>
<START>
The

Wathen
has
learned
that
while

company
can

to

,

.
<END>
<START>
``
We

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
He

in

the
next

.
<END>
<START>
Over

20

,
California

opened
125

around

country
.
<END>
<START>
He

's

with

while

because

.
<END>
<START>
``
The

is

.
<END>
<START>
I

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
``

anyway
.
''
<END>
<START>
``
We

because

.
<END>
<START>
If
we
had
,
it
might
have
scared

off
,
''
he

.
<END>
<START>
Five

under
American
Brands
,
with

emphasis
on

the
agency
's

instead

,

's

,

.
<END>
<START>
He

could

.
<END>
<START>
Pinkerton
's

,

''

<END>

,

.

.

<START>

.

,

.

<START>
Paramount
Communications
Inc.
,
New
York
,
completed
the
sale
of
its
Associates
Corp.
consumer
and
commercial
finance
subsidiary
to
a

of
Ford
Motor
Co.
for
$
3.35
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Paramount
said
the
gain
would
be
recorded
in
its
fourth
quarter
,
which
ended
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
Paramount
said
the
sale
``
completes
the
strategic
restructuring
''
it
began
in
1983
,
and
would
enable
it
to
focus
on
its

and

businesses
.
<END>
<START>
Ford
said
in
July
it
planned
to
operate
Associates
,
based
in
Dallas
,
as
a
separate
entity
in
its
Ford

Group
.
<END>
<START>
Paramount
said
Associates
has
about
$
14
billion
in
total
assets
,
making
it
third-largest
in
terms
of
assets
among
independent

in

.
<END>
<START>
Together

,

and

,

would

Sea

a

.
<END>
<START>

``
asset

,
''

said

will
move

to
sell
two

,

,

,

,

.

<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

Containers
added
that

will

by
more
than

500

.
<END>
<START>

,

13.8

,

that

was

a

to
ward

.

.

<START>
You

No

.

<START>

,

.

.

.

<START>

.
<END>

,

<START>
After
20

system
,
Bert
Seidman
of

is

from
an

quarter
:
big

.
<END>
<START>
Corporate

,
frustrated
by
double-digit
increases
in
health-care

,
are
beginning
to
sound
like

.
<END>
<START>
The
pocketbook

of
health

has
driven

to

.
<END>
<START>
Agreement

these

,
and

to

.
<END>
<START>

could

and

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>
``

-LRB-

,

.
-RRB-
.

.
''

<START>

.
<END>
<START>
Partly

,

.

<START>
It
will
feature
a

designed
to

from

.
<END>
<START>

11.1
%

,

already

.
<END>
<START>

,

's
equal
6.7
%

,
a
nation
's

output
of

and

.
<END>
<START>
Management
and

worry
that
the

less

.
<END>
<START>

is

,
''

closed

.
''
<END>
<START>
A
Georgia-Pacific
acquisition
of
Nekoosa
would
create
the
largest
U.S.

company
.
<END>
<START>
Based
on
1988
sales
,
Georgia-Pacific
ranked
third
at
$
9.51
billion
,
behind
Weyerhaeuser
Co.
at
$
10
billion
and
International
Paper
Co.
at
$
9.53
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Nekoosa
ranked
11th
with
sales
of
$
3.59
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
combined
company
would
have
had
1988
sales
of
$
13.1
billion
.
<END>
<START>
But
such
a
combination
also
presents
great
risks
.
<END>
<START>
``
Nobody
knows
how
deep
the
cycle
is
going
to
be
,
''
said
Rod
Young
,

Inc.
,

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
``
Depending
on
how
far
down
you
go
,
it
may
be
difficult
to
pay
off
that
debt
.
''
<END>
<START>
One
person
familiar
with
Georgia-Pacific
said
the
acquisition
would
more
than
double
the
company
's
debt
of
almost
$
3
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Georgia-Pacific
's
Mr.
Hahn
said
that
a
combined
operation
would
allow
savings
in
many
ways
.
<END>
<START>
The
two
companies
each
produce
market
pulp
,
containerboard
and
white
paper
.
<END>
<START>
That
means
goods
could
be
manufactured
closer
to
customers
,
saving
shipping
costs
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
production
runs
would
be
longer
,
cutting
inefficiencies
from
adjusting
machinery
between
production
cycles
.
<END>
<START>
And
Georgia-Pacific
could
save
money
in
selling
pulp
,
because
the
company
uses
its
own
sales
organization
while
Nekoosa
employs
higher-cost
agents
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Hahn
said
Georgia-Pacific
has
accounted
in
its

for
a
``
significant
downturn
''
in
the

and

industry
,

that
he
said

.

''

<START>
The
condition
,
known
as
paroxysmal
supraventricular
tachycardia
,
leads
to
dizziness
and
fainting
.
<END>
<START>
The
typical
healthy
heart
beats
70
times
a
minute
.
<END>
<START>
The
drug
,
called
adenocard
,
returns
the
heart
to
a
normal
rhythm
within
seconds
,
according
to
Lyphomed
.
<END>
<START>
Medco
Research
developed
the
drug
and
licensed
it
to
Lyphomed
for
sale
in
the
U.S.
and
Canada
.
<END>
<START>
Private
industry
's
labor
costs
rose
1.2
%
in
the
third
quarter
,
matching
the
second-quarter
pace
,
as
health
insurance
costs
continued
to
soar
,
the
Labor
Department
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
increase
in
wage
and
benefit
costs
in
the
third
quarter
was
greater
than
the
1
%
rise
reported
for
the
third
quarter
of
1988
.
<END>
<START>
``
One
would
have
thought
this
would
have
happened
two
or
three
years
ago
as
the
labor
market
tightened
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
a
considerably

reaction
and
it
's
not

severe
one
at
all
,
''
she
added
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
data
underscored
the
severity
of
the
nation
's
health-care
cost
problem
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
12
months
ended
in
September
,
wages
and
salaries
of
private-sector
workers
rose
4.4
%
,
while
health
insurance
costs
spurted
by
13.7
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
consumer
price
index
climbed
4.3
%
in
the
same
period
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
the
big
increases
in
health-care
costs
,
wages
still
account
for
a
far
greater
share
of
overall
labor
costs
.
<END>
<START>
Labor
costs
are
climbing
at
a
far
more
rapid
pace
in
the
health
care
industry
than
in
other
industries
.
<END>
<START>
For
instance
,
wages
of
private-sector
hospital
workers
leaped
6.6
%
in
the
12
months
ended
in
September
,
compared
with
4.4
%
for
workers
in
all
industries
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
past
five
years
,
unions
have
n't
managed
to
win
wage
increases
as
large
as
those
granted
to
nonunion
workers
.
<END>
<START>
For
private-sector
union
workers
,
the
cost
of
wages
and
benefits
rose
0.9
%
in
the
third
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
For
nonunion
workers
,
the
costs
rose
1.4
%
.
<END>
<START>
Labor
costs
continued
to
rise
more
rapidly
in
service
industries
than
in
goods-producing
industries
,
the
report
showed
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
found
them
rising
much
more
in
the
Northeast
than
elsewhere
.
<END>
<START>
The
index
rose
1.1
%
in
the
second
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
12
months
ended
in
September
,
this
index
was
up
5.1
%
.
<END>
<START>
It
rose
4.8
%
for
the
12
months
ended
in
June
and
4.7
%
in
the
12
months
ended
in
September
1988
.
<END>
<START>
Unlike
most
economic
indicators
,
none
of
these
figures
are
adjusted
for

variations
.

The

said
its
junk-bond
portfolio
after
these
moves
had
been
reduced
to
less
than
1
%
of
assets
.
<END>
<START>
The
campaign
,
a

of
the
200th

of
the
Bill
of
Rights
,
does
n't
mention

or

;

.

.

.

<START>

<START>

.
<END>
<START>
The

,

.
<END>
<START>
But

.
<END>
<START>
The

.

.

<START>

.

<START>

,

,

.

<START>
On

,

.
<END>
<START>

.

.

,

.

<START>

'

.

<START>

,

,

.

.

,

<START>
Senate

Robert
Byrd
-LRB-

,

.
-RRB-

.

<START>

,

,

jealously
protects
its
prerogatives
over
operations
at
the
State
Department
.
<END>
<START>

,

,

this

.

30

after

would

.

<END>
<START>
Santa
Fe
Pacific
was
the
kind
of
story
Wall
Street
loved
.
<END>
<START>
Since
the
value
of
its
assets
was
n't
known
,
analysts
were
free
to
pick
a
number
.
<END>
<START>
In
one
of
many
rosy
scenarios
,
Bear
Stearns
's
Gary
Schneider
wrote
in
March
that
its
real
estate
alone
had
a
value
of
$
4.5
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Throw
in
its
railroad
,
minerals
,
pipeline
and
oil
assets
,
he
and
others
argued
,
and
the
Chicago-based
conglomerate
should
be
worth
30
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
And
why
should
holders
expect
to
realize
that
presumed
``
worth
?
''
<END>
<START>
That
was
another
reason
the
Street
loved
Santa
Fe
.
<END>
<START>
But
value
,
it
turns
out
,
is
only
what
a
buyer
will
pay
.
<END>
<START>
And
with
the
company
's
recent
announcement
that
it
is
contemplating
a
partial
sale
of
its
real
estate
,
the
values
suddenly
look
poorer
.
<END>
<START>
Santa
Fe
has
disclosed
that
it
is
negotiating
to
sell
a
20
%
interest
in
its
real
estate
unit
to
the
California
Public
Employees
Retirement
System
for
roughly
$
400
million
.
<END>
<START>
Since
the
real
estate
unit
also
includes
debt
,
the
imputed
value
of
the
real
estate
itself
is
close
to
$
3
billion
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
implied
current
net
asset
value
of
22.70
-LCB-
per
share
-RCB-
is
well
below
the
30
level
that
the
Street
believed
,
''
PaineWebber
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
upside
was
in
the
intangible
real
estate
...
which
is
no
longer
an
intangible
.
''
<END>
<START>
So
what
is
Santa
Fe
worth
?
<END>
<START>
A
compromise
between
bulls
and
bears
puts
remaining
assets
and
cash
--
including
its
44
%
stake
in
its
publicly
traded
pipeline
--
at
$
2
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Santa
Fe
also
has
$
3.7
billion
in
debt
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
its
railroad
lost
a
$
750
million
antitrust
suit
,
which
is
on
appeal
,
and
which
analysts
say
could
be
settled
for
one-third
that
amount
.
<END>
<START>
That
nets
out
to
about
$
17
a
share
for
the
company
on
a
private
market
basis
.
<END>
<START>
But
Santa
Fe
,
currently
trading
at
18
7/8
,
is
n't
likely
to
realize
private
market
values
by
selling
assets
,
because
the
tax
against
it
would
be
onerous
.
<END>
<START>
Its
plan
,
instead
,
is
to
spin
off
the
remainder
of
its
real
estate
unit
and
to
possibly
do
the
same
with
its
mining
and
energy
assets
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
is
n't
clear
why
that
should
be
so
.
<END>
<START>
The
spinoff
argument
,
after
all
,
reverses
the
current
notion
that
assets
are
worth
more
to
private
buyers
than
to
public
shareholders
.
<END>
<START>
And
real
estate
usually
has
n't
traded
well
under
public
ownership
.
<END>
<START>
Salomon
Brothers
says
,
``
We
believe
the
real
estate
properties
would
trade
at
a
discount
...
after
the
realty
unit
is
spun
off
...
.
<END>
<START>
And
what
about
the
cost
,
and
risk
,
of
waiting
to
realize
the
hypothetical
private
market
values
?
''
<END>
<START>
Some
analysts
remain
bullish
.
<END>
<START>
He
adds
:
``
If
for
any
reason
I
do
n't
have
the
values
,
then
I
wo
n't
recommend
it
.
''
<END>
<START>

Fe
at
24
,

29
.
<END>
<START>
Her

``

.
''
<END>
<START>
But

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
In
other

:
The

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>

``

,
''

.

.

13

's

.

,

,

<START>
LTV
Steel
Co.
is
boosting
the
prices
of
flat
rolled
steel
products
by
an
average
of
3
%
following
a
recent
erosion
in
the
prices
of
such
crucial
steel
products
.
<END>
<START>
The
big
questions
are
whether
the
increase
,
effective
Jan.
1
,
1990
,
will
stick
,
and
whether
other
major
steelmakers
will
follow
suit
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
widely
expected
that
they
will
.
<END>
<START>
The
increase
is
on
the
base
price
,
which
is
already
being
discounted
by
virtually
all
steel
producers
.
<END>
<START>
But
LTV
's
move
marks
the
first
effort
by
a
major
steelmaker
to
counter
the
free
fall
in
spot
prices
.
<END>
<START>
Major
steel
producers
are
selling
cold
rolled
sheet
steel
at
about
$
370
a
ton
,
compared
with
a
peak
price
of
$
520
a
ton
in
1988
.
<END>
<START>
Second-tier
companies
are
receiving
even
less
per
ton
.
<END>
<START>
LTV
's
planned
increase
,
which
was
announced
in
an
Oct.
26
memo
to
district
managers
,
does
n't
affect
electrogalvanized
steel
or
tin
plate
.
<END>
<START>
LTV
confirmed
the
price-increase
plan
,
saying
the
move
is
designed
to
more
accurately
reflect
the
value
of
products
and
to
put
steel
on
more
equal
footing
with
other
commodities
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
same
time
,
steelmakers
are
trying
to
invest
more
to
modernize
technology
and
make
themselves
more
competitive
.
<END>
<START>
But
analysts
say
the
company
is
also
trying
to
prevent
further
price
drops
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
they
note
that
LTV
may
be
trying
to
send
a
signal
to
major
customers
,
such
as
Chrysler
Corp.
and
Whirlpool
Corp.
,
that
steelmakers
need
more
money
.
<END>
<START>
Both
companies
are
in
the
process
of
negotiating
contracts
with
LTV
and
others
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Marcus
believes
spot
steel
prices
will
continue
to
fall
through
early
1990
and
then
reverse
themselves
.
<END>
<START>
He
is
n't
convinced
,
though
,
that
the
price
decline
reflects
falling
demand
because
the
world
economy
remains
relatively
strong
.
<END>
<START>
And
while
customers
such
as
steel
service
centers
are
continuing
to
reduce
inventories
through
the
fourth
quarter
,
they
eventually
will
begin
stocking
up
again
,
he
notes
.
<END>
<START>
It
wo
n't
be
clear
for
months
whether
the
price
increase
will
stick
.
<END>
<START>
Steelmakers
announced
a
round
of
base-price
increases
last
year
,
but
began
offering
sizable
discounts
over
the
summer
.
<END>
<START>
In

,
LTV
was
the
first

to

for
buyers
of
cold

.

.

During

<END>
<START>
LUTHER

CROSS-BRED

to

.

<START>

--

--

.

<START>

DNA
-LRB-

acid
-RRB-
,

.

<START>
When

,

,

.

.

was

.
<END>

,

,

.

.

.

.

.

holding
company
said
Hunter
will
receive
390,000
shares
of
a
new
series
of
Cilcorp
convertible
preferred
stock
with
a
face
value
of
$
39
million
for
the
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
Cilcorp
will
also
assume
$
22
million
of
Hunter
's
existing
debt
.
<END>
<START>
As

of
the
agreement
,
Cilcorp
said
it
will
pay
Hunter
$
4
million
in
exchange
for
agreements
not
to

.
<END>
<START>
Cilcorp
said
the
businesses
to
be
acquired
had
revenue
of
$
76
million
for
the
year
ended
March
31
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
,
which
currently
has
13.5
million
common
shares
outstanding
,
said
it
has
no
specific
plans
for

shares
.

.

<START>

,

with

trades
in

to

off
a
hostile
bid
by
two
European
shipping
firms
.
<END>
<START>

Airlines
pilots
were

between

60
million
and

100
million
in
back
pay
by
an

,
a

that
could
complicate
the
carrier
's
bankruptcy
reorganization
.
<END>
<START>
LTV
Steel
is
boosting

an

3
%
,
but
it
's

whether

,

for
Jan.
1
,
1990
,
will
stick
.
<END>
<START>
Southern
's

paid
$

in

after

to

to

and

.

<START>
More

are

,

.

as

.

.

<START>
The

disclosed

two

.

<START>

--

:

.

:

3426.33
,
up
<END>
<START>

:
Dow
Jones
futures

129.63
,

;

129.84
,

.
<END>
<START>
Dollar
:
142.85
yen
,
up
0.95
;
1.8415
marks
,
up
0.0075
.
<END>
<START>
Bond
prices
staggered
in
seesaw
trading
,
rising
on
reports
of
economic
weakness
and
falling
on
reports
of
economic
strength
.
<END>
<START>
Treasury
bonds
got
off
to
a
strong
start
,
advancing
modestly
during
overnight
trading
on
foreign
markets
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
saw
good
buying
in
Japan
and
excellent
buying
in
London
,
''
said
Jay
Goldinger
,
market
strategist
and
trader
at
Capital
Insight
Inc.
,
Beverly
Hills
,
Calif
.
<END>
<START>
The
market
's
tempo
was
helped
by
the
dollar
's
resiliency
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Late
in
London
,
the
dollar
was
quoted
at
1.8410
West
German
marks
and
142.70
Japanese
yen
,
up
from
late
Monday
in
New
York
.
<END>
<START>
British
sterling
eased
to
$
1.5775
from
$
1.5825
.
<END>
<START>
When
U.S.
trading
began
,
Treasury
bonds
received
an
additional
boost
from
news
that
sales
of
new
single-family
homes
fell
14
%
in
September
.
<END>
<START>
The
contraction
was
twice
as
large
as
economists
projected
and
was
the
sharpest
decline
since
a
19
%
drop
in
January
1982
.
<END>
<START>
Economists
said
the
report
raised
speculation
that
the
economic
slowdown
could
turn
into
a
recession
,
which
would
pave
the
way
for
the
Federal
Reserve
to
lower
interest
rates
.
<END>
<START>
But
later
in
the
day
,
a
report
by
the
Purchasing
Management
Association
of
Chicago
cast
doubt
on
the
recession
scenario
.
<END>
<START>
The
association
said
its
October
index
of
economic
activity
rose
to
51.6
%
after
having
been
below
50
%
for
three
consecutive
months
.
<END>
<START>
A
reading
below
50
%
indicates
that
the
manufacturing
industry
is
slowing
while
a
reading
above
50
%
suggests
that
the
industry
is
expanding
.
<END>
<START>
Bond
prices
fell
after
the
Chicago
report
was
released
.
<END>
<START>
By
the
end
of
the
day
,
bond
prices
were
mixed
.
<END>
<START>
The
benchmark
30-year
bond
was
nearly
1/4
point
higher
,
or
up
about
$
2.50
for
each
$
1,000
face
amount
.
<END>
<START>
New
two-year
notes
ended
unchanged
while
three-year
and
four-year
notes
were
slightly
lower
.
<END>
<START>
Municipal
bonds
ended
unchanged
to
as
much
as
1/2
point
higher
while
mortgage-backed
securities
were
up
about
1/8
point
.
<END>
<START>
Corporate
bonds
were
unchanged
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
corporate
market
,
an
expected
debt
offering
today
by
International
Business
Machines
Corp.
generated
considerable
attention
.
<END>
<START>
The
giant
computer
maker
is
slated
to
offer
$
500
million
of
30-year
non-callable
debentures
through
underwriters
led
by
Salomon
Brothers
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
Traders
expect
the
bonds
to
yield
about
0.60
to
0.65
percentage
point
above
the
Treasury
's
benchmark
30-year
bond
,
which
ended
Tuesday
with
a
yield
of
about
7.90
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
last
time
IBM
tapped
the
corporate
debt
market
was
in
April
1988
,
when
it
offered
$
500
million
of
debt
securities
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
's
visits
to
the
debt
market
are
closely
watched
by
treasurers
at
other
corporations
and
by
credit
market
analysts
.
<END>
<START>
Some
analysts
believe
the
company
has
the
ability
to
pinpoint
the
trough
in
interest-rate
cycles
.
<END>
<START>
In
October
1979
,
just
days
before
the
Federal
Reserve
raised
interest
rates
,
IBM
offered
$
1
billion
in
debt
securities
.
<END>
<START>
The
boost
in
rates
sent
IBM
's
bonds
tumbling
,
leaving
underwriters
with
millions
of
dollars
of
losses
and
triggering
a
sell-off
in
the
overall
market
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
``
ca
n't
be
bullish
if
they
're
doing
a
sizable
30-year
bullet
,
''
said
one
analyst
.
<END>
<START>
Others
said
IBM
might
increase
the
size
of
the
offering
to
as
much
as
$
1
billion
if
investor
demand
is
strong
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
has
$
1
billion
in
debt
filed
with
the
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
think
the
$
500
million
is
a
little
bit
of
a
fire
drill
,
''
said
Jim
Ednee
,
head
of
the
industrial
bond
department
at
Drexel
Burnham
Lambert
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
think
as
the
pricing
time
arrives
,
the
bonds
will
come
a
little
richer
and
in
a
larger
amount
.
''
<END>
<START>
Treasury
Securities
<END>
<START>
Treasury
prices
ended
mixed
in
light
trading
.
<END>
<START>
The
benchmark
30-year
bond
was
quoted
late
at
102
12/32
to
yield
7.90
%
compared
with
102
7/32
to
yield
7.92
%
Monday
.
<END>
<START>
The
latest
10-year
notes
were
unchanged
at
100
16/32
to
yield
7.904
%
.
<END>
<START>
Short-term
rates
also
were
mixed
.
<END>
<START>
The

on

Treasury
bills
rose

from
the
average
rate
at
Monday
's
auction
to
7.79
%
for
a
bond-equivalent
yield
of
8.04
%
.
<END>
<START>
The

rate
on

Treasury
bills
fell
slightly
to
7.60
%
for
a
bond-equivalent

of
7.99
%
.

<START>
Corporate
Issues
<END>
<START>

were

,

by
Beatrice
Co
.
<END>
<START>
The

LIBOR
rate
yesterday
was
8
7/16
%
.
<END>
<START>
Since
the
recent

of
the

market
,
at
least
two
other
junk
issuers
have
said
they
plan
to

back

,
and

have
been

.
<END>
<START>
William
Carmichael
,

chief

,
said

in
September
prompted
the
company
to
plan
more
debt
than

.
<END>
<START>
The
$
150
million
in

were
targeted
to
be

at
a

to
float
four

above

LIBOR
.
<END>
<START>
By
October
,

,

had

and
the
reset
notes
were
targeted
to
be

at
a

of
between
13
1/4
%
and
13
1/2
%
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.

also
demanded

.

Municipal
Issues
<END>
<START>

little
changed

.

<START>
``
We

and

.
<END>
<START>

-LCB-
market
-RCB-
,

.

-LCB-
sell
-RCB-

.
<END>
<START>
There
's
light

,
''
he
said
,

that

to
``
inch
up
''
in

.
<END>
<START>
The
market
's
tone
improved
after
Monday
's
pricing
of
$
813
million
New
York
City
general
obligation
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
The
issue
's
smooth
absorption
eased
fears
that
supply
would
overwhelm
demand
in
coming
sessions
,
traders
said
.
<END>
<START>
Demand
for

was
strong
enough
to

to

some

in

of

offering
late
Monday
.
<END>
<START>
The
debt
was

priced
to
yield
from
6
%
in
1991
to
7.15
%
in
2008-2009
.

<START>
Foreign
Bonds
<END>
<START>
Most
foreign
government
bonds
markets
were
quiet
.
<END>
<START>
West
German
bonds
firmed
a
bit
after
Monday
's
fall
,
but
traders
said
the
market
remains
bearish
due
to
speculation
that
interest
rates
could
rise
again
.
<END>
<START>
His
comments
were
interpreted
as
a
sign
that
higher
interest
rates
are
possible
.
<END>
<START>
On
Oct.
5
,

raised

and

by
one

to

,

,

.

.

,

.

,

.

<START>

,

.

.

<START>
Arthur
H.
Rosenfeld
,
previously
president
of
the
Prentice
Hall
Tax
and
Professional
Services
division
,
was
named
president
of
the
newly
formed
Macmillan
Professional
and
Business
Reference
division
.
<END>
<START>
Simon
&
Schuster
retains
the
Corporation
Law
looseleaf
service
,
which
will
become
part
of
its
Prentice
Hall
Law
&
Business
unit
.
<END>
<START>
A
governing
body
of
both
the
Financial
Accounting
Standards
Board
and
the
Governmental
Accounting
Standards
Board
voted
to
give
the
FASB
jurisdiction
over
accounting
standards
for
certain
government-owned
entities
.
<END>
<START>
The
Financial
Accounting
Foundation
voted
12-2
that
FASB
accounting
rules
supercede
GASB
rules
in
regard
to
utilities
,
hospitals
,
and
colleges
and
universities
owned
by
the
government
.
<END>
<START>
GASB
rules
still
apply
for
other
government
units
.
<END>
<START>
After
the
GASB
was
founded
in
1984
,
11
years
after
the
FASB
,
the
government-owned
entities
were
supposed
to
follow
FASB
rules
unless
the
GASB
superceded
them
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
may
lead
to
separate
financial
reports
based
on
different
rules
for
the
government
entities
under
FASB
rules
and
those
still
under
GASB
rules
.
<END>
<START>
Avery
Inc.
said
it
completed
the
sale
of
Uniroyal
Chemical
Holding
Co.
to
a
group
led
by
management
of
Uniroyal
Chemical
Co.
,
the
unit
's
main
business
.
<END>
<START>
It
valued
the
transaction
at
$
800
million
.
<END>
<START>
Avery
,
which
continues
to
operate
a
coal
company
it
expects
to
sell
at
a
loss
,
said
in
proxy
materials
it
intends
to
seek
control
of
one
or
more
companies
.
<END>
<START>
After
fees
and
repayment
of
debt
,
Avery
is
left
with
about
$
24
million
in
cash
and
securities
from
the
Uniroyal
sale
.
<END>
<START>
Avery
paid
$
750
million
,
including
various
legal
and
financing
fees
,
to
acquire
Uniroyal
Chemical
,
Middlebury
,
Conn.
,
in
1986
--
a
move
that
burdened
Avery
with
debt
.
<END>
<START>
In
over-the-counter
trading
,
Avery
shares
were
quoted
yesterday
at
a
bid
price
of
93.75
cents
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
Avery
,
for
the
year
ended
Sept.
30
,
1988
,
Uniroyal
Chemical
had
sales
of
$
734.2
million
and
a
net
loss
of
$
47.1
million
.
<END>
<START>
An
Avery
spokesman
said
that
the
loss
was
magnified
by
accounting
adjustments
and
that
the
company
's
loss
was
smaller
on
a
cash
basis
.
<END>
<START>
Uniroyal
has
2,600
employees
and
facilities
in
the
U.S.
,
Canada
,
Brazil
,
Italy
and
Taiwan
.
<END>
<START>
On
a
fully
diluted
basis
,
the
two
raised
their
stake
to
68
%
from
51
%
.
<END>
<START>
In
December
1988
,
Messrs.
Peltz
and
May
sold
their
stock
in
Triangle
Industries
Inc.
,
a
packaging
company
they
controlled
,
to
Pechiney
Corp.
of
France
.
<END>
<START>
The
executives
had
profited

by
building
American
National
Can
Co.
,

's
chief
asset
.
<END>
<START>

,

of

,

in

.

,

,

.

<START>
Clarcor

.

,

,

.

.

Rally
's

.

.

.

''
by

.

<START>
Fujitsu
Ltd.

.

<START>

,

into

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

last

to

,

11

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

``

,
''

.
<END>
<START>

<START>

.
<END>
<START>
Wary
investors
have
been
running
for
the
stock
market
's
equivalent
of
bomb
shelters
,
buying
shares
of
gold-mining
and
utility
companies
.
<END>
<START>
Those
two
groups
have
recently
been
leading
the
list
of
stocks
setting
new
highs
.
<END>
<START>
On
Friday
,
when
only
a
dozen
common
stocks
hit
52-week
highs
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
,
five
were
gold-mining
issues
,
and
another
four
were
utilities
.
<END>
<START>
On
Monday
,
when
a
mere
seven
common
stocks
managed
new
highs
,
six
were
utilities
or
golds
.
<END>
<START>
At
first
glance
,
gold
and
utilities
seem
strange
bedfellows
.
<END>
<START>
After
all
,
gold
prices
usually
soar
when
inflation
is
high
.
<END>
<START>
Utility
stocks
,
on
the
other
hand
,
thrive
on
disinflation
,
because
the
fat
dividends
utilities
pay
look
more
attractive
when
prices
are
falling
-LRB-
or
rising
slowly
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
two
groups
have
something
very
important
in
common
:
They
are
both
havens
for
scared
money
,
stocks
for
people
who
hate
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
as
if
investors
,
the
past
few
days
,
are
betting
that
something
is
going
to
go
wrong
--
even
if
they
do
n't
know
what
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
stock
market
and
the
economy
catch
their
breath
and
show
that
they
're
on
firmer
footing
,
these
stocks
might
well
fall
back
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
that
happened
to
some
extent
yesterday
,
as
industrial
stocks
rebounded
,
partly
on
news
of
takeovers
in
the
paper
industry
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
a
lot
of
investors
clearly
have
revived
their
interest
in
gold
and
utility
shares
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
primary

thing
is
that

are

,
''
says
Martin
Sass
,
a
New
York
money
manager
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
aftershocks
of
Oct.
13
-LRB-
when
the
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
dropped
190
points
-RRB-
are
still
reverberating
.
''
<END>
<START>
Certainly
,
the
Oct.
13
sell-off
did
n't
settle
any
stomachs
.
<END>
<START>
Beyond
that
,
money
managers
and
analysts
see
other
problems
.
<END>
<START>
Inventories
are
creeping
up
;
car
inventories
are
already
high
,
and
big
auto
makers
are
idling
plants
.
<END>
<START>
Takeover
fever
has
cooled
,
removing
a
major
horse
from
the
market
's
cart
.
<END>
<START>
Britain
's
unsettled
political
scene
also
worries
some
investors
.
<END>
<START>
``
One
of
the
three
major
markets
in
the
world
is
getting
chewed
up
pretty
bad
.
''
<END>
<START>
With
this
sort
of
sentiment
common
,
it
's
natural
for
investors
to
seek
out
``
defensive
''
investments
.
<END>
<START>
Utilities
are
a
classic

:
Even
in

,
people
continue
to
use
electric
power
,
water
and
gas
at
a
fairly
steady
rate
.
<END>
<START>
Such
defensive
issues
as
food
,
tobacco
,
and
drug
stocks
have
been
in
favor
for
some
time
.
<END>
<START>
But
many
of
these
stocks
have
now

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Wachtel
points
to

Co.
and
PepsiCo
Inc.
as

:
They
're
selling
for
18

22

1990

.
<END>
<START>
Gold
stocks
are
n't
cheap
on
this
basis
,
either
,
with
many
selling
for
20
times
earnings
or
more
.
<END>
<START>
Even
utility
stocks
are
n't
all
that
inexpensive
,
at
an
average
of
14
times
earnings
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
two
groups
represent
a
further
step
in

.
<END>
<START>
If
gold
stocks
and
utilities
continue
to
lead
,
it
may

that
the
market
is
in
for
rough

.
<END>
<START>
That
's
just
what
Joseph
Granville
expects
.
<END>
<START>
``
We

lower
,
''

,

.
<END>
<START>
``

.
<END>
<START>

.

<END>
<START>

.

But

,

.

<START>

.

<START>

.

.

.

-LCB-

-RCB-
based

.

<END>

,

,

.

<START>

.

<START>

.

<START>

.

Mark

.

<START>

<START>
In

,

by
Joseph
Scotto
of

National
Cancer
Institute
and
several

reporting

in

.
<END>
<START>
Our

for

,

,

,

.

<START>

,

Scotto

<START>

,

,
that

by
Norwegians
,

and

Max

that
show

or

UV-B
at

.
<END>
<START>

,

calls

the

theory
and

.

<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>

,

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

''

,

.

.

<START>

.

White

,

.

.

<START>

,

.

<START>
Bankers
Trust
New
York
Corp.
won
permission
from
the
Federal
Reserve
Board
to
move
the
company
's
private
placement
department
to
its
fledgling
securities
subsidiary
.
<END>
<START>
The
seemingly
mundane
action
,
which
was
opposed
by
the
Securities
Industry
Association
,
a
trade
group
,
has
important
implications
for
banks
'
recent
entry
into
the
underwriting
of
corporate
securities
.
<END>
<START>
The
Fed
's
action
increases
the
volume
of
publicly
registered
securities
that
banks
'
securities
affiliates
will
be
able
to
underwrite
.
<END>
<START>
Several
other
banks
have
similar
applications
pending
.
<END>
<START>
Securities
firms
have
challenged
those
Fed
approvals
,
saying
they
violate
federal
laws
separating
the
banking
and
securities
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
For
some
banks
that
10
%
ceiling
created
problems
.
<END>
<START>
But
,
by
allowing
BT
Securities
Inc.
to
handle
private
placements
,
the
Fed
boosted
the
volume
of
new
types
of
underwriting
that
the
unit
can
do
.
<END>
<START>
Private
placements
involve
debt
and
equity
securities
,
typically
in
denominations
of
$
1
million
,
that
are
sold
to
institutional
investors
and
are
n't
registered
with
the
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
.
<END>
<START>
Last
year
,
Bankers
Trust
said
it
placed
$
10
billion
of
corporate
debt
and
equities
privately
.
<END>
<START>
Companies
listed
below
reported
quarterly
profit
substantially
different
from
the
average
of
analysts
'
estimates
.
<END>
<START>
The
companies
are
followed
by
at
least
three
analysts
,
and
had

in

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
The

30-day

.

<START>
As
many
as
50
of
his
employees
at
Specialized
Bicycle
Components
Inc.
ride
with
him
.
<END>
<START>
When
they
return
to
their
desks
at
1
p.m.
,
they
have
pedaled
20
miles
.
<END>
<START>
Such
fervor
for
cycling
helped
Mr.
Sinyard
build
a
creative
company
at
the
forefront
of
its
industry
.
<END>
<START>
Founded
by
bike
enthusiasts
rather
than
businessmen
,
Specialized
spotted
the
appeal
of
fat-tired
bikes
that
go
almost
anywhere
and
began
mass-producing
them
in
1981
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
past
five
years
,
the
company
's
sales
have
grown
to
$
80
million
from
$
26
million
.
<END>
<START>
Today
,
so-called
mountain
bikes
account
for
two-thirds
of
the
$
2
billion
spent
annually
on
all
bicycles
in
the
U.S.
.
<END>
<START>
With
65
%
of
its
sales
coming
from
mountain
bikes
,
Specialized
is
widely
considered
to
be
a
market
leader
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Accessories
,
largely
for
mountain-bike
users
,
account
for
much
of
the
rest
of
sales
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
But
today
,
the
company
needs
its
entrepreneurial
spirit
more
than
ever
.
<END>
<START>
One
large
competitor
after
another
is
leaping
into
the
booming
market
Specialized
helped
create
,
turning
out
mountain
bikes
with
such
well-known
names
as
Schwinn
,
Peugeot
,
Raleigh
and
Nishiki
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
,
Mr.
Sinyard
's
company
must
innovate
more
than
ever
to
stay
ahead
of
them
,
by
developing
new
products
specifically
for
mountain
biking
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
same
time
,
though
,
it
must
become
more
structured
to
better
manage
its
growth
.
<END>
<START>
Accomplishing
both
will
be
a
balancing
act
as
challenging
as
riding
a
unicycle
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
a
problem
common
to
small
companies
that
have
grown
fast
--
especially
when
their
success
attracts
big-time
competitors
.
<END>
<START>
``

,
''

,

.

.
<END>
<START>

.

.

.
''
<END>

.

of

.

.

,

,

in

<START>

,

.

<START>
And
we
'll
raise
it
through
existing
shareholders
''
as
well
as
through
junk
bonds
,
said
Anthony
Simonds-Gooding
,
the
private
consortium
's
chief
executive
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
he
believes
the
bank
loan
,
to
be
arranged
by
February
,
will
supply
about
half
of
the
financing
.
<END>
<START>
British
Satellite
,
which
already
has
raised
#
423.5
million
from
10
backers
,
initially
expected
to
seek
an
additional
#
400
million
.
<END>
<START>
Bond
Corp.
,
British
Satellite
's
biggest

,
would
like
to
withdraw
from
the
satellite-TV
consortium
,
and

have
speculated
Hollywood

might
buy
the
Bond

.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Simonds-Gooding
said
he
is
n't

to
any

about

.
<END>
<START>
Besides
Bond
Corp.
,

Satellite
's

include
Pearson

,

PLC
and

.
<END>
<START>

consortium
faced

in

when

forced

to

September
launch
until

.
<END>
<START>
Continued

about

of

consortium
's

could
make

hard
to
find
a
#
450

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Simonds-Gooding
conceded
that
British
Satellite
's
potential
U.K.
lenders
``
are
saying
,
`
When
you
're
on
the
air
,
you
'll
-LCB-
actually
-RCB-
get
the
money
.
'
''
<END>
<START>
The
bankers
also
insist
that
the
loans
depend
on
the
consortium

more

from

.

<START>
British

's

,

.

.

<START>
Shares

in

in

year
's

Monday
,

.

<START>

Monday
,
while

in

,

,

.

<START>

,

.

.
<END>
<START>

,

.

<START>

.
<END>
<START>

,

.

.

.

<START>
Courtaulds
PLC
announced

to

in

to
boost

.
<END>
<START>
The

of

company
,
to
be

Textiles
,
could

as

's

.
<END>
<START>
Investors
welcomed
the

.
<END>
<START>
Courtaulds
'

rose
15
pence
to
362
pence
,

the
entire
company
at
about
#
1.44
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Courtaulds
'
spinoff
reflects
pressure
on
British
industry
to
boost
share
prices
beyond
the
reach
of
corporate
raiders
.
<END>
<START>
The
divested
Courtaulds

operations
had

profit
of
#
50
million
on
#
980
million
in

in

year
ended
March
31
.
<END>
<START>
In

,

said
the

are

because
they
will
allow
both
the
chemicals
and
textile

to

more

on

.
<END>
<START>
Courtaulds
has
been
under

to

since
takeover

--
including
Australian
financier
Kerry
Packer
--

holding

last

.
<END>
<START>
Though
Mr.
Packer
has
since
sold
his

,

is
moving
to
keep
its

happy
.
<END>
<START>
Even
without

threat
,

is
giving

``
choice
and
value
,
''

Julia

,

.
<END>
<START>
In

,

said
:
``
Both
parts
can
only
realize
their
full
potential
and
be

if

.
<END>
<START>
The
sharper
definition
and

autonomy
which
each
will
thereby

will

,

and

.
''
<END>
<START>

.

<START>
Japan
's

fell
12.2
%
in
September
from
a
year

and
were
down
1.1
%
from
the
previous
month
,

and

Federation
reported
.
<END>
<START>
September
was
the
10th
consecutive
month
in
which
steel
exports
failed
to
reach
the
year-earlier
level
.
<END>
<START>
A
federation
official
attributed
the
decline
to
brisk
demand
from
domestic
industries
backed
by
continuing
economic
expansion
in

.
<END>
<START>
Japanese

companies
are
apparently
focusing
on
domestic
sales
,
but

said

does
n't

that

.
<END>
<START>
``
They

just
too

to
meet

demand
and
have
little
room
for
overseas
shipments
,
''
the
official
said
.
<END>
<START>
After
a
bad
start
,
Treasury
bonds
were
buoyed
by
a
late
burst
of
buying
to
end
modestly
higher
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
market
was
pretty
dull
''
for
most
of
the
day
,
said
Robert
H.
Chandross
,
vice
president
at
Lloyds
Bank
PLC
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
some
investors
were
reluctant
to
plunge
into
the
market
ahead
of
several
key
economic
indicators
due
this
week
,
especially
Friday
's
potentially
market-moving
employment
report
.
<END>
<START>
During
the
first
hour
of
trading
yesterday
,
prices
fell
as
much
as
1/4
point
,
or
down
about
$
2.50
for
each
$
1,000
face
amount
.
<END>
<START>
But
market
activity
was
energized
as
investors
started
to
view
the
lower
price
levels
as
attractive
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
Treasury
's
$
17.6
billion
auction
of
short-term
bills
,
which
generated
strong
buying
interest
,
helped
to
lift
the
bond
market
out
of
the
doldrums
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
the
change
in
sentiment
also
reflected
perceptions
that
the
slate
of
economic
statistic
due
this
week
will
be
``
conducive
to
a
bond
market
rally
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
employment
report
,
which
will
provide
the
first
official
measure
of
the
economy
's
strength
in
October
,
is
expected
to
show
smaller
gains
in
the
generation
of
new
jobs
.
<END>
<START>
Other
key
economic
indicators
due
this
week
include
today
's
release
of
the
September
leading
indicators
index
and
new-home
sales
.
<END>
<START>
Tomorrow
,
the
October
purchasing
managers
report
is
due
and
on
Thursday
comes
October

sales
.

<START>

,

,

<END>
<START>
Short-term
interest
rates
rose
at
the
government
's
regular
weekly
Treasury-bill
auction
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
discount
rate
on
three-month
bills
was
7.78
%
and
the
rate
on
six-month
bills
was
7.62
%
.
<END>
<START>
Those
rates
are
up
from
7.52
%
and
7.50
%
,
respectively
,
at
last
week
's
auction
.
<END>
<START>
Due
to
the
Treasury
's
need
to
raise
funds
quickly
before
the
current
authority
to
issue
debt
expires
at
midnight
tonight
,
yesterday
's
auction
was
structured
differently
from
previous
sales
.
<END>
<START>
The
Treasury
bills
sold
yesterday
settle
today
,
rather
than
the
standard
settlement
day
of
Thursday
.
<END>
<START>
And
because
of
the
early
settlement
,
the
three-month
bills
actually
have
a
93-day
maturity
,
and
the
six-month
bills
have
an
184-day
maturity
.
<END>
<START>
Because
of
the
early
settlement
,
the
Federal
Reserve
was
unable
to
purchase
bills
for
its
system
account
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
analysts
expect
the
Fed
to
buy
Treasury
bills
that
were
auctioned
yesterday
in
the
secondary
market
.
<END>
<START>
The
Treasury
also
held
a
hastily
scheduled
$
2
billion
sale
of
51-cash
management
bills
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
Here
are
details
of
yesterday
's
three-month
and
six-month
bill
auction
:
<END>
<START>
Rates
are
determined
by
the
difference
between
the
purchase
price
and
face
value
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
,
higher
bidding
narrows
the
investor
's
return
while
lower
bidding
widens
it
.
<END>
<START>
The
percentage
rates
are
calculated
on
a
360-day
year
,
while
the
coupon
equivalent
yield
is
based
on
a
365-day
year
.
<END>
<START>
Both
issues
are
dated
Oct.
31
.
<END>
<START>
The
13-week
bills
mature
Feb.
1
,
and
the
26-week
bills
mature
May
3
,
1990
.
<END>
<START>
Here
are
details
of
yesterday
's
51-day
cash
management
bill
auction
:
<END>
<START>
Interest
rate
8.07
%
<END>
<START>
The
bills
are
dated
Oct.
31
and
mature
Dec.
21
,
1989
.

<START>
So-called
cross-border
acquisitions
totaled
$
23.1
billion
in
the
second
quarter
,
down
from
$
33.6
billion
a
year
earlier
,
according
to
the
accounting
firm
KPMG
Peat
Marwick
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
cross-border
transaction
,
the
buyer
is
in
a
different
region
of
the
globe
from
the
target
.
<END>
<START>
Such
transactions
numbered
670
in
the
second
quarter
,
up
from
527
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
the
total
value
declined
for
deals
of
$
100
million
and
up
.
<END>
<START>
The
downturn
in
total
value
may
be
only
temporary
,
suggested
Herb
Adler
,
a
KPMG
Peat
Marwick
partner
.
<END>
<START>
Large

deals
numbered
51
and
totaled
$
17.1
billion
in
the
second
quarter
,
the
firm
added
.
<END>
<START>
That
compared
with
49
such
transactions
totaling
$
28.7
billion
as
year
earlier
.

.

.

.

<START>

,

.

,
''

.

,

.

<START>
``
We
think

has
technology
important

's
health
,
''
he

,
adding
:
``
We
think
it
is
important
for

to
have

.
''

<START>
He
and
Mr.
Bologna
emphasized

knowledge
through

of

,

''

.

,

.

.

,

.

,

.

<START>

including
launch
services
and
propulsion
hardware
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
were
just
surprised
,
''
says
Tad
Inada
,
NASDA
's
director
for
international
affairs
.
<END>
<START>
``
Shocked
.
''
<END>
<START>
That
Moscow
,
with
its
dilapidated
economic
machine
,
would
try
to
sell
high
technology
to
Japan
,
one
of
the
world
's
high-tech
leaders
,
sounds
like
a
coals-to-Newcastle
notion
.
<END>
<START>
But
``
the
Soviet
Union
has
areas
where
it
is
n't
behind
Japan
,
''
says
Mikhail
Shapovalov
of
the
Soviet
Ministry
of
Foreign
Economic
Relations
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
have
obtained
through
the
development
of
Cosmos
-LCB-
the
Soviet
space
program
-RCB-
technologies
you
do
n't
see
anywhere
else
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
sales
pitch
might
n't
be
as
farfetched
as
it
seems
.
<END>
<START>
And
,
despite
its
image
as
a
technology
superpower
,
Japan
has
a
lot
of
weaknesses
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
a
world
leader
in
semiconductors
,
but
behind
the
U.S.
in
making
the
computers
that
use
those
chips
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
a
world
leader
in
auto
manufacturing
,
but
its
aviation
industry
is
struggling
,
and
its
space
program
is
years
behind
the
U.S.
,
the
Europeans
and
the
Soviets
.
<END>
<START>
One
question
being
debated
in
the
Soviet
Union
is
how
to
use
the
defense
sector
's
research-and-production
expertise
in
the
rest
of
the
economy
.
<END>
<START>
Many
plants
that
used
to
make
military
equipment
are
now
being
ordered
to
produce
televisions
,
videocassette
recorders
,
small
tractors
and
food-processing
machinery
.
<END>
<START>
The
Soviets
also
hope
to
make
better
use
of
their
considerable
expertise
in
theoretical
science
,
which
has
helped
them
win
twice
as
many
Nobel
science
prizes
as
the
Japanese
.
<END>
<START>
Where
they
lag
behind
the
Japanese
is
in
turning
the
scientific
inventiveness
into
improved
production
.
<END>
<START>
By
contrast
,
the
Japanese
have
proved
adept
at
making
use
of
Soviet
inventions
.
<END>
<START>
Kobe
Steel
Ltd.
adopted
Soviet
casting
technology
in
1966
and
used
it
for
14
years
until
it
developed
its
own
system
.
<END>
<START>
Kawasaki
Steel
Corp.
bought
a
Soviet
steel-casting
patent
two
years
ago
and
has
jointly
developed
the
system
with
the
Soviets
.
<END>
<START>
In
1991
,
the
Soviets
will
take
a
Japanese
journalist
into
space
,
the
first
Japanese
to
go
into
orbit
.
<END>
<START>
Soviet
efforts
to
sell
their
technology
abroad
do
n't
appear
to
worry
the
U.S.
,
Japan
's
principal
ally
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
have
never
opposed
the
development
of
economic
relations
between
our
allies
and
the
Soviet
Union
,
''
says
a
State
Department
official
.
<END>
<START>
``
Frankly
,
I
would
n't
expect
the
Japanese
to
get
hooked
on
anybody
's
technology
,
least
of
all
the
Soviets
.
''
<END>
<START>
Under
Mikhail
Gorbachev
's
perestroika
,
the
Soviets
have
sought
economic
ties
all
over
the
world
,
including
new
export
markets
.
<END>
<START>
They
believe
technology
is
one
of
their
best
bets
,
and
some
Soviet
officials
say
Moscow
will
even
consider
declassifying
military
know-how
if
the
price
is
right
.
<END>
<START>
The
Soviets
held
export
exhibitions
that
included
high-tech
items
in
New
York
and
West
Germany
.
<END>
<START>
Last
week
,
a
Soviet
delegation
came
to
Japan
to
push
more
space
technologies
.
<END>
<START>
Japan
is
a
major
target
for
the
Soviets
.
<END>
<START>
In
August
,
representatives
of
Keidanren
,
Japan
's
largest
business
organization
,
visited
Moscow
to
explore
exports
and
investments
that
would
help
the
Soviet
economy
.
<END>
<START>
Out
of
the
blue
,
the
Soviet
Chamber
of
Commerce
handed
over
details
on
59
technologies
that
the
Japanese
might
want
to
buy
.
<END>
<START>
These
mainly
involved
such
areas
as
materials
--
advanced
soldering
machines
,
for
example
--
and
medical
developments
derived
from
experimentation
in
space
,
such
as
artificial
blood
vessels
.
<END>
<START>
A
main
motive
is
hard
cash
.
<END>
<START>
But
,
while
the
Soviets
ca
n't
expect
direct
technology
flow
from
Japan
,
they
also
hope
to
benefit
from
Japanese
manufacturing
expertise
.
<END>
<START>
The
Soviets
are
``
contemplating
a
flexible
system
under
which
it
would
be
possible
to
develop
-LCB-
technology
-RCB-
jointly
and
even
to
market

jointly
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Even
if
the
Japanese
find
Soviet
technology
desirable
,
such
discussions
would
be
fraught
with
political

.
<END>
<START>
Another

Japan
's

to
persuade
the
Soviet
Union
to
relinquish
its
post-World

of
four

.
<END>
<START>
So

,

have

about

and

.
<END>
<START>
And

is

.
<END>
<START>
``
My

there
is

at

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
Peter
Gumbel
in
Moscow
contributed
to

.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
During
its
centennial
year
,
The
Wall
Street
Journal
will
report
events
of
the
past
century
that
stand
as
milestones
of
American
business
history
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
MAY
1
,
1975
,
SIGNALED
A
DISTRESSFUL
May
Day
for
securities
houses
,
which
were
forced
to
end
183
years
of
charging
fixed
commissions
.
<END>
<START>
It
scared
brokers
,
but
most
survived
.
<END>
<START>
It
took
effect
after
seven
years
of
bitter
debate
between
the
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
and
traders
and
exchanges
.
<END>
<START>
The
timing
for
change
was
right
.
<END>
<START>
Institutions
had
become
active
market
players
in
the
early
1970s
and
sought
exchange
seats
to
handle
their
own
trades
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
industry
was
rife
with
brokers
trying
to
secure
big
client
orders
by
using
kickbacks
,
gifts
,
women
and
junkets
.
<END>
<START>
Ray
Garrett
Jr.
,
SEC
chairman
,
said
the
``
breadth
and
depth
of
the
discounting
is
more
than
I
expected
.
''
<END>
<START>
Even
a
federal
measure
in
June
allowing
houses
to
add
research
fees
to
their
commissions
did
n't
stop
it
.
<END>
<START>
Longer
term
,
the
impact
is
unclear
.
<END>
<START>
The
change
prompted
the
rise
of
discount
brokers
and
a
reduction
in
securities
research
firms
.
<END>
<START>
But
there
are
currently
more
exchange
members
than
in
1975
,
with
the
bigger
houses
gaining
a
larger
share
of
total
commissions
.
<END>
<START>
Commissions
,
however
,
account
for
a
smaller
share
of
investment-house
business
as
takeover
advisory
fees
have
soared
.
<END>
<START>
Foreign
stock
markets
,
with
which
the
U.S.
is
entwined
,
also
have
ended
fixed
commissions
in
recent
years
.
<END>
<START>
It
came
in
London
's
``
Big
Bang
''
1986
deregulation
;
and
Toronto
's
``
Little
Bang
''
the
same
year
.
<END>
<START>
Paris
is
currently
phasing
out
fixed
commissions
under
its
``
Le
Petit
Bang
''
plan
.
<END>
<START>
President
Bush
said
that
three
members
of
his
cabinet
will
lead
a
presidential
mission
to
Poland
to
gauge
how
the
U.S.
can
help
the
new
non-Communist
government
's
economic
changes
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bush
announced
several
weeks
ago
that
he
intended
to
send
such
a
mission
,
composed
of
top
government

and
business
and
labor

.
<END>
<START>
The
mission
will
visit
Poland
from
Nov.
29
to
Dec.
2
,
the
White

said
.
<END>
<START>
Michael
Boskin
,
chairman
of
the
Council
of
Economic
Advisers
,
also
will
be
a
member
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bush
said
the
group
is
to
``
focus
on
economic
sectors
where
U.S.
expertise
and
cooperation
can
indeed
make
a
difference
.
''
<END>
<START>
Warner
and
Mr.
Azoff
declined
comment
,
as
did
MCA
,
where
Mr.
Azoff
had

.

.

.

<START>

,

,

.

,

<START>

<START>

Series
-RCB-
<END>
<START>
Tom
Panelli

300

.

,

,

<START>
Mr.
Panelli
has

.
<END>
<START>
The
Roper
Organization
,
which
conducted
the
survey
,
said
almost
half
of
the
exercise

owners
found
it
duller
than
they

.
<END>
<START>
It
is

that

n't

.
<END>
<START>
The

has

,

.
<END>
<START>
Fewer

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>

,

.

.

.

<END>
<START>

,

.

<START>

.

<START>
Electronic

.

<START>
Premark

,

,

,

.

<START>

,

,
''

,

.

<START>
Nancy
Igdaloff
,

America
in

,
may

.
<END>
<START>
She
's

<END>
<START>
The
poll
points
up
some
inconsistencies
between
what
people

and

.
<END>
<START>
A
surprising
78
%
of

,

%
in

.
<END>
<START>
This
conjures
up

full

,

,
and
suggests
couch

.
<END>
<START>
Of

,

.
<END>
<START>
The

may

because

is

bit

.
<END>
<START>
They
're
bound
to

.
<END>
<START>
``
It

.
<END>
<START>
People
are

to

have
n't

.
''
<END>
<START>
One

's

,
set

1980
,
was
to

than
60
%

age
getting

.
<END>
<START>
That

has

to
30
%
by

year
2000
.
<END>
<START>
But

may

.
<END>
<START>
Of
14

,

Journal
survey
found
that
12
--
including

,
skiing
and
swimming
--
are

.
<END>
<START>
Time
pressures
and
the
ebb
of
the
fitness
fad

BROKERAGE
HIRING
languishes
amid
market
turmoil
.
<END>
<START>
But
survivors
earn
more
.
<END>
<START>
Shearson
Lehman
Hutton
Inc.
counts
under
39,000
workers
,
down
100
from
the
start
of
the
year
and
off
8,500
from
after
its
merger
and
the
market
collapse
two
years
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Another
major
firm
has
cut
6,000
workers
,
13
%
of
its
staff
,
since
Black
Monday
.
<END>
<START>
The
Bureau
of
Labor
Statistics
says
securities
firms
in
New
York
City
alone
have
slashed
17,000
jobs
from
the
December
1987
peak
of
163,000
.
<END>
<START>
Average
annual

of
those
who
have
hung
on
,
though
,
surged
to
$
78,625
last
year
from
$
69,553
in
1987
.
<END>
<START>
Any

is

to

sales
.
<END>
<START>
Illinois
Company
Investments
had
been
trimming
its
ranks
until
last
summer
.
<END>
<START>
But
then
it
was

Household
International
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
Now
it
offers
richer

to

a
broker
a

.
<END>
<START>
Interstate/Johnson
Lane
Inc.
this
year
adds
70

--
60

in
retail
--
to
its
1,300-member

.
<END>
<START>
A.G.
Edwards
&
Sons

and

.
<END>
<START>

We

,
''

.

SKILLED
WORKERS
aplenty
are
available
to

with

.
<END>
<START>
``
I
do
n't

,
''

.
<END>
<START>

``

,

,
''
especially

.
<END>
<START>
But

Oct.
17
temblor
put

much

,
and
heavy

last
week
slowed
the
rest
,

construction

for

.
<END>
<START>
The

of

engineers
,

,

.
<END>
<START>
In
recent
months
,
California
's
Transportation
Department
has
been
recruiting
in
Pennsylvania
,
Arizona
and
Texas
for
engineers
experienced
in
road
and

.
<END>
<START>
He
says
the
department
now
has
75
openings
and
wants
to
hire
625
civil
engineers
over
the
next
15
months
.
