<START>
Democracy
is
making
a
return
with
a
vengeance
to
Latin
America
's
most
populous
and
deeply
indebted
country
.
<END>
<START>
On
Nov.
15
,
when
Brazilians
elect
a
president
for
the
first
time
in
29
years
,
the
country
's
82
million
voters
will
have
22
candidates
to
choose
from
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
feel
sorry
for
whoever
wins
,
''
says
a
Brazilian
diplomat
.
<END>
<START>
Who
that
winner
will
be
is
highly
uncertain
.
<END>
<START>
A
half-dozen
candidates
,
backing
policies
ranging
from
Thatcherism
to
watered-down
Marxism
,
are
given
a
chance
of
winning
.
<END>
<START>
``
Whoever
says
he
knows
which
of
the
six
will
win
is
out
of
his
mind
,
''
says
Antonio
Britto
,
a
centrist
member
of
Parliament
.
<END>
<START>
The
favorite
remains
Fernando
Collor
de
Mello
,
a
40-year-old
former
governor
of
the
state
of
Alagoas
.
<END>
<START>
To
avoid
a
runoff
,
one
candidate
would
have
to
win
50
%
of
the
vote
--
a
feat
that
most
analysts
consider
impossible
with
so
many
candidates
running
.
<END>
<START>
The
uncertainty
is
sending
shivers
through
Brazilian
financial
markets
.
<END>
<START>
The
dollar
,
the
best
indicator
of
the
country
's
mood
,
has
skyrocketed
on
the
parallel
market
,
as
has
gold
.
<END>
<START>
Capital
flight
is
reported
to
be
strong
.
<END>
<START>
The
big
question
is
whether
the
new
president
will
have
the
strength
and
the
political
support
in
Congress
to
take
steps
to
cure
Brazil
's
economic
ills
.
<END>
<START>
President
Jose
Sarney
,
who
took
office
in
1985
when
the
man
picked
by
an
electoral
college
became
critically
ill
,
appears
to
be
simply
trying
to
avoid
hyperinflation
.
<END>
<START>
The
unpopular
Mr.
Sarney
,
whose
task
was
to
bring
about
a
smooth
transition
to
democracy
after
21
years
of
military
rule
,
is
n't
seeking
re-election
.
<END>
<START>
``
Depending
on
the
president
,
we
could
either
be
a
trillion-dollar
economy
by
the
end
of
the
century
or
stay
where
we
are
,
''
says
political
scientist
Amaury
de
Souza
.
<END>
<START>
``
And
where
we
are
is
bad
.
''
<END>
<START>
Despite
valiant
efforts
by
Finance
Minister
Mailson
Ferreira
da
Nobrega
,
inflation
came
to
36
%
in
September
alone
and
is
expected
to
top
1,000
%
for
the
year
.
<END>
<START>
That
might
have
been
considered
hyperinflation
not
long
ago
,
but
Argentina
endured
price
increases
of
almost
200
%
in
July
before
bringing
the
rate
down
sharply
in
August
and
September
.
<END>
<START>
By
some
estimates
,
Brazil
's
internal
debt
,
or
combined
public
deficit
,
could
reach
6.5
%
of
its
$
351
billion
gross
domestic
product
.
<END>
<START>
Much
of
the
money
goes
into
subsidies
or
keeping
inefficient
state-controlled
companies
operating
.
<END>
<START>
Among
the
results
is
a
frequent
breakdown
of
public
services
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
not
uncommon
to
wait
three
minutes
for
a
dial
tone
after
picking
up
the
telephone
,
and
then
to
be
interrupted
by
a
busy
signal
before
finishing
dialing
the
number
.
<END>
<START>
Officials
also
say
a
national
electricity
shortage
might
not
be
far
off
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
also
say
it
's
inevitable
that
Brazil
will
seek
to
renegotiate
its
$
115
billion
foreign
debt
,
on
which
it
suspended
interest
payments
last
month
.
<END>
<START>
About
80
%
of
Brazil
's
voters
are
believed
to
live
near
the
poverty
level
.
<END>
<START>
Of
the
three
candidates
with
a
serious
chance
of
winning
,
Mr.
Collor
comes
closest
to
advocating
the
sort
of
measures
that
economists
say
are
necessary
.
<END>
<START>
But
his
inexperience
raises
doubts
that
he
would
have
the
political
power
to
carry
them
out
.
<END>
<START>
The
67-year-old
Mr.
Brizola
has
been
vague
about
his
intentions
and
often
inflammatory
in
his
rhetoric
,
but
analysts
say
he
probably
would
be
pragmatic
.
<END>
<START>
But
despite
the
differences
in
what
they
say
,
according
to
some
analysts
here
,
economic
constraints
mean
the
next
president
may
not
have
many
choices
about
what
he
does
.

<START>
Hospital
Regulation
Sparks
Kentucky
Feud
<END>
<START>
WHICH
IS
the
best
medicine
for
runaway
health
costs
:
competition
or
regulation
?
<END>
<START>
The
question
is
at
the
root
of
a
brawl
between
Humana
Inc.
,
the
big
for-profit
hospital
and
insurance
company
,
and
its
not-for-profit
brethren
in
its
home
state
of
Kentucky
.
<END>
<START>
The
battle
focuses
on
the
state
's
certificate-of-need
law
,
which
regulates
investment
in
new
medical
technology
.
<END>
<START>
The
law
has
prevented
$
216
million
of
unnecessary
expenditures
since
1986
,
according
to
William
S.
Conn
,
president
of
the
Kentucky
Hospital
Association
.
<END>
<START>
But
according
to
David
Jones
,
Humana
's
chief
executive
,
it
promotes
technology
monopolies
,
stifles
innovation
and
raises
prices
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
complains
that
it
paid
$
10
million
to
non-Humana
hospitals
in
its
latest
fiscal
year
for
services
provided
to
its
insurance
plan
members
.
<END>
<START>
But
Humana
says
its
own
facilities
could
serve
its
insured
for
less
if
they
were
properly
equipped
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Conn
charges
that
Humana
's
own
actions
undermine
its
argument
.
<END>
<START>
When
a
hospital
in
Lexington
installed
a
lithotripter
last
year
,
demand
for
a
similar
kidney-stone
smashing
machine
at
a
Humana
hospital
in
Louisville
fell
34
%
.
<END>
<START>
Humana
contends
that
$
8,000
represents
an
extreme
case
and
that
its
regular
charge
for
lithotripsy
is
$
4,900
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
another
hospital
's
proposal
for
a
new-generation
lithotripter
is
pending
before
the
board
that
administers
the
certificate-of-need
law
.
<END>
<START>
Humana
,
which
wants
to
acquire
one
of
the
new
machines
itself
,
is
on
the
record
as
opposed
to
the
proposal
.
<END>
<START>
Debt-Burdened
Doctors
Seek
Financial
Security
<END>
<START>
And
81
%
preferred
a
group
practice
or
health
maintenance
organization
,
while
just
11
%
favored
solo
practice
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
wo
n't
do
that
very
often
today
at
all
.
<END>
<START>
They
're
looking
for
something
that
's
very
safe
.
''
<END>
<START>
That
's
115
%
more
than
in
1981
.
<END>
<START>
Money
is
n't
the
only
reason
for
the
shift
in
practice
preferences
.
<END>
<START>
It
reflects
values
of
a
generation
that
wants
more
time
for
families
and
personal
interests
,
says
John
H.
Moxley
III
,
who
directs
physician-executive
searches
for
Korn/Ferry
International
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
a
change
in
the
social
fabric
of
medicine
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Related
Roommates
Trim
Hospital
Bills
<END>
<START>
WHEN
Catherine
Bobar
spent
several
weeks
at
the
Medical
Center
of
Vermont
recently
with
a
bone
infection
in
her
toe
,
she
shared
a
room
just
like
most
patients
.
<END>
<START>
But
unlike
most
patients
,
her
roommate
was
her
husband
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
was
certainly
good
to
have
him
handy
,
''
Mrs.
Bobar
says
.
<END>
<START>
The
12-bed
``
cooperative
care
''
unit
is
one
of
about
18
nationwide
where
a
family
member
or
friend
helps
care
for
a
patient
in
the
hospital
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
helps
us
,
and
them
,
while
they
're
here
,
and
it
certainly
makes
them
a
better
health-care
team
when
they
get
home
.
''
<END>
<START>
It
also
saves
money
.
<END>
<START>
Because
patients
require
less
attention
from
nurses
and
other
staff
,
room
charges
are
lower
--
about
$
100
less
per
day
than
a
regular
room
at
the
Vermont
hospital
.
<END>
<START>
Cancer
patients
needing
prolonged
radiation
therapy
,
diabetics
learning
to
manage
their
blood
sugar
levels
,
and
cardiac
bypass
patients
are
among
those
who
spend
time
on
cooperative-care
units
.
<END>
<START>
The
approach
has
generated
so
much
interest
that
NYU
is
host
to
the
first
conference
on
cooperative
care
Nov.
30
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
really
part
of
the
hospital
of
the
21st
century
,
''
Dr.
Grieco
says
.
<END>
<START>
Odds
and
Ends
<END>
<START>
So
says
the
Commonwealth
Fund
,
a
New
York
philanthropist
that
's
sponsoring
a
$
1
million
project
to
develop
joint
masters
in
business
and
nursing
programs
at
10
universities
...
.

.

<START>
A
group
of
Michigan
investors
has
offered
to
buy
Knight-Ridder
Inc.
's
ailing
Detroit
Free
Press
for
$
68
million
but
has
left
unclear
how
the
offer
will
be
financed
.
<END>
<START>
The
group
led
by
Birmingham
,
Mich.
,
publicist
William
D.
McMaster
did
n't
name
an
investment
banker
backing
the
deal
or
say
how
much
its
members
will
contribute
to
the
offer
.
<END>
<START>
Knight-Ridder
would
n't
comment
on
the
offer
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
has
said
the
paper
is
n't
for
sale
,
and
has
rebuffed
Mr.
McMaster
's
earlier
requests
for
access
to
Free

.
<END>
<START>
But

,

and
his

would
need
access
to

before

offer
.

<START>
Mitsui
&

Co.
,

,
to

.
<END>

.
<END>

expects

to

.

hopes
to

.

<START>
NRM
Energy
Co.
said
it
filed
materials
with
the
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
calling
for
it
to
restructure
into
a
corporation
from
a
limited
partnership
.
<END>
<START>
The
partnership
said
it
is
proposing
the
change
largely
because
the
provisions
of
its
senior
notes
restrict
it
from
making
distributions
on
its
units
outstanding
.
<END>
<START>
NRM
suspended
its
common
distribution
in
June
1988
and
the
distribution
on
its
$
2
cumulative
convertible
acquisition
preferred
units
in
September
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
plan
,
NRM
said
holders
of
its
common
units
will
receive
one
share
of
new
common
stock
in
Edisto
Resources
Corp.
for
every
14.97
common
units
owned
.
<END>
<START>
Holders
of
NRM
's
$
2
cumulative
convertible
acquisition
preferred
units
will
receive
one
new
common
share
in
Edisto
for
every
1.342
units
they
own
.
<END>
<START>
Edisto
currently
is
the
general
partner
of
NRM
.
<END>
<START>
As
the
largest
holder
of
acquisition
preferred
units
,
Mesa
Limited
Partnership
would
own
about
28
%
of
Edisto
after
the
transaction
.
<END>
<START>
NRM
said
its
$
2.60
senior
cumulative
convertible
preferred
units
will
be
converted
into
an
equal
number
of
shares
of
$
2.60
senior
cumulative
convertible
preferred
stock
of
Edisto
.
<END>
<START>
The
transaction
is
subject
to
approval
of
NRM
unitholders
of
record
on
Oct.
23
,
among
other
conditions
.
<END>
<START>
NRM
said
it
expects
unitholders
to
vote
on
the
restructuring
at
a
meeting
Dec.
15
.
<END>
<START>
Sherwin-Williams
Co.
and
Whittaker
Corp.
said

've
discontinued

toward
a

agreement
regarding
Sherwin-Williams
'

Whittaker
's

.
<END>
<START>

reached

in

.
<END>
<START>
Terms
were
n't

.

Cleveland-based
Sherwin-Williams
produces
paints
and
coatings
,
while
the
Los
Angeles-based
Whittaker
coatings
group
produces
industrial
coatings
.

<START>
USG
Corp.
agreed

its
headquarters
building
here
to

Insurance
Co.
of
Toronto
,
and
will

19-story

until

to

in

.

<START>
The

did
n't
disclose
terms
of
the
sale
,
which
will
close
in

first
quarter
of

year
.
<END>
<START>
Proceeds
from
the
planned

of
the
250,000-square-foot
building
``
will
help
reduce
the
debt
incurred
as
a
result
of
our
July
1988

,
''
said
a
USG
official
.
<END>
<START>
The
recently
revived
enthusiasm
among
small
investors
for
stock
mutual
funds
has
been
damped
by
a
jittery
stock
market
and
the
tumult
over
program
trading
.
<END>
<START>
After
hitting
two-year
highs
this
summer
,
net
sales
of
stock
funds
slowed
in
September
,
according
to
the
Investment
Company
Institute
,
a
trade
group
.
<END>
<START>
The
sales
recovery
screeched
to
a
halt
this
month
,
some
analysts
say
.
<END>
<START>
``
Now
everything
''
--
such
as
program
trading
and
wide
stock
market
swings
--
``
that
everyone
had
pushed
back
in
their
consciousness
is
just
sitting
right
there
.
''
<END>
<START>
Net
sales
of
stock
funds
in
September
totaled
$
839.4
million
,
down
from
$
1.1
billion
in
August
,
the
institute
said
.
<END>
<START>
But
if
reinvested
dividends
are
excluded
,
investors
put
in
only
$
340
million
more
than
they
pulled
out
for
the
month
.
<END>
<START>
October
's
numbers
,
which
wo
n't
be
released
for
a
month
,
are
down
further
,
mutual
fund
executives
say
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
in
stock
funds
did
n't
panic
the
weekend
after
mid-October
's
190-point
market
plunge
.
<END>
<START>
Most
of
the
those
who
left
stock
funds
simply
switched
into
money
market
funds
.
<END>
<START>
And
some
fund
groups
said
investors
actually
became
net
buyers
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
stock
market
swings
have
continued
.
<END>
<START>
The
recent
outcry
over
program
trading
will
cast
a
pall
over
the
stock-fund
environment
in
the
coming
months
,
some
analysts
say
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
public
is
very
close
to
having
had
it
,
''
Mr.
Jenks
says
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
pulled
back
from
bond
funds
in
September
,
too
.
<END>
<START>
Net
sales
of
bond
funds
for
the
month
totaled
$
1.1
billion
,
down
two-thirds
from
$
3.1
billion
in
August
.
<END>
<START>
The
major
reason
:
heavy
outflows
from
high-risk
,
high-yield
junk
bond
funds
.
<END>
<START>
Big
withdrawals
from
the
junk
funds
have
continued
this
month
.
<END>
<START>
Overall
,
net
sales
of
all
mutual
funds
,
excluding
money
market
funds
,
fell
to
$
1.9
billion
in
September
from
$
4.2
billion
in
August
,
the
trade
group
said
.
<END>
<START>
Many
small
investors
went
for
the
safety
of
money
market
funds
.
<END>
<START>
Assets
of
these
and
other
short-term
funds
surged
more
than
$
5
billion
in
September
,
the
institute
said
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
say
additional
investors
transferred
their
assets
into
money
funds
this
month
.
<END>
<START>
At
Fidelity
Investments
,
the
nation
's
largest
fund
group
,
money
funds
continue
to
draw
the
most
business
,
says
Michael
Hines
,
vice
president
,
marketing
.
<END>
<START>
In
October
,
net
sales
of
stock
funds
at
Fidelity
dropped
sharply
,
Mr.
Hines
said
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
emphasized
that
new
accounts
,
new
sales
,
inquiries
and
subsequent
sales
of
stock
funds
are
all
up
this
month
from
September
's
level
.
<END>
<START>
Investor
interest
in
stock
funds
``
has
n't
stalled
at
all
,
''
Mr.
Hines
maintains
.
<END>
<START>
He
notes
that
most
of
the
net
sales
drop
stemmed
from
a
three-day
period
following
the
Friday
the
13th
plunge
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
that
follows
through
next
month
,
then
it
will
be
a
different
story
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
But
,
Mr.
Hines
adds
,
sales
``
based
on
a
few
days
'
events
do
n't
tell
you
much
about
October
's
trends
.
''
<END>
<START>
One
trend
that
continues
is
growth
in
the
money
invested
in
funds
.
<END>
<START>
Buoyed
by
the
continued
inflows
into
money
funds
,
assets
of
all
mutual
funds
swelled
to
a
record
$
953.8
billion
in
September
,
up
fractionally
from
$
949.3
billion
in
August
.
<END>
<START>
Stock-fund
managers
,
meantime
,
went
into
October
with
less
cash
on
hand
than
they
held
earlier
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
These
managers
held
9.8
%
of
assets
in
cash
at
the
end
of
September
,
down
from
10.2
%
in
August
and
10.6
%
in
September
1988
.
<END>
<START>
Large
cash
positions
help
buffer
funds
from
market
declines
but
can
cut
down
on
gains
in
rising
markets
.
<END>
<START>
Managers
of
junk
funds
were
bolstering
their
cash
hoards
after
the
September
cash
crunch
at
Campeau
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
Junk-portfolio
managers
raised
their
cash
position
to
9.4
%
of
assets
in
September
from
8.3
%
in
August
.
<END>
<START>
In
September
1988
,
that
level
was
9.5
%
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
in
all
funds
will
seek
safety
in
the
coming
months
,
some
analysts
say
.
<END>
<START>
Among
stock
funds
,
the
conservative
growth-and-income
portfolios
probably
will
remain
popular
,
fund
specialists
say
.
<END>
<START>
We
keep
wondering
what
Mr.
Gates
wanted
to
say
.
<END>
<START>
Perhaps
he
might
have
cited
Mr.
Gorbachev
's
need
for
``
a
stable
currency
,
free
and
competitive
markets
,
private
property
and
real
prices
''
and
other
pie-in-the-sky
reforms
.
<END>
<START>
Perhaps
he
'd
have
called
for
``
a
decentralized
political
and
economic
system
''
without
a
dominant
communist
party
.
<END>
<START>
Or
political
arrangements
``
to
alleviate
the
grievances
and
demands
of
Soviet
ethnic
minorities
and
republics
.
''
<END>
<START>
Why
,
a
Bob
Gates
might
even
have
said
,
``
Nor
are
Soviet
problems
susceptible
to
rescue
from
abroad
through
abundant
Western
credits
.
''
<END>
<START>
If
Mr.
Gates
had
been
allowed
to
say
these
things
,
we
would
now
be
hearing
about
``
discord
''
and
``
disarray
''
on
foreign
policy
.
<END>
<START>
Dark
hints
would
be
raised
that
parts
of
the
administration
hope
Mr.
Gorbachev
would
fail
,
just
as
they
were
when
Vice
President
Quayle
voiced
similar
sentiments
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
somehow
OK
for
Secretary
Baker
himself
,
however
,
to
say
all
the
same
things
.
<END>
<START>
In
fact
,
he
did
;
the
quotes
above
are
from
Mr.
Baker
's
speech
of
two
weeks
ago
.
<END>
<START>
So
far
as
we
can
see
,
there
is
no
disagreement
among
Mr.
Baker
,
Mr.
Quayle
,
the
Mr.
Gates
we
've
read
,
or
for
that
matter
President
Bush
.
<END>
<START>
They
all
understand
point
one
:
Nothing
the
U.S.
can
do
will
make
much
difference
in
whether
Mr.
Gorbachev
succeeds
with
perestroika
.
<END>
<START>
Perhaps
Mr.
Gates
would
emphasize
more
than
Mr.
Baker
the
many
hurdles
the
Soviet
leader
must
leap
if
he
is
going
to
succeed
.
<END>
<START>
But
everyone
agrees
that
Mr.
Gorbachev
's
problems
result
from
the
failure
of
his
own
system
.
<END>
<START>
They
can
be
relieved
only
by
changing
that
system
,
not
by
pouring
Western
money
into
it
.
<END>
<START>
GATT
membership
will
not
matter
to
Donbas
coal
miners
short
of
soap
,
nor
will
a
START
treaty
make
any
difference
to
Ukrainian
nationalists
.
<END>
<START>
On
the
other
hand
,
so
long
as
Mr.
Gorbachev
is
easing
his
grip
on
his
empire
,
everyone
we
've
heard
agrees
that
the
U.S.
can
benefit
by
engaging
him
.
<END>
<START>
If
a
deal
can
be
made
to
cut
the
world
's
Ortegas
loose
from
Moscow
,
why
not
?
<END>
<START>
We
do
n't
expect
much
good
from
nuclear-arms
control
,
but
conventional-arms
talks
might
demilitarize
Eastern
Europe
.
<END>
<START>
There
's
nothing
in
the
least
contradictory
in
all
this
,
and
it
would
be
nice
to
think
that
Washington
could
tolerate
a
reasonably
sophisticated
,
complex
view
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
much
of
the
political
culture
seems
intent
on
castigating
the
Bush
administration
for
not
``
helping
''
Mr.
Gorbachev
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Baker
seems
especially
sensitive
to
the
Washington
ailment
known
as
Beltway-itis
.
<END>
<START>
Its
symptoms
include
a
cold
sweat
at
the
sound
of
debate
,
clammy
hands
in
the
face
of
congressional
criticism
,
and
fainting
spells
when
someone
writes
the
word
``
controversy
.
''
<END>
<START>
In
short
,
the
problem
is
not
intra-administration
disagreement
,
but
preoccupation
with
the
prospect
that
perestrokia
might
fail
,
and
its
political
opponents
will
ask
``
Who
lost
Gorbachev
?
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Baker
may
want
to
avoid
criticism
from
Senate
Majority
Leader
George
Mitchell
,
but
as
Secretary
of
State
his
audience
is
the
entire
Free
World
,
not
just
Congress
.
<END>
<START>
Letting
officials
express
their
own
nuances
can
be
educational
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
in
the
Western
interest
to
see
Mr.
Gorbachev
succeed
.
<END>
<START>
The
odds
are
against
him
,
as
he
himself
would
no
doubt
tell
you
.
<END>
<START>
The
ultimate
outcome
depends
on
what
he
does
,
not
on
what
we
do
.
<END>
<START>
Even
if
the
press
is
ready
to
seize
and
misinterpret
,
these
are
not
very
complicated
thoughts
.
<END>
<START>
Surely
there
is
someone
in
the
administration
,
maybe
Bob
Gates
,
who
could
explain
them
to
college
students
,

.

E.

.

.

<START>
The

,

5,000
from

last

.

<START>

,

,

,

.

<START>
Two
gunmen
entered
a
Maryland
restaurant
,
ordered
two
employees
to
lie
on
the
floor
and
shot
them
in
the
backs
of

heads
.
<END>
<START>
The
killers
fled
with
less
than
$
100
.
<END>
<START>
Describing
this
and
other

killings
,
Sen.
Strom
Thurmond
-LRB-
R.
,
S.C
.
-RRB-
recently

to

.
<END>
<START>
``
The
ultimate

,
''
he

,
``

from

,
cruel
individuals
who
commit
these
crimes
.
''
<END>
<START>
There
's
just
one
problem
:
The
law
that
Sen.
Thurmond
is
pushing
would
be
irrelevant
in
the
case
of
the
Maryland
restaurant
murders
and
almost
all
other
killings
.
<END>
<START>
Most
murders
are
state
crimes
,
so
any
federal
capital-punishment
law
probably
would
turn
out
to
be
more
symbolism
than
substance
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
the
bill
is
riding
high
on
the
furor
over
drug
trafficking
.
<END>
<START>
Senate
Republicans
,
after
repeatedly
failing
to
attach
death-penalty
amendments
to
unrelated
legislation
,
have
finally
gotten
a
full-blown
death-penalty
bill
through
committee
.
<END>
<START>
The
Democratic
leadership
agreed
to
allow
a
floor
vote
on
the
issue
before
the
end
of
the
year
--
a
debate
certain
to
focus
on
the
alleged
racial
inequality
of
death
sentencing
.
<END>
<START>
Even
some
Democrats
concede
that
there
is
probably
a
majority
in
the
Senate
that
favors
some
kind
of
broad
capital-punishment
measure
.
<END>
<START>
The
pending
bill
,
introduced
by
Mr.
Thurmond
,
would
revive
the
long-dormant
federal
death-penalty
laws
by
instituting
legal
procedures
required
by
the
Supreme
Court
.
<END>
<START>
In
1972
,
the
high
court
swept
aside
all
capital-punishment
laws
--
federal
and
state
alike
--
as
unconstitutional
.
<END>
<START>
But
in
1976
,
the
court
permitted
resurrection
of
such
laws
,
if
they
meet
certain
procedural
requirements
.
<END>
<START>
For
instance
,
juries
would
have
to
consider
specific
``
aggravating
''
and
``
mitigating
''
factors
before
deciding
whether
to
condemn
someone
to
death
.
<END>
<START>
Since
that
1976
ruling
,
37
states
have
reintroduced
the
death
penalty
.
<END>
<START>
But
congressional
Democrats
have
blocked
the
same
from
occurring
at
the
federal
level
,
with
the
exception
of
a
1988
law
allowing
capital
punishment
for
certain
drug-related
homicides
.
<END>
<START>
The
Thurmond
bill
would
establish
a
federally
administered
death
sentence
for
23
crimes
,
most
of
which
were
formerly
punishable
by
death
under
federal
statutes
that
the
Supreme
Court
invalidated
.
<END>
<START>
Among
these
crimes
are
murder
on
federal
land
,
presidential
assassination
and
espionage
.
<END>
<START>
The
Thurmond
bill
would
also
add
five
new
crimes
punishable
by
death
,
including
murder
for
hire
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Separately
,
the
Senate
last
week
passed
a
bill
permitting
execution
of
terrorists
who
kill
Americans
abroad
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Amid
the
swirl
of
punitive
rhetoric
surrounding
the
issue
,
one
critical
question
involves
whether
a
federal
death
penalty
,
on
top
of
existing
state
laws
,
would
deter
any
would-be
criminals
.
<END>
<START>
For
one
thing
,
it
's
unlikely
that
many
people
would
receive
federal
death
sentences
,
let
alone
be
executed
.
<END>
<START>
``
In
that
sense
,
the
whole
debate
is
sort
of
a
fraud
,
''
argues
a
Democratic
Senate
staff
member
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
distracting
attention
from
serious
issues
,
like
how
to
make
DEA
,
FBI
and
Customs
work
together
''
on
drug
enforcement
.
<END>
<START>
Republicans
acknowledge
that
few
people
would
be
executed
under
the
Thurmond
bill
,
but
they
contend
that
is
n't
the
point
.
<END>
<START>
Executions
,
regardless
of
how
frequently
they
occur
,
are
also
``
proper
retribution
''
for
heinous
crimes
,
Mr.
Hatch
argues
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
to
resuscitating
the
old
issue
of
whether
death
sentences
deter
criminals
,
this
bill
has
made
race
a
major
part
of
the
death-penalty
debate
.
<END>
<START>
The
amendment
prompted
an
ironic
protest
from
Mr.
Thurmond
,
who
complained
that
it
would
``
kill
''
capital
punishment
.
<END>
<START>
A
large
number
of
studies
suggest
that
state
judges
and
juries
have
imposed
the
penalty
in
a
racially
discriminatory
fashion
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
Kennedy
amendment
would
invade
not
only
federal
but
state
sentencings
,
in
two
important
ways
.
<END>
<START>
It
would
allow
all
defendants
to
introduce
statistical
evidence
showing
racially
disproportionate
application
of
the
death
penalty
in
the
past
.
<END>
<START>
And
it
would
shift
the
burden
to
prosecutors
to
disprove
that
discrimination
caused
any
statistical
racial
disparities
.
<END>
<START>
``
That
burden
is
very
difficult
,
if
not
impossible
,
to
meet
,
''
says
Mr.
Boyd
.
<END>
<START>
``
How
do
you
prove
a
negative
?
''
<END>
<START>
Since
most
prosecutors
would
n't
be
able
to
demonstrate
conclusively
that
racial
considerations
did
n't
affect
sentencing
,
executions
everywhere
might
come
to
a
halt
,
Mr.
Boyd
explains
.
<END>
<START>
The
Kennedy
amendment
would
,
in
effect
,
legislate
around
the
Supreme
Court
ruling
.
<END>
<START>
Lawyers
would
eagerly
seize
on
the
provision
in
their
death-penalty
appeals
,
says
Richard
Burr
,
director
of
the
NAACP
Legal
Defense
and
Educational
Fund
's
capital-punishment
defense
team
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Kennedy
failed
to
get
his
amendment
incorporated
into
last
year
's
anti-drug
legislation
,
and
it
will
be
severely
attacked
on
the
Senate
floor
this
time
around
.
<END>
<START>
But
if
it
survives
,
it
could
prompt
other
statutory
changes
,
according
to
the
Mr.
Burr
.
<END>
<START>
Narrowing
the
penalty
in
this
fashion
would
clearly
reduce
whatever
deterrent
effect
it
now
has
.
<END>
<START>
And
that
,
in
turn
,
would
only
strengthen
the
argument
of
those
who
oppose
execution
under
any
circumstances
.
<END>

<START>
Japan
's

of

,

2.4
%

535,322
units
in

from

,
the

Manufacturers
Association
said
.
<END>
<START>

to

overseas
.
<END>
<START>

,

2.1
%
,

every

from

.

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
Under

11
,
a

,

while

.
<END>
<START>

of

.
<END>
<START>
Not
even

.
<END>
<START>
On

17
,

of

with

insurance-claims
adjusters
over

a

,

had
an

in

.
<END>
<START>
The

;
the

.
<END>
<START>
For

,

like
the
deal
--
not
to

--

.
<END>
<START>
``
The

,

,
'
''

.

<START>

?
'
<END>
<START>

.
''
<END>
<START>
A

,

.
<END>
<START>

on

;

,

.

The

.

.

.

Revco

,

,

.

<START>

,

would

.

in

that

to

.
<END>
<START>

``

,
''
because

11
Revco

``

rights
''
until

28
.
<END>
<START>
Those
rights
prevent
anyone
other
than
Revco
from
proposing
a
reorganization
plan
.
<END>
<START>
Also
under
Chapter
11
,
a
reorganization
plan
is
subject
to
approval
by
bondholders
,
banks
and
other
creditors
.
<END>
<START>
A
financial
adviser
for
Revco
bondholders
,
David
Schulte
,
of
Chilmark
Partners
,
had
mixed
reactions
to
the
offer
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
he
feared
a
Revco
reorganization
might
force
bondholders
to
accept
a
``
cheap
deal
,
''
and
that
the
Bass
group
's
offer
would
give
them
more
money
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
the
group
is
offering
to
pay
off
bondholders
in
cash
only
--
$
260.5
million
--
and
no
equity
.
<END>
<START>
The
Revco
bonds
are
high-yield
,
high-risk
``
junk
''
bonds
;
holders
have
$
750
million
in
claims
against
Revco
,
Mr.
Schulte
said
.
<END>
<START>
Revco
received
the
offer
Oct.
20
,
but
issued
a
response
yesterday
only
after
a
copy
of
the
proposal
was
made
public
by
bondholders
.
<END>
<START>
Acadia
Partners
Limited
Partnership
,
a
Fort
Worth
,
Texas
,
partnership
that
includes
the
Robert
M.
Bass
Group
,
made
the
proposal
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bass
is
based
in
Fort
Worth
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
said
the
nation
's
second-largest
drugstore
chain
was
a
valuable
company
,
despite
its
financial
woes
.
<END>
<START>
Its
problem
,
they
say
,
is
that
management
paid
too
much
in
the
leveraged
buy-out
and
the
current
$
515
million
debt
load
is
keeping
Revco
in
the
red
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
bought
at
the
right
price
,
it
could
still
be
profitable
,
''
said
Jeffrey
Stein
,
an
analyst
at
McDonald
&
Co.
,
Cleveland
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
were
$
597.8
million
,
up
2.4
%
from
the
previous
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
,
based
in
Twinsburg
,
Ohio
,
said
its
operating
profit
before
depreciation
and
amortization
increased
51
%
,
to
$
9.2
million
from
$
6.1
million
.
<END>
<START>
Acadia
Partners
and
the
Bass
Group
declined
to
comment
.
<END>
<START>
The
partnership
also
includes
American
Express
Co.
,
Equitable
Life
Assurance
Society
of
the
U.S.
and
Shearson
Lehman
Hutton
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
The
offer
consists
of
$
410.5
million
in
cash
and
the
rest
in
notes
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
he
has
not
met
with
representatives
from
Acadia
.
<END>
<START>
Any
reorganization
proposal
,
Mr.
Sells
said
,
is
difficult
to
assess
because
it
must
be
agreed
upon
by
the
company
,
bondholders
,
banks
and
other
creditors
.
<END>
<START>
Revco
has
$
1.5
billion
in
claims
outstanding
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
not
like
the
board
can
decide
''
by
itself
,
Mr.
Sells
said
,
adding
,
``
we
're
indifferent
to
-LRB-
the
Bass
-RRB-
plan
.
<END>
<START>
We
just
want
a
plan
that
satisfies
creditors
and
at
the
end
leaves
a
healthy
Revco
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Schulte
,
the
bondholders
'
adviser
,
said
Revco
was
dragging
its
feet
in
responding
to
the
proposal
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
want
to
pretend
it
does
n't
exist
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Schulte
,
who
met
with
Acadia
representatives
on
Oct.
10
,
said
,
``
It
's
certainly
a
responsible
offer
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
not
an
effort
to
steal
the
company
''
in
the
middle
of
the
night
.
<END>
<START>
Copper
futures
prices
failed
to
extend
Friday
's
rally
.
<END>
<START>
Declines
came
because
of
concern
that
demand
for
copper
may
slow
down
.
<END>
<START>
The
December
contract
was
down
three
cents
a
pound
,
settling
at
$
1.1280
,
which
was
just
above
the
day
's
low
of
$
1.1270
.
<END>
<START>
Futures
prices
fell
during
three
of
five
sessions
last
week
,
and
the
losses
,
individually
and
cumulatively
,
were
greater
than
the
advances
.
<END>
<START>
Two
of
the
major
factors
buoying
prices
,
the
prolonged
strikes
at
the
Highland
Valley
mine
in
Canada
and
the
Cananea
mine
in
Mexico
,
were
finally
resolved
.
<END>
<START>
Also
,
the
premiums
paid
by
the
U.S.
government
on
a
purchase
of
copper
for
the
U.S.
Mint
were
lower
than
expected
,
and
acted
as
a
price
depressant
,
analysts
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
mint
purchases
were
at
premiums
about
4
1/2
cents
a
pound
above
the
respective
prices
for
the
copper
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
time
merchants
were
asking
for
premiums
of
about
five
cents
a
pound
.
<END>
<START>
All
this
has
led
to
prolonged
selling
in
futures
,
mostly
on
the
part
of
computer-guided
funds
.
<END>
<START>
Prices
fell
through
levels
regarded
as
important
support
areas
,
which
added
to
the
selling
.
<END>
<START>
The
reluctance
of
traders
to
buy
contracts
indicates
that
they
have
begun
focusing
on
demand
rather
than
supply
.
<END>
<START>
At
least
one
analyst
noted
that
as
production
improves
,
the
concern
among
traders
is
whether
the
prospective
increased
supply
will
find
buyers
because
of
uncertainty
over
national
economies
.
<END>
<START>
``
Demand
from
Japan
is
expected
to
continue
strong
,
but
not
from
other
areas
of
the
world
into
the
first
quarter
of
next
year
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Japan
normally
depends
heavily
on
the
Highland
Valley
and
Cananea
mines
as
well
as
the
Bougainville
mine
in
Papua
New
Guinea
.
<END>
<START>
Recently
,
Japan
has
been
buying
copper
elsewhere
.
<END>
<START>
But
as
Highland
Valley
and
Cananea
begin
operating
,
they
are
expected
to
resume
their
roles
as
Japan
's
suppliers
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
Fred
Demler
,
metals
economist
for
Drexel
Burnham
Lambert
,
New
York
,
``
Highland
Valley
has
already
started
operating
and
Cananea
is
expected
to
do
so
soon
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
Bougainville
mine
is
generally
expected
to
remain
closed
until
at
least
the
end
of
the
year
.
<END>
<START>
It
has
n't
been
operating
since
May
15
because
of
attacks
by
native
landowners
.
<END>
<START>
A
recent
attempt
to
resume
operations
was
cut
short
quickly
by
these
attacks
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
traders
disregarded
a
potential
production
disruption
in
Chile
and
a
continued
drop
in
inventories
.
<END>
<START>
The
mines
produced
a
total
of
110,000
tons
of
copper
in
1988
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
Drexel
's
Mr.
Demler
,
the
potential
strike
is
expected
to
be
resolved
quickly
,
which
may
be
one
reason
why
the
situation
did
n't
affect
prices
much
.
<END>
<START>
Another
analyst
said
that
,
if
there
was
any
concern
,
it
was
that
a
strike
could
encourage
other
walkouts
in
Chile
.
<END>
<START>
London
Metal
Exchange
copper
inventories
fell
550
tons
last
week
to
83,950
tons
,
a
smaller-than-expected
decline
.
<END>
<START>
But
that
development
also
had
little
effect
on
traders
'
sentiment
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Demler
said
that
stocks
of
copper
in
U.S.
producers
'
hands
at
the
end
of
September
were
down
16,000
metric
tons
from
August
to
30,000
tons
.
<END>
<START>
Outside
the
U.S.
,
he
said
,
producer
stocks
at
the
end
of
August
were
273,000
tons
,
down
3,000
tons
from
the
end
of
July
.
<END>
<START>
The
high
point
of
foreigners
'
copper
stocks
this
year
was
136,000
tons
at
the
end
of
April
,
according
to
Mr.
Demler
.
<END>
<START>
In
other
commodity
markets
yesterday
:
<END>
<START>
GRAINS
AND
SOYBEANS
:
<END>
<START>
The
prices
of
most
corn
,
soybean
and
wheat
futures
contracts
dropped
slightly
as
farmers
in
the
Midwest
continued
to
rebuild
stockpiles
that
were
depleted
by
the
1988
drought
.
<END>
<START>
Buying
by
the
Soviets
has
helped
to
prop
up
corn
prices
in
recent
weeks
,
but
a
lack
of
any
new
purchases
kept
prices
in
the
doldrums
.
<END>
<START>
COFFEE
:
<END>
<START>
Futures
prices
rose
slightly
in
a
market
filled
with
rumors
that
a
new
international
coffee
agreement
might
still
be
achieved
.
<END>
<START>
The
December
contract
ended
with
a
gain
of
1.29
cents
a
pound
at
74.35
cents
.
<END>
<START>
The
reports
,
attributed
to
the
Colombian
minister
of
economic
development
,
said
Brazil
would
give
up
500,000
bags
of
its
quota
and
Colombia
200,000
bags
,
the
analyst
said
.
<END>
<START>
These
reports
were
later
denied
by
a
high
Brazilian
official
,
who
said
Brazil
was
n't
involved
in
any
coffee
discussions
on
quotas
,
the
analyst
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
minister
was
also
quoted
as
saying
that
a
new
pact
could
be
achieved
during
the
first
half
of
next
year
,
according
to
the
analyst
.
<END>
<START>
PRECIOUS
METALS
:
<END>
<START>
Futures
prices
showed
modest
changes
in
light
trading
volume
.
<END>
<START>
December
delivery
gold
eased
40
cents
an
ounce
to
$
380.80
.
<END>
<START>
December
silver
was
off
3.7
cents
an
ounce
at
$
5.2830
.
<END>
<START>
January
platinum
rose
90
cents
an
ounce
at
$
500.20
.
<END>
<START>
The
market
turned
quiet
after
rising
sharply
late
last
week
,
according
to
one
analyst
.
<END>
<START>
Last
week
's
uncertainty
in
the
stock
market
and
a
weaker
dollar
triggered
a
flight
to
safety
,
he
said
,
but
yesterday
the
market
lacked
such
stimuli
.
<END>
<START>
There
was
some
profit-taking
because
prices
for
all
the
precious
metals
had
risen
to
levels
at
which
there
was
resistance
to
further
advance
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
dollar
was
also
slightly
firmer
and
prompted
some
selling
,
as
well
,
according
to
the
analyst
.
<END>
<START>
Louisiana-Pacific
Corp.
said
its
board
authorized
the
purchase
of
as
many
as
five
million
of
its
common
shares
for
employee
stock
plans
and
other
general
corporate
purposes
.
<END>
<START>
The
forest-products
concern
currently
has
about
38
million
shares
outstanding
.
<END>
<START>
In
yesterday
's
composite
trading
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
,
Louisiana-Pacific
shares
closed
at
$
39.25
,
down
37.5
cents
.
<END>
<START>
Their
only
doubt
concerned
the
possibility
that
Mr.
Gorbachev
might
not
survive
the
opposition
that
his
reforms
would
arouse
and
that
the
whole
process
might
be
reversed
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
the
Soviet
miners
strike
this
summer
clearly
demonstrated
that
Mr.
Gorbachev
must
proceed
with
economic
reform
.
<END>
<START>
But
is
he
so
clever
that
he
has
achieved
the
political
equivalent
of
making
water
run
uphill
?
<END>
<START>
And
has
he
truly
persuaded
the
Communist
Party
to
accept
economic
change
of
a
kind
that
will
,
sooner
or
later
,
lead
to
its
demise
?
<END>
<START>
Before
becoming
self-employed
,
or
setting
up
a
cooperative
,
workers
must
seek
permission
from
the
local
soviet
-LRB-
council
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
Permission
is
far
from
automatic
:
The
soviets
have
the
legal
right
to
turn
down
applications
and
impose
conditions
,
and
they
appear
to
be
exercising
these
powers
.
<END>
<START>
Private
dressmaking
,
for
example
,
is
allowed
in
10
Soviet
republics
but
banned
by
five
;
shoemaking
is
allowed
in
seven
but
illegal
in
nine
.
<END>
<START>
The
controls
on
cooperatives
appeared
relatively
liberal
when
first
introduced
.
<END>
<START>
All
independent
media
activity
is
now
illegal
,
which
perhaps
is
not
surprising
,
but
so
is
the
manufacture
of
perfume
,
cosmetics
,
household
chemicals
and
sand
candles
.
<END>
<START>
If
Mr.
Gorbachev
is
looking
toward
unleashing
the
productive
forces
of
the
market
,
these
latest
resolutions
are
nothing
short
of
reckless
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Gorbachev
has
ruled
out
the
use
of
the
market
to
solve
the
problem
of
insufficient
consumer
goods
.
<END>
<START>
Most
important
,
this
would
leave
the
party
intact
and
its
monopoly
of
political
power
largely
undisturbed
.
<END>
<START>
They
,
too
,
promised
to
combine
economic
efficiency
with
order
and
discipline
.
<END>
<START>
The
fascist
concept
of
corporatism
envisaged
an
``
organic
''
society
in
which
citizens
were
spiritually
and
morally
unified
,
and
prepared
to
sacrifice
themselves
for
the
nation
.
<END>
<START>
This
unification
was
to
be
brought
about
through
policies
and
institutions
that
would
unite
workers
and
employers
with
government
in
a
fully
integrated
and
``
harmonic
''
society
.
<END>
<START>
The
key
to
the
creation
of
the
``
organic
''
state
lay
in
the
formation
of
``
natural
''
groups
that
would
undertake
the
role
of
decision-making
.
<END>
<START>
By
contrast
,
a
parliamentary
system
based
on
abstract
political
rights
and
groups
was
held
to
cause
,
rather
than
resolve
,
conflict
.
<END>
<START>
The
closeness
of
Soviet
perestroika
to
the
fascist
social
blueprint
of
Mussolini
was
evident
when
Mr.
Gorbachev
presented
his
economic
vision
to
the
Soviet
Congress
.
<END>
<START>
In
doing
so
,
he
neither
rejected
a
socialist
planned
economy
nor
embraced
the
free
market
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
,
he
proposed
a
``
law-governed
economy
,
''
in
which
there
would
be
a
``
clear-cut
division
between
state
direction
of
the
economy
and
economic
management
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
latter
would
be
undertaken
by
``
enterprises
,
joint
stock
companies
and
cooperatives
.
''
<END>
<START>
These
would
not
function
independently
,
but
would
act
together
to
form
``
combines
,
unions
and
associations
''
to
tackle
problems
and
coordinate
their
activities
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Gorbachev
is
in
a
much
stronger
position
to
pursue
the
corporatist
ideal
than
was
Mussolini
,
who
was
never
able
to
influence
business
giants
such
as
Pirelli
and
Fiat
.
<END>
<START>
The
Soviet
Communist
Party
has
the
power
to
shape
corporate
development
and
mold
it
into
a
body
dependent
upon
it
.
<END>
<START>
To
ensure
the
loyalty
of
the
business
sector
,
Mr.
Gorbachev
may
offer
concessions
and
powers
that
will
allow
the
business
community
to
preserve
its
own
interests
,
probably
by
restricting
competition
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
Mr.
Gorbachev
must
ensure
that
within
this
``
alliance
''
the
business
sector

,

<START>
Because
the

have
lacked

considered
standard

in
the
U.S.
and
Western
Europe
,
Japanese
corporations
'

is

.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
the

revolution
is
finally

Japan
.
<END>
<START>
In
April
,
the
Long-Term
Credit
Bank
linked
its
computers
in
Tokyo
with
its
three
American
offices
.
<END>
<START>
Overall
,
PC
sales
in
Japan
in
the
first
half
of
1989
were
34
%
higher
than
in
the
year-earlier
period
.
<END>
<START>
And
with
a

and
intense

pressure
to
improve
efficiency
,
more
and
more
Japanese
companies
are
concluding
that
they
have
no

.
<END>
<START>
``
We
have
too
many

in

,
''

Yoshio
Hatakeyama
,
the

.
<END>
<START>
``
Productivity
in
Japanese
offices
is
relatively
low
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
it
also
offers
opportunities
;
Americans
are
well
poised
to
supply
the
weapons
.
<END>
<START>
Japan
may
be
a
tough
market
for
outsiders
to
penetrate
,
and
the
U.S.
is
hopelessly
behind
Japan
in
certain

.
<END>
<START>
But
for
now
,
at
least
,
Americans
are
far
better
at
making

and
the
software
that

.
<END>
<START>
After
years
of
talking
about
selling
in
Japan
,
more
and
more
U.S.
companies
are
seriously
pouring
in
.
<END>
<START>
Apple
Computer
Inc.
has
doubled
its
staff
here
over
the
past
year
.
<END>
<START>
Lotus
Development
Corp.
has
slashed

lag
between
U.S.
and
Japan
product
introductions
to
six
months
from
three

.
<END>
<START>
Ungermann-Bass
Inc.
has
a
bigger
share
of
the
computer-network
market
in
Japan
than
at
home
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
Japanese
have
to
go
a
long
way
to
catch

.
<END>
<START>
Typical
is
one
office
of
the
Ministry
of
International
Trade
and
Industry
's
Machinery
and
Information
Industries
Bureau
--

overseeing

.
<END>
<START>
``
Personal
Computer
''
yearbooks
are
lined
up
on
nearly
every
desk
,
and
dog-eared
copies
of
Nikkei
Computer
crowd
magazine
racks
.
<END>
<START>
But
amid
the
two
dozen
bureaucrats
and
secretaries
sits
only
one
real-life
PC
.
<END>
<START>
While
American
PC
sales
have
averaged
roughly
25
%
annual
growth
since
1984
and
West
European
sales
a
whopping
40
%
,
Japanese
sales
were
flat
for
most
of
that
time
.
<END>
<START>
Japanese
office
workers
use
PCs
at
half
the
rate
of
their
European
counterparts
and
one-third
that
of
the
Americans
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
Japanese
offices
tend
to
use
computers
less
efficiently
than
American
offices
do
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
U.S.
,
PCs
commonly
perform
many
tasks
and
plug
into
a
broad
network
.
<END>
<START>
In
Japan
,
many
desktop
terminals
are
limited
to
one
function
and
ca
n't
communicate
with
other
machines
.
<END>
<START>
The
market
planning
and
sales
promotion
office
of
Nomura
Securities
Co.
,
for
example
,
has
more
than
30
computers
for
its
60
workers
,
a
respectable
ratio
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
machines
are
n't
on
employees
'
desks
;
they
ring
the
perimeter
of
the
large
office
.
<END>
<START>
Some
machines
make
charts
for
presentations
.
<END>
<START>
Others
analyze
the
data
.
<END>
<START>
To
transfer
information
from
one
to
the
other
,
employees
make
printouts
and
enter
the
data
manually
.
<END>
<START>
To
transmit
charts
to
branch
offices
,
they
use
a
fax
machine
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
a
woman
sitting
next
to
a
new
Fujitsu
terminal
writes
stock-market
information
on
a
chart
with
a
pencil
and
adds
it
up
with
a
hand
calculator
.
<END>
<START>
In
an
efficient
setup
,
the
same
PC
could
perform
all
those
tasks
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
U.S.
,
more
than
half
the
PC
software
sold
is
either
for
spreadsheets
or
for
database
analysis
,
according
to
Lotus
.
<END>
<START>
In
Japan
,
those
functions
account
for
only
about
a
third
of
the
software
market
.
<END>
<START>
Machines
dedicated
solely
to
word
processing
,
which
have
all
but
disappeared
in
the
U.S.
,
are
still
more
common
in
Japan
than
PCs
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
U.S.
,
one-fifth
of
the
office
PCs
are
hooked
up
to
some
sort
of
network
.
<END>
<START>
In
Japan
,
about
1
%
are
linked
.
<END>
<START>
``
Computers
here
are
used
for
data
gathering
,
''
says
Roger
J.
Boisvert
,
who
manages
the
integrated-technologies
group
in
McKinsey
&
Co.
's
Tokyo
office
.
<END>
<START>
Of
course
,
simply
buying
computers
does
n't
always
solve
problems
,
and
many
American
companies
have
erred
by
purchasing
technology
they
did
n't
understand
.
<END>
<START>
But
healthy
skepticism
is
only
a
small
reason
for
Japan
's
PC
lag
.
<END>
<START>
Various
cultural
and
economic
forces
have
suppressed
demand
.
<END>
<START>
While
most
American
employees
have
their
own
private
space
,
Japanese
``
salarymen
''
usually
share
large
,
common
tables
and
rely
heavily
on
old-fashioned
personal
contact
.
<END>
<START>
Top
Japanese
executives
often
make
decisions
based
on
consensus
and
personal
relationships
rather
than
complex
financial
projections
and
fancy
presentations
.
<END>
<START>
And
Japan
's
management
system
makes
it
hard
to
impose
a
single
,
integrated
computer
system
corporatewide
.
<END>
<START>
Besides
,
a
computer
processing
the
Japanese
language
needs
a
huge
memory
and
much
processing
capability
,
while
the
screen
and
printer
need
far
better
definition
to
depict
accurately
the
intricate
symbols
.
<END>
<START>
Until
recently
,
much
of
the
necessary
technology
has
been
unavailable
or
at
least
unaffordable
.
<END>
<START>
Some
analysts
estimate
the
average
PC
costs
about
50
%
more
in
Japan
than
the
U.S.
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
complex
language
is
n't
the
only
reason
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
past
decade
,
NEC
Corp.
has
owned
more
than
half
the
Japanese
PC
market
and
ruled
it
with
near-monopoly
power
.
<END>
<START>
With
little
competition
,
the
computer
industry
here
is
inefficient
.
<END>
<START>
The
U.S.
market
,
too
,
is
dominated
by
a
giant
,
International
Business
Machines
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
But
early
on
,
IBM
offered
its
basic
design
to
anybody
wanting
to
copy
it
.
<END>
<START>
Dozens
of
small
companies
did
,
swiftly
establishing
a
standard
operating
system
.
<END>
<START>
That
is
the
state
of
Japan
's
computer
industry
.
<END>
<START>
NEC
wo
n't
release
its
code
,
and
every
one
of
the
dozen
or
so
makers
has
its
own
proprietary
operating
system
--
all
incompatible
with
each
other
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
established
its
standard
to
try
to
stop
falling
behind
upstart
Apple
Computer
,
but
NEC
was
ahead
from
the
start
and
did
n't
need
to
invite
in
competitive
allies
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
the
big
players
have
n't
tried
to
copy
the
NEC
standard
.
<END>
<START>
Corporate
pride
as
well
as
the
close
ties
common
among
Japanese
manufacturers
help
explain
why
.
<END>
<START>
Most
rivals
``
have
a
working
relationship
with
NEC
,
often
through
cross-licensing
of
technology
,
''
the
Japan
Personal
Computer
Software
Association
noted
recently
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
hesitate
to
market
NEC-compatible
machines
;
NEC
disapproves
of
such
machines
,
and
marketing
one
would
jeopardize
their
relationship
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
result
,
according
to
many
analysts
,
is
higher
prices
and
less
innovation
.
<END>
<START>
While
tens
of
thousands
of
software
packages
using
the
IBM
standard
are
available
in
the
U.S.
,
they
say
only
about
8,000
are
written
for
NEC
.
<END>
<START>
A
year
ago
,
Japan
's
Fair
Trade
Commission
warned
NEC
about
possible
violations
of
anti-monopoly
laws
for
discouraging
retailers
from
discounting
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
are
no
price
wars
,
no
competition
.
''
<END>
<START>
An
NEC
spokeswoman
responds
that
prices
are
higher
in
Japan
because
customers
put
a
greater
emphasis
on
quality
and
service
than
they
do
in
the
U.S.
.
<END>
<START>
She
adds
that
some
technological
advances
trail
those
in
the
U.S.
because
the
Japanese
still
import
basic
operating
systems
from
American
companies
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
market
is
changing
.
<END>
<START>
The
government
is
funding
several
projects
to
push
PC
use
.
<END>
<START>
Over
the
next
three
years
,
public
schools
will
get
1.5
million
PCs
,
a
15-fold
increase
from
current
levels
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
private
sector
,
practically
every
major
company
is
setting
explicit
goals
to
increase
employees
'
exposure
to
computers
.
<END>
<START>
``
Managers
have
long
been
those
who
supervise
their
subordinates
so
orders
would
be
properly
acted
on
,
''
a
spokesman
says
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
more
computer
makers
now
are
competing
for
the
new
business
.
<END>
<START>
Seiko
Epson
Corp.
,
a
newcomer
to
the
industry
,
fought
off
a
legal
challenge
and
started
selling
NEC
clones
last
year
.
<END>
<START>
It
has
won
about
15
%
of
the
retail
PC
market
.
<END>
<START>
Sony
Corp.
,
which
temporarily
dropped
out
of
the
PC
business
three
years
ago
,
started
selling
its
work
station
in
1987
and
quickly
became
the
leading
Japanese
company
in
that
market
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
country
where
elbow
room
is
scarce
,
laptop
machines
will
take
a
large
portion
of
the
industry
's
future
growth
.
<END>
<START>
Many
of
the
companies
are
even
dropping
their
traditional
independence
and
trying
to
band
together
to
create
some
sort
of
standard
.
<END>
<START>
Two
years
ago
,
most
of
the
smaller
makers
joined
under
the
Microsoft
Corp.
umbrella
to
adopt
a
version
of
the
American
IBM
AT
standard
.
<END>
<START>
That
has
n't
generated
much
sales
,
but
this
summer
Microsoft
rallied
all
the
major
NEC
competitors
to
make
their
new
machines
compatible
with
the
IBM
OS/2
standard
.
<END>
<START>
A
healthy
,
coherent
Japanese
market
could
also
make
it
far
easier
for
Japanese
companies
to
sell
overseas
,
where
their
share
is
still
minimal
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
could
also
help
American
companies
,
which
also
are
starting
to
try
to
open
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
As
with
many
other
goods
,
the
American
share
of
Japan
's
PC
market
is
far
below
that
in
the
rest
of
the
world
.
<END>
<START>
U.S.
makers
have
under
10
%
share
,
compared
with
half
the
market
in
Europe
and
80
%
at
home
.
<END>
<START>
Though
no
formal
trade
barriers
exist
,
the
Japanese
computer
industry
is
difficult
for
outsiders
to
enter
.
<END>
<START>
His
company
,
without
any
major
effort
,
sells
more
machines
in
China
than
in
Japan
.
<END>
<START>
Although
it
has
opened
a
New
Zealand
subsidiary
,
it
is
still
only
``
studying
''
Japan
,
the
only
nation
that
has
n't
adopted
IBM-oriented
specifications
.
<END>
<START>
And
because
general
retail
centers
such
as
ComputerLand
have
little
presence
in
Japan
,
sales
remain
in
the
iron
grip
of
established
computer
makers
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
Americans
are
also
to
blame
.
<END>
<START>
They
long
made
little
effort
here
.
<END>
<START>
Apple
did
n't
introduce
a
kanji
machine
--
one
that
handles
the
Chinese
characters
of
written
Japanese
--
until
three
years
after
entering
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
Critics
also
say
American
companies
charge
too
much
.
<END>
<START>
Japan
's
FTC
says
it
is
investigating
Apple
for
allegedly
discouraging
retailers
from
discounting
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
U.S.
companies
are
redoubling
their
efforts
.
<END>
<START>
Apple
recently
hired
its
first
Japanese
president
,
luring
away
an
official
of
Toshiba
's
European
operations
,
as
well
as
a
whole
Japanese
top-management
team
.
<END>
<START>
Earlier
this
year
,
it
introduced
a
much
more
powerful
kanji
operating
system
and
a
kanji
laser
printer
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
just
last
year
started
selling
its
first
machine
that
could
run
in
both
Japanese
and
English
and
that
substantially
enhances
compatibility
with
its
American
products
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
may
take
five
years
to
break
even
in
Japan
,
''
says
John
A.
Siniscal
,
who
runs
the
Asia-Pacific
office
for
McCormack
&
Dodge
,
a
U.S.
software
company
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
it
's
an
enormous
business
opportunity
.
<END>
<START>
From
a
reading
of
the
somewhat
scant
English-language
medical
literature
on
RU-486
,
the
French
abortion
pill
emerges
as
one
of
the
creepiest
concoctions
around
.
<END>
<START>
By
contrast
,
surgical
abortion
is
99
%
effective
.
<END>
<START>
Abortion
via
the
pill
is
far
more
of
an
ordeal
than
conventional
surgical
abortion
.
<END>
<START>
Nausea
and
vomiting
are
other
common
side
effects
.
<END>
<START>
Timing
is
of
the
essence
with
RU-486
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
most
effective
taken
about
a
week
after
a
woman
misses
her
menstrual
period
up
through
the
seventh
week
of
pregnancy
,
when
it
is
markedly
less
effective
.
<END>
<START>
That
is
typically
about
a
three-week
window
.
<END>
<START>
So
far
,
all
the
studies
have
concluded
that
RU-486
is
``
safe
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
``
safe
,
''
in
the
definition
of
Marie
Bass
of
the
Reproductive
Health
Technologies
Project
,
means
``
there
's
been
no
evidence
so
far
of
mortality
.
''
<END>
<START>
No
one
has
researched
the
long-term
effects
of
RU-486
on
a
woman
's
health
or
fertility
.
<END>
<START>
The
drug
seems
to
suppress
ovulation
for
three
to
seven
months
after
it
is
taken
.
<END>
<START>
Some
women
clearly
have
no
trouble
eventually
conceiving
again
:
The
studies
have
reported
repeaters
in
their
programs
.
<END>
<START>
But
there
are
no
scientific
data
on
this
question
.
<END>
<START>
Rather
ominously
,
rabbit
studies
reveal
that
RU-486
can
cause
birth
defects
,
Lancet
,
the
British
medical
journal
,
reported
in
1987
.
<END>
<START>
All
the
published
studies
recommend
that
women
on
whom
the
drug
proves
ineffective
not
carry
the
pregnancy
to
term
but
undergo
a
surgical
abortion
.
<END>
<START>
A
risk
of
birth
defects
,
a
sure
source
of
lawsuits
,
is
one
reason
the
U.S.
pharmaceutical
industry
is
steering
clear
of
RU-486
.
<END>
<START>
One
might
well
ask
:
Why
bother
with
this
drug
at
all
?
<END>
<START>
Some
abortion
advocates
have
been
asking
themselves
this
very
question
.
<END>
<START>
Many
physicians
have
expressed
concern
over
the
heavy
bleeding
,
which
occurs
even
if
the
drug
fails
to
induce
an
abortion
.
<END>
<START>
The
Health
and
Human
Services
Department
currently
forbids
the
National
Institutes
of
Health
from
funding
abortion
research
as
part
of
its
$
8
million
contraceptive
program
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Its
scare-tactic
prediction
:
the
pill
``
will
be
available
in
the
U.S.
,
either
legally
or
illegally
,
in
no
more
than
2-5
years
.
''
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Following
the
feminist
and
population-control
lead
has
been
a
generally
bovine
press
.
<END>
<START>
A
June
1988
article
in
Mother
Jones
magazine
is
typical
of
the
general
level
of
media
ignorance
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
also
means
she
will
never
have
to
know
whether
she
had
actually
been
pregnant
.
''
<END>
<START>
Wrong
on
all
counts
,
Miss
Fraser
.
<END>
<START>
RU-486
is
being
administered
in
France
only
under
strict
supervision
in
the
presence
of
a
doctor
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Roussel
reportedly
has
every
pill
marked
and
accounted
for
to
make
sure
none
slips
into
the
black
market
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
No
doctor
who
fears
malpractice
liability
would
likely
expose
a
non-pregnant
patient
to
the
risk
of
hemorrhaging
.
<END>
<START>
Many
women
may
even
see
the
dead
embryo
they
have
expelled
,
a
sight
the
surgical-abortion
industry
typically
spares
them
.
<END>
<START>
At
seven
weeks
,
an
embryo
is
about
three-fourths
of
an
inch
long
and
recognizably
human
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
could
put
the
government
into
the
RU-486
business
,
which
would
please
feminists
dismayed
at
what
they
view
as
pusillanimity
in
the
private-sector
drug
industry
.
<END>
<START>
We
do
not
know
whether
RU-486
will
be
as
disastrous
as
some
of
the
earlier
fertility-control
methods
released
to
unblinking
,
uncritical
cheers
from
educated
people
who
should
have
known
better
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Remember
the
Dalkon
Shield
and
the
early
birth-control
pills
?
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Mrs.
Allen
is
a
senior
editor
of
Insight
magazine
.
<END>
<START>
This
article
is
adapted
from
one
in
the
October
American
Spectator
.
<END>
<START>
On
June
30
,
a
major
part
of
our
trade
deficit
went
poof
!
<END>
<START>
No
figure
juggling
;
no
witchcraft
;
just
vastly
improved
recording
of
some
of
our
exports
.
<END>
<START>
The
result
?
<END>
<START>
More
than
half
of
the
``
newly
found
''
net
exports
were
from
just
a
few
service-sector
categories
.
<END>
<START>
Some
of
the
biggest
service-industry
exporters
--
American
financial-service
companies
,
for
example
--
have
yet
to
be
fully
included
in
our
export
statistics
.
<END>
<START>
Nearly
10
years
ago
,
representatives
of
service-sector
companies
worked
out
a
plan
with
the
Commerce
Department
to
improve
the
data
on
service-sector
exports
.
<END>
<START>
The
monthly
``
trade
deficit
''
figure
is
limited
to
traditional
merchandise
trade
:

.

<START>
Wall
Street
continued
to
buckle
under
the
public
outcry
against
computer-driven
program
trading
.
<END>
<START>
The

,
a

,

``
livid
''

's

``
here

.
''
<END>
<START>
Many
investors
blame
program
trading
for
wild
swings
in
the
stock
market
,
including
the
190-point
plunge
in
the
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
on
Oct.
13
.
<END>
<START>
A
specialist
is
an
exchange
member
designated
to
maintain
a
fair
and
orderly
market
in
a
specified
stock
.
<END>
<START>
The
decision
by
Merrill
,
the
nation
's
largest
securities
firm
,
represents
the
biggest
retreat
yet
from
program
trading
.
<END>
<START>
Merrill
's
move
is
one
of
the
most
sweeping
program-trading
pullbacks
of
recent
days
,
because
the
big
securities
firm
will
no
longer
execute
stock-index
arbitrage
trades
for
customers
.
<END>
<START>
Most
Wall
Street
firms
,
in
pulling
back
,
have
merely
stopped
such
trading
for
their
own
accounts
.
<END>
<START>
Merrill
has
been
one
of
the
main
firms
executing
index
arbitrage
for
customers
.
<END>
<START>
Merrill
also
said
it
is
lobbying
for
significant
regulatory
controls
on
program
trading
,
including
tough
margin
--
or
down-payment
--
requirements
and
limits
on
price
moves
for
program-driven
financial
futures
.
<END>
<START>
In
stock-index
arbitrage
,
traders
buy
and
sell
large
amounts
of
stocks
with
offsetting
trades
in
stock-index
futures
and
options
.
<END>
<START>
The
idea
is
to
lock
in
profits
from
short-term
swings
in
volatile
markets
.
<END>
<START>
Last
Thursday
,
PaineWebber
Group
Inc.
also
said
it
would
cease
index
arbitrage
altogether
,
but
the
firm
was
n't
as
big
an
index
arbitrager
as
Merrill
is
.
<END>
<START>
Kidder
made

on

trading
yesterday
,
after
a

meeting
between
the
firm
's

and

,

.

.

.

<START>

Ford

.

.

<START>

<END>
<START>
Termination
means
that
the
agency
's
insurance
assumes
the
liabilities
and
pays
the
pension
benefits
already
owed
under
the
plans
,
but
workers
do
n't
accrue
new
benefits
.
<END>
<START>
A
few
months
later
,
under
pressure
from
the
United
Steelworkers
of
America
,
LTV
instituted
a
new
program
to
provide
retirement
benefits
similar
to
those
in
the
terminated
plans
.
<END>
<START>
Because
the
federal
pension
agency
had
taken
over
the
old
plans
,
LTV
would
be
responsible
only
for
benefits
paid
under
the
new
pension
plans
.
<END>
<START>
The
agency
also
concluded
that
LTV
's
financial
status
had
improved
while
it
was
under
reorganization
.
<END>
<START>
In
September
1987
,
it
ordered
LTV
to
reassume
liability
and
funding
for
the
three
original
plans
.
<END>
<START>
LTV
challenged
the
order
,
and
a
federal
district
court
in
New
York
in
June
1988
ruled
that
the
agency
improperly
ordered
LTV
to
reassume
responsibility
for
the
plans
.
<END>
<START>
In
May
,
a
federal
appeals
court
in
New
York
agreed
that
the
agency
acted
unlawfully
.
<END>
<START>
The
appeals
court
also
said
the
agency
had
to
consider
a
company
's
long-term
ability
to
fund
pension
plans
,
not
just
short-term
improved
financial
status
.
<END>
<START>
In
Dallas
,
LTV
said
that
it
was
disappointed
that
the
court
agreed
to
hear
the
case
because
it
believes
the
move
will
further
delay
its
Chapter
11
proceedings
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
has
n't
been
able
to
come
up
with
a
reorganization
plan
,
in
part
,
because
of
the
sizable
disagreement
with
the
pension
agency
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Pension
Benefit
Guaranty
Corp.
vs.
LTV
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
The
commercial
was
absolutely

.
<END>
<START>
Breaking
into

,

.
<END>
<START>
``
Due
to
the
earthquake
in
San
Francisco
,
Nissan
is
donating
its
commercial
air

to
broadcast
American

messages
.
<END>
<START>
Please
contribute
what
you
can
,
''
the
ad
said
.
<END>
<START>
Within
two
hours
,
viewers
pledged
over
$
400,000
,
according
to
a
Red
Cross
executive
.
<END>
<START>
Call
it
disaster
marketing
.
<END>
<START>
Nissan
Motor
is
just
one
of
a
slew
of
advertisers
that
have
hitched
their
ads
to
the
devastating
San
Francisco
quake
and
Hurricane
Hugo
.
<END>
<START>
Sometimes
,
the
ads
attempt
to
raise
money
;
always
,
they
try
to
boost
good
will
.
<END>
<START>
By
advertising
disaster
relief
,
these
companies
are
hoping
to
don
a
white
hat
and
come
out
a
hero
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
strategy
can
backfire
;
if
the
ads
appear
too
self-serving
,
the
companies
may
end
up
looking
like
rank
opportunists
instead
of
good
Samaritans
.
<END>
<START>
That
has
n't
deterred
plenty
of
companies
.
<END>
<START>
Along
with
Nissan
,
Grand
Metropolitan
PLC
's

King
and
New

Life
Insurance
have

to

Cross

.
<END>
<START>
``
What
did

out

?
<END>
<START>
We
got
some
exposure
...
and
pretty
much
good
will
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
ads
are
just
the
latest
evidence
of
how
television

is
getting
faster
on
the
draw
.
<END>
<START>
The
big
brokerage
houses
learned
the
art
of
the
instant
commercial
after
the
1987
crash
,
when
they
turned
out
reassuring
ads
inviting
investors
right
back

.
<END>
<START>

instant

after

a

.
<END>
<START>
Nissan
created
its

in

.
<END>
<START>
But

latch
onto

with

,

.
<END>
<START>

chance

.
<END>
<START>
``

.
''
<END>

.

,

<END>
<START>
``

.

.

<START>
Viacom

.
<END>
<START>
The
high
court
's
action
,
refusing
to
hear
appeals
by
several
drug
companies
,
is
likely
to
have
a
significant
impact
at
several
levels
.
<END>
<START>
The
lawsuits
stemmed
from
the
development
of
cancer
and
other
problems
in
the
daughters
of
women
who
took
the
drug
.
<END>
<START>
Paul
Rheingold
,
a
New
York
lawyer
who
represents
DES
victims
,
said
that
before
the
New
York
ruling
,
only
the
states
of
Washington
and
Wisconsin
had
followed
the
California
decision
.
<END>
<START>
Now
that
the
New
York
decision
has
been
left
intact
,
other
states
may
follow
suit
.
<END>
<START>
``
Generally
,
when
New
York
and
California
go
one
way
,
it
has
a
tremendous
influence
on
other
states
,
especially
small
ones
,
''
said
Mr.
Rheingold
.
<END>
<START>
The
appeals
involved
DES
,
which
was
approved
by
the
Food
and
Drug
Administration
for
use
from
the
1940s
until
1971
to
prevent
miscarriages
during
pregnancy
.
<END>
<START>
In
1971
,
the
FDA
banned
the
use
of
DES
after
studies
linked
it
to
cancer
and
other
problems
in
daughters
of
women
who
took
the
drug
.
<END>
<START>
Lawsuits
over
the
harm
caused
by
DES
have
flooded
federal
and
state
courts
in
the
past
decade
.
<END>
<START>
Under
traditional
legal
theories
,
inability
to
prove
which
company
manufactured
a
drug
that
caused
an
injury
or
death
would
lead
to
the
lawsuit
being
dismissed
.
<END>
<START>
Each
company
's
share
of
liability
would
be
based
on
their
share
of
the
national
DES
market
.
<END>
<START>
The
New
York
court
also
upheld
a
state
law
,
passed
in
1986
,
extending
for
one
year
the
statute
of
limitations
on
filing
DES
lawsuits
.
<END>
<START>
The
effect
is
that
lawsuits
that
might
have
been
barred
because
they
were
filed
too
late
could
proceed
because
of
the
one-year
extension
.
<END>

<START>
Unemployment
still

16.5
%
,

in

,

.

<START>

--

.
<END>
<START>
Large

of

still

.
<END>
<START>
The
left
also

of
the
Socialist

--

to

in

.
<END>
<START>

.

.
<END>
<START>

14

.
<END>
<START>

this

,

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Gonzalez
also

split
with
the
left
in

Spain
's

and

.

,

.

<START>

<START>
Cetus
Corp.
said
the
government
of
Spain
approved
the
marketing
of
its
Proleukin
interleukin-2
drug
to
treat
kidney
cancer
.
<END>
<START>
The
biotechnology
concern
said
Spanish
authorities
must
still
clear
the
price
for
the
treatment
,
but
that
it
expects
to
receive
such
approval
by
year
end
.
<END>
<START>
Four
other
countries
in
Europe
have
approved
Proleukin
in
recent
months
.
<END>
<START>
Cetus
is
currently
trying
to
obtain
federal
regulatory
clearance
for
U.S.
distribution
.
<END>
<START>
The
Treasury
is
still
working
out
the
details
with
bank
trade
associations
and
the
other
government
agencies
that
have
a
hand
in
fighting
money
laundering
.
<END>
<START>
Among
the
possibilities
the
Treasury
is
considering
are
requirements
that
banks
keep
records
identifying
the
originators
and
recipients
of
international
wire
transfers
.
<END>
<START>
Another
suggestion
would
draw
banks
more
directly
into
tracking
down
money
launderers
by
developing
a
``
suspicious
international
wire
transfer
profile
,
''
which
banks
would
use
to
spotlight
questionable
payments
.
<END>
<START>
But
banks
may
prefer
using
a
profile
that
targets
selected
transactions
,
rather
than
a
blanket
reporting
requirement
.
<END>
<START>
Banks
now
are
required
only
to
report
cash
deposits
or
withdrawals
of
$
10,000
or
more
.
<END>
<START>
But
wire
transfers
from
a
standing
account
--
including
those
bigger
than
$
10,000
--
are
n't
reported
.
<END>
<START>
Officials
believe
this
has
left
a
gaping
loophole
that
illegal
drug
businesses
are
exploiting
.
<END>
<START>
Authorities
estimate
that
revenues
from
illegal
drugs
in
the
U.S.
total
about
$
110
billion
annually
.
<END>
<START>
The
American
Bankers
Association
did
n't
have
any
comment
on
the
plan
.
<END>
<START>
The
proposal
now
enters
a
60-day
comment
period
,
after
which
the
Treasury
will
propose
final
regulations
,
followed
by
another
comment
period
.
<END>
<START>

$

,

$

,

.

.

.

<START>
Investors

.

,

.

.

.

3.23

<END>
<START>

100

,

0.47

.
<END>
<START>
Profit-taking
accounted
for
much

slide
in
OTC

,
according
to
David
Mills
,

.
<END>
<START>

,
whose

are

to

,
are
selling
now
rather

further
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
profit

is
definitely
going
on
,
''
said
Mr.
Mills
,
whose
firm
manages
$
600
million
for
Boston
Co
.
<END>
<START>
Tax-loss
sellers
,
those

who
sell

so

can

from
this

's

,

,

said
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
helping
put
pressure
on
both

's

and
its

.
<END>
<START>
``
The
stocks
that
have
been
the
best
are
having
big

,
and
the
ones
that
have
been
the

are

,
''

said
.
<END>
<START>
He
expects
the
market
to
sink
further
and
to

low

next
month
or

.
<END>
<START>
The
selling
by
money
managers
and

is
turning

bearish
as

.
<END>
<START>

,

,
Harris
Upham
,

.

.

,

.

.

<START>
Medical
scientists
are
starting
to
uncover
a
handful
of
genes
which
,
if
damaged
,
unleash
the
chaotic
growth
of
cells
that
characterizes
cancer
.
<END>
<START>
Scientists
say
the
discovery
of
these
genes
in
recent
months
is
painting
a
new
and
startling
picture
of
how
cancer
develops
.
<END>
<START>
An
emerging
understanding
of
the
genes
is
expected
to
produce
an
array
of
new
strategies
for
future
cancer
treatment
and
prevention
.
<END>
<START>
That
is
for
the
future
.
<END>
<START>
Already
,
scientists
are
developing
tests
based
on
the
newly
identified
genes
that
,
for
the
first
time
,
can
predict
whether
an
otherwise
healthy
individual
is
likely
to
get
cancer
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
a
super-exciting
set
of
discoveries
,
''
says
Bert
Vogelstein
,
a
Johns
Hopkins
University
researcher
who
has
just
found
a
gene
pivotal
to
the
triggering
of
colon
cancer
.
<END>
<START>
``
Only
a
decade
ago
cancer
was
a
black
box
about
which
we
knew
nothing
at
the
molecular
level
.
<END>
<START>
Today
,
we
know
that
the
accumulation
of
several
of
these
altered
genes
can
initiate
a
cancer
and
,
then
,
propel
it
into
a
deadly
state
.
''
<END>
<START>
Scientists
call
the
new
class
of
genes
tumor-suppressors
,
or
simply
anti-cancer
genes
.
<END>
<START>
When
functioning
normally
,
they
make
proteins
that
hold
a
cell
's
growth
in
check
.
<END>
<START>
The
newly
identified
genes
differ
from
a
family
of
genes
discovered
in
the
early
1980s
called
oncogenes
.
<END>
<START>
Like
all
genes
,
tumor-suppressor
genes
are
inherited
in
two
copies
,
one
from
each
parent
.
<END>
<START>
Either
copy
can
make
the
proteins
needed
to
control
cell
growth
,
so
for
cancer
to
arise
,
both
copies
must
be
impaired
.
<END>
<START>
Emerging
genetic
tests
will
be
able
to
spot
such
cancer-susceptible
individuals
,
ushering
in
what
some
scientists
believe
is
a
new
age
of
predictive
cancer
diagnosis
.
<END>
<START>
Bill
and
Bonnie
Quinlan
are
among
the
first
beneficiaries
of
the
new
findings
.
<END>
<START>
Because
of
the
isolation
of
the
retinoblastoma
tumor-suppressor
gene
,
it
became
possible
last
January
to
find
out
what
threat
the
Quinlan
baby
faced
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
made
our
New
Year
,
''
says
Mr.
Quinlan
.
<END>
<START>
This
test
was
the
first
to
predict
reliably
whether
an
individual
could
expect
to
develop
cancer
.
<END>
<START>
To
date
,
scientists
have
fingered
two
of
these
cancer-suppressors
.
<END>
<START>
Dr.
Dryja
made
his
retinoblastoma
discovery
in
1986
.
<END>
<START>
Then
last
spring
,
researchers
reported
finding
a
gene
called
p53
which
,
if
impaired
,
turns
healthy
colon
cells
cancerous
.
<END>
<START>
Soon
after
that
report
,
two
other
research
teams
uncovered
evidence
that
the
same
damaged
p53
gene
is
present
in
tissue
from
lung
and
breast
cancers
.
<END>
<START>
Colon
,
lung
and
breast
cancers
are
the
most
common
and
lethal
forms
of
the
disease
,
collectively
killing
almost
200,000
Americans
a
year
.
<END>
<START>
Right
now
about
a
dozen
laboratories
,
in
the
U.S.
,
Canada
and
Britain
,
are
racing
to
unmask
other
suspected
tumor-suppressing
genes
.
<END>
<START>
They
have
about
seven
candidates
.
<END>
<START>
The
story
of
tumor-suppressor
genes
goes
back
to
the
1970s
,
when
a
pediatrician
named
Alfred
G.
Knudson
Jr.
proposed
that
retinoblastoma
stemmed
from
two
separate
genetic
defects
.
<END>
<START>
He
theorized
that
in
the
eye
cancer
,
an
infant
inherited
a
damaged
copy
of
a
gene
from
one
parent
and
a
normal
copy
from
the
other
.
<END>
<START>
The
tumor
,
he
suggested
,
developed
when
the
second
,
normal
copy
also
was
damaged
.
<END>
<START>
But
there
was
no
way
to
prove
Dr.
Knudson
's
``
two-hit
''
theory
.
<END>
<START>
Back
then
,
scientists
had
no
way
of
ferreting
out
specific
genes
,
but
under
a
microscope
they
could
see
the
23
pairs
of
chromosomes
in
the
cells
that
contain
the
genes
.
<END>
<START>
Occasionally
,
gross
chromosome
damage
was
visible
.
<END>
<START>
Dr.
Knudson
found
that
some
children
with
the
eye
cancer
had
inherited
a
damaged
copy
of
chromosome
No.
13
from
a
parent
who
had
had
the
disease
.
<END>
<START>
Under
a
microscope
he
could
actually
see
that
a
bit
of
chromosome
13
was
missing
.
<END>
<START>
He
assumed
the
missing
piece
contained
a
gene
or
genes
whose
loss
had
a
critical
role
in
setting
off
the
cancer
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
did
n't
know
which
gene
or
genes
had
disappeared
.
<END>
<START>
Then
,
a
scientific
team
led
by
molecular
geneticist
Webster
Cavenee
,
then
at
the
University
of
Utah
,
found
the
answer
.
<END>
<START>
The
team
used
a
battery
of
the
newly
developed
``
gene
probes
,
''
snippets
of
genetic
material
that
can
track
a
gene
's
presence
in
a
cell
.
<END>
<START>
By
analyzing
cells
extracted
from
eye
tumors
,
they
found
defects
in
the
second
copy
of
chromosome
13
in
the
exact
area
as
in
the
first
copy
of
the
chromosome
.
<END>
<START>
The
finding
riveted
medicine
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
the
first
time
anyone
had
showed
that
the
loss
of
both
copies
of
the
same
gene
could
lead
to
the
eruption
of
a
cancer
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
was
extraordinarily
satisfying
,
''
says
Dr.
Knudson
,
now
at
Fox
Chase
Cancer
Research
Center
in
Philadelphia
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
was
convinced
that
what
was
true
of
retinoblastoma
would
be
true
for
all
cancers
.
''
<END>
<START>
It
was
an
audacious
claim
.
<END>
<START>
His
was
one
of
two
research
teams
in
1984
to
report
dual
chromosome
losses
for
a
rare
childhood
cancer
of
the
kidney
called
Wilm
's
tumor
.
<END>
<START>
Dr.
Vogelstein
next
turned
his
attention
to
colon
cancer
,
the
second
biggest
cancer
killer
in
the
U.S.
after
lung
cancer
.
<END>
<START>
He
believed
colon
cancer
might
also
arise
from
multiple
``
hits
''
on
cancer
suppressor
genes
,
because
it
often
seems
to
develop
in
stages
.
<END>
<START>
Dr.
Vogelstein
and
a
doctoral
student
,
Eric
Fearon
,
began
months
of
tedious
and
often
frustrating
probing
of
the
chromosomes
searching
for
signs
of
genetic
damage
.
<END>
<START>
They
began
uncovering
a
confusing
variety
of
genetic
deletions
,
some
existing
only
in
benign
polyps
,
others
in
malignant
cells
and
many
in
both
polyps
and
malignant
cells
.
<END>
<START>
Gradually
,
a
coherent
picture
of
cancer
development
emerged
.
<END>
<START>
If
both
copies
of
a
certain
gene
were
knocked
out
,
benign
polyps
would
develop
.
<END>
<START>
If
both
copies
of
a
second
gene
were
then
deleted
,
the
polyps
would
progress
to
malignancy
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
clear
that
more
than
one
gene
had
to
be
damaged
for
colon
cancer
to
develop
.
<END>
<START>
Their
report
galvanized
other
molecular
biologists
.
<END>
<START>
But
Dr.
Vogelstein
had
yet
to
nail
the
identity
of
the
gene
that
,
if
damaged
,
flipped
a
colon
cell
into
full-blown
malignancy
.
<END>
<START>
They
focused
on
chromosome
17
.
<END>
<START>
Such
a
piece
of
DNA
would
probably
constitute
a
gene
.
<END>
<START>
When
they
found
it
last
winter
,
Dr.
Vogelstein
was
dubious
that
the
search
was
over
.
<END>
<START>
The
deletion
Dr.
Vogelstein
found
was
in
exactly
the
same
spot
as
p53
.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Levine
had
said
the
p53
gene
caused
cancer
by
promoting
growth
,
whereas
the
Johns
Hopkins
scientists
were
looking
for
a
gene
that
suppressed
growth
.
<END>
<START>
Evidence
now
is
emerging
that
the
p53
suppressor
gene
is
involved
in
other
cancers
,
too
.
<END>
<START>
Researchers
in
Edinburgh
,
Scotland
,
have
found
that
in
23
of
38
breast
tumors
,
one
copy
of
chromosome
17
was
mutated
at
the
spot
where
gene
p53
lies
.
<END>
<START>
The
scientists
say
that
since
breast
cancer
often
strikes
multiple
members
of
certain
families
,
the
gene
,
when
inherited
in
a
damaged
form
,
may
predispose
women
to
the
cancer
.
<END>
<START>
The
p53
gene
has
just
been
implicated
in
lung
cancer
.
<END>
<START>
There
also
are
reports
from
several
labs
,
as
yet
unpublished
,
of
missing
p53
genes
in
tissue
taken
from
kidney
,
brain
and
skin
cancers
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
same
time
,
the
Johns
Hopkins
team
and
others
are
rushing
to
pinpoint
other
tumor-suppressor
genes
.
<END>
<START>
Dr.
Vogelstein
hopes
soon
to
isolate
one
on
chromosome
18
,
also
involved
in
colon
cancer
.
<END>
<START>
Dr.
Minna
believes
people
who
inherit
a
defective
gene
somewhere
on
one
of
their
two
copies
of
chromosome
3
are
especially
prone
to
lung
cancer
.
<END>
<START>
Recently
,
he
and
others
reported
that
the
retinoblastoma
suppressor
gene
may
also
be
involved
in
some
lung
cancers
,
as
well
as
several
other
more
common
cancers
,
too
.
<END>
<START>
Where
these
discoveries
will
lead
,
scientists
can
only
speculate
.
<END>
<START>
Some
researchers
say
new
cancer
drugs
to
slow
or
reverse
tumor
growth
may
be
based
on
the
suppressor
proteins
normally
produced
by
the
genes
.
<END>
<START>
The
idea
would
be
to
administer
to
patients
the
growth-controlling
proteins
made
by
healthy
versions
of
the
damaged
genes
.
<END>
<START>
It
may
even
be
possible
to
replace
defective
genes
with
healthy
versions
,
though
no
one
has
come
close
to
doing
that
so
far
.
<END>
<START>
In
any
case
,
says
Dr.
Minna
of
the
National
Cancer
Institute
,
``
We
're
witnessing
the
discovery
of
one
of
the
most
important
steps
in
the
genesis
of
cancer
.
<END>
<START>
Many
investors
give
Michael
Foods
about
as
much
chance
of
getting
it
together
as
Humpty
Dumpty
.
<END>
<START>
But
now
at
least
there
's
a
glimmer
of
hope
for
the
stock
.
<END>
<START>
Burger
King
,
which
breaks

each

,
is

over
to
an
alternative

product

Michael
Foods
.
<END>
<START>
Known

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

.

<START>
Michael
wo
n't

,

.

<START>
Two

``

.
''

.

,

The

.

<END>
<START>

,

.

<START>

.

<START>

,

<START>
Many

<START>

<START>
-LRB-
The

.
<END>
<START>
A

.

<START>

<START>

<START>

.

Last

<START>

.

<END>
<START>
Michael
late

.
<END>
<START>
Michael
,

,

<START>
Pierre

,

there
.
<END>
<START>
The
purchase
,
expected
to
be
completed
by
year
end
,
will
make
Quebecor
the
second-largest
commercial
printer
in
North
America
,
behind
only
R.R.
Donnelley
&
Sons
Co.
,
Chicago
.
<END>
<START>
The
printing
customers
that
Quebecor
will
gain
through
Maxwell
Graphics
include
the
Sunday
newspaper
supplement
Parade
,
Time
,
Sports
Illustrated
and
TV
Guide
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
say
Quebecor
's
purchase
is
part
of
a
trend
toward
consolidation
in
the
North
American
printing
industry
.
<END>
<START>
Along
with
Donnelley
,
says
Jacques
Massicotte
,
an
analyst
with
Nesbitt
Thomson
Deacon
Inc.
in
Montreal
,
``
Quebecor
has
positioned
itself
as
one
of
the
two
key
players
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
adds
:
``
I
think
this
is
a
great
strategic
move
for
Quebecor
.
<END>
<START>
They
are
buying
an
operation
that
is
running
well
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Peladeau
says
he
is
n't
trying
to
catch
up
to
Donnelley
,
which
has
annual
sales
of
over
$
3
billion
.
<END>
<START>
``
Size
does
n't
matter
,
''
Mr.
Peladeau
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
What
counts
is
the
bottom
line
.
''
<END>
<START>
Some

Mr.
Peladeau
's
ventures
,
including
an
earlier
push
into
the
U.S.
market
,
have
n't

off
on
the
bottom
line
.
<END>
<START>
Quebecor
started
the
Philadelphia
Journal
,
a
daily
tabloid
,
in
1977
and
closed
it
three
years
later
.
<END>
<START>
The
venture
cost
Quebecor
$
12
million
,
Mr.
Peladeau
says
.
<END>
<START>
More
recently
,
some
former
Quebecor
executives
started
their
own
printing
company
,
specializing
in
printing
and
distributing
advertising
circulars
.
<END>
<START>
Quebecor
still
lags
in
the
Quebec
circulars
market
,
while
Mr.
Peladeau
's
former
employees
are
expanding
across
Canada
.
<END>
<START>
The
tabloid
's
circulation
soared
to
80,000
,
but
plunged
to
under
10,000
when
the
La
Presse
strike
ended
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
Mr.
Peladeau
stuck
with
the
venture
.
<END>
<START>
Now
the
Journal
,
flush
with
ads
and

,
is
even
with
La
Presse
in
weekend

and
outsells
it
3
to
2
every

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Peladeau
has
never
made
any
apologies
for
publishing
the
tabloid
,
a
brash
mix
of
crime
and
sports
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
've
read
Balzac
,
''
he
answers

.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
tabloid
news
from
A
to
Z
.
''
<END>
<START>
A
series
of
recent
acquisitions
made
it
the
dominant
magazine
publisher
in
Quebec
.
<END>
<START>
After
a
recent

,
it
is
also
the
only

of
magazines
and

in
Quebec
.
<END>
<START>
Finally
,
with
Maxwell
Communication
,
the

controls
54

of

Inc.
,

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

will

's

and
Maxwell

.
<END>
<START>

61

from

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>

.

.

,

.

,
