<START>
The
U.S.
Equal
Employment
Opportunity
Commission
sued
New
York
state
for
age
discrimination
against
appointed
state
judges
.
<END>
<START>
The
suit
,
filed
in
federal
court
in
Manhattan
,
charges
that
New
York
's
mandatory
retirement
age
of
76
violates
federal
law
.
<END>
<START>
Separately
,
the
commission
intervened
in
a
Connecticut
state
judge
's
age-bias
suit
in
federal
court
in
New
Haven
.
<END>
<START>
The
commission
's
filing
in
that
case
challenges
Connecticut
's
mandatory
retirement
age
of
70
for
appointed
judges
.
<END>
<START>
Justice
Rubin
,
a
state
judge
since
1969
,
said
the
mandatory-retirement
age
hurts
the
court
system
because
it
deprives
the
state
of
experienced
judges
still
capable
of
serving
on
the
bench
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
issue
is
n't
age
--
age
is
just
a
number
.
<END>
<START>
The
issue
is
one
of
a
judge
's
experience
,
his
competence
and
his
physical
ability
to
serve
on
the
bench
,
''
Justice
Rubin
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
've
had
no
problems
performing
my
duties
and
responsibilities
.
''
<END>
<START>
Because
Justice
Rubin
turned
76
on
May
9
,
he
is
n't
eligible
to
be
reappointed
to
the
bench
at
the
end
of
the
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
suit
's
impact
on
New
York
may
be
narrow
,
however
.
<END>
<START>
Most
New
York
judges
are
elected
,
and
the
federal
age-discrimination
law
does
n't
apply
to
elected
officials
,
said
James
L.
Lee
,
regional
attorney
for
the
EEOC
in
New
York
.
<END>
<START>
Under
New
York
law
,
elected
judges
must
retire
at
age
70
,
but
then
can
be
appointed
to
two-year
terms
until
they
reach
76
.
<END>
<START>
A
spokeswoman
for
the
state
's
Office
of
Court
Administration
declined
to
comment
on
the
suit
.
<END>
<START>
But
she
said
the
state
currently
has
35
appointed
judges
who
are
over
70
.
<END>
<START>
In
Connecticut
,
however
,
most
state
judges
are
appointed
by
the
governor
and
approved
by
the
state
legislature
.
<END>
<START>
The
parties
in
the
Connecticut
case
have
agreed
to
stay
proceedings
pending
the
appeal
of
another
EEOC
age-bias
case
against
Vermont
.
<END>
<START>
Aaron
Ment
,
Connecticut
's
chief
court
administrator
,
declined
to
comment
on
the
suit
and
the
EEOC
's
intervention
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
the
state
has
165
appointed
judges
and
15
``
trial
referees
,
''
who
are
former
judges
over
age
70
and
serve
a
restricted
role
on
the
bench
.
<END>
<START>
ORGANIZED
CRIME
Strike
Forces
likely
to
be
abolished
next
month
.
<END>
<START>
The
units
are
autonomous
from
U.S.
attorneys
'
offices
and
focus
exclusively
on
prosecuting
organized-crime
cases
.
<END>
<START>
In
February
,
Mr.
Thornburgh
announced
his
plan
to
abolish
the
units
.
<END>
<START>
He
says
the
strike-force
lawyers
will
work
more
efficiently
under
the
supervision
of
U.S.
attorneys
.
<END>
<START>
The
bill
is
expected
to
pass
in
Congress
next
month
.
<END>
<START>
Congress
temporarily
halted
Mr.
Thornburgh
's
effort
with
an
appropriation
resolution
that
prohibited
him
from
using
budgeted
funds
to
implement
his
plan
.
<END>
<START>
Opponents
say
Mr.
Thornburgh
's
plan
will
needlessly
break
up
longtime
,
tightly
knit
crime-fighting
units
that
have
successfully
prosecuted
major
organized-crime
figures
.
<END>
<START>
They
predict
that
organized-crime
activity
will
increase
once
the
units
are
dissolved
and
their
responsibilities
transferred
to
U.S.
attorneys
'
offices
.
<END>
<START>
Some
former
strike-force
personnel
say
the
units
have
already
begun
to
break
up
.
<END>
<START>
``
Those
who
have
left
have
expressed
an
opinion
that
the
strike
force
should
continue
,
''
Ms.
Brevetti
says
.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Runkel
contends
there
has
been
no
exodus
of
strike-force
lawyers
.
<END>
<START>
He
says
27
lawyers
have
left
and
21
have
been
hired
since
Mr.
Thornburgh
announced
his
plan
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
time
the
plan
was
announced
,
there
were
135
lawyers
.
<END>
<START>
Some
congressional
leaders
intend
to
continue
to
fight
for
independent
strike
forces
.
<END>
<START>
Among
other
things
,
the
bill
calls
for
a
reorganization
of
the
Justice
Department
.
<END>
<START>
The
Senate
is
expected
to
consider
the
bill
shortly
,
says
the
senator
's
spokesman
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Runkel
says
he
doubts
Mr.
Kennedy
can
muster
enough
congressional
support
to
reorganize
the
Justice
Department
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
will
vigorously
oppose
the
bill
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
do
n't
think
-LRB-
the
reorganization
is
-RRB-
going
to
happen
.
''

Boeing

,

,

,

.

.

,

at

$

,

<END>
<START>

.

.

.

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

``

,
''

.

.

.

.

French
merchant
bank
that
Deutsche
Bank
had
looked
at
and
passed
over
.
<END>
<START>

had

in
Credit
Lyonnais
,
until
the
Socialists
returned
to
government
last

and

to

the
large
French
bank
.
<END>
<START>
Deutsche
Bank
has
actively
sought
a
French

for
at
least

years
.
<END>
<START>
Lately
,

say
,

has

in
the
French

community
by
indicating
it
wants
a

with

.
<END>
<START>
``

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
``

not

,

.
''

.

.

.

with

of

of
1990
.
<END>

early

.
<END>
<START>

to

,

.

.
<END>
<START>

,

300

.

.

.

.

,

.

<START>
Cray
Research
Inc.
won
government
clearance
for
its
proposed
reorganization
of
founder
Seymour
Cray
's
supercomputer
design
team
into
a
separate
company
.
<END>
<START>
Internal
Revenue
Service
approval
of
the
move
as
a
tax-free
transaction
was
the
last
hurdle
to
splitting
up
the
world
's
dominant
maker
of
supercomputers
,
which
Mr.
Cray
founded
in
1974
.
<END>
<START>
Cray
's
directors
set
Nov.
15
as
the
record
date
for
distribution
of
shares
in
the
new
company
,
to
be
called
Cray
Computer
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
It
will
trade
over
the
counter
under
the
symbol
CRAY
.
<END>
<START>
The
plan
calls
for
Cray
Research
holders
to
receive
one
share
in
the
new
company
for
every
two
shares
held
.
<END>
<START>
An
estimated
14.7
million
Cray
Computer
shares
will
be
distributed
,
Cray
Research
said
.
<END>
<START>
Cray
Research
will
retain
a
10
%
interest
in
the
new
company
,
which
will
be
based
in
Colorado
Springs
,
Colo
.
<END>
<START>
When
it
announced
the
planned
breakup
in
May
,
Cray
Research
said
development
costs
of
several
competing
projects
were
squeezing
its
earnings
growth
.
<END>
<START>
After
the
split
,
the
two
companies
presumably
will
be
rivals
for
orders
from
government
and
commercial
customers
.
<END>
<START>
Chairman
Carl
L.
Bixby
said
the
decline
occurred
although
revenue
rose
30
%
to
more
than
$
8.3
million
from
$
6.4
million
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
,
which
makes
computer
parts
said
fiscal
1989
earnings
were
``
down
slightly
''
from
$
3.2
million
,
or
74
cents
a
share
,
in
fiscal
l988
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
fiscal
1989
revenue
increased
about
30
%
to
more
than
$
32
million
from
$
25.3
million
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bixby
said
that
early
signs
point
to
improved

and
revenue
in
the
first
quarter
of
fiscal
1990
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
current
backlog
of
orders
is
strong
throughout
the
corporation
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Priam
Corp.
said

filed
for
protection
under

11
of

Code
and
announced
a
35
%

in

world-wide

.
<END>
<START>
The

in

court
here
follows
a

of
quarterly

and

for
the
maker
of

for

.
<END>

7
,

,

.
<END>
<START>

13
%
to

122.7

.
<END>
<START>
The
200-person

cutback
announced

will
bring

's

to
about
380
workers
,
less
than

of
what

before

,

in

.
<END>
<START>

.

,

,

about

.

hinted
over

.

,

.

.

,

,

to
reduce

.
<END>
<START>
Japanese
companies
have
long
been
accused
of
sacrificing
profit
to
boost
sales
.
<END>
<START>
But
Fujitsu
Ltd.
has
taken
that
practice
to
a
new
extreme
.
<END>
<START>
Japan
's
biggest
computer
maker
last
week
undercut
seven
competitors
to
win
a
contract
to
design
a
mapping
system
for
the
city
of
Hiroshima
's
waterworks
.
<END>
<START>
Its
bid
:
one
yen
,
or
less
than
a
U.S.
penny
.
<END>
<START>
The
bid
created
such
a
furor
that
Fujitsu
said
it
is
now
offering
to
withdraw
from
the
project
.
<END>
<START>
``
From
a
common-sense
viewpoint
,
it
was
not
socially
acceptable
,
''
a
Fujitsu
spokeswoman
said
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
Hiroshima
city
officials
could
n't
be
reached
to
find
out
whether
they
would
drop
Fujitsu
's
bid
.
<END>
<START>
Fujitsu
said
it
issued
the
low
bid
because
it
wanted
a
foot
in
the
door
of
a
potentially
lucrative
market
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
desperately
wanted
the
contract
because
we
want
experience
in
the
field
,
''
the
Fujitsu
spokeswoman
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
expect
a
big
market
in
the
future
,
so
in
the
long
term
it
will
be
profitable
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
a
kind
of
an
investment
.
''
<END>
<START>
Hiroshima
's
waterworks
bureau
said
the
municipal
government
had
budgeted
about
11
million
yen
-LRB-
$
77,500
-RRB-
for
the
project
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
was
flabbergasted
,
''
Tatsuhara
Yamane
,
head
of
the
bureau
,
was
quoted
by
Kyodo
news
service
as
saying
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
understand
the
firm
's
enthusiasm
in
getting
the
deal
,
but
such
a
large
company
would
have
been
better
off
showing
a
little
more
discretion
.
''
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
Fujitsu
officials
admitted
they
may
have
been
a
little
overzealous
.
<END>
<START>
The
Fujitsu
spokeswoman
said
headquarter
officials
did
n't
approve
the
bid
in
advance
and
will
take
measures
so
this
kind
of
thing
does
n't
happen
in
the
future
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
contrary
to
common
sense
,
''
she
added
.
<END>
<START>
Specifically
,
Fujitsu
won
the
right
to
design
the
specifications
for
a
computerized
system
that
will
show
water
lines
throughout
the
city
.
<END>
<START>
The
system
could
be
used
in
a
fire
or
earthquake
to
locate
problems
,
among
other
things
.
<END>
<START>
A

official
said
Fujitsu
will
have
to
design
the
system
so
it
would
be
compatible
with
other
makers
'
equipment
.
<END>
<START>
But
industry
officials
expressed
concern
that
the
initial
project
might
give
Fujitsu
an
edge
in
winning
more
lucrative
contracts
later
.
<END>
<START>
Fujitsu
said
it
hopes
the
Hiroshima
contract
will
help
it
secure
pacts
with
other
municipalities
.
<END>
<START>
Japanese
local
governments
are
expected
to
invest
heavily
in
computer
systems
over
the
next
few
years
,
and
many
companies
expect
that
field
to
provide

.
<END>
<START>
``

,

will

market
,
not

,

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
``
We
can
expect
a
hundreds-of-billions-of-yen
market
.
''
<END>
<START>
No
foreign
companies
bid
on
the
Hiroshima
project
,
according
to
the
bureau
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
Japanese
practice
of
deep
discounting
often
is
cited
by
Americans
as
a

to
entry

's

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>

.
<END>

,

.
<END>
<START>

10
million
yen
to
29

.

.

.

.

<START>
Georgia-Pacific
Corp.
offered
to
acquire
Great
Northern
Nekoosa
Corp.
for
$
58
a
share
,

$
3.18
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The

capped

of

that
Georgia-Pacific
,
an
Atlanta-based

company
,
was
considering

for

,

concern
based
in
Norwalk
,

.
<END>
<START>
Executives
at
Nekoosa
could
n't
be
reached
,
and

at
Georgia
Pacific
declined
to
comment
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
,
however
,
were

because
the
tender
offer
appeared

.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
quite
a
bombshell
,
''
said
one
,
adding
that
the
offer
could
spark
a
period
of
industry

.
<END>
<START>
Nekoosa
closed
yesterday
at
$
42.75
,
up
$
2.75
,
in
New
York
Stock
Exchange
composite
trading
.
<END>
<START>
But
industry
observers
still
questioned
whether
Georgia
Pacific
will
ultimately
prevail
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
have
to
watch
out
for
counterbids
,
''
said
one
analyst
.
``
<END>
<START>
International
Paper
or
Weyerhaeuser
could
step
in
.
''
<END>
<START>
While
Georgia-Pacific
's
stock
has
outperformed
the
market
in
the
past
two
years
,
Nekoosa
has
lagged
the
market
in
the
same
period
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
's
rise
in
Nekoosa
's
share
price
came
on
volume
of
786,700
shares
,
four
times
the
daily
average
.
<END>
<START>
According

the
Value
Line
Investment
Survey
,
demand
for
Nekoosa
's
commodity
paper
has
weakened
,
prompting
earnings
to
decline
by
6.6
%
in
the
third
quarter
ended
Sept.
30
.
<END>
<START>
Value
Line
added
,
``
With
discounts
widening
on
business
papers
,
and
with
newsprint
and
corrugated
shipments
flat
,
we
expect
negative
earnings
comparisons
through
next
year
.
''
<END>
<START>
Also
,
it
is
n't
exposed
to
the
weakening
newsprint
business
,
and
is
strong
in
the
less-cyclical
tissue
business
.
<END>
<START>
The

of
Nekoosa
would
easily
eclipse

's
$
530
million

of
Brunswick

&

Co.
last

.
<END>

Wasserstein

&
Co.
is

for
the
offer
,
which
will

Nov.
29
,

.

<START>

.
<END>

,

's

,

.

,

.
<END>
<START>
He
could
not

.
<END>
<START>

,

's

,

Corp
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lorenzo
,

,

was

before
Mr.
Corr
signed
on
.
<END>
<START>
The

also
named
Mickey
Foret
as

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Foret
,
44
,
is
a
15-year
veteran
of
Texas
Air
and
Texas
International
Airlines
,
its
predecessor
.
<END>
<START>

for

and

at

Air
.
<END>
<START>
Top

at

have

lasted
long
,

those
recruited
from
outside
.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Corr
's
tenure
was
shorter
than
most
.
<END>
<START>
The
48-year-old
Mr.
Corr
was
hired
largely
because
he
was
credited
with
returning
Trans
World
Airlines
Inc.
to
profitability
while
he
was

from
1986
to
1988
.
<END>
<START>
Before
that
,

was

with
a

.
<END>
<START>
At
Continental
he
cut

,
which
helped
produce
a
modest

in
this
year
's

.
<END>
<START>
But

Corr
,

in

,
was

to
be

by
what

as
limited

under
Mr.
Lorenzo
.
<END>
<START>
While

at
Continental
during

Corr
's

,

Lorenzo
is
known
for

on
Texas

's

.
<END>
<START>
Continental
is
Texas

's

under

Lorenzo

.
<END>
<START>
It

role
,

,

's

of

.

<END>
<START>
It
is
a
peaceful
time
in
this
part
of
western
India
.
<END>
<START>
The
summer
crop
is
harvested
,
winter
sowing
has
yet
to
begin
.
<END>
<START>
Farmers
in
loose
turbans
and
fancy
earrings
spend
their
afternoons
laughing
and
gossiping
at
the
markets
.
<END>
<START>
One
could
imagine
such
a
lull
in
the
lives
of
the
Arabs
before
the
quadrupling
of
oil
prices
.
<END>
<START>
For
just
as
the
Arabs
were
in
the
1960s
,
the
farmers
of
Sidhpur
are
on
the
brink
of
global
power
and
fame
.
<END>
<START>
The
Arabs
had
merely
oil
.
<END>
<START>
These
farmers
may
have
a
grip
on
the
world
's
very
heart
.
<END>
<START>
Or
,
at
least
,
its
heart
disease
.
<END>
<START>
Ever
since
the
link
to
cholesterol
was
disclosed
,
Americans
have
begun
scarfing
up
psyllium
in
their
breakfast
cereals
.
<END>
<START>
If
further
research
proves
the
seed
's
benefits
,
this
dusty
farm
district
could
become
the
epicenter
of
a
health-food
fad
to
rival
all
fads
since
cod-liver
oil
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
proper
climatic
conditions
do
n't
exist
in
many
places
in
the
world
.
''
<END>
<START>
Arvind
Patel
,
a
processor
and
exporter
of
the
seed
,
raves
:
``
If
psyllium
takes
the
place
of
oat
bran
,
it
will
be
huge
.
''
<END>
<START>
Whether
psyllium
makes
Sidhpur
's
fortune
depends
on
cholesterol-fearing
Americans
,
the
U.S.
Food
and
Drug
Administration
and
,
of
course
,
the
outcome
of
further
research
.
<END>
<START>
Only
one
thing
is
certain
here
:
Pysllium
is
likely
to
remain
solely
an
export
item
from
Sidhpur
for
a
long
time
.
<END>
<START>
Local
farmers
say
it
is
as
good
a
cash
crop
as
mustard
or
fenugreek
,
a
legume
.
<END>
<START>
Psyllium
is
an
annual
herb
,
Plantago
ovata
,
that
has
been
used
for
centuries
by
folk
doctors
here
,
mainly
as
a
laxative
and
anti-diarrheal
.
<END>
<START>
As
such
,
the
soluble
fiber
has
an
almost
fanatic
following
in
northern
India
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
can
assure
you
,
''
attests
a
25-year-old
lawyer
in
New
Delhi
,
with
a
meaningfully
raised
eyebrow
,
``
from
personal
experience
,
it
works
.
''
<END>
<START>
A
prominent
businessman
in
Bombay
gives
a
similar
testimonial
:
``
I
have
been
taking
it
daily
since
1961
.
<END>
<START>
''
Folk
doctors
also
prescribe
it
for
kidney
,
bladder
and
urethra
problems
,
duodenal
ulcers
and
hemorrhoids
.
<END>
<START>
Some
apply
it
to
gouty
joints
.
<END>
<START>
The
plant
has
a
hairy
stem
that
produces
flowers
and
diminutive
seeds
.
<END>
<START>
The
transluscent
husk
of
the
seed
is
removed
,
sifted
and
crushed
;
the
seed
itself
is
fed
to
animals
.
<END>
<START>
Some
90
%
of
the
crop
,
which
was
worth
$
26
million
last
year
,
is
exported
.
<END>
<START>
But
some
time
ago
,
researchers
discovered
that
soluble
fibers
also
lower
cholesterol
levels
in
the
blood
.
<END>
<START>
Cincinnati-based
P&G
took
an
interest
;
it
ordered
two
studies
on
psyllium
and
cholesterol
.
<END>
<START>
One
of
the
studies
,
done
at
the
University
of
Minnesota
,
tested
75
people
with
raised
cholesterol
levels
.
<END>
<START>
In
late
1987
,
P&G
asked
the
FDA
for
approval
to
market
Metamucil
as
the
first
non-prescription
,
cholesterol-lowering
product
in
the
<END>
<START>
In
April
,
the
psyllium
bandwagon
got
more
crowded
.
<END>
<START>
In
September
,
Kellogg
Co.
launched
a
competing
psyllium-fortified
cereal
called
Heartwise
.
<END>
<START>
Suddenly
,
on
television
,
in
advertisements
and
on
their
cereal
boxes
,
Americans
were
inundated
with
news
about
the
obscure
seed
.
<END>
<START>
The
flood
of
claims
and
counter-claims
worried
consumers
and
actually
hurt
sales
of
the
new
cereals
.
<END>
<START>
This
month
,
the
Food
and
Drug
Administration
expressed
concern
that
Americans
might
someday
,
in
various
forms
,
ingest
too
much
psyllium
.
<END>
<START>
Currently
,
there
is
a
lull
in
the
psyllium
war
.
<END>
<START>
The
FDA
has
asked
Kellogg
and
General
Mills
to
show
research
that
their
cereals
are
safe
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
ordered
P&G
to
produce
more
studies
to
buttress
its
claims
that
Metamucil
can
lower
cholesterol
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
agency
has
n't
yanked
psyllium
off
store
shelves
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
FDA
approves
the
new
uses
of
psyllium
,
other
companies
are
expected
to
rush
to
market
with
psyllium
products
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
going
to
be
a
sensational
thing
,
''
says
Mr.
Krishnamurthy
of
P&G
in
Bombay
.
<END>
<START>
Says
psyllium

Mr.
Patel
:
``
I
just
got
back
yesterday
from
the
U.S.
.
<END>
<START>
In

,

,
psyllium
is
everywhere
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
the
news
of
the
boom
has
yet

down
to

.
<END>
<START>
``
Psyllium
's
not
a
good
crop
,
''

Sooraji
Jath
,

.
``
<END>
<START>
You
get
a
rain
at
the
wrong

and
the
crop
is
ruined
.
''
<END>
<START>
Even
at
the
Basic
Chemicals
,
Pharmaceuticals
and
Cosmetics
Export
Promotion
Council
,
the
government
agency
that
promotes
the
seed
,

psyllium
boom
is
distant

.
<END>
<START>
The
staff
brags
about
psyllium
's
hefty
contribution
to
American
regularity
,
without
quite
grasping
the
implications
of
the
research
on
cholesterol
.
<END>
<START>
The
council
's
annual
report
has
psyllium
on
its
last
page
,
lumped
with
such
unglamorous
export
items
as
sarsaparilla
and
``
Nux
vomica
,
''
a
plant
that
induces
vomiting
.
<END>
<START>
In
one

,
the
psyllium
middlemen
--
the
buyers
and
exporters
--
are
glad
to
keep
news
of
the
boom
to

.
<END>
<START>
They
want
psyllium
prices
low
for
their
purchases
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
But
there
's
a
catch
.
<END>
<START>
Sidhpur
and
adjacent
districts
are
the
only
places
in
the
world
where
psyllium
is
grown
in
large
quantities
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
partly
due
to
the
particular

of
the
crop
.
<END>
<START>
Psyllium
needs
sandy
soil
,
dew
during
the
first
few
weeks
,
and
then
total
dryness
when
its
seeds
are
maturing
.
<END>
<START>
Small
crops
are
grown
in
Pakistan
,
France
,
Spain
,
Italy
,
Belgium
and
Brazil
,
but
their
quality
ca
n't
compare
to
that
of
Indian
psyllium
.
<END>
<START>
Big
buyers
like
Procter
&
Gamble
say
there
are
other
spots
on
the
globe
,
and
in
India
,
where
the
seed
could
be
grown
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
not
a
crop
that
ca
n't
be
doubled
or

,
''
says
Mr.
Krishnamurthy
.
<END>
<START>
But
no
one
has

to
transplant

crop
.
<END>
<START>
In

,

's

.
<END>
<START>
Many

,
too

to

's
new

in
the
West
,
have

to
plant

,

,
cumin
,

or

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.

altogether
this

in

a

with
a
future
such

cumin
or

.
<END>
<START>
``
Maybe

'll
plant

seeds
.
''
<END>
<START>
His

,

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
And
the
world
could
experience
its
first

shortage
.
<END>
<START>

<START>
Small
businesses
say
a
recent
trend
is
like
a
dream
come
true
:
more-affordable
rates
for
employee-health
insurance
,
initially
at
least
.
<END>
<START>
But
then
they
wake
up
to
a
nightmare
.
<END>
<START>
The
reasonable
first-year
rates
can
be
followed
by
increases
of
60
%
or
more
if
a
covered
employee
files
a
major
claim
,
they
complain
.
<END>
<START>
Insurance
premiums
for
one
small
Maryland
concern
went
up
130
%
in
less
than
two
years
,
the
last
increase
coming
after
one
of
its
three
workers
developed
a
herniated
disk
.
<END>
<START>
She
said
her
employer
ca
n't
afford
the
rate
increases
,
and
she
fears
she
wo
n't
find
another
job
with
a
benefit
plan
covering
her
ailment
.
<END>
<START>
For
employee
and
employer
alike
,
the
worry
is
widespread
.
<END>
<START>
Surveys
repeatedly
show
that
small-business
owners
rank
the
availability
and
rising
cost
of
health
insurance
as
one
of
their
biggest
concerns
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
have
an
old-fashioned
name
for
people
in
that
position
:
sick
people
who
need
health
insurance
,
''
Rep.
Waxman
says
.
``
<END>
<START>
What
we
're
seeing
now
makes
a
mockery
of
the
idea
of
insurance
:
collect
premiums
from
the
healthy
,
dump
the
sick
and
let
them
pay
their
own
bills
.
''
<END>
<START>
Some
lawmakers
may
seek
legislation
to
limit
overly
restrictive
insurance
policies
.
<END>
<START>
The
concern
grows
out
of
increased
efforts
by
the
insurers
to
woo
the
small-business
market
.
<END>
<START>
``
One
case
of
cancer
or
a
high-risk
pregnancy
with
a
sick
infant
,
and
rates
go
up
40
%
to
60
%
.
<END>
<START>
Small-business
people
end
up
paying
insurance
premiums
worth
two
to
three
times
the
cost
of
one
illness
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
it
says
that
rapid
rate
increases
are
directly
tied
to
the
soaring
cost
of
health
care
.
<END>
<START>
Some
business
analysts
blame
the
problem
on
tough
competition
in
the
insurance
market
.
<END>
<START>
They
say
insurance
companies
use
policies
aimed
at
excluding
bad
risks
because
their
competitors
do
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
general
practice
makes
it
more
difficult
to
combine
small
groups
of
people
into
larger
groups
,
thus
spreading
the
risk
over
a
larger
base
of
premiums
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
'm
not
accusing
insurers
of
dereliction
of
duty
,
''
Robert
Patricelli
of
the
U.S.
Chamber
of
Commerce
told
Mr.
Waxman
's
panel
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
ca
n't
ask
one
carrier
to
underwrite
on
social
grounds
when
that
might
destroy
it
in
the
marketplace
.
''
<END>
<START>
Rep.
Waxman
and
Democratic
Sen.
Edward
Kennedy
of
Massachusetts
have
proposed
regulation
to
deal
with
the
problem
.
<END>
<START>
Such
requirements
,
they
argue
,
make
it
difficult
to
provide
a
basic
,
low-cost
health-benefits
package
.
<END>
<START>
She
contends
that
similar
mandates
have
driven
up
insurance
costs
20
%
in
Maryland
and
30
%
in
California
.
<END>
<START>
The
insurance-industry
association
also
strongly
disagrees
with
the
proposed
community
rating
,
which
``
does
n't
save
one
dollar
,
''
argues
James
Dorsch
,
HIAA
's
Washington
counsel
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
just
makes
healthy
businesses
subsidize
unhealthy
ones
and
gives
each
employer
less
incentive
to
keep
his
workers
healthy
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Dorsch
says
the
HIAA
is
working
on
a
proposal
to
establish
a
privately
funded
reinsurance
mechanism
to
help
cover
small
groups
that
ca
n't
get
insurance
without
excluding
certain
employees
.
<END>
<START>
The
complexities
of
the
insurance
problem
make
the
outcome
difficult
to
predict
.
<END>
<START>
But
to
Ms.
Allen
,
the
employee
whose
back
problem
triggered
a
huge
insurance-rate
increase
,
the
issue
was
simple
.
<END>
<START>
``
What
good
is
having
health
insurance
,
''
she
asked
,
``
when
it
's
so
expensive
that
it
becomes
impossible
to
keep
after
only
one
major
claim
?
<END>
<START>
The
Belgian
consumer
price
index
rose
a
provisional
0.1
%
in
October
from
the
previous
month
and
was
up
3.64
%
from
October
1988
,
the
Ministry

Economic
Affairs
said
.
<END>
<START>
The

,
which
uses
a
base
of
1981
as
100
,
was
calculated
at
140.91
points
in
October
,
from
140.74
in
September
.
<END>
<START>
Annual
inflation
rose
to
3.64
%
in
October
from
3.55
%
in

.
<END>
<START>
Belgium
's

has

the

,
but

in

.

<START>
Nashua
Corp.
,

,

.

,

.

.

Nashua

.

said

``

.

.

.

Weisfield
's
Inc.

.

.

.

.

.

<START>
The
stock
gained
$
2.75
Thursday
to

at
a
then-52
week
high
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
aftermath
of
the
Beijing
massacre
on
June
4
,
economists
advanced
wildly
divergent
views
on
how
Hong
Kong
would
be
affected
.
<END>
<START>
Among
the
most
upbeat
was
BT
Brokerage
-LRB-
Asia
-RRB-
Ltd
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
June
5
reaction
,
the
Bankers
Trust
Co.
unit
proclaimed
the
economy
``
shockproof
.
''
<END>
<START>
Others
were
more
cautious
.
<END>
<START>
Today
,
with
business
activity
in
Hong
Kong
staggering
along
at
an
uneven
pace
,
the
economy
itself
seems
locked
in
a
struggle
between
hope
and
fear
.
<END>
<START>
Manufacturers
have
survived
the
turmoil
in
China
largely
unscathed
.
<END>
<START>
Signs
of
revival
seem
evident
in
Hong
Kong
's
hard-hit
hotel
sector
.
<END>
<START>
But
in
the
stock
and
real-estate
markets
,
activity
remains
spotty
even
though
prices
have
regained
much
of
their
lost
ground
.
<END>
<START>
Waning
demand
reported
by
importers
,
retailers
and
even
fancy
restaurants
all
reinforce
a
profile
of
a
community
that
is
sharply
tightening
its
belt
.
<END>
<START>
As
many
economists
and
businessmen
see
it
,
those
incongruities
underscore
a
paradox
that
seems
likely
to
bedevil
the
economy
throughout
the
1990s
.
<END>
<START>
That
paradox
is
Hong
Kong
's
economically
rewarding
yet
politically
perilous
relationship
with
China
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
model
of
capitalist
efficiency
on
southern
China
's
doorstep
,
Hong
Kong
's
prospects
look
good
.
<END>
<START>
China
's
land
and
labor
offer
inexpensive
alternatives
to
local
industry
.
<END>
<START>
China-bound
freight
streams
through
the
territory
's
port
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
decade
since
the
communist
nation
emerged
from
isolation
,
its
burgeoning
trade
with
the
West
has
lifted
Hong
Kong
's
status
as
a
regional
business
center
.
<END>
<START>
These
benefits
seem
secure
despite
China
's
current
economic
and
political
troubles
.
<END>
<START>
But
to
Hong
Kong
,
China
is
n't
purely
business
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
also
the
sovereign
power
that
,
come
1997
,
will
take
over
this
British
colony
.
<END>
<START>
China
's
leaders
have
promised
generous
liberties
for
post-1997
Hong
Kong
.
<END>
<START>
That
promise
sounds
shaky
now
that
those
same
leaders
have
fallen
back
on
Marxist
dogma
and
brute
force
to
crush
their
nation
's
democracy
movement
.
<END>
<START>
Outflows
of
people
and
capital
from
Hong
Kong
have
been
growing
since
the
sovereignty
issue
first
arose
in
the
early
1980s
.
<END>
<START>
A
widely
held
assumption
all
along
has
been
that
,
given
its
robust
economy
,
Hong
Kong
will
be
able
to
attract
sufficient
foreign
money
and
talent
to
comfortably
offset
the
outflows
.
<END>
<START>
With
interest
in
emigration
and
investment
abroad
soaring
since
June
4
,
that
assumption
no
longer
seems
so
safe
.
<END>
<START>
Investment
and
emigration
plans
take
time
to
come
to
fruition
.
<END>
<START>
Only
four
months
have
passed
since
the
Beijing
massacre
,
and
few
are
prepared
to
predict
its
ultimate
impact
.
<END>
<START>
The
only
consensus
is
that
more
money
and
people
may
leave
Hong
Kong
than
had
been
thought
likely
.
<END>
<START>
This
expected
blow
has
cast
a
pall
over
the
economy
's
prospects
.
<END>
<START>
The
question
,
as
many
people
see
it
,
is
how
long
such
uncertainty
will
last
.
<END>
<START>
It
may
experience
an
upswing
or
two
in
between
.
<END>
<START>
But
with
local
investors
shaken
by
China
's
political
and
economic
turmoil
,
she
says
,
a
genuine
recovery
may
not
arrive
until
Hong
Kong
can
prove
itself
secure
under
Chinese
sovereignty
.
<END>
<START>
``
Investors
have
to
accept
the
possibility
of
a
significant
slowdown
in
economic
activity
in
the
runup
to
1997
,
''
she
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
Over
the
next
few
years
,
I
would
advise
caution
.
''
<END>
<START>
In
a
soon-to-be
published
book
on
the
territory
,
a
political
economist
,
Miron
Mushkat
,
has
derived
three
future
scenarios
from
interviews
with
41
Hong
Kong
government
officials
and
businessmen
.
<END>
<START>
Nearly
half
of
them
argue
that
Hong
Kong
's
uneasy
relationship
with
China
will
constrain
--
though
not
inhibit
--
long-term
economic
growth
.
<END>
<START>
The
rest
are
split
roughly
between
optimists
who
expect
Hong
Kong
to
hum
along
as
before
and
pessimists
who
foresee
irreparable
chaos
.
<END>
<START>
The
interviews
took
place
two
years
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Since
the
China
crisis
erupted
,
Mr.
Mushkat
says
,
the
scenario
as
depicted
by
the
middle-of-the-road
group
bears
a
remarkable
resemblance
to
the
difficulties
Hong
Kong
currently
faces
.
<END>
<START>
Such
a
pace
of
growth
,
though
respectable
for
mature
industrialized
economies
,
would
be
unusually
slow
for
Hong
Kong
.
<END>
<START>
Only
twice
since
the
1960s
has
annual
gross
domestic
product
growth
here
fallen
below
5
%
for
two
or
more
consecutive
years
.
<END>
<START>
The
first
instance
occurred
in
1967-68
,
when
China
's
Cultural
Revolution
triggered
bloody
street
rioting
in
the
colony
.
<END>
<START>
The
other
came
in
1974-75
from
the
combined
shock
of
world
recession
and
a
severe
local
stock
market
crash
.
<END>
<START>
During
the
past
10
years
,
Hong
Kong
's
economic
growth
has
averaged
8.3
%
annually
.
<END>
<START>
Given
Hong
Kong
's
record
,
Mr.
Mushkat
's
``
realists
''
might
have
sounded
unduly
conservative
when
the
interviews
took
place
two
years
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
current
circumstances
,
he
says
,
their
scenario
no
longer
seems
unrealistic
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
city
could
lose
some
of
its
entrepreneurial
flavor
.
<END>
<START>
It
could
lose
some
of
its
dynamism
,
''
says
Mr.
Mushkat
,
a
director
of
Baring
Securities
-LRB-
Hong
Kong
-RRB-
Ltd.
,
a
unit
of
Britain
's
Barings
PLC
.
``
<END>
<START>
It
does
n't
have
to
be
a
disaster
.
<END>
<START>
It
just
means
that
Hong
Kong
would
become
a
less
exciting
place
.
''
<END>
<START>
After
taking
into
account
the
fallout
from
the
China
crisis
,
the
government
has
projected
1989
GDP
growth
of
5
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
updated
forecast
,
published
Aug.
25
,
compares
with
an
earlier
forecast
of
6
%
published
March
1
and
a
7.4
%
rate
achieved
in
<END>
<START>
Sir
Piers
Jacobs
,
Hong
Kong
's
financial
secretary
,
says
a
further
downward
revision
may
be
justified
unless
the
economy
stages
a
more
convincing
rally
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
are
n't
looking
at
anything
like
a
doomsday
scenario
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
clearly
we
're
entering
a
difficult
period
.
''
<END>
<START>
Many
factors
besides
a
dread
of
1997
will
have
a
bearing
on
Hong
Kong
's
economy
.
<END>
<START>
One
concerns
Japanese
investors
.
<END>
<START>
Barely
visible
on
Hong
Kong
's
property
scene
in
1985
,
by
last
year
Japan
had
become
the
top
foreign
investor
,
spending
$
602
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
market
has
grown
relatively
quiet
since
the
China
crisis
.
<END>
<START>
But
if
the
Japanese
return
in
force
,
their
financial
might
could
compensate
to
some
extent
for
local
investors
'
waning
commitment
.
<END>
<START>
Another
--
and
critical
--
factor
is
the
U.S.
,
Hong
Kong
's
biggest
export
market
.
<END>
<START>
Even
before
the
China
crisis
,
weak
U.S.
demand
was
slowing
local
economic
growth
.
<END>
<START>
Conversely
,
strong
consumer
spending
in
the
U.S.
two
years
ago
helped
propel
the
local
economy
at
more
than
twice
its
current
rate
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
a
few
economists
maintain
that
global
forces
will
continue
to
govern
Hong
Kong
's
economic
rhythm
.
<END>
<START>
But
economic
arguments
,
however
solid
,
wo
n't
necessarily
impress
Hong
Kong
's
5.7
million
people
.
<END>
<START>
Many
are
refugees
,
having
fled
China
's
unending
cycles
of
political
repression
and
poverty
since
the
Communist
Party
took
power
in
1949
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
many
of
those
now
planning
to
leave
Hong
Kong
ca
n't
easily
be
swayed
by
momentary
improvements
in
the
colony
's
political
and
economic
climate
.
<END>
<START>
Emigration
applications
soared
in
1985
,
when
Britain
and
China
ratified
their
accord
on
Hong
Kong
's
future
.
<END>
<START>
In
1987
,
Hong
Kong
's
most
prosperous
year
for
a
decade
,
30,000
left
,
up
58
%
from
the
previous
year
.
<END>
<START>
Last
year
,
45,000
went
.
<END>
<START>
The
government
predicts
that
annual
outflows
will
level
off
over
the
next
few
years
at
as
much
as
60,000
--
a
projection
that
is
widely
regarded
as
unrealistically
low
.
<END>
<START>
A
large
number
of
those
leaving
are
managers
and
professionals
.
<END>
<START>
While
no
one
professes
to
know
the
exact
cost
of
such
a
``
brain
drain
''
to
the
economy
,
hardly

that
it
poses
a

.
<END>
<START>
While
Wall
Street
is
retreating
from
computer-driven
program
trading
,
big
institutional
investors
are
likely
to
continue
these
strategies
at
full
blast
,
further
roiling
the
stock
market
,
trading
executives
say
.
<END>
<START>
PaineWebber
Group
Inc.
announced
a
pullback
on
Thursday
from
stock-index
arbitrage
,
a
controversial
program-trading
strategy
blamed
by
many
investors
for
encouraging
big
stock-market
swings
.
<END>
<START>
Though
the
trading

are
offered
as
a

of
concern
about
recent
stock
market
volatility
,
most
Wall
Street
firms
remain
open
to
handle

trading
for

.
<END>
<START>
Wells
Fargo

,

Trust
Co.
and
Mellon
Capital
Management
are
among
the
top
stock-index

of
Wall

,
trading

say
.
<END>
<START>
These
huge
stock-index
funds
build

that
match
the
S&P
500
stock
index
or
other
stock
indexes
,
and
frequently
swap
between

and
futures
to
capture
profits
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
will
do

every

,
''
said
one

.
<END>
<START>
Consequently
,
abrupt

in
the
stock
market
are
not
likely

anytime
soon
,

say
.
<END>
<START>
In

,

for

,

.
<END>
<START>
``

,
''

.

<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.

,

<END>
<START>
Since
the
cost
of
transporting
gas
is
so
important
to
producers
'
ability
to
sell
it
,
it
helps
to
have
input
and
access
to
transportation
companies
.
''
<END>
<START>
All
700
Toronto-based
employees
will
be
offered
positions
in
Calgary
,
the
company
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
will
save
between
C$
4
million
and
C$
6
million
annually
in
office
expenses
and
other
administrative
costs
by
moving
to
Calgary
,
Mr.
Maier
added
.
<END>
<START>
TransCanada
is
49.1
%
owned
by
Montreal-based
holding
company
BCE
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
But
with
sales
growth
sluggish
and
other
men
's
stores
putting
on
the
heat
,
the
venerable
retailer
can
no
longer
afford
such
a
smug
attitude
.
<END>
<START>
During
the
four-day
promotion
,
shoppers
at
the
Short
Hills
,
N.J.
,
store
lined
up
to
pay
for
big-ticket
items
like
coats
and
suits
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
not
all
.
<END>
<START>
One
color
photo
displays
a
rainbow
of
dress
shirts
tied
in
a
knot
;
another
picture
shows
neckties
with
bold
designs
.
<END>
<START>
The
message
is
loud
and
clear
:
This
is
not
your
father
's
Brooks
Brothers
.
<END>
<START>
As
part
of
its
national
ad
pitch
,
Brooks
Brothers
will
show
less
preppy
women
's
clothes
,
moving
away
from
its
floppy-tie
business
stereotype
.
<END>
<START>
One
ad
shows
a
bright
red
jacket
paired
with
a
black
leather
skirt
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
ad
copy
is
cheeky
:
``
How
can
you
be
a
Wall
Street
hot
shot
without
at
least
one
Brooks
Brothers
suit
in
your
portfolio
?
''
<END>
<START>
Brooks
Brothers
hopes
that
shaking
its
time-honored
traditions
will
attract
more
young
men
and
more
women
and
change
consumer
perceptions
about
its
range
of
merchandise
.
<END>
<START>
We
want
them
to
buy
more
of
their
wardrobe
here
.
''
<END>
<START>
Industry
watchers
agree
that
Brooks
Brothers
is
long
overdue
in
updating
its
buttoned-down
image
,
which
has
stunted
its
growth
.
<END>
<START>
When
acquired
in
May
1988
by
British
retailer
Marks
&
Spencer
PLC
,
Brooks
Brothers
'
annual
operating
profit
was
about
$
41.8
million
on
sales
of
$
290.1
million
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Roberti
concedes
that
since
the
$
750
million
takeover
,
``
sales
growth
has
n't
been
dramatic
.
''
<END>
<START>
For
the
11
months
ended
March
31
,
operating
profit
at
the
52-store
chain
totaled
$
40.5
million
on
sales
of
$
286.8
million
.
<END>
<START>
As
Brooks
Brothers
jumps
into
the
fashion
fray
,
it
will
be
playing
catch
up
.
<END>
<START>
Many
clothiers
,
especially
Ralph
Lauren
,
have
cashed
in
on
the
recent
popularity
of
updated
Ivy
League
and
English
styles
.
<END>
<START>
In
keeping
with
men
's
broader
fashion
scope
today
,
businessmen
are
dabbling
in
English
and
Italian
suits
that
are
conservative
but
not
stodgy
.
<END>
<START>
The
rigid
Ivy
League
customer
,
Brooks
Brothers
'
bread
and
butter
,
meanwhile
is
becoming
extinct
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
,
Brooks
Brothers
has
lost
customers
to
stores
that
offer
more
variety
such
as
Paul
Stuart
,
Barneys
New
York
and
Louis
,
Boston
.
<END>
<START>
By
making
a
break
from
tradition
,
Brooks
Brothers
is
seeking
a
delicate
balance
.
<END>
<START>
If
it
promotes
fashion
too
much
,
the
shop
risks
alienating
its
old-line
customers
;
by
emphasizing
``
value
,
''
it
risks
watering
down
its
high-minded
mystique
.
<END>
<START>
Brooks
Brothers
'
aim
is
for
20
%
of
total
sales
to
come
from
the
women
's
department
,
up
from
the
current
12
%
.
<END>
<START>
``
Everybody
forgets
that
there
are
fashion
cycles
in
classic
merchandise
,
''
observes
Carol
Farmer
,
a

.
<END>
<START>
``
For
women
,
dressing
for
success
in
a
real
structured
way
is
over
.
''
<END>
<START>
Despite
these
challenges
,
Marks
&
Spencer
sees
big
potential
in
Brooks
Brothers
,
noting
the
widely
recognized
name
and
global

.
<END>
<START>
Marks
&
Spencer
plans
to
open
roughly
18

stores
in
the
next
five
years
.
<END>
<START>
Brooks
Brothers
says
business
is
robust
at
its
30

in
Japan
and
two
shops
in
Hong
Kong
.
<END>
<START>
Marks
&
Spencer
is
also
considering
opening
stores
across
Europe
sometime
in
the
future
.
<END>
<START>
Brooks
Brothers
is
also

its

.
<END>
<START>
Wednesday
,
it
will
unveil
a
$
7
million
refurbishing
at
its
flagship
store
on
Madison
Avenue
.
<END>
<START>
With
newly
installed

,
the
store
retains
its
signature
wood-and-brass
look
but
is
less

.
<END>
<START>
Because

biggest
growth
in
menswear
is
in

,
Brooks
Brothers
is
chasing
more
of
that

.
<END>
<START>
The

,

,

's

,

.

<START>
But

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

,

<END>

Says

:
``
We

turn

on
.
<END>
<START>
Ferro

.

.

.

,

.

.

,

.
<END>
<START>
Arthur
Price
abruptly
quit
as
president
and
chief
executive
officer
of
MTM
Entertainment
Inc.
,
a
Los
Angeles
production
company
that
has
fallen
on
hard
times
.
<END>
<START>
A
TVS
spokesman
said
he
did
n't
know
Mr.
Price
's
plans
.
<END>
<START>
James
Gatward
,
TVS
's
chief
executive
,
said
in
a
statement
that
he
will
``
assume
overall
responsibility
''
for
MTM
's
operations
until
a
successor
is
named
.
<END>
<START>
Industry
analysts
speculated
that
Mr.
Price
's
sudden
departure
may
have
stemmed
from
conflicts
with
Mr.
Gatward
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Gatward
declined
to
comment
,
and
Mr.
Price
could
n't
be
reached
on
Friday
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
TVS
statement
,
Mr.
Price
said
``
leaving
MTM
was
a
very
difficult
decision
,
''
but
added
that
``
it
is
now
time
for
a
change
...
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
$
320
million
purchase
of
MTM
represented
an
audacious
international
move
for
TVS
,
which
then
was
about
half
the
U.S.
concern
's
size
.
<END>
<START>
At
the

,
Mr.
Gatward
said
his

with
Mr.
Price
had
smoothed
the
way
for
its

with
the
small
British
company
.
<END>
<START>
But
TVS
stunned

last
month
by
disclosing
that
it
expected
MTM
to
post
an
operating
loss
for
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
In
that

,
TVS
also
said
it
was
trimming
production
finance
and
hiring
a
new
U.S.
sales
manager
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Gatward
has
spent
a
lot
of
time
since
late
September
at
MTM
's
headquarters
;
he
eliminated
three
departments
and
fired
six

,
according
to

TVS
spokesman
.
<END>
<START>
Further
staff
cuts
are
likely
,
the
spokesman
indicated
.
<END>
<START>
``
Obviously
,
we
are
looking
at
making
economies
across
the
board
.
''
<END>
<START>
TVS
blames
difficulties
in
peddling
reruns
of
MTM
shows
to
U.S.
broadcasters
for
the
problems
at
MTM
.
<END>
<START>
The
market
for
reruns
sold
to
local
U.S.
broadcasters
has
been
weak
for
the
past
three
or
four
seasons
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Price
co-founded
MTM
in
1969
with
U.S.

Mary
Tyler

Grant
Tinker
,

.
<END>
<START>

<START>

.

,

.

<START>
Two
rival
bidders
for
Connaught
BioSciences
extended
their
offers
to
acquire
the
Toronto-based
vaccine
manufacturer
Friday
.
<END>
<START>
A
C$
30-a-share
bid
by
Ciba-Geigy
Ltd.
,
a
pharmaceutical
company
based
in
Basel
,
Switzerland
,
and
California-based
Chiron
Corp.
,
a
bioresearch
concern
,
was
extended
to
Nov.
16
.
<END>
<START>
It
had
been
due
to
expire
Friday
evening
.
<END>
<START>
Merieux
previously
said
it
would
ensure
its
bid
remained
open
pending
a
final
decision
by
Canadian
regulators
on
whether
to
approve
the
takeover
.
<END>
<START>
Merieux
,
a
vaccine
and
bioresearch
firm
based
in
Lyon
,
France
,
is
controlled
50.1
%
by
state-owned
Rhone
Poulenc
S.A
.
<END>
<START>
The
Canadian
government
previously
said
Merieux
's
bid
did
n't
offer
enough
``
net
benefit
''
to
Canada
to
be
approved
,
and
gave
Merieux
an
until
mid-November
to
submit
additional
information
.
<END>
<START>
Merieux
officials
said
last
week
that
they
are
``
highly
confident
''
the
offer
will
be
approved
once
it
submits
details
of
its
proposed
investments
to
federal
regulators
.
<END>
<START>
Both
offers
are
conditional
on
regulatory
approvals
and
enough
shares
being
tendered
to
give
the
bidders
a
majority
of
Connaught
's

.
<END>
<START>
At

close
of
business
Thursday
,
Ciba-Geigy
and
Chiron
said
11,580
common
shares
had
been
tendered
to
their
offer
.
<END>
<START>
At
last
report
,
Connaught
had
21.8
million
shares
outstanding
.
<END>
<START>
Separately
,

.

.

<START>
Centerior
Energy
Corp.
said
the
Ohio
Water
Development
Authority
approved
terms
for
two
series
of
tax-exempt
bonds
to
finance
a
water-pollution
control
and
solid-waste
disposal
facilities
.
<END>
<START>
The
authority
will
issue
a
total
of
$
446.5
million
of
pollution-control
revenue
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
Proceeds
of

sale
will
go
to
Centerior
's
operating
subsidiaries
to
finance
the
projects
,
located
at
a
nuclear
unit
located
near
Cleveland
.
<END>
<START>
The
bonds
will
be
issued
for
a
term
of
34
years
at
an

rate
of
8
%
.
<END>
<START>
Goldman
,
Sachs
&
Co.
is
the
underwriter
.
<END>
<START>

Motors
Corp.
's

750

.

The

,

4
,

.
<END>
<START>
After
days
of
intense
but
fruitless
negotiations
,
a
federal
judge
last
week
threatened
to
convert
William
Herbert
Hunt
's
Chapter
11
personal
bankruptcy
case
into
a
Chapter
7
liquidation
.
<END>
<START>
Judge
Harold
C.
Abramson
raised
the
possibility
after
talks
to
end
a
feud
between
two
major
creditors
failed
and
all
three
reorganization
plans
in
the
case
ran
into
roadblocks
.
<END>
<START>
Hundreds
of
smaller
creditors
could
get
nothing
,
according
to
attorneys
involved
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
would
be
a
shame
to
have
a
Chapter
7
after
all
the
progress
in
this
case
,
''
said
Judge
Abramson
.
<END>
<START>
Under
Chapter
11
of
the
Federal
Bankruptcy
Code
,
a
company
continues
to
operate
under
protection
from
creditors
'
lawsuits
while
it
works
out
a
plan
to
pay
its
debts
.
<END>
<START>
Under
Chapter
7
,
the
assets
of
a
company
are
sold
off
to
pay
creditors
.
<END>
<START>
Under
prodding
from
Judge
Abramson
,
a
Minpeco
executive
flew
in
from
Peru
last
week
to
talk
directly
with
executives
from
Manufacturers
Hanover
on
a
settlement
.
<END>
<START>
All
three
major
creditors
--
the
IRS
,
Minpeco
and
Manufacturers
Hanover
--
voted
against
and
effectively
doomed
a
reorganization
plan
proposed
by
Mr.
Hunt
.
<END>
<START>
A
reorganization
plan
proposed
jointly
by
the
IRS
and
Manufacturers
Hanover
was
stalled
by
a
negative
vote
from
Minpeco
.
<END>
<START>
The
mineral
concern
's
own
reorganization
plan
met
a
similar
fate
after
opposition
from
the
IRS
and
Manufacturers
Hanover
.
<END>
<START>
Neither
plan
is
dead
,
however
,
and
the
judge
could
force
creditors
to
accept
some
version
of
them
after
ruling
on
the
Minpeco-Manufacturers
Hanover
dispute
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
settlement
negotiations
continue
between
Mr.
Hunt
and
the
IRS
,
which
has
already
reached
a
tentative
agreement
with
Nelson
Bunker
Hunt
.
<END>
<START>
The
two
sides
have
been
far
apart
on
how
much
Herbert
Hunt
will
continue
to
owe
the
government
after
his
assets
are
sold
.
<END>
<START>
Pacific
First
Financial
Corp.
said
it
signed
a
non-binding
letter
of
intent
to
acquire
the
construction
lending
unit

to
be
one
of
the
few
major
chemical
companies
to
show
profit
growth
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
bank
projects
Akzo
will
show
per-share
earnings
of
24
guilders
in
1990
,
up
from
an
estimated
22.5
guilders
for
this
year
and
the
20.9
guilders
reported
for
1988
.
<END>
<START>
At
James
Capel
&
Co.
in
London
,
analyst
Jackie
Ashurst
notes
that
Akzo
is
less
exposed
than
many
of
its
rivals
to
the
most
volatile
chemical
products
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
Akzo
has
only
minor
petrochemical
operations
,
is
small
in
plastics
and
does
n't
make
fertilizers
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
,
while
Akzo
profited
less
than
many
rivals
from
the
boom
of
recent
years
in
petrochemicals
and
plastics
,
it
has
less
to
fear
from
the
current
slump
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
is
exposed
to
bulk
chemicals
,
however
.
<END>
<START>
Although
bulk-chemical
prices
have
begun
falling
in
the
U.S.
,
they
are
generally
stable
in
Europe
,
Mr.
Bergsma
said
.
<END>
<START>
A
decline
may
come
in
the
first
half
of
1990
,
he
said
,
but
the
market
does
n't
appear
on
the
verge
of
a
severe
downturn
.
<END>
<START>
Akzo
's
biggest
move
in
this
area
was
the
1987
acquisition
of
Stauffer
Chemical
Co.
's
specialty
chemical
business
for
$
625
million
.
<END>
<START>
Akzo
also
makes
products
derived
from
salt
,
such
as
chlorine
and
caustic
soda
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
fibers
division
,
profit
remains
weak
,
largely
because
of
persistent
overcapacity
.
<END>
<START>
But
Akzo
is
still
slimming
down
:
It
recently
announced
plans
to
eliminate
about
1,700
fiber-related
jobs
in
the
Netherlands
and
West
Germany
.
<END>
<START>
Akzo
's
Twaron
aramid
fiber
is
a
distant
second
to
Du
Pont
Co.
's
Kevlar
,
which
dominates
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bergsma
said
world-wide
industry
sales
of
aramid
fibers
are
expected
to
total
about
$
500
million
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
growth
of
10
%
a
year
seems
possible
,
he
said
,
and
Akzo
expects
its
Twaron
business
to
become
profitable
in
1990
.
<END>
<START>
Akzo
also
has
spent
heavily
on
acquisitions
in
paints
,
auto
finishes
and
industrial
coatings
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bergsma
said
Akzo
is
likely
to
see
strong
profit
growth
from
coatings
as
it
realizes
cost
savings
and
other
benefits
from
its
greater
scale
.
<END>
<START>
For
Akzo
's
drug
business
,
where
profits
have
shown
litle
change
for
the
past
five
years
,
Mr.
Bergsma
predicted
moderate
profit
growth
.
<END>
<START>
Akzo
is
the
leading
seller
of
birth-control
pills
in
Europe
but
is
still
seeking
regulatory
approvals
to
enter
that
market
in
the
U.S.
and
Japan
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bergsma
said
Akzo
hopes
to
have
approval
to
sell
its
Marvelon
pill
in
the
U.S.
in
1992
.
<END>
<START>
Akzo
also
has
small
operations
in
diagnostic
tests
,
generic
drugs
and
veterinary
products
.
<END>
<START>
Veterinary
products
are
showing
especially
strong
growth
,
Mr.
Bergsma
said
.
<END>
<START>
Among
the
leading
products
is
a
flu
shot
for
horses
.
<END>
<START>
We
're
sorry
to
see
Nigel
Lawson
's
departure
from
the
British
government
.
<END>
<START>
He
is
a
politician
with
the
courage
of
true
conviction
,
as
in
summarily
sacking
exchange
controls
and
in
particular
slashing
the
top
rate
of
income
taxation
to
40
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
early
omens
,
we
admit
,
scarcely
suggest
so
wholesome
an
outcome
.
<END>
<START>
The
Fleet
Street
reaction
was
captured
in
the
Guardian
headline
,
``
Departure
Reveals
Thatcher
Poison
.
''
<END>
<START>
British
politicians
divide
into
two
groups
of
chickens
,
those
with
their
necks
cut
and
those
screaming
the
sky
is
falling
.
<END>
<START>
The
problem
is
that
on
the
vital
issue
of
monetary
policy
and
exchange
rates
,
conservative
,
free-market
economists
divide
into
at
least
three
incompatible
camps
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
the
strict
monetarists
,
who
believe
that
floating
exchange
rates
free
an
economy
to
stabilize
its
price
level
by
stabilizing
the
monetary
aggregates
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
the
supply-side
globalists
,
who
seek
to
spread
the
advantages
of
a
common
currency
through
fixed
exchange
rates
.
<END>
<START>
And
there
are
the
twin-deficit
Keynesians
,
who
predict/advocate
devaluations
to
balance
trade
flows
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
a
problem
not
only
for
Prime
Minister
Thatcher
but
for
President
Bush
,
as
shown
in
the
ongoing
bickering
over
the
dollar
between
the
Federal
Reserve
and
the
Mulford
Treasury
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
British
case
,
Mr.
Lawson
is
the
closest
thing
in
London
to
a
supply-side
globalist
.
<END>
<START>
While
no
doubt
agreeing
with
Mr.
Lawson
on
everything
else
,
Sir
Alan
is
a
dyed-in-the-wool
monetarist
,
inclined
to
defend
floating
rates
to
the
death
.
<END>
<START>
They
increased
the
after-tax
rate
of
return
and
made
Britain
a
far
more
attractive
place
to
invest
,
producing
sudden
capital
inflows
.
<END>
<START>
By
accounting
definitions
,
this
had
to
produce
a
sudden
trade
deficit
.
<END>
<START>
As
in
the
U.S.
,
it
also
produced
a
sudden
burst
in
the
demand
for
sterling
,
that
is
a
surge
in
the
sterling
monetary
aggregates
,
M-Whatever
.
<END>
<START>
At
this
point
,
the
options
were
:
Crunch
money
to
stop
the
boost
in
the
aggregates
,
as
Sir
Alan
surely
advised
,
and
forget
the
soaring
pound
.
<END>
<START>
To
push
the
pound
even
lower
trying
to
cure
the
trade
deficit
,
a
policy
Britain
has
repeatedly
proved
disastrous
.
<END>
<START>
Or
to
supply
enough
money
to
meet
the
increased
demand
and
stabilize
the
exchange
rate
,
as
the
Chancellor
argued
,
and
ensure
the
permanence
of
this
policy
by
joining
the
EMS
.
<END>
<START>
Faced
with
a
similar
situation
,
Paul
Volcker
let
the
dollar
soar
,
-LRB-
though
monetary
aggregates
also
grew
so
rapidly
monetarists
issued
egg-on-the-face
warnings
of
inflation
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
But
this
devastated
the
U.S.
manufacturing
sector
,
laying
the
seeds
of
protectionism
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lawson
,
though
not
allowed
to
join
the
EMS
,
chose
to
``
shadow
''
the
deutsche
mark
.
<END>
<START>
He
reaped
inflation
along
with
rapid
growth
,
no
doubt
validating
Sir
Alan
's
predictions
in
the
Prime
Minister
's
mind
.
<END>
<START>
But
more
recently
,
the
pound
has
been
falling
with
high
inflation
,
which
has
also
seemed
almost
impervious
to
the
high
interest
rates
Mr.
Lawson
deployed
to
stop
it
.
<END>
<START>
So
the
British
experience
presents
a
genuine
puzzle
that
reaches
far
beyond
the
shores
of
Albion
.
<END>
<START>
We
had
been
soliciting
opinions
on
it
long
before
Mr.
Lawson
's
resignation
,
and
offer
some
of
the
collection
for
the
benefit
of
his
successor
and
one-time
deputy
,
John
Major
.
<END>
<START>
To
begin
with
,
we
should
note
that
in
contrast
to
the
U.S.
deficit
,
Britain
has
been
running
largish
budget
surpluses
.
<END>
<START>
In
pursuit
of
this
mystery
,
Keynesian
adepts
and
twin-deficit
mavens
need
not
apply
.
<END>
<START>
We
should
also
add
Mr.
Lawson
's
own
explanation
,
as
we
understand
it
.
<END>
<START>
Unlike
the
U.S.
,
Britain
never
achieved
even
a
momentary
reduction
in
real
wages
.
<END>
<START>
The
wage
stickiness
,
which
OECD
studies
confirm
is
particularly
high
in
Britain
,
gives
its
economy
a
structural
bias
toward
inflation
.
<END>
<START>
Inflation
is
easier
to
spark
and
harder
to
control
.
<END>
<START>
We
should
also
concede
that
in
the
British
experience
the
monetarist
cause
regains
some
of
the
credibility
it
lost
in
the
U.S.
experience
.
<END>
<START>
Nearby
Paul
Craig
Roberts
,
a
distinguished
supply-sider
with
monetarist
sympathies
,
argues
the
case
for
Sir
Alan
.
<END>
<START>
Somewhere
in
between
there
must
be
a
golden
mean
,
perhaps
measured
by
M-Whatever
,
but
perhaps
measured
by
purchasing
power
parity
.
<END>
<START>
The
globalists
tend
to
think
Mr.
Lawson
ran
onto
technical
reefs
.
<END>
<START>
In
fixing
rates
the
choice
of
initial
parities
is
crucial
,
for
example
,
and
perhaps
he
picked
the
wrong
pound-DM
rate
.
<END>
<START>
For
that
matter
,
perhaps
he
fixed
to
the
wrong
currency
.
<END>
<START>
We
sympathize
with
Mrs.
Thatcher
's
reluctance
to
tie
her
currency
to
one
governed
by
the
domestic
political
imperatives
of
West
Germany
.
<END>
<START>
Perhaps
the
shock
would
have
been
less
if
they
'd
fixed
to
another
low-tax
,
deregulated
,
supply-side
economy
.
<END>
<START>
Alan
Reynolds
of
Polyconomics
adds
his
suspicion
that
the
unrecognized
inflationary
culprit
is
the
budget
surplus
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Reynolds
also
notes
that
since
British
banks
have
no
reserve
requirements
,
high
interest
rates
are
less
likely
to
curb
inflation
than
to
cause
recession
.
<END>
<START>
We
would
add
that
in
political
terms
,
Mrs.
Thatcher
's
problem
was
failing
to
decide
between
the
Chancellor
and
her
adviser
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
end
,
neither
policy
was
followed
,
and
instead
of
learning
anything
we
are
left
with
a
mystery
.
<END>
<START>
In
particular
,
``
shadowing
''
a
currency
is
anything
but
fixing
;
it
is
an
open
announcement
that
the
exchange
rate
target
has
no
credibility
.
<END>
<START>
All
the
more
so
when
strong
voices
are
heard
opposing
the
policy
.
<END>
<START>
Better
to
have
a
true
monetarist
policy
,
just
for
the
experience
.
<END>
<START>
So
Mr.
Lawson
had
to
resign
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
end
his
move
was
sparked
by

in

from
Sir
Alan
's
autobiography
in
The
American
Economist
,
a
10,000-circulation
academic
journal
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
was
the
underlying
situation
that
became
intolerable
.
<END>
<START>
What
Mr.
Major
and
Mrs.
Thatcher
will
do
now
remains
to
be
seen
.
<END>
<START>
They
confront
stubborn
inflation
and
a
sagging
economy
,
that
is
to
say
,
stagflation
.
<END>
<START>
This
can
not
be
solved
by
provoking
a
further
downturn
;
reducing
the
supply
of
goods
does
not
solve
inflation
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Phillips
made
his
comments
during
an
interview
detailing
his
plans
for
the
agency
.
<END>
<START>
Surrounded
by
stacks
of
paper
,
two
computers
and
photos
of
himself
boating
and
flying
,
Mr.
Phillips
laid
out
several
changes
he
hopes
to
make
at
the
agency
.
<END>
<START>
First
and
foremost
,
Mr.
Phillips
said
he
hopes
to
improve
client
service
.
<END>
<START>
Ogilvy
under
the
fastidious
Mr.
Roman
gained
a
reputation
as
occasionally
being
high-handed
in
its
treatment
of
clients
,
of
preaching
what
strategy
a
client
should
--
indeed
,
must
--
follow
.
<END>
<START>
And
some
of
its
top
client-service
executives
,
including
Mr.
Phillips
,
were
promoted
to
the
point
they
were
saddled
with
administrative
duties
,
with
little
time
to
see
clients
.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Phillips
recently
freed
himself
up
to
spend
more
time
with
clients
by
delegating
much
of
his
administrative
work
to
a
deputy
.
<END>
<START>
He
also
plans
to
get
to
know
clients
that
Mr.
Roman
was
closer
to
,
such
as
Lever
Brothers
,
American
Express
and
Seagram
.
<END>
<START>
The
two
men
are
planning
joint
visits
to
a
number
of
clients
to
attempt
to
smoothly
hand
over
the
reins
.
<END>
<START>
``
Clients
want
to
see
more
of
our
senior
people
involved
in
the
business
--
not
once
a
month
,
but
two
or
three
times
a
week
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Phillips
also
hopes
to
finally
implement
a
reorganization
announced
earlier
this
year
but
put
on
hold
by
the
WPP
takeover
.
<END>
<START>
The
reorganization
is
supposed
to
make
one-stop
shopping
--
buying
advertising
,
public
relations
and
design
all
in
one
place
,
or
``
Ogilvy
Orchestration
''
in
Ogilvyspeak
--
a
reality
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
reorganization
,
Ogilvy
plans
to
name
one
executive
on
each
account
as
a
``
client
service
director
''
to
work
as
the
client
's
single
contact
for
all
those
services
.
<END>
<START>
Now
Mr.
Phillips
says
he
hopes
to
have
the
new
system
in
place
for
several
clients
--
including
American
Express
,
American
Telephone
&
Telegraph
and
Ryder
--
by
year
's
end
.
<END>
<START>
Industry
executives
and
analysts
are
divided
on
whether
Mr.
Phillips
is
up
to
the
task
.
<END>
<START>
He
is
n't
as
well-known
to
clients
as
is
Mr.
Roman
.
<END>
<START>
Under
his
watch
,
office

was
often
rampant
in
the
agency
's
New
York
operation
and
the
office
there
has

a

for
more

.
<END>
<START>
The

Mr.
Phillips
clearly
does

going
for
him
is

,
although
it
is
n't

if

will

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Phillips
and
Mr.
Roman
are
indeed
quite
similar
in

,
if
not

style
.
<END>
<START>
While
Mr.
Roman
is
a

detailsman
,
Mr.
Phillips
would
rather
delegate
,
leaving
him
time
for
his
interests
outside

office
.
<END>
<START>
The
move
,
budgeted
at
about
$
7
million
,
actually
came
in
at
about
$
10
million
,

.
<END>
<START>
But
margins
will
be
helped
,
too
,
by
some
other

steps
.
<END>
<START>
Ogilvy
eliminated
the

staff
,

and
,

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
Y&R
's
Klein
Steps
Down
<END>
<START>
``
The
fact
that
he
is
in
the

charges
could
conceivably
have
an
adverse
impact
on
Y&R
,
''
Mr.
Kroll
wrote
.
<END>
<START>

said
Mr.
Klein
will
return
to
his

``
at

.
''
<END>

.

<START>
Waxman
sells
a
variety
of
hardware
products
for
the

market
.
<END>
<START>
Comparable
store
sales
for
the
quarter
were
up
7.3
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
net
loss
for
the
quarter
was
$
43.1
million
against
a
year-earlier
loss
of
$
106
million
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
year
,
sales
were
up
5.6
%
to
$
6.97
billion
compared
with
$
6.61
billion
in

1988
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
for

Magnin
,

's
,

Wilshire
.
<END>
<START>
Macy

in

.
<END>
<START>

,

for

,

for

1989

1.9
%
.
<END>
<START>

for

$
53.7
million
compared

a

$

for

.
<END>
<START>
The
$
833.6
million
figures
includes

.
<END>
<START>

those

,

before
interest
,

and

for
1988
would
have

$
728.5

.
<END>
<START>
As

Feb.
1
,
1990
,
the

Wilshire
stores
will
operate
as
I.
Magnin
stores
.
<END>
<START>

,

and

149

.

<START>

.

.

,

.

,

.

.
<END>
<START>

includes

in

,
Ill.
,

800

.
<END>

,

's

by

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

.

.

.

<START>
Catastrophe
losses
reduced

's

by

50

,

36
million
from

.
<END>
<START>

$
5

,

,

2.07

.
<END>
<START>
The

.

<START>

.

,

.

<START>

,

closed
at

60
,
down
50

.
<END>
<START>

latest
quarter
,
Aetna
had
a
$
23
million
loss
on
its
auto/homeowners
line
,

with

of
$
33

last

.
<END>
<START>

fell
30
%
to
$
59

,
reflecting
higher

and

war
in

for

.

<START>

,

,

.

<START>

48

,

27

from

.

4.67

,

,

$
4.41
a

,
last
year
.
<END>
<START>
Out
of
the
mouths
of
revolutionaries
are
coming
words
of
moderation
.
<END>
<START>
Here
were
more
than
70,000
ANC
supporters
,
gathering
for
the
first
ANC
rally
inside
South
Africa
since
the
black
liberation
movement
was
banned
in
1960
.
<END>
<START>
Here
was
the
state
security
appartus
poised
to
pounce
on
any
words
or
acts
of
provocation
,
let
alone
revolution
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
words
that
boomed
over
the
loudspeakers
bore
messages
of
peace
,
unity
,
negotiation
and
discipline
.
<END>
<START>
Some
members
of
the
huge
crowd
shouted
``
Viva
peace
,
viva
.
''
<END>
<START>
These
are
curious
times
in
South
African
politics
.
<END>
<START>
The
government
and
the
ANC
,
the
bitterest
of
enemies
,
are
engaged
in
an
elaborate
mating
dance
designed
to
entice
each
other
to
the
negotiating
table
.
<END>
<START>
Pretoria
releases
the
ANC
leaders
,
most
of
whom
were
serving
life
sentences
,
and
allows
them
to
speak
freely
,
hoping
that
the
ANC
will
abandon
its
use
of
violence
.
<END>
<START>
The
government
of
President
F.W.
de
Klerk
is
using
this
situation
to
improve
its
international
image
and
head
off
further
economic
sanctions
.
<END>
<START>
The
result
is
that
the
unthinkable
and
illogical
are
happening
.
<END>
<START>
Six
months
ago
,
government
approval
for
an
ANC
rally
was
inconceivable
.
<END>
<START>
Equally
inconceivable
is
that
the
ANC
,
given
the
chance
to
hold
a
rally
,
would
extend
a
hand
,
albeit
warily
,
to
the
government
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
this
does
n't
mean
that
either
the
government
or
the
ANC
is
changing
stripes
--
or
that
either
has
moved
significantly
closer
to
the
other
.
<END>
<START>
The
government
may
ease
repression
in
some
areas
,
but
it
still
keeps
a
tight
grip
in
others
.
<END>
<START>
The
ANC
vows
to
keep
up
pressure
on
the
government
.
<END>
<START>
Speakers
yesterday
called
on
foreign
governments
to
increase
sanctions
against
Pretoria
and
urged
supporters
inside
the
country
to
continue
defying
emergency
restrictions
and
racial
segregation
,
known
as
apartheid
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
can
not
wait
on
the
government
to
make
changes
at
its
own
pace
,
''
Mr.
Sisulu
said
.
<END>
<START>
Because
the
ANC
remains
banned
,
both
the
government
,
which
approved
the
rally
,
and
the
organizers
,
who
orchestrated
it
,
denied
it
was
an
ANC
rally
.
<END>
<START>
They
both
called
it
a
``
welcome
home
''
gathering
.
<END>
<START>
Nevertheless
,
an
ANC
rally
by
any
other
name
is
still
an
ANC
rally
.
<END>
<START>
The
recently
released
leaders
sat
high
atop
a
podium
in
one
section
of
the
stadium
stands
.
<END>
<START>
Behind
them
was
a
huge
ANC
flag
and
an
even
bigger
sign
that
said
``
ANC
Lives
,
ANC
Leads
.
''
<END>
<START>
Next

was
the
red
flag
of
the
outlawed
South
African
Communist
Party
,
which
has
long

an
ANC

.
<END>
<START>
In
the
stands
,
people
waved
ANC
flags
,
wore
ANC
T-shirts
,
sang
ANC
songs
and

ANC

.
<END>
<START>
``
Today
,
''
said
Mr.
Sisulu
,
``
the
ANC
has
captured
the
center
stage
of
political

.
''
<END>
<START>
If
these
conditions
are

,

,

ANC
would

discuss

.
<END>
<START>
``
There
can
be
no

armed

,
''
he

.
``
<END>
<START>

date
,
we
see
no
clear

that
the
government
is
serious
about
negotiations
.
<END>
<START>
All
their
utterances
are
vague
.
''
<END>
<START>
Echoing
a
phrase
from
Mr.
de
Klerk
,
Mr.
Sisulu
said
,
``
Let
all
of
us
who
love
this
country
engage
in
the
task
of
building
a
new
South
Africa
.
<END>
<START>
But
now
Westinghouse
is
enjoying
a
resurgence
in
demand
for
both
steam
and
combustion
turbines
and
may
even
join
the
growing
legion
of
independent
electric
producers
.
<END>
<START>
And
with
its
new
venture
with
Japan
's
Mitsubishi
Heavy
Industries
Ltd.
,
announced
last
week
,
it
is
poised
to
penetrate
growing
markets
overseas
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
first
time
since
the
mid-1970s
,
Westinghouse
this
year
has
seen
a
significant
increase
in
orders
for
power
plants
.
<END>
<START>
Most
are
from
independent
producers
instead
of
regulated
utilities
,
and
Westinghouse
believes
it
will
ride
a
wave
of
demand
stretching
over
the
next
six
years
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
agree
,
predicting
that
the
revived
market
could
significantly
boost
Westinghouse
's
bottom
line
in
coming
years
.
<END>
<START>
``
Westinghouse
's
earnings
could
be
materially
enhanced
in
the
mid-1990s
or
sooner
,
''
says
Russell
L.
Leavitt
,
of
Salomon
Brothers
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
expects
a
need
for
140,000
megawatts
of
new
generation
in
the
U.S.
over
the
next
decade
.
<END>
<START>
Already
this
year
,
it
has
received
orders
for
four
150-megawatt
advanced
combustion
turbines
from
Florida
Power
&
Light
Co.
and
for
two
300-megawatt
plants
from
Intercontinental
Energy
Corp.
,
among
others
.
<END>
<START>
Westinghouse
's
own
role
as
a
supplier
also
is
changing
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
past
,
the
company
usually
took
token
equity
positions
in
power
plants
it
supplied
as
a
``
kicker
''
to
close
deals
.
<END>
<START>
But
last
June
's
annnouncement
that
Westinghouse
would
put
up
all
of
the
$
70
million
to
build
a
new
55-megawatt
plant
could
herald
a
new
age
.
<END>
<START>
Westinghouse
's
plant
will
provide
electrical
power
to
the
Southern
California
Edison
Co.
and
backup
power
and
steam
to
the
U.S.
Borax
&
Chemical
Co
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
agreement
,
Westinghouse
will
be
able
to
purchase
smaller
combustion
turbines
from
its
Japanese
partner
,
and
package
and
sell
them
with
its
own
generators
and
other
equipment
.
<END>
<START>
Westinghouse
also
jointly
will
bid
on
projects
with
Misubishi
,
giving
it
an
edge
in
developing
Asian
markets
.
<END>
<START>
The
Westinghouse-Mitsubishi
venture
was
designed
as
a
non-equity
transaction
,
circumventing
any
possible
antitrust
concerns
.
<END>
<START>
Westinghouse
carefully
crafted
the
agreement
because
the
Justice
Department
earlier
this
year
successfully
challenged
a
proposed
steam
turbine
joint
venture
with
Asea
Brown
Boveri
.
<END>
<START>
Westinghouse
expects
about
half
of
its
new
orders
for
turbines
to
come
from
independent
producers
for
at
least
the
next
six
years
.
<END>
<START>
Even

.
<END>
<START>
The
rationale
for

'

is
clear
:
Your
company
will

.

<START>

,

today
are

more

as

than

.
<END>
<START>
However
,

,

.
<END>
<START>
``
But

,

are

.
<END>
<START>

.
''
<END>
<START>

that

speed

of
their
service
train
their
managers
to
lead
and
participate
in

that
increase

and
improve

in

.
<END>
<START>
Managers
learn
to
spot
opportunities
to
increase
customer
satisfaction
through
speed
,
and
shift
some
responsibility
for
analyzing
,

and

work

from

to

.
<END>
<START>
One
team
at
the
Federal
Express
Ground
Operations
station
in
Natick
,
Mass.
,
focused
on
a
particularly
time-sensitive
operation
:
the
morning
package
sort
.
<END>
<START>
Every
morning
,
tractor-trailer
trucks
arrive
at
the
Natick
Ground
Station
from
Boston
's
Logan
Airport
,
carrying
the
day
's
package
load
.
<END>
<START>
In
peak
periods
that
load
may
include
4,000
pieces
.
<END>
<START>
The
packages
must
be
sorted
quickly
and
distributed
to
smaller
vans
for
delivery
,
so
couriers
can
be
on
the
road
by
8:35
.
<END>
<START>
No
customer
is
present
at
the
morning
package
sort
,
but
the
process
is
nevertheless
critical
to
customer
satisfaction
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're
committed
to
deliver
the
customer
's
package
by
a
stated
time
,
usually
10:30
,
''
notes
Glenn
Mortimer
,
a
Federal
Express
courier
who
led
the
Natick
team
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
sooner
our
vans
hit
the
road
each
morning
,
the
easier
it
is
for
us
to
fulfill
that
obligation
.
''
<END>
<START>
``
We
suspected
there
was
downtime
built
into
our
process
.
<END>
<START>
But
we
did
n't
know
just
where
it
was
until
we
completed
our
data
gathering
,
''
Mr.
Mortimer
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
used
the
data
to
redesign
our
sorting
system
and
put
our
resources
where
they
could
do
the
most
good
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
team
even
created
a
points
system
to
identify
those
couriers
and
subgroups
that
were
doing
the
most
to
reduce
package-sort
cycle
time
.
<END>
<START>
Winners
of
the
friendly
competition
earn
a
steak
dinner
out
with
their
spouses
.
<END>
<START>
``
Monitoring
shows
that
the
Natick
team
's
new
system
really
does
reduce
cycle
time
for
the
morning
package
sort
,
''
reports
James
Barksdale
,
chief
operating
officer
at
Federal
Express
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
vans
leave
at
least
15
minutes
earlier
,
on
average
,
than
they
used
to
.
<END>
<START>
And
service
levels
have
increased
to
the
point
where
they
're
consistently
above
99
%
.
''
<END>
<START>
A
cross-functional
team
at
Union
Carbide
's
Tonawanda
,
N.Y.
,
facility
,
which
produces
air-separation
plants
,
followed
a
similar
path
to
reduce
manufacturing
cycle
time
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
team
included
craftsmen
from
the
shop
floor
as
well
as
engineering
,
scheduling
and
purchasing
personnel
,
''
reports
Alan
Westendorf
,
director
of
quality
.
<END>
<START>
``
First
,
they
produced
a
flowchart
detailing
the
process
by
which
an
air-separation
plant
actually
gets
built
.
<END>
<START>
Then
they
identified
snags
in
the
process
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
team
then
proposed
modifications
in
their
work
process
to
management
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
streamlined
manufacturing
process
benefits
our
customers
in
at
least
two
ways
,
''
Mr.
Westendorf
concludes
.
<END>
<START>
``
First
,
we
have
better
quality
assurance
than
ever
,
because
the
people
building
the
product
have
taken
on
more
responsibility
for
the
quality
of
their
own
work
.
<END>
<START>
Second
,
we
trimmed
more
than
a
month
off
the
time
required
to
deliver
a
finished
product
.
''
<END>
<START>
At
Grumman
's
Aircraft
Systems
Division
,
a
cross-functional
team
reduced
the
cycle
time
required
to
produce
a
new
business
proposal
for
an
important
government
contract
.
<END>
<START>
The
team
was
composed
of
representatives
from
engineering
,
manufacturing
,
corporate
estimating
,
flight
test
,
material
,
quality
control
,
and
other
departments
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
needed
contributions
from
all
these
departments
to
generate
the
proposal
,
''
says
Carl
Anton
,
configuration-data
manager
for
Grumman
's
A-6
combat
aircraft
program
.
<END>
<START>
Armed
with
this
shared
understanding
and
requisite
background
information
,
each
department
developed
its
specialized
contribution
to
the
proposal
,
submitting
data
and
cost
estimates
on
a
closely
managed
schedule
.
<END>
<START>
The
team
trimmed
more
than
two
months
from
the
cycle
time
previously
required
to
develop
comparable
proposals
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
team
eliminated
the
crisis
mentality
that
proposal
deadlines
can
generate
.
<END>
<START>
The
result
was
a
more
thoughtful
,
complete
and
competitive
proposal
,
''
Mr.
Anton
concludes
.
<END>
<START>
The
successes
achieved
at
Federal
Express
,
Union
Carbide
and
Grumman
suggest
that
managing
speed
may
be
an
underutilized
source
of
competitive
advantage
.
<END>
<START>
Managers
in
all
three
companies
recognize

as
a
component
of
quality
and
a
key
to
customer
satisfaction
.
<END>
<START>
They
effectively

.
<END>
<START>
And
they
prepare
all

to
increase
the

their
own
work
.

<START>
Mr.
Labovitz
is
president
of
ODI
,
a
consulting
firm
in
Burlington
,
Mass
.
<END>
<START>
Home
taping
of
pre-recorded
music
cuts
into
record
industry
revenues
,
but
banning
home
taping
would
hurt
consumers
even
more
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
the
conclusion
of
an
independent
report
prepared
by
the
Office
of
Technology
Assessment
at
the
request
of
the
House
and
Senate
judiciary
committees
.
<END>
<START>
The
report
is
to
be
released
today
.
<END>
<START>
The
report
says
the
availability
of
such
advanced
analog
recording
equipment
as
cassette
recorders
does
n't
seem
to
increase
the
quantity
of
home
copying
.
<END>
<START>
The
people
who
tape
the
most
buy
the
most
.
''
<END>
<START>
Trish
Heimers
,
a
spokesperson
for
RIAA
says
her
organization
has
n't
received
a
copy
of
the
completed
report
yet
and
has
no
immediate
comment
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
disappointing
sales
of
DAT
machines
here
and
abroad
so
far
have
not
seemed
to
warrant
the
three
years
of
legal
wrangling
that
went
into
the
agreement
.
<END>
<START>
The
study
says
that
the
``
ambiguous
legal
status
''
of
home
copying
makes
it
``
appropriate
to
examine
the
effects
on
consumers
,
as
well
as
on
industry
.
''
<END>
<START>
Reports
by
the
Office
of
Technology
Assessment
do
n't
prescribe
any
specific
legislative
action
but
suggest
a
range
of
options
that
Congress
may
pursue
.
<END>
<START>
Switzerland
's
most
famous
raider
says
he
is
n't
one
.
<END>
<START>
Werner
K.
Rey
believes

are
made
by
being
friendly
.
<END>
<START>
He
achieved
this
in
part

an
uncanny

for

in
the
door

established
European

.
<END>
<START>
Shareholders
must

merger

of

two

in

.
<END>
<START>
But

is
almost
certain
since
Mr.
Rey
and
a
friendly
Adia
management
are

.
<END>
<START>
This
will

his
return
on
an
original
investment
of
between
50
million
Swiss
francs
and
80
million
Swiss
francs
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Rey
bought
a

in
Inspectorate
for
18
million
Swiss
francs
in
1982
,
building

the
little-known
engineering
company
with

and

.
<END>
<START>
``
I
like
to
succeed
,
''

Rey
during

recent

of
working
at

,

.
<END>
<START>
Home
is
an
estate
with

meadows
opening
onto
Lake
Geneva
and
a
low-slung
house
whose
rooms
overlook
the
water
and

.

.
<END>
<START>

Renoir

.

<START>
Zurich-based

lists
Mr.
Rey
as
having
a

1.5

francs
.
<END>
<START>
Writes

``
No

so

...
<END>
<START>

.

<START>

:

.
''
<END>
<START>

,

<START>

''
an
image
that
has
proved
hard
to
overcome
.
<END>
<START>
Investing
four
million
Swiss
francs
earned
from
his
financial
transactions
and
two
million
Swiss
francs
from
his
parents
and
his
wife
,
Mr.
Rey
acquired
20
%
of
Bally
's
shares
.
<END>
<START>
But
such
tactics
were
alien
to
Switzerland
in
1976
,
and
still
are
n't
common
because
of
share
restrictions
that
companies
are
allowed
to
maintain
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Rey
made
50
million
Swiss
francs
on
the
sale
.
<END>
<START>
``
Bally
was
not
an
unfriendly
takeover
,
''
he
insists
.
<END>
<START>
Buying

willing

makes

,
Mr.
Rey
contends
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
bought
from
willing
shareholders
.
''
<END>
<START>
Nevertheless
,
Mr.
Rey
has
been
very

since
then
to
make

are
welcome
.
<END>
<START>
And

has
worked

his

.
<END>
<START>
In
1979
,

as

of
the
Swiss

works
Selve
,

.
<END>
<START>
With

in

and

,

.
<END>
<START>
But

brought

a

in
the
next

between
the
country
's

producers
;
the
increased
efficiency
has
perked
up

industry
.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>
Once

's

less
than

.
<END>
<START>
But

,

.
<END>
<START>
A

among

60

to

.
<END>
<START>
They

.
<END>

,

's

,

.

Sulzer

,

.

.

<START>
If
a
TV
weatherman
gets
butterflies
facing
the
camera
again
after
a
questionable
forecast
,
Donald
H.
Straszheim
surely
understands
.
<END>
<START>
The
chief
economist
of
Merrill
Lynch
&
Co.
finds
himself
in
such
a
position
as
he
buzzes
the
Midwest
on
his
first
road
trip
since
backpedaling
on
a
major
prediction
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Straszheim
expects
he
will
take
some
heat
,
and
he
's
right
.
<END>
<START>
Since
the
last
time
he
traveled
this
way
several
months
ago
,
he
has
recanted
a
series
of
bold
forecasts
of
a
recession
.
<END>
<START>
In
February
1988
,
for
example
,
Merrill
Lynch
's
weekly
commentary
announced
that
``
the
economy
is
likely
to
fall
into
recession
in
early
1989
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
forecasts
were
widely
disseminated
,
and
,
in
a
splashy
ad
campaign
launched
in
the
summer
of
1988
,
Merrill
Lynch
urged
investors
to
buy
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
The
firm
also
raised
the
percentage
of
bonds
in
its
model
portfolio
from
40
%
to
45
%
and
later
to
55
%
.
<END>
<START>
He
softened
the
talk
about
a
recession
.
<END>
<START>
And
,
just
recently
,
Merrill
Lynch
cut
the
recommended
bondholdings
back
to
50
%
.
<END>
<START>
While
such
changes
might
sound
minor
,
they
are
n't
:
Merrill
Lynch
manages
or
oversees
some
$
300
billion
in
retail
accounts
that
include
everything
from
mutual
funds
to
individual
annuities
.
<END>
<START>
Two
well-known
colleagues
who
believe
Mr.
Straszheim
was
right
the
first
time
are
David
Bostian
Jr.
and
A.
Gary
Shilling
,
both
of
whom
run
their
own
New
York
research
firms
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bostian
said
in
August
that
his
macroeconomic
index
signaled
recession
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Shilling
,
who
was
Merrill
Lynch
's
chief
economist
from
1967
to
1971
,
has
heralded
a
recession
for
months
.
<END>
<START>
``
My
own
personal
opinion
is
that
Don
threw
in
the
towel
just
about
the
time
he
should
have
doubled
his
bet
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Now
a
rocky
stock
market
and
weak
corporate
profits
may
further
threaten
the
economy
.
<END>
<START>
He
adds
,
``
That
's
the
forecasting
business
.
''
<END>
<START>
However
risky
the
business
,
it
's
brisk
these
days
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
surprisingly
durable
seven-year
economic
expansion
has
made
mincemeat
of
more
than
one
forecast
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
n't
the
quiet
economic
science
practiced
in
the
universities
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
the
commercial
version
.
<END>
<START>
Carrying
the
new
message
on
the
road
,
Mr.
Straszheim
meets
confrontation
that
often
occurs
in
inverse
proportion
to
the
size
of
the
client
.
<END>
<START>
No
sophisticated
professional
expects
economists
to
be
right
all
the
time
.
<END>
<START>
Some
smaller
clients
do
n't
seem
to
notice
his
switch
.
<END>
<START>
But
with
some
clients
,
the
talk
can
heat
up
a
bit
.
<END>
<START>
Dennis
O'Brien
,
the
treasurer
of
Commonwealth
Edison
Co.
in
Chicago
,
adopts
a
polite
approach
,
waiting
for
an
opportunity
to
ask
about
the
forecast
.
<END>
<START>
A
good
half-hour
into
breakfast
at
the
Palmer
House
,
Mr.
O'Brien
looks
up
from
his
plate
after
Mr.
Straszheim
says
something
about
people
who
believe
interest
rates
are
about
to
nosedive
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
'm
one
of
them
who
hope
they
will
,
with
$
6
billion
in
debt
on
the
books
.
<END>
<START>
Is
that
the
forecast
?
''
Mr.
O'Brien
asks
,
trying
to
pin
down
the
economist
.
<END>
<START>
He
does
n't
fully
succeed
,
although
Mr.
Straszheim
lists
an
array
of
interest-rate
scenarios
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
chilly
conference
room
at
Alliance
Capital
Management
in
Minneapolis
,
in
contrast
,
the
firm
's
money
managers
seem
ready
to
pin
Mr.
Straszheim
to
the
wall
.
<END>
<START>
Alfred
Harrison
,
the
manager
,
shoves
Mr.
Straszheim
's
handout
back
at
him
:
``
Do
we
want
to
go
through
this
?
<END>
<START>
Or
can
we
ask
you
why
you
changed
your
forecast
just
when
it
's
about
to
be
right
?
''
<END>
<START>
Swiveling
in
his
chair
,
Mr.
Straszheim
replies
that
the
new
outlook
,
though
still
weak
,
does
n't
justify
calling
a
recession
right
now
.
``
<END>
<START>
It
's
all
in
this
handout
you
do
n't
want
to
look
at
.
<END>
<START>
We
could
still
have
a
recession
''
at
some
point
.
<END>
<START>
One
of
Mr.
Straszheim
's
recurring
themes
is
that
the
state
of
the
economy
is
n't
a
simple
black
or
white
.
<END>
<START>
Sometimes
,
like
now
,
it
's
gray
.
<END>
<START>
This
somewhat-ambiguous
assessment
moves
one
Alliance
portfolio
manager
to
ask
:
``
So
,
what
is
this
--
a
Stealth
recession
?
''
<END>
<START>
Another
challenges
Merrill
Lynch
's
bond
recommendation
last
year
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're
not
running
that
ad
campaign
any
more
,
''
Mr.
Straszheim
snaps
in
a
rare
show
of
irritation
.
<END>
<START>
He
adds
,
``
I
think
it
was
a
fairly
decent
call
.
''
<END>
<START>
Explaining
his
change
of
mind
,
Mr.
Straszheim
says
later
,
``
It
's
hard
to
pin
this
on
one
factor
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
says
the
economy
,
and
especially
the
employment
numbers
,
look
much
better
than
he
expected
;
interest
rates
have
generally
declined
;
inflation
has
n't
run
amok
.
<END>
<START>
``
Our
business
is
constantly
looking
at
all
these
things
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
His
new
forecast
calls
for
``
a
soft
landing
.
''
<END>
<START>
And
it
may
be
right
,
judging
from
last
week
's
report
that
inflation-adjusted
gross
national
product
rose
at
a
2.5
%
annual
rate
in
the
third
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Shilling
understands
Mr.
Straszheim
's
problems
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
's
unbelievable
pressure
on
economists
to
forecast
these
numbers
,
''
he
says
.
``
<END>
<START>
You
make
a
forecast
,
and
then
you
become
its
prisoner
.
''
<END>
<START>
It
is
indeed
hard
to
back
away
from
a
widely
publicized
forecast
,
and
Mr.
Straszheim
is
fidgeting
with
the
handcuffs
on
this
trip
.
<END>
<START>
His
approach
to
the
recantation
is
direct
but
low-key
.
<END>
<START>
``
For
some
time
,
we
had
forecast
negative
third
-
and
fourth-quarter
growth
.
<END>
<START>
We
pulled
that
forecast
,
''
he
begins
matter-of-factly
in
a
meeting
with
Piper
,
Jaffray
&
Hopwood
Inc.
officials
in
Minneapolis
,
the
first
stop
.
<END>
<START>
Crane
Co.
said
it
holds
an
8.9
%
stake
in
Milton
Roy
Corp.
,
an
analytical-instruments
maker
,
and
may
seek
control
of
the
company
.
<END>
<START>
Crane
,
a
maker
of
engineered
products
for
aerospace
,
construction
,
defense
and
other
uses
,
made
the
disclosure
in
a
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
filing
.
<END>
<START>
Crane
officials
did
n't
return
phone
calls
seeking
comment
.
<END>
<START>
Crane
holds
504,200
Milton
Roy
shares
,
including
254,200
bought
from
Sept.
14
to
Thursday
for
$
15.50
to
$
16.75
each
.
<END>
<START>
In
New

Stock
Exchange
composite

Friday
,
Milton
Roy
shares
leaped
$
2
,
to
$
18.375
each
,
while
Crane
sank
$
1.125
,
to
$
21.125
a

.
<END>
<START>
John
M.
McNamara
,
chief

of
Milton
Roy
,
said
the
company
has
no
comment
on

's
