.
<END>
<START>
Milton
Roy
recently
fended
off
unsolicited
overtures
from
Thermo
Electron
Corp.
,
a
Waltham
,
Mass.
,
maker
of
biomedical
products
.
<END>
<START>
Milton
Roy
disclosed
in
May
that
it
was
approached
for
a
possible
acquisition
by
Thermo
Electron
,
which
agreed
to
purchase
Milton
Roy
's
liquid-chromatography
line
for
$
22
million
in
February
.
<END>
<START>
Thermo
Electron
acquired
some
6
%
of
Milton
Roy
's
common
stock
before
throwing
in
the
towel
and
reducing
its
stake
in
early
September
.
<END>
<START>
Gabelli
Group
began
raising
its
Milton
Roy
stake
in
July
,
and
holds
14.6
%
,
according
to
a
recent
SEC
filing
.
<END>
<START>
It
has
n't
made
merger
overtures
to
the
board
.
<END>
<START>
The
companies
are
automotive-emissions-testing
concerns
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
terms
,
Milton
Roy
will
pay
an
initial
$
4
million
for
the
operations
and
additional
payments
during
the
next
four
years
based
on
the
earnings
performance
of
the
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
nine
months
,
Milton
Roy
earned
$
6.6
million
,
or
$
1.18
a
share
,
on
sales
of
$
94.3
million
.
<END>
<START>
Last
week
the
British
displayed
unusual
political
immaturity
.
<END>
<START>
The
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
,
Nigel
Lawson
,
resigned
because
Prime
Minister
Thatcher
would
not
fire
her
trusted
adviser
Sir
Alan
Walters
.
<END>
<START>
Behind
the
silly
posturing
lies
a
real
dispute
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lawson
and
his
European-minded
colleagues
want
the
British
pound
formally
tied
to
the
West
German
mark
.
<END>
<START>
Sir
Alan
considers
this
an
ill-advised
and
costly
policy
.
<END>
<START>
As
there
is
an
effort
to
``
anchor
the
dollar
''
either
to
gold
or
other
currencies
,
the
dispute
is
worth
examining
.
<END>
<START>
Until
his
resignation
,
Mr.
Lawson
had
been
conducting
British
monetary
policy
as
if
the
pound
were
tied
to
the
mark
.
<END>
<START>
When
Mrs.
Thatcher
cut
the
top
tax
rate
to
40
%
,
Mr.
Lawson
flooded
the
country
with
money
to
prevent
the
pound
from
rising
against
the
mark
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
he
reignited
the
inflation
that
Mrs.
Thatcher
,
through
a
long
and
costly
effort
,
had
subdued
.
<END>
<START>
With
inflation
surging
,
the
pound
began
falling
against
the
mark
.
<END>
<START>
To
keep
the
exchange
rate
pegged
,
Mr.
Lawson
tightened
monetary
policy
and
pushed
interest
rates
up
to
15
%
.
<END>
<START>
This
doubled
the
mortgage
interest
rates
of
the
many
new
homeowners
that
Mrs.
Thatcher
's
policies
had
created
,
producing
widespread
disaffection
and
pushing
Labor
ahead
in
the
polls
.
<END>
<START>
This
put
Mrs.
Thatcher
in
a
bind
.
<END>
<START>
The
concept
of
European
integration
is
one
of
those
grand
schemes
that
appeal
to
intellectuals
,
the
media
and
the
imagination
,
but
are
full
of
practical
pitfalls
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
pound
had
been
tied
to
the
mark
,
the
British
would
have
been
unable
to
cut
their
exorbitant
tax
rates
.
<END>
<START>
The
reason
is
simple
.
<END>
<START>
When
a
country
cuts
tax
rates
,
it
makes
itself
more
attractive
to
investors
and
drives
up
the
value
of
its
currency
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
fear
of
disturbing
EMS
exchange-rate
relationships
that
caused
the
Chirac
government
in
France
to
be
timid
about
cutting
tax
rates
.
<END>
<START>
The
price
of
attracting
capital
--
whether
one
's
own
or
that
of
foreigners
--
is
a
trade
deficit
.
<END>
<START>
To
avoid
this
deficit
Mr.
Lawson
inflated
the
pound
in
order
to
prevent
its
rise
.
<END>
<START>
This
misguided
policy
could
not
prevent
a
British
trade
deficit
.
<END>
<START>
Consequently
,
Mr.
Lawson
saddled
Mrs.
Thatcher
with
a
record
trade
deficit
,
renewed
inflation
and
high
interest
rates
--
three
political
failures
in
a
row
.
<END>
<START>
Little
wonder
that
Mrs.
Thatcher
's
opponents
were
so
anxious
to
keep
Mr.
Lawson
in
office
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
extraordinary
that
the
British
Treasury
thought
it
could
prevent
a
trade
deficit
by
inflating
the
pound
.
<END>
<START>
This
change
in
the
British
capital
account
required
an
offsetting
change
in
the
trade
account
,
a
change
that
could
not
be
prevented
by
pegging
the
currency
.
<END>
<START>
Nigel
Lawson
was
a
victim
of
the
immense
confusion
in
thought
that
has
been
characteristic
of
Western
financial
circles
during
the
1980s
.
<END>
<START>
The
most
important
governments
have
ignored
the
role
of
low
tax
rates
in
attracting
real
capital
investment
,
instead
emphasizing
financial
flows
in
response
to
high
interest
rates
.
<END>
<START>
This
has
led
them
in
a
fruitless
and
destructive
policy
circle
.
<END>
<START>
First
comes
monetary
expansion
to
drive
down
the
currency
's
value
that
was
pushed
up
by
tax-rate
reduction
.
<END>
<START>
Then
,
when
the
currency
falls
,
interest
rates
are
raised
to
attract
financial
flows
in
order
to
stabilize
the
exchange
rate
.
<END>
<START>
This
policy
is
totally
mindless
,
and
Sir
Alan
is
correct
to
point
out
its
deficiencies
.
<END>
<START>
Britain
and
all
of
Europe
need
to
reconsider
the
prospects
for
European
integration
in
light
of
the
possible
reunification
and
neutralization
of
Germany
.
<END>
<START>
A
unified
Germany
that
remained
within
the
Western
alliance
would
give
Germany
such
an
overshadowing
position
that
all
other
members
of
a
unified
Europe
would
become
vassals
of
the
German
state
.
<END>
<START>
Unless
the
Soviet
Union
collapses
,
German
reunification
is
likely
to
require
Germany
's
neutralization
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
least
,
we
must
recognize
the
futility
of
trying
to
use
exchange-rate
intervention
to
offset
the
effects
of
tax-rate
reduction
on
capital
flows
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Roberts
was
assistant
Treasury
secretary
under
President
Reagan
.
<END>
<START>
Joseph
P.
Jordan
,
52
years
old
,
becomes
president
,
chief
executive
officer
and
a
director
of
the
bank
company
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Jordan
,
formerly
president
and
chief
executive
of
Fishkill
National
Bank
in
Beacon
,
N.Y.
,
succeeds
Donald
Broderick
,
who
died
at
52
in
an
automobile
accident
.
<END>
<START>
Personal
spending
grew
0.2
%
in
September
to
a
$
3.526
trillion
annual
rate
,
the
Commerce
Department
said
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
the
smallest
monthly
increase
in
a
year
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
same
time
,
personal
income
was
held
down
by
the
effects
of
Hurricane
Hugo
,
which
tore
through
parts
of
North
and
South
Carolina
in
late
September
.
<END>
<START>
The
department
said
personal
income
rose
0.3
%
in
September
to
a
$
4.469
trillion
rate
but
would
have
climbed
0.6
%
had
it
not
been
for
the
storm
.
<END>
<START>
Among
the
economic
effects
of
the
hurricane
was
a
sharp
drop
in
rental
income
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
new
statistics
show
that
by
September
,
the
burst
in
spending
seemed
to
be
tapering
off
.
<END>
<START>
Many
economists
expect
the
weakness
to
continue
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
think
the
consumer
has
pretty
well
played
himself
out
,
''
said
David
Littman
,
senior
economist
at
Manufacturers
National
Bank
of
Detroit
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
do
n't
think
there
's
a
lot
in
the
wings
''
in
other
sectors
of
the
economy
to
keep
growth
above
1
%
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
third
quarter
,
the
economy
grew
at
a
moderate
2.5
%
annual
rate
.
<END>
<START>
In
August
,
personal
income
rose
0.3
%
and
spending
grew
0.9
%
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
have
attributed
much
of
the
summer
's
spurt
in
spending
to
bargain
car
prices
at
the
end
of
the
model
year
.
<END>
<START>
Car
sales
slackened
in
September
after
the
1990
models
were
introduced
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
the
Commerce
Department
report
,
spending
on
durable
goods
--
items
expected
to
last
at
least
three
years
,
including
cars
--
declined
by
$
6.2
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
nation
's
savings
rate
was
unchanged
in
September
at
4.9
%
of
after-tax
income
,
far
below
the
5.6
%
it
reached
in
July
.
<END>
<START>
All
the
figures
are
adjusted
for
seasonal
variations
.
<END>
<START>
Here
is
the
Commerce
Department
's
latest
report
on
personal
income
.
<END>
<START>
The
figures
are
at
seasonally
adjusted
annual
rates
in
trillions
of
dollars
.
<END>
<START>
CRA
Ltd.
said
it
agreed
to
sell
a
40
%
stake
in
its
Howick
coal
mine
in
the
state
of
New
South
Wales
to
Mitsubishi
Development
Pty.
of
Japan
.
<END>
<START>
The
price
was
n't
disclosed
.
<END>
<START>
The
agreement
is
subject

approval
.
<END>
<START>
RA
acquired
the
Howick
coal
mine
Oct.
20
when
it
bought
British
Petroleum
Co.
's
Australian
coal
interests
for
$
275
million
.
<END>
<START>
CRA
said
then
that
it
was
looking
for
a

for
the
mine
,
which
produces
more
than
three
million
metric
tons
of

a

.
<END>
<START>
CRA
is
49%-owned
by
RTZ
Corp.
of

.
<END>
<START>
Control
Data
Corp.
,
which
just
months

was
hemorrhaging
financially
,
thinks
it
will
be
healthy
enough
soon
to
consider

.
<END>
<START>
``
I
'm
not
saying
everything
is
hunky-dory
,
but
we
have
completed
the
transition
,
''
Robert
M.
Price
,
chairman
and

,
said
in

.
<END>
<START>
``
Transition
''
is
a
reference
to
the
company
's

.

<END>
<START>
Dozens

''

``

,
''

.

.

.

<START>
Despite
politicians
'
hand-wringing
about
the
federal
budget
,
the
government
ended
fiscal
1989
with
a
$
152.08
billion
deficit
,
about
the
same
as
the
two
previous
years
.
<END>
<START>
Even
White
House
budget
director
Richard
Darman
had
trouble
finding
a
silver
lining
in
the
report
.
<END>
<START>
The
federal
deficit
was
$
155.15
billion
in
1988
and
$
149.69
billion
in
1987
.
<END>
<START>
Because
the
Resolution
Trust
Corp
.
could
n't
spend
the
money
fast
enough
,
the
savings-and-loan
outlays
were
pushed
into
fiscal
1990
.
<END>
<START>
Nevertheless
,
the
1989
deficit
still
exceeded
the
$
136
billion
target
set
by
the
Gramm-Rudman
deficit-reduction
law
by
$
16
billion
,
a
reminder
of
that
law
's
shortcomings
.
<END>
<START>
The
law
sets
a
deficit
target
of
$
100
billion
for
fiscal
1990
.
<END>
<START>
A
partisan
fight
over
cutting
capital-gains
taxes
has
slowed
the
progress
of
1990
deficit-reduction
legislation
almost
to
a
halt
,
triggering
across-the-board
spending
cuts
under
the
Gramm-Rudman
law
.
<END>
<START>
The
White
House
and
the
Democratic
leadership
in
Congress
blame
each
other
for
turning
capital-gains
taxes
into
such
a
divisive
issue
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Neither
side
showed
any
sign
of
retreating
.
<END>
<START>
In
all
,
federal
outlays
amounted
to
$
1.143
trillion
in
1989
,
up
7.5
%
from
the
previous
year
,
the
Treasury
said
.
<END>
<START>
Federal
revenues
rose
9
%
to
$
990.79
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
Treasury
said
a
surge
in
tax
receipts
noted
earlier
in
the
year
did
n't
turn
out
to
be
quite
as
strong
as
it
first
appeared
.
<END>
<START>
The
Treasury
marked
up
its
forecast
by
$
17
million
in
July
,
but
that
proved
to
be
about
$
5
billion
too
optimistic
.
<END>
<START>
The
government
ran
a
deficit
of
$
6.16
billion
in
September
,
compared
with
a
surplus
of
$
10.17
billion
in
September
1988
.
<END>
<START>
Outlays
for
the
month
totaled
$
105.39
billion
,
up
from
$
87.57
billion
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Revenues
were
$
99.23
billion
,
up
from
$
97.74
billion
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
CMS
Energy
Corp.

,

's

.

.

when

.

.

,

.

27

in

and

.

to

first
quarter

30
.
<END>
<START>
The

is
about
$
9
million
.
<END>
<START>

on

was
about
$
18

as

25
.

from

.

<START>
Polly
Peck
International
Inc.
's
agreement
to
acquire
51
%
of
Sansui
Electric
Co.
proves
that
foreign
companies
can
acquire
Japanese
companies
--
if
the
alternative
for
the
Japanese
company
is
extinction
.
<END>
<START>
Japanese

,

to
rebut

of

overseas
,
hailed
the
transaction
as
proof

can
make

in
Japan
.
<END>
<START>
Polly
Peck
's

,
Asil
Nadir
,
echoed
the
official

view
of
the
accord
,
which
was

Friday
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
myths
that
Japan

has
,
I

,
been

,
''

said
.
<END>
<START>
But
analysts
say
Sansui
is
a
special
case
.
<END>
<START>
It
expects
to
post
a
loss
of
6.4
billion
yen
for
the
year
ending
tomorrow
and
its
liabilities
currently
exceed
its
assets
by
about
13.8
billion
yen
.
``
<END>
<START>
If
you
find
sound
,
healthy
companies
in
Japan
,
they
are
not
for
sale
,
''
said
George

,

at
Tokyo-based
Asia

Services
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
But

all

have
bought
only

relative

of
Japanese
companies
this
year
,
while
Japanese
companies
have
acquired

of
foreign

.
<END>
<START>
Nor
do

expect
the
Sansui
deal
to
touch

a
fresh
wave
of
foreign

.
<END>
<START>
Sansui
was
once
one
of
Japan
's
premier
makers
of
expensive
,

stereo
gear
for

.
<END>
<START>
Sansui
was
late
into
the
mini-component
business
and
failed
to
branch
into
other
new
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
As
the
yen
soared
in
recent
years
,
Sansui
's
deepening
financial
problems
became
a
vicious
circle
.
<END>
<START>
While
competitors
moved
production
offshore
in
response
to
the
sagging
competitiveness
of
Japanese
factories
,

lacked
the
money
to
build

in

.
<END>
<START>
``
Our

has
not
been
able
to
cope
very
effectively
with
''
changes
in
the
marketplace
,
said
Ryosuke
Ito
,

's

.
<END>
<START>
But
even

Japanese
company
that

dog
may

,

.
<END>
<START>
``

-LCB-

-RCB-

,

,
''

.

,

.

.

<START>
Joann
S.

in

to

.
<END>
<START>
The
bolstered
cellular
agreement
between
BellSouth
Corp.
and
LIN
Broadcasting
Corp.
carries
heightened
risks
and
could
fail
to
fend
off
McCaw
Cellular
Communications
Inc.
,
the
rival
suitor
for
LIN
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
the
amended
pact
shows
how
McCaw
's
persistence
has
pushed
LIN
and
BellSouth
into
a
corner
,
forcing
huge
debt
on
the
proposed
new
company
.
<END>
<START>
The
debt
,
estimated
at
$
4.7
billion
,
could
mortgage
the
cellular
company
's
future
earning
power
in
order
to
placate
some
LIN
holders
in
the
short
term
.
<END>
<START>
The
plan
still
calls
for
LIN
to
combine
its
cellular
telephone
properties
with
BellSouth
's
and
to
spin
off
its
broadcasting
operations
.
<END>
<START>
LIN
said
it
expects
to
borrow
the
money
to
pay
the
dividend
,
but
commitments
from
banks
still
have
n't
been
obtained
.
<END>
<START>
Under
previous
terms
,
holders
would
have
received
a
dividend
of
only
$
20
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
That
money
also
would
have
to
be
borrowed
.
<END>
<START>
In
effect
,
McCaw
has
forced
LIN
's
hand
by
bidding
$
1.9
billion
for
the
stake
earlier
this
month
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're
taking
on
more
debt
than
we
would
have
liked
to
,
''
acknowledged
Michael
Plouf
,
LIN
's
vice
president
and
treasurer
.
<END>
<START>
Analyst
estimate
the
value
of
the
BellSouth
proposal
at
about
$
115
to
$
125
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
They
value
McCaw
's
bid
at
$
112
to
$
118
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
The
previous
BellSouth
pact
was
valued
at
about
$
98
to
$
110
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
McCaw
,
the
largest
provider
of
cellular
telephone
service
in
the
U.S.
,
already
owns
about
9.4
%
of
LIN
's
stock
.
<END>
<START>
Over
the
weekend
,
McCaw
continued
to
call
for
an
auction
of
LIN
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
said
they
expect
McCaw
to
escalate
the
bidding
again
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
game
is
n't
over
yet
,
''
said
Joel
D.
Gross
,
a
vice
president
at
Donaldson
,
Lufkin
&
Jenrette
Securities
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
``
At
some
point
,
it
will
become
non-economical
for
one
company
.
<END>
<START>
But
I
do
n't
think
we
're
at
that
point
yet
.
''
<END>
<START>
Under
its
revised
proposal
,
Atlanta-based
BellSouth
would
have
a
50
%
interest
in
the
new
cellular
company
and
would
be
responsible
for
half
of
its
debt
.
<END>
<START>
The
provision
,
described
as
``
back-end
''
protection
,
would
require
BellSouth
to
pay
a
price
equivalent
to
what
an
outside
party
might
have
to
pay
.
<END>
<START>
McCaw
's
bid
also
has
a
similar
clause
.
<END>
<START>
Only
McCaw
's
proposal
requires
the
company
to
begin
an
auction
process
in
June
1994
for
remaining
shares
at
third-party
prices
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're
very
pleased
with
the
new
deal
.
<END>
<START>
We
did
n't
expect
BellSouth
to
be
so
responsive
,
''
said
Frederick
A.
Moran
,
president
of
Moran
Asset
Management
Inc.
,
which
holds
500,000
LIN
shares
.
<END>
<START>
BellSouth
's
``
back-end
protection
was
flawed
previously
.
<END>
<START>
We
think
this
is
a
superior
deal
to
McCaw
's
.
<END>
<START>
We
're
surprised
.
<END>
<START>
We
did
n't
think
a
sleeping
-LCB-
Bell
-RCB-
mentality
would
be
willing
to
take
on
dilution
.
''
<END>
<START>
``
How
many
shares
will
be
around
in
1995
?
''
he
asked
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
's
nothing
preventing
BellSouth
from
buying
up
shares
in
the
meanwhile
.
''
<END>
<START>
BellSouth
's
revised
proposal
surprised
many
industry
analysts
,
especially
because
of
the
company
's
willingness
to
accept
some
dilution
of
future
earnings
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
BellSouth
's
cellular
operations
were
among
the
first
in
the
country
to
become
profitable
.
<END>
<START>
For
1988
,
BellSouth
earned
$
1.7
billion
,
or
$
3.51
a
share
,
on
revenue
of
$
13.6
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
were
predicting
1990
BellSouth
earnings
in
the
range
of
$
3.90
a
share
,
or
$
1.9
billion
,
but
now
those
estimates
are
being
scaled
back
.
<END>
<START>
In
composite
trading
Friday
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
,
BellSouth
shares
fell
87.5
cents
to
$
52.125
.
<END>
<START>
In
national
over-the-counter
trading
,
LIN
shares
soared
$
4.625
to
closed
at
$
112.625
,
while
McCaw
fell
$
2.50
a
share
to
$
37.75
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
McCaw
seemed
to
hint
at
that
option
in
a
brief
statement
.
<END>
<START>
Market
makers
in
Nasdaq
over-the-counter
stocks
are
adding
their
voices
to
the
swelling
chorus
of
complaints
about
program
trading
.
<END>
<START>
Their
motivation
,
however
,
has
a
strong
practical
aspect
:
Program
trading
is
hazardous
to
their
paychecks
.
<END>
<START>
The
S&P
500
is
often
used
in
arbitrage
strategies
.
<END>
<START>
Estimates
from
traders
put
it
at
less
than
5
%
of
Nasdaq
's
average
daily
volume
of
roughly
133
million
shares
.
<END>
<START>
Other
market-maker
gripes
:
Program
trading
also
causes
the
Nasdaq
Composite
Index
to
lose
ground
against
other
segments
of
the
stock
market
.
<END>
<START>
Because
of
program
trading
it
is
more
difficult
to
trade
many
OTC
stocks
without
sharp
price
moves
,
a
condition
known
as
illiquidity
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
the
price
volatility
that
is
amplified
by
program
trading
is
undercutting
efforts
to
woo
individual
investors
back
to
an
OTC
market
that
sorely
misses
them
.
<END>
<START>
Some
of
these
problems
are
neither
new
nor
unique
to
the
OTC
market
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
big
,
often
tumultuous
slide
in
stock
prices
this
month
has
turned
some
of
those
who
have
been
profiting
from
the
practice
against
it
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
were
n't
as
concerned
until
they
became
sell
programs
,
''
says
Mr.
DaPuzzo
,
who
now
thinks
it
adds
unnecessary
volatility
.
<END>
<START>
Shearson
Lehman
,
however
,
executes
program
trades
for
clients
.
<END>
<START>
Merrill
Lynch
,
Goldman
Sachs
and
Kidder
Peabody
,
in
addition
to
Shearson
,
do
program-trade
OTC
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
Shearson
,
Merrill
Lynch
and
Goldman
Sachs
say
they
do
so
only
for
customers
,
however
.
<END>
<START>
Kidder
Peabody
does
program
trading
for
its
own
as
well
as
clients
'
accounts
.
<END>
<START>
Of
course
,
there
were
sell
programs
in
past
years
,
too
,
but
they
seem
to
hurt
market
makers
more
painfully
these
days
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
largely
because
of
defensive
measures
they
adopted
after
the
1987
crash
,
when
individual
investors
fled
the
market
and
trading
activity
dwindled
.
<END>
<START>
Market
makers
,
to
cut
costs
,
slashed
inventories
of
stocks
they
keep
on
hand
to
sell
investors
when
other
holders
are
n't
selling
.
<END>
<START>
And
to
protect
their
reduced
capital
investment
from
eroding
further
,
market
makers
became
quicker
to
lower
price
quotes
when
sell
programs
are
in
progress
.
<END>
<START>
On
days
when
prices
are
tumbling
,
they
must
be
willing
to
buy
shares
from
sellers
when
no
one
else
will
.
<END>
<START>
In
such
an
environment
,
market
makers
can
suffer
huge
losses
both
on
trades
made
that
day
at
steadily
dropping
prices
and
in
the
value
of
their
inventories
of
shares
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
makes
no
sense
for
us
to
put
money
at
risk
when
you
know
you
're
going
to
lose
,
''
says
Mr.
Antolini
,
of
Donaldson
Lufkin
.
<END>
<START>
But
this
skittishness
,
Mr.
Antolini
says
,
is
creating
liquidity
problems
in
certain
OTC
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
harder
to
sell
stocks
when
the
sell
programs
come
in
because
some
market
makers
do
n't
want
to
-LCB-
take
the
orders
-RCB-
.
<END>
<START>
No
one
has
big
positions
and
no
one
wants
to
take
big
risks
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
,
he
observes
,
while
makers
suffer
losses
when
program
trading
drags
the
market
down
,
they
also
make
money
when
program
trading
pushes
the
prices
higher
.
<END>
<START>
``
Sometimes
-LCB-
traders
-RCB-
lose
sight
of
that
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
The
OTC
stocks
in
the
S&P
500
include
Nasdaq
's
biggest
,
such
as
Apple
Computer
,
MCI
Communications
,
Tele-Communications
and
Liz
Claiborne
.
<END>
<START>
These
big
stocks
greatly
influence
the
Nasdaq
Composite
Index
.
<END>
<START>
When
the
computers
say
``
sell
,
''
the
composite
tumbles
as
well
as
the
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
.
<END>
<START>
The
problem
,
market
makers
say
,
is
that
while
the
industrial
average
and
the
S&P
500
usually
recover
as
buy
programs
kick
in
,
the
Nasdaq
Composite
frequently
is
left
behind
.
<END>
<START>
This
gap
eventually
closes
,
but
slowly
.
<END>
<START>
The
main
reason
for
this
lag
is
that
individual
investors
own
65
%
of
the
OTC
market
's
capitalization
,
according
to
Mr.
Hardiman
,
much
more
than
on
the
Big
Board
.
<END>
<START>
Such
investors
tend
to
be
more
cautious
than
institutional
investors
are
about
re-entering
the
market
after
massive
selloffs
,
market
makers
say
.
<END>
<START>
Friday
's
Market
Activity
<END>
<START>

,

.

.

,

.

.

.

.

,

.

.

<START>
APARTHEID
FOES
STAGED
a

in

.
<END>
<START>

filled

black

of

and

.

.

,

's

.

,

.

.

<START>
CONGRESSIONAL

.
<END>
<START>
''

,

moves
to

.
<END>
<START>
Ortega
cited

.
<END>
<START>
Lawmakers

.

<START>

,

.

<START>

,

's

,

.

.

.

.

<START>

.

.

,

.

.

,

.

<START>
An

Oct.
17

had

,

's

.

<START>
Died
:
Rudolf

,

,

of
Veba
AG
of

Germany
,
in

,
of

.

<START>
Before
adjustment
for

,
the
association
said
,
orders
were
up
a

5

.

While

an

8
%

%
in

,
foreign
orders
declined
4

after

and
1
%
on

.

In

third

,

rose
a

5
%
and

9
%
.

<START>
Domestic

were
up
a

11
%
and
a
nominal
14
%
,
while
foreign
orders
rose
a
real
1
%
and
a
nominal
5
%
.
<END>
<START>
When
Michael
S.
Perry
took
the
podium
at
a
recent
cosmetics
industry
event
,
more
than
500
executives
packing
the
room
snapped
to
attention
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Perry
,
who
runs
Unilever
Group
's
world-wide
personal-care
business
,
paused
to
scan
the
crowd
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
see
we
have
about
half
the
audience
working
for
us
,
''
he
said
,
tongue
in
cheek
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
other
half
,
we
may
have
before
long
.
''
<END>
<START>
Members
of
the
audience
gasped
or
laughed
nervously
;
their
industry
has
been
unsettled
recently
by
acquisitions
.
<END>
<START>
First
Unilever
,
the
Anglo-Dutch
packaged-goods
giant
,
spent
$
2
billion
to
acquire
brands
such
as
Faberge
and
Elizabeth
Arden
.
<END>
<START>
It
now
holds
the
No.
3
position
at
U.S.
department-store
cosmetic
counters
.
<END>
<START>
Then
Procter
&
Gamble
Co.
agreed
to
buy
Noxell
Corp.
for
$
1.3
billion
.
<END>
<START>
That
acquisition
,
to
be
completed
by
year
end
,
will
include
the
Cover
Girl
and
Clarion
makeup
lines
,
making
P&G
the
top
marketer
of
cosmetics
in
mass-market
outlets
.
<END>
<START>
Though
it
is
far
from
certain
that
companies
best
known
for
selling
Promise
margarine
and
Tide
detergent
will
succeed
in
cosmetics
,
there
's
little
doubt
they
will
shake
up
the
industry
.
<END>
<START>
For
now
,
both
companies
are
keeping
quiet
about
their
specific
plans
.
<END>
<START>
But
industry
watchers
expect
them
to
blend
the
methodical
marketing
strategies
they
use
for
more
mundane
products
with
the
more
intuitive
approach
typical
of
cosmetics
companies
.
<END>
<START>
Likely
changes
include
more
emphasis
on
research
,
soaring
advertising
budgets
and
aggressive
pricing
.
<END>
<START>
But
some
cosmetics-industry
executives
wonder
whether
techniques
honed
in
packaged
goods
will
translate
to
the
cosmetics
business
.
<END>
<START>
Estee
Lauder
Inc.
,
Revlon
Inc.
and
other
cosmetics
houses
traditionally
have
considered
themselves
fashion
enterprises
whose
product
development
is
guided
by
the
creative
intuition
of
their
executives
.
<END>
<START>
Cosmetics
companies
roll
out
new
makeup
colors
several
times
a
year
,
and
since
most
products
can
be
easily
copied
by
competitors
,
they
're
loath
to
test
them
with
consumers
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
're
really
fashion
items
wrapped
up
in
little
jars
.
''
<END>
<START>
In
contrast
to
the
more
artistic
nature
of
traditional
cosmetics
houses
,
Unilever
and
P&G
are
the
habitats
of
organization
men
in
gray-flannel
suits
.
<END>
<START>
Both
companies
are
conservative
marketers
that
rely
on
extensive
market
research
.
<END>
<START>
P&G
,
in
particular
,
rarely
rolls
out
a
product
nationally
before
extensive
test-marketing
.
<END>
<START>
P&G
already
has
shown
it
can
meld
some
traditional
packaged-goods
techniques
with
the
image-making
of
the
cosmetics
trade
in
the
mass-market
end
of
the
business
.
<END>
<START>
Consider
Oil
of
Olay
,
which
P&G
acquired
as
part
of
Richardson-Vicks
International
in
1985
.
<END>
<START>
The
moisturizer
,
introduced
in
1962
,
had
a
dowdy
image
.
<END>
<START>
P&G
set
out
to
reposition
the
brand
by
broadening
the
product
line
to
include
facial
cleansers
and
moisturizers
for
sensitive
skin
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
redesigned
Oil
of
Olay
's
packaging
,
stamping
the
traditional
pink
boxes
with
gold
lines
to
create
a
more
opulent
look
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
P&G
shifted
its
ad
campaign
from
one
targeting
older
women
to
one
featuring
a
woman
in
her
mid-30s
vowing
``
not
to
grow
old
gracefully
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
company
says
sales
have
soared
.
<END>
<START>
Goliaths
like
Unilever
and
P&G
have
enormous
financial
advantages
over
smaller
rivals
.
<END>
<START>
Next
year
,
Noxell
plans
to
roll
out
a
perfume
called
Navy
,
says
George
L.
Bunting
Jr.
,
chairman
of
Noxell
.
<END>
<START>
Without
P&G
's
backing
,
Noxell
might
not
have
been
able
to
spend
the
estimated
$
5
million
to
$
7
million
needed
to
accomplish
that
without
scrimping
on
its
existing
brands
.
<END>
<START>
Packaged-goods
companies
``
will
make
it
tougher
for
smaller
people
to
remain
competitive
,
''
Mr.
Bunting
says
.
<END>
<START>
Further
consolidations
in
the
industry
could
follow
.
<END>
<START>
Rumors
that
Unilever
is
interested
in
acquiring
Schering-Plough
Corp.
's
Maybelline
unit
are
widespread
.
<END>
<START>
Unilever
wo
n't
comment
;
Schering
,
however
,
denies
the
brand
is
for
sale
.
<END>
<START>
The
presence
of
Unilever
and
P&G
is
likely
to
increase
the
impact
of
advertising
on
cosmetics
.
<END>
<START>
While
the
two
are
among
the
world
's
biggest
advertisers
,
most
makers
of
upscale
cosmetics
spend
relatively
little
on
national
ads
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
,
they
focus
on
events
in
department
stores
and
pour
their
promotional
budgets
into
gifts
that
go
along
with
purchases
.
<END>
<START>
Estee
Lauder
,
for
example
,
spends
only
an
estimated
5
%
of
sales
on
advertising
in
the
U.S.
,
and
Mr.
Lauder
says
he
has
no
plans
to
change
his
strategy
.
<END>
<START>
The
most
dramatic
changes
,
however
,
probably
will
come
in
new-product
development
.
<END>
<START>
Nearly
70
%
of
cosmetics
sales
come
through
mass-distribution
outlets
such
as
drug
stores
and
supermarkets
,
according
to
Andrew
Shore
,
an
analyst
at
Shearson
Lehman
Hutton
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
That
figure
has
been
inching
up
for
several
years
.
<END>
<START>
As
the
trend
continues
,
demand
for
mass-market
items
that
are
high
quality
but
only
mid-priced
--
particularly
skin-care
products
--
is
expected
to
increase
.
<END>
<START>
The
packaged-goods
marketers
may
try
filling
that
gap
with
a
spate
of
new
products
.
<END>
<START>
Unlike
the
old-line
cosmetics
houses
,
Unilever
and
P&G
both
have
enormous
research
and
development
bases
to
draw
on
for
new
products
.
<END>
<START>
P&G
,
in
fact
,
is
noted
for
gaining
market
leadership
by
introducing
products
that
offer
a
technical
edge
over
the
competition
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
of
its
Tide
detergent
soared
earlier
this
year
,
for
example
,
after
P&G
introduced
a
version
that
includes
a
bleach
safe
for
all
colors
and
fabrics
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
led
industry
executives
to
speculate
that
future
product
development
will
be
driven
more
by
technological
innovation
than
by
fashion
whims
--
especially
among
mass-market
brands
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
will
be
more
emphasis
on
quality
,
''
says
Guy
Peyrelongue
,
chief
executive
of
Cosmair
Inc.
,
the
U.S.
licensee
of
L'Oreal
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
'll
see
fewer
gimmicks
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
success
for
Unilever
and
P&G
is
far
from
guaranteed
,
as
shown
by
the
many
consumer-product
companies
that
have
tried
and
failed
to
master
the
quirky
beauty
business
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
1970s
,
several
pharmaceutical
and
packaged-goods
companies
,
including
Colgate-Palmolive
Co.
,
Eli
Lilly
&
Co.
,
Pfizer
Inc.
and
Schering-Plough
acquired
cosmetics
companies
.
<END>
<START>
Industry
consultants
say
only
Schering-Plough
,
which
makes
the
mass-market
Maybelline
,
has
maintained
a
meaningful
business
.
<END>
<START>
Colgate
,
which
acquired
Helena
Rubenstein
in
1973
,
sold
the
brand
seven
years
later
after
the
brand
languished
.
<END>
<START>
Unilever
already
has
experienced
some
disappointment
.
<END>
<START>
The
mass-market
Aziza
brand
,
which
it
acquired
in
1987
along
with
Chesebrough-Pond
's
Inc.
,
has
lost
share
,
according
to
industry
analysts
.
<END>
<START>
The
ritzy
world
of
department-store
cosmetics
retailing
,
where
Unilever
is
concentrating
its
efforts
,
may
prove
even
more
treacherous
.
<END>
<START>
In
this
niche
,
makeup
colors
change
seasonally
because
they
are
linked
to
ready-to-wear
fashions
.
<END>
<START>
Because
brand
loyalty
is
weak
and
most
cosmetics
purchases
are
unplanned
,
careful
training
of
store
sales
staffs
by
cosmetics
companies
is
important
.
<END>
<START>
There
may
be
a
truce
in
the
long
war
of
nerves
between
the
White
House
and
Congress
over
how
this
country
conducts
secret
intelligence
operations
abroad
.
<END>
<START>
If
that
attitude
lasts
,
it
could
infuse
covert
action
planning
with
a
level
of
care
and
confidence
that
has
n't
been
seen
in
years
.
<END>
<START>
Over
the
past
week
,
the
president
has
agreed
to
keep
the
committee
informed
,
usually
in
advance
,
of
covert
actions
and
to
put
key
intelligence
decisions
in
writing
.
<END>
<START>
That
was
n't
always
the
way
the
Reagan
administration
handled
such
matters
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bush
has
pledged
as
well
to
respect
the
14-year-old
executive
order
barring
U.S.
agents
from
assassinating
foreign
leaders
or
helping
others
to
do
so
.
<END>
<START>
Congress
never
fully
trusted
former
CIA
chief
William
Casey
and
National
Security
Adviser
John
Poindexter
to
honor
the
ban
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
objections
by
the
CIA
,
Mr.
Bush
also
has
agreed
to
the
establishment
of
an
inspector
general
at
the
CIA
who
would
be
independent
of
the
CIA
director
.
<END>
<START>
In
return
,
the
Senate
panel
has
dropped
efforts
to
enact
legislation
requiring
the
administration
to
inform
it
within
48
hours
of
the
launching
of
any
covert
activity
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
've
finally
been
able
to
convince
them
that
Casey
and
-LCB-
Oliver
-RCB-
North
do
n't
work
here
anymore
,
''
says
one
administration
official
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
understanding
did
n't
just
spring
to
life
in
a
spontaneous
eruption
of
sweetness
and
light
.
<END>
<START>
It
emerged
after
a
rancorous
display
of
old-style
intelligence
politics
that
followed
this
month
's
failed
coup
attempt
in
Panama
.
<END>
<START>
The
White
House
used
television
appearances
and
leaks
to
argue
that
congressionally
imposed
restrictions
on
covert
actions
made
U.S.
support
for
such
coups
difficult
.
<END>

<START>
Wives
May
Not
Benefit
When
Men
Do
Chores
<END>
<START>
WHEN
HUSBANDS
take
on
more
housework
,
they
tend
to
substitute
for
chores
done
by
the
kids
rather
than
by
the
wife
.
<END>
<START>
Rand
Corp.
researchers
Linda
Waite
and
Frances
Goldscheider
analyzed
a
large
sample
of
married
women
with
at
least
one
child
at
home
between
the
ages
of
six
and
18
.
<END>
<START>
The
women
indicated
which
family
member
usually
did
various
household
chores
and
the
approximate
share
each
did
.
<END>
<START>
Only
for
yardwork
and
home
maintenance
did
women
do
less
than
half
.
<END>
<START>
This
pattern
was
particularly
evident
among
more
highly
educated
couples
.
<END>
<START>
In
these
families
,
husbands
took
on
80
%
more
chores
than
in
couples
with
only
grammar
school
education
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
kids
with
highly
educated
parents
did
68
%
less
housework
than
those
in
less-educated
families
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
is
clear
,
''
Ms.
Waite
says
,
``
that
most
of
the
effect
of
increasing
education
has
been
to
shift
who
is
helping
the
wife/mother
.
<END>
<START>
Her
share
decreases
,
but
only
slightly
.
''
<END>
<START>
Nursing
Home
Patients
Apt
to
Be
Private
Payers
<END>
<START>
FAR
FEWER
elderly
nursing
home
residents
bankrupt
themselves
than
was
previously
believed
,
two
recent
studies
declare
.
<END>
<START>
State
governments
place
very
low
ceilings
on
how
much
property
people
may
own
or
how
much
income
they
may
keep
if
they
want
welfare
help
on
medical
bills
.
<END>
<START>
Conventional
wisdom
has
long
held
that
anywhere
from
one-fourth
to
one-half
of
all
elderly
long-term
care
patients
are
obliged
to
spend
themselves
into
poverty
before
qualifying
for
Medicaid
assistance
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Another
one-third
are
already
on
Medicaid
when
they
enter
the
nursing
homes
,
a
considerably
higher
proportion
than
the
analysts
anticipated
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
But
a
remarkably
high
percentage
--
over
half
--
are
private
payers
throughout
their
stay
,
even
a
fairly
lengthy
one
.
<END>
<START>
About
one-third
pay
out
of
their
own
pockets
,
while
the
rest
are
covered
throughout
by
Medicare
,
private
insurers
or
the
Veterans
Administration
.
<END>
<START>
Both
reports
are
based
on
several
thousand
patients
sampled
in
a
1985
nationwide
government
survey
.
<END>
<START>
Reagan
Era
Young
Hold
Liberal
Views
<END>
<START>
Many
political
analysts
have
speculated
that
the
Reagan
years
would
produce
a
staunchly
conservative
younger
generation
.
<END>
<START>
NORC
's
most
recent
opinion
surveys
find
the
youngest
adults
indeed
somewhat
more
pro-Reagan
and
pro-Republican
than
other
adults
.
<END>
<START>
But
,
says
chief
investigator
Tom
Smith
,
this
``
does
not
translate
into
support
for
conservatism
in
general
or
into
conservative
positions
on
feminist
and
civil
rights
issues
.
''
<END>
<START>
They
were
also
as
liberal
or
more
liberal
than
any
other
age
group
in
the
1986
through
1989
surveys
.
<END>
<START>
That
compares
with
58
%
of
the
similar
age
group
in
the
1980
through
1982
surveys
and
55
%
in
the
1972
through
1975
surveys
.
<END>
<START>
Odds
and
Ends
<END>
<START>
SEPARATED
and

<START>

<START>
A

.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,

.
<END>
<START>

,

often

are

,

.
<END>
<START>

.

,

.
<END>
<START>
In
an
age
of
specialization
,
the
federal
judiciary
is
one
of
the
last
bastions
of
the
generalist
.
<END>
<START>
A
judge
must
jump
from
murder
to
antitrust
cases
,
from
arson
to
securities
fraud
,
without
missing
a
beat
.
<END>
<START>
But
even
on
the
federal
bench
,
specialization
is
creeping
in
,
and
it
has
become
a
subject
of
sharp
controversy
on
the
newest
federal
appeals
court
.
<END>
<START>
The
Court
of
Appeals
for
the
Federal
Circuit
was
created
in
1982
to
serve
,
among
other
things
,
as
the
court
of
last
resort
for
most
patent
disputes
.
<END>
<START>
Previously
,
patent
cases
moved
through
the
court
system
to
one
of
the
12
circuit
appeals
courts
.
<END>
<START>
There
,
judges
who
saw
few
such
cases
and
had
no
experience
in
the
field
grappled
with
some
of
the
most
technical
and
complex
disputes
imaginable
.
<END>
<START>
A
new
specialty
court
was
sought
by
patent
experts
,
who
believed
that
the
generalists
had
botched
too
many
important
,
multimillion-dollar
cases
.
<END>
<START>
Some
patent
lawyers
had
hoped
that
such
a
specialty
court
would
be
filled
with
experts
in
the
field
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
Reagan
administration
thought
otherwise
,
and
so
may
the
Bush
administration
.
<END>
<START>
Since
1984
,
the
president
has
filled
four
vacancies
in
the
Federal
Circuit
court
with
non-patent
lawyers
.
<END>
<START>
Now
only
three
of
the
12
judges
--
Pauline
Newman
,
Chief
Judge
Howard
T.
Markey
,
68
,
and
Giles
Rich
,
85
--
have
patent-law
backgrounds
.
<END>
<START>
The
latter
two
and
Judge
Daniel
M.
Friedman
,
73
,
are
approaching
senior
status
or
retirement
.
<END>
<START>
Several
organizations
,
including
the
Industrial
Biotechnical
Association
and
the
Pharmaceutical
Manufacturers
Association
,
have
asked
the
White
House
and
Justice
Department
to
name

with
both

and
scientific
backgrounds
.
<END>
<START>
The
associations
would
like
the
court
to
include
between

six
judges
with
specialized
training
.
<END>
<START>
Dr.
Lourie
says

Justice
Department
interviewed
him
last
July
.
<END>
<START>
Their

has

from

.
<END>
<START>
``
But
we
will
take

into

.
''
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Judge
Mayer
was
not

.

1

and
more
.
<END>
<START>
The
minimum
unit
is
$
100,000
.
<END>
<START>
Typical
rates
in
the
secondary
market
:
8.55
%
one
month
;
8.50
%
three
months
;
8.40
%
six
months
.
<END>
<START>
BANKERS
ACCEPTANCES
:
8.52
%
30
days
;
8.35
%
60
days
;
8.33
%
90
days
;
8.17
%
120
days
;
8.08
%
150
days
;
8
%
180
days
.
<END>
<START>
Negotiable
,
bank-backed
business
credit
instruments
typically
financing
an
import
order
.
<END>
<START>
LONDON
INTERBANK
OFFERED

-LRB-

-RRB-
:
8

%

;
8
11/16
%
three

;
8
7/16

;
8
3/8

.

average
of

based

.

<START>
Kidder
,
Peabody
&
Co.
is
trying
to
struggle
back
.
<END>
<START>
Only
a
few
months
ago
,
the
124-year-old
securities
firm
seemed
to
be
on
the
verge
of
a
meltdown
,
racked
by
internal
squabbles
and
defections
.
<END>
<START>
Its
relationship
with
parent
General
Electric
Co.
had
been
frayed
since
a
big
Kidder
insider-trading
scandal
two
years
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Chief
executives
and
presidents
had
come
and
gone
.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
the
firm
says
it
's
at
a
turning
point
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
've
done
what
I
came
to
do
''
at
Kidder
,
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Carpenter
says
he
will
return
Kidder
to
prominence
as
a
great
investment
bank
.
<END>
<START>
Wall
Street
is
understandably
skeptical
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
quite
a
fall
from
the
early
1980s
,
when
Kidder
still
was
counted
as
an
investment-banking
powerhouse
.
<END>
<START>
Gary
S.
Goldstein
,
president
of
the
Whitney
Group
,
an
executive
search
firm
,
said
:
``
I
'd
like
to
see
-LRB-
Kidder
-RRB-
succeed
.
<END>
<START>
But
they
have
to
attract
good
senior
bankers
who
can
bring
in
the
business
from
day
one
.
''
<END>
<START>
In
1988
,
Kidder
eked
out
a
$
46
million
profit
,
mainly
because
of
severe
cost
cutting
.
<END>
<START>
Its
1,400-member
brokerage
operation
reported
an
estimated
$
5
million
loss
last
year
,
although
Kidder
expects
it
to
turn
a
profit
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
In
fact
,
Kidder
is
a
minor
player
in
just
about
every
business
it
does
except
computer-driven
program
trading
;
in
that
controversial
business
,
only
Morgan
Stanley
&
Co.
rivals
Kidder
.
<END>
<START>
But
even
that
niche
is
under
attack
,
as
several
Wall
Street
firms
pulled
back
from
program
trading
last
week
under
pressure
from
big
investors
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Carpenter
,
a
former
consulting-firm
executive
who
has
a
love
for
``
task
forces
,
''
says
he
has
done
a
``
complete
rethink
''
of
Kidder
in
recent
months
.
<END>
<START>
There
have
been
a
dizzying
parade
of
studies
of
the
firm
's
operations
.
<END>
<START>
More
than
20
new
managing
directors
and
senior
vice
presidents
have
been
hired
since
January
.
<END>
<START>
The
firm
's
brokerage
force
has
been
trimmed
and
its
mergers-and-acquisitions
staff
increased
to
a
record
55
people
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Carpenter
says
that
when
he
assumes
full
control
,
Kidder
will
finally
tap
the
resources
of
GE
.
<END>
<START>
The

buy-out

of
GE
Capital
now
reports
to
Mr.
Carpenter
.
<END>
<START>
So

have

.
<END>
<START>

.
''
<END>
<START>

have

37

this

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
``

,

could
say

--
uh
,

.
<END>
<START>

's

,
''

.
<END>
<START>

,

``

.

''

.
<END>
<START>
Everywhere
,

stresses

``
always

''

.
<END>
<START>
The

,

``

''

.
<END>
<START>

<END>

``

''

42-branch

<END>
<START>
Mr.

.
<END>
<START>
To

,
Kidder
,

.
<END>
<START>

``

''

.

.

<START>
Mr.
Lee
,
president
of
Luzon
Petrochemical
Corp.
,
said
the
contract
was
signed
Wednesday
in
Tokyo
with
USI
Far
East
officials
.
<END>
<START>
Contract
details
,
however
,
have
n't
been
made
public
.
<END>
<START>
The
complex
is
to
be
located
in
Batangas
,
about
70
miles
south
of
Manila
.
<END>
<START>
USI
Far
East
will
hold
a
60
%
stake
in
Luzon
Petrochemical
,
according
to
papers
signed
with
the
Philippine
government
's
Board
of
Investments
.
<END>
<START>
The
proposed
petrochemical
plant
would
use
naphtha
to
manufacture
the
petrochemicals
propylene
and
ethylene
and
their
resin
derivatives
,
polypropylene
and
polyethylene
.
<END>
<START>
These
are
the
raw
materials
used
in
making
plastics
.
<END>
<START>
The
contract
signing
represented
a
major
step
in
the
long-planned
petrochemical
project
.
<END>
<START>
At
an
estimated
$
360
million
,
the
project
would
represent
the
single
largest
foreign
investment
in
the
Philippines
since
President
Corazon
Aquino
took
office
in
February
1986
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
is
considered
critical
to
the
country
's
efforts
to
both
attract
other
investment
from
Taiwan
and
raise
heavy
industry
capabilities
.
<END>
<START>
The
project
has
been
in
and
out
of
the
pipeline
for
more
than
a
decade
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
workers
ca
n't
break
ground
until
legal
maneuvers
to
block
the
complex
are
resolved
,
moves
which
caused
the
signing
to
remain
questionable
up
to
the
last
moment
.
<END>
<START>
As
previously
reported
,
a
member
of
the
Philippines
'
House
of
Representatives
has
sued
to
stop
the
plant
.
<END>
<START>
The
legislator
,
Enrique
Garcia
,
had
actively
backed
the
plant
,
but
at
the
original
site
in
his
constituency
northwest
of
Manila
.
<END>
<START>
The
country
's
Supreme
Court
dismissed
the
suit
,
but
Mr.
Garcia
late
last
month
filed
for
a
reconsideration
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
President
Aquino
has
yet
to
sign
into
law
a
bill
removing
a
stiff
48
%
tax
on
naphtha
,
the
principal
raw
material
to
be
used
in
the
cracker
.
<END>
<START>
The
project
appeared
to
be
on
the
rocks
earlier
this
month
when
the
other
major
partner
in
the
project
,
China

Corp.
,

out
.
<END>
<START>
China
General
Plastics
,
another

,

40

.
<END>
<START>
However
,

Lee

.
<END>

.

<START>
President
Bush
insists
it
would
be
a
great
tool
for
curbing
the
budget
deficit
and
slicing
the
lard
out
of

.
<END>
<START>
He
wants
it
now
.
<END>
<START>
Not
so
fast
,
says
Rep.
Mickey
Edwards
of
Oklahoma
,
a
fellow
Republican
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
consider
it
one
of
the
stupidest
ideas
of
the
20th
century
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
the
line-item
veto
,
a
procedure
that
would
allow
the
president
to
kill
individual
items
in
a
big

passed

Congress
without

.
<END>
<START>
Whatever
one
thinks
of
the
idea
,
it
's
far
more
than
the
budgetary
gimmick
it
may
seem
at
first

.
<END>
<START>
President
Bush
badly
wants
a
line-item
veto
and
has
long
called
for
a
law
giving
it
to
the
president
.
<END>
<START>
Although
that
may
sound
like
an
arcane
maneuver
of
little
interest
outside
Washington
,
it
would
set
off
a

.
<END>
<START>
``
The
ramifications
are
enormous
,
''
says
Rep.
Don
Edwards
,
a
California
Democrat
who
is
a
senior
member
of
the
House
Judiciary
Committee
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
a
real
face-to-face
arm
wrestling
challenge
to
Congress
.
''
<END>
<START>
White
House
aides
know
it
's
a
step
that
ca
n't
be
taken
lightly
--
and
for
that
reason
,
the
president
may
back
down
from
launching
a
test
case
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Some
senior
advisers
argue
that
with
further
fights
over
a
capital-gains
tax
cut
and
a
budget-reduction
bill
looming
,
Mr.
Bush
already
has
enough
pending
confrontations
with
Congress
.
<END>
<START>
They
prefer
to
put
off
the
line-item
veto
until
at
least
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
Mr.
Bush
and
some
other
aides
are
strongly
drawn
to
the
idea
of
trying
out
a
line-item
veto
.
<END>
<START>
The
issue
arose
last
week
when
Vice
President
Dan
Quayle
told
an
audience
in
Chicago
that
Mr.
Bush
was
looking
for
a
test
case
.
<END>
<START>
White
House
Press
Secretary
Marlin
Fitzwater
confirmed
that
Mr.
Bush
was
interested
in
the
idea
,
but
cautioned
that
there
was
n't
a
firm
decision
to
try
it
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bush
,
former
President
Reagan
and
a
host
of
conservative
activists
have
been
arguing
that
a
line-item
veto
would
go
a
long
way
in
restoring
discipline
to
the
budget
process
.
<END>
<START>
They
maintain
that
a
president
needs
the
ability
to
surgically
remove
pork-barrel
spending
projects
that
are
attached
to
big
omnibus
spending
bills
.
<END>
<START>
Those
bills
ca
n't
easily
be
vetoed
in
their
entirety
because
they
often
are
needed
to
keep
the
government
operating
.
<END>
<START>
Conservatives
note
that
43
governors
have
the
line-item
veto
to
use
on
state
budgets
.
<END>
<START>
There
's
little
doubt
that
such
a
move
would
be
immediately
challenged
in
court
--
and
that
it
would
quickly
make
its
way
to
the
Supreme
Court
to
be
ultimately
resolved
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
puts
this
president
in
the
legislative
business
,
''
he
declares
.
<END>
<START>
``
That
's
not
what
our
fathers
had
in
mind
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
notes
that
,
as
a
lawmaker
from
the
San
Francisco
area
,
he
fights
each
year
to
preserve
federal
funds
for
the
Bay
Area
Rapid
Transit
system
.
<END>
<START>
Proponents
maintain
that
a
president
would
choose
to
use
a
line-item
veto
more
judiciously
than
that
.
<END>
<START>
But
there
may
be
another
problem
with
the
device
:
Despite
all
the
political
angst
it
would
cause
,
it
might
n't
be
effective
in
cutting
the
deficit
.
<END>
<START>
Big
chunks
of
the
government
budget
,
like
the
entitlement
programs
of
Social
Security
and
Medicare
,
would
n't
be
affected
.
<END>
<START>
Governors
have
found
that
they
have
to
use
the
device
sparingly
to
maintain
political
comity
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
proponents
contend
that
the
veto
would
have
what
Mr.
Glazier
calls
an
important
``
chilling
effect
''
on
all
manner
of
appropriations
bills
.
<END>
<START>
Lawmakers
,
they
say
,
would
avoid
putting
many
spending
projects
into
legislation
in
the
first
place
for
fear
of
the
embarrassment
of
having
them
singled
out
for
a
line-item
veto
later
.
<END>
<START>
Republicans
have
as
much
interest
as
Democrats
in
``
the
way
the
system
works
,
''
he
notes
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
although
a
majority
of
Republican
lawmakers
favor
a
line-item
veto
,
some
,
ranging
from
liberal
Oregon
Sen.
Mark
Hatfield
to
conservative
Rep.
Edwards
are
opposed
.
<END>
<START>
Rep.
Edwards
voices
the
traditional
conservative
view
that
it
's
a
mistake
to
put
too
much
power
in
the
hands
of
a
single
person
.
<END>
<START>
This
has
n't
been
Kellogg
Co.
's
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
oat-bran
craze
has
cost
the
world
's
largest
cereal
maker
market
share
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
's
president
quit
suddenly
.
<END>
<START>
And
now
Kellogg
is
indefinitely
suspending
work
on
what
was
to
be
a
$
1
billion
cereal
plant
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
it
was
delaying
construction
because
of
current
market
conditions
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
Memphis
,
Tenn.
,
facility
was
n't
to
begin
turning
out
product
until
1993
,
so
the
decision
may
reveal
a
more
pessimistic
long-term
outlook
as
well
.
<END>
<START>
Kellogg
's
current
share
is
believed
to
be
slightly
under
40
%
while
General
Mills
'
share
is
about
27
%
.
<END>
<START>
Led
by
its
oat-based
Cheerios
line
,
General
Mills
has
gained
an
estimated
2
%
share
so
far
this
year
,
mostly
at
the
expense
of
Kellogg
.
<END>
<START>
Each
share
point
is
worth
about
$
60
million
in
sales
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
say
much
of
Kellogg
's
erosion
has
been
in
such
core
brands
as
Corn
Flakes
,
Rice
Krispies
and
Frosted
Flakes
,
which
represent
nearly
one-third
of
its
sales
volume
.
<END>
<START>
Kellogg
is
so
anxious
to
turn
around
Corn
Flakes
sales
that
it
soon
will
begin
selling
boxes
for
as
little
as
99
cents
,
trade
sources
say
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
are
not
a
happy
group
of
people
at
Battle
Creek
right
now
.
''
<END>
<START>
Kellogg
is
based
in
Battle
Creek
,
Mich.
,
a
city
that
calls
itself
the
breakfast
capital
of
the
world
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
do
n't
think
Kellogg
can

back
to
40
%
this
year
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
Kellogg
's
main
problem
is
life
style
.
<END>
<START>
People
are
reading
the
boxes
and
deciding
they
want
something
that
's
`
healthy
'

--
oats
,

.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Maxwell
said

,

the
next

years
or

,
General
Mills
'

to
30
%
or
more
.
<END>
<START>

,

William
E.

said
,
``
Cereal
volume
growth
in

U.S.
has
not

for
1989
.
''
<END>
<START>
He

would
n't

until

conditions
warrant

.
<END>
<START>
Kellogg
indicated
that
it
has
room
to
grow
without
adding

.
<END>
<START>
The
company

five

,

at

Creek
headquarters
known
as
Building
100
,
which

to

and

next

.
<END>
<START>
General
Mills
,
meanwhile
,
finds
itself
constrained
from
boosting
sales
further
because
its
plants
are
operating
at
capacity
.
<END>
<START>
A
large
plant
in
Covington
,
Ga.
,
is
to
come
on
line
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
Initial

for
the

,
which
was
to
have
been

in

,
ranged
from
$
1

to

.
<END>
<START>
A

it

``
possible
,

,
''
that

.
<END>
<START>
The

was
to

the
world
's
most

,
and

's

.
<END>
<START>
The

had

Fluor

as

.
<END>
<START>
But

,

that

was

at

185-acre

.
<END>
<START>
Subcontractors
said

that

would
be

.
<END>
<START>
Fluor
Daniel
already
has

most

its
work
crew
,
the
sources
said
.
<END>
<START>
Last
Friday
's

was
the
first

that
the

was
in
trouble
and
that
the
company
's

market

may

.
<END>
<START>
Until

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

``

,
''

,

.

,

,

.

,

.

<START>
Net

16

,

,

,

.

.

.

<START>
The

,

.

<START>
Italy
's

to
2.007

lire
-LRB-
$
1.49
billion
-RRB-
in
September
from
2.616
trillion
lire
a
year
earlier
,
the
state
statistical
office
Istat
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
deficit
was
466
billion
lire
in
August
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
first
nine
months
,
the
trade
deficit
was
14.933
trillion
lire
,
compared
with
10.485
trillion
lire
in
the
year-earlier
period
.
<END>
<START>
Istat
said
the
statistics
are
provisional
and
are
n't
seasonally
adjusted
.
<END>
<START>
Imports
rose
11
%
to
18.443
trillion
lire
in
September
from
a
year
earlier
,
while
exports
rose
17
%
to
16.436
trillion
lire
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
nine
months
,
imports
rose
20
%
to
155.039
trillion
lire
,
while
exports
grew
18
%
to
140.106
trillion
lire
.
<END>
<START>
Import
values
are
calculated
on
a
cost
,
insurance
and
freight
-LRB-
c.i.f
.
-RRB-
basis
,
while
exports
are
accounted
for
on
a
free-on-board
-LRB-
f.o.b
.
-RRB-
basis
.
<END>
<START>
As
competition
heats
up
in
Spain
's
crowded
bank
market
,
Banco
Exterior
de
Espana
is
seeking
to
shed
its
image
of
a
state-owned
bank
and
move
into
new
activities
.
<END>
<START>
The
state-owned
industrial
holding
company
Instituto
Nacional
de
Industria
and
the
Bank
of
Spain
jointly
hold
a
13.94
%
stake
in
Banco
Exterior
.
<END>
<START>
The
government
directly
owns
51.4
%
and
Factorex
,
a
financial
services
company
,
holds
8.42
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
rest
is
listed
on
Spanish
stock
exchanges
.
<END>
<START>
Some
analysts
are
concerned
,
however
,
that
Banco
Exterior
may
have
waited
too
long
to
diversify
from
its
traditional
export-related
activities
.
<END>
<START>
Catching
up
with
commercial
competitors
in
retail
banking
and
financial
services
,
they
argue
,
will
be
difficult
,
particularly
if
market
conditions
turn
sour
.
<END>
<START>
With
700
branches
in
Spain
and
12
banking
subsidiaries
,
five
branches
and
12
representative
offices
abroad
,
the
Banco
Exterior
group
has
a
lot
to
offer
a
potential
suitor
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Luzon
and
his
team
,
however
,
say
they
are
n't
interested
in
a
merger
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
,
they
are
working
to
transform
Banco
Exterior
into
an
efficient
bank
by
the
end
of
1992
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
want
this
to
be
a
model
of
the
way
a
public-owned
company
should
be
run
,
''
Mr.
Luzon
says
.
<END>
<START>
Banco
Exterior
was
created
in
1929
to
provide
subsidized
credits
for
Spanish
exports
.
<END>
<START>
The
market
for
export
financing
was
liberalized
in
the
mid-1980s
,
however
,
forcing
the
bank
to
face
competition
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
same
time
,
many
of
Spain
's
traditional
export
markets
in
Latin
America
and
other
developing
areas
faced
a
sharp
decline
in
economic
growth
.
<END>
<START>
The
bank
was
hamstrung
in
its
efforts
to
face
the
challenges
of
a
changing
market
by
its
links
to
the
government
,
analysts
say
.
<END>
<START>
Until
Mr.
Luzon
took
the
helm
last
November
,
Banco
Exterior
was
run
by
politicians
who
lacked
either
the
skills
or
the
will
to
introduce
innovative
changes
.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Luzon
has
moved
swiftly
to
streamline
bureaucracy
,
cut
costs
,
increase
capital
and
build
up
new
areas
of
business
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
've
got
a
lot
to
do
,
''
he
acknowledged
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
've
got
to
move
quickly
.
''
<END>
<START>
In
Mr.
Luzon
's
first
year
,
the
bank
eliminated
800
jobs
.
<END>
<START>
Now
it
says
it
'll
trim
another
1,200
jobs
over
the
next
three
to
four
years
.
<END>
<START>
The
bank
employs
8,000
people
in
Spain
and
2,000
abroad
.
<END>
<START>
To
strengthen
its
capital
base
,
Banco
Exterior
this
year
issued
$
105
million
in
subordinated
debt
,
launched
two
rights
issues
and
sold
stock
held
in
its
treasury
to
small
investors
.
<END>
<START>
The
bank
is
now
aggressively
marketing
retail
services
at
its
domestic
branches
.
<END>
<START>
Last
year
's
drop
in
export
credit
was
partially
offset
by
a
15
%
surge
in
lending
to
individuals
and
small
and
medium-sized
companies
.
<END>
<START>
Expansion
plans
also
include
acquisitions
in
growing
foreign
markets
.
<END>
<START>
The
bank
says
it
's
interested
in
purchasing
banks
in
Morocco
,
Portugal
and
Puerto
Rico
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
bank
's
retail
activities
in
Latin
America
are
likely
to
be
cut
back
.
<END>
<START>
Banco
Exterior
was
one
of
the
last
banks
to
create
a
brokerage
house
before
the
four
Spanish
stock
exchanges
underwent
sweeping
changes
in
July
.
<END>
<START>
The
late
start
may
be
a
handicap
for
the
bank
as
Spain
continues
to
open
up
its
market
to
foreign
competition
.
<END>
<START>
The
bank
also
says
it
'll
use
its
international
network
to
channel
investment
from
London
,
Frankfurt
,
Zurich
and
Paris
into
the
Spanish
stock
exchanges
.
<END>
<START>
General
Motors
Corp.
's
general
counsel
hopes
to
cut
the
number
of
outside
law
firms
the
auto
maker
uses
from
about
700
to
200
within
two
years
.
<END>
<START>
GM
trimmed
about
40
firms
from
its
approved
local
counsel
list
,
Mr.
Pearce
says
.
<END>
<START>
The
move
is
consistent
with
a
trend
for
corporate
legal
staffs
to
do
more
work
in-house
,
instead
of
farming
it
out
to
law
firms
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Pearce
set
up
GM
's
first
in-house
litigation
group
in
May
with
four
lawyers
,
all
former
assistant
U.S.
attorneys
with
extensive
trial
experience
.
<END>
<START>
He
intends
to
add
to
the
litigation
staff
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Pearce
has
also
encouraged
his
staff
to
work
more
closely
with
GM
's
technical
staffs
to
help
prevent
future
litigation
.
<END>
<START>
GM
lawyers
have
been
working
with
technicians
to
develop
more
uniform
welding
procedures
--
the
way
a
vehicle
is
welded
has
a
lot
to
do
with
its
durability
.
<END>
<START>
The
lawyers
also
monitor
suits
to
identify
specific
automobile
parts
that
cause
the
biggest
legal
problems
.
<END>
<START>
This
does
n't
necessarily
mean
larger
firms
have
an
advantage
;
Mr.
Pearce
said
GM
works
with
a
number
of
smaller
firms
it
regards
highly
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Pearce
has
shaken
up
GM
's
legal
staff
by
eliminating
all
titles
and
establishing
several
new
functions
,
including
a
special-projects
group
that
has
made
films
on
safety
and
drunk
driving
.
<END>
<START>
FEDERAL
PROSECUTORS
are
concluding
fewer
criminal
cases
with
trials
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
a
finding
of
a
new
study
of
the
Justice
Department
by
researchers
at
Syracuse
University
.
<END>
<START>
David
Burnham
,
one
of
the
authors
,
says
fewer
trials
probably
means
a
growing
number
of
plea
bargains
.
<END>
<START>
In
1980
,
18
%
of
federal
prosecutions
concluded
at
trial
;
in
1987
,
only
9
%
did
.
<END>
<START>
The
study
covered
11
major
U.S.
attorneys
'
offices
--
including
those
in
Manhattan
and
Brooklyn
,
N.Y.
,
and
New
Jersey
--
from
1980
to
1987
.
<END>
<START>
The
Justice
Department
rejected
the
implication
that
its
prosecutors
are
currently
more
willing
to
plea
bargain
.
<END>
<START>
``
Our
felony
caseloads
have
been
consistent
for
20
years
,
''
with
about
15
%
of
all
prosecutions
going
to
trial
,
a
department
spokeswoman
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
discrepancy
is
somewhat
perplexing
in
that
the
Syracuse
researchers
said
they
based
their
conclusions
on
government
statistics
.
<END>
<START>
In
1980
,
the
study
says
,
prosecutors
surveyed
filed
charges
against
25
defendants
for
each
100,000
people
aged
18
years
and
older
.
<END>
<START>
In
1987
,
prosecutors
filed
against
35
defendants
for
every
100,000
adults
.
<END>
<START>
Another
finding
from
the
study
:
Prosecutors
set
significantly
different
priorities
.
<END>
<START>
The
Manhattan
U.S.
attorney
's
office
stressed
criminal
cases
from
1980
to
1987
,
averaging
43
for
every
100,000
adults
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
New
Jersey
U.S.
attorney
averaged
16
.
<END>
<START>
On
the
civil
side
,
the
Manhattan
prosecutor
filed
an
average
of
only
11
cases
for
every
100,000
adults
during
the
same
period
;
the
San
Francisco
U.S.
attorney
averaged
79
.
<END>
<START>
The
study
is
to
provide
reporters
,
academic
experts
and
others
raw
data
on
which
to
base
further
inquiries
.
<END>

MARCOS

,

.

<START>
The
Treasury
Department
said
the
U.S.
trade
deficit
may
worsen
next
year
,
after
two
years
of
significant
improvement
.
<END>
<START>
The
statement
was
the
U.S.
government
's
first
acknowledgement
of
what
other
groups
,
such
as
the
International
Monetary
Fund
,
have
been
predicting
for
months
.
<END>
<START>
Continued
strength
in
the
dollar
was
cited
as
one
reason
the
trade
position
may
deteriorate
.
<END>
<START>
The
Treasury
's
report
,
which
is
required
annually
by
a
provision
of
the
1988
trade
act
,
again
took
South
Korea
to
task
for
its
exchange-rate
policies
.
<END>
<START>
The
Treasury
expressed
pleasure
,
however
,
with
the
government
of
Taiwan
,
which
was
cited
for
exchange-rate
manipulation
in
last
year
's
report
.
<END>
<START>
The
Treasury
said
Taiwan
has
liberalized
its
exchange
rate
system
in
the
past
year
.

<START>

.

.

<START>
Costa
Rica
reached
an
agreement
with
its
creditor
banks
that
is
expected
to
cut
that
government
's
$
1.8
billion
in
bank
debt
by
as
much
as
60
%
.
<END>
<START>
Costa
Rica
had
been
negotiating
with
the
U.S.
and
other
banks
for
three
years
,
but
the
debt
plan
was
rushed
to
completion
in
order
to
be
announced
at
the
meeting
.
<END>
<START>
The
government
had
fallen
$
300
million
behind
in
interest
payments
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
plan
,
Costa
Rica
will
buy
back
roughly
60
%
of
its
bank
debt
outstanding
at
a
deeply
discounted
price
,
according
to
officials
involved
in
the
agreement
.
<END>
<START>
The
remainder
of
the
debt
will
be
exchanged
for
new
Costa
Rican
bonds
with
a
6
1/4
%
interest
rate
.
<END>
<START>
The
International
Monetary
Fund
and
the
World
Bank
are
expected
to
provide
approximately
$
180
million
to
help
support
the
deal
,
and
additional
funds
are
expected
from
Japan
.
<END>
<START>
Treasury
officials
say
the
Costa
Rican
agreement
demonstrates
that
the
Brady
debt
plan
can
benefit
small
debtor
countries
as
well
as
big
debtors
,
such
as
Mexico
.
<END>
<START>
The
Treasury
said
it
plans
to
sell
$
2
billion
of
51-day
cash-management
bills
today
,
raising
all
new
cash
.
<END>
<START>
The
bills
will
be
dated
Oct.
31
and
will
mature
Dec.
21
,
<END>
<START>
No
non-competitive
tenders
will
be
accepted
.
<END>
<START>
Tenders
,
available
in
minimum
denominations
of
$
1
million
,
must
be
received
by
noon
EST
today
at
Federal
Reserve
Banks
or
branches
.
<END>
<START>
The
Treasury
also
announced
details
of
this
week
's
unusual
bill
auction
,
which
has
been
changed
to
accommodate
the
expiration
of
the
federal
debt
ceiling
at
midnight
tomorrow
.
<END>
<START>
The
13-week
and
27-week
bills
will
be
issued
tomorrow
rather
than
Thursday
,
Nov.
2
,
as
originally
planned
.
<END>
<START>
The
three-month
bills
will
still
mature
Feb.
1
,
1990
,
and
the
six-month
bills
on
May
3
,
1990
.
<END>
<START>
The
Treasury
also
said
noncompetitive
tenders
will
be
considered
timely
if
postmarked
no
later
than
Sunday
,
Oct.
29
,
and
received
no
later
than
tomorrow
.
<END>
<START>
The
Treasury
said
it
wo
n't
be
able
to
honor
reinvestment
requests
from
holders
of
bills
maturing
Nov.
2
held
in
the
Treasury
's
book-entry
system
.
<END>
<START>
American
Pioneer
Inc.

Insurance
Co.

to

's

for

27

.
<END>
<START>

,

American

,
said

sale
will
add

and
reduce

of

in

for
the
thrift
holding
company
.
<END>
<START>
Recently
,

of
both

parent
company
and
the

also
voted
to

on

of

and

all

into

.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said

was
necessary
to
meet

.
<END>
<START>
In

second
quarter
,
American
Pioneer
reported
a
loss
of
$
7.3
million
,
compared
with

of
$
1.1
million
a

.
<END>
<START>

had

of
$
8.7
million
in
the
second
quarter
,
largely
because
of
problem

,

the

operations

$
884,000
.
<END>
<START>
October
employment
data
--
also
could
turn
out
to
be
the
most
confusing
.
<END>
<START>
On
the
surface
,
the
overall
unemployment
rate
is
expected
to
be
little
changed
from
September
's
5.3
%
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
actual
head
count
of
non-farm
employment
payroll

is
likely
to
be
muddied
by
the
impact
of
Hurricane
Hugo
,
strikes
,
and

,

.
<END>
<START>
The

view
calls
for
an
overall
job
gain
of
155,000
compared
with
September
's
209,000

.
<END>
<START>
But
the
important

segment
,
which
last
month
plunged
by
103,000
positions
and
raised
recession
fears
,
is
most
likely
to
be
skewed
by
the
month
's
unusual
events
.
<END>
<START>
Friday
brings
the
final
count
on
October

.
<END>
<START>
``
The
employment
report
is

,
''

Michael
Englund
,

,

.

,

.
<END>
<START>
Wednesday
's
report
from
the
purchasing
agents
will
be
watched
to
see
if
the
index
maintains
a
level
below
50
%
,
as
it
has
for
the
past
couple
of
months
.
<END>
<START>
A
reading
of
less
than
50
%
indicates
an
economy
that
is
generally
contracting
while
a
reading
above
50
%
indicates
an
economy
that
's
expanding
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
added
:
``
Some
people
use
the
purchasers
'
index
as
a
leading
indicator
,
some
use
it
as
a
coincident
indicator
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
thing
it
's
supposed
to
measure
--
manufacturing
strength
--
it
missed
altogether
last
month
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
consensus
view
on
September
leading
indicators
calls
for
a
gain
of
0.3
%
,
the
same
as
in
August
.
<END>
<START>
Economists
said
greatly
increased
consumer
optimism
,
a
larger
money
supply
and
higher
stock
prices
helped
lift
the
index
.
<END>
<START>
All
orders-related
components
,
such
as
consumer-goods
orders
and
building
permits
,
are
thought
to
have
been
weaker
.
<END>
<START>
Data
Resources
'
Mr.
Wyss
added
that
he
will
be
keeping
a
closer
eye
than
ususal
on
October
chain-store
sales
.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Wyss
said
he
will
watch
the
numbers
to
get
an
inkling
of
whether

'
general
buying
habits
may
slack
off
as
much
as
their
auto-buying
apparently
has
.
<END>
<START>
He
noted
that
higher
gasoline
prices
will
help
buoy
the
October
totals
.
<END>
<START>
Seasonal
factors
are
also
expected
to
have
taken
their
toll
on
September
new-home
sales
,
which
are
believed
to
have
fallen
sharply
from
August
's
755,000
units
.
<END>
<START>
September
orders
for
machine
tools
rebounded
from
the
summer
doldrums
,
but
remained
7.7
%
below
year-earlier
levels
,
according
to
figures
from
NMTBA
--
the
Association
for
Manufacturing
Technology
.
<END>
<START>
Machine
tools
are
complex
machines
ranging
from
lathes
to
metal-forming
presses
that
are
used
to
shape
most
metal
parts
.
<END>
<START>
``
Overall
demand
still
is
very
respectable
,
''
says
Christopher
C.
Cole
,
group
vice
president
at
Cincinnati
Milacron
Inc.
,
the
nation
's
largest
machine
tool
producer
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
outlook
is
positive
for
the
intermediate
to
long
term
.
''
<END>
<START>
September
orders
for
all
U.S.
producers
,
in
fact
,
were
slightly
above
the
monthly
average
for
1988
,
a
good
year
for
the
industry
.
<END>
<START>
``
Aerospace
orders
are
very
good
,
''
Mr.
Cole
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
And
export
business
is
still
good
.
<END>
<START>
While
some
automotive
programs
have
been
delayed
,
they
have
n't
been
canceled
.
''
<END>
<START>
At
a
recent
meeting
of
manufacturing
executives
,
``
everybody
I
talked
with
was
very
positive
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Most
say
they
plan
to
spend
more
on
factory
equipment
in
1990
than
in
1989
.
<END>
<START>
But
sales
of
North
American-made
1990-model
cars
are
running
at
an
annual
rate
of
only
six
million
,
down
from
7.1
million
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
And
truck
sales
also
are
off
more
than
20
%
.
<END>
<START>
Auto
makers
,
who
began
deferring
some
equipment
purchases
last
spring
,
can
be
expected
to
remain
cautious
about
spending
if
their
sales
do
n't
pick
up
,
machine
tool
builders
say
.
<END>
<START>
Machine
tool
executives
are
hopeful
,
however
,
that
recent
developments
in
Eastern
Europe
will
expand
markets
for
U.S.-made
machine
tools
in
that
region
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
there
's
a
continuing
dispute
between
machine
tool
makers
and
the
Defense
Department
over
whether
sophisticated
U.S.
machine
tools
would
increase
the
Soviet
Union
's
military
might
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
Commerce
Department
says
go
,
and
the
Defense
Department
says
stop
,
''
complains
one
machine
tool
producer
.
<END>
<START>
If
that
controversy
continues
,
U.S.
machine
tool
makers
say
,
West
German
and
other
foreign
producers
are
likely
to
grab
most
of
the
sales
in
Eastern
Europe
.
<END>
<START>
Today
's
presses
are
large
and
costly
machines
,
and
a
few
orders
can
produce
a
high
total
for
one
month
that
does
n't
necessarily
indicate
a
trend
.
<END>
<START>
Machine
tool
shipments
last
month
were
$
281.2
million
,
a
24
%
rise
from
a
year
earlier
and
a
25
%
increase
from
August
.
<END>
<START>
Shipments
have
run
well
ahead
of
1988
all
year
,
as
machine
tool
builders
produce
against
relatively
good
backlogs
.
<END>
<START>
U.S.
producers
had
a
$
2.15
billion
backlog
of
unfilled
orders
at
the
end
of
September
.
<END>
<START>
That
was
up
2.8
%
from
a
year
earlier
,
even
though
orders
for
the
first
nine
months
of
1989
were
down
19
%
from
the
comparable
1988
period
.
<END>
<START>
$
2,057,750,000
.
<END>
<START>
$
675,400,000
.
<END>
<START>
$
1,048,500,000
.
<END>
<START>
$
588,350,000
.
<END>
<START>
In
Bombay
stock
market
circles
,
the
buzzword
is
``
mega
.
''
<END>
<START>
At
least
40
companies
are
coming
to
the
capital
market
to
raise
$
6
billion
,
an
amount
never
thought
possible
in
India
.
<END>
<START>
``
When
they
talk
mega-issues
,
they
're
truly
talking
mega
,
''
says
S.A.
Dave
,
chairman
of
the
Securities
and
Exchange
Board
of
India
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
capital
market
is
booming
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
the
mega-issues
are
raising
megaquestions
about
the
rapidly
evolving
Indian
capital
market
.
<END>
<START>
One
is
whether
there
is
enough
money
to
fund
the
new
issues
without
depressing
stock
trading
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
in
the
relatively
unregulated
Indian
stock
markets
,
investors
frequently
do
n't
know
what
they
are
getting
when
they
subscribe
to
an
issue
.
<END>
<START>
A
prospectus
in
India
does
n't
always
tell
a
potential
investor
much
.
<END>
<START>
Some
of
the
large
amounts
are
being
raised
by
small
firms
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
once
money
is
raised
,
investors
usually
have
no
way
of
knowing
how
it
is
spent
.
<END>
<START>
Some
analysts
are
concerned
that
the
mega-issues
,
in
such
an
unregulated
environment
,
could
lead
to
a
mega-crash
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
're
going
to
have
mega-problems
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
Indian
stock
markets
have
been
on
a
five-year
high
,
with
dips
and
corrections
,
since
Prime
Minister
Rajiv
Gandhi
started
liberalizing
industry
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
last
stock
market
boom
,
in
1986
,
seems
small
compared
with
the
current
rush
to
market
.
<END>
<START>
In
fiscal
1984
,
before
Mr.
Gandhi
came
to
power
,
only
$
810
million
was
raised
.
<END>
<START>
This
year
's
biggest
issue
,
$
570
million
of
convertible
debentures
by
engineering
company
Larsen
&
Toubro
Ltd.
,
is
the
largest
in
Indian
history
.
<END>
<START>
And
it
is
n't
the
only
giant
issue
:
together
,
the
top
four
issues
will
raise
$
1.3
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Convertible
debentures
--
bonds
that
can
later
be
converted
into
equity
shares
--
are
the
most
popular
instrument
this
year
,
though
many
companies
are
also
selling
nonconvertible
bonds
or
equity
shares
.
<END>
<START>
These
mega-issues
are
being
propelled
by
two
factors
,
economic
and
political
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
industry
operated
out
of
small
,
expensive
,
highly
inefficient
industrial
units
.
<END>
<START>
When
Mr.
Gandhi
came
to
power
,
he
ushered
in
new
rules
for
business
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
industry
should
build
plants
on
the
same
scale
as
those
outside
India
and
benefit
from

.
<END>
<START>
If

was

for
the

,

,

should

.
<END>
<START>
India
's

had
to

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

has
called

,

-LRB-

.

.

.

.

``

<START>

Pat
Brown
in

epsiode
on
Caryl
Chessman
,

in
California
,
in
1960
.
<END>
<START>
CBS
News
,
which
as

,

.

,

<START>
Dentsu
Inc.
,
the
world
's
largest
advertising
agency
on
the
strength
of
its
dominance
in
the
Japanese
market
,
is
setting
its
sights
on
overseas
expansion
.
<END>
<START>
Last
year
,
Dentsu
started
HDM
,
a
joint
network
with
U.S.
ad
agency
Young
&
Rubicam
and
Eurocom
of
France
.
<END>
<START>
A
few
months
ago
,
Dentsu
acquired
69
%
of
Australian
agency
Fortune
Communication
Holdings
Ltd.
for
5.9
million
Australian
dollars
-LRB-
US$
4.6
million
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
Dentsu
has
U.S.
subsidiaries
,
but
they
keep
low
profiles
.
<END>
<START>
What
is
driving
Dentsu
's
international
expansion
largely
is
the
need
to
keep
up
with
its
Japanese
clients
as
they
grow
in
the
U.S.
and
Europe
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
we
do
n't
do
something
...
we
wo
n't
be
able
to
catch
up
with
demand
,
''
says
a
Dentsu
spokesman
.
<END>
<START>
``
Our
president
said
acquisition
is
an
effective
method
.
''
<END>
<START>
Last
year
,
Dentsu
's
foreign
business
accounted
for
less
than
10
%
of
total
billings
,
but
the
company
is
aiming
at
20
%
in
the
near
future
.
<END>
<START>
So
far
,
it
appears
cautious
about
taking
the
big
step
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
the
spokesman
says
Dentsu
has
been
approached
by
banks
and
securities
companies
a
number
of
times
to
invest
in
the
troubled
British
marketing
group
Saatchi
&
Saatchi
PLC
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
said
Dentsu
has
n't
looked
seriously
at
Saatchi
.
<END>
<START>
Though
Dentsu
says
it
has
no
concrete
acquisition
plans
or
deadlines
,
it
is
laying
the
groundwork
for
international
growth
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
setting
up
a
special
team
in
charge
of
international
markets
and
training
workers
to
do
business
abroad
.
<END>
<START>
Dentsu
's
billings
last
year
were
larger
than
those
of
Young
&
Rubicam
,
the
world
's
second-largest
ad
agency
,
according
to
a
survey
by
the
publication
Advertising
Age
.
<END>
<START>
But
success
overseas
in
unfamiliar
markets
could
be
trickier
than
for
other
industries
such
as
manufacturers
.
<END>
<START>
On
its
own
,
Dentsu
's
muscle
in
Japan
may
count
for
little
in
major
foreign
markets
when
seeking
non-Japanese
clients
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
,
an
acquisition
may
prove
the
necessary
course
.
<END>
<START>
But
Japanese
agencies
are
cautious
about
expanding
abroad
because
client
relationships
are
different
.
<END>
<START>
Although
acquiring
a
foreign
company
would
expand
Japanese
advertising
agencies
'
business
to
foreign
clients
,
many
clients
would
also
be
Japanese
companies
expanding
overseas
,
says
the
Dentsu
spokesman
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
different
business
system
would
make
it
hard
for
Dentsu
to
provide
these
Japanese
companies
the
same
kind
of
services
they
do
in
Japan
.
<END>

<START>
John
Labatt
Ltd.
said

of
150

Canadian
dollars
-LRB-
US$
127.5
million
-RRB-
in
preferred
