,
to
be
completed
around
Nov.
1
.
<END>
<START>
Proceeds
will
be
used
to
reduce
short-term
debt
at
the
beer
and
food
concern
,
said
Robert
Vaux
,
vice
president
,
finance
.
<END>
<START>
The
preferred
shares
will
carry
a
floating
annual
dividend
equal
to
72
%
of
the
30-day
bankers
'
acceptance
rate
until
Dec.
31
,
1994
.
<END>
<START>
Thereafter
,
the
rate
will
be
renegotiated
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Vaux
said
that
if
no
agreement
is
reached
,
other
buyers
will
be
sought
by
bid
or
auction
.
<END>
<START>
The
shares
are
redeemable
after
the
end
of
1994
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Vaux
said
the
share
issue
is
part
of
a
strategy
to
strengthen
Labatt
's
balance
sheet
in
anticipation
of
acquisitions
to
be
made
during
the
next
12
to
18
months
.
<END>
<START>
Labatt
's
has
no
takeover
bids
outstanding
currently
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Lead
underwriter
to
the
issue
is
Toronto
Dominion
Securities
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
Texas
Instruments
Inc.
,
once
a
pioneer
in
portable
computer
technology
,
today
will
make
a
bid
to
reassert
itself
in
that
business
by
unveiling
three
small
personal
computers
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
the
inevitable
comparison
with
Compaq
,
however
,
Texas
Instruments
'
new
notebook
wo
n't
be
a
direct
competitor
.
<END>
<START>
While
Compaq
sells
its
machines
to
businesses
through
computer
retailers
,
Texas
Instruments
will
be
selling
most
of
its
machines
to
the
industrial
market
and
to
value-added
resellers
and
original-equipment
manufacturers
.
<END>
<START>
The
introductions
also
mark
Texas
Instruments
'
plunge
back
into
a
technology
it
has
all
but
ignored
for
the
past
several
years
.
<END>
<START>
It
stopped
selling
a
standard
personal
computer
a
while
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Now
that
is
about
to
change
,
as
Texas
Instruments
begins
marketing
two
14-pound
laptop
PCs
with
20
megabyte
and
40
megabyte
hard
drives
.
<END>
<START>
The
laptops
are
not
revolutionary
and
,
indeed
,
are
tardy
in
a
market
first
opened
by
GRiD
Systems
Corp.
,
now
a
unit
of
Tandy
Corp.
,
almost
two
years
ago
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
notebook
,
with
the
more
advanced
microprocessor
and
hard
disk
,
is
more
innovative
.
<END>
<START>
Its
keyboard
,
according
to
industry
consultants
,
is
better
than
Compaq
's
,
but
its
battery
life
of
two
to
three
hours
is
shorter
.
<END>
<START>
It
does
n't
have
an
internal
floppy
disk
drive
,
although
a
snap-on
drive
can
be
purchased
separately
.
<END>
<START>
Its
greatest
drawback
may
be
its
3-inch
thickness
,
big
enough
for
one
consultant
to
describe
it
as
``
clunky
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
notebook
,
the
TI
Model
12
,
will
be
priced
at
$
4,199
.
<END>
<START>
Shearson
Lehman
Hutton
Inc.
said
it
applied
to
Taiwanese
securities
officials
for
permission
to
open
brokerage
offices
in
Taipei
.
<END>
<START>
Shearson
's
application
is
the
first
since
the
Taiwan
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
announced
June
21
that
it
would
allow
foreign
brokerage
firms
to
do
business
in
that
country
.
<END>
<START>
Taiwan
officials
are
expected
to
review
the
Shearson
application
later
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Under
current
rules
,
investors
in
Taiwan
can
buy
overseas
stocks
only
through
the
purchase
of
mutual
funds
issued
by
local
and
foreign
investment
trusts
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
rules
will
allow
investors
to
buy
foreign
stocks
directly
.
<END>
<START>
A
spokesman
for
Shearson
said
the
brokerage
service
will
be
directed
at
individual
investors
who
want
to
buy
foreign
and
domestic
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
an
attractive
market
with
good
growth
opportunities
,
''
he
added
.
<END>
<START>
Retailers
in
the
West
and
parts
of
the
South
are
entering
the
critical
Christmas
shopping
season
with
more
momentum
than
those
in
other
regions
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
new
report
,
the
International
Council
of
Shopping
Centers
said
sales
of
general
merchandise
in
the
West
for
the
first
seven
months
of
1989
rose
6.6
%
above
year-earlier
levels
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
increased
a
more
modest
4.8
%
in
the
South
and
4.4
%
in
the
Midwest
.
<END>
<START>
But
sales
in
the
oil-patch
state
of
Texas
surged
12.9
%
and
sales
in
South
Carolina
jumped
10.6
%
in
the
period
,
the
New
York
trade
group
said
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
Northeast
,
however
,
sales
declined
0.4
%
in
the
period
,
with
sales
in
New
England
falling
2.6
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
numbers
show
that
``
we
do
n't
have
a
monolithic
economy
,
''
said
Isaac
Lagnado
,
council
research
director
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
are
a
lot
of
have
and
have-not
markets
.
''
<END>
<START>
Sales
nationally
rose
3.9
%
through
July
,
the
latest
month
for
which
the
figures
are
available
,
the
council
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
Northern
California
earthquake
and
Hurricane
Hugo
are
likely
to
temporarily
damp
sales
growth
in
the
West
and
South
Carolina
.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Lagnado
predicted
the
regional
trends
would
continue
through
Christmas
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
big
mo
is
as
much
of
a
factor
in
retailing
as
in
politics
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
Christmas
quarter
is
important
to
retailers
because
it
represents
roughly
a
third
of
their
sales
and
nearly
half
of
their
profits
.
<END>
<START>
The
council
's
report
is
based
on
data
the
trade
group
buys
from
the
U.S.
Census
Bureau
.
<END>
<START>
The
council
plans
to
release
its
regional
reports
monthly
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lagnado
said
strength
in
employment
appears
to
have
the
biggest
impact
on
sales
growth
.
<END>
<START>
El
Paso
,
Austin
and
Fort
Worth
,
the
three
strongest
retail
markets
in
the
nation
,
are
all
located
in
Texas
,
where
employment
grew
a
relatively
strong
2
%
.
<END>
<START>
Massachusetts
,
which
has
lost
jobs
in
the
computer
and
defense-related
industries
,
was
the
weakest
link
in
bleak
New
England
.
<END>
<START>
The
results
reflect
a
reversal
in
the
fortunes
of
the
regions
during
the
past
two
years
.
<END>
<START>
In
1987
,
the
West
had
the
slowest
sales
growth
,
and
the
South
and
the
Midwest
were
first
and
second
respectively
,
according
to
the
council
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lagnado
said
that
although
retailers
probably
wo
n't
ever
recover
sales
lost
because
of
the
California
quake
and
Hurricane
Hugo
,
they
could
see
some
benefits
later
on
.
<END>
<START>
Stores
such
as
Sears
that
sell
big-ticket
durable
goods
might
actually
get
a
boost
as
consumers
rush
to
replace
items
lost
in
the
disasters
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Kerr-McGee
Corp.
said
it
will
spend
$
42
million
to
purchase
land
and
relocate
its
ammonium
perchlorate
storage
facility
to
Clark
County
,
Nev.
,
from
Henderson
,
Nev
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
it
will
move
the
storage
and
cross-blending
operations
to
a
site
23
miles
northeast
of
Las
Vegas
to
distance
the
operations
from
residential
areas
.
<END>
<START>
Ammonium
perchlorate
is
an
oxidizer
that
is
mixed
with
a
propellant
to
make
rocket
fuel
used
in
the
space
shuttle
and
military
rockets
.
<END>
<START>
In
May
1988
,
an
ammonium
perchlorate
plant
in
Henderson
owned
by
an
American
Pacific
Corp.
unit
was
leveled
by
a
series
of
explosions
.
<END>
<START>
After
the
explosion
,
Kerr-McGee
temporarily
shut
down
its
facility
just
south
of
Las
Vegas
for
a
safety
inspection
.
<END>
<START>
American
Pacific
and
Kerr-McGee
are
the
only
two
U.S.
manufacturers
of
ammonium
perchlorate
.
<END>
<START>
When
the
plant
was
destroyed
,
``
I
think
everyone
got
concerned
that
the
same
thing
would
happen
at
our
plant
,
''
a
KerrMcGee
spokeswoman
said
.
<END>
<START>
That
prompted
Kerr-McGee
to
consider
moving
the
potentially
volatile
storage
facilities
and
cross-blending
operations
away
from
town
.
<END>
<START>
Kerr-McGee
said
it
has
purchased
3,350
acres
from
the
federal
government
in
Clark
County
and
plans
to
begin
construction
early
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
facility
is
expected
to
begin
operations
in
early
1991
.
<END>
<START>
The
Henderson
plant
will
continue
its
other
chemical
operations
,
the
company
said
.
<END>
<START>
Elected
as
directors
were
Mr.
Hollander
,
Frederick
Ezekiel
,
Frederick
Ross
,
Arthur
B.
Crozier
and

.

.

-RRB-

,

.

's

.

3.73

,

the
four

.

,

.

,

year

30
,
1988
.
<END>
<START>
It
said
it
expects

to
rise
to
11
billion
yen

.

<START>

,

Merrill
Lynch
&
Co.
's
W.T.
Grimm
&
Co.
unit
in
Schaumburg
,
Ill
.
<END>
<START>
A
total
of
672
transactions
were
announced
during
the
latest
quarter
,
up
13
%
from
the
year-earlier
period
's
597
,
Grimm
said
.
<END>
<START>
Transactions
in
which
prices
were
disclosed
totaled
$
71.9
billion
,
up
36
%
from
$
52.9
billion
a
year
earlier
,
the
company
added
.
<END>
<START>
Grimm
counted
16
transactions
valued
at
$
1
billion
or
more
in
the
latest
period
,
twice
as
many
as
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
The
largest
was

$
12
billion

Bristol-Myers

Co
.
<END>
<START>

nine
months
,
1,977
transactions
were

,

15
%
from
1,716
in

.
<END>
<START>

in

$
188.1
billion
,

15
%
from
$

billion
a

.

<START>

SHOPPE
INTERNATIONAL
Inc.

,

.
<END>
<START>

of
pharmacies
said
the
added

will

Dec.
4
to
stock
of

Nov.
13
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
also
changed

dividend
policy
,
under
which
holders
had
received
an
annual
10
cents-a-share
payment
,
by
declaring
a
four-cents-a-share
dividend
,
to
be
paid
quarterly
on
post-split
shares
.
<END>
<START>
NBI
said
that
it
has
the
funds
to
pay
the
dividend
,
but
that
it
does
n't
have
the
surplus
or
profit
required
under
Delaware
law
for
payment
of
the
dividend
.
<END>
<START>
All
the
preferred
stock
is
held
by
the
Yukon
Office
Supply
Stock
Ownership
Plan
.
<END>
<START>
NBI
,
a
maker
of

systems
,

it
ca
n't
predict
if
any
of
the
preferred

will

.
<END>

as

and

to

and

.

<START>
The
property
claims
service
division
of
the
American
Insurance
Services
Group
estimated
insured
losses
from
the
earthquake
at
$
960
million
.
<END>
<START>
This
estimate
does
n't
include
claims
under
workers
'
compensation
,
life
,
health
disability
and
liability
insurance
and
damage
to
infrastructure
such
as
bridges
,
highways
and
public
buildings
.
<END>
<START>
The
estimated
earthquake
losses
are
low
compared
with
the
$
4
billion
in
claims
that
insurers
face
from
Hurricane
Hugo
,
which
ripped
through
the
Caribbean
and
the
Carolinas
last
month
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
because
only
about
30
%
of
California
homes
and
businesses
had
earthquake
insurance
to
cover
the
losses
.
<END>
<START>
She
believes
the
impact
of
losses
from
these
catastrophes
is
n't
likely
to
halt
the
growth
of
the
industry
's
surplus
capital
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
Property
reinsurance
rates
are
likely
to
climb
first
,
analysts
and
brokers
believe
.
<END>
<START>
Insurers
typically
retain
a
small
percentage
of
the
risks
they
underwrite
and
pass
on
the
rest
of
the
losses
.
<END>
<START>
After
the
earthquake
two
weeks
ago
,
brokers
say
companies
scrambled
to
replace
reinsurance
coverages
again
and
Lloyd
's
syndicates
turned
to
the
London
market
excess
lines
for
protection
of
their
own
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
companies
with
few
catastrophe
losses
this
year
and
already
big
buyers
of
reinsurance
are
likely
to
see
their
rates
remain
flat
,
or
perhaps
even
decline
slightly
.
<END>
<START>
Many
companies
will
be
negotiating
their
1990
reinsurance
contracts
in
the
next
few
weeks
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
a
seller
's
market
,
''
said
Mr.
Snedeker
of
the
reinsurance
market
right
now
.
<END>
<START>
But
some
large
insurers
,
such
as
State
Farm
Mutual
Automobile
Insurance
Co.
,
do
n't
purchase
reinsurance
,
but
fund
their
own
program
.
<END>

22

.

<START>
Nelson
Holdings
International
Ltd.
shareholders
approved
a
1-for-10
consolidation
of
the
company
's
common
stock
at
a
special
meeting
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
same
time
,
shareholders
approved
the
adoption
of
a
rights
plan
and
a
super-majority
voting
approval
requirement
.
<END>
<START>
They
also
approved
the
relocation
of
the
company
's
registered
office
to
Toronto
from
Vancouver
and
a
name
change
to
NHI
Nelson
Holdings
International
Ltd
.
<END>
<START>
Following
the
consolidation
,
the
entertainment
company
,
which
has
film
and
television
operations
in
Beverly
Hills
,
Calif.
,
will
have
about
4.1
million
shares
outstanding
.
<END>
<START>
The
number
of
authorized
common
shares
will
remain
at
100
million
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
rights
plan
,
holders
will
have
one
right
for
each
common
share
held
,
with
each
right
entitling
the
purchase
of
one
common
share
for
100
Canadian
dollars
.
<END>
<START>
The
rights
plan
would
be
triggered
if
a
person
or
group
acquires
20
%
or
more
of
the
common
shares
outstanding
without
making
an
offer
to
all
shareholders
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
super-majority
amendment
,
certain
mergers
and
other
transactions
would
require
approval
of
holders
of
80
%
of
the
company
's
common
shares
outstanding
.
<END>

.

.

.

.

,

<START>
Leaseway
Transportation
Corp.
said
it
will
restructure
$
192.5
million
of
certain
subordinated
debentures
to
reduce
its
debt
obligations
and
interest
expense
.
<END>
<START>
The
13.25
%
subordinated
debentures
due
2002
were
issued
in
August
1987
as
part
of
the
$
690
million
financing
for
a
leveraged
buy-out
of
the
company
.
<END>
<START>
Leaseway
provides
transportation
services
for
manufacturers
,
distributors
and
retailers
.
<END>
<START>
Leaseway
said
it
has
begun
discussions
with
certain
institutional
debt
holders
to
review
the
proposed
private
placement
transaction
,
which
would
exchange
the
debt
for
new
subordinated
debt
instruments
and
equity
securities
.
<END>
<START>
Specific
terms
are
subject
to
review
and
a
final
agreement
with
debt
holders
,
the
company
said
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
proposed
transaction
calls
for
an
exchange
of
the
debt
for
new
debentures
of
lower
face
value
and
reduced
cash
interest
.
<END>
<START>
Also
,
debt
holders
would
be
offered
an
equity
position
in
Leaseway
,
which
in
total
would
represent
a
controlling
interest
in

company
.

<START>
Drexel
Burnham
Lambert
Inc.
is
the
adviser
on
the
transaction
.
<END>
<START>
Nicaraguan
President
Daniel
Ortega
may
have
accomplished
over
the
weekend
what
his
U.S.
antagonists
have
failed
to
do
:
revive
a
constituency
for
the
Contra
rebels
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bush
returned
to
Washington
Saturday
night
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Ortega
announced
on
Friday
that
he
would
end
the
cease-fire
this
week
in
response
to
the
periodic
Contra
assaults
against
his
army
.
<END>
<START>
Saturday
,
he
amended
his
remarks
to
say
that
he
would
continue
to
abide
by
the
cease-fire
if
the
U.S.
ends
its
financial
support
for
the
Contras
.
<END>
<START>
He
asked
that
the
remaining
U.S.
humanitarian
aid
be
diverted
to
disarming
and
demobilizing
the
rebels
.
<END>
<START>
Outside
observers
are
gathering
in
Nicaragua
to
monitor
the
registration
and
treatment
of
opposition
candidates
.
<END>
<START>
While
few
lawmakers
anticipated
that
the
humanitarian
aid
would
be
cut
off
next
month
,
Mr.
Ortega
's
threat
practically
guarantees
that
the
humanitarian
aid
will
be
continued
.
<END>
<START>
Sen.
Dole
also
said
he
hoped
for
unanimous

for
a

he
plans
to
offer
tomorrow
denouncing
the
Nicaraguan
leader
.
<END>
<START>
``
In
these

,
I
think
they
'd
win
.
''
<END>
<START>

Ortega
's

to

comes
as

were

that
the
Contras
have
at

.
<END>
<START>

U.S.
has
cut
off

to
some

when
it
was

.

<START>

.

<START>
``

''
by

,

.

<START>

,

.

.
<END>
<START>

will
take

.
<END>
<START>

said

of
Secaucus
,

,

.

,

.

,

.

.

<START>
The
Tokyo
camera
maker

yen
,
or
16.08

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
Nikon
said
sales
rose
despite
the
adverse
effect
of
Japan
's
unpopular
consumption
tax
,
introduced
in
April
.
<END>
<START>
Increasing
personal
spending
and
capital
investment
are
fueling
growth
,
the
company
said
.
<END>
<START>
Rising
export
sales
also
contributed
to
strong
growth
,
Nikon
added
.
<END>
<START>
Total
sales
gained
20
%
to
122.36
billion
yen
from
102.01
billion
yen
.
<END>
<START>
Exports
made
up
46.2
%
of
the
latest
year
's
total
,
up
from
39.8
%
a
year
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Camera
sales
showed
the
strongest
gains
,
rising
37
%
to
50.59
billion
yen
.
<END>
<START>
Nikon
forecast
sales
for
the
year
ending
March
31
will
rise
9.6
%
to
240
billion
yen
.
<END>
<START>
Pretax
profit
is
expected
to
increase
18
%
to
22
billion
yen
and
net
income
is
expected
to
rise
53
%
to
10.5
billion
yen
.
<END>
<START>

Oil

Ltd.
's

for

.
<END>
<START>

said

are
generally

in

,

Dakota
,
Texas
,

and

.
<END>
<START>
Gulf
Canada
,
Calgary
,

is

to
sell
non-strategic
assets
and
focus
operations
on
Canada
,
Indonesia
and
other
international
areas
.
<END>

said

Canada
will

from

in
the

,
but

would
n't

a
specific

.
<END>
<START>
The
transaction
is
expected
to
close
by
Nov.
30
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
rose
7.4
%
to
1.255
trillion
yen
from
1.168
trillion
yen
.
<END>
<START>
NEC
said

computer
sales
totaled
555.5
billion
yen
,
up
11
%
from
500.26
billion
yen
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
of

devices
rose
13
%
to
283.8
billion
yen
from
251.8
billion
yen
.
<END>
<START>
It
said

of
home
electronic
products
advanced
3.7

to
44.92
billion
yen
from
43.34
billion
yen
.
<END>
<START>

just

,

for
44

,

,

.

,

.

25

69

.

<START>
Montedison
S.p.A.
definitively
agreed
to
buy
all
of
the
publicly
held
shares
of
Erbamont
N.V.
for
$
37
each
.
<END>
<START>
Montedison
now
owns
about
72
%
of
Erbamont
's
shares
outstanding
.
<END>
<START>
The
companies
said
the
accord
was
unanimously
approved
by
a
special
committee
of
Erbamont
directors
unaffiliated
with
Montedison
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
pact
,
Montedision
will
make
a
$
37-a-share
tender
offer
for
Erbamont
stock
outstanding
.
<END>
<START>
The
tender
offer
will
be
followed
by
the
sale
of
all
of
Erbamont
's
assets
,
subject
to
all
of
its
liabilities
,
to
Montedison
.
<END>
<START>
Erbamont
will
then
be
liquidated
,
with
any
remaining
Erbamont
holders
receiving
a
distribution
of
$
37
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
The
companies
said
the
transaction
is
being
structured
this
way
because
the
laws
of
the
Netherlands
Antilles
,
under
which
Erbamont
is
organized
,
do
n't
provide
for
merger
transactions
.
<END>
<START>

Acquisition

,

,

and

.

<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>
The

.

that

.

,

.

.

.

<START>
Jayark
Corp.

,

of

,

.

<START>

Friday
,

was

at
87.5
cents
bid
,

15.625

.
<END>
<START>

,

transaction
has
a

of

7.4

.

<START>

is
a

,

and

.

,

,

Jayark
,

,

and

for

.
<END>
<START>

31
,

had
an

of
5.6
million

.

<START>

,

,

.

<START>
Sales

30

billion
yen

.

.

<START>
The
New
York
Mercantile
Exchange
,
the
world
's
chief
oil
futures
marketplace
,
is
at
a
critical
juncture
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
exchange
falters
in
these
moves
,
they
say
,
it
might
once
again
fall
behind
its
chief
New
York
competitor
,
the
Commodity
Exchange
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
said
that
it
would
start
trading
the
contract
as
soon
as
the
CFTC
approved
it
.
<END>
<START>
The
CFTC
has
90
days
to
respond
to
such
applications
.
<END>
<START>
The
Merc
first
started
working
on
developing
this
contract
in
1984
.
<END>
<START>
Only
three
weeks
earlier
,
the
Merc
had
turned
to
one
of
its
own
executives
,
40-year-old
R.
Patrick
Thompson
,
to
replace
Rosemary
T.
McFadden
as
president
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
McFadden
had
been
forced
out
in
July
in
a
bitter
power
struggle
with
Z.
Lou
Guttman
,
chairman
and
a
longtime
floor
trader
on
the
exchange
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Thompson
first
came
to
the
exchange
in
1981
and
has
been
executive
vice
president
since
March
1988
.
<END>
<START>
He
previously
held
posts
of
senior
vice
president
of
compliance
and
senior
vice
president
and
general
counsel
.
<END>
<START>
By
contrast
,
the
Comex
in
July
imported
a
highly
regarded
outsider
,
Arnold
F.
Staloff
,
as
its
president
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Staloff
,
44
,
was
a
senior
officer
of
the
Philadelphia
Stock
Exchange
and
is
considered
a
specialist
in
new
financial
products
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Thompson
is
n't
bereft
of
experience
with
new
products
,
however
.
<END>
<START>
``
Our
members
are
eager
to
begin
trading
this
contract
,
so
we
expect
no
difficulty
in
attracting
locals
to
the
natural
gas
pit
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
educational
effort
of
teaching
companies
in
the
natural
gas
industry
how
to
use
the
futures
to
hedge
would
have
to
continue
for
another
a
year
or
two
,
he
added
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
recent
interview
,
Mr.
Thompson
said
the
biggest
problem
facing
all
commodity
exchanges
was
one
of
image
.
<END>
<START>
Earlier
this
year
,
the
U.S.
attorney
indicted
45
floor
traders
and
one
clerk
at
the
two
big
Chicago
exchanges
.
<END>
<START>
Federal
authorities
in
New
York
started
investigating
exchanges
in
May
,
though
no
indictments
have
been
handed
down
there
.
<END>
<START>
So
far
they
have
issued
scores
of
subpoenas
,
some
of
which
went
to
members
of
the
New
York
Merc
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Thompson
will
have
to
face
some
of
the
consequences
of
those
subpoenas
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
recent
General
Accounting
Office
study
,
the
Merc
was
found
to
have
been
the
most
lax
in
enforcing
exchange
rules
.
<END>
<START>
It
levied
the
smallest
number
of
suspensions
of
traders
and
fines
of
the
four
largest
commodity
exchanges
studied
over
the
past
five
years
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
had
both
the
fewest
,
and
least
experienced
,
investigators
per
million
contracts
traded
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Conway
is
no
longer
at
the
exchange
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
had
a
management
breakdown
in
1987
in
terms
of
compliance
,
''
Mr.
Thompson
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
recognized
the
problem
and
took
care
of
it
.
''
<END>
<START>
For
years
the
five
New
York
exchanges
have
been
talking
about
cooperating
in
various
aspects
of
their
business
in
order
to
improve
the
efficiency
of
their
operations
.
<END>
<START>
Periodically
,
there
has
even
been
talk
of
mergers
between
one
or
more
exchanges
.
<END>
<START>
So
far
there
is
little
to
show
for
such
efforts
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Thompson
believes
the
case
for
working
together
is
stronger
now
than
ever
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
cost
of
competition
has
become
extremely
high
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
must
find
ways
to
save
money
for
the
futures
commission
merchants
who
do
business
on
our
exchanges
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
thinks
that
progress
in
cooperation
can
be
made
in
areas
where
no
vested
interests
have
built
up
.
<END>
<START>
One
of
those
areas
is
the
development
of
a
hand-held
electronic
device
that
would
permit
floor
traders
to
enter
trades
as
they
make
them
.
<END>
<START>
The
GAO
has
recommended
the
creation
of
a
system
to
record
trade
data
so
that
an
independent
,
verifiable
audit
trail
can
be
established
to
prevent
customer
fraud
.
<END>
<START>
The
Merc
is
now
cooperating
with
the
Comex
in
developing
such
a
device
to
provide
such
an
audit
trail
.
<END>
<START>
The
Chicago
exchanges
also
are
working
on
such
a
device
.
<END>
<START>
Another
major
electronics
problem
faces
Mr.
Thompson
--
the
creation
of
a
24-hour
trading
system
that
can
be
used
outside
normal
trading
hours
.
<END>
<START>
In
January
,
the
New
York
Merc
signed
a
letter
of
intent
with
the
Chicago
Merc
as
a
preliminary
step
to
joining
their
electronic
system
called
Globex
.
<END>
<START>
But
in
May
,
the
Chicago
Merc
said
it
was
looking
into
creating
a
common
system
with
the
Chicago
Board
of
Trade
,
and
it
suspended
negotiations
with
the
New
York
Merc
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Thompson
says
his
exchange
is
n't
waiting
for
the
results
of
the
Chicago
exchanges
'
cooperation
.
<END>
<START>
It
recently
began
a
pilot
program
to
test
an
electronic
trading
system
called
ATS/2
,
the
automated
trading
system
created
by
the
International
Commodities
Clearing
House
.
<END>
<START>
Looking
ahead
to
commodity
markets
this
week
:
<END>
<START>
Copper
<END>
<START>
He
views
the
$
1.10
to
$
1.12
range
as

opportunity
and
considers
the
market
oversold
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
think
the
market
could
pop
up
to
the
$
1.22
to
$
1.25
level
without
too
much

,
''
he

.
<END>
<START>
But
he
said
it
wo
n't
climb
further
and
he
expects
it
to
remain
in
a
trading
range
between
$
1.10
and
$
1.25
.
<END>
<START>
He
noted
that
the
equity
markets
will
set
the
tone
for
the
industrial

this
week
and

.

William

,

.
<END>
<START>

of

at

.
<END>

,

,

,

.

<START>

.

<START>
Precious
Metals
<END>
<START>
Friday
's
strong
price
gains
confirmed
a
turnaround
in
the
precious

markets
,
according
to
PaineWebber
's
Mr.
Frawley
.
<END>
<START>
``
Most
traders
will
be
looking
to
buy
-LCB-
on
-RCB-
pullbacks
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
He
thought

in

last
week
were
most

by
the

in

and

.
<END>
<START>

's

in

could

to
$
390

for

.
<END>

,

``

,

.
''
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
He

that

some
light

in

.
<END>
<START>
Grains
And
Soybeans
<END>
<START>
In
recent
weeks
,
warm
and
dry
weather
has
sped
the
Midwest
harvest
and
that
is
permitting
farmers
to
rebuild
the
stockpiles
that
were
cut
by
the
1988
drought
.
<END>
<START>
That
selling
of
futures
contracts
by
elevators
is
what
helps
keep
downward
pressure
on
crop
prices
during
the
harvest
.
<END>
<START>
Traders
will
also
watch
for
whether
the
Soviet
Union
continues
its
traditional
fall
buying
of
U.S.
grain
.
<END>
<START>
So
far
this
month
,
the
Soviets
have
bought
about
7.2
million
metric
tons
of
U.S.
corn
.
<END>
<START>
There
may
be
some
activity
in
soybean
prices
this
week
as
investors
try
to
get
rid
of
the
contract
for
November
delivery
.
<END>
<START>

,

Saturday
,

at

's

.

,

He
said

70

voted
in

of
the
agreement
.
<END>
<START>
Wall
Street
is
just
about
ready
to
line
the
bird
cage
with
paper
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
For
three
years
,
a
healthy
economy
and
the
export-boosting
effects
of
a
weak
dollar
propelled
sales
and
earnings
of
the
big
paper
companies
to
record
levels
.
<END>
<START>
But
now
the
companies
are
getting
into
trouble
because
they
undertook
a
record
expansion
program
while
they
were
raising
prices
sharply
.
<END>
<START>
Third-quarter
profits
fell
at
several
companies
.
<END>
<START>
``
Put
your
money
in
a
good
utility
or
bank
stock
,
not
a
paper
company
,
''
advises
George
Adler
of
Smith
Barney
.
<END>
<START>
Other
analysts
are
nearly
as
pessimistic
.
<END>
<START>
Gary
Palmero
of
Oppenheimer
&
Co.
expects
a
30
%
decline
in
earnings
between
now
and
1991
for
``
commodity-oriented
''
paper
companies
,
which
account
for
the
majority
of
the
industry
.
<END>
<START>
Robert
Schneider
of
Duff
&
Phelps
sees
paper-company
stock
prices
falling
10
%
to
15
%
in
1990
,
perhaps
25
%
if
there
's
a
recession
.
<END>
<START>
Paper
companies
concede
that
business
has
been
off
recently
.
<END>
<START>
But
they
attribute
much
of
the
weakness
to
customer
inventory
reductions
.
<END>
<START>
Generally
they
maintain
that
,
barring
a
recession
and
a
further
strengthening
of
the
dollar
against
foreign
currencies
,
the
industry
is
n't
headed
for
a
prolonged
slump
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
wo
n't
be
an
earthshaking
drop
,
''
a
Weyerhaeuser
spokesman
says
.
<END>
<START>

rating

''

Lawrence

.

.

.

A

''

Wall

.

.

<START>
Shoney
's

,

,

.

.

.

.

about

next

,

.

that

$

<END>

<START>
ABB
Asea

.

N.V
.

.

.

,

.

.

.

<START>
Mr.
Kume
made

for

,

,

.

<START>

because

is

to

.

,

.

,

.

,

,

a

outside
Japan
,
or

to

.
<END>
<START>
``

,
''

,
``

overseas

.
''
<END>

,

,
but

n't

.

<START>
National
Intergroup
Inc.
said

5.3

related

of

unit
's

division
for
the
third
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said

has

to
sell

for

15
million
to
R.D.
Werner
Co.
,
a
closely
held
firm
based
in
Greenville
,
Pa
.
<END>
<START>
The
charge
is
offset
by
an
after-tax
gain
of
about
$
30
million
in
the
quarter
from
the
previously
announced
pact
to
sell
National
Aluminum
's
rolling
division
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
was
$
778.6
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
also
said
it
continues
to
explore
all

of
National
Aluminum
's
54.5
%

in
an
aluminum

in
Hawesville
,
Ky
.
<END>
<START>
The
sale
of
the
extrusion
division
is
subject
to
audit
adjustments
for
working
capital
changes
through
the
closing
.
<END>
<START>
The
agreement
also

for

additional

to
National
Aluminum
over

next
two
years
,

's

.
<END>
<START>
The
extrusion
unit
produces
bare
and
painted
custom
extrusions
for
building
products
and
construction
industries
.
<END>
<START>
In
fiscal
1989
,
it
had
sales
of
about
$
40
million
and
an
operating
loss
of
$
1.5
million
.
<END>
<START>
Commercial
banks
and
property/casualty
insurers
,
which
together
own
about
36
%
of
all
municipal
bonds
,
have
been
dumping
their
securities
for
weeks
.
<END>
<START>
Last
week
,
traders
said
,
there
were
three
institutional
sellers
for
every
buyer
.
<END>
<START>
``
Every
day
we
're
getting
new
bid
lists
''
from
would-be
sellers
,
one
trader
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
Most
dealers
can
not
continue
to
absorb
this
supply
.
''
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
yields
on
long-term
muni
bonds
now
stand
at
about
95
%
of
long-term
Treasury
yields
,
the
highest
such
level
in
more
than
two
years
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
is
incredible
negative
psychology
building
in
the
market
,
''
said
Donna
Avedisian
,
a
vice
president
at
Merrill
Lynch
&
Co
.
<END>
<START>
``
People
are
very
concerned
about
who
is
going
to
step
up
to
the
plate
and
buy
municipal
bonds
in
the
absence
of
institutional
buyers
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
yield
on
a
group
of
25
revenue
bonds
compiled
by
the
Bond
Buyer
,
a
trade
publication
,
now
exceeds
7.50
%
.
<END>
<START>
At
this
week
's
New
York
City
bond
sale
,
traders
expect
yields
on
the
20-year
New
York
bonds
to
nearly
match
the
7.9
%
yield
on
30-year
Treasury
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
For
an
investor
in
the
28
%
federal
tax
bracket
,
7.9
%
tax-free
is
the
same
as
10.38
%
on
a
taxable
investment
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
a
taxable-equivalent
yield
nearly
three
percentage
points
more
than
the
current
yield
on
30-year
Treasury
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
How
quickly
things
change
.
<END>
<START>
This
past
summer
,
investors
'
appetite
for
municipal
bonds
seemed
insatiable
.
<END>
<START>
Individuals
eager
for
tax-free
income
drove
up
bond
prices
,
making
state
and
local
government
debt
one
of
the
best-performing
types
of
fixed-income
investments
during
the
period
.
<END>
<START>
But
while
analysts
say
that
municipal
bonds
still
offer
good
value
,
you
would
n't
know
it
by
the
way
institutional
investors
are
rushing
to
dump
their
holdings
.
<END>
<START>
Bond
market
analysts
say
the
institutional
selling
was
triggered
by
several
factors
.
<END>
<START>
Big
banks
such
as
Chemical
Bank
and
Chase
Manhattan
,
which
have
been
taking
heavy
charges
to
expand
their
Third
World
loan-loss
reserves
,
are
n't
looking
for
tax-exempt
income
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
do
n't
need
the
shelter
of
tax-free
bonds
,
''
said
a
spokeswoman
at
Chemical
.
<END>
<START>
In
recent
weeks
,
traders
said
,
Chemical
has
sold
more
than
$
1
billion
of
tax-free
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
The
spokeswoman
confirmed
that
the
bank
has
significantly
reduced
its
muni
holdings
,
but
could
n't
immediately
confirm
the
amount
.
<END>
<START>
Insurance
companies
are
rushing
to
sell
before
the
end
of
the
year
,
when
some
of
their
tax
benefits
associated
with
municipal
bonds
will
be
phased
out
.
<END>
<START>
There
is
speculation
that
property/casualty
firms
will
sell
even
more
munis
as
they
scramble
to
raise
cash
to
pay
claims
related
to
Hurricane
Hugo
and
the
Northern
California
earthquake
.
<END>
<START>
Fundamental
factors
are
at
work
as
well
.
<END>
<START>
Some
of
the
recent
selling
could
actually
be
considered
a
positive
sign
.
<END>
<START>
Mutual
funds
,
for
example
,
are
said
to
be
selling
existing
municipal
bonds
to
raise
cash
to
buy
new
issues
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Avedisian
believes
that
the
mutual
funds
are
selling
muni
bonds
that
have
a
negative
convexity
--
those
that
have
appreciated
in
price
slowly
relative
to
the
decline
in
interest
rates
.
<END>
<START>
Such
bonds
,
she
says
,
are
those
that
are
nearing
their
call
date
.
<END>
<START>
But
traders
said
the
market
's
tone
could
pick
up
this
week
if
New
York
City
's
$
787
million
bond
offering
goes
well
.
<END>
<START>
The
offering
will
include
$
729
million
of
20-year
tax-exempt
bonds
and
$
57.8
million
of
taxable
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
A
few
weeks
ago
,
New
York
sold
$
750
million
of
tax-exempts
.
<END>
<START>
New
York
City
bonds
have
been
beaten
down
for
three
straight
weeks
.
<END>
<START>
On
Friday
,
some
issues
fell
nearly
one
point
,
or
close
to
$
10
for
each
$
1,000
face
amount
.
<END>
<START>
The
sell-off
in
New
York
City
bonds
was
triggered
by
concerns
about
the
city
's
financial
health
and
political
uncertainty
in
view
of
the
impending
mayoral
election
.
<END>
<START>
The
city
's
economy
is
growing
weaker
and
expenditures
are
rising
as
tax
revenue
is
falling
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
city
has
issued
so
much
supply
recently
that
some
people
are
getting
a
little
concerned
.
<END>
<START>
They
'd
like
to
see
some
other
names
in
their
portfolios
,
''
said
Michael
S.
Appelbaum
,
first
vice
president
at
Shearson
Lehman
Hutton
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
thinks
investors
may
be
overreacting
to
the
market
's
problems
.
<END>
<START>
Overall
,
he
says
,
municipal
prices
are
``
very
cheap
''
and
represent
an
``
excellent
buying
opportunity
.
''
<END>
<START>
Friday
's
Market
Activity
<END>
<START>
Treasury
bonds
fell
sharply
on
confusion
about
this
week
's
Treasury
debt
auction
and
rumors
that
a
major
Japanese
investor
was
unloading
large
amounts
of
long-term
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
The
Treasury
's
benchmark
30-year
bond
ended
at
a
price
of
102
2/32
,
down
nearly
5/8
point
from
Thursday
,
or
about
$
6.25
for
each
$
1,000
face
amount
.
<END>
<START>
The
issue
's
yield
rose
to
7.93
%
from
7.88
%
.
<END>
<START>
Late
Thursday
,
the
Treasury
said
it
needed
to
raise
$
17
billion
quickly
and
would
do
so
by
issuing
new
securities
this
week
.
<END>
<START>
Credit
market
analysts
expected
the
Treasury
to
cancel
today
's
three-month
and
six-month
sale
and
to
sell
$
17
billion
of
cash
management
bills
.
<END>
<START>
The
market
also
was
hurt
by
rumors
that
Nippon
Kangyo
Kakumaru
,
a
Japanese
brokerage
firm
,
was
unloading
some
of
the
30-year
bonds
it
recently
purchased
.
<END>
<START>
One
dealer
said
the
talk
was
that
the
firm
sold
about
$
500
million
of
bellwether
30-year
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
The
firm
is
thought
to
have
purchased
up
to
$
3
billion
of
30-year
bonds
in
a
buying
spree
on
Wednesday
and
the
previous
Thursday
.
<END>
<START>
Dealers
say
the
firm
apparently
has
wanted
to
publicize
its
recent
buying
and
subsequent
selling
of
30-year
bonds
by
using
Cantor
Fitzgerald
Securities
Corp.
as
a
broker
.
<END>
<START>
Cantor
provides
price
quotes
to
Telerate
Systems
Inc.
,
a
widely
used
electronic
system
.
<END>
<START>
Nippon
Kangyo
's
moves
puzzled
traders
and
created
confusion
among
potential
investors
,
many
of
whom
decided
to
stay
out
of
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
In
other
markets
:
<END>
<START>
--
The
junk
bonds
of
RJR
Nabisco
Inc.
rallied
Friday
on
news
that
the
company
is
selling
its
candy
bar
brands
to
Nestle
Foods
Corp.
for
$
370
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
sale
price
,
which
was
above
Wall
Street
expectations
,
sent
many
RJR
securities
up
by
one
point
.
<END>
<START>
The
sale
,
expected
to
close
before
the
end
of
the
year
,
also
includes
a
manufacturing
plant
in
Franklin
Park
,
Ill
.
<END>
<START>
RJR
's
subordinated
discount
debentures
of
2001
,
which
traded
as
low
as
45
Friday
,
finished
the
day
at
46
7/8
.
<END>
<START>
Other
RJR
securities
also
closed
higher
.
<END>
<START>
RJR
Holdings
Capital
Corp.
's
14.7
%
convertible
pay-in-kind
securities
maturing
in
2009
closed
1/2
higher
at
86
1/2
after
trading
as
low
as
85
1/4
.
<END>
<START>
Most
other
junk
bond
issues
finished
a
quarter-point
lower
on
rumors
that
Campeau
Corp.
was
filing
for
protection
from
creditors
under
Chapter
11
of
the
Bankruptcy
Code
.
<END>
<START>
A
spokesman
for
Campeau
called
the
rumors
``
ridiculous
.
''
<END>
<START>
Most
investment-grade
bonds
fell
3/8
to
1/2
point
.
<END>
<START>
--
Mortgage
securities
fell
7/32
to
8/32
but
held
up
better
than
intermediate
Treasurys
.
<END>
<START>
Dealers
said
some
defensive
investors
were
buyers
of
mortgages
,
as
were
dealers
seeking
collateral
for
REMICs
priced
earlier
last
week
.
<END>
<START>
Under
a
less-sweeping
Senate
plan
,
the
catastrophic-care
monthly
premium
would
continue
,
rising
to
$
4.90
next
year
,
but
the
surtax
would
be
abolished
.
<END>
<START>
Medicare
Part
B
pays
80
%
of
a
beneficiary
's
allowable
doctor
's
bills
after
an
annual
deductible
of
$
75
.
<END>
<START>
The
Catastrophic
Coverage
Act
would
add
a
stop-loss
provision
next
year
to
limit
the
maximum
beneficiaries
must
pay
for
doctors
.
<END>
<START>
Both
the
House
and
Senate
bills
to
reduce
the
cost
and
coverage
of
the
catastrophic-care
plan
would
eliminate
the
cap
on
doctor
's
bills
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
House
prevails
in
its
efforts
to
kill
the
catastrophic-care
plan
,
the
monthly
Part
B
premium
will
be
$
29
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
Senate
plan
prevails
,
the
premium
will
be
$
33.90
,
with
the
additional
$
4.90
going
to
pay
for
expanded
hospital
coverage
under
Part
A
of
Medicare
.
<END>
<START>
Most
of
Part
A
's
costs
are
paid
by
a
payroll
tax
on
workers
and
employers
.
<END>
<START>
Lockheed
Corp.
said
it
will
trim
its
Aeronautical
Systems
work
force
in
California
and
Georgia
by
several
hundred
workers
,
reflecting
the
defense
industry
's
decline
.
<END>
<START>
The
Lockheed
unit
has
24,000
workers
;
it
expects
to
make
the
cuts
through
a
combination
of
furloughs
,
attrition
and
retirements
.
<END>
<START>
The
reductions
should
be
complete
by
the
end
of
the
year
,
a
spokesman
said
,
adding
that
the
exact
number
to
be
cut
has
n't
been
determined
.
<END>
<START>
Lockheed
reported
a
$
32
million
third-quarter
net
loss
,
largely
because
of
cost
overruns
on
fixed-price
military
contracts
.
<END>
<START>
Noting
that
other
defense
contractors
are
complaining
of
losses
on
such

,
analysts
say
taxpayers
have
been
getting

on

in

.
<END>
<START>
Defense
contractors
``
can
not
continue
to
get

on
that

,
''
said
Howard
Rubel
,
an

with
C.J.
Lawrence
,
Morgan
Grenfell
Inc.
in
New
York
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
pain
is
too
great
.
<END>
<START>
Separately
,
Innopac
reported
a
fourth-quarter
loss
of
about
C$
2.6
million
,
or
18
Canadian
cents
a
share
,
reflecting
inventory
write-downs
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
was
C$
291.6
million
,
up
from
C$
252
million
in
1988
.
<END>
<START>
Martin
Fabi
,

's

and

,

viewed

Pattison
's

to

as

''

.
<END>
<START>
``
I

,
''

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
Among

,

products
that
are

,

's

,
for

.

,

,

.

<START>
PROGRAM
TRADING
is
being
curbed
by
more

firms
,
but
big

investors
are
expected
to
continue
the
practice
,
further
roiling

.
<END>
<START>
Bowing
to

,

,

and

.

Still
,

are

.
<END>
<START>
Several

and

's

in

.
<END>

.
<END>
<START>
Personal
spending
rose
0.2
%
in
September
,
the

in

.
<END>
<START>
The
slowdown
raises
questions
about
the

's
strength
because

fueled
much

the

GNP

.

Meanwhile
,

edged

0.3
%
.

,

.

.

.

.
<END>
<START>
RJR
Nabisco

.
<END>
<START>
The

RJR

7

<START>
-LRB-
During
its
centennial
year
,
The
Wall
Street
Journal
will
report
events
of
the
past
century
that
stand
as
milestones
of
American
business
history
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Thomas
Jefferson
sold
Congress
on
the
idea
of
the
decimal
system
for
currency
,
thus
saving
Americans
the
headaches
of
pounds
,
shillings
and
pence
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
struck
out
with
the
decimal
system
of
metric
weights
and
measures
the
French
had
invented
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
,
Congress
opted
for
the
inches
,
feet
and
yards
the
colonists
had
brought
with
them
.
<END>
<START>
Americans
did
n't
dislike
metrics
;
they
simply
ignored
them
.
<END>
<START>
Scientists
felt
differently
.
<END>
<START>
In
1807
,
the
Swiss
mathematician
who
headed
the
U.S.
Coast
and
Geodetic
Survey
made
an
``
iron
meter
''
that
he
had
brought
from
Europe
the
standard
of
measure
.
<END>
<START>
By
the
end
of
the
century
scientists
had
embraced
the
system
.
<END>
<START>
Businessmen
took
their
cue
from
the
engineers
.
<END>
<START>
When
Congress
finally
passed
the
Metric
Conversion
Act
in
1975
,
industry
was
far
ahead
.
<END>
<START>
Because
the
law
made
compliance
voluntary
,
it
inspired
little
more
than
jokes
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
The
press
had
a
field
day
with
questions
about
what
would
happen
to
``
six-footer
,
''
``
yardstick
''
and
``
inchworm
.
''
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Today
,
though
the
public
is
barely
aware
,
much
of
U.S.
industry
,
particularly
companies
manufacturing
or
selling
overseas
,
have
made
metrics
routine
.
<END>
<START>
General
Motors
,
for
example
,
uses
metric
terms
for
its
automobile
bodies
and
power
trains
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
In
auto
advertising
,
however
,
items
such
as
wheelbases
are
still
described
in
inches
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Farm-machine
makers
such
as
Caterpillar
and
Deere
work
in
the
metric
system
.
<END>
<START>
The
liquor
industry
went
metric
10
years
ago
.
<END>
<START>
The
Pentagon
has
led
the
charge
,
particularly
as
military
alliances
spread
world-wide
.
<END>
<START>
New
weapons
systems
will
be
around
until
the
next
century
,
notes
John
Tascher
,
the
Defense
Department
's
metric
coordinator
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
like
the
auto
makers
,
when
dealing
with
Mr.
Everyman
the
Pentagon
sticks
to
the
tried
and
true
.
<END>
<START>
Soldiers
and
sailors
are
still
measured
in
inches
and

.
<END>
<START>
Channel
One
,
a
satellite-delivered
daily
program
supported
by
advertising
,
is
scheduled
to
be
launched

.
<END>
<START>

,

.

.
<END>
<START>

.

,

.

.

<START>
Twice
in
two
weeks
the
unraveling
of
the
on-again
,
off-again
UAL
buy-out
slammed
the
stock
market
.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
stock
prices
seem
to
be
in
a
general
retreat
.
<END>
<START>
Since
peaking
at
2791.41
on
Oct.
9
,
the
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
has
lost
194.69
points
,
or
7
%
,
closing
Friday
at
2596.72
,
down
17.01
.
<END>
<START>
The
number
of
issues
falling
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
each
day
is
eclipsing
the
number
of
gainers
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
number
of
stocks
hitting
new
lows
far
outstrips
the
number
setting
new
highs
.
<END>
<START>
But
why
should
an
iffy
$
6.79
billion
leveraged
buy-out
deal
shake
the
foundations
of
the
entire
stock
market
?
<END>
<START>
Sure
,
price
action
is
volatile
and
that
's
scary
,
but
all-in-all
stocks
are
still
a
good
place
to
be
,
they
suggest
.
<END>
<START>
The
reaction
to
the
UAL
debacle
``
is
mindless
,
''
says
John
Connolly
,
chief
market
strategist
at
Dean
Witter
.
<END>
<START>
``
UAL
is
a
small
deal
as
far
as
the
overall
market
is
concerned
.
<END>
<START>
The
only
way
you
can
make
it
a
big
deal
is
to
draw
linkages
that
just
do
n't
make
sense
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
suggests
,
for
example
,
that
investors
may
have
assumed
that
just
because
UAL
could
n't
get
financing
,
no
leveraged
buy-outs
can
get
financing
.
<END>
<START>
Carried
even
further
,
some
investors
assumed
that
since
leveraged
buy-outs
are
the
only
thing
propping
up
stock
prices
,
the
market
would
collapse
if
no
more
LBOs
could
be
done
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
will
still
be
deals
,
''
argues
Mr.
Connolly
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
may
not
be
as
many
and
the
buyers
may
not
get
away
with
some
of
the
things
they
've
done
in
the
past
,
but
deals
wo
n't
disappear
.
''
<END>
<START>
And
even
without
deals
,
Mr.
Connolly
figures
the
market
would
remain
healthy
.
<END>
<START>
``
Those
stocks
are
up
because
their
earnings
are
up
and
their
dividends
are
up
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Even
the
volatility
created
by
stock
index
arbitrage
and
other
computer-driven
trading
strategies
is
n't
entirely
bad
,
in
Mr.
Connolly
's
view
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
long-term
investor
who
picks
stocks
carefully
,
the
price
volatility
can
provide
welcome
buying
opportunities
as
short-term
players
scramble
frantically
to
sell
stocks
in
a
matter
of
minutes
.
<END>
<START>
``
What
on
earth
does
the
UAL
deal
have
to
do
with
the
price
of
Walmart
,
which
I
was
able
to
buy
on
Oct.
16
at
a
very
attractive
price
?
''
<END>
<START>
Kidder
Peabody
's
Mr.
Jarrett
also
sees
some
benefits
to
the
stock
market
's
recent
drop
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
've
run
into
a
market
that
was
beginning
to
run
out
of
steam
and
get
frothy
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>
Maybe

.

<START>

.

<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>
A
frozen
mountaintop
in
Tibet
may
offer
an
important
clue
about
whether
the
Earth
is
warming
perilously
.
<END>
<START>
A
substantial
warming
would
melt
some
of
the
Earth
's
polar
ice
caps
,
raising
the
level
of
the
oceans
and
causing
widespread
flooding
of
heavily
populated
coastal
areas
.
<END>
<START>
To
compare
temperatures
over
the
past
10,000
years
,
researchers
analyzed
the
changes
in
concentrations
of
two
forms
of
oxygen
.
<END>
<START>
These
measurements
can
indicate
temperature
changes
,
researchers
said
,
because
the
rates
of
evaporation
of
these
oxygen
atoms
differ
as
temperatures
change
.
<END>
<START>
Some
climate
models
project
that
interior
regions
of
Asia
would
be
among
the
first
to
heat
up
in
a
global
warming
because
they
are
far
from
oceans
,
which
moderate
temperature
changes
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
ice-core
samples
are
n't
definitive
proof
that
the
so-called
greenhouse
effect
will
lead
to
further
substantial
global
heating
,
Mr.
Thompson
acknowledged
.
<END>
<START>
Skeptics
say
that
if
that
's
the
case
,
temperatures
should
have
risen
fairly
uniformly
over
the
past
century
,
reflecting
the
increase
in
carbon
dioxide
.
<END>
<START>
Other
temperature
data
show
similar
unexplained
swings
.
<END>
<START>
``
Climate
varies
drastically
due
to
natural
causes
,
''
said
Mr.
Thompson
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
said
ice
samples
from
Peru
,
Greenland
and
Antarctica
all
show
substantial
signs
of
warming
.
<END>

<START>

.

.

<START>

,

that

.

<START>

.
<END>
<START>
And

,

unprepared

.

<START>
Denton
Harris
<END>
<START>
Chairman
<END>
<START>
Metro
Bank
<END>
<START>
Atlanta
<END>
<START>
Because

cycle
of
poverty
along

lower
Mississippi
goes
back
so
many
generations
,

this
cycle
will
be
next
to

.
<END>
<START>
Sadly
,

appears
not
as
waves
but
as
a
downward

.
<END>
<START>
Yet
the
evidence
that
we
have
not

bottom
is
found
in

fact
that
we
are
not
yet

.
<END>
<START>
The

Delta
are

to

,

to

,

.

<START>

for

,

.

<START>
Management
advised

Friday

was

to

the
group

8

,

.
<END>
<START>

the
unit

recently
undergone
a
similar
overhaul
,
during
which
it
also
lost
as
many
as
400
employees
,
a
company
spokesman
said
in
response
to
questions
.
<END>
<START>
Mobil
Exploration
&
Producing
U.S.
Inc.
,
the
group
involved
,
currently
has
a
work
force
of
somewhat
less
than
5,000
.
<END>
<START>
A
few
years
ago
,
Mobil
restructured
the
entire
company
during
an
industrywide
shakeout
.
<END>
<START>
But
since
then
U.S.
oil
production
has
declined
and
Mobil
wants
to
focus
its

efforts
overseas
.
<END>
<START>

to

when

and

.

unlikely

.
<END>
<START>
On
Wednesday
,

will

in

.
<END>
<START>
Mobil

said
they
have
been

of

operations
since
early
this

.
<END>
<START>
During

coming
months
,

will

and

will

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>
Field
offices

;

;

;

,

;

,

.

.

For

.

<START>
The

``
focus

of
assets
,
''

.
<END>
<START>
Wanted
:
An
investment
that
's
as
simple
and
secure
as
a
certificate
of
deposit
but
offers
a
return
worth
getting
excited
about
.
<END>
<START>
With
$
150
billion
of
CDs
maturing
this
month
,
a
lot
of
people
have
been
scouring
the
financial
landscape
for
just
such
an
investment
.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
the
nationwide
average
yield
on
a
six-month
CD
is
just
under
8
%
,
and
8.5
%
is
about
the
best
around
.
<END>
<START>
But
investors
looking
for
alternatives
are
n't
finding
it
easy
.
<END>
<START>
Yields
on
most
fixed-income
securities
are
lower
than
several
months
ago
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
stock
market
's
recent
gyrations
are
a
painful
reminder
of
the
dangers
there
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
,
however
,
some
alternatives
that
income-oriented
investors
should
consider
,
investment
advisers
say
.
<END>
<START>
Short-term
municipal
bonds
,
bond
funds
and
tax-deferred
annuities
are
some
of
the
choices
they
mention
--
and
not
just
as
a
way
to
get
a
higher
return
.
<END>
<START>
A
mix
of
CDs
and
other
holdings
may
make
the
most
sense
.
<END>
<START>
Here
's
a
look
at
some
of
the
alternatives
:
<END>
<START>
SHORT-TERM
MUNICIPALS
:
<END>
<START>
Investors
with
a
heavy
tax
load
should
take
out
their
calculators
.
<END>
<START>
Yields
on
municipal
bonds
can
be
higher
than
after-tax
yields
on
CDs
for
maturities
of
perhaps
one
to
five
years
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
because
municipal-bond
interest
is
exempt
from
federal
income
tax
--
and
from
state
and
local
taxes
too
,
for
in-state
investors
.
<END>
<START>
For
an
investor
paying
tax
at
a
33
%
rate
,
a
seemingly
puny
6
%
yield
on
a
one-year
muni
is
equivalent
to
a
taxable
9
%
.
<END>
<START>
Rates
approach
6.5
%
on
five-year
municipals
.
<END>
<START>
Some
of
the
more
cautious
CD
holders
might
like
``
pre-refunded
''
municipals
.
<END>
<START>
These
securities
get
top
credit
ratings
because
the
issuers
have
put
aside
U.S.
bonds
that
will
be
sold
to
pay
off
holders
when
the
municipals
are
retired
.
<END>
<START>
The
idea
is
to
have
money
rolling
over
each
year
at
prevailing
interest
rates
.
<END>
<START>
BOND
FUNDS
:
<END>
<START>
Bond
mutual
funds
offer
diversification
and
are
easy
to
buy
and
sell
.
<END>
<START>
Buyers
can
look
forward
to
double-digit
annual
returns
if
they
are
right
.
<END>
<START>
But
they
will
have
disappointing
returns
or
even
losses
if
interest
rates
rise
instead
.
<END>
<START>
Bond
resale
prices
,
and
thus
fund
share
prices
,
move
in
the
opposite
direction
from
rates
.
<END>
<START>
The
price
movements
get
bigger
as
the
maturity
of
the
securities
lengthens
.
<END>
<START>
Consider
,
for
instance
,
two
bond
funds
from
Vanguard
Group
of
Investment
Cos.
that
were
both
yielding
8.6
%
on
a
recent
day
.
<END>
<START>
But
,
in
the
same
circumstances
,
the
returns
would
be
a
more
extreme
14.6
%
and
2.6
%
for
the
Vanguard
Bond
Market
Fund
,
with
its
12
1/2-year
average
maturity
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
get
equity-like
returns
''
from
bonds
if
you
guess
right
on
rates
,
says
James
E.
Wilson
,
a
Columbia
,
S.C.
,
planner
.
<END>
<START>
If
interest
rates
do
n't
change
,
bond
fund
investors
'
returns
will
be
about
equal
to
the
funds
'
current
yields
.
<END>
<START>
DEFERRED
ANNUITIES
:
<END>
<START>
Aimed
specifically
at
CD
holders
are
so-called
CD-type
annuities
,
or
certificates
of
annuity
.
<END>
<START>
Some
current
rates
exceed
those
on
CDs
.
<END>
<START>
Annuities
are
rarely
a
good
idea
at
age
35
because
of
the
withdrawal
restrictions
.
<END>
<START>
But
at
age
55
,
``
they
may
be
a
great
deal
,
''
says
Mr.
Wilson
,
the
Columbia
,
S.C.
,
planner
.
<END>
<START>
MONEY
MARKET
FUNDS
:
<END>
<START>
That
's
right
,
money
market
mutual
funds
.
<END>
<START>
The
conventional
wisdom
is
to
go
into
money
funds
when
rates
are
rising
and
shift
out
at
times
such
as
the
present
,
when
rates
seem
headed
down
.
<END>
<START>
With
average
maturities
of
a
month
or
so
,
money
funds
offer
fixed
share
prices
and
floating
returns
that
track
market
interest
rates
,
with
a
slight
lag
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
because
top-yielding
funds
currently
offer
yields
almost
1
1/2
percentage
points
above
the
average
CD
yield
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Witman
likes
the
Dreyfus
Worldwide
Dollar
Money
Market
Fund
,
with
a
seven-day
compound
yield
just
under
9.5
%
.
<END>
<START>
A
new
fund
,
its
operating
expenses
are
being
temporarily
subsidized
by
the
sponsor
.
<END>
<START>
If
rates
unexpectedly
rise
,
the
increasing
return
on
the
money
fund
will
partly
offset
the
lower-than-expected
return
from
the
bond
fund
.
<END>
<START>
The
United
Kingdom
reports
came
from
Dr.
Patrick
Toseland
,
head
of
clinical
chemistry
at
Guy
's
Hospital
in
London
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
telephone
interview
Friday
,
Dr.
Toseland
said
the
number
of
sudden
,
unexplained
deaths
of
diabetics
he
had
seen
this
year
was
17
compared
with
just
two
in
1985
.
<END>
<START>
At
least
six
of
the
deaths
occurred
among
relatively
young
diabetics
who
had
switched
from
animal
to
human
insulin
within
the
past
year
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Dr.
Solomon
Sobel
,
director
of
metabolism
and
endrocrine
drug
products
for
the
U.S.
Food
and
Drug
Administration
,
said
FDA
officials
have
discussed
Dr.
Toseland
's
findings
``
fairly
intensively
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
usual
warning
signs
of
hypoglycemia
include
sweating
,
anxiety
and
cramps
.
<END>
<START>
With
proper
warning
,
diabetics
can
easily
raise
their
blood
sugar
to
safe
levels
by
eating
sugar
or
sugary
food
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
anecdotal
data
certainly
shows
that
some
of
the
people
were
not
aware
of
the
rapid
onset
of
hypoglycemia
,
''
Dr.
Toseland
said
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
he
said
officials
conducting
the
study
had
n't
been
looking
for
signs
of
problems
related
to
hypoglycemia
unawareness
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
are
now
monitoring
for
it
much
more
closely
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
do
know
there
are
slight
differences
in
the
way
human
and
animal
insulins
drive
down
blood
sugar
,
''
Dr.
Sobel
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
human-based
drug
starts
the
blood
sugar
dropping
sooner
and
drives
it
down
faster
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
we
do
n't
believe
there
is
enough
of
a
difference
to
be
clinically
significant
,
''
Dr.
Sobel
said
.
<END>
<START>
Reports
of
Dr.
Toseland
's
findings
in
the
British
press
have
triggered
widespread
concern
among
diabetics
there
.
<END>
<START>
On
Friday
,
the
American
Diabetes
Association
issued
a
similar
statement
urging
the
six
million
U.S.
diabetics
not
to
overreact
to
the
British
report
.
<END>
<START>
The
FDA
already
requires
drug
manufacturers
to
include
warnings
with
insulin
products
that
symptoms
of
hypoglycemia
are
less
pronounced
with
human
insulin
than
with
animal-based
products
.
<END>
<START>
Eli
Lilly
&
Co.
,
the
Indianapolis-based
drug
manufacturer
,
dominates
the
U.S.
human
insulin
market
with
its
product
known
as
Humulin
.
<END>
<START>
Lilly
is
building
plants
to
make
the
insulin
in
Indianapolis
and
Fagershein
,
France
.
<END>
<START>
In
its
latest
annual
report
,
Lilly
said
Humulin
sales
have
shown
``
excellent
growth
.
''
<END>
<START>
Dr.
Toseland
said
most
of
the
British
diabetics
who
died
had
been
taking
a
human-based
insulin
made
by
Novo/Nordisk
,
a
Danish
manufacturer
.
<END>
<START>
None
of
the
diabetics
were
using
Lilly
's
insulin
.
<END>
<START>
SharesBase
Corp.
said
it
will
reduce
its
221-person
work
force
by
about
25
%
,
effective
tomorrow
,
in
an

to
stem

.

<START>
The
company
,
which

data
base
systems
and

,
said

ended

30
.
<END>
<START>
Defense
intellectuals
have
complained
for
years
that
the
Pentagon
can
not
determine
priorities
because
it
has
no
strategy
.
<END>
<START>
Last
April
,
the
new
defense
secretary
,
Richard
Cheney
,
acknowledged
that
,
``
given
an
ideal
world
,
we
'd
have
a
nice
,
neat
,
orderly
process
.
<END>
<START>
We
'd
do
the
strategy
and
then
we
'd
come
around
and
do
the
budget
.
<END>
<START>
This
city
does
n't
work
that
way
.
''
<END>
<START>
With
a
five-year
defense
plan
costing
more
than
$
1.6
trillion
,
it
's
about
time
we
put
together
a
defense
strategy
that
works
in
Washington
.
<END>
<START>
This
wo
n't
happen
until
strategists
come
down
from
their
ivory
tower
and
learn
to
work
in
the
real
world
of
limited
budgets
and
uncertain
futures
.
<END>
<START>
These
procedures
consume
millions
of
man-hours
of
labor
and
produce
tons
of
paper
,
and
each
year
,
their
end
product
--
the
Five
Year
Defense
Plan
--
promptly
melts
away
.
<END>
<START>
The
graph
on
the
left
shows
how
this
happens
-LRB-
see
accompanying
illustration
--
WSJ
Oct.
30
,
1989
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
Compare
the
past
eight
five-year
plans
with
actual
appropriations
.
<END>
<START>
The
Pentagon
's
strategists
produce
budgets
that
simply
can
not
be
executed
because
they
assume
a
defense
strategy
depends
only
on
goals
and
threats
.
<END>
<START>
Strategy
,
however
,
is
about
possibilities
,
not
hopes
and
dreams
.
<END>
<START>
By
ignoring
costs
,
U.S.
strategists
abdicate
their
responsibility
for
hard
decisions
.
<END>
<START>
That
puts
the
real
strategic
decisions
in
the
hands
of
others
:
bean
counters
,
budgeteers
,
and
pork-barrelers
.
<END>
<START>
These
people
have
different
agendas
.
<END>
<START>
How
can
we
turn
this
situation
around
?
<END>
<START>
Reform
starts
in
the
Pentagon
.
<END>
<START>
Strategists
should
consider
the
impact
of
budget
uncertainties
at
the
beginning
of
the
planning
process
.
<END>
<START>
They
ought
to
examine
how
a
range
of
optimistic
to
pessimistic
budget
scenarios
would
change
the
defense
program
.
<END>
<START>
They
would
then
develop
priorities
by
identifying
the
least
painful
program
cuts
as
they
moved
from
higher
to
lower
budgets
.
<END>
<START>
They
would
also
identify
the
best
way
to
add
programs
,
should
the
budget
come
in
at
higher
levels
.
<END>
<START>
This
kind
of
contingency
analysis
is
common
in
war
planning
and
business
planning
.
<END>
<START>
There
is
no
reason
that
it
can
not
be
done
for
defense
planning
.
<END>
<START>
Two
steps
are
necessary
to
translate
this
idea
into
action
.
<END>
<START>
Step
1
cleans
up
our
books
.
<END>
<START>
Negative
money
was
invented
in
1988
to
make
the
1990-94
Five
Year
Defense
Plan
conform
to
the
numbers
in
President
Reagan
's
final
budget
submission
to
Congress
.
<END>
<START>
That
plan
exceeded
the
numbers
contained
in
his
budget
message
by
$
45
billion
.
<END>
<START>
To
make
the
books
balance
,
as
is
required
by
law
,
somebody
invented
a
new
budget
line
item
that
simply
subtracted
$
45
billion
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
known
in
the
Pentagon
as
the
``
negative
wedge
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
1990
plan
also
assumes
inflation
will
decline
to
1.7
%
by
1994
.
<END>
<START>
Most
forecasters
,
including
those
in
the
Congressional
Budget
Office
,
assume
inflation
will
be
in
excess
of
4
%
in
each
of
those
five
years
.
<END>
<START>
At
that
rate
,
the
defense
plan
is
underfunded
by
$
48
billion
.
<END>
<START>
By
adding
the
negative
wedge
and
recalculating
the
remaining
program
using
a
more
probable
inflation
estimate
,
we
arrive
at
a
baseline
program
costing
$
1.7
trillion
between
1990
and
1994
.
<END>
<START>
Step
2
examines
how
four
progressively
lower
budget
scenarios
would
change
the
baseline
and
how
these
changes
would
affect
our
national
security
.
<END>
<START>
Note
how
the
baseline
program
assumes
a
sharp
increase
in
future
appropriations
.
<END>
<START>
Step
2
will
answer
the
question
:
What
happens
if
these
increases
do
not
materialize
?
<END>
<START>
Scenario
1
,
known
as
the
``
Constant
Dollar
Freeze
,
''
reimburses
the
Pentagon
for
inflation
only
--
it
slopes
upward
at
4
%
per
year
.
<END>
<START>
This
scenario
has
been
the
rough
position
of
the
U.S.
Senate
since
1985
,
and
it
reduces
the
baseline
by
$
106
billion
between
1990
and
1994
.
<END>
<START>
Scenario
3
,
the
``
Current
Dollar
Freeze
,
''
has
been
the
approximate
position
of
the
House
of
Representatives
for
about
four
years
.
<END>
<START>
It
freezes
the
budget
at
its
current
level
,
and
forces
the
Pentagon
to
eat
the
effects
of
inflation
until
1994
.
<END>
<START>
This
reduces
the
baseline
by
$
229
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Scenario
2
extends
the
recent
compromises
between
the
House
and
the
Senate
;
it
splits
the
difference
between
Scenarios
1
and
3
,
by
increasing
the
budget
at
2
%
per
year
.
<END>
<START>
It
reduces
the
baseline
by
$
169
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Finally
,
Scenario
4
reduces
the
budget
by
2
%
per
year
for
the
next
five
years
--
a
total
reduction
of
$
287
billion
.
<END>
<START>
This
can
be
thought
of
as
a
pessimistic
prediction
,
perhaps
driven
by
the
sequestering
effects
of
the
Gramm-Rudman
deficit
reduction
law
or
possibly
a
relaxation
of
tensions
with
the
Soviet
Union
.
<END>
<START>
The
strategic
planners
in
the
Joint
Chiefs
of
Staff
would
construct
the
most
effective
defense
program
for
each
scenario
,
maximizing
strengths
and
minimizing
weaknesses
.
<END>
<START>
This
exercise
would
reveal
the
true
cost
of
a
particular
program
by
forcing
the
strategists
to
make
hard
decisions
.
<END>
<START>
These
trade-offs
would
evolve
priorities
by
revealing
when
the
cost
of
the
B-2
became
prohibitive
.
<END>
<START>
Some
may
be
tempted
to
argue
that
the
idea
of
a
strategic
review
merely
resurrects
the
infamous
Zero-Based
Budgeting
-LRB-
ZBB
-RRB-
concept
of
the
Carter
administration
.
<END>
<START>
But
ZBB
did
not
involve
the
strategic
planners
in
the
Joint
Chiefs
of
Staff
,
and
therefore
degenerated
into
a
bean-counting
drill
driven
by
budget
politics
.
<END>
<START>
Anyway
,
ZBB
's
procedures
were
so
cumbersome
that
everyone
involved
was
crushed
under
a
burden
of
marginalia
.
<END>
<START>
A
strategic
review
is
fundamentally
different
.
<END>
<START>
It
might
be
feared
that
even
thinking
about
lower
budgets
will
hurt
national
security
because
the
door
will
be
opened
to
opportunistic
budget
cutting
by
an
irresponsible
Congress
.
<END>
<START>
This
argument
plays
well
in
the
atmosphere
of
gaming
and
mistrust
permeating
the
Pentagon
and
Congress
,
and
unfortunately
,
there
is
some
truth
to
it
.
<END>
<START>
But
in
the
end
,
it
must
be
rejected
for
logical
as
well
as
moral
reasons
.
<END>
<START>
Strategy
is
not
a
game
between
the
Pentagon
and
Congress
;
it
is
the
art
of
the
possible
in
a
world
where
constraints
force
us
to
choose
between
unpleasant
or
imperfect
alternatives
.
<END>
<START>
If
we
want
meaningful
priorities
,
we
must
understand
the
trade-offs
they
imply
before
we
make
commitments
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Spinney
is
a
permanent
Pentagon
official
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
a
condensed
version
of
an
essay
that
will
appear
in
the
January
issue
of
the
Naval
Institute
Proceedings
.
<END>
<START>
The
views
expressed
do
not
reflect
the
official
policy
of
the
Department
of
Defense
.
<END>
<START>
Although

,

probably
wo

.

.

''

,

.

.

Rally

.

.

<START>
Efforts

Kong

for

.

,

,

's

's

way
to
go
before
they
answer
all
the
remaining
detailed
questions
about
the
contract
.
<END>
<START>
The
exchange
had
forecast
that
the
contract
would
begin
trading
by
December
.
<END>
<START>
But
securities
regulators
now
say
privately
that
it
is
n't
likely
to
start
until
the
first
quarter
of
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
Many
believe
that
without
a
healthy
futures
exchange
,
Hong
Kong
's
aspirations
to
be
recognized
as
an
international
financial
center
will
suffer
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
local
banks
say
the
new
contract
is
important
in
helping
them
offset
their
Hong
Kong-dollar
exposure
.
<END>
<START>
The
contract
will
be
based
on
the
three-month
Hong
Kong
interbank
offered
rate
,
or
Hibor
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
contract
is
as
successful
as
some
expect
,
it
may
do
much
to
restore
confidence
in
futures
trading
in
Hong
Kong
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
contract
is
definitely
important
to
the
exchange
,
''
says
Robert
Gilmore
,
executive
director
of
the
Securities
and
Futures
Commission
.
<END>
<START>
Two
years
ago
,
the
futures
exchange
was
the
envy
of
other
would-be
futures
centers
.
<END>
<START>
After
only
17
months
,
its
main
contract
,
based
on
the
Hang
Seng
index
,
had
grown
to
be
the
second-largest
stock-index-futures
contract
in
the
world
.
<END>
<START>
-LCB-
A
futures
contract
is
an
agreement
to
buy
or
sell
a
commodity
or
financial
instrument
at
a
set
price
on
a
specified
date
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
case
of
stock-index
and
interest-rate
futures
,
the
instruments
are
given
an
underlying
cash
value
and
are
settled
in
cash
.
-RCB-
<END>
<START>
But
in
the
week
following
the
1987
stock
crash
,
the
exchange
verged
on
collapse
,
and
the
stock
and
futures
markets
in
Hong
Kong
were
closed
for
four
days
.
<END>
<START>
Only
a
government-sponsored
bailout
kept
the
crisis
from
swallowing
the
exchange
.
<END>
<START>
Trading
in
Hang
Seng
index
futures
remains
crippled
by
the
experience
.
<END>
<START>
Volume
for
the
entire
month
of
September
totaled
only
21,687
contracts
,
compared
with
a
daily
average
of
27,000
in
the
month
before
the
1987
crash
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
the
thin
trading
,
and
after
two
painful
years
of
restructuring
,
the
futures
market
has
shown
itself
to
be
resilient
in
two
recent
tests
.
<END>
<START>
While
Asian
markets
struggled
to
cope
with
the
uncertainty
caused
by
the
Oct.
13
plunge
in
New
York
stock
prices
,
futures
trading
in
Hong
Kong
was
relatively
heavy
and
went
smoothly
.
<END>
<START>
That
was
also
the
case
in
the
days
following
the
June
4
massacre
in
Beijing
,
which
caused
a
sharp
drop
in
Hong
Kong
stock
prices
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
was
no
problem
at
all
,
''
says
Douglas
Ford
,
chief
executive
officer
of
the
futures
exchange
.
<END>
<START>
The
two
big
banks
were
instrumental
in
designing
the
new
contract
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
those
two
banks
are
there
,
then
the
balance
of
the
banking
institutions
will
be
there
,
''
says
Mr.
Gilmore
,
the
Securities
and
Futures
Commission
official
.
<END>
<START>
Colony
banks
have
a
major
stake
in
how
interest
rates
move
because
of
their
enormous
Hong
Kong-dollar
exposure
.
<END>
<START>
In
early
1988
,
when
the
three-month
Eurodollar
rate
was
between
7
%
and
8
%
,
the
three-month
Hibor
rate
was
as
low
as
1
%
.
<END>
<START>
Just
a
few
months
ago
,
the
three-month
Eurodollar
rate
was
around
9.5
%
,
while
three-month
Hibor
hit
highs
above
11
%
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
the
initial
support
expected
,
trading
in
the
contract
is
likely
to
start
slowly
.
<END>
<START>
Companies
and
financial
institutions
familiar
with
Hong
Kong
remain
wary
of
trading
in
its
futures
market
.
<END>
<START>
And
Mr.
Gilmore
cautions
that
there
may
be
limits
on
how
much
the
contract
can
grow
because
the
Hong
Kong
dollar
is
n't
a
widely
traded
currency
.
<END>
<START>
He
says
the
contract
will
be
considered
a
success
if
it
starts
trading
500
to
1,000
lots
a
day
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Cheng
says
the
low
margin
required
for
trading
futures
attracted
a
lot
of
small
investors
before
the
1987
crash
who
did
n't
realize
that
their
risk
was
virtually
unlimited
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
're
not
going
to
get
your
taxi
drivers
and
amahs
and
all
that
,
''
says
Rory
Nicholas
,
a
director
for
securities
company
Elders
Bullion
&
Futures
Ltd
.
<END>
<START>
That
should
help
to
inspire
confidence
,
Mr.
Gilmore
says
.
<END>
<START>
But
many
bankers
remain
nervous
,
especially
as
the
start-up
of
the
contract
continues
to
be
delayed
.
<END>
<START>
Oji
Paper
,
the
nation
's
largest
in
terms
of
sales
,
said
its
pretax
profit
rose
1.5
%
to
23.11
billion
yen
-LRB-
US$
163.3
million
-RRB-
from
22.76
billion
yen
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
jumped
12.2
%
to
232.12
billion
yen
from
206.87
billion
yen
.
<END>
<START>
Net
income
increased
6.7
%
to
12.43
billion
yen
from
11.66
billion
yen
.
<END>
<START>
Per-share
net
rose
to
20.48
yen
from
19.51
yen
.
<END>
<START>
Pulp
,
processed
and

sales
also

.

,

that

sales
of
477.00
billion
yen
,

from
420.68
billion
yen
in
the
previous

.
<END>
<START>
Pretax
profit
is
seen
at
45.00
billion
yen
,
down
from
47.17
billion
yen
,
while
net
income
is

at
23.500
billion
yen
,

from
23.031
billion
yen
.
<END>
<START>
The

did
n't

for

and

could
n't

.

.
<END>

10
%

billion
yen

billion

.
<END>
<START>

yen
.

,

,

,

yen
.

Jujo

31
,

will
total
400.0
billion
yen
,

billion

.

<START>

23.0

,

billion

,

billion

,

.

The

.

.

<START>
Unocal
said
it
expects
to
complete
the
sale
of
its
Unocal
Norge
A/S
unit
by
next
March
or
April
.
<END>
<START>
In
1986
,
Unocal
sold
a
7.5
%
stake
in
the
Veslefrikk
field
to
Deutsche
Erdolversorgungs
G.m.b
.
H.
,
a
West
German
oil
company
,
for
an
undisclosed
amount
.
<END>
<START>
In
1987
,
it
sold
a
2.5
%
stake
in
the
Veslefrikk
field
to
the
Swedish
national
oil
company
,
resulting
in
a
$
7
million
after-tax
gain
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
those
sales
were
early
in
the
field
's
history
,
before
production
equipment
was
installed
.
<END>
<START>
The
field
is
currently
being
developed
and
is
slated
to
start
production
by
the
end
of
the
year
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
expected
to
produce
about
62,000
barrels
per
day
.
<END>
<START>
A
company
spokesman
said
the
Veslefrikk
field
's
gross
reserves
were
estimated
in
1987
at
229
million
barrels
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
he
added
that
that
estimate
,
made
before
extensive
development
drilling
,
currently
is
being
reappraised
.
<END>
<START>
The
spokesman
said
Unocal
has
had
``
considerable
interest
''
from
prospective
buyers
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
has
retained
J.
Henry
Schroder
Wagg
&
Co.
as
financial
adviser
and
agent
for
the
sale
.
<END>
<START>

.

.

.

Security

.

.

.
<END>
<START>

's

.
<END>
<START>
He

,
''

<START>
The
firm
did

in

on

's

.
<END>
<START>
On

Monday
,

16
,

across

and

.
<END>
<START>
London

,

.
<END>
<START>
The

's

provided

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
But

's

were
nothing
compared
with
the
Continent
's
.
<END>
<START>
For
48

,
no

had

were
worth
.
<END>
<START>
By

,

,

.

rally

,

.

<START>
Calgene
Inc.
and
Gustafson
Inc.
said
they
plan
a
joint
project
to
develop
biological
products
to
control
such
plant
diseases
as
aflatoxin
,
a
potent
cancer-causing
agent
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
plan
,
the
companies
will
use
Calgene
's
patented
technology
to
encapsulate
microbes
such
as
Bacillus
subtilis
,
a
bacterium
,
to
enhance
their
biological
activity
against
plant
diseases
.
<END>
<START>
Calgene
,
an
agricultural
biotechnology
concern
,
said
initial
work
will
concentrate
on
a
proprietary
strain
of
Bacillus
subtilis
which
has
shown
promise
for
controlling
aflatoxin
.
<END>
<START>
The
strain
was
discovered
by
Morinaga
&
Co.
and
licensed
to
Gustafson
,
a
unit
of
Uniroyal
Chemical
Co
.
<END>
<START>
Aflatoxin
is
released
by
molds
during
grain
and
seed
storage
.
<END>
<START>
The
recent
appearance
of
aflatoxin
in
such
foods
as
corn
and
peanut
butter
has
sparked
public
concern
and
consumer
scrutiny
of
food
handling
and
storage
procedures
.
<END>
<START>
European
Community
employers
fear
that
the
EC
Commission
's
plans
for
a
``
charter
of
fundamental
social
rights
''
is
a
danger
to
industrial
competitiveness
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
do
n't
want
Brussels
deciding
conditions
for
workers
unless
they
are
necessary
and
useful
,
''
said
Zygmunt
Tyszkiewicz
,
secretary
general
of
the
employers
'
confederation
Unice
.
<END>
<START>
Unice
--
an
acronym
for
the
Union
of
Industrial
and
Employers
'
Confederations
of
Europe
--
fears
that
the
charter
will
force
EC
countries
to
adopt
a
single
pattern
in
labor
relations
.
<END>
<START>
Workers
and
management
,
Mr.
Tyszkiewicz
said
,
would
lose
the
``
flexibility
and
diversity
''
that
has
so
far
allowed
them
to
adapt
to
local
conditions
and
traditions
.
<END>
<START>
The
British
government
also
strongly
opposes
the
charter
in
its
current
form
.
<END>
<START>
It
argues
,
as
does
Unice
,
that
labor
relations
are
best
left
to
be
regulated
at
the
national
level
.
<END>
<START>
France
will
propose
a
slightly
watered-down
version
of
the
charter
to
be
discussed
by
EC
social-affairs
ministers
on
Monday
,
officials
said
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
cosmetic
changes
are
n't
expected
to
win
over
Britain
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
still
have
serious
differences
with
the
text
,
''
a
British
official
said
,
because
it
provides
for
a
``
regulation
of
the
labor
market
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Tyszkiewicz
said
the
charter
would
put
poorer
EC
countries
such
as
Spain
,
Greece
and
Portugal
at
a
disadvantage
.
<END>
<START>
It
would
force
these
countries
to
introduce
minimum
standards
for
pay
and
working
hours
,
and
provide
for
collective
bargaining
and
worker
``
participation
''
in
major
corporate
decisions
.
<END>
<START>
This
,
he
warned
,
would
prevent
these
countries
from
bridging
the
difference
with
their
richer
EC
brethren
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
lower
wages
--
in
Greece
,
they
are
a
third
of
the
EC
average
--
are
n't
enough
to
offset
higher
transport
costs
and
lower
productivity
in
the
southern
countries
.
<END>
<START>
Increasing
labor
costs
,
Mr.
Tyszkiewicz
argued
,
would
only
put
the
countries
at
a
further
disadvantage
in
competing
in
the
barrier-free
EC
market
planned
for
after
1992
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
Unice
official
said
that
producing
a
charter
acceptable
to
both
Britain
and
European
industry
is
n't
an
unattainable
goal
.
<END>
<START>
The
charter
would
just
have
to
be
restricted
to
a
list
of
workers
'
fundamental
rights
,
without
seeking
to
impose
any
norms
.
<END>
<START>
This
provision
lies
at
the
heart
of
the
British
and
Unice
fears
of
``
social
engineering
''
by
the
commission
.
<END>
<START>
This
would
leave
Britain
free
to
adopt
the
charter
after
having
rebutted
the
action
program
.
<END>
<START>
The
charter
was
approved
by
the
EC
Commission
on
Sept.
21
.
<END>
<START>
Bruno
DeGol
,
chairman
of
DeGol
Brothers
Lumber
,
Gallitzin
,
Pa.
,
was
named
a
director
of
this
bank-holding
company
,
expanding
the
board
to
11
members
.
<END>
<START>
Sam
Ramirez
and
his
men
are
late
.
<END>
<START>
They
pile
out
of
their
truck
and
furiously
begin
twisting
together
steel
pipes
linking
a
giant
storage
tank
to
the
Sharpshooter
,
a
freshly
drilled
oil
well
two
miles
deep
.
<END>
<START>
If
they
finish
today
,
the
Sharpshooter
can
pump
tomorrow
.
<END>
<START>
One
roustabout
,
hanging
by
his
hands
from
a
ladder
,
bounces
his
weight
on
a
three-foot
wrench
to
loosen
a
stuck
fitting
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
've
been
putting
in
long
hours
,
''
Mr.
Ramirez
says
--
six-day
weeks
and
13-hour
days
for
the
last
two
months
.
<END>
<START>
A
year
ago
,
when
almost
nothing
was
happening
amid
these
desolate
dunes
,
``
you
'd
spend
two
days
working
and
two
days
in
the
yard
,
''
he
recalls
.
<END>
<START>
After
a
three-year
nightmare
of
uncertain
oil
prices
,
draconian
budget
cuts
and
sweeping
layoffs
,
fear
is
finally
leaving
the
oil
patch
.
<END>
<START>
Independent
drillers
are
gingerly
sinking
bits
into
the
Earth
's
crust
again
.
<END>
<START>
Some
in
Big
Oil
are
easing
the
grip
on
their
wallets
.
<END>
<START>
Investment
capital
is
creeping
back
,
and
oil
properties
are
fetching
more
.
<END>
<START>
Oil-tool
prices
are
even
edging
up
.
<END>
<START>
What
happened
?
<END>
<START>
In
broadest
terms
,
stability
has
quietly
settled
into
international
oil
markets
.
<END>
<START>
Mideast
politics
have
calmed
down
and
the
squabbling
within
the
Organization
of
Petroleum
Exporting
Countries
seems
under
control
for
now
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
fundamentals
of
supply
and
demand
once
again
are
setting
oil
prices
,
''
says
Victor
Burk
,
an
Arthur
Andersen
&
Co.
oil
expert
.
<END>
<START>
After
years
of
wild
swings
,
oil
prices
over
the
last
12
months
have
settled
at
around
$
15
to
$
20
a
barrel
.
<END>
<START>
That
is
n't
the
$
40
that
delighted
producers
a
decade
ago
or
the
$
10
that
pleased
users
a
year
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Not
that
oil
suddenly
is
a
sure
thing
again
.
<END>
<START>
The
current
equilibrium
is
fragile
and
depends
on
steady
,
strong
demand
and
continued
relative
harmony
within
OPEC
,
producer
of
more
than
40
%
of
the
non-Communist
world
's
crude
.
<END>
<START>
A
recession
or
new
OPEC
blowup
could
put
oil
markets
right
back
in
the
soup
.
<END>
<START>
Also
,
the
new
stirrings
are
faint
,
and
some
question
their
extent
.
<END>
<START>
Drilling
activity
is
still
far
below
eight
years
ago
,
there
's
no
hiring
surge
and
some
companies
continue
to
shrink
.
<END>
<START>
With
all
this
,
even
the
most
wary
oil
men
agree
something
has
changed
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
does
n't
appear
to
be
getting
worse
.
<END>
<START>
That
in
itself
has
got
to
cause
people
to
feel
a
little
more
optimistic
,
''
says
Glenn
Cox
,
the
president
of
Phillips
Petroleum
Co
.
<END>
<START>
Though
modest
,
the
change
reaches
beyond
the
oil
patch
,
too
.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
at
least
some
predictability
has
returned
,
for
everyone
from
economists
to
motorists
.
<END>
<START>
Corporate
planners
can
plan
again
.
<END>
<START>
``
Management
does
n't
want
surprises
,
''
notes
Jack
Zaves
,
who
,
as
fuel-services
director
at
American
Airlines
,
buys
some
2.4
billion
gallons
of
jet
fuel
a
year
.
<END>
<START>
Prices
had
been
so
unstable
that
two
years
ago
Mr.
Zaves
gave
up
on
long-term
forecasts
.
<END>
<START>
And
consumers
``
should
be
comfortable
,
''
adds
W.
Henson
Moore
,
U.S.
deputy
secretary
of
energy
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
do
n't
see
anything
on
the
horizon
that
could
lead
to
a
precipitous
rise
in
the
price
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
catalyst
for
all
this
has
been
OPEC
.
<END>
<START>
About
a
year
ago
,
it
ended
an
on-again
,
off-again
internal
production
war
that
had
put
prices
on
a
roller
coaster
and
pitched
oil
towns
from
Houston
to
Caracas
into
recession
.
<END>
<START>
Saudi
Arabia
,
OPEC
's
kingpin
,
abandoned
a
policy
of
flooding
the
market
to
punish
quota-cheaters
.
<END>
<START>
About
the
same
time
,
the
Iran-Iraq
war
,
which
was
roiling
oil
markets
,
ended
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
global
petroleum
demand
has
been
climbing
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
projected
to
keep
growing
by
a
million
barrels
a
day
,
or
up
to
2
%
annually
,
for
years
to
come
.
<END>
<START>
For
OPEC
,
that
's
ideal
.
<END>
<START>
The
resulting
firm
prices
and
stability
``
will
allow
both
producers
and
consumers
to
plan
confidently
,
''
says
Saudi
Arabian
Oil
Minister
Hisham
Nazer
.
<END>
<START>
OPEC
Secretary-General
Subroto
explains
:
Consumers
offer
security
of
markets
,
while
OPEC
provides
security
of
supply
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
an
opportune
time
to
find
mutual
ways
-LCB-
to
prevent
-RCB-
price
shocks
from
happening
again
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
To
promote
this
balance
,
OPEC
now
is
finally
confronting
a
long-simmering
internal
problem
.
<END>
<START>
At
its
November
meeting
,
it
will
try
to
revise
its
quotas
to
satisfy
Persian
Gulf
members
that
can
produce
far
more
oil
than
their
allotments
.
<END>
<START>
Being
held
well
below
capacity
greatly
irritates
them
,
and
has
led
to
widespread
cheating
.
<END>
<START>
OPEC
has
repeatedly
raised
its
self-imposed
production
ceiling
to
legitimize
some
of
that
unauthorized
output
.
<END>
<START>
That
would
send
prices
plummeting
from
what
some
gun-shy
U.S.
oil
executives
still
regard
as
too
low
a
level
.
<END>
<START>
Patrick
J
.
Early
,
president
of
Amoco
Corp.
's
oil-production
unit
,
says
that
despite
recent
stability
,
he
plans
continued
tightening
of
costs
and
exploration
spending
.
<END>
<START>
The
view
of
some
others
in
Big
Oil
,
he
maintains
,
``
is
very
much
-LCB-
similar
to
-RCB-
Amoco
's
outlook
.
''
<END>
<START>
Just
this
week
Mobil
Corp.
disclosed
new
cutbacks
in
its
domestic
exploration
and
production
operations
.
<END>
<START>
Santa
Fe
Energy
Co.
,
a
unit
of
Santa
Fe
Southern
Pacific
Co.
,
bought
from
Amoco
the
rights
that
allowed
it
to
drill
the
Sharpshooter
.
<END>
<START>
A
mile
and
a
half
away
looms
the
150-foot-tall
rig
of
the
Sniper
,
due
to
be
pumping
by
December
.
<END>
<START>
``
Talk
is
that
everybody
is
going
to
drill
more
wells
,
''
says
foreman
Tommy
Folsom
.
<END>
<START>
Santa
Fe
aims
to
drill
about
30
wells
in
this
area
in
1989
and
double
that
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
more
aggressive
than
most
,
but
it
is
n't
the
only
company
with
a
new
attitude
,
as
it
found
when
it
went
looking
for
a
