for
the
Sharpshooter
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
went
to
six
companies
over
two
days
pitching
the
prospect
,
''
says
Tim
Parker
,
a
Santa
Fe
exploration
manager
.
<END>
<START>
``
Five
were
interested
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mitchell
Energy
&
Development
Corp.
became
the
partner
,
ponying
up
more
than
half
of
the
$
600,000
in
drilling
and
start-up
costs
.
<END>
<START>
Mitchell
will
get
a
half-interest
in
the
oil
.
<END>
<START>
``
A
kind
of
no-mistakes
mentality
''
had
been
stifling
activity
,
says
Don
Covey
,
Mitchell
's
oil
exploration
chief
.
<END>
<START>
Now
``
everybody
is
a
lot
more
optimistic
.
''
<END>
<START>
One
attraction
for
oil
operators
here
and
in
other
fields
is
the
bargain-basement
cost
of
drilling
and
equipment
,
reflecting
service
companies
'
hunger
for
work
.
<END>
<START>
Kadane
Oil
Co.
,
a
small
Texas
independent
,
is
currently
drilling
two
wells
itself
and
putting
money
into
three
others
.
<END>
<START>
One
of
its
wells
,
in
southwestern
Oklahoma
,
is
a
``
rank
wildcat
,
''
a
risky
well
where
oil
previously
has
n't
been
found
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
you
know
you
've
got
stability
in
price
,
you
can
do
things
you
would
n't
do
with
the
volatility
of
the
past
few
years
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
activity
is
enough
to
move
some
oil-service
prices
back
up
a
little
.
<END>
<START>
Some
drill-bit
prices
have
risen
5
%
in
the
past
month
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
Gulf
of
Mexico
,
a
boat
to
deliver
supplies
to
offshore
rigs
now
costs
around
$
3,000
a
day
,
up
nearly
60
%
since
June
.
<END>
<START>
Some
service
boats
recently
were
auctioned
for
about
$
1.7
million
each
,
up
from
less
than
$
1
million
two
years
ago
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
bottom
of
the
slump
,
Schlumberger
Inc.
was
discounting
75
%
on
an
electronic
evaluation
of
a
well
;
now
it
discounts
about
50
%
,
drillers
say
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
there
is
money
to
be
made
.
<END>
<START>
Most
oil
companies
,
when
they
set
exploration
and
production
budgets
for
this
year
,
forecast
revenue
of
$
15
for
each
barrel
of
crude
produced
.
<END>
<START>
Prices
have
averaged
more
than
$
2
a
barrel
higher
than
that
--
not
a
windfall
,
but
at
least
a
pleasant
bonus
for
them
.
<END>
<START>
So
,
according
to
a
Dun
&
Bradstreet
Corp.
survey
,
companies
that
had
been
refusing
to
spend
even
their
very
conservative
budgets
may
loosen
up
before
year
end
.
<END>
<START>
It
says
40
%
of
those
surveyed
report
that
1989
exploration
spending
will
exceed
1988
's
.
<END>
<START>
Funds
for
drilling
may
inch
up
more
next
year
if
oil
prices
stay
stable
.
<END>
<START>
Texaco
,
thinking
in
terms
of
$
18-to-$19
oil
for
1990
,
may
raise
spending
,
especially
for
low-risk
prospects
,
an
official
says
.
<END>
<START>
Outside
investors
,
scarce
since
'86
,
are
edging
back
.
<END>
<START>
Wall
Street
generally
likes
the
industry
again
.
<END>
<START>
The
appetite
for
oil-service
stocks
has
been
especially
strong
,
although
some
got
hit
yesterday
when
Shearson
Lehman
Hutton
cut
its
short-term
investment
ratings
on
them
.
<END>
<START>
Contractors
such
as
Parker
Drilling
Co.
are
raising
cash
again
through
stock
offerings
,
and
for
the
first
time
in
years
,
two
oil-service
companies
recently
went
public
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
They
are
Grace
Energy
Corp.
of
Dallas
and
Marine
Drilling
Co.
of
Houston
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Most
oil
companies
are
still
reluctant
to
add
to
the
office
and
professional
staffs
they
slashed
so
deeply
.
<END>
<START>
But
a
few
new
spots
are
opening
.
<END>
<START>
Arthur
Andersen
,
the
accounting
firm
,
has
increased
its
energy
staff
10
%
in
a
year
.
<END>
<START>
Out
in
the
oil
fields
,
if
activity
picks
up
much
more
,
shortages
could
appear
because
so
many
roughnecks
,
roustabouts
and
others
left
after
the
crash
.
<END>
<START>
Already
``
it
's
hard
to
get
people
.
<END>
<START>
They
're
so
busy
,
''
says
one
Santa
Fe
drilling
foreman
here
.
<END>
<START>
For
most

workers
,
it
's
about
time
.
<END>
<START>
Norman
Young
,
a
``
mud-logger
''
at
the
Sniper
well
,
has
worked
all
but
about
nine
days
of
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Last
year
,
``
I
was
off
a
straight
month
,
then
one
time
for
two
to
three
weeks
and
another
two
to
three
weeks
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Butch
McCarty
,
who
sells
oil-field
equipment
for
Davis
Tool
Co.
,
is
also
busy
.
<END>
<START>
A
native
of
the
area
,
he
is
back
now
after
riding
the
oil-field
boom
to
the
top
,
then

the
bust
running
an
Oklahoma

.
<END>
<START>
``
First

I
came
back
there
was

,
''
he

.
<END>
<START>
``
I

's

now
.
<END>
<START>
But

wo

again
.
<END>
<START>
No

,
no

,
''
he

.
<END>
<START>
Business
has
been
good
enough
that
he
just
took
a

weekend
trip
to
the
mountain
area
of
Cloudcroft
,
something
``
I
have
n't

in

.
''
<END>
<START>
The

confirm
that
there
certainly
is
n't
any

boom
.
<END>
<START>
But
that
was
off
less
than
at
midyear
,
when
completions
lagged
by
27.1
%
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
number
of
rigs
active
in
the
U.S.
is
inching
up
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
Baker
Hughes
Inc.
,
992
rotary
rigs
were
at
work
in
the
U.S.
last
week
,
up
from
the
year-ago
count
of
933
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
In
1981
,
before
the
bust
,
the
rig
count
was
above
4,000
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Global
offshore-rig
use
shows
a
similar
upward
trend
.
<END>
<START>
Some
equipment
going
to
work
is
almost
new
.
<END>
<START>
Grace
Energy
just
two

ago
hauled
a

here
500

from
Caspar
,
Wyo.
,
to

<START>
California
Thefts
Make
Travel
Agents
Jittery
<END>
<START>
BEING
A
TRAVEL
agent
used
to
be
pretty
glamorous
.
<END>
<START>
Now
it
's
getting
downright
dangerous
.
<END>
<START>
In
recent
months
,
more
than
25
agencies
have
been
robbed
,
compared
with
only
a
handful
all
last
year
,
according
to
police
and
travel-agency
groups
.
<END>
<START>
Most
of
the
cases
have
been
in
California
,
where
one
agent
was
stabbed
and
another
was
shot
and
killed
.
<END>
<START>
Los
Angeles
police
say
the
thieves
seem
to
be
part
of
a
crime
network
that
knows
how
to
convert
blank
tickets
into
real
ones
.
<END>
<START>
Already
,
the
stolen
tickets
have
been
used
for
flights
all
over
the
world
.
<END>
<START>
So
far
,
the
thieves
have
stolen
3,632
blank
tickets
,
according
to
Airline
Reporting
Corp.
,
a
ticket
processing
center
.
<END>
<START>
Police
say
the
robberies
are
usually
pulled
off
by
two
to
five
men
,
who
walk
into
the
agencies
near
closing
or
lunch
time
,
when
few
employees
are
there
.
<END>
<START>
But
then
,
he
says
,
they
put
two
loaded
pistols
to
his
temple
and
demanded
he
open
the
safe
.
<END>
<START>
When
he
initially
refused
,
he
says
,
they
stabbed
him
in

back
and
made
off
with
$
2,000
and
280
blank
tickets
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
said
they
wanted
to
show
me
how
serious

were
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
As
word
of

crime

has
spread
,
many
agents
have
started
changing

open-door
policies
.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>
``
But

.
''
<END>

<START>
Texans
Get
Reasonable
Car
Rental
Insurance
<END>
<START>
CONSUMER
advocates
have
long
claimed
that
car
rental
companies
charge
too
much
for
car
rental
insurance
.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
a
new
law
in
Texas
seems
to
be
providing
the
proof
.
<END>
<START>
The
law
--
the
first
of
its
kind
--
requires
car
rental
companies
in
Texas
to
charge
only
``
reasonable
''
rates
for
collision-damage
waiver
insurance
.
<END>
<START>
Specifically
,
the
law
says
the
rates
must
closely
reflect
what
the
company
's
actual
expenses
have
been
to
replace
damaged
cars
.
<END>
<START>
Before
the
law
went
into
effect
last
month
,
car
rental
companies
were
charging
as
much
as
$
12
a
day
for
the
waiver
in
Texas
.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
they
're
charging
as
little
$
3
a
day
.
<END>
<START>
A
spokesman
for
Hertz
Corp.
acknowledges
,
``
The
waiver
is
n't
a
source
of
protection
for
consumers
,
but
a
source
of
revenue
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
Hertz
points
out
that
at
least
it
's
now
charging
only
$
3.95
a
day
in
Texas
,
while
some
competitors
are
charging
$
6.99
.
<END>
<START>
The
state
attorney
general
's
office
is
investigating
rental
car
agencies
charging
noticeably
higher
prices
.

<START>
Flight
Attendants
Lag
Before

Even

<END>
<START>
IF
YOUR
FLIGHT
attendant
seems
a
little

may

because
he

has
been
working
20

.
<END>
<START>
Some

on

are
putting
in
20-hour

days
,
the
study
found
.
<END>
<START>
Experts
say
such
long
hours
for
attendants
pose
a
safety
risk
.
<END>
<START>
For
instance
,
tired

might
not

enough

an

.
<END>
<START>
``

,

''

,

,
Ohio
.
<END>
<START>

They
have
to
work
such

hours
and
then
we
expect

to
be
heroes
if
there
's

.
''
<END>
<START>

,

is
considering
changing
its
policy
--
or
lack
of
it
--
on

.

.

.

.

.

K.

-LRB-

.

Washington

<START>
That
the
motivation
for

to
19.6
%

.
<END>
<START>

and

.
<END>

.
<END>
<START>

''

?

.

to

sales
of
about
$
100
million
in
1990
,
Grace
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
company
's
product
lines
will
be
aimed
at
nurseries
,
greenhouses
and
the
lawn
and
garden
industry
.
<END>
<START>
The
Financial
Accounting
Standards
Board
said
it
will
soon
issue
a
rule
requiring
disclosure
about
the
financial
risk
of
certain
financial
instruments
.
<END>
<START>
The
balance-sheet
detail
was
opposed
by
many
banks
and
thrifts
that
felt
the
cost
of
supplying
such
data
was
n't
worth
the
value
of
the
disclosures
.
<END>
<START>
The
final
rule
wo
n't
require
such
a
breakdown
of
the
allowances
for
loan
losses
,
which
appears
on
the
balance
sheet
.
<END>
<START>
The
FASB
rule
will
cover
such
financial
instruments
as
interest
rate
swaps
,
financial
guarantees
,
foward
interest
rate
contracts
,
loan
contracts
,
loan
commitments
and
options
written
on
securites
held
.
<END>
<START>
It
will
require
companies
to
spell
out
in
more
detail
collateral
polices
and
concentrations
of
credit
risk
for
all
financial
instruments
.
<END>
<START>
Scott
Miller
,
an
FASB
project
manager
,
said
that
a
final
rule
will
be
issued
before
year
end
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
noted
that
the
initial
effective
date
of
the
earlier
proposal
had
been
delayed
by
six
months
.
<END>

,

,

.

,

.

associated

Poughkeepsie
's

in

banks
it
is

its
North
Carolina
branches
as
well
.

thrift

Aug.
21
.

,

``

,

.

,

.

,

,

cents

.

.

.

The

.

<START>
Joe
Frank
Sanderson
Jr.
was
elected
president
and

of

.

<START>
Joe
Frank

,

is
currently

,

and

,

.

,

,

.

<START>
Kinder-Care
Inc.
was
dropped
from
the
consumer
services
industry
group
of
the
Dow
Jones
Equity
Market
index
because
the

in

.
<END>
<START>
It
was
succeeded
in
the
group
by
Fuqua
Industries
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
Both
moves
are
effective
today
.
<END>
<START>
A
potentially
safer
whooping
cough
vaccine
made
by
novel
genetic
engineering
techniques
was
described
by
a
team
of
Italian
,
U.S.
and
Japanese
scientists
.
<END>
<START>
The
team
reported
they
managed
to
induce
bacteria
to
produce
a
non-toxic
version
of
the
poisons
produced
by
the
bacterium
that
causes
whooping
cough
.
<END>
<START>
Laboratory
tests
showed
that
non-toxic
versions
of
the
poisons
are
capable
of
inducing
an
immunity
to
whooping
cough
,
the
researchers
reported
in
this
week
's
issue
of
the
journal
Science
.
<END>
<START>
The
current
vaccine
for
whooping
cough
,
or
pertussis
,
is
part
of
the
``
DPT
''
-LRB-
for
diphtheria
,
pertussis
,
tetanus
-RRB-
shot
given
most
infants
and
young
children
.
<END>
<START>
The
vaccine
is
effective
in
preventing
a
disease
that
still
afflicts
about
60
million
children
a
year
world-wide
,
causing
an
estimated
one
million
deaths
.
<END>
<START>
The
vaccine
,
however
,
causes
allergic
reactions
that
can
be
fatal
.
<END>
<START>
The
reactions
stem
from
the
fact
that
the
vaccine
contains
multiple
copies
of
the
whole
Bordetella
pertussis
bacterium
,
which
causes
whooping
cough
.
<END>
<START>
This
bacterium
produces
a
toxin
that
,
if
used
as
a
vaccine
,
can
induce
immunity
to
whooping
cough
.
<END>
<START>
Unfortunately
,
the
toxin
is
also
poisonous
.
<END>
<START>
The
Italian-led
scientific
team
said
they
had
succeeded
in
getting
bacteria
to
produce
a
non-toxic
version
of
the
pertussis
toxin
,
which
could
be
used
as
a
safe
vaccine
.
<END>
<START>
The
researchers
reported
they
have
been
able
to
pluck
the
five
genes
that
produced
the
toxin
out
of
the
pertussis
bacterium
.
<END>
<START>
It
turned
out
that
although
it
took
all
five
genes
to
produce
the
toxin
,
only
one
was
responsible
for
the
toxin
's
virulence
.
<END>
<START>
The
researchers
said
they
did
this
,
but
the
toxin
did
n't
induce
immunity
to
whooping
cough
.
<END>
<START>
The
scientists
then
took
the
five
toxin
genes
and
triggered
a
mutation
in
the
one
gene
that
caused
virulence
.
<END>
<START>
Then
,
using
a
new
technique
-LRB-
called
homologous
recombination
-RRB-
for
introducing
genes
into
cells
,
they
transferred
all
five
genes
to
bacteria
closely
related
to
the
pertussis
organism
.
<END>
<START>
These
bacterial
``
cousins
''
ordinarily
do
n't
make
the
toxin
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
genes
were
accompanied
by
a
piece
of
DNA
,
called
a
promoter
,
that
turns
the
genes
on
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
bacteria
recipients
of
the
genes
began
producing
pertussis
toxin
which
,
because
of
the
mutant
virulence
gene
,
was
no
longer
toxic
.
<END>
<START>
Carl
E.
Pissocra
,
president
and
chief
executive
officer
of
Bank
One
,
Dover
,
has
been
named
regional
president
,
a
new
post
at
the
bank-holding
company
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Pissocra
,
56
years
old
,
will
be
responsible
for
the
company
's
10
banks
in
the
Eastern
region
.
<END>
<START>
Dan
J.
Hartwell
,
41
,
executive
vice
president
of
Bank
One
,
Dover
,
was
named
president
and
chief
executive
of
the
Dover
bank
,
succeeding
Mr.
Pissocra
.
<END>
<START>
No
one
was
named
to
succeed
Mr.
Hartwell
.
<END>
<START>
Unless
,
of
course
,
it
happens
to
be
run
by
the
Rothschilds
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
the
Rothschilds
do
n't
deny
an
emotional
element
to
the
decision
.
<END>
<START>
The
original
bank
in
Frankfurt
closed
in
1901
after
the
death
of
Wilhelm
Carl
von
Rothschild
,
and
the
family
's
banking
activities
focused
on
London
and
Paris
.
<END>
<START>
Baron
Elie
de
Rothschild
,
the
family
's
elder
spokesman
,
explains
that
by
the
end
of
the
19th
century
,
Berlin
had
replaced
Frankfurt
as
Germany
's
financial
center
.
<END>
<START>
``
At
the
time
we
had
only
daughters
,
''
explains
the
72-year-old
patriarch
,
``
so
we
had
to
close
the
bank
.
''
<END>
<START>
Much
of
the
family
's
mystique
remained
.
<END>
<START>
The
family
's
long
absence
is
understandable
.
<END>
<START>
The
family
was
in
Allied
countries
during
both
World
War
I
and
the
long
period
of
economic
strife
of
the
1920s
.
<END>
<START>
During
the
Third
Reich
,
the
Rothschilds
were
a
target
of
Nazi
propaganda
against
Jewish
financiers
.
<END>
<START>
The
persecution
pursued
the
Rothschilds
across
Europe
as
the
Nazis
grabbed
countries
,
confiscating
the
family
's
property
in
the
process
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
immediate
postwar
years
,
the
Rothschilds
concentrated
on
rebuilding
their
other
European
operations
,
delaying
their
return
to
Frankfurt
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
the
competition
is
n't
greatly
concerned
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
would
be
surprising
if
they
did
n't
come
to
Frankfurt
in
time
for
1992
,
and
they
bring
an
interesting
tradition
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
market
really
is
n't
going
to
be
stood
on
its
head
,
''
said
a
banker
at
one
of
Frankfurt
's
Big
Three
banks
.
<END>
<START>
The
return
of
the
Rothschilds
is
modest
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
representative
office
,
with
one
manager
and
two
assistants
--
none
a
member
of
the
Rothschild
family
--
will
carry
out
no
banking
operations
of
its
own
.
<END>
<START>
The
constraints
do
n't
bother
the
office
's
54-year-old
manager
,
Erich
Stromeyer
.
<END>
<START>
He
left
his
job
as
general
manager
of
Shearson
Lehman
Hutton
Holdings
Inc.
's
Frankfurt
office
because
,
he
says
,
``
When
the
Rothschilds
called
,
I
could
n't
resist
.
''
<END>
<START>
Each
Rothschild
bank
is
linked
by
family
ties
and
cross-ownership
.
<END>
<START>
The
Paris
bank
does
n't
publish
that
figure
.
<END>
<START>
In
Europe
,
the
Rothschilds
banks
are
focusing
on
mergers
and
acquisitions
as
European
industry
restructures
ahead
of
1992
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
the
group
's
limited
resources
makes
it
a
niche
player
.
<END>
<START>
``
Obviously
,
there
are
quantitative
limitations
on
the
assistance
we
can
provide
,
''
concedes
Baron
David
de
Rothschild
,
``
but
we
feel
we
have
some
cards
to
play
.
''
<END>
<START>
Among
them
,
he
says
,
is
the
family
's
traditional
ties
to
old
wealth
and
decision-makers
in
banking
and
industry
throughout
Europe
and
beyond
.
<END>
<START>
The
Rothschilds
hope
to
use
a
long
history
in
private
banking
and
an
aura
of
exclusivity
to
attract
private
and
institutional
investors
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
we
do
make
exceptions
,
''
says
a
smiling
Baron
Elie
de
Rothschild
,
``
especially
if
they
are
very
young
and
have
very
rich
parents
.
<END>
<START>
As
program
trading
comes
under
renewed
attack
for
causing
stock
market
gyrations
,
a
few
people
on
Wall
Street
say
it
is
time
to
consider
extreme
measures
.
<END>
<START>
The
real
answer
to
curbing
wild
swings
in
stock
prices
,
they
say
,
might
be
to
curb
or
even
abolish
stock-index
futures
.
<END>
<START>
A
stock-index
future
is
a
contract
to
buy
or
sell
the
market
value
of
a
basket
of
stocks
,
such
as
the
Standard
&
Poor
's
500-stock
index
.
<END>
<START>
But
increasingly
,
people
are
questioning
that
view
,
and
the
critics
include
some
of
the
country
's
most
successful
investors
.
<END>
<START>
Warren
Buffett
has
been
on
record
as
opposing
stock-index
futures
since
their
inception
in
1982
.
<END>
<START>
And
Mario
Gabelli
,
another
star
in
the
investing
world
,
says
,
``
My
gut
says
the
negatives
of
futures
and
synthetics
far
outweigh
the
benefits
.
''
<END>
<START>
Like
others
,
Mr.
Gabelli
says
that
if
futures
cause
investors
to
lose
confidence
in
stocks
,
they
will
move
away
from
stocks
--
as
many
have
already
done
.
<END>
<START>
And
those
who
remain
,
he
says
``
will
demand
a
higher
return
and
over
time
raise
the
cost
of
capital
to
companies
.
''
<END>
<START>
Essentially
,
the
critics
of
stock-index
futures
fall
into
two
camps
.
<END>
<START>
``
Before
futures
,
''
says
New
York
investor
Michael
Harkins
,
``
you
actually
had
to
pay
attention
to
whether
the
thing
you
were
buying
had
any
intrinsic
value
.
''
<END>
<START>
While
it
was
once
expected
that
futures
would
mimic
stock
prices
,
traders
now
routinely
check
the
futures
markets
in
Chicago
before
they
buy
or
sell
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
When
Chicago
futures
prices
jump
up
or
down
,
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
follows
.
<END>
<START>
On
Tuesday
,
for
instance
,
the
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
plunged
80
points
in
little
more
than
an
hour
.
<END>
<START>
Then
,
in
the
space
of
a
20-minute
coffee
break
,
the
average
rallied
almost
all
of
the
way
back
.
<END>
<START>
Paul
Lesutis
,
who
manages
more
than
$
3
billion
of
investments
at
Provident
Capital
Management
Inc.
,
blames
futures
markets
for
leading
the
way
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
fundamentals
do
n't
change
in
an
hour
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
think
they
should
close
down
the
futures
exchange
and
then
we
could
get
back
to
investing
.
''
<END>
<START>
Index
arbitrage
--
the
rapid-fire
buying
and
selling
of
stocks
offset
with
opposite
trades
in
futures
--
is
frequently
blamed
for
adding
to
stock
market
volatility
.
<END>
<START>
Although
index
arbitrage
is
said
to
add
liquidity
to
markets
,
John
Bachmann
,
managing
partner
of
Edward
D.
Jones
,
says
too
much
liquidity
is
n't
a
good
thing
<END>
<START>
``
The
kind
of
instant
liquidity
that
is
implied
by
index
futures
is
that
you
can
buy
a
portfolio
over
two
years
and
get
out
in
one
day
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
too
disruptive
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
is
n't
investing
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
stock-index
futures
have
plenty
of
support
.
<END>
<START>
Defenders
say
futures
make
markets
more
efficient
and
provide
ways
for
investors
to
reduce
risks
.
<END>
<START>
They
note
that
stocks
experienced
volatile
swings
long
before
futures
.
<END>
<START>
And
,
defenders
say
,
few
people
complain
about
futures
when
stock
prices
are
rising
.
<END>
<START>
Futures
,
he
says
,
merely
cut
down
on
trading
costs
.
<END>
<START>
He
says
``
blaming
futures
is
like
blaming
the
messenger
.
''
<END>
<START>
Since
stock-index
arbitrage
merely
narrows
the
gap
between
prices
in
the
futures
and
stock
markets
,
it
ca
n't
add
to
volatility
,
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
the
current
outcry
over
stock
market
volatility
,
few
people
expect
stock
futures
to
disappear
.
<END>
<START>
For
one
thing
,
the
Chicago
futures
exchanges
have
political
and
financial
clout
--
including
many
friends
in
Congress
.
<END>
<START>
And
traders
say
that
futures
have
become
an
accepted
part
of
the
financial
landscape
.
<END>
<START>
``
All
life
is
about
change
--
either
you
adapt
or
die
,
''
says
one
Chicago
futures
trader
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
futures
are
n't
permitted
here
,
we
'll
take
it
to
Australia
or
Tokyo
.
''
<END>
<START>
Average
daily
volume
in
S&P
500
futures
last
year
was
44,877
contracts
.
<END>
<START>
Based
on
yesterday
's
closing
price
of
the
S&P
,
the
average
value
of
one
day
's
trading
amounts
to
$
7.6
billion
.
<END>
<START>
By
contrast
,
average
dollar
volume
on
the
Big
Board
last
year
was
$
5.3
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Many
investment
managers
say
futures
are
useful
as
a
way
to
hedge
portfolios
.
<END>
<START>
Average
daily
volume
in
S&P
500
futures
last
year
was
44,877
contracts
.
<END>
<START>
Based
on
yesterday
's
closing
price
of
the
S&P
,
the
average
value
of
one
day
's
trading
amounts
to
$
7.6
billion
.
<END>
<START>
By
contrast
,
average
dollar
volume
on
the
Big
Board
last
year
was
$
5.3
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Many
investment
managers
say
futures
are
useful
as
a
way
to
hedge
portfolios
.
<END>
<START>
One
reason
futures
are
said
to
add
volatility
is
that
--
unlike
in
stocks
--
people
can
speculate
in
futures
with
little
money
down
.
<END>
<START>
Margin
requirements
for
speculators
on
the
Chicago
Mercantile
Exchange
are
currently
about
7
%
.
<END>
<START>
``
For
$
10
million
,
you
can
move
$
100
million
of
stocks
,
''
a
specialist
on
the
Big
Board
gripes
.
<END>
<START>
``
That
gives
futures
traders
a
lot
more
power
.
''
<END>
<START>
By
contrast
,
an
investor
in
stocks
must
put
up
50
%
in
cash
.
<END>
<START>
Some
critics
say
futures
encourage
people
to
think
of
stocks
as
a
single
commodity
,
rather
than
as
investments
in
individual
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
,
they
say
,
futures
inhibit
the
basic
purpose
of
the
stock
market
:
to
accurately
price
securities
so
that
capital
and
investment
flows
where
it
's
needed
most
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
took
away
the
need
to
know
the
bad
third-quarter
report
of
IBM
,
for
example
,
''
Mr.
Kegler
says
.
<END>
<START>
Of

,

--
the
increasingly
common
practice
of
buying
or
selling
baskets
of
actual
stocks
--
also
treats
stocks
as
homogenous
commodities
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
is
a
class

that
wants
to
be
exposed
''
to
the

,

,

Travelers

.
<END>
<START>

are

``
cheaper

''

all
500

,

.
<END>
<START>
The
Big
Board
yesterday
began

in
its
own
basket

vehicle
representing
the
S&P
500
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
But

index
futures
is

the

as
owning
the

stocks
.
<END>
<START>
Stockholders
,
as
a
group
,
can
win
,
because

own
a
share
of

,

grow

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.

<START>

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
``

're

the

.

.
''
<END>
<START>

would

.
<END>
<START>
``

,

.
''
<END>
<START>

--

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
Ford

or

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

's
#

-LRB-

.

17

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>

,

,

.

<START>

,

<START>
Environmental
concerns
are
beginning
to
have
as
much
influence
in
oil-industry
spending
plans
as
the
price
of
crude
does
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
wake
of
the
Exxon
Valdez
spill
in
March
,
new
governmental
drilling
bans
are
sharply
curtailing
exploration
in
promising
locations
offshore
and
in
Alaska
.
<END>
<START>
Over
the
years
,
the
world
's
stream
of
oil
has
been
growing
heavier
.
<END>
<START>
So
the
scramble
is
on
for
lighter
crudes
globally
,
and

natural
gas
in

U.S.
.
<END>
<START>

and

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

has
also

200

in

for

exploration
.
<END>
<START>
And

are
trying
to
lock
in
future

.
<END>
<START>
AGIP
already
has
an

stake
in
Libya
.
<END>
<START>
Both
countries
produce
high-quality
,
low-sulfur
crudes
especially
suited
to
making
high-octane
motor
fuel
at
minimum

cost
.
<END>
<START>
He
made

to

U.S.
environmental
trends
because
they
are
often

in

.
<END>
<START>
ENI

,

.
<END>

,

.

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>

has

.
<END>
<START>
A

and

is

.
<END>
<START>
But

.
<END>
<START>

<START>
As
the
Soviet
Union
grapples
with
its
worsening

,

have
drawn
up
a
blueprint
for
change

to

.
<END>
<START>

's

.

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>
While

's

are

,

blueprint
is

attention
here

and
presumed

.
<END>
<START>
Although

<START>

chairman
of
the
Soviet
government
and
head
of
a
state
commission
on
economic
reform
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
clearly
a
manifesto
for
the
next
stage
of
perestroika
,
''
said
one
analyst
.
<END>
<START>
The
economic
ideas
in
the
document
are
much
bolder
than
current
policies
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
the
proposed
overhaul
of
prices
--
an
extremely
sensitive
political
topic
--
is
far
more
precise
than
the
vague
plans
announced
by
Mr.
Gorbachev
in
1987
and
later
dropped
.
<END>
<START>
Seeking
a
middle
path
between
opponents
of
change
and
radicals
who
demand
overnight
solutions
,
the
article
advocates
what
it
calls
a
``
radical-moderate
approach
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
document
is
to
be
discussed
at
a
conference
of
leading
economists
late
this
month
,
and
will
probably
be
presented
to
the
Soviet
Parliament
for
consideration
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
authors
make
a
gloomy
assessment
of
the
economy
and
concede
that
``
quick
and
easy
paths
to
success
simply
do
n't
exist
.
''
<END>
<START>
Instead
,
they
map
out
a
strategy
in
several
phases
from
now
until
1995
.
<END>
<START>
Most
of
the
measures
would
probably
only
start
to
have
an
effect
on
beleaguered
Soviet
consumers
in
two
to
three
years
at
the
earliest
.
<END>
<START>
The
key
steps
advocated
include
:
--
PROPERTY
.
<END>
<START>
Rigid
ideological
restrictions
on
property
ownership
should
be
abandoned
.
<END>
<START>
The
document
proposes
breaking
up
the
monolithic
system
of
state-owned
enterprises
and
farms
and
allowing
a
big
private
sector
to
flourish
,
helped
by
tough
anti-monopoly
legislation
.
<END>
<START>
The
economy
would
be
thrown
open
to
numerous
types
of
ownership
between
now
and
1992
,
including
factories
leased
by
workers
or
owned
by
shareholders
,
cooperatives
and
joint
ventures
.
<END>
<START>
Some
forms
of
private
property
would
be
sanctioned
.
<END>
<START>
Such
moves
would
greatly
reduce
the
power
of
government
ministries
,
who
now
jealously
guard
their
turf
and
are
seen
as
one
of
the
major
obstacles
blocking
economic
reform
.
<END>
<START>
--
FINANCES
.
<END>
<START>
Emergency
measures
would
be
introduced
to
ease
the
country
's
financial
crisis
,
notably
its
$
200
billion
budget
deficit
.
<END>
<START>
Similar
steps
would
be
taken
to
liquidate
unprofitable
state
and
collective
farms
by
the
end
of
1991
.
<END>
<START>
A
unified
system
of
taxation
should
be
introduced
rapidly
.
<END>
<START>
To
mop
up
some
of
the
300
billion
rubles
in
circulation
,
the
government
should
encourage
home
ownership
,
including
issuing
bonds
that
guarantee
holders
the
right
to
purchase
an
apartment
.
<END>
<START>
--
LABOR
.
<END>
<START>
A
genuine
market
for
labor
and
wages
would
replace
the
present
rigid
,
centralized
system
.
<END>
<START>
Departing
from
decades
of
Soviet
dogma
,
the
new
system
would
lead
to
big
differences
in
pay
between
workers
and
almost
certainly
to
unemployment
.
<END>
<START>
To
cushion
the
blows
,
the
government
would
introduce
a
minimum
wage
and
unemployment
benefits
.
<END>
<START>
--
PRICES
.
<END>
<START>
The
entire
system
of
centrally
set
prices
would
be
overhauled
,
and
free-market
prices
introduced
for
most
wholesale
trade
and
some
retail
trade
.
<END>
<START>
Consumers
would
still
be
able
to
buy
some
food
and
household
goods
at
subsidized
prices
,
but
luxury
and
imported
items
,
including
food
,
would
be
sold
at
market
prices
.
<END>
<START>
Inflation-adjusted
social
benefits
would
ensure
that
the
poor
and
elderly
do
n't
suffer
unduly
.
<END>
<START>
--
FOREIGN
TRADE
.
<END>
<START>
The
current
liberalization
and
decentralization
of
foreign
trade
would
be
taken
much
further
.
<END>
<START>
Soviet
companies
would
face
fewer
obstacles
for
exports
and
could
even
invest
their
hard
currency
abroad
.
<END>
<START>
Foreigners
would
receive
greater
incentives
to
invest
in
the
U.S.S.R.
<END>
<START>
Alongside
the
current
non-convertible
ruble
,
a
second
currency
would
be
introduced
that
could
be
freely
exchanged
for
dollars
and
other
Western
currencies
.
<END>
<START>
A
domestic
foreign
exchange
market
would
be
set
up
as
part
of
an
overhaul
of
the
nation
's
banking
system
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
hints
strongly
that
both
organizations
would
increasingly
lose
their
clout
as
the
changes
,
particularly
the
introduction
of
wholesale
trade
and
the
breakup
of
state
monopolies
,
take
effect
.
<END>
<START>
Ready
,
Willing
and
Unable
I
always
lift
the
hood
When
my
car
does
n't
start
;
If
gadgets
at
home
do
n't
work
I
coolly
take
them
apart
.
<END>
<START>
I
'll
admit
there
's
nothing
wrong
That
I
ever
do
find
,
But
it
's
nice
when
people
say
I
appear
mechanically
inclined
.
<END>
<START>
--
Joshua
Adams
.
<END>
<START>
Flick
Shock
<END>
<START>
At
the
movies
today
In
detail
you
see
What
the
prof
would
n't
show
In
Physiology
Three
.
<END>
<START>
--
Robert
Gordon
.
<END>
<START>
Candid
Comment
<END>
<START>
Do
n't
worry
;
people
will
learn
to
read
as
long
as
there
are
TV
program
listings
.
<END>
<START>
--
John
Drybred
.
<END>
<START>
Albert
Engelken
and
Robert
Thomson
had
never
met
,
though
for
38
years
their
lives
had
been
intertwined
in
a
way
peculiar
to
the
sports
world
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Engelken
,
now
a
transit-association
executive
in
Washington
,
D.C.
,
and
Mr.
Thomson
,
a
paper-products
salesman
in
Montvale
,
N.J.
,
had
n't
even
talked
to
each
other
.
<END>
<START>
But
one
recent
day
,
they
became
much
closer
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Engelken
,
a
rabid
baseball
fan
,
pores
over
the
sports
pages
to
chart
the
exploits
of
``
my
favorite
and
not-so-favorite
teams
and
players
.
''
<END>
<START>
His
morning
paper
,
the
Washington
Post
,
even
carries
a
sports
column
called
``
Jurisprudence
''
that
recounts
the
latest
arrests
and
convictions
of
players
and
team
managers
.
<END>
<START>
Like
many
sports
buffs
,
Mr.
Engelken
has
turned
cynic
.
<END>
<START>
Some
34,320
fans
jammed
the
stands
,
and
shouted
at
the
top
of
their
lungs
.
<END>
<START>
The
playoff
series
had
riveted
the
12-year-old
Giants
fan
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
Giants
struck
first
,
winning
the
opener
,
3-1
,
on
a
two-run
homer
off
Dodger
right-hander
Ralph
Branca
,
''
Mr.
Engelken
recalls
with
precision
today
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
Giants
got
swamped
in
the
second
game
,
100
,
and
trailed
4-1
going
into
the
bottom
of
the
ninth
of
the
third
and
deciding
game
.
<END>
<START>
The
Giants
scored
once
and
had
runners
on
second
-LCB-
Whitey
Lockman
-RCB-
and
third
-LCB-
Clint
Hartung
-RCB-
as
Bobby
Thomson
advanced
to
the
plate
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
rest
,
as
they
say
,
is
history
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Thomson
,
a
tall
,
Scottish-born
,
right-hand
hitter
,
stepped
into
the
batter
's
box
.
<END>
<START>
``
Thomson
took
a
called
strike
,
''
Mr.
Engelken
recounts
.
<END>
<START>
The
tension
mounted
as
Ralph
Branca
,
again
on
the
mound
,
stared
down
the
batter
.
<END>
<START>
He
wound
up
and
let
loose
a
fastball
.
<END>
<START>
The
pitch
sailed
toward
Bobby
Thomson
high
and
inside
and
then
,
with
a
crack
of
the
bat
,
was
sent
rocketing
back
into
the
lower
leftfield
stands
.
<END>
<START>
``
Giants
fans
went
into
euphoria
,
''
says
Mr.
Engelken
.
<END>
<START>
And
Bobby
Thomson
was
made
a
legend
.
<END>
<START>
The
same
Bobby
Thomson
,
it
turns
out
,
who
sells
those
paper-goods
today
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Thomson
played
outfield
and
third
base
until
1960
,
posting
a
lifetime
.270
batting
average
and
chalking
up
264
home
runs
before
retiring
and
going
into
paper-goods
sales
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Engelken
moved
south
to
Washington
,
but
he
took
with
him
enduring
memories
of
the
homer
of
1951
.
<END>
<START>
The
couple
's
first
dog
,
Homer
,
was
named
after
the
Great
Event
,
though
unwitting
friends
assumed
he
was
the

of

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Thomson
sent
off
a
card
to
Martha
:
``
It
does
n't
seem
like
25
years
since
I
hit
that
home
run
to
celebrate
your
birth
,
''
it
read
.
<END>
<START>
Martha
was
pleased
,
but
nowhere
near
as
much
as
Mr.
Engelken
.
<END>
<START>
The
family
license
plate
reads
``
ENG
23
,
''
the
first
three
letters
of
the
family
name
and
--
no

here
--
Bobby
Thomson
's

number
.
<END>
<START>
And

Mr.
Engelken
's

,
his
wife
bought
a
book
detailing
the
big
homer
and
sent

off

Mr.
Thomson
to

.
<END>
<START>
``
What
could
have
been
better
?
''
asks
Mr.
Engelken
.
<END>
<START>
Betsy
Engelken
asked
the
same
question
earlier
this
year
,
when
her
husband
was
about
to
turn
50
.
<END>
<START>
She
had
an
idea
.
<END>
<START>
Mrs.
Engelken
had

a
stop
on
the
New
Jersey
Turnpike
to
,
she
told
her
husband
,
pick

some

for

.
<END>
<START>
The
papers
would
be
handed
over
at
a

of

just

Exit
10
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
sounded
like

Ian
Fleming
,
''
Mr.
Engelken
recalls
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
appointed

,

pulled
over
,
and
Mrs.
Engelken

to

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Engelken
turned

and
rolled

.
<END>
<START>
In

,

,

man

.
<END>
<START>

:
<END>
<START>
``
Bertie
,
''

Happy

.
<END>
<START>

Bobby
Thomson
.
''
<END>
<START>
``
And

,
''
recalls

.
<END>
<START>
``
The
hero
of

,

I

.
<END>
<START>

,

;

's

.
''
<END>
<START>
They

.
<END>
<START>

I

,
''
said
Bobby
Thomson
,
now
66

.
<END>
<START>
They

.
<END>
<START>
``
I

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.

,

,
``
was

.
<END>
<START>
It

,

's

.
''
<END>
<START>
The

,

,
``
fulfilling

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
His

of

Ralph
Branca
``
a

.
''
<END>
<START>
But

,

.
<END>
<START>

,
''

.

<START>

,

.

,

,

.

,

.

'

.

of

.

<START>
Southam
Inc.
said
its
unprofitable
weekly
newspaper
,
The
Financial
Times
of
Canada
,
is
up
for
sale
.
<END>
<START>
When
that
agreement
expires
,
Torstar
will
be
free
to
increase
its
22.4
%
stake
in
Southam
,
or
to
make
an
offer
for
the
whole
company
.
<END>
<START>
Descendants
of
the
Southam
family
hold
an
additional
22.6
%
stake
in
the
Toronto-based
company
,
Canada
's
largest
newspaper
publisher
.
<END>
<START>
The
newspaper
could
fetch
between
15
million
and
20
million
Canadian
dollars
-LRB-
US$
12.8
million
to
$
17.1
million
-RRB-
,
said
one
analyst
,
who
asked
not
to
be
identified
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
,
Southam
reported
third-quarter
earnings
of
C$
10.8
million
on
revenue
of
C$
395.4
million
,
down
from
C$
14.6
million
on
revenue
of
C$
389.6
million
in
the
year-ago
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
``
To
be
profitable
,
the
paper
requires
more
circulation
and
building
circulation
is
an
expensive
undertaking
,
''
said
John
Macfarlane
,
the
paper
's
publisher
.
<END>
<START>
Southam
said
the
level
of
future
investment
required
by
the
paper
would
have
restricted
its
options
in
other
areas
.
<END>
<START>
Possible
bidders
include
Christopher
Ondaatje
,
a
Toronto
financier
and
vice
chairman
of
Hees
International
Bancorp
Inc.
,
a
holding
company
controlled
by
Toronto
's
Bronfman
family
.
<END>
<START>

<START>
For
the
Parks
and
millions
of
other
young
Koreans
,
the
long-cherished
dream
of
home
ownership
has
become
a
cruel
illusion
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
government
,
it
has
become
a
highly
volatile
political
issue
.
<END>
<START>
Last
May
,
a
government
panel
released
a
report
on
the
extent
and
causes
of
the
problem
.
<END>
<START>
During
the
past
15
years
,
the
report
showed
,
housing
prices
increased
nearly
fivefold
.
<END>
<START>
The
report
laid
the
blame
on
speculators
,
who
it
said
had
pushed
land
prices
up
ninefold
.
<END>
<START>
The
result
is
that
those
rich
enough
to
own
any
real
estate
at
all
have
boosted
their
holdings
substantially
.
<END>
<START>
For
those
with
no
holdings
,
the
prospects
of
buying
a
home
are
ever
slimmer
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
the
government
's
Land
Bureau
reports
that
only
about
a
third
of
Korean
families
own
their
own
homes
.
<END>
<START>
Rents
have
soared
along
with
house
prices
.
<END>
<START>
Former
National
Assemblyman
Hong
Sa-Duk
,
now
a
radio
commentator
,
says
the
problem
is
intolerable
for
many
people
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
'm
afraid
of
a
popular
revolt
if
this
situation
is
n't
corrected
,
''
he
adds
.
<END>
<START>
President
Roh
Tae
Woo
's
administration
has
been
studying
the
real-estate
crisis
for
the
past
year
with
an
eye
to
partial
land
redistribution
.
<END>
<START>
Last
week
,
the
government
took
three
bills
to
the
National
Assembly
.
<END>
<START>
The
proposed
legislation
is
aimed
at
rectifying
some
of
the
inequities
in
the
current
land-ownership
system
.
<END>
<START>
The
government
will
penalize
offenders
,
but
wo
n't
confiscate
property
.
<END>
<START>
--
A
tax
of
between
3
%
and
6
%
on
property
holdings
that
exceed
the
governmentset
ceiling
.
<END>
<START>
--
Taxes
of
between
15
%
and
50
%
a
year
on
``
excessive
''
profits
from
the
resale
of
property
,
or
the
sale
of
idle
land
to
the
government
.
<END>
<START>
The
government
defines
excessive
profits
as
those
above
the
average
realized
for
other
similar-sized
properties
in
an
area
.
<END>
<START>
--
Grace
periods
ranging
from
two
to
five
years
before
the
full
scope
of
the
penalties
takes
effect
.
<END>
<START>
Some
want
lower
limits
on
house
sizes
;
others
insist
on
progressively
higher
taxation
for
larger
homes
and
lots
.
<END>
<START>
But
others
,
large

,

and
business

,
say
the
government
's

are

.
<END>
<START>
Led

Korean
Industries
,

for
the
government
to
weaken
its
proposed

and

.
<END>
<START>
Government
officials
who
are
urging

reforms
balk
at
the
arguments
of
business
leaders
and
chafe
at
their
pressure
.
<END>
<START>
But
,
he
adds
,
the
constitution
empowers
the
government
to
impose
some
controls
,
to
mitigate

shortage
of
land
.
<END>
<START>
The
land

at
about
46.2

--
18
%
lower
than
in
Taiwan
and

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lee

10,000

.
<END>
<START>
One

calculated

as

67

is

by
403
companies
--
and

1.5

.
<END>
<START>
The
Ministry

Finance
,
as

result
,
has

a
series
of
measures
that
would
restrict
business
investment
in
real
estate
even
more

than
restrictions
aimed

.
<END>
<START>
Under
those
measures
,
financial
institutions
would
be
restricted
from
owning
any
more
real
estate
than
they
need
for
their
business
operations
.
<END>
<START>
Banks
,
investment
and
credit
firms
would
be
permitted
to
own
land
equivalent
in
value
to
50
%
of
their
capital
--
currently
the
proportion
is
75
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
maximum
allowable
property
holdings
for
insurance
companies
would
be
reduced
to
10
%
of
their
total
asset
value
,
down
from
15
%
currently
.
<END>
<START>
But

Park

<START>

's

1988

.
<END>
<START>

,

.

<START>

.

<START>

<START>

<START>

.
<END>
<START>
The
American

and
their

also
woke
up

to
the
menace
drugs
posed
to
the

of

.
<END>
<START>
Even
now
,
the
American
attack
upon
this

problem
is
timid
in
relation
to
the

of

.
<END>
<START>
Colombia
alone
--
its

,
its
people
,
its

--
does
not

to

.
<END>
<START>
All

must
jointly

to

and

and

of

.
<END>
<START>
The
U.S.
,
as
the
major

consumer
,
should
lead
this

.
<END>
<START>
Reduction
,
if
not
the
total
cessation
,
of
drug

is
the

for

.
<END>
<START>
Much
is
being
done
in
Colombia
to
fight
the
drug
cartel
mafia
.
<END>
<START>
Luxurious
homes
and
ranches
have
been
raided
by
the
military
authorities
,
and
sophisticated
and
powerful
communications
equipment
have
been
seized
.
<END>
<START>
More
than
300
planes
and
helicopters
have
been
impounded
at
airports
,
and
a
large
number
of
vehicles
and
launches
has
been
confiscated
.
<END>
<START>
The
military
has
also
captured
enormous
arsenals
of
powerful
and
sophisticated
weapons
,
explosives
and
other
war-like
materiel
.
<END>
<START>
Much
has
been
accomplished
and
public
opinion
decisively
supports
the
government
and
the
army
--
but
,
on
the
other
hand
,
none
of
the
key
drug
barons
have
been
captured
.
<END>
<START>
There
has
been
a
lot
of
talk
that
a
large
portion
of
the
Colombian
economy
is
sustained
by
the
laundering
of
drug
money
.
<END>
<START>
In
my
opinion
,
this
is
not
true
.
<END>
<START>
Laundered
drug
money
has
served
only
to
increase
,
unrealistically
,
the
price
of
real
estate
,
creating
serious
problems
for
low-income
people
who
aspire
to
own
their
own
homes
.
<END>
<START>
Drug
money
has
also
gone
to
buy
expensive
cars
,
airplanes
,
launches
and
nightclubs
where
drugs
are
consumed
.
<END>
<START>
But
most
of
the
drug
money
is
kept
in
investments
and
in
financial
institutions
outside
Colombia
.
<END>
<START>
In
fact
,
the
cooperation
of
those
financial
institutions
is
essential
to
the
success
of
the
drug
battle
.
<END>
<START>
What
is
of
much
more
importance
to
the
Colombian
economy
than
the
supposed
benefits
of
laundered
drug
money
is
higher
prices
for
Colombia
's
legitimate
products
.
<END>
<START>
The
price
of
coffee
has
gone
down
almost
45
%
since
the
beginning
of
the
year
,
to
the
lowest
level
-LRB-
after
inflation
-RRB-
since
the
Great
Depression
.
<END>
<START>
Market
conditions
point
to
even
lower
prices
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
27-year-old
coffee
cartel
had
to
be
formally
dissolved
this
summer
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
Colombia
will
earn
$
500
million
less
from
its
coffee
this
year
than
last
.
<END>
<START>
Our
coffee
growers
face
reductions
in
their
income
,
and
this
tempts
them
to
contemplate
substituting
coca
crops
for
coffee
.
<END>
<START>
U.S.
interests
occasionally
try
to
impose

to
the

another
important
Colombian
export
--
cut

--

.
<END>
<START>

just

and

open
market
for
what
Colombian
produces
and

should
be
the
policy

the
U.S.
.
<END>
<START>
Each
gram
of

consumed
is

against
those
in
our
country
and

the
rest

the
world

.
<END>
<START>
A

of
NO
to

.

<START>

Cano

,

.

<START>

,

<START>

.

may
be
no
treat
,
but
at
least
Mr.
Dinkins
knows
what
to
expect
from
it
.
<END>
<START>
As
the
campaign
hits
the
home
stretch
,
however
,
voters
still
have
very
little
idea
what
they
can
expect
from
him
.
<END>
<START>
After
25
years
in
city
politics
,
David
Dinkins
remains
an
enigma
.
<END>
<START>
The
soft-spoken
,
silver-haired
Manhattan
borough
president
--
the
first
black
man
to
win
the
Democratic
nomination
for
mayor
here
--
does
n't
have
a
single
prominent
political
enemy
.
<END>
<START>
While
he
is
widely
described
as
a
man
with
deep
convictions
,
he
has
few
major
political
programs
that
he
can
call
his
own
.
<END>
<START>
Asked
about
his
greatest
achievement
in
public
life
,
he
first
speaks
about
the
quality
of
his
staff
.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
as
election
day
nears
,
even
some
supporters
wonder
what
he
will
do
if
he
wins
the
mayoralty
on
Nov.
7
.
<END>
<START>
They
wonder
whether
he
can
be
firm
with
his
longtime
allies
,
including
union
leaders
and
political
cronies
who
may
seek
a
place
at
the
trough
.
<END>
<START>
They
wonder
whether
he
has
the
economic
know-how
to
steer
the
city
through
a
possible
fiscal
crisis
,
and
they
wonder
who
will
be
advising
him
.
<END>
<START>
Polls
also
have
recorded
some
slippage
in
Mr.
Dinkins
's
support
among
Jewish
voters
,
and
citywide
projections
now
put
his
lead
at
between
four
and
20
percentage
points
.
<END>
<START>
In
an
interview
with
reporters
and
editors
of
The
Wall
Street
Journal
,
Mr.
Dinkins
appears
quite
confident
of
victory
and
of
his
ability
to
handle
the
mayoralty
.
<END>
<START>
``
A
lot
of
people
think
I
will
give
away
the
store
,
but
I
can
assure
you
I
will
not
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
am
aware
we
have
real
budgetary
problems
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
city
is
full
of
aging
bridges
,
water
mains
and
roadways
that
are
in
need
of
billions
of
dollars
worth
of
repair
.
<END>
<START>
Renewed
efforts
to
fight
drugs
and
crime
will
be
costly
.
<END>
<START>
But
city
officials
say
tax
revenues
are
lagging
.
<END>
<START>
And
after
a
decade
of
explosive
job
growth
on
Wall
Street
,
a
period
of
contraction
is
under
way
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Koch
already
has
announced
he
will
drop
3,200
jobs
from
the
city
payroll
,
but
that
wo
n't
be
enough
.
<END>
<START>
New
York
State
Comptroller
Edward
Regan
predicts
a
$
1.3
billion
budget
gap
for
the
city
's
next
fiscal
year
,
a
gap
that
could
grow
if
there
is
a
recession
.
<END>
<START>
If
elected
,
Mr.
Dinkins
will
probably
have
no
choice
but
to
raise
taxes
on
overburdened

or
cut

in

.
<END>
<START>
``
He
is
going
to
face
a

,
''

City

Andrew

.
<END>
<START>
``
His

are

,
but
their
solution
to
everything
will
be
to
spend
more
money
,
and
he
wo
n't
have
any
money
.
''
<END>
<START>
By
and

,
Mr.
Dinkins
has
finessed
the
touchy
question
of
whose
ox
he
would
gore
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
is
a
feel-good
candidacy
.
''
<END>
<START>
No
doubt
,
Mr.
Dinkins
has
been
a
calming
influence
.
<END>
<START>
He
is
an
avuncular
figure
who
remembers
the
birthdays
of
colleagues
'
children
,
opens
doors
for
women
,
and
almost
never
has

word
to
say
about

.
<END>
<START>
Rather

off

,

many

would
,
Mr.
Dinkins
attracted
many
whites
precisely
because
of
his
reputation
for
having
a
cool
head
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Keeping
cool
is
a
Dinkins
priority
:
On

days
this
summer
,
he
was
known
to
change
his

.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Over

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

have

Mr.

into

.
<END>
<START>
``

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Mr.
O'Dwyer
is
now

Mr.
Sutton
's

.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
The
debt
rose
further
in
1977
when
Mr.
Sutton
resigned

Manhattan
borough

to

.
<END>
<START>
David

,

,
``
He

.
<END>
<START>
But
the
guy
is
so

,

.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Dinkins
lost
twice
by
wide

before

elected
borough
president
in

.
<END>
<START>
``

,
I
'll

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
Often
,

's

prevented

,

.
<END>
<START>
On

,

's

.
<END>
<START>

:
``

.
<END>
<START>
He

.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.

's

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

,
''
Mr.
Lynch

.
<END>
<START>
On

has
discussed
the
issues
during

,
he
has
run
into
a

.
<END>
<START>
Some

were

this

when
Mr.
Dinkins
suggested

law
forbidding
public
employees
to

.
<END>
<START>
He
withdrew
the

.
<END>
<START>
When

later
sided
with
striking
hospital
workers
,
some

cringed
a

more
,
concerned
that
Mr.
Dinkins
was

the

for

.
<END>
<START>
Then
,

,

Dinkins
promised

would

on

.
<END>
<START>
While

public

have
at

,
Mr.
Dinkins
's
position

have
more

reflected
anti-development

.
<END>
<START>
He
favors
a
form

rent

,
which
the

believes
would
make

more

to

in

.
<END>
<START>
In

,

to

to
their
record

New
York

.
<END>
<START>
With

pool
,
many

believe
,
that
policy
could
drive

from
the
city
.
<END>
<START>
And

a

the

of
New
Jersey
and
Connecticut
in

.
<END>
<START>
Many

say

Koch

's

5,000
Chase

.

<START>
But

's

,

.

<START>
Mr.

.

<START>
A

<START>
``

will

for

David
.
<END>
<START>
Toni
Johnson
pulls
a
tape
measure
across
the
front
of
what
was
once
a
stately
Victorian
home
.
<END>
<START>
A
deep
trench
now
runs
along
its
north
wall
,
exposed
when
the
house
lurched
two
feet
off
its
foundation
during
last
week
's

.
<END>
<START>
A
side
porch
was
ripped
away
.
<END>
<START>
The
chimney
is
a
pile
of
bricks
on
the
front
lawn
.
<END>
<START>
The
remainder
of
the
house
leans
precariously
against
a
sturdy
oak
tree
.
<END>
<START>
The
petite
,
29-year-old
Ms.
Johnson
,
dressed
in
jeans
and
a
sweatshirt
as
she
slogs
through
the
steady
afternoon
rain
,
is
a
claims
adjuster
with
Aetna
Life
&
Casualty
.
<END>
<START>
Some
of
the
funds
will
used
to
demolish
unstable
buildings
and
clear
sites
for
future
construction
.
<END>
<START>
Many
adjusters
are
authorized
to
write
checks
for
amounts
up
to
$
100,000
on
the
spot
.
<END>
<START>
They
do
n't
flinch
at
writing
them
.
<END>
<START>
The
Victorian
house
that
Ms.
Johnson
is
inspecting
has
been
deemed
unsafe
by
town
officials
.
<END>
<START>
But
she
asks
a
workman
toting
the
bricks
from
the
lawn
to
give
her
a
boost
through
an
open
first-floor
window
.
<END>
<START>
Once
inside
,
she
spends
nearly
four
hours
measuring
and
diagramming
each
room
in
the
80-year-old
house
,
gathering
enough
information
to
estimate
what
it
would
cost
to
rebuild
it
.
<END>
<START>
She
snaps
photos
of
the
buckled
floors
and
the
plaster
that
has
fallen
away
from
the
walls
.
<END>
<START>
While
she
works
inside
,
a
tenant
returns
with
several
friends
to
collect
furniture
and
clothing
.
<END>
<START>
One
of
the
friends
sweeps
broken
dishes
and
shattered
glass
from
a
countertop
and
starts
to
pack
what
can
be
salvaged
from
the
kitchen
.
<END>
<START>
Others
grab
books
,
records
,
photo
albums
,
sofas
and
chairs
,
working
frantically
in
the
fear
that
an
aftershock
will
jolt
the
house
again
.
<END>
<START>
The
owners
,
William
and
Margie
Hammack
,
are
luckier
than
many
others
.
<END>
<START>
A
few
years
ago
,
Mrs.
Hammack
insisted
on
buying
earthquake
insurance
for
this
house
,
which
had
been
converted
into
apartments
.
<END>
<START>
Only
about
20
%
of
California
home
and
business
owners
carried
earthquake
coverage
.
<END>
<START>
The
Hammacks
'
own
home
,
also
in
Los
Gatos
,
suffered
comparatively
minor
damage
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Johnson
,
who
works
out
of
Aetna
's
office
in
Walnut
Creek
,
an
East
Bay
suburb
,
is
awed
by
the
earthquake
's
destructive
force
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
really
brings
you
down
to
a

level
,
''
she

.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
hard

people
are
going
through
,
but
you
have
to
.
<END>
<START>
If
you
do
n't
,
you
ca
n't
do
your
job
.
''
<END>
<START>
For
Aetna
and
other
insurers
,
the
San
Francisco
earthquake
hit
when

in
the
field
already
were

.
<END>
<START>
Most

still
are

to
sort
through
the

by
Hurricane
Hugo
in
the
Carolinas
last

.
<END>
<START>
Aetna
,
which
has
nearly
3,000

,
had

about
750
of
them
in
Charlotte
,
Columbia
,
and
Charleston
.
<END>
<START>
Adjusters
who
had
been
working
on
the
East
Coast
say
the
insurer
will
still
be
processing
claims
from
that
storm
through
December
.
<END>
<START>
It
could
take
six
to
nine
months
to
handle
the
earthquake-related
claims
.
<END>
<START>
Because
of
the
difficulty
of
assessing
the
damages
caused
by
the
earthquake
,
Aetna
pulled
together
a
team
of
its
most
experienced
claims
adjusters
from
around
the
country
.
<END>
<START>
Even
so
,
few
had
ever
dealt
with
an
earthquake
.
<END>
<START>
Some
adjusters
,
like
Alan
Singer
of
San
Diego
,
had
been
working
in
Charleston
for
nearly
four
weeks
.
<END>
<START>
He
returned
home
last
Thursday
,
packed
a
bag
with
fresh
clothes
and
reported
for
duty
Friday
in
Walnut
Creek
.
<END>
<START>
Offices
were
set
up
in
San
Francisco
and
San
Jose
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
few
instances
,
Aetna
knew
it
would
probably
be
shelling
out
big
bucks
,
even
before
a
client
called
or
faxed
in
a
claim
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
secret
to
being
a
good
adjuster
is
counting
,
''
says
Gerardo
Rodriguez
,
an
Aetna
adjuster
from
Santa
Ana
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
have
to
count
everything
.
''
<END>
<START>
Adjusters
must
count
the
number
of
bathrooms
,
balconies
,
fireplaces
,
chimneys
,
microwaves
and
dishwashers
.
<END>
<START>
To
do

,
they
must
think
in
terms
of
sheetrock
by
the
square
foot
,
carpeting
by
the
square
yard
,
wallpaper
by
the
roll
,
molding
by
the
linear
foot
.
<END>
<START>
Sometimes
repairs
are
out
of
the
question
.
<END>
<START>
When
Aetna
adjuster
Bill
Schaeffer
visited
a
retired

in
Oakland
last
Thursday
,
he
found
them
living
in
a

.
<END>
<START>
The
house

,

880
,
was

and

into

.
<END>
<START>
The

,

with

151,000
to

.
<END>
<START>
He

agent
to
help
find

an

to
rent
while

is
being

.
<END>
<START>
Many
of
the
adjusters
employed
by
Aetna
and
other
insurers
have
some
experience
with
construction
work
or

.
<END>
<START>
But
such
skills
were
alien
to
Toni
Johnson
.
<END>
<START>
Four
years
ago
,
she
was

a

shop
and
was

.
<END>
<START>
A

,

.
<END>
<START>
She

,

``

''

,

and

.
<END>
<START>
A

,

.
<END>
<START>
She

in

,

,

construction

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

in

,

in

.
<END>
<START>
Her

.
<END>
<START>
Recently
,

saved

from

three

as

what

of
an
old

house

.
<END>
<START>
``
I
owe
that

.
<END>
<START>
I

,
''

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
It

,

<END>

.
<END>

.
<END>

,

ca

,

.

<START>
Mr.

is

,

.
<END>
<START>

<START>

.

.

that

,

,

.
<END>

''

,

.

<START>

2

,

.
<END>

<START>
The
Federal
Communications
Commission
allowed
American
Telephone
&
Telegraph
Co.
to
continue
offering
discount
phone
services
for
large-business
customers
and
said

would

its

of

market
.
<END>
<START>
The
FCC

were

for
AT&T
,
which
has
been

since
the
breakup
of
the
phone
system
for

in

and

.
<END>
<START>
Alfred
Sikes
,

,

.
<END>
<START>

,
''

,

<START>

-LCB-

-RCB-
for

.
''
<END>
<START>
The
FCC
took

.
<END>
<START>

,

to

to
big

,
called

12
,

that

were

.
<END>
<START>
Then

4-0

,

grounds
to

,

15
,
that

to

Corp
.
<END>
<START>

that

's

could
n't

.
<END>
<START>

did
n't

by

.
<END>
<START>
The

``
did

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
Apart

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

to

.
<END>
<START>

's

.
<END>
<START>
But

,

,

,

.

.

,

.

<START>
Julie
Amparano
Lopez
in

also

to
this
article
.
<END>
<START>
Billions
of
investors
'
dollars
are
pouring
out
of
the
nation
's
junk-bond
mutual
funds
,
undermining
a
pillar
of
support
in
the
already
reeling
junk
market
.
<END>
<START>
It
made
the
estimates
based
on
data
collected
from
more
than
a
dozen
big
junk
funds
.
<END>
<START>
Interviews
with
three
major
fund
groups
--
Fidelity
Investments
,
Vanguard
Group
Inc.
and
T.
Rowe
Price
Associates
Inc.
--
confirm
the
trend
.
<END>
<START>
Their
junk
funds
combined
have
had
net
outflows
totaling
nearly
$
500
million
,
or
about
13
%
of
their
junk
fund
assets
,
in
the
past
two
months
.
<END>
<START>
Some
fund
managers
say
negative
publicity
has
exacerbated
investors
'
concern
about
recent
declines
in
junk-bond
prices
.
<END>
<START>
The
withdrawals
could
spell
trouble
for
the
$
200
billion
junk
market
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
heavy
outflows
continue
,
fund
managers
will
face
increasing
pressure
to
sell
off
some
of
their
junk
to
pay
departing
investors
in
the
weeks
ahead
.
<END>
<START>
Such
selling
could
erode
prices
of
high-yield
junk
bonds
,
already
weakened
by
a
rash
of
corporate
credit
problems
.
<END>
<START>
Mutual
fund
groups
have
n't
lost
control
of
much
of
the
outgoing
money
,
says
Louis
Harvey
,
Dalbar
's
president
.
<END>
<START>
Mutual
fund
officials
say
that
investors
have
transferred
most
of
it
into
their
money
market
accounts
,
and
to
a
lesser
extent
,
government-bond
funds
.
<END>
<START>
So
the
impact
on
the
$
950
billion
mutual
fund
industry
as
a
whole
probably
will
be
slight
.
<END>
<START>
But
tremors
are
likely
in
the
junk-bond
market
,
which
has
helped
to
finance
the
takeover
boom
of
recent
years
.
<END>
<START>
Mutual
funds
are
the
among
the
largest
holders
of
junk
,
accounting
for
more
than
a
quarter
of
the
entire
high-yield
,
high-risk
market
.
<END>
<START>
The
88
mutual
funds
investing
solely
in
junk
bonds
hold
assets
of
about
$
32
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Other
funds
hold
a
smattering
of
junk
bonds
,
too
.
<END>
<START>
The
$
1.5
billion
Fidelity
High
Income
Fund
has
had
a
net
outflow
of
about
$
150
million
in
the
past
two
months
.
<END>
<START>
About
$
60
million
streamed
out
last
week
alone
,
double
the
level
of
the
week
following
last
month
's
Campeau
Corp.
credit
squeeze
.
<END>
<START>
About
98
%
of
the
outflow
was
transferred
to
other
Fidelity
funds
,
says
Neal
Litvack
,
a
Fidelity
vice
president
,
marketing
,
with
most
going
into
money
market
funds
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
get
a
news
item
,
it
hits
,
you
have
strong
redemptions
that
day
and
for
two
days
following
--
then
go
back
to
normal
,
''
says
Mr.
Litvack
.
<END>
<START>
The
fund
,
with
a
cash
cushion
of
more
than
10
%
,
has
``
met
all
the
redemptions
without
having
to
sell
one
thing
,
''
Mr.
Litvack
says
.
<END>
<START>
He
adds
:
``
Our
fund
has
had
-LCB-
positive
-RCB-
net
sales
every
month
for
the
last
three
years
--
until
this
month
.
''
<END>
<START>
Vanguard
's
$
1
billion
High
Yield
Bond
Portfolio
has
seen
$
161
million
flow
out
since
early
September
;
$
14
million
of
that
seeped
out
Friday
Oct.
13
alone
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
two-thirds
of
the
outflow
has
been
steered
into
other
Vanguard
portfolios
,
says
Brian
Mattes
,
a
vice

.
<END>
<START>
The
fund
now
holds
a
cash
position
of
about
15
%
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
$
932
million
T.
Rowe
Price
High
Yield
Fund
,
investors
yanked
out
about
$
182
million
in
the
past
two
months
.
<END>
<START>
Those
withdrawals
,
most
of
which
were
transferred
to
other
T.
Rowe
Price
funds
,
followed
little
change
in
the
fund
's
sales
picture
this
year
through
August
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
last
two
months
have
been
the
whole
ball
game
,
''
says
Steven
Norwitz
,
a
vice
president
.
<END>
<START>
Junk-fund
holders
have
barely
broken
even
this
year
,
as
fat
interest
payments
barely
managed
to
offset
declining
prices
.
<END>
<START>
Through
Oct.
19
,
high-yield
funds
had
an
average
0.85
%
total
return
-LRB-
the
price
change
plus
dividends
on
fund
shares
-RRB-
,
according
to
Lipper
Analytical
Services
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
even
less
than
the
4.35
%
total
return
of
the
Merrill
Lynch
High-Yield
Index
.
<END>
<START>
People
who
remain
in
junk
funds
now
could
get
hit
again
,
some
analysts
and
fund
specialists
say
.
<END>
<START>
Many
funds
in
recent
weeks
and
months
have
been
selling
their
highest-quality
junk
issues
,
such
as
RJR
Nabisco
,
to
raise
cash
to
meet
expected
redemptions
.
<END>
<START>
Funds
might
be
forced
to
accept
lower
prices
if
they
expand
their
selling
to
the
securities
of
less-creditworthy
borrowers
.
<END>
<START>
And
then
,
asset
values
of
the
funds
could
plunge
more
than
they
have
so
far
.
<END>
<START>
Says
Michael
Hirsch
,
chief
investment
officer
of
Republic
National
Bank
and
manager
of
the
FundTrust
Group
in
New
York
:
``
It
's
a
time
bomb
just
waiting
to
go
off
.
<END>
<START>
The
surprise
resignation
yesterday
of
British
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
Nigel
Lawson
sent
sterling
into
a
tailspin
against
the
dollar
by
creating
uncertainties
about
the
direction
of
the
British
economy
.
<END>
<START>
The
U.S.
unit
also
firmed
against
other
currencies
on
the
back
of
sterling
's
tumble
,
as
market
participants
switched
out
of
pounds
.
<END>
<START>
The
pound
also
dropped
precipitously
against
the
mark
,
falling
below
the
key
2.90-mark
level
to
2.8956
marks
from
2.9622
marks
late
Wednesday
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lawson
's
resignation
shocked
many

,
despite
the
recent

of
a
rift
between

and

.
<END>
<START>

,

``

''

``

''

.
<END>
<START>

,
''

.
<END>

.
''
<END>
<START>

...
.
<END>
<START>
Everyone
was

long
on

,
''

.

was

at

1.5765
,

late

.
<END>

,

.

<START>
On
an
office

of
the
Senate

committee
hangs
a
quote
from
Chairman
David
Boren
,
``
Do
n't

'til

's

.
''
<END>
<START>
He
once
used

line
in
a

on
Panama
,
meaning
do
n't
shrink
from
taking

against
Manuel
Noriega
.
<END>
<START>
So
how
did
a
good

like
this
end
up

that
required

to

of

?
<END>
<START>
George
Bush

last

by

,

.
<END>
<START>
But

--

.
<END>
<START>
The

in

and

.
<END>
<START>
Staff

for

were

about

could

.
<END>
<START>
They

what

really

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.

himself
did

the

until

told

last

.
<END>
<START>
It
's

that
David
Boren
should
be
in

center
of
this

.
<END>
<START>
A
former

,

's

of

in

.
<END>
<START>
He
's

rare

.
<END>
<START>
He
's
the
senator
most
like
Arthur
Vandenberg
,
the
GOP

from
Michigan
who
worked
to
forge
a

in

.
<END>
<START>
``
Vandenberg
and
Rayburn
are

of

,
''
Mr.
Boren
says
,
referring
as
well
to
Sam

,

who
cooperated
with

.
<END>
<START>
``
They
allowed
this
country
to
be

.
<END>
<START>
I
really
want
to
see
that
happen
again
.
''
<END>
<START>
If
this
were
1949
,
Mr.
Boren
might
even
succeed
.
<END>
<START>
But
in
1989
most
senators
have
other

.
<END>
<START>
Last
July
,
his
committee
rejected
a
Reagan
administration
plan
to
support
a
coup
in
Panama
.
<END>
<START>
Ohio

Howard
Metzenbaum
refused

any

that
might

,

.
<END>
<START>
Maine

.
<END>
<START>
So

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

was

little

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.

this

,

.
<END>
<START>
But

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
''
<END>
<START>
So

?
<END>
<START>
``

,
''
he
insists
,

.
<END>
<START>
``

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
``

?
<END>
<START>

.
''
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
Elliott

,

,

.

.

?

<END>

Mr.

.

''

.

,

''

.

<START>
Maybe

<START>

.

The

,

<START>
Americans

.
<END>
<START>
I
was

by

of
your

12

``
Rural

:
Tough
Row
To

.
''

<START>
We

,

Louis
County
,

.
<END>
<START>
The

,

is

in

.
<END>
<START>
I

.
<END>
<START>
I

at

,

,
when

were

.
<END>
<START>
How

to

.
<END>
<START>
Now
,

,

,

of

.
<END>
<START>
Yet

two

,
I

in

of
a

.
<END>
<START>
So

,

for
those

,
rural

,

and

.
<END>
<START>
Ronald
Edwin
Parsons
Ballwin
,
Mo
.
<END>
<START>
At
stake
are
almost
10,000
jobs
in
an
industry
that
has
been
the
mainstay
of
Finland
's
post-war
economic
revival
.
<END>
<START>
Shipbuilding
became
a
point
of
pride
as
Finnish
shipyards
remained
profitable
long
after
rivals
collapsed
all
over
Europe
.
<END>
<START>
But
if
,
as
many
now
fear
,
Waertsilae
Marine
joins
the
ranks
of
failed
shipyards
it
might
turn
out
to
be
remembered
most
as
a
blemish
on
Finland
's
international
reputation
.
<END>
<START>
The
shipyard
's
6.5
billion
Finnish
markka
-LRB-
$
1.54
billion
-RRB-
backlog
includes
about
20
ships
ordered
by
big
international
shippers
,
including
three
for
Carnival
Cruise
Lines
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
Miami-based
Carnival
said
the
first
of
the
three
ships
is
scheduled
to
be
delivered
next
month
,
just
in
time
for
the
winter
tourist
season
in
the
Caribbean
.
<END>
<START>
The
second
ship
is
scheduled
to
be
delivered
in
fall
1990
and
the
third
in
fall
1991
.
<END>
<START>
All
the
ships
are
covered
by
loan
guarantees
from
a
state
export
financing
agency
,
even
though
it
's
not
clear
whether
they
will
actually
be
built
.
<END>
<START>
Bankers
worry
that
if
the
government
makes
good
a
threat
to
withdraw
its
guarantee
commitments
,
shippers
will
counter
with
a
hail
of
lawsuits
.
<END>
<START>
State
loan
guarantees
are
rarely
a
source
of
controversy
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
some
bankers
cited
possible
parallels
between
the
Waertsilae
Marine
case
and
the
collapse
of
Norway
's
state-owned
Kongsberg
Vappenfabrikk
AS
two
years
ago
.
<END>
<START>
In
that
case
,
international
banks
and
investors
incurred
big
losses
because
they
incorrectly
believed
the
company
's
debt
carried
implicit
state
guarantees
.
<END>
<START>
Doubts
about
the
quality
of
state
credit
guarantees
could
reduce
the
competitive
strength
of
Finnish
companies
in
world
markets
where
financing
often
is
the
key
to
winning
orders
,
analysts
warn
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
state-owned
Finnish
companies
lacking
formal
state
guarantees
could
face
greater
difficulty
raising
funds
in
international
financial
markets
,
bankers
say
.
<END>
<START>
The
decision
by
a
majority
of
state-appointed
Waertsilae
Marine
directors
Monday
to
file
for
bankruptcy
was
an
abrupt
about-face
from
previous
government
policy
.
<END>
<START>
In
August
,
the
government
played
a
major
part
in
a
sweeping
restructuring
of
the
troubled
shipyard
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
time
71%-controlled
by
Oy
Waertsilae
,
a
conglomerate
,
the
shipbuilding
unit
faced
potential
losses
estimated
at
one
billion
markka
and
was
on
the
brink
of
liquidation
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
rescue
plan
,
Waertsilae
sold
51
%
of
its
stake
to
a
group
of
banks
and
pension
funds
.
<END>
<START>
The
government
,
in
turn
,
guaranteed
financing
to
complete
the
order
backlog
and
took
control
of
the
board
.
<END>
<START>
Government
officials
were
expected
to
combine
Waertsilae
Marine
with
two
other
struggling
firms
,
and
thus
ensure
Finland
's
survival
as
a
shipbuilding
nation
.
<END>
<START>
The
government
spent
most
of
last
year
attempting
to
carry
out
such
a
plan
but
was
thwarted
when
the
parent
Waertsilae
concern
pulled
out
at
the
last
minute
.
<END>
<START>
After
the
restructuring
of
Waertsilae
Marine
and
bolstered
by
state
loan
guarantees
,
two
big
bank
creditors
,
Union
Bank
of
Finland
and
state-controlled
Postipankki
,
resumed
lending
the
shipyard
working
capital
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
bankers
got
cold
feet
recently
as
government
officials
complained
they
had
been
misled
about
the
shipyard
's
actual
financial
condition
,
and
hinted
the
credit
guarantees
might
be
withdrawn
.
<END>
<START>
People
familiar
with
Monday
's
board
meeting
said
it
was
the
state
's
refusal
to
explicitly
reaffirm
the
credit
guarantees
that
led
Union
Bank
and
Postipankki
to
halt
lending
to
Waertsilae
Marine
.
<END>
<START>
Then
,
in
a
boardroom
showdown
,
state-appointed
directors
voted
to
file
for
bankruptcy
,
apparently
under
instructions
from
Finland
's
Industry
Minister
Ilkka
Suominen
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
say
Mr.
Suominen
had
grown
increasingly
worried
about
the
state
's
potential
financial
exposure
as
Waertsilae
Marine
's
losses
ballooned
to
more
than
double
the
figure
estimated
in
August
.
<END>
<START>
Senior
ministry
officials
huddled
with
creditors
during
the
week
in
an
attempt
to
agree
on
some
form
of
restructuring
that
would
keep
Waertsilae
Marine
operating
.
<END>
<START>
The
talks
may
drag
on
for
weeks
before
any
concrete
result
is
announced
,
people
familiar
with
them
said
.
<END>
<START>
One
solution
would
be
to
sell
the
shipyard
to
an
outsider
.
<END>
<START>
But
there
appear
to
be
few
,
if
any
,
suitors
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
the
potential
losses
make
any
rescue
scheme
unlikely
unless
the
politicians
once
again
change
tack
and
agree
to
pick
up
the
bill
,
analysts
said
.
<END>
<START>
Meantime
,
shippers
with
vessels
on
order
from
Waertsilae
Marine
will
remain
in
limbo
.
<END>

<START>
SYDNEY-Qintex
Australia

,

.

,

,

.

,

Skase

``

.

,

,

.

<START>
The
government
is

newest

against

:

.

<START>
And

wo

.
<END>
<START>

's

by

.

<START>
A

also
would

case
the
largest
--

--
in
which

'

have

in

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Antar
is
being
investigated
by
a
federal
grand
jury
in
Newark
,
where
prosecutors
have
told
him
that
they
may
soon
seek
an

on
racketeering
and
securities
fraud
charges
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
Racketeer
Influenced
and
Corrupt
Organizations
law
,
or
RICO
,
the
government
has
the
authority
to
seek
to
freeze
or
seize
a
defendant
's
assets
before
trial
.
<END>
<START>
According
to

Mr.
Antar
's

,

issued
their
warning
this
week
after
one

Mr.
Antar
's

asked
whether
legal
fees
might
be
subject
to
seizure
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
letter
,

told
Mr.
Antar
's
lawyers
that
because
of
the
recent
Supreme
Court
rulings
,
they
could
expect
that
any
fees
collected
from
Mr.
Antar
may
be
seized
.
<END>
<START>
Prosecutors
have
told
Mr.
Antar
's
attorneys
that
they
believe
Mr.
Antar
's
allegedly
ill-gotten
gains
are
so
great
that
any

has
used
to
pay

derives
from
