.
<END>
<START>
Therefore
,
they
said
,
the
money
can
be
taken
from
the
lawyers
even
after
they
are
paid
.
<END>
<START>
Justin
Feldman
and
Jack
Arseneault
,
attorneys
for
Mr.
Antar
,
both
declined
to
comment
on
the
matter
.
<END>
<START>
In
Newark
,
U.S.
Attorney
Samuel
A.
Alito
said
,
``
I
do
n't
think
there
's
any
legal
reason
to
limit
forfeiture
of
attorney
's
fees
to
drug
cases
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Antar
was
charged
last
month
in
a
civil
suit
filed
in
federal
court
in
Newark
by
the
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
.
<END>
<START>
Through
his
lawyers
,
Mr.
Antar
has
denied
allegations
in
the
SEC
suit
and
in
civil
suits
previously
filed
by
shareholders
against
Mr.
Antar
and
others
.
<END>
<START>
The
SEC
has
alleged
that
Mr.
Antar
aimed
to
pump
up
the
company
's
stock
price
through
false
financial
statements
in
order
to
sell
his
stake
and
reap
huge
profits
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Antar
,
the
SEC
said
,
made
more
than
$
60
million
from
the
sale
of
his
shares
between
1985
and
1987
.
<END>
<START>
The
Justice
Department
has
emphasized
that
the
government
's
fee-forfeiture
power
is
to
be
used
sparingly
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
department
policy
,
prosecutors
must
make
a
strong
showing
that
lawyers
'
fees
came
from
assets
tainted
by
illegal
profits
before
any
attempts
at
seizure
are
made
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
criminal
defense
lawyers
worry
that
defendants
are
being
deprived
of
their
Sixth
Amendment
right
to
counsel
and
a
fair
trial
if
the
government
can
seize
lawyers
'
fees
.
<END>
<START>
They
also
worry
that
if
the
government
applies
asset-forfeiture
laws
broadly
,
the
best
defense
lawyers
will
be
unwilling
to
take
criminal
cases
unless
they
are
assured
of
being
paid
.
<END>
<START>
The
stock
market
correction
of
Oct.
13
,
1989
,
was
a
grim
reminder
of
the
Oct.
19
,
1987
market
collapse
.
<END>
<START>
Since
,
like
earthquakes
,
stock
market
disturbances
will
always
be
with
us
,
it
is
prudent
to
take
all
possible
precautions
against
another
such
market
collapse
.
<END>
<START>
In
general
,
markets
function
well
and
adjust
smoothly
to
changing
economic
and
financial
circumstances
.
<END>
<START>
But
there
are
times
when
they
seize
up
,
and
panicky
sellers
can
not
find
buyers
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
just
what
happened
in
the
October
1987
crash
.
<END>
<START>
These
failures
in
turn
contributed
to
the
fall
in
the
market
averages
:
Uncertainty
extracted
an
extra
risk
premium
and
margin-calls
triggered
additional
selling
pressures
.
<END>
<START>
The
situation
was
like
that
of
a
skier
who
is
thrown
slightly
off
balance
by
an
unexpected
bump
on
the
slope
.
<END>
<START>
His
skis
spread
farther
and
farther
apart
--
just
as
buy-sell
spreads
widen
during
a
financial
panic
--
and
soon
he
is
out
of
control
.
<END>
<START>
Unable
to
stop
his
accelerating
descent
,
he
crashes
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
doubtful
,
though
,
whether
circuit
breakers
do
any
real
good
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
additional
time
they
provide
even
more
order
imbalances
might
pile
up
,
as
would-be
sellers
finally
get
their
broker
on
the
phone
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
,
an
appropriate
institution
should
be
charged
with
the
job
of
preventing
chaos
in
the
market
:
the
Federal
Reserve
.
<END>
<START>
The
availability
of
timely
assistance
--
of
a
backstop
--
can
help
markets
retain
their
resilience
.
<END>
<START>
The
Fed
already
buys
and
sells
foreign
exchange
to
prevent
disorderly
conditions
in
foreign-exchange
markets
.
<END>
<START>
The
Fed
has
assumed
a
similar
responsibility
in
the
market
for
government
securities
.
<END>
<START>
The
stock
market
is
the
only
major
market
without
a
market-maker
of
unchallenged
liquidity
or
a
buyer
of
last
resort
.
<END>
<START>
This
does
not
mean
that
the
Federal
Reserve
does
not
already
play
an
important
indirect
role
in
the
stock
market
.
<END>
<START>
In
1987
,
it
pumped
billions
into
the
markets
through
open
market
operations
and
the
discount
window
.
<END>
<START>
It
lent
money
to
banks
and
encouraged
them
to
make
funds
available
to
brokerage
houses
.
<END>
<START>
They
,
in
turn
,
lent
money
to
their
customers
--
who
were
supposed
to
recognize
the
opportunity
to
make
a
profit
in
the
turmoil
and
buy
shares
.
<END>
<START>
The
Fed
also
has
the
power
to
set
margin
requirements
.
<END>
<START>
But
would
n't
it
be
more
efficient
and
effective
to
supply
such
support
to
the
stock
market
directly
?
<END>
<START>
The
stock
market
is
certainly
not
too
big
for
the
Fed
to
handle
.
<END>
<START>
The
foreign-exchange
and
government
securities
markets
are
vastly
larger
.
<END>
<START>
Daily
trading
volume
in
the
New
York
foreign
exchange
market
is
$
130
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
daily
volume
for
Treasury
Securities
is
about
$
110
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
combined
value
of
daily
equity
trading
on
the
New
York
Exchange
,
the
American
Stock
Exchange
and
the
NASDAQ
over-the-counter
market
ranges
between
$
7
billion
and
$
10
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
$
13
billion
the
Fed
injected
into
the
money
markets
after
the
1987
crash
is
more
than
enough
to
buy
all
the
stocks
traded
on
a
typical
day
.
<END>
<START>
More
carefully
targeted
intervention
might
actually
reduce
the
need
for
government
action
.
<END>
<START>
And
taking
more
direct
action
has
the
advantage
of
avoiding
sharp
increases
in
the
money
supply
,
such
as
happened
in
October
1987
.
<END>
<START>
The
Fed
's
stock
market
role
ought
not
to
be
very
ambitious
.
<END>
<START>
It
should
seek
only
to
maintain
the
functioning
of
markets
--
not
to
prop
up
the
Dow
Jones
or
New
York
Stock
Exchange
averages
at
a
particular
level
.
<END>
<START>
The
Fed
should
guard
against
systemic
risk
,
but
not
against
the
risks
inherent
in
individual
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
It
would
be
inappropriate
for
the
government
or
the
central
bank
to
buy
or
sell
IBM
or
General
Motors
shares
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
,
the
Fed
could
buy
the
broad
market
composites
in
the
futures
market
.
<END>
<START>
The
increased
demand
would
normalize
trading
and
stabilize
prices
.
<END>
<START>
Stabilizing
the
derivative
markets
would
tend
to
stabilize
the
primary
market
.
<END>
<START>
The
Fed
would
eliminate
the
cause
of
the
potential
panic
rather
than
attempting
to
treat
the
symptom
--
the
liquidity
of
the
banks
.
<END>
<START>
Disorderly
market
conditions
could
be
observed
quite
frequently
in
foreign
exchange
markets
in
the
1960s
and
1970s
.
<END>
<START>
But
since
the
member
countries
of
the
International
Monetary
Fund
agreed
to
the
``
Guidelines
to
Floating
''
in
1974
,
such
difficulties
have
been
avoided
.
<END>
<START>
I
can
not
recall
any
disorder
in
currency
markets
since
the
1974
guidelines
were
adopted
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
,
the
mere
existence
of
a
market-stabilizing
agency
helps
to
avoid
panic
in
emergencies
.
<END>
<START>
The
old
saying
advises
:
``
If
it
ai
n't
broke
,
do
n't
fix
it
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
this
could
be
a
case
where
we
all
might
go
broke
if
it
is
n't
fixed
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Heller
,
now
at
VISA
International
,
was
a
governor
of
the
Federal
Reserve
Board
from
1986
until
earlier
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
adapted
from
a
speech
to
the
Commonwealth
Club
in
San
Francisco
.
<END>
<START>
Bank
of
England
Governor
Robin
Leigh-Pemberton
urged
banks
to
be
cautious
in
financing
leveraged
buy-outs
.
<END>
<START>
``
Caution
should
...
be
the
rule
of
the
day
,
''
said
Mr.
Leigh-Pemberton
in
a
speech
to
the
Association
of
Corporate
Treasurers
'
annual
dinner
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
would
be
damaging
to
industry
and
to
the
financial
sector
in
general
,
to
say
nothing
of
banks
,
if
prudence
does
not
guide
the
financing
of
leveraged
transactions
.
''
<END>
<START>
His
remarks
were
distributed
to
the
press
before
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
Nigel
Lawson
announced
his
resignation
last
evening
.
<END>
<START>
Bank
of
England
officials
said
the
central
bank
had
no
comment
on
Mr.
Lawson
's
resignation
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Leigh-Pemberton
reiterated
that
the
exposure
of
United
Kingdom
banks
to
leveraged
deals
have
n't
yet
reached
``
worrying
levels
.
''
<END>
<START>
In
other
comments
,
he
said
takeovers
may
not
always
be
the
most
efficient
way
of
securing
a
change
of
corporate
direction
or
strategy
.
<END>
<START>
``
A
similar
result
could
sometimes
be
achieved
,
at
less
cost
,
by
changing
managements
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Intel
said
that
last
week
a
customer
discovered
two
flaws
in
its
80486
microprocessor
chip
's
``
floating-point
unit
''
,
a
set
of
circuits
that
do
certain
calculations
.
<END>
<START>
On
Friday
,
Intel
began
notifying
customers
about
the
bugs
which
cause
the
chip
to
give
wrong
answers
for
some
mathematical
calculations
.
<END>
<START>
But
while
International
Business
Machines
Corp.
and
Compaq
Computer
Corp.
say
the
bugs
will
delay
products
,
most
big
computer
makers
said
the
flaws
do
n't
affect
them
.
<END>
<START>
``
Bugs
like
this
are
just
a
normal
part
of
product
development
,
''
said
Richard
Archuleta
,
director
of
Hewlett-Packard
Co.
's
advanced
systems
development
.
<END>
<START>
Hewlett
announced
last
week
that
it
planned
to
ship
a
computer
based
on
the
486
chip
early
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
``
These
bugs
do
n't
affect
our
schedule
at
all
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Likewise
,
AST
Research
Inc.
and
Sun
Microsystems
Inc.
said
the
bugs
wo
n't
delay
their
development
of
486-based
machines
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
have
n't
modified
our
schedules
in
any
way
,
''
said
a
Sun
spokesman
.
<END>
<START>
To
switch
to
another
vendor
's
chips
,
``
would
definitely
not
be
an
option
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
,
Compaq
plunged
further
,
closing
at
$
100
a
share
,
off
$
8.625
a
share
,
on
volume
of
2,633,700
shares
.
<END>
<START>
Most
of
Compaq
's
decline
is
being
attributed
to
a
third-quarter
earnings
report
that
came
in
at
the
low
end
of
analysts
'
expectations
.
<END>
<START>
Intel
said
it
had
corrected
the
problems
and
would
start
producing
bugless
chips
next
week
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
should
not
be
seeing
any
more
,
''
said
Bill
Rash
,
Intel
's
director
for
the
486
chip
.
<END>
<START>
What
's
more
,
the
bugs
only
emerge
on
esoteric
applications
such
as
computer-aided
design
and
scientific
calculations
,
he
said
,
and
then
very
seldom
.
<END>
<START>
``
These
errata
do
not
affect
business
programs
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Sun
,
Hewlett-Packard
and
others
say
Intel
is
n't
wholly
to
blame
for
the
snafu
.
<END>
<START>
The
real
culprits
,
they
said
,
are
computer
makers
such
as
IBM
that
have
jumped
the
gun
to
unveil
486-based
products
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
reason
this
is
getting
so
much
visibility
is
that
some
started
shipping
and
announced
early
availability
,
''
said
Hewlett-Packard
's
Mr.
Archuleta
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
can
do
that
but
you
're
taking
a
risk
.
<END>
<START>
Those
companies
are
paying
the
price
for
taking
the
risk
.
''
<END>
<START>
In
late
September
,
IBM
began
shipping
a
plug-in
card
that
converts
its
PS/2
model
70-A21
from
a
80386
machine
to
an
80486
machine
.
<END>
<START>
An
IBM
spokeswoman
said
the
company
told
customers
Monday
about
the
bugs
and
temporarily
stopped
shipping
the
product
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
has
no
plans
to
recall
its
add-on
cards
,
the
spokeswoman
said
,
and
could
probably
circumvent
the
bugs
without
long
product
delays
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
do
n't
look
at
this
as
a
major
problem
for
us
,
''
she
said
.
<END>
<START>
Compaq
,
which
said
it
discovered
the
bugs
,
still
plans
to
announce
new
486
products
on
Nov.
6
.
<END>
<START>
Because
of
the
glitch
,
however
,
the
company
said
it
does
n't
know
when
its
machine
will
be
commercially
available
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
a
break
from
Compaq
tradition
,
because
the
company
does
n't
announce
products
until
they
're
actually
at
the
dealers
.
<END>
<START>
The
problem
is
being
ballyhooed
,
experts
say
,
because
the
486
is
Intel
's
future
flagship
.
<END>
<START>
``
Although
these
sorts
of
bugs
are
not
at
all
uncommon
,
the
486
is
an
extremely
high-profile
product
,
''
said
Mr.
Slater
,
the
newsletter
editor
.
<END>
<START>
Unveiled
last
April
,
the
chip
crams
1.2
million
transistors
on
a
sliver
of
silicon
,
more
than
four
times
as
many
as
on
Intel
's
earlier
model
,
80386
.
<END>
<START>
Intel
clocks
the
chip
's
speed
at
15
million
instructions
per
second
,
or
MIPs
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
four
times
as
fast
as
the
386
.
<END>
<START>
Machines
using
the
486
are
expected
to
challenge
higher-priced
work
stations
and
minicomputers
in
applications
such
as
so-called
servers
,
which
connect
groups
of
computers
together
,
and
in
computer-aided
design
.
<END>
<START>
But
while
the
chip
's
speed
in
processing
power
is
dazzling
,
it
's
real
strength
lies
in
its
software
inheritance
.
<END>
<START>
The
486
is
the
descendant
of
a
long
series
of
Intel
chips
that
began
dominating
the
market
ever
since
IBM
picked
the
16-bit
8088
chip
for
its
first
personal
computer
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
A
16-bit
microprocessor
processes
16
pieces
of
data
at
a
time
and
is
slower
than
newer
,
32-bit
chips
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Since
then
,
Intel
has
cornered
a
large
part
of
the
market
with
successive
generations
of
16-bit
and
32-bit
chips
,
all
of
which
can
run
software
written
for
previous
models
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
what
will
keep
computer
makers
coming
in
spite
of
the
irritation
of
bugs
.
<END>
<START>
Big
personal
computer
makers
and
many
makers
of
engineering
workstations
are
developing
486-based
machines
,
which
are
expected
to
reach
the
market
early
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
Of
the
big
computer
makers
,
only
Apple
Computer
Co.
bases
its
machines
on
Motorola
chips
instead
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
486
is
going
to
have
a
big
impact
on
the
industry
,
''
said
Hewlett-Packard
's
Mr.
Archuleta
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
going
to
be
the
leading
edge
technology
in
personal
computers
for
the
next
few
years
.
<END>
<START>
This
bug
is
not
going
to
have
any
affect
on
that
at
all
.
''
<END>
<START>
Andy
Zipser
in
Dallas
contributed
to
this
article
.
<END>
<START>
The
other
element
includes
consolidating
BethForge
's
press-forge
operations
.
<END>
<START>
The
entire
division
employs
about
850
workers
.
<END>
<START>
Wall
Street
analysts
have
criticized
Bethlehem
for
not
following
its
major
competitors
in
linking
with
a
foreign
company
to
share
costs
and
provide
technology
to
modernize
old
facilities
or
build
new
ones
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
think
it
's
a
step
in
the
right
direction
for
Bethlehem
,
''
said
Felix
Bello
,
WEFA
Group
's
international
steel
analyst
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
important
to
share
the
risk
and
even
more
so
when
the
market
has
already
peaked
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
said
the
move
could
be
the
beginning
of
a
broader
relationship
between
the
two
companies
,
one
that
could
open
up
new
markets
for
Bethlehem
.
<END>
<START>
Bethlehem
had
little
choice
but
to
go
with
a
European
steelmaker
,
because
its
competitors
already
have
tapped
the
Japanese
and
South
Korean
industry
leaders
,
analysts
noted
.
<END>
<START>
Under
terms
of
the
agreement
,
Usinor
's
Chavanne-Ketin
unit
and
Bethlehem
would
establish
a
modernized
facility
to
make
cast-iron
mill
rolls
at
the
company
's
cast-iron
shop
here
.
<END>
<START>
Terms
for
the
venture
,
which
would
be
jointly
owned
by
both
companies
,
were
n't
disclosed
.
<END>
<START>
The
Usinor
unit
has
agreed
to
provide
technology
and
expertise
to
install
a
so-called
spin
caster
by
early
next
fall
.
<END>
<START>
The
caster
improves
the
metallurgical
quality
of
the
iron
mill
rolls
,
which
are
basically
huge
rolling
pins
used
to
flatten
or
shape
steel
products
.
<END>
<START>
Bethlehem
is
also
working
with
the
United
Steelworkers
union
to
consolidate
BethForge
's
two
machine
shops
and
four

of
the

.
<END>
<START>
Once

is

,

plans
to

its
forgings

on
nuclear

,
hardened
steel
and

for
rolling

and

.
<END>
<START>
Bethlehem
said
earlier
this
year
that

planned
to

BethForge
division
to

.
<END>
<START>

,

posted

50

to

.
<END>
<START>
If

.

?
<END>
<START>

.

<START>
Now
,

''

.

:

.

<START>
Healthy

.

,

.

<START>
Exxon
Corp.
said
it
will
move
its
headquarters
from
Manhattan
to
Dallas
.
<END>
<START>
The
shift
wo
n't
affect

.
<END>
<START>
As

of
its

several
years
ago
,
Exxon
moved
most
of
those
out
of
the
city
and
sold
its
53-floor

skyscraper
to
a
Japanese
company
.
<END>
<START>
But

is
an

to

,
coming
at

of

and

by

.
<END>
<START>
Mobil
Corp.
is

here
,
and
huge
operations
like
J.C.
Penney

have

.

,

.

.

<START>

,

,

.

<START>

.

<START>

.

,

,

,

.

.

<START>

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
Canadian
production
of
market
pulp
rose
1
%
in
September
from
a
year
earlier
as
the
industry
operated
at
87
%
of
capacity
.
<END>
<START>
The
Canadian
Pulp
and
Paper
Association
,
an
industry
group
,
said
Canadian
mills
produced
532,000
metric
tons
of
market
pulp
in
September
,
compared
with
527,000
metric
tons
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Market
pulp
is
wood
pulp
sold
on
the
open
market
to
producers
of
paper
and
other
products
.
<END>
<START>
The
statistics
exclude
pulp
consumed
at
the
producing
mill
or
shipped
to
another
mill
that
is
affiliated
with
the
producing
mill
.
<END>
<START>
Canada
is
the
world
's
largest
producer
of
market
pulp
.
<END>
<START>
The
September
87
%
operating
rate
compared
with
a
rate
of
101
%
in
August
but
was
unchanged
from
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
first
nine
months
of
this
year
output
was
5,377,000
metric
tons
,
down
from
5,441,000
metric
tons
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
The
price
also
includes
assumption
of
about
$
1.4
billion
in
debt
.
<END>
<START>
IMA
is
a
group
that
includes
First
Boston
Corp.
and
the
Pritzker
family
of
Chicago
through
the
leveraged
buy-out
fund
Harry
Gray
Melvyn
Klein
&
Partners
.
<END>
<START>
Harry
J.
Gray
and
Melvyn
N.
Klein
,
along
with
five
other
IMA
designees
,
were
named
to
join
American
Medical
's
10-member
board
.
<END>
<START>
The
completion
of
the
merger
agreement
follows
months
of
twists
and
turns
.
<END>
<START>
In
January
,
American
Medical
brought
in
a
new
chief
executive
officer
,
Richard
A.
Gilleland
,
45
,
who
will
remain
as
chairman
,
president
and
chief
executive
.
<END>
<START>
A
few
days
later
,
American
Medical
announced
sharply
lower
earnings
,
taking
charges
of
$
24
million
for
insurance
reserves
and
canceled
real
estate
leases
.
<END>
<START>
In
March
,
American
Medical
received
a
$
24-a-share
offer
to
take
the
company
private
from
an
investor
group
including
large
holder
M.
Lee
Pearce
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
was
considering
a
restructuring
to
help
boost
the
stock
price
.
<END>
<START>
A
group
including
several
members
of
the
the
Bass
family
of
Texas
urged
the
company
to
take
some
steps
to
maximize
shareholder
value
.
<END>
<START>
The
following
month
,
the
company
put
itself
up
for
sale
.
<END>
<START>
It
received
more
offers
,
but
the
auction
was
surprisingly
won
by
IMA
,
which
bid
$
28
a
share
and
asked
Mr.
Gilleland
to
stay
on
as
an
equity
participant
.
<END>
<START>
He
indicated
that
some
assets
might
be
sold
off
to
service
the
debt
.
<END>
<START>
American
Medical
accepted
the
offer
,
meanwhile
indicating
it
had
heard
from
two
other
suitors
.
<END>
<START>
But
they
never
materialized
and
IMA
completed
the
purchase
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
Other
new
board
members
include
John
S.
Harrison
and
Mark
A.
Adley
of
First
Boston
,
James
F.
Lyons
,
William
S.
Goldberg
and
Harold
S.
Handelsman
.
<END>
<START>
Treasury
Secretary
Nicholas
Brady
said
that
Congress
should
grant
the
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
the
power
to
close
the
stock
markets
in
periods
of
crisis
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Breeden
contended
that
discretionary
power
could
have
an
impact
on
the
markets
if
rumors
were
to
circulate
about
when
the
exchanges
might
be
closed
.
<END>
<START>
He
added
that
the
president
already
has
the
power
to
close
the
markets
in
an
emergency
.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Brady
argued
that
the
SEC
is
closer
to
the
markets
and
in
a
better
position
to
understand
when
the
exchanges
are
under
such
stress
that
they
should
be
closed
.
<END>
<START>
Separately
,
Mr.
Brady
said
he
asked
the
Working
Group
on
Financial
Markets
to
determine
whether
futures
margins
are
too
low
.
<END>
<START>
He
noted
that
some
minimum
margin
requirements
have
been
reduced
to
levels
below
those
before
the
1987
crash
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
raises
questions
whether
futures
and
equity
margin
requirements
are
consistent
at
these
levels
and
whether
futures
margins
are
adequate
,
''
Mr.
Brady
said
.
<END>
<START>
Margins
are
the
amount
of
money
an
investor
needs
to
put
up
to
buy
or
sell
a
futures
contract
.
<END>
<START>
Margins
on
the
futures
exchanges
typically
are
raised
and
lowered
according
to
market
volatility
.
<END>
<START>
Margins
were
raised
or
lowered
about
a
dozen
times
since
the
crash
Oct.
19
,
1987
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Brady
also
said
he
expects
the
leveraged
buy-out
phenomenon
to
``
end
under
-LRB-
its
-RRB-
own
weight
.
''
<END>
<START>
Before
taking
any
action
,
he
advised
the
panel
to
``
see
what
the
market
has
produced
as
a
cure
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Brady
also
agreed
with
senators
'
concerns
about
recent
stock-market
volatility
,
and
said
he
realizes
that
the
gyrations
are
scaring
investors
from
investing
in
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
added
that
individuals
still
are
participating
in
the
equity
market
indirectly
through
mutual
funds
and
pension
funds
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
do
not
have
a
view
of
whether
we
should
do
anything
about
program
trading
at
this
time
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Brady
endorsed
the
market-revision
bill
that
both
houses
of
Congress
will
try
to
push
through
this
session
.
<END>
<START>
The
bill
also
would
give
the
SEC
the
power
to
close
the
markets
,
a
discretion
that
former
SEC
Chairman
David
Ruder
wanted
but
Mr.
Breeden
does
n't
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Brady
and
senators
agreed
to
have
their
staffs
meet
within
the
next
week
to
start
fine-tuning
the
bill
.
<END>
<START>
The
Senate
Agriculture
Committee
is
responding
to
trading
abuses
in
the
futures
markets
with
a
far-reaching
bill
that
would
become
the
Futures
Trading
Practices
Act
of
1989
.
<END>
<START>
The
proposed
legislation
has
a
laudable
goal
:
to
assure
the
integrity
of
the
U.S.
futures
markets
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
as
is
common
with
sweeping
legislation
,
the
proposal
contains
many
provisions
that
could
destroy
important
parts
of
the
system
it
sets
out
to
preserve
.
<END>
<START>
The
bill
also
elevates
even
minor
rule
infractions
to
felonies
and
provides
for
recovery
of
punitive
damages
in
civil
lawsuits
and
arbitration
cases
without
any
showing
of
willful
misconduct
.
<END>
<START>
Many
aspects
of
the
bill
are
salutary
,
providing
appropriate
public
safeguards
that
can
and
should
be
instituted
throughout
the
industry
.
<END>
<START>
One
of
the
most
prominent
features
is
the
requirement
that
in
three
years
all
exchanges
have
in
place
a
system
that
records
all
trades
by
a
source
independent
of
the
executing
broker
.
<END>
<START>
The
New
York
futures
exchanges
have
been
working
together
to
develop
a
trade
recording
system
much
like
the
one
called
for
in
the
bill
.
<END>
<START>
We
would
be
delighted
to
have
such
a
system
in
place
today
.
<END>
<START>
But
is
it
realistic
for
Congress
to
mandate
by
a
rigid
deadline
a
system
that
has
not
yet
been
subjected
to
feasibility
studies
?
<END>
<START>
What
if
the
system
does
n't
work
?
<END>
<START>
What
if
the
only
system
that
does
work
is
so
expensive
that
,
at
best
,
only
the
largest
exchanges
can
afford
it
?
<END>
<START>
Cost
is
a
key
consideration
because
of
the
global
sweep
of
the
financial
markets
.
<END>
<START>
The
U.S.
futures
exchanges
compete
world-wide
as
never
before
.
<END>
<START>
Today
,
trading
in
almost
any
commodity
can
be
diverted
from
U.S.
markets
with
just
a
few
strokes
of
a
keyboard
.
<END>
<START>
All
foreign
markets
are
aggressively
courting
U.S.
business
.
<END>
<START>
In
fact
,
several
London
markets
already
offer
lower
costs
for
trading
in
the
same
or
very
similar
contracts
.
<END>
<START>
The
U.S.
exchanges
need
both
market
integrity
and
cost-efficiency
;
long-term
growth
depends
on
it
.
<END>
<START>
The
Senate
bill
contains
many
provisions
that
will
increase
the
costs
of
trading
.
<END>
<START>
The
most
arbitrary
of
these
is
the
imposition
of
``
service
fees
,
''
which
will
directly
widen
the
cost
spread
between
U.S.
and
foreign
markets
.
<END>
<START>
Other
provisions
have
a
more
subtle
,
but
nonetheless
real
and
detrimental
effect
on
the
international
position
of
U.S.
exchanges
.
<END>
<START>
These
include
the
extension
of
liability
into
areas
beyond
those
established
by
judicial
precedent
and
the
expansion
of
liability
to
include
punitive
damages
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
to
increasing
costs
as
a
result
of
greater
financial
exposure
for
members
,
these
measures
could
have
other
,
far-reaching
repercussions
.
<END>
<START>
One
section
of
the
bill
would
make
all
commodity
brokerage
firms
and
floor
brokers
liable
for
damages
without
willful
misconduct
.
<END>
<START>
Nowhere
in
the
federal
securities
law
is
simple
negligence
or
inadvertent
action
a
source
of
liability
under
similar
circumstances
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
only
logical
to
assume
that
the
enactment
of
this
provision
will
lead
to
increased
litigation
.
<END>
<START>
Another
measure
makes
commodity
brokerage
firms
liable
for
violations
committed
by
independent
floor
brokers
who
execute
trades
for
them
.
<END>
<START>
This
untried
concept
would
expose
these
firms
to
potentially
astronomical
punitive
damages
.
<END>
<START>
This
would
force
out
of
business
many
of
the
individuals
and
small
firms
that
function
as
floor
brokers
.
<END>
<START>
A
consequence
of
their
departure
could
be
a
serious
diminution
of
market
liquidity
.
<END>
<START>
In
other
words
,
regulation
will
occur
through
inaction
and
happenstance
,
rather
than
through
a
normal
deliberative
procedure
.
<END>
<START>
Also
precluded
would
be
dual
trading
,
whereby
a
broker
trades
for
customers
as
well
as
his
own
account
,
a
practice
that
provides
needed
liquidity
to
the
markets
.
<END>
<START>
All
U.S.
futures
exchanges
agree
that
these
and
other
trading
practices
require
proper
regulation
and
supervision
.
<END>
<START>
The
markets
are
complex
,
as
is
the
environment
in
which
they
function
.
<END>
<START>
When
problems
surface
,
the
temptation
becomes
strong
to
summarily
overhaul
a
market
system
that
has
served
for
more
than
100
years
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Nastro
is
chairman
of
the
Coffee
,
Sugar
&
Cocoa
Exchange
in
New
York
and
director
of
commodity
administration
at
Shearson
Lehman
Hutton
.
<END>
<START>
Initial
claims
for
state
unemployment
benefits
fell
to
a
seasonally
adjusted
332,000
for
the
week
ended
Oct.
14
from
396,000
the
previous
week
,
the
Labor
Department
said
.
<END>
<START>
Counting
all
state
and
federal
benefit
programs
,
the
number
of
people
receiving
unemployment
benefits
in
the
week
ended
Oct.
7
fell
to
1,784,400
from
1,810,700
a
week
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
These
figures
are
n't
seasonally
adjusted
.
<END>
<START>
On
the
hungry
streets
of
Naguib
Mahfouz
's
Cairo
,
life
is
nasty
,
brutish
and
wickedly
entertaining
.
<END>
<START>
Zaita
the
``
cripple-maker
''
rearranges
the
limbs
of
aspiring
beggars
--
and
takes
a
cut
of
every
cent
they
cadge
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
killer
and
thief
,
Said
Mahran
,
fame
flows
from
the
barrel
of
a
gun
.
<END>
<START>
``
One
man
said
you
act
as
a
stimulant
,
''
a
prostitute
tells
him
,
``
a
diversion
to
relieve
people
's
boredom
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Mahfouz
's
Cairo
also
has
Sufi
sheiks
and
saintly
wives
who
look
to
God
,
not
crime
,
for
their
salvation
.
<END>
<START>
But
they
do
show
the
range
of
a
restless
intellect
whose
30-odd
novels
span
five
decades
and
include
work
of
social
realism
,
protest
and
allegory
.
<END>
<START>
``
Soon
it
'll
be
so
crowded
,
''
a
narrator
complains
,
``
that
people
will
start
eating
each
other
.
''
<END>
<START>
Published
in
1949
,
it
follows
the
decline
of
a
Cairo
family
with
the
saga-like
sweep
and
rich
detail
that
critics
often
compare
to
Dickens
,
Balzac
and
Galsworthy
.
<END>
<START>
A
minor
bureaucrat
dies
suddenly
,
dooming
his
family
to
poverty
and
eventual
disgrace
.
<END>
<START>
His
daughter
turns
to
dressmaking
,
then
to
peddling
herself
for
a
few
piasters
.
<END>
<START>
One
son
sacrifices
his
own
career
so
that
his
avaricious
brother
can
succeed
,
while
another
helps
support
the
family
with
money
siphoned
from
crime
.
<END>
<START>
The
real
tragedy
,
though
,
lies
not
in
the
family
's
circumstances
but
in
its
concern
for
appearances
.
<END>
<START>
Mourning
for
the
father
is
overshadowed
by
the
shame
of
burying
him
in
a
pauper
's
grave
.
<END>
<START>
The
family
moves
to
another
house
at
night
to
conceal
shabby
belongings
from
neighbors
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
successful
son
wishes
his
embarrassing
siblings
dead
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
critique
of
middle-class
mores
,
the
story
is
heavy-handed
.
<END>
<START>
But
its
unsentimental
sketches
of
Cairo
life
are
vintage
Mahfouz
.
<END>
<START>
And
we
meet
engaging
crooks
,
such
as
Hassan
``
the
Head
,
''
famed
for
his
head-butting
fights
,
his
whoring
and
his
hashish
.
<END>
<START>
``
`
God
has
not
yet
ordained
that
I
should
have
earnings
,
'
he
tells
his
worried
mother
.
''
<END>
<START>
Hassan
comes
to
a
bad
end
,
but
so
does
almost
everyone
else
in
the
book
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
setting
is
exotic
,
the
prose
is
closer
to
Balzac
's
``
Pere
Goriot
''
than
it
is
to
``
Arabian
Nights
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Mahfouz
began
writing
when
there
was
no
novelistic
tradition
in
Arabic
,
and
he
modeled
his
work
on
Western
classics
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
Thief
and
the
Dogs
,
''
written
in
1961
,
is
a
taut
,
psychological
drama
,
reminiscent
of
``
Crime
and
Punishment
.
''
<END>
<START>
Its
antihero
,
Said
Mahran
,
is
an
Egyptian
Raskolnikov
who
seeks
nobility
in
robbing
and
killing
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
am
the
hope
and
the
dream
,
the
redemption
of
cowards
,
''
he
says
in
one
of
many
interior
monologues
.
<END>
<START>
Later
,
he
recalls
the
words
of
his
Marxist
mentor
:
``
The
people
!
Theft
!
The
holy
fire
!
''
<END>
<START>
Said
's
story
reflects
the
souring
of
socialism
under
Nasser
,
whose
dictatorial
rule
replaced
the
monarchy
overthrown
in
1952
.
<END>
<START>
By
1961
,
Mr.
Mahfouz
's
idealism
had
vanished
or
become
twisted
,
as
it
has
in
Said
.
<END>
<START>
Cairo
's
spirited
squalor
also
has
gone
gray
.
<END>
<START>
Here
,
the
city
is
dark
and
laden
with
symbolism
:
Said
has
left
his
jail
cell
only
to
enter
the
larger
prison
of
Cairo
society
.
<END>
<START>
While
the
theme
is
compelling
,
the
plot
and
characters
are
not
.
<END>
<START>
We
never
care
about
Said
or
the
``
hypocrites
''
he
hunts
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
Thief
and
the
Dogs
''
is
a
pioneering
work
,
the
first
stream-of-consciousness
novel
in
Arabic
,
but
it
is
likely
to
disappoint
Western
readers
.
<END>
<START>
The
1981
novel
``
Wedding
Song
''
also
is
experimental
,
and
another
badly
aimed
bullet
.
<END>
<START>
The
story
of
a
playwright
's
stage
debut
unfolds
in
first-person
monologues
,
in
the
manner
of
Faulkner
's
``
The
Sound
and
the
Fury
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
the
device
obscures
more
than
it
illuminates
.
<END>
<START>
Buried
in
the
work
is
a
meditation
on
the
morality
of
art
,
and
on
the
struggle
for
integrity
in
an
unfair
world
.
<END>
<START>
But
again
,
the
themes
get
tangled
in
Mr.
Mahfouz
's
elliptical
storytelling
.
<END>
<START>
The
indirectness
of
his
later
work
reflects
both
an
appetite
for
new
genres
and
the
hazards
of
art
in
the
Arab
world
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Mahfouz
has
been
pilloried
and
censored
for
questioning
Islam
and
advocating
peace
with
Israel
.
<END>
<START>
Veiling
his
message
has
helped
him
endure
.
<END>
<START>
Art
,
says
the
playwright
in
``
Wedding
Song
,
''
is
``
the
surrogate
for
the
action
that
an
idealist
like
me
is
unable
to
take
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
clutter
of
the
1940s
remains
,
but
its
color
has
drained
away
,
and
the
will
to
overcome
has
been
defeated
.
<END>
<START>
Cars
ca
n't
move
because
of
overflowing
sewers
.
<END>
<START>
Characters
complain
ceaselessly
about
food
queues
,
prices
and
corruption
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
ubiquitous
opium
addict
is
now
a
cynical
and
selfish
man
who
gripes
:
``
Only
government
ministers
can
afford
it
these
days
!
''
<END>
<START>
Having
lost
their
faith
in
God
,
in
social
reform
and
in
opium
,
Cairenes
are
left
with
nothing
but
their
sense
of
humor
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Horwitz
is
a
Journal
staff
reporter
covering
the
Middle
East
.
<END>
<START>
Norwood
Partners
Limited
Partnership
of
Boston
said
it
may
make
a
tender
offer
for
some
or
all
of
Phoenix
Technologies
Ltd.
's
common
shares
.
<END>
<START>
Norwood
,
Mass.-based
Phoenix
,
a
once-high-flying
maker
of
software
for
personal
computers
,
has
had
substantial
losses
in
the
past
two
quarters
.
<END>
<START>
Its
stock
,
which
was
as
high
as
$
18.75
a
share
,
has
been
trading
under
$
4
a
share
recently
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
it
closed
at
$
4.375
a
share
,
up
$
1.125
,
in
national
over-the-counter
trading
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
filing
,
Norwood
said
it
's
part
of
a
group
that
holds
525,546
Phoenix
Technologies
common
shares
,
or
a
5.3
%
stake
.
<END>
<START>
Norwood
has
made
``
no
detailed
plans
,
''
but
it
has
engaged
in
talks
with
other
shareholders
,
the
filing
said
.
<END>
<START>
Phoenix
declined
to
comment
.
<END>
<START>
Norwood
is
controlled
by
Daniel
L.
Barnett
and
Paul
A.
Reese
,
both
officers
of
Boston-based
Oasis
Capital
Management
Inc.
,
a
small
Boston
money
management
firm
.
<END>
<START>
Also
involved
in
the
group
is
Robert
F.
Angelo
,
formerly
Phoenix
's
senior
vice
president
,
field
operations
,
who
left
Phoenix
at
the
beginning
of
October
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Angelo
was
described
in
the
filing
as
a
consultant
to
Oasis
.
<END>
<START>
Weirton
Steel
Corp.
said
it
reached
a
tentative
agreement
on
a
48-month
labor
contract
with
the
Independent
Steelworkers
Union
covering
production
and
maintenance
employees
.
<END>
<START>
The
agreement
,
subject
to
approval
of
union
members
,
would
cover
about
6,000
workers
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
provides
for
benefit
adjustments
,
including
a
partial
restoration
of
vacations
and
holidays
,
as
well
as
work-rule
changes
to
increase
productivity
.
<END>
<START>
Ground
zero
of
the
HUD
scandal
is
the
Secretary
's
``
discretionary
fund
,
''
a
honey
pot
used
to
fund
projects
that
were
n't
approved
through
normal
HUD
channels
.
<END>
<START>
Jack
Kemp
wants
to
abolish
it
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
,
Congress
's
idea
of
reform
is
to
increase
this
slush
fund
by
$
28.4
million
.
<END>
<START>
And
transfer
control
of
much
of
it
to
Capitol
Hill
.
<END>
<START>
The
HUD
scandals
will
simply
continue
,
but
under
new
mismanagement
.
<END>
<START>
HUD
has
no
paper
work
whatsoever
on
30
of
the
projects
,
none
of
the
others
has
been
approved
and
not
a
single
congressional
hearing
has
been
held
on
any
of
them
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
four
are
in
the
Michigan
district
of
Rep.
Bob
Traxler
,
the
chairman
of
the
House
subcommittee
that
writes
the
HUD
spending
bill
.
<END>
<START>
Unlike
those
awful
Republican
consultants
,
Members
do
n't
profit
directly
from
HUD
projects
.
<END>
<START>
They
merely
collect
campaign
contributions
from
developers
that
help
keep
them
in
office
.
<END>
<START>
Conference
committees
are
breeding
grounds
for
mischief
.
<END>
<START>
They
are
often
closed
to
the
public
and
no
minutes
are
taken
.
<END>
<START>
Members
find
it
easy
to
doctor
legislation
by
slipping
in
special
provisions
that
could
never
survive
in
the
cold
light
of
day
.
<END>
<START>
In
this
case
,
the
Members
outdid
themselves
.
<END>
<START>
Rep.
Traxler
recently
purchased
an
unimproved
building
lot
on
the
island
.
<END>
<START>
I
was
struck
a
couple
of
years
ago
by
the
drug-interdiction
effort
in
the
Bahamas
.
<END>
<START>
We
had
intercepted
during
the
year
an
estimated
$
5
billion
street
value
of
cocaine
.
<END>
<START>
I
do
n't
know
how
much
got
through
.
<END>
<START>
Nobody
has
any
credible
estimate
.
<END>
<START>
The
GNP
of
the
Bahamas
is
probably
somewhere
between
one
and
two
billion
dollars
.
<END>
<START>
So
you
get
an
idea
of
the
leverage
there
and
elsewhere
that
our
market
for
drugs
has
brought
about
.
<END>
<START>
I
welcome
the
emphasis
that
is
now
being
put
on
the
drug
problem
.
<END>
<START>
But
,
I
have
to
tell
you
that
it
seems
to
me
that
the
conceptual
base
of
the
current
program
is
flawed
and
the
program
is
not
likely
to
work
.
<END>
<START>
We
designed
a
comprehensive
program
,
and
we
worked
hard
on
it
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
Reagan
administration
we
designed
a
comprehensive
program
;
we
worked
very
hard
on
it
.
<END>
<START>
Our
international
efforts
were
far
greater
than
ever
before
.
<END>
<START>
You
're
looking
at
a
guy
whose
motorcade
was
attacked
in
Bolivia
by
the
drug
terrorists
,
so
I
'm
personally
a
veteran
of
this
war
.
<END>
<START>
What
we
have
before
us
now
is
essentially
the
same
program
but
with
more
resources
plowed
into
all
of
the
efforts
to
enforce
and
control
.
<END>
<START>
These
efforts
wind
up
creating
a
market
where
the
price
vastly
exceeds
the
cost
.
<END>
<START>
With
these
incentives
,
demand
creates
its
own
supply
and
a
criminal
network
along
with
it
.
<END>
<START>
It
seems
to
me
we
're
not
really
going
to
get
anywhere
until
we
can
take
the
criminality
out
of
the
drug
business
and
the
incentives
for
criminality
out
of
it
.
<END>
<START>
They
wo
n't
have
that
incentive
because
they
wo
n't
have
that
market
.
<END>
<START>
So
I
think
the
conceptual
base
needs
to
be
thought
out
in
a
different
way
.
<END>
<START>
If
I
am
catching
your
attention
,
then
read
a
bold
and
informative
article
in
this
September
's
issue
of
Science
by
Ethan
Nadelmann
on
this
subject
.
<END>
<START>
We
need
at
least
to
consider
and
examine
forms
of
controlled
legalization
of
drugs
.
<END>
<START>
I
find
it
very
difficult
to
say
that
.
<END>
<START>
Sometimes
at
a

or

I

for

.
<END>
<START>
They

.
<END>
<START>
I
know
that

into

here
as

as
what

're

now
.
<END>
<START>
No
politician
wants
to
say
what
I
just
said
,
not
for
a
minute
.
<END>
<START>
Personal
spending
,
buoyed
by
a
burst
of
automobile
buying
,
was
the
main
catalyst
to
the
economy
's
expansion
.
<END>
<START>
But
trade
,
one
of
the
economy
's
main
forces
in
the
past
few
years
,
showed
a
sharp
deterioration
.
<END>
<START>
Imports
of
goods
and
services
soared
,
while
exports
were
flat
.
<END>
<START>
Some
economists
found
the
mixture
ominous
.
<END>
<START>
``
For
the
past
two
years
,
the
foreign
trade
sector
has
been
a
major
contributor
to
economic
growth
.
<END>
<START>
You
ca
n't
rely
now
solely
on
consumer
spending
to
sustain
the
economy
on
a
solid
growth
path
,
''
said
Norman
Robertson
,
chief

at
Mellon
Bank
in
Pittsburgh
.
<END>
<START>
Many
economists
think
the
rise
in
the
value
of
the
U.S.
dollar
this
year
will
further
crimp
progress
in
trade
,
because
it
makes
exports
more
expensive
and
imports
cheaper
.
<END>
<START>
And
business
investment
--
which
slowed
in
the
third
quarter
,
according
to
yesterday
's
report
--
is
expected
to
continue
to
be
sluggish
.
<END>
<START>
Much
of
the
moderation
came
from
declining
energy
prices
,
which
have
since
turned
up
a
bit
,
analysts
said
.
<END>
<START>
Consequently
,
Michael
Darby
,

for

at
the
Commerce

,
said

probably
will
edge
up
from

third-quarter
rate
in
the

of
1989
.
<END>
<START>
But

believes

second
quarter
's
5
%

``
will
prove
to
have
been
this
year
's
peak

.
''
<END>
<START>
Generally
,
the
Bush
administration
expressed

with
the
economy
's
progress
as

heads
into

eighth
year
of

next

.
<END>
<START>
Treasury

Nicholas

called

2.5
%

``
good
,

,
''
although

said

expects

to

.
<END>
<START>

:
``

is
lower
than

to

,

.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Darby
called
it
a
``
disappointment
''
but
predicted

will
pick

.
<END>
<START>

in

,
''

,

.
<END>
<START>
Some

by

.
<END>
<START>

,

can

the
economy
because

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.
''

<START>

<START>
Iverson
Technology
Corp.
was
one
of
the
fastest-growing
small
companies
in
America
--
until
last
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
McLean
,
Va.
,
company
modifies
computers
to
keep
sensitive
military
data
out
of
unfriendly
hands
.
<END>
<START>
From
1984
to
1987
,
its
earnings
soared
six-fold
,
to
$
3.8
million
,
on
a
seven-fold
increase
in
revenue
,
to
$
44.1
million
.
<END>
<START>
But
in
1988
,
it
ran
into
a
buzz
saw
:
a
Defense
Department
spending
freeze
.
<END>
<START>
Iverson
's
earnings
plunged
70
%
to
$
1.2
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
troubles
continued
in
this
year
's
first
half
,
when
profit
plunged
81
%
to
$
302,000
.
<END>
<START>
Iverson
Technology
is
one
of
many
small
defense
contractors
besieged
by
the
slowdown
in
defense
spending
.
<END>
<START>
Companies
that
only
recently
were
thriving
find
themselves
scrambling
to
survive
.
<END>
<START>
As
their
varied
strategies
suggest
,
there
is
more
than
one
way
to
respond
to
a
disaster
--
though
it
's
too
soon
to
tell
whether
the
changes
will
pay
off
.
<END>
<START>
For
many
companies
,
the
instinctive
first
response
is
to
cut
costs
.
<END>
<START>
Others
are
trying
to
find
specialty
defense
work
spared
by
the
slowdown
or
new
niches
created
by
budget-cutting
.
<END>
<START>
More
venturesome
businesses
are
applying
their
skills
in
commercial
fields
.
<END>
<START>
ERC
International
Inc.
,
which
provides
professional
and
technical
services
to
the
military
,
is
refining
its
defense
niche
,
not
retreating
from
it
.
<END>
<START>
UNC
Inc.
,
an
Annapolis
,
Md.
,
contractor
that
earned
$
23.8
million
on
revenue
of
$
400.4
million
in
1988
,
has
gone
even
further
in
realigning
its
military
business
.
<END>
<START>
As
orders
for
its
aircraft
and
submarine
parts
dwindled
,
three
years
of
steady
growth
ended
with
a
69
%
drop
in
income
in
this
year
's
first
half
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
hit
on
a
new
strategy
:
If
the
Defense
Department
is
so
intent
on
saving
money
,
why
not
make
money
off
that
trend
?
<END>
<START>
Among
the
company
's
current
efforts
:
repairing
old
parts
at
25
%
of
the
cost
of
replacing
them
.
<END>
<START>
UNC
also
is
selling
new
parts
,
if
needed
,
directly
to
the
military
instead
of
through
a
prime
contractor
.
<END>
<START>
At
as
little
as
one-third
of
the
government
's
cost
,
the
company
is
running
a
program
to
train
Army
helicopter
pilots
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
also
taking
over
the
maintenance
of
certain
Navy
aircraft
with
40
%
fewer
people
than
the
military
used
.
<END>
<START>
In
another

,
tiny
Iverson
Technology
is

by

the

of

.

,

,

.

<START>

``

.

,

<END>
<START>
Many
of
these
financiers
lend
freely
,
often
without

.
<END>
<START>
But
the

they
charge
are
often
near
Japan
's
54.75
%
legal
limit
,

Kenji
Utsunomiya
,

.
<END>
<START>
Aichi
is
a
machikin
,
Mr.
Utsunomiya
says
,
and
``
one
of
the
nasty
ones
.
''
<END>
<START>
Last

,

Morishita
's

,
Aska

Ltd.
,

6.4
%

Christies
for
#
33
million
-LRB-
$
53.3

-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>

,

Aska
one
of
Christies
'

,

.
<END>
<START>
``
We

,
''

,

.
<END>
<START>
``
In

,

-LCB-

.
''

.
<END>
<START>
But

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Morishita
considers

of

.
<END>
<START>
In
30

and

,

600

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
He

300

.
<END>
<START>
A

,

23

's

in

,

.

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Morishita
's
main

,

wo
n't

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

15
%

49.3
billion
yen
-LRB-
$

million
-RRB-

.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
doubled
from
two
years
ago
.
<END>
<START>
That
is
,
if
the
company
reported
results
correctly
.
<END>
<START>
The
small
,
wiry
Mr.
Morishita
comes
across
as
an
outspoken
man
of
the
world
.
<END>
<START>
But
when
asked
what
exactly
he
does
in
business
,
he
immediately
takes
offense
.
<END>
<START>
``
Are
you
stupid
?
''
he
snaps
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
should
know
what
questions
to
ask
to
get

to
answer
.
''
<END>
<START>
Not
many
people
know
the
details
of
Mr.
Morishita
's
business
,
but
it
's
a
source
of
rumors
about
shady

.
<END>
<START>
When
a
small
company
goes
belly-up
,
for
instance
,
the
gossipy
weekly
magazines
are
often
quick
to
link

with
Aichi
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Morishita
scoffs
at
those

,
as
well
as
the
ones
connecting
him
to
the
Japanese
mob
.
<END>
<START>
He
says
he
has
never
even
dined
with
gangsters
.
<END>
<START>
The
seventh
child
of
a
store
owner
in
Aichi
prefecture
,
Mr.
Morishita
started
out
in
the
textile
business
.
<END>
<START>
From
there
,
he
set
up
his
finance
company
and
rapidly
expanded
from
lending
to
investment
in
real

to
building
golf
courses
.
<END>
<START>
He
spends
most
weekends
flying
his
helicopter
to
one
of
his
nine
courses
,
he
says
,
two
of
which
were
designed
by
Jack
Nicklaus
.
<END>
<START>
He
also
owns

in
the
U.S.
and

.
<END>
<START>
The
gruff

recently
started

in

.
<END>
<START>
Although

,

York

where

.
<END>
<START>
He

.
<END>
<START>

,

's

's

--
one

10

--

'
.
<END>
<START>
A

.
<END>

Never

.

.

<START>
Arthur
Price
resigned
as
president
and
chief
executive
officer
of
MTM
Enterprises
Inc.
,
a
Studio-City
,
Calif.
,
entertainment
concern
.
<END>
<START>
He
co-founded
the
company
with
Grant
Tinker
and
Mary
Tyler
Moore
in
1969
.
<END>
<START>
MTM
is
a
unit
of
British-based
TVS
Entertainment
PLC
,
whose
chief
executive
officer
,
James
Gatward
,
will
oversee
the
company
until
a
successor
is
named
.
<END>
<START>
As

,

reported

15.5

for
its
third

because

First

.
<END>
<START>

,

said
its

in
Texas
also
reported
a
loss
of
$
23.5
million
for

quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Private-sector
union
contracts
signed
in
the
third
quarter
granted
slightly
lower
wage
increases
than
those
signed
in
the
second
quarter
,
but
wage
increases
still
are
running
above
last
year
's
levels
.
<END>
<START>
The
Labor
Department
said
wage
settlements
in
the
third
quarter
called
for
average
annual
wage
increases
of
3.6
%
in
the
first
year
and
3.0
%
over
the
life
of
the
contracts
.
<END>
<START>
The
last
time
parties
to
these
settlements
negotiated
wage
increases
,
mostly
in
1986
or
1987
,
wages
increased
an
average
of
2.4
%
a
year
over
the
life
of
the
contracts
.
<END>
<START>
This
reflects
the
restoration
of
wage
cuts
in
the
steel
and
other
industries
as
well
as
higher
wages
granted
nurses
who
work
in
health-care
facilities
.
<END>
<START>
For
all
of
1988
,
union
contracts
provided
for
2.5
%
wage
increases
in
the
first
year
and
2.4
%
over
the
life
of
the
contracts
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
second
quarter
,
contracts
called
for
increases
of
3.9
%
in
the
first
year
and
3.4
%
over
the
life
of
the
contracts
.
<END>
<START>
The
figures
exclude
lump-sum
payments
and
cost-of-living
adjustments
,
so
the
actual
wage
increases
may
have
been
bigger
.
<END>
<START>
About
35
%
of
the
workers
covered
by
contracts
signed
in
the
first
nine
months
of
year
get
lump-sum
payments
;
about
15
%
are
covered
by
cost-of-living
clauses
.
<END>
<START>
Unions
covered
by
one
or
other
provisions
generally
settled
for
lower
percentage
wage
increases
.
<END>
<START>
The
Labor
Department
said
wage
increases
in
manufacturing
industries
continue
to
be
smaller
than
those
in
other
industries
.
<END>
<START>
An
enormous
turtle
has
succeeded
where
the
government
has
failed
:
He
has
made
speaking
Filipino
respectable
.
<END>
<START>
The
6
1/2-foot-tall
turtle
,
Pong
Pagong
,
is
a
character
who
stars
in
the
children
's
television
show
``
Batibot
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
speaks
only
in
Filipino
.
<END>
<START>
``
Batibot
,
''
which
started
in
1983
as
a
hybrid
of
the
U.S.
program
``
Sesame
Street
,
''
has
developed
into
a
distinctly
Philippine
effort
.
<END>
<START>
Radio
programs
and
books
have
followed
the
daily
television
show
.
<END>
<START>
``
When
we
started
the
program
six
years
ago
,
the
use
of
Filipino
was
deemed
unwise
by
the
predominantly
middle
class
,
''
says
Lydia
Brown
,
the
program
's
creator
.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
she
says
,
``
it
's
no
longer
an
issue
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
success
of
``
Batibot
''
stands
in
marked
contrast
to
many
academic
and
government
attempts
to
promote
Filipino
as
a
national
language
.
<END>
<START>
Filipino
--
once
known
as
Pilipino
--
is
predominantly
Tagalog
,
the
Malay-based
language
spoken
in
a
part
of
the
country
's
principal
island
of
Luzon
.
<END>
<START>
Resistance
to
a
national
language
comes
primarily
from
members
of
the
country
's
elite
,
who
generally
prefer
English
.
<END>
<START>
``
For
the
middle
and
upper-middle
class
-LCB-
Filipino
-RCB-
is
declasse
,
''
says
Bien
Lumbera
,
a
Philippine-studies
professor
at
Quezon
City
's
University
of
the
Philippines
.
<END>
<START>
There
's
also
resentment
.
<END>
<START>
Other
opponents
of
Filipino
come
from
non-Tagalog
regions
.
<END>
<START>
They
argue
that
their
own
languages
should
have
equal
weight
,
although
recent
surveys
indicate
that
the
majority
of
the
country
's
population
understands
Filipino
more
than
any
other
language
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
There
are
seven
major
languages
and
more
than
70
dialects
in
the
country
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
What
tongue
to
speak
is
an
emotional
mine
field
in
the
Philippines
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
entrenched
in
the
country
's
colonial
bonds
to
the
U.S.
,
in
Philippine
class
structure
,
in
the
regional
loyalties
of
its
people
and
in
its
island
geography
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
they
often
speak
one
language
at
home
,
another
at
school
.
<END>
<START>
Mrs.
Brown
calls
the
modern-day
cultural
ambivalence
to
Filipino
a
``
language
schizophrenia
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
issue
has
been
simmering
for
years
.
<END>
<START>
It
does
n't
take
much
to
provoke
an
intense
debate
.
<END>
<START>
But
many
proponents
of
Filipino
see
resistance
to
the
language
finally
crumbling
.
<END>
<START>
They
believe
the
media
,
including
``
Batibot
,
''
have
played
a
crucial
role
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
chief
scriptwriter
Rene
Villanueva
,
``
Batibot
''
does
n't
set
out
to
advance
the
cause
of
Filipino
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
not
as
if
we
're
teaching
language
per
se
,
''
he
says
,
``
We
're
just
using
it
.
''
<END>
<START>
These
days
,
``
Batibot
''
is
produced
in
a
converted
lumberyard
on
a
shoestring
budget
of
$
3,000
a
one-hour
segment
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
shown
weekdays
on
two
of
the
country
's
five
networks
.
<END>
<START>
With
an
audience
totaling
more
than
400,000
,
``
Batibot
''
consistently
ranks
in
the
country
's
top-four
most-watched
daytime
programs
.
<END>
<START>
But
advertising
revenue
is
inadequate
.
<END>
<START>
Periodically
,
there
are
threats
that
the
program
will
fold
.
<END>
<START>
``
Batibot
''
lacks
the
polish
of
``
Sesame
Street
.
''
<END>
<START>
Sound
stages
echo
.
<END>
<START>
Acting
sometimes
falls
flat
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
only
two
large
puppets
in
the
program
:
Pong
Pagong
and
a
monkey
named
Kiko
Matsing
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
production
is
the
equal
of
any
local
program
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
show
's
creativity
makes
up
for
any
technological
deficiencies
.
<END>
<START>
The
program
is
n't
afraid
to
tackle
controversial
topics
such
as
nuclear
weapons
and
the
environment
.
<END>
<START>
Not
that
the
language
war
is
won
,
even
on
``
Batibot
.
''
<END>
<START>
During
one
recent
episode
,
all
the
advertisements
were
in
English
.
<END>
<START>
CMS
ENERGY
Corp.
said

would
recommend
to
its
board
today
that
its
common
stock
dividend
be
reinstated
at
a
``
modest
level
''
later
this
year
.

<START>
The
Dearborn
,
Mich.
,
energy
company
stopped
paying
a
dividend
in
the
third
quarter
of
1984
because
of
troubles
at
its
Midland
nuclear
plant
.

<START>
HEALTHDYNE
Inc.
,
Atlanta
,
said
its
subsidiary
,
Home
Nutritional
Services
Inc.
,
registered
with
the
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
an
initial
public
offering
of
four
million
shares
of
common
.
<END>
<START>
The
in-home
health
care
services
provider
said
it
will
sell
1.8
million
of
the
new
shares
,
while
Home
Nutritional
Services
will
sell
the
remaining
2.2
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
estimates
the
offering
price
at
between
$
14
and
$
16
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
it
expects
to
use
the
proceeds
to
repay
certain
bank
debt
and
for
general
corporate
purposes
,
including
establishing
new
operating
centers
and
possible
acquisitions
.
<END>
<START>
Home
Nutritional
currently
has
10
million
shares
outstanding
.
<END>
<START>
It
will
have
11.8
million
shares
outstanding
after
the
offering
,
with
Healthdyne
owning
about
65
%
of
the
total
.
<END>
<START>
Black
&
Decker
Corp.
said
it
agreed
to
sell
its
Bostik
chemical
adhesives
unit
to
Orkem
S.A.
,
a
French
chemical
company
,
for
$
345
million
.
<END>
<START>
Bostik
is
the
first
Emhart
Corp.
unit
to
be
sold
as
part
of
the
power-tool
manufacturer
's
effort
to
reduce
debt
and
consolidate
operations
after
it
acquired
Emhart
earlier
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Black
&
Decker
said
it
plans
to
put
other
Emhart
units
on
the
block
in
the
future
,
with
the
goal
of
raising
$
1
billion
in
net
proceeds
.
<END>
<START>
Black
&
Decker
rescued
Emhart
from
the
takeover
bid
of
Topper
Limited
Partnership
last
March
by
agreeing
to
acquire
the
maker
of
door
locks
and
gardening
tools
for
about
$
2.8
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
move
significantly
expanded
Black
&
Decker
's
product
line
,
but
also
significantly
increased
its
debt
load
.
<END>
<START>
The
acquisition
boosted
Black
&
Decker
's
ratio
of
debt
to
total
capital
to
more
than
80
%
.
<END>
<START>
Company
officials
have
said
they
plan
to
reduce
that
ratio
to
less
than
50
%
over
the
next
2
1/2
years
.
<END>
<START>
Earlier
this
year
,
Black
&
Decker
put
three
Emhart
businesses
on
the
auction
block
:
the
information
and
electronics
segment
,
the
Dynapert
electrical

business
and
Mallory

.
<END>
<START>
The
three
units
had
combined
1988
sales
of
about
$
904
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
three
units
contributed
about
a
third
of
Emhart
's
total
sales
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
Black
&
Decker
had
said

would
sell
two
other
undisclosed
Emhart
operations
if

.
<END>
<START>
Bostic
is
one

units
,
and

first

five
to
be
sold
.
<END>
<START>
The

is
still

sales
of
the
other
four
units
and
expects
to
announce

by

.
<END>
<START>
The
five

generated

of
about
$
1.3
billion
in
1988
,
almost
half
of
Emhart
's
$
2.3

.
<END>
<START>
Bostic
posted
1988
sales
of
$
255
million
.
<END>
<START>
The

an

's

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>

<START>
Embedded
in
the
``
budget
''
being

by
the
House-Senate

is
something
that

,

like

.
<END>
<START>
It
's
a
nuisance
tax
on
mergers
.
<END>
<START>
Congress
has
decided
to
raise
$
40
million
by
charging
companies
$
20,000
for
the
honor
of
filing
the
required
papers
under
the
Hart-Scott-Rodino
law
.
<END>
<START>
Ever
since
the
bad
days
of
Big
is
Bad
antitrust
enforcement
,
this
law
has
required
that
anyone
proposing
a
merger
must
make
a
filing
describing
the
effects
on
all
relevant
markets
.
<END>
<START>
The
Hart-Scott
filing
is
then
reviewed
and
any
antitrust
concerns
usually
met
.
<END>
<START>
Typically
,
Hart-Scott
is
used
now
to
give
managers
of
target
firms
early
news
of
a
bid
and
a
chance
to
use
regulatory
review
as
a
delaying
tactic
.
<END>
<START>
The
$
20,000
tax
would
be
a
small
cost
in
a
multibillion-dollar
deal
,
but
a
serious
drag
on
thousands
of
small
,
friendly
deals
.
<END>
<START>
One
especially
dangerous
aspect
to
the
new
tax
would
be
that
the
proceeds
will
be
used
to
increase
the
budgets
of
the
antitrust
division
at
Justice
and
the
Federal
Trade
Commission
.
<END>
<START>
This
amounts
to
a

--
the
more
regulating
the
more

to
keep
.
<END>

.

<START>
Ford
,

long

,

.
<END>
<START>
Nearly

's

.
<END>
<START>

primarily

from

and

.

<START>

,

of
$
856.3
million
,
or

1.78

,

billion
.
<END>
<START>

,

$
3.52
billion
,

7.51
a

,

4.14
billion
,

8.53

.

The

loss
was

for

.
<END>

,

said

,

.
<END>
<START>
As

will

,

44

,

,

.

,

.

,

,

caused
a
``
moderate
''
loss
in
the
Highland
Park
,
Mich.
,
company
's
North
American
car
and
truck
business
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
the
loss
was
n't
``
that
much
different
''
from
Ford
's
$
37
million
loss
on
U.S.
automotive
operations
,
but
he
declined
to
be
specific
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
Chrysler
``
is
no
longer
sure
''
of
its
forecast
for
industry
car
and
truck
sales
of
14.2
million
in
the
1990
model
year
.
<END>
<START>
Consumers
,
he
said
,
are
balking
at
higher
prices
on
1990
cars
,
especially
after
seeing
the
incentive-reduced
prices
on
1989
models
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
rose
8.4
%
to
$
27.95
billion
from
$
25.78
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Heavy
losses
in
North
American
auto
operations
sent
GM
's
net
tumbling
to
$
516.9
million
from
a
record
$
859.2
million
.
<END>
<START>
Detroit-based
GM
does
n't
issue
separate
quarterly
earnings
for
the
North
American
automotive
business
.
<END>
<START>
But
analysts
estimated
that
GM
had
a
loss
of
as
much
as
$
300
million
on
domestic
vehicle
operations
.
<END>
<START>
But
GM
's
results
also
illustrate
the
increasing
diversity
of
its
operations
.
<END>
<START>
In
one
breakdown
,
GM
attributed
half
of
its
net
to
its
two
big
technology
units
,
Electronic
Data
Systems
Corp.
and
GM
Hughes
Electronics
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
GM
said
overseas
auto
operations
are
on
track
to
exceed
last
year
's
record
full-year
net
of
$
2.7
billion
.
<END>
<START>
This
cushion
could
come
in
handy
if
GM
has
to
trim
fourth-quarter
North
American
production
schedules
more
than
the
already
scheduled
9.5
%
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
circumstances
,
it
wo
n't
be
easy
for
GM
to
exceed
its
record
1988
fourth-quarter
net
of
$
1.4
billion
,
the
spokesman
acknowledged
.
<END>
<START>
It
earned
$
3.46
billion
on
revenue
of
$
91.21
billion
in
the
1988
nine
months
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
two
versions
of
``
Measure
for
Measure
''
on
stage
at
the
Alley
Theater
here
.
<END>
<START>
One
is
a
strong
,
vigorous
portrayal
of
Shakespeare
's
play
;
the
other
is
director
Gregory
Boyd
's
overlay
of
present-day
punk
rock
decadence
on
old
Vienna
.
<END>
<START>
Its
ambiguity
and
uneasy
mixture
of
the
serious
and
the
comic
is
no
doubt
one
reason
why
it
is
very
much
in
vogue
with
directors
just
now
.
<END>
<START>
When
Angelo
hears
that
the
young
man
Claudio
has
made
his
fiancee
pregnant
before
he
could
marry
her
,
Angelo
summarily
condemns
Claudio
to
death
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
Alley
production
,
scene
designer
Peter
David
Gould
has
arranged
a
stark
but
extremely
effective
set
featuring
a
rectangular
platform
of
white-washed
boards
that
extends
into
the
audience
.
<END>
<START>
When
the
action
requires
,
a
prison
cell
,
consisting
of
an
enlarged
wire
cage
,
rolls
forward
on
iron
wheels
on
the
platform
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
play
's
major
scenes
Mr.
Boyd
demonstrates
that
he
has
a
firm
grasp
of
the
Shakespearean
dynamic
.
<END>
<START>
At
such
moments
Mr.
Boyd
makes
it
clear
that
he
has
the
capacity
to
be
a
superior
interpreter
of
Shakespeare
.
<END>
<START>
When
,
however
,
he
decides
to
be
modern
,
or
more
accurately
,
when
he
decides
to
be
trendy
,
the
results
are
far
less
satisfactory
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Boyd
is
of
the
directorial
school
that
believes
one
must
find
modern
parallels
or
metaphors
to
make
Shakespeare
accessible
to
today
's
audiences
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
a
valid
approach
,
but
it
puts
a
heavy
burden
on
the
director
to
show
an
uncommon
degree
of
imagination
and
taste
.
<END>
<START>
Loud
rock
music
accompanies
all
the
scene
changes
,
even
those
in
the
convent
.
<END>
<START>
When
Claudio
is
arrested
,
he
is
brought
on
stage
nude
except
for
the
manacles
on
his
wrists
and
ankles
.
<END>
<START>
The
problem
here
is
not
in
the
concept
but
in
its
lack
of
discrimination
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
the
excesses
,
however
,
the
scorecard
for
the
production
has
many
more
pluses
than
minuses
.
<END>
<START>
What
's
more
,
it
represents
an
important
step
for
the
Alley
Theater
.
<END>
<START>
``
Measure
for
Measure
''
is
Mr.
Boyd
's
first
directorial
assignment
as
the
theater
's
new
artistic
director
.
<END>
<START>
He
succeeded
Pat
Brown
,
who
was
fired
by
the
Alley
board
18
months
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Her
dismissal
angered
many
in
the
regional
theater
establishment
and
led
Peter
Zeisler
,
head
of
Theatre
Communications
Group
,
to
write
an
editorial
in
American
Theatre
magazine
condemning
the
board
.
<END>
<START>
None
of
this
backlash
could
change
the
fact
that
Ms.
Brown
's
regime
was
remarkably
undistinguished
and
unimaginative
.
<END>
<START>
Now
the
Alley
has
moved
ahead
on
both
artistic
and
financial
fronts
.
<END>
<START>
Not
only
is
Mr.
Boyd
giving
the
theater
a
new
sense
of
adventure
and
excitement
on
stage
,
the
balance
sheet
is
the
best
the
theater
has
had
in
10
years
.
<END>
<START>
As
opposed
to
the
$
1.4
million
deficit
of
the
1987-88
season
,
the
1988-89
year
concluded
with
a
$
200,000
surplus
and
a
$
500,000
cash
reserve
.
<END>
<START>
Admittedly
last
season
's
runaway
hit
,
``
Steel
Magnolias
,
''
helped
a
lot
,
but
so
did
cost
cutting
and
other
measures
insisted
on
by
the
board
.
<END>
<START>
Only
time
will
tell
if
Mr.
Boyd
can
restore
to
the
Alley
the
acclaim
it
received
when
its
founder
,
Nina
Vance
,
was
at
the
height
of
her
powers
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
is
clear
he
is
going
to
give
it
a
shot
.
<END>
<START>
Democratic
leaders
have
bottled
up
President
Bush
's
capital-gains
tax
cut
in
the
Senate
and
may
be
able
to
prevent
a
vote
on
the
issue
indefinitely
.
<END>
<START>
And
neither
Democrats
nor
Republicans
are
predicting
that
the
capital-gains
forces
can
produce
enough
votes
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
60-vote
requirement
will
be
there
and
they
do
n't
have
the
60
votes
,
''
Sen.
Mitchell
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
do
n't
have
the
votes
to
get
it
passed
.
''
<END>
<START>
Sen.
Bob
Packwood
-LRB-
R.
,
Ore.
-RRB-
,
the
leading
Republican
proponent
of
the
tax
cut
,
did
n't
disagree
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
'm
not
sure
what
's
going
to
happen
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Previously
he
had
said
he
would
be
able
to
find
the
requisite
60
votes
eventually
.
<END>
<START>
Sen.
Packwood
has
offered
his
capital-gains-cut
package
as
an
amendment
to
a
bill
,
now
pending
in
the
Senate
,
that
would
authorize
aid
to
Poland
and
Hungary
.
<END>
<START>
Democrats
are
holding
up
a
vote
on
the
amendment
by
threatening
a
filibuster
,
or
extended
debate
.
<END>
<START>
For
a
cloture
vote
to
stop
the
filibuster
,
Republicans
must
muster
at
least
60
votes
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
,
Sen.
Packwood
acknowledged
,
``
We
do
n't
have
the
votes
for
cloture
today
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
Republicans
show
no
sign
of
relenting
.
<END>
<START>
GOP
leaders
continued
to
press
for
a
vote
on
the
amendment
to
the
Eastern
Europe
aid
measure
.
<END>
<START>
And
they
threatened
to
try
to
amend
any
other
revenue
bill
in
the
Senate
with
the
capital-gains
provision
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
serious
business
;
we
're
serious
about
a
capital-gains
reduction
,
''
said
Kansas
Sen.
Robert
Dole
,
the
Senate
's
Republican
leader
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
strategy
is
`
Let
's
vote
.
'
''
<END>
<START>
The
Republicans
contend
that
they
can
garner
a
majority
in
the
100-member
Senate
for
a
capital-gains
tax
cut
.
<END>
<START>
They
accuse
the
Democrats
of
unfairly
using
Senate
rules
to
erect
a
60-vote
hurdle
.
<END>
<START>
Democrats
counter
that
the
Republicans
have
often
used
the
same
rules
to
suit
their
own
ends
.
<END>
<START>
The
two
sides
also
traded
accusations
about
the
cost
of
the
Packwood
plan
.
<END>
<START>
Republicans
countered
that
long-range
revenue
estimates
were
unreliable
.
<END>
<START>
The
Packwood
proposal
would
reduce
the
tax
depending
on
how
long
an
asset
was
held
.
<END>
<START>
A
White
House
spokesman
said
President
Bush
is
``
generally
supportive
''
of
the
Packwood
plan
.
<END>
<START>
The
transaction
,
for
cash
and
stock
,
would
represent
the
biggest
European
takeover
since
1980
for
New
York-based
Marsh
&
McLennan
,
the
world
's
largest
insurance
broker
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
also
the
first
major
sign
of
the
long-awaited
consolidation
in
the
European
insurance
industry
as
the
European
Community
Commission
moves
toward
a
single
market
by
1992
.
<END>
<START>
Earlier
this
year
,
New
York
Life
Insurance
Co.
agreed
to
acquire
Windsor
Group
Ltd.
,
a
first
step
toward
establishing
a
presence
in
the
European
market
ahead
of
1992
.
<END>
<START>
But
most
U.S.
insurers
have
n't
rushed
to
change
the
way
they
do
business
in
Europe
because
they
believe
the
European
market
will
still
be
dominated
by
a

companies
.
<END>
<START>
Under

proposed

,
Marsh
&
McLennan
would
gain
a
majority
stake
in
Gradmann
&
Holler
that
would
increase
over
time
to
the
rest
of
the
remaining
85
%
.
<END>
<START>
Beatrice
E.
Garcia
in

contributed
to

article
.

.

.

.

<START>
Robert
H.
Knight
's
Oct.
5
editorial-page
article
bemoaning
violence
in
comedy
movies
-LRB-
``
Hollywood
,
You
Slay
Me
''
-RRB-
is
interesting
,
but
somewhat
off-base
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
fan
of
older
movies
from
the
1920s
on
,
I
do
not
find
modern
comedies
contain
violence
,
sex
and
foul
language
to
any
greater
degree
than
other
recent
movies
.
<END>
<START>
Older
movies
have
plenty
of
violence
,
though
it
is
portrayed
in
keeping
with
the
more
restrictive
social
conventions
of
the
time
.
<END>
<START>
Similarly
,
one
of
the
most
popular
comedy
genres
of
the
1930s
and
'40s
was
the
``
murder
mystery/comedy
.
''
<END>
<START>
Further
,
I
think
Mr.
Knight
made
a
poor
choice
in
picking
``
A
Fish
Called
Wanda
''
as
an
example
of
the
deplorable
state
of
modern
comedy
movies
.
<END>
<START>
There
is
no
slow-motion
close-up
,
blood-and-guts
portrayal
of
the
animal
's
demise
.
<END>
<START>
I
will
be
the
first
to
agree
that
there
is
much
to
be
found
wrong
with
modern
movie
making
.
<END>
<START>
Many
modern
scriptwriters
seem
to
be
incapable
of
writing
drama
,
or
anything
else
,
without
foul-mouthed
cursing
.
<END>
<START>
Sex
and
violence
are
routinely
included
even
when
they
are
irrelevant
to
the
script
,
and
high-tech
special
effects
are
continually
substituted
for
good
plot
and
character
development
.
<END>
<START>
In
short
,
we
have
a
movie
and
television
industry
that
is
either
incapable
or
petrified
of
making
a
movie
unless
it
carries
a
PG-13
or
R
rating
.
<END>
<START>
Hence
copious
amounts
of
gratuitous
sex
,
violence
and
gutter
language
are
included
as
a
crutch
.
<END>

Smith

has
annual

.

.

,

,

,

<START>

in

.
<END>
<START>
Seagram
closed

84.75
,

in
Big
Board

.
<END>
<START>
Leading

for
Du
Pont
in

was

segment
,
where

soared
to
$
155

from
$
99
million
a

.
<END>
<START>
The

from
continued

and

for

,
a

pigment
used

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

to
$
64

.
<END>
<START>

said

in

of

was

earlier

by

,

in

.
<END>
<START>

,

$

from

,

to

in

U.S.
for
most

.
<END>
<START>

posted
lower

for
the
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Profit
from
coal
fell
to
$
41

from
$
58
million
,
partly
because
of

'

.
<END>
<START>

amid

.

<START>
Sales
increased
10
%

.

<START>

.

<START>

,

,

.

<START>
Western
European
leaders
who
favor
speedy
economic
and
monetary
union
are
adding
a
new
argument
to
their
arsenal
:
the
dizzying
political
changes
under
way
in
Eastern
Europe
.
<END>
<START>
They
are
stressing
that
the
best
way
for
the
West
to
help
the
East
is
to
move
faster
towards
Western
European
economic
and
monetary
unity
.
<END>
<START>
This
would
make
the
market-oriented
system
more
attractive
to
Eastern
countries
,
they
argue
,
and
allow
greater
economic
aid
and
technological
know-how
to
flow
from
West
to
East
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Mitterrand
proposed
that
a
conference
be
convened
next
fall
to
write
a
new
treaty
for
the
EC
allowing
a
European
central
bank
,
and
that
the
treaty
be
ratified
by
1992
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Mitterrand
also
proposed
a
separate
``
Bank
for
Europe
''
that
would
channel
development
money
to
the
East
.
<END>
<START>
Says
a
European
strategist
:
``
The
U.S.
tends
to
look
at
Eastern
Europe
-LCB-
not
including
the
Soviet
Union
-RCB-
as
Europe
looks
at
Latin
America
:
important
but
far
away
.
<END>
<START>
But
for
us
in
Western
Europe
,
these
are
Europeans
next
door
.
''
<END>
<START>
A
reintegrated
Europe
implies
big
changes
in
40-year-old
military
and
economic
policies
.
<END>
<START>
The
designation
at
July
's
economic
summit
of
major
industrialized
nations
of
the
EC
Commission
as
coordinator
of
Western
aid
to
Poland
and
Hungary
was
a
first
step
.
<END>
<START>
In
part
,
this
division
is
dictated
by
economics
:
West
Germany
is
a
net
exporter
of
capital
while
the
U.S.
is
n't
.
<END>
<START>
While
American
aid
efforts
have
been
limited
by
budget
problems
,
yesterday
France
announced
a
three-year
,
four
billion
French
franc
-LRB-
$
650
million
-RRB-
aid
plan
for
Poland
.
<END>
<START>
But
British
analysts
are
beginning
to
link
the
issues
.
<END>
<START>
``
For
Poland
and
Hungary
we
need
to
think
about
a
stick-and-carrot
economic
approach
that
would
force
them
to
price
things
realistically
in
return
for
removing
all
our
tariff
barriers
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
notes
that
the
Marshall
Plan
of
U.S.
aid
to
Europe
``
did
n't
just
throw
money
at
post-war
Europe
,
it
also
liberalized
and
opened
up
those
markets
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
French
analysis
goes
further
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
they
have
n't
yet
drawn
the
operational
policy
conclusions
.
''
<END>
<START>
Managing
change
,
he
adds
,
will
require
a
lot
more
aid
and
a
prominent
role
for
the
EC
,
especially
in
dealing
with
the
question

German

.
<END>
<START>
Thierry

,

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.
''
<END>
<START>
``

there
's

deal

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
``
They

we
wo
n't

...
.
<END>
<START>
In

,

.

<START>
H.
Marshall
Schwarz
was
named
chairman
and
chief
executive
officer
of
U.S.
Trust
Corp.
,
a
private-banking
firm
with
assets
under
management
of
about
$
17
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Schwarz
,
52
years
old
,
will
succeed
Daniel
P.
Davison
Feb.
1
,
soon
after
Mr.
Davison
reaches
the
company
's
mandatory
retirement
age
of
65
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
U.S.
Trust
's
earnings
have
been
hurt
.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Schwarz
welcomes
the
competition
in
U.S.
Trust
's
flagship
businesses
,
calling
it
``
flattery
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Schwarz
says
the
competition
``
broadens
the
base
of
opportunity
for
us
.
''
<END>
<START>
Other
firms
``
are
dealing
with
the
masses
.
<END>
<START>
I
do
n't
believe
they
have
the
culture
''
to
adequately
service
high-net-worth
individuals
,
he
adds
.
<END>
<START>
U.S.
Trust
recently
introduced
certain
mutual-fund
products
,
which
allow
it
to
serve
customers
with
minimum
deposits
of
$
250,000
.
<END>
<START>
Previously
,
the
company
advertised
at
the
$
2
million
level
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
have
always
taken
smaller
accounts
,
but
now
we
are
looking
for
smaller
accounts
that
will
grow
,
''
Mr.
Schwarz
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
Our
bread
and
butter
is
still
the
$
2
million
to
$
20
million
account
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
services
allow
U.S.
Trust
to
cater
to
the
``
new
wealth
,
''
Mr.
Schwarz
says
.
<END>
<START>
Quarterly
net
income
this
year
has
risen
just
over
comparable
periods
in
1988
,
when
year-end
net
was
below
the
1987
level
.
<END>
<START>
Assets
as
of
Sept.
30
fell
to
$
2.46
billion
from
about
$
2.77
billion
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
will
have
a
reasonably
flat
year
this
year
,
''
Mr.
Schwarz
says
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Schwarz
also
said
costs
associated
with
U.S.
Trust
's
planned
move
to
midtown
Manhattan
from
Wall
Street
will
continue
to
be
a
drag
on
earnings

<START>

<START>
The
amount
of
blood
surgical
patients
can
donate
and
store
before
surgery
can
be
increased
by
the
new
genetically
engineered
drug
,
EPO
.
<END>
<START>
EPO
,
or
erythropoietin
,
is
a
protein
the
human
body
makes
to
stimulate
the
growth
of
red
blood
cells
.
<END>
<START>
A
genetically
engineered
version
of
the
human
protein
developed
by
Amgen
Corp.
of
Thousand
Oaks
,
Calif.
,
recently
has
been
marketed
by
the
Ortho
Pharmaceuticals
division
of
Johnson
&
Johnson
.
<END>
<START>
A
competing
version
of
EPO
is
being
developed
by
Genetics
Institute
Inc.
in
Cambridge
,
Mass
.
<END>
<START>
The
drug
is
being
used
primarily
to
treat
anemias
.
<END>
<START>
The
patients
began
receiving
EPO
injections
about
a
month
before
their
scheduled
surgery
.
<END>
<START>
They
then
began
donating
blood
twice
a
week
,
receiving
an
EPO
injection
each
time
.
<END>
<START>
If
tests
indicated
a
low
number
of
red
cells
,
blood
was
n't
taken
.
<END>
<START>
The
EPO-treated
patients
donated
an
average
of
5.4
units
of
blood
each
compared
with
only
4.1
units
donated
by
a
similar
group
of
surgical
patients
who
received
a
placebo
injection
.
<END>
<START>
The
volume
of
red
cells
donated
by
the
EPO-treated
patients
was
41
%
higher
per
donor
,
the
research
team
representing
a
number
of
hospitals
and
blood
banks
reported
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
During
its
centennial
year
,
The
Wall
Street
Journal
will
report
events
of
the
past
century
that
stand
as
milestones
of
American
business
history
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
TAX
SHELTERS
CALLED
Individual
Retirement
Accounts
,
or
``
IRAs
,
''
were
created
without
fanfare
on
Sept.
2
,
1974
,
but
grew
beyond
expectations
as
an
inducement
to
personal
saving
.
<END>
<START>
That
Labor
Day
,
in
his
first
major
act
after
succeeding
the
resigned
Richard
Nixon
as
president
,
Gerald
R.
Ford
signed
the
Employee
Retirement
Income
Security
Act
.
<END>
<START>
Pension
reform
was
its
main
thrust
.
<END>
<START>
Labor
and
business
leaders
,
quoted
at
the
White
House
Rose
Garden
rites
,
hailed
its
provisions
for
insuring
corporate
pension
benefits
.
<END>
<START>
IRAs
were
like
stepchildren
there
.
<END>
<START>
The
IRA
's
conception
is
murky
.
<END>
<START>
In
1972
,
then
Treasury
Secretary
George
Shultz
,
with
the
key
support
of
Sen.
Carl
Curtis
,
sought
some
form
of
pensions
for
the
uncovered
.
<END>
<START>
They
used
the
1962
Keogh
Plan
,
a
pension
plan
created
by
a
New
York
congressman
for
the
self-employed
,
as
a
partial
model
.
<END>
<START>
This
team
initially
called
its
new
model
Personal
Retirement
Account
,
or
``
PRA
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
it
did
n't
sing
.
<END>
<START>
So
they
opted
for
IRA
,
naming
it
after
Ira
Cohen
,
a
brilliant
IRS
actuary
who
helped
them
.
<END>
<START>
Ira
,
himself
,
confirms
this
account
.
<END>
<START>
IRA
rules
have
been
changed
over
the
years
.
<END>
<START>
This
caused
an
explosion
of
IRA
promotions
by
brokers
,
banks
,
mutual
funds
and
others
.
<END>
<START>
But
in
1986
Congress
sharply
reduced
the
number
of
people
who
could
qualify
for
its
benefits
and
IRA
tax-deductions
slowed
their
roaring
growth
.
<END>
<START>
IRA
account
assets
have
grown
to
about
$
400
billion
from
$
393
billion
last
year
and
just
$
26
billion
in
1981
.
<END>
<START>
The
measure
,
which
will
take
effect
next
Wednesday
,
will
create
a
two-tier
exchange
rate
.
<END>
<START>
Commercial
transactions
will
continue
to
be
based
on
the
official
rate
of
about
0.63
rubles
to
the
dollar
.
<END>
<START>
But
for
Soviet
citizens
who
travel
abroad
for
business
or
tourism
,
the
rate
will
jump
to
6.26
rubles
to
the
dollar
.
<END>
<START>
Tass
news
agency
said
the
devaluation
also
will
apply
to
foreigners
'
transactions
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
did
n't
elaborate
,
and
it
remains
unclear
how
far
Western
tourists
and
foreigners
living
in
Moscow
will
be
allowed
to
benefit
from
the
sweeping
rate
cut
.
<END>
<START>
The
current
ruble
rate
has
long
been
out
of
line
with
the
black
market
.
<END>
<START>
As
Soviet
leader
Mikhail
Gorbachev
has
opened
up
the
country
to
foreign
trade
,
the
discrepancy
has
become
ever
greater
.
<END>
<START>
Western
tourists
in
the
Soviet
Union
who
could
exchange
a
dollar
--
albeit
illegally
--
for
about
four
rubles
a
year
ago
are
now
being
offered
15
rubles
or
more
.
<END>
<START>
Even
at
such
rates
,
black
marketeers
have
been
able
to
make
big
profits
because
of
the
dire
shortage
of
consumer
goods
here
.
<END>
<START>
They
use
dollars
to
buy
Western
items
such
as
video
recorders
and
personal
computers
and
then
sell
them
at
a
huge
mark-up
.
<END>
<START>
The
going
rate
for
a
small
personal
computer
that
costs
about
$
2,000
in
the
West
is
anywhere
from
50,000
to
100,000
rubles
.
<END>
<START>
Even
a
pack
of
20
Western
cigarettes
can
fetch
20
rubles
or
more
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
absurdity
of
the
official
rate
should
seem
obvious
to
everyone
,
''
the
afternoon
newspaper
Izvestia
wrote
in
a
brief
commentary
on
the
devaluation
.
<END>
<START>
Rumors
of
an
impending
devaluation
have
been
circulating
in
Moscow
for
weeks
,
but
the
size
of
the
cut
took
many
Western
bankers
by
surprise
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
much
bigger
than
we
expected
,
''
said
one
German
banker
,
who
asked
not
to
be
named
.
<END>
<START>
Soviet
companies
needing
Western
currencies
to
buy
equipment
and
supplies
abroad
will
be
able
to
submit
bids
.
<END>
<START>
Plans
for
the
auction
,
which
was
supposed
to
take
place
last
spring
and
become
a
regular
event
,
have
been
thwarted
by
a
lack
of
hard
currency
.
<END>
<START>
Soviet
firms
that
hold
some
are
unwilling
to

with
it
,
and
joint
ventures
are
n't
yet

to

.
<END>
<START>
The

also
has
been
unwilling
to
provide
hard
currency
for
the
auction
,
using
a
lot
of
it
instead
to
finance

of

goods
.
<END>
<START>
But
the

they
exchange
may
be
limited
;
most
Soviet
hotels
,
for
example
,
demand
payment
in
hard
currency
from
Western
visitors
.
<END>
<START>
Unless
other

are
changed
,

devaluation
could
cause

for
the
people
it
is
primarily

to
help
:
Soviets
who
travel
abroad
.
<END>
<START>
Over

three

,

here
have
made

of

to

.
<END>
<START>
But

,

are
allowed
to
change
just
200

into
dollars
and
other

.
<END>
<START>
At

rate
,

would
give

about
$
30
to
travel
on
.
<END>
<START>
It
is

200-ruble

will
be

.
<END>
<START>
If

is

,
the
black

for
dollars
probably
will
continue
to
thrive
.
<END>
<START>
International

<START>

to
30.2
%
of
Cineplex
for
C$
17.50
a
share
from
Bronfman
associates
.
<END>
<START>
MCA
strongly
opposed
the
Drabinsky
group
's
move
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
being
done
at
the
suggestion
of
-LCB-
Mr.
Drabinsky
-RCB-
and
to
accommodate
him
,
to
facilitate
his
financing
arrangements
,
''
Ms.
Kolber
said
.
<END>
<START>
Cineplex
shareholders
responded
coolly
to
yesterday
's
announcement
.
<END>
<START>
In
trading
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
,
Cineplex
closed
at
$
11
,
down
25
cents
,
with
more
than
a
million
shares
changing
hands
.
<END>
<START>
On

Toronto
Stock
Exchange
,
Cineplex
closed
at
C$
12.875
,
off
37.5
Canadian
cents
,
well
below
the
C$
16.40

.
<END>
<START>
``
Where
's

?
''

,

and

with

.

n't

.

<START>
Two
West
German
chemical
companies
announced
steps
that
apparently
are
designed
to
boost
the
chemical
industry
's
standing
among
environmental
groups
and
the
general
public
.
<END>
<START>
Hoechst
AG
's
Chairman
Wolfgang
Hilger
said
the
company
wants
to
have
a
substitute
product
to
completely
replace
ozone-damaging
chlorofluorocarbons
by
1995
.
<END>
<START>
In
April
,
Hoechst
,
the
largest
producer
of
CFCs
in
West
Germany
,
said
it
wanted
to
reduce
production
of
the
product
by
50
%
by
1993
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Hilger
said
Hoechst
will
invest
50
million
marks
-LRB-
$
27.2
million
-RRB-
in
a
plant
to
make
a
substitute
product
it
has
developed
that
it
says
is
unchlorinated
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
hopes
the
new
plant
,
likely
to
be
built
in
Frankfurt
,
will
be
able
to
produce
10,000
tons
a
year
.
<END>
<START>
This
year
,
Hoechst
will
produce
about
62,000
tons
of
CFCs
in
factories
in
Frankfurt
,
Spain
and
Brazil
.
<END>
<START>
Of
Hoechst
's
40.9
billion
marks
in
group
sales
in
1988
,
200
million
marks
came
from
sales
of
CFCs
.
<END>
<START>
Also
,
BASF
AG
,
another
large
chemicals
company
,
said
it
formed
a
separate
division
that
will
study
the
environmental
impact
of
plastics
and
will
investigate
all
possibilities
of
recycling
plastics
.
<END>
<START>
George
L.

,
53

,

,

.

,

.
