<START>
Adolph
Coors
Co.
said
its
Coors
Brewing
Co.
unit
will
test
market
a
new
line
of
bottled
water
in
the
West
beginning
early
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
Coors
is
hoping
to
become
one
of
the
first
companies
to
distribute
bottled
water
nationwide
.
<END>
<START>
Coors
,
with
its
large
beer-distribution
network
,
could
penetrate
more
markets
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
the
water
will
be
called
Coors
Rocky
Mountain
Sparkling
Water
and
will
come
from
the
same
mountain
spring
as
water
used
in
Coors
beer
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
it
will
sell
the
water
plain
and
with
lemon-lime
and
cherry
flavors
and
will
package
it
in
28-ounce
bottles
and
6.5
ounce
bottles
as
part
of
six-packs
.
<END>
<START>
The
test
markets
,
though
not
specified
,
will
be
in
northern
California
,
Arizona
and
Colorado
,
some
of
the
hottest
bottled-water
markets
.
<END>
<START>
Some
of
America
's
biggest
trading
partners
gave
a
quick
thumbs-down
to
a
U.S.
proposal
to
liberalize
world
trade
and
reduce
farm-product
subsidies
.
<END>
<START>
The
U.S.
,
in
a
far-reaching
plan
submitted
to
the
Geneva
meeting
Tuesday
,
proposed
curbing
price
support
subsidies
within
10
years
and
eliminating
export
subsidies
within
five
years
.
<END>
<START>
U.S.
officials
said
the
plan
was
flexible
,
and
was
intended
as
a
pragmatic
approach
for
gradually
removing
trade-distorting
subsidies
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
EC
reacted
defiantly
,
arguing
that
the
proposal
's
main
aim
is
to
destroy
the
Common
Agricultural
Policy
,
the
EC
's
$
28
billion-a-year
price
support
program
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
American
proposal
is
not
an
adequate
basis
for
negotiation
,
''
the
EC
said
in
a
statement
.
<END>
<START>
EC
officials
say
they
are
irked
that
the
U.S.
has
set
a
specific
timetable
and
is
insisting
on
the
``
elimination
''
of
export
subsides
,
not
just
reduction
.
<END>
<START>
U.S.
Deputy
Trade
Representative
Jules
Katz
replied
that
the
proposal
was
entirely
consistent
with
the
April
accord
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
he
was
surprised
by
the
EC
's
reaction
,
calling
it
``
vehement
,
even
frenetic
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
U.S.
proposal
also
was
criticized
by
food-importing
developing
countries
,
who
said
that
the
U.S.
made
no
special
allowances
for
poor
nations
.
<END>
<START>
While
many
experts
argue
that
food-importing
nations
would
eventually
become
self-sufficient
in
a
free-market
system
,
the
poorest
nations
are
likely
to
need
help
in
the
meantime
.
<END>
<START>
Ambassador
Katz
said
the
U.S.
was
open
to
discussing
particular
problems
of
developing
countries
.
<END>
<START>
The
U.S.
administration
said
its
plan
would
allow
considerable
flexibility
in
determining
how
and
when
the
free-trade
goals
would
be
achieved
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
EC
is
strongly
opposed
to
converting
agricultural
supports
into
tariffs
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
U.S.
package
also
says
countries
could
temporarily
raise
tariffs
on
certain
products
if
they
experience
an
unusually
heavy
volume
of
imports
.
<END>
<START>
It
would
establish
procedures
to
prevent
countries
from
using
health
and
sanitation
rules
to
impede
trade
arbitrarily
.
<END>
<START>
The
EC
,
with
a
population
of
320
million
,
has
8.5
million
farmers
,
while
the
U.S.
,
with
a
population
of
about
245
million
,
has
only
two
million
farmers
.
<END>
<START>
Japan
's
objections
to
the
U.S.
plan
center
around
its
desire
to
stay
self-sufficient
in
rice
,
a
staple
food
,
even
though
foreign
producers
are
far
more
efficient
.
<END>
<START>
Bell
Atlantic
Corp.
said
it
agreed
definitively
to
acquire
one
of
Control
Data
Corp.
's
computer-maintenance
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
Terms
of
the
accord
were
n't
disclosed
.
<END>
<START>
Control
Data
's
third-party
maintenance
unit
services
products
primarily
made
by
Digital
Equipment
Corp.
and
International
Business
Machines
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
The
unit
has
6,000
customers
and
,
according
to
one
analyst
,
had
1988
revenue
of
about
$
85
million
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
agreement
,
which
had
been
widely
expected
,
Bell
Atlantic
would
be
buying
Control
Data
's
customer
base
and
its
approximately
100
U.S.
maintenance
facilities
in
about
33
cities
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
Control
Data
would
continue
to
provide
maintenance

for

of
its
Cyber
product
line
.
<END>
<START>
The

represents
a

Minneapolis-based
Control
Data
's
overall
computer-servicing
business
,
which
last
year
posted
sales
of
about
$
400
million
.
<END>
<START>
Earlier
this
year
,

company
sold
a
similar
unit
in
Europe
for
about
$
25
million
.
<END>
<START>
Lawrence

,
Control

's
president
and
chief

,
said
the
maintenance
business
no
longer
fits
into
the
company
's
``
strategy
to
be
a
data
solutions
company
.
''
<END>
<START>
Two
recent
decisions
by
federal
courts
cast
judges
in
the
odd
role
of
telling
authors
how
they
should
write
history
and
biography
.
<END>
<START>
These
decisions
deserve
more
attention
than
they
have
received
from
scholars
,
and
from
journalists
as
well
.
<END>
<START>
Russell
Miller
's
``
Bare-Faced
Messiah
:
The
True
Story
of
L.
Ron
Hubbard
''
is
a
biography
of
the
founder
of
the
Church
of
Scientology
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Hubbard
,
who
died
in
1986
,
bequeathed
the
copyrights
on
his
writings
to
his
church
,
which
licensed
them
to
New
Era
Publications
,
a
Danish
corporation
.
<END>
<START>
District
Court
Judge
Pierre
Leval
denied
the
injunction
on
the
ground
that
New
Era
had
failed
to
make
its
claim
within
a
reasonable
time
--
the
doctrine
lawyers
call
``
laches
.
''
<END>
<START>
As
for
the
merits
,
Judge
Leval
said
that
Mr.
Miller
had
written
``
a
serious
book
of
responsible
historical
criticism
.
''
<END>
<START>
``
The
biographer/critic
,
''
Judge
Leval
wrote
,
``
should
not
be
required
simply
to
express
...
conclusions
without
defending
them
by
example
.
<END>
<START>
''
In
such
circumstances
,
free-speech
interests
outweighed
the
interests
of
the
copyright
owner
.
<END>
<START>
But
Judge
Leval
felt
constrained
by
an
earlier
decision
of
the
Second
Circuit
Court
forbidding
a
biographer
of
J.D.
Salinger
to
quote
from
Mr.
Salinger
's
personal
letters
.
<END>
<START>
He
distinguished
the
two
cases
:
In
Salinger
,
Judge
Leval
noted
,
the
quotations
were
for
the
purpose
of
enlivening
the
biography
rather
than
of
proving
points
about
the
subject
.
<END>
<START>
Still
the
Salinger
decision
created
a
strong
presumption
against
fair
use
of
unpublished
materials
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
proper
remedy
,
Judge
Leval
said
,
lay
in
a
suit
for
damages
,
not
in
an
injunction
.
<END>
<START>
The
case
went
on
appeal
to
the
Second
Circuit
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
conclude
,
''
the
two
judges
wrote
,
``
that
laches
is
the
sole
bar
to
the
issuance
of
an
injunction
.
''
<END>
<START>
Had
the
suit
been
filed
in
time
,
they
said
,
``
Bare-Faced
Messiah
''
would
have
been
suppressed
.
<END>
<START>
This
was
too
much
for
James
Oakes
,
the
court
's
chief
judge
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
thought
that
Salinger
might
by
being
taken
in
another
factual
context
come
back
to
haunt
us
.
<END>
<START>
This
case
realizes
that
concern
.
''
<END>
<START>
And
the
injunction
Judges
Miner
and
Altimari
would
so
readily
have
granted
had
New
Era
sued
in
time
?
<END>
<START>
Suppression
of
the
book
,
Judge
Oakes
observed
,
would
operate
as
a
prior
restraint
and
thus
involve
the
First
Amendment
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
and
here
Judge
Oakes
went
to
the
heart
of
the
question
,
``
Responsible
biographers
and
historians
constantly
use
primary
sources
,
letters
,
diaries
,
and
memoranda
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
it
would
be
irresponsible
to
ignore
such
sources
of
information
.
''
<END>
<START>
Now
,
scholars
in
fulfilling
their
responsibility
do
not
claim
the
right
to
invade
every
collection
of
papers
that
bears
upon
their
topics
of
investigation
.
<END>
<START>
And
of
course
they
agree
that
people
can
impose
restrictions
on
the
use
of
their
papers
,
whether
in
their
own
possession
or
as
donated
or
sold
to
libraries
.
<END>
<START>
But
in
the
``
Bare-Faced
Messiah
''
case
the
author
found
most
of
his
material
in
court
records
or
via
the
Freedom
of
Information
Act
.
<END>
<START>
And
when
responsible
scholars
gain
legitimate
access
to
unpublished
materials
,
copyright
should
not
be
permitted
to
deny
them
use
of
quotations
that
help
to
establish
historical
points
.
<END>
<START>
Judges
Oakes
and
Leval
understand
the
requirements
of
historical
scholarship
.
<END>
<START>
Judges
Miner
and
Altimari
do
not
appear
to
have
a
clue
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
at
the
moment
they
are
the
judges
who
are
making
the
law
.
<END>
<START>
As
matters
stand
,
the
Salinger
ruling
,
torn
from
context
and
broadly
construed
,
is
controlling
.
<END>
<START>
If
an
author
quotes
``
more
than
minimal
amounts
''
of
unpublished
copyrighted
materials
,
as
the
Salinger
decision
had
it
,
``
he
deserves
to
be
enjoined
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
courts
have
not
defined
``
minimal
amounts
,
''
but
publishers
,
I
understand
,
take
it
to
mean
about
50
words
.
<END>
<START>
The
``
Bare-Faced
Messiah
''
decision
strikes
a
blow
against
the
whole
historical
enterprise
.
<END>
<START>
A
second
decision
,
handed
down
in
August
by
the
Court
of
Appeals
for
the
Ninth
Circuit
,
is
another
blow
against
scholarship
.
<END>
<START>
The
articles
were
largely
based
on
interviews
Ms.
Malcolm
had
taped
with
Jeffrey
Masson
,
a
psychoanalyst
who
had
served
as
projects
director
of
the
Freud
Archives
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Masson
then
brought
a
libel
suit
against
Ms.
Malcolm
,
the
New
Yorker
and
Knopf
.
<END>
<START>
For
all
historians
and
most
journalists
,
this
admission
would
have
been
sufficient
to
condemn
the
Malcolm
articles
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Malcolm
,
for
example
,
wrote
that
Mr.
Masson
described
himself
as
``
the
greatest
analyst
who
ever
lived
.
''
<END>
<START>
No
such
statement
appears
on
the
tapes
.
<END>
<START>
The
majority
cited
Mr.
Masson
's
remark
``
It
's
me
alone
...
against
the
rest
of
the
analytic
world
''
as
warrant
for
the
Malcolm
fabrication
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Malcolm
had
Mr.
Masson
describing
himself
as
``
an
intellectual
gigolo
.
''
<END>
<START>
Again
,
no
such
statement
appears
on
the
tapes
.
<END>
<START>
Judge
Kozinski
found
the
derivation
entirely
strained
and
writes
that
``
for
an
academic
to
refer
to
himself
as
an
intellectual
gigolo
is
...
a
devastating
admission
of
professional
dishonesty
.
''
<END>
<START>
As
Robert
Coles
wrote
in
a
review
of
Ms.
Malcolm
's
book
,
Mr.
Masson
emerges
``
as
a
grandiose
egotist
...
and
,
in
the
end
,
a
self-destructive
fool
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
is
not
Janet
Malcolm
who
calls
him
such
:
his
own
words
reveal
this
psychological
profile
.
''
<END>
<START>
We
now
know
that
the
words
were
not
always
his
own
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
is
one
sacred
rule
of
journalism
,
''
John
Hersey
has
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
writer
must
not
invent
.
''
<END>
<START>
As
Judge
Kozinski
put
it
:
``
To
invoke
the
right

...
.

<START>
Legal

<START>
Dr.
Morgan

'

,

.

.

.
''
<END>

.

<START>
Certainly

.
<END>
<START>

.

.

''

.

<END>
<START>

.

.

'

.

.

.

.

disconnect

New
York
Stock
Exchange
or
go
out
to
the
secretary
's
desk
.
''
<END>
<START>
It
wo
n't
happen
again
.
<END>
<START>
Now
there
are
more
lines
connected
to
the
chairman
's
office
,
and
the
market-monitoring
computer
has
been
moved
next
to
his
desk
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
all
part
of
a
new
``
command
center
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
changes
in
the
office
layout
illustrate
Mr.
Breeden
's
stance
as
the
nation
's
top
securities
regulator
.
<END>
<START>
Like
his
predecessor
,
David
Ruder
,
he
was
faced
with
a
crisis
in
the
stock
markets
soon
after
coming
into
office
.
<END>
<START>
A
veteran
of
another
financial
crisis
,
the
savings-and-loan
bailout
,
Mr.
Breeden
wants
to
have
the
SEC
regulate
securities
issued
by
banks
and
S&Ls
.
<END>
<START>
More
broadly
,
he
wants
to
``
modernize
''
regulation
by
eliminating
barriers
between
commercial
and
investment
banking
and
by
helping
U.S.
financial
firms
compete
in
the
global
market
.
<END>
<START>
Also
unlike
Mr.
Ruder
,
Mr.
Breeden
appears
to
be
in
a
position
to
get
somewhere
with
his
agenda
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
former
White
House
aide
who
worked
closely
with
Congress
,
he
is
savvy
in
the
ways
of
Washington
.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Breeden
,
a
39-year-old
securities
lawyer
,
has
skirted
some
of
the
heftier
issues
facing
the
financial
markets
.
<END>
<START>
For
instance
,
he
has
n't
stated
a
clear
position
on
high-risk
,
high-yield
junk
bonds
,
an
area
of
growing
concern
as
turmoil
in
the
junk
market
spills
over
into
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
He
may
be
waiting
to
see
the
results
of
several
pending
SEC
studies
of
junk
market
liquidity
and
disclosure
rules
.
<END>
<START>
He
also
has
kept
a
close
wrap
on
the
names
of

under
consideration
for
the
crucial
post
of
enforcement
director
at
the
commission
,
a
job

since
the
summer
.
<END>
<START>
Congress
seems
likely
to
let
the
new
chairman
have
his
way
for
a
while
.
<END>
<START>
Members
of
the
Senate
Banking
Committee
know
Mr.
Breeden
from
working
on
the
thrift-bailout
bill
,
and
the
relationship
generally
remains

.
<END>
<START>
These
days
,
Mr.
Breeden
is
winning

in

for
his
behind-the-scenes
role
in

the

's

.
<END>
<START>
As

charged

,

avoided

comments
and
worked
to
gather

to

and

.
<END>
<START>
Not

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
``

,
''

.
<END>
<START>

.

,

.

<START>
New
Technology
<END>
<START>
The
hottest
displays
were
items
that
insulate
passengers
from
bumps
,
potholes
and
other
rigors
of
the
road
.
<END>
<START>
These
``
active
suspension
systems
''
electronically
sense
road
conditions
and
adjust
a
car
's
ride
.
<END>
<START>
Existing
suspension
systems
try
to
absorb
bounces
,
but
active
suspension
provides
power
to
counter
the
jolts
.
<END>
<START>
Toyota
Motor
Corp.
grandly
touted
its
system
in
a
car
that
splits
in
half
to
reveal
the
suspension
's
inner
workings
.
<END>
<START>
Nissan
says
it
will
introduce
its
first
system
next
month
on
the
Infiniti
Q45
luxury
sedan
,
and
Toyota
's
Celica
coupe
will
go
on
sale
with
the
suspension
device
next
spring
.
<END>
<START>
But
drivers
in
the
U.S.
must
wait
:
The
Japanese
,
for
now
,
are
keeping
active
suspension
for
domestic
use
only
.
<END>
<START>
And
Detroit
's
Big
Three
auto
makers
say
their
systems
are
still
under
development
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
so-called
two-stroke
engines
,
which
are
expected
to
get
sharply
higher
gas
mileage
,
each
piston
goes
up
and
down
only
once
to
provide
power
.
<END>
<START>
By
contrast
,
the
pistons
in
conventional
four-stroke
engines
must
move
up
and
down
twice
in
each
power
cycle
.
<END>
<START>
Honda
Motor
Co.
shows
a
more
conventional
five-cylinder
engine
in
the
new
Accord
Inspire
model
,
which
made
its
debut
just
this
month
--
in
Japan
only
.
<END>
<START>
Honda
says
the
five-cylinder
engine
provides
a
compromise
between
the
fuel-economy
of
a
four-cylinder
,
and
the
power
of
a
V-6
.
<END>
<START>
It
is

be
bound
for
a
new
model
in
the
luxury
Acura
line
in
the
U.S.
,
but

would
n't

.

of

between
the
Fed
and
the
Treasury
over
exchange-rate
policy
.
<END>
<START>
``
What
seem
to
be
interpreted
as
great
conflicts
are
relatively
minor
issues
of
tactics
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
He
did
n't
elaborate
.
<END>
<START>
In
other
words
,
economic
growth
would
be
lower
and

would
be
higher
for
a
few
years
.
<END>
<START>
Rep.
Neal
's
bill
originally
called
on
the
Fed
to
reduce
the
inflation
rate
by
one
percentage
point
a
year
for
five
years
and
to

a
zero
inflation
rate
thereafter
.
<END>
<START>
He
altered
the
wording
to
win
Mr.
Greenspan
's

.
<END>
<START>
Even
so
,
his
bill
is

.
<END>
<START>
Reps.
Hamilton
and
Dorgan
also

bill
,

a

to
add
the
Treasury

to

12-member

that

.
<END>
<START>
Instead
,

.
<END>
<START>

,

would

's

,

.

.

<START>
He

Comerica
Inc.
in

.
<END>
<START>
The
White
House
has
decided
to
push
for
changes
in
pesticide
law
that
are
designed
to
speed
the
removal
of
harmful
chemicals
from
the
nation
's
food
supply
.
<END>
<START>
The
proposed
changes
,
which
are
scheduled
to
be
announced
today
,
would
apply
to
pesticides
and
other
substances
found
on
fresh
and
processed
foods
,
according
to
federal
officials
.
<END>
<START>
Environmental
groups
have
been
calling
for
faster
action
on
dangerous
pesticides
and
may
welcome
part
of
the
proposal
.
<END>
<START>
But
they
are
already
objecting
to
,
among
other
things
,
a
plan
to
give
more
weight
to
cost-benefit
considerations
in
evaluating
pesticides
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
a
tremendous
disappointment
,
''
said
Janet
Hathaway
,
an
attorney
with
the
Natural
Resources
Defense
Council
.
<END>
<START>
``
Allowing
the
EPA
to
condone
continued
use
of
a
chemical
whenever
the
benefits
outweigh
the
risks
is
absolutely
anathema
to
the
environmental
community
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
Bush
administration
plans
to
announce
a
series
of
principles
and
to
work
with
congressional
leaders
in
writing
specific
legislative
proposals
that
embody
them
.
<END>
<START>
The
principles
would
give
the
Environmental
Protection
Agency
increased
authority
and
flexibility
in
regulating
pesticides
,
with
the
aim
of
enabling
the
agency
to
move
more
quickly
.
<END>
<START>
There
already
are
proposals
pending
in
Congress
to
overhaul
pesticide
law
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
the
principles
attempt
to
eliminate
the
so-called
Delaney
Paradox
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
Delaney
clause
,
which
applies
to
processed
food
,
a
chemical
is
banned
if
it
causes
cancer
in
laboratory
animals
.
<END>
<START>
Under
other
laws
applying
to
pesticide
use
,
however
,
that
same
chemical
could
be
allowed
to
be
used
on
fresh
food
if
it
fell
within
the
EPA
's
tolerance
level
.
<END>
<START>
Among
other
changes
,
the
White
House
wants
to
:
<END>
<START>
--
Give
the
EPA
more
flexibility
to
declare
a
pesticide
an
imminent
hazard
and
pull
it
from
the
marketplace
.
<END>
<START>
--
Speed
up
the
process
for
removing
a
pesticide
that
is
n't
an
imminent
hazard
.
<END>
<START>
--
Bar
states
from
setting
more
stringent
tolerance
levels
for
a
pesticide
once
the
federal
government
has
set
a
standard
.
<END>
<START>
--
Give
the
EPA
added
discretion
to
set
``
negligible
risk
''
levels
for
pesticide
residues
in
processed
food
.
<END>
<START>
Chemicals
that
exceed
these
risk
levels
would
be
barred
,
but
those
that
fall
below
these
levels
would
be
allowed
.
<END>
<START>
--
Allow
the
EPA
to
permit
the
continued
use
of
pesticides
that
exceed
its
negligible
risk
standard
if
the
benefits
of
doing
so
outweigh
the
cost
.
<END>
<START>
Financial
markets
took
a
midweek
break
from
their
recent
wild
gyrations
with
stock
prices
falling
modestly
,
bond
prices
posting
tiny
gains
and
the
dollar
almost
unchanged
.
<END>
<START>
The
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
lost
5.94
points
to
2653.28
in
moderate
trading
.
<END>
<START>
The
dollar
was
barely
changed
against
the
West
German
mark
and
up
marginally
against
the
Japanese
yen
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
's

action
was
in
marked

to
the
rearing
and
plunging
of
stock
prices
Tuesday
after
the
proposed

of
UAL
Corp.
once
again

.
<END>
<START>
Traders
said

stock
market
's
lurching
moves
have
prompted
many

to
head
for
the
sidelines
until
it
regains
some

of

.
<END>
<START>
Although

were

as

,

nevertheless
said
action
also
was
much

market
.
<END>
<START>
Many

are
expecting
the
Fed
to
lower
interest
rates
at
least
once
more
before
the
end
of

year
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
now
are

today
's
release

of

gross
national
product
.
<END>
<START>
Economists
predict

report
will
show
economic
growth
of
about
2.5
%
in
the
third
quarter
,
which
would
have
little
effect
on
financial
markets
.
<END>
<START>
But
an
unexpected
deviation
either
way
could
roil

.
<END>
<START>
In

market

:
<END>
<START>

lower
in

.
<END>

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

,

.

<START>

<START>

Brooks

.

<START>

,

,

<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>

.

<START>
John
C.
Marous
,

,

company
expects

to

.

<START>

,

,

,

.

<START>

,
Westinghouse
has

70

that

did

10
%

.

.

,

,
''

.

<START>
GNP
is

's

of

.
<END>
<START>
A

,

.

.

annually
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Marous
said
Westinghouse
would
own
70
%
of
the
facility
.
<END>
<START>
The
deal
,
which
will
involve
an
initial
$
20
million
investment
,
was
struck
with
a
handshake
,
he
added
.
<END>
<START>
The
executives
did
n't
disclose
the
size
of
the
expected
gain
.
<END>
<START>
Capital
expenditure
in
1990
will
rise
slightly
,
Mr.
Marous
said
,
from
an
estimated
$
470
million
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
SHORT
INTEREST
in
International
Mobile
Machines
Corp.
fell
to
3,102,935
shares
in
the
month
ended
Oct.
13
from
3,420,936
in
September
.
<END>
<START>
Because
of
an
error
by
the
National
Association
of
Securities
Dealers
,
the
listing
appeared
incorrectly
in
the
main
table
and
several
highlight
tables
in
yesterday
's
edition
.
<END>
<START>
A
proposed
conflict-of-interest
policy
for
federally
funded
biomedical
researchers
may
thwart
many
high-technology
new
ventures
,
say
financiers
,
researchers
and
university
administrators
.
<END>
<START>
The
National
Institutes
of
Health
policy
would
require
researchers
to
cut
financial
ties
with
health-care
businesses
--
or
lose
their
government
money
.
<END>
<START>
Among
other
concerns
,
the
agency
says
researchers
with
business
ties
are
more
likely
to
falsify
findings
in
order
to
tout
new
drugs
.
<END>
<START>
As
ties
between
academia
and
venture
capital
have
blossomed
in
recent
years
,
governmental
fear
of
abuse
has
risen
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
guidelines
could
``
make
it
impossible
to
commercialize
research
,
''
says
Kenneth
Smith
,
associate
provost
and
vice
president
for
research
at
Massachusetts
Institute
of
Technology
.
<END>
<START>
The
NIH
is
asking
grant
recipients
and
others
for
comments
on
the
proposed
guidelines
until
Dec.
15
.
<END>
<START>
After
that
,
it
will
make
a
final
decision
on
the
policy
.
<END>
<START>
With
$
2.3
million
,
he
and
other
investors
launched
Lithox
last
year
to
market
a
gallstone
cure
being
developed
by
researchers
of
the
University
of
California
at
San
Diego
.
<END>
<START>
The
researchers
,
who
are
being
financed
by
the
Lithox
funds
,
will
receive
a
royalty
,
or
percentage
of
sales
,
if
their
research
yields
a
commercial
product
.
<END>
<START>
The
high-tech
industry
is
full
of
the
kind
of
arrangement
that
the
new
guidelines
would
affect
.
<END>
<START>
For
instance
,
Commonwealth
BioVentures
Inc.
,
a
venture-capital
concern
,
last
month
invested
$
600,000
to
launch
Amira
Inc.
,
a
Worcester
,
Mass.
,
concern
that
will
produce
pharmaceuticals
.
<END>
<START>
Scientists
Rima
Kaddurah-Daouk
and
Paul
Schimmel
conducted
the
initial
research
at
the
Massachusetts
Institute
of
Technology
.
<END>
<START>
While
Ms.
Kaddurah-Daouk
left
MIT
to
head
Amira
,
Prof.
Schimmel
will
continue
to
work
at
MIT
,
serve
on
Amira
's
board
and
own
a
small
equity
stake
in
the
company
.
<END>
<START>
The
Amira
transaction
is
typical
of
the
way
venture-capital
firms
are
approaching
the
task
of
commercializing
biotechnology
research
.
<END>
<START>
While
universities
develop
the
basic
research
,
``
venture
capitalists
are
the
ones
best
positioned
to
finance
its
commercialization
,
''
says
Gloria
W.
Doubleday
of
Commonwealth
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
the
best
way
to
transfer
technology
straight
off
the
campuses
of
universities
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
the
new
guidelines
could
prevent
scientists
like
Prof.
Schimmel
from
being
involved
with
start-ups
such
as
Amira
,
venture
capitalists
point
out
.
<END>
<START>
And
if
that
happens
,
the
entire
process
of
transferring
technology
to
the
marketplace
could
be
harmed
,
they
say
.
<END>
<START>
The
stakes
in
the
controversy
are
large
.
<END>
<START>
Last
year
,
venture
capitalists
spent
an
estimated
$
600
million
to
finance
start-up
companies
in
medical
and
biotechnology
businesses
,
according
to
the
National
Venture
Capital
Association
,
a
trade
group
.
<END>
<START>
Many
of
the
deals
involved
transactions
in
which
scientific
institutions
or
researchers
agreed
to
commercialize
their
work
in
return
for
an
equity
stake
or
royalties
.
<END>
<START>
In
many
of
these
deals
,
``
venture
capitalists
had
the
inside
track
,
''
says
Lawrence
Bock
of
Avalon
Ventures
,
La
Jolla
,
Calif
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
were
willing
to
gamble
on
new
technologies
because
``
we
had
exclusive
rights
to
those
technologies
,
''
he
adds
.
<END>
<START>
But
under
the
proposed
guidelines
,
all
federally
funded
research
will
have
to
be
reported
publicly
so
that
anyone
can
capitalize
on
the
work
.
<END>
<START>
``
Without
the
exclusivity
,
most
venture
capitalists
wo
n't
have
the
incentive
to
invest
in
such
deals
,
''
Mr.
Bock
says
.
<END>
<START>
Athena
eventually
acquired
exclusive
rights
to
the
technology
and
currently
is
developing
it
.
<END>
<START>
But
,
says
Mr.
Bock
,
``
It
was
a
close
call
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
proposed
guidelines
could
also
delay
commercialization
--
and
force
small
companies
to
waste
scarce
capital
,
entrepreneurs
say
.
<END>
<START>
Duplicating
research
is
both
costly
and
time-consuming
for
a
start-up
,
Ms.
Emyanitoff
says
.
<END>
<START>
For
its
part
,
NIH
insists
that
its
guidelines
``
should
not
stifle
research
creativity
or
technology
transfer
from
the
research
laboratory
to
commercial
use
.
''
<END>
<START>
NIH
staff
members
believe
the
guidelines
are
essential
to
prevent
the
escalation
of
problems
that
have
already
begun
to
surface
in
scientific
ventures
.
<END>
<START>
Not
long
ago
,
scientists
holding
stock
in
Spectra
Pharmaceutical
Services
Inc.
were
accused
of
falsifying
research
to
boost
the
stock
.
<END>
<START>
Many
officials
are
also
concerned
about
companies
getting
a
``
free
ride
''
on
government-sponsored
research
.
<END>
<START>
A
congressional
subcommitee
has
been
investigating
the
potential
abuse
from
researchers
holding
stock
in
companies
exploiting
their
research
.
<END>
<START>
Among
other
provisions
,
the
NIH
guidelines
would
prohibit
researchers
and
members
of
their
immediate
families
from
holding
stock
in
any
company
that
is
affected
by
the
outcome
of
their
research
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Bick
,
the
NIH
administrator
,
says
the
business
and
scientific
community
is
overreacting
to
what
the
agency
merely
meant
to
be
``
ideas
for
discussion
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
predictions
of
doom
are
``
premature
,
''
she
says
.
<END>
<START>
But
when
agencies
like
the
NIH
circulate
guidelines
,
they
've
often
already
formulated
policy
,
veteran
scientists
say
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
institutions
already
are
taking
note
.
<END>
<START>
On
Sept.
14
,
Harvard
began
circulating
a
conflict-of-interest
policy
statement
that
,
in
effect
,
would
follow
the
NIH
guidelines
faithfully
.
<END>
<START>
The
University
of
California
at
San
Francisco
is
also
circulating
a
memo
among
its
scientific
faculty
that
will
restrict
contact
with
the
world
of
business
.
<END>
<START>
In
many
other
institutions
,
scientists
are
shunning
contacts
with
venture
investors
until
the
NIH
policy
is
settled
.
<END>
<START>
Says
Mr.
Daly
,
the
venture
capitalist
:
``
It
does
n't
matter
whether
they
call
it
guidelines
or
policy
.
<END>
<START>
The
damage
is
already
done
.
<END>

<START>
Merksamer
Jewelers
Inc.

from

.

,

,

.

<START>
L.J.
Hooker
,

,

11

in

and

<START>

<START>
The

,

of
$
62
million
and
operating
profit
of
$
2.5
million
for
the
year
ended
June
30
.
<END>
<START>
For
all
of
this
year
's
explosive

in

,
Renaissance
Investment
Management
Inc.
's

sat
on

.
<END>
<START>
Now

's

.
<END>
<START>
It
was
the

that

has

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>

,

.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
,

.

<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

,

Average
fell

,

.

<START>
Renaissance

,

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.

.

<START>

,

.

.

,

.

<START>
The
Sept.
25
``
Tracking
Travel
''
column
advises
readers
to
``
Charge
With
Caution
When
Traveling
Abroad
''
because
credit-card
companies
charge
1
%
to
convert
foreign-currency
expenditures
into
dollars
.
<END>
<START>
In
fact
,
this
is
the
best
bargain
available
to
someone
traveling
abroad
.
<END>
<START>
In
contrast
to
the
1
%
conversion
fee
charged
by
Visa
,
foreign-currency
dealers
routinely
charge
7
%
or
more
to
convert
U.S.
dollars
into
foreign
currency
.
<END>
<START>
On
top
of
this
,
the
traveler
who
converts
his
dollars
into
foreign
currency
before
the
trip
starts
will
lose
interest
from
the
day
of
conversion
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
end
of
the
trip
,
any
unspent
foreign
exchange
will
have
to
be
converted
back
into
dollars
,
with
another
commission
due
.
<END>
<START>
The
card
holder
will
pay
the
modest
1
%
fee
only
on
the
amounts
actually
needed
.
<END>
<START>
Typically
,
he
will
be
billed
only
several
weeks
after
the
expenditure
,
and
then
has
another
couple
of
weeks
before
he
has
to
pay
the
bill
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
meantime
,
the
money
can
continue
to
earn
interest
for
the
card
holder
--
often
more
than
1
%
during
that
``
float
''
period
alone
.
<END>
<START>
Daniel
Brigham
<END>
<START>
Visa
U.S.A.
Inc
.
<END>
<START>

.

.

<START>
Investors
poured
$
2.8
billion
more
into
money-market
mutual
funds
in
the
latest
week
despite
further
declines
in
yields
.
<END>
<START>
Assets
of
the
400
taxable
funds
tracked
by
IBC/Donoghue
's
Money
Fund
Report
jumped
to
$
351.2
billion
in
the
week
ended
Tuesday
,
the
Holliston
,
Mass.-based
newsletter
said
.
<END>
<START>
Assets
soared
$
4.5
billion
in
the
previous
week
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
the
average
yield
on
taxable
funds
dropped
nearly
a
tenth
of
a
percentage
point
,
the
largest
drop
since
midsummer
.
<END>
<START>
``
Lower
yields
are
just
reflecting
lower
short-term
interest
rates
,
''
said
Brenda
Malizia
Negus
,
editor
of
Money
Fund
Report
.
<END>
<START>
Money
funds
invest
in
such
things
as
short-term
Treasury
securities
,
commercial
paper
and
certificates
of
deposit
,
all
of
which
have
been
posting
lower
interest
rates
since
last
spring
.
<END>
<START>
Individual
investors
can
still
get
better
yields
on
money
funds
than
on
many
other
short-term
instruments
.
<END>
<START>
The
yield
on
six-month
Treasury
bills
sold
at
Monday
's
auction
,
for
example
,
was
just
7.77
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
maturity
of
the
taxable
funds
that
Donoghue
's
follows
increased
by
two
days
in
the
latest
week
to
40
days
,
its
longest
since
August
.
<END>
<START>
Average
maturity
was
as
short
as
29
days
at
the
start
of
this
year
,
when
short-term
interest
rates
were
moving
steadily
upward
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
seven-day
compound
yield
of
the
funds
reached
9.62
%
in
late
April
.
<END>
<START>
The
highest-yielding
funds
are
still
above
9
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
top-performing
fund
in
the
latest
week
was
Dreyfus
Worldwide
Dollar
,
with
a
seven-day
compound
yield
of
9.45
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
fund
invests
heavily
in
dollar-denominated
money-market
securities
overseas
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
currently
waiving
management
fees
,
which
contributes
to
the
higher
yield
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
seven-day
simple
yield
of
the
400
funds
fell
to
8.14
%
from
8.21
%
,
Donoghue
's
reported
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
30-day
simple
yield
slid
to
8.22
%
from
8.26
%
,
and
the
average
30-day
compound
yield
fell
to
8.56
%
from
8.60
%
.
<END>
<START>
These
people
invested
in
``
leveraged
''
junk
bond
mutual
funds
,
the
publicly
traded
funds
that
make
a
habit
of
taking
out
loans
to
buy
extra
junk
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
a
good
strategy
in
a
rising
market
,
where
a
25
%
leveraged
portfolio
in
effect
allows
investors
to
have
125
%
of
their
money
working
for
them
.
<END>
<START>
The
strategy
boosts
current
yield
by
putting
more
bonds
into
the
portfolio
.
<END>
<START>
Trouble
is
,
junk
bond
prices
have
been
weak
for
months
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
,
the
leverage
has
amplified
the
funds
'
portfolio
losses
.
<END>
<START>
And
shares
of
leveraged
junk
funds
this
year
have
been
clobbered
even
harder
than
the
junk
bonds
they
hold
.
<END>
<START>
``
That
's
really
where
the
leverage
hurt
,
''
says
Thomas
Herzfeld
,
a
Miami-based
investment
manager
who
specializes
in
closed-end
funds
.
<END>
<START>
``
Share
prices
performed
even
worse
than
the
funds
'
asset
values
because
fear
has
taken
hold
''
in
the
junk
market
,
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Leverage
is
never
a
problem
for
the
traditional
``
open
end
''
mutual
funds
,
which
are
n't
publicly
traded
and
are
n't
allowed
to
use
leverage
at
all
.
<END>
<START>
Leverage
is
used
only
by
some
of
the
closed-end
funds
.
<END>
<START>
The
usual
maneuver
is
to
borrow
against
the
portfolio
value
or
issue
preferred
stock
,
using
the
proceeds
to
buy
additional
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
The
fallout
for
investors
lately
has
been
painful
.
<END>
<START>
Consider
the
New
America
High
Income
Fund
.
<END>
<START>
With
a
leveraged
position
of
about
45
%
,
the
fund
's
share
price
has
plunged
28.5
%
so
far
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
worse
than
the
price
drop
sustained
by
the
bonds
in
its
portfolio
,
whose
total
return
-LRB-
bond-price
changes
plus
interest
-RRB-
has
amounted
to
a
negative
6.08
%
.
<END>
<START>
Such
problems
may
not
be
over
.
<END>
<START>
Many
investors
are
unaware
their
funds
have
borrowed
to
speculate
in
such
a
risky
market
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
typical
leverage
strategy
,
a
fund
tries
to
capture
the
spread
between
what
it
costs
to
borrow
and
the
higher
return
on
the
bonds
it
buys
with
the
borrowed
money
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
market
surges
,
holders
can
make
that
much
more
profit
;
the
leverage
effectively
acts
as
an
interest-free
margin
account
for
investors
.
<END>
<START>
But
when
the
market
moves
against
the
fund
,
investors
lose
more
than
other
junk
holders
because
the
market
decline
is
magnified
by
the
amount
the
fund
is
leveraged
.
<END>
<START>
Fund
managers
,
for
their
part
,
defend
their
use
of
leverage
.
<END>
<START>
Carl
Ericson
,
who
runs
the
Colonial
Intermediate
High
Income
Fund
,
says
the
fund
's
25
%
leverage
has
jacked
up
its
interest
income
.
<END>
<START>
``
As
long
as
I
am
borrowing
at
9.9
%
and
each
-LCB-
bond
-RCB-
yields
over
that
,
it
enhances
the
yield
,
''
he
maintains
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Ericson
says
he
tries
to
offset
the
leverage
by
diversifying
the
fund
's
portfolio
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
some
funds
have
pulled
in
their
horns
.
<END>
<START>
New
America
High
Income
Fund
recently
said
that
it
plans
to
reduce
its
leverage
position
by
buying
back
$
5
million
in
preferred
stock
and
notes
from
investors
.
<END>
<START>
The
fund
made
a
similar
move
earlier
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
are
trying
to
increase
our
flexibility
,
''
says
Ellen
E.
Terry
,
a
vice
president
at
Ostrander
Capital
Management
,
the
fund
's
investment
adviser
.
<END>
<START>
She
declined
to
elaborate
and
would
n't
disclose
the
fund
's
recent
purchases
,
sales
or
cash
position
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Terry
did
say
the
fund
's
recent
performance
``
illustrates
what
happens
in
a
leveraged
product
''
when
the
market
does
n't
cooperate
.
<END>
<START>
``
When
the
market
turns
around
,
''
she
says
,
``
it
will
give
a
nice
picture
''
of
how
leverage
can
help
performance
.
<END>
<START>
Several
leveraged
funds
do
n't
want
to
cut
the
amount
they
borrow
because
it
would
slash
the
income
they
pay
shareholders
,
fund
officials
said
.
<END>
<START>
But
a
few
funds
have
taken
other
defensive
steps
.
<END>
<START>
Some
have
raised
their
cash
positions
to
record
levels
.
<END>
<START>
High
cash
positions
help
buffer
a
fund
when
the
market
falls
.
<END>
<START>
He
says
the
fund
,
which
is
40
%
leveraged
,
has
maintained
a
``
substantial
cushion
''
between
its
borrowing
costs
and
the
yields
of
the
portfolio
's
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
do
n't
want
to
be
in
a
position
to
have
to
sell
,
''
Mr.
Frabotta
says
.
<END>
<START>
Other
funds
have
recently
sold
weak
junk
bonds
to
raise
cash
.
<END>
<START>
``
That
's
a
problem
because
cash
is
n't
earning
us
very
much
money
,
''
Mr.
Bianchi
says
.
<END>
<START>
He
concedes
:
``
This
is
the
most
difficult
market
that
I
've
been
involved
in
.
''
<END>
<START>
Because
of
the
recent
junk-market
turmoil
,
the
fund
is
considering
investing
in
other
issues
instead
,
including
mortgage-backed
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're
looking
at
the
leverage
factor
every
day
,
''
says
Robert
Moore
,
president
of
Bernstein-Macaulay
Inc.
,
a
Shearson
Lehman
Hutton
Inc.
unit
and
the
fund
's
adviser
.
<END>
<START>
One
of
the
more
bizarre
garden
stories
since
Eden
has
been
unfolding
for
four
years
now
,
in
the
private
paper-and-crayon
fantasies
of
artist
Jennifer
Bartlett
.
<END>
<START>
And
if
she
and
the
Battery
Park
City
Authority
have
their
way
,
her
horticulturally
inept
plan
will
soon
go
public
as
a
real
garden
``
artwork
''
in
the
downtown
complex
.
<END>
<START>
South
Gardens
,
as
the
Bartlett
scheme
is
called
,
will
occupy
the
last
3.5
acres
of
open
space
at
the
southwest
tip
of
Manhattan
.
<END>
<START>
It
could
cost
taxpayers
$
15
million
to
install
and
BPC
residents
$
1
million
a
year
to
maintain
.
<END>
<START>
Created
by
an
artist
who
flaunts
her
ignorance
of
plants
and
gardens
,
South
Gardens
,
as
now
planned
,
will
die
from
congestive
garden
design
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Bartlett
's
previous
work
,
which
earned
her
an
international
reputation
in
the
non-horticultural
art
world
,
often
took
gardens
as
its
nominal
subject
.
<END>
<START>
Mayhap
this
metaphorical
connection
made
the
BPC
Fine
Arts
Committee
think
she
had
a
literal
green
thumb
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Ms.
Bartlett
would
not
discuss
her
garden
for
this
article
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Last
year
she
boasted
to
HG
magazine
:
``
I
'd
never
looked
at
a
garden
in
my
life
.
''
<END>
<START>
I
view
this
as
a
building
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
third
principal
in
the
South
Gardens

did
have
garden
experience
.
<END>
<START>
The
firm
of
Bruce
Kelly/David
Varnell
Landscape
Architects
had
created
Central
Park
's
Strawberry
Fields
and

.
<END>
<START>
The
BPCA
called

a
``

''

.
<END>
<START>
After
four
years
,
though
,

South
Gardens
design
is
100
%

Jennifer
Bartlett
.
<END>
<START>

,

was
to

of

or

with

.
<END>
<START>
In

,

``

.
''
<END>
<START>
The

were

in

.
<END>
<START>
All

,

Bartlett
had
been
busy
at
her

,

in

.
<END>
<START>

,

``

20

''

.

.

.
''
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
This

,

's

.

<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
''
<END>
<START>
Plant

.
<END>
<START>
They
looked
at
the

and

.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Bartlett
's

rooms

.
<END>
<START>

had

'

,

.
<END>
<START>
Inside

grid
were
24

.
<END>
<START>

into

,

,

.

--

--

.

''

.

.

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-

.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>

<START>
Mr.
Angell
is
incorrect
when
he
states
that
the
Soviet
Union
's
large
gold
reserves
would
give

``
great

to
establish

.
''
<END>
<START>

contrast
,
in
19th-century
Russia
an
authoritarian
government
owned
the
bank
and
had
the
power
to
revoke

whenever

,

's

.

was

and

law
,

of

for

.

.

would
consider
imposing
``
circuit
breakers
''
to
halt
program
trading
at
volatile
times
.
<END>
<START>
After
the
study
,
the
SEC
would
be
willing
to
consider
adding
new
circuit
breakers
or
fine-tuning
the
current
ones
,
he
added
.
<END>
<START>
Circuit
breakers
,
designed
to
give
the
markets
a
breather
in
cases
of
sharp
price
movements
,
curb
trading
of
futures
or
stocks
at
various
trigger
points
.
<END>
<START>
At
certain
points
during
the
Friday
the
13th
drop
,
circuit
breakers
kicked
in
on
the
futures
market
,
slowing
trading
at
times
.
<END>
<START>
A
circuit
breaker
that
would
have
closed
down
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
was
n't
tripped
.
<END>
<START>
He
argued
that
program-trading
by
roughly
15
big
institutions
is
pushing
around
the
markets
and
scaring
individual
investors
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Breeden
did
n't
reject
the
proposal
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Breeden
backed
most
of
the
provisions
in
a
market-reform
bill
that
the
SEC
brought
to
the
subcommittee
last
year
under
then-chairman
David
Ruder
.
<END>
<START>
The
measure
is
expected
to
move
through
this
Congress
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
new
chairman
vehemently
opposed
a
provision
in
the
bill
that
would
give
the
agency
the
right
to
close
the
markets
at
times
of
stress
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Breeden
contended
that
uncertainty
over
when
the
SEC
might
act
could
worsen
volatility
in
the
markets
.
<END>
<START>
He
argued
that
the
current
circuit-breaker
system
allows
investors
to
know
``
precisely
when
and
where
any
trading
interruptions
will
occur
and
how
long
they
will
last
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Breeden
offered
strong
support
for
two
other
provisions
in
the
bill
.
<END>
<START>
One
would
force
brokerage
houses
to
provide
the
SEC
detailed
information
about
loans
made
by
their
holding
companies
.
<END>
<START>
Such
loans
often
are
used
to
finance
leveraged
buy-outs
,
and
the
agency
is
worried
that
a
sharp
market
drop
could
create
capital
problems
for
the
firms
.
<END>
<START>
He
also
backed
a
rule
to
require
large
traders
to
report
transactions
on
a
systematic
basis
.
<END>
<START>
That
information
,
he
argued
,
is
critical
to
reconstructing
sharp
market
moves
,
such
as
the
one
nearly
two
weeks
ago
.
<END>
<START>
They
estimate
the
value
of
the
transaction
at
close
to
$
100
million
.
<END>
<START>
K
mart
officials
and
Mr.
Pilevsky
would
n't
comment
on
the
sale
.
<END>
<START>
K
mart
previously
had
announced
it
would
report
its
third
consecutive
decline
in
quarterly
earnings
for
the
period
ended
yesterday
,
the
same
day
the
real
estate
deal
was
completed
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
are
estimating
third-quarter
earnings
will
drop
between
13
%
and
20
%
to
about
50
to
55
cents
per
share
,
compared
with
63
cents
per
share
in
the
year-ago
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
unclear
what
effect
the
sale
of
the
shopping
centers
will
have
on
earnings
.
<END>
<START>
K
mart
developed
the
centers
,
which
range
in
size
from
about
150,000
square
feet
to
just
over
250,000
square
feet
.
<END>
<START>
Most
are
anchored
by
a
K
mart
store
.
<END>
<START>
The
retailer
reportedly
will
lease
its
stores
back
from
the
developer
,
who
plans
to
expand
the
small
centers
.
<END>
<START>
The
centers
comprise
a
total
of
about
1.6
million
square
feet
of
retail
space
.
<END>
<START>
They
are
spread
around
the
country
and
include
locations
in
California
,
Florida
,
Washington
and
Arizona
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Pilevsky
,
who
heads
Philips
International
Holding
Corp.
,
a
New
York-based
real
estate
company
,
owns
more
than
a
dozen
other
shopping
centers
in
which
K
mart
is
a
tenant
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
is
active
in
office
and
residential
development
in
New
York
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
nationally
,
Mr.
Pilevsky
controls
through
limited
partnerships
about
85
shopping
centers
with
about
17
million
square
feet
.
<END>
<START>
K
mart
runs
2,200
K
mart
stores
,
primarily
in
leased

.
<END>
<START>
The
company
typically
sells
the
centers
it
develops
,
but
has
usually
sold
only
one
or
several
at
a
time
.
<END>
<START>
Motorola
is
fighting
back
against
junk
mail
.
<END>
<START>
So
much
of
the
stuff
poured
into
its
Austin
,
Texas
,
offices
that
its
mail
rooms
there
simply
stopped
delivering
it
.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
thousands
of
mailers
,
catalogs
and
sales
pitches
go
straight
into
the
trash
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
the
overload
problem
and
the
weight
problem
we
have
.
''
<END>
<START>
Motorola
is
in
good
company
.
<END>
<START>
Businesses
across
the
country
are
getting
fed
up
with
junk
mail
,
and
some
are
saying
they
just
are
n't
going
to
take
it
anymore
--
literally
.
<END>
<START>
While
no
one
has
tracked
how
many
company
mail
rooms
throw
out
junk
mail
,
direct-mail
advertising
firms
say
the
number
is
growing
.
<END>
<START>
Why
the
revolt
?
<END>
<START>
Anybody
with
a
mailbox
can
answer
that
:
sheer
,
overwhelming
,
mind-numbing
volume
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
the
Direct
Marketing
Association
,
total
direct
mail
--
to
both
businesses
and
consumers
--
jumped
50
%
to
65.4
billion
pieces
in
1988
from
five
years
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Though
direct
mail
to
businesses
is
n't
broken
out
separately
,
the
association
says
it
's
growing
even
faster
.
<END>
<START>
The
deluge
has
spurred
cost-conscious
companies
to
action
,
with
mail
rooms
throwing
the
stuff
out
rather
than
taking
the
time
or
money
to
deliver
it
.
<END>
<START>
The
direct-mail
industry
,
not
surprisingly
,
is
fuming
at
the
injustice
of
it
all
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
it
's
like
biting
the
hand
that
feeds
them
,
because
every
one
of
these
companies
uses
direct
marketing
.
''
<END>
<START>
It
's
almost
impossible
to
track
the
number
of
companies
trashing
junk
mail
,
since
the
decision
is
usually
made
in
the
mail
room
--
not
the
board
room
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
practice
often
varies
from
location
to
location
even
within
a
company
.
<END>
<START>
But
industry
executives
say
businesses
seem
especially
inclined
to
dump
mailers
sent
to
titles
rather
than
to
individual
names
.
<END>
<START>
Motorola
's
Austin
operation
was
one
of
the
first
to
lose
patience
,
deciding
a
few
years
ago
to
junk
any
bulk
mail
that
was
n't
addressed
to
an
individual
.
<END>
<START>
At
Air
Products
,
meanwhile
,
the
mailroom
staff
opens
junk
mail
and
often
throws
it
away
--
even
if
addressed
to
an
individual
.
<END>
<START>
Direct
marketers
were
especially
alarmed
when
General
Motors
--
one
of
the
country
's
largest
companies
and
a
big
direct-mail
user
itself
--
entered
the
junk-mail
battle
.
<END>
<START>
As
of
March
1
,
its
Flint
office
,
with
about
2,500
employees
,
stopped
delivering
bulk
mail
and
non-subscription
magazines
.
<END>
<START>
Employees
were
told
that
if
they
really
wanted
the
publications
,
they
would
have
to
have
them
sent
home
instead
.
<END>
<START>
The
reason
:
overload
,
especially
of
non-subscription
magazines
.
<END>
<START>
Direct-mail
executives
see
GM
's
stand
as
an
ominous
sign
--
even
if
the
junk-mail
kings
did
bring
it
on
themselves
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
smacks
of
big
brotherism
.
<END>
<START>
They
're
going
to
decide
what
their
employees
can
or
can
not
read
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
practice
is
,
however
,
legal
in
most
cases
.
<END>
<START>
The
junk-mail
titans
,
ever
optimistic
,
are
looking
for
ways
around
the
problem
.
<END>
<START>
So
far
,
they
say
,
it
has
n't
had
any
noticeable
effect
on
response
rates
.
<END>
<START>
And
before
it
does
,
they
're
trying
to
cut
back
on
the
clutter
that
created
the
situation
in
the
first
place
.
<END>
<START>
Among
other
things
,
the
industry
is
trying
to
come
up
with
standardized
business
lists
that
cut
down
on
duplications
.
<END>
<START>
But
then
again
,
mailing
less
and
smarter
wo
n't
be
much
help
if
the
mail
ends
up
in
the
garbage
anyway
.
<END>

<START>
Senate
Democrats
who
favor
cutting
the

tax
are

behind

leading
Senate

.
<END>
<START>
Senate

Leader
George
Mitchell
-LRB-
D.
,
Maine
-RRB-
was
confident
he
had
enough
votes
to
block

on

,

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Packwood
all
but

,
telling

:
``
I
sense
at
this
stage
you
may

the

.
''
<END>
<START>
The
two
lawmakers
sparred
in
a
highly
personal
fashion
,
violating
usual
Senate
decorum
.
<END>
<START>
And
Democrats
,
who
are
under
increasing
pressure
from
their

to
reject
the
gains-tax
cut
,
are

,

.
<END>
<START>
A
major
reason
is
that
they
believe
the
Packwood-Roth
plan
would

of
revenue
over

run
.
<END>
<START>
The
Packwood-Roth
proposal
would
reduce
the
tax
depending
on
how
long
an
asset
was
held
.
<END>
<START>
President
Bush
has
been

this
kind

opposition
first
hand
during

over

with

.
<END>
<START>
And

Tuesday
of
Democratic
senators
,
there
was
outspoken
opposition
to
cutting
the
capital-gains
tax
this

,

.
<END>
<START>
The
trend
is
making

of
the
tax
cut
less
optimistic
about

.
<END>
<START>
``
There

this

,
''

David

,

of

tax
.
<END>
<START>
He

the

``
uphill
.
''
<END>
<START>
Other
Democrats
who
favor
a
capital-gains
cut
are

.
<END>
<START>
``
There

capital-gains
bill
this

,
''

Dale
Bumpers
-LRB-

,

.
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
'm

vote
for

proposal
.
<END>
<START>
The
IRA
portion
-LRB-
of

Packwood-Roth
plan
-RRB-

.
''
<END>
<START>
Another

<START>
Mr.

.
<END>
<START>
Today
,

and

plan
to

.

.

.

<START>
Japanese
immigration
authorities
said
they
found
658
more
Chinese
among
Vietnamese
boat
people
,
bringing
the
number
of
Chinese
trying
to
enter
Japan
by
posing
as
Vietnamese
refugees
this
year
to
1,642
.
<END>
<START>
Japan
plans
to
send
the
Chinese
back
home
and
is
negotiating
with
the
Chinese
government
,
a
Justice
Ministry
official
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
Chinese
were
among
3,372
boat
people
supposedly
from
Vietnam
who
arrived
in
Japan
this
year
,
compared
with
219
for
all
of
1988
,
the
official
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
658
Chinese
,
who
have
been
in
a
refugee-assistance
center
,
were
sent
to
immigration
facilities
yesterday
pending
deportation
to
China
,
the
official
said
.
<END>
<START>
On
Sept.
13
,
Japan
began
a
policy
of
screening
boat
people
,
accepting
only
those

<START>
Regarding
your
Oct.
4
page-one
article
``
Bad
Blood
''
on
the
generic-drug
battle
:
The
Epilepsy
Institute
is
not
just
a
patient-advocacy
organization
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
primarily
a
certified
outpatient
treatment
facility
providing
comprehensive
services
to
people
with
epilepsy
and
their
families
.
<END>
<START>
The
institute
's
advocacy
efforts
are
based
on
the
needs
of
the
population
it
serves
and
represents
.
<END>
<START>
In
1985
,
the
Medical
Tribune
reported
that
a
growing
number
of
critics
are
challenging
the
FDA
bioequivalence-therapeutic-equivalence
equation
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
contend
it
is
based
on
an
assumption
that
has
not
yet
been
proven
in
valid
tests
,
''
the
Tribune
said
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
neurologists
were
beginning
to
report
these
observations
as
well
.
<END>
<START>
Call
it
anecdotal
if
you
will
.
<END>
<START>
But
no
ethical
physician
would
switch
patients
who
were
doing
well
on
a
specific
medication
from
a
specific
manufacturer
to
prove
a
point
.
<END>
<START>
We
do
not
depend
on
pharmaceutical
companies
for
our
support
.
<END>
<START>
The
institute
has
governmental
service
contracts
for
the
provision
of
direct
patient
services
;
collects
patient
fees
;
receives
money
through
contributions
from
individuals
,
foundations
and
bequests
.
<END>
<START>
The
funds
received
from
pharmaceutical
firms
are
used
to
offset
physician
symposiums
,
and
these
symposiums
do
not
stress
any
particular
medication
or
manufacturer
.
<END>
<START>
The
Epilepsy
Institute
's
reporting
of
breakthrough
seizures
stemmed
from
concerns
about
the
people
we
treat
and
care
about
daily
.
<END>
<START>
This
perhaps
was
perceived
as
a
``
bold
''
stance
,
and
thus
suspicious
.
<END>
<START>
But
let
us
not
confuse
profits
of
big
business
masquerading
as
concerns
for
people
's
health
care
or
for
the
cost
.
<END>
<START>
For

is
the
saving
?
<END>
<START>
Surely

who
depend

the
same

of
medication
in
their

daily
to

.

,

Ellen

.

.

<START>

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.

<START>
The

probably

or

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>
The

,

from

,

.

<START>

.

<START>

wave
of
building
.
<END>
<START>
Atlantic
City
casino
owner
Donald
Trump
is
scouting
the
Las
Vegas
market
with
an
eye
toward
building
an
appropriately

.
<END>
<START>
Even
before
the
huge
new

began
,
the
Strip
's
recent
expansion
squeezed
smaller
competitors
.
<END>
<START>
Many

of
downtown
's

spots
have
been

to

Strip
or

Laughlin
,

,
a

to

.
<END>
<START>

expansion
and

of

have
hurt

.
<END>
<START>
Since
1979
,
the
number
of

has
fallen
by
17,000
.
<END>
<START>
Many

here
expect
a

as

open
.
<END>
<START>
Skeptics

such

Mirage
will

a

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

Wynn
seems

,

.

<START>

.

.

.

,

<START>
ARTICLE
I
,
SECTION
7
,
CLAUSE
2
:
<END>
<START>
ARTICLE
I
,
SECTION
7
,
CLAUSE
3
:
<END>
<START>
President
Bush
told
reporters
a
few
months
ago
that
he
was
looking
for
the
right
test
case
to
see
whether
he
already
has
the
line-item
veto
.
<END>
<START>
Vice
President
Quayle
and
Budget
Director
Darman
said
recently
they
've
joined
the
search
.
<END>
<START>
On
Tuesday
,
the
subject
came
up
again
when
Marlin
Fitzwater
explained
the
constitutional
argument
based
on
the
provisions
above
to
the
White
House
press
corps
.
<END>
<START>
President
Bush
does
n't
have
any
provision
in
mind
,
but
line-item-veto
bait
will
be
like
earthworms
at
midnight
in
the
coming
Continuing
Resolution
.
<END>
<START>
The
harder
question
is
whether
anyone
yet
understands
that
Mr.
Bush
's
fight
for
his
constitutional
prerogatives
is
about
politics
as
much
as
it
is
about
law
.
<END>
<START>
We
have
been
persuaded
by
the
constitutional
argument
for
the
inherent
line-item
veto
since
1987
,
when
lawyer
Stephen
Glazier
first
made
the
case
on
this
page
.
<END>
<START>
The
1974
budget
``
reform
,
''
passed
over
President
Nixon
's
veto
,
took
away
the
presidential
impoundment
power
,
thereby
introducing
monstrous
CRs
and
eviscerating
the
presidential
veto
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Glazier
discovered
that
the
Founders
had
worried
that
Congress
might
take
the
President
out
of
the
loop
.
<END>
<START>
Labeling
an
omnibus
budget
a
``
bill
''
ca
n't
deprive
the
President
of
his
power
to
veto
items
.
<END>
<START>
Finding
a
test
case
should
n't
be
hard
,
but
there
is
something
to
be
said
for
picking
the
best
one
possible
.
<END>
<START>
The
White
House
had
the
perfect
case
,
but
Congress
blinked
before
it
could
go
to
court
.
<END>
<START>
After
the
HUD
and
S&L
stories
broke
,
some
Congressmen
began
to
worry
that
their
influence
peddling
at
executive-branch
and
independent
agencies
might
some
day
get
them
in
trouble
.
<END>
<START>
They
worried
about
an
Interior
Department
directive
to
log
all
communications
with
Members
or
their
staffs
.
<END>
<START>
The
White
House
warned
that
this
would
be
an
unconstitutional
usurpation
of
its
power
.
<END>
<START>
When
it
threatened
to
use
this
provision
as
the
test
for
a
line-item
veto
,
Congress
caved
.
<END>
<START>
This
means
Interior
contacts
can
not
be
logged
only
on
one
day
--
a
Sunday
that
had
already
passed
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
White
House
is
looking
for
another
unconstitutional
bill
,
Rep.
John
Dingell
is
trying
again
to
raise
the
Fairness
Doctrine
from
the
dead
.
<END>
<START>
President
Reagan
vetoed
this
as
a
First
Amendment
violation
.
<END>
<START>
The
``
Fairness
''
Doctrine
's
enthusiasts
are
incumbents
in
the
House
who
know
the
rules
squelch
lively
discussions
on
broadcasts
,
deterring
feisty
challengers
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
also
other
provisions
requiring
Congressmen
to
join
treaty-negotiating
teams
and
new
restrictions
on
OMB
.
<END>
<START>
Unconstitutional
bills
make
good
legal
targets
,
but
the
line-item
veto
is
better
understood
as
a
political
opportunity
than
as
mere
fodder
for
lawyers
.
<END>
<START>
Commenting
on
the

this

,
President
Bush
said
:
``
The
perception
out
there
is
that

.
<END>
<START>

.

<END>
<START>
Exactly

.
<END>
<START>

that
Presidents
need

to

,

.

.

<START>
Troubled
SCI
Television
Inc.
proposed
to
restructure
much
of
its
$
1.3
billion
in
debt
to
buy
time
to
sell
assets
and
pay
its
obligations
.
<END>
<START>
They
immediately
termed
the
proposal
inadequate
and
said
the
restructuring
would
not
solve
the
company
's
problems
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
interpreted
the
KKR
move
as
a
desire
by
the
firm
to
wash
its
hands
of
SCI
TV
.
<END>
<START>
But
a
spokesman
for
KKR
says
that
with
only
a
15
%
equity
stake
,
it
would
n't
be
appropriate
for
KKR
to
keep
board
representation
.
<END>
<START>
KKR
already
has
made
about
$
1
billion
of
gains
from
earlier
transactions
with
SCI
TV
,
thus
it
is
n't
significantly
affected
by
the
company
's
troubles
.
<END>
<START>
SCI
TV
,
which
is
controlled
by
Nashville
,
Tenn.
,
entrepreneur
George
Gillett
,
owns
six
TV
stations
,
including
several
CBS
Inc.
affiliates
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
having
trouble
meeting
its
debt
payments
because
of
heavy
borrowing
in
1987
for
a
leveraged
buy-out
.
<END>
<START>
KKR
would
give
up
a
31
%
equity
stake
to
bondholders
,
while
Mr.
Gillett
would
surrender
an
8
%
stake
.
<END>
<START>
While
one
big
SCI
TV
investor
thinks
that
's
pretty
generous
,
many
junkholders
had
been
hoping
that
KKR
and
Mr.
Gillett
would
invest
new
money
in
SCI
TV
.
<END>
<START>
Those
investors
think
SCI
TV
needs
new
equity
to
survive
.
<END>
<START>
SCI
TV
's
debt

plan
would
defer

of
$
153
million
of
bank
debt
.
<END>
<START>
It

and

on
junk

that
have
fallen
due
;
the

for

16
.
<END>
<START>
At

,

would
cut

company
's

from

90
million
to

85

.
<END>
<START>

to
pay

interest

,

say
SCI
TV
will
only
produce
about
$
80
million
to
$
90
million
of
cash
flow
a
year
.

<START>
Office
Market
Weakens
In
Overbuilt
Northeast
<END>
<START>
THE
NORTHEAST
office
market
is
feeling
serious
aftereffects
of
the
giddy
overbuilding
of
the
1980s
.
<END>
<START>
Foreclosures
and
other
signs
of
financial
distress
,
most
often
associated
with
the
real
estate
market
in
the
Southwest
,
are
surfacing
in
the
suburban
office
market
of
the
once
thriving
Northeast
.
<END>
<START>
Some
projects
are
now
in
the
hands
of
lenders
,
including
a
425,000-square-foot
office
facility
in
Little
Falls
,
N.J
.
<END>
<START>
The
owners
of
a
32-acre
hotel
and
office
complex
in
King
of
Prussia
,
Pa.
,
have
advertised
for
new
financing
.
<END>
<START>
Rising
office
vacancy
rates
in
Fairfield
County
,
Conn.
,
have
builders
and
bankers
scrambling
to
restructure
loans
.
<END>
<START>
And
in
suburban
Boston
,
developers
are
bracing
for
cutbacks
in
the
computer
industry
,
a
major
user
of
office
space
.
<END>
<START>
Owners
are
voluntarily
--
and
quietly
--
turning
over
properties
to
lenders
through
``
deeds
in
lieu
of
foreclosure
.
''
<END>
<START>
Often
,
developers
stay
on
as
property
manager
.
<END>
<START>
Real
estate
analyst
Lloyd
Lynford
says
the
Northeast
's
distress
is
masked
by
relatively
low
vacancy
rates
.
<END>
<START>
But
in
today
's
overbuilt
market
,
tenants
have
many
choices
and
are
negotiating
low
rents
that
squeeze
building
owners
.
<END>
<START>
On
average
,
Mr.
Lynford
says
,
it
now
takes
three
to
3
1/2
years
to
fill
new
office
space
,
compared
with
2
1/2
years
in
1988
.
<END>
<START>
Beverly
Hills
Comes
To
Suburban
Tokyo
<END>
<START>
WHY
SHOULD
the
Japanese
cross
the
Pacific
to
buy
American
real
estate
when
they
can
simply
recreate
it
at
home
?
<END>
<START>
Tokyu
Development
Corp.
is
spending
$
500
million
to
build
American-style
luxury
homes
in
suburban
Tokyo
with
rarely
seen
back
yards
,
front
yards
,
swimming
pools
and
tennis
courts
.
<END>
<START>
The
Japanese
company
hired
Richardson
Nagy
Martin
,
a
Newport
Beach
,
Calif.
,
architectural
firm
,
to
design
what
the
Japanese
press
has
dubbed
``
the
Beverly
Hills
of
Tokyo
.
''
<END>
<START>
Instead
of
Japan
's
typical
small
homes
clustered
on
narrow
streets
with
no
sidewalks
,
the
new
``
One
Hundred
Hills
''
development
will
offer
65
houses
on
half-acre
lots
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
more
than
10
times
the
usual
housing
site
size
.
<END>
<START>
Buyers
with
$
6
million
to
spend
can
select
from
11
designs
,
including
a
Mediterranean-inspired
California
style
,
a
traditional
Yankee
look
and
designs
inspired
by
Midwestern
architect
Frank
Lloyd
Wright
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
spacious
living
rooms
and
baths
,
plus
a
master
grandparents
suite
and
a
foyer
for
removing
shoes
to
suit
Japanese
life
styles
.
<END>
<START>
Exteriors
are
faced
with
brick
,
wood
or
stone
,
but
the
homes
are
made
of
steel-reinforced
concrete
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
were
disappointed
we
could
n't
use
wood
,
''
says
architect
Walter
J.
Richardson
,
``
but
the
Japanese
only
want
stronger
materials
.
''
<END>
<START>
At
$
1,000
per
square
foot
,
the
Japanese
want
the
feeling
of
indestructibility
,
he
explains
,
not
to
mention
protection
from
possible
earthquake
damage
.
<END>
<START>
Housing
Developers
Try
Brand-Name
Buildings
<END>
<START>
RESIDENTIAL
builders
,
faced
with
a
more
competitive
market
,
are
turning
to
a
traditional
consumer
marketing
technique
to
establish
brand-name
identity
.
<END>
<START>
So
he
's
using
``
river
''
in
many
project
names
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
'll
never
be
like
what
Bristol-Myers
does
,
''
he
adds
,
``
but
it
helps
establish
recognition
with
the
public
--
and
with
banks
.
''
<END>
<START>
Weingarten-Siegel
Group
Inc.
of
Manalapan
,
N.J.
,
has
built
Cross
Creek
Pointe
,
Allegro
Pointe
and
other
Pointes
in
New
Jersey
.
<END>
<START>
Caspi
Development
Corp
of
Armonk
,
N.Y.
,
has
developed
two
apartment
buildings
called
Classic
and
plans
a
third
.
<END>
<START>
Developer
Steve
Caspi
says
the
same
brand
name
indicates
consistent
quality
,
``
regardless
of
location
,
design
or
amenities
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
leader
in
real
estate
brand
names
is
developer
Ara
Hovnanian
.
<END>
<START>
His
entry-price
condos
are
labeled
Society
Hill
.
<END>
<START>
Beacon
Hill
is
for
``
move-up
''
town
houses
,
and
Nob
Hill
,
for
single-family
houses
.
<END>
<START>
Because
of
standardized
designs
,
Mr.
Hovnanian
says
,
``
a
buyer
can
visualize
Society
Hill
regardless
of
where
it
is
.
''
<END>
<START>
Quake
Not
Likely
to
Jolt
The
Commercial
Market
<END>
<START>
THE
EARTHQUAKE
in
San
Francisco
has
sent
few
tremors
through
the
hearts
of
real
estate
investors
.
<END>
<START>
But
like
other
real
estate
professionals
accustomed
to
California
's
quake
risks
,
Mr.
Leventhal
anticipates
little
long-term
change
in
the
city
's

.
<END>
<START>
Still
,

are
eager
to
tell
the
world
that
most
of
San
Francisco
does
n't

TV

.
<END>
<START>
Planners
of
the
Urban
Land
Institute
real
estate
conference
this
week
hastily
added
a
panel
on
the
quake
's
effects
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
message
is
we
build
'em
right
,
''
says
Peter
Bedford
,
a

Land
Institute
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
's
seven
million
square
feet
of
space
that
's
doing
great
.
<END>
<START>
HEALTH
CLUBS
gear
up
for
a
graying
clientele
.
<END>
<START>
Although
their
ads
picture
curvy
young
people
in
skimpy
outfits
,
club
owners
know
the
future
lies
with
the
lumpier
over-40
set
.
<END>
<START>
About
10
%
to
15
%
of
members
at
Atlanta
's
Holiday
Espre
Center
are
elderly
,
says
Gerald
Williams
,
fitness
consultant
.
<END>
<START>
``
Most
want
cardiovascular
conditioning
...
the
No.
1
way
of
reducing
risk
of
heart
disease
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
Association
of
Quality
Clubs
,
which
puts
1988
industry
revenue
at
$
5
billion
,
surveyed
the
health-conscious
over-40
market
and
found
that
43
%
exercise
regularly
.
<END>
<START>
Michael
Hays
,
head
of
ProBody
Fitness
,
notes
an
industry
``
wash
''
is
in
progress
.
<END>
<START>
``
Clubs
need
to
be
run
like
restaurants
where
every
square
foot
makes
a
dollar
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Older
people
help
profits
by
filling
in
``
downtime
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
adds
:
``
The
medical
market
and
the
fitness
market
parallel
each
other
and
are
going
to
cross
real
soon
.
''
<END>
<START>
People
on
fixed
incomes
get
a
break
at
Espre
;
over
55
wins
a
45
%
discount
at
Anaheim
Imperial
Health
Spa
.
<END>
<START>
``
HOT
''
TOPAZ
sparks
regulator
,
jeweler
concern
over
import
of
irradiated
stones
.
<END>
<START>
A
committee
of
gem
dealers
investigates
the
source
of
some
``
hot
''
blue
topaz
stones
recently
reported
by
a
Hong
Kong
jewelry
manufacturer
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
U.S.
,
radiation
limits
are
set
and
monitored
by
the
Nuclear
Regulatory
Commission
,
which
licenses
reactors
that
process
the
topaz
.
<END>
<START>
The
agency
is
working
on
licensing
importers
but
does
n't
currently
monitor
imports
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
-LCB-
stones
-RCB-
that
were
irradiated
in
the
U.S.
are
safe
,
''
says
John
Hickey
,
chief
of
the
NRC
operations
branch
,
Washington
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
believe
that
the
vast
majority
of
imported
material
is
safe
.
<END>
<START>
But
there
is
a
small
risk
that
some
were
imported
with
high
radiation
levels
.
''
<END>
<START>
Some
jewelers
have
Geiger
counters
to
measure
topaz
radiation
.
<END>
<START>
CAPITAL
TRAVELS
to
Europe
as
1992
unification
nears
.
<END>
<START>
Boston
's
Advent
International
raises
$
230
million
from
U.S.
pension
funds
and
other
institutions
to
invest
in
Europe
.
<END>
<START>
European
venture
capital
funds
total
about
$
14
billion
and
are
expected
to
continue
growing
35
%
annually
.
<END>
<START>
Continentals
believe
that
the
strongest
growth
area
will
be
southern
Europe
.
<END>
<START>
Spain
and
Italy
are
most
often
mentioned
as
the
future
economic
hot
spots
.
<END>
<START>
Favored
ventures
include
media
,
telecommunications
and
retailing
.
<END>
<START>
Most
popular
acquisition
method
:
the
leveraged
buy-out
.
<END>
<START>
Family-owned
firms
that
need
cash
to
grow
are
attractive
,
says
John
Turner
of
Matuschka
Gruppe
,
Munich
.
<END>
<START>
AN
AIDS
DIRECTORY
from
the
American
Foundation
for
AIDS
Research
rates
and
reviews
educational
materials
.
<END>
<START>
``
Learning
AIDS
''
lists
films
,
pamphlets
,
brochures
,
videos
and
other
educational
data
.
<END>
<START>
The
distributor
is
R.R.
Bowker
,
New
York
.
<END>
<START>
SUSPECT
``
SALES
''
ads
are
challenged
by
the
Better
Business

of

New
York
.
<END>
<START>
The
bureau
found
that
only
two
of
six
New
York
furniture

could
prove
their
presale
prices
were
higher
.

<START>
DRACULA
'S
BUSY
this
time
of
year
,
but
a
visit
to
his
Transylvania
castle
is
part
of
a
Chicago-based
Unitours
trip
in

,
presumably

count

.
<END>
<START>
RADIO
MALAISE
draws
the
ear
of
the
Federal
Communications
Commission
.
<END>
<START>
AM
radio
,
which
has
been
losing
listeners
to
FM
channels
since
the
1970s
,
approaches
the
1990s
with
a
diminished
voice
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
may
have
a
good
listener
in
Washington
.
<END>
<START>
The
FCC
plans
to
hear
a
day
of
testimony
Nov.
16
on
the
plight
of
AM
radio
.
<END>
<START>
The
commission
believes
that
improving
AM
service
would
broaden
listening
selections
and
increase
options
for
advertisers
.
<END>
<START>
The
issues
are
also
thought
to
be
important
to
the
FCC
's
new
chairman
,
Alfred
Sikes
,
a
former
AM
broadcaster
in
his
native
Missouri
.
<END>
<START>
The
FM
radio
band
,
considered
technically
superior
because
it
can
carry
stereo
broadcasts
,
has
cornered
the
airwaves
for
delivering
music
.
<END>
<START>
AM
stereo
remains
largely
undeveloped
because
it
lacks
a
uniform
delivery
system
.
<END>
<START>
Listeners
turned
to
radios
run
on
batteries
for
news
when
the
San
Francisco
earthquake
and
Hurricane
Hugo
cut
power
lines
.
<END>
<START>
BRIEFS
:
<END>
<START>
A
Modern
Healthcare
magazine
article
says
40
%
of
surveyed
executives
admitted
falling
asleep
during
formal
presentations
...
.
<END>
<START>
Lee
Co.
,
the
jeans
maker
,
celebrates
its
100th
anniversary
with
a
hardcover
yearbook
featuring
photos
of
its
10,000
employees
.
<END>
<START>
Kemper
Financial
Services
Inc.
,
charging
that
program
trading
is
ruining
the
stock
market
,
cut
off
four
big
Wall
Street
firms
from
doing
any
of
its
stock-trading
business
.
<END>
<START>
Several
big
securities
firms
backed
off
from
program
trading
a
few
months
after
the
1987
crash
.
<END>
<START>
But
most
of
them
,
led
by
Morgan
Stanley
&
Co.
,
moved
back
in
earlier
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
most
volatile
form
of
program
trading
is
index
arbitrage
--
the
rapid-fire
,
computer-guided
buying
and
selling
of
stocks
offset
with
opposite
trades
in
stock-index
futures
and
options
.
<END>
<START>
The
object
is
to
capture
profits
from
fleeting
price
discrepancies
between
the
futures
and
options
and
the
stocks
themselves
.
<END>
<START>
Index
arbitrage
recently
has
accounted
for
about
half
of
all
program
trading
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
.
<END>
<START>
Last
month
,
program
trading
accounted
for
20.9
million
shares
a
day
,
or
a
record
13.8
%
of
the
Big
Board
's
average
daily
volume
.
<END>
<START>
``
Index
arbitrage
does
n't
work
,
and
it
scares
natural
buyers
''
of
stock
.
<END>
<START>
We
've
talked
to
proponents
of
index
arbitrage
and
told
them
to
cool
it
because
they
're
ruining
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
They
said
,
`
Too
bad
,
'
so
we
finally
said
we
're
not
going
to
do
business
with
them
.
''
<END>
<START>
Kemper
also
blasted
the
Big
Board
for
ignoring
the
interests
of
individual
and
institutional
holders
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
New
York
Stock
Exchange
has
vested
interests
''
in
its
big
member
securities
firms
``
that
cloud
its
objectivity
,
''
Mr.
Timbers
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
has
never
been
interested
in
what
we
think
.
<END>
<START>
The
Big
Board
also
has
a
terrible
communication
problem
with
individual
investors
,
''
he
added
.
<END>
<START>
Big
Board
Chairman
John
J.
Phelan
said
in
a
recent
interview
that
he
has
no
inclination
to
eliminate
program
trading
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
the
market
's
volatility
disturbs
him
,
but
that
all
the
exchange
can
do
is
``
slow
down
the
process
''
by
using
its
circuit
breakers
and
shock
absorbers
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Timbers
countered
that
``
the
mere
fact
they
put
in
circuit
breakers
is
an
admission
of
their
problems
.
''
<END>
<START>
Morgan
Stanley
and
Kidder
Peabody
,
the
two
biggest
program
trading
firms
,
staunchly
defend
their
strategies
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
continue
to
believe
the
position
we
've
taken
is
reasonable
,
''
a
Morgan
Stanley
official
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
would
stop
index
arbitrage
when
the
market
is
under
stress
,
and
we
have
recently
,
''
he
said
,
citing
Oct.
13
and
earlier
this
week
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
Lawrence
Eckenfelder
,
a
securities
industry
analyst
at
Prudential-Bache
Securities
Inc.
,
``
Kemper
is
the
first
firm
to
make
a
major
statement
with
program
trading
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
added
that
``
having
just
one
firm
do
this
is
n't
going
to
mean
a
hill
of
beans
.
<END>
<START>
But
if
this
prompts
others
to
consider
the
same
thing
,
then
it
may
become
much
more
important
.
<END>
<START>
The
following
were
among
yesterday
's
offerings
and
pricings
in
the
U.S.
and
non-U.S.
capital
markets
,
with

and

manager
,

Dow
Jones
Capital
Markets
Report
:
<END>
<START>
The
notes
are

securities
and
will
not

periodically
.
<END>
<START>
The
size
of
the
offering
was
increased
from

originally

$
250
million
-LRB-
redemption
amount
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
The
notes
are

into

of

Entertainment
at
$
22.26
a

,

12
%

premium
over

's
closing

.

<START>

Ba-3
by

's
Investors
Service
Inc.
and

by

,

will

.

,

.

.

<START>
Rated

S&P
,
the
issue
will
be
sold
through
underwriters
led
by
Salomon
Brothers
Inc
.

<START>

,

's
and

,

from
6.30

.

6.30

7

.
<END>

7.10

.

.

$
12,915,000

7

.

.

.

.

<START>

,

<START>
Bethlehem
Steel
Corp.
,
hammered
by
higher
costs
and
lower
shipments
to
key
automotive
and
service-center
customers
,
posted
a
54
%
drop
in
third-quarter
profit
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
does
n't
bode
well
for
coming
quarters
,
''
said
John
Jacobson
,
who
follows
the
steel
industry
for
AUS
Consultants
.
<END>
<START>
In
fact
,
he
thinks
several
steelmakers
will
report
actual
losses
through
the
third
quarter
of
1990
.
<END>
<START>
Bethlehem
,
the
nation
's
second
largest
steelmaker
,
earned
$
46.9
million
,
or
54
cents
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
The
figures
include
$
15
million
in
costs
related
to
a
blast
furnace
outage
and
$
8
million
in
losses
from
unauthorized
work
outages
at
the
company
's
coal
operations
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
year-ago
period
,
Bethlehem
earned
$
101.4
million
,
or
$
1.27
a
share
,
including
a
$
3.8
million
gain
from
early
retirement
of
debt
.
<END>
<START>
Third-quarter
sales
dropped
11
%
to
$
1.27
billion
from
$
1.43
billion
a
year
ago
.
<END>
<START>
In
composite
trading
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
,
Bethlehem
shares
rose
50
cents
to
$
17.375
.
<END>
<START>
Of
all
the
major
steelmakers
,
Bethlehem
would
seem
to
be
the
most
vulnerable
to
a
slowdown
.
<END>
<START>
It
has
n't
diversified
beyond
steel
,
nor
has
it
linked
up
with
a
joint
venture
partner
to
share
costs
and
risks
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Applebaum
had
estimated
third-quarter
earnings
of
55
cents
a
share
,
but
said
the
losses
for
the
unusual
items
were
larger
than
expected
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
its
shipments
declined
as
a
result
of
a
reduction
in
inventories
by
service
centers
,
a
lackluster
automotive
market
and
increasing
competitive
pressures
in
the
construction
market
.
<END>
<START>
He
noted
,
however
,
that
the
company
's
order
entry
has
increased
from
the
low
levels
of
the
early
summer
,
following
the
end
of
labor
negotiations
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
dropped
to
$
441.1
million
from
$
820.4
million
,
because
the
company
no
longer
consolidates
its
Eastern
Steel
division
,
which
is
now
a
joint
venture
with
Kawasaki
Steel
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
Along
with
reduced
volume
,
analysts
said
the
nation
's
fifth
largest
steelmaker
was
hurt
by
holding
higher-cost
inventory
when
raw
material

of
such
key
products
as
nickel
dropped
.
<END>
<START>
Operating
profit
dropped
46
%
in

segment
.
<END>
<START>
Armco
shares
closed

10.625
in

.
<END>
<START>

bolster
the
U.S.
semiconductor
industry
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
,
which
made
the
announcement
at
the
dedication
of
a
research
center
here
,
said
it
invited
many
other
companies
to
participate
as
well
,
including
some
from
Europe
.
<END>
<START>
Jack
Kuehler
,
IBM
's
president
,
said
IBM
is
also
considering
letting
other
companies
participate
in
additional
semiconductor
work
but
declined
to
be
more
specific
.
<END>
<START>
While
IBM
,
Armonk
,
N.Y.
,
makes
the
bulk
of
the
DRAMs
it
uses
,
it
does
n't
make
the
equipment
needed
to
produce
those
chips
.
<END>
<START>
And
IBM
worries
that
the
Japanese
will
take
over
that
equipment
market
,
too
,
unless
U.S.
semiconductor
companies
produce
enough
memory
chips
here
to
keep
U.S.
equipment
makers
healthy
.
<END>
<START>
Failure
of
U.S.
equipment
makers
,
IBM
fears
,
would
leave
it
dependent
on
many
of
the
Japanese
companies
that
compete
with
it
in
other
parts
of
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
also
said
it
expects
to
benefit
from
the
expertise
that
Motorola
and
other
companies
can
bring
to
bear
on
the
difficult
problems
involved
in
semiconductor
manufacturing
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
already
participates
in
one
industrywide
effort
to
improve
semiconductor-manufacturing
techniques
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
said
it
expects
industrywide
efforts
to
become
prevalent
because
semiconductor
manufacturing
has
become
so
expensive
.
<END>
<START>
A
state-of-the-art
plant
cost
$
40
million
in
the
mid-1970s
but
costs
$
500
million
today
because
the
technology
is
so
complex
.
<END>
<START>
And
IBM
said
it
expects
the
costs
to
continue
climbing
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
,
which
said
Motorola
is
paying
just
a
nominal
fee
to
cover
the
21-month
agreement
,
acknowledged
some
companies
had
turned
down
its
invitation
to
join
in
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
said
that
was
mainly
because
the
project
may
not
bear
fruit
until
the
mid-1990s
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
said
it
thought
more
companies
would
become
interested
as
the
project
progresses
.
<END>
<START>
The
project
involving
Motorola
concerns
a
technique
,
called
X-ray
lithography
,
that
figures
to
be
crucial
to
future
generations
of
memory
chips
.
<END>
<START>
Currently
,
chips
are
produced
by
shining
light
through
a
mask
to
produce
an
image
on
the
chip
,
much
as
a
camera
produces
an
image
on
film
.
<END>
<START>
X-rays
,
by
contrast
,
travel
straighter
and
can
be
focused
more
tightly
than
light
.
<END>
<START>
X-rays
have
problems
,
too
.
<END>
<START>
They
can
make
the
masks
brittle
and
can
pass
through
material
they
're
not
supposed
to
.
<END>
<START>
Allied-Signal
Aerospace
Co.
received
a
$
65

to

Continental

'
393

.

,

.

.

,

.

,

.
<END>
<START>
In

in

,
Provigo
Inc.
said

will
sell
all

operations
to

and

.

<START>

's
7.38

Canadian
dollars
-LRB-
US$
6.3
billion
-RRB-

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

in

.
<END>
<START>
He

.
<END>
<START>
Bertin

,

.

.

.

.

,
''

.

''

.

<START>
Lawrence

Co.
,
a

and

company
,
from

of

.

<START>

3.2

for

7.125

to

,

Group
Inc
.
<END>
<START>

Insurance
,
based

,

,

to

the
$
22.5

in

United

.

<START>

,

to
93.2

91.2
%
.
<END>

,

.

<START>

of

.

,

,

,

.

,

.

this

.
<END>
<START>
Wall
Street
would
like
UAL
Corp.
's
board
to
change

about
keeping
the
company
independent
.
<END>
<START>
But

next

may

more
on

company

:

.

<START>

$
6.79

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
As

result
,

may
now
have

UAL

.
<END>
<START>
``
United

have

,
''

,

's

.
<END>

-RCB-

,

've

no

and
that
's
a

to
be
looking

.
''
<END>
<START>
Another
reason
:
Emboldened
by
their
success
in
helping
to
scuttle
the
previous
transaction
,
the
machinists
are
likely
to

more

if

.
<END>
<START>
The
two

already
had
significant
leverage
simply
because
their
employer
has
yet
to
settle
with
either
on
new

.
<END>
<START>
That
gives
them
both
the
threat
of
a

and
the
ability
to
resist
any
wage
concessions
that
may

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Nye
thinks

UAL

should
be
ousted
if
it
does
n't
move
soon
to
increase

.
<END>
<START>
Both

and
machinists
have
made
it
clear
that
they
intend
to
block
any
transaction
they
do
n't

.
<END>
<START>
``
The

will
be

in
any

that
takes

around
here
,
''
pilot
union

Frederick

declared
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
But

pilots
can
team
up
with
their
longtime

,
the
machinists
,
is
another

.
<END>
<START>
The
pilots
'
Mr.
Dubinsky
says
his
union
would
like
majority

for
employees
.
<END>
<START>
At

very
least
,
the
pilots
want
some
form

control
over
the
airline
,
perhaps
through
super-majority

.
<END>
<START>
On
the
other
hand
,
the
machinists
have
always
opposed
majority
ownership
in
principle
,
saying
they
do
n't

should
be
owners
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
in
recent
days
,
machinists
'
union
leaders
have
shown
some
new
flexibility
.
<END>
<START>
If
a

ca
n't
be
reached
,
the
pilots
maintain
they
can
do
a
transaction
without
the
support
of
the
machinists
.
<END>
<START>
But
at
this
point
,

may
just
be

.
<END>
<START>
The
machinists
lobbied

against
the
original

from
UAL
pilots
and
management
for
the
company
.
<END>
<START>
Their

.
<END>
<START>
The

'

on

also

.
<END>
<START>
``

'

?
''

,

.
<END>
<START>
``
Who

--

?
''
she

.
<END>
<START>
Ms.

involving
employee

would
succeed
only
if
the
pilots

<START>

.

15

.

,

.

.

.

.

'

.
