WHO
'S
NEWS
:
<END>
<START>
Michael
T.
Carr
,
advertising
director
of
Playboy
magazine
,
was
named
publisher
of
National
Lampoon
and
Heavy
Metal
magazines
,
succeeding
George
Agoglia
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
the
first
management
change
since
film-makers
Daniel
Grodnik
and
Tim
Matheson
took
control
of
National
Lampoon
Inc.
in
March
.
<END>
<START>
They
are
looking
for
a
new
editor
for
National
Lampoon
and
are
trying
to
sell
Heavy
Metal
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
quarter
a
year
ago
,
Columbia
reported
earnings
of
$
16.3
million
,
or
37
cents
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Total
assets
increased
to
$
12.7
billion
in
the
latest
quarter
from
$
12.4
billion
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Columbia
owes
its
spectacular
growth
in
recent
years
to
its
junk-bond
portfolio
,
the
largest
of
any
U.S.
thrift
.
<END>
<START>
Much
of
Columbia
's
junk-bond
trading
has
been
done
through
the
high-yield
department
of
its
Beverly
Hills
neighbor
,
Drexel
Burnham
Lambert
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
The
results
include
a
$
130.2
million
write-down
of
the
securities
in
the
high-yield
portfolio
to
the
lower
of
their
cost
or
market
value
.
<END>
<START>
On
June
30
,
loss
reserves
stood
at
$
108.3
million
.
<END>
<START>
Thrift
officials
said
the
$
300
million
reserve
will
be
adjusted
quarterly
and
will
reflect
the
rate
of
dispositions
and
market
conditions
.
<END>
<START>
The
adjustments
result
from
the
recently
passed
thrift-industry
bailout
legislation
,
which
requires
thrifts
to
divest
all
high-yield
bond
investments
by
1994
.
<END>
<START>
Previously
,
Columbia
did
n't
have
to
adjust
the
book
value
of
its
junk-bond
holdings
to
reflect
declines
in
market
prices
,
because
it
held
the
bonds
as
long-term
investments
.
<END>
<START>
Because
Columbia
now
must
sell
the
bonds
within
five
years
,
accounting
rules
require
the
thrift
to
value
the
bonds
at
the
lower
of
cost
or
market
prices
.
<END>
<START>
For
its
future
strategy
,
Columbia
officials
said
the
thrift
may
branch
out
into
commercial
lending
or
managing
outside
investments
,
as
well
as
beefing
up
more
traditional
thrift
activities
.
<END>
<START>
The
quarterly
results
also
reflected
$
21.4
million
in
non-recurring
losses
from
commercial
real-estate
activities
in
California
.
<END>
<START>
Thomas
Spiegel
,
Columbia
's
chairman
,
said
in
a
statement
that
the
thrift
was
``
disappointed
''
by
the
effects
of
the
accounting
changes
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
said
Columbia
remains
``
one
of
the
most
strongly
capitalized
thrifts
in
the
industry
,
''
based
on
the
economic
value
of
its
assets
and
tangible
capital
.
<END>
<START>
Columbia
announced
the
results
after
the
close
of
the
stock
market
.
<END>
<START>
Its
shares
closed
at
$
5.125
each
in
composite
New
York
Stock
Exchange
trading
,
down
37.5
cents
.
<END>
<START>
The
stock
's
decline
accelerated
in
the
past
two
weeks
,
from
a
price
of
$
8
a
share
on
Oct.
9
.
<END>
<START>
Its
ratio
of
tangible
equity
to
total
assets
as
of
Sept.
30
was
3.6
%
,
and
total
equity
was
$
457.9
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
thrift
emphasized
that
it
has
a
large
portfolio
of
equity
securities
issued
in
connection
with
corporate
restructurings
and
leveraged
buy-outs
,
which
has
a
book
value
of
$
90
million
.
<END>
<START>
Columbia
also
has
unrealized
gains
in
its
public
equity
securities
portfolio
of
more
than
$
70
million
.
<END>
<START>
David
B.
Hilder
in
New
York
contributed
to
this
article
.
<END>
<START>
Anheuser-Busch
Cos.
said
it
plans
to
aggressively
discount
its
major
beer
brands
,
setting
the
stage
for
a
potentially
bruising
price
war
as
the
maturing
industry
's
growth
continues
to
slow
.
<END>
<START>
Anheuser
,
the
world
's
largest
brewer
and
U.S.
market
leader
,
has
historically
been
reluctant
to
engage
in
price-cutting
as
a
means
of
boosting
sales
volume
.
<END>
<START>
With
the
passing
of
the
heady
days
of
swelling
industry
sales
,
however
,
the
once-sporadic
and
brief
forays
into
discounting
are
becoming
standard
competitive
weapons
in
the
beer
industry
.
<END>
<START>
Over
the
summer
,
Anheuser
competitors
offered
more
and
deeper

than
industry
observers
have
seen
for
a
long

.
<END>
<START>

now
predict

's
entry
into

fray

near-term

trouble
for

.
<END>
<START>

said

's

policy
basically
would

matching

by
rivals
on

basis
.

,

's

2.34
billion
.

.

.

.

.
''

the
costs
for
German
industry
.
<END>
<START>
The
market
also
shrugged
off
positive
factors
,
such
as
higher
bond
prices
and
a
slowdown
in
monetary
growth
in
September
,
traders
said
.
<END>
<START>
They
said
they
expect
the
bearish
mood
to
persist
a
while
longer
,
as
trading
volume
is
falling
toward
the
end
of
the
year
and
the
market
is
becoming
more
volatile
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
auto
sector
,
Bayerische
Motoren
Werke
plunged
14.5
marks
to
529
marks
-LRB-
$
288
-RRB-
,
Daimler-Benz
dropped
10.5
to
700
,
and
Volkswagen
slumped
9
to
435.5
.
<END>
<START>
Continental
gave
up

of

recent

,

8
to
338
,
as

of
an
impending

for
the
tiremaker
faded
,

said
.
<END>
<START>
Deutsche
Bank
plummeted
12
to
645
,
hurt
by
the

mood
.
<END>
<START>
Other

were
slightly
more

,

4.8
to
320
,

2.5
to
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,

unnerved

.

<START>
Share

closed

,

,

,

,

in

.
<END>
<START>

,

closed
lower
in

,
Seoul
,
Hong

,
Manila
,

and

.
<END>
<START>
Trading

.
<END>
<START>
Here
are
price

on
the
world
's

markets
,
as

by
Morgan
Stanley
Capital
International

,

.
<END>
<START>
To

,

is
based

the
close
of
1969
equaling
100
.
<END>
<START>
The
percentage
change
is
since

.
<END>
<START>
French

,

.

.

<START>
The
231-191
roll

illustrates

a

.

<START>

,

.

.

<START>
The
New
York
Stock
Exchange
is
expected
to
launch
its
own
program
trading
vehicle
today
,
just
as
controversy
over
this
trading
strategy
heats
up
.
<END>
<START>
The
Big
Board
this
morning
plans
to
begin
trading
its
Exchange
Stock
Portfolio
``
basket
''
product
,
the
first
program-trading
vehicle
carrying
the
exchange
's
seal
of
approval
.
<END>
<START>
ESPs
will
allow
institutional
investors
to
buy
or
sell
all
500
stocks
in
Standard
&
Poor
's
index
in
a
single
trade
of
a
minimum
of
$
5
million
.
<END>
<START>
``
Customized
''
baskets
of
fewer
stocks
will
also
be
available
.
<END>
<START>
The
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
gave
provisional
six-month
approval
to
the
Big
Board
basket
at
a
meeting
late
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
The
SEC
at
the
same
time
approved
a
similar
but
smaller
basket
product
on
the
Chicago
Board
Options
Exchange
,
where
the
minimum
will
be
$
1.7
million
.
<END>
<START>
Also
approved
was
a
plan
to
trade
stock
portfolios
by
computer
after
regular
hours
on
the
Midwest
Stock
Exchange
.
<END>
<START>
But
Richard
Ketchum
,
the
SEC
's
market
regulation
chief
,
said
he
did
n't
believe
``
this
will
spawn
dramatic
new
program-trading
strategies
that
will
be
destabilizing
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
Big
Board
argues
that
its
new
product
will
help
rather
than
hurt
the
situation
by
possibly
drawing
business
from
more-volatile
forms
of
program
trading
.
<END>
<START>
ESPs
are
also
an
attempt
by
the
Big
Board
to
head
off
the
exodus
of
program
trading
business
to
overseas
markets
such
as
London
.
<END>
<START>
Big
Board
officials
also
hope
Japanese
investors
will
become
interested
in
the
exchange
's
product
.
<END>
<START>
Already
,
many
of
the
Big
Board
's
own
floor
traders
are
warning
that
the
ESP
baskets
are
risky
and
not
in
the
best
interests
of
the
investing
public
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
New
York
Stock
Exchange
is
losing
its
cool
here
,
''
said
James
Andrews
,
head
of
institutional
trading
at
Janney
Montgomery
Scott
Inc.
in
Philadelphia
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
stock
baskets
``
are
going
to
make
it
easier
for
program
trading
to
be
done
.
<END>
<START>
And
it
's
going
to
be
done
more
frequently
as
the
result
of
having
more
access
to
it
at
different
places
.
''
<END>
<START>
Both
the
Big
Board
's
Exchange
Stock
Portfolio
and
the
Chicago
exchange
's
Market
Basket
are
designed
for
institutional
investors
.
<END>
<START>
The
Big
Board
lists
its
targets
as
pension
plans
,
mutual
fund
managers
and
index-arbitrage
traders
.
<END>
<START>
In
index
arbitrage
,
program
traders
buy
and
sell
stocks
and
stock-index
futures
to
profit
from
small
price
discrepancies
between
the
markets
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
same
time
,
only
four
securities
firms
have
signed
up
with
the
Big
Board
to
buy
and
sell
ESPs
as
market
makers
,
an
unenthusiastic
response
.
<END>
<START>
The
market
makers
so
far
are
CS
First
Boston
Group
's
First
Boston
Corp.
unit
,
Morgan
Stanley
&
Co.
,
PaineWebber
Group
Inc.
and
Salomon
Inc.
's
Salomon
Brothers
Inc.
unit
.
<END>
<START>
Similarly
,
the
Big
Board
hopes
to
entice
Merrill
Lynch
&
Co
.
<END>
<START>
Neither
has
plans
to
be
a
market
maker
for
now
.
<END>
<START>
Traders
said
major
securities
firms
are
reluctant
to
become
market
makers
because
they
fear
the
baskets
may
attract
only
limited
trading
.
<END>
<START>
Big
Board
officials
say
only
25
contracts
a
day
may
trade
at
first
,
equivalent
to
a
day
's
action
at
a
small
,
regional
exchange
.
<END>
<START>
With
the
futures
locked
into
a
trading
halt
Oct.
13
and
trading
in
some
individual
stock
difficult
,
program
traders
would
have
undoubtedly
fled
to
the
basket
system
,
the
traders
say
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
we
had
the
baskets
,
we
would
be
leaving
in
caskets
,
''
one
trader
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
SEC
's
Mr.
Breeden
said
the
after-hours
trading
on
the
Midwest
exchange
would
help
the
U.S.
win
back
business
that
has
moved
overseas
to
conduct
after-hours
trades
.
<END>

<START>
In

,

Robertson
closed
at
$
11.625
,

.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
terms
of
the
settlement
,
the
limited
partners
would
drop
their
civil
suits
against
Drexel
,
now
pending
in
federal
court
in
New
York
,
another

said
.
<END>
<START>
Attorneys
involved
in
the
talks
said
that
the
parties
were
closer
to
accord
than
they
were
a
year
ago
,
when
reports
of
an
imminent
agreement
circulated
.
<END>
<START>
One
individual
said
the
shareholders
'
accord
was
``
well
worked
out
.
''
<END>
<START>
However
,
less
optimistic
attorneys
warned
that
because
of
the
tangle
of
numerous
defendants
and
plaintiffs
with
overlapping
claims
,
there
is
always
the
possibility
that
the
talks
will
again
fall
apart
.
<END>
<START>
The
plaintiffs
are
investors
who
bought
and
sold
securities
in
which
Mr.
Boesky
and
his
partnerships
were
dealing
.
<END>
<START>
Some
claim
they
suffered
losses
because
they
sold
while
he
was
buying
and
others
because
they
bought
while
he
was
selling
.
<END>
<START>
Stocks
involved
in
the
shareholder
suits
include
Union
Carbide
,
RJR
Nabisco
,
American
Natural
Resources
,
Boise
Cascade
Corp.
,
General
Foods
Corp.
,
Houston
Natural
Gas
and
FMC
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
at
least
27
class-action
shareholder
suits
that
have
been
consolidated
in
federal
court
in
New
York
under
U.S.
District
Judge
Milton
Pollack
.
<END>
<START>
Charles
Davidow
,
of
the
Washington
,
D.C.-based
law
firm
Wilmer
,
Cutler
&
Pickering
,
which
represents

Boesky
in
this
matter
,
said
only
that
``
discussions
are
under
way
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
no
agreements
yet
.
''
<END>
<START>
Out
of
this
,
the
government
set
up
a
$
50
million
fund
for
plaintiffs
who
can
prove
their

losses
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
William
Orbe
,
an

at
Grais
&
Richards
,
the
escrow
agents
for
the
fund
,
as
of
Sept.
30
the
fund
amounted
to
$
60.5
million
.
<END>
<START>
Separately
,

for
the
42
or
so
limited
partners
have
had
serious
discussions
that
could
lead
to
the
distribution

's

.
<END>
<START>
The
limited

include
insurance

,

institutions
and
individual
investors
.
<END>
<START>
An
agreement
with
Drexel
regarding
the
limited
partners
'
investments
is
an
essential
step
toward
getting
their
money
back
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
because
a
Delaware
court
earlier
this
year
said
that
Drexel
is
entitled
to
get
its
money
back
before
or
at
the
same
time
as
the
limited
partners
.
<END>
<START>
Drexel
is
owed
$
20
million
by
the
partnership
.
<END>
<START>
JAILED
AFRICAN-AMERICAN
activist
wins
a
battle
against
the
<END>
<START>
U.S.
District
Judge
Robert
P.
Patterson
Jr.
ordered
the
FBI
to
immediately
begin
processing
Herman
Benjamin
Ferguson
's
request
for
documents
stemming
from
the
agency
's
investigation
of
him
during
the
1960s
.
<END>
<START>
The
FBI
had
said
it
would
not
be
able
to
begin
processing
the
request
until
June
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Ferguson
,
who
is
68
years
old
,
fled
the
U.S.
in
1970
after
exhausting
his
appeals
of
a
1968
conviction
on
conspiracy
to
murder
.
<END>
<START>
He
turned
himself
in
to
authorities
in
New
York
earlier
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
He
maintains
that
the
information
from
the
FBI
will
help
him
get
his
1968
conviction
vacated
and
his
bail-jumping
indictment
dismissed
.
<END>
<START>
His
attorneys
claim
he
was
framed
by
the
FBI
and
New
York
police
as
part
of
a
campaign
to
destroy
the
black
liberation
movement
of
the
1960s
.
<END>
<START>
But
in
federal
court
in
Manhattan
,
Judge
Patterson
said
the
FBI
records
could
show
that
Mr.
Ferguson
's
arrest
was
the
result
of
questionable
legal
practices
.
<END>
<START>
Gabriel
W.
Gorenstein
,
the
assistant
U.S.
attorney
handling
the
case
for
the
FBI
,
said
no
decision
has
been
made
about
appealing
the
judge
's
ruling
.
<END>
<START>
FEDERAL
COURTS
URGED
to
cut
costs
and
reduce
delays
of
civil
suits
.
<END>
<START>
The
study
,
conducted
by
a
task
force
of
the
Brookings
Institution
,
suggests
that
Congress
should
require
the
courts
to
develop
the
plans
.
<END>
<START>
The
study
was
initiated
by
Senate
Judiciary
Committee
chairman
Joseph
Biden
-LRB-
D.
,
Del
.
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
Complex
cases
,
such
as
antitrust
suits
and
many
business
disputes
,
would
receive
intense
supervision
by
federal
judges
to
keep
pretrial
proceedings
moving
.
<END>
<START>
Standard
cases
would
require
less
judicial
attention
,
and
fast-track
cases
could
be
resolved
quickly
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
study
said
federal
courts
should
set
firm
trial
dates
early
in
the
process
.
<END>
<START>
Although
some
of
the
study
's
recommendations
resemble
those
of
similar
projects
,
the
makeup
of
the
task
force
was
unusually
diverse
,
adding
significance
to
the
effort
.
<END>
<START>
It
included
lawyers
from
civil
rights
and
consumer
groups
,
plaintiffs
'
lawyers
and
defense
attorneys
,
corporate
counsel
and
law
professors
.
<END>
<START>
Businessland
Inc.
said
it

,

Computer
Centre
Inc.
,

,

.

.

.

.

10

.

,

.
<END>

.

.

,

.

<START>

.

<START>

,

<START>
GRAINS
AND
SOYBEANS
:
<END>
<START>
Soybean
and
corn
futures
prices
moved
higher
on
the
strength
of
buying
from
commodity
pool
managers
trying
to
profit
from
technical
price
trends
,
as
well
as
continued
export
strength
.
<END>
<START>
A
leveling
off
of
farmer
selling
tied
to
the
harvest
also
removed
some
of
the
downward
pressure
on
futures
contract
prices
.
<END>
<START>
Wheat
futures
prices
fell
,
however
,
at
least

in
reaction
to
the
rumored
selling
of
futures

equal

of

by

Richard
Dennis
.
<END>
<START>
Neither

Dennis
nor

,

,
could

for

.
<END>
<START>

for

gained
5.25
cents
a

to
close
at
$
5.66
a

on

Chicago

of
Trade
.
<END>
<START>

added
2.25
cents
a
bushel
to
close
at
$
2.4225
a
bushel
on
the
Board
of
Trade
.
<END>
<START>

and

from

.
<END>
<START>

Soviet

has

eight
million
tons
of
grain
this
month
,
and
is
expected
to
take

by

,

said
.
<END>
<START>
COTTON
:
<END>
<START>
Futures
prices
rose
modestly
,
but
trading
volume
was
n't
very
heavy
.
<END>
<START>
The
December
contract
settled
at
73.97
cents
a
pound
,
up
0.59
cent
,
but
it
rose
as
high
as
74.20
cents
.
<END>
<START>
Several
cotton
analysts
said
that
the
move
appeared
to
be
mostly
technical
.
<END>
<START>
Traders
who
had
sold
contracts
earlier
,
in
hopes
of
buying
them
back
at
lower
prices
,
yesterday
were
buying
contracts
back
at
higher
prices
to
limit
their
losses
.
<END>
<START>
Floor
traders
also
said
that
the
market
could
have
been
helped
by
rumors
,
which
have
been
circulating
for
the
past
two
days
,
about
China
purchasing
cotton
.
<END>
<START>
The
rumor
,
which
has
been
neither
confirmed
nor
denied
,
has
China
buying
125,000
to
200,000
bales
for
near-term
delivery
.
<END>
<START>
One
floor
trader
said
that
if
there
were
Chinese
purchases
,
they
should
have
had
a
bigger
effect
on
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
Another
said
that
if
China
was
a
buyer
,
it
would
be
the
earliest
that
country
had
made
purchases
since
the
1979-80
crop
year
,
and
thus
would
be
a
bullish
sign
.
<END>
<START>
This
trader
said
that
he
thought
the
market
would
turn
aggressively
bullish
from
a
technical
standpoint
if
the
December
contract
was
able
to
exceed
75.75
cents
.
<END>
<START>
He
also
noted
that
stocks
on
Aug.
1
,
1990
,
are
currently
projected
at
3.3
million
bales
,
the
smallest
end-of-season
supply
since
1985
.
<END>
<START>
COCOA
:
<END>
<START>
The
modest
sell-off
,
which
started
on
Tuesday
,
continued
.
<END>
<START>
The
December
contract
ended
at
$
999
a
metric
ton
,
down
$
15
.
<END>
<START>
The
market
is

,
at
least

,
because
of
a
lack
of
crop
information
out
of
Ghana
and

Ivory
Coast
,

largest
African

.
<END>
<START>
By
this

last
year
,
he
noted
,
arrivals
totaling
33,270
tons
had
been
announced
.
<END>
<START>
A
similar
situation
apparently
exists
in
the
Ivory
Coast
with
no
figures
released
yet
this
year
,
compared
with
55,000
tons
as
of
this
time
a
year
ago
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
that
if
little
cocoa
actually
has
arrived
at
the
ports
,
shipping
delays
could
result
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
the
worry
that
probably
brought

to
the
market
earlier
in
the
week
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>

,
the
French
merchant
has
about
200,000

of
old

Ivory

from

.

,

,

to

,

,

.

.

<START>

,

.

<START>

.
<END>

.

<START>

.
<END>

.

<START>

.

<START>

.
<END>
<START>
Mission

Partners
lost
5
1/4
to
14
1/8
.
<END>
<START>

,

had

,

but

for

.
<END>
<START>
Japan
is
going
on
a
capital-spending
binge
that
could
make
its
trade
surpluses
even
harder
to
shrink
.
<END>
<START>
The
more
factories
and
robots
Japanese
manufacturers
add
,
the
more
they
will
be
able
to
export
,
and
the
less
their
domestic
customers
will
need
to
import
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
building
,
among
other
things
,
a
new
laser-beam-printer
factory
in
western
Japan
that
can
produce
up
to
150,000
printers
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
Some
70
%
of
them
are
to
be
exported
to
the
U.S.
.
<END>
<START>
Even
companies
in
smokestack
industries
wrestling
with
world-wide
overcapacity
are
joining
the
boom
.
<END>
<START>
Japan
's
steelmakers
are
raising
capital
spending
22
%
this
year
to
$
4.8
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Hitachi
Zosen
Corp.
,
a
shipbuilder
buried
in
debt
just
a
few
years
ago
,
will
build
a
machinery
plant
,
its
first
expansion
in
14
years
.
<END>
<START>
From
a
financial
standpoint
,
the
boom
could
n't
come
at
a
better
time
.
<END>
<START>
Many
Japanese
companies
expect
record
profits
this
fiscal
year
,
and
Japanese
interest
rates
,
though
up
a
bit
recently
,
are
still
low
.
<END>
<START>
And
in
a
business
system
where
shareholders
have
few
rights
and
expect
only
modest
dividends
,
companies
can
plow
their
profits
back
into
plant
and
equipment
.
<END>
<START>
But
some
economists
and
government
officials
here
are
n't
applauding
.
<END>
<START>
They
fear
that
the
boom
may
be
too
big
for
Japan
's
or
anyone
else
's
good
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
an
explosive
cocktail
''
thrown
at
the
world
,
says
Kenneth
Courtis
,
senior
economist
at
the
Tokyo
unit
of
Deutsche
Bank
Group
.
<END>
<START>
The
Ministry
of
International
Trade
and
Industry
is
so
concerned
that
it
recently
took
the
unusual
step
of
urging
Japanese
auto
companies
to
exercise
caution
in
capital
spending
.
<END>
<START>
MITI
officials
hope
to
avoid
yet-another
source
of
trade
friction
with
the
U.S.
even
though
export
restraints
currently
limit
Japanese
car
exports
to
the
U.S.
.
<END>
<START>
Not
everyone
is
worried
,
however
.
<END>
<START>
Some
economists
--
and
many
Japanese
companies
--
are
puzzled
by
the
warnings
.
<END>
<START>
The
investment
boom
is
mainly
sparked
,
they
say
,
by
strong
domestic
demand
and
is
n't
likely
to
increase
exports
sharply
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
much
investment
is
n't
aimed
at
increasing
capacity
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
worriers
remain
unconvinced
.
<END>
<START>
With
Japan
running
enormous
trade
surpluses
against
much
of
the
world
,
they
think
that
Japan
should
meet
the
increased
domestic
demand
by
importing
more
.
<END>
<START>
And
eventually
,
they
contend
,
domestic
demand
will
weaken
,
forcing
companies
to
emphasize
exports
again
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
there
's
a
further
drive
to
export
,
''
says
Nobuyuki
Arai
,
an
economist
at
the
Japan
Development
Bank
,
``
that
'll
be
a
problem
.
''
<END>
<START>
Even
in
the
short
run
,
the
investment
boom
could
exacerbate
a
disturbing
trend
:
Japanese
exports
are
showing
surprisingly
little
tendency
to
ease
.
<END>
<START>
Japanese
auto
makers
,
for
example
,
are
increasing
their
production
capacity
in
the
U.S.
;
the
additional
production
should
,
in
part
,
replace
imported
vehicles
with
locally
manufactured
ones
.
<END>
<START>
In
contrast
to
previous
economic
booms
,
Japanese
auto
companies
are
n't
just
trying
to
boost
production
.
<END>
<START>
Many
are
pouring
money
into
developing
high-quality
products
to
target
affluent
consumers
and
,
to
some
extent
,
to
avoid
direct
combat
with
cheaper
cars
from
South
Korea
and
Taiwan
.
<END>
<START>
Others
are
replacing
older
facilities
with
flexible
assembly
lines
on
which
different
models
can
be
turned
out
at
once
.
<END>
<START>
So
many
companies
are
investing
in
high-tech
machinery
that
Fanuc
Ltd.
,
a
robot
maker
,
also
had
to
build
a
new
plant
.
<END>
<START>
The
buildup
is
``
making
Japan
clearly
more
efficient
,
more
technologically
advanced
and
more
competitive
,
''
declares
a
Western
diplomat
in
Tokyo
.
<END>
<START>
But
whatever
its
effects
on
exports
and
imports
,
Japan
's
investment
boom
during
the
past
two
years
has
been
stimulated
at
least
partly
by
soaring
domestic
demand
.
<END>
<START>
Japanese
consumers
are
increasingly
eager
to
spend
their
money
,
especially
on
high-priced
goods
such
as
29-inch
television
sets
and
luxury
cars
.
<END>
<START>
Nissan
Motor
Co.
's
domestic
auto
sales
are
up
20
%
this
year
largely
because
its
expensive
Cima
,
Sylvia
and
Cefiro
models
are
in
heavy
demand
.
<END>
<START>
``
One
dealer
told
me
that
if
he
had
more
cars
,
he
'd
sell
them
right
away
,
''
says
Takuro
Endo
,
Nissan
executive
vice
president
.
<END>
<START>
He
adds
that
the
company
is
trying
to
keep
up
with
demand
``
by
overworking
''
its
employees
.
<END>
<START>
Similarly
,
Honda
Motor
Co.
's
sales
are
so
brisk
that
workers
grumble
they
have
n't
had
a
Saturday
off
in
years
,
despite
the
government
's
encouragement
of
more
leisure
activity
.
<END>
<START>
With
demand
growing
and
workers
in
short
supply
,
many
Japanese
manufacturers
are
spending
heavily
on
automation
.
<END>
<START>
Sasebo
Heavy
Industries
Co.
,
a
medium-sized
shipbuilder
,
expects
its
sales
to
increase
30
%
this
year
,
largely
because
of
rising
demand
for
oil
tankers
.
<END>
<START>
Once
one
Japanese
company
steps
up
its
investments
,
the
whole
industry
follows
.
<END>
<START>
Because
most
businesses
put
market
share
above
profitability
,
to
let
a
competitor
's
addition
to
capacity
go
unmatched
is
to
concede
defeat
.
<END>
<START>
The
emphasis
on
market
share
is
evident
at
Daikin
Industries
Ltd.
,
Japan
's
biggest
maker
of
industrial
air
conditioners
.
<END>
<START>
Seeing
new
office
buildings
sprout
up
and
its
sales
soar
,
Daikin
is
building
another
plant
,
which
will
lift
its
production
capacity
50
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
expansion
is
aimed
not
just
at
meeting
demand
but
also
at
expanding
the
company
's
market
share
to
30
%
from
27
%
currently
.
<END>
<START>
Besides
,
Daikin
's
major
competitors
,
Hitachi
Ltd.
and
Mitsubishi
Heavy
Industries
Ltd.
,
``
are
all
adding
production
lines
,
''
a
Daikin
spokesman
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
Until
now
,
we
were
trying
to
increase
productivity
with
the
facilities
we
already
had
.
<END>
<START>
But
we
ca
n't
produce
enough
anymore
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
competition
is
even
more
heated
in
the
auto
industry
,
where
companies
are
racing
one
another
in
a
world-wide
market
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
Toyota
Motor
Corp.
's
$
247
million
buildup
is
increasing
its
annual
capacity
by
180,000
cars
,
and
Honda
is
spending
$
317
million
on
expansion
.
<END>
<START>
Mazda
Motor
Corp.
is
still
considering
its
options
,
but
it
boldly
aims
to
double
its
annual
domestic
sales
to
800,000
cars
in
the
next
four
years
.
<END>
<START>
Those
who
are
n't
worried
about
how
Japanese
manufacturers
'
investments
will
affect
trade
note
that
many
new
products
are
n't
replacements
for
imports
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
much
of
the
investment
boom
is
in
high-tech
fields
in
which
Japanese
companies
have
only
limited
foreign
competition
;
so
,
more
investment
practically
assures
more
exports
.
<END>
<START>
Toshiba
Corp.
,
for
example
,
is
spending
$
986
million
on
two
new
plants
to
build
four-megabit
dynamic
random
access
memories
,
the
next
generation
of
computer
chips
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
important
to
gain
leadership
,
''
a
Toshiba
spokesman
says
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
Toshiba
's
Japanese
rivals
,
Hitachi
,
Fujitsu
Ltd.
and
NEC
Corp.
,
are
n't
sitting
still
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
chip
plants
``
wo
n't
be
excessive
investment
,
''
says
Hajime
Sasaki
,
an
NEC
vice
president
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
have
enough
products
to
make
and
the
markets
to
sell
these
products
.
''
<END>
<START>
Some
of
Japan
's
goods
being
produced
as
a
result
of
the
investment
boom
are
already
successful
overseas
.
<END>
<START>
Toyota
plans
to
raise
Lexus
exports
when
a
new
plant
starts
up
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
What
if
its
sales
weaken
someday
?
<END>
<START>
Japanese
companies
have
a
caveat
competitor
attitude
.
<END>
<START>
If
excess
capacity
develops
,
they
say
,
not
everyone
will
suffer
.
<END>
<START>
The
losers
will
be
those
with
the
least
attractive
products
,
and
many
of
them
,
analysts
think
,
will
be
foreign
companies
.
<END>
<START>
The
Portland
,
Ore.
,
thrift
said
the

should
help
it
meet
new
capital
standards
from
the
Financial
Institution
Reform
,
Recovery
and

Act
.
<END>

,

Franklin
had

$
1.8

,

.
<END>
<START>

yesterday
,

Franklin

25
cents
to
$
4.25
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
the

's

will
feature
a

and

.
<END>
<START>

plan
may
include

,

or
eliminating
departments
,
and
winding
down
or
disposing
of

units
within
18

.
<END>
<START>

,
the
company
said
it
will
close
its

,
and

at

.
<END>
<START>
Details
of
the

wo
n't
be

until

approve
the

by
the
new

,

.
<END>
<START>
Net

fell
37
%

,

30

,

,

,

.

.

<START>
Amdahl
's

.

.

.

,

.

.

<START>
Federal
health
officials
are
expected
today
to
approve
a
program
granting
long-deferred
access
to
the
drug
AZT
for
children
with
acquired
immune
deficiency
syndrome
.
<END>
<START>
Announcement
of
the
approval
is
expected
to
be
made
by
Louis
Sullivan
,
secretary
of
Health
and
Human
Services
.
<END>
<START>
The
drug
will
be
given
treatment
investigational
new
drug
status
,
a
label
accorded
to
drugs
believed
effective
but
lacking
formal
approval
.
<END>
<START>
The
move
will
make
the
drug
available
free
of
charge
for
a
time
to
children
with
the
disease
and
symptoms
of
advanced
infection
.
<END>
<START>
Adults
with
AIDS
have
had
access
to
AZT
since
FDA
approved
the
drug
's
usage
for
adults
in
March
1987
.
<END>
<START>
But
despite
more
than
two
years
of
research
showing
AZT
can
relieve
dementia
and
other
symptoms
in
children
,
the
drug
still
lacks
federal
approval
for
use
in
the
youngest
patients
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
many
youngsters
have
been
unable
to
obtain
the
drug
and
,
for
the
few
exceptions
,
insurance
carriers
wo
n't
cover
its
cost
of
$
6,400
a
year
.
<END>
<START>
So
far
,
AIDS
has
stricken
1,859
children
under
age
13
,
with
many
times
that
number
believed
to
carry
the
infection
without
symptoms
.
<END>
<START>
To
date
,
1,013
of
those
children
have
died
,
according
to
the
federal
Centers
for
Disease
Control
.
<END>
<START>
Mothers
of
young
AIDS
patients
expressed
somber
satisfaction
.
<END>
<START>
``
Thank
goodness
it
's
happening
.
<END>
<START>
One
of
them
,
a
daughter
Ariel
,
died
a
year
ago
at
age
seven
after
her
parents
unsuccessfully
pleaded
for
the
drug
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
could
get
AZT
,
''
says
Mrs.
Glaser
,
who
bears
her
infection
without
any
symptoms
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
my
daughter
could
n't
,
until
she
was
too
ill
to
take
it
.
<END>
<START>
To
watch
your
child
die
is
an
inhuman
experience
.
''
<END>
<START>
Her
son
,
healthy
and
symptom-free
,
currently
takes
no
medication
.
<END>
<START>
The
delay
in
getting
AZT
to
children
has
been
blamed
on
a
combination
of
factors
.
<END>
<START>
Traditionally
,
the
medical
establishment
has
waited
two
years
to
approve
adult
treatments
for
pediatric
uses
,
because
of
a
combination
of
conservative
safety
standards
and
red
tape
.
<END>
<START>
Wellcome
has
replied
that
it
is
moving
ahead
to
compile
the
relevant
data
,
and
recently
promised
to
develop
a
pediatric
syrup
form
easier
for
youngsters
to
take
.
<END>
<START>
Since
then
,
roughly
50
pediatric
patients
have
received
the
drug
in
his
program
.
<END>
<START>
To
some
mothers
,
the
expected
FDA
action
is
a
poignant
reminder
of
what
might
have
been
.
<END>
<START>
``
My
first
reaction
is
I
do
n't
understand
why
it
's
taken
so
long
.
<END>
<START>
Similar
sentiments
were
voiced
on
Capitol
Hill
.
<END>
<START>
``
While
I
'm
pleased
the
FDA
is
finally
releasing
AZT
for
children
,
it
's
taken
much
too
long
to
get
to
this
point
,
''
said
Rep.
Ted
Weiss
.
<END>
<START>
``
Why
did
it
take
Burroughs
Wellcome
so
long
to
apply
''
for
treatment
investigational
new
drug
status
?
the
New
York
Democrat
asked
.
<END>
<START>
``
Let
's
not
forget
this
is
the
same
company
that
has
been
profiteering
with
this
drug
for
2
1/2
years
,
''
Mr.
Weiss
added
.
<END>
<START>
Mrs.
Glaser
,
who
is
a
co-founder
of
the
Pediatric
AIDS
Foundation
,
based
in
Santa
Monica
,
Calif.
,
condemned
neither
bureaucratic
nor
corporate
foot-dragging
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
's
no
finger
to
be
pointed
,
''
she
said
.
<END>
<START>
AIDS
dementia
--
which
gradually
steals
children
's
ability
to
speak
,
walk
and
think
--
is
often
the
most
striking
aspect
of
the
pediatric
syndrome
.
<END>
<START>
For
some
patients
,
AZT
has
restored
the
ability
to
ride
a
bicycle
or
solve
puzzles
,
giving
back
a
piece
of
their
childhood
if
only
temporarily
.
<END>
<START>
AVON
RENT-A-CAR
&
TRUCK
Corp.
said
it
declared
a
dividend
of
one
warrant
for
each
three
shares
of
common
stock
.
<END>
<START>
Currently
,
Avon
,
based
in
Santa
Monica
,
Calif.
,
has
3.3
million
common
shares
outstanding
.
<END>
<START>

1.1
million

C

were

,

said
.
<END>
<START>

of

Class
C
warrants
will
enable

holders
to

one
share
of
common

at
$
5.50
.
<END>
<START>
The
warrants
may

exercised
until
90
days
after

date
.
<END>
<START>

also

243,677
of

Class
C

to

Class
A
,

B

.
<END>
<START>
Issuance
of
those
warrants
will
be
at
the
rate
of
one-third
warrant
for
each
warrant
exercised
.

<START>
THE
BIG
BOARD
PLANS
to
launch
its
own
vehicle
for
program
trading
today
amid
growing
controversy
over
the
practice
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
``
baskets
''
of
stocks
will
allow
big
investors
to
buy
or
sell
all
500
S&P
index
stocks
in
a
single
trade
.
<END>
<START>
The
exchange
argues
that
the
product
,
which
the
SEC
temporarily
approved
yesterday
,
will
help
ease
rather
than

any

in

.
<END>
<START>
SEC
Chairman
Breeden
said

would
consider
imposing
``
circuit
breakers
''
to
halt
program
trading
during
sharp
swings
in
the
market
.

because

,

.

.

.

<START>
Columbia

posted

quarterly
loss
of
$
226.3
million
as
the
Beverly
Hills
thrift
reeled
from
new
industry
rules
and

in

bonds
.
<END>
<START>

,

.

.

<START>
Dun
&
Bradstreet
Corp.
said
business
failures
fell
17.8
%
to
11,586
in
the
third
quarter
from
14,099
in
the
year-earlier
period
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
first
nine
months
of
this
year
,
business
failures
dropped
15.6
%
to
37,820
from
44,796
.
<END>
<START>
Except
for
a
few
spots
,
notably
Georgia
,
Virginia
and
Michigan
,
failures
declined
almost
across
the
board
,
according
to
the
business
information
services
company
.
<END>
<START>
D&B
defines
a
business
failure
as
a
company
that
closes
with
losses
to
creditors
.
<END>
<START>
The
current
decline
in
failures
continues
a
trend
begun
in
late
1987
,
D&B
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
drop
accelerated
in
this
year
's
third
quarter
,
underscoring
an
overall
lack
of
stress
in
the
U.S.
economy
,
the
company
said
.
<END>
<START>
Failures
in
seven
of
nine
regional
areas
fell
more
than
10
%
in
the
nine
months
.
<END>
<START>
The
South
Atlantic
States
were
the
only
region
to
report
an
increase
in
bankruptcies
,
up
5.3
%
to
5,791
from
5,502
.
<END>
<START>
This
occurred
partly
because
of
more
competition
as
the
number
of
new
businesses
surged
.
<END>
<START>
The
only
industry
sector
to
report
more
business
failures
for
the
nine
months
was
the
finance
,
insurance
and
real-estate
sector
,
where
bankruptcies
grew
8.1
%
to
2,046
from
1,892
.
<END>
<START>
The
troubled
savings-and-loan
industry
and
subsequent
stress
in
real-estate
businesses
fueled
bankruptcies
in
this
sector
,
D&B
said
.
<END>

<START>
McCaw
's

.

.

's
biggest
percentage
gainer
.
<END>
<START>
Star
States
plunged
3
1/4
to
8
3/4
on
207,000
shares
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
suffered
a
$
9
million
loss
in
the
third
quarter
,
compared
with
net
of
$
2.5
million
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Collagen
dropped
2
5/8
to
15
5/8
on
428,000
shares
.
<END>
<START>
Occupational-Urgent
Care
Health
fell
1
3/4
to
15
1/2
on
354,000
shares
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
's
third-quarter
earnings
also
rose
to
10
cents
a
share
from
eight
cents
a
share
a
year
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Companies
listed
below
reported
quarterly
profit
substantially
different
from
the
average
of
analysts
'
estimates
.
<END>
<START>
The
companies
are
followed
by
at
least
three
analysts
,
and
had
a
minimum
five-cent
change
in
actual
earnings
per
share
.
<END>
<START>
Estimated
and
actual
results
involving
losses
are
omitted
.
<END>
<START>
The
percent
difference
compares
actual
profit
with
the
30-day
estimate
where
at
least
three
analysts
have
issues
forecasts
in
the
past
30
days
.
<END>
<START>
Otherwise
,
actual
profit
is
compared
with
the
300-day
estimate
.
<END>
<START>
One
day
last
March
,
CBS
Sports
President
Neal
Pilson
and
Olympics
superagent
Barry
Frank
met
for
lunch
at
the
Lotos
Club
here
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Frank
told
Mr.
Pilson
that
Olympics
officials
wanted
$
290
million
or
more
for
TV
rights
to
the
1994
Winter
Games
in
Norway
.
<END>
<START>
The
CBS
official
said
that
price
sounded
fine
.
<END>
<START>
At
that
price
,
CBS
was
the
only
player
at
the
table
when
negotiations
with
the
International
Olympic
Committee
started
in
Toronto
Aug.
23
.
<END>
<START>
Dick
Pound
,
a
committee
member
,
began
by
disclosing
that
ABC
and
NBC
had
refused
to
even
bid
.
<END>
<START>
Then
,
he
asked
Mr.
Pilson
to
raise
his
offer
anyway
:
``
If
we
can
have
a
number
that
starts
with
a
three
,
you
can
have
a
dea
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Pilson
and
his
team
huddled
in
a
hallway
and
took
just
10
minutes
to
return
with
a
$
300
million
offer
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Pound
responded
,
``
It
's
a
deal
.
''
<END>
<START>
A
beaming
Mr.
Pilson
announced
his
lastest
coup
at
a
news
conference
that
afternoon
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Pilson
's
rivals
at
ABC
and
NBC
grimaced
at
the
price
.
<END>
<START>
How
could
CBS
get
pushed
into
outbidding
itself
?
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Pilson
has
been
put
in
the
uncomfortable
role
of
setting
off
a
bidding
frenzy
for
sports
rights
,
a
frenzy
that
the
networks
had
hoped
to
avoid
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
price
of
poker
has
gone
up
,
''
crows
Charles
M.
Neinas
,
the
College
Football
Association
's
executive
director
.
<END>
<START>
With
CBS
Inc.
on
a
spending
spree
that
may
top
$
2.5
billion
for
four
years
of
major
sports
events
,
the
new
bout
of
hyperinflation
could
jolt
the
entire
broadcast
business
.
<END>
<START>
CBS
itself
could
run
up
losses
of
a
few
hundred
million
dollars
on
four
years
of
various
sports
if
its
big
gamble
goes
wrong
.
<END>
<START>
ABC
,
a
unit
of
Capital
Cities/ABC
Inc.
,
and
General
Electric
Co.
's
National
Broadcasting
Co.
also
risk
losses
if
they
outbid
CBS
for
other
contracts
.
<END>
<START>
While
rights
fees
head
skyward
,
ad
rates
wo
n't
.
<END>
<START>
Advertisers
already
are
balking
at
higher
prices
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
networks
are
paying
too
much
for
rights
,
''
warns
adman
Paul
Isacsson
of
Young
&
Rubicam
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
they
ask
advertisers
to
absorb
the
costs
,
they
're
likely
to
lose
all
but
a
few
who
need
sports
,
above
all
.
''
<END>
<START>
Viewers
may
not
be
cheering
,
either
.
<END>
<START>
Soaring
rights
fees
will
lead
to
an
even
greater
clutter
of
commercials
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
same
time
,
some
sports
events
will
move
off
``
free
''
television
and
onto
cable
or
pay-cable
,
where
half
the
nation
's
TV
homes
ca
n't
see
them
.
<END>
<START>
CBS
has
changed
the
rules
by
throwing
out
the
old
basis
for
sports
bids
--
that
is
,
can
the
network
alone
make
a
profit
on
it
?
<END>
<START>
The
billion-dollar
question
is
,
How
much
are

?
<END>
<START>
Some
TV
people
doubt
they
will
materialize
and
argue
that
even

they
do
,
they
wo
n't
offset
the
multimillion-dollar
deficits
that

could
run
up
.
<END>
<START>
And
three

later
,

of
red
ink
,
the
heroes
can
find
themselves
with

.
''
<END>
<START>
``
They
lost
the

crown
,
and

.
<END>
<START>
And
they
've
bought
one
.
''
<END>
<START>
On

--
for

Olympic
Winter
Games
in
both
1992

--
Pilson
bid

.
<END>
<START>
That
's

were

.
<END>
<START>
Next

,

CBS

,

.
<END>
<START>
CBS
is
likely
to

.
<END>
<START>
The
potential
bill
:
more
than
$
600
million
for

,
an
80
%

.
<END>
<START>
``
What

to

will

of

,
''

,

now

.
<END>
<START>
And

will

the

,

.
<END>
<START>
Nor
,
by
the
way
,
advertisers
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Pilson
is
an
unlikely
big

.
<END>
<START>
In

,
after

had
just

$
309

for

1988

,

for

.
<END>
<START>
``
I

Pilson
,

,
''

,

.
<END>
<START>
``
And
yet
his
company
is
one

why

are
so
high
today
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
the
49-year-old
Mr.
Pilson
is

to

.
<END>
<START>
A
Yale
law

,

in

and
then
put
in

and

.
<END>
<START>

,

to

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.

,
``

,

.
''
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>
``

.
<END>
<START>

?
<END>
<START>
Maybe

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Pilson
's
``

''

jelled

Mr.
Tisch

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Tisch
,

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
That

.
<END>
<START>
The

''

,

,

notch

on

of

.
<END>
<START>
It
's

a
fast
fix
for
an
ailing

.
<END>
<START>
Next

,
CBS
,
for

first

,
wo
n't

to
start

season
against

.
<END>
<START>
``

,
''

Jonathan

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
That
is

.
<END>
<START>
Regular

have

in

,

``

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
But

are

a
strong
bet
to
lure

30
%

40
%

CBS
usually

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Pilson
says
baseball
and

2

,

's

.
<END>
<START>
And

Olympics
will

during

February
``

,
''
when
ratings
are
used
to

.
<END>
<START>
That
will

once-grumpy

--

.
<END>
<START>
They

``

''

.

<START>
CBS

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
``

,
''

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

as

carries
no

,

.
<END>
<START>
No

will
bring

back
if

.
<END>
<START>
``
In
this

,

,
trial
is
n't

,
''
ESPN
's

.
<END>
<START>
``
If
the
show
ai
n't
a

,
they
're

.
''
<END>
<START>
During

1984

Games
,

,

``
Call

,
''
but

military

was
missing

.
<END>
<START>
Last

,

the
1988

Games
,
NBC
relentlessly
pitched
a
new

,
``
Tattingers
.
''
<END>
<START>
It
belly-flopped
anyway
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
sports
is
hardly
the
best
way
to
lure
adult
women
.
<END>
<START>
Though
CBS
might
move

No.
2

,
most

buy
based

for

18

.
<END>
<START>
CBS
may
remain
a

No.
3
in

.
<END>
<START>
Nor

a

to

.
<END>
<START>
In

,

and

were

against

's

.
<END>
<START>
But

will

up

Bill
Cosby
,
``

''
and

in

's

1

.
<END>
<START>
Even

.
<END>
<START>
The

lineup
may
add
only
1
%

5
%
to

's

.
<END>
<START>
It
alone
is
n't
likely

.
<END>
<START>
``
The
World

,
seven

,

,
''

,

.
<END>
<START>
``
You
've

.
''
<END>
<START>

may

if

ca
n't

on

itself
.
<END>
<START>
And

will

.
<END>
<START>
Nevertheless
,

deems

``
plain

''
for

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.

``

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's

''
what

,

.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Tisch
expects
losses
in
all
four

of

,

.
<END>
<START>
CBS
will

82

NBC
had

--

expect

.
<END>
<START>
Yet
CBS
will
air
only
12

,
26
fewer
than
ABC
and
NBC
.
<END>
<START>
That

.
<END>
<START>
It

50

for

--
a

CBS

to

.
<END>
<START>
If

end

,

could

.
<END>
<START>
Advertisers
are
resisting
higher

,
which
would
help
close

.
<END>
<START>
CBS
signed
General

and
Toyota
to
be
the
only

sponsors
in

for

.
<END>
<START>
Price
:

265

.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
``
there
's

ad

will

''

,

.
<END>
<START>
Other

,

,

could
rise
later
if
ad

.
<END>
<START>
The
Winter
Games
outlook
also
is
mixed
.
<END>
<START>
CBS
expects
to
make
modest
profits
,
but
rivals
contend
that
it
will
take
a
beating
.
<END>
<START>
ABC
lost
$
75
million
on
the
1988
Winter
Games
,
partly
because
of
its
$
309
million
rights
fee
.
<END>
<START>
It
aired
94.5
hours
of
mostly

in
Calgary
--
helping
raise
ratings
slightly
from
1984
--
but
still
failed

promised
to

.
<END>
<START>
CBS
will
add
25
1/2

to
that
load
in
1992
,
and

could

.

,

Bosses
have

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
Some
would
make
even
James
Bond
green

.
<END>
<START>
Eavesdropping
--
both
corporate
and
private
--
is
on
the
rise
,
thanks
to
the
proliferation
of
surveillance
technologies
.
<END>
<START>
And
while
sellers
of
the
equipment
and
companies
``
monitoring
''
employees
have
few

,

.
<END>
<START>
``
New

are
changing

,
''

,

.

<START>

Our

of

.
''
<END>
<START>
On
the

,

claim
that
monitoring
employee
phone
conversations
is
both
legal
and
necessary
to
gauge

and

.
<END>
<START>
The
practice
is
common
at

,

and

,

,

and

.
<END>
<START>

in

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
The

,
which

,

listen
in
on

400

each

.
<END>
<START>
Among

they

are

,

,

,

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
Some
Wall
Street
firms
monitor
for

purposes
.
<END>
<START>
Businesses
``
want
to
verify
information
and
ensure

,
''
says
John
Hiltunen
,
Dictaphone
's

.
<END>
<START>
The
state
of
Alaska
recently
bought
the
Veritrac
system
,
he

,
``
to
monitor

Exxon
cleanup

.
''
<END>
<START>
Merrill
Lynch

and

Hutton

say

to

and

between

and

.
<END>
<START>
Shearson
says

,
such

,

.
<END>
<START>
Both

.
<END>
<START>
Kidder

and

to

.
<END>
<START>
Eavesdropping
by
individuals
is
harder
to
measure
.
<END>
<START>
But
devices
are
there
for
the
asking
,
whether
in
stores
or
through

mail
.
<END>
<START>
The
Counter
Spy
Shop
in
Washington
,
D.C.
,
for
instance
,
offers
the
``
Secret
Connection
''
attache
case
,
which
can
surreptitiously
record
conversations
for
nine
hours
at
a

.
<END>
<START>
That
and
other
fancy

may
cost
thousands
,
but
simple

tape
recorders
sell
for
as
little
as
$
70
at

like

.
<END>
<START>
The
most

use
of
spying

is
in

,

.
<END>
<START>
While
tape

to
uncover
,

,
infidelity
are
n't

in

,
they
can
mean
leverage
in

.
<END>
<START>
Concerned
with
the
increased
availability
of
surveillance
technology
and
heavier
use
of
it
,

have
proposed
laws
addressing
the
issue
.
<END>
<START>
Nine
states
have
introduced
bills
requiring
that
workers
and
customers
be
made
aware
of
monitoring
.
<END>
<START>
And
four
states
--
California
,
Florida
,
Michigan
and
Pennsylvania
--
have
adopted
rules
that
all

involved
must
consent
when
phone
calls
are
recorded
.
<END>
<START>
Two
bills
in
Congress
hope
to
make
such
restrictions
national
.
<END>
<START>
In
May
,
Rep.
Don
Edwards
-LRB-
D.
Calif
.
-RRB-
introduced
congressional
legislation
that
would
require
an
audible
beeping
during
any
employee
monitoring
,
warning
people
that
they
are
being
heard
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
The
legislation
is
similar
to
a
1987
``
beeper
bill
''
that
was
defeated
after
heavy
lobbying
by
the
telemarketing
industry
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Also
last
spring
,
Rep.
Ron
Dellums
-LRB-
D.
,
Calif.
-RRB-
,
introduced
a
bill
requiring
universal

consent
to
any
tapings
in
cases
that
do
n't

.
<END>
<START>
In

,

as

would

and

.
<END>
<START>
The

on

is
uncertain
,
especially
remembering
the
1987

.
<END>
<START>
The

back

,
but

and

object
.
<END>
<START>
``
But

only

can

are

.
''
<END>
<START>
The
powerful
group
,
which

the

's

,
was

1987

.
<END>
<START>
Spiegel
also

the

bill
,
saying
the
noise
it
requires
would

,

.
<END>
<START>

.

.

<START>
``
Sometimes
,
''

.
''
<END>
<START>
Federal

recognize

to

'

.
<END>
<START>
And

,

.
<END>
<START>
But

,

,

.
<END>

,

.

<START>

''

,

<START>
The
hottest

in
the

intensified
sharply
yesterday
as
Digital
Equipment
Corp.
announced
its
first
line
of
mainframe
computers
,

International

Machines
Corp.
's

.
<END>
<START>
IBM
fired
back
with

of

,

3090
line
with

7
%

.
<END>
<START>
But

's

into

will
target
IBM
's

,
where

a
commanding
70
%

.
<END>
<START>
Digital
,
Maynard
,
Mass.
,
insisted
yesterday
that
its

focus
would
differ
sharply
from
IBM
's
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
not
your
father
's
mainframe
,
''
said

McGuire
,
a
Digital

.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
a
whole
new

,
''
he

.
<END>
<START>
Batch
processing
is
the

,

processing
that
most
mainframes
typically
chug
through
at
night
,
such
as

at

.
<END>
<START>
IBM
said
the
16
new
J
and
JH
models
will
generally

,
though

wo
n't
ship
until

.

<START>

,

13

,
generally
wo
n't

.
<END>
<START>
Small

,
whose

increased
as

46
%
,
will

.
<END>
<START>
Upgrades

also
will

.
<END>
<START>
The

will

,

.

<START>
Analysts

's

wo

,

.

.
<END>
<START>
Digital
also
plans
to
compete
fiercely
with
IBM
when
the
giant
's
customers
are
computerizing
new
aspects
of
their
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
Digital
,
however
,
does
n't
expect
to
displace
IBM
mainframes
that
are
already
installed
at
big
companies
.
<END>
<START>
Although
Digital
has
staked
out
a
major
presence
in
the
booming
workstation
market
,
profit
margins
in
that
market
are
much
slimmer
than
for
mainframes
.
<END>
<START>
The
slow-growing
mainframe
market
also
has
shown
new
signs
of
life
lately
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
's
mainframe
sales
have
held
up
better
than
expected
this
year
,
with
analysts
estimating
they
have
risen
10
%
to
12
%
.
<END>
<START>
``
Demand
for
these
systems
has
been
very
,
very
strong
,
''
said
Bill
Grabe
,
a
senior
IBM
marketing
executive
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
have
a
good
strong
backlog
for
the
fourth
quarter
even
without
''
the
systems
that
were
announced
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
3090
line
is
nearly
five
years
old
--
which
is
getting
up
there
in
mainframe
years
--
and
its
growth
is
expected
to
slow
in
1990
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
,
Armonk
,
N.Y.
,
said
it
wanted
to
bring
out
the
mainframes
as
soon
as
it
could
to
spark
as
many
sales
as
possible
by
the
end
of
the
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
fourth
quarter
is
always
IBM
's
biggest
by
far
,
with
most
sales
coming
in
December
as
customers
seek
to
use
budgets
before
year
end
.
<END>
<START>
Some
analysts
have
estimated
IBM
's
fourth-quarter
per-share
earnings
will
fall
10
%
to
$
3.57
a
share
from
$
3.97
a
share
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
That
should
help
IBM
address
the
damage
that
a
resurgent
Storage
Technology
Corp.
has
inflicted
in
that
market
.
<END>

.
H.
,

.

Terms
were
n't

.
<END>

Concord

.

Navy
awarded

Inc.
's

$
15.5

for

.
<END>

award
exercises
a

to

given
in
1984
.
<END>
<START>
The
White
House
called
on
Congress
to
attach
the
proposed
capital-gains
tax
cut
to
its
final
deficit-reduction
bill
,
but
lawmakers
seem
likely
to
balk
at
the
idea
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
that
does
n't
happen
,
then
we
press
forward
on
another
vehicle
and
a
separate
vote
,
''
said
press
secretary
Marlin
Fitzwater
.
<END>
<START>
On
Capitol
Hill
,
though
,
there
does
n't
seem
to
be
sufficient
sentiment
to
pair
capital
gains
and
the
deficit-reduction
bill
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
President
Bush
stepped
up
his
personal
lobbying
for
the
capital-gains
tax
cut
.
<END>
<START>
The
first
meeting
yesterday
was
with
10
Senate
Democrats
who
have
expressed
an
interest
in
cutting
the
tax
.
<END>
<START>
Issues
discussed
in
this
context
were
an
increase
in
the
minimum
wage
and
an
increase
in
child-care
spending
.
<END>
<START>
The
president
was
said
to
have
been
noncommittal
.
<END>
<START>
A
recent
change
in

law
,

,

arm
in

.
<END>
<START>
American
Telephone
&
Telegraph
Co.
unveiled
new
optical
transmission
systems
for
data
,
video
and
voice
communications
.
<END>
<START>
Two
products
in
what
the
telecommunications
giant
called
a
new
generation
of
such
equipment
are
available
now
,
AT&T
said
,
and
three
others
will
be
introduced
in
1990
and
1991
.
<END>
<START>
The
products
already
available
are
cross-connect
systems
,
used
instead
of
mazes
of
wiring
to
interconnect
other
telecommunications
equipment
.
<END>
<START>
This
cuts
down
greatly
on
labor
,
Mr.
Buchner
said
.
<END>
<START>
AT&T
said
the
products
,
unlike
previous
generations
,
will
meet
so-called
Sonet
compatability
standards
,
which
AT&T
expects
to
be
broadly
adopted
.
<END>
<START>
Sonet
,
or
synchronous
optical
network
,
products
have
more
capacity
than
earlier
models
.
<END>
<START>
``
These
products
are
the
heart
of
our
transmission-product
line
,
''
Mr.
Buchner
said
.
<END>
<START>
He
declined
to
disclose
specific
prices
,
but
said
each
product
costs
in
the
tens
of
thousands
,
or
even
hundreds
of
thousands
,
of
dollars
.
<END>
<START>
AT&T
said
it
expects
to
beat
to
the
marketplace
two
rivals
,
Northern
Telecom
Ltd.
of
Canada
and
France
's
Alcatel
N.V.
,
which
also
have
announced
Sonet-based
products
.
<END>
<START>
AT&T
predicted
strong
growth
in
demand
for
such
products
.
<END>
<START>
It
noted
that
last
July
,
Nippon
Telegraph
&
Telephone
Corp.
of
Japan
selected
AT&T
to
supply
$
154
million
of
such
equipment
over
a
four-year
period
starting
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
Law
firms
that
have
feasted
and
grown
on
the
revenue
from
mergers
and
acquisitions
work
are
feeling
the
squeeze
as
that
work
declines
.
<END>
<START>
Much
of
this
work
was
done
for
higher
fees
than
other
legal
work
and
was
not
generally
billed
by
the
hour
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're
planning
on
a
rip-roaring
year
in
1989
,
but
next
year
we
'll
be
another
story
,
''
said
Robert
Freedman
,
a
partner
at
Simpson
Thacher
&
Bartlett
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're
settling
down
to
a
less
active
period
.
''
<END>
<START>
``
Everyone
is
waiting
to
see
if
deals
can
be
done
at
sensible
prices
and
if
money
is
available
,
''
said
Jack
Nusbaum
,
co-chairman
of
Willkie
Farr
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
hard
to
know
right
now
if
the
change
is
fundamental
or
cyclical
.
''
<END>
<START>
Some
lawyers
say
the
slump
,
while
more
obvious
in
recent
weeks
,
began
earlier
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Lawyers
also
say
an
erratic
stock
market
and
uncertain
financing
conditions
have
sharply
reduced
the
number
of
lucrative
big
deals
likely
to
be
proposed
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
some
lawyers
say
the
mergers
slowdown
has
n't
affected
foreign
buyers
as
much
as
domestic
ones
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
just
took
another
floor
for
our
London
offices
,
''
said
Joseph
Flom
of
the
New
York
firm
of
Skadden
,
Arps
,
Slate
,
Meagher
&
Flom
.
<END>
<START>
Davis
Polk
&
Wardwell
also
said
its
international
clients
are
keeping
mergers
and
acquisitions
partners
busy
.
<END>
<START>
``
European
companies
are
looking
to
buy
American
ones
,
''
said
Henry
King
,
the
managing
partner
at
that
firm
.
<END>
<START>
``
But

question

whether
things
people
are
looking
at
will
actually

in

.
''

<START>
MURDER
THREAT
charged
in
Haas
Securities
Corp
.
stock-manipulation
trial
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
trial
of
former
Haas
Securities
Chairman
Eugene
Laff
,
the
defense
accused
one
of
the
government
's
chief
witnesses
of
threatening
to
kill
Mr.
Laff
.
<END>
<START>
The
conversation
was
taped
by
federal
investigators
in
what
Mr.
Lang
said
was
an
effort
to
get
Mr.
Lorin
to
implicate
Mr.
Laff
.
<END>
<START>
In
March
,
Mr.
Laff
was
indicted
on
15
counts
of
conspiracy
,
mail
and
securities
fraud
,
and
obstructing
an
investigation
by
the
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
.
<END>
<START>
The
government
has
charged
that
Mr.
Lorin
and
Mr.
Laff
were
part
of
a
conspiracy
to
maintain
the
prices
of
certain
stocks
at
artificially
high
prices
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lorin
,
a
stock
promoter
,
pleaded
guilty
to
the
stock-manipulation
charges
in
April
and
agreed
to
cooperate
with
the
government
's
investigation
of
Mr.
Laff
.
<END>
<START>
During
his
cross
examination
of
Mr.
Lorin
,
Mr.
Lang
read
from
the
transcripts
of
a
conversation
that
was
taped
Oct.
20
,
1988
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
the
transcript
,
Mr.
Lorin
said
Mr.
Laff
should
be
killed
after
Mr.
Aslanian
told
him
that
information
given
to
Mr.
Laff
by
another
conspirator
could
jeopardize
the
stock
scheme
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lorin
then
repeated
the
threat
,
and
Mr.
Aslanian
urged
him
not
to
say
such
things
.
<END>
<START>
From
the
parts
of
the
transcript
read
by
Mr.
Lang
,
it
was
unclear
what
exactly
Mr.
Lorin
feared
might
happen
.
<END>
<START>
When
asked
for
a
copy
of
the
transcript
,
Mr.
Lang
said
Judge
Thomas
P.
Griesa
had
instructed
him
not
to
release
it
or
the
memorandum
.
<END>
<START>
During
the
trial
,
Mr.
Lang
asked
Mr.
Lorin
whether
he
had
been
so
upset
``
that
you
considered
killing
Mr.
Laff
?
...
<END>
<START>
Is
n't
it
true
that
you
were
so
worked
up
that
framing
Mr.
Laff
for
this
crime
was
the
least
that
you
planned
for
him
?
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lorin
responded
,
``
No
.
''
<END>
<START>
When
Mr.
Lang
asked
Mr.
Lorin
whether
he
had
taken
steps
to
have
Mr.
Laff
killed
,
the
witness
again
said
no
.
<END>
<START>
Peter
Lieb
,
the
assistant
U.S.
attorney
prosecuting
the
case
,
declined
to
comment
on
the
trial
.
<END>

''

<START>
Kennametal
Inc.
said
it
intends
to
acquire
J&L
America
Inc.
for
$
44
million
plus
a
consideration
of
as
much
as
an
additional
$
12
million
,
payable
over
five
years
.
<END>
<START>
Kennametal
is
a
carbide-products
and
cutting-tools
company
.
<END>
<START>
J&L
,
whose
principal
offices
are
in
Detroit
,
is
a
mail-order
distributer
of
industrial
tools
and
supplies
.
<END>
<START>
The
acquisition
is
subject
to
approval
by
Kennametal
's
board
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
rose
23
%
to
$
100
million
from
$
81.6
million
.
<END>
<START>
Net
product
sales
accounted
for
$
76
million
,
up
from
$
57.5
million
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
of
the
heart
drug
TPA
were
$
43.6
million
,
better
than
last
year
's
depressed
third
period
when
the
company
sold
just
$
29.1
million
of
the
drug
.
<END>
<START>
But
TPA
sales
fell
below
levels
for
this
year
's
first
and
second
quarter
sales
of
$
48
million
,
cooling
investors
.
<END>
<START>
Genentech
stock
fell
12.5
cents
in
trading
yesterday
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
to
$
20.125
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
nine
months
,
net
income
slid
21
%
to
$
28.4
million
,
or
33
cents
a
share
,
from
$
36
million
,
or
42
cents
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Revenues
climbed
18
%
to
$
289
million
from
$
245.3
million
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
continue
to
be
on
target
for
...
increasing
TPA
sales
20
%
to
25
%
this
year
,
''
said
founder
and
Chief
Executive
Officer
Robert
Swanson
.
<END>
<START>
But
some
analysts
remain
sour
on
the
company
.
<END>
<START>
``
TPA
sales
are
down
quarter
to
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Expenses
are
flat
and
that
's
a
good
sign
.
<END>
<START>
There
's
contract
revenue
from
-LCB-
limited
research
and
development
-RCB-
partnerships
.
<END>
<START>
But
I
still
think
the
fundamentals
are
poor
,
''
said
Denise
Gilbert
,
an
analyst
with
Montgomery
Securities
in
San
Francisco
.
<END>
<START>
Genentech
faces
competition
in
the
cardiac-drug
market
from
SmithKline
Beecham
PLC
's
heart
drug
Eminase
,
expected
to
receive
market
approval
shortly
.
<END>
<START>
And
Genentech
is
n't
likely
to
have
any
new
products
ready
for
market
until
at
least
1992
,
Ms.
Gilbert
added
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
company
's
stock
is
trading
at
40
times
next
year
's
numbers
,
and
that
's
too
much
,
''
she
said
.
<END>
<START>
On
the
plus
side
,
Genentech
is
benefiting
from
a
lower
tax
rate
due
to
its
research
outlays
,
giving
a
boost
to
earnings
,
she
said
.
<END>

,

%
of

.

,

.

<START>
Ryder
System
Inc.
posted
a
third-quarter
net
loss
of
$
27.6
million
,
because
of
an
expected
$
57
million
after-tax
charge
and
continued

in

company
's

business
.
<END>
<START>

previous

's

included
gains
on
the
sale
of
aircraft
by
the
company
's
Aviation
Leasing
&
Services
Division
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
was
flat
at
$
1.3
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Many

said
they
were
n't
surprised
that

in
many
of
Ryder
's
lines
of
business
continued
to

company
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
pretty
much
confirms
what
we
had

expecting
,
''

Anthony
Hatch
,

PaineWebber
Inc
.

<START>

New

Stock
Exchange
composite

,

closed
at
$
22.25
,
down
37.5

.
<END>
<START>
M.
Anthony
Burns
,

's

and
chief

,

:
``
We
're

.
<END>
<START>
But

.
''

``

,
''

``
wo
n't

.
''
<END>
<START>
Revenue
rose
slightly
to
$
3.8
billion
from
$
3.7
billion
.
<END>

.

<START>
Advanced
Medical
Technologies
Inc.
said
it
purchased
93
%
of
a
unit
of
Henley
Group
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
Advanced
Medical
paid
$
106
million
in
cash
for
its
share
in
a
unit
of
Henley
's
Fisher
Scientific
subsidiary
.
<END>
<START>
The
unit
makes
intravenous
pumps
used
by
hospitals
and
had
more
than
$
110
million
in
sales
last
year
,
according
to
Advanced
Medical
.
<END>
<START>
The
plan
,
outlined
in
a
filing
with
the
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
,
also
calls
for
creditors
and

to
receive
common

and

in
the
new
company
.
<END>
<START>
The
health-maintenance
concern
said
it
reached
the
agreement
with
its
court-appointed
creditors
'
committees
Sept.
28
,
and
intends
to
submit
the
plan
to
the
bankruptcy
court
in
November
.
<END>
<START>
Maxicare
,
which
filed
for
bankruptcy
protection
March
16
,
has
total
debt
of
$
750
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
has
promptly
paid
all
its
expenses
and
obligations
since
March
16
,
a
Maxicare
spokesman
said
.
<END>
<START>
Those
creditors
,
whose
claims
are
estimated
at
about
$
200
million
,
include
doctors
and
hospitals
.
<END>
<START>
General
unsecured
creditors
of
Maxicare
's
discontinued
operations
,
whose
claims
total
$
110
million
,
initially
will
receive
$
17.8
million
in
cash
and
$
10
million
in
senior
notes
.
<END>
<START>
That
group
includes
banks
and
bondholders
,
who
have
claims
of
$
150
million
and
$
350
million
respectively
.
<END>
<START>
Maxicare
also
will
guarantee
that
the
banks
will
realize
at
least
$
7
million
on
certain
notes
pledged
to
them
.
<END>
<START>
Maxicare
said
the
plan
stipulates
that
enrollees
in
the
company
's
health
plans
will
have
valid
claims
covered
in
full
.
<END>
<START>
Those
claims
,
along
with
priority
employee
claims
,
administrative
claims
,
priority
tax
claims
and
administrative
convenience
claims
,
are
expected
to
total
about
$
16
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
plan
is
subject
to
approval
by
the
bankruptcy
court
and
others
.
<END>
<START>
The
spokesman
said
Maxicare
hopes
to
complete
the
reorganization
by
early
1990
.
<END>

AB
,

division
.

's

with

.

<START>

We
know
that

is

,
''
Fiat

.
<END>

But

n't
Fiat
.
''

auto

,

.

<START>
ITT
Corp.
,
its
insurance
business
hurt
by
Hurricane
Hugo
,
reported
a
4
%
decline
in
third-quarter
net
income
,
despite
a
4.2
%
rise
in
revenue
.
<END>
<START>
ITT
also
forecast
a
fourth-quarter
blow
to
earnings
from
the
California
earthquake
.
<END>
<START>
Except
for
insurance
,
however
,
ITT
said
it
expects
improved
operating
earnings
``
in
all
of
our
businesses
for
the
full
year
.
''
<END>
<START>
Third-quarter
net
income
dropped
to
$
221
million
,
or
$
1.55
a
share
,
from
$
230
million
,
or
$
1.60
a
share
,
in
the
year-earlier
period
.
<END>
<START>
ITT
bought
back
8.8
million
shares
this
year
,
including
2.8
million
during
the
third
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Third-quarter
revenue
rose
to
$
4.9
billion
from
$
4.7
billion
.
<END>
<START>
In
New
York
Stock
Exchange
composite
trading
yesterday
,
ITT
common
stock
fell
62.5
cents
to
close
at
$
58.75
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
to
insurance
and
finance
,
ITT
has
interests
in
electronic
parts
,
defense
technology
,
automotive
parts
,
fluid
technology
,
pulp
and
timber
,
and
communications
and
information
services
.
<END>
<START>
ITT
's
Hartford
Insurance
Group
had
a
$
53
million
quarterly
pretax
loss
from
Hurricane
Hugo
,
ITT
said
.
<END>
<START>
Hartford
expects
to
report
a
further
pretax
loss
of
about
$
30
million
for
the
current
quarter
,
as
a
result
of
the
California
earthquake
this
month
,
ITT
added
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
also
disclosed
its
financial
operations
had
increased
reserves
for
bankrupt
accounts
,
resulting
in
a
$
40
million
pretax
charge
for
the
third
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
This
charge
was
partly
offset
,
however
,
by
$
19
million
in
pretax
capital
gains
.
<END>
<START>
ITT
also
said
its
consumer
finance
unit
agreed
in
September
to
settle
a
civil
suit
with
the
California
attorney
general
over
alleged
improper
lending
and
sales
practices
.
<END>
<START>
Anticipating
this
settlement
,
the
company
recorded
a
pretax
charge
of
$
24
million
during
the
fourth
quarter
of
1988
.
<END>
<START>
An
ITT
spokesman
said
the
charge
was
n't
publicly
reported
at
the
time
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
company
's
product
businesses
,
with
the
exception
of
electronic
components
,
had
higher
operating
earnings
for
the
first
nine
months
of
1989
,
''
the
company
said
.
<END>
<START>
Elaborating
on
the
exception
,

said
volume
and

were
lower
in
semiconductor
and
power
systems
operations
.
<END>
<START>
Production
is
expected
to
be
about
40,000
barrels
of
oil
a
day
after
completion
of
the
drilling
program
.
<END>

<START>
French
consumer

0.2
%

August
,

by

Institute
.
<END>
<START>

Finance

the

usually

.
<END>
<START>

agency
noted
,

,
the
estimate
will
likely
be
confirmed
.
<END>
<START>
The
index
was
178.5
in
August
and
is
based
on
1980
equaling
100
.

;

,

.

Sanford
Kane
,

,

were

from

57

based

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
Conspicuous
by

is
California
.
<END>
<START>
San
Jose
and
several
other
California
cities
mounted
major
campaigns
during

to

the
group
,

last
June
by
seven
electronics
concerns
.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>

by

.

,

.

<START>
Fred

,

.

.

<START>
Quickview
Systems
Inc.

Inc.
,

in

's

.
<END>
<START>
The

program
allows

for
Macintosh

without
having
to
be
hardcore

and
is
distributed
with

.
<END>
<START>

of

,

said

Quickview

does

.
<END>
<START>

at

``
is

to

,
''

Goodman
,

.
<END>
<START>

,

suit
seeks

that
an

for
Quickview
claimed
could
run
into

of

.
<END>
<START>

,

has
no

,
and
that
HyperCard
does
not

``
any

''
of

Quickview

.
<END>
<START>

own
in

in

,

,

's

.

<START>

.

<END>
<START>

<START>
As

.
<END>
<START>

?
<END>
<START>

''

.
<END>

.
<END>
<START>

,

Bush

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
``
I

for

's

is

,
''

,
and

last

.
<END>
<START>
So
what
does
George
Bush
really
believe
?
<END>
<START>
The
answer
is
so
murky
that

is

to
get

president
in

with

of

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

forces

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
He
's

to

.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bush
is

with

.
<END>
<START>
For

,

has

to

of

for

.
<END>
<START>
Many

still

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bush
's

is

that

seems
to
be

over

as

.
<END>
<START>
The

would

far
less
if

and

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

''

.
<END>

for

Bush
,

,

,

.
<END>

.

--

--

overcome

.
<END>
<START>

''

.

<START>

,

,

can

.
<END>

.
<END>

.

<END>
<START>
The
1989
Americans
With
Disabilities
Act
is
about
eliminating

.
<END>
<START>
This

.
<END>
<START>
And

how

and

were

as

in

.
<END>
<START>

,

1989
Americans

Disabilities
Act
provides
the

.
<END>
<START>
Disabled
Americans
have
had

guaranteed
in
all

since

504
was
passed
as
a

of
the
1973

Act
.
<END>
<START>
The
1989
act
simply
extends
these
guarantees
to

sector
.
<END>
<START>
Those

Act
.
<END>
<START>
Without

recourse
,

are
no
guarantees
of

rights
for
anyone
.

earlier
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
total
tax
outlays
were
$
73.5
million
,
compared
with
$
44.1
million
the
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Net
was
$
192.1
million
,
or
$
3.33
a
share
,
compared
with
net
of
$
293.7
million
,
or
$
5.13
a
share
,
the
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
The
latest
nine
months
included
charges
of
$
95
million
related
to
the
company
's
South
African
subsidiary
and
unused
pipe
sold
by

unit
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
rose
nearly
2
%
to
$
8.13
billion
from
$
7.98
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Environmental
Control
Group
Inc.
said
it
expects
to
report
``
minimal
''
earnings
or
a
loss
for
the
third
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
year-ago
quarter
,
the
company
reported
earnings
of
$
2.2
million
,
or
35
cents
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Former
USX
Corp.
Chairman
David
M.
Roderick
may
have
been
lucky
he
retired
last
May
.
<END>
<START>
As
he
handed
over
the
reins
to
successor
Charles
A.
Corry
,
steel
profits
were
close
to
a
cyclical
peak
.
<END>
<START>
Though
imports
were
troublesome
,
they
were
n't
running
away
with
the
market
,
and
American
companies
had
high
hopes
that
steel
import
quotas
would
be
extended
for
another

.
<END>
<START>
Perhaps
most

,
Carl
Icahn
,

once

a

,
was
subdued
.
<END>
<START>
He
and
Mr.
Roderick
were
even

.
<END>
<START>
Today
,
Mr.
Corry
presides
over
a
company
whose

have

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Icahn
,
the

,

,

had
raised

USX

to
13.1
%
,

again

.
<END>
<START>
A

with
Mr.
Icahn
would
rattle
even
the
most

chief
executive
,
to
say
nothing
of
one
who
took

less

.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
The

is
whether

new

can

without

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.

.
<END>
<START>
With

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

's

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

,

.

<START>

,

,

.

.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Both

.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
But

's

.
<END>
<START>
He

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

<END>
<START>

?
<END>
<START>

,

.

.
<END>

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.
<END>

.

,

.

.

,

.

,

's

.
''

,

,

.

<START>
Israel

,

,

.

<START>

.

,

.
<END>
<START>
The

said
it
has
n't

seen

of

.
<END>
<START>
Israel
has
long
claimed
Mr.
Arafat
never
meant
to
renounce
terrorism
,
particularly
because
he
and
his
lieutenants
reserved
the
right
to

``

''
against
the
Jewish

.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
Jerusalem
says
it
is
backing
up
its
contention
with
detailed
accounts
of
alleged
terrorist
acts
and
plans
linked
to
Mr.
Arafat
.
<END>
<START>
It
blames
most
of
these
on
Fatah
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
accusations
come
at
a
delicate
time
in
U.S.
efforts
to
bring
about

between
Israel
and

representatives
.
<END>
<START>
Deciding
what
constitutes
``
terrorism
''
can
be
a
legalistic
exercise
.
<END>
<START>
The
U.S.
defines
it
as
``
premediated
,
politically
motivated
violence
perpetrated
against
noncombatant
targets
by
subnational
groups
or
clandestine
state
agents
.
''
<END>
<START>
To
meet

U.S.

,
Israel
contended
it
only
listed
incidents
that
involved
civilians
and
occurred
inside

.
<END>
<START>
At
the
heart
of
Israel
's
report
is

of

dozen
incidents
Jerusalem
attributes
to
Fatah
,
including
the
use
of

and

.
<END>
<START>
In

,

say

has

these

were
ordered
by
Fatah
or

Mr.
Arafat

.
<END>
<START>
U.S.

are

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

to

.
''
<END>
<START>
Some

is
colored

with
the
PLO
.
<END>
<START>
But
State
Department
officials
accuse
Israel
of
leaking
questionable
claims
to
embarrass
the
U.S.
.
<END>
<START>
The
dollar
finished
lower
yesterday
,
after
tracking
another
rollercoaster
session
on
Wall
Street
.
<END>
<START>
But
seesaw
gyrations
in
the
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
yesterday
put
Wall
Street
back
in
the
spotlight
and
inspired
market
participants
to
bid
the
U.S.
unit
lower
.
<END>
<START>
UAL
's
decision
to
remain
an
independent
company
sent
share
prices
tumbling
.
<END>
<START>
By
midmorning
,
the
DJIA
had
plunged
80
points
and
foreign-exchange
dealers
quickly
drove
the
dollar
down
.
<END>
<START>
When
the
DJIA
modestly
rebounded
,
the
dollar
bounced
back
in
choppy
dealings
but
ended
the
day
below
the
levels
of
late
Monday
.
<END>
<START>
Stock
prices
,
meanwhile
,
posted
significant
gains
in
later
trading
and
closed
down
by
only
3.69
points
on
the
day
.
<END>
<START>
Some
dealers
said
that
the
market
's
strong
reaction
to
Wall
Street
reflects
a
general
uneasiness
about
the
dollar
.
<END>
<START>
They
added
that
the
DJIA
's
swift
drop
proved
an
easy
excuse
for
the
market
to
drive
the
U.S.
currency
in
the
direction
it
was
already
headed
.
<END>
<START>
In
late
New
York
trading
yesterday
,
the
dollar
was
quoted
at
1.8355
marks
,
down
from
1.8470
marks
Monday
,
and
at
141.45
yen
,
down
from
141.90
yen
late
Monday
.
<END>
<START>
Sterling
was
quoted
at
$
1.6055
,
up
from
$
1.6030
late
Monday
.
<END>
<START>
In
Tokyo
Wednesday
,
the
U.S.
currency
opened
for
trading
at
141.57
yen
,
down
from
Tuesday
's
Tokyo
close
of
142.10
yen
.
<END>
<START>
Tom
Trettien
,
a
vice
president
with
Banque
Paribas
in
New
York
,
sees
a
break
in
the
dollar
's
long-term
upward
trend
,
a
trend
that
began
in
January
1988
.
<END>
<START>
He
argues
that
the
dollar
is
now
``
moving
sideways
,
''
adding
that
``
the
next
leg
could
be
the

of
a
longer

phase
.
''
<END>
<START>
They
also
point
out
that
narrowing
interest-rate

between
the
U.S.
and
its
major
trading
partners
tend
to
make

U.S.
currency
less

to
foreign

.
<END>
<START>
Despite

of
dollar

,

was

that
mark-yen
cross
trade
grabbed
much

's

.
<END>
<START>
Following
the
dive
in
U.S.

,

mark
has

more
than

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.

''

,

.

<START>

,

.

,

,

Safe
Deposit
's

has
been

this

by

.
<END>
<START>
As

and

,

ought

,

.
<END>
<START>

over

's

in

.
<END>
<START>

at

last
year
forced
Boston
Co.
to

pretax

by

44

.
<END>
<START>

as

's

and

.

<START>

and

,
in

to

--

.

.
''

's

.
<END>
<START>
The

's

found

``
locked
into

,
''

.

<START>
CHICAGO
-
<END>
<START>
Sears
,
Roebuck
&
Co.
is
struggling
as
it
enters
the
critical
Christmas
season
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
news
was
even
worse
for
Sears
's
core
U.S.
retailing
operation
,
the
largest
in
the
nation
.
<END>
<START>
Sears
said
its
U.S.
stores
had
a
loss
of
$
6.9
million
,
their
first
deficit
for
the
period
in
more
than
five
years
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
estimated
that
sales
at
U.S.
stores
declined
in
the
quarter
,
too
.
<END>
<START>
The
results
underscore
Sears
's
difficulties
in
implementing
the
``
everyday
low
pricing
''
strategy
that
it
adopted
in
March
as
part
of
a
broad
attempt
to
revive
its
retailing
business
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
new
approach
,
Sears
set
prices
that
were
somewhere
between
its
old
``
regular
''
and
``
sale
''
prices
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
it
would
resort
far
less
often
to
slashing
prices
to
woo
shoppers
.
<END>
<START>
Sears
officials
insist
they
do
n't
intend
to
abandon
the
everyday
pricing
approach
in
the
face
of
the
poor
results
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
pricing
strategy
``
is
working
,
''
the
spokesman
asserted
.
<END>
<START>
He
added
that
,
after
an
initial
surge
triggered
by
an
advertising
blitz
in
March
,
Sears
expected
that
the
pricing
program
would
n't
have
any
effect
on
revenue
.
<END>
<START>
But
analysts
say
Sears
faces
an
especially
daunting
challenge
on
the
eve
of
the
Christmas
shopping
season
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
believe
everyday
pricing
in
the
current
environment
does
n't
work
,
''
says
Walter
Loeb
of
Morgan
Stanley
&
Co.
,
pointing
to
soft
durable-goods
sales
.
<END>
<START>
``
Sears
is
likely
to
be
unsuccessful
if
it
continues
with
its
pricing
policy
when
everyone
else
is
offering
unusual
values
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
company
is
highlighting
more
special
deals
in
its
advertising
and
stores
,
and
it
's
offering
to
defer
finance
charges
on
certain
big-ticket
items
.
<END>
<START>
Sears
is
also
stepping
up
its
television
ads
and
changing
its
message
.
<END>
<START>
''
By
lowering
prices
throughout
its
stores
,
she
says
,
``
Sears
has
the
right
idea
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
the
ad
also
mentions
Sears
's
sales
--
a
topic
that
the
retailer
has
avoided
since
switching
to
everyday
pricing
.
<END>
<START>
``
When
Sears
has
a
sale
at
a
special
price
,
''
the
woman
in
the
ad
declares
,
``
it
's
something
you
do
n't
want
to
miss
.
''
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
the
number
of
people
who
spontaneously
cited
lower
prices
as
the
reason
for
their
interest
in
Sears
declined
to
16

in
September
from
33
%
in
March
.
<END>
<START>
Just
5
%
of

respondents
mentioned

,

2

.
<END>
<START>

2

of

``

.
''
<END>
<START>
``

in

,

small

.
''

4.8

from

,

,

by
$
80

,

23

.
