<START>
Oil
imports
to
Japan
rose
12
%
in
September
from
year-earlier
levels
,
according
to
statistics
released
by
the
government
's
Ministry
of
International
Trade
and
Industry
.
<END>
<START>
The
imports
,
totaling
98.5
million
barrels
,
were
11
%
lower
than
August
levels
.
<END>
<START>
The
year-on-year
rise
was
partly
because
of
higher
demand
for
petroleum
products
,
and
partly
because
of
tax
changes
in
1988
that
left
oil
companies
with
high
inventories
in
the
late-summer/early-FALL
PERIOD
.
<END>
<START>
Imports
of
crude
from
the
Middle
East
grew
17
%
from
year-earlier
levels
,
and
Southeast
Asian
crude
imports
grew
43
%
.
<END>
<START>
While
Mideast
crude
imports
were
higher
compared
with
year-earlier
levels
,
they
fell
18
%
compared
with
August
imports
.
<END>
<START>
Southeast
Asian
crude
imports
,
however
,
were
3.6
%
higher
than
August
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
in
response
to
George
Melloan
's
Business
World
column
``
The
Housing
Market
Is
a
Bigger
Mess
Than
You
Think
''
-LRB-
op-ed
page
,
Sept.
26
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
In
Houston
,
we
have
seen
how
bad
the
housing
problem
can
become
.
<END>
<START>
Unused
houses
deteriorate
rapidly
,
affecting
the
value
of
nearby
homes
;
in
a
domino
effect
,
the
entire
neighborhood
can
fall
victim
.
<END>
<START>
At
this
stage
some
people
just
``
walk
away
''
from
homes
where
the
mortgage
exceeds
current
market
value
.
<END>
<START>
But
most
of
them
could
have
afforded
to
keep
up
their
payments
--
they
chose
not
to
do
so
.
<END>
<START>
The
problem
is
so
vast
that
we
need
to
try
innovative
solutions
--
in
small-scale
experiments
.
<END>
<START>
Here
are
some
ideas
:
<END>
<START>
3
-RRB-
Develop
rental
agreements
with
exclusive
purchase
options
for
the
renter
.
<END>
<START>
An
occupant
will
,
in
most
every
case
,
be
better
for
the
home
and
neighborhood
than
a
vacant
house
.
<END>
<START>
In
this
way
,
the
house
is
not
dumped
on
to
a
glutted
market
.
<END>
<START>
John
F.
Merrill
<END>
<START>
Houston
<END>
<START>
Paul
Padget
<END>
<START>
Istat
said
a
national
survey
during
the
first
week
of
July
showed
the
number
of
job
seekers
was
2,888,000
up
from
2,822,000
in
April
,
and
from
2,853,000
a
year
ago
.
<END>
<START>
The
unemployment
rate
was
by
far
the
highest
in
the
southern
,
so-called
Mezzogiorno
region
.
<END>
<START>
The
southern
unemployment
rate
rose
to
21.3
%
in
July
from
21.2
%
in
April
and
from
20.6
%
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Istat
said
369,000
more
people
were
employed
in
July
than
in
April
.
<END>
<START>
Xerox
Corp.
's
third-quarter
net
income
grew
6.2
%
on
7.3
%
higher
revenue
,
earning
mixed
reviews
from
Wall
Street
analysts
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
rose
to
$
4.45
billion
from
$
4.15
billion
.
<END>
<START>
In
New
York
Stock
Exchange
composite
trading
,
Xerox
closed
at
$
62.75
a
share
,
up
$
1
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
of
Xerox
copiers
and
other
office
products
grew
1.6
%
;
``
we
expected
growth
of
6
%
to
7
%
,
''
Mr.
Henderson
said
.
<END>
<START>
Operating-profit
margins
slipped
almost
18
%
,
to
4.3
%
of
sales
,
the
analyst
noted
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
with
competitors
such
as
Eastman
Kodak
Co.
faltering
in
copier
sales
,
Xerox
's
sales
increases
``
were
encouraging
,
''
says
Eugene
Glazer
of
Dean
Witter
Reynolds
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
are
holding
their
own
in
a
weak
market
,
and
the
restructuring
is
working
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Glazer
expects
Xerox
to
experience
tough
sledding
,
though
,
in
financial
services
because
of
rate
pressures
and
uncertainty
surrounding
tax
treatment
of
capital
gains
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
quarter
,
the
Crum
&
Forster
insurance
unit
reported
$
200
million
before
tax
of
capital
gains
from
property
and
casualty
operations
.
<END>
<START>
The
subsidiary
also
increased
reserves
by
$
140
million
,
however
,
and
set
aside
an
additional
$
25
million
for
claims
connected
with
Hurricane
Hugo
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
nine
months
,
Xerox
earned
$
492
million
,
or
$
4.55
a
share
,
up
5.8
%
from
$
465
million
,
or
$
4.32
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
rose
7.6
%
to
$
12.97
billion
from
$
12.05
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Most
analysts
had
expected
a
sharper
decline
after
the
steep
rise
in
August
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
a
recent
government
report
showing
widespread
layoffs
in
manufacturing
had
contributed
to
perceptions
that
the
manufacturing
sector
of
the
economy
had
slowed
to
a
crawl
.
<END>
<START>
But
many
economists
pointed
to
a
1.8
%
September
rise
in
orders
outside
the
volatile
transportation
category
.
<END>
<START>
That
``
suggests
the
manufacturing
sector
is
not
falling
apart
,
''
said
Sally
Kleinman
,
an
economist
at
Manufacturers
Hanover
Securities
Corp.
in
New
York
.
<END>
<START>
She
added
,
however
:
``
It
is
not
robust
by
any
means
.
''
<END>
<START>
While
a
decline
in
orders
for
cars
and
civilian
airplanes
pulled
down
the
orders
total
,
an
enormous
jump
in
orders
for
heavy
military
equipment
propped
it
up
.
<END>
<START>
Orders
for
capital
defense
goods
skyrocketed
56
%
,
and
a
government
analyst
said
nearly
all
areas
saw
increases
,
including
airplanes
,
missiles
,
ships
,
tanks
and
communications
equipment
.
<END>
<START>
Orders
for
military
goods
usually
catapult
in
September
,
government
officials
say
,
as
the
Pentagon
scrambles
to
spend
its
money
before
the
new
fiscal
year
begins
Oct.
1
.
<END>
<START>
Without
the
increase
in
defense
bookings
,
September
orders
would
have
plummeted
3.9
%
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
were
most
unsettled
by
evidence
the
backlog
of
orders
at
factories
is
slipping
.
<END>
<START>
Unfilled
orders
for
durable
goods
rose
0.4
%
in
September
,
to
$
476.14
billion
,
after
declining
for
the
first
time
in
2
1/2
years
in
August
.
<END>
<START>
In
July
unfilled
orders
grew
1
%
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
means
we
're
eating
into
the
bread
that
keeps
us
going
.
<END>
<START>
That
is
a
little
disturbing
,
''
Ms.
Kleinman
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
also
means
if
you
have
a
real
drop-off
in
orders
,
production
will
likely
fall
off
very
quickly
because
there
is
less
to
keep
things
going
.
''
<END>
<START>
Capital
goods
orders
outside
of
the
defense
sector
tumbled
for
the
second
month
in
a
row
,
posting
a
5.6
%
drop
after
a
10.3
%
decline
.
<END>
<START>
Such
steep
drops
in
a
category
seen
as
a
barometer
of
business
investment
would
customarily
be
grave
news
for
the
economy
.
<END>
<START>
Now
at
least
there
are
question
marks
about
that
,
and
without
any
question
the
pace
of
growth
has
slowed
.
<END>
<START>
Norfolk
Southern
Corp.
directors
authorized
the
railroad
company
to
buy
back
as
many
as
45
million
of
its
shares
,
which
would
have
a
current
value
of
more
than
$
1.7
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
buy-back
,
coupled
with
a
nearly
completed
earlier
purchase
of
20
million
shares
,
would
reduce
shares
outstanding
by
more
than
26
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
Norfolk
,
Va.
,
company
has
172.2
million
shares
outstanding
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
statement
,
Arnold
B.
McKinnon
,
chairman
and
chief
executive
officer
,
noted
that
the
new
repurchase
program
``
should
serve
to
enhance
shareholder
value
.
''
<END>
<START>
A
spokeswoman
said
the
company
will
finance
the
buy-back
with
cash
on
hand
,
borrowing
and
``
cash
Norfolk
expects
to
generate
.
''
<END>
<START>
Analysts
said
they
expected
the
action
,
and
investors
applauded
the
move
.
<END>
<START>
In
composite
trading
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
,
Norfolk
Southern
shares
closed
at
$
37.875
,
up
$
1.125
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
analysts
do
n't
expect
the
buy-back
to
significantly
affect
per-share
earnings
in
the
short
term
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
impact
wo
n't
be
that
great
,
''
said
Graeme
Lidgerwood
of
First
Boston
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
That
is
in
part
because
of
the
effect
of
having
to
average
the
number
of
shares
outstanding
,
she
said
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
Mrs.
Lidgerwood
said
,
Norfolk
is
likely
to
draw
down
its
cash
initially
to
finance
the
purchases
and
thus
forfeit
some
interest
income
.
<END>
<START>
Longer
term
,
however
,
the
buy-back
is
expected
to
increase
earnings
,
especially
after
1990
,
Mrs.
Lidgerwood
said
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
the
extensive
program
in
effect
establishes
a
floor
for
the
stock
price
,
said
Joel
Price
,
analyst
for
Donaldson
,
Lufkin
&
Jenrette
.
<END>
<START>
The
buy-back
``
is
really
a
comfort
to
those
who
want
to
buy
the
stock
that
there
is
a
-LCB-
price
-RCB-
floor
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
At
a
certain
price
,
if
the
management
thinks
-LCB-
the
stock
-RCB-
is
cheap
,
they
can
go
in
and
buy
it
.
''
<END>
<START>
Under
the
program
,
Norfolk
plans
to
acquire
shares
in
the
open
market
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
earlier
plan
,
Norfolk
was
authorized
in
1987
to
buy
up
to
20
million
shares
.
<END>
<START>
It
has
purchased
about
19
million
of
them
.
<END>

Roy
E.

,

<START>
Simpson
is
an
auto
parts
maker
.
<END>
<START>
Japan
has
climbed
up
from
the
ashes
of
World
War
II
and
a
gross
national
product
of
about
$
800
per
capita
to
reach
the
heavyweight
class
among
industrialized
nations
.
<END>
<START>
Now
this
remarkable
economic
growth
seems
to
be
coming
to
an
end
because
the
government
has
not
converted
itself
into
a
modern
,
democratic
,
``
developed
nation
''
mode
of
operation
.
<END>
<START>
Until
1980
,
when
Japan
joined
the
$
10,000
per
capita
GNP
club
of
the
advanced
countries
,
it
was
a
model
developing
nation
.
<END>
<START>
The
government
built
ports
,
bridges
,
highways
,
schools
,
hospitals
and
railways
.
<END>
<START>
When
industries
were
weak
,
it
protected
them
.
<END>
<START>
Individual
prosperity
inevitably
would
result
.
<END>
<START>
That
system
has
worked
.
<END>
<START>
The
standard
of
living
has
increased
steadily
over
the
past
40
years
;
more
than
90
%
of
the
people
consider
themselves
middle
class
.
<END>
<START>
The
people
have
given
their
leading
and
only
credible
political
party
,
the
Liberal
Democratic
Party
,
clear
and
uninterrupted
power
for
those
40
years
.
<END>
<START>
The
LDP
won
by
a
landslide
in
the
last
election
,
in
July
1986
.
<END>
<START>
But
less
than
two
years
later
,
the
LDP
started
to
crumble
,
and
dissent
rose
to
unprecedented
heights
.
<END>
<START>
The
symptoms
all
point
to
one
thing
:
Japan
does
not
have
a
modern
government
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
allows
people
to
buy
the
best
and
the
cheapest
goods
from
anywhere
in
the
world
.
<END>
<START>
The
Japanese
government
does
n't
allow
this
.
<END>
<START>
The
Ministry
of
Agriculture
and
Fishery
actually
is
a
ministry
for
farmers
and
fishermen
instead
of
a
ministry
of
provisions
.
<END>
<START>
The
Ministry
of
Health
and
Welfare
is
a
ministry
of
doctors
and
pharmaceutical
companies
rather
than
an
organization
dedicated
to
protecting
the
health
of
the
people
.
<END>
<START>
The
Ministry
of
Education
is
nothing
but
a
cartel
for
licensed
teachers
,
and
certainly
does
not
act
on
behalf
of
students
.
<END>
<START>
The
Ministry
of
Transportation
serves
the
industry
,
certainly
not
the
passengers
who
must
pay
extraordinarily
high
prices
.
<END>
<START>
This
ministry
has
done
nothing
to
correct
the
misunderstandings
and
misperceptions
that
are
at
the
root
of
Japan
's
deteriorating
image
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
,
it
seems
to
be
using
foreign
pressure
and
even
the
trade
conflict
to
expand
its
sphere
of
influence
vis
a
vis
other
ministries
.
<END>
<START>
All
this
illustrates
that
Japanese
ministries
still
have
a
``
provider
''
mentality
;
they
do
not
serve
the
people
,
and
particularly
not
consumers
.
<END>
<START>
They
serve
the
industries
and
the
special-interest
groups
.
<END>
<START>
The
rest
of
the
world
accepted
such
methods
when
Japan
was
developing
.
<END>
<START>
Japanese
put
up
with
it
because
the
government
provided
job
stability
and
growing
paychecks
.
<END>
<START>
Japan
is
not
a
political
country
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
a
bureaucratic
country
.
<END>
<START>
The
Diet
plays
a
minor
role
compared
with
the
powerful
bureaucratic
system
.
<END>
<START>
Most
bills
are
drafted
by
bureaucrats
,
not
politicians
.
<END>
<START>
The
Diet
does
n't
normally
even
debate
bills
because
the
opposition
parties
are
so
often
opposed
to
whatever
LDP
does
that
it
would
be
a
waste
of
time
.
<END>
<START>
So
most
bills
are
passed
without
full
discussion
;
particularly
difficult
bills
are
passed
in
the
absence
of
the
opposition
parties
.
<END>
<START>
A
recent
example
is
the
3
%
consumption
tax
on
all
commercial
activities
.
<END>
<START>
This
makes
enormous
sense
in
Japan
,
where
direct
tax
accounts
for
more
than
70
%
of
revenues
and
the
capture
rate
of
direct
tax
is
so
unfair
.
<END>
<START>
If
you
are
a
salaried
man
,
Amen
!
100
%
captured
.
<END>
<START>
If
you
are
a
retailer
,
50
%
,
and
a
farmer
,
30
%
.
<END>
<START>
To
correct
this
inequality
,
most
people
would
have
favored
an
indirect
tax
,
like
the
consumption
tax
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
bill
was
passed
without
debate
in
the
Diet
,
in
the
absence
of
the
opposition
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
the
Japanese
people
did
n't
know
what
to
expect
when
the
new
law
was
introduced
on
April
1
.
<END>
<START>
They
were
frustrated
by
the
longer

at
the
cashier
and

small
coins
given
as

.
<END>
<START>
All
of
a

,
prices
were
no
longer
in

of
100
or
200
.
<END>
<START>
They
were
103
or
206
.
<END>
<START>
Pockets
exploded
with
one-yen
coins
.
<END>
<START>
While
people
were
jingling
their
change
,
the
LDP
politicians
were
caught
in
scandals
.
<END>
<START>
Whereas
most

were
a
bit

about
the
sex

-LRB-
though

were
furious
about
Recruit
-RRB-
,

.
<END>
<START>
Taken

,

Socialist
Party
is

.
<END>
<START>
It
's
now
OK
to
deal
with

U.S.
,
but

.
<END>
<START>
Nuclear

are
acceptable
.
<END>
<START>
The
U.S.-Japan
Security

can
continue
,
sort
of
.
<END>
<START>
And
so
on
.
<END>
<START>
Against

rapid

overhaul
of
the
Socialist
Party
the

has
been

.
<END>
<START>
Now

from

vanguard

to

of

.
<END>
<START>
If

,

,
ca

,

.
<END>
<START>
One

,

<END>
<START>

;

.
<END>
<START>
In

,

,

.

.

<START>
At

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Ohmae
is

of

&

in

.
<END>
<START>
Early
this
century
,
diamond
mining
in
the
magnificent
dunes
where
the
Namib
Desert
meets
the
Atlantic
Ocean
was
a
day
at
the
beach
.
<END>
<START>
Men
would
crawl
in
the
sand
looking
for
shiny
stones
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
as
easy
as
collecting
sea
shells
at
Malibu
.
<END>
<START>
Men
are
still
combing
the
beach
with
shovels
and
hand
brushes
,
searching
for
that
unusual
glint
.
<END>
<START>
But
only
after
a
fleet
of
336
gargantuan
earthmoving
vehicles
belonging
to
De
Beers
Consolidated
Mines
Ltd.
,
the
world
's
diamond
kingpins
,
do
their
work
.
<END>
<START>
Oh
yes
,
the
Atlantic
was
also
pushed
back
300
yards
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
there
's
diamonds
out
there
,
we
'll
get
to

,
''
says
Les
Johns
,
De
Beers
's
engineering
manager
.
<END>
<START>
Here
,
wedged
between
shifting
dunes
and
pounding
waves
at
the
world
's
most
inhospitable
diamond
dig
,
lies
the
earth
's
most
precious
jewel
box
.
<END>
<START>
While
other
mines
might
yield
more
carats
,
a
higher
percentage
of
them
go
to
industrial
use
.
<END>
<START>
Since
this
treasure
chest
is
too
big
to
fit
in
a
bank
vault
,
it
has
been
turned
into
one
.
<END>
<START>
When
the
Germans
lost
World
War
I
,
they
lost
Namibia
to
South
Africa
and
the
diamonds
to
Ernest
Oppenheimer
,

of

Corp.
and

.
<END>
<START>
Today
,
no

or

restricted
area
without
De
Beers
's

.
<END>
<START>
The
mining
zone
has
thus
remained
one
of
the
most

in
Africa
.
<END>
<START>
Ghost
towns
dot
the
Namib
dunes
,
proving
diamonds
are
n't
forever
.
<END>
<START>
Oranjemund
,
the
mine
headquarters
,
is
a
lonely
corporate
oasis
of
9,000
residents
.
<END>
<START>
Jackals
roam
the
streets
at
night
,
and
gemsbok
,
hardy
antelope
with
long
straight
horns
,
wander
in
from
the
desert
to
drink
from
water

.
<END>
<START>
On
most
days
,
the
desert
's
heat
and
the
cool
of
the
ocean
combine
to
create
a
mist
like
a
damp
rag
.
<END>
<START>
The
wind
,
stinging
with
sand
,
never
seems
to
stop
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
miners
from
all

of
Namibia
as
well
as

from
De
Beers
's

in
South
Africa
and
London
keep
coming
.
<END>
<START>
And
Oranjemund
boasts
attractions
besides

.
<END>
<START>
There
are
six
video
rental
shops
,
three
restaurants
,
one

and
34
sports
and
recreation
clubs
for
everything
from

to

.
<END>
<START>
The
pride
of
Oranjemund
is
the
18-hole
golf
course
--
with
the
largest
sand
trap
in
the
world
.
<END>
<START>
``
Nothing
is
too
good
for
our
golf
course
,
''
says
Tony
George
,

.
<END>
<START>
Huge
machines
that
look
as

from

Wars

lumber

.
<END>
<START>
Then
there
is
the
artifical
sea
wall
,
600
yards
long
and
60
yards
thick
,

.
<END>
<START>
Made
of
sand
,
it
receives
around-the-clock

against
the
battering
waves
.
<END>
<START>
When
the
mining
in
front
of
the
wall
is
complete
,
it
is
moved
northward
.
<END>
<START>
A
companion
jetty
that
helps
hold
back

sea
looks
like

rusting
junkyard
.
<END>
<START>
Engineers
first
used

blocks
to
bolster

barrier
,
but
the
ocean
tossed

aside
like

.
<END>
<START>
Then
someone
decided
to
try
broken-down
earthmoving
equipment
that
,
inexplicably
,
held
against
the
waves
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
Caterpillar
people
are
n't

their

used
like

,
''
shrugs
Mr.
George
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
figure

's
not

.
''
<END>
<START>
Laboring

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
But

,

.
<END>
<START>
Still
,

.
<END>
<START>
One

.
<END>
<START>
Another

.
<END>
<START>
A

.
<END>
<START>
None

.

<START>
THE
IRS
WILL
PAY
if
its
error
burdens
you
with
bank
charges
.
<END>
<START>
Policy
statement
P-5-39
sets
out
terms
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
of
an

IRS
levy
on
a

account
,

taxpayer
may
incur

and
overdraft
charges
.
<END>
<START>
The
IRS
recently
amended
the
policy
to
cover
stop-payment
charges
for
checks
lost
by
the
IRS
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
IRS
asks
for
and

replacement
for
a

that
it
concedes
it
lost
in
processing
,
it
will

taxpayer
for
the
stop-payment
charge
on
the
original
.
<END>
<START>
Reimbursement
claims
must
be
filed
with
the
IRS
district
or
service-center
director
within
a
year
after
the
expense
accrues
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
IRS
seeks
late-payment
interest
because
of
the
lost
check
,
you
should
request
interest
abatement
,
publisher
Prentice
Hall
notes
.

<START>

<START>
WHY

?
a

.
<END>
<START>
A

we

Ben

,

;

.

<START>

.

<START>
Well
,

8934014
,
``
a

''
is
that

must

.
<END>
<START>
The

,
Robert
Willens
of
Shearson
Lehman
Hutton
says
.
<END>
<START>
If
you
assign
your
income
to
another
,
you
still
have
controlled
its
disposition
and
enjoyed
the
fruits
of
your
labor
,
even
if
indirectly
.
<END>
<START>
Ben
earns
any
fees
sent
directly
to
charity
and
is
taxable
on
them
,
the
IRS
says
;
of
course
,
he
also
may
take
a
charitable
deduction
for
them
.
<END>
<START>
BRIEFS
:
<END>
<START>
Ways
and
Means
veteran
Gephardt
-LRB-
D.
,
Mo
.
-RRB-
moves
to
the
House
Budget
Committee
;
Rep.
Cardin
-LRB-
D.
,
Md
.
-RRB-
replaces
him
...
.
<END>
<START>
Blue-chip
advertisers
have
plenty
of
complaints
about
the
magazines
they
advertise
in
,
ranging
from
inadequate
consumer
research
to
ad
``
clutter
''
and
a
seemingly
unchecked
proliferation
of
special
interest
magazines
.
<END>
<START>
Criticism
from
such
big
advertisers
as
Estee
Lauder
Inc.
,
Colgate-Palmolive
Co.
and
Seagram
Co.
put
a
damper
on
the
euphoria
at
the
American
Magazine
Conference
here
.
<END>
<START>
The
conference
opened
Monday
with
glowing
reports
about
consumer
magazines
'
growth
in
circulation
and
advertising
revenue
in
the
past
year
.
<END>
<START>
``
Magazines
are
not
providing
us
in-depth
information
on
circulation
,
''
said
Edgar
Bronfman
Jr.
,
president
and
chief
operating
officer
of
Seagram
,
in
a
panel
discussion
.
<END>
<START>
``
How
do
readers
feel
about
the
magazine
?
<END>
<START>
How
deeply
do
they
read
it
?
<END>
<START>
Research
does
n't
tell
us
whether
people
actually
do
read
the
magazines
they
subscribe
to
.
''
<END>
<START>
Reuben
Mark
,
chief
executive
of
Colgate-Palmolive
,
said
advertisers
lack
detailed
demographic
and
geographic
breakdowns
of
magazines
'
audiences
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
need
research
that
convinces
us
that
magazines
are
a
real
value
in
reader
's
lives
,
that
readers
are
really
involved
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
critics
also
lambasted
the
magazine
industry
for
something
executives
often
are
very
proud
of
:
the
growth
in
magazine
titles
during
the
1980s
.
<END>
<START>
``
Niche-itis
fragments
our
advertising
dollars
,
''
said
Mr.
Lauder
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
are
being
over-magazined
.
<END>
<START>
We
are
constantly
faced
with
deciding
which
partnerships
-LCB-
with
magazines
-RCB-
we
can
keep
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
added
:
``
There
's
probably
even
a
magazine
for
left-handed
golfers
...
but
the
general
interest
magazine
is
something
we
all
miss
,
and
it
should
come
back
.
''
<END>
<START>
``
Readers
do
n't
want
to
face
all
those
ad
pages
at
the
front
of
a
magazine
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Magazine
editors
did
not
take
the
criticisms
lying
down
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
spend
a
fortune
on
research
information
,
''
said
Steve
Burzon
,
publisher
of
Meredith
Corp.
's
Metropolitan
Home
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
advertisers
would
n't
think
of
it
,
''
she
said
.
<END>
<START>
Wall
Street
securities
giant
Salomon
Inc.
posted
a
big
,
unexpected
earnings
gain
in
the
third
quarter
,
buoyed
by
its
securities
trading
and
investment
banking
activities
.
<END>
<START>
Salomon
said
net
income
soared
to
$
177
million
,
or
$
1.28
a
share
,
from
$
65
million
,
or
38
cents
a
share
,
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
more
than
doubled
to
$
2.62
billion
from
$
1.29
billion
.
<END>
<START>
A
Salomon
spokesman
said
its
stock
,
bond
and
foreign
exchange
trading
,
as
well
as
its
investment
banking
operations
,
were
mostly
responsible
for
the
earnings
jump
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
earnings
were
fine
and
above
expectations
,
''
said
Michael
W.
Blumstein
,
an
analyst
at
First
Boston
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
Nevertheless
,
Salomon
's
stock
fell
$
1.125
yesterday
to
close
at
$
23.25
a
share
in
New
York
Stock
Exchange
composite
trading
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
suspect
October
was
n't
as
good
as
the
third
quarter
,
and
they
'll
have
difficulty
matching
the
third
quarter
in
the
fourth
quarter
,
''
Mr.
Blumstein
said
.
<END>
<START>
But
some
analysts
say
Salomon
has
turned
the
corner
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
upgraded
the
firm
to
my
buy
list
because
I
certainly
see
signs
of
improvement
,
''
says
Lawrence
Eckenfelder
,
an
analyst
at
Prudential-Bache
Securities
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
market
has
been
overly
harsh
to
them
.
''
<END>
<START>
Analysts
say
investors
remain
skittish
toward
Salomon
because
of
its
volatile
earnings
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
first
quarter
,
Salomon
had
a
record
loss
of
$
28
million
on
revenue
of
$
1.54
billion
.
<END>
<START>
But
in
the
second
quarter
,
Salomon
posted
a
record
$
253
million
net
on
revenue
of
$
2.33
billion
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
real
estate
industry
,
a
watchword
for
the
1990s
will
be
buy
,
more
than
build
.
<END>
<START>
The
ULI
is
a
non-profit
research
and
education
group
based
in
Washington
,
D.C.
,
with
14,000
members
nationwide
.
<END>
<START>
With
the
market
overbuilt
,
builders
are
finding
limited
opportunities
and
increased
risks
.
<END>
<START>
Developers
and
money
managers
are
looking
for
bargains
among
the
thousands
of
financially
troubled
properties
around
the
country
.
<END>
<START>
Real
estate
professionals
now
often
bill
themselves
as
``
turnaround
experts
''
and
``
workout
specialists
.
''
<END>
<START>
Developers
are
also
eyeing
the
real
estate
portfolios
of
major
corporations
.
<END>
<START>
Some
plan
to
pursue
foreign
development
ventures
,
mostly
in
Europe
.
<END>
<START>
And
other
developers
may
shift
from
commercial
to
residential
development
in
the
U.S.
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
are
n't
as
many
economically
viable
alternatives
for
real
estate
developers
in
this
country
as
10
years
ago
,
''
says
Charles
Shaw
,
a
Chicago-based
real
estate
developer
.
``
<END>
<START>
So
developers
are
saying
they
will
look
into
distressed
properties
.
<END>
<START>
They
'll
go
into
someone
else
's
pasture
as
long
as
it
's
greener
than
the
one
they
're
in
now
.
''
<END>
<START>
Developers
are
also
forming
more
joint
ventures
with
pension
funds
and
insurance
companies
that
can
finance
big
projects
.
<END>
<START>
The
builders
are
more
willing
to
give
up
some
equity
and
rely
on
management
and
consulting
fees
to
stay
afloat
in
the
soft
market
.
<END>
<START>
``
Developers
are
teaming
up
with
institutions
often
acting
as
project
managers
,
''
says
Smedes
York
,
ULI
president
and
president
of
York
Properties
Inc.
,
of
Raleigh
,
N.C
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
are
growing
more
pragmatic
about
their
role
.
''
<END>
<START>
Real
estate
firms
are
also
using
their
alliances
with
financial
institutions
to
amass
acquisition
funds
.
<END>
<START>
But
experts
say
that
when
it
comes
to
distressed
properties
,
finding
diamonds
in
the
rough
is
n't
easy
.
<END>
<START>
And
to
succeed
in
the
turnaround
business
,
he
says
,
developers
may
have
to
put
in
a
lot
of
money
and
time
.
<END>
<START>
Finding
pension
funds
and
other
sources
willing
to
invest
is
a
high
priority
.
<END>
<START>
Quips
David
Shulman
,
director
of
real
estate
research
for
Salomon
Brothers
Inc.
:
``
A
theme
of
the
Urban
Land
conference
will
be
`
take
a
pension
fund
manager
to
lunch
.
<END>
<START>
Sheraton
Corp.
and
Pan
American
World
Airways
announced
that
they
and
two
Soviet
partners
will
construct
two
``
world-class
''
hotels
within
a
mile
of
Red
Square
in
Moscow
.
<END>
<START>
U.S.
and
Soviet
officials
hailed
the
joint
project
as
a
new
indication
of
the
further
thaw
in
U.S.-Soviet
relations
.
<END>
<START>
Commerce
Secretary
Robert
Mosbacher
,
who
attended
the
ceremony
,
called
the
undertaking
a
``
historic
step
''
in
the
evolution
of
U.S.-Soviet
ties
.
<END>
<START>
He
added
that
it
likely
will
have
a
``
mulitiplier
effect
''
in
stimulating
further
trade
between
the
two
countries
.
<END>
<START>
The
project
will
be
the
largest
U.S.-backed
joint
venture
to
be
undertaken
in
the
Soviet
Union
in
recent
years
.
<END>
<START>
One
of
the
hotels
,
to
be
called
the
Sheraton
Moscow
,
will
have
450
rooms
and
will
cost
an
estimated
$
75
million
to
build
.
<END>
<START>
The
six-story
hotel
will
be
on
Gorky
Street
and
initially
will
cater
mostly
to
business
travelers
.
<END>
<START>
It
will
have
a
Russian
tavern
,
an
English
pub
,
a
discotheque
and
Japanese
and
Italian
restaurants
,
according
to
a
Sheraton
announcement
.
<END>
<START>
The
hotel
is
scheduled
to
open
in
1992
.
<END>
<START>
The
second
hotel
,
to
be
called
the
Budapest
Hotel
,
is
to
be
constructed
at
a
site
even
closer
to
Red
Square
.
<END>
<START>
Details
about
its
size
and
cost
have
n't
yet
been
determined
.
<END>
<START>
The
Soviet
owners
will
be
Mossoviet
,
Moscow
's
city
governing
body
,
and
Aeroflot
,
the
Soviet
national
airline
.
<END>
<START>
U.S.
companies
account
for
less
than
8
%
of
the
1,000
or
more
Soviet
joint
ventures
that
have
been
announced
since
the
Soviets
began
encouraging
such
undertakings
in
1987
.
<END>
<START>
But
some
U.S.
companies
are
negotiating
projects
that
could
be
among
the
biggest
ones
to
be
launched
.
<END>
<START>
Chevron
Corp.
,
Amoco
Corp.
,
Archer-Daniels-Midland
Co.
,
and
Eastman
Kodak
Co.
are
among
the
U.S.
companies
known
to
be
considering
such
ventures
.
<END>
<START>
Sheraton
and
Pan
Am
said
they
are
assured
under
the
Soviet
joint-venture
law
that
they
can
repatriate
profits
from
their
hotel
venture
.
<END>
<START>
Thomas
Plaskett
,
Pan
Am
's
chairman
,
said
the
U.S.
airline
's
participation
is
a
natural
outgrowth
of
its
current
arrangements
with
Aeroflot
to
jointly
operate
nonstop
New
York-Moscow
flights
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
the
rising
volume
of
passenger
traffic
on
this
route
justifies
a
major
investment
in
new
high-standard
Moscow
hotels
.
<END>
<START>
David
Shaffer
was
named
to
the
new
post
of
executive
vice
president
of
the
Maxwell
Macmillan
group
of
this
communications
giant
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Shaffer
takes
primary
responsibility
for
the
electronic
and
technical-services
group
.
<END>
<START>
He
had
been
group
vice
president
of
the
electronic-publishing
group
.
<END>
<START>
Also
,
Sheldon
Aboff
,
formerly
a

president
at
Maxwell
,
was
named
group
vice
president
with
responsibility
for
various
electronic
and
publishing-group
companies
.
<END>
<START>
Soichiro
Honda
's
picture
now
hangs
with
Henry
Ford
's
in
the
U.S.
Automotive
Hall
of
Fame
,
and
the
game-show
``
Jeopardy
''
is
soon
to
be
Sony-owned
.
<END>
<START>
But
no
matter
how
much
Japan
gets
under
our
skin
,
we
'll
still
have
mom
and
apple
pie
.
<END>
<START>
On
second
thought
,
make
that
just
mom
.
<END>
<START>
A
Japanese
apple
called
the
Fuji
is
cropping
up
in
orchards
the
way
Hondas
did
on
U.S.
roads
.
<END>
<START>
By
1995
it
will
be
planted
more
often
than
any
other
apple
tree
,
according
to
a
recent
survey
of
six
apple-industry
sages
by
Washington
State
University
horticulturist
Robert
Norton
.
<END>
<START>
Some
fruit
visionaries
say
the
Fuji
could
someday
tumble
the
Red
Delicious
from
the
top
of
America
's
apple
heap
.
<END>
<START>
It
certainly
wo
n't
get
there
on
looks
.
<END>
<START>
Compared
to
the
Red
Delicious
,
the
exemplar
of
apple
pulchritude
,
the
Fuji
is
decidedly
more
dowdy
--
generally
smaller
,
less-perfectly
shaped
,
greenish
,
with
tinges
of
red
.
<END>
<START>
To
hear
most
U.S.
growers
tell
it
,
we
'd
still
be
in
Paradise
if
the
serpent
had
proffered
one
to
Eve
.
<END>
<START>
But
how
sweet
it
is
.
<END>
<START>
It
has
more
sugar
``
than
any
apple
we
've
ever
tested
,
''
says
Duane
Greene
,
a
University
of
Massachusetts
pomologist
,
or
apple
scholar
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
does
n't
look
nice
on
the
outside
while
getting
mealy
inside
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Auvil
,
razor
sharp
at
83
,
has
picked
and
packed
a
zillion
pecks
of
apples
over
the
past
65
years
.
<END>
<START>
He
is
known
as
the
father
of
the
U.S.-grown
Granny
Smith
,
a
radically
different
apple
that
the
conventional
wisdom
once
said
would
never
catch
on
.
<END>
<START>
It
did
,
shaking
the
apple
establishment
to
its
roots
.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
even
more
radical
changes
seem
afoot
as
the
grand
old
maverick
of
American
apples
plays
the
role
of
Hiroshi
Appleseed
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
Fuji
is
going
to
be
No.
1
to
replace
the
Red
Delicious
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
The
Delicious
hegemony
wo
n't
end
anytime
soon
.
<END>
<START>
New
apple
trees
grow
slowly
,
and
the
Red
Delicious
is
almost
as
entrenched
as
mom
.
<END>
<START>
Its
roots
are
patriotic
--
with
the
first
trees
appearing
in
1872
in
an
orchard
near
Peru
,
Iowa
,
to
be
exact
.
<END>
<START>
For
more
than
50
years
,
it
has
been
the
apple
of
our
eye
.
<END>
<START>
A
good
Delicious
can
indeed
be
delicious
.
<END>
<START>
More
than
twice
as
many
Red
Delicious
apples
are
grown
as
the
Golden
variety
,
America
's
No.
2
apple
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
apple
industry
is
ripe
for
change
.
<END>
<START>
``
Red
Delicious
has
been
overplanted
,
and
its
prices
have
dropped
below
the
cost
of
production
,
''
says
Washington
State
's
Mr.
Norton
.
<END>
<START>
The
glut
and
consequent
lower
prices
,
combined
with
cancer
fears
,
was
a
very
serious
blow
to
growers
.
<END>
<START>
``
A
lot
of
growers
wo
n't
be
around
in
a
few
years
,
''
says
Mr.
Norton
,
although
they
have
stopped
using
Alar
.
<END>
<START>
One
may
be
William
Broderick
,
a
Sterling
,
Mass.
,
grower
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
beautiful
stuff
,
''
he
says
,
looking
ruefully
at
big
boxes
of
just-picked
Red
Delicious
next
to
his
barn
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
I
'm
going
to
lose
$
50,000
to
$
60,000
on
it
.
<END>
<START>
I
'm
going
to
have
to
get
another
job
this
year
just
to
eat
.
''
<END>
<START>
Besides
rotten
prices
,
he
has
been
hit
recently
by
hail
,
a
bark-nibbling
horde
of
mice
,
fungi
and
bugs
.
<END>
<START>
Some
500
insects
and
150
diseases
wiggle
,
chew
and
romp
through
growers
'
nightmares
,
including
maggots
,
mites
,
mildew
,
thrips
,
black
rot
and
the
flat-headed
borer
.
<END>
<START>
Even
if
a
grower
beats
them
back
,
his
$
2,000
rented
bees
might
buzz
off
to
the
neighbors
'
orchards
instead
of
pollinating
his
,
Mr.
Broderick
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
've
got
70
kinds
of
apples
.
<END>
<START>
Here
's
a
Waltana
,
''
he
exclaims
,
picking
one
off
a
tree
.
<END>
<START>
He
bites
it
,
scowls
and
throws
it
down
.
``
<END>
<START>
It
's
a
real
dog
.
''
<END>
<START>
Supermarkets
are
getting
into
the
variety
act
,
too
.
<END>
<START>
They
still
buy
apples
mainly
for
big
,
red
good
looks
--
that
's
why
so
many
taste
like
woodchucks
'
punching
bags
.
<END>
<START>
But
freshness
counts
more
than
it
once
did
,
and
stores
are
expanding
shelf
space
for
unconventional
,
but
tastier
,
and
often
pricier
,
apples
.
<END>
<START>
The
Fuji
is
a
product
of
meticulous
Japanese
pomological
engineering
,
which
fostered
it
50
years
ago
at
a
government
research
orchard
.
<END>
<START>
Japanese
researchers
have
bred
dozens
of
strains
of
Fujis
to
hone
its
color
,
taste
and
shelf
life
.
<END>
<START>
Now
the
best
of
them
age
as
gracefully
as
Grannies
,
the
industry
's
gold
standard
for
storability
.
<END>
<START>
The
U.S.
Department
of
Agriculture
estimates
that
this
year
Americans
will
eat
about
40
%
more
fresh
apples
per
capita
than
the
Japanese
.
<END>
<START>
The
Fuji
is
still
small
potatoes
in
the
U.S.
,
sold
mainly
in
fruit
boutiques
.
<END>
<START>
But
in
California
,
says
Craig
Ito
,
a
Fuji-apple
grower
,
``
There
's
a
Fuji
apple
cult
.
<END>
<START>
Once
somebody
eats
one
,
they
get
hooked
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Auvil
,
the
Washington
grower
,
says
that
he
could
sell
Fujis
to
Taiwan
buyers
at
$
40
a
box
if
he
had

.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Taiwan
already
is
a
big
importer
of
Fujis
from
other
places
,
he
adds
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
But
his
first
crop
wo
n't
be
picked
till
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
expect
to
see
the
demand
exceed
supply
for
Fujis
for
the
next
10
to
15
years
,
''
he
adds
.
<END>
<START>
Washington
Red
Delicious
,
by
the
way
,
are
wholesaling
for
less
than
$
10
a
box
these
days
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Auvil
sees
Fujis
,
in
part
,
as
striking
a
blow
against
the
perversion
of
U.S.
apples
by
supermarkets
.
<END>
<START>
``
When
the
chain
stores
took
over
,
there
was
no
longer
a
connection
between
grower
and
consumer
.
<END>
<START>
A
guy
is
sitting
up
in
an
office
deciding
what
you
're
going
to
eat
.
''
<END>
<START>
After
all
,
until
the
1950s
even
the
Red
Delicious
was
a
firm
,
delectable
morsel
.
<END>
<START>
Then
,
as
growers
bred
them
more
for
looks
,
and
to
satisfy
supermarket
chains
'
demands
of
long-term
storage
,
the
Red
went
into
decline
.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
those
red
applelike
things
stores
sell
in
summer
are
fruitbowl
lovely
,
but
usually
not
good
eating
.
<END>
<START>
They
do
deserve
respect
,
however
--
they
are
almost
a
year
old
,
probably
equal
to
about
106
in
human
years
.
<END>
<START>
The
Fuji
,
to
be
sure
,
has
blemishes
too
.
<END>
<START>
It
ripens
later
than
most
apples
,
and
growing
it
in
U.S.
areas
with
chilly
autumns
may
be
tricky
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
the
frumpy
Fuji
must
compete
with
an
increasingly
dolledup
Delicious
.
<END>
<START>
And
he
had
n't
used
hormones
,
which
many
growers
employ
to
elongate
their
Delicious
apples
for
greater
eye
appeal
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
Mr.
Auvil
points
out
,
Grannies
became
popular
without
big
,
red
looks
,
so
why
not
Fujis
?
<END>
<START>
He
sees
a
shift
in
American
values
--
at
least
regarding
apples
--
toward
more
emphasis
on
substance
and
less
on
glitz
.
<END>
<START>
``
Taste
has
finally
come
to
the
fore
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Or
,
for
that
matter
,
the
core
.
<END>
<START>
Brush
Wellman
Inc.
said
its
board
increased
the
number
of
shares
of
common
stock
to
be
purchased
under
a
previously
authorized
program
to
3.9
million
from
2.9
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
maker
of
engineered
materials
has
acquired
more
than
2.7
million
shares
under
the
program
.
<END>
<START>
The
suit
sets
the
firms
'
liability
at
more
than
$
185
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
firms
are
Morgan
Stanley
&
Co.
,
Salomon
Brothers
Inc.
,
County
Natwest
Government
Securities
Inc.
,
Greenwich
Capital
Markets
Inc.
and
Goldman
,
Sachs
&
Co
.
<END>
<START>
The
firms
have
all
said
that
West
Virginia
's
suit
is
without
merit
.
<END>
<START>
On
Friday
,
the
firms
filed
a
suit
against
West
Virginia
in
New
York
state
court
asking
for
a
declaratory
judgment
absolving
them
of
liability
.
<END>
<START>
That
suit
is
pending
.
<END>
<START>
The
suits
relate
to
a
$
200
million
loss
,
disclosed
in
December
,
that
was
suffered
by
West
Virginia
's
consolidated
investment
pool
.
<END>
<START>
The
pool
invested
idle
cash
for
many
state
agencies
and
local
governments
.
<END>
<START>
In
its
suit
,
the
attorney
general
's
office
alleges
that
brokers
encouraged
members
of
the
treasurer
's
office
to
engage
in
high-volume
,
high-risk
transactions
that
benefited
the
brokers
.
<END>
<START>
Few
people
are
aware
that
the
federal
government
lends
almost
as
much
money
as
it
borrows
.
<END>
<START>
These
figures
omit
secondary
guarantees
,
deposit
insurance
,
and
the
activities
of
Government-Sponsored
Enterprises
-LRB-
a
huge
concern
in
its
own
right
,
as
detailed
on
this
page
May
3
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
Federal
credit
programs
date
back
to
the
New
Deal
,
and
were
meant
to
break
even
financially
.
<END>
<START>
As
we
will
see
,
many
of
these
obligations
do
n't
show
up
as
part
of
the
federal
deficit
.
<END>
<START>
But
recent
events
indicate
that
federal
credit
is
out
of
control
.
<END>
<START>
Student
loan
defaults
remain
high
at
about
12
%
,
and
the
program
has
been
rocked
by
allegations
of
fraud
and
mismanagement
.
<END>
<START>
Farmers
Home
Administration
-LRB-
FmHA
-RRB-
loans
have
turned
into
de
facto
giveaway
programs
;
losses
over
the
next
three
years
are
expected
to
exceed
$
20
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Defaults
on
Veterans
Affairs
loan
guarantees
have
quadrupled
in
the
past
eight
years
.
<END>
<START>
GAO
's
findings
are
particularly
troubling
because
the
FHA
has
about
$
300
billion
in
obligations
outstanding
and
had
previously
been
considered
one
of
the
most
financially
secure
credit
programs
.
<END>
<START>
Scores
of
other
credit
programs
,
subsidizing
agriculture
,
small
business
,
exporters
,
defense
,
energy
,
transportation
and
others
,
are
less
visible
but
in
no
better
shape
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Secondary
guarantees
of
pools
of
FHA
-
and
VA-backed
loans
by
the
agency
known
as
Ginnie
Mae
currently
exceed
$
330
billion
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Although
external
events
have
contributed
to
the
morass
,
the
principal
causes
of
the
current
crisis
are
internal
and
generic
to
all
programs
.
<END>
<START>
There
is
a
fundamental
conflict
between
providing
a
subsidy
and
maintaining
the
integrity
of
a
credit
program
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
program
is
meant
to
provide
a
subsidy
,
collecting
the
debt
defeats
the
original
goal
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
,
subsidized
loans
tend
to
turn
into
giveaway
programs
,
with
increasing
subsidy
and
default
rates
over
time
.
<END>
<START>
To
avoid
this
problem
,
government
should
issue
credit
only
if
it
intends
to
use
every
legal
method
to
collect
.
<END>
<START>
In
contrast
,
credit
programs
can
be
appropriate
tools
to
improve
the
operation
of
capital
markets
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
legal
restrictions
on
interstate
banking
once
inhibited
the
supply
of
credit
to
the
agricultural
sector
.
<END>
<START>
Farm
lending
was
enacted
to
correct
this
problem
by
providing
a
reliable
flow
of
lendable
funds
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
this
in
no
way
justifies
the
huge
government
subsidies
and
losses
on
such
loans
.
<END>
<START>
Credit
policy
should
separate
these
two
competing
objectives
and
eliminate
aspects
that
provide
the
subsidy
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
student
loans
currently
attempt
to
subsidize
college
attendance
and
mitigate
problems
created
by
the
fact
that
students
'
future
earnings
are
not
accepted
as
collateral
.
<END>
<START>
The
program
provides
highly
subsidized
loans
to
any
student
whose
family
earns
less
than
a
particular
amount
.
<END>
<START>
High
default
rates
,
a
low
interest
rate
,
and
government
coverage
of
all
interest
costs
while
the
student
is
in
school
make
program
costs
extremely
high
.
<END>
<START>
Families
that
do
not
need
the
loan
can
make
money
simply
by
putting
the
loan
in
the
bank
and
paying
it
back
when
the
student
graduates
.
<END>
<START>
In
contrast
,
a
student
loan
program
that
was
meant
solely
to
correct
capital-market
imperfections
would
allow
loans
for
any
student
,
regardless
of
family
income
,
at
market
or
near-market
rates
.
<END>
<START>
While
the
student
was
in
school
,
interest
costs
would
either
be
paid
by
the
student
or
added
to
the
loan
balance
.
<END>
<START>
This
program
,
combined
with
cash
grants
to
needy
students
,
would
reduce
program
costs
and
much
more
effectively
target
the
intended
beneficiaries
.
<END>
<START>
2
.
Provide
better
incentives
.
<END>
<START>
Given
the
structure
of
most
credit
programs
,
it
is
surprising
that
default
rates
are
not
even
higher
.
<END>
<START>
Guarantee
rates
are
typically
100
%
,
giving
lenders
little
reason
to
screen
customers
carefully
.
<END>
<START>
Reducing
those
rates
moderately
-LRB-
say
,
to
75
%
-RRB-
would
still
provide
substantial
assistance
to
borrowers
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
would
also
encourage
lenders
to
choose
more
creditworthy
customers
,
and
go
a
long
way
toward
reducing
defaults
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
the
Small
Business
Administration
has
had
reasonable
success
in
reducing
both
guarantee
rates
and
default
rates
in
its
Preferred
Lenders
'
Program
.
<END>
<START>
Borrowers
'
incentives
are
equally
skewed
.
<END>
<START>
Since
the
government
has
a
dismal
record
of
collecting
bad
debts
,
the
costs
to
the
borrower
of
defaulting
are
usually
low
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
it
is
often
possible
to
obtain
a
new
government
loan
even
if
existing
debts
are
not
paid
off
.
<END>
<START>
Simple
policy
prescriptions
in
this
case
would
be
to
improve
debt
collection
-LRB-
taking
the
gloves
off
contracted
collection
agencies
-RRB-
and
to
deny
new
credit
to
defaulters
.
<END>
<START>
These
provisions
would
be
difficult
to
enforce
for
a
program
intended
to
provide
a
subsidy
,
but
would
be
reasonable
and
effective
devices
for
programs
that
attempt
to
offset
market
imperfections
.
<END>
<START>
3
.
Record
the
true
costs
of
credit
programs
in
the
federal
budget
.
<END>
<START>
Loan
guarantees
do
n't
appear
at
all
until
the
borrower
defaults
,
so
new
guarantees
do
not
raise
the
deficit
,
even
though
they
create
future
liabilities
for
the
government
.
<END>
<START>
By
converting
an
expenditure
or
loan
to
a
guarantee
,
the
government
can
ensure
the
same
flow
of
resources
and
reduce
the
current
deficit
.
<END>
<START>
Predictably
,
guarantees
outstanding
have
risen
by
$
130
billion
since
1985
,
while
direct
loans
outstanding
have
fallen
by
$
30
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
true
budgetary
cost
of
a
credit
subsidy
is
the
discounted
value
of
the
net
costs
to
government
.
<END>
<START>
This
figure
could
be
estimated
using
techniques
employed
by
private
lenders
to
forecast
losses
,
or
determined
by
selling
loans
to
private
owners
-LRB-
without
federal
guarantees
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
A
budget
that
reflected
the
real
costs
of
lending
would
eliminate
incentives
to
convert
spending
or
lending
programs
to
guarantees
and
would
let
taxpayers
know
what
Congress
is
committing
them
to
.
<END>
<START>
4
.
Impose
standard
accounting
and
administrative
practices
.
<END>
<START>
Creative
accounting
is
a
hallmark
of
federal
credit
.
<END>
<START>
Many
agencies
roll
over
their
debt
,
paying
off
delinquent
loans
by
issuing
new
loans
,
or
converting
defaulted
loan
guarantees
into
direct
loans
.
<END>
<START>
In
any
case
,
they
avoid
having
to
write
off
the
loans
.
<END>
<START>
Some
agencies
simply
keep
bad
loans
on
the
books
;
as
late
as
1987
,
the
Export-Import
Bank
held
in
its
portfolio
at
face
value
loans
made
to
Cuba
in
the
1950s
.
<END>
<START>
More
seriously
,
FmHA
has
carried
several
billion
dollars
of
defaulted
loans
at
face
value
.
<END>
<START>
Until
GAO
's
recent
audit
,
FHA
books
had
not
been
subject
to
a
complete
external
audit
in
15
years
.
<END>
<START>
The
administration
of
federal
credit
should
closely
parallel
private
lending
practices
,
including
the
development
of
a
loan
loss
reserve
and
regular
outside
audits
.
<END>
<START>
Establishing
these
practices
would
permit
earlier
identification
of
emerging
financial
crises
,
provide
better
information
for
loan
sales
and
budgeting
decisions
,
and
reduce
fraud
.
<END>
<START>
Government
lending
was
not
intended
to
be
a
way
to
obfuscate
spending
figures
,
hide
fraudulent
activity
,
or
provide
large
subsidies
.
<END>
<START>
The
reforms
described
above
would
provide
a
more
limited
,
but
clearer
,
safer
and
ultimately
more
useful
role
for
government
as
a
lender
.
<END>
<START>
Without
such
reforms
,
credit
programs
will
continue
to
be
a
large-scale
,
high-risk
proposition
for
taxpayers
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Gale
is
an
assistant
professor
of
economics
at
UCLA
.
<END>
<START>
Malcolm
S.
Todt

in

.

.

.

.

,

.
<END>
<START>
The
Bush
administration
said
it
is
submitting
a
``
comprehensive
''
proposal
for
overhauling
agricultural
trade
that
could
help
break
an
impasse
in
the
current
round
of
multilateral
trade
negotiations
.
<END>
<START>
The
proposal
reiterates
the
U.S.
desire
to
scrap
or
reduce
a
host
of
trade-distorting
subsidies
on
farm
products
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
would
allow
considerable
flexibility
in
determining
how
and
when
these
goals
would
be
achieved
.
<END>
<START>
Trade
Representative
Carla
Hills
,
who
along
with
Agriculture
Secretary
Clayton
Yeutter
unveiled
the
proposal
,
said
she
is
confident
it
will
gain
considerable
support
from
the
U.S.
's
trading
partners
.
<END>
<START>
Another
U.S.
proposal
filed
Monday
urges
more
``
fair
play
''
in
services
trade
,
including
predictable
and
clear
rules
and
equality
in
the
treatment
of
foreign
and
domestic
service
companies
.
<END>
<START>
Unlike
the
earlier
U.S.
farm-trade
proposal
which
struck
European
countries
as
too
extreme
,
the
latest
plan
would
provide
some
room
for
maneuver
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
says
countries
could
temporarily
raise
tariffs
on
certain
products
if
they
experience
an
unusually
heavy
volume
of
imports
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
of
proposing
a
complete
elimination
of
farm
subsidies
,
as
the
earlier
U.S.
proposal
did
,
the
new
package
calls
for
the
elimination
of
only
the
most
tradedistorting
ones
.
<END>
<START>
Less
objectionable
ones
would
be
subject
only
to
some
restraints
,
and
others
with
a
``
relatively
minor
trade
impact
''
would
be
allowed
to
continue
under
certain
conditions
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
U.S.
plan
also
would
establish
procedures
to
prevent
countries
from
using
health
and
sanitation
rules
to
impede
trade
arbitrarily
.
<END>
<START>
The
goal
would
be
to
resolve
disputes
such
as
one
prompted
by
the
European
Community
's
current
attempt
to
bar
imports
of
beef
from
hormone-treated
U.S.
cattle
.
<END>
<START>
The
U.S.
contends
that
the
rules
are
n't
justified
on
health
grounds
.
<END>
<START>
To
encourage
more
competition
among
exporting
countries
,
the
U.S.
is
proposing
that
export
subsidies
,
including
tax
incentives
for
exporters
,
be
phased
out
in
five
years
.
<END>
<START>
Procter
&
Gamble
Co.
,

and
continued

overseas
,

38
%

in

net

.
<END>
<START>
Per-share
figures
have
been
adjusted
for
a
2-for-1

split
effective
Oct.
20
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
increased
6
%
to
$
5.58
billion
from
$
5.27
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Excluding
the

,
P&G
's
earnings
were
close
to
analysts
'
predictions
of
about
$
1.40
a
share
for
the
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Wall
Street
had
expected
a
modest
rise
in
the
company
's
domestic
sales
and

,
and
more

increases
in

.
<END>
<START>
One

sales
and

was
a
3
%

rise
for
most
P&G
products
,
except
coffee
,

said
.
<END>
<START>
Unit

,
or
amount
of

,
rose
about
11
%
in
the
international
segment
,
with
P&G
continuing
to
win

in

's

.
<END>
<START>
He
figures

will
expand

in

to
``
continue
that
momentum
.
''
<END>
<START>

were

,

.
<END>
<START>
Hugh

,

,

will

's

will

``

.
''

<START>

for

's

,

.

<START>

's

in

on

ahead
of

,

for

and

,

.

<START>
For

1990
,

's

,

.

,

,

of

.

<START>
``
But

''

In

,

.
<END>
<START>
One
big
factor
affecting

will

of
Edwin
L.

,

.

<START>
Because
of
his
remarkable
success
turning
around
P&G
's
international
operations
,
analysts
have
high
hopes
for

.
<END>
<START>
The
program
has
even
been
called
upon
to
create
``
safe
''
white
electoral
districts
in
municipalities
where
whites
are
the
minority
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
goal
of
the
Voting
Rights
Act
--
more
minorities
in
political
office
--
is
laudable
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
political
process
to
work
,
all
citizens
,
regardless
of
race
,
must
feel
represented
.
<END>
<START>
One
essential
indicator
that
they
are
is
that
members
of
minority
groups
get
elected
to
public
office
with
reasonable
frequency
.
<END>
<START>
As
is
,
blacks
constitute
12
%
of
the
population
,
but
fewer
than
2
%
of
elected
leaders
.
<END>
<START>
But
racial
gerrymandering
is
not
the
best
way
to
accomplish
that
essential
goal
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
a
quick
fix
for
a
complex
problem
.
<END>
<START>
Such
a
policy
implies
that
only
a
black
politician
can
speak
for
a
black
person
,
and
that
only
a
white
politician
can
govern
on
behalf
of
a
white
one
.
<END>
<START>
Examples
of
the
divisive
effects
of
racial
gerrymandering
can
be
seen
in
two
cities
--
New
York
and
Birmingham
,
Ala
.
<END>
<START>
When
they
reapportion
their
districts
after
the
1990
census
,
every
other
municipality
and
state
in
the
country
will
face
this
issue
.
<END>
<START>
New
York
City
:
<END>
<START>
Racial
gerrymandering
has
been
a
familiar
policy
in
New
York
City
since
1970
,
when
Congress
first
amended
the
Voting
Rights
Act
to
expand
its
reach
beyond
the
Southern
states
.
<END>
<START>
This
year
,
a
commission
appointed
by
the
mayor
to
revise
New
York
's
system
of
government
completed
a
new
charter
,
expanding
the
City
Council
to
51
from
35
members
.
<END>
<START>
Sometime
in
1991
,
as
soon
as
the
1990
census
becomes
available
,
a
redistricting
panel
will
redraw
the
City
Council
district
lines
.
<END>
<START>
Blacks
and
Hispanics
currently
make
up
38
%
of
the
city
's
population
and
hold
only
25
%
of
the
seats
on
the
council
.
<END>
<START>
To
win
their
seats
on
the
council
,
these
political
leaders
have
had
to
listen
to
all
the
voices
in
their
district
and
devise
public
policies
that
would
benefit
all
.
<END>
<START>
Often
they
have
found
that
the
relevant
issue
is
not
race
,
but
rather
housing
,
crime
prevention
or
education
.
<END>
<START>
Birmingham
,
Ala.
:
<END>
<START>
The
unusual
situation
in
Birmingham
vividly
illustrates
the
divisive
consequences
of
carving
out
safe
districts
for
racial
minorities
.
<END>
<START>
In
Birmingham
,
which
is
57
%
black
,
whites
are
the
minority
.
<END>
<START>
The
white
group
argued
that
whites
were
not
fully
and
fairly
represented
,
because
in
city-wide
elections
only
black
candidates
or
white
candidates
who
catered
to
``
black
interests
''
could
win
.
<END>
<START>
Richard
Arrington
,
Birmingham
's
black
mayor
,
lamented
the
consequences
.
<END>
<START>
``
In
the
past
,
people
who
had
to
run
for
office
had
to
moderate
their
views
because
they
could
n't
afford
to
offend
blacks
or
whites
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
Now
you
go
to
districts
,
you
're
likely
to
get
candidates
whose
views
are
more
extreme
,
white
and
black
,
on
racial
issues
.
''
<END>
<START>
Two
hundred
years
ago
,
critics
of
the
new
United
States
Constitution
warned
that
the
electoral
districts
for
Congress
were
too
large
and
encompassed
too
many
different
economic
interests
.
<END>
<START>
A
small
farmer
and
a
seaport
merchant
could
not
be
represented
by
the
same
spokesman
,
they
said
.
<END>
<START>
But
James
Madison
refuted
that
argument
in
one
of
the
most
celebrated
political
treatises
ever
written
,
No.
10
of
the
Federalist
Papers
.
<END>
<START>
Madison
explained
that
a
representative
's
duty
was
to
speak
not
for
the
narrow
interests
of
one
group
but
instead
for
the
common
good
.
<END>
<START>
Large
,
heterogeneous
election
districts
would
encourage
good
government
,
said
Madison
,
because
a
representative
would
be
compelled
to
serve
the
interests
of
all
his
constituents
and
be
servile
to
none
.
<END>
<START>
Madison
's
noble
and
unifying
vision
of
the
representative
still
can
guide
us
.
<END>
<START>
As
long
as
we
believe
that
all
Americans
,
of
every
race
and
ethnic
background
,
have
common
interests
and
can
live
together
cooperatively
,
our
political
map
should
reflect
our
belief
.
<END>
<START>
Racial
gerrymandering
--
creating
separate
black
and
white
districts
--
says
that
we
have
discarded
that
belief
in
our
ability
to
live
together
and
govern
ourselves
as
one
people
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
McCaughey
is
a
constitutional
scholar
at
the
Center
for
the
Study
of
the
Presidency
in
New
York
.
<END>
<START>
The
Justice
Department
has
distributed
these
new
guidelines
for
U.S.
Attorneys
prosecuting
RICO
cases
.
<END>
<START>
A
related
editorial
appears
today
.
<END>
<START>
Such
orders
can
have
a
wide-ranging
impact
on
third
parties
who
do
business
with
the
defendants
,
including
clients
,
vendors
,
banks
,
investors
,
creditors
,
dependents
,
and
others
.
<END>
<START>
In
order
to
ensure
that
the
rights
of
all
interested
parties
are
protected
,
the
Criminal
Division
has
instituted
the
following
requirements
to
control
the
use
of
TROs
in
RICO
prosecutions
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
It
should
be
noted
that
these
requirements
are
in
addition
to
any
other
existing
requirements
,
such
as
review
by
the
Asset
Forfeiture
Office
.
-RRB-
:
<END>
<START>
1
.
As
part
of
the
approval
process
for
RICO
prosecutions
,
the
prosecutor
must
submit
any
proposed
forfeiture
TRO
for
review
by
the
Organized
Crime
and
Racketeering
Section
.
<END>
<START>
The
prosecutor
must
show
that
less-intrusive
remedies
-LRB-
such
as
bonds
-RRB-
are
not
likely
to
preserve
the
assets
for
forfeiture
in
the
event
of
a
conviction
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
of
North
American-built
cars
and
trucks
plunged
20.5
%
in
mid-October
from
a
year
earlier
,
as
domestic
manufacturers
paid
the
price
for
heavy
incentives
earlier
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
``
People
are
waiting
for
-LCB-
new
-RCB-
factory
giveaways
,
''
said
Ben
Kaye
,
sales
manager
of
Bob
Brest
Auto
World
in
Lynn
,
Mass.
,
whose
sales
are
slow
.
<END>
<START>
This
trend
appears
to
be
especially
true
at
General
Motors
Corp.
,
which
used
both
dealer
and
consumer
incentives
to
ignite
sales
in
August
and
September
.
<END>
<START>
Since
then
,
deliveries
have
slumped
.
<END>
<START>
GM
's
car
sales
dropped
24.8
%
in
mid-October
to
69,980
,
while
truck
sales
fell
26
%
to
37,860
.
<END>
<START>
GM
also
had
dismal
results
in
the
first
10
days
of
the
month
,
while
other
auto
makers
reported
mixed
results
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
of
domestically
made
trucks
also
continued
to
be
sluggish
in
mid-October
,
dropping
22.8
%
to
94,543
from
a
year
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Ford
Motor
Co.
reported
a
21.2
%
drop
in
sales
of
domestic-made
cars
to
46,995
and
a
24.2
%
drop
in
domestic
trucks
to
31,143
.
<END>
<START>
The
sales
are
being
dragged
down
by
a
glut
of
1989
vehicles
,
said
Joel
Pitcoff
,
a
Ford
analyst
.
<END>
<START>
The
earlier
use
of
incentives
depleted
the
market
of
``
scavengers
''
for
bargain-basement
1989
cars
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Town
&
Country
Ford
in
Charlotte
,
N.C.
,
still
needs
to
move
about
850
1989
cars
and
trucks
.
<END>
<START>
Business
had
been
fairly
strong
until
Hurricane
Hugo
hit
the
area
,
but
has
been
down
since
.
<END>
<START>
Chrysler
Corp.
also
hit
the
rocks
in
mid-October
.
<END>
<START>
Honda
Motor
Co.
,
which
continues
to
have
short
supplies
of
domestically
made
Accords
,
saw
its
sales
of
North
American-built
cars
fall
14.1
%
to
8,355
.
<END>
<START>
But
sales
of
domestic
cars
and
trucks
at
Nissan
Motor
Corp.
rose
26.1
%
to
5,651
.
<END>
<START>
A
Nissan
spokesman
attributed
the
increase
to
the
use
of
incentives
this
year
and
not
a
year
ago
and
to
higher
fleet
sales
.
<END>
<START>
Toyota
Motor
Corp.
,
which
opened
a
plant
in
Georgetown
,
Ky.
,
last
year
,
saw
sales
triple
to
6,256
vehicles
.
<END>
<START>
a
-
Totals
include
only
vehicle
sales
reported
in
the
period
.
<END>
<START>
c
-
Domestic
car
<END>
<START>
d
-
Percent
change
greater
than
999
%
.
<END>
<START>
x
-
There
were
9
selling
days
in
the
most
recent
period
and
9
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Percentage
differences
based
on
daily
sales
rate
rather
than
sales
volume
.
<END>
<START>
Short
interest
in
Nasdaq
over-the-counter
stocks
rose
6
%
as
of
mid-October
,
its
biggest
jump
since
6.3
%
last
April
.
<END>
<START>
The
most
recent
OTC
short
interest
statistics
were
compiled
Oct.
13
,
the
day
the
Nasdaq
composite
index
slid
3
%
and
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
tumbled
7
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
coincidence
might
lead
to
the
conclusion
that
short-sellers
bet
heavily
on
that
day
that
OTC
stocks
would
decline
further
.
<END>
<START>
As
it
happens
,
the
Nasdaq
composite
did
continue
to
fall
for
two
days
after
the
initial
plunge
.
<END>
<START>
Generally
,
it
takes
five
business
days
to
transfer
stock
and
to
take
the
other
steps
necessary
to
settle
a
trade
.
<END>
<START>
Short
interest
,
which
represents
the
number
of
shares
borrowed
and
sold
,
but
not
yet
replaced
,
can
be
a
bad-expectations
barometer
for
many
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
Among
2,412
of
the
largest
OTC
issues
,
short
interest
rose
to
196.8
million
shares
,
from
185.7
million
in
2,379
stocks
in
September
.
<END>
<START>
Big
stocks
with
large
short
interest
gains
as
of
Oct.
13
included
First
Executive
,
Intel
,
Campeau
and
LIN
Broadcasting
.
<END>
<START>
Short
interest
in
First
Executive
,
an
insurance
issue
,
rose
55
%
to
3.8
million
.
<END>
<START>
Intel
's
short
interest
jumped
42
%
,
while
Campeau
's
increased
62
%
.
<END>
<START>
Intel
makes
semiconductors
and
Campeau
operates
department-store
chains
and
is
strained
for
cash
.
<END>
<START>
Meritor
Savings
again
had
the
dubious
honor
of
being
the
OTC
stock
with
the
biggest
short
interest
position
on
Nasdaq
.
<END>
<START>
Meritor
has
headed
the
list
since
May
.
<END>
<START>
First
Executive
and
troubled
Valley
National
Corp.
of
Arizona
were
next
in
line
.
<END>
<START>
Short
selling
is
n't
necessarily
bad
for
the
overall
market
.
<END>
<START>
Shorted
shares
must
eventually
be
replaced
through
buying
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
changes
in
short
interest
in
some
stocks
may
be
caused
by
arbitrage
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
an
investor
may
seek
to
profit
during
some
takeover
situations
by
buying
stock
in
one
company
involved
and
shorting
the
stock
of
the
other
.
<END>
<START>
Two
big
stocks
involved
in
takeover
activity
saw
their
short
interest
surge
.
<END>
<START>
Short
interest
in
the
American
depositary
receipts
of
Jaguar
,
the
target
of
both
Ford
Motor
and
General
Motors
,
more
than
doubled
.
<END>
<START>
Nasdaq
stocks
that
showed
a
drop
in
short
interest
included
Adobe
Systems
,
Class
A
shares
of
Tele-Communications
and
takeover
targets
Lyphomed
and
Jerrico
.
<END>
<START>
Short
interest
in
1,327
non-NMS
securities
totaled
40.3
million
shares
,
compared
with
almost
38
million
shares
in
1,310
issues
in
September
.
<END>
<START>
The
October
short
interest
represents
1.04
days
of
average
daily
trading
volume
in
the
smaller
stocks
in
the
system
for
the
reporting
period
,
compared
with
0.94
day
a
month
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Among
bigger
OTC
stocks
,
the
figures
represent
2.05
days
of
average
daily
volume
,
compared
with
2.14
days
in
September
.
<END>
<START>
From
the
Sept.
30-Oct
.
4
issue
of
The
Economist
:
<END>
<START>
What
defeated
General
Aoun
was
not
only
the
weight
of
the
Syrian
army
.
<END>
<START>
The
weight
of
Lebanon
's
history
was
also
against
him
;
and
it
is
a
history
Israel
is
in
danger
of
repeating
.
<END>
<START>
Like
Lebanon
,
and
however
unfairly
,
Israel
is
regarded
by
the
Arab
world
as
a
colonial
aberration
.
<END>
<START>
Its
best
hope
of
acceptance
by
its
neighbours
lies
in
reaching
a
settlement
with
the
Palestinians
.
<END>
<START>
Like
Lebanon
,
Israel
is
being
remade
by
demography
.
<END>
<START>
In
Greater
Israel
more
than
half
the
children
under
six
are
Muslims
.
<END>
<START>
Within
25
years
Jews
will
probably
be
the
minority
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
Israel
will
neither
share
power
with
all
these
Arabs
nor
,
says
its
present
prime
minister
,
redraw
its
borders
closer
to
its
pre-1967
Jewish
heartland
.
<END>
<START>
Unlike
the
Maronites
,
Israel
's
Jews
will
not
let
themselves
become
the
weakest
force
in
a
system
of
private
armies
;
Jerusalem
will
become
Belfast
before
it
becomes
Beirut
.
<END>
<START>
But
that
is
not
much
of
a
consolation
to
draw
from
the
failure
of
General
Aoun
.
<END>
<START>
The
Nasdaq
over-the-counter
market
did
n't
fully
recover
from
a
selling
stampede
,
and
closed
down
1.2
%
.
<END>
<START>
After
plummeting
1.8
%
at
one
point
during
the
day
,
the
composite
rebounded
a
little
,
but
finished
down
5.52
,
at
461.70
.
<END>
<START>
In
contrast
,
the
industrial
average
recovered
almost
completely
from
its
skid
and
closed
down
0.1
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
New
York
Stock
Exchange
Composite
was
0.4
%
lower
for
the
day
.
<END>
<START>
As
usual
,
the
over-the-counter
market
's
biggest
technology
stocks
were
hardest
hit
.
<END>
<START>
Microsoft
,
battered
by
profit
taking
in
recent
sessions
,
sank
as
much
as
4
;
but
it
finished
at
80
7/8
,
down
2
1/4
on
volume
of
one
million
shares
.
<END>
<START>
MCI
Communications
,
the
most
active
issue
,
finished
down
5/8
to
42
1/8
.
<END>
<START>
MCI
traded
as
low
as
41
3/8
during
the
session
.
<END>
<START>
Other
active
stocks
included
Jaguar
,
whose
American
depositary
receipts
added
1/8
to
11
1/4
.
<END>
<START>
Apple
Computer
improved
7/8
to
47
5/8
;
Intel
slipped
1/4
to
33
1/4
,
and
Valley
National
Corp.
was
up
1/8
to
15
1/8
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
computer-guided
selling
in
response
to
those
developments
dealt
a
serious
blow
to
the
over-the-counter
market
,
Mr.
DaPuzzo
said
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
DaPuzzo
also
complained
that
the
sharp
swings
in
stock
prices
lately
is
scaring
away
retail
and
foreign
investors
.
<END>
<START>
The
volatility
inherent
in
program
trading
troubled
other
traders
,
too
.
<END>
<START>
They
do
n't
like
the
risks
they
are
forced
to
assume
when
prices
swing
so
drastically
.
<END>
<START>
Market
makers
are
supposed
to
keep
supplies
of
stocks
on
hand
to
maintain
orderly
trading
when
imbalances
occur
.
<END>
<START>
That
means
that
on
days
when
prices
are
tumbling
and
sellers
abound
they
must
be
willing
to
buy
shares
from
sellers
when
no
one
else
will
.
<END>
<START>
In
such
an
environment
,
a
market
maker
can
absorb
huge
losses
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
recent
volatility
in
stock
prices
caused
by
the
program
trading
has
made
some
market
makers
less
willing
to
soak
up
the
stocks
that
are
for
sale
.
<END>
<START>
The
market
makers
say
they
are
n't
comfortable
carrying
big
positions
in
stocks
because
they
realize
prices
can
tumble
quickly
.
<END>
<START>
The
situation
makes
it
harder
to
buy
and
sell
shares
quickly
,
exacerbating
the
rise
and
fall
in
stock
prices
during
program-dominated
trading
.
<END>
<START>
Groused
Robert
Antolini
,
head
of
over-the-counter
trading
at
Donaldson
,
Lufkin
&
Jenrette
:
``
It
's
making
it
tough
for
traders
to
make
money
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
said
that
when
sell
programs
kick
in
,
many
traders
believe
that
``
there
's
no
sense
in
sticking
your
nose
out
because
you
're
an
instant
loser
.
''
<END>
<START>
Kinder-Care
Learning
Centers
added
1/4
to
4
7/8
on
461,200
shares
.
<END>
<START>
Shares
of
KinderCare
Inc.
closed
at
3
1/2
,
also
up
1/4
,
on
volume
of
700,000
.
<END>
<START>
Ohio
Casualty
dropped
2
1/8
to
49
1/2
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
posted
third-quarter
earnings
of
95
cents
a
share
,
down
from
$
1.26
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
estimated
that
losses
from
Hurricane
Hugo
reduced
net
income
by
32
cents
a
share
in
the
most

quarter
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said

from
the
Oct.
17
earthquake
in
California
have
n't
yet
been
determined
,
but
that
it
provides
earthquake

to
about
1,400
properties
in
the
stricken
area
.
<END>
<START>
Any
quake-related
losses
will
be
reported
in
the
fourth
quarter
,
the
company
said
.
<END>
<START>
North
Atlantic
Industries
jumped
1
to
5
3/4
.
<END>
<START>
The
electronics-instruments
maker
is
to
be
acquired
by
Asset
Management
Associates
for
$
7.25
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
LIN
Broadcasting
slid
1
3/8
to
108
3/4
,
despite
reporting
third-quarter
net
of
46
cents
a

,

from
39
cents
the

.

<START>
McCaw
was
unchanged
at

.
<END>
<START>

2
1/4

1/2
amid

about

's

.

<START>
IBM
is

,

confirmed
earlier

.

Remarketers
make

to

's

and

.
<END>
<START>
Omni
Capital
Group

1

1/4
.

<START>

company
said
net

38
cents

in

quarter
ended

,

cents
a
shares
a

.
<END>
<START>
Probably
the
most
clear-cut
Soviet
violation
,
for
example
,
is
the
Krasnoyarsk
radar
.
<END>
<START>
--
``
Arms
Control
Reality
,
''
Nov.
20
,
1984
,
the

some

.

--
``

,

,
''

.

``

.
''
<END>
<START>
The

,

<START>
--
The

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
--

from

Shevardnadze
to

,

.

<START>

constituted
,
I

,

of

.
<END>
<START>
--
Eduard
Shevardnadze
,
Oct.
23
,
1989
.
<END>
<START>
We
're
happy
,
we
guess
,
to
receive
confirmation
of
the
Krasnoyarsk
violation
from
the
Soviets
,
five
years
after
we
started
writing
about
it
.
<END>
<START>
Perhaps
even
the
American
apologists
will
now
accede
.
<END>
<START>
Without
question
,
something
intriguing
is
going
on
in
the
policy
chambers
of
the
Politburo
.
<END>
<START>
As
it
bids
for
new
agreements
,
new
loans
and
indeed
admission
to
the
civilized
world
,
the
Soviet
government
has
recognized
it
has
a
credibility
problem
.
<END>
<START>
So
after
70
years
,
it
is
confessing
the
obvious
,
hoping
to
be
believed
about
other
things
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
not
enough
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
Soviets
want
to
be
believed
,
they
need
to
start
telling
the
truth
about
more
than
the
totally
obvious
.
<END>
<START>
The
U.S.
government
has
never
waivered
in
its
assessment
of
this
incident
as
an
accident
at
a
biological
weapons
facility
there
,
and
hence
a
violation
of
the
1972
Biological
Weapons
Convention
.
<END>
<START>
The
Pentagon
's
recently
issued
``
Soviet
Military
Power
,
''
though
in
general
adopting
a
softer
line
,
repeated
the
Sverdlovsk
assessment
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
was
detailed
in
Congressional
testimony
this
past
February
:
An
explosion
at
the
Microbiology
and
Virology
Institute
in
Sverdlovsk
released
anthrax
germs
that
caused
a
significant
number
of
deaths
.
<END>
<START>
Since
Mr.
Shevardnadze
did
not
address
this
topic
before
the
Supreme
Soviet
,
the
Soviet
Union
's
official
position
remains
that
the
anthrax
deaths
were
caused
by
tainted
meat
.
<END>
<START>
We
doubt
this
claim
just
as
we
doubted
Mr.
Shevardnadze
's
assurance
last
year
that
Krasnoyarsk
did
n't

.
<END>
<START>

.

.

.

<START>

<START>

<START>

raised

,

.

.

.

<START>

,

.

January
<END>

.

.

<START>
The

.

<START>

<START>
Factory

off

;

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

held

,

July
's

.
<END>
<START>
The

.
<END>
<START>
The

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
The

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>

<START>

<START>

,

.
''
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>
Food

's

,

.
<END>
<START>
As

have

and

,

where

fail
.
<END>
<START>
Ownership
,

,
is

best

.
<END>
<START>
The
Poles
have
had

all

.
<END>
<START>
Poland
's
2.7
million
small
private
farms
cover
76
%
of

.
<END>
<START>
Like
the

,
the
Polish

is

the
nation
.
<END>
<START>
Try
as
they
might
,
the
Communists
could
neither
replace
nor
break
him
.
<END>
<START>
And
they
did
try
.
<END>
<START>
A
few
miles
past
Radzymin
,
a
dirt
road
narrows
to
a
track
of
sand
and
leads
into
Zalubice
,

.
<END>
<START>
Czeslaw
Pyszkiewicz
owns
30

in
14

.
<END>
<START>
He
grows
rye
and

for
a
few
hens
,
five

and
25

.
<END>
<START>
In

and

,

with

.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
bad

,
''

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
Their

was

.
<END>
<START>
The

to

.
<END>
<START>
Mr
Pyszkiewicz
smiles

.
<END>
<START>
He
expected

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

brought

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
``

,
''
he

.
<END>
<START>
``

,

.
''
<END>
<START>
A

,

,

the

.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
Russian
.
<END>
<START>
Good

.
<END>
<START>
Parts
are

.
<END>
<START>
Even

I
had

,

n't

.
''
<END>
<START>
The

can

for
coal
,

,

.
<END>
<START>
In
Poland
,

goes

want
;

,

.
<END>
<START>
The

take
first
crack

.
<END>
<START>
They
use
60
%

,

.
<END>
<START>
Yet

%

.
<END>
<START>
``
I

,
''

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
``
We
have

.
<END>
<START>
There
is

.
<END>
<START>
A
private
farmer
never

.
''
<END>
<START>
The
state
quit

onto
its

over
30

ago
.
<END>
<START>
But

never

.
<END>
<START>
Until

,

will

state
his
land
to

.
<END>
<START>
The

's

produce

state
.
<END>
<START>
His
allotment

,

<START>
Mobil

in

U.S.
,

as

as

month
,

's

.
<END>
<START>
Employees
have
n't

.
<END>

.
<END>
<START>

's

could

the

by

in

.
<END>
<START>

,

to

40

for

.
<END>
<START>

and

.
''
<END>

,

.
<END>
<START>
Most
oil
companies
,
including
Mobil
,
have
been

lower

earnings
,
largely
as
a
result
of
lower

from

as

.
<END>
<START>

's

that

is
reducing
its
U.S.

because
of
declining

output
.
<END>
<START>

,

said

and
production
operations
had

$
16
million
loss
in
the
third
quarter
,
while
comparable

234

.
<END>
<START>

,

in
this
country
fell
by
500,000

a

to
7.7
million
barrels
in

of
this
year
.
<END>
<START>

is
expected
to

.
<END>
<START>

``

''

.
<END>
<START>

to

operations
.

<START>

``

.

<END>

prosecutions
of
Drexel
Burnham
Lambert
,
Michael
Milken
and
Princeton/Newport
violated
notions
of
fundamental
fairness
.
<END>
<START>
Justice
is
attempting
to
avoid
a
replay
of
these
tactics
.
<END>
<START>
This
amounts
to
an
extraordinary
repudiation
of
the
tenure
of
New
York
mayoral
candidate
and
former
U.S.
Attorney
Rudolph
Giuliani
,
who
was
more
inclined
to
gathering
scalps
than
understanding
markets
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
guidelines
limit
the
pretrial
forfeitures
of
assets
of
RICOed
defendants
and
their
investors
,
clients
,
bankers
and
others
.
<END>
<START>
This
follows
earlier
new
guidelines
from
the
Tax
Division
prohibiting
Princeton/Newport-like
tax
cases
from
masquerading
as
RICO
cases
.
<END>
<START>
The
forfeiture
memo
cited
``
considerable
criticism
in
the
press
,
because
of
a
perception
that
pre-trial
freezing
of
assets
is
tantamount
to
a
seizure
of
property
without
due
process
.
''
<END>
<START>
These
changes
come
a
tad
late
for
Princeton/Newport
,
the
first
RICOed
securities
firm
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
forced
into
liquidation
before
trial
when
investors
yanked
their
funds
after
the
government
demanded
a
huge
pre-trial
asset
forfeiture
.
<END>
<START>
Prosecutors
wanted
$
23.8
million
in
forfeiture
for
alleged
tax
fraud
of
some
$
400,000
.
<END>
<START>
The
experience
of
Princeton/Newport
and
initiation

other
RICO-forfeiture
cases
against
legitimate

taught

that
a

would
be
an

bank
.
<END>
<START>

to

``
which

company

not

''
because
of

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>

.

<START>

's

<END>
<START>
Prices
of

moved
inversely
to
the
stock
market
as

sought

amid
growing

.
<END>
<START>

lower
against

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

rout
was

UAL
Corp.
's

.

<START>

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

in

and

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

5.8
million

,

.

reforms
,
a
spokesman
for
the
Foreign
Ministry
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
the
first

,
if
we
decide
to
do
so
,
for
Japan
to
extend
aid
of
this
kind
to
Eastern
European

,
''
the
spokesman
said
.
<END>
<START>
He
said

Minister
Toshiki
Kaifu
also
is
studying
the
possibility
of
a
visit
to
the
two
Eastern
bloc
nations
and
to
Western
Europe
next
January
.
<END>
<START>

were
a
major

in
two

of

between

and

.

in

against

,
''
President

after

in

,

.
<END>
<START>

:
``
Banks
must

.
''

.

,

.

<START>
Cray
Research
Inc.
forecast
that

will
be
a
no-growth
year
for
its
supercomputer
line
.
<END>
<START>
Cray
jolted
the
market
in
July
when
it
slashed
revenue
and
earnings
projections
for
this
year
,
citing
a
slowing
economy
that
has
delayed
orders
from
government
as
well
as
commercial
customers
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
made
its
1990
projection
--
an
unusual
event
for
Cray
--
in
announcing
improved
net
income
for
the
third
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Cray
said
it
earned
$
30.6
million
,
or
$
1.04
a
share
,
up
35
%
from
$
22.6
million
,
or
73
cents
a
share
,
a
year
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
gained
45
%
to
$
210.2
million
from
$
145.2
million
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
was
$
454.6
million
,
a
6.9
%
gain
from
$
425.4
million
.
<END>
<START>
Cray
made
its
announcement
after
the
stock
market
closed
.
<END>
<START>
In
New
York
Stock
Exchange
composite
trading
yesterday
,
Cray
closed
down
$
1.125
at
$
34.25
.
<END>
<START>
Cray
said
its
order
backlog
at
Sept.
30
was
$
315
million
,
down
$
25
million
from
June
30
.
<END>
<START>
He
added
that
the
company
expects
``
strong
''
operating
profit
for
the
year
,
``
but
at
a
level
significantly
lower
than
last
year
.
''
<END>
<START>
Last
year
,
Cray
earned
$
156.6
million
,
or
$
4.99
a
share
,
on
revenue
of
$
756.3
million
.
<END>
<START>
Next
year
``
looks
dismal
,
''
said
analyst
Paul
Luber
of
Robert
Baird
&
Co.
,
Milwaukee
.
<END>
<START>
Cray
has
indicated
it
will
decide
on
whether
to
build
such
a
machine
before
year
end
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
rose
to
$
2.45
billion
from
$
2.2
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
year-ago
per-share
earnings
are
adjusted
to
reflect
a
2-for-1
stock
split
last
May
.
<END>
<START>
David
J.
Lothson
,
an
industry
analyst
for
PaineWebber
Group
Inc.
,
said
Johnson
&
Johnson
's
results
slightly
exceeded
his
expectations
for
the
third
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
In
New
York
Stock
Exchange
composite
trading
yesterday
,
Johnson
&
Johnson
shares
fell
37.5
cents
to
$
54.625
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Larsen
noted
``
substantial
sales
growth
''
for
the
recently
introduced
Acuvue
disposable
contact
lens
and
Hismanal
,
a
once-a-day
antihistamine
.
<END>
<START>
Eprex
,
used
by
dialysis
patients
who
are
anemic
,
and
Prepulsid
,
a
gastro-intestinal
drug
,
did
well
overseas
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
But
domestic
consumer
sales
slipped
1.2
%
for
the
quarter
,
to
$
490
million
from
$
496
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
cited
softness
in
the
retail
health
and
beauty
aids
category
,
``
as
well
as
the
intense
competition
in
the
company
's
sanitary
protection
product
line
.
''
<END>
<START>
Overseas
sales
were
stronger
,
principally
because
of
a
rebound
in
Brazil
,
where
economic
turmoil
had
hurt
year-earlier
results
,
Johnson
&
Johnson
said
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lothson
of
PaineWebber
said
the
company
's
sales
pace
has
been
picking
up
largely
because
the
effect
of
unfavorable
exchange
rates
has
been
easing
--
a
pattern
continuing
this
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
He
cautioned
,
however
,
that
a
``
tough
tax-rate
comparison
''
may
slow
the
company
's
earnings
growth
for
the
current
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
For
last
year
's
fourth
quarter
,
the
company
's
tax
rate
was
less
than
20
%
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
While
the
third
period
contained
no
major
surprises
,
Mr.
Lothson
said
,
the
results
show
how
sensitive
the
multinationals
can
be
to
developments
in
a
single
country
such
as
Brazil
.
<END>
<START>
He
also
questioned
whether
recent
gains
in
that
country
can
be
sustained
.

<START>
Insiders
have
been
selling
shares
in
Dun
&
Bradstreet
Corp.
,
the
huge
credit-information
concern
.
<END>
<START>
Six
top
executives
at
the
New
York-based
company
sold
shares
in
August
and
September
.
<END>
<START>
Four
of
those
insiders
sold
more
than
half
their
holdings
.
<END>
<START>
Much
of
the
recent
slide
in
Dun
&
Bradstreet
's
stock
came
late
last
week
,
after
negative
comments
by
analysts
at
Merrill
Lynch
&
Co.
and
Goldman
,
Sachs
&
Co
.
<END>
<START>
A
company
spokesman
declined
to
comment
and
said
that
the
officials
who
sold
shares
would
n't
comment
.
<END>
<START>
One
of
Dun
&
Bradstreet
's
chief
businesses
is
compiling
reports
that
rate
the
credit-worthiness
of
millions
of
American
companies
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
owns
Moody
's
Investors
Service
,
which
assigns
credit-ratings
to
bonds
and
preferred
stock
;
A.C.
Nielsen
,
known
for
its
data
on
television-viewing
patterns
,
and
Yellow-pages
publisher
Donnelley
.
<END>
<START>
Last
March
,
this
newspaper
reported
on
widespread
allegations
that
the
company
misled
many
customers
into
purchasing
more
credit-data
services
than
needed
.
<END>
<START>
In
June
,
the
company
agreed
to
settle
for
$
18
million
several
lawsuits
related
to
its
sales
practices
,
without
admitting
or
denying
the
charges
.
<END>
<START>
An
investigation
by
U.S.
Postal
inspectors
is
continuing
.
<END>
<START>
Among
the
insider
sales
,
Charles
Raikes
,
the
firm
's
general
counsel
,
sold
12,281
shares
in
August
,
representing
46
%
of
his
holdings
in
the
company
.
<END>
<START>
He
received
$
724,579
for
the
shares
,
according
to
insider

with
the

and
Exchange

.
<END>
<START>
John
C.

,

and
Dun
&

,

10,000

on

31
for

,

show
.
<END>
<START>
He

9,232

.

,

.
<END>
<START>

66

,

.

<START>

,

.

the

.

,

,

.

<START>

,

,

,

.

to

from

and

1990

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.

continues
to
rank
the
stock
a
longterm

.
<END>
<START>
The

slid
$
1.875
on
more
than
four
times

daily

.
<END>
<START>
The
stock
fell
75
cents
.
<END>
<START>

most

,

.

.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
only
God
exists
as
a
matter
of
absolute
necessity
;
it
is
built
into
His
nature
.
<END>
<START>
But
since
the
time
of
Darwin
,
we
humans
could
at
least
claim
a
sort
of
natural
necessity
for
the
existence
of
our
species
.
<END>
<START>
Are
n't
we
,
after
all
,
the
inevitable
culmination
of
that
stately
pageant
called
evolution
?
<END>
<START>
Now
along
comes
Stephen
Jay
Gould
to
dash
this
flattering
illusion
.
<END>
<START>
His
credentials
are
excellent
for
the
task
.
<END>
<START>
Star
lecturer
at
Harvard
,
author
of
numerous
popular
books
on
science
,
and
scourge
of
the
creationist
lobby
,
Mr.
Gould
is
perhaps
the
world
's
most
eminent
evolutionary
theorist
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
he
puts
quite
a
twist
on
the
old
story
handed
down
from
Darwin
.
<END>
<START>
The
argument
turns
on
the
discovery
in
1909
of
an
amazing
fossil
quarry
high
in
the
Canadian
Rockies
called
the
Burgess
Shale
.
<END>
<START>
Such
an
embarrassment
of
riches
was
inconceivable
to
the
man
who
discovered
the
Burgess
Shale
,
one
Charles
Doolittle
Walcott
.
<END>
<START>
The
received
Darwinian
wisdom
of
the
day
said
that
animals
living
so
long
ago
must
be
simple
in
design
,
limited
in
scope
and
ancestral
to
contemporary
species
.
<END>
<START>
Accordingly
,
the
hidebound
traditionalist
reconstructed
hypothetical
organisms
from
the
Burgess
fossils
in
such
a
way
that
they
could
be
shoehorned
into
familiar
categories
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
not
until
the
early
1970s
that
Cambridge
Prof.
Harry
Whittington
and
two
sharp
graduate
students
began
to
publish
a
reinterpretation
of
the
Burgess

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>
