<START>
People
start
their
own
businesses
for
many
reasons
.
<END>
<START>
But
a
chance
to
fill
out
sales-tax
records
is
rarely
one
of
them
.
<END>
<START>
Red
tape
is
the
bugaboo
of
small
business
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
every
business
owner
has
to
face
the
mound
of
forms
and
regulations
--
and
often
is
the
only
one
available
to
tackle
it
.
<END>
<START>
There
is
hope
of
change
.
<END>
<START>
Last
week
,
Sen.
Malcolm
Wallop
-LRB-
R.
,
Wyo
.
-RRB-
held
hearings
on
a
bill
to
strengthen
an
existing
law
designed
to
reduce
regulatory
hassles
for
small
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
``
A
great
many
federal
regulations
are
meant
for
larger
entities
and
do
n't
really
apply
to
small
businesses
,
''
says
Marian
Jacob
,
a
legislative
aide
to
Sen.
Wallop
.
<END>
<START>
Other
lawmakers
are
busy
trying
to
revive
the
recently
lapsed
Paperwork
Reduction
Act
,
which
many
feel
benefited
small
enterprises
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
,
optimistic
entrepreneurs
await
a
promised
land
of
less
red
tape
--
just
as
soon
as
Uncle
Sam
gets
around
to
arranging
it
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
they
tackle
the
mounds
of
paper
--
and
fantasize
about
a
dream
world
where
bulk-mail
postal
regulations
and
government
inspectors
are
banished
.
<END>
<START>
Some
entrepreneurs
say
the
red
tape
they
most
love
to
hate
is
red
tape
they
would
also
hate
to
lose
.
<END>
<START>
They
concede
that
much
of
the
government
meddling
that
torments
them
is
essential
to
the
public
good
,
and
even
to
their
own
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
West
cites
the
Federal
Communications
Commission
and
its
standards
for
telecommunications
equipment
:
``
They
monitor
product
quality
and
prevent
junk
from
flooding
the
market
.
''
<END>
<START>
Some
gripes
about
red
tape
are
predictable
:
Architects
complain
about
a
host
of
building
regulations
,
auto
leasing
companies
about
car
insurance
rules
.
<END>
<START>
Determining
when
handicapped
access
is
required
can
be
a
nightmare
for
architects
,
says
Mark
Dooling
,
president
of
Dooling
&
Co.
,
a
Newton
,
Mass.
,
architectural
firm
.
<END>
<START>
There
is
such
a
maze
of
federal
,
state
and
local
codes
that
``
building
inspectors
are
backing
away
from
interpreting
them
,
''
Mr.
Dooling
says
.
<END>
<START>
Taxi
,
leasing
and
other
companies
that
maintain
fleets
of
vehicles
devote
substantial
resources
to
complying
with
state
insurance
laws
and
a
host
of
agencies
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
very
costly
and
time-consuming
,
''
says
Phil
Rosen
,
a
partner
in
Fleet
&
Leasing
Management
Inc.
,
a
Boston
car-leasing
company
.
<END>
<START>
One
senior
executive
at
his
firm
spends
nearly
20
%
of
his
time
on
insurance
,
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Other
forms
of
red
tape
are
more
pervasive
.
<END>
<START>
The
most
onerous
,
many
entrepreneurs
say
,
is
the
record-keeping
and
filing
required
by
tax
authorities
.
<END>
<START>
Complying
with
environmental
and
workplace
regulations
runs
a
close
second
.
<END>
<START>
But
gripes
run
the
gamut
.
<END>
<START>
Here
is
the
red
tape
that
irks
surveyed
business
owners
the
most
:
<END>
<START>
ENVIRONMENTAL
REGULATIONS
:
<END>
<START>
Next
to
medical
insurance
,
``
costs
of
compliance
''
are
the
fastest-growing
expense
at
Impco
Inc.
,
a
Providence
,
R.I.
,
chemical
company
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Gebhard
adds
that
spending
on
environmental
red
tape
amounts
to
between
6.5
%
and
7.5
%
of
Impco
's
total
operating
expenses
.
<END>
<START>
One
state
environmental
regulator
returned
a
report
because
``
it
was
n't
heavy
enough
,
it
could
n't
have
been
correct
,
''
Mr.
Maguire
says
.
<END>
<START>
WITHHOLDING
RULES
:
<END>
<START>
Employers
must
deposit
withholding
taxes
exceeding
$
3,000
within
three
days
after
payroll
--
or
pay
stiff
penalties
--
and
that
's
a
big
problem
for
small
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
EMPLOYEE
MANUALS
:
<END>
<START>
An
employer
leaves
itself
open
to
a
great
deal
of
liability
if
its
employee
manuals
do
n't
reflect
the
most
recent
laws
,
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
ever-changing
laws
are
usually
so
complicated
and
confusing
that
``
you
need
professionals
to
help
you
;
you
ca
n't
do
it
yourself
,
''
he
adds
.
<END>
<START>
PENSION
AND
PROFIT-SHARING
RULES
:
<END>
<START>
Complying
with
these
is
enough
to
make
business
owners
look
forward
to
their
own
pension
days
.
<END>
<START>
Yearly
changes
in
federal
benefit
laws
force
small
businesses
to
repeatedly
re-evaluate
and
redesign
existing
plans
.
<END>
<START>
Alice
Fixx
,
who
runs
her
own
public-relations
concern
in
New
York
,
says
she
has
had
to
overhaul
her
pension
and
profit-sharing
plans
three
times
in
the
past
three
years
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
does
n't
increase
benefits
,
but
it
's
costly
and
time-consuming
,
''
Ms.
Fixx
says
.
<END>
<START>
Compliance
added
15
%
to
20
%
to
her
accounting
bill
last
year
,
she
says
.
<END>
<START>
SALES
TAX
RECORDS
:
<END>
<START>
Advertising
agencies
and
other
service
companies
are
exempt
from
city
and
state
sales
tax
in
most
locales
--
but
the
exemption
comes
at
a
price
of
exhaustive
records
and
rigorous
reviews
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
need
one
person
to
just
take
care
of
sales
tax
,
''
says
Jennie
Tong
,
executive
vice
president
of
Lee
Liu
&
Tong
Advertising
Inc.
,
New
York
.
<END>
<START>
When
the
Trinity
Repertory
Theater
named
Anne
Bogart
its
artistic
director
last
spring
,
the
nation
's
theatrical
cognoscenti
arched
a
collective
eyebrow
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Bogart
,
an
acclaimed
creator
of
deconstructed
dramatic
collages
that
tear
into
such
sacred
texts
as
Rodgers
and
Hammerstein
's
``
South
Pacific
,
''
is
decidedly
downtown
.
<END>
<START>
Trinity
Rep
meanwhile
is
one
of
the
nation
's
oldest
and
most
respected
regional
theaters
,
still
hosting
an
annual
``
A
Christmas
Carol
.
''
<END>
<START>
How
would
this
bastion
of
traditional
values
fare
in
Ms.
Bogart
's
iconoclastic
hands
?
<END>
<START>
She
held
her
fire
with
her
first
production
at
the
Trinity
earlier
this
season
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
a
predictable
revival
of
her
prize-winning
off-Broadway
anthology
of
Bertolt
Brecht
's
theoretical
writings
,
called
``
No
Plays
,
No
Poetry
.
''
<END>
<START>
Now
,
with
the
opening
of
Maxim
Gorky
's
bourgeois-bashing
``
Summerfolk
,
''
Ms.
Bogart
has
laid
her
cards
on
the
table
.
<END>
<START>
Hers
is
a
hand
that
will
test
the
mettle
of
her
audiences
.
<END>
<START>
And
Gorky
,
considered
the
father
of
Soviet
socialist
realism
,
did
not
write
plays
that
easily
lend
themselves
to
deliberately
antirealistic
distancing
techniques
.
<END>
<START>
Gorky
was
a
loyal
if
occasionally
ambivalent
proletarian
writer
committed
to
enlightening
the
masses
with
plain
speaking
rooted
in
a
slightly
sour
version
of
Chekhovian
humanism
.
<END>
<START>
Along
the
way
there
also
are
lots
of
romantic
dalliances
.
<END>
<START>
Wisely
Ms.
Bogart
has
kept
Gorky
's
time
and
place
intact
.
<END>
<START>
The
director
's
attempt
to
force
some
Brechtian
distance
between
her
actors
and
their
characters
frequently
backfires
with
performances
that
are
unduly
mannered
.
<END>
<START>
Not
only
do
the
actors
stand
outside
their
characters
and
make
it
clear
they
are
at
odds
with
them
,
but
they
often
literally
stand
on
their
heads
.
<END>
<START>
``
Talk
hurts
from
where
it
spurts
,
''
one
of
them
says
.
<END>
<START>
The
clash
of
ideologies
survives
this
treatment
,
but
the
nuance
and
richness
of
Gorky
's
individual
characters
have
vanished
in
the
scuffle
.
<END>
<START>
As
for
the
humor
that
Gorky
's
text
provides
,
when
repainted
in
such
broad
strokes
-LRB-
particularly
by
the
lesser
members
of
the
ensemble
-RRB-
it
looks
and
sounds
forced
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Bogart
does
better
with
music
than
with
words
when
she
wants
,
as
she
so
often
does
want
,
to
express
herself
through
Gorky
's
helpless
play
.
<END>
<START>
For
Gorky
,
Mr.
Helpern
provided
an

of
Debussy
and

,
which
is
less
a
score
than

separate

with
a

view
.
<END>
<START>
Like
Brecht
,
and

Pound
,
Ms.

has
said
that
her
intent
in
such

staging
of
the

is

``

.
''
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Bogart
's
cast
is
part
and

of
the
problem
.
<END>
<START>
Ed
Shea
and
Barbara

never

love

as
the
foolish
,

Vass
and

Maria

.
<END>
<START>
Cynthia
Strickland
as
the
long-suffering
Varvara
is
a
tiresome
whiner
,
not
the
inspirational
counterrevolutionary
Gorky
intended
.
<END>
<START>
Better
to
look
in
the
corners
for
performances
that
inspire
or

.
<END>
<START>
Janice
Duclos
,

's

,

<START>
Marni

as

.
<END>
<START>
Ms.

about

.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
During

,
The

will

that
stand

.

<END>
<START>
MORGAN
STANLEY
,
THE
ONCE
STODGY
investment
house
,
in
1974
helped
a
corporate
client
complete
a
hostile
takeover
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
the
start
of
a
boom
in
unfriendly
,
even
ungentlemanly
,
mergers
.
<END>
<START>
ESB
said
it
was
given
only
a
three-hour
advance
warning
on
a
``
take
it
or
leave
it
''
basis
from
Inco
,
as
the
Toronto
company
is
called
.
<END>
<START>
``
ESB
is
aware
that
a
hostile
tender
offer
is
being
made
by
a
foreign
company
for
all
of
ESB
's
shares
,
''
said
F.J.
Port
,
ESB
's
president
.
<END>
<START>
``
Hostile
''
thus
entered
the
merger-acquisition
lexicon
.
<END>
<START>
Joseph
Flom
,
of
Skadden
,
Arps
,
Slote
,
Meagher
&
Flom
,
which
became
a
leading
legal
firm
in
merger
cases
,
said
the
case
``
made
takeovers
respectable
.
''
<END>
<START>
Gray
was
advised
by
Goldman
Sachs
and
Merrill
Lynch
.
<END>
<START>
ESB
directors
warmly
accepted
,
but
a
whirlwind
bidding
match
ensued
.
<END>
<START>
Within
a
few
days
in
July
,
Inco
raised
its
bid
to
$
36
and
United
matched
it
.
<END>
<START>
On

day
Inco
lifted
its
offer
to
$
38
and
then
to
$
41
,
equal
to
$
225.5

.
<END>
<START>
United
met

$
38
but

.
<END>
<START>

29

--
unlike

intricate

of

--
was

.
<END>
<START>
The
new

's

.

,

<START>
The
decline
surprised
analysts
and
jolted
HomeFed
's
stock
,
which
lost
8.6
%
of
its
value
,
closing
at
$
38.50
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
,
down
$
3.625
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
had
been
projecting
fully
diluted
earnings
in
the
third
quarter
in
the
range
of
about
$
1.30
a

.
<END>
<START>
However
,
HomeFed
's
loan
originations
and

plunged
26
%
in
the
quarter
,
to
$
1.4
billion
from
$
1.9
billion
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,

assets
rose
to
$
593
million
from
$
518.7
million
.
<END>
<START>
Some
$
380
million
of

assets
is

,

55.6
%

from

$
244.2
million
of

property
HomeFed
held
a
year
ago
.
<END>
<START>
HomeFed
has
$
17.9
billion
of
assets
.
<END>
<START>
HomeFed
said
most
of
the
troubled
assets
are

,

and
other

.
<END>
<START>
It

are

,

rest
scattered

.
<END>
<START>
It

of

were
slower
than

in
the
third
quarter
,
but
it
expects

to

.
<END>
<START>
HomeFed

in

was
more

than
a
sign
of
cooling
in

.
<END>
<START>

in
California
would

for
West

,

less

,

.
<END>
<START>
It

21.7

,

.

<START>

,

.

<START>
Yields
on
certificates
of
deposit
at
major
banks
were
little
changed
in
the
latest
week
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
yield
on
six-month
CDs
of
$
50,000
and
less
slipped
to
7.96
%
from
8.00
%
,
according
to
Banxquote
Money
Markets
,
an
information
service
based
here
.
<END>
<START>
On
one-year
CDs
of
$
50,000
and
less
,
the
average
slid
to
8.02
%
from
8.06
%
.
<END>
<START>
Both
issues
are
among
the
most
popular
with
individual
investors
.
<END>
<START>
``
Because
of
shrinkage
in
the
economy
,
rates
can
be
expected
to
decline
over
a

,
''

Mehl
,

.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
unclear
how
much
rates
can
fall
and

.
''
<END>
<START>
Changes
in

in

week

were

with

within

range
for
the
last
two
months
.
<END>
<START>
Interest
rates
generally
began
declining
last
spring
after
moving
steadily
upward
for
more
than
a
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
yield
on
small-denomination
three-month
CDs
moved
up
two-hundredths
of
a
percentage
point
in
the
latest
week
to
7.85
%
.
<END>
<START>
Long-term
CDs
declined
just
a
fraction
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
yield
on
both
two-year
CDs
and
five-year
CDs
was
7.98
%
.
<END>
<START>
Only
CDs
sold
by
major
brokerage
firms
posted
significant
increases
in
average
yields
in
the
latest
week
,
reflecting
increased
yields
on
Treasury
bills
sold
at
Monday
's
auction
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
yield
on
six-month
broker-sold
CDs
rose
to
8.29
%
from
8.05
%
and
on
one-year
CDs
the
average
yield
rose
to
8.30
%
from
8.09
%
.
<END>
<START>
T-bills
sold
at
Monday
's
auction
yielded
7.90
%
for
six
months
and
7.77
%
for
three
months
,
up
from
7.82
%
and
7.61
%
,
respectively
,
the
week
before
.
<END>
<START>
So-called
jumbo
CDs
,
typically
in
denominations
of
$
90,000
and
up
,
also
usually
follow
T-bills
and
interest
rate
trends
in
general
more
than
those
aimed
at
small
investors
.
<END>
<START>
Some
jumbos
posted
fractional
changes
in
average
yields
this
week
,
both
up
and
down
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
yield
on
threemonth
jumbos
rose
to
8.00
%
from
7.96
%
,
while
the
two-year
average
fell
by
the
same
amount
to
7.89
%
.
<END>
<START>
Six-month
and
oneyear
yields
were
unchanged
,
on
average
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
-LRB-
CD
-RRB-
market
is
unsettled
right
now
,
''
said
Banxquote
's
Mr.
Mehl
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
very

by

in
the

and

.
''
<END>
<START>
The
small
changes
in
averages
reflect
generally

at

.
<END>
<START>
Some
,

,

.

<START>

.

.

<START>
Benjamin

.
<END>
<START>

did

.
<END>
<START>

,

's

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>

,
'
''

.

?

,

''

.

<START>

,
``

.
''

<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

,

:
``
OK
,

.
''
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
Already

in

's

65,000

.
<END>
<START>

,

.

<START>

,

.

.

,

<START>

,

.

<START>
Chancellor

Nigel

,

.

.

.

<START>
But

probably

''

.

business
,
''
warns
Charles
C.
Mihalek
,
a
Lexington
attorney
and
former
Kentucky
state
securities
commissioner
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
have
to
go
into
it
firmly
believing
that
it
's
the
kind
of
investment
where
you
can
lose
everything
.
''
<END>
<START>
And
many
have
done
just
that
.
<END>
<START>
Consider
Spendthrift
Farm
,
a
prominent
Lexington
horse
farm
that
went
public
in
1983
but
hit
hard
times
and
filed
for
bankruptcy-court
protection
last
year
.
<END>
<START>
A
group
of
investors
recently
bought
the
remaining
assets
of
Spendthrift
,
hoping
to
rebuild
it
.
<END>
<START>
Other
investors
have
lost
millions
in
partnerships
that
bought
thoroughbred
racehorses
or
stallion
breeding
rights
.
<END>
<START>
One
big
problem
has
been
the
thoroughbred
racehorse
market
.
<END>
<START>
From
1974
to
1984
,
prices
for
the
best
yearlings
at
the
summer
sales
rose
918
%
to
an
average
of
$
544,681
.
<END>
<START>
Since
then
,
prices
have
slumped
,
to
an
average
of
$
395,374
this
summer
.
<END>
<START>
But
that
's
for
the
best
horses
,
with
most
selling
for
much
less
--
as
little
as
$
100
for
some
pedestrian
thoroughbreds
.
<END>
<START>
Even
while
they
move
outside
their
traditional
tony
circle
,
racehorse
owners
still
try
to
capitalize
on
the
elan
of
the
sport
.
<END>
<START>
Glossy
brochures
circulated
at
racetracks
gush
about
the
limelight
of
the
winner
's
circle
and
high-society
schmoozing
.
<END>
<START>
One
handout
promises
:
``
Pedigrees
,
parties
,
post
times
,
parimutuels
and
pageantry
.
''
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
just
a
matter
of
marketing
and
promoting
ourselves
,
''
says
Headley
Bell
,
a
fifth-generation
horse
breeder
from
Lexington
.
<END>
<START>
Maybe
it
's
not
that
simple
.
<END>
<START>
For
starters
,
racehorse
buyers
have
to
remember
the
basic
problem
of
such
ventures
:
These
beasts
do
n't
come
with
warranties
.
<END>
<START>
And
for
every
champion
,
there
are
plenty
of
nags
.
<END>
<START>
One
brown
two-year-old
filly
was
wheezing
from
a
cold
,
while
another
had
splints
on
its
legs
,
keeping
both
animals
from
the
racetrack
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
can
see
the
highs
and
lows
of
the
business
all
under
one
roof
,
''
she
tells
the
group
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
are
n't
too
many
winners
.
''
<END>
<START>
Perhaps
the
biggest
hurdle
owners
face
is
convincing
newcomers
that
this
is
a
reputable
business
.
<END>
<START>
Some
badly
managed
partnerships
have
burned
investors
,
sometimes
after
they
received
advice
from
industry
``
consultants
.
''
<END>
<START>
So
owners
have
developed
a
``
code
of
ethics
,
''
outlining
rules
for
consultants
and
agents
,
and
disclosure
of
fees
and
any
conflicts
of
interest
.
<END>
<START>
But
some
are
skeptical
of
the
code
's
effectiveness
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
industry
is
based
on
individual
honesty
,
''
says
Cap
Hershey
,
a
Lexington
horse
farmer
and
one
of
the
investors
who
bought
Spendthrift
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
the
drop
in
prices
for
thoroughbreds
,
owning
one
still
is
n't
cheap
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
low
end
,
investors
can
spend
$
15,000
or
more
to
own
a
racehorse
in
partnership
with
others
.
<END>
<START>
At
a
yearling
sale
,
a
buyer
can
go
solo
and
get
a
horse
for
a
few
thousand
dollars
.
<END>
<START>
But
that
means
paying
the
horse
's
maintenance
;
on
average
,
it
costs
$
25,000
a
year
to
raise
a
horse
.
<END>
<START>
BUELL
INDUSTRIES
Inc.

a

,

.

.

.

<START>

.

,

,

company
said

56

of
$
2.39
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
fell
1.5
%
to
$
884
million
from
$
897.2
million
.
<END>
<START>
Strong
profit
in
the
process
industries
,

and
pulp
and

,
were
offset
by
higher
interest
expense
and
by

as

.
<END>
<START>

reported

in

and

products
businesses
,
and

narrowed
its

in

.
<END>
<START>
Power
generation
had
higher
sales
but

;
the

cited
factors

on

from

.
<END>
<START>
Net
in

's

N.V.

.

<START>

.

.

<START>

.

,

.
<END>

will

to

,

.
<END>

is

.

<START>

,

,

.

.

.

<START>

.
<END>

from

partnership
between

1
and

31
.
<END>
<START>

is

Nov.
30
to

Oct.
31
.
<END>
<START>
The
money
manager
is
controlled
67.7
%
by

top
officers
and

of
Oppenheimer
&
Co.
,
a

.
<END>

.

Capital

7.9
million
limited

outstanding
.

New

Stock

,

,

.

.

.

18

.

,

,

and

,

.

7.5
%
to

million
from

.

F.

,

,

.

<START>
ALBERTA
ENERGY
Co.
,
Calgary
,
said
it
filed
a
preliminary
prospectus
for
an
offering
of
common
shares
.
<END>
<START>
The
natural
resources
development
concern
said
proceeds
will
be
used
to
repay
long-term
debt
,
which
stood
at
598
million
Canadian
dollars
-LRB-
US$
510.6
million
-RRB-
at
the
end
of
1988
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
plans
to
raise
between
C$
75
million
and
C$
100
million
from
the
offering
,
according
to
a
spokeswoman
at
Richardson
Greenshields
of
Canada
Ltd.
,
lead
underwriter
.
<END>
<START>
The
shares
will
be
priced
in
early
November
,
she
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
has
been
considered
an
industry
leader
in
advocating
cooperation
and
voluntary
disclosures
of
improper
or
inflated
billing
practices
.
<END>
<START>
The
dispute
stems
from
pretrial
maneuvering
in
the
pending
court
case
,
in
which
prosecutors
have
been
demanding
access
to
a
host
of
internal
company
memos
,
reports
and
documents
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
,
for
its
part
,
maintains
that
many
of
the
disputed
documents
are
privileged
attorney-client
communications
that
should
n't
be
turned
over
to
prosecutors
.
<END>
<START>
A
hearing
is
scheduled
on
the
issue
today
.
<END>
<START>
Prosecutors
depict
a
company
that
allegedly
sat
on
damaging
evidence
of
overcharges
from
1983
to
1985
,
despite
warnings
from
an
internal
auditor
.
<END>
<START>
When
GE
finally
disclosed
the
problems
,
prosecutors
contend
that
Mr.
Orr
``
was
erroneously
informed
that
the
-LCB-
suspected
-RCB-
practices
had
only
just
been
discovered
''
by
GE
management
.
<END>
<START>
In
its
brief
,
the
government
asserted
that
it
needs
the
internal
GE
documents
to
rebut
anticipated
efforts
by
GE
during
the
trial
to
demonstrate
``
its
good
corporate
character
.
''
<END>
<START>
GE
's
filing
contends
that
the
billing
practices
at
the
heart
of
the
current
controversy
involved
technical
disputes
rather
than
criminal
activity
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
's
conduct
``
does
not
even
raise
a
question
of
wrongful
corporate
intent
,
ratification
or
cover-up
,
''
GE
's
brief
asserts
.
<END>
<START>
``
On
the
contrary
,
it
shows
a
corporation
reacting
swiftly
and
aggressively
to
very
difficult
issues
in
largely
uncharted
waters
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Orr
could
n't
be
reached
for
comment
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
The
proposed
acquisition
provides
for
a
cash
payment
of
$
10
a
share
at
closing
and
a

payment
of
as

.

<START>

of

n't

,

.
<END>
<START>
There
are
3.5

Solar
,

.

on
the
back
of
Wall
Street
's
steep
drop
and
renewed
fears
over
U.K.
economic
fundamentals
.
<END>
<START>
Tokyo
's
winning
streak
came
to
an
end
,
and
stocks
fell
in
Frankfurt
and
across
Europe
as
well
.
<END>
<START>
London
's
Financial
Times
100-share
index
shed
40.4
points
to
finish
at
2149.3
.
<END>
<START>
At
London
's
close
,
the
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
was
51.23
points
lower
at
2611.68
.
<END>
<START>
The
trade
and
CBI
reports
refocused
attention
on
high
interest
rates
and
corporate
profitability
and
helped
rekindle
underlying
concerns
over
prospects
for
a
recession
in
the
U.K.
,
dealers
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
30-share
index
fell
33.3
points
to
1739.3
.
<END>
<START>
Volume
was
a
modest
405.4
million
shares
traded
,
but
better
than
the
year
's
lowest
turnover
of
276.8
million
Monday
.
<END>
<START>
Market
watchers
also
noted
an
absence
of
institutional
interest
later
in
the
session
helped
pave
the
way
for
broader
declines
when
Wall
Street
opened
weaker
.
<END>
<START>
They
added
that
market-makers
were
knocking
share
prices
down
in
midafternoon
in
a
bid
to
attract
some
interest
,
but
the
action
largely
helped
open
the
way
for

's
late

.
<END>
<START>
Insurance
stocks
provided

,

and

of

.

,

5
lower

640
,

15

#

.

<START>

finished
4
lower
at

.

<START>

,

,

.

.

.

,

.

<START>
On
Tuesday
,

Tokyo

index
of

was
down
6.31
at
2681.22
.
<END>
<START>
First
section
volume
was
estimated
at
900
million
shares
,
up
from
605
million
Monday
.
<END>
<START>
Observers
said
the
market
again
failed
to
find
a
trading
focus
,
discouraging
much
participation
by
investors
.
<END>
<START>
The
market
,
however
,
is
expected
to
remain
stable
and
expectations
for
future
gains
are
high
,
traders
said
.
<END>
<START>
Such
sentiment
is
being
supported
by
word
that
a
large
amount
of
cash
from
investment
trust
funds
is
scheduled
to
enter
the
market
later
this
week
and
in
early
November
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
to
a
large
amount
of
investment
trust
fund
cash
,
analysts
generally
see
the
market
environment
improving
compared
with

past

weeks
.
<END>
<START>
Toshiyuki
Nishimura
,
an

at
Yamaichi
Securities
,
said
,
``
The
market
sentiment
is
bullish
,
simply
because
there
are
few
bad
factors
.
''
<END>
<START>
Buying
activity
Tuesday
centered
on
a
wide
range
of
midcapitalization
,
domestic
demand-related
shares
whose
prices
range
from
1,000
to
2,000
yen
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
expect
these
shares
will
be
targets
of
investment
trust
funds
,
which
often
buy
small
amounts
spread

a
wide
range

.
<END>
<START>
Tuesday
's
notable
losers
were
highpriced

,

210
yen
to
5,900
yen
.
<END>
<START>

was
down
130
to
8,590
.
<END>
<START>

120
to
5,960
,

160

,

.

as

.

<START>

15.85
to

at
1507.37
.
<END>
<START>
It
jumped
7.5
Monday
.
<END>
<START>
Traders

was

,
as

.
<END>
<START>
Market

following

week
,
but

by
two

in
West
Germany
.
<END>
<START>
On

,

,

,
in

in

.

wo
n't

in

.

,

,

,

.

<START>
Here

's

,
as

,

.

To

,

close
of
1969
equaling
100
.
<END>
<START>
The
percentage
change
is
since

.

<START>
Directors
of
Bergen
Bank
and
Den
Norske
Creditbank
,
two
of
Norway
's
leading
banks
,
announced
they
had
agreed
to
the
formal
merger
of
the
banks
.
<END>
<START>
The
merger
would
create
Scandinavia
's
seventh
largest
bank
,
with
combined
assets
of
210
billion
Norwegian
kroner
-LRB-
$
30.3
billion
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
The
banks
said
an
application
for
a

to
merge
into
one
entity
to
be
called
Den
Norske
Bank
AS
was
sent
Monday
to

.
<END>
<START>
The
two
boards
said
in
a
joint
statement
that
the
proposed
merger
agreement
was
considered
in

board
meetings
in
Oslo
Monday
.
<END>
<START>
They
said
the
agreement
will
be
submitted
to
their
respective
supervisory
boards
next
Wednesday
.
<END>
<START>
Extraordinary
general
meetings
,
to
be
held
Nov.
28
,
will
decide
the
share
exchange
ratio
.
<END>
<START>
The
merger
requires
the
approval
of
Norwegian
authorities
.
<END>
<START>
Savings
and
loans
reject
blacks
for
mortgage
loans
twice
as
often
as
they
reject
whites
,
the
Office
of
Thrift
Supervision
said
.
<END>
<START>
But
that
does
n't
necessarily
mean
thrifts
are
discriminating
against
blacks
,
the
agency
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
office
,
an
arm
of
the
Treasury
,
said
it
does
n't
have
data
on
the
financial
position
of
applicants
and
thus
ca
n't
determine
why
blacks
are
rejected
more
often
.
<END>
<START>
Nevertheless
,
on
Capitol
Hill
,
where
the
information
was
released
yesterday
at
a
Senate
banking
subcommittee
hearing
,
lawmakers
said
they
are
worried
that
financial
institutions
are
routinely
discriminating
against
minorities
.
<END>
<START>
They
asked
regulators
to
suggest
new
ways
to
force
banks
and
thrifts
to
comply
with
anti-discrimination
laws
.
<END>
<START>
Sen.
Alan
Dixon
-LRB-
D
,
Ill.
-RRB-
,
chairman
of
the
subcommittee
on
consumer
and
regulatory

,
said
,
``
I
'm
not
a
statistician
.
<END>
<START>
The
trade
group
official
added
:
``
Certainly
the
federal
government
should
take
a
hard
look
at
it
.
''
<END>
<START>
Sen.
Dixon
held
the
hearing
to
follow
up
on
a
provision
in
the
savings
and
loan
bailout
bill
that
required
regulators
to
report
on
evidence
of
discimination
in
mortgage
lending
.
<END>
<START>
The
Federal
Reserve
said
its
studies
in
recent
years
,
which
adjust
for
income
differences
and
other
variables
,
showed
that
blacks
received
fewer
home
mortgages
from
banks
and
thrifts
than
whites
.
<END>
<START>
But
John
LaWare
,
a
Fed
governor
,
told
the
subcommittee
the
evidence
is
mixed
and
that
the
Fed
's
believes
the
vast
majority
of
banks
are
n't
discriminating
.
<END>
<START>
For
instance
,
he
noted
,
the
Fed
studies
have
shown
that
blacks
receive
more
home
improvement
loans
than
whites
.
<END>
<START>
Officials
of
the
Federal
Deposit
Insurance
Corp.
and
the
Office
of
the
Comptroller
of
the
Currency
said
they
have
punished
only
a
few
banks
for
violations
of
anti-discrimination
laws
.
<END>
<START>
The
FDIC
said
it
has
issued
five
citations
to
banks
over
the
past
three
years
for
discriminatory
practices
.
<END>
<START>
The
comptroller
's
office
said
it
found
no
indications
of
illegal
discrimination
in
3,437
examinations
of
banks
since
April
1987
.
<END>
<START>
The
comptroller
's
office
also
said
that
of
37,000
complaints
it
received
since
January
1987
,
only
16
alleged
racial
discrimination
in
real
estate
lending
.
<END>
<START>
The
agency
investigated
the
complaints
but
no
violations
were
cited
.
<END>
<START>
Thrift
regulators
did
n't
give
any
figures
on
their
enforcement
actions
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Fiechter
said
that
among
the
possibilities
being
considered
by
regulators
to
fight
discrimination
is
the
use
of
``
testers
''
--
government
investigators
who
would
pose
as
home
buyers
.
<END>
<START>
The
Department
of
Housing
and
Urban
Development
has
used
testers
to
investigate
discrimination
in
rental
housing
.
<END>
<START>
Using
testers
could
be
controversial
with
financial
institutions
,
but
Mr.
Grohl
said
the
U.S.
League
of
Savings
Institutions
had
n't
yet

any
position
on
the
matter
.
<END>
<START>
Time
is
also
fighting
the
transaction
on
other
fronts
,
by

to
discourage
other
cable
operators
from
joining
Tele-Communications
as

Showtime
,

.
<END>
<START>
Time

declined
to
comment
.
<END>
<START>
Tele-Communications
,
the
U.S.
's
largest
cable
company
,
said
it
may
seek
other
cable

to
join
in
its

.
<END>
<START>
Tele-Communications
is
HBO
's
largest
customer
,
and
the
two
have
a
number

other
business

.
<END>
<START>

,

even

Tele-Communications
in
as

,

.

<START>

,
''

<START>

Viacom
and
Tele-Communications
as

.
<END>
<START>
Viacom

declined
to
comment
.
<END>
<START>

,

'

,

n't

's

.
<END>
<START>

as

``

.
''
<END>
<START>
In

HBO
,

22
million

,
Time
Warner
separately
operates
cable-TV
system
serving
about
5.6

.
<END>
<START>
Tele-Communications
controls
close

million

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

both

and

.
<END>
<START>

,

more

,

MTV
,

.

<START>
Ironically
,

and

have

.

<START>

,

;

,

.

<START>
The

industry
's

,

shape
for
most
of
the
year
,
have
taken
a
sudden
turn
for
the
worse
in
the
past
few
weeks
.
<END>
<START>
Citing
rising
fuel

,

fare
cuts
and
a

in
travel
,
several
major
carriers
have
posted
or
are
expected
to
post
relatively
poor
third-quarter
results
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
,
USAir
Group
Inc.
,
recently
one
of
the
industry
's
stellar
performers
,
posted
a
worse-than-expected
$
77.7
million
net
loss
for
the
period
.
<END>
<START>
And
they
say
the
outlook
for
1990
is
nearly
as
bad
.
<END>
<START>
Airlines
in
1989
``
came
in
like
a

and
are
going
out
like

,
''
said
Kevin
Murphy
,
an

Morgan
Stanley
&
Co
.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
many
airline
companies
might
become
a
lot
less
attractive
as
takeover
targets
on
Wall
Street
.
<END>
<START>
The
downturn
also
raises
questions
about
the
carriers
'
ambitious
orders
for
new
airplanes
,
which
currently
total
$
32.5
billion
over
the
next
three
years
.
<END>
<START>
For
travelers
,
though
,
the
industry
's
problems
have
had
some
positive
effects
.
<END>
<START>
In
recent
weeks
,
airlines
have
cut
numerous
fares
in
leisure
markets
to
try
to
win
back
customers
.
<END>
<START>
Others
have
tried
to
spruce
up
frequent-flier
programs
.
<END>
<START>
Previously
,
airlines
were
limiting
the
programs
because
they
were
becoming
too
expensive
.
<END>
<START>
Shortly
before
that
,
USAir
had
said
its
third-quarter
results
would
be
``
significantly
lower
''
than
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
,
it
provided
the
details
:
<END>
<START>
Its
loss
of
$
77.7
million
,
or
$
1.86
a
share
,
contrasted
with
net
of
$
68.5
million
,
or
$
1.58
a
share
,
in
the
1988
third
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
rose
only
3.3
%
in
the
latest
period
,
to
$
1.53
billion
from
$
1.48
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
rose
12
%
to
$
4.75
billion
from
$
4.22
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
results
surprised
many
analysts
,
because
USAir
has
almost
no
competition
in
its
Pittsburgh
hub
and
has
expanded
operations
by
completing
its
acquisition
of
Piedmont
Airlines
.
<END>
<START>
Shortly
after
announcing
its
quarterly
loss
,
USAir
's
stock
tumbled
$
3
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
It
ended
at
$
40.125
,
down
$
2.375
,
in
New
York
Stock
Exchange
composite
trading
.
<END>
<START>
``
Nobody
was
expecting
this
size
of
a
loss
,
''
said
Paul
Karos
,
an
analyst
with
First
Boston
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
One
airline
executive
,
who
declined
to
be
identified
,
called
the
loss
``
amazing
.
''
<END>
<START>
In
announcing
the
results
,
USAir
cited
many
of
the
same
problems
that
several
other
industry
officials
have
named
recently
.
<END>
<START>
But
so
far
,
the
effort
has
failed
,
and
traffic
is
still
slow
.
<END>
<START>
Some
other
fare
promotions
have
backfired
.
<END>
<START>
This
summer
,
the
industry
introduced
a
``
kids
fly
free
''
program
,
in
which
children
were
allowed
to
fly
free
if
they
were
traveling
with
an
adult
.
<END>
<START>
Airlines
tried
to
restrict
the
program
substantially
by
limiting
the
offer
to
certain
days
of
the
week
,
but
it
still
was
apparently
used
far
more
heavily
than
the
airlines
expected
.
<END>
<START>
Airlines
also
say
their
frequent-flier
programs
are
squeezing
profits
because
awards
are
being
redeemed
at
a
heavier-than-normal
rate
.
<END>
<START>
Rising
operating
expenses
are
another
problem
.
<END>
<START>
Fuel
costs
were
up
10
%
in
the
third
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Labor
costs
,
which
leveled
off
in
the
past
few
years
because
of
lower
pay
scales
for
newer
employees
,
are
on
the
upswing
again
at
many
carriers
.
<END>
<START>
And
some
carriers
are
facing
other
unexpected
headaches
:
USAir
,
for
example
,
blamed
some
of
its
loss
on
merger
expenses
and
on
disruptions
caused
by
Hurricane
Hugo
last
month
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
can
not
quantify
the
total
adverse
effects
of
Hugo
,
''
said
Edwin
Colodny
,
chairman
and
president
of
USAir
Group
.
<END>
<START>
Whatever
the
cause
for
the
downturn
,
few
people
are
predicting
any
sudden
improvement
.
<END>
<START>
As
for
1990
,
the
firm
predicts
that
profit
will
slip
to
between
$
1
billion
and
$
1.5
billion
.
<END>

grief

,

,

Australian

-LRB-
US$
17
million
-RRB-
.

,

,

.

20

,

.

.

.

5.32

-RRB-
,

.

<START>

,

,

,

.

5

.

,

A$

,
1990
,

That

,

<START>

,

4

,

,

.

.

.

<START>

8.8

.
<END>
<START>

has
been

,

.
<END>

3

.

<START>

new

,

a

of

among
Japanese

,
replaced
a
higher

that
applied
to

.
<END>
<START>
Japanese
domestic
motor-vehicle
sales
rose
12
%
in
September
,
the
Japan
Automobile
Dealers
'
Association
said
earlier
this
month
.
<END>
<START>
The
manufacturers
'
association
will
issue
statistics
on
vehicle
exports
later
this
month
.
<END>
<START>
Production
of
cars
rose
to
801,835
units
in
September
,
a
5.5
%
increase
from
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Midsized
cars
accounted
for
the
greatest
growth
in
units
,
rising
62,872
units
to
134,550
units
,
or
88
%
.
<END>
<START>
Minicar
output
more
than
tripled
.
<END>
<START>
Manufacturers
produced
46,835
of
the
vehicles
--
which
have
engines
of
500
cubic
centimeters
or
less
--
an
increase
of
31,777
units
.
<END>
<START>
Total
truck
production
fell
22
%
from
a
year
earlier
to
315,546
units
.
<END>
<START>
Minitruck
production
fell
13
%
to
94,243
units
.
<END>
<START>
Bus
production
also
slipped
,
by
49
%
from
a
year
earlier
to
2,936
units
.
<END>
<START>
The
association
spokesman
said
bus
production
has
declined
since
January
,
but
could
n't
offer
an
explanation
for
the
fall
.
<END>
<START>
Auto
production
for
the
first
half
of
the
fiscal
year
,
which
began
in
August
,
totaled
6,379,884
units
,
the
association
said
.
<END>
<START>
Half-year
production
was
up
3.4
%
compared
with
the
same

a

.
<END>
<START>
The

closed

only

at
2659.22
.
<END>
<START>
UAL

$

,

.
<END>
<START>

a

4.9

,

UAL

.
<END>
<START>
Traders

that
Bear
,

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>

<START>

.

<START>
He

.

.

also
is
said
to
be
very
unhappy
.
<END>
<START>
SCI
TV
's
six
stations
once
were
part
of
Storer
Communications
.
<END>
<START>
KKR
loaded
up
the
cable
and
television
company
with
debt
in
an
1985
buy-out
,
then
later
sold
Storer
's
cable
operations
at
a
fat
profit
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Storer
also
took
$
125
million
of
junior
SCI
TV
bonds
as
partial
payment
for
the
TV
assets
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
With
the
other
hand
,
KKR
put
back
into
SCI
TV
less
than
10
%
of
the
cash
it
had
taken
out
,
buying
SCI
TV
common
and
preferred
shares
.
<END>
<START>
On
Storer
as
a
whole
,
KKR
racked
up
compound
annual
returns
of
60
%
in
the
three
years
it
owned
Storer
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
Mr.
Gillett
risks
losing
his
entire
equity
investment
of
about
$
100
million
in
SCI
TV
if
the
company
ca
n't
be
restructured
.
<END>
<START>
Overall
,
Mr.
Gillett
's
holding
company
,
Gillett
Holdings
,
is
heavily
indebted
and
,
except
for
its
Vail
Mountain
resorts
,
is
n't
doing
very
well
.
<END>
<START>
SCI
TV
's
grace
period
for
paying
its
bills
is
due
to
expire
Nov.
16
.
<END>
<START>
It
now
is
quietly
circulating
among
creditors
a
preliminary
plan
to
restructure
debt
.
<END>
<START>
No
major
player
in
the
SCI
TV
deal
will
talk
publicly
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
's
understood
that
Mr.
Kravis
is
disappointed
that
Mr.
Gillett
did
n't
manage
to
boost
SCI
TV
's
operating
profit
after
the
buy-out
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Kravis
apparently
thinks
SCI
TV
can
survive
if
lenders
extend
its
debt
payments
until
TV
stations
rise
in
value
again
,
allowing
SCI
TV
to
sell
assets
to
pay
debt
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Gillett
is
said
to
be
proud
of
his
operating
record
;
he
has
lifted
some
stations
'
ratings
and
turned
around
a
Detroit
station
.
<END>
<START>
As
for
junk-holders
,
they
're
discovering
it
can
be
a
mistake
to
take
the
other
side
of
a
trade
by
KKR
.
<END>
<START>
People
who
have
seen
SCI
TV
's
restructuring
plan
say
it
offers
concessions
by
KKR
and
Gillett
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
But
some
militant
SCI
TV
junk-holders
say
that
's
not
enough
.
<END>
<START>
They
contend
that
SCI
TV
's
equity
now
is
worthless
.
<END>
<START>
Kemper
,
the
biggest
holder
of
senior
SCI
TV
bonds
,
has
refused
to
join
the
bond-holders
committee
and
is
said
to
be
reviewing
its
legal
options
.
<END>
<START>
To
protect
their
claims
,
some
junk-holders
want
KKR
and
perhaps
Mr.
Gillett
to
invest
new
money
in
SCI
TV
,
perhaps
$
50
million
or
more
.
<END>
<START>
One
investment
banker
who
is
n't
involved
in
the
deal
says
SCI
TV
needs
at
least
$
50
million
of
new
equity
to
survive
.
<END>
<START>
This
could
be
the
first
major
bankruptcy-law
proceeding
for
KKR
,
he
adds
.
<END>
<START>
A
big
bankruptcy-court
case
might
tarnish
KKR
's
name
,
and
provide
new
fuel
for
critics
of
LBOs
in
Washington
and
elsewhere
.
<END>
<START>
But
others
say
junk-holders
have
nothing
to
gain
by
putting
SCI
TV
into
bankruptcy-law
proceedings
.
<END>
<START>
While
KKR
does
n't
control
SCI
TV
which
is
unusual
for
a
KKR
investment
--
it
clearly
has
much
deeper
pockets
than
Mr.
Gillett
.
<END>
<START>
Bankruptcy
specialists
say
Mr.
Kravis
set
a
precedent
for
putting
new
money
in
sour
LBOs
recently
when
KKR
restructured
foundering
Seaman
Furniture
,
doubling
KKR
's
equity
stake
.
<END>
<START>
But
with
Seaman
,
KKR
was
only
trying
to
salvage
its
original
investment
,
says
bankruptcy
investor
James
Rubin
of
Sass
Lamle
Rubin
in
New
York
.
<END>
<START>
By
contrast
,
KKR
probably
has
already
made
all
the
money
it
can
on
SCI
TV
.
<END>
<START>
And
people
who
know
Mr.
Kravis
say
he
is
n't
in
a
hurry
to
pour
more
money
into
SCI
TV
.
<END>
<START>
Rubbermaid
Inc.
,
reflecting
strong
earnings
growth
,
boosted
its
quarterly
dividend
18
%
,
to
13
cents
a

from
11
cents
.
<END>
<START>
The
maker
of
household
products
said
the
new
dividend
is
payable
Dec.
1
to
shares
of
record
Nov.
10
.
<END>
<START>
Separately
,

company
's
board
adopted
a
proposal
to
amend
its
1986
shareholder
rights
plan
,
further
insulating
the
company
from

.
<END>
<START>
Rubbermaid

said

are
n't

of
any

to
take

the
company
,
but
believed

needed
to
be

.
<END>
<START>
``
The
board
has
stated
repeatedly
that
Rubbermaid
should
be
independent
,
''
said
Walter
W.
Williams
,
Rubbermaid
president
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
rose
9.7
%
to
$
351.5
million
from
$
320.4
million
.
<END>
<START>
Rubbermaid
shares
closed
yesterday
at
$
33.875
,
off
12.5
cents
,
in
New
York
Stock
Exchange
composite
trading
.
<END>
<START>
The
stock
market
went
on
a
dizzying
ride
as
UAL
,
parent
of
United
Airlines
,
once
again
led
shares
into
a
breathtaking
decline
and
then
an
afternoon
comeback
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
end
of
it
all
,
the
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
closed
down
3.69
to
2659.22
.
<END>
<START>
At
one
point
yesterday
morning
,
the
Dow
was
down
80.53
points
.
<END>
<START>
New
York
Stock
Exchange
volume
was
237,960,000
shares
.
<END>
<START>
Declining
issues
swamped
advancers
,
1,222
to
382
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
's
sell-off
and
rebound
was
a
powerful
reminder
that
11
days
after
the
190-point
plunge
on
Friday
the
13th
,
the
stock
market
still
has
a
bad
case
of
nerves
.
<END>
<START>
Takeover
stock
speculation
and
futures-related
program
trading
drove
the
industrial
average
through
wide
ranges
.
<END>
<START>
And
there
is
more
volatility
to
come
.
<END>
<START>
``
October
13th
left
us
with
a
cut
and
exposed
nerve
,
''
said
Jack
Solomon
,
technical
analyst
for
Bear
Stearns
.
<END>
<START>
``
People
are
fearful
and
sensitive
.
<END>
<START>
Everybody
's
finger
is
one
inch
closer
to
the
button
.
<END>
<START>
I
have
never
had
as
many
calls
as
I
had
this
morning
.
<END>
<START>
Volatility
is
here
to
stay
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
plunged
about
80
points
in
slightly
more
than
one
hour
after
the
opening
bell
.
<END>
<START>
For
many
,
it
began
to
look
like
a
replay
of
Oct.
13
.
<END>
<START>
As
stocks
and
stock-index
futures
fell
,
a
trading
limit
was
hit
in
the
S&P
500
stock
futures
pit
.
<END>
<START>
Under
a
post-1987
crash
reform
,
the
Chicago
Mercantile
Exchange
would
n't
permit
the
December
S&P
futures
to
fall
further
than
12
points
for
a
half
hour
.
<END>
<START>
That
caused
a
brief
period
of
panic
selling
of
stocks
on
the
Big
Board
.
<END>
<START>
But
at
a
critical
moment
,
stock-index
arbitrage
traders
showed
their
power
and
control
.
<END>
<START>
They
scooped
up
hundreds
of
S&P
futures
when
the
market
needed
it
most
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
is
very
clear
that
those
buy
orders
came
from
people
who
wanted
their
franchise
protected
,
''
said
one
Chicago-based
futures
trader
.
<END>
<START>
``
These
guys
wanted
to
do
something
to
show
how
powerful
they
are
.
''
<END>
<START>
Traders
said
Goldman
Sachs
,
Shearson
Lehman
Hutton
and
Salomon
Brothers
were
the
main
force
behind
the
futures
buying
at
the
pivotal
moment
.
<END>
<START>
Shearson
Lehman
Hutton
declined
to
comment
.
<END>
<START>
Officials
at
Goldman
Sachs
and
Salomon
Brothers
were
unavailable
for
comment
.
<END>
<START>
As
in
the
Oct.
13
massacre
,
yesterday
morning
's
drop
was
triggered
by
bad
news
for
speculators
in
UAL
.
<END>
<START>
A
UAL
statement
after
the
market
closed
Monday
indicated
that
the
airline
's
board
wanted
to
keep
the
company
independent
,
effectively
crushing
hopes
of
an
immediate
buy-out
.
<END>
<START>
UAL
finally
opened
for
trading
at
10:08
a.m.
at
150
,
down
$
28
.
<END>
<START>
Floor
traders
said
there
was
a
huge
crowd
around
the
Big
Board
specialist
's
post
where
UAL
trades
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
was
a
seething
mass
of
people
,
''
said
one
floor
trader
.
<END>
<START>
``
Then
there
was
a
big
liquidation
of
stock
''
across
the
board
,
he
added
.
<END>
<START>
Shortly
after
the
UAL
opening
,
program
traders
started
selling
stocks
in
the
Major
Market
Index
and
S&P
500
index
.
<END>
<START>
The
20-stock
MMI
mimics
the
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
.
<END>
<START>
By
10:30
a.m.
the
Dow
was
down
62.70
.
<END>
<START>
All
20-stocks
in
the
MMI
except
Exxon
,
General
Motors
and
Sears
were
down
$
1
to
$
2
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
rules
adopted
by
the
Chicago
Mercantile
Exchange
,
the
futures
contract
can
not
drop
below
the
limit
,
but
buyers
can
purchase
futures
.
<END>
<START>
At
this
point
,
the
Dow
industrials
were
down
75.41
points
and
falling
.
<END>
<START>
The
trading
halt
in
the
S&P
500
futures
exacerbated
selling
and
confusion
,
many
traders
maintain
.
<END>
<START>
But
as
the
fright
began
to
spread
through
the
S&P
pit
,
the
big
brokerage
firms
came
in
and
bought
futures
aggressively
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
was
whooosh
!
''
said
one
futures
trader
.
<END>
<START>
In
five
minutes
,
the
Dow
industrials
climbed
almost
30
points
.
<END>
<START>
The
big
futures
buying
triggered
stock-index
buy
programs
that
eventually
trimmed
the
Dow
's
loss
to
31
points
by
11
a.m
.
<END>
<START>
Traders
said
the
futures
buying
was
finely
calculated
by
program
traders
.
<END>
<START>
Then
they
completed
the
other
side
of
the
trade
by
buying
futures
,
which
abruptly
halted
the
stock
market
's
decline
as
traders
began
to
buy
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
From
then
on
,
the
Dow
industrials
held
at
a
loss
of
40
to
50
points
.
<END>
<START>
Then
,
in
late-afternoon
trading
,
hundred-thousand-share
buy
orders
for
UAL
hit
the
market
,
including
a
200,000-share
order
through
Bear
Stearns
that
seemed
to
spark
UAL
's
late
price
surge
.
<END>
<START>
Almost
simultaneously
,
PaineWebber
began
a
very
visible
buy
program
for
dozens
of
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
The
combined
buying
rallied
the
Dow
into
a
small
gain
,
before
closing
at
a
slight
loss
.
<END>
<START>
Some
institutional
traders
loved
the
wild
ride
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
fun
,
''
asserted
Susan
Del
Signore
,

at

Management
Co
.
<END>
<START>
She
said

used
the
market
's
wild

to
buy
shares
cheaply
on
the
sell-off
.
<END>
<START>
On
the
comeback
,
Ms.
Del
Signore
unloaded
shares
she
has
been
aiming
to
get
rid
of
.
<END>
<START>
But

who
risk
money
handling
big
blocks
of
stock
were

.
<END>
<START>
``
This
market
is

away

,
''

Chung
Lew
,

at
Kleinwort
Benson
North

Inc
.
<END>
<START>
``
Credibility
sounds
intangible
.
<END>
<START>
But
I
think

are
losing

because
when

does

,

.
<END>
<START>
But

,

still
.
''
<END>
<START>
Dow
Jones
climbed
5
3/4

41
on
very

786,100

.

.
<END>

.

.

,

.

<START>

<END>
<START>
After
being
whipsawed
by
a
volatile
stock
market
,
Treasury
bonds
closed
higher
.
<END>
<START>
But
junk
bonds
took
more
hits
.
<END>
<START>
That
happens
when
nervous
stock
investors
dump
equities
and
buy
Treasurys
,
which
are
higher
in
quality
and
thus
considered
safe
.
<END>
<START>
At
one
point
,
the
Dow
Jones
Industrial
average
fell
about
80
points
on
news
that
UAL
Corp.
decided
to

independent
.
<END>
<START>
In

,

prices
soared
1
1/8

,

$
11.25
for

$
1,000

.
<END>
<START>
But

in

were

as

.
<END>
<START>
The
industrial
average
ended
at
2659.22
,
down
3.69
points
.
<END>
<START>
Economists
said
the
bond
market
's
strength
also
is
a
sign
that
investors
expect
the
Federal
Reserve
to
cut
interest

amid

that

.
<END>
<START>
While

do
n't
expect
the
Fed
to
move

,

case
for
lower
rates
is
building
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
,

,

reported

for

fell
0.1
%
,
while

.
<END>
<START>
The

's
30-year
bond
ended
over
1/4
point
higher
.
<END>
<START>
Municipal
,

and

rose
1/8
to
1/2
point
.
<END>
<START>
But

,

bonds
fell
1/4
to
1/2
point
with
the
stock
market
early

the

and
never

.
<END>
<START>
According

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
RJR
's
14.70

fell
2

.
<END>
<START>
Trading

in
the

market
was

as

could
n't

to

.
<END>
<START>
``
It
was

down

.
<END>
<START>
Everybody
was

.
''
<END>
<START>
TW
is
the
largest

of
Hardee
's
,
a

,
and
operates

.
<END>
<START>
Donaldson
Lufkin
would
n't

.
<END>
<START>
Also
,
the
TW

includes

and

,

are

.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
investors
turned
a
cold
shoulder
to
the
Treasury
's
sale
of
$
10
billion
of
new

yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
``
People

looking
past

to
lower

,
but

about

by

.
''
<END>
<START>
The
new

were

with

of
7.74
%
.
<END>
<START>
That
was
higher
than
the
7.71
%

7.73
%

that
traders
had
expected
.
<END>
<START>
In
when-issued
trading
,
the
notes
were
quoted
at
a
price
to
yield
7.78
%
.
<END>
<START>
Sluggish
demand
was
also
evidenced
by
the
weak
2.41-to-1
bid-to-cover
ratio
,
which
was
lower
than
the
average
2.79-to-1
ratio
at
the
last
12
similar
auctions
.
<END>
<START>
The
ratio
,
which
reflects
the
number
of
bids
the
Treasury
receives
for
each
bid
accepted
,
is
used
to

.

<START>

in

,

.

by

was

,
''

,

America

.

``

,

.
''

,

.

''

,

.

<START>

,

was

102
18/32

7.89

,

102
9/32

.
<END>
<START>
The
latest

Treasury
was

at
100
22/32
to
yield
7.88
%
,

with
100
17/32
to
yield
7.9
%
.
<END>
<START>
Short-term
rates
were
unchanged
to
slightly
lower
.
<END>
<START>
Rates
are
determined
by
the
difference
between
the
purchase
price
and
face
value
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
,
higher
bidding
narrows
the
investor
's
return
while
lower
bidding
widens
it
.
<END>
<START>
Corporate
Issues
<END>
<START>
Several
blue-chip
companies
tapped

market
yesterday
to

.

,

,

.

.

,

.

<START>
BSB
BANCORP

,

.

<START>
Genetic
Defect
Spotted
In
3-Day-Old
Embryo
<END>
<START>
RESEARCHERS
diagnosed
a
genetic
defect
in
a
three-day-old
mouse
embryo
in
an
experiment
directly
applicable
to
humans
.
<END>
<START>
Prenatal
diagnosis
of
genetic
defects
as
early
as
the
sixth
week
of
pregnancy
is
increasingly
common
today
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
mouse
experiment
at
a
Medical
Research
Council
laboratory
in
London
shows
genetic
defects
can
be
detected
three
days
after
conception
using
a
new
American-developed
gene-copying
technique
.
<END>
<START>
The
experiment
,
applicable
to
many
genetic
disorders
,
involved
beta-thalassemia
,
a
severe
blood
anemia
resulting
from
a
missing
hemoglobin
gene
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
an
inherited
human
disorder
that
's
been
duplicated
in
mice
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
experiment
,
mice
with
the
defective
gene
were
mated
.
<END>
<START>
Three
days
later
,
before
the
new
embryo
had
become
implanted
in
the
uterus
,
it
was
washed
out
of
the
mother
mouse
.
<END>
<START>
The
embryo
had
progressed
only
to
a
clump
of
eight
identical
cells
.
<END>
<START>
One
cell
was
teased
out
,
and
its
DNA
extracted
.
<END>
<START>
A
genetic
probe
showed
the
hemoglobin
gene
was
missing
,
the
researchers
report
in
the
medical
journal
Lancet
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
report
,
two
molecular
biologists
suggest
such
embryo
diagnosis
can
be
used
by
couples
at
high
risk
of
passing
a
genetic
defect
to
a
child
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
infertile
couples
who
have
the
woman
's
eggs
fertilized
in
the
test
tube
usually
have
several
eggs
fertilized
at
a
time
.
<END>
<START>
When
the
fertilized
cells
divide
to
eight
cells
,
a
single
cell
from
each
embryo
can
be
tested
for
genetic
defects
.
<END>
<START>
A
healthy
embryo
can
be
picked
for
implantation
and
defective
ones
discarded
.
<END>
<START>
Or
in
other
couples
,
the
embryo
could
be
temporarily
taken
out
and
tested
three
days
after
conception
and
returned
if
healthy
,
or
discarded
if
not
.
<END>
<START>
Yeast
Adapted
to
Make
Gene-Spliced
Drugs
<END>
<START>
AN
OIL
COMPANY
finds
a
sideline
in
the
microscopic
world
of
yeast
.
<END>
<START>
Phillips
found
and
improved
a
yeast
,
``
Pichia
pastoris
,
''
which
made
protein
from
natural
gas-derived
alcohol
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
could
convert
glucose
from
farm
wastes
into
edible
protein
.
<END>
<START>
Single-cell
protein
never
panned
out
,
and
most
companies
abandoned
such
research
.
<END>
<START>
But
Phillips
persisted
,
calling
in
scientists
from
the
Salk
Institute
.
<END>
<START>
They
've
now
adapted
the
yeast
to
making
genetically
engineered
drugs
.
<END>
<START>
Like
the
bacteria
used
by
genetic
engineers
,
the
yeast
can
take
in
human
genes
and
churn
out
human
proteins
for
medical
use
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
yeast
genetic
apparatus
is
more
like
that
of
animals
than
the
bacterial
genetic
apparatus
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
,
the
proteins
from
the
yeast
are
molecularly
more
like
human
proteins
than
those
from
bacteria
.
<END>
<START>
The
oil
company
claims
its
yeast
system
also
is
better
than
bacteria
at
high-volume
production
of
genetically
engineered
drugs
.
<END>
<START>
Chiron
Corp.
,
an
Emeryville
,
Calif.
,
biotechnology
firm
,
is
seeing
if
the
Phillips
yeast
can
be
used
to
make
its
genetically
engineered
human
proteins
.
<END>
<START>
Peeking
Inside
Arteries
From
Outside
the
Body
<END>
<START>
VISUALIZING
BLOOD
vessels
without
poking
catheters
into
the
body
may
come
out
of
research
at
AT&T
Bell
Laboratories
.
<END>
<START>
Strokes
,
heart
attacks
,
leg
pains
-LRB-
intermittent
claudication
-RRB-
and
other
problems
stem
from
clogging
of
the
arteries
by
cholesterol-rich
deposits
.
<END>
<START>
At
present
,
doctors
can
see
how
badly
an
artery
is
clogged
only
by
inserting
a
thin
catheter
into
the
artery
and
injecting
a
fluid
that
makes
the
arteries
visible
on
X-rays
.
<END>
<START>
A
non-invasive
method
is
being
researched
by
biophysicist
Lynn
Jelinski
at
the
AT&T
unit
.
<END>
<START>
It
relies
on
the
fact
that
certain
atoms
give
off
detectable
signals
when
subjected
to
an
intense
magnetic
field
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
the
same
phenomenon
used
in
the
new
MRI
-LRB-
magnetic
resonance
imaging
-RRB-
scanners
being
used
in
hospitals
in
place
of
X-ray
scans
.
<END>
<START>
The
scientists
have
experimented
on
the
tiny
neck
arteries
of
rats
.
<END>
<START>
They
now
are
experimenting
with
measuring
blood
flow
.
<END>
<START>
The
ultimate
hope
is
that
the
technique
could
identify
diseased
vessels
.
<END>
<START>
Odds
and
Ends
<END>
<START>
Almost
40
%
of
schizophrenic
men
have
an
impaired
sense
of
smell
vs.
fewer
than
10
%
of
schizophrenic
women
,
reports
the
American
Journal
of
Psychiatry
.
<END>
<START>
The
government
contract
required
Meredith
Relocation
Corp.
to
purchase
employees
'
homes
based
on
independent
appraisals
.
<END>
<START>
The
Justice
Department
alleges
that
the
company
``
engaged
in
various
forms
of
misrepresentation
''
with
the
goal
of
reducing
the
appraised
value
of
employees
'
homes
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
suit
,
the
department
seeks
to
recover
$
7.7
million
in
costs
incurred
when
the
government
terminated
its
contract
with
Meredith
Relocation
and
sought
other
contracts
to
replace
it
.
<END>
<START>
The
department
also
said
it
seeks
``
three
times
the
government
's
damages
,
which
are
presently
undetermined
,
plus
penalties
.
''
<END>
<START>
Officials
with
Meredith
did
n't
have
any
immediate
comment
on
the
suit
.
<END>
<START>
Lloyd
's
of
London
said
it
plans
to
clamp
down
on
the
ability
of
underwriting
syndicates
to
leave
their
annual
accounts
open
beyond
the
customary
three
years
.
<END>
<START>
Underwriting
syndicates
at
Lloyd
's
,
the
world
's
largest
insurance
market
,
generally
do
n't
close
their
accounts
for
three
years
,
to
allow
for
the
filing
of
claims
and
litigation
.
<END>
<START>
When
such
claims
and
litigation
extend
beyond
the
period
,
the
syndicates
can
extend
their
accounting
deadlines
.
<END>
<START>
Lloyd
's
said
there
are
currently
115
open
account
years
involving
68
of
the
market
's
roughly
360
syndicates
.
<END>
<START>
The
procedure
causes
``
great
uncertainty
''
because
an
investor
ca
n't
be
sure
of
his
or
her
individual
liability
,
Lloyd
's
said
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
the
insurance
market
plans
new
measures
to
restrict
the
ability
of
syndicate
officials
to
leave
years
open
.
<END>
<START>
Lloyd
's
said
it
expects
to
enact
new
rules
mandating
the
changes
by
year
end
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
new
rules
,
the
officials
will
have
to
secure
additional
information
and
reports
from
actuaries
,
including
an
assessment
of
whether
officials
have
acted
reasonably
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
officials
will
have
to
get
quotes
for
certain
reinsurance
contracts
and
obtain
approvals
from
other
syndicate
directors
.
<END>
<START>

Associates

,

66

,

.

,

$
13.63
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Earnings
included
a
one-time
gain
of
$
192
million
on
a
property
transaction
in
Hong
Kong
.
<END>
<START>
Exploration
and
production
profits
slumped
$
40
million
due
to
a
provision
for
restructuring
costs
.
<END>
<START>
The
restructuring
will
take
place
over
a
two-year
period
and
will
involve
the
transfer
and
layoff
of
employees
in
U.S.
operations
to
reduce
costs
and
focus
efforts
in
other
areas
.
<END>
<START>
Last
year
,
third-quarter
earnings
included
a
$
157
million
gain
from
foreign
tax
rate
changes
and
a
loss
from
a
$
65

of

.

<START>

<END>
<START>

fell
0.7

,

$
417

,

1.22
a

,

$
420

,

.

11

.

,

in

.

.

.

Jeff

.

<START>
Companies

substantially

analysts

.
<END>
<START>
The

are
followed
by
at
least
three
analysts
,
and
had
a
minimum

change
in
actual
earnings
per

.
<END>
<START>
Estimated
and
actual
results
involving
losses
are
omitted
.
<END>
<START>
The
percent
difference
compares
actual
profit
with
the
30-day
estimate
where
at
least
three
analysts
have
issues
forecasts
in
the
past
30
days
.
<END>
<START>
Otherwise
,
actual
profit
is
compared
with
the
300-day
estimate
.

<START>
The
Philippine
merchandise

deficit
widened
to
$
1.71
billion
during
the
first
eight
months
of
1989
from
$
807
million
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Imports
continued
to
outpace
Philippine
exports
,
despite
gains
in
shipments
abroad
,
the
government
National
Statistics
Office
said
.
<END>
<START>
Exports
reached
$
5.12
billion
,
up
from
$
4.52
billion
a
year
earlier
,
while
imports
rose
to
$
6.81
billion
from
$
5.33
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
trade
deficit
in
the
first
eight
months
is
already
wider
than
the
trade
gap
of
$
1.09
billion
for
all
of
1988
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
expect
the
trade
gap
for
the
year
to
surpass
$
2
billion
as
demand
for
capital
equipment
and
raw
materials
continues
to
push
imports
higher
.

the

,

.

.

last

,

%
the

a

.

<START>

,

.

.

<START>
Bausch
&
Lomb
Inc.
said
its
pharmaceuticals
subsidiary
agreed
to
supply
collagen
corneal
shields
for
animal
eye
surgery
to
a
unit
of
International
Minerals
&
Chemical
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
Terms
were
n't
disclosed
.
<END>
<START>
The
agreement
marks
Bausch
&
Lomb
's
first
venture
selling
its
eye
care
products
for
use
by
veterinarians
.
<END>
<START>
The
collagen
corneal
shield
helps
speed
healing
of
the
cornea
after
eye
surgery
.
<END>
<START>
The
product
will
be
distributed
by
Pitman-Moore
Inc.
,
a
subsidiary
of
International
Minerals
.
<END>
<START>
Semifinished
goods
turned
in
a
strong
showing
,
with
a
monthly
rise
of
2
%
and
a
year-on-year
advance
of
3
%
.
<END>
<START>
Food
production
was
ahead
1.7
%
from
June
and
5.3
%
from
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Output
in
the
capital-goods
sector
was
ahead
0.9
%
on
a
monthly
basis
and
2.7
%
year
on
year
.
<END>
<START>
These
gains
were
partly
offset
by
output
of
cars
and
other
consumer
durables
,
which
eased
3.9
%
from
June
's
high
level
.
<END>
<START>
The
sector
was
still
8.8
%
above
its
output
levels
from
a
year
earlier
,
however
.
<END>

<START>
Consumers
Power
Co.
filed

Michigan
Public
Service
Commission
a
contract
to
buy
power
from
the
Palisades
nuclear
plant
under

arrangement
for

.

and

last
year
announced
a
joint

to

,
currently
owned
completely
by

.
<END>
<START>
Two
Japanese
scientists
said
they
discovered
an
antibody
that
,
in
laboratory
test-tube
experiments
,
kills
AIDS-infected
cells
while
preserving
healthy
cells
.
<END>
<START>
If
further
experiments
are
successful
,
the
work
would
represent
a
major
advance
in
research
on
acquired
immune
deficiency
syndrome
.
<END>
<START>
The
drug
AZT
,
the
only
treatment
currently
on
the
market
,
claims
only
to
help
stop
the
spread
of
AIDS
,
not
to
cure
it
.
<END>
<START>
But
several
analysts
and
Japanese
scientists
familiar
with
the
study
,
which
was
announced
at
a
conference
in
Nagoya
yesterday
,
expressed
skepticism
over
the
significance
of
the
results
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
researchers
themselves
acknowledged
they
still
must
do
much
more
work
before
they
can
say
whether
the
treatment
would
actually
cure
humans
.
<END>
<START>
The
antibody
then
kills
the
cell
.
<END>
<START>
Dr.
Yonehara
and
his
partner
,
Nobuyuki
Kobayashi
of
Yamaguchi
University
,
said
their
experiments
showed
that
the
antibody
wiped
out
an
average
of
60
%
of
AIDS-infected
cells
within
three
days
.
<END>
<START>
In
some
of
the
experiments
,
it
killed
almost
all
the
infected
cells
,
the
researchers
said
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
fewer
than
10
%
of
the
healthy
cells
were
killed
.
<END>
<START>
The
two
said
they
must
still
do
more
laboratory
tests
,
then
experiment
on
animals
.
<END>
<START>
They
said
they
hoped
to
conduct
tests
on
human
patients
in
the
U.S.
by
late
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
Japan
does
n't
have
enough
AIDS
patients
to
do
significant
experimentation
in
that
country
,
they
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
announcement
got
wide
exposure
in
the
Japanese
media
,
and
even
moved
some
pharmaceutical
stocks
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
some
infected
cells
may
not
have
the
relevant
antigen
and
so
would
n't
be
killed
even
after
exposure
to
the
antibody
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
results
seem
to
be
very
premature
,
''
said
Mitsuru
Miyata
,
editor
of
Nikkei
Biotechnology
,
a
leading
Japanese
industry
newsletter
.
<END>
<START>
Dr.
Kobayashi
responded
that
he
thought
the
antibody
could
potentially
kill
all
infected
cells
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
and
Dr.
Yonehara
said
there
were
still
several
uncertainties
,
particularly
regarding
possible
side
effects
.
<END>
<START>
``
Our
antibody
specifically
killed
infected
cells
at
a
very
low
dose
,
but
it
can
also
kill
other
cells
,
''
said
Dr.
Yonehara
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
do
n't
know
the
effect
of
our
antibody
on
the
human
body
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
said
that
when
scientists
from
the
two
countries
meet
again
in
January
in
New
Orleans
,
the
Japanese
will
present
at
least
three
more
drugs
for
human
testing
.
<END>
<START>
AZT
is
the
world
's
only
prescription
medicine
approved
for
treating
the
disease
.
<END>
<START>
Wellcome
PLC
,
a
major
British
pharmaceutical
maker
,
sells
the
drug
under
the
name
Retrovir
.
<END>
<START>
A
Wellcome
spokesman
declined
to
comment
on
the
discovery
of
the
antibody
in
Japan
.
<END>
<START>
The
following
issues
were
recently
filed
with
the
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
:
<END>
<START>
American
Exploration

<START>
The
Food
and
Drug
Administration
banned
all
imports
of
mushrooms
from
China
in
response
to
a
rash
of
food-poisoning
outbreaks
linked
to
canned
Chinese
mushrooms
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
agency
has
concluded
that
contamination
may
be
widespread
throughout
the
mushroom-processing
industry
in
China
,
''
an
FDA
spokesman
said
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
On
May
19
,
the
FDA
began
detaining
Chinese
mushrooms
in
68-ounce
cans
after
more
than
100
people
in
Mississippi
,
New
York
and
Pennsylvania
became
ill
from
eating
tainted
mushrooms
.
<END>
<START>
In
subsequent
tests
,
the
agency
found
smaller-size
cans
from
several
Chinese
plants
to
be
similarly
contaminated
.
<END>
<START>
The
outbreaks
were
traced
to
staphylococcus
aureus
,
a
type
of
bacteria
that
produces
a
toxin
capable
of
surviving
the
high
temperatures
used
in
canning
vegetables
.
<END>
<START>
A
recall
of
the
mushrooms
blamed
for
the
food
poisoning
began
in
early
March
.
<END>
<START>
In
1987
,
China
exported
65
million
pounds
of
mushrooms
,
valued
at
$
47
million
,
to
the
U.S.
.
<END>
<START>
The
shipments
went
mostly
to
food-service
distributors
that
supply
pizzerias
and
restaurants
.
<END>
<START>
A

for
the
Chinese

here

that
the
Beijing

has
taken
``
many
effective
measures
''
to
stop
the
mushroom

and
is
further

the
underlying
causes
.
<END>
<START>
He

problem
will
be

``
very

.
''

.

that

.

,

target
and
attack
major

organizations
that

.

<START>

<START>
Bond
prices
took
the
high
road
and
stock
prices
took
the
low
road
as
worries
mounted
about
the
economy
and

.
<END>
<START>
The
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
fell
26.23

to
2662.91
in

.
<END>
<START>
But

Treasury
bonds
staged
a
modest

,
with

on
most
issues
rising
about
half

,
or

5

amount
.
<END>
<START>
The
dollar
sagged
against
other

in

.
<END>
<START>
Traders
and
analysts
said
the
divergence
between
the
stock
and
bond
markets
is
a
sign
of
growing
unease
about
the
economic
outlook
.
<END>
<START>
A
sinking
economy
depresses
corporate
earnings
and
thus
stock
prices
,
but
it
buoys
bond
prices
as
interest
rates
fall
.
<END>
<START>
That
unease
is
expected
to
grow
today
when
the
government
reports
on
September
durable
goods
orders
and
again
Thursday
when

first

of

is

.
<END>
<START>
The
stock
market
's
decline
,
coming
after
a
record
weekly
gain
of
119.88
points
,
surprised
some

.
<END>
<START>
But
A.C.
Moore
,

,

's
rally

13

rout
.
<END>
<START>
Overall
,

said
,
the
trend
in
stock
prices
will
be
down
as
the
economy
weakens
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
think
we
're
on

in

,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``

decrease
faster
than

will
fall
,
and

in

.
''
<END>
<START>
In
major
market
activity
:
Stock
prices
slumped
in
sluggish
trading
.
<END>
<START>
Volume
on
the
New
York

Exchange
totaled
135.9

.
<END>
<START>
Declining

Big
Board
were

of

,
1,012
to

.
<END>
<START>
Bond

.
<END>
<START>
The
yield
on
the

's

30-year
bond
slipped
to
7.93
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
dollar
weakened
against
most
other
major
currencies
.
<END>
<START>
In
late
New
York
trading
,
the
dollar
was
quoted
at
1.8470
marks
and
141.90
yen
,
compared
with
1.8578
marks
and
142.43
yen
late

.
<END>
<START>
The
two
surveys
,
which
asked
different
questions
,
were
conducted
using
national
random
probability
samples
.
<END>
<START>
The
poll
conducted
by
Peter
D.
Hart
Research
Associates
interviewed
2,064
adults
age
18
and
older
from
June
15
to
June
30
,
1989
.
<END>
<START>
The
poll
conducted
by
the
Roper
Organization
interviewed
2,002
adults
age
18
and
older
from
July
7
to
July
15
,
1989
.
<END>
<START>
Responses
were
weighted
on
the
basis
of
age
and
gender
to
conform
with
U.S.
Census
data
.
<END>
<START>
The
margin
of
error
for
subgroups
--
for
example
,
married
women
with
children
at
home
--
would
be
larger
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
in
any
survey
,

<START>
FRANKLIN
NATIONAL
BANK
DIED
at
3
p.m.
EDT
,
Oct.
8
,
1974
,
and
was
promptly
resurrected
under
new
owners
to
shore
up
confidence
in
other
banks
during
a
recession
.
<END>
<START>
Federal
officials
who
had
been
probing
the
bank
for
months
arranged
a
merger
with
European-American
Bank
&
Trust
,
owned
by
six
foreign
banks
,
to
avert
the
closedown
.
<END>
<START>
And
federal
insurance
protected
the
bank
's
631,163
depositors
.
<END>
<START>
The
crisis
had
peaked
on
May
10
,
1974
,
when
the
bank
disclosed
``
severe
''
foreign-exchange
losses
due
to
``
unauthorized
''
trading
.
<END>
<START>
Massive
withdrawals
followed
and
there
was
a
brief
rescue
attempt
,
with
political
undertones
,
including
$
1.77
billion
in
Federal
Reserve
loans
.
<END>
<START>
Within
six
years
many
figures
were
convicted
for
their
illegal
abuse
of
Franklin
funds
.
<END>
<START>
Included
was
the
charge
that
Sindona
siphoned
$
45
million
of
Franklin
funds
for
his
other
ventures
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Sindona
in
1979
faked
his
``
kidnapping
''
for
2
1/2
months
to
delay
his
trial
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
During
1976
to
1979
,
other
former
Franklin
officials
either
pleaded
guilty
to
or
were
found
guilty
of
violations
including
phony
transactions
to
hide
the
bank
's
losses
.
<END>
<START>
It
happened
four
days
after
he
was
sentenced
to

in

for
ordering
a
1979
murder
.

.

<START>
In

office
building
south
of
Los
Angeles
,
human
behavior
is
being
monitored
,
dissected
and
,
ultimately
,
manipulated
.
<END>
<START>
A
squiggly
line
snakes
across
a
video
screen
,
gyrating
erratically
as
subjects
with

computers
register
their
second-by-second

to
a

's

.
<END>
<START>
Agreement
,

,
boredom
and
distraction
all
can
be
inferred
from
the
subjects
'

of
a
dial
.
<END>
<START>
In
another

,
an
elaborate
chart
with
color
codes
reveals
how
people
's
opinions
were
shaped
--
and

.

<START>
Donald
Vinson
,
who

,

n't

.
<END>
<START>
He
heads
Litigation
Sciences
Inc.
,
the
nation
's
largest
legal
consulting
firm
,
which
is
helping
corporate
America
prepare
for
high-stakes
litigation
by
predicting
and
shaping
jurors
'
reactions
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
process
,
Litigation
Sciences
is
quietly
but
inexorably
reshaping
the
world
of
law
.
<END>
<START>
Twenty-one
of
its
workers
are
Ph.
D.s
.
<END>
<START>
With
jury
verdicts
getting
bigger
all
the
time
,
companies
are
increasingly
willing
to
pay
huge
sums
for
such
advice
.
<END>
<START>
Recently
,
Litigation
Sciences
helped
Pennzoil
Co.
win
a
$
10.5
billion
jury
verdict
against
Texaco
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
It
advised
the
National
Football
League
in
its
largely
successful
defense
of
antitrust
charges
by
the
United
States
Football
League
.
<END>
<START>
And
it
helped
win
defense
verdicts
in
product-liability
suits
involving
scores
of
products
,
ranging
from
Firestone
500
tires
to
the
anti-nausea
drug
Bendectin
.
<END>
<START>
Largely
as
a
result
,
Litigation
Sciences
has
more
than
doubled
in
size
in
the
past
two
years
.
<END>
<START>
Its
1988
revenue
was
$
25
million
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
competitors
are
being
spawned
almost
daily
;
some
300
new
businesses
--
many
just
one-person
shops
--
have
sprung
up
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Vinson
estimates
the
industry
's
total
revenues
approach
$
200
million
.
<END>
<START>
In
any
high-stakes
case
,
you
can
be
sure
that
one
side
or
the
other
--
or
even
both
--
is
using
litigation
consultants
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
their
ubiquity
,
the
consultants
are
n't
entirely
welcome
.
<END>
<START>
Some
lawyers
and
scholars
see
the
social
scientists
'
vision
of
the
American
jury
system
as
a
far
cry
from
the
ideal
presented
in
civics
texts
and
memorialized
on
the
movie
screen
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
film
classic
``
Twelve
Angry
Men
,
''
the
crucible
of
deliberations
unmasks
each
juror
's
bias
and
purges
it
from
playing
a
role
in
the
verdict
.
<END>
<START>
After
hours
of
conflict
and
debate
,
that
jury
focuses
on
the
facts
with
near-perfect
objectivity
.
<END>
<START>
In
real
life
,
jurors
may
not
always
work
that
way
,
but
some
court
observers
question
why
they
should
n't
be
encouraged
to
do
so
rather
than
be
programmed
not
to
.
<END>
<START>
Litigation
consulting
is
,
as
New
York
trial
attorney
Donald
Zoeller
puts
it
,
``
highly
manipulative
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
adds
,
``
The
notion
they
try
to
sell
is
that
juries
do
n't
make
decisions
rationally
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
effort
is
also
being
made
to
try
and
cause
jurors
not
to
decide
things
rationally
.
<END>
<START>
I
find
it
troubling
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Zoeller
also
acknowledges
that
consultants
can
be
very
effective
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
gotten
to
the
point
where
if
the
case
is
large
enough
,
it
's
almost
malpractice
not
to
use
them
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Others
complain
that
the
consultants
'
growing
influence
exacerbates
the
advantage
of
litigants
wealthy
enough
to
afford
such
pricey
services
.
<END>
<START>
Sophisticated
trial
consulting
grew
,
ironically
,
from
the
radical
political
movements
of
the
1960s
and
1970s
before
finding
its
more
lucrative
calling
in
big
commercial
cases
.
<END>
<START>
The
Harrisburg
7
trial
in
1972
,
in
which
Daniel
Berrigan
and
others
were
charged
with
plotting
anti-war-related
violence
,
was
a
landmark
.
<END>
<START>
In
that
case
,
a
group
of
left-leaning
sociologists
interviewed
252
registered
voters
around
Harrisburg
.
<END>
<START>
The
researchers
discovered
that
Episcopalians
,
Presbyterians
,
Methodists
and
fundamantalist
Protestants
were
nearly
always
against
the
defendants
;
the
lawyers
resolved
to
try
to
keep
them
off
the
jury
.
<END>
<START>
The
defense
also
learned
that
college-educated
people
were
uncharacteristically
conservative
about
the
Vietnam
War
.
<END>
<START>
A
more
blue-collar
panel
became
a
second
aim
.
<END>
<START>
Ultimately
,
that
carefully
picked
jury
deadlocked
with
a
10-2
vote
to
acquit
,
and
the
prosecution
decided
not
to
retry
the
case
.
<END>
<START>
Litigation
consulting
had
arrived
.
<END>
<START>
The
fledgling
science
went
corporate
in
1977
when
International
Business
Machines
Corp.
hired
a
marketing
professor
to
help
defend
a
complex
antitrust
case
.
<END>
<START>
The
problem
for
IBM
trial
lawyers
Thomas
Barr
and
David
Boies
was
how
to
make
such
a
highly
technical
case
understandable
.
<END>
<START>
As
the
trial
progressed
,
they
were
eager
to
know
if
the
jury
was
keeping
up
with
them
.
<END>
<START>
The
solution
devised
by
the
professor
was
to
hire
six
people
who
would
mirror
the
actual
jury
demographically
,
sit
in
on
the
trial
and
report
their
reactions
to
him
.
<END>
<START>
He
then
briefed
Messrs.
Boies
and
Barr
,
who
had
the
chance
to
tilt
their
next
day
's
presentation
accordingly
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
,
the
``
shadow
''
jury
was
born
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Vinson
,
the
professor
,
got
the
law
bug
and
formed
Litigation
Sciences
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
IBM
won
the
case
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
``
The
hardest
thing
in
any
complex
case
is
to
retain
objectivity
and
,
in
some
sense
,
your
ignorance
,
''
says
Mr.
Boies
of
Cravath
,
Swaine
&
Moore
.
<END>
<START>
A
shadow
jury
is
a
way
to
do
that
in
a
more
systematic
and
organized
way
.
''
<END>
<START>
Energy
Transportation
retained
Litigation
Sciences
,
at
a
cost
of
several
hundred
thousand
dollars
,
to
poll
,
pre-try
,
profile
and
shadow
.
<END>
<START>
Just
before
the
actual
closing
arguments
,
the
firm
put
the
case
to
a
vote
of
the
five
shadow
jurors
,
each
of
whom
was
being
paid
$
150
a
day
.
<END>
<START>
The
jurors
,
who
did
n't
know
which
side
had
retained
them
,
decided
for
Energy
Transportation
,
and
awarded
$
500
million
in
damages
.
<END>
<START>
The
real
jury
returned
days
later
with
a
$
345
million
victory
for
Energy
Transportation
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
just
like
weather
forecasting
,
''
says
Energy
Transportation
trial
attorney
Harry
Reasoner
of
Vinson
&
Elkins
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
often
wrong
,
but
it
's
better
than
consulting
an
Indian
rain
dancer
.
''
<END>
<START>
Forecasting
is
only
one
part
of
Litigation
Sciences
'
work
.
<END>
<START>
Changing
the
outcome
of
the
trial
is
what
really
matters
.
<END>
<START>
And
to
the
uninitiated
,
some
of
the
firm
's
approaches
may
seem
chillingly
manipulative
.
<END>
<START>
Theoretically
,
jurors
are
supposed
to
weigh
the
evidence
in
a
case
logically
and
objectively
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
,
Mr.
Vinson
says
,
interviews
with
thousands
of
jurors
reveal
that
they
start
with
firmly
entrenched
attitudes
and
try
to
shoe-horn
the
facts
of
the
case
to
fit
their
views
.
<END>
<START>
Pre-trial
polling
helps
the
consultants
develop
a
profile
of
the
right
type
of
juror
.
<END>
<START>
If
it
is
a
case
in
which
the
client
seeks
punitive
damages
,
for
example
,
depressed
,
underemployed
people
are
far
more
likely
to
grant
them
.
<END>
<START>
Someone
with
a
master
's
degree
in
classical
arts
who
works
in
a
deli
would
be
ideal
,
Litigation
Sciences
advises
.
<END>
<START>
So
would
someone
recently
divorced
or
widowed
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Since
Litigation
Sciences
generally
represents
the
defense
,
its
job
is
usually
to
help
the
lawyers
identify
and
remove
such
people
from
the
jury
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
For
personal-injury
cases
,
Litigation
Sciences
seeks
defense
jurors
who
believe
that
most
people
,
including
victims
,
get
what
they
deserve
.
<END>
<START>
Such
people
also
typically
hold
negative
attitudes
toward
the
physically
handicapped
,
the
poor
,
blacks
and
women
.
<END>
<START>
The
consultants
help
the
defense
lawyers
find
such
jurors
by
asking
questions
about
potential
jurors
'
attitudes
toward
volunteer
work
,
or
toward
particular
movies
or
books
.
<END>
<START>
Litigation
Sciences
does
n't
make
moral
distinctions
.
<END>
<START>
If
a
client
needs
prejudiced
jurors
,
the
firm
will
help
find
them
.
<END>
<START>
As
Mr.
Vinson
explains
it
,
``
We
do
n't
control
the
facts
.
<END>
<START>
They
are
what
they
are
.
<END>
<START>
But
any
lawyer
will
select
the
facts
and
the
strategy
to
employ
.
<END>
<START>
In
our
system
of
advocacy
,
the
trial
lawyer
is
duty
bound
to
present
the
best
case
he
possibly
can
.
''
<END>
<START>
Once
a
jury
is
selected
,
the
consultants
often
continue
to
determine
what
the
jurors
'
attitudes
are
likely
to
be
and
help
shape
the
lawyers
'
presentation
accordingly
.
<END>
<START>
Logic
plays
a
minimal
role
here
.
<END>
<START>
More
important
are
what
LSI
calls
``
psychological
anchors
''
--
a
few
focal
points
calculated
to
appeal
to
the
jury
on
a
gut
level
.
<END>
<START>
By
repeatedly
drawing
the
jury
's
attention
to
the
arm
,
the
defense
lawyers
planted
doubt
about
the
origin
of
the
woman
's
injuries
.
<END>
<START>
The
ploy
worked
.
<END>
<START>
The
defense
won
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
classic
defense
of
a
personal-injury
case
,
the
consultants
concentrate
on
encouraging
the
jury
to
shift
the
blame
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
ideal
defense
in
a
case
involving
an
accident
is
to
persuade
the
jurors
to
hold
the
accident
victim
responsible
for
his
or
her
plight
,
''
Mr.
Vinson
has
written
.
<END>
<START>
Slick
graphics
,
pre-tested
for
effectiveness
,
also
play
a
major
role
in
Litigation
Sciences
'
operation
.
<END>
<START>
Studies
show
,
the
consultants
say
,
that
people
absorb
information
better
and
remember
it
longer
if
they
receive
it
visually
.
<END>
<START>
Computer-generated
videos
help
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
average
American
watches
seven
hours
of
TV
a
day
.
<END>
<START>
They
are
very
visually
sophisticated
,
''
explains
LSI
graphics
specialist
Robert
Seltzer
.
<END>
<START>
Lawyers
remain
divided
about
whether
anything
is
wrong
with
all
this
.
<END>
<START>
Supporters
acknowledge
that
the
process
aims
to
manipulate
,
but
they
insist
that
the
best
trial
lawyers
have
always
employed
similar
tactics
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
may
not
have
been
able
to
articulate
it
all
,
but
they
did
it
,
''
says
Stephen
Gillers
,
a
legal
ethics
expert
at
New
York
University
law
school
.
<END>
<START>
``
What
you
have
here
is
intuition
made
manifest
.
''
<END>
<START>
Many
lawyers
maintain
that
all
's
fair
in
the
adversary
system
as
long
as
no
one
tampers
with
the
evidence
.
<END>
<START>
Others
point
out
that
lawyers
in
small
communities
have
always
had
a
feel
for
public
sentiment
--
and
used
that
to
advantage
.
<END>
<START>
Litigation
consulting
is
n't
a
guarantee
of
a
favorable
outcome
.
<END>
<START>
Litigation
Sciences
concedes
that
in
one
in
20
cases
it
was
flatout
wrong
in
its
predictions
.
<END>
<START>
Some
litigators
scoff
at
the
notion
that
a
sociologist
knows
more
than
they
do
about
what
makes
a
jury
tick
.
<END>
<START>
He
says
he
used
consultants
in
the
case
but
``
found
them
to
be
virtually
useless
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
most
lawyers
accept
that
the
marketplace
has
spoken
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
question
remains
whether
the
jury
system
can
maintain
its
integrity
while
undergoing
such
a
skillful
massage
.
<END>
<START>
For
more
than
a
decade
,
Mr.
Etzioni
,
the
sociologist
,
has
been
a
leading
critic
of
the
masseurs
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
's
no
reason
to
believe
that
juries
rule
inappropriately
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
the
last
thing
you
want
to
do
is
manipulate
the
subconscious
to
make
them
think
better
.
<END>
<START>
What
you
then
do
is
you
make
them
think
inappropriately
.
''
<END>
<START>
In
most
civil
cases
,
judges
allow
each
side
three
such
challenges
.
<END>
<START>
For
complex
cases
,
judges
sometimes
allow
many
more
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Etzioni
also
suggests
forbidding
anyone
from
gathering
background
information
about
the
jurors
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Some
courts
release
names
and
addresses
,
and
researchers
can
drive
by
houses
,
look
up
credit
ratings
,
and
even
question
neighbors
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Furthermore
,
he
says
,
psychologists
should
not
be
allowed
to
analyze
jurors
'
personalities
.
<END>
<START>
Even
some
lawyers
who
have
used
consultants
to
their
advantage
see
a
need
to
limit
their
impact
.
<END>
<START>
Silicon
Graphics
Inc.
,
a
fast-growing
maker
of
computer
workstations
,
said
it
landed
two
federal
government
contracts
worth
more
than
$
100
million
over
the
next
five
years
.
<END>
<START>
One
award
is
part
of
a
Department
of
Defense
contract
to
Loral
Rolm
Mil-Spec
Computers
and
could
be
valued
at
more
than
$
100
million
over
five
years
.
<END>
<START>
The
other
involves
the
sale
of
about
35
of
the
company
's
high-end
workstations
to
the
National
Institutes
of
Health
.
<END>
<START>
The
models
,
which
cost
about
$
75,000
each
,
will
be
used
in
research
.
<END>
<START>
The
awards
are
evidence
that
Silicon
Graphics
'
approach
to
computer
graphics
is
catching
on
with
users
of
powerful
desktop
computers
,
analysts
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
company
's
on
a
roll
,
''
said
Robert
Herwick
,
an
analyst
at
Hambrecht
&
Quist
.
<END>
<START>
``
No
other
-LCB-
computer
-RCB-
vendor
offers
graphics
performance
that
good
for
their
price
.
''
<END>
<START>
Silicon
Graphics
,
on
the
other
hand
,
has
targeted
a
specific
niche
since
its
inception
in
1982
,
which
has
been
dubbed
by
some
as
``
motion-picture
computing
.
''
<END>
<START>
This
is
a
style
of
``
visual
''
computing
that
provides
three-dimensional
,
color
models
of
everything
from
the
inside
of
a
house
to
the
latest
in
women
's
fashion
.
<END>
<START>
Though
Silicon
Graphics
is
much
smaller
than
Digital
,
Hewlett
and
Sun
,
it
has
emerged
in
recent
years
as
a
feared
adversary
in
this
graphics
portion
of
the
workstation
market
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
the
company
has
made
it
tough
on
competitors
by
offering
a
stream
of
desktop
computers
at
sharply
lower
prices
.
<END>
<START>
A
year
ago
,
Silicon
Graphics
introduced
a
model
priced
at
$
15,000
--
almost
as
cheap
as
mainstream
workstations
that
do
n't
offer
special
graphics
features
.
<END>
<START>
Silicon
Graphics
also
plans
to
unveil
even
less
expensive
machines
in
the
near
future
.
<END>
<START>
Silicon
Graphics
'
strategy
seems
to
be
paying
off
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
for
its
first
quarter
ended
Sept.
30
was
$
86.4
million
,
a
95
%
increase
over
the
year-ago
period
.
<END>
<START>
Profit
was
$
5.2
million
,
compared
with
$
1
million
for
the
year-ago
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Remember
those
bulky
,
thick-walled

of
30

?
<END>
<START>
They
,

,

.
<END>
<START>
That

.
<END>
<START>
World-wide

would
be
cut
in

.
<END>
<START>
The

Senate
liked
the

so

it
ratified

by
a

of
89

0
.
<END>
<START>
Not

,

2000
,

.
<END>
<START>
That

,

.
<END>
<START>
Gases
containing

are
pumped

to

.
