<START>
CALIFORNIA
,
A
TREND-SETTER
in
franchising
rules
,
stirs
a
controversy
.
<END>
<START>
With
some
new
rules
,
state
officials
say
they
made
it
easier
--
and
faster
--
to
sell
new

whose
terms
stray
from
those
in
state-registered
contracts
.
<END>
<START>
Previously
,
regulators
insisted
that
franchisers
pre-register
such
changes
with
the
state
--
a
costly
process
taking
at
least
six
weeks
.
<END>
<START>
Now
some
negotiated
sales
that
meet
a
series
of
tests
do
n't
have
to
be
pre-registered
.
<END>
<START>
For
instance
,
franchisers
no
longer
must
pre-register
sales
to
aspiring
franchisees
who
qualify
as
``
sophisticated
purchasers
.
''
<END>
<START>
Such
buyers
must
have
a
minimum
net
worth
of
$
1
million
,
$
200,000
annual
income
,
or
recent
experience
in
the
business
area
of
the
franchise
being
sold
.
<END>
<START>
But
critics
consider
the
changes
regressive
.
<END>
<START>
Lewis
G.
Rudnick
,
a
Chicago
lawyer
who
represents
franchisers
,
contends
California
is
narrowly
limiting
--
rather
than
expanding
--
opportunities
for
negotiating
sales
.
<END>
<START>
He
argues
California
regulators
historically
have
misinterpreted
their
law
--
and
he
says
negotiated
sales
that
are
n't
pre-registered
have
been
legal
all
along
.
<END>
<START>
San
Francisco

Timothy
H.
Fine
,
who
represents

,
insists
California
's
cautiousness
helps
protect
franchisees
from
crafty
sales
negotiators
who
push
unlawful
clauses
.

''
<END>
<START>
But
while
traffic
was
heavy
early
in
the
commute
over
the
Golden
Gate
,
by
8
a.m.
it
already
had
thinned
out
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
one
of
the
smoothest
commutes
I
've
ever
had
,
''
said
Charles
Catania
,
an
insurance
broker
on
the
bus
from
Mill
Valley
in
Marin
County
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
looks
like
a
holiday
.
<END>
<START>
I
think
a
lot
of
people
got
scared
and
stayed
home
.
''
<END>
<START>
However
,
a
spokeswoman
for
BankAmerica
Corp.
said
yesterday
's
absenteeism
at
the
bank
holding
company
was
no
greater
than
on
an
average
day
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
San
Mateo
Bridge
,
which
connects
the
San
Francisco
peninsula
with
the
East
Bay
,
police
were
surprised
at
the
speed
with
which
traffic
moved
.
<END>
<START>
``
Everybody
pretty
much
pitched
in
and
cooperated
,
''
said
Stan
Perez
,
a
sergeant
with
the
California
Highway
Patrol
.
<END>
<START>
There
were
many
indications
that
the
new
work
hours
implemented
by
major
corporations
played
a
big
role
.
<END>
<START>
The
Golden
Gate
handled
as
many
cars
as
normally
yesterday
,
but
over
four
hours
rather
than
the
usual
two-hour
crush
.
<END>
<START>
Of
Bechtel
's
17,500
employees
,
about
4,000
work
in
San
Francisco
--
one-third
of
them
commuting
from
stricken
East
Bay
.
<END>
<START>
Pacific
Gas
&
Electric
Co.
is
offering
its
6,000
San
Francisco
employees
a
two-tier
flextime
schedule
--
either
6
a.m.
to
2
p.m.
or
10
a.m.
to
6
p.m
.
<END>
<START>
The
flextime
may
cut
by
almost
a
third
the
number
of
PG&E
employees
working
conventional
9-5
hours
,
a

.
<END>
<START>
Some
of
the
utility
's

may
opt
for
a
four-day
workweek
,
10
hours
a
day
,
to
cut
the
commute
by
20
%
.
<END>
<START>
Some
individuals
went
to
some
lengths
on
their
own
to
avoid
the
anticipated
gridlock
.
<END>
<START>
One
senior
vice
president
at
Bechtel
said
he
got
up
at
3
a.m.
to
drive
into
San
Francisco
from

East
Bay
.
<END>
<START>
But
transportation
officials
worry
that
such
extraordinary
measures
and
cooperation
may
not
last
.
<END>
<START>
And
some
commuters
,
relieved
by
the
absence
of
gridlock
,
were
planning
to
return
to
their
old
ways
.
<END>
<START>
Garry
Kasparov
went
to
combat
Sunday
with
the
world
's
most
advanced
chess
computer
and
kicked
it
around
--
symbolically
,
anyway
--
like
an
old
tin
can
.
<END>
<START>
Playing
black
in
the
first
game
,
the
human
champion
maneuvered
Deep
Thought
,
known
for
its
attacking
prowess
,
into
a
totally
passive
position
.
<END>
<START>
Then
he
unleashed
his
own
,
unstoppable
,
attack
.
<END>
<START>
And
in
the
second
game
,
with
Mr.
Kasparov
advancing
ferociously
as
white
,
D.T.
offered
feeble
resistance
and
lost
even
faster
.
<END>
<START>
Well
,
mankind
can
rest
easier
for
now
.
<END>
<START>
Though
almost
everybody
at
the
playing
site
had
been
looking
for
the
26-year-old
Soviet
to
beat
the
Pennsylvania-based
computer
,
he
gave
the
machine
a
far
worse
drubbing
than
many
expected
.
<END>
<START>
And
when
Mr.
Kasparov
strode
into
the
playing
hall
,
he
called
the
outcome
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Kasparov
was
underwhelmed
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
computer
's
mind
is
too
straight
,
too
primitive
,
''
lacking
the
intuition
and
creativity
needed
to
reach
the
top
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
champion
apparently
was
not
worried
at
all
about
D.T.
's
strong
points
.
<END>
<START>
Its
chief
builder
,
Taiwan-born
Feng-hsiung
Hsu
,
nicknamed
his
brainchild
``
the
Weasel
''
for
its
tactical
flair
at
wriggling
out
of
horrible
positions
.
<END>
<START>
In
fact
,
D.T.
never
left
home
,
Carnegie
Mellon
University
in
Pittsburgh
,
but
communicated
with
its
human
handlers
by
telephone
link
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
handlers
mistakenly
stuck
with
silicon
chips
;
they
needed
kryptonite
.
<END>
<START>
This
became
apparent
as
game
one
,
a
Sicilian
Defense
by
Mr.
Kasparov
,
proceeded
.
<END>
<START>
No
human
can
examine
millions
of
moves
,
but
Mr.
Kasparov
,
using
his
ineffably
powerful
brain
,
consistently
found
very
good
ones
.
<END>
<START>
After
eight
moves
by
each
side
,
the
board
was
the
same
as
in
a
game
in
which
Nigel
Short
of
Great
Britain
fought
the
champion
to
a
draw
in
1980
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
computer
did
n't
play
Mr.
Short
's
ninth
move
,
a
key
pawn
thrust
,
and
its
position
deteriorated
rapidly
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
of
castling
,
a
standard
measure
to
safeguard
the
king
,
D.T.
made
a
second-rate
rook
maneuver
at
move
13
;
then
it
put
a
knight
offside
on
move
16
.
<END>
<START>
By
move
21
,
D.T.
had
fallen
into
a
deep
positional
trap
.
<END>
<START>
It
allowed
Mr.
Kasparov
to
exchange
his
dark-squared
bishop
for
one
of
D.T.
's
knights
.
<END>
<START>
Bishops
usually
are
worth
slightly
more
than
knights
,
but
in
this
case
Mr.
Kasparov
was
left
with
a
very
dangerous
knight
and
D.T.
's
surviving
bishop
was
reduced
to
passivity
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
it
looked
more
like
a
pawn
,
a
``
tall
pawn
,
''
as
spectators
snidely
put
it
.
<END>
<START>
Consistently
,
D.T.
was
over-optimistic
about
its
chances
,
which
it
continually
sized
up
,
in
numerical
form
.
<END>
<START>
When
most
spectators
thought
its
position
hopeless
,
the
computer
thought
it
was
only
,
in
effect
,
one-half
of
a
pawn
down
.
<END>
<START>
Such
evaluations
met
with
derision
,
and
kept
the
machine
from
resigning
as
soon
as
humans
would
have
--
prompting
more
derision
.
<END>
<START>
While
D.T.
shuffled
its
king
back
and
forth
in
a
defensive
crouch
,
Mr.
Kasparov
maneuvered
the
knight
to
a
dominant
outpost
.
<END>
<START>
He
also
launched
a
kingside
storm
,
sacrificing
a
pawn
to
denude
D.T.
's
king
.
<END>
<START>
No
amount
of
weasling
could
have
saved
this
game
for
D.T
.
<END>
<START>
A
piece
down
,
the
computer
resigned
.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
with
the
crowd
in
the
analysis
room
smelling
figurative
blood
,
the
only
question
seemed
to
be
how
fast
Mr.
Kasparov
could
win
game
two
.
<END>
<START>
With
the
advantage
of
playing
white
-LRB-
which
moves
first
-RRB-
,
Mr.
Kasparov
followed
up
cleverly
against
the
computer
's
defense
,
a
Queen
's
Gambit
Accepted
.
<END>
<START>
As
early
as
move
six
,
Mr.
Kasparov
deviated
from
a
well-known
sequence
of
moves
,
developing
a
knight
instead
of
making
a
standard
bishop
attack
against
the
computer
's
advanced
knight
.
<END>
<START>
This
left
the
computer
with
a
broader
range
of
plausible
replies
--
and
it
immediately
blundered
by
moving
a
queenside
pawn
,
to
the
neglect
of
kingside
development
.
<END>
<START>
``
In
a
new
position
just
after
the
opening
,
a
computer
will
have
serious
problems
,
''
Mr.
Kasparov
said
later
.
<END>
<START>
In
such
positions
,
he
explained
,
``
you
have
to
create
something
new
,
and
the
computer
is
n't
able
to
do
that
right
now
.
''
<END>
<START>
After
only
11
moves
for
each
side
,
the
computer
's
position
was
shaky
.
<END>
<START>
Greedily
,
it
grabbed
a
pawn
,
at
the
cost
of
facing
a
brutal
attack
.
<END>
<START>
And
when
a
defensive
move
was
called
for
,
D.T.
passed
up
an
obvious
pawn
move
and
instead
exposed
its
queen
to
immediate
tactical
threats
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Kasparov
remarked
later
that
``
even
a
weak
club
player
''
would
have
avoided
the
queen
move
.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
after
only
a
dozen
moves
,
spectators
were
looking
for
a
mating
combination
.
<END>
<START>
On
a
demonstration
board
,
emcee
Shelby
Lyman
showed
a
quick
kill
initiated
by
a
knight
sacrifice
;
no
spectator
refuted
this
line
of
play
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Kasparov
's
continuation
was
slower
but
,
in
the
end
,
just
as
deadly
.
<END>
<START>
He
won
D.T.
's
queen
for
two
minor
pieces
and
two
pawns
--
not
enough
compensation
,
in
this
position
,
to
give
the
computer
much
hope
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
hopeless
position
,
the
computer
resigned
rather
than
make
its
37th
move
.
<END>
<START>
And
Mr.
Kasparov
,
to
cheers
and
applause
,
marched
back
into
the
analysis
room
.
<END>
<START>
``
In
both
games
I
got
exactly
what
I
wanted
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
What
he
had
demonstrated
,
he
added
,
is
that
there
's
more
to
chess
than
sheer
calculation
.
<END>
<START>
Undeterred
,
D.T.
's
handlers
vowed
to
press
on
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
three
of
them
will
be
building
a
successor
machine
for
International
Business
Machines
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
Promises
Feng-hsiung
Hsu
:
``
In
three
years
we
'll
mount
a
better
challenge
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Tannenbaum
is
a
reporter
in
the
Journal
's
New
York
bureau
.
<END>
<START>
Reaching
for
that
extra
bit
of
yield
can
be
a
big
mistake
--
especially
if
you
do
n't
understand
what
you
're
investing
in
.
<END>
<START>
Just
ask
Richard
Blumenfeld
,
a
New
Jersey
dentist
who
considers
himself
``
a
reasonably
sophisticated
investor
.
''
<END>
<START>
In
May
1986
,
Dr.
Blumenfeld
gave
Merrill
Lynch
&
Co.
about
$
40,000
for
a
federally
insured
certificate
of
deposit
offering
an
effective
yield
of
more
than
9
%
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
was
a
time
when
interest
rates
came
down
very
rapidly
,
''
Dr.
Blumenfeld
recalls
.
<END>
<START>
Yields
on
five-year
CDs
at
major
banks
were
averaging
about
7.45
%
,
and
10-year
Treasury
notes
were
paying
less
than
8
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
CD
seemed
like
a
great
deal
.
<END>
<START>
The
problem
is
that
the
CD
he
bought
for
a
retirement
plan
was
n't
a
plain
vanilla
CD
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
,
his
Merrill
broker
put
him
in
a
zero-coupon
CD
,
which
is
sold
at
a
deep
discount
to
its
face
value
.
<END>
<START>
The
difference
between
the
price
and
the
face
value
payable
at
maturity
is
the
investor
's
return
.
<END>
<START>
More
important
,
the
CD
was
purchased
on
the
secondary
,
or
resale
,
market
.
<END>
<START>
Now
the
thrift
that
issued
the
CD
is
insolvent
,
and
Dr.
Blumenfeld
has
learned
to
his
surprise
that
the
premium
is
n't
insured
under
federal
deposit
insurance
.
<END>
<START>
The
tip-off
came
when
he
opened
a
recent
Merrill
Lynch
statement
and
found
that
the
CD
's
``
estimated
current
market
value
''
had
plummeted
by
$
9,000
in
a
month
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
one
thing
I
was
never
aware
of
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
He
assumed
that
principal
and
interest
were
``
fully
insured
up
to
$
100,000
,
''
he
adds
.
<END>
<START>
Dr.
Blumenfeld
is
n't
unique
.
<END>
<START>
``
Yield
greed
often
gets
in
the
way
of
understanding
things
,
''
says
John
Markese
,
research
director
of
the
American
Association
of
Individual
Investors
,
a
Chicago-based
educational
group
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
biggest
problem
we
have
is
that
investors
realize
,
after
the
fact
,
that
they
did
n't
understand
what
they
were
investing
in
.
''
<END>
<START>
Dr.
Blumenfeld
concedes
he
did
n't
fully
understand
what
he
was
buying
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
says
he
did
n't
understand
he
was
buying
the
CD
on
the
secondary
market
,
and
he
contends
his
broker
never
fully
explained
the
risks
.
<END>
<START>
Those
officials
say
there
was
full
disclosure
of
the
risks
in
a
``
fact
sheet
''
sent
to
all
CD
investors
with
their
confirmation
of
sale
.
<END>
<START>
Computations
involving
zero-coupon
CDs
are
more
complicated
and
you
should
discuss
any
questions
you
may
have
with
your
financial
consultant
.
''
<END>
<START>
Dr.
Blumenfeld
says
he
does
n't
remember
the
paragraph
about
premiums
in
the
fact
sheet
he
received
and
did
n't
realize
part
of
what
he
paid
was
a
premium
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
assumed
I
was
buying
a
CD
as
a
CD
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Federal
deposit
insurance
would
pay
principal
and
interest
accrued
to
the
date
of
liquidation
,
to
a
maximum
of
$
100,000
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
not
a
blanket
commitment
,
it
's
a
case-by-case
situation
,
''
says
Albert
Disposti
,
a
managing
director
of
Merrill
Lynch
Money
Markets
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
's
a
question
whether
brokers
at
the
time
were
fully
aware
''
of
the
risks
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
were
n't
sure
that
full
disclosure
,
as
we
wanted
it
,
was
being
made
.
''
<END>
<START>
Merrill
Lynch
now
provides
credit
rating
information
about
the
institutions
whose
CDs
it
sells
,
which
it
did
n't
provide
in
1986
.
<END>
<START>
Zero-coupon
CDs
are
only
a
small
portion
of
the
$
1
trillion-plus
in
CDs
outstanding
,
and
those
purchased
on
the
secondary
market
are
an
even
smaller
part
of
the
total
.
<END>
<START>
Merrill
Lynch
estimates
that
fewer
than
10
financial
institutions
currently
issue
zero-coupon
CDs
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
there
are
several
billion
dollars
of
zero-coupon
CDs
with
various
maturities
outstanding
.
<END>
<START>
Most
zero-coupon
CDs
are
in
maturities
of
six
to
nine
years
,
and
they
usually
double
in
value
by
maturity
.
<END>
<START>
But
investors
who
bought
zero-coupon
CDs
in
the
secondary
market
are
n't
the
only
ones
who
may
be
surprised
to
learn
the
full
amount
of
their
investments
is
n't
insured
.
<END>
<START>
People
who
paid
a
premium
for
standard
CDs
purchased
on
the
secondary
market
could
also
find
that
those
premiums
are
n't
insured
if
the
institutions
that
issued
the
CDs
failed
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
those
premiums
are
usually
far
smaller
than
on
zero-coupon
CDs
,
and
the
simpler
pricing
structure
of
a
standard
CD
makes
it
more
apparent
when
a
premium
is
paid
.
<END>
<START>
Dr.
Blumenfeld
says

's

.
<END>

.

.

<START>
Americans
are
drinking
less
,
but
young
professionals
from
Australia
to
West
Germany
are
rushing
to
buy
premium-brand
American
vodka
,
brandy
and
other
spirits
.
<END>
<START>
In
particular
,
many
are
snubbing
the
scotch
preferred
by
their
parents
and
opting
for
bourbon
,
the
sweet
firewater
from
the
Kentucky
countryside
.
<END>
<START>
With
U.S.
liquor
consumption
declining
steadily
,
many
American
producers
are
stepping
up
their
marketing
efforts
abroad
.
<END>
<START>
``
Spirits
companies
now
view
themselves
as
global
marketers
,
''
says
Michael
Bellas
,
president
of
Beverage
Marketing
Corp.
,
a
research
and
consulting
firm
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
you
want
to
be
a
player
,
you
have
to
be
in
America
,
Europe
and
the
Far
East
.
<END>
<START>
You
must
have
world-class
brands
,
a
long-term
perspective
and
deep
pockets
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
internationalization
of
the
industry
has
been
hastened
by
foreign
companies
'
acquisitions
of
many
U.S.
producers
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
shift
has
also
been
fueled
by
necessity
.
<END>
<START>
In
recent
years
,
growth
has
come
in
the
foreign
markets
.
<END>
<START>
U.S.
brandy
exports
more
than
doubled
last
year
to
360,000
proof
gallons
,
a
standard
industry
measure
,
according
to
Jobson
Beverage
Alcohol
Group
,
an
industry
association
.
<END>
<START>
Exports
of
rum
surged
54
%
to
814,000
proof
gallons
.
<END>
<START>
Mexico
is
the
biggest
importer
of
both
rum
and
brandy
from
the
U.S.
.
<END>
<START>
California
wineries
,
benefiting
from
lowered
trade
barriers
and
federal
marketing
subsidies
,
are
expanding
aggressively
into
Japan
,
as
well
as
Canada
and
Great
Britain
.
<END>
<START>
In
Japan
,
the
wineries
are
promoting
their
products
'
Pacific
roots
and
courting
restaurant
and
hotel
chefs
,
whose
recommendations
carry
weight
.
<END>
<START>
In
Australia
,
Britain
,
Canada
and
Greece
,
Brown-Forman
Corp.
has
increased
its
marketing
of
Southern
Comfort
Liqueur
.
<END>
<START>
Using
cinema
,
television
and
print
ads
,
the
company
pitches
Southern
Comfort
as
a
grand
old
drink
of
the
antebellum
American
South
.
<END>
<START>
The
biggest
foreign
inroads
,
though
,
have
been
made
by
bourbon
.
<END>
<START>
While
U.S.
makers
of
vodka
,
rum
and
other
spirits
compete
against
powerhouses
abroad
,
trade
agreements
prohibit
any
other
country
from
making
bourbon
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
All
bourbon
comes
from
Kentucky
,
though
Jack
Daniel
's
Tennessee
whiskey
often
is
counted
as
bourbon
because
of
similarity
of
taste
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
just
as
vodka
has
acquired
an
upscale
image
in
the
U.S.
,
bourbon
has
become
fashionable
in
many
foreign
countries
,
a
uniquely
American
product
tied
to
frontier
folklore
.
<END>
<START>
How
was
the
West
won
?
<END>
<START>
With
a
six-shooter
in
one
hand
and
bourbon
in
the
other
.
<END>
<START>
Suntory
distributes
Brown-Forman
bourbons
in
Japan
.
<END>
<START>
Big
U.S.
distillers
are
fiercely
vying
for
this
market
,
which
grew
to
$
77
million
last
year
from
$
33
million
in
1987
,
according
to
government
figures
.
<END>
<START>
Jim
Beam
Brands
Co.
,
a
division
of
American
Brands
Inc.
,
is
the
leading

of
bourbon
and

10
other

.
<END>
<START>
The

says

will
increase

international

35
%
in
1990
,
with

representing
most

.
<END>
<START>
Guinness
's
Schenley
Industries

has

in
Japan
and
has
built

with
duty-free
shops
throughout
Asia
,
enabling

to

counter

.
<END>
<START>
The
company
's
I.W.
Harper
brand
is
the
leading

in
Japan
,
with
40
%
of

market
.
<END>
<START>
Bourbon

have
succeeded
in
Japan

other

have

,

in

.

<START>
Jim
Beam

,

.
<END>
<START>

Co.
,

,

Co
.

<START>
Some

.

<START>

,

's

.
''

.

.

,

.

.

<START>
McDonald
's
Corp.
said
third-quarter
earnings
rose
14
%
on
a
hefty
sales
gain
,
but
domestic
franchisees
apparently
did
n't
partake
of
the
improvement
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
latest
period
,
the
company
had
an
average
of
370.8
million
shares
,
5.6
million
shares
below
last
year
's
level
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
rose
12
%
to
$
1.63
billion
from
$
1.46
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Systemwide
sales
,
which
include
sales
at
franchisee
as
well
as
company-owned
stores
,
totaled
$
4.59
billion
compared
with
$
4.2
billion
.
<END>
<START>
But
sales
for
U.S.
franchisees
were
flat
at
best
on
a
per-store
basis
despite
weak
1988
figures
.
<END>
<START>
Compared
with
the
first
nine
months
of
last
year
,
average
franchisee
store
sales
this
year
were
down
nearly
$
3,200
,
reflecting
a
fierce
discounting
war
among
fast-food
chains
.
<END>
<START>
Since
McDonald
's
menu
prices
rose
this
year
,
the
actual
decline
may
have
been
more
.
<END>
<START>
McDonald
's
closed
at
$
31.375
,
up
$
1
,
in
New
York
Stock
Exchange
composite
trading
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
While
franchisees
were
having
a
tough
time
holding
sales
,
McDonald
's
company-operated
stores
posted
hefty
gains
for
the
nine
months
,
with
sales
per
company-operated
unit
rising
$
20,000
.
<END>
<START>
One
analyst
noted
that
the
company
often
has
better
store
locations
than
do
its
franchisees
,
thus
aiding
promotional
efforts
.
<END>
<START>
On
average
in
the
latest
nine
months
,
company-operated
units
in
the
U.S.
had
$
90,552
more
in
sales
than
did
franchised
outlets
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
more
than
three
times
as
many
franchised
domestic
outlets
as
there
are
company
stores
.
<END>
<START>
Profit
margins
at
U.S.
company-owned
stores
in
the
quarter
were
up
nearly
1
%
,
which
the
company
attributed
in
part
to
lower
food
costs
.
<END>
<START>
Prudential-Bache
Securities
analyst
Leslie
Steppel
said
reduced
labor
costs
helped
boost
margins
,
although
she
doubted
``
that
kind
of
performance
is
sustainable
.
''
<END>
<START>
Calling
sales
``
still
relatively
soft
,
''
Ms.
Steppel
believes
that
in
real
terms
,
U.S.
sales
slipped
3
1/2
%
to
4
%
at
company-operated
stores
in
the
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Apparently
acknowledging
weaker
U.S.
sales
systemwide
,
McDonald
's
vowed
``
to
use
our
size
and
muscle
to
do
all
that
is
necessary
to
build
the
brand
.
''
<END>
<START>
Overseas
,
both
franchisees
and
the
company
performed
substantially
better
than
a
year
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Third-quarter
sales
in
Europe
were
exceptionally
strong
,
boosted
by
promotional

and
new
products
--
although
weaker
foreign
currencies
reduced

company
's

.
<END>
<START>
McDonald
's
said
that
systemwide
sales
would
have
been
$
115

greater
had
1988
exchange
rates
remained

.
<END>
<START>
``

the

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
Revenue

11

.

<START>
Carnival
Cruise
Lines
Inc.
's
common
stock
was
dragged
down

amid

that
a

filing
by
a
Finnish
shipbuilder
would
delay
delivery
of
three
big

ships
.
<END>
<START>
The
Miami-based
company
's

fell
$
1.75
yesterday
to
$
20.75
a

in
heavy
American
Stock
Exchange

trading
.
<END>
<START>
Officials
at
Carnival
declined
to
comment
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
did
n't
even
know
that
a
company
in
a
socialistic
country
could
file
for
bankruptcy
.
''
<END>
<START>

,

about
2,050

,
would
expand

capacity
of
Carnival
's
existing
14-ship
fleet
by
24
%
.
<END>
<START>

second

,
which
is

,
is

to
be
delivered
in
fall
1990
,
and
the
third
in
fall
1991
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
's
a
99
%

that
the
Fantasy
will
be
delivered
close
to
schedule
,
''

Caroline
Levy
,

Hutton
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
others
will
probably
be
delivered
as
well
,
but
Carnival
will
likely
have
to
pay
a
higher
price
for
them
.
''
<END>
<START>
She
said
the
company
could
pay
as
much
as
25
%
more
for
the
ships
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
ships
are
n't
delivered
,
however
,
it
will
likely
have
an
effect
on
the
company
's
earnings
as
soon
as
the
1990
fiscal
year
,
which
begins
Dec.
1
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
said
those
estimates
--
which
range
from
about
$
1.80
a
share
to
$
1.95
a
share
--
are
based
on
Fantasy
being
in
operation
in
1990
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
ship
fails
to
arrive
,
those
per-share
earnings
estimates
could
be
trimmed
15
cents
or
more
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
were
n't
willing
to
speculate
on
how
much
money
Carnival
might
lose
through
deposits
.
<END>
<START>
Normally
,
a
company
pays
a
portion
of
the
total
cost
of
a
ship
as
it
reaches
various
stages
of
construction
.
<END>
<START>
Carnival
,
for
example
,
has
already
paid
about
$
160
million
of
the
total
cost
for
Fantasy
.
<END>
<START>
Some
analysts
say
this
may
give
it
the
right
to
seize
the
ship
if
the
situation
warrants
it
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
reports
from
Finland
,
Waertsilae
Marine
,
19%-owned
by
conglomerate
Oy
Waertsilae
,
filed
for
bankruptcy
yesterday
after
the
shipyard
's

had
started
to
demand

.
<END>
<START>
The
shipyard
disclosed
in
mid-August
that
it
expected
losses
stemming
from
a
series
of
unprofitable
orders
.
<END>
<START>
Designer
Sandra
Garratt
filed
for
Chapter
7
Bankruptcy
Code
protection
,
saying
that
her

flow
had
been
cut

.
<END>
<START>
The

,

of

,

has

a

,
has
been

with

latest

,
Jerell
Inc.
for
several
months
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Garratt
was

in

.
<END>
<START>
The

's

,

,

Garratt
was
forced
to

because

last

.
<END>

Multiples

,

.

,

,
in

of

.
<END>
<START>
That
lawsuit
is
still
pending
.
<END>
<START>
Jerell
could
n't
immediately
be
reached
for
comment
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Garratt
's
assets
and
liabilities
were
n't
disclosed
.
<END>
<START>
Eaton
Corp.
had
a
26
%
drop
in
third-quarter
profit
mainly
because
of
lower
sales
of
truck
parts
,
its
largest
and
most
profitable
single
business
.
<END>
<START>
He
declined
to
make
a
specific
earnings
estimate
.
<END>
<START>
Third-quarter
net
was
$
40
million
,
or
$
1.04
a
share
,
from
$
54.4
million
,
or
$
1.47
a
share
,
a
year
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
rose
2.8
%
to
$
864.1
million
,
from
$
840.4
million
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
Eaton
's
quarter
profit
margin
on
controls
was
lower
than
he
anticipated
.
<END>
<START>
Eaton
said
sales
of
truck
axles
,
transmissions
and
other
parts
fell
7.2
%
to
$
295
million
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
of
parts
for
cars
and
construction
vehicles
rose
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Hardis
said
truck-fleet
operators
appear
to
be
cautious
about
buying
new
trucks
until
they
see
how
the
economy
behaves
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
attributed
the
decline
to
weakness
in
the
commercial-switch
market
in
North
America
and
in
the
European
appliance-controls
market
.
<END>

earned
from

$

million
,

4.40
a

,
down
7

from

,

,

.

$

,

$
2.58

.
<END>
<START>

Exchange

,

closed
at
$
57.50
a
share
,
down
$
2.50
.
<END>
<START>
Initial
steps
were
taken
at
Poland
's
first
international
environmental
conference
,
which
I
attended
last
month
.
<END>
<START>
Even
more
remarkably
,
it
focused
on
emissions
trading
and
similar
market
approaches
to
address
pollution
,
notwithstanding
Poland
's
lack
of
functioning
markets
.
<END>
<START>
Why
did
East
Bloc
participants
unanimously
endorse
market-based
pollution
approaches
?
<END>
<START>
The
answer
lies
both
in
the
degraded
environment
of
these
countries
and
the
perceived
causes
of
that
degradation
.
<END>
<START>
Like
other
East
Bloc
countries
,
Poland
possesses
environmental
laws
more
honored
in
their
breach
than
in
their
observance
.
<END>
<START>
Norms
are
consistently
exceeded
at
60
%
of
nitrogen
oxide
monitoring
sites
and
80
%
of
those
for
dust
and
soot
emissions
.
<END>
<START>
Four-fifths
of
Poland
's
soils
have
become
highly
acidified
;
70
%
of
its
southern
forests
are
projected
to
die
by
century
's
end
.
<END>
<START>
Between
1965
and
1985
,
Polish
waters
fit
for
human
consumption
dropped
from
33
%
to
6
%
of
all
surface
waters
,
while
those
unfit
even
for
industry
use
nearly
doubled
.
<END>
<START>
Poland
produces
about
20
times
more
soot
and
five
times
more
sulfur
dioxide
and
solid
waste
per
unit
of
gross
national
product
than
does
Western
Europe
.
<END>
<START>
Its
mortality
rate
for
males
over
35
is
about
50
%
higher
than
West
Germany
's
,
and
50
%
higher
in
hazard
areas
than
the
national
average
.
<END>
<START>
Since
1978
,
average
annual
growth
rates
for
most
pollutants
have
outstripped
the
growth
of
GNP
.
<END>
<START>
The
solutions
they
formally
proposed
included
lead/sulfur
taxes
,
conservation
and
recycling
incentives
,
reforestation
offsets
,
transferable
pollution
permits
,
an
ecological
bank
to
finance
pollution-reduction
credits
,
and
debt-for-environment
swaps
.
<END>
<START>
But
their
most
fundamental
recommendation
was
to
separate
industry
from
the
state
,
making
it
fully
accountable
for
pollution
control
.
<END>
<START>
A
revolution
takes
more
than
conference
manifestos
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
skepticism
was
amply
captured
by
a
joke
told
by
Poles
at
the
conference
:
``
The
world
must
be
coming
to
an
end
.
<END>
<START>
The
Russians
are
talking
peace
.
<END>
<START>
The
Palestinians
are
talking
elections
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
Poles
are
engaged
in
commerce
.
''
<END>
<START>
Those
implications
include
:
--
Privatization
.
<END>
<START>
Faced
with
a
$
40
billion
foreign
debt
and
skyrocketing
inflation
,
Poland
must
privatize
industry
and
eliminate
subsidies
to
stabilize
its
currency
and
qualify
for
international
assistance
.
<END>
<START>
Market-based
pollution
control
may
consume
some
capital
that
would
otherwise
purchase
state
industries
.
<END>
<START>
--
Least-cost
solutions
.
<END>
<START>
As
conferees
noted
,
scarce
capital
means
the
costs
of
control
must
be
minimized
through
a
broad
menu
of
compliance
choices
for
individual
firms
.
<END>
<START>
That
means
simple
,
clear
rules
that
secure
the
first
large
blocks
of
reduction
,
deferring
more
complex
issues
such
as
risk
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
means
use
of
quantity-based
pollution
limits
such
as
transferable
permits
,
rather
than
price-based
limits
such
as
effluent
fees
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
because
quota-trained
managers
will
likely
respond
better
to
quantity
than
to
price
signals
.
<END>
<START>
--
Creative
financing
.
<END>
<START>
Even
least-cost
environmental
solutions
will
require
billions
of
dollars
.
<END>
<START>
New
types
of
financing
must
make
funds
available
without
draining
Poland
's
hard-currency
reserves
.
<END>
<START>
--
Democratization
.
<END>
<START>
East
Bloc
pollution
data
typically
have
been
state
secrets
.
<END>
<START>
While
Polish
data
have
been
freely
available
since
1980
,
it
was
no
accident
that
participants
urged
the
free
flow
of
information
.
<END>
<START>
For
once
information
flows
,
public
participation
follows
and
repression
becomes
difficult
to
reimpose
.
<END>
<START>
--
Global
reciprocity
.
<END>
<START>
One
participant
prematurely
declared
that
America
has
had
a
free
market
in
goods
but
a
planned
economy
for
environmental
protection
,
while
Poland
represents
the
opposite
.
<END>
<START>
His
point
:
It
will
be
increasingly
difficult
for
the
U.S.
to
cling
to
command-and-control
measures
if
even
the
East
Bloc
steps
to
a
different
drummer
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
moment
,
Poland
resembles
19th-century
Pittsburgh
more
than
a
modern
industrial
society
--
with
antiquated
production
,
inadequate
environmental
management
,
and
little
ecological
awareness
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
continuing
pressures
for
free-market
economics
suggest
the
conference
's
vision
was
not
all
fantasy
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Levin
,
former
head
of
EPA
's
regulatory
reform
staff
,
adapted
this
from
his
November
column
for
the
Journal
of
the
Air
and
Waste
Management
Association
.
<END>
<START>
Disappointing
earnings
news
from
some

unnerved

in

,

,

.

<START>

by

.
<END>
<START>
It

467.22
,

.

<START>

about

,

.

.

.

.

.

.

.

Yesterday

's

.

,

.

1/8

<START>

.

<START>

<START>

1/8

.

<START>
Some

say

will

,

.

<START>
They

that

of
15
%

.
<END>
<START>
That

OTC
market
,

say
,
because
many

.

<START>
Michael

,

.

<START>
The

.

<START>
The

this

.

<START>

<START>

.

<START>
Higher

.

<START>
Amgen

3/4

,

CVB
Financial
jumped
4
to
41
on
only
1,000
shares
.
<END>
<START>
Why
ca
n't
we
teach
our
children
to
read
,
write
and
reckon
?
<END>
<START>
It
's
not
that
we
do
n't
know
how
to
,
because
we
do
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
that
we
do
n't
want
to
.
<END>
<START>
These
beliefs
so
dominate
our
educational
establishment
,
our
media
,
our
politicians
,
and
even
our
parents
that
it
seems
almost
blasphemous
to
challenge
them
.
<END>
<START>
Here
is
an
example
.
<END>
<START>
But
what
do
we
mean
,
specifically
,
by
``
creativity
''
?
<END>
<START>
No
one
can
say
.
<END>
<START>
In
practice
,
it
ends
up
being
equated
with
a
``
self-expression
''
that
encourages
the
youngsters
'
``
self-esteem
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
result
is
a
generation
of
young
people
whose
ignorance
and
intellectual
incompetence
is
matched
only
by
their
good
opinion
of
themselves
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
not
surprising
that
parents
find
this
romantic
extravagance
so
attractive
.
<END>
<START>
Fortunately
,
these
same
parents
do
want
their
children
to
get
a
decent
education
as
traditionally
understood
,
and
they
have
enough
common
sense
to
know
what
that
demands
.
<END>
<START>
Their
commitment
to
``
creativity
''
can
not
survive
adolescent
illiteracy
.
<END>
<START>
American
education
's
future
will
be
determined
by
the
degree
to
which
we
--
all
of
us
--
allow
this
common
sense
to
prevail
over
the
illusions
that
we
also
share
.
<END>
<START>
The
education
establishment
will
fight
against
common
sense
every
inch
of
the
way
.
<END>
<START>
The
reasons
are
complex
,
but
one
simple
reason
ought
not
to
be
underestimated
.
<END>
<START>
``
Progressive
education
''
-LRB-
as
it
was
once
called
-RRB-
is
far
more
interesting
and
agreeable
to
teachers
than
is
disciplined
instruction
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
nice
for
teachers
to
think
they
are
engaged
in
``
personality
development
''
and
even
nicer
to
minimize
those
irksome
tests
with
often
disappointing
results
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
provides
teachers
with
a
superior
self-definition
as
a
``
profession
,
''
since
they
will
have
passed
courses
in
educational
psychology
and
educational
philosophy
.
<END>
<START>
I
myself
took
such
courses
in
college
,
thinking
I
might
end
up
a
schoolteacher
.
<END>
<START>
They
could
all
fairly
be
described
as
``
pap
''
courses
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
is
unfair
to
dump
on
teachers
,
as
distinct
from
the
educational
establishment
.
<END>
<START>
I
know
many
schoolteachers
and
,
on
the
whole
,
they
are
seriously
committed
to
conscientious
teaching
.
<END>
<START>
They
may
not
be
among
the
``
best
and
brightest
''
of
their
generation
--
there
are
very
few
such
people
,
by
definition
.
<END>
<START>
But
they
need
not
be
to
do
their
jobs
well
.
<END>
<START>
Yes
,
we
all
can
remember
one
or
two
truly
inspiring
teachers
from
our
school
days
.
<END>
<START>
But
our
education
proceeded
at
the
hands
of
those
others
,
who
were
merely
competent
and
conscientious
.
<END>
<START>
In
this
sense
,
a
teacher
can
be
compared
to
one
's
family
doctor
.
<END>
<START>
If
he
were
brilliant
,
he
probably
would
not
be
a
family
doctor
in
the
first
place
.
<END>
<START>
If
he
is
competent
and
conscientious
,
he
serves
us
well
.
<END>
<START>
Our
teachers
are
not
an
important
factor
in
our
educational
crisis
.
<END>
<START>
Whether
they
are
or
are
not
underpaid
is
a
problem
of
equity
;
it
is
not
an
educational
problem
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
silly
libel
on
our
teachers
to
think
they
would
educate
our
children
better
if
only
they
got
a
few
thousand
dollars
a
year
more
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
the
kind
of
libel
the
teachers
'
unions
do
n't
mind
spreading
,
for
their
own
narrow
purposes
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
also
the
kind
of
libel
politicians
find
useful
,
since
it
helps
them
strike
a
friendly
posture
on
behalf
of
an
important
constituency
.
<END>
<START>
But
there
is
not
one
shred
of
evidence
that
,
other
things
being
equal
,
salary
differentials
result
in
educational
differentials
.
<END>
<START>
If
there
were
such
evidence
,
you
can
be
sure
you
would
have
heard
of
it
.
<END>
<START>
If
we
wish
to
be
serious
about
American
education
,
we
know
exactly
what
to
do
--
and
,
just
as
important
,
what
not
to
do
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
many
successful
schools
scattered
throughout
this
nation
,
some
of
them
in
the
poorest
of
ghettos
,
and
they
are
all
sending
us
the
same
message
.
<END>
<START>
Conversely
,
there
are
the
majority
of
unsuccessful
schools
,
and
we
know
which
efforts
at
educational
reform
are
doomed
beforehand
.
<END>
<START>
We
really
do
know
all
we
need
to
know
,
if
only
we
could
assimilate
this
knowledge
into
our
thinking
.
<END>
<START>
In
this
respect
,
it
would
be
helpful
if
our
political
leaders
were
mute
,
rather
than
eloquently
``
concerned
.
''
<END>
<START>
They
are
inevitably
inclined
to
echo
the
conventional
pap
,
since
this
is
the
least
controversial
option
that
is
open
to
them
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
at
the
recent
governors
'
conference
on
education
,
Gov.
Bill
Clinton
of
Arkansas
announced
that
``
this
country
needs
a
comprehensive
child-development
policy
for
children
under
five
.
''
<END>
<START>
A
comprehensive
development
policy
for
governors
over
30
would
seem
to
be
a
more
pressing
need
.
<END>
<START>
What
Gov.
Clinton
is
advocating
,
in
effect
,
is
extending
the
educational
system
down
to
the
pre-kindergarten
years
.
<END>
<START>
Whether
desirable
or
not
,
this
is
a
child-care
program
,
not
an
educational
program
.
<END>
<START>
We
know
that
very
early
exposure
to
schooling
improves
performance
in
the
first
grade
,
but
afterward
the
difference
is
quickly
washed
away
.
<END>
<START>
Let
us
sum
up
what
we
do
know
about
education
and
about
those
education
reforms
that
do
work
and
do
n't
work
:
--
``
Parental
involvement
''
is
a
bad
idea
.
<END>
<START>
Parents
are
too
likely
to
blame
schools
for
the
educational
limitations
of
their
children
.
<END>
<START>
Parents
should
be
involved
with
their
children
's
education
at
home
,
not
in
school
.
<END>
<START>
They
should
see
to
it
that
their
kids
do
n't
play
truant
;
they
should
make
certain
that
the
children
spend
enough
time
doing
homework
;
they
should
scrutinize
the
report
card
.
<END>
<START>
If
parents
are
dissatisfied
with
a
school
,
they
should
have
the
option
of
switching
to
another
.
<END>
<START>
--
``
Community
involvement
''
is
an
even
worse
idea
.
<END>
<START>
Here
,
the
experience
of
New
York
City
is
decisive
.
<END>
<START>
Locally
elected
school
boards
,
especially
in
our
larger
cities
,
become
the
prey
of
ambitious
,
generally
corrupt
,
and
invariably
demagogic
local
politicians
or
would-be
politicians
.
<END>
<START>
--
In
most
states
,
increasing
expenditures
on
education
,
in
our
current
circumstances
,
will
probably
make
things
worse
,
not
better
.
<END>
<START>
The
reason
is
simple
:
Education
takes
place
in
the
classroom
,
where
the
influence
of
money
is
minimal
.
<END>
<START>
Decades
of
educational
research
tell
us
unequivocally
that
even
smaller
classes
have
zero
effect
on
the
academic
performance
of
the
pupils
--
though
they
may
sometimes
be
desirable
for
other
reasons
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
money
flows
into
the
already
top-heavy
administrative
structure
,
which
busies
itself
piling
more
and
more
paper
work
on
the
teachers
.
<END>
<START>
That
is
the
way
the
system
works
.
<END>
<START>
--
Students
should
move
up
the
educational
ladder
as
their
academic
potential
allows
.
<END>
<START>
No
student
should
be
permitted
to
be
graduated
from
elementary
school
without
having
mastered
the
3
R
's
at
the
level
that
prevailed
20
years
ago
.
<END>
<START>
The
notion
that
tracking
is
somehow
``
undemocratic
''
is
absurd
.
<END>
<START>
The
purpose
of
education
is
to
encourage
young
men
and
women
to
realize
their
full
academic
potential
.
<END>
<START>
No
one
in
his
right
mind
actually
believes
that
we
all
have
an
equal
academic
potential
.
<END>
<START>
--
It
is
generally
desirable
to
use
older
textbooks
--
many
of
them
,
alas
,
out
of
print
--
rather
than
newer
ones
.
<END>
<START>
The
latter
are
modish
,
trendy
,
often
downright
silly
,
and
at
best
insubstantial
.
<END>
<START>
They
are
based
on
dubious
psychological
and
sociological
theories
rather
than
on
educational
experience
.
<END>
<START>
--
Most
important
of
all
,
schools
should
have
principals
with
a
large
measure
of
authority
over
the
faculty
,
the
curriculum
,
and
all
matters
of
student
discipline
.
<END>
<START>
With
that
authority
,
of
course
,
goes
an
unambiguous
accountability
.
<END>
<START>
Schools
that
are
structured
in
this
way
produce
students
with
higher
morale
and
superior
academic
performance
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
a
fact
--
though
,
in
view
of
all
the
feathers
that
are
ruffled
by
this
fact
,
it
is
not
surprising
that
one
hears
so
little
about
it
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Kristol
,
an
American
Enterprise
Institute
fellow
,
co-edits
The
Public
Interest
and
publishes
The
National
Interest
.
<END>
<START>
International
Business
Machines
Corp.
unveiled
a
broad
strategy
to
tackle
the
biggest
problem
that
manufacturers
face
when
computerizing
their
operations
:
Most
machines
ca
n't
talk
to
each
other
.
<END>
<START>
The
aim
,
ultimately
,
is
to
increase
the
flow
of
information
into
a
manufacturer
's
main
computer
network
for
use
in
business
planning
,
marketing
and
other
operations
.
<END>
<START>
Manufacturers
have
already
spent
so
heavily
on
automation
that
they
are
one
of
the
computer
industry
's
leading
revenue
sources
.
<END>
<START>
But
many
manufacturers
find
that
communication
between
different
computers
has
been
rendered
nearly
impossible
by
the
babel
of
computer
languages
used
by
different
machines
,
including
robots
and
machine
tools
.
<END>
<START>
Sam
Albert
,
a
consultant
in
Scarsdale
,
N.Y.
,
said
that
in
the
past
IBM
has
developed
broad
software
strategies
only
for
problems
that
crossed
industry
lines
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
he
expects
IBM
to
unveil
similar
strategies
for
other
industries
in
coming
months
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
's
push
is
also
unusual
in
its
approach
to
marketing
.
<END>
<START>
Rather
than
just
send
out
marketing
people
to
knock
on
customers
'
doors
,
IBM
is
making
several
hundred
of
its
own
manufacturing
people
available
to
discuss
specific
needs
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
's
manufacturing
staff
also
will
be
able
to
provide
software
that
IBM
has
developed
internally
and
will
be
able
to
form
teams
with
a
customer
to
jointly
solve
manufacturing
problems
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
may
not
have
every
manufacturing
problem
,
but
we
have
most
,
''
said
George
Conrades
,
IBM
's
top
marketing
official
.

<START>
National

<START>
National

,
formerly
Yankee
Cos.
,
is
a
sludge
treatment
company
.

<START>

Clothes

,

11
of

,

.

<START>

Roth
,

has
been
on

from
his
posts
,

be

by
Geoffrie
D.
Lurie
of
GDL
Management
Inc.
,
which
is
Eagle
's
crisis
manager
.

<START>
Mr.
Lurie
is
currently

.

<START>
Arnold
Levine
,

,

.

<START>

8

in

.

,

.

.

.

.

American

.
<END>
<START>
The
tougher
new
regulations
under
the
savings-and-loan
bailout
law
are
accelerating
the
thrift
industry
's
shrinking
act
.
<END>
<START>
Largely
to
meet
tougher
new
capital
requirements
,
thrifts
reduced
their
assets
$
13.4
billion
in
August
,
by
selling
such
assets
as
mortgage-backed
securities
and
loans
.
<END>
<START>
Industry
assets
as
of
Aug.
31
were
$
1.31
trillion
,
the
lowest
since
August
1988
.
<END>
<START>
As
thrifts
sell
assets
to
improve
their
capital-to-asset
ratio
,
as
required
under
the
new
law
passed
in
August
,
they
must
also
reduce
liabilities
,
such
as
deposits
.
<END>
<START>
As
interest
rates
paid
depositors
were
lowered
,
thrift
withdrawals
exceeded
deposits
by
$
5.1
billion
,
not
including
interest
credited
to
accounts
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
the
third
consecutive
month
in
which
thrifts
shed
assets
to
increase
the
size
of
their
capital
in
relation
to
their
assets
,
the
Office
of
Thrift
Supervision
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
asset
shrinkage
was
particularly
concentrated
in
several
large
California
institutions
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
downsizing
of
the
thrift
industry
is
well
under
way
,
''
said
Bert
Ely
,
an
industry
consultant
in
Alexandria
,
Va
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
suggests
the
bailout
law
is
having
a
more
dramatic
effect
than
anyone
would
have
imagined
so
soon
.
''
<END>
<START>
James
Barth
,
an
economist
with
the
Office
of
Thrift
Supervision
,
also
attributed
some
of
the
outflow
to
seasonal
factors
.
<END>
<START>
``
August
is
a
month
when
people
are
paying
school
tuition
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
That
and
adjustment
to
the
new
law
were
the
biggest
factors
in
the
industry
.
''
<END>
<START>
Not
including
thrifts
under
government
conservatorship
,
S&Ls
reduced
their
assets
by
$
10.1
billion
from
the
previous
month
,
and
deposit
outflows
totaled
$
3.9
billion
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
264
insolvent
thrifts
under
government
management
at
the
end
of
August
,
assets
declined
by
$
3.3
billion
and
withdrawals
exceeded
deposits
by
$
1.2
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Thrifts
raised
capital
mostly
by
selling
mortgages
and
mortgage-backed
securities
,
which
were
reduced
by
$
7.8
billion
in
August
from
the
prior
month
.
<END>
<START>
As
of
Aug.
31
,
thrifts
held
$
185
billion
in
mortgage-backed
securities
.
<END>
<START>
The
deposit
numbers
for
August
marked
a
swing
back
to
huge
outflows
after
a
July
net
deposit
inflow
of
$
54
million
--
the
only
net
inflow
in
more
than
a
year
.
<END>
<START>
Deposits
are
n't
expected
to
exceed
withdrawals
in
the
foreseeable
future
,
as
the
industry
continues
to
shrink
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
think
we
are
going
to
see
deposit
shrinkage
continue
,
unless
we
see
big
changes
in
rates
,
''
Mr.
Ely
said
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
first
eight
months
of
1989
,
thrifts
'
withdrawals
exceeded
deposits
by
$
44.5
billion
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
prior
year
,
deposits
exceeded
withdrawals
by
$
8.8
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
estimates
of
real
gross
national
product
prepared
by
the
Bureau
of
Economic
Analysis
in
the
Department
of
Commerce
significantly
understate
the
rate
of
economic
growth
.
<END>
<START>
Since
the
bureau
's
estimates
for
the
business
sector
provide
the
numerator
for
the
productivity
ratios
calculated
by
the
Department
of
Labor
,
underestimated
growth
rates
artificially
depress
official
productivity
statistics
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
early
1980s
,
I
predicted
a
significant
acceleration
in
productivity
growth
over
the
rest
of
the
decade
.
<END>
<START>
There
has
indeed
been
more
than
a
one
percentage
point
improvement
in
productivity
growth
since
1981
.
<END>
<START>
But
I
had
expected
more
,
which
is
one
reason
I
began
looking
at
evidence
suggesting
defects
in
the
official
output
estimates
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
It
is
,
however
,
possible
,
that
further
study
will
reveal
increasing
bias
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
This
bias
is
in
no
way
deliberate
.
<END>
<START>
The
understatement
of
growth
is
due
largely
to
the
conservative
expedients
adopted
to
deal
with
deficiencies
in
basic
economic
data
.
<END>
<START>
This
means
that
no
allowance
is
made
for
possible
increases
in
output
per
unit
of
labor
.
<END>
<START>
The
federal
productivity
estimators
use
labor
input
,
rather
than
output
,
data
for
their
calculations
of
half
of
private
financial
and
service
industries
as
well
.
<END>
<START>
Because
finance
and
services
contribute
10
%
to
final
business
product
,
missing
these
productivity
improvements
depresses
the
overall
growth
rate
by
0.15
%
a
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
second
source
of
error
in
growth
statistics
is
the
use
of
inappropriate
deflators
to
adjust
for
price
changes
.
<END>
<START>
Finally
,
the
official
estimates
understate
growth
because
they
make
inadequate
allowance
for
improvements
in
quality
of
goods
and
services
.
<END>
<START>
Since
then
,
further
research
argues
that
failure
to
take
account
of
quality
improvements
has
contributed
a
total
of
at
least
0.26
percentage
point
to
the
downward
bias
in
the
growth
rate
.
<END>
<START>
In
sum
,
the
biases
ennumerated
above
indicate
a
0.7
percentage
point
understatement
in
growth
of
total
real
GNP
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
private
domestic
business
economy
,
the
bias
was
a
bit
over
0.5
percentage
point
.
<END>
<START>
In
other
words
,
the
growth
rates
of
both
total
GNP
and
real
private
business
product
per
labor
hour
have
been
underestimated
by
about
20
%
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Kendrick
is
professor
emeritus
of
economics
at
George
Washington
University
.
<END>
<START>
He
is
co-author
of
``
Personal
Productivity
:
How
to
Increase
Your
Satisfaction
in
Living
''
-LRB-
M.E.
Sharp
,
1988
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
Union
Carbide
Corp.
said
third-quarter
net
income
plunged
35
%
from
a
year
earlier
on
weakness
in
the
company
's
mainstay
chemicals
and
plastics
business
.
<END>
<START>
Net
was
$
139
million
,
or
98
cents
a
share
,
for
the
quarter
,
compared
with
$
213
million
,
or
$
1.56
a
share
,
a
year
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
were
$
2.14
billion
,
up
1.6
%
from
$
2.11
billion
the
previous
year
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
company
's
latest
quarter
was
a
few
pennies
a
share
lower
than
the
more
pessimistic
projections
on
Wall
Street
.
<END>
<START>
In
New
York
Stock
Exchange
composite
trading
,
Carbide
closed
at
$
24.50
a
share
,
down
50
cents
.
<END>
<START>
Prices
also
fell
for
ethylene
oxide
and
glycols
,
products
used
in
making
antifreeze
.
<END>
<START>
Some
producers
of
polyethylene
,
figuring
the
inventory
reductions
are
near
an
end
,
have
announced
price
boosts
.
<END>
<START>
The
first
real
test
of
whether
prices
have
hit
bottom
may
come
in
the
next
several
weeks
,
when
the
new
prices
become
effective
.
<END>
<START>
A
Carbide
spokesman
said
``
the
conditions
are
right
for
the
increase
to
hold
.
''
<END>
<START>
Operating
profit
from
carbon
products
,
such
as
graphite
electrodes
,
also
declined
,
to
$
6
million
from
$
20
million
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
industrial-gases
segment
,
operating
profit
climbed
to
$
87
million
from
$
58
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
latest
quarter
included
a
gain
of
about
$
62
million
on
the
sale
of
the
company
's
urethane
polyols
and
propylene
glycols
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
Propylene
glycols
are
used
in
making
personal-care
products
such
as
shampoo
,
and
urethane
polyols
are
used
in
making
the
polyurethane
foam
found
in
furniture
cushioning
and
other
products
.
<END>
<START>
That
gain
was
mostly
offset
by
a
loss
of
about
$
55
million
from
a
write-down
in
its
polysilicon
business
.
<END>
<START>
Polysilicon
is
used
in
making
integrated
circuits
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
rose
7.7
%
to
$
6.66
billion
from
$
6.19
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Up
to
now
,
Drexel
has
made
a
rapid-fire
series
of
settlements
with
25
states
and
the
commonwealth
of
Puerto
Rico
.
<END>
<START>
Just
yesterday
,
New
Hampshire
announced
it
made
a
$
75,000
settlement
with
Drexel
,
a
record-tying
fine
for
a
securities-law
matter
in
that
state
.
<END>
<START>
These
states
have
been
entering
into
settlements
with
Drexel
as
part
of
the
firm
's
efforts
to
operate
freely
anywhere
in
the
U.S.
despite
its
record
as
an
admitted
felon
.
<END>
<START>
Officials
in
some
of
these
states
say
they
do
n't
want
to
simply
accept
the
settlements
offered
by
Drexel
.
<END>
<START>
They
question
if
Drexel
is
getting
easier
treatment
than
the
many
small
penny-stock
firms
whose
brokerage
licenses
are
routinely
revoked
.
<END>
<START>
These
stem
from
a
two-year
federal
investigation
of
insider
trading
and
securities
fraud
on
Wall
Street
.
<END>
<START>
Drexel
says
it
does
n't
expect
any
of
its
state
brokerage
licenses
will
be
revoked
,
and
even
if
some
are
,
its
securities
business
would
n't
be
directly
hurt
.
<END>
<START>
It
already
has
sold
its
retail
,
or
individual-investor
,
brokerage
network
;
securities
firms
do
n't
need
brokerage
licenses
for
non-retail
activities
such
as
investment
banking
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
if
nothing
else
,
a
revoked
brokerage
license
could
be
a
burden
because
it
must
be
disclosed
in
many
of
the
transactions
in
which
Drexel
could
be
involved
.
<END>
<START>
Securities
regulators
praise
Drexel
for
its
energetic
effort
,
led
by
government-approved
general
counsel
Saul
S.
Cohen
,
to
settle
its
legal
problems
with
the
states
.
<END>
<START>
But
they
disagree
about
the
message
these
settlements
give
to
the
public
.
<END>
<START>
I
can
see
both
sides
.
''
<END>
<START>
Similarly
,
Alfred
Rubega
,
New
Hampshire
's
director
of
securities
regulation
,
said
his
state
had
n't
received
any
complaints
about
Drexel
,
so
it
really
could
n't
press
the
issue
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
``
I
understand
the
reasons
''
that
other
states
are
holding
out
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Asked
about
states
that
are
taking
a
hard
line
,
he
said
,
``
There
are
states
that
have
asked
for
additional
information
,
which
we
are
providing
to
them
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Cohen
said
more
than
$
2.8
million
has
been
paid
to
26
states
and
that
Drexel
still
expects
to
pay
out
a
total
of
$
11.5
million
.
<END>
<START>
By
the
end
of
this
week
,
Drexel
should
have
another
three
to
four
settlements
,
Mr.
Cohen
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
rate
we
're
going
,
I
think
that
by
the
end
of
the
month
,
we
're
looking
to
have
a
total
of
30
to
35
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
That
total
would
be
important
for
Drexel
.
<END>
<START>
The
investment
bank
has
previously
announced
that
as
part
of
its
punishment
it
would
create
an
independent
foundation
to
promote
ethical
behavior
in
the
securities
industry
.
<END>
<START>
A
proviso
to
that
promise
is
that
a
minimum
of
35
states
reach
settlement
agreements
before
next
Tuesday
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
,
according
to
several
securities
commissioners
,
at
least
16
states
that
are
either
close
to
settlements
with
Drexel
or
who
do
n't
appear
opposed
to
settling
.
<END>
<START>
Drexel
's
proposed
state
fines
have
been
based
on
a
state
's
population
and
on
the
size
of
Drexel
's
business
in
the
state
.
<END>
<START>
New
Jersey
,
for

,
was
asked
to
accept
$
300,000
,
but
refused
.
<END>
<START>
The
state
is
n't
ruling

revoking
Drexel
's

license
.
<END>
<START>
The
state
can
also
bar
Drexel
as
an
investment

.
<END>
<START>
Connecticut
already
has
issued
a
``
notice
of

''
to
revoke
Drexel
's
brokerage
license
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
one
of

states
that
have
met

Mr.
Cohen
and

for

about
investors
'

.
<END>
<START>
``
This
particular
issue
goes
to
the
very
integrity
of
the
capital-formation
market
,
''

.
<END>
<START>

``

<START>
Neither

,

wo

.

.

<END>
<START>
At
Lloyd
's
of
London
,
underwriters
still
scratch
out
policies
using
fountain
pens
and
blotting
paper
.
<END>
<START>
Visitors
are
ushered
into
the
premises
by
red-frocked
doormen
known
as
waiters
,
a
reminder
of
the
insurance
market
's
origins
in
a
coffeehouse
in
17th
century
London
.
<END>
<START>
Such
trappings
suggest
a
glorious
past
but
give
no
hint
of
a
troubled
present
.
<END>
<START>
Lloyd
's
,
once
a
pillar
of
the
world
insurance
market
,
is
being
shaken
to
its
very
foundation
.
<END>
<START>
The
301-year-old
exchange
is
battered
by
enormous
claims
from
a
decade-long
run
of
unprecedented
disasters
,
the
most
recent
of
which
is
last
week
's
earthquake
in
California
's
Bay
Area
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
same
time
,
Lloyd
's
is
besieged
by
disgruntled
investors
and
hamstrung
by
inefficient
but
time-honored
ways
of
conducting
business
.
<END>
<START>
The
exchange
is
gradually
being
squeezed
into
narrow
,
less-profitable
segments
of
the
market
by
less
hidebound
competitors
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
needs
more
discipline
.
<END>
<START>
It
needs
to
sort
itself
out
.
''
<END>
<START>
Most
troublesome
is
the
shrinking
pool
of
``
names
,
''
the
well-heeled
investors
-LRB-
some
of
them
royal
-RRB-
who
,
as
members
of
about
360
syndicates
,
underwrite
policies
.
<END>
<START>
Some
1,750
members
quit
the
exchange
last
year
,
more
than
triple
the
number
of
resignations
in
1987
.
<END>
<START>
Names
are
resigning
at
an
even
faster
pace
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Lackluster
returns
are
one
reason
.
<END>
<START>
In
1985
,
it
was
2.1
%
.
<END>
<START>
Many
of
the
31,329
investors
who
remain
are
beginning
to
question
one
of
the
exchange
's
most
basic
tenets
,
the
concept
of
unlimited
personal
liability
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
may
reap
huge
profits
when
premiums
exceed
claims
,
but
they
are
liable
to
their
last
pound
or
dollar
in
the
event
of
a
catastrophe
.
<END>
<START>
And
catastrophes
are
getting
ever
more
costly
.
<END>
<START>
Lloyd
's
claims
for
the
1988
Piper
Alpha
oil-rig
disaster
in
the
North
Sea
,
for
instance
,
may
reach
$
1
billion
.
<END>
<START>
During
the
five-year
period
ended
1986
,
roughly
80
%
of
the
names
had
money
tied
up
in
money-losing
syndicates
,
according
to
Chatset
consultants
.
<END>
<START>
The
peril
of
unlimited
liability
looms
large
for
a
number
of
them
now
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
have
wished
I
could
die
and
be
out
of
it
--
that
's
how
bad
it
is
,
''
Betty
Atkins
,
a
secretary
from

London
,
says
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Atkins
,
who
underwrote
#
20,000
,
or
about
$
32,000
,
of
insurance
coverage
on
that

,
now
faces
potential
losses
of
roughly
#
70,000
,
or
$
111,000
.
<END>
<START>
Unease
is
widespread
among
exchange
members
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
ca
n't
think
of
any
reason
to
join
Lloyd
's
now
,
''
says
Keith
Whitten
,
a
British
businessman
and
a
Lloyd
's
member
since
1979
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
downside
is
very
considerable
,
and
at
the
moment

upside
is
very
marginal
.
''
<END>
<START>
If
profits
do
n't
improve
,
Mr.
Whitten
says
he
may
quit
the
exchange
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
competition
from
rivals
unencumbered
by
history
is
intensifying
.
<END>
<START>
Lloyd
's
is
being
squeezed
out
of
low-margin
but
more
consistently
profitable
product
lines
such
as
primary
property
and
marine
insurance
.
<END>
<START>
Over
the
past
decade
,
competitors
have
chipped
away
at
the
exchange
's
share
of
the
#
2.5
billion
marine
market
in
London
,
where
half
the
world
's
ships
are
insured
.
<END>
<START>
Lloyd
's
66
%
stake
in
that
market
has
shrunk
to
50
%
in
that
period
,
according
to
an
official
at
the
Institute
of
London
Underwriters
,
a
Lloyd
's
competitor
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
The
official
asked
not
to
be
named
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Lloyd
's
has
endured
decades
of
genteel
decline
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
peak
of
its
power
and
influence
a
century
ago
,
Lloyd
's
dominated
the
insurance
world
with
a
50
%
stake
.
<END>
<START>
It
virtually
dictated
how
ships
were
to
be
built
and
it
monitored
commerce
through
a
unrivaled
intelligence
network
in
ports
around
the
globe
.
<END>
<START>
Today
,
Lloyd
's
share
of
the
world
market
,
excluding
life
insurance
,
is
about
2
%
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Its
stake
is
even
smaller
if
life
insurance
is
included
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Beyond
that
,
many
big
oil
,
chemical
and
airline
companies
are
siphoning
off
big
chunks
of
the
market
by
insuring
themselves
through
``
captive
''
offshore
companies
for
industry-specific
coverage
.
<END>
<START>
Even
Lloyd
's
specialty
--
unusually
risky
ventures
--
is
being
challenged
.
<END>
<START>
Only
10
years
ago
,
for
instance
,
Lloyd
's
was
the
pre-eminent
insurer
of
thoroughbred
horses
.
<END>
<START>
But
since
1981
,
Kirk
Horse
Insurance
Inc.
of
Lexington
,
Ky.
has
grabbed
a
20
%
stake
of
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
Ronald
Kirk
,
president
,
says
Lloyd
's
has
suffered
because
its
structure
does
n't
allow
underwriters
to
deal
directly
with
clients
;
brokers
are
required
intermediaries
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
,
he
asserts
,
Lloyd
's
ca
n't
react
quickly
to
competition
.
<END>
<START>
``
Lloyd
's
has
lost
control
of
the
situation
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
are
n't
controlling
their
destiny
like
they
used
to
.
''
<END>
<START>
Murray
Lawrence
,
Lloyd
's
chairman
,
agrees
the
exchange
faces
big
challenges
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
a
watershed
time
,
and
we
are
trying
to
plot
our
way
ahead
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
have
been
a
great
market
for
inventing
risks
which
other
people
then
take
,
copy
and
cut
rates
.
''
<END>
<START>
Lloyd
's
,
he
says
,
is
cut
off
from
``
the
vast
body
of
premium
down
at
the
bottom
end
which
acts
as
a

influence
''
against
catastrophic
losses
.
<END>
<START>
By
that
,
he
means
low-margin
but
low-risk
products
such
as
certain
types
of
primary
property
insurance
.
<END>
<START>
The
exchange
,
he
says
,
must
find
new
products
and
new
markets
.
<END>
<START>
That
wo
n't
be
an
easy
task
.
<END>
<START>
Tradition
is
dictator
at
Lloyd
's
.
<END>
<START>
Three
years
ago
,
the
exchange
took
up
residence
in
a

tower
of
steel
and
glass
--
evocative
of
the
kind

that
Britain
's

Charles
has
denounced
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Some
exchange
wags
call
the
building
``
the
oil
rig
.
''
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
But
along
with
such
treasured
artifacts
as
Lord
Nelson
's
spyglass
,
Lloyd
's
also
brought
its
outmoded
ways
of
doing
business
.
<END>
<START>
The
Lloyd
's
market
actively
underwrites
insurance
just
4
1/2
hours
a
day
,
brokers
say
.
<END>
<START>
Underwriting
does
n't
get
under
way
until
after
morning
tea
at
10
a.m
.
<END>
<START>
A
two-hour
lunch
break
follows
.
<END>
<START>
Things
wind
down
at
about
4:30
p.m.
,
just
in
time
for
afternoon
tea
.
<END>
<START>
Lloyd
's
vast
trading
hall
houses
a
warren
of
well-polished
desks
.
<END>
<START>
The
hall
's
few
computers
are
used
mostly
to
send
messages
.
<END>
<START>
Sandwiched
between
desks
,
underwriters
sit
on
benches
surrounded
by
stacks
of
policies
.
<END>
<START>
Brokers
clutching
thick
folders
stand
in
lines
,
waiting
their
turn
to
speak
to
the
underwriters
.
<END>
<START>
A
broker
may
have
to
approach
as
many
as
20
underwriters
who
insure
the
endeavors
on
behalf
of
the
syndicates
.
<END>
<START>
It
could
take
six
months
for
a
claim
to
be
paid
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
system
,
''
says
Nicholas
Samengo-Turner
,
a
Lloyd
's
broker
who
left
the
exchange
in
1985
,
``
is
so
ludicrously
unprofessional
it
drives
you
mad
.
''
<END>
<START>
Some
maintain
underwriters
also
have
been
inept
.
<END>
<START>
``
How
unprofessional
we
must
have
appeared
to
the
outside
world
--
how
incompetent
at
risk
assessment
and
evaluation
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Lloyd
's
officials
decline
to
comment
on
the
matter
.
<END>
<START>
More
recently
,
property
rates
have
increased
.
<END>
<START>
Many
at
Lloyd
's
expect
the
San
Francisco
earthquake
will
cause
the
industry
to
boost
rates
even
further
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
will
be
years
before
it
is
clear
whether
higher
rates
will
offset
the
payouts
for
such
disasters
.
<END>
<START>
Lloyd
's
only
recently
reported
its
financial
results
for
1986
.
<END>
<START>
That
year
,
it
posted
record
pretax
profit
of
#
650
million
,
a
gain
it
attributes
to
higher
rates
and
fewer
claims
.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Lawrence
says
reported
profit
will
be
down
in
1987
,
1988
and
1989
,
though
he
declines
to
specify
how

will
be
.
<END>
<START>
Lloyd
's
says
the
departures
of
names
is
n't
likely
to
hurt
its
underwriting
capacity
,
currently
about
#
11
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lawrence
says
the
drain
of
funds
has
been
offset
by
an
increase
in
investments
by
the
remaining
names
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
the
exchange
has
been
trying
to
lower
costs
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
It
recently
cut
its
work
force
by
9
%
,
or
213
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
But
Lloyd
's
is
hampered
in
its
efforts
to
overhaul
operations
by
its
reluctance
to
embrace
modern
technology
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Wetherell
,
the
underwriter
,
reckons
half
of
his
business
could
be
transacted
by
computer
,
cutting
costs
at
least
10
%
.
<END>
<START>
Though
Lloyd
's
has
talked
for
years
about
computerizing
underwriting
transactions
,
the
effort
has
n't
gotten
very
far
.
<END>
<START>
Competition
among
underwriters
and
brokers
makes
them
loath
to
centralize
price
and
policy
information
.
<END>
<START>
Both
groups
cling
to
traditional
face-to-face
dealings
,
even
for
routine
policies
.
<END>
<START>
Lloyd
's
overblown
bureaucracy
also
hampers
efforts
to
update
marketing
strategies
.
<END>
<START>
Some
underwriters
have
been
pressing
for
years
to
tap
the
low-margin
business
by
selling
some
policies
directly
to
consumers
.
<END>
<START>
Lloyd
's
presently
sells
only
auto
insurance
directly
to
the
public
,
and
such
policies
are
sold
only
in
limited
markets
such
as
the
U.K.
and
Canada
.
<END>
<START>
But
such
changes
must
be
cleared
by
four

and

underwriters
,

and

before

.
<END>
<START>
The

to
sell
directly
to
the
public
remains

in

.
<END>
<START>
Lloyd
's
is
moving
forward
on
some

,
though
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lawrence
says
the
exchange
is
updating
some

to
make

payments
on
claims
.
<END>
<START>
By
next
year
,
all
underwriters
will
be
linked
to
a
communications
network
that
could
reduce
paper
work
on
claims
.

<START>
Japan
's
Daiwa
Securities
Co.
named
Masahiro
Dozen
president
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Dozen
succeeds
Sadakane
Doi
,
who
will
become
vice
chairman
.
<END>
<START>
Yoshitoki
Chino
retains
his
title
of
chairman
of
Daiwa
,
Japan
's
second-largest
securities
firm
.
<END>
<START>
In
Japanese
firms
,
the
president
usually
is
in
charge
of
day-to-day
operations
,
while
the
chairman
's
role
is
more
a
ceremonial
one
.
<END>
<START>
The
title
of
chief
executive
officer
is
n't
used
.
<END>
<START>
While
people
within
Daiwa
,
particularly
internationalists
,
expected
that
Mr.
Dozen
,
52
,
would
eventually
become
Daiwa
's
president
,
the
speed
of
his
promotion
surprised
many
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
only
earlier
this
year
that
the
jovial
,
easygoing
executive
--
he
likes
to
joke
with
Americans
about
how
his
name
is
synonymous
with
twelve
--
was
appointed
deputy
president
.
<END>
<START>
Daiwa
is
one
of
the
world
's
largest
securities
firms
.
<END>
<START>
As
of
March
31
,
the
Daiwa
group
had
shareholder
equity
of
801.21
billion
yen
-LRB-
$
5.64
billion
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
Both
figures
were
record
highs
.
<END>
<START>
American
institutional
investors
have
never
had
a
large
appetite
for
Japanese
equities
.
<END>
<START>
And
while
the
Japanese
have
stepped
up
their
purchases
of
U.S.
shares
in
the
past
several
months
,
they
have
shown
themselves
in
the
past
to
be
fickle
investors
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
same
time
,
Daiwa
and
its
brethren
have
faced
stiff
competition
from
well-entrenched
American
competitors
that
have
prevented
them
from
building
strong
links
to
U.S.
corporations
and
institutional
investors
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Dozen
knows
these
problems
firsthand
.
<END>
<START>
When
he
arrived
in
the
U.S.
in
1969
--
the
start
of
an
eight-year
tour
--
he
tried
selling
Japanese
yen-denominated
bonds
to
U.S.
investors
.
<END>
<START>
``
He
made
desperate
efforts
,
using
the
yellow
pages
from
beginning
to
end
,
''
said
Koji
Yoneyama
,
president
of
Daiwa
's
U.S.
unit
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
not
a
single
piece
of
paper
was
sold
.
''
<END>
<START>
By
his
own
account
,
Mr.
Dozen
did
n't
do
much
better
with
U.S.
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
could
n't
sell
any
.
<END>
<START>
``
Japanese
stock
salesmen
selling
American
bonds
?
<END>
<START>
Maybe
it
's
crazy
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Dozen
even
related
the
indignity
suffered
when
he
and
two
colleagues
went
on
an
overnight
fishing
expedition
off
the
New
Jersey
shore
and
caught
nothing
.
<END>
<START>
Upon
returning
to
New
York
,
``
Exhausted
,
I
got
into
a
taxicab
,
and
the
woman
driver
said
:
`
Americans
make
better
fishermen
,
'
''
he
recalled
.
<END>
<START>
Undaunted
,
Mr.
Dozen
said
that
Daiwa
's
goal
is
to
build
``
a
high-technology
oriented
international
organization
with
maybe
some
Japanese
flavor
to
it
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
said
that
he
was
particularly
interested
in
his
firm
gaining
expertise
in
futures
,
options
,
mortgaged-backed
securities
,
computerized
trading
and
investment
systems
as
well
as
mergers
and
acquisitions
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Dozen
said
Daiwa
's
strengths
were
its
large
capital
base
,
its
influential
position
in
the
Tokyo
market
and
its
links
to
Japanese
corporations
and
institutional
investors
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Dozen
joined
Daiwa
upon
his
graduation
from
Kyoto
University
in
1959
.
<END>
<START>
Like
many
young
recruits
in
Japanese
securities
firms
,
he
began
his
career
peddling
stock
to
individual
investors
.
<END>
<START>
In
his
climb
to
the
top
,
Mr.
Dozen
also
headed
the
company
's
stock-exchange
division
,
its
fixed-income
units
and
its
international
operations
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
Mr.
Dozen
's
experience
as
a
salesman
that
enabled
him
to
gain
the
political
support
--
particularly
from
the
retail
sales
force
--
to
accede
to
the
presidency
.
<END>
<START>
Commission
income
from
domestic
stock
and
bond
sales
accounts
form
a
large
portion
of
Japanese
securities
companies
'
earnings
.
<END>
<START>
And
anybody
who
lacked
the
backing
of
the
retail
sales
force
``
would
be
fragile
,
''
said
a
Daiwa

.
<END>
<START>
If
Mr.
Dozen
has
a
weakness
,
it
may
be
his
golf
game
.
<END>
<START>
``
He
digs
in
the
sand
instead
of
hitting
the
ball
,
like
a
farmer
,
''
said
Mr.
Yoneyama
.
<END>
<START>
Inco
Ltd.
posted
a
35
%
decline
in
third-quarter
net

,
a

that
was
in

with

'

.
<END>
<START>
The

25

20

.
<END>
<START>
Inco

after

.
<END>
<START>

.

closed

,

,

.

3
.
<END>
<START>
Sales

8.2

.
<END>
<START>

.

,

1.7
million
of

since

.
<END>
<START>
UAL
Corp.
's
board
quashed
any
prospects
for
an
immediate
revival
of
a
labor-management
buy-out
,
saying
United
Airlines
'
parent
should
remain
independent
for
now
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
UAL
's
chairman
,
Stephen
M.
Wolf
,
pulled
out
of
the
buy-out
effort
to
focus
on
running
the
company
.
<END>
<START>
The
effort
to
create
the
nation
's
largest

company
began
unraveling
Oct.
13
when
the

group
was

for

$
300-a-share
,
$
6.79
billion

.
<END>
<START>
Just

week
it
suffered
another

when
British
Airways
PLC
,
the
largest
equity
investor
in
the
labor-management
bid
,
withdrew
its
support
.
<END>
<START>
Takeover
stock
traders
,
focusing
on
the
company
's
intention
to
stay
independent
,
took
the
announcement
as
bad
news
.
<END>
<START>
Twelve
of
UAL
's
outside

met
at

five-hour

yesterday
in
Chicago
to
consider
an
informal

from
the

group
for
a

.
<END>
<START>
But
the
board
said
it
was

for

.
<END>
<START>
That

,

at
between
$
225
and
$
240

,
would
have
transferred
majority

to

while

some
stock
in
public
hands
.
<END>
<START>
The

group
had
no
firm

for

.
<END>
<START>
And
,
with
no
other

on

,
the
board
apparently

no
pressure
to
act
on

.
<END>
<START>
But

was

that
for

being
,

board
wants

company
to
return
to

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Wolf
urged
all

to
``
now

''
to

the
airline
.
<END>
<START>
He

to
``
make
every
effort
to
nurture
...
a
constructive
new
relationship
that
has
been
forged
with

employee
groups
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Wolf
faces
a

task
in
pulling
the
company
back
together
again
.
<END>
<START>
Labor
problems
top
the
list
.
<END>
<START>
For
a
brief
time
,
the
buy-out
effort
seemed
to
solve
his
problems
with
United
's
pilot
union
.
<END>
<START>
That

was

.
<END>
<START>
As

``

,

<END>
<START>
It

.
<END>
<START>
The

also

's

.
<END>
<START>
The

.
<END>
<START>

Wolf
,

.
<END>
<START>

Wolf

in

.
<END>
<START>
They

$
15

for

1

9

at

.
<END>
<START>
His

is
also
on

line
in

.
<END>
<START>
Until
the
collapse
of

,

Wolf

's

.
<END>
<START>
The

's

leave

some

700

and

.
<END>
<START>
It

.
<END>
<START>

<END>
<START>
Amerada
Hess
<END>
<START>
Revenue
climbed
28
%
,
to
$
1.18
billion
from
$
925
million
.
<END>
<START>
Profits
improved
across
Hess
's
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
Refining
and
marketing
earnings
climbed
to
$
33.3
million
from
$
12.9
million
,
and
exploration
and
production
earnings
rose
to
$
37.1
million
from
$
17.9
million
.
<END>
<START>
Hess
's
earnings
were
up
despite
a
$
30
million
charge
to
cover
the
cost
of
maintaining
operations
after
Hurricane
Hugo
heavily
damaged
the
company
's
refinery
at
St.
Croix
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
widely
known
within
industry
circles
that
Hess
had
to
buy
oil
products
in
the
high-priced
spot
markets
to
continue
supplying
its
customers
.
<END>
<START>
Hess
declined
to
comment
.
<END>
<START>
Phillips
Petroleum
<END>
<START>
Phillips
Petroleum
's
third-quarter
earnings
slid
60
%
,
to
$
87
million
,
or
36
cents
a
share
,
from
$
215
million
,
or
89
cents
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
rose
6.9
%
,
to
$
3.1
billion
from
$
2.9
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Shrinking
profit
margins
in
chemical
and
refining
and
marketing
sectors
accounted
for
most
of
the
decline
,
said
Chairman
C.J.
Silas
in
a
statement
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
higher
oil
prices
,
exploration
and
production
profits
were
off
because
of
foreign-currency
losses
and
some
construction
costs
incurred
in
one
of
Phillips
'
North
Sea
oil
fields
.
<END>
<START>
A
year
ago
,
results
were
buoyed
by
a
$
20
million
after-tax
gain
from
an
asset
sale
.
<END>
<START>
Occidental
Petroleum
<END>
<START>
The
latest
quarter
included
an
after-tax
gain
of
$
71
million
from
non-recurring
items
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
dropped
2
%
,
to
$
4.8
billion
from
$
4.9
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Both

included

of
$
3
million
for

of

.
<END>
<START>
Occidental

and
gas

fell
to
$
17
million
from
$
20
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
latest
period
includes

of
$
32

in

credits
from
the
sale
of

,

for

in
the
oil
and
gas

.

<START>
Chemical

10

,

of

.

<END>
<START>

20

3.7

.

's

from

49.9

,

.

<START>
Imo
Industries
Inc.
--
$
150
million
of

2001
,

to

12
%
.
<END>
<START>
The

will
be
sold
through
Morgan
Stanley
&
Co
.
<END>
<START>
Other

were

.
<END>
<START>

due
1991-2000
,
2009
,

,

and

,

.
<END>
<START>

bonds
are

to
yield
from
6.15
%
in
1991
to
7.10
%
in
2000
.
<END>
<START>

about

100

7
%

2009
,

to
yield
7.30
%
,

.
<END>
<START>

,

.

to

to

from
7
%
in
2001

7.10
%

.

.

to

7.10
%
in
1999
.
<END>
<START>
The
bonds
are
rated
double-A
by

's
and

by

.
<END>
<START>

in

that
may

.

.

<START>

said

.

.

.
<END>
<START>
Investors
dumped
stocks
of
big
companies
whose
earnings
fluctuate
with
the
economy
.
<END>
<START>
Many
of
those
``
cyclical
''
issues
are
in
the
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
,
which
fell
26.23
to
2662.91
.
<END>
<START>
Declining
issues
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
outpaced
advancers
,
1,012
to
501
.
<END>
<START>
Recession
fears
are
springing
up
again
among
investors
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
say
that
the
selling
of
cyclical
stocks
yesterday
will
be
followed
by
a
sell-off
in
shares
of
companies
with
big
debt
loads
on
their
balance
sheets
.
<END>
<START>
In
an
economic
slowdown
,
heavy
debt
loads
reduce
the
flexibility
of
companies
because
cash
that
would
normally
be
used
to
keep
the
company
buoyant
must
be
diverted
to
interest
payments
.
<END>
<START>
On
the
other
hand
,
investors
beat
a
clear
path
yesterday
to
blue-chip
issues
with
proven
earnings
growth
records
.
<END>
<START>
Among
the
30
Dow
industrials
,
they
bought
McDonald
's
,
Coca-Cola
Co.
and
Procter
&
Gamble
and
sold
Aluminum
Co.
of
America
.
<END>
<START>
In
another
sign
of
slowdown
fears
,
investors
dumped
technology
shares
.
<END>
<START>
Many
money
managers
are
bracing
for
a
decline
in
stocks
of
companies
with
big
debt
loads
on
their
balance
sheets
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
junk
bond
market
is
being
taken
apart
''
because
of
recession
fears
,
said
J.
David
Mills
,
senior
vice
president
at
Boston
Company
Advisers
.
<END>
<START>
``
Under
this
scrutiny
,
the
first
thing
you
do
is
sell
your
cyclical
stocks
and
the
second
thing
you
do
is
sell
your

companies
.
''
<END>
<START>
In
fact
,
much
of
the
buying
in
blue
chips
yesterday
was
a
pursuit
of
companies
with
lower
debt
levels
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're

increasing

,
''

.

,

Philip

.

.

72
1/8
;

1

31
3/8
,

.

<START>

,

no

's

.

``

,
''
Mr.

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Fernandez
does
n't

in
New

until

,
but

's

waters
.
<END>
<START>
He
's
attacked
the
concept
of
``
building
tenure
,
''
one

in
American

.
<END>
<START>
It

.
<END>
<START>
Once

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>
He

.
<END>
<START>
Naturally
,

'

,

.

<START>

,

.

<START>

.

<START>

.

<START>

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>
Ingersoll

$
275

from
Goodson
Newspaper
Group
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
Goodson

.

<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.

this
one
of
France
's
largest-ever
attempted
takeovers
.
<END>
<START>
The
cost
of
buying
the
additional
48
%
stake
would
be
10.95
billion
francs
-LRB-
$
1.74
billion
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
The
move
would
greatly
boost
Paribas
's
stake
in
the
insurance
,
transport
and
food
businesses
,
where
Navigation
Mixte
is
strong
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
would
make
Paribas
a
major
French
ally
of
West
Germany
's
Allianz
AG
insurance
group
.
<END>
<START>
Allianz
holds
a
50
%
stake
in
Navigation
Mixte
's
insurance
interests
,
acquired
three
weeks
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Those
include
Rhin
et
Moselle
Vie
and
Via
Assurances
.
<END>
<START>
Long
considered
a
potential
takeover
target
,
Navigation
Mixte
had
hoped
Allianz
would
help
protect
it
from
raiders
.
<END>
<START>
That
idea
may
have
backfired
.
<END>
<START>
Paribas
is
Allianz
's
main
French
bank
,
and
the
Munich-based
group
said
it
intends
to
stay
neutral
.
<END>
<START>
Navigation
Mixte
said
it
would
n't
have
any
comment
until
its
board
meets
Wednesday
.
<END>
<START>
But
Navigation
Mixte
is
loosely
held
and
hard
to
defend
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
defensive
options
are
limited
,
''
says
Philippe
Braye
,
a
partner
in
portfolio
management
concern
France
Finance
Quatre
.
<END>
<START>
``
Who
would
bid
against
Paribas
?
''
<END>
<START>
If
the
Paribas
bid
succeeds
,
it
will
be
the
second
time
in
two
months
a
big
French
investment
banking
group
has
snapped
up
an
insurance
group
.
<END>
<START>
That
complex
bid
was
billed
as
France
's
largest
takeover
ever
-LRB-
this
one
is
slightly
smaller
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
Suez
had
just
finished
winning
an
even
larger
battle
last
year
for
control
of
Societe
Generale
de
Belgique
.
<END>
<START>
Paribas
officials
,
once
considered
France
's
toughest
bankers
,
felt
abashed
at
Suez
's
success
and
its
rapid
growth
.
<END>
<START>
Although
Paribas
denies
it
,
analysts
say
the
new
bid
in
part
simply
reflects
the
continuing
rivalry
between
France
's
two
largest
investment
banking
groups
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
reflects
the
broader
pressure
on
companies
in
Europe
to
keep
up
as
the
European
Community
prepares
to
reduce
internal
trade
barriers
by
1992
.
<END>
<START>
Although
Paribas
Chairman
Michel
Francois-Poncet
would
n't
rule
out
eventually
selling
all
of
Navigation
Mixte
's
insurance
operations
to
Allianz
,
he
stressed
the
potential
for
the
two
groups
instead
to
cooperate
.
<END>
<START>
He
also
told
reporters
the
acquisition
would
give
Paribas
fresh
diversity
,
bringing
it
properties
in
food
and
transport
where
it
has
been
weak
.
<END>
<START>
Navigation
Mixte
has
investments
in
a
sugar
company
,
a
food
and
canning
concern
,
a
bakery
and
bus
and
trucking
firms
,
among
others
.
<END>
<START>
And
Navigation
Mixte
has
a
huge
hidden
attraction
.
<END>
<START>
Payment
by
Allianz
for
the
insurance
interests
it
has
just
bought
will
help
swell
the
French
concern
's
treasury
to
an
estimated
11
billion
francs
.
<END>
<START>
Alternatively
,
it
said
it
would
offer
three
Paribas
shares
,
themselves
eligible
for
dividends
as
of
next
Jan.
1
,
for
one
Navigation
Mixte
share
.
<END>
<START>
Paribas
shares
closed
down
30
francs
at
610
francs
,
and
Navigation
Mixte
shares
were
suspended
at
1,800
francs
pending
the
outcome
of
the
bid
.
<END>
<START>
Paribas
said
it
would
publish
details
of
its
bid
once
authorities
clear
it
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
one
of
the
first
bids
under
new
takeover
rules
aimed
at
encouraging
open
bids
instead
of
gradual
accumulation
of
large
stakes
.
<END>
<START>
Some
financial
sources
said
privately
that
Paribas
blundered
in
failing
to
move
sooner
for
the
insurance
and
industrial
group
,
bidding
only
after
speculation
had
pushed
up
the
price
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Francois-Poncet
responded
that
his
group
initially
intended
to
take
only
a
minority
stake
,
striking
an
alliance
with
current
management
.
<END>
<START>
When
notoriously
independent-minded
Navigation
Mixte
Chairman
Marc
Fournier
rejected
Paribas
's
offer
and
began
buying
Paribas
shares
in
retaliation
,
Mr.
Francois-Poncet
said
,
he
felt
obliged
to
bid
for
control
.
<END>
<START>
He
told
reporters
he
had
information
that
Mr.
Fournier
was
preparing
to
buy
as
much
as
20
%
of
Paribas
,
up
from
less
than
5
%
currently
.
<END>
<START>
A
bid
against
Paribas
could
n't
be
ruled
out
.
<END>
<START>
France
's
second-largest
government-owned
insurance
company
,
Assurances
Generales
de
France
,
has
been
building
its
own
Navigation
Mixte
stake
,
currently
thought
to
be
between
8
%
and
10
%
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts

do
n't
think
it
is
contemplating
a
takeover
,
however
,
and
its
officials
could
n't

.
<END>
<START>
Crude
oil
futures
prices
fell
further
as
analysts
and
traders
said
OPEC
oil
producers
are
n't
putting
the
brakes
on
output
ahead
of
the
traditionally
weak
first
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
In
trading
on
the
New
York
Mercantile
Exchange
,
the
U.S.
benchmark
West
Texas
Intermediate
crude
fell
39
cents
a
barrel
to
$
19.76
for
December
delivery
.
<END>
<START>
Petroleum
products
prices
also
declined
.
<END>
<START>
That
level
of
production
did
n't
take
its
toll
on
futures
prices
for
the
fourth
quarter
,
when
demand
is
traditionally
strong
.
<END>
<START>
But
because
first-quarter
demand
is
normally
the
weakest
of
the
year
,
several
market
participants
say
,
OPEC
production
will
have
to
decline
to
keep
prices
from
eroding
further
.
<END>
<START>
The
group
plans
to
meet
in
a
month
to
discuss
production
strategy
for
early
1990
.
<END>
<START>
With
prices
already
headed
lower
,
news
of
a
series
of

at
a
major
Phillips
Petroleum
Co.
chemical
facility
on
the
Houston
Ship
Channel
also
was
bearish
for

.
<END>
<START>
Even
though
such

use
a
relatively
small

of

,

say
,
now
the

wo
n't
need
any
,
at

.
<END>
<START>
The

makes

,

and
other

products
.
<END>
<START>
A

said

began
when
a

blew
out
.
<END>
<START>
Dozens

were

,

said
.
<END>
<START>
There
was
no

of

from

company
.
<END>
<START>
Some

say

now
will

.
<END>
<START>
For

,

.
<END>
<START>
``
Our

is

now
that

've

$
20
,
''

.
<END>
<START>
In
other
