markets
yesterday
:
<END>
<START>
COPPER
:
<END>
<START>
The
selling
that
started
on
Friday
continued
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
The
December
contract
fell
3.85
cents
a
pound
to
$
1.1960
.
<END>
<START>
London
Metal
Exchange
warehouse
stocks
were
down
only
4,800
metric
tons
for
the
week
to
84,500
tons
;
expectations
late
last
week
were
a
drop
of
10,000
to
15,000
tons
.
<END>
<START>
Fund
selling
also
picked
up
at
that
point
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
Bernard
Savaiko
,
senior
commodity
analyst
at
PaineWebber
,
the
only
stability
to
the
market
came
when
short
sellers
periodically
moved
in
to
cover
their
positions
by
buying
contracts
.
<END>
<START>
This
activity
produced
small
rallies
,
which
in
turn
attracted
new
short
selling
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Savaiko
noted
that
copper
had
a
steep
fall
in
spite
of
a
weak
dollar
,
which
would
normally
support
the
U.S.
copper
market
.
<END>
<START>
Such
support
usually
comes
from
arbitragers
who
use
a
strong
British
pound
to
buy
copper
in
New
York
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
sell-off
would
probably
have
been
worse
if
the
dollar
had
been
strong
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Copper
has
been
stuck
in
a
trading
range
of
$
1.19
to
$
1.34
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Savaiko
believes
that
if
copper
falls
below
the
bottom
of
this
range
the
next
significant
support
level
will
be
about
$
1.04
.
<END>
<START>
PRECIOUS
METALS
:
<END>
<START>
January
platinum
closed
down
$
2.80
an
ounce
at
$
486.30
,
nearly
$
4
above
its
low
for
the
day
.
<END>
<START>
December
palladium
was
off
$
1.55
an
ounce
at
$
137.20
.
<END>
<START>
Platinum
is
believed
to
have
good
support
around
$
480
and
palladium
at
around
$
130
.
<END>
<START>
Some
traders
were
thought
to
be
waiting
for
the
auto
sales
report
,
which
will
be
released
today
.
<END>
<START>
Such
sales
are
watched
closely
by
platinum
and
palladium
traders
because
both
metals
are
used
in
automobile
catalytic
converters
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Savaiko
theorized
that
the
news
on
cold
fusion
did
n't
affect
the
market
yesterday
because
many
traders
have
already
been
badly
burnt
by
such
stories
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
the
traders
are
demanding
a
higher
level
of
proof
before
they
will
buy
palladium
again
.
<END>
<START>
Also
weighing
on
both
metals
'
prices
is
the
role
of
the
chief
supplier
,
the
Soviet
Union
.
<END>
<START>
Many
analysts
believe
that
the
Soviets
'
thirst
for
dollars
this
year
to
buy
grain
and
other
Western
commodities
and
goods
will
bring
them
to
the
market
whenever
prices
rally
very
much
.
<END>
<START>
GRAINS
AND
SOYBEANS
:
<END>
<START>
Prices
closed
mixed
as
contracts
reacted
to
largely
offsetting
bullish
and
bearish
news
.
<END>
<START>
Supporting
prices
was
the
announcement
late
Friday
of
additional
grain
sales
to
the
Soviet
Union
.
<END>
<START>
But
acting
as
a
drag
on
prices
was
the
improved
harvest
weather
over
the
weekend
and
the
prospect
for
continued
fair
weather
this
week
over
much
of
the
Farm
Belt
.
<END>
<START>
Strong
farmer
selling
over
the
weekend
also
weighed
on
prices
.
<END>
<START>
SUGAR
:
<END>
<START>
World
prices
tumbled
,
mostly
from
their
own
weight
,
according
to
analysts
.
<END>
<START>
The
March
contract
ended
at
13.79
cents
a
pound
,
down
0.37
cent
.
<END>
<START>
But
with
no
reports
of
either
country
actually
entering
the
market
,
analysts
said
,
futures
prices
became
vulnerable
.
<END>
<START>
COCOA
:
<END>
<START>
Futures
rallied
modestly
.
<END>
<START>
The
December
contract
rose
$
33
a
metric
ton
to
$
1,027
,
near
its
high
for
the
day
.
<END>
<START>
Gill
&
Duffus
Ltd.
,
a
British
cocoa-trading
house
,
estimated
that
the
1989-90
world
cocoa
surplus
would
be
231,000
tons
,
down
from
314,000
tons
for
the
previous
year
.
<END>
<START>
Market
technicians
were
encouraged
by
the
price
patterns
,
which
in
the
past
have
preceded
sharp
rallies
.
<END>
<START>
Recent
prices
for
cocoa
have
been
near
levels
last
seen
in
the
mid-1970s
.
<END>
<START>
At
such
prices
,
according
to
Mr.
Savaiko
,
bargain
hunting
and
short-covering
--
buying
back
of
contracts
previously
sold
--
by
speculators
is
n't
uncommon
.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Savaiko
expects
stepped-up
producer
selling
at
around
the
$
1,040
to
$
1,050
level
.
<END>
<START>
He
also
noted
that
a
strong
sterling
market
yesterday
might
have
helped
cocoa
in
New
York
as
arbitragers
took
advantage
of
the
currency
move
.
<END>
<START>
Sandra
Kaul
,
research
analyst
at
Shearson
Lehman
Hutton
,
said
the
market
pushed
higher
mainly
in
anticipation
of
a
late
harvest
in
the
Ivory
Coast
,
a
major
cocoa
producer
.
<END>
<START>
Rockwell
International
Corp.
bought
out
Ikegai
Corp.
's
interest
in
Ikegai-Goss
,
a
joint
venture
of
the
two
companies
based
in
Tokyo
.
<END>
<START>
The
price
was
3.6
billion
yen
-LRB-
$
25
million
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
The
agreement
provides
that
Ikegai
Corp.
will
remain
a
supplier
to
Ikegai-Goss
,
which
makes
printing
presses
for
the
newspaper
industry
.
<END>
<START>
The
purchase
was
made
by
Rockwell
Graphic
Systems
,
a
Chicago
subsidiary
of
the
El
Segundo
,
Calif.
,
concern
.
<END>
<START>
Ikegai-Goss
,
which
has
about
200
employees
,
is
among
the
industry
leaders
in
keyless
inking
technology
,
which
reduces
time
and
materials
waste
when
preparing
a
press
for
printing
.
<END>
<START>
The
bond
market
,
which
sometimes
thrives
on
bad
news
,
cheered
yesterday
's
stock
market
sell-off
and
perceptions
that
the
economy
is
growing
weaker
.
<END>
<START>
Early
in
the
day
,
bonds
rose
modestly
on
economists
'
forecasts
that
this
week
's
slate
of
economic
data
will
portray
an
economy
headed
for
trouble
.
<END>
<START>
Such
news
is
good
for
bonds
because
economic
weakness
sometimes
causes
the
Federal
Reserve
to
lower
interest
rates
in
an
effort
to
stimulate
the
economy
and
stave
off
a
recession
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
today
the
Department
of
Commerce
is
scheduled
to
release
the
September
durable
goods
report
.
<END>
<START>
The
consensus
forecast
of
14
economists
surveyed
by
Dow
Jones
Capital
Markets
Report
is
for
a
1.2
%
drop
in
September
orders
.
<END>
<START>
That
would
follow
a
3.9
%
advance
in
August
.
<END>
<START>
Bonds
received
a
bigger
boost
later
in
the
day
when
stock
prices
moved
broadly
lower
.
<END>
<START>
The
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
fell
26.23
points
to
2662.91
.
<END>
<START>
``
Bond
investors
have
been
watching
stocks
closely
,
''
said
Joel
Marver
,
chief
fixed-income
analyst
at
Technical
Data
Global
Markets
Group
.
<END>
<START>
``
When
you
get
a
big
sell-off
in
equities
,
money
starts
to
shift
into
bonds
,
''
which
are
considered
safer
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Municipals
ended
mixed
,
while
mortgage-backed
and
investment-grade
corporate
bonds
rose
.
<END>
<START>
Prices
of
high-yield
,
high-risk
corporate
securities
ended
unchanged
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
Treasury
market
,

expect
bond
prices
to
trade
in
narrow
ranges
this
week
as
the
market
takes
in
positive
and

.
<END>
<START>
``

the
other
hand
,
we
have
economic
news
that
is
-LCB-
expected

be
-RCB-

.
<END>
<START>
We
will
go
back
and

with

,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Today
,
the
Treasury
will
sell
$
10
billion
of
new
two-year
notes
.
<END>
<START>
So
far
,
money

and
other

have

in
the
Refcorp
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
have
mixed
views
about
the
two-year
note
auction
.
<END>
<START>
The
division
of
auto
maker
Ford
Motor
Co.
made
its
debut
in
the
asset-backed
securities
market
with
the
second-largest
issue
in
the
market
's
four-year
history
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
offered
securities
backed
by
automobile
loans
through
an
underwriting
group
headed
by
First
Boston
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
The
issue
yields
8.90
%
and
carries
a
guarantee
covering
9
%
of
the
deal
from
the
company
.
<END>
<START>
First
Boston
sweetened
the
terms
from
the
original
yield
estimate
in
an
apparent
effort
to
place
the
huge
offering
.
<END>
<START>
The
issue
was
offered
at
a
yield
nearly
one
percentage
point
above
the
yield
on
two-year
Treasurys
.
<END>
<START>
The
only
asset-backed
deal
larger
than
Ford
's
was
a
$
4
billion
offering
by
General
Motors
Acceptance
Corp.
in
1986
.
<END>
<START>
Treasury
Securities
<END>
<START>
Treasury
bonds
were
1/8
to
1/2
point
higher
yesterday
in
light
trading
.
<END>
<START>
The
benchmark
30-year
bond
ended
at
a
price
of
102
3/32
,
compared
with
101
17/32
Friday
.
<END>
<START>
The
latest
10-year
notes
were
quoted
late
at
100
17/32
to
yield
7.90
%
,
compared
with
100
3/32
to
yield
7.97
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
latest
two-year
notes
were
quoted
late
at
100
28/32
to
yield
7.84
%
.
<END>
<START>
Short-term
rates
rose
yesterday
at
the
government
's
weekly
Treasury
bill
auction
,
compared
with
the
previous
bill
sale
.
<END>
<START>
The
Treasury
sold
$
7.81
billion
of
three-month
bills
with
an
average
discount
rate
of
7.52
%
,
the
highest
since
the
average
of
7.63
%
at
the
auction
on
Oct.
10
.
<END>
<START>
The
$
7.81
billion
of
six-month
Treasury
bills
were
sold
with
an
average
discount
rate
of
7.50
%
,
the
highest
since
the
average
of
7.60
%
at
the
Oct.
10
auction
.
<END>
<START>
The
rates
were
up
from
last
week
's
auction
,
when
they
were
7.37
%
and
7.42
%
,
respectively
.
<END>
<START>
Here
are
auction
details
:
<END>
<START>
Rates
are
determined
by
the
difference
between
the
purchase
price
and
face
value
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
,
higher
bidding
narrows
the
investor
's
return
while
lower
bidding
widens
it
.
<END>
<START>
The
percentage
rates
are
calculated
on
a
360-day
year
,
while
the
coupon-equivalent
yield
is
based
on
a
365-day
year
.
<END>
<START>
Both
issues
are
dated
Oct.
26
.
<END>
<START>
The
13-week
bills
mature
Jan.
25
,
1990
,
and
the
26-week
bills
mature
April
26
,
1990
.
<END>
<START>
Corporate
Issues
<END>
<START>
Investment-grade
corporates
closed
about
1/4
point
higher
in
quiet
trading
.
<END>
<START>
Peter
Karches
,

at
underwriter
Morgan
Stanley
&

,

the
issue
was

.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's

,
and
if
you
have
a
good
,
strong
credit
,
people
have
an

for
it
,
''
he

.
<END>
<START>
Morgan
Stanley
is
expected
to
price
another
junk
bond
deal
,
$
350
million
of
senior
subordinated

by
Continental
Cablevision
Inc.
,
next

.
<END>
<START>
In
light
of
the
recent

in
the
high-yield
market
,

bond
analysts
and
traders
expect
other
high-yield
deals
to
be

or

before
they
are

to

.
<END>
<START>
In
the
case
of
Beatrice
,
Salomon
Brothers
Inc.
is
considering
restructuring
the
reset
mechanism
on
the
$
200
million
portion
of
the
offering
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
originally
contemplated
terms
of
the
offering
,
the
notes
would
have
been
reset
annually
at
a
fixed
spread
above
Treasurys
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
new
plan
being
considered
,
the
notes
would
reset
annually
at
a
rate
to
maintain
a
market
value
of
101
.
<END>
<START>
Price
talk
calls
for
the
reset
notes
to
be
priced
at
a
yield
of
between
13
1/4
%
and
13
1/2
%
.
<END>

<START>

<END>
<START>
Texas
is
big

,

.
<END>
<START>
Jutting

the
Blackjack
Peninsula
-LRB-
after
the
oak
,

-RRB-

.

<START>

,

<START>
Last

.

<START>

Manville
,

<START>

<START>

's

,

<START>

.

<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

--

.
<END>
<START>

<START>
Yesterday

``

''

<START>

<START>

,

.

<START>
The

in
the

.

<START>

,

,

<START>
In

on

,

Pacific
closed
at
$
20.625
,
down
25

.
<END>
<START>
Santa
Fe
Pacific
Realty
is
a

California

whose
prime
properties
include
1,850

in

San

,

.
<END>
<START>
A

in

's

.
<END>
<START>
A

for
Chicago-based
Santa
Fe
Pacific
confirmed
that

were
being
held
with
the
fund
.
<END>
<START>
The

,

Santa
Fe
Pacific

,
have
been

,

.
<END>
<START>
The
debt-laden
parent
has
been
under
pressure
from
large
shareholders
to
boost
the
company
's
share
price
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
same
time
it
has
been
caught
in
an

.
<END>
<START>
The
California
pension
fund
's
planned
investment
in
the
real
estate
unit
is
unusual
.
<END>
<START>
Pension
funds
rarely
own
as
much
as
a
20
%
stake
in
what
is
expected
to
be
a
publicly
traded
company
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
pension
funds
are
rarely
given
seats
on
company
boards
and
most
often
try
to
avoid
them
because
of
legal
concerns
.
<END>
<START>
But
fund
officials
said
the
Santa
Fe
Pacific
Realty
investment
provides
an
opportunity
to
buy
a
stake
in
a
large
real
estate
portfolio
heavily
weighted
with
California
properties
.
<END>
<START>
The
purpose
of
the
note
is
to
provide
added

for
the
spun-off
company
in
a
form
that
will
save
it
spending
cash
on

,

Roulac
said
.
<END>
<START>
The

``
clearly
will
be
one
of
the
dominant

development

with

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
Real

for

first
nine

fell
to
$
71.9
million
from
$
143

,

.
<END>
<START>
That

's

<START>

<START>
Santa

2.8

,

<START>

<START>

<START>

the

fund
on
the
Santa
Fe
Pacific
Realty
board
,
Mr.
Roulac
said
,
to
insulate
the
fund
from

problems
.

<START>
GAF
,
Part
III
is

to

today
.
<END>
<START>
After
two

,
the
stakes
in
the

of
GAF
Corp.
and

,

.

.

<START>

.
<END>

.

,

.

,

.

,

.

,

.

,

.

<START>

,

.

.

<START>
Neither

at

.

.

.

because

.

<START>
JURY
'S
CRIMINAL
CONVICTION
under
Superfund
law
is
a
first
.
<END>
<START>
Charles
A.
Donohoo
,
sole
proprieter
of
a
Louisville
,
Ky.
,
demolition
company
,
was
found
guilty
of
violating
the
Superfund
law
as
well
as
the
Clean
Air
Act
.
<END>
<START>
Criminal
convictions
under
the
federal
Superfund
law
are
rare
,
and
the
decision
is
the
first
jury
verdict
in
such
a
case
.
<END>
<START>
Under
Superfund
,
those
who
owned
,
generated
or
transported
hazardous
waste
are
liable
for
its
cleanup
,
regardless
of
whether
their
actions
were
legal
at
the
time
.
<END>
<START>
Environmental
lawyers
say
virtually
all
of
the
Superfund
cases
to
date
have
involved
civil
penalties
designed
to
insure
cleanup
of
past
polluting
activities
.
<END>
<START>
But
Superfund
also
contains
a
criminal
provision
concerning
the
release
of
toxic
substances
into
the
environment
.
<END>
<START>
In
1986
Congress
strengthened
the
penalty
by
making
it
a
felony
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Donohoo
was
convicted
in
Louisville
late
last
month
of
violating
Superfund
by
failing
to
report
the
release
of
asbestos
into
the
environment
from
a
building
he
was
demolishing
.
<END>
<START>
He
was
also
convicted
of
failing
to
properly
remove
asbestos
from
the
building
,
a
violation
of
the
Clean
Air
Act
.
<END>
<START>
The
government
sought
a
criminal
penalty
because
``
no
cleanup
is
possible
here
.
<END>
<START>
Once
-LCB-
asbestos
-RCB-
is
released
into
the
environment
,
it
can
lodge
anywhere
,
''
says
Richard
A.
Dennis
,
the
assistant
U.S.
attorney
who
prosecuted
the
case
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Donohoo
is
scheduled
to
be
sentenced
Dec.
11
.
<END>
<START>
His
lawyer
could
not
be
reached
for
comment
.
<END>
<START>
TED
BUNDY'S
LAWYERS
switch
to
victims
'
side
in
death-sentence
case
.
<END>
<START>
The
law

,

<START>
Westamerica

.

``

.

<START>
Mr.

is
about

.
<END>
<START>
Neither

Payne
nor

could

.
<END>
<START>

has
about

in

.
<END>
<START>

controls
about
35

Marin

bridge
from

.
<END>

.
<END>
<START>

was

Angeles-based
First

.
<END>
<START>

had

from

.

...

''

.
''

in

,

.
<END>
<START>

has

,

.

,

,

75

.

.

<START>

<START>

<START>

,
47

,

of

and

.
<END>
<START>

,

Nov.
1
.

<START>

declined
to
give
his
age
,
but
he
said
his

is
a
normal
retirement
.

Mr.
Beddall
had

of

since

.

,

<START>
American
Telephone
&
Telegraph
Co.
said
it
will
spend
$
20
million
to
build
a
factory
in
Guadalajara
,
Mexico
,
to
make
telephone
answering
machines
.
<END>
<START>
Construction
of
the
265,000-square-foot
facility
will
begin
next
year
,
with
production
expected
to
start
in
late
1991
.
<END>
<START>
When
fully
operational
,
the
Guadalajara
factory
will
employ
about
1,500
workers
and
have
annual
operating
expenses
of
$
5
million
to
$
6
million
.
<END>
<START>
An
AT&T
representative
said
that
the
Guadalajara
factory
will
make
a
full
line
of
answering
machines
.
<END>
<START>
AT&T
already
has
a
factory
in
Matamoros
,
Mexico
,
to
make
electrical
devices
.
<END>
<START>
It
also

products
from
a

in

.
<END>
<START>

in

#
187.1

-LRB-
$
297.1

-RRB-
from
#
146.3

<START>
Exxon
Corp.
filed
suit
against
the
state
of
Alaska
,

officials
interfered
with
the
oil
company
's

to
treat
last
spring
's

.
<END>
<START>
The

is
a

to
a
suit
filed
by
Alaska
in
August
against
Exxon
and
six
other
oil
companies
.
<END>
<START>
The
state
's
suit
alleges
that
Exxon
's
response
to
the
spill
failed
to
prevent
contamination
of
hundreds
of
miles
of
shoreline
along
Prince
William
Sound
.
<END>
<START>
That
suit
and
Exxon
's
countersuit
were
filed
in
a
state
court
in
Anchorage
.
<END>
<START>
Neither
suit
lists
specific
dollar
claims
,
largely
because
damage
assessment
has
n't
yet
been
completed
.
<END>
<START>
Legal
strategists
say
that
damage
claims
against
the
oil
giant
and
others
could
well
exceed
$
1
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Litigation
,
if
not
settled
out
of
court
,
could
drag
on
for
years
.
<END>
<START>
Exxon
said
in
its
suit
that
it
will
seek
reimbursement
from
the
state
for
that
part
of
the
cleanup

and

claims
it
says
resulted
from
the
state
's
conduct
.
<END>
<START>
The
oil
company
claims
that
Alaskan

prevented
Exxon
from
spraying
dispersant
onto
the
almost
11
million
gallons
of
oil

when

ran

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

's

``

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>

's

,

``

.
''
<END>

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

on

.
<END>
<START>
Currently
,

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>
The
Justice
Department
has
revised
certain
internal
guidelines
and
clarified
others
in
a
move
that
could
restrict
the
use
of
criminal
racketeering
charges
against
white-collar
defendants
.
<END>
<START>
The
department
distributed
the
revisions
and
clarifications
to
U.S.
attorneys
around
the
country
this
summer
as
part
of
a
routine
process
of
updating
prosecutorial
guidelines
,
Mr.
Runkel
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
changes
apply
to
prosecutions
brought
under
the
Racketeer
Influenced
and
Corrupt
Organizations
law
.
<END>
<START>
The
RICO
law
has
come
under
criticism
from
some
defendants
and
defense
lawyers
.
<END>
<START>
They
argue
that
the
rights
of
RICO
defendants
and
third
parties
not
named
in
RICO
indictments
have
been
unfairly
damaged
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
the
kind
of
snubbing
rarely
seen
within
the
Congress
,
let
alone
within
the
same
party
.
<END>
<START>
Sen.
Alan
Cranston
trekked
over
to

.

.

,
''

.

,

.

.
<END>
<START>
``
Unless

,

.
''
<END>
<START>
Lawmakers
often

,

.
<END>
<START>
But

.

He

,

who

and

.
<END>

,

.

.
<END>
<START>

<START>

.

<START>

.
<END>

,

.
''
-RRB-
<END>

.

.

No

,

request
Friday
.
<END>
<START>
No
reason
for
the
request
was
given
.
<END>
<START>
Credit
Agricole

could
n't

.
<END>
<START>

's

,

283.3
billion
lire
-LRB-
$

-RRB-
,

.
<END>
<START>
Nuovo
Banco
's

,

,

,

's

.
<END>

,

,

,

.

.

.

''

.

.

<START>
Chip
's
Memory
Is
Here
Today
,
Here
Tomorrow
<END>
<START>
TWO
COMPANIES
plan
to
market
a
new
chip
with
ceramic
circuits
that
store
data
even
when
the
power
is
off
.
<END>
<START>
National
Semiconductor
Corp.
and
a
start-up
named
Ramtron
Corp.
plan
to
start
shipping
so-called
ferroelectric
memories
,
which
can
remember
data
for
at
least
10
years
without
any
current
flowing
to
them
.
<END>
<START>
The
chips
use
materials
,
such
as
lead
zirconate
titanate
,
to
form
microscopic
switches
that
retain
their
data
without
electricity
.
<END>
<START>
Developers
caution
that
broad
applications
are
several
years
away
because
the
technology
is
n't
fully
refined
.
<END>
<START>
But
Ramtron
of
Colorado
Springs
,
Colo.
,
plans
to
start
shipping
commercial
quantities
of
simple
ferroelectric
chips
in
December
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
expects
the
chips
eventually
to
be
used
in
devices
that
mimic
a
whole
range
of
computer
memory
equipment
,
including
floppy-disk
and
hard-disk
drives
.
<END>
<START>
National
Semiconductor
is
getting
ferroelectric
technology
from
Krysalis
Corp.
in
Albuquerque
,
N.M
.
<END>
<START>
National
says
it
agreed
to
acquire
Krysalis
's
assets
and
will
start
shipping
commercial
quantities
of
its
first
chips
,
including
a
4-kilobit
memory
,
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
Once
production
hurdles
are
overcome
,
the
chips
could
take
over
a
significant
part
of
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
to
not
needing
an
outside
power
source
,
they
are
potentially
cheaper
to
make
because
they
require
fewer
manufacturing
steps
than
conventional
chips
.
<END>
<START>
Military
buyers
have
shown
interest
,
National
says
,
because
ferroelectric
chips
resist
atomic
radiation
.
<END>
<START>
Showing
Up
in
Court
Without
Being
There
<END>
<START>
AN
AUSTIN
,
Texas
,
company
plans
to
make
it
easy
for
you
show
up
in
court
a
thousand
miles
away
without
leaving
town
.
<END>
<START>
Witnesses
often
must
travel
long
distances
to
give
face-to-face
depositions
before
lawyers
and
court
reporters
.
<END>
<START>
That
means
huge
travel
bills
.
<END>
<START>
And
telephone
or
videotape
depositions
just
do
n't
match
physical
encounters
.
<END>
<START>
That
could
change
,
thanks
to
lower
long-distance
rates
and
cheaper
electronics
.
<END>
<START>
Video
Telecom
Corp.
,
which
markets
videoconferencing
systems
,
is
working
with
court
reporters
to
wire
a
nationwide
network
to
allow
depositions
by
live
television
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
installed
a
prototype
system
that
connects
Dallas
with
Miami
over
digital
phone
lines
.
<END>
<START>
And
it
is
preparing
to
set
up
shop
in
Chicago
,
New
York
and
10
other
cities
where
court-reporting
agencies
can
tie
conference
rooms
into
the
network
.
<END>
<START>
While
lawyers
arranged
individual
tie-ups
before
,
the
formal
network
of
court
reporters
should
make
things
easier
and
cheaper
.
<END>
<START>
Japanese
Reverse
Tack
On
Patent
Protection
<END>
<START>
JAPAN
'S
MISUSE
of
U.S.
patents
has
been
a
sore
point
for
American
chip
makers
.
<END>
<START>
Now
at
least
one
Japanese
company
is
turning
the
courtroom
tables
.
<END>
<START>
Until
now
,
most
Japanese
charges
have
been
responses
to
suits
against
them
.
<END>
<START>
But
last
year
Hitachi
Ltd.
surprised
Japan
's
electronics
industry
when
it
accused
Korea
's
Samsung
Electronics
Co.
of
using
Hitachi
technology
to
make
dynamic
random-access
memory
chips
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
A
settlement
was
reached
but
was
n't
made
public
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
And
Hitachi
went
on
the
offensive
against
the
U.S.
's
Motorola
Inc.
earlier
this
month
with
a
suit
charging
that
Motorola
's
new
MC88200
chip
infringes
on
a
Hitachi
patent
.
<END>
<START>
Another
recent
Hitachi
suit
accuses
Motorola
of
reverse
engineering
a
Hitachi
technology
--
a
turnabout
from
a
nation
of
champion
reverse
engineers
.
<END>
<START>
The
moves
illustrate
the
more
aggressive
attitude
toward
patent
protection
that
patent
experts
say
Japan
is
starting
to
take
.
<END>
<START>
Hitachi
made
the
reverse-engineering
charges
in
an
amendment
to
a
counterclaim
filed
in
a
federal
district
court
in
Texas
after
Motorola
sued
Hitachi
for
patent
violation
.
<END>
<START>
Hitachi
charges
Motorola
``
has
engaged
in
fraudulent
and
inequitable
conduct
in
the
procurement
of
certain
Motorola
patents
''
used
in
Motorola
's
MC68030
microprocessor
chip
.
<END>
<START>
Translation
:
Motorola
appears
to
have
taken
a
Hitachi
technology
that
is
patented
in
the
U.S.
,
Hitachi
says
,
and
``
tried
to
make
it
look
like
a
new
technology
.
''
<END>
<START>
Motorola
either
denied
or
would
n't
comment
on
the
various
charges
.
<END>
<START>
Odds
and
Ends
<END>
<START>
COMPUTER
chips
that
simulate
human
vision
have
been
developed
by
Japan
's
Sharp
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
They
mimic
the
brain
by
``
looking
''
at
an
image
,
extracting
the
fundamentals
--
boundaries
,
corners
and
lines
--
and
translating
them
into
computer
data
.
<END>
<START>
Sharp
says
the
set
of
chips
could
improve
fax
machines
,
graphics
computers
or
identification
systems
that
recognize
facial
features
...
.
<END>
<START>
An
N.V
.
Philips
unit
has
created
a
computer
system
that
processes
video
images
3,000
times
faster
than
conventional
systems
.
<END>
<START>
Tandy
Corp.
,
citing
sluggish
sales
of
consumer-electronics
goods
,
said
net
income
dropped
3.3
%
for
the
first
quarter
ended
Sept.
30
.
<END>
<START>
The
results
,
which
represented
the
fifth
consecutive
quarter
of
flat-to-lower
earnings
for
the
big
electronics
retailer
,
disappointed
analysts
and
traders
.
<END>
<START>
Tandy
's
stock
fell
$
1.375
a
share
to
close
at
$
44
in
New
York
Stock
Exchange
composite
trading
.
<END>
<START>
Net
for
the
quarter
was
$
62.8
million
,
or
73
cents
a
share
,
down
from
$
64.9
million
,
or
72
cents
a
share
,
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
earnings
would
have
increased
if
it
had
n't
been
actively
repurchasing
its
shares
,
thus
increasing
its
interest
expense
and
reducing
its
interest
income
.
<END>
<START>
Tandy
had
86.3
million
shares
outstanding
at
Sept.
30
,
down
from
90
million
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
rose
5
%
to
$
986
million
from
$
937
million
.
<END>
<START>
Tandy
said
consumer
electronics
sales
at
its
Radio
Shack
stores
have
been
slow
,
partly
because
of
a
lack
of
hot
,
new
products
.
<END>
<START>
``
Radio
Shack
continues
to
be
lackluster
,
''
said
Dennis
Telzrow
,
analyst
with
Eppler
,
Guerin
&
Turner
in
Dallas
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
at
Radio
Shack
stores
open
more
than
a
year
grew
only
2
%
in
the
quarter
from
a
year
earlier
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
Mr.
Telzrow
said
he
cut
his
fiscal
1990
per-share
earnings
estimate
for
Tandy
to
$
4.05
from
$
4.20
.
<END>
<START>
Tandy
earned
$
88.8
million
,
or
$
3.64
a
share
,
in
the
year
ended
June
30
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bryant
and
other
analysts
hope
all
those
moves
will
combine
to
help
Tandy
's
results
improve
in
the
important
Christmas
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
've
been
promising
13
%
to
15
%
growth
based
on
the
strategic
moves
they
've
made
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
the
earnings
acceleration
is
to
take
place
,
that
should
be
the
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
At
a
private
dinner
Thursday
,
Drexel
Burnham
Lambert
Inc.
chief
executive
Frederick
Joseph
delivered
a
sobering
message
about
the
junk
bond
market
to
officials
of
Prudential
Insurance
Co.
of
America
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Joseph
conceded
the
junk
market
was
in
disarray
,
according
to
people
familiar
with
the
discussion
.
<END>
<START>
The
dinner
was
a
stark
confirmation
that
1989
is
the
worst
year
ever
for
the
$
200
billion
junk
market
.
<END>
<START>
And
investors
and
traders
alike
say
the
current
turmoil
could
take
years
to
resolve
.
<END>
<START>
Amid
the
market
disorder
,
even
Drexel
,
which
has
the
widest
and
most
loyal
following
of
junk
bond
investors
,
is
pulling
in
its
horns
.
<END>
<START>
For
many
money
managers
,
the
past
four
months
have
been
humiliating
.
<END>
<START>
Since
the
end
of
last
year
,
junk
bonds
have
been
outperformed
by
all
categories
of
investment-grade
bonds
,
including
ultra-safe
Treasury
securities
.
<END>
<START>
The
fragile
market
received
its
biggest
jolt
last
month
from
Campeau
Corp.
,
which
created
its
U.S.
retailing
empire
with
more
than
$
3
billion
in
junk
financing
.
<END>
<START>
Campeau
developed
a
cash
squeeze
that
caused
it
to
be
tardy
on
some
interest
payments
and
to
put
its
prestigious
Bloomingdale
's
department
store
chain
up
for
sale
.
<END>
<START>
At
that
point
,
the
junk
market
went
into
a
tailspin
as
buyers
disappeared
and
investors
tried
to
sell
.
<END>
<START>
In
an
interview
,
Mr.
Joseph
says
his
dinner
discussion
with
the
Prudential
executives
acknowledged
problems
for
junk
.
<END>
<START>
What
has
jolted
many
junk
buyers
is
the
sudden
realization
that
junk
bonds
can
not
necessarily
be
bought
and
sold
with

of

and

.
<END>
<START>
Unlike

York

,
where

and

are
quickly
matched
,
the
junk
market
,
where
risky

are
traded
,
is
sometimes
closed
for
repairs
.
<END>
<START>
At
closely
held
Deltec

Corp.
,

K.

and
Hannah
H.

say
the
problems
of
the
junk

go

than

.
<END>
<START>
Mutual

have
also
been
net

of
junk

as
junk
's
relatively
poor
performance
and
negative
press

have
produced
``
above-normal
''
redemptions
by

,
Deltec
said
.
<END>
<START>
And
,

said
,

has
been
severely
reduced
because

and
loans
have
been
restricted
in
their
junk

by

.
<END>
<START>
``
In
fact
,
savings
and
loans
were
sellers
of
high

throughout
the
quarter
,
''
Deltec
said
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Minella
and

say

are

,

and

.
<END>
<START>
``

,
''

,

.
<END>
<START>
``
I

,

this

has

.
<END>
<START>
This

.
''
<END>
<START>
The

's
``

,
''

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
And
the

are
n't

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
The

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

's

.
<END>
<START>
His

that

over

of
34

.
<END>
<START>

of

less

.

<START>

.
<END>

SMYRNA

<START>

.

,

,

,

<END>
<START>
The
1980s
have
spawned
an

of
consumer
choice
in
America
,
in

from

to

.
<END>
<START>
And

,
as

,

.
<END>
<START>
Americans
now
can

572

models
of
cars
,
vans
and
trucks
,
up
from
just
408
when
the
decade
began
,
according
to
Automotive
News
,

.
<END>
<START>
For

,

has

a
much

battle
to
keep

from
defecting
to
one

new
makes
on

block
.
<END>
<START>
For
American
car

,
the

of
choice
is
both
liberating
and
confusing
.
<END>
<START>
Malcolm
MacDougall
,

of
the
Jordan
,

,
Case
&
Taylor

,

``

.
''
<END>
<START>

says

choices
is
causing

among

today
,
and
that

will
simply
ignore
new

that

.
<END>
<START>
``

,
''
he

,
``

that
have

.
''
<END>
<START>
He

.

<START>

.

<END>
<START>
Market

,
but

than

P.

Jr.

50

.
<END>
<START>
The

declared
that
his
company
would
make
``
a
car
for
every

and
purpose
.
''
<END>
<START>
Now
there

many
cars
for
every

and

.
<END>
<START>
Just
four

,

divided

into
seven

.
<END>
<START>
Today
,

identify
19

for

,

11
for

and

.
<END>
<START>
The

has

because

is

's
biggest

for

;

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>
But
slow
sales
forced
Ford
to
kill
the
brand
just
last
week
.
<END>
<START>
When
consumers
have
so
many
choices
,
brand
loyalty
is
much
harder
to

.
<END>
<START>
The
Wall
Street
Journal
's
``
American
Way
of
Buying
''
survey
found
that
53
%
of
today
's
car
buyers
tend
to
switch

.
<END>
<START>
For

,
Peter
D.
Hart
Research
Associates
and
the
Roper
Organization
each
asked
about
2,000
U.S.

.
<END>
<START>
Which
cars
do
Americans
favor
most
these
days
?
<END>
<START>
It
's
hard
to
generalize
,
but
age
seems
to
be
the
best
predictor
.
<END>
<START>
Adults
under
age
30
like
sports
cars
,
luxury
cars
,
convertibles
and
imports
far
more
than
their

do
.
<END>
<START>
Three
of
every
10
buyers
under
30
would
prefer
to
buy
a
sports
car
,
compared
with
just
16
%
of

30
and
over
,
according

the
Journal

.
<END>
<START>
Perhaps

,
35

18

44

.
<END>
<START>
That

14

.
<END>
<START>
Generally
,

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

68

.
<END>
<START>
Some
46
%

,

50

.
<END>
<START>

,

.

<START>
Program
trading
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
in
September
rose
to

highest

level
as

of

.
<END>
<START>
A
daily
average
of
20.9
million
shares
traded
in
program
strategies
in
September
,
the
second-highest
level
ever
.
<END>
<START>
The
highest
level
was
in
June
1989
,
when
a
daily
average
of
22.1
million
shares
traded
in
program
strategies
.
<END>
<START>
Average
daily

volume
in
June
of
180.3
million
shares
was
considerably

than
in
September
.
<END>
<START>
Program
trading
amounted
to
12.3
%
of
average
daily
volume
in
June
.
<END>
<START>
The
Big
Board
says
program
trading
describes
a
variety
of
strategies
involving
the
purchase
or
sale
of
a
basket
of
15
or
more
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
the
most
controversial
form
of
program
trading
because
it
can
create

in
the
stock
market
.
<END>
<START>
Salomon
Brothers
Inc.
was

in

's

.

,

75.2

.

.

Eastman

<START>

,

,

.

a
kind
of
pinball
,
is
Japan
's
favorite
form
of
legal
gambling
.
<END>
<START>
The
donations
so
far
appear
to
be
small
,
especially
compared
with
the
huge
sums
that
changed
hands
in
the
Recruit
Co
.
influence-peddling
scandal
that
plagued
the
ruling
party
last
year
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
implications
could
be
great
.
<END>
<START>
Pachinko
is
slightly
on
the
shady
side
,
often
linked
to
the
lower
ranks
of
Japan
's
underworld
and
regularly
at
the
top
of
annual
lists
of
tax
evaders
.
<END>
<START>
Recently
the
industry
has
faced
the
threat
of
new
restrictions
,
and
political
donations
may
have
been
made
with
the
intent
to
bribe
.
<END>
<START>
To
many
Japanese
,
pachinko
is
benign
or
enticingly
unsavory
.
<END>
<START>
Garish
neon
pachinko
marquees
blaze
from
the
main
streets
and
narrow
alleys
of
cities
and
towns
across
the
country
.
<END>
<START>
And
because
the
pachinko
industry
is
regularly
at
the
top
of
annual
lists
for
tax
evasion
,
some
observers
estimate
the
real
income
could
be
as
much
as
20
trillion
yen
.
<END>
<START>
If
that
money
were
being
taxed
,
it
could
bring
the
government
a
badly
needed
several
trillion
yen
.
<END>
<START>
In
1984
,
an
attempt
was
made
to
crack
down
on
the
industry
with
tougher
restrictions
.
<END>
<START>
Then
,
in
1988
,
a
proposal
to
keep
better
track
of
income
by
selling
prepaid
cards
for
pachinko
was
fielded
in
parliament
.
<END>
<START>
The
proposal
split
the
industry
in
two
,
along
the
lines
of
national
origin
:
North
Koreans
oppose
the
plan
while
South
Koreans
,
Japanese
and
Taiwanese
accept
it
or
are
neutral
.
<END>
<START>
In
August
,
a
conservative
weekly
magazine
reported
that
a
pachinko
industry
organization
donated
money
to
Japan
Socialist
Party
members
.
<END>
<START>
The
Chosen
Soren
and
the
JSP
immediately
denied
the
report
.
<END>
<START>
And
at
first
,
neither
the
opposition
nor
the
LDP
wanted
to
pursue
the
issue
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
press
kept
it
alive
;
as
with
the
Recruit
scandal
,
lists
began
circulating
with
names
of
people
who
had
received
money
.
<END>
<START>
Within
a
matter
of
weeks
,
less-conservative
magazines
reported
that
members
of
the
ruling
LDP
had
received
much
larger
donations
from
pachinko
organizations
.
<END>
<START>
So
far
,
though
,
there
have
been
no
allegations
that
the
contributions
the
LDP
members
received
amounted
to
bribes
.
<END>
<START>
No
one
has
alleged
that
the
donations
were
by
themselves
illegal
.
<END>
<START>
Direct
donations
from
either
of
the
residents
'
organizations
would
be
illegal
because
the
groups
are
defined
as
foreign
,
but
both
groups
deny
making
direct
donations
.
<END>
<START>
They
say
it
s
possible
some
of
their
members
may
be
donating
privately
.
<END>
<START>
The
issue
is
further
complicated
because
although
the
organizations
represent
Korean
residents
,
those
residents
were
largely
born
and
raised
in
Japan
and
many
speak
only
Japanese
.
<END>
<START>
Many
Japanese
think
it
only
natural
that
the
organizations
or
their
members
would
donate
to
politicians
,
the
way
many
Japanese
do
,
to
win
favor
or
support
.
<END>
<START>
Both
residents
'
organizations
admit
to
receiving
some
funding
from
abroad
.
<END>
<START>
When
Robert
McDuffie
was
14
,
he
got
a
chance
to
play
in
the
starting

for

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.
<END>

,
''

,

.
<END>
<START>

But

,

...
.
<END>
<START>
Afterwards

.
''

Today
,

.
<END>
<START>

31
,

McDuffie
has
a

,

tone
,

and

.
<END>
<START>
Later
this

at

's

,
and

.

.

``
I

,
''

,

.
<END>
<START>
``

.

<END>
<START>

.
''
<END>
<START>

I

,
''

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
She

,
''

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
She

.
''
<END>
<START>
The

McDuffie
gave

<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
``

was

,
''

the

,
who

's

.
<END>
<START>
``
He
did

,

's

.
<END>
<START>
There

--

--

...
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

'

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

'
-LCB-
`
sweet
!
sweet
!
'

.

<END>
<START>

''

<END>

<END>
<START>

-RCB-

.
<END>

.

<END>
<START>
Since

,

McDuffie
has

.
<END>
<START>
His
guest

on
the
NBC

``
Another
World
,
''
scandalized

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
McDuffie
's

,

and

.
<END>
<START>
Aided

's

,

``

''

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Schuman

``

,
''

.

<END>
<START>
His

was

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>
Ms.
Jepson
is
a

music
writer
in
New

.
<END>
<START>
Are
consumers
too
deep
in
hock
?
<END>
<START>
A

observers
think
so
,
and
,

're

,
the
whole

as
well

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
The

.
<END>
<START>

--

--

.

<START>

,

.

-LRB-

--

.

,

<START>
Maidenform
Inc.
loves
to
be
intimate
with

customers
,

the
rest

.

<START>

.

.

.

.

<START>

's

.

.

.

,

.

The

,

,

.

,

,

,

.

.

.
<END>
<START>
China
could
exhaust
its
foreign-exchange
reserves
as
early
as
next
year
,
a
Western
government
report
says
,
unless
imports
are
cut
drastically
to
help
narrow
the
balance-of-payments
deficit
.
<END>
<START>
A
country
is
considered
financially
healthy
if
its
reserves
cover
three
months
of
its
imports
.
<END>
<START>
The
$
14
billion
of
reserves
China
had
in
June
would
cover
just
that
much
.
<END>
<START>
But
before
import
growth
slowed
,
China
's
buying
spree
in
the
first
half
already
had
taken
its
toll
on
foreign-exchange
reserves
.
<END>
<START>
The
$
14
billion
level
in
June
marked
a
drop
from
$
19
billion
at
the
end
of
April
.
<END>
<START>
China
's
last
big
import
binge
sent
reserves
tumbling
to
$
10.6
billion
in
June
1985
from
$
16.6
billion
the
previous
September
.
<END>
<START>
China
might
stave
off
a
crisis
if
it
acts
as
forcefully
as
it
did
to
arrest
the
1985
decline
,
when
Beijing
slammed
the
brakes
on
foreign-exchange
spending
and
devalued
the
currency
.
<END>
<START>
But
this
time
,
China
faces
a
more
difficult
battle
because
of
economic
forces
that
have
come
into
play
since
the
Tiananmen
Square
killings
June
4
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
China
's
hard-currency
income
is
expected
to
suffer
from
the
big
drop
in
tourist
arrivals
since
June
4
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
from
tourism
this
year
is
projected
to
total
$
1.3
billion
,
down
from
$
2.2
billion
last
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
Western
government
report
suggests
a
number
of
scenarios
for
China
's
current-account
balance
,
two
of
which
are
considered
most
likely
.
<END>
<START>
In
1985
,
China
had
a
record
deficit
of
$
11.4
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
other
scenario
assumes
that
Beijing
takes
effective
actions
to
curb
imports
in
the
coming
months
.
<END>
<START>
But
since
June
,
foreign
bankers
led
by
international
financial
institutions
have
virtually
suspended
their
new
loans
to
China
.
<END>
<START>
Even
if
borrowing
resumes
,
commercial
bankers
are
n't
expected
to
lend
as
much
as
before
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
economists
are
forecasting
a
slowdown
in
foreign
direct
investments
as
businessmen
become
increasingly
wary
of
China
's
deteriorating
political
and
economic
environment
.
<END>
<START>
On
top
of
all
this
,
foreign-debt
repayments
are
expected
to
peak
in
1991
to
1992
.
<END>
<START>
With
less
capital
coming
in
,
China
's
balance
of
payments
would
suffer
.
<END>
<START>
The
Western
government
report
's
first
scenario
assumes
a
30
%
reduction
in
foreign
borrowing
and
a
5
%
contraction
in
foreign
direct
investment
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
second
,
foreign
borrowing
is
projected
to
grow
10
%
and
investment
to
drop
10
%
.
<END>
<START>
But
in
either
case
,
the
report
says
,
China
's
balance
of
payments
would
rapidly
dry
up
foreign
reserves
,
which
are
used
to
finance
the
imbalance
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
first
scenario
,
the
reserves
would
be
exhausted
next
year
,
and
in
the
second
they
would
be
wiped
out
in
1991
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
reported
good
gains
in
all
of
its
divisions
.
<END>
<START>
Roche
also
said
it
expects
a
``
considerable
rise
''
in
1989
group
profit
from
the
641.5
million-franc
-LRB-
$
396
million
-RRB-
net
in
1988
.
<END>

<START>
Ralph
Brown
was
31,000
feet
over
Minnesota
when
both
jets
on
his
Falcon
20
flamed
out
.
<END>
<START>
At
18,000
feet
,
he
says
,
he
and
his
co-pilot
``
were
looking
for
an
interstate
or
a
cornfield
''
to
land
.
<END>
<START>
At
13,000
feet
,
the
engines
restarted
.
<END>
<START>
Had
he
been
a
little
less
gung-ho
,
``
I
'd
have
gotten
the
thing
on
the
ground
and
headed
for
the
nearest
bar
,
''
Mr.
Brown
says
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
flies
for
Federal
Express
Corp.
,
perhaps
the
closest
thing
in
corporate
America
to
the
Green
Berets
.
<END>
<START>
Federal
's
employees
work
long
hours
and
seem
to
thrive
on
the
stress
of
racing
the
clock
.
<END>
<START>
Like
Mr.
Brown
,
they
sometimes
go
to
surprising
lengths
to
meet
that
overarching
corporate
goal
:
delivering
the
goods
on
time
.
<END>
<START>
That
may
soon
change
.
<END>
<START>
The
election
,
which
would
bring
the
first
major
union
to
Federal
's
U.S.
operations
,
has
pitted
new
hires
against
devoted
veterans
such
as
Mr.
Brown
.
<END>
<START>
It
has
also
rattled
Federal
's
strongly
anti-union
management
,
which
is
already
contending
with
melding
far-flung
operations
and
with
falling
profits
.
<END>
<START>
``
In
our
formula
,
we
do
n't
have
any
losers
except
the
competition
.
''
<END>
<START>
What
managers
really
fear
is
that
the
pro-union
movement
could
spread
beyond
the
pilots
.
<END>
<START>
Under
federal
transportation
law
,
a
government
mediator
is
attempting
to
reconcile
the
melding
of
Tiger
's
job
classifications
into
Federal
's
.
<END>
<START>
Depending
on
the
outcome
,
the
merged
company
may
face
union
elections
this
fall
among
airplane
mechanics
,
ramp
workers
,
stock
clerks
and
flight
dispatchers
.
<END>
<START>
These
groups
constitute
up
to
10
%
of
its
work
force
.
<END>
<START>
That
culture
,
carefully
crafted
by
Mr.
Smith
,
leaves
little
,
if
any
,
room
for
unions
.
<END>
<START>
Since
founding
the
company
,
the
charismatic
Vietnam
vet
,
who
is
still
only
46
years
old
,
has
fostered
an
ethos
of
combat
.
<END>
<START>
Flights
are
``
missions
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Smith
's
managers
have
,
at
times
,
been
called
``
Ho
Chi
Minh
's
Guerrillas
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
Bravo
Zulu
award
,
the
Navy
accolade
for
a
``
job
well
done
,
''
is
bestowed
on
Federal
's
workers
who
surpass
the
call
of
duty
.
<END>
<START>
Competitors
are
known
as
the
``
enemy
.
''
<END>
<START>
To
reinforce
employees
'
dedication
,
Mr.
Smith
pays
well
.
<END>
<START>
He
also
lets
workers
vent
steam
through
an
elaborate
grievance
procedure
and
,
as
a
perk
,
fly
free
in
empty
cockpit
seats
.
<END>
<START>
He
gives
pep
talks
in
periodic
``
family
briefings
''
beamed
internationally
on
``
FXTV
,
''
the
company
's
own
television
network
.
<END>
<START>
And
,
with
many
of
his
70,000
workers
,
Mr.
Smith
's
damn-the-torpedoes
attitude
has
caught
on
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
do
n't
just
hand
the
customer
the
package
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
just
the
beginning
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
In
essence
,
we
run
the
show
.
''
<END>
<START>
David
Sanders
,
a
longtime
pilot
,
bristles
at
the
mere
suggestion
that
a
union
might
tamper
with
his
flight
schedule
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
America
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
Nobody
has
the
right
to
tell
me
how
much
I
can
work
.
''
<END>
<START>
Such
attitudes
have
given
Federal
flexibility
,
not
only
to
rapidly
implement
new
technology
but
to
keep
its
work
force
extraordinarily
lean
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
deliberately
understaffs
,
stretching
employees
'
schedules
to
the
limit
.
<END>
<START>
But
though
couriers
work
as
many
as
60
hours
a
week
during
the
autumn
rush
,
they
leave
early
during
slack
times
while
still
being
assured
of
a
minimum
paycheck
.
<END>
<START>
Pilots
,
as
well
,
routinely
fly
overtime
to
ensure
that
none
are
furloughed
during
seasonal
lows
.
<END>
<START>
The
operational
freedom
has
also
given
Federal
a
leg
up
on
archrival
United
Parcel
Service
Inc.
,
the
nation
's
largest
employer
of
United
Brotherhood
of
Teamsters
members
.
<END>
<START>
Because
UPS
drivers
are
n't
permitted
to
load
their
own
vehicles
at
the
depot
,
say
these
couriers
,
packages
often
get
buried
in
the
load
and
are
delivered
late
.
<END>
<START>
Labor
problems
are
the
last
thing
Mr.
Smith
needs
right
now
.
<END>
<START>
Although
the
Tiger
acquisition
has
brought
Federal
a
long
way
toward
becoming
the
global
player
it
wants
to
be
,
it
also
has
brought
problems
.
<END>
<START>
Federal
,
on
its
own
,
had
n't
been
doing
very
well
overseas
.
<END>
<START>
It
had
hemorrhaged
in
its
attempt
to
get
into
Asia
,
where
treaty
restrictions
forced
it
to
fly
some
planes
half-empty
on
certain
routes
.
<END>
<START>
On
routes
to
South
America
,
the
company
had
no
backup
jets
to
ensure
delivery
when
planes
were
grounded
.
<END>
<START>
In
Europe
,
business
suffered
as
Federal
bought
several
local
companies
,
only
to
have
the
managers
quit
.
<END>
<START>
These
and
other
problems
squeezed
Federal
's
profit
margins
last
year
to
8
%
,
down
from
more
than
13
%
annually
in
the
first
half
of
the
decade
.
<END>
<START>
Earnings
have
plummeted
,
too
,
in
each
of
the
past
three
quarters
.
<END>
<START>
Federal
's
stock
price
,
however
,
has
held
up
well
,
driven
in
part
by
the
general
run-up
of
airline
stocks
,
analysts
say
.
<END>
<START>
Since
trading
as
low
as
$
42.25
a
share
in
May
,
Federal
's
shares
have
rallied
as
high
as
$
57.87
in
New
York
Stock
Exchange
composite
trading
.
<END>
<START>
They
closed
Friday
at
$
53.25
,
down
50
cents
on
the
day
.
<END>
<START>
There
's
a
certain
irony
in
the
fact
that
Federal
Express
faces
its
first
union
problems
as
a
result
of
its
Tiger
purchase
.
<END>
<START>
Tiger
itself
was
founded
by
a
band
of
gungho
airmen
who
had
airlifted
supplies
``
over
the
Hump
''
from
India
to
China
during
World
War
II
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
early
1970s
,
Mr.
Smith
modeled
his
fledgling
company
on
Tiger
's
innovation
of
hub-and-spoke
and
containerized-cargo
operations
.
<END>
<START>
But

<START>
The
Senate
convicted
U.S.
District
Judge
Alcee
Hastings
of
Florida
of
eight
impeachment
articles
,
removing
the
53-year-old
judge
from
his
$
89,500-a-year
,
lifetime
job
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Hastings
's
case
was
particularly
nettlesome
because
it
marked
the
first
time
a
federal
official
was
impeached
and
removed
from
office
on
charges
of
which
a
jury
had
acquitted
him
.
<END>
<START>
In
1983
,
Mr.
Hastings
was
found
not
guilty
of
accepting
a
$
150,000
bribe
in
a
case
before
him
,
the
central
charge
on
which
the
Senate
convicted
him
.
<END>
<START>
He
was
only
the
sixth
federal
judge
ever
ousted
from
office
after
an
impeachment
trial
.
<END>
<START>
With
no
floor
debate
,
the
Senate
on
Friday
voted
69-26
to
convict
Mr.
Hastings
of
perjury
and
conspiring
to
accept
a
bribe
,
five
votes
more
than
needed
.
<END>
<START>
Conviction
on
any
single
impeachment
article
was
enough
to
remove
Judge
Hastings
from
office
.
<END>
<START>
He
was
found
not
guilty
of
three
charges
,
involving
accusations
that
he
had
improperly
disclosed
information
about
a
sensitive
,
government
investigation
.
<END>
<START>
The
Senate
did
n't
vote
on
six
lesser
charges
.
<END>
<START>
Although
Mr.
Hastings
had
been
acquitted
by
a
jury
,
lawmakers
handling
the
prosecution
in
Congress
had
argued
that
the
purpose
of
impeachment
is
n't
to
punish
an
individual
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
,
they
argued
that
impeachment
aims
to
protect
public
institutions
from
people
who
have
abused
their
positions
of
trust
,
irrespective
of
the
outcome
of
prior
criminal
or
civil
cases
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Hastings
faced
the
senators
and
sat

during
the
first
two

,
then
quickly
left

.
<END>
<START>
In

on

,

senators
'

.
<END>
<START>
``
Their

is

of

'

,
''
Mr.
Hastings

.
<END>
<START>
For

,

.
<END>
<START>

<START>

?
<END>
<START>
A

,

.

.

<START>

''

``

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>

.

<START>

.

,

.
<END>
<START>

FBI
''

,

:
<END>
<START>

.

Texaco

,

<START>
Tana

17
oil
and
gas
fields
in
south
Texas
,
will
provide
Texaco
with
mostly
gas
reserves
.
<END>
<START>
The
fields
contain
recoverable
reserves
of
435
billion
cubic
feet
of
natural
gas
and
four
million

of
oil
.
<END>
<START>
``

's

to

,
''

James

.
<END>
<START>
Texaco
has
also
been
attempting
to
sell

.
<END>
<START>
At
least
two
years
ago
,
the
company
put
60
million

of
oil
reserves
on
the
block
.
<END>
<START>
They
were
either
too
small
or

to

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

before

because

's

are
high

and
near
other

Texaco

,

.
<END>
<START>
Texaco
,

many

,
has

to
replace

falling
oil
and
gas

.
<END>
<START>
Pennzoil
had
sued

for

with
its

.

.

.

.

.

.

<START>

.

.

.

.

<START>

<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

.

<START>

<START>

.

<START>

ministry
officials
have
been
growing
increasingly
concerned
during
the
past
few
months
about
Japanese
banks
getting
in
over
their
heads
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
-LCB-
ministry
-RCB-
wants
to
see
the
Japanese
banks
pull
in
their
horns
''
on
leveraged
buy-outs
,
he
added
.
<END>
<START>
Japanese
banks
are
under
``
political
pressure
''
as
well
,
the
analyst
said
.
<END>
<START>
Clearly
,
some
financial
authorities
are
concerned
about
the
Japanese
banks
role
in
leveraged
buy-outs
.
<END>
<START>
At
a
news

this
week
,
Bank
of
Japan
Gov.
Satoshi
Sumita
cautioned
banks
to
take
a
``
prudent
''
stance
regarding
highly
leveraged
deals
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
Mr.
Sumita
's
statements
,
it
is
the
Finance
Ministry
,
not
the
central
bank
,
that
makes
policy
decisions
.
<END>
<START>
While
recent
events
may
cool
some
of
the
leveraged
buy-out
fever
,
Japanese
banks
are
n't
likely
to
walk
away
from
the
game
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
the
risks
,
the
deals
can
be
an

way
for
Japanese
banks
to
increase
their

in
the
U.S.

,

say
.
<END>
<START>
Flush
with
cash
at

,
but
with
fewer

to
lend
to
,
leading
banks
are
eager
to
expand

.
<END>
<START>
Jumping
in
on
big

is
a
high
profile
way
to
leapfrog
the
problem
of
not
having
a

network
.
<END>
<START>
France
's
national
tobacco
company
,
known
for
making
brown-tobacco
cigarettes
such
as
Gauloises
and
Gitanes
,
is
branching
out
.
<END>
<START>
Concerned
by
dipping
demand
for
its
traditional
products
,
it
is
moving
not
only
into
blonde
cigarettes
,
but
also
into
electronic
car-parking
payment
cards
to
be
sold
in
neighborhood
tobacco
stores
.
<END>
<START>
Brown
tobacco
in
France
is
a
more
pungent
,
stronger
grade
than
the
lighter
grade
,
or
blonde
tobacco
,
used
in
so-called
American-style
cigarettes
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
are
n't
Philip
Morris
Cos.
,
''
says
Bertrand
de
Galle
,
chairman
of
government-owned
Societe
Nationale
d'Exploitation
Industrielle
des
Tabacs
&
Allumettes
S.A.
,
known
as
Seita
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
,
he
said
in
an
interview
,
he
is
looking
for
ways
to
exploit
France
's
network
of
39,000
tobacco
agents
,
most
of
them
cafes
.
<END>
<START>
While
Seita
does
n't
own
the
French
tabacs
,
its
close
alliance
with
them
offers
distribution
possibilities
.
<END>
<START>
One
proposal
is
to
introduce
a
new
payment
system
for
parking
in
Paris
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
of
paying
for
parking
by
putting
money
in
the
existing
machines
,
which
deliver
little
paper
receipts
,
drivers
would
be
able
to
buy
electronic
cards
in
local
tobacco
shops
.
<END>
<START>
Once
activated
,
the
card
would
sit
in
the
car
's
window
,
showing
traffic
wardens
how
much
time
the
motorist
could
remain
.
<END>
<START>
When
the
motorist
returned
to
his
car
he
could
turn
the
card
off
and
,
if
it
showed
time
remaining
,
save
it
for
later
.
<END>
<START>
Seita
is
a
partner
in
the
project
,
which
was
developed
by
Matra
SA
using
Japanese
technology
.
<END>
<START>
Seita
and
Matra
currently
are
negotiating
with
city
officials
for
the
right
to
begin
service
.
<END>
<START>
And
Seita
is
considering
further

.
<END>
<START>
It
currently
is
considering
bidding
for
Swedish
Match
Co
.
<END>
<START>
And
it
retains
an
interest
in
acquiring
candies
and
other

that
might
be
sold
in
tobacco
shops
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
is
trying
to
shore
up
its
tobacco
business
.
<END>
<START>
Brown-tobacco
cigarettes
such
as
Gauloises
now
make
up
just
40
%
of
the
French
tobacco
market
,
half
the
level
of
about
two
decades
ago
.
<END>
<START>
While
Seita
retains
a
manufacturing
monopoly
in
France
,
it
is
being
hurt
by
rising
imports
and
from
waning
cigarette
demand
.
<END>
<START>
So
Seita
has
introduced
blonde
cigarettes
under
the
Gauloises
label
,
and
intends
to
relaunch
the
unsuccessful
Gitanes
Blondes
in
new

,
similar
to

slide-packs
used
by
brown-tobacco

.
<END>
<START>
The
aim
,
says
Mr.
de
Galle
,
is
to
win
market
share
from
imported
cigarettes
,
and
to
persuade
smokers
who
are
switching
to
blonde
cigarettes
to
keep
buying
French
.
<END>
<START>
When

.

Constitution
.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

now
to
decide
whether

has

.
<END>
<START>
The

said

.
<END>

.

''

<START>

<START>
OPEC
's
ability
to
produce
more
petroleum
than
it
can
sell
is
beginning
to
cast
a
shadow
over
world
oil
markets
.
<END>
<START>
Output
from
the
Organization
of
Petroleum
Exporting
Countries
is
already
at
a
high
for
the
year
and
most
member
nations
are
running
flat
out
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
the
effort
by
some
oil
ministers
to
get
OPEC
to
approve
a
new
permanent
production-sharing
agreement
next
month
is
taking
on
increasing
urgency
.
<END>
<START>
The
organization
is
scheduled
to
meet
in
Vienna
beginning
Nov.
25
.
<END>
<START>
So
far
this
year
,
rising
demand
for
OPEC
oil
and
production
restraint
by
some
members
have
kept
prices
firm
despite
rampant
cheating
by
others
.
<END>
<START>
But
that
could
change
if
demand
for
OPEC
's
oil
softens
seasonally
early
next
year
as
some
think
may
happen
.
<END>
<START>
At
that
rate
,
a
majority
of
OPEC
's
13
members
have
reached
their
output
limits
,
they
said
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
is
estimated
that
at
least
three
million
barrels
a
day
--
and
possibly
as
much
as
seven
million
barrels
a
day
--
of
spare
capacity
still
exists
within
OPEC
.
<END>
<START>
Most
is
concentrated
in
five
Persian
Gulf
countries
,
including
his
own
,
Issam
Al-Chalabi
,
Iraq
's
oil
minister
,
told
the
conference
Friday
.
<END>
<START>
He
puts
OPEC
's
current
capacity
at
28
million
to
29
million
barrels
a
day
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
higher
than
some
other
estimates
.
<END>
<START>
Ali
Khalifa
Al-Sabah
,
Kuwait
's
oil
minister
,
recently
estimated
OPEC
capacity
at
25
million
barrels
a
day
.
<END>
<START>
Either
way
,
the
overhang
is
big
enough
to
keep
delicately
balanced
oil
markets
on
edge
.
<END>
<START>
Even
modest
amounts
of
additional
output
by
those
with
the
huge
extra
capacity
and
reserves
,
such
as
Saudi
Arabia
and
Iraq
,
could
upset
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
The
Iraqi
oil
minister
and
Saudi
oil
minister
Hisham
Nazer
insisted
in
their
comments
to
the
conference
that
their
countries
would
act
responsibly
to
maintain
a
stable
market
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
in
interviews
later
,
both
ministers
stressed
that
they
expect
future
OPEC
quotas
to
be
based
mainly
on
the
production
capacity
and
reserves
of
each
member
.
<END>
<START>
Under
that
approach
,
countries
with
the
most
unused
oil
capacity
would
get
bigger
shares
of
any
future
increases
in
OPEC
's
production
ceiling
than
they
would
under
the
current
system
.
<END>
<START>
At
an
inconclusive
Geneva
meeting
late
last
month
,
OPEC
's
oil
ministers
halfheartedly
approved
another
increase
of
one
million
barrels
a
day
in
their
production
ceiling
.
<END>
<START>
They
doled
it
out
using
the
existing
formula
,
however
,
which
meant
that
even
those
countries
that
could
n't
produce
more
received
higher
official
allotments
.
<END>
<START>
The
main
effect
of
the
ceiling
boost
was
to
``
legitimize
''
some
of
the
overproduction
already
coming
from
the
quota
cheaters
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
there
was
a
breakthrough
at
Geneva
.
<END>
<START>
Previously
,
no
OPEC
member
had
been
willing
to
accept
a
reduction
in
its
percentage
share
of
the
group
's
total
output
target
,
or
ceiling
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
concept
of
disproportionate
quotas
for
those
with
unused
capacity
,
advanced
there
in
an
Iranian
proposal
,
was
generally
endorsed
by
the
ministers
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
end
politics
got
in
the
way
.
<END>
<START>
Libya
accepted
Iran
's
proposal
only
so
long
as
it
was
promised
production
parity
with
Kuwait
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
United
Arab
Emirates
,
a
chronic
quota
cheater
,
refused
to
give
any
guarantee
it
would
change
its
ways
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
oil
ministers
continue
to
study
the
plan
,
and
it
will
probably
be
the
basis
for
discussion
at
next
month
's
meeting
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
understood
several
compromises
already
have
been
worked
into
the
plan
.
<END>
<START>
The
ceiling
would
be
lifted
to
21.5
million
barrels
to
provide
Kuwait
and
the
United
Arab
Emirates
much
higher
official
quotas
while
reducing
percentage
shares
of
some
others
.
<END>
<START>
Libya
's
previous
conditions
are
no
longer
considered
a
problem
,
although
the
United
Arab
Emirates
is
still
an
issue
.
<END>
<START>
Saudi
Arabia
,
OPEC
's
kingpin
,
also
has
surfaced
as
a
possible
obstacle
,
some
OPEC
sources
said
.
<END>
<START>
Insisting
on
a
24.5
%
share
of
any
ceiling
,
Saudi
officials
have
long
pressed
for
the
pro
rata
distribution
of
increases
to
all
members
.
<END>
<START>
Some
of
the
proposed
modifications
since
,
however
,
call
on
Saudi
Arabia
to
``
give
back
''
to
the
production-sharing
pool
a
token
23,000
barrels
.
<END>
<START>
Though
tiny
,
that
's
a
reduction
in
its
share
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Nazer
,
the
Saudi
oil
minister
,
reiterated
here
that
the
kingdom
would
insist
on
maintaining
its
percentage
share
of
OPEC
production
under
any
quota
revisions
.
<END>
<START>
``
Under
any
circumstances
,
Saudi
Arabia
should
get
more
''
rather
than
less
,
Mr.
Nazer
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
statement
is
likely
to
sharpen
the
debate
within
France
's
military
establishment
over
the
Rafale
,
which
is
made
by
Avions
Marcel
Dassault-Breguet
Aviation
SA
.
<END>
<START>
The
air
force
is
to
take
at
least
250
more
.
<END>
<START>
Officially
,
the
statement
is
n't
an
attack
on
the
Rafale
.
<END>
<START>
Adm.
Goupil
said
that
when
the
F-18s
wear
out
,
the
navy
is
prepared
to
take
Rafales
to
replace

.
<END>
<START>
But
unofficially
,
senior
navy
officials
sharply
criticize
the
Rafale
as
an
air
force

ill-suited
to
carrier
use
.
<END>
<START>

they
never
said

publicly

they
have
made
no
secret
of
their
preference
for
the
F-18
on
operational
grounds
.
<END>
<START>
Adm.
Goupil
's
comments
are
likely
to
inflame
the
broader
dispute
within
the
military
establishment
here
over
the
role
of
Dassault
.
<END>
<START>
Although
government-controlled
,
Dassault
still
is
run
by
the
founder
's
son
,
Chairman
Serge
Dassault
,
who
has
fiercely
protected
his
company
's
independence
.
<END>
<START>
So
far
,
Mr.
Dassault
has
resisted
pressure
to
change
.
<END>
<START>
What
brought
the
naval

to
a
head
is
that
the
Crusaders
are

,

.
<END>
<START>
Adm.
Goupil
,
a

,

that
the
last
other
country
to

,

,

two

.
<END>
<START>

here
.
<END>
<START>
Adm.
Goupil

's

,

.

<START>

from

earlier
,

.
<END>

bureau

the

that
discouraged

and

.
<END>
<START>

by

290,782
yen
-LRB-
$
2,052.10
-RRB-
in
August
.
<END>
<START>

0.6
%
from
a
year

before

.
<END>
<START>

by

was
down
0.6
%
to
309,381
yen
from
a
year

.
<END>
<START>

of
wage-earning
families
in
the
month
eased
1.2
%
to
438,845
yen
from
the
previous
year
.

<START>
For
Cathay
Pacific
Airways
,
the
smooth
ride
may
be
ending
.
<END>
<START>
Securities
analysts
,
many
of
whom
scrapped
their
buy
recommendations
after
seeing
Cathay
's
interim
figures
,
believe
more
jolts
lie
ahead
.
<END>
<START>
Fuel
and
personnel
costs
are
rising
,
and
tourism
in
and
through
Hong
Kong
remains
clouded
by
China
's
turmoil
since
the
June
4
killings
in
Beijing
.
<END>
<START>
And
tough
competition
in
the
air-freight
market
is
cutting
into
an
important
sideline
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
sense
is
we
would
never
be
in
a
position
again
where
everything
works
for
us
the
way
it
did
before
,
''
says
Rod
Eddington
,
Cathay
's
commercial
director
.
<END>
<START>
These
factors
are
further
complicated
by
the
airline
's
push
to
transform
itself
from
a
regional
carrier
to
an
international
one
,
Ms.
Hall
says
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Hall
expects
Cathay
's
profit
to
grow
around
13
%
annually
this
year
and
next
.
<END>
<START>
In
1988
,
it
earned
$
2.82
billion
Hong
Kong
-LRB-
US$
361.5
million
-RRB-
on
revenue
of
HK$
11.79
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Cathay
is
taking
several
steps
to
bolster
business
.
<END>
<START>
One
step
is
to
beef
up
its
fleet
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
to
aircraft
from
Boeing
Co.
,
Cathay
announced
earlier
this
year
an
order
for
as
many
as
20
Airbus
A330-300s
.
<END>
<START>
Cathay
also
is
moving
some
of
its
labor-intensive
data-processing
operations
outside
Hong
Kong
.
<END>
<START>
Some
jobs
already
have
been
moved
to
Australia
,
and
there
are
plans
to
place
others
in
Canada
.
<END>
<START>
David
Bell
,
a
spokesman
for
the
airline
,
says
the
move
is
partly
aimed
at
retaining
existing
staff
who
are
leaving
to
secure
foreign
passports
ahead
of
1997
.
<END>
<START>
Cathay
is
working
to
promote
Hong
Kong
as
a
destination
worth
visiting
on
its
own
merits
,
rather
than
just
a
stopover
.
<END>
<START>
Although
the
June
4
killings
in
Beijing
have
hurt
its
China
flights
,
Cathay
's
other
routes
have
retained
high
load
factors
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Eddington
regards
promoting
Hong
Kong
as
an
important
part
of
attracting
visitors
from
Japan
,
South
Korea
and
Taiwan
,
where
the
number
of
people
looking
to
travel
abroad
has
surged
.
<END>
<START>
Cathay
officials
decline
to
comment
on
the
speculation
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Eddington
sees
alliances
with
other
carriers
--
particularly
Cathay
's
recent
link
with
AMR
Corp.
's
American
Airlines
--
as
an
important
part
of
Cathay
's
strategy
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
believe
Cathay
is
approached
for
such
swaps
by
other
carriers
on
a
regular
basis
,
particularly
as
the
popularity
of
share
exchanges
has
grown
among
European
carriers
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
think
alliances
are
very
important
,
''
Mr.
Eddington
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
we
'd
rather
put
funds
into
our
own
business
rather
than
someone
else
's
.
<END>
<START>
I
'm
not
sure
cross-ownership
would
necessarily
make
things
smoother
.
''
<END>
<START>
``
We
'll
never

a
big

in
the
U.S.
,
and
they
'll
never
have
one
as
big
as

,
''
Mr.

.
<END>
<START>
``
But
this

,

will
coordinate

Boston
,
New

,
Chicago

.
<END>
<START>

this

to
places

Bangkok
,

.
''
<END>
<START>

,

65

.

<START>
MERRILL
LYNCH
READY
ASSETS
TRUST
:
8.52
%
.
<END>
<START>
Annualized
average
rate
of
return
after
expenses
for
the
past
30
days
;
not
a
forecast
of
future
returns
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
hard-hit
Marina
neighborhood
,
life
after
the
earthquake
is
often
all
too
real
,
but
sometimes
surreal
.
<END>
<START>
Some
scenes
:
--
Saturday
morning
,
a
resident
was
given
15
minutes
to
scurry
into
a
sagging
building
and
reclaim
what
she
could
of
her
life
's
possessions
.
<END>
<START>
Saturday
night
she
dined
in
an
emergency
shelter
on
salmon
steaks
prepared
by
chefs
from
one
of
the
city
's
four-star
restaurants
.
<END>
<START>
--
Mayor
Art
Agnos
stands
in
the
glare
of
television
lights
trying
to
explain
for
the
20th
time
why
the
city
is
severely
restricting
access
to
badly
damaged
structures
.
<END>
<START>
A
couple
in
fashionable
spandex
warm-up
suits
jogs
by
,
headphones
jauntily
in
place
,
weaving
their
way
along
a
street
of
fractured
and
fallen
houses
.
<END>
<START>
At
a
nearby
corner
,
they
swerve
perilously
close
to
a
listing
apartment
house
,
oblivious
to
any
danger
.
<END>
<START>
A
policeman
shakes
his
head
in
amazement
as
he
steers
them
away
.
<END>
<START>
--
A
young
woman
who
has
been
out
of
town
shows
up
at
the
Marina
Middle
School
to
learn
that
her
apartment
is
on
the
condemned
list
.
<END>
<START>
She
is
told
she
ca
n't
enter
unless
she
is
accompanied
by
an
inspector
.
<END>
<START>
She
bursts
into
tears
and
walks
away
.
<END>
<START>
Nearby
,
five
temporary
residents
of
the
school
shelter
sit
on
stools
,
having
their
necks
and
backs
kneaded
by
volunteer
masseuses
.
<END>
<START>
The
Marina
rescue
center
offered
a
very
San
Franciscan
response
to
the
disaster
.
<END>
<START>
The
cafeteria
offered
donated
croissants
and
brie
for
breakfast
,
and
for
dinner
,
pasta
salad
and
chocolate
mousse
torts
along
with
the
salmon
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
has
been
a
15-pound
earthquake
for
me
,
''
said
resident
Joan
O'Shea
,
who
works
in
an
acupuncturist
's
office
.
<END>
<START>
She
and
some
friends
are
considering
offering
earthquake
victims
free
yoga
classes
and
``
aroma
therapy
''
--
massages
with
scented
oils
.
<END>
<START>
She
finds
the
response
of
Marina
residents
--
primarily
yuppies
and
elderly
people
--
to
the
devastation
of
their
homes
``
incredible
.
<END>
<START>
People
have
been
very
respectful
of
each
other
.
<END>
<START>
I
do
n't
know
if
this
would
have
happened
somewhere
else
.
''
<END>
<START>
Out
on
the
streets
,
some
residents
of
badly
damaged
buildings
were
allowed
a
15-minute
scavenger
hunt
through
their
possessions
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
so
weird
to
have
to
decide
what
's
really
important
to
you
,
''
said
Barbara
May
.
<END>
<START>
She
went
first
for
personal
mementos
.
<END>
<START>
In
post-earthquake
parlance
,
her
building
is
a
``
red
.
''
<END>
<START>
After
being
inspected
,
buildings
with
substantial
damage
were
color-coded
.
<END>
<START>
Green
allowed
residents
to
re-enter
;
yellow
allowed
limited
access
;
red
allowed
residents
one
last
entry
to
gather
everything
they
could
within
15
minutes
.
<END>
<START>
Reds
and
yellows
went
about
their
business
with
a
kind
of
measured
grimness
.
<END>
<START>
Some
frantically
dumped
belongings
into
pillowcases
,
others
threw
goods
out
windows
.
<END>
<START>
It
did
n't
help
that
on
Saturday
,
after
three
days
of
sunshine
,
it
rained
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
guys
are
going
for
their
skis
,
their
stereos
,
their
personal
computers
,
''
said
Frank
Fitzgerald
,
who
helped
others
empty
their
apartments
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
women
wanted
photo
albums
,
a
certain
brooch
,
kind
of
sentimental
things
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
showed
an
unbroken
,
still-ticking
pocket
watch
that
he
retrieved
for
one
woman
.
<END>
<START>
It
belonged
to
her
grandfather
.
<END>
<START>
Some
residents
defied
orders
and
returned
to
``
red
''
buildings
to
retrieve
goods
.
<END>
<START>
A
policewoman
had
to
be
called
in
to
make
her
leave
;
the
policewoman
helped
carry
out
one
last
load
.
<END>
<START>
Enforcement
of
restricted-entry
rules
was
sporadic
,
residents
said
.
<END>
<START>
One
man
trying
to
remove
his
car
was
told
by
officials
to
get
out
of
his
garage
.
<END>
<START>
When
he
sneaked
back
later
to
try
again
,
a
different
policeman
offered
to
help
him
get
the
car
out
.
<END>
<START>
The
Marina
also
has
become
the
focal
point
of
city
efforts
to
reunite
residents
with
any
pets
that
may
have
fled
or
become
lost
during
the
earthquake
.
<END>
<START>
On
lampposts
along
Fillmore
Street
,
a
major
Marina
artery
,
posters
were
offering
a
$
100
reward
for
a
cat
lost
during
the
quake
.
<END>
<START>
The
San
Francisco
Society
for
the
Prevention
of
Cruelty
to
Animals
also
has
been
providing
medical
care
,
food
,
water
and
foster
homes
for
quake-displaced
animals
.
<END>
<START>
The
SPCA
says
it
has
received
more
than
100
requests
for
foster
homes
on
behalf
of
dogs
and
cats
,
though
some
people
have
sought
temporary
homes
for
birds
and
fish
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
one
parakeet
owner
returning
home
found
that
her
apartment
,
like
many
others
in
the
Marina
,
did
n't
have
heat
.
<END>
<START>
``
She
can
stay
there
with
no
heat
,
but
for
a
parakeet
,
that
can
be
deadly
,
''
says
Daralee
Konowitch
,
animalcare
services
manager
for
the
SPCA
.
<END>
<START>
A
warm
foster
home
has
been
found
.
<END>
<START>
But
turn
into
the
shopping
center
's
parking
lot
,
and
one
could
be
in
the
safe
,
busy
mall
of
a
prosperous
suburb
.
<END>
<START>
Only
it
is
safer
,
and
busier
.
<END>
<START>
The
Watts
mall
has
annual
sales
of
more
than
$
350
per
leasable
square
foot
;
the
figure
for
a
comparable
suburban
shopping
center
would
be
$
200
.
<END>
<START>
Three
other
Haagen
shopping
centers
in
the
Watts
area
are
doing
almost
as
well
.
<END>
<START>
Major
regional
and
national
chain
stores
are
replaced
by
mom-and-pop
operations
offering
poorer-quality
merchandise
at
higher
prices
.
<END>
<START>
Along
with
the
exodus
of
shopping
opportunities
is
an
exodus
of
the
jobs
that
the
major
chains
used
to
provide
to
community
residents
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
there
is
even
more
to
the
Vermont-Slauson
Center
than
a
good
place
to
shop
.
<END>
<START>
The
center
improves
the
community
image
to
outsiders
as
well
,
and
may
help
to
arrest
,
or
even
reverse
,
the
exodus
of
capital
and
investment
.
<END>
<START>
An
additional
benefit
is
the
creation
of
jobs
.
<END>
<START>
This
starts
in
the
construction
phase
through
the
use
of
minority
contractors
and
local
workers
.
<END>
<START>
It
continues
through
the
life
of
the
center
;
the
Vermont-Slauson
Center
has
created
500
permanent
private-sector
jobs
at
a
one-time
cost
in
public
funds
of
only
$
2,500
per
job
.
<END>
<START>
And
that
is
before
consideration
of
increased
state
and
local
revenues
from
taxes
and
fees
on
sales
,
real
estate
,
licenses
and
the
like
.
<END>
<START>
Bradford
Crowe
,
director
of
the
mayor
's
City
Economic
Development
Office
,
says
:
``
There
is
no
question
that
Vermont-Slauson
had
a
halo
effect
on
the
surrounding
neighborhood
.
<END>
<START>
Another
benefit
is
that
substantial
percentages
of
the
proprietors
in
these
centers
are
minority
businessmen
and
women
.
<END>
<START>
Children
from
the
community
will
have
worthier
role
models
than
the
drug
kingpins
.
<END>
<START>
So
what
's
the
catch
?
<END>
<START>
Primarily
that
putting
one
of
these
inner-city
deals
together
takes
time
,
patience
,
breadth
of
vision
and
negotiating
skills
that
not
all
developers
possess
.
<END>
<START>
Security
costs
are
also
quite
high
.
<END>
<START>
One
of
these
centers
can
involve
years
of
negotiating
with
numerous
public
agencies
,
local
political
leaders
,
and
citizen
groups
,
and
with
prospective
tenants
and
sources
of
financing
.
<END>
<START>
Suburban
deals
are
not
without
their
delays
and
complications
--
inner-city
deals
just
have
more
of
them
.
<END>
<START>
Security
at
a
typical
Haagen
inner-city
center
is
impressive
,
but
unobtrusive
.
<END>
<START>
The
entire
site
is
enclosed
by
a
6-to-8-foot-high
ornamental
iron
fence
with
a
small
number
of
remote-controlled
gates
.
<END>
<START>
Shrubs
and
flowers
give
it
a
pleasing
and
non-fortress-like
appearance
.
<END>
<START>
Infrared
motion
detectors
and
closed-circuit
TV
cameras
monitor
the
entire
center
;
lighting
levels
are
three
to
five
times
the
industry
standard
.
<END>
<START>
Local
law
enforcement
is
present
in
a
sub-station
occupying
space
donated
by
the
center
.
<END>
<START>
These
features
are
also
used
in
Matanky
Realty
Group
's
Grand
Boulevard
Plaza
.
<END>
<START>
Haagen
has
its
own
large
security
force
of
well-trained
and
well-paid
personnel
on
round-the-clock
duty
at
each
center
.
<END>
<START>
Security
is
60
%
to
70
%
of
the
common
area
charges
of
these
centers
,
vs.
an
industry
average
of
about
15
%
.
<END>
<START>
Many
of
these
programs
no
longer
exist
,
or
have
been
severely
cut
back
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
since
these
centers
appear
to
pay
for
themselves
,
there
is
nothing
to
prevent
state
and
local
governments
from
enacting
legislation
with
similar
provisions
.
<END>
<START>
These
programs
could
be
expanded
to
focus
on
funds
for
project
planning
,
identifying
sources
of
funds
,
and
for
acquiring
a
site
and
preparing
it
.
<END>
<START>
Combatting
crime
and
the
fear
of
it
in
inner-city
commercial
areas
should
give
Enterprise
Zones
more
success
than
most
have
enjoyed
to
date
.
<END>
<START>
With
many
suburban
areas
basically
overbuilt
with
shopping
centers
,
inner-city
areas
may
represent
a
major
new
untapped
market
for
investment
.
<END>
<START>
New
approaches
to
mall
design
and
operation
make
it
possible
to
tap
these
markets
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
risks
and
rewards
are
reasonable
,
developers
will
respond
.
<END>
<START>
Government
officials
who
wonder
how
important
it
is
for
them
to
encourage
development
in
high-risk
areas
should
visit
Vermont-Slauson
and
Grand
Boulevard
Plaza
and
decide
for
themselves
.
<END>
<START>
The
answer
will
be
obvious
.
<END>

Mr.
Titus
is
a

at
the

Department
's
National

.

,

.

<START>
One
company
recently
was
listed
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
,
and
another
will
join
the
Big
Board
from
the
over-the-counter
market
this
week
.
<END>
<START>
Putnam
Investment
Grade
Municipal
Trust
,
Boston
,
was
listed
with
the
symbol
PGM
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
closed-end
management
investment
company
trades
shares
of
beneficial
interest
.
<END>
<START>
It
invests
primarily
in
tax-exempt
municipal
securities
.
<END>
<START>
Hibernia
Corp.
,
a
New
Orleans
bank
holding
company
,
will
join
the
Big
Board
Thursday
under
HIB
.
<END>
<START>
Three
companies
began
trading
over
the
counter
.
<END>
<START>
Exabyte
Corp.
,
a
Boulder
,
Colo.
,
maker
of
high-capacity
tape
cartridge
systems
used
to
back
up

,
started
OTC

with

.
<END>
<START>
Rally
's
Inc.
,

,

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
Sierra
Tucson
Cos.
,

,
Ariz.
,
started
trading

STSN
.
<END>
<START>
It
operates

.
<END>
<START>
Separately
,
on
the
Pacific
Stock
Exchange
,
put
and
call
options
on
the
common
stock
of
Aldus
Corp.
started
trading
.
<END>
<START>
Aldus
,
Seattle
,
makes
computer
software
products
.
<END>
<START>
Options
give
a
holder
the
right
,
but
not
the
obligation
,
to
buy
or
sell
a
security
at
a
set
price
within
a
set
period
of
time
.
<END>
<START>
Dow
Chemical
Co.
said
its
Destec
Energy
Inc.
unit
has
agreed
to
buy
PSE
Inc.
,
a
Houston
energy
company
,
in
a
deal
valued
at
about
$
115
million
.
<END>
<START>
Dow
,
of
Midland
,
Mich.
,
said
its
unit
will
begin
by
Thursday
a
tender
offer
of
$
12.25
a
share
for
all
PSE
common
shares
outstanding
.
<END>
<START>
Among
other
conditions
,
the
offer
depends
on
the
Dow
unit
acquiring
at
least
66
2/3
%
of
the
PSE
shares
outstanding
,
the
companies
said
in
a
joint
statement
Friday
.
<END>
<START>
PSE
has
about
9.2
million
shares
outstanding
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
the
approximately
$
115
million
acquisition
price
includes
its
total
$
33
million
of
long-term
debt
outstanding
.
<END>
<START>
PSE
is
a
designer
and
operator
of
energy-cogeneration
facilities
and
had
1988
sales
of
$
234
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
is
owner
and
operator
,
or
an
equity
partner
,
in
six
cogeneration
facilities
--
two
in
Texas
and
four
in
California
.
<END>
<START>
If
growth
regains
its
glamour
among
investors
,
a
sluggish
segment
of
the
Nasdaq
over-the-counter
market
could
show
some
flash
.
<END>
<START>
Some
stock
pickers
already
are
targeting
the
OTC
market
,
where
,
they
say
,
await
plenty
of
small
-
and
medium-sized
growth
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
Best
of
all
,
they
add
,
these
growth
issues
,
unlike
their
big
blue-chip
cousins
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
,
are
languishing
at
depressed
prices
.
<END>
<START>
Against
such
a
backdrop
,
companies
with
proven
track
records
of
earnings
gains
of
20
%
or
so
annually
have
extra
appeal
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
market
will
have
to
look
for
a
new
theme
now
and
that
theme
will
be
a
return
to
growth
,
''
declares
Mary
Farrell
,
a
PaineWebber
analyst
.
<END>
<START>
Among
her
OTC
picks
are
Oshkosh
B'Gosh
and
A&W
Brands
.
<END>
<START>
Like
many
OTC
growth
issues
,
they
have
market
values
--
as
measured
by
stock
price
times
shares
outstanding
--
of
roughly
$
100
million
to
$
500
million
.
<END>
<START>
Some
like
to
specialize
in
growth
companies
whose
shares
have
n't
traded
publicly
very
long
.
<END>
<START>
These
are
sometimes
dubbed
``
emerging
''
growth
companies
,
though
they
also
have
expanding-profit
track
records
.
<END>
<START>
While
many
growth
stocks
are
small
,
not
all
small
stocks
have
earnings-growth
momentum
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Palicka
's
picks
from
the
OTC
market
include
Legent
,
Mail
Boxes
Etc.
,
and
Payco
American
.
<END>
<START>
The
main
argument
for
growth
stocks
is
their
usually
superior
performance
in
a
slowing
economy
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
the
market
refocuses
on
earnings
,
we
should
get
better
valuations
of
growth
stocks
,
''
says
L.
Keith
Mullins
,
a
growth-stock
analyst
at
Morgan
Stanley
.
<END>
<START>
Eventually
,
he
believes
,
investors
will
be
willing
to
pay
higher
prices
for
companies
with
proven
track
records
of
earnings
growth
.
<END>
<START>
In
anticipation
of
that
shift
,
he
and
other
analysts
are
encouraging
their
clients
to
buy
such
issues
now
.
<END>
<START>
Understandably
,
smaller
growth
stocks
have
n't
been
in
favor
recently
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
issue
on
Standard
&
Poor
's
500-stock
Index
gained
35
%
last
year
,
Ms.
Farrell
of
PaineWebber
says
.
<END>
<START>
Smaller-stock
earnings
,
by
comparison
,
rose
between
15
%
and
20
%
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
earnings
growth
took
a
back
seat
to
cash
flow
,
restructuring
and
takeover
potential
,
and
breakup
value
as
the
preferred
stock-picking
standards
for
much
of
the
year
.
<END>
<START>
Also
,
the
smaller
growth
stocks
are
n't
widely
traded
,
and
so
are
harder
to
buy
and
sell
quickly
than
blue
chips
.
<END>
<START>
The
Nasdaq
Composite
has
gained
23
%
this
year
,
but
that
's
largely
due
to
the
100
largest
nonfinancial
stocks
,
which
have
soared
30
%
.
<END>
<START>
``
People
are
naturally
suspicious
of
them
,
''
says
Mr.
Mullins
of
Morgan
Stanley
.
<END>
<START>
Among
his
favorites
in
his
firm
's
index
are
Legent
,
Silicon
Graphics
and
Novell
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
more
money
managers
are
reassured
that
profit
is
regaining
importance
.
<END>
<START>
Barney
Hallingby
,
managing
director
of
research
at
Hambrecht
&
Quist
,
also
believes
earnings
growth
is
beginning
to
play
a
greater
part
in
investors
'
buying
decisions
.
<END>
<START>
On
Friday
,
Hambrecht
&
Quist
added
St.
Jude
Medical
to
the
list
of
20
stocks
it
strongly
recommends
.
<END>
<START>
The
opinion
is
largely
based
on
the
company
's
earnings
momentum
,
Mr.
Hallingby
says
.
<END>
<START>
St.
Jude
's
market
value
on
Nasdaq
exceeds
$
1
billion
,
so
it
is
n't
a
small
stock
.
<END>
<START>
The
medical
devices
maker
's
earnings
rose
nearly
35
%
in
1987
from
1986
,
and
75
%
in
1988
.
<END>
<START>
Kurt
Kruger
,
who
follows
the
stock
for
Hambrecht
&
Quist
,
anticipates
that
the
company
's
net
income
will
grow
51
%
to
$
2.15
a
share
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
St.
Jude
finished
up
1/4
to
44
1/2
on
Friday
.
<END>
<START>
Friday
's
Market
Activity
<END>
<START>
The
Nasdaq
Composite
Index
eased
0.13
to
470.67
.
<END>
<START>
The
composite
finished
up
0.7
%
from
last
Friday
's
close
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
a
busy
week
for
OTC
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
Friday
's
volume
totaled
158.2
million
shares
;
the
daily
average
for
the
week
was
a
bustling
176.7
million
.
<END>
<START>
Valley
National
lost
1
3/8
to
17
1/8
on
volume
of
1.9
million
shares
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
reported
a
big
third-quarter
loss
on
Thursday
.
<END>
<START>
Merchants
Bank
of
New
York
lost
1
to
106
after

that
its
third-quarter
net
income
fell
to
$
1.62
a
share
from
last
year
's
$
1.67
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Eliot
Savings
Bank
lost
7/8
to
1
5/8
after
reporting
that
it
had
a
$
4.8
million
loss
in
the
latest
third
quarter
mostly
because
of
loan-loss

.
<END>
<START>
In

1988
quarter
,
the
bank
earned
$
1.1
million
.
<END>
<START>
One
bank
stock
was
a
winner
.
<END>
<START>
BanPonce
jumped
4
1/2
to
47
3/4
after

to

by
Banco
Popular
de

Rico
for
$

a

.
<END>
<START>
Banco
Popular
,

,

1
1/4
to
21
1/2
.
<END>
<START>
Sierra
Tucson
,
an

,

the

.
<END>
<START>
The

's

12
1/2
,

of
12
,

.
<END>
<START>
Sierra

center
.
<END>
<START>
Among

,

down
6
1/4

.

<START>

28

a

.
<END>
<START>

International

3
1/4

1/4
.
<END>
<START>

and

has

to

.
<END>

.

.

5/8

5/8

1/4

.

''

,

.

.

,

,

.

<START>

<START>
Chicago
&
North
Western
Acquisition
Corp.
--
$
475
million
of

debentures
,

Oct.
15
,

,

at
par
to

14.75
%
.
<END>
<START>
The

will
be
reset
in
one
year
at
a
rate
that
will
give
the
issue
a
market
value
of
101
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
the
maximum
coupon
rate
on
the
issue
when
it
is
reset
can
only
be
15.5
%
.
<END>
<START>
Debenture
holders
will
also
receive
the
equivalent
of
10
%
of
the
common
stock
of
CNW
Holdings
.
<END>
<START>
The
issue
is
noncallable
for
five
years
and
has
a
sinking
fund
starting
in
2000
to
retire
50
%
of
the
issue
before
