.
<END>
<START>
Rated
single-B-2
by
Moody
's
Investors
Service
Inc.
and
single-B-minus
by
Standard
&
Poor
's
Corp.
,
the
issue
will
be
sold
through
underwriters
led
by
Donaldson
Lufkin
&
Jenrette
Securities
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
For
bankers
and
regulators
,
Arizona
is
looking
more
like
Texas
every
day
.
<END>
<START>
First
Interstate
said
the
unit
,
bludgeoned
by
Arizona
's
worsening
real-estate
woes
,
will
have
a
$
174
million
loss
for
the
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
First
Interstate
took
a
huge
$
350
million
provision
for
loan
losses
at
the
Arizona
bank
.
<END>
<START>
First
Interstate
made
the
move
under
pressure
from
regulators
.
<END>
<START>
The
action
capped
a
spurt
of
grim
Arizona
banking
news
for
the
third
quarter
,
and
emphatically
signaled
that
Arizona
is
challenging
Texas
's
long
reign
as
banking
's
busiest
graveyard
.
<END>
<START>
Earlier
last
week
,
Valley
National
Corp.
,
the
state
's
largest
locally
owned
banking
company
,
reported
a
$
72.2
million
loss
and
suspended
its
dividend
.
<END>
<START>
Security
Pacific
Corp.
said
third-quarter
credit
losses
surged
a
third
to
$
109
million
,
mainly
because
of
sour
Arizona
real-estate
loans
.
<END>
<START>
New
York-based
Chase
Manhattan
Corp.
took
an
$
85
million
Arizona-related
charge
.
<END>
<START>
When
First
Interstate
balked
,
arguing
that
the
figure
was
too
high
,
regulators
responded
by
raising
their
recommendation
to
$
350
million
.
<END>
<START>
``
At
that
point
,
-LCB-
First
Interstate
-RCB-
decided
it
was
the
better
part
of
valor
not
to
negotiate
further
,
''
said
one
industry
official
close
to
the
talks
.
<END>
<START>
Thomas
P.
Marrie
,
chief
financial
officer
,
would
n't
comment
about
the
details
of
the
negotiations
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
the
provision
``
was
n't
forced
upon
us
,
but
the
regulators
made
it
very
clear
what
they
thought
was
an
appropriate
number
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
tough
regulatory
stance
portends
large
future
losses
,
especially
at
the
state
's
thrifts
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
Western
Savings
&
Loan
Association
,
which
is
now
in
conservatorship
,
had
tangible
capital-assets
minus
liabilities
--
of
a
negative
$
357.4
million
at
June
30
.
<END>
<START>
It
had
a
$
258.9
million
loss
in
the
second
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
it
still
held
$
916.3
million
of
repossessed
real
estate
,
for
which
it
maintains
no
reserves
whatsoever
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
had
$
479.7
million
of
past-due
loans
;
its
level
of
reserves
against
those
was
n't
immediately
available
,
though
it
is
believed
to
be
small
.
<END>
<START>
The
rapid
deterioration
of
the
Arizona
thrifts
only
adds
to
the
ever-swelling
cost
of
the
government
's
massive
thrift
bailout
,
officially
estimated
at
about
$
166
billion
.
<END>
<START>
They
have
no
reserves
against
the
real
estate
,
and
their
reserves
against
the
loans
are
miniscule
compared
with
the
levels
of
reserves
banks
are
moving
to
set
up
.
<END>
<START>
The
thrifts
had
a
combined
loss
of
$
487.8
million
in
the
second
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Other
lenders
have
been
recovering
only
50
cents
to
60
cents
on
the
dollar
on
foreclosed
Arizona
property
,
if
they
can
sell
it
at
all
.
<END>
<START>
Many
Arizona
real-estate
experts
think
the
worst
may
be
yet
to
come
.
<END>
<START>
Ralph
Shattuck
,
publisher
of
Foreclosure
Update
newsletter
,
said
foreclosures
have
climbed
to
about
1,482
a
month
just
in
Maricopa
County
,
where
Phoenix
is
located
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
up
from
about
687
a
month
in
1985
,
and
it
's
accelerating
:
So
far
this
month
,
foreclosures
are
averaging
about
85
a
day
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
frightening
,
''
Mr.
Shattuck
said
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
Mr.
Shattuck
and
others
said
residential
real
estate
,
which
had
remained
fairly
strong
through
most
of
the
downturn
,
is
beginning
to
comprise
more
and
more
of
the
foreclosures
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
generally
frail
condition
of
Arizona
's
lenders
means
there
is
little
capital
available
in
the
state
to
shore
up
the
economy
and
slow
down
the
slide
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
reasonable
to
say
there
is
not
a
solvent
S&L
in
the
state
and
the
amount
of
viable
bank
capital
is
very
low
,
''
said
Mr.
Jackson
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're
going
to
see
another
big
wave
of
failures
and
defaults
between
now
and
year-end
...
.
<END>
<START>
The
only
thing
a
lot
of
these
lenders
can
get
out
of
their
mouth
now
is
:
`
Pay
me
in
60
days
.
'
''
<END>
<START>
First
Interstate
had
a
$
214.4
million
loss
in
1988
's
third
quarter
,
mainly
from
writedowns
and
reserves
connected
with
its
Texas
operations
.
<END>
<START>
The
bank
's
Arizona
unit
holds
about
$
6
billion
of
First
Interstate
's
$
50
billion
of
assets
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Marrie
said
the
bank
expects
Arizona
real-estate
prices
,
which
plummeted
40
%
over
the
last
year
,
to
fall
another
20
%
before

.
<END>
<START>
Some
in

think

may
be

.
<END>
<START>

Interstate
said
its

outside
of
Arizona
``
achieved
results
as
expected
for
the
quarter
,
''
but
did
n't

results
.
<END>
<START>
First
Interstate
stock
closed
at
$
57.625
,
down
25
cents
,
in

Friday
on

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Marrie

in

``

.
''

<START>
Separately
,
Standard
&
Poor
's
Corp.
lowered
its
ratings
on
Valley
National
Corp.
's
senior
debt
to
double-B
from
double-B-plus
,
affecting
about
$
300
million
of
long-term
debt
.
<END>
<START>
S&P
also
lowered
ratings
on
unsecured

and
issues
backed
by
a
letter
of
credit
from
the
bank
holding
company
's
principal
unit
,
Valley
National
Bank
of
Arizona
.
<END>
<START>
The
ratings
service
said
the
downgrades
reflect
the
continued
slide
in
the
company
's
financial
condition
.
<END>
<START>
A
spokesman
for
Phoenix
,
Ariz.-based
Valley
National
,
said
the
concern
will
be
able
to
withstand
the
current
downturn
in
Arizona
real
estate
.
<END>
<START>
Commercial
paper
holders
have
reinvested
their
funds
,
he
said
,
and
consumer
deposits
have
been
up
in
the
last
few
days
.
<END>
<START>
Immunex
Corp.
said
its
scientists
isolated
a
molecule
which
may
hold
potential
as
a
treatment
for
disruptions
of
the
immune-system
,
ranging
from
organ-transplant
rejection
,
to
allergies
and
asthma
.
<END>
<START>
The
molecule
is
the
mouse
version
of
a
protein
called
the
interleukin-4
receptor
.
<END>
<START>
IL-4
is
a
hormone
which
directs
the
growth
and
function
of
white
blood
cells
involved
in
the
body
's
immune
response
.
<END>
<START>
The
IL-4
receptor
on
the
surface
of
such
cells
receives
the
hormone
's
message
to
rally
the
body
's
defense
.
<END>
<START>
A
soluble
form
of
the
receptor
might
turn
off
a
specific
part
of
the
immune
response
without
general
immune
suppression
,
the
company
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
IL-4
receptor
is
one
of
five
such
receptors
to
be
developed
and
tested
by
Receptech
Corp.
,
a
spinoff
of
Immunex
,
through
a
proposed
$
30
million
initial
public
offering
.
<END>
<START>
Immunex
will
contract
with
the
spinoff
to
provide
the
research
,
development
and
initial
testing
of
the
new
agents
.
<END>
<START>
Immunex
will
have
the
option
to
buy
back
Receptech
shares
after
five
years
.
<END>
<START>
The
following
issues
were
recently
filed
with
the
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
:
<END>
<START>
Heller
Financial
Inc.
,
an
indirect
subsidiary
of
Fuji
Bank
Ltd.
,
shelf
offering
of
up
to
$
1
billion
debt
securities
and
warrants
.
<END>
<START>
Jason
Overseas
Ltd.
,
proposed
offering
of
five
million
common
shares
,
via
Smith
Barney
&
Co.
and
Mabon
Nugent
&
Co
.
<END>
<START>
Millicom
Inc.
,
offering
of
$
60
million
subordinated
exchangeable
debentures
,
via
Bear
,
Stearns
&
Co.
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
Union
Tank
Car
Co.
,
offering
of
$
100
million
of
equipment
trust
certificates
,
via
Salomon
Brothers
.
<END>
<START>
Conner
dominates
the
market
for
hard-disk
drives
used
to
store
data
in
laptop
computers
.
<END>
<START>
Its
revenue
totaled
$
184.4
million
,
an
increase
of
172
%
from
$
67.8
million
a
year
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
nearly
tripled
to
$
479
million
,
from
$
160
million
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
a
faster
growth
rate
than
reported
by
Compaq
,
which
did
n't
post
similar
results
until
its
fourth
year
,
in
1986
.
<END>
<START>
But
Compaq
had
achieved
that
level
of
sales
faster
than
any
previous
manufacturing
start-up
.
<END>
<START>
Conner
's
performance
is
closely
tied
to
the
burgeoning
demand
for
battery-operated
computers
,
the
computer
industry
's
fastest-growing
segment
.
<END>
<START>
Today
,
Conner
controls
an
estimated
90
%
of
the
hard-disk
drive
market
for
laptop
computers
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
coming
months
,
however
,
this
is
likely
to
change
.
<END>
<START>
Next
month
,
Seagate
Technology
,
which
is
the
dominant
supplier
of
hard-disk
drives
for
personal
computers
,
plans
to
introduce
its
first
family
of
low-power
drives
for
battery-operated
computers
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
Japanese
are
likely
to
keep
close
on
Conner
's
heels
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
are
going
to
catch
up
,
''
said
David
Claridge
,
an
analyst
with
Hambrecht
&
Quist
.
<END>
<START>
Both
Toshiba
and
NEC
already
produce
hard-disk
drives
,
and
Sony
also
is
studying
the
field
,
Mr.
Claridge
said
.
<END>
<START>
But
Conner
is
n't
standing
still
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
,
the
company
introduced
four
products
,
three
of
which
are
aimed
at
a
hot
new
class
of
computers
called
notebooks
.
<END>
<START>
Each
of
the
three
drives
uses
a
mere
1.5
watts
of
power
and
one
weighs
just
5.5
ounces
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
continue
to
develop
products
faster
than
anyone
else
can
.
''
<END>
<START>
These
new
products
could
account
for
as
much
as
35
%
of
the
company
's
business
in
1990
,
Mr.
Conner
estimated
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're
not
afraid
of
obsoleting
some
of
our
old
stuff
to
stay
ahead
of
the
competition
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Conner
already
is
shipping
its
new
drives
.
<END>
<START>
Last
week
,
for
instance
,
Compaq
introduced
its
first
notebook
computer
to
rave
reviews
.
<END>
<START>
Conner
is
supplying
hard-disk
drives
for
the
machine
,
which
weighs
only
six
pounds
and
fits
in
a
briefcase
.
<END>
<START>
From
its
inception
,
Conner
has
targeted
the
market
for
battery-operated
machines
,
building
hard-disk
drives
that
are
smaller
and
use
far
less
power
than
those
offered
by
competitors
such
as
Seagate
.
<END>
<START>
The
availability
of
these
drives
,
in
turn
,
boosted
demand
for
laptop
computers
,
whose
usefulness
had
been
limited
because
of
lack
of
storage
.
<END>
<START>
Conner
also
makes
hard-disk
drives
for
desktop
computers
and
is
a
major
supplier
to
Compaq
,
which
as
of
July
owned
40
%
of
Conner
's
stock
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
to
Compaq
represented
26
%
of
Conner
's
business
in
its
third
quarter
,
compared
with
42
%
in
the
year-ago
period
.
<END>
<START>
Move
over
,
pornographic
phone
services
:
A
legal
service
with
a
``
900
''
number
has
been
launched
in
California
.
<END>
<START>
A
Newport
Beach
law
firm
started
the
pay-as-you-go
legal
service
,
called
Telelawyer
,
using
MCI
Communication
Corp.
's
toll-tele-phone
service
.
<END>
<START>
Cane
&
Associates
touts
its
$
2-a-minute
service
as
the
``
cheapest
legal
hour
you
'll
ever
find
.
''
<END>
<START>
Though
the
service
is
available
only
in
California
,
Telelawyer
founder
Michael
Cane
says
he
plans
to
franchise
it
in
other
states
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Cane
stresses
that
he
is
n't
using
the
telephone
to
lure
clients
to
his
doorstep
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
will
only
deal
with
clients
on
the
phone
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
have
no
in-office
business
.
''
<END>
<START>
Telelawyer
is
apparently
the
only
telephone
service
that
offers
the
telephone
equivalent
of
an
office
visit
.
<END>
<START>
Local
bar
associations
in
some
states
have
numbers
that
provide
free
tape-recorded
messages
explaining
certain
areas
of
the
law
.
<END>
<START>
There
also
are
``
800
''
hotlines
which
refer
people
to
lawyers
,
usually
personal-injury
specialists
,
for
in-office
consultation
.
<END>
<START>
When
a
caller
reaches
Telelawyer
by
dialing
900-TELELAW
,
a
receptionist
refers
the
call
to
one
of
six
attorneys
.
<END>
<START>
There
is
no
charge
for
research
--
only
for
time
on
the
phone
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
matter
requires
further
legal
work
or
litigation
,
Mr.
Cane
says
,
his
lawyers
may
refer
the
client
to
a
law
firm
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
says
Cane
&
Associates
does
n't
receive
referral
fees
.
<END>
<START>
So
far
,
says
Mr.
Cane
,
most
calls
have
involved
landlord-tenant
problems
,
tax
problems
,
divorce
,
and
probate
questions
.
<END>
<START>
The
firm
is
getting
about
50
calls
a
day
,
and
the
average
call
lasts
about
15
minutes
.
<END>
<START>
Out
of
the
$
2
charge
,
the
law
firm
pockets
about
$
1.55
.
<END>
<START>
JURY
CONVICTS
congressman
in
connection
with
Wedtech
Corp.
scandal
.
<END>
<START>
The
jury
also
convicted
them
of
extortion
in
obtaining
a
$
20,000
,
interest-free
loan
from
a
Wedtech
officer
.
<END>
<START>
The
jury
found
them
guilty
of
conspiracy
in
obtaining
the
payments
,
some
of
which
were
disguised
as
fees
for
consulting
services
from
Mrs.
Garcia
.
<END>
<START>
Wedtech
,
which
became
embroiled
in
political-corruption
cases
that
eventually
led
to
its
demise
,
formerly
was
a
minority-owned
South
Bronx
,
N.Y.
,
defense
contractor
.
<END>
<START>

J.M.
Little
,

of

U.S.

who
prosecuted
the
case
,
said
the
Garcia
trial
``
is
the
last
of
the
Wedtech
prosecutions
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Little
said
more
than
20
people
have
been
convicted
in
the
Wedtech
cases
,
including
former
U.S.
Rep.
Mario
Biaggi
-LRB-
D.
,
N.Y
.
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
Lawyers
for
the
Garcias
said
they
plan
to
appeal
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Garcia
,
who
represents
New
York
's
18th
congressional
district
,
which
includes
the
Bronx
,
said
he
has
n't
decided
whether
he
will
resign
.
<END>
<START>
Mrs.
Garcia
,
49
,
formerly
was
a
member
of
Mr.
Garcia
's

staff
.
<END>
<START>
The

were
cleared
of
four
other

,

the

of

and

.
<END>
<START>

Leonard
B.
Sand
set
the
Garcias
'

for
Jan.
5
.

<START>

SHEA
&

PARTNERS

leaving
to
form
a
new
firm
.

new
firm
,
Hutton
Ingram
Yuzek
Gainen
Carroll
&
Bertolotti
,
will
be
based
in
New
York
.
<END>
<START>
The
five
partners
who
resigned
from
Shea
&
Gould
late
last
week
are
Tom
Hutton
,
Sam
Ingram
,
Dean
Yuzek
,
Daniel
Carroll
and
Ernest
Bertolotti
.
<END>
<START>
They
will
be
joined
by
Larry
Gainen
,
who
resigned
from
the
firm
of
LePatner
,
Gainen
&
Block
.
<END>

Rubenstein
said
the
five
,
who
were
n't
on
Shea
&
Gould
's
management

,
``
are
leaving

.
''

Ingram
will
have
a
general
corporate
,
securities
,
real-estate
and
litigation
practice
,
and
a
substantial
practice
serving
the
professional-design
community
.

<START>
DISCIPLINARY
PROCEEDINGS
against
lawyers
open
to
public
in
Illinois
.
<END>
<START>
While
investigations
into
lawyer
misconduct
will
remain
secret
,
the
public
will
be
notified
once
a
formal
complaint
is
filed
against
an
attorney
.
<END>
<START>
The
actual
disciplinary
hearings
will
be
public
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
Illinois
attorneys
will
lose
the
right
to
sue
clients
who
file
malicious
complaints
against
them
.
<END>
<START>
Non-lawyers
will
be
added
to
the
inquiry
panels
that
look
into
allegations
of
misconduct
.
<END>
<START>
Illinois
joins
36
other
states
that
allow
public
participation
in
attorney-disciplinary
proceedings
and
32
states
that
open
disciplinary
hearings
to
the
public
,
according
to
the
American
Bar
Association
.
<END>
<START>
One
vocal
critic
of
the
changes
,
Chicago
lawyer
Warren
Lupel
,
says
non-lawyers
should
n't
be
on
the
inquiry
panels
because
they
are
unlikely
to
appreciate
the
nuances
of
attorney-client
relationships
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
he
says
,
publishing
the
names
of
lawyers
who
are
facing
charges
unnecessarily
subjects
them
to
public
derogation
.
<END>
<START>
Nevertheless
,
Mr.
Lupel
anticipates
no
legal
action
to
reverse
the
Illinois
Supreme
Court
's
decision
to
institute
the
changes
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
's
no
constitutional
right
involved
in
the
rule
change
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
do
n't
have
a
right
to
practice
.
<END>
<START>
You
only
have
a
privilege
to
practice
.
''
<END>
<START>
Drexel
does
n't
have
a
Delaware
office
,
but
the
New
York
firm
has
been
negotiating
settlements
that
would
allow
it
to
operate
freely
nationwide
despite
its
record
as
an
admitted
felon
.
<END>
<START>
The
firm
has
said
it
expects
to
pay
$
11.5
million
overall
to
settle
with
states
.
<END>
<START>
Drexel
pleaded
guilty
in
September
to
six
felony
counts
of
securities
and
mail
fraud
;
it
also
made
a
$
650
million
civil
settlement
with
the
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
.
<END>
<START>
Several
executives
said
another
potential
contender
is
WPP
Group
's
Ogilvy
&
Mather
agency
,
which
works
on
some
other
Philip
Morris
products
.
<END>
<START>
Both
Philip
Morris
and
Backer
Spielvogel
declined
to
comment
.
<END>
<START>
A
spokeswoman
for
Ogilvy
&
Mather
said
the
agency
does
n't
comment
on
``
idle
speculation
.
''
<END>
<START>
Also
mentioned
as
a
contender
was
TBWA
Advertising
,
but
the
company
denied
it
was
participating
.

<START>
The
loss
of
the
cigarette
account
would
be
a
severe
blow
to
Wells
Rich
.
<END>
<START>
Benson
&
Hedges
has
been
one
of
its
most
high-visibility
campaigns
,
as
well
as
one
of
its
largest
clients
.
<END>
<START>
The
account
billed
almost
$
60
million
last
year
,
according
to
Leading
National
Advertisers
.
<END>
<START>
But
Philip
Morris
has
scaled
back
ad
spending
on
the
brand
over
the
past
year
,
industry
executives
said
,
and
it
now
bills
about
$
30
million
to
$
40
million
.
<END>
<START>
Industry
executives
said
Philip
Morris
had
asked
the
other
agencies
to
create
campaigns
in
a
bid
to
stop
the
brand
's
slipping
market
share
.
<END>
<START>
The
brand
is
No.
7
overall
in
the
cigarette
business
,
Mr.
Maxwell
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
slip
has
come
despite
high-profile
ads
created
by
Wells
Rich
,
including
one
picturing
a
young
man
clad
only
in
pajama
bottoms
interrupting
a
festive
brunch
.
<END>
<START>
That
ad
generated
so
much
publicity
that
a
trade
magazine
launched
a
contest
for
its
readers
to
guess
who
the
guy
was
and
what
he
was
doing
.
<END>
<START>
Wells
Rich
first
popularized
the
Benson
&
Hedges
brand
more
than
20
years
ago
with
ads
portraying
,
among
other
things
,
an
elevator
door
closing
on
a
passenger
's
cigarette
.
<END>
<START>
The
brand
early
on
achieved
an
upscale
appeal
--
a
trait
that
some
analysts
believe
is
partly
responsible
for
its
staid
performance
.
<END>
<START>
Philip
Morris
,
trying
to
revive
the
Benson
&
Hedges
franchise
,
put
the
account
up
for
review
in
1986
.
<END>
<START>
Wells
Rich
Greene
,
however
,
in
an
effort
directed
by
Mary
Wells
Lawrence
,
emerged
the
victor
of
the
review
and
retained
the
business
.
<END>
<START>
Kenneth
Olshan
,
Wells
Rich
's
chairman
,
did
n't
return
phone
calls
seeking
comment
.
<END>
<START>
Its
victories
include
more
than
$
30
million
in
Sheraton
Corp.
business
and
an
assignment
from
Dun
&
Bradstreet
worth
$
5
million
to
$
10
million
.
<END>
<START>
This
city
is
girding
for
gridlock
today
as
hundreds
of
thousands
of
commuters
avoid
travel
routes
ravaged
by
last
week
's
earthquake
.
<END>
<START>
Estimates
of
damage
in
the
six-county
San
Francisco
Bay
area
neared
$
5
billion
,
excluding
the
cost
of
repairing
the
region
's
transportation
system
.
<END>
<START>
The
Bay
Bridge
,
the
main
artery
into
San
Francisco
from
the
east
,
will
be
closed
for
at
least

weeks
.
<END>
<START>
Part
of
the
bridge
collapsed
in
the
quake
,
which
registered
6.9
on
the
Richter
scale
.
<END>
<START>
The
bridge
normally
carries
250,000
commuters
a

.
<END>
<START>
Also
,

connecting

to
its

,

101

,

for

.
<END>
<START>
The

,

,

to

.
<END>
<START>
BART
has
increased

to
24

in

for

.
<END>
<START>
Most

will
be

from

of
Oakland
and

.
<END>
<START>
For

32

,

has

between
the
East

and
San
Francisco
.
<END>
<START>
That
tariff
is
too
stiff
for
some

District
wage

.
<END>
<START>
``
I
'll

,
''

,

.
<END>
<START>
Officials
expect

Bridge
to

of

,

.
<END>
<START>
``

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
About
23,000

during

.
<END>
<START>
About
130,000
vehicles
cross
during

.
<END>
<START>
Meetings

Inc.
's

and

raised
the

.
<END>
<START>
It

.
<END>
<START>
City

2

.
<END>
<START>
The

.
<END>
<START>
All

,

.
<END>
<START>
Among

in

.
<END>
<START>
The

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>

.
<END>
<START>
As

,

.

.

<START>
Bond
Corp
.
Holdings
Ltd.
posted
a
loss
for

1989
of
980.2
million
Australian
dollars
-LRB-
US$
762.4
million
-RRB-
,
the
largest
in
Australian

history
.
<END>
<START>
That
loss
compared
with
a

profit
of
A$
273.5
million
.
<END>
<START>
Operating

rose
69
%
to
A$
8.48
billion
from
A$
5.01
billion
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
net
interest
bill
jumped
85
%
to
A$
686.7
million
from
A$
371.1
million
.
<END>
<START>
Bond
Corp.
has
interests
in
brewing
,
media
and
communications
,
natural
resources
and
property
.
<END>
<START>
Much

Bond
Corp.
's
losses
stemmed
from
one-time
write-downs
of
the
value
of
some
of
Bond
Corp.
's
assets
and
those
of
its
units
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
Bond
Corp.
said
the
tax
benefits
remain
available
and
might
be
used
later
.
<END>
<START>
Earnings
before
interest
and
tax
from
brewing
dived
50
%
to
A$
123.8
million
from
A$
247.3
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
the
general

performance
of
its
U.S.
brewing
operations
,
G.
Heileman
Brewing
Co.
,
was
``
disappointing
,
and
this
has
been
reflected
in
the
results
.
''
<END>
<START>
Bond
Corp.
's
shares
closed
Friday
before
news
of
the
results
at
28
Australian
cents
a

,
up
one
Australian
cent
.
<END>
<START>
The

cap

Alan
Bond
and

,
Bond
Corp
.
<END>
<START>

,

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
Now

Australian

.
<END>
<START>
It

.
<END>
<START>
But

,

We

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
But

.

<START>
Bond
Corp.

.
<END>
<START>

in

,

and

.

group

,
''
Bond
Corp.

in

.
<END>
<START>
The
Bakersfield
Supermarket
went
out
of
business
last
May
.
<END>
<START>
The
reason
was
not
high
interest
rates
or
labor
costs
.
<END>
<START>
Nor
was
there
a
shortage
of
customers
in
the
area
,
the
residential
Inwood
section
of
northern
Manhattan
.
<END>
<START>
The
business
closed
when
the
owner
was
murdered
by
robbers
.
<END>
<START>
The
owner
was
Israel
Ortiz
,
a
29-year-old
entrepreneur
and
father
of
two
.
<END>
<START>
In
his
first
year
of
operating
the
store
he
bought
for
$
220,000
,
Mr.
Ortiz
was
robbed
at
least
twice
at
gunpoint
.
<END>
<START>
The
first
time
he
was
shot
in
the
hand
as
he
chased
the
robbers
outside
.
<END>
<START>
The
second
time
he
identified
two
robbers
,
who
were
arrested
and
charged
.
<END>
<START>
Two
weeks
later
--
perhaps
in
retaliation
--
Mr.
Ortiz
was
shot
three
times
in
the
back
,
during
what
police
classified
as
a
third
robbery
attempt
.
<END>
<START>
That
was
his
reward
for
working
until
11
p.m.
seven
days
a
week
to
cover
his
$
3,000
a
month
rent
.
<END>
<START>
For
providing
what
his
customers
described
as
very
personal
and
helpful
service
.
<END>
<START>
For
creating
a
focus
for
neighborhood
life
.
<END>
<START>
Israel
Ortiz
is
only
one
of
the
thousands
of
entrepreneurs
and
their
employees
who
will
be
injured
or
killed
by
crime
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Only
a
few
other
occupations
have
higher
reported
rates
of
criminal
injury
,
such
as
police
,
bartenders
and
taxi
drivers
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
these
figures
show
only
the
most
visible
part
of
the
problem
.
<END>
<START>
Recent
data
from
New
York
City
provide
more
of
the
picture
.
<END>
<START>
While
by
no
means
the
highest
crime
community
in
the
country
,
New
York
is
a
prime
example
of
a
city
where
crime
strangles
small-business
development
.
<END>
<START>
A
survey
of
small
businesses
there
was
conducted
this
spring
by
Interface
,
a
policy
research
organization
.
<END>
<START>
It
gave
1,124
businesses
a
questionnaire
and
analyzed
353
responses
.
<END>
<START>
The
survey
found
that
over
a
three-year
period
22
%
of
the
firms
said
employees
or
owners
had
been
robbed
on
their
way
to
or
from
work
or
while
on
the
job
.
<END>
<START>
Seventeen
percent
reported
their
customers
being
robbed
.
<END>
<START>
Crime
was
the
reason
that
26
%
reported
difficulty
recruiting
personnel
and
that
19
%
said
they
were
considering
moving
.
<END>
<START>
More
than
one-third
of
the
responding
businesses
said
they
suffer
from
drug
dealing
and
loitering
near
their
premises
.
<END>
<START>
In
Brooklyn
and
the
Bronx
,
one
out
of
four
commercial
firms
is
burglarized
each
year
.
<END>
<START>
Industrial
neighborhoods
fare
even
worse
,
with
burglary
rates
twice
the
citywide
average
.
<END>
<START>
Crime
is
clearly
more
deadly
to
small-scale
entrepreneurship
than
to
big
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
Two
decades
ago
,
the
Small
Business
Administration
reported
Yale
Prof.
Albert
Reiss
's
landmark
study
of
crime
against
2,500
small
businesses
drawn
from
national
IRS
records
.
<END>
<START>
He
found
that
monetary
crime
losses
,
as
a
proportion
of
gross
receipts
,
were
37
times
higher
for
small
businesses
than
for
large
ones
.
<END>
<START>
The
costs
of
crime
may
also
be
enough
to
destroy
a
struggling
business
.
<END>
<START>
Whatever
the
monetary
crime
losses
,
they
may
not
be
nearly
as
important
to
entrepreneurs
as
the
risk
of
personal
injury
.
<END>
<START>
After
repeated
gun
robberies
,
some
entrepreneurs
may
give
up
a
business
out
of
fear
for
their
lives
.
<END>
<START>
One
Washington
couple
recently
sold
their
liquor
store
after
34
years
in
business
that
included
four
robbery
deaths
and
16
robberies
or
burglaries
on
the
premises
.
<END>
<START>
These
findings
illustrate
the
vicious
cycle
that
National
Institute
of
Justice
Director
James
K.
Stewart
calls
``
crime
causing
poverty
.
''
<END>
<START>
Underclass
neighborhoods
offer
relatively
few
employment
opportunities
,
contributing
to
the
poverty
of
local
residents
.
<END>
<START>
Small
neighborhood
businesses
could
provide
more
jobs
,
if
crime
were
not
so
harmful
to
creating
and
maintaining
those
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
This
may
help
explain
why
small
businesses
create
65
%
of
all
jobs
nationally
,
but
only
22
%
of
jobs
in
a
crime-ridden
city
like
New
York
.
<END>
<START>
Bigger
business
can
often
better
afford
to
minimize
the
cost
of
crime
.
<END>
<START>
The
shift
of
retailing
to
large
shopping
centers
has
created
even
greater
economies
of
scale
for
providing
low-crime
business
environments
.
<END>
<START>
Private
security
guards
and
moonlighting
police
can
invoke
the
law
of
trespass
to
regulate
access
to
these
quasi-public
places
.
<END>
<START>
Since
1984
,
in
fact
,
revenues
of
the
10
largest
guard
companies
,
primarily
serving
such
big
businesses
,
have
increased
by
almost
62
%
.
<END>
<START>
Few
small
neighborhood
businesses
,
however
,
can
afford
such
protection
,
even
in
collaboration
with
other
local
merchants
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
neighborhoods
with
the
highest
crime
rates
,
small
business
generally
relies
on
the
public
police
force
for
protection
.
<END>
<START>
This
creates
several
problems
.
<END>
<START>
One
is
that
there
are
not
enough
police
to
satisfy
small
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
The
number
one
proposal
for
reducing
crime
in
the
New
York
survey
was
to
put
more
police
on
foot
or
scooter
patrol
,
suggested
by
more
than
two-thirds
of
the
respondents
.
<END>
<START>
Only
22
%
supported
private
security
patrols
funded
by
the
merchants
themselves
.
<END>
<START>
A
second
problem
is
the
persistent
frustration
of
false
alarms
,
which
can
make
urban
police
less
than
enthusiastic
about
responding
to
calls
from
small
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
Only
half
the
New
York
small
businesses
surveyed
,
for
their
part
,
are
satisfied
with
the
police
response
they
receive
.
<END>
<START>
Some
cities
,
including
New
York
,
have
experimented
with
special
tax
districts
for
commercial
areas
that
provide
additional
patrols
funded
by
local
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
But
this
raises
added
cost
barriers
to
urban
entrepreneurship
.
<END>
<START>
Another
solution
cities
might
consider
is
giving
special
priority
to
police
patrols
of
small-business
areas
.
<END>
<START>
For
cities
losing
business
to
suburban
shopping
centers
,
it
may
be
a
wise
business
investment
to
help
keep
those
jobs
and
sales
taxes
within
city
limits
.
<END>
<START>
Increased
patrolling
of
business
zones
makes
sense
because
urban
crime
is
heavily
concentrated
in
such
``
hot
spots
''
of
pedestrian
density
.
<END>
<START>
Small-business
patrols
would
be
an
especially
helpful
gesture
whenever
a
small-business
person
is
scheduled
to
testify
against
a
robbery
suspect
.
<END>
<START>
While
no
guarantee
,
an
increased
police
presence
might
even
deter
further
attacks
.
<END>
<START>
It
might
even
have
saved
the
life
,
and

,
of
Israel
Ortiz
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Sherman
is

at
the
University
of
Maryland
and
president

.
<END>
<START>
ENFIELD
Corp.
said
in

that
it
hopes
to
raise
56
million
Canadian
dollars
-LRB-
US$
47.7

-RRB-

.

,

.

,

.
<END>

.

<START>
Former

,

.
<END>
<START>
Diversification
pays
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
a
fundamental
lesson
for
investors
,
but
its
truth
was
demonstrated
once
again
in
the
performance
of
mutual
funds
during
and
after
the
stock
market
's
Friday-the-13th
plunge
.
<END>
<START>
Stock
funds
,
like
the
market
as
a
whole
,
generally
dropped
more
than
2
%
in
the
week
through
last
Thursday
,
according
to
figures
compiled
by
Lipper
Analytical
Services
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
That
reflects
the
huge
drop
a
week
ago
Friday
,
last
Monday
's
rebound
and
the
dips
and
blips
that
followed
.
<END>
<START>
But
several
other
types
of
funds
shielded
investors
from
the
worst
of
the
market
's
slide
.
<END>
<START>
Funds
that
invest
internationally
were
the
top-performing
stock
and
fixed-income
funds
.
<END>
<START>
``
More
than
ever
,
people
should
realize
they
should
have
a
diversified
portfolio
,
''
said
Jeremy
Duffield
,
a
senior
vice
president
of
Vanguard
Group
.
<END>
<START>
``
That
means
stocks
,
bonds
,
money
market
instruments
and
real
estate
.
''
<END>
<START>
One
week
's
performance
should
n't
be
the
basis
for
any
investment
decision
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
latest
mutual
fund
performance
figures
do
show
what
can
happen
when
the
going
gets
rough
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
want
to
know
how
a
fund
did
when
the
market
got
hammered
,
''
said
Kurt
Brouwer
,
an
investment
adviser
with
Brouwer
&
Janachowski
in
San
Francisco
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
like
kicking
the
tires
of
a
car
...
.
<END>
<START>
What
you
want
to
know
is
when
the
road
's
rough
,
when
there
's
snow
and
ice
,
how
's
this
car
going
to
perform
?
''
<END>
<START>
General
equity
funds
fell
an
average
of
2.35
%
in
the
week
ended
Thursday
,
compared
with
a
2.32
%
slide
for
the
Standard
&
Poor
's
500-stock
index
.
<END>
<START>
But
Lipper
Analytical
's
figures
show
that
there
were
a
number
of
ways
investors
could
have
cushioned
themselves
from
the
stock
market
's
gyrations
.
<END>
<START>
Gold-oriented
funds
,
for
instance
,
which
invest
in
companies
that
mine
and
process
the
precious
metal
,
posted
an
average
decline
of
1.15
%
.
<END>
<START>
Global
allocation
funds
take
the
asset-allocation
concept
one
step
further
by
investing
at
least
25
%
of
their
portfolios
outside
the
U.S.
.
<END>
<START>
This
gives
them
the
added
benefits
of
international
diversification
--
including
a
foreign-exchange
boost
during
periods
,
like
the
past
week
,
when
the
dollar
declines
against
other
major
currencies
.
<END>
<START>
With
all
that
going
for
them
,
global
flexible
portfolio
funds
declined
only
1.07
%
in
the
week
through
last
Thursday
.
<END>
<START>
And
Friday
the
13th
notwithstanding
,
stocks
have
been
this
year
's
hot
investment
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
,
even
including
the
latest
week
,
the
average
general
stock
fund
has
soared
more
than
24
%
so
far
this
year
,
the
Lipper
Analytical
figures
show
.
<END>
<START>
By
comparison
,
global
asset
allocation
funds
have
turned
in
an
average
total
return
of
about
19
%
,
while
domestic
flexible
portfolios
are
up
about
17
%
.
<END>
<START>
Fixed-income
funds
have
returned
8.2
%
,
while
gold
funds
,
which
tend
to
be
volatile
,
have
risen
just
4.55
%
,
on
average
.
<END>
<START>
``
That
's
the
problem
with
trying
to
hedge
too
much
,
''
said
Mr.
Brouwer
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
do
n't
make
any
real
money
.
''
<END>
<START>
Some
equity
funds
did
better
than
others
in
the
week
that
began
on
Friday
the
13th
.
<END>
<START>
The
$
4
million
Monetta
Fund
,
for
instance
,
was
the
seventh
top
performing
fund
for
the
week
,
with
a
2.65
%
return
.
<END>
<START>
Its
return
so
far
this
year
has
been
a
credible
21.71
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
fund
's
strategy
is
to
sell
when
a
stock
appreciates
30
%
over
its
cost
.
<END>
<START>
By
the
time
the
market
plummeted
10
days
ago
,
Monetta
was
55
%
in
cash
,
said
Robert
Bacarella
,
president
and

.
<END>
<START>
Last
Monday
,
he
started
``
buying
the
high-quality
growth
companies
that
people
were
throwing
away
at
discount

.
''
<END>
<START>
Among
Mr.
Bacarella
's
picks
:
Oracle
Systems
,
Reebok
International
Ltd.
and
Digital
Microwave
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
The
fund
's
cash
position
is
now
about
22
%
,
which
Mr.
Bacarella
calls
``
still
bearish
.
''
<END>
<START>
Howard
Stein
,

of
Dreyfus
Corp.
,
said
the
fund
was
about
half
invested
in
government

on
Oct.
13
,
and
about
10
%
in
cash
.
<END>
<START>
``
In
a
downward
market
,
bonds
act
better
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
still
think
there
's
a
lot
of
unsettlement
in
this
market
.
<END>
<START>
We
believe
interest
rates
will
continue
to
trend
lower
,
and
the
economy
will
slow
around
the
world
.
''
<END>
<START>
Many
of
the
funds
that
did
best
in
the
last
week
are
heavily
invested
overseas
,
giving
them
the
benefit
of
foreign
currency
translations
when
the
dollar
is
weak
.
<END>
<START>
Three
International
Cash
Portfolios
funds
,
which
invest
almost
exclusively
in
bonds
and
money-market
instruments
overseas
,
were
among
the
four
top-performing
funds
in
the
latest
week
.
<END>
<START>
Because
the
funds
'
investments
are
denominated
in
foreign
currencies
,
their
value
expressed
in
dollars
goes
up
when
those
currencies
rise
against
the
dollar
.
<END>
<START>
But
when
the
dollar
rises
against
major
foreign
currencies
,
as
it
did
for
much
of
this
year
,
the
dollar
value
of
these
funds
declines
.
<END>
<START>
All
three
funds
posted
negative
returns
for
the
year
to
date
.
<END>
<START>
The
small
drop
in
equity
funds
in
general
in
the
latest
week
may
not
necessarily
be
a
good
sign
,
said
A.
Michael
Lipper
,

Lipper

.
<END>
<START>
There
's
either
more
to
come
or
an

long

of
dullness
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
investors
do
n't

.
<END>
<START>
Several

.

.

<START>
Sitting

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>

!
''
he

.
<END>
<START>
``
The
ventilation
here
is
great
!
''
<END>
<START>
You
may
be
hearing
more
about
the
38-year-old
Mr.
McDonough
and
his

with
clean

.
<END>
<START>
After

of

,

is
starting
to
attract

for
the

as

of

.
<END>
<START>
He
has
designed
furniture
and

as
well
as

and

.
<END>
<START>
He
is
now
designing
a
Broadway
stage
set
for
a

by
the
band
Kid
Creole
and
the
Coconuts
.
<END>
<START>
What
really
stirs
his

,
though
,
is
aerobic
architecture
.
<END>
<START>
Now
the
question
is
:
Is
Poland
ready
for

?
<END>
<START>
Mr.
McDonough
is
about
to

his

challenge
yet
,
the
proposed
Warsaw
Trade
Center
in

,
the

in
Eastern
Europe
.
<END>
<START>
The
project
has
already
acquired
a
certain
New
York
cachet
.
<END>
<START>
Bloomingdale
's
plans
to
sell
a
foot-tall
chocolate
model
of
the
center
during
the
holidays
.
<END>
<START>
Some
of
the
sales
proceeds
will
go
to
the
Design
Industries
Foundation
for
AIDS
.
<END>
<START>
A
cake
topped
with
a
replica
of
the
center
will
be
auctioned
at
an
AIDS
benefit
at
Sotheby
's
in
December
.
<END>
<START>
If
Mr.
McDonough
's
plans
get
executed
,
as
much
of
the
Polish
center
as
possible
will
be
made
from

,

and

from

's

.
<END>
<START>
A

mesh

will
stand
atop
50

of

space
.
<END>
<START>
Solar-powered
batteries
will
make

.
<END>
<START>
The
windows
will
open
.
<END>
<START>
The
carpets
wo
n't
be
glued
down
,
and
walls
will
be
coated
with

finishes
.
<END>
<START>
If
Mr.
McDonough
has

way
,
the
Poles
will
compensate
for
the
trade
center
's
emissions
of

,

warming

.
<END>
<START>
The
Poles
would
plant

somewhere
in
the
country
at
a

$
150,000
,

's

.
<END>
<START>
The
news
has
n't
exactly
moved
others
in
Mr.
McDonough
's
profession
to
become
architectural
Johnny
Appleseeds
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
McDonough
responds
:
``
I
'm
asking
people
to
broaden
their
agendas
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
earned
a
master
's
degree
in
architecture
from
Yale
.
<END>
<START>
His
interest
in
the
natural
environment
dates
from
his
youth
.
<END>
<START>
He
and
his
father
still
spend
time
each
summer
fly-fishing
for
salmon
in
Iceland
.
<END>
<START>
Living
in
Hong
Kong
,
he
says
,
made
him
sensitive
to
the
limits
on
food
,
power
and
water
supplies
.
<END>
<START>
At
his
first
school
in
the
U.S.
he
was
thought
a
little
strange
for
shutting
off
open
water
taps
and
admonishing
his
schoolmates
to
take
only
brief
showers
.
<END>
<START>
He
and
a
Dartmouth
roommate
established
a
company
that
restored
three
hydroelectric
power
plants
in
Vermont
.
<END>
<START>
At
Yale
,
he
designed
one
of
the
first
solarheated
houses
to
be
built
in
Ireland
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
McDonough
's
first
professional
project
fully
to
reflect
his
environmental
ardor
was
his
1986
design
for
the
headquarters
of
the
Environmental
Defense
Fund
in
New
York
.
<END>
<START>
The
offices
took
10,000
square
feet
of
a
building
with
14-foot
ceilings
and
big
,
operable
windows
.
<END>
<START>
Since
the
1970s
energy
crisis
,
some
efforts
to
conserve
energy
by
sealing
buildings
have
had
an
unintended
side
effect
:
high
indoor
pollution
.
<END>
<START>
To
reduce
it
at
the
fund
's
building
,
workers
rubbed
beeswax
instead
of
polyurethane
on
the
floors
in
the
executive
director
's
office
.
<END>
<START>
Jute
,
rather
than
a
synthetic
material
,
lies
under
the
tacked-down
carpets
,
and
the
desks
are
of
wood
and
granite
instead
of
plastic
.
<END>
<START>
The
budget
was
only
$
400,000
.
<END>
<START>
``
Athens
with
Spartan
means
,
''
Mr.
McDonough
says
.
<END>
<START>
The
fund
's
lawyers
work
in
an
Athenian
grove
of
potted
trees
.
<END>
<START>
Economists
and
administrators
sit
along
a
``
boulevard
''
with
street
lamps
and

trees
.
<END>
<START>
In
offices
,

bulbs
simulate

.
<END>
<START>
Offices
with
outside
windows
have

windows
,
too
,
to
let
in
more
real

.
<END>
<START>
``
We
proved
a
healthy
office
does
n't

,
''

Frederic
Krupp
,

``

to
entrench
management
and
thwart
Royal
's
offer
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
suit
seeks
``
in
excess
of
$
350,000
in
damages
.
''
<END>
<START>
A
Realist
official
said
the
company
had
n't
yet
received
the
full
complaint
and
would
n't
have
a
response
until
it
had
an
opportunity
to
review
it
.
<END>
<START>
Winnebago
Industries
Inc.
,
battered
by
a
deepening
slowdown
in
recreational
vehicle
industry
sales
,
reported
a
widened
fourth-quarter
loss
and
slashed
its
dividend
in
half
.
<END>
<START>
The
Forest
City
,
Iowa
,
maker
of
motor
homes
said
it
had
a
loss
of
$
11.3
million
,
or
46
cents
a
share
,
in
the
quarter
ended
Aug.
26
.
<END>
<START>
A
year
earlier
,
the
company
had
a
deficit
of
$
1.5
million
,
or
six
cents
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
Winnebago
said
it
started
``
several
promotional
programs
''
to
spur
retail
sales
in
the
fall
and
winter
.
<END>
<START>
The
year
was
already
shaping
up
as
a
difficult
one
for
the
recreational
vehicle
industry
,
which
makes
products
such
as
motor
homes
,
travel
trailers
,
folding
campers
and
van
conversions
.
<END>
<START>
With
the
exception
of
van
conversions
,
the
industry
has
seen
a
decline
from
1988
's
robust
sales
.
<END>
<START>
At
Winnebago
,
sales
for
the
quarter
fell
6
%
to
$
89.5
million
from
$
95.4
million
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
attributed
the
decline
to
consumers
'
concern
over
interest
rates
and
gas
prices
--
two
key
expenses
for
RV
buyers
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
a
large-ticket
discretionary
purchase
,
''
said
Robert
Curran
,
who
follows
the
industry
for
Merrill
Lynch
&
Co
.
<END>
<START>
``
So
when
there
's
talk
and
concern
about
the
economy
,
it
's
not
unreasonable
for
a
portion
of
the
buying
public
to
defer
purchases
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Curran
expects
industry
RV
sales
for
all
of
1989
to
fall
about
5
%
from
1988
,
when
sales
of
427,300
units
were
the
highest
since
1978
.
<END>
<START>
And
he
said
the
weakness
could
continue
in
the
first
half
of
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
said
the
industry
has
``
a
good
decade
ahead
,
''
particularly
if
aging
baby
boomers
fulfill
the
industry
's
dreams
by
buying
RVs
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
it
also
suffered
in
the
quarter
from
incentive
programs
,
losses
from
discontinuing
a
motor
home
line
and
costs
of
developing
a
new
commercial
vehicle
,
among
other
things
.
<END>
<START>
The
news
sent
Winnebago
stock
falling
62.5
cents
,
to
$
5.25
,
in
New
York
Stock
Exchange
composite
trading
-
a
52-week
low
.
<END>
<START>
The
dividend
cut
will
prove
most
costly
for
John
K.
Hanson
,
Winnebago
's
founder
and
chairman
.
<END>
<START>
Based
on
his
control
of
about
45
%
of
Winnebago
's
24.7
million
shares
,
his
annual
dividend
income
would
be
cut
to
about
$
2.2
million
from
$
4.4
million
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
rose
2
%
to
$
437.5
million
from
$
430.3
million
.
<END>
<START>
Bullish
bond
market
sentiment
is
on
the
rise
again
.
<END>
<START>
As
the
government
prepares
to
release
the
next
batch
of
economic
reports
,
the
consensus
among
economists
and
money
managers
is
that
the
news
will
be
negative
.
<END>
<START>
And
that
,
they
say
,
will
be
good
for
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
``
Recent
data
have
indicated
somewhat
weaker
economic
activity
,
''
said
Elliott
Platt
,
director
of
economic
research
at
Donaldson
,
Lufkin
&
Jenrette
Securities
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Platt
is
advising
clients
that
``
the
near-term
direction
of
bond
prices
is
likely
to
remain
upward
.
''
<END>
<START>
That
would
be
comforting
to
fixed-income
investors
,
many
of
whom
were
badly
burned
in
the
third
quarter
by
incorrectly
assuming
that
the
Fed
would
ease
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
rushed
to
buy
bonds
during
the
summer
as
prices
soared
on
speculation
that
interest
rates
would
continue
to
fall
.
<END>
<START>
But
when
it
became
clear
that
rates
had
stabilized
and
that
the
Fed
's
credit-easing
policy
was
on
hold
,
bond
yields
jumped
and
prices
tumbled
.
<END>
<START>
Long-term
bonds
have
performed
erratically
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Total
return
is
price
changes
plus
interest
income
.
<END>
<START>
Now
some
investment
analysts
insist
that
the
economic
climate
has
turned
cold
and
gloomy
,
and
they
are
urging
clients
to
buy
bonds
before
the
rally
begins
.
<END>
<START>
Among
other
things
,
economists
note
that
consumer
spending
is
slowing
,
corporate
profit
margins
are
being
squeezed
,
business
confidence
is
slipping
and
construction
and
manufacturing
industries
are
depressed
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
same
time
,
last
week
's
consumer
price
index
showed
that
inflation
is
moderating
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
think
we
will
see
a
federal
funds
rate
of
close
to
8
1/2
%
in
the
next
two
weeks
and
8
%
by
year
end
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
federal
funds
rate
,
which
banks
charge
each
other
on
overnight
loans
,
is
considered
an
early
signal
of
changes
in
the
Fed
's
credit
policy
.
<END>
<START>
Although
the
rate
briefly
drifted
even
lower
following
the
stock
market
sell-off
that
occurred
Oct.
13
,
it
ended
Friday
at
about
8
11/16
%
.
<END>
<START>
James
Kochan
,
chief
fixed-income
strategist
at
Merrill
Lynch
,
is
touting
shorter-term
securities
,
which
he
says
should
benefit
more
quickly
than
longer-term
bonds
as
interest
rates
fall
.
<END>
<START>
``
Given
our
forecast
for
lower
rates
,
purchases
made
now
should
prove
quite
rewarding
before
year
end
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Kochan
also
likes
long-term
,
investment-grade
corporate
bonds
and
long-term
Treasurys
.
<END>
<START>
He
says
these
bonds
should
appreciate
in
value
as
some
investors
,
reacting
to
the
recent
turmoil
in
the
stock
and
high-yield
junk
bond
markets
,
seek
safer
securities
.
<END>
<START>
TVA
,
in
its
first
public

in
15
years
,
sold
$
4
billion
of
long-term
and

securities
last
week
.
<END>
<START>
Strong
investor
demand
prompted
the
utility
to
boost

of
the
issue
from
$
3
billion
.
<END>
<START>
TVA
,
which
operates
one
of
the
nation
's
largest
electric
power
systems
,
is
a
corporation
owned
by
the
federal
government
.
<END>
<START>
But
persuading

to

may

this

,
when

30

.
<END>
<START>
Today
,

15.6

at

regular

.
<END>
<START>

,

$
10

of

.
<END>
<START>
All
of

comes
ahead
of
the
government
's
big
quarterly

of

,
which

.
<END>
<START>
So
far
,

have
n't

for

's

.
<END>
<START>
Roger
Early
,
a

at
Federated

Corp.
,
said
that

on
the
so-called

are

to

.
<END>
<START>
``
Why
should
I
bother
with
something
that
's
an
unknown
for
a

in

?
''
he

.
<END>
<START>
``
I
'm
not
going
to
jump
on
them
the
first

come
out
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
seems
to
be
typical
of
many
professional
money

.
<END>
<START>
On
Friday
,
the
yield
was
quoted
at
about
1/4
percentage
point
higher
than
the
benchmark
bond
,
an
indication
of
weak
demand
.
<END>
<START>
Some
economists
believe
that
yields
on
all
Treasury
securities
may
rise
this
week
as
the
market
struggles
to
absorb
the
new
supply
.
<END>
<START>
But
once
the
new
securities
are
digested
,
they
expect
investors
to
focus
on
the
weak
economic
data
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
supply
is
not
a

to

market
,
''
said
Samuel
Kahan
,

Government

.
<END>
<START>
``
If

are

,

do
n't

how
much
supply
is
coming
.
''
<END>
<START>
Friday
's
Market
Activity
<END>
<START>
Most
bond
prices
fell
on
concerns
about
this
week
's
new
supply
and
disappointment
that
stock
prices
did
n't
stage
a
sharp
decline
.
<END>
<START>
Junk
bond
prices
moved
higher
,
however
.
<END>
<START>
In
early
trading
,
Treasury
bonds
were
higher
on
expectations
that
a
surge
in
buying
among
Japanese
investors
would
continue
.
<END>
<START>
Also
providing
support
to
Treasurys
was
hope
that
the
stock
market
might
see
declines
because
of
the
expiration
of
some
stock-index
futures
and
options
on
indexes
and
individual
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
Those
hopes
were
dashed
when
the
stock
market
put
in
a
relatively
quiet
performance
.
<END>
<START>
Treasury
bonds
ended
with
losses
of
as
much
as
1/4
point
,
or
about
$
2.50
for
each
$
1,000
face
amount
.
<END>
<START>
The
benchmark
30-year
bond
,
which
traded
as
high
as
102
1/4
during
the
day
,
ended
at
101
17/32
.
<END>
<START>
The
yield
on
the
benchmark
bond
rose
slightly
to
7.98
%
from
7.96
%
.
<END>
<START>
Today
,
for
example
,

at
Morgan
Stanley
&

,

Inc
.
<END>
<START>
Traders

12
%
.
<END>
<START>
Shearson
Lehman

Inc.

issue
by
R.P.
Scherer
Drugs
is
expected
by

.
<END>
<START>
However
,

,

.

<START>

,

<START>

.

<START>

,

<START>

.
<END>
<START>

,

.

to
give
the
capital
its

.

<START>

,

.

.

.

<START>

.

<START>
``

ca
n't

''
to

,

.

<START>

<START>

.
<END>
<START>
The
comic

will
cost
about
$
2
.
<END>
<START>
Softer-than-expected
orders
in
early
September
also
played
a
role
,
he
said
in
an

.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Stein
said
he
is
``
reasonably

''
that

for

will

$
3.1

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
That
would
require
fourth-quarter
net
of
more
than

22
cents
to
24
cents
a

,

Mr.
Stein
's

.
<END>
<START>
In

,
the
company
had

of
$
2.7
million
,
or

cents
a

.
<END>
<START>
Third-quarter

is

$
40

to

,
up
from
$
38.2
million
a

,
according
to
Neil
Gordon
,

.
<END>
<START>
The
year-earlier
periods
do
n't
reflect
results
of
the
company
's
Woodstream
Corp.
unit
,
acquired
last
January
,
but
include
some
Canadian
operations
that
were
sold
at

end

1988
.
<END>
<START>
August
through
October
traditionally
is
the
busiest
season
for
the
bakeware
business
,
as
many
retailers
use
the
goods
as

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Stein
said
some

--
perhaps
anxious
about

--
appear
to
have
held
back
on

in
September
but
have
been

more

in

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Stein
said
Woodstream
is
``
marginally
profitable
''
but
has
n't
performed
as
well
as
expected
.
<END>
<START>
Woodstream
's
Victor-brand
mousetraps
and
other
pest-control
products
are
``
doing
very
well
,
''
and
its
plastic
storage-case
products
``
are
poised
for
growth
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
unit
's
third
segment
,
wildlife
traps
,
is
suffering
from
a
``
depressed
market
,
''
and
Ekco
is
seeking
to
sell
that
segment
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Stein
said
he
expects
profit
to
be
higher
in
1990
than
in
1989
,
reflecting
a
number
of
measures
taken
since
the
acquisition
of
Ekco
Housewares
in
late
1987
.
<END>
<START>
Ekco
's
housewares
operation
makes
kitchen
tools
and
gadgets
,
as
well
as
bakeware
,
at
factories
in
the
U.S.
and
Canada
.
<END>
<START>
The
main
issue
in
the
strike
at
the
Ohio
facility
was
health-care
benefits
,
Mr.
Stein
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
strike
ended
Oct
.
<END>
<START>
Ekco
continues
to
seek
further
acquisitions
in
the
consumer-products
industry
,
Mr.
Stein
said
.
<END>
<START>
After
several
years
of
booming
business
with
China
,
foreign
traders
are
bracing
for
the
biggest
slump
in
a
decade
.
<END>
<START>
The
imposition
of
austerity
measures
,
starting
last
October
,
already
had
begun
to
pinch
when
the
massacre
in
Tiananmen
Square
on
June
4
and
subsequent
events
tugged
the
belt
far
tighter
.
<END>
<START>
Foreign
lending
has
been
virtually
suspended
since
then
,
choking
liquidity
and
hobbling
many
projects
.
<END>
<START>
And
Beijing
has
pulled
back
on
domestic
loans
and
subsidies
,
leaving
many
domestic
buyers
and
export-oriented
plants
strapped
for
cash
.
<END>
<START>
Givaudan
Far
East
Ltd.
,
a
Swiss
concern
that
sells
chemicals
to
shampoo
and
soap
factories
in
China
,
typifies
the
problems
.
<END>
<START>
Last
year
's
retrenchment
dried
up
the
working
capital
of
Chinese
factories
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
's
sales
flattened
during
1989
's
first
half
.
<END>
<START>
The
June
killings
magnified
the
problems
.
<END>
<START>
In
Canton
,
Givaudan
's
representative
office
received
no
orders
in
June
.
<END>
<START>
``
Things
have
grown
worse
since
June
4
,
''
Mr.
Lai
says
.
<END>
<START>
He
predicts
that
sales
will
drop
between
30
%
and
40
%
from
last
year
's
$
3
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
consumer-products
and
light-industrial
sectors
are
bearing
the
brunt
of
China
's
austerity
measures
,
and
foreign
companies
such
as
Givaudan
that
deal
with
those
industries
are
being
hit
the
hardest
.
<END>
<START>
But
in
general
,
all
foreign-trading
companies
are
feeling
the
pinch
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
import
pie
will
shrink
,
''
says
John
Kamm
,
first
vice
president
of
the
American
Chamber
of
Commerce
in
Hong
Kong
and
a
China
trade
specialist
.
<END>
<START>
``
On
the
down
side
,
sales
could
fall
as
much
as
90
%
for
some
companies
;
on
the
upper
side
,
sales
will
be
flat
.
''
<END>
<START>
China
's
foreign
trade
has
gone
in
cycles
during
the
past
decade
.
<END>
<START>
The
last
time
that
traders
experienced
a
trough
was
during
1985-86
,
when
Beijing
imposed
tough
measures
to
curb
imports
and
conserve
foreign
exchange
.
<END>
<START>
The
current
trough
is
expected
to
be
much
deeper
,
because
Beijing
has
cut
off
domestic
funds
from
factories
for
the
first
time
to
slow
inflation
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
the
suspension
of
loans
and
export
credits
from
foreign
governments
and
institutions
following
the
June
killings
have
been
a
big
setback
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
freeze
on
new
lending
is
dealing
the
single
biggest
blow
to
trading
,
''
says
Raymond
Wong
,
China
manager
for
Mannesmann
AG
,
a
West
German
machinery-trading
company
.
<END>
<START>
Import
growth
from
the
year-earlier
months
slowed
to
16
%
in
July
and
7.1
%
in
August
,
compared
with
an
average
growth
rate
of
26
%
in
the
first
half
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
first
eight
months
of
1989
,
imports
grew
21
%
,
to
$
38.32
billion
,
down
slightly
from
a
growth
rate
of
23
%
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
The
picture
for
China
's
exports
is
just
as
bleak
,
mainly
because
of
the
domestic
credit
squeeze
.
<END>
<START>
The
threat
to
China
's
balance
of
payments
is
further
aggravated
by
the
plunge
in
its
foreign-exchange
reserves
,
excluding
gold
holdings
.
<END>
<START>
The
reserves
dropped
for
the
first
time
in
recent
years
,
to
$
14
billion
in
June
from
$
19
billion
in
April
.
<END>
<START>
The
trend
has
prompted
Beijing
to
intensify
efforts
to
curb
imports
.
<END>
<START>
In
recent
weeks
,
China
's
leaders
have
recentralized
trading
in
wool
and
scores
of
chemical
products
and
commodities
.
<END>
<START>
The
Ministry
of
Foreign
Economic
Relations
and
Trade
set
up
a
special
bureau
last
month
to
monitor
the
issue
of
import
and
export
licenses
.
<END>
<START>
Beijing
's
periodic
clampdowns
on
imports
have
taught
many
trading
companies
that
the
best
way
to
get
through
the
drought
is
by
helping
China
export
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
Nissho
Iwai
Corp.
,
one
of
the
biggest
Japanese
trading
houses
,
now
buys
almost
twice
as
many
goods
from
China
as
it
sells
to
that
country
.
<END>
<START>
Three
years
ago
,
the
ratio
was
reversed
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
strategy
is
n't
helping
much
this
time
.
<END>
<START>
``
Both
sectors
of
imports
and
exports
look
just
as
bad
,
''
says
Masahiko
Kitamura
,
general
manager
of
Nissho
Iwai
's
Canton
office
.
<END>
<START>
He
expects
the
company
's
trading
business
to
drop
as
much
as
40
%
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
For
a
short
time
after
June
4
,
it
appeared
that
the
trade
picture
would
remain
fairly
bright
.
<END>
<START>
Many
foreign
trading
offices
in
Hong
Kong
were
swamped
with
telexes
and
telephone
calls
from
Chinese
trade
officials
urging
them
not
to
sever
ties
.
<END>
<START>
Even
the
Bank
of
China
,
which
normally
took
weeks
to
process
letters
of
credit
,
was
settling
the
letters
at
record
speed
to
dispel
rumors
about
the
bank
's
financial
health
.
<END>
<START>
But
when
foreign
traders
tried
to
do
business
,
they
discovered
that
the
eagerness
of
Chinese
trade
officials
was
just
a
smokescreen
.
<END>
<START>
The
suspension
of
foreign
loans
has
weakened
the
buying
power
of
China
's
national
trading
companies
,
which
are
among
the
country
's
biggest
importers
.
<END>
<START>
Business
is
n't
any
better
on
the
provincial
or
municipal
level
,
foreign
traders
say
.
<END>
<START>
Shanghai
Investment
&
Trust
Co.
,
known
as
Sitco
,
is
the
city
's
main
financier
for
trading
business
.
<END>
<START>
Sitco
had
customarily
tapped
the
Japanese
bond
market
for
funds
,
but
it
ca
n't
do
that
any
longer
.
<END>
<START>
Foreign
traders
say
the
company
is
strapped
for
cash
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
has
difficulties
paying
its
foreign
debts
,
''
says
a
Hong
Kong
executive
who
is
familiar
with
Sitco
's
business
.
<END>
<START>
``
How
can
it
make
available
funds
for
purchases
?
''
<END>
<START>
Foreign
traders
also
say
many
of
China
's
big
infrastructural
projects
have
been
canceled
or
postponed
because
of
the
squeeze
on
domestic
and
foreign
credit
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
are
virtually
no
new
projects
,
and
that
means
no
new
business
for
us
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
These
have
been
among
the
country
's
leading
imports
,
particularly
last
year
when
there
were
shortages
that
led
many
traders
to
buy
heavily
and
pay
dearly
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
shortages
also
spawned
rampant
speculation
and
spiraling
prices
.
<END>
<START>
To
stem
speculation
,
Beijing
imposed
ceiling
prices
that
went
into
effect
earlier
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Traders
who
had
bought
the
goods
at
prices
above
the
ceiling
do
n't
want
to
take
a
loss
on
resales
and
are
holding
onto
their
stock
.
<END>
<START>
The
resulting
stockpiling
has
depressed
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
But
Beijing
ca
n't
cut
back
on
such
essential
imports
as
raw
materials
for
too
long
without
hampering
the
country
's
export
business
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Kamm
,
the
China
trade
expert
,
estimates
that
as
much
as
50
%
of
Guangdong
's
exports
is
made
up
of
processed
imported
raw
materials
.
<END>
<START>
Oil
Spill
Case
Shows
Liability
Fund
Flaws
<END>
<START>
AN
UNRESOLVED
two-year-old
dispute
stemming
from
an
Alaskan
oil
spill
has
helped
spur
a
drive
for
tougher
federal
laws
to
protect
victims
of
such
accidents
.
<END>
<START>
The
class-action
suit
highlights
shortcomings
of
the
Trans-Alaska
Pipeline
Liability
Fund
,
which
gets
its
money
from
oil
companies
using
the
pipeline
and
compensates
those
harmed
by
oil
spills
.
<END>
<START>
On
July
2
,
1987
,
the
tanker
S.S.
Glacier
Bay
struck
a
rock
and
spilled
almost
150,000
gallons
of
oil
into
the
Cook
Inlet
.
<END>
<START>
Commercial
fishermen
and
fish
processors
filed
suit
in
federal
court
in
a
claim
that
has
ballooned
to
more
than
$
104.8
million
.
<END>

;

;

.

.

.

<START>
Many
Law
School
Grads
Find
Classes
Never
End
<END>
<START>
RECENT
LAW
school
graduates
are
starting
jobs
with
law
firms
this
fall
--
and
heading
back
to
class
.
<END>
<START>
Bar
associations
and
consultants
are
offering
more
programs
to
teach
associates
all
they
need
to
know
about
law
but
did
n't
learn
in
law
school
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
past
,
associates
learned
the
basics
from
senior
lawyers
who
acted
as
mentors
.
<END>
<START>
The
Hildebrandt
course
enables
students
to
brush
up
on
negotiation
skills
by
role
playing
in
simulated
deals
.
<END>
<START>
Students
also
are
taught
to
return
clients
'
phone
calls
immediately
and
to
treat
the
support
staff
with
respect
.
<END>
<START>
Many
law
firms
sponsor
their
own
programs
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
Baltimore
firm
of
Weinberg
&
Green
,
new
corporate
and
banking
associates
are
required
to
enroll
in
a
20-class
course
.
<END>
<START>
Partners
lecture
on
how
to
form
corporations
,
draft
agreements
and
defend
clients
against
unwanted
tender
offers
.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
clients
know
that
new
associates
have
had
some
practical
training
before
working
on
their
cases
,
says
James
J.
Hanks
,
a
partner
at
the
firm
.

<START>
Los
Angeles
Creates
A
Courthouse
for
Kids
<END>
<START>
THE
CHILDREN
of
Los
Angeles
will
soon
have
their
own
$
52
million
courthouse
.
<END>
<START>
Designs
call
for
an
L-shaped
structure
with
a
playground
in
the
center
.
<END>
<START>
There
will
be
recreation
and
movie
rooms
.
<END>
<START>
Teens
will
be
able
to
listen
to
music
with
headsets
.
<END>
<START>
Study
halls
,
complete
with
reference
materials
,
will
be
available
.
<END>
<START>
And
there
will
be
a
nurse
's
station
and
rooms
for
children
to
meet
with
social
workers
.
<END>
<START>
The
building
's
25
courtrooms
will
be
smaller
,
says
Charlene
Saunders
,
a
court
administrator
.
<END>
<START>
The
bench
will
be
lower
so
the
judge
seems
less
intimidating
,
and
walls
will
be
painted
in
bright
colors
and
covered
with
murals
.
<END>
<START>
Cases
in
Los
Angeles
County
involving
dependent
children
are
usually
heard
in
the
Criminal
Courts
Building
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
need
to
get
the
kids
away
from
the
criminals
into
a
less
traumatic
environment
,
''
says
Mr.
Edelman
.
<END>
<START>
About
45,000
children
in
Los
Angeles
County
are
under
court
supervision
,
Mr.
Edelman
says
,
and
an
average
of
1,500
new
children
are
added
each
month
.
<END>
<START>
The
courthouse
,
to
be
built
in
Monterey
Park
,
is
expected
to
open
in
the
spring
of
1992
.
<END>
<START>
Law
Firm
Management
Can
Be
Quite
Rewarding
<END>
<START>
IT
PAYS
to

a
management
career
path
--
even

.
<END>
<START>
That
's

by
Altman
&

Inc.
,

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
Managing

who
responded
to
the
survey
typically
spend
over
half
their
time
supervising
their
firms
'
day-to-day
operations
and
just
a
little
more
than
a
third
of
their
time

law
.
<END>
<START>
Partners
in

who
devote
most

to

law
earned
an
average
of
about
$
217,000
.
<END>
<START>
The
funds
would
be

to
a
stop-gap
spending
bill
required
to
keep
most
of
the
government
operating
past
Wednesday
.
<END>
<START>
The
measure
is
scheduled
to
be
taken
up
by
the
Appropriations
Committee
today
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
will
support
it
,
we
will
thank
him
,
and
we
will
augment
it
where
appropriate
,
''
said
Rep.
Vic
Fazio
-LRB-
D.
,
Calif
.
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
Dubbed
the
``
Dire

,
''

vintage

in

.

,

wo

.

<START>
First
,
the
somewhat

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
What
now
?

<START>
To
judge
from
novels
that
mirror
the
contemporary
scene
,
we
're
back
in
the
age
of
anxiety
.
<END>
<START>
Nora
Worth
and
Malcolm
DeWitt
,
33
and
39
respectively
,
live
together
in
a
townhouse
in
a
transitional
Philadelphia

.
<END>
<START>
After
all
,
she

,
``
there
were

with
Nikons
and

from
cooking

in
France
who
would
kill
for
her
job
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
Nora
and
Malcolm
feel
trapped
.
<END>
<START>
Uncertainty
dogs
every
aspect
of
their
lives
.
<END>
<START>
Malcolm
faces
bankruptcy
and
an
IRS

,
but
Nora
finds
an
extra
$
30,000
in
her
bank
account
,
suddenly
increasing
her
available
funds
some
fifteenfold
.
<END>
<START>
In
novels
of
an
earlier
vintage
,
David
would
have
represented
excitement
and
danger
;
Malcolm
,
placid
,
middle-class
security
.
<END>
<START>
The
characters
confront
a
world
in
which
it
seems
increasingly
difficult
to
find
a
``
middle
way
''
between
the
extremes
of
success
and
failure
,
wealth
and
poverty
.
<END>
<START>
In
making
Malcolm
and
Nora
such

representative
specimens
of
their
class
and
generation
,
Ms.
Zeidner
has
somewhat
neglected
the
task
of
making

distinctively
individual
characters
.
<END>
<START>
The
humor
of
the
story
owes
much
to
the
fact
that
no
hearts
-LRB-
even
the
characters
'
own
-RRB-
are
likely
to
bleed
for
the
plight
of
health-food
eaters
.
<END>
<START>
But
readers
may
well
feel
the
pangs
of
recognition
.
<END>
<START>
In
any
case
,
the
foundering
middle
classes
are
n't
the
only
ones
in
trouble
--
or
whose
troubles
provide
material
for
fiction
.
<END>
<START>
Patrician
,
dynamic
Scott
Thatcher
,
founder
and
head
of
PegaSys
,
initially
finds
the
takeover
threat
risible
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Garber
manages
to
invest
this
tale
of
financial
wars
with
the
colorful
characters
and
fast-paced
action
of
a
suspense

.
<END>
<START>
And
like

,
this
novel
has
strong

of
allegory
,
as

good

battle

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Garber
depicts
these

with
the
broad

of

that
occasionally

.
<END>
<START>
Standard-issue

,

and
Neanderthal
union

undermine
the
force
of

author
's
perceptions
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Rubin
is
a
free-lance
writer
based
in
Los
Angeles
.
<END>
<START>
High-definition
television
promises
to
be
the
TV
of
tomorrow
,
so
it
is
a
natural
multibillion-dollar
market
.
<END>
<START>
Although
major
U.S.
manufacturers
have
all
but
ceded
the
main
segment
of
that
future
business
to
Japan
,
not
everyone
here
is
ready
to
give
up
.
<END>
<START>
Planar
Systems
Inc.
of
Beaverton
,
Ore.
,
the
largest
of
these
firms
,
with
$
20
million
in
annual
revenue
,
has
similar
plans
.
<END>
<START>
It
already
has
had
success
in
electroluminescence
,
another
promising
technology
adaptable
for
high-definition
television
.
<END>
<START>
Two
other
firms
,
Ovonic
Imaging
Systems
Inc.
of
Troy
,
Mich.
,
and
Magnascreen
Corp.
of
Pittsburgh
are
developing
a
variation
of
the
flat-panel
screens
called
active-matrix
liquid
crystal
displays
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
technologies
are
intended
to
retire
the
cathode-ray
tube
,
which
accounts
for
most
of
the
bulk
of
the
conventional
TV
set
.
<END>
<START>
Large
U.S.
companies
are
interested
in
other
segments
of
the
HDTV
business
,
such
as
signal-processing
and
broadcast
equipment
.
<END>
<START>
But
except
for
Zenith
Electronics
Corp.
and
International
Business
Machines
Corp.
,
which
is
collaborating
with
Toshiba
on
computer
displays
,
they
are
poorly
positioned
to
exploit
advances
in
large
panels
.
<END>
<START>
General
Electric
Co.
recently
sold
off
its
interests
in
liquid-crystal
displays
to
Thompson-CSF
of
France
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
found
the
market
not
developing
as
we
thought
it
would
,
''
a
GE
spokesman
says
.
<END>
<START>
The
small
U.S.
firms
are
persisting
because
of
their
strong
positions
in
patents
,
and
because
the
prize
is
still
there
to
be
seized
.
<END>
<START>
``
No
one
yet
has
shown
the
ability
to
manufacture
these
panels
''
at
commercial
costs
,
says
Zvi
Yaniv
,
the
president
of
Ovonic
Imaging
.
<END>
<START>
He
says
he
thinks
his
company
is
just
a
few
years
from
doing
that
.
<END>
<START>
The
Bush
administration
,
hearing
conflicting
advice
about
what
its
role
in
HDTV
should
be
,
is
n't
doing
much
for
now
.
<END>
<START>
The
only
material
support
it
is
extending
to
the
struggling
U.S.
industry
is
$
30
million
in
awards
from
the
Pentagon
's
Defense
Advanced
Research
Projects
Agency
.
<END>
<START>
The
DARPA
funds
are
a
pittance
compared
with
what
Japan
and
other
prospective
competitors
are
spending
.
<END>
<START>
The
Commerce
Department
estimates
that
Japanese
government
and
industry
spending
on
HDTV
research
is
already
over
$
1
billion
.
<END>
<START>
``
Unless
it
gets
more
help
,
the
U.S.
industry
wo
n't
have
a
chance
,
''
says
Peter
Friedman
,
Photonics
's
executive
vice
president
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
far
,
almost
all
of
the
basic
technology
relating
to
high-definition
television
has
come
from
U.S.
laboratories
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
1970s
,
Mr.
Brody
helped
develop
the
first
display
panels
based
on
active-matrix
liquid
crystals
at
Westinghouse
Electric
Corp.
's
research
labs
in
Pittsburgh
.
<END>
<START>
The
panels
are
like
oversized
semiconductors
surfaced
with
a
million
or
more
picture
elements
,
each
contributing
to
the
color
and
tone
of
a
TV
image
.
<END>
<START>
In
1979
,
however
,
Westinghouse
abandoned
the
project
along
with
its
stake
in
advanced
television
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Brody
left
the
company
to
find
other
backers
.
<END>
<START>
He
has
a
claim
to
the
right
to
commercialize
the
Westinghouse
patents
,
but
he
contends
that
those
patents
are
being
infringed
by
a
number
of
Japanese
producers
.
<END>
<START>
``
Most
American
investors
have
just
given
up
,
''
Mr.
Brody
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
are
n't
prepared
to
compete
in
an
area
where
the
Japanese
want
to
enter
.
''
<END>
<START>
Many
critics
question
the
industry
's
need
for
federal
support
;
the
Pentagon
justifies
its
help
on
national-security
grounds
.
<END>
<START>
So
DARPA
is
trying
to
keep
the
industry
interested
in
developing
large
display
panels
by
doling
out
research
funds
.
<END>
<START>
HDTV
already
has
some
military
applications
,
such
as
creating
realistic
flight
simulations
and
transmitting
information
to
combat
commanders
.
<END>
<START>
The
Navy
is
ordering
displays
for
its
Aegis
cruisers
and
the
Army
wants
smaller
versions
for
its
Abrams
battle
tanks
.
<END>
<START>
The
Commerce
Department
also
is
trying
to
encourage
HDTV
because
of
the
benefits
that
could
spin
off
to
the
semiconductor
and
computer
industries
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
is
n't
just
yuppie
television
,
''
argues
Jack
Clifford
,
director
of
the
department
's
office
of
microelectronics
and
instrumentation
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
industry
will
create
industrial
products
such
as
displays
for
work
stations
and
medical
diagnostic
equipment
before
it
acquires
a
mass
consumer
market
.
''
<END>
<START>
Although
some
HDTV
advocates
are
calling
for
other
forms
of
aid
,
such
as
antitrust
relief
for
research
consortia
,
the
small
firms
simply
would
prefer
more
DARPA
funds
.
<END>
<START>
Each
claims
to
possess
the
right
technology
and
wants
just
a
bit
more
money
to
make
it
commercial
.
<END>
<START>
They
also
want
U.S.
trade
policy
to
reflect
the
Pentagon
and
Commerce
department
's
concern
over
their
future
.
<END>
<START>
And
they
want
the
U.S.
to
help
them
sell
overseas
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
n't
a
technology
issue
,
but
an
attitude
issue
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
just
have
n't
learned
what
it
takes
to
compete
.
<END>
<START>
Burmah
Oil
PLC
,
a
British
independent

and

,
said
SHV
Holdings
N.V.

.
<END>
<START>
The

that

SHV

.

<START>
Citizens
&

Corp.
said

Corp.
's

.
<END>

'

.
<END>
<START>

of
another
company
's

.
<END>
<START>

,
based
in

,

has
about
$
4.6
billion
in

sales
annually
;

annually
.

<START>

's

business
works

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
Generally
,

.

,

.

.

,

<START>
The

,

,

.

,

of

.
<END>
<START>
Growth
is
good
.
<END>
<START>
They
are
starting
to
buy
growth
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
Remember
them
?
<END>
<START>
That
sort
of
workhorse
performance
sounds
made
to
order
for
a
time
when
corporate
profits
overall
have
been
weakening
from
the
brisk
increases
of
recent
years
.
<END>
<START>
The
current
flood
of
third-quarter
reports
are
producing
many
more
negative
surprises
than
positive
ones
.
<END>
<START>
The
question
for
investors
is
,
how
to
protect
these
returns
and
yet
reach
a
little
for
additional
gains
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
the
path
of
reasoning
leading
to
growth
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
think
it
is
a
good
theme
for
what
looks
to
be
an
uncertain
market
,
''
says
Steven
Einhorn
,
partner
at
Goldman
Sachs
.
<END>
<START>
Growth
stocks
also
are
attractive
in
periods
of
market
volatility
,
which
many
investors
and
analysts
expect
in
the
weeks
ahead
as
everybody
tries
to
discern
where
the
economy
is
heading
.
<END>
<START>
And
they
will
again
,
say
money-manager
proponents
of
the
growth-stock
theme
.
<END>
<START>
He
also
thinks
foreign
investors
,
who
are
showing
signs
of
more
discriminate
investing
,
will
join
the
pursuit
and
pump
up
prices
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're
just
seeing
the
beginning
of
a
shift
,
''
Mr.
Smith
says
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Smith
recommends
Cypress
Semiconductor
that
is
currently
showing
a
robust
63
%
earnings
growth
rate
.
<END>
<START>
Ronald
Sloan
,
executive
vice
president
of
Siebel
Capital
Management
,
likes
Wellman
Inc.
,
a
company
that
recycles
plastic
into
synthetic
fibers
for
carpeting
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Sloan
praises
the
company
as
recession
resistant
and
notes
that
it
has
an
annual
earnings
growth
rate
of
32
%
a
year
over
the
past
five
years
.
<END>
<START>
Wellman
stock
closed
Friday
at
39
3/8
,
up
1/8
;
Mr.
Sloan
thinks
that
in
a
year
it
could
hit
60
.
<END>
<START>
Others
preach
the
gospel
of
buying
only
blue-chip
growth
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
He
recommends
such
blue-chip
growth
stalwarts
as
Philip
Morris
,
PepsiCo
,
CPC
International
,
Reebok
International
,
and
Limited
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
All
have
a
fiveyear
earnings
growth
rate
of
more
than
20
%
a
year
.
<END>
<START>
Some
money
managers
are
pursuing
growth
stocks
at
the
expense
of
those
that
rise
and
fall
along
with
the
economic
cycle
.
<END>
<START>
He
recently
trimmed
his
portfolio
of
International
Paper
,
Dow
Chemical
,
Quantum
Chemical
,
International
Business
Machines
and
Digital
Equipment
.
<END>
<START>
He
is
putting
money
in
Dress
Barn
,
Circuit
City
Stores
,
Bruno
's
,
and
Rubbermaid
.
<END>
<START>
Big
cyclical
companies
are
using
``
all
the
tricks
they
can
to
stabilize
earnings
,
''
says
Mr.
Sloan
.
<END>
<START>
He
cites
IBM
,
which
reported
a
30
%
earnings
decline
in
the
third
quarter
,
and
which
last
week
announced
a
$
1
billion
buy-back
of
its
shares
.
<END>
<START>
``
What
they
are
telling
you
is
that
they
do
n't
have
the
ability
to
generate
higher
returns
internally
,
''
says
Mr.
Sloan
.
<END>
<START>
``
When
they
are
buying
back
stock
at
10
times
earnings
,
they
are
suggesting
that
the
rate
of
return
on
competing
internal
projects
is
below
''
returns
on
the
stock
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
says
it
considers
its
shares
a
good
investment
.
<END>
<START>
But
not
all
strategists
or
money
managers
are
ready
to
throw
in
the
towel
completely
on
cyclicals
.
<END>
<START>
Growth
stocks
may
underperform
cyclical
stocks
next
year
if
the
Federal
Reserve
begins
to
let
interest
rates
drift
sufficiently
lower
to
boost
the
economy
.
<END>
<START>
Goldman
Sachs
's
Mr.
Einhorn
,
for
one
,
subscribes
to
that
scenario
.
<END>
<START>
He
suggests
investors
think
about
buying
cyclical
shares
in
the
weeks
ahead
,
as
well
as
growth
issues
.
<END>
<START>
Friday
's
Market
Activity
<END>
<START>
Stock
prices
finished
about
unchanged
Friday
in
quiet
expiration
trading
.
<END>
<START>
Traders
anticipated
a
volatile
session
due
to
the
October
expiration
of
stock-index
futures
and
options
,
and
options
on
individual
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
But
there
were
fewer
price
swings
than
expected
.
<END>
<START>
Buy
order
imbalances
on
several
big
stocks
were
posted
by
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
.
<END>
<START>
But
block
trading
desks
and
money
managers
made
a
concerted
effort
to
meet
the
imbalances
with
stock
to
sell
,
one
trader
said
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
the
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
drifted
in
narrow
ranges
in
the
final
hour
of
trading
,
and
closed
5.94
higher
to
2689.14
.
<END>
<START>
New
York
Stock
Exchange
volume
was
164,830,000
.
<END>
<START>
Advancers
on
the
Big
Board
lagged
decliners
662
to
829
.
<END>
<START>
Broader
market
averages
were
little
changed
in
the
latest
session
.
<END>
<START>
Most
of
last
week
's
surge
in
the
industrial
average
came
on
Monday
,
when
the
average
rose
88.12
points
as
market

snapped
up

and
shunned
the
broad
market
.
<END>
<START>

by

.
<END>
<START>

500

4

,

index

3.7
%

3.5
%
.
<END>

.

5/8

.

<START>
The
collapse
of
a
$
6.79
billion
buy-out
of
United
Airlines
parent
UAL
Corp.
has
handed
Wall
Street
's
takeover
stock
speculators
their
worst
loss
ever
on
a
single
deal
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
meantime
,
the
question
faced
by
investors
is
:
What
is
UAL
stock
worth
?
<END>
<START>
The
short
answer
,
on
a
fundamental
basis
,
is
that
airline
analysts
say
the
stock
is
worth
somewhere
between
$
135
and
$
150
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
based
on
a
multiple
of
anywhere
between
8.5
to
10
times
UAL
earnings
,
which
are
estimated
to
come
in
somewhere
around
$
16
a
share
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Airline
stocks
typically
sell
at
a
discount
of
about
one-third
to
the
stock
market
's
price-earnings
ratio
--
which
is
currently
about
13
times
earnings
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
because
airline
earnings
,
like
those
of
auto
makers
,
have
been
subject
to
the
cyclical
ups-and-downs
of
the
economy
.
<END>
<START>
At
that
level
,
and
given
the
uncertainty
,
he
believes
UAL
stock
should
trade
closer
to
<END>
<START>
By
that
logic
,
the
closing
of
a
deal
could
be
much
further
away
than
three
to
four
months
,
even
though
the
eventual
price
might
be
higher
.
<END>
<START>
The
pilots
have
a
strong
financing
tool
in
their
willingness
to
cut
their
annual
compensation
by
$
200
million
,
and
to
commit
$
200
million
from
their
retirement
funds
.
<END>
<START>
On
Friday
,
they
also
persuaded
the
UAL
flight
attendants
to
join
them
.
<END>
<START>
Banks
want
to
see
someone
putting
up
real
cash
at
risk
,
that
is
,
subordinate
to
the
bank
debt
in
any
deal
.
<END>
<START>
Banks
also
want
to
be
able
to
call
someone
on
the
telephone
to
fix
a
problem
with
a
deal
that
goes
bad
--
preferably
someone
other
than
a
union
leader
.
<END>
<START>
One
obstacle
to
the
pilots
'
finding
such
a
huge
amount
of
cash
is
their
insistence
on
majority
ownership
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
such
as
Marvin
Davis
of
Los
Angeles
who
have
sought
airline
ownership
this
year
have
insisted
they
,
not
the
pilots
,
must
have
control
.
<END>
<START>
One
way
out
of
that

could
be
a
partial

in
which
the
pilots
would
wind
up
sharing
the
value
of
their
concessions
with
public
shareholders
.
<END>
<START>
The
pilots
could
borrow
against
the
value
of
their
concessions
,
using
the
proceeds
to
buy
back
stock
from
the
public
and
give
themselves
the
majority
control
they
have
been
seeking
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
is
n't
clear
that
banks
would
lend
sufficient
money
to
deliver
a
big
enough
price
to
shareholders
.
<END>
<START>
The
lack
of
any
new
cash
probably
would
still
leave
the
banks
dissatisfied
.
<END>
<START>
First
Boston
's

.
<END>

.

.

.
