Partners
Limited
Partnership
said
it
proposed
to
acquire
A.P.
Green
Industries
Inc.
for
$
40
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
In
an
Oct.
19
letter
to
A.P.
Green
's
board
,
East
Rock
said
the
offer
is
subject
to
the
signing
of
a
merger
agreement
by
no
later
than
Oct.
31
.
<END>
<START>
The
letter
,
attached
to
a
filing
with
the
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
,
said
the
approval
is
also
contingent
upon
obtaining
satisfactory
financing
.
<END>
<START>
An
A.P.
Green
official
declined
to
comment
on
the
filing
.
<END>
<START>
The
$
40-a-share
proposal
values
the
company
at
about
$
106.6
million
.
<END>
<START>
A.P.
Green
currently
has
2,664,098
shares
outstanding
.
<END>
<START>
Its
stock
closed
at
$
38
,
up
$
1.875
,
in
national
over-the-counter
trading
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
is
a
Mexico
,
Mo.
,
maker
of
refractory
products
.
<END>
<START>
East
Rock
also
said
in
the
filing
that
it
boosted
its
stake
in
A.P.
Green
to
8.7
%
.
<END>
<START>
It
now
holds
233,000
A.P.
Green
common
shares
,
including
30,000
shares
bought
last
Thursday
for
$
35.50
to
$
36.50
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
New
York-based
John
Kuhns
and
Robert
MacDonald
control
East
Rock
Partners
Inc.
,
the
sole
general
partner
of
East
Rock
Partners
L.P
.
<END>
<START>
The
sole
limited
partner
of
the
partnership
is
Westwood
Brick
Lime
Inc.
,
an
indirect
subsidiary
of
Westwood
Group
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
Both
Westwood
Brick
and
Westwood
Group
are
based
in
Boston
.
<END>
<START>
Freight
rates
,
declining
for
most
of
the
decade
because
of
competition
spurred
by
deregulation
,
are
bottoming
out
,
turning
upward
and
threatening
to
fuel
inflation
.
<END>
<START>
Trucking
,
shipping
and
air-freight
companies
have
announced
rate
increases
,
scheduled
for
this
fall
or
early
next
year
,
reflecting
higher
costs
and
tightened
demand
for
freight
transport
.
<END>
<START>
Major
shippers
say
they
expect
freight
rates
to
rise
at
least
as
fast
as
inflation
and
maybe
faster
in
the
next
few
years
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
a
big
change
from
recent
years
when
freight
haulage
was
a
bright
spot
for
U.S.
productivity
,
helping
to
restrain
inflation
and
make
U.S.
industry
more
competitive
abroad
.
<END>
<START>
Shippers
surveyed
recently
by
Ohio
State
University
said
they
expect
their
freight-transport
,
storage
and
distribution
costs
to
rise
about
4
%
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Only
10
%
of
the
250
shippers
polled
expected
their
freight-transport
costs
to
decrease
,
compared
with
30
%
who
had
looked
to
freight
transport
to
reduce
costs
in
past
years
.
<END>
<START>
The
deregulation
of
railroads
and
trucking
companies
that
began
in
1980
enabled
shippers
to
bargain
for
transportation
.
<END>
<START>
Carriers
could
use
their
equipment
more
efficiently
,
leading
to
overcapacity
they
were
eager
to
fill
.
<END>
<START>
But
with
much
of
the
inefficiency
squeezed
out
of
the
freight-transport
system
,
rising
costs
are
likely
to
be
reflected
directly
in
higher
freight
rates
.
<END>
<START>
``
Shippers
are
saying
`
the
party
's
over
,
'
''
said
Mr.
LaLonde
.
<END>
<START>
``
Shippers
wo
n't
be
able
to
look
for
transportation-cost
savings
as
they
have
for
the
last
eight
or
nine
years
.
<END>
<START>
Transport
rates
wo
n't
be
an
opportunity
for
offsetting
cost
increases
in
other
segments
of
the
economy
.
''
<END>
<START>
Robert
Delaney
,
a
consultant
at
Arthur
D.
Little
Inc.
,
Cambridge
,
Mass.
,
said
``
We
've
gotten
all
the
benefits
of
deregulation
in
freight-cost
reductions
.
<END>
<START>
Now
we
are
starting
to
see
real
freight-rate
increases
as
carriers
replace
equipment
,
pay
higher
fuel
costs
and
pay
more
for
labor
.
<END>
<START>
You
'll
see
carriers
try
to
recoup
some
of
the
price
cutting
that
occurred
previously
.
''
<END>
<START>
Not
everyone
believes
that
the
good
times
are
over
for
shippers
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
's
still
a
lot
of
pressure
on
rates
in
both
rail
and
truck
,
''
said
Gerard
McCullough
,
lecturer
in
transportation
at
Massachusetts
Institute
of
Technology
.
<END>
<START>
Less-than-truckload
companies
,
which
carry
the
freight
of
several
shippers
in
each
truck
trailer
,
discounted
away
a
4.7
%
rate
increase
implemented
last
April
.
<END>
<START>
The
carriers
were
competing
fiercely
for
market
share
.
<END>
<START>
Railroad-rate
increases
are
likely
to
be
restrained
by
weakening
rail-traffic
levels
and
keen
competition
for
freight
from
trucks
.
<END>
<START>
An
official
at
Consolidated
Freightways
Inc.
,
a
Menlo
Park
,
Calif.
,
less-than-truckload
carrier
,
said
rate
discounting
in
that
industry
has
begun
to
``
stabilize
.
''
<END>
<START>
Consolidated
Freightways
plans
to
raise
its
rates
5.3
%
late
this
year
or
early
next
year
,
and
at
least
two
competitors
have
announced
similar
increases
.
<END>
<START>
And
``
shippers
are
getting
the
feeling
that
they
have
played
one
trucker
off
against
another
as
much
as
they
can
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Air-freight
carriers
raised
their
rates
for
U.S.
products
going
across
the
Pacific
to
Asia
by
about
20
%
earlier
this
month
.
<END>
<START>
And
Japan
Air
Lines
said
it
plans
to
boost
its
rates
a
further
25
%
over
the
next
two
years
.
<END>
<START>
Ship
companies
carrying
bulk
commodities
,
such
as
oil
,
grain
,
coal
and
iron
ore
,
have
been
able
to
increase
their
rates
in
the
last
couple
of
years
.
<END>
<START>
Some
bulk
shipping
rates
have
increased
``
3
%
to
4
%
in
the
past
few
months
,
''
said
Salomon
's
Mr.
Lloyd
.
<END>
<START>
And
ship
lines
carrying
containers
are
also
trying
to
raise
their
rates
.
<END>
<START>
Carriers
boosted
rates
more
than
10
%
in
the
North
Atlantic
between
the
U.S.
and
Europe
last
September
,
hoping
to
partly
restore
rates
to
earlier
levels
.
<END>
<START>
Ship
lines
operating
in
the
Pacific
plan
to
raise
rates
on
containers
carrying
U.S.
exports
to
Asia
about
10
%
,
effective
next
April
.
<END>
<START>
MGM
Grand
Inc.
said
it
filed
a
registration
statement
with
the
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
for
a
public
offering
of
six
million
common
shares
.
<END>
<START>
The
Beverly
Hills
,
Calif.-based
company
said
it
would
have
26.9
million
common
shares
outstanding
after
the
offering
.
<END>
<START>
The
hotel
and
Gaming
company
said
Merrill
Lynch
Capital
Markets
will
lead
the
underwriters
.
<END>
<START>
Proceeds
from
the
sale
will
be
used
for
remodeling
and
refurbishing
projects
,
as
well
as
for
the
planned
MGM
Grand
hotel/casino
and
theme
park
.
<END>
<START>
Bob
Stone
stewed
over
a
letter
from
his
manager
putting
him
on
probation
for
insubordination
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Stone
thought
the
discipline
was
unfair
;
he
believed
that
his
manager
wanted
to
get
rid
of
him
for
personal
reasons
.
<END>
<START>
Unable
to
persuade
the
manager
to
change
his
decision
,
he
went
to
a
``
company
court
''
for
a
hearing
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
scheduled
time
,
Mr.
Stone
entered
a
conference
room
in
a
building
near
where
he
worked
.
<END>
<START>
After
the
three
members
of
the
court
introduced
themselves
,
the
chairman
of
the
panel
said
:
``
Go
ahead
and
tell
us
what
happened
.
<END>
<START>
We
may
ask
questions
as
you
go
along
,
or
we
may
wait
until
the
end
.
''
<END>
<START>
No
lawyers
or
tape
recorders
were
present
.
<END>
<START>
Over
a
cup
of
coffee
,
Mr.
Stone
told
his
story
.
<END>
<START>
He
talked
about
20
minutes
.
<END>
<START>
When
he
was
through
,
the
court
members
asked
many
questions
,
then
the
chairman
said
they
would
like
to
hear
his
manager
's
side
and
talk
to
witnesses
.
<END>
<START>
The
chairman
promised
Mr.
Stone
a
decision
within
two
weeks
.
<END>
<START>
Bob
Stone
is
a
fictional
name
,
but
the
incident
described
is
real
.
<END>
<START>
It
happened
at
Northrop
Corp.
in
Los
Angeles
.
<END>
<START>
The
court
is
called
the
Management
Appeals
Committee
,
or
just
``
MAC
,
''
and
it
is
likely
to
hear
a
couple
of
dozen
cases
a
year
.
<END>
<START>
These
firms
are
pioneers
in
a
significant
new
trend
in
the
corporate
world
:
the
rise
of
what
I
call
corporate
due
process
.
<END>
<START>
Although
corporate
due
process
is
practiced
today
in
few
companies
--
perhaps
40
to
60
--
it
is
one
of
the
fastest
developing
trends
in
industry
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
coming
decade
a
majority
of
people-oriented
companies
are
likely
to
adopt
it
.
<END>
<START>
Corporate
due
process
appeals
to
management
for
a
variety
of
reasons
.
<END>
<START>
It
reduces
lawsuits
from
disgruntled
employees
and
ex-employees
,
with
all
that
means
for
reduced
legal
costs
and
better
public
relations
.
<END>
<START>
It
helps
to
keep
out
unions
.
<END>
<START>
It
increases
employee
commitment
to
the
company
,
with
all
that
means
for
efficiency
and
quality
control
.
<END>
<START>
What
must
your
management
team
do
to
establish
corporate
due
process
?
<END>
<START>
Here
are
four
key
steps
:
<END>
<START>
1
.
Make
sure
you
have
a
strong
personnel
department
.
<END>
<START>
At
Polaroid
,
the
Personnel
Policy
Planning
Committee
may
hear
only
about
20
cases
a
year
;
the
rest
of
the
many
hundreds
of
complaints
are
resolved
at
earlier
stages
.
<END>
<START>
At
TWA
,
the
System
Board
of
Adjustment
hears
50
to
75
cases
a
year
,
only
a
fraction
of
the
complaints
brought
to
personnel
specialists
.
<END>
<START>
At
Citicorp
,
the
Problem
Review
Board
may
hear
only
12
or
so
cases
because
of
personnel
's
skill
in
complaint-resolution
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
typical
year
,
up
to
20
%
of
the
work
force
goes
to
personnel
specialists
with
complaints
of
unfair
treatment
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
large
company
that
means
many
hundreds
of
complaints
for
personnel
to
handle
.
<END>
<START>
2
.
Formally
or
informally
,
train
all
your
managers
and
supervisors
in
the
company
's
due-process
approach
.
<END>
<START>
See
that
they
know
company
personnel
policy
backwards
and
forwards
,
for
it
is
the
``
law
''
governing
company
courts
and
adjudicators
.
<END>
<START>
Coach
them
in
handling
complaints
so
that
they
can
resolve
problems
immediately
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
15
companies
I
studied
,
reversal
rates
range
on
the
average
from
20
%
to
40
%
.
<END>
<START>
3
.
Decide
whether
you
want
a
panel
system
or
a
single
adjudicator
.
<END>
<START>
A
panel
system
like
that
in
the
Bob
Stone
example
enjoys
such
advantages
as
high
credibility
and
,
for
the
panelists
,
mutual
support
.
<END>
<START>
International
Business
Machines
and
Bank
of
America
are
among
the
companies
using
the
single-adjudicator
approach
.
<END>
<START>
4
.
Make
your
due-process
system
visible
.
<END>
<START>
It
wo
n't
do
any
good
for
anybody
unless
employees
know
about
it
.
<END>
<START>
Most
managements
hesitate
to
go
all
out
in
advertising
their
due-process
systems
for
fear
of
encouraging
cranks
and
chronic
soreheads
to
file
complaints
.
<END>
<START>
On
the
other
hand
,
they
make
sure
at
a
minimum
that
their
systems
are
described
in
their
employee
handbooks
and
talked
up
by
personnel
specialists
.
<END>
<START>
Smith-Kline
Beecham
goes
further
and
sometimes
features
its
grievance
procedure
in
closed-circuit
TV
programs
.
<END>
<START>
Naturally
,
one
of
the
best
ways
to
guarantee
visibility
for
your
due-process
system
is
for
top
management
to
support
it
.
<END>
<START>
At
IBM
,
the
company
's
Open
Door
system
is
sometimes
the
subject
of
memorandums
from
the
chief
executive
.
<END>
<START>
Tokyo
stocks
closed
higher
in
active
trading
Friday
,
marking
the
fourth
consecutive
daily
gain
since
Monday
's
sharp
fall
.
<END>
<START>
London
shares
closed
moderately
lower
in
thin
trading
.
<END>
<START>
At
Tokyo
,
the
Nikkei
index
of
225
selected
issues
was
up
112.16
points
to
35486.38
.
<END>
<START>
The
index
advanced
266.66
points
Thursday
.
<END>
<START>
In
early
trading
in
Tokyo
Monday
,
the
Nikkei
index
rose
101.98
points
to
35588.36
.
<END>
<START>
Friday
's
volume
on
the
First
Section
was
estimated
at
one
billion
shares
,
up
from
862
million
Thursday
.
<END>
<START>
Winners
outpaced
losers
,
572
to
368
,
while
181
issues
remained
unchanged
.
<END>
<START>
With
investors
relieved
at
the
overnight
gain
in
New
York
stocks
,
small-lot
buying
orders
streamed
into
the
market
from
early
morning
,
making
traders
believe
the
market
was
back
to
normal
.
<END>
<START>
The
Nikkei
,
which
reached
as
high
as
35611.38
right
after
the
opening
,
surrendered
part
of
its
early
advance
toward
the
end
of
the
day
because
of
profit-taking
.
<END>
<START>
The
Second
Section
index
,
which
rose
15.72
points
Thursday
,
was
up
11.88
points
,
or
0.32
%
,
to
close
at
3717.46
.
<END>
<START>
Volume
in
the
second
section
was
estimated
at
30
million
shares
,
up
from
28
million
Thursday
.
<END>
<START>
In
turmoil
caused
by
the
previous
Friday
's
plunge
in
New
York
stocks
,
the
Nikkei
marked
a
sharp
647.33-point
fall
Monday
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
Nikkei
fell
an
overall
1.8
%
in
value
that
day
compared
with
Wall
Street
's
far
sharper
6.9
%
drop
on
Oct.
13
.
<END>
<START>
The
Nikkei
continued
to
gain
for
the
rest
of
the
week
,
adding
1017.69
points
in
four
days
--
more
than
erasing
Monday
's
losses
.
<END>
<START>
But
further
major
advances
on
the
Nikkei
are
n't
foreseen
this
week
by
market
observers
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
are
still
waiting
to
see
how
the
U.S.
government
will
decide
on
interest
rates
and
how
the
dollar
will
be
stabilized
.
<END>
<START>
Some
high-priced
issues
made
a
comeback
Friday
.
<END>
<START>
Pioneer
surged
450
yen

<START>
Here

's

,

1969

100
.
<END>
<START>
The
percentage
change
is
since
year-end
.
<END>
<START>
The
U.S.
is
required
to
notify
foreign
dictators
if
it
knows
of
coup
plans
likely
to
endanger
their
lives
,
government

said
.
<END>
<START>
The
notification
policy
was
part
of
a
set
of
guidelines
on
handling
coups
outlined
in
a
secret
1988
exchange

.
<END>
<START>
The

has

known
since
President
Bush
disclosed

to
seven

at

last
Monday
.
<END>
<START>
According

officials
,
Mr.
Bush
even
read
to
the
senators
selections
from
a
highly
classified
letter
from
the
committee
to
the
White
House
discussing
the
guidelines
.
<END>
<START>
They
said
the
president
conceded
the
notification
requirement
did
n't
affect
his
decision
to
lend
only
minor
support
to
this
month
's
Panama
coup
effort
.
<END>
<START>
No
notification
was
ever
considered
,
officials
said
,
apparently
because
the
U.S.
did
n't
think
the
coup
plotters
intended
to
kill
Mr.
Noriega
,
but

to

.
<END>
<START>
The

was

and
intelligence

Oct.
12
,

.

<START>
However
,

,

,
is

.
<END>
<START>
The

,
``

.
''

.

.
''

<START>

n't

by

because

.
<END>
<START>
But
the

and

stressed
that
the
notification

was

imposed

by

.
<END>
<START>
Instead
,

<END>

.
<END>
<START>
One

``
gets

''
of
somebody
else
's

that

.
<END>
<START>
But

.

<START>

''

.

<START>

,

,

had

.

<START>
Though

that

never

,

.

<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.

,

,

.

<START>
-LRB-
During
its
centennial
year
,
The
Wall
Street
Journal
will
report
events
of
the
past
century
that
stand
as
milestones
of
American

history
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
By
1980
,
there
were
more
than
100
such
funds
.
<END>
<START>
Besides
creating
a
vehicle
for
investors
,
money
market
funds
also
helped
rewrite
banking
regulations
.
<END>
<START>
The
idea
was
to
let
small
investors
,
the
backbone
of
the
fund
business
,
deal
in
the
money
market
's
high
short-term
interest
rates
.
<END>
<START>
This
had
been
the
exclusive
province
of
those
rich
enough
to
use
six-figure
sums
to
get
income
that
was
figured
beyond
the
third
or
fourth
decimal
place
.
<END>
<START>
The
now-standard
price
of
$
1
a
share
came
about
by
accident
.
<END>
<START>
An
early
fund
had
filed
a
registration
with
the
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
that
included
a
fixed
$
1
price
.
<END>
<START>
It
arrived
just
as
the
regulator
handling
such
operations
was
retiring
.
<END>
<START>
His
successor
approved
the
$
1
price
in
the
process
of
clearing
the
backed-up
papers
on
his
desk
.
<END>
<START>
When
Dreyfus
started
the
first
advertising-backed
retail
fund
in
February
1974
,
it
was
priced
at
$
10
a
share
-LRB-
and
reached
$
1
billion
in
assets
in
one
year
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Dreyfus
moved
to
the
$
1
price
after
the
SEC
set
standards
--
an
average
120-day
maturity
of
high-grade
paper
--
that
are
still
the
rule
.
<END>
<START>
Keeping
the
listed
price
at
a
dollar
is
primarily
a
convenience
.
<END>
<START>
Actually
,
the
funds
do
fluctuate
,
but
beyond
the
third
decimal
place
.
<END>
<START>
Rounding-off
keeps
them
at
$
1
.
<END>
<START>
Eventually
,
the
money
funds
'
success
forced
relaxation
of
curbs
on
bank
interest
rates
to
allow

to
offer
competing

.
<END>
<START>
The
new

also
introduced
many
to
the
industry
--
30
%
of
fund
owners
-LRB-
there

more
than
54
million

-RRB-
started

.

Today

470

.

.

<START>

<START>

estimate
of
3.3
%
for
third-quarter
GNP
is
higher
than
the
consensus
largely
because
he
believes
current
inventories
are
n't
as
low
as
official
figures
indicate
.
<END>
<START>
Demand
,
he
believes
,
is
being
met
from
overhang
rather
than
new
production
.
<END>
<START>
By
and
large
,
economists
believe
the
two
natural
catastrophes
will
limit
economic
damage
to
their
regions
.
<END>
<START>
He
expects
real
GNP
growth
of
only
2.1
%
for
the
quarter
,
noting
a
wider
trade
deficit
,
slower
capital
and
government
spending
and
the
lower
inventory
figures
.
<END>
<START>
The
consensus
calls
for
a
0.5
%
increase
in
September
personal
income
and
a
0.3
%
gain
in
consumption
.
<END>
<START>
In
August
,
personal
income
rose
0.4
%
and
personal
consumption
increased
0.9
%
.
<END>
<START>
Durable
goods
orders
for
September
,
due
out
tomorrow
,
are
expected
to
show
a
slip
of
1
%
,
compared
with
August
's
3.9
%
increase
.
<END>
<START>
As
usual
,
estimates
on
the
fickle
report
are
wide
,
running
from
a
drop
of
3.5
%
to
a
gain
of
1.6
%
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
the
11th
consecutive
quarter
in
which
the
company
has
paid
shareholders
an
extra
dividend
of
five
cents
.
<END>
<START>
The
Hastings
,
Mich.
,
concern
makes
piston
rings
,
filters
and
fuel
pumps
.
<END>
<START>
I.E.P.
Securities
Ltd.
,
a
unit
of
Mr.
Brierley
's
Hong
Kong-based
Industrial
Equity
-LRB-
Pacific
-RRB-
Ltd.
,
boosted
its
holdings
in
Vickers
to
38.8
million
shares
.
<END>
<START>
The
latest
purchase
follows
small
increases
in
his
holdings
made
over
the
past
five
months
.
<END>
<START>
In
May
,
Mr.
Brierley
's
stake
shrank
to
8.7
%
after
ranging
between
9
%
and
11
%
for
much
of
the
previous
year
.
<END>
<START>
``
Ron
Brierley
clearly
views
our
company
as
a
good
investment
,
''
a
Vickers
spokesman
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
spokesman
refused
to
comment
on
speculation
that
Industrial
Equity
might
use
its
interest
as
a
platform
to
launch
a
hostile
bid
for
the
company
.
<END>
<START>
Vickers
makes
tanks
for
the
U.K.
army
,
Rolls
Royce
cars
,
and
has
marine
and
medical
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
When
Rune
Andersson
set
out
to
revive
flagging
Swedish
conglomerate
Trelleborg
AB
in
the
early
1980s
,
he
spurned
the
advice
of
trendy
management
consultants
.
<END>
<START>
``
All
these
consultants
kept
coming
around
telling
us
we
should
concentrate
on
high
technology
,
electronics
or
biotechnology
,
and
get
out
of
mature
basic
industries
,
''
Mr.
Andersson
recalls
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
a
gutsy
move
for
a
little-known
executive
,
fired
after
only
two
months
as
president
of
his
previous
company
.
<END>
<START>
But
going
against
the
grain
has
never
bothered
Mr.
Andersson
.
<END>
<START>
Stroking
his
trademark
white
goatee
during
a
recent
interview
,
the
diminutive
Swede
quips
:
``
It
turned
out
to
be
lucky
for
us
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
whole
market
thinks
what
you
're
doing
is
crazy
you
do
n't
have
much
competition
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Andersson
is
anxious
to
strengthen
Trelleborg
's
balance
sheet
.
<END>
<START>
Characteristically
,
he
did
n't
waste
much
time
getting
started
.
<END>
<START>
On
Tuesday
,
Trelleborg
's
directors
announced
plans
to
spin
off
two
big
divisions
--
minerals
processing
,
and
building
and
distribution
--
as
separately
quoted
companies
on
Stockholm
's
Stock
Exchange
.
<END>
<START>
The
board
had
also
been
expected
to
approve
a
SKr1.5
billion
international
offering
of
new
Trelleborg
shares
.
<END>
<START>
But
that
share
issue
--
intended
to
make
Trelleborg
better
known
among
international
investors
--
was
postponed
until
market
conditions
stabilize
,
people
familiar
with
the
situation
say
.
<END>
<START>
Trelleborg
's
internationally
traded
``
Bfree
''
series
stock
plunged
SKr29
-LRB-
$
4.48
-RRB-
to
SKr205
-LRB-
$
31.65
-RRB-
in
volatile
trading
Monday
in
Stockholm
.
<END>
<START>
Tuesday
,
the
shares
regained
SKr20
,
closing
at
SKr225
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Andersson
says
he
is
confident
that
taking
parts
of
the
company
public
will
help
erase
the
``
conglomerate
stigma
''
that
has
held
down
Trelleborg
's
share
price
.
<END>
<START>
Trelleborg
plans
to
remain
the
dominant
shareholder
with
stakes
of
slightly
less
than
50
%
of
both
units
.
<END>
<START>
The
spinoff
should
solve
a
problem
for
the
parent
.
<END>
<START>
A
family
foundation
set
up
by
late
founder
Henry
Dunker
controls
59
%
of
Trelleborg
's
voting
shares
outstanding
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
foundation
bylaws
require
the
entire
Trelleborg
stake
to
be
sold
in
the
open
market
if
control
drops
below
50
%
.
<END>
<START>
That
possibility
had
crept
closer
as
repeated
new
share
offerings
to
finance
Trelleborg
's
rapid
growth
steadily
diluted
the
foundation
's
holding
.
<END>
<START>
That
growth
is
the
result
of
Mr.
Andersson
's
shopping
spree
,
during
which
he
has
bought
and
sold
more
than
100
companies
during
the
past
five
years
.
<END>
<START>
Most
of
the
new
additions
were
barely
profitable
,
if
not
outright
loss
makers
.
<END>
<START>
Applying
prowess
gained
during
earlier
stints
at
appliance
maker
AB
Electrolux
,
Mr.
Andersson
and
a
handful
of
loyal
lieutenants
aggressively
stripped
away
dead
wood
--
and
got
quick
results
.
<END>
<START>
The
treatment
turned
Trelleborg
into
one
of
Scandinavia
's
biggest
and
fastest-growing
industrial
concerns
.
<END>
<START>
Between
1985
and
1988
,
sales
multipled
more
than
10
times
and
pretax
profit
surged
almost
twelvefold
.
<END>
<START>
Many
analysts
expect
Mr.
Andersson
,
who
owns
1.7
%
of
the
company
,
to
be
named
Trelleborg
's
new
chairman
when
Ernst
Herslow
steps
down
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
Industry
analysts
suggest
that
the
conquest
of
Falconbridge
could
vault
Trelleborg
from
a
regional
Scandinavian
success
story
to
a
world-class
mining
concern
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
we
certainly
like
what
we
've
seen
so
far
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
Trelleborg
still
must
clear
some
tough
hurdles
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Andersson
acknowledges
that
the
company
's
mining
division
``
will
be
busy
for
a
while
digesting
its
recent
expansion
.
''
<END>
<START>
Booming
metals
prices
have
fueled
Trelleborg
's
recent
profit
surge
,
raising
mining
's
share
of
pretax
profit
to
68
%
this
year
from
a
big
loss
two
years
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
But
analysts
caution
an
expected
fall
in
metal
prices
next
year
could
slow
profit
growth
.
<END>
<START>
Mining
is
likely
to
remain
Trelleborg
's
main
business
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
say
its
chances
of
success
will
likely
hinge
on
how
well
Trelleborg
manages
to
cooperate
with
Noranda
in
the
Falconbridge
venture
.
<END>
<START>
Noranda
and
Trelleborg
each
came
close
to
winning
Falconbridge
alone
before
the
successful
joint
bid
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Andersson
insists
that
Trelleborg
and
Noranda
have
n't
discussed
a
Falconbridge
break-up
.
<END>
<START>
Falconbridge
,
he
says
,
will
continue
operating
in
its
current
form
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
'd
be
reluctant
to
accept
50-50
ownership
in
a
manufacturing
company
.
<END>
<START>
But
such
partnerships
are
common
in
mining
,
where
there
are
n't
problems
or
conflict
of
interest
or
risk
of
cheating
by
a
partner
,
''
Trelleborg
's
president
says
.
<END>
<START>
Perhaps
more
important
,
both
companies
share
Mr.
Andersson
's
belief
in
the
coming
renaissance
of
base
industries
.
<END>
<START>
``
If

1980s
were
a
decade
of
consumption
,
the
'90s
will
be
the

,
''
Mr.

.
<END>
<START>
``
The
whole

Europe

is

in

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
``
That
's

to
change
.
<END>
<START>
And

is
the

word
for
base
metals
,
and
most

Trelleborg
is
in
.
<END>
<START>
Apple
Computer
Inc.
posted

48
million
gain

.
<END>
<START>

Adobe

brought

in

quarter
to
$
161.1

,

.
<END>
<START>
Apple
shares

75

in

to

at
$
48
a

.
<END>
<START>

18

a

.

<START>

,

.

<START>

for

30

billion
a

.

<START>
John
Sculley
,

,

SE/30
and

,

.

,

,

as

.

<START>
``
Adverse

on

...

,
''

.

<START>

in

,

51

.

49

,

.

<START>

--

,

--

.

<START>
The

will
display

.

<START>
Lotus
,
Cambridge
,
Mass.
,
has
been
rumored
to
have
the
sale
of
the
four-year-old
unit
under

for
a
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
business
is
n't

to

's
main

of

computer
software
and

on

.
<END>
<START>
``
Please
submit
your
offers
,
''
says
Felipe
Bince
Jr
.
<END>
<START>
The
agency
expects
the
bids
to
be
equivalent
of
more
than
$
80
million
.
<END>
<START>
Not
a

is

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bince
,
the

's

,

.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
getting
harder
to
sell
,
''
he
mutters
as
he
leaves
the
room
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
.
Recently
,
the
trust
failed
to
auction
off
the
paper
mill
,
a

,
an

and
a

.
<END>
<START>
Of
the
four
,
only
the
bank
and
the
plant
drew

--
one

.
<END>
<START>
Two
years
later
,
Mrs.
Aquino
's
promise
remains
largely
unfulfilled
.
<END>
<START>
October
is
a
critical
month
for
the
privatization
program
.
<END>
<START>
Manila
is
offering
several
major
assets
for
the
first
time
and
is
trying
to
conclude
sales
already
arranged
.
<END>
<START>
All
told
,
there
are
assets
on
the
line
valued
at
up
to
$
1.03
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
privatization
program
is
designed
to
rid
the
government
of
hundreds
of
assets
and
to
raise
critically
needed
funds
.
<END>
<START>
Much
of
the
money
from
the
sales
is
earmarked
for
a
multibillion-dollar
agrarian-reform
program
.
<END>
<START>
But
efforts
have
been
thwarted
by
official
indifference
,
bureaucratic
resistance
,
a
legal
system
that
operates
at
a
snail
's
pace
,
political
opposition
and
government
misjudgments
.
<END>
<START>
Most
recently
,
a
lack
of
buyers
has
been
added
to
the
list
.
<END>
<START>
Rather
than
gathering
momentum
,
the
program
is
in
danger
of
slowing
even
more
as
the
government
tackles
several
big
assets
.
<END>
<START>
The
axiom
appears
to
be
that
the
more
valuable
the
asset
,
the
harder
the
privatization
process
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
just
do
n't
see
a
whole
lot
happening
,
''
says
an
international
economist
.
<END>
<START>
To
be
sure
,
the
program
has
n't
completely
stalled
.
<END>
<START>
The
Asset
Privatization
Trust
,
the
agency
chiefly
responsible
for
selling
government-held
properties
,
has
recorded
sales
of
more
than
$
500
million
since
it
began
functioning
in
December
1986
.
<END>
<START>
But
its
success
has
been
largely
in
the
sale
of
small
,
nonperforming
companies
,
which
are
valued
for
their
assets
.
<END>
<START>
Dealing
with
the
sales
this
month
could
be
particularly
challenging
because
almost
every
problem
that
has
hobbled
the
program
in
the
past
is
popping
up
again
.
<END>
<START>
Ramon
Garcia
,
the
Asset
Trust
's
executive
trustee
,
admits
to
what
he
calls
``
temporary
setbacks
.
''
<END>
<START>
In
light
of
the
poor
results
recently
,
he
says
,
the
agency
is
adopting
an
``
attitude
of
flexibility
.
''
<END>
<START>
October
's
troubles
began
when
the
trust
failed
to
sell
a
state-owned
commercial
bank
,
Associated
Bank
,
for
the
minimum
price
of
671
million
pesos
-LRB-
$
31
million
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
end
of
the
month
,
the
agency
again
will
offer
the
bank
.
<END>
<START>
But
instead
of
a
minimum
price
,
only
a
target
price
will
be
established
.
<END>
<START>
Bankers
say
,
however
,
that
the
government
may
have
difficulty
selling
the
institution
even
without
a
floor
price
.
<END>
<START>
The
bank
has
a
negative
net
worth
,
they
say
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
special
bidding
rules
give
the
bank
's
former
owner
,
Leonardo
Ty
,
the
right
to
match
the
highest
bid
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Ty
lost
control
to
the
government
in
1980
when
a
government
bank
made
emergency
loans
to
the
cash-strapped
institution
.
<END>
<START>
In
1983
,
the
loans
were
converted
into
equity
,
giving
Manila
98
%
of
the
bank
,
but
with
the
understanding
that
Mr.
Ty
had
repurchase
rights
.
<END>
<START>
His
ability
to
match
any
bid
has
scared
off
many
potential
buyers
.
<END>
<START>
The
price
will
depend
on
how
much
Picop
shares
fetch
on
the
local
stock
market
.
<END>
<START>
But
according

and

who
have

,

.
<END>
<START>
As

,

would
continue

45
%

Picop

36

.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
About
7.5
%
of
Picop
is
publicly

and
other

own
the
rest

the
equity
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Garcia

the
problem
and

Asset
Trust

study

failed

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

.

.

<START>
Eagle
Financial
Corp.
and
Webster
Financial
Corp.
,
two
Connecticut
savings
bank-holding
companies
,
agreed
to
merge
in
a
tax-free
stock
transaction
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
holding
company
,
Webster/Eagle
Bancorp
Inc.
,
will
have
about
$
1.2
billion
of
assets
and
19
banking
offices
in
Connecticut
.
<END>
<START>
Tangible
capital
will
be
about
$
115
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
merger
is
subject
to
regulatory
clearance
and
a
definitive
agreement
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
merger
,
each
share
of
Webster
,
based
in
Waterbury
,
will
be
converted
into
one
share
of
the
new
company
.
<END>
<START>
Each
share
of
Eagle
,
based
in
Bristol
,
will
become
0.95
share
of
Webster/Eagle
.
<END>
<START>
In
American
Stock
Exchange
composite
trading
Friday
,
Eagle
shares
rose
12.5
cents
to
$
11
.
<END>
<START>
In
national
over-the-counter
trading
,
Webster
shares
fell
25
cents
to
$
12.375
.
<END>
<START>
Webster
has
3.5
million
shares
outstanding
and
Eagle
2.6
million
.
<END>
<START>
Their
indicated
market
values
thus
are
about
$
43.3
million
and
$
28.6
million
,
respectively
.
<END>
<START>
Harold
W.
Smith
Sr.
,
chairman
of
Webster
,
will
become
chairman
emeritus
and
a
director
of
the
new
company
.
<END>
<START>
Ralph
T.
Linsley
,
vice
chairman
of
Eagle
,
will
become
vice
chairman
of
Webster/Eagle
.
<END>
<START>
The
board
will
be
made
up
of
seven
directors
of
each
holding
company
.
<END>
<START>
In
an
interview
,
James
Smith
said
the
banks
'
``
markets
are
contiguous
and
their
business
philosophies
are
similar
and
conservative
.
''
<END>
<START>
Nonperforming
loans
will
make
up
only
about
0.5
%
of
the
combined
banks
'
total
loans
outstanding
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
At
June
30
,
Webster
,
which
owns
First
Federal
Savings
&
Loan
Association
of
Waterbury
,
had
assets
of
$
699
million
.
<END>
<START>
Eagle
,
which
controls
Bristol
Federal
Savings
Bank
and
First
Federal
Savings
&
Loan
Association
of
Torrington
,
had
assets
of
$
469.6
million
on
that
date
.
<END>
<START>
Having
said
that
,
we
must
caution
against
an
apparent
tendency
to
overstate
the
case
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
not
quite
true
,
for
example
,
that
the
Mexican
government
has
``
privatized
''
Mexicana
de
Aviacion
,
as
Mr.
Ortiz
claims
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
same
sentence
he
contradicts
himself
when
he
reports
that
the
government
still
retains
40
%
of
the
total
equity
of
the
airline
.
<END>
<START>
How
can
a
company
be
considered
``
privatized
''
if
the
state
is
so
heavily
represented
in
it
?
<END>
<START>
''
But
the
enterprises
still
in
state
hands
include
the
biggest
and
most
economically
powerful
ones
in
Mexico
;
indeed
,
they
virtually
constitute
the
economic
infrastructure
.
<END>
<START>
I
refer
essentially
to
petroleum
,
electric
power
,
banking
and
newsprint
.
<END>
<START>
Those
enterprises
,
however
,
are
not
going
to
be
privatized
.
<END>
<START>
They
are
officially
considered
``
strategic
,
''
and
their
privatization
is
prohibited
by
the
Mexican
Constitution
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
clearly
,
modernization
must
embrace
its
key
industries
before
it
can
be
said
to
have
caught
the
``
privatization
bug
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
bottom
line
,
however
,
is
not
economic
but
political
reform
.
<END>
<START>
A
long
succession
of
Mexican
presidents
arbitrarily
nationalized
whatever
industry
they
took
a
fancy
to
,
without
having
to
answer
to
the
public
.
<END>
<START>
To
guarantee
that
Mexicana
de
Aviacion
and
other
companies
will
really
be
privatized
,
Mexico
needs
a
pluri-party
political
system
that
will
ensure
democracy
and
hence
accountability
.
<END>
<START>
Daniel
James
President
Mexico-United
States
Institute
<END>
<START>
The
board
of
this
Ponce
,
Puerto
Rico
concern
voted
to
suspend
payment
of
its
quarterly
of
11
cents
a
share
for
the
third
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
The
third-largest
thrift
institution
in
Puerto
Rico
also
said
it
expects
a
return
to
profitability
in
the
third
quarter
when
it
reports
operating
results
this
week
.
<END>
<START>
Ponce
Federal
said
the
dividend
was
suspended
in
anticipation
of
more
stringent
capital
requirements
under
the
Financial
Institutions
Reform
,
Recovery
,
and
Enforcement
Act
of
1989
.
<END>
<START>
The
group
has
been
discussing
a
proposal
valued
in
a
range
of
$
225
to
$
240
a
share
,
or
$
5.09
billion
to
$
5.42
billion
.
<END>
<START>
But
to
avoid
the
risk
of
rejection
,
the
group
does
n't
plan
to
submit
the
plan
formally
at
a
UAL
board
meeting
today
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
,
the
group
is
raising
the
proposal
informally
to
try
to
test
the
board
's
reaction
.
<END>
<START>
In
composite
trading
Friday
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
,
UAL
closed
at
$
168.50
a
share
,
down
$
21.625
.
<END>
<START>
Although
the
bidding
group
has
n't
had
time
to
develop
its
latest
idea
fully
or
to
discuss
it
with
banks
,
it
believes
bank
financing
could
be
obtained
.
<END>
<START>
After
the
collapse
of
the
last
effort
,
the
group
does
n't
plan
to
make
any
formal
proposal
without
binding
commitments
from
banks
covering
the
entire
amount
to
be
borrowed
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
type
of
transaction
being
discussed
,
the
pilot-management
group
would
borrow
several
billion
dollars
from
banks
that
could
then
be
used
to
finance
a
cash
payment
to
current
holders
.
<END>
<START>
Those
current
holders
would
also
receive
minority
interests
in
the
new
company
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
the
group
could
offer
$
200
a
share
in
cash
plus
stock
valued
at
$
30
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
UAL
currently
has
22.6
million
shares
,
fully
diluted
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
structure
would
be
similar
to
a
recapitalization
in
which
holders
get
a
special
dividend
yet
retain
a
controlling
ownership
interest
.
<END>
<START>
The
difference
is
that
current
holders
would
n't
retain
majority
ownership
or
control
.
<END>
<START>
The
failed
takeover
would
have
given
UAL
employees
75
%
voting
control
of
the
nation
's
second-largest
airline
,
with
management
getting
10
%
control
and
British
Air
15
%
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
n't
clear
how
the
ownership
would
stack
up
under
the
new
plan
,
but
employees
would
keep
more
than
50
%
.
<END>
<START>
Management
's
total
could
be
reduced
,
and
the
public
could
get
more
than
the
15
%
control
that
had
been
earmarked
for
British
Air
.
<END>
<START>
One
option
the
board
is
likely
to
consider
today
is
some
sort
of
cooling-off
period
.
<END>
<START>
The
labor-management
buy-out
group
plans
to
keep
its
offer
on
the
table
in
an
apparent
attempt
to
maintain
its
bargaining
position
with
the
board
.
<END>

participate
with
the
pilots
in
crafting
a
revised
offer
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
machinists
union
,
whose
opposition
helped
scuttle
the
first
buy-out
bid
,
is
likely
to
favor
a
recapitalization
with
a
friendly
third-party
investor
.
<END>
<START>
One
advantage
the
buy-out
group
intends
to
press
with
the
board
is
that
pilots
have
agreed
to
make
$
200
million
in
annual
cost
concessions
to
help
finance
a
bid
.
<END>
<START>
Speculation
has
also
arisen
that
the
UAL
executive
most
closely
identified
with
the
failure
to
gain
bank
financing
,
chief
financial
officer
John
Pope
,
may
come
under
pressure
to
resign
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
people
familiar
with
the
buy-out
group
said
Mr.
Pope
's
departure
would
weaken
the
airline
's
management
at
a
critical
time
.

.

<START>
The
Food
and

Administration
said
American
Home
Products
Corp.
agreed
to
recall
certain
generic
drugs
that
were
produced
by
its
Quantum
Pharmics
unit
in
Amityville
,
N.Y
.
<END>
<START>
Quantum
stopped
shipping
the
drugs
last
month
,
following
a
federal
investigation
regarding
information
the
company
supplied
to
obtain
three
drug
approvals
.
<END>
<START>

safety
problems
with
the
products
are
known
,
the
FDA
said
.
<END>
<START>
An
FDA
spokesperson
said
the
drugs
are
still
available
under
other
brand
names
.
<END>
<START>

month
,

Home

said
it
was
suspending
production
and

of
all
21
of
Quantum
's
generic

pending
the
completion
of
an
exhaustive
internal

.

also
temporarily
closed
Quantum
,
because
of
the
internal

,
as

the
FDA
's

inquiry
.

,

75

to
$
105
on

.

<START>
Lyondell
Petrochemical
Co.
said
third-quarter
net
income
fell
54
%
,
to
$
73
million
,
or
91
cents
a
share
,
from
$
160
million
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Year-earlier
per-share
results
are
n't
applicable
because
the
company
went
public
in
January
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
rose
7.7
%
to
$
1.28
billion
from
$
1.18
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
petrochemical
maker
said
the
biggest
reason
earnings
declined
was
a
loss
of
production
time
and
the
increased
costs
associated
with
a
temporary
maintenance
closing
and
expansion
of
an
olefins
plant
.
<END>
<START>
Like
other
refiners
,
Lyondell
's
margins
for
chemicals
and
gasoline
were
narrower
.
<END>
<START>
While
the
company
said
chemical
margins
continued
to
worsen
this
quarter
,
costs
will
be
lower
because
the
maintenance
and
expansions
are
complete
.
<END>
<START>
In
New
York
Stock
Exchange
composite
trading
Friday
,
Lyondell
was
unchanged
at
$
18.50
a
share
.

,

.

<START>

,

<START>

<START>

.

,

.

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
And

.
<END>

,

.

.
''
<END>
<START>

's

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.

<START>
Indeed
,

.

<START>

.

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

``

''

,

,

,

.

<START>

.

<START>

,

.

,
''

,
``

's
information
I
still
ca
n't

.
''
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
East
Germany
's
growing
openness
may
even
allow
the
state-controlled

to
display

of

.
<END>
<START>
Television
last
week
carried
a
new
report
on
East
Berlin
's
main

factory
and
the
need
to
boost

.
<END>
<START>
His
point
was
there
is
no

for

Germany
to
copy

changes
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's

,
''
says
the
East
Berlin
shopkeeper
,
``
But
everyone
I
know
laughed
about
it
.
<END>
<START>
The
list
of
laboratories
claiming
to
be
producing
inexplicable
amounts
of
heat
from
``
cold
fusion
''
experiments
is
slowly
growing
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
experiments
continue
to
be
plagued
by
lack
of
firm
evidence
that
the
extra
heat
is
coming
from
the
fusing
of
hydrogen
atoms
.
<END>
<START>
The
meeting
offered
stark
evidence
of
a
dramatic
fall
in
scientific
interest
in
cold
fusion
research
.
<END>
<START>
Of
the
1,300
chemists
registered
for
the
society
's
weeklong
meeting
,
fewer
than
200
sat
through
the
day
and
a
half
of
cold
fusion
presentations
at
week
's
end
.
<END>
<START>
Neither
of
the
two
chemists
whose
Utah
experiments
triggered
the
cold
fusion
uproar
,
Martin
Fleischmann
and
B.
Stanley
Pons
,
were
at
the
meeting
.
<END>
<START>
But
some
members
of
an
ad
hoc
expert
committee
set
up
by
the
Department
of
Energy
to
evaluate
the
cold
fusion
research
were
in
the
audience
.
<END>
<START>
The
committee
is
to
recommend
at
the
end
of
the
month
whether
DOE
should
support
cold
fusion
research
.
<END>
<START>
Most
of
the
two
dozen
scientists
taking
the
podium
reported
results
with
new
,
more
sophisticated
variations
of
the
seemingly
simple
electrolysis-of-water
experiments
described
last
March
by
Messrs.
Fleischmann
and
Pons
.
<END>
<START>
When
an
electric
current
is
applied
to
the
palladium
and
platinum
electrodes
,
the
heavy
water
did
begin
to
break
up
,
or
dissociate
.
<END>
<START>
Ordinarily
the
electrolysis
,
or
breakup
,
of
the
water
would
consume
almost
all
of
the
electrical
energy
.
<END>
<START>
But
Messrs.
Fleischmann
and
Pons
said
their
experiments
also
produced
large
amounts
of
heat
.
<END>
<START>
The
heat
energy
plus
the
energy
consumed
by
the
breakup
of
the
water
molecules
added
to
far
more
energy
coming
out
of
the
apparatus
than
electrical
energy
going
in
,
they
reported
.
<END>
<START>
As
of
last
weekend
,
a
dozen
labs
also
have
reported
measuring
``
excess
''
heat
from
similar
electrolytic
experiments
,
although
amounts
of
such
heat
vary
widely
.
<END>
<START>
One
of
the
seven
reports
presented
here
of
excess
heat
production
was
given
by
Richard
A.
Oriani
,
professor
of
chemical
engineering
at
the
University
of
Minnesota
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Oriani
said
his
skepticism
of
the
Utah
claims
was
initially
confirmed
when
his
first
experiments
last
spring
failed
to
produce
results
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
then
borrowed
a
palladium
rod
from
chemists
at
Texas
A&M
who
said
they
were
getting
excess
heat
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
results
were
fascinating
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
On
the
fourth
``
run
''
with
the
borrowed
rod
,
the
experiment
began
producing
excess
heat
.
<END>
<START>
The
experiment
was
stopped
briefly
to
change
an
instrument
.
<END>
<START>
When
it
was
restarted
,
heat
output
``
really
took
off
''
and
produced
excess
heat
for
several
hours
before
dying
down
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Typical
of
other
experiments
,
Mr.
Oriani
said
his
experiment
was
``
very
erratic
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
excess
heat
was
15
%
to
20
%
more
than
the
energy
involved
in
the
electrolysis
of
water
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
is
a
reality
to
the
excess
energy
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Other
scientists
said
they
also
were
getting
sporadic
bursts
of
excess
heat
lasting
several
hours
at
a
time
.
<END>
<START>
One
chemist
privately
suggested
this
hinted
that
some
``
anomalous
''
chemical
reactions
might
be
producing
the
heat
.
<END>
<START>
One
reason
questions
surround
the
heat
experiments
is
that
they
involve
unusually
meticulous
measurements
.
<END>
<START>
Typically
,
the
input
energy
ranges
from
a
third
of
a
watt
to
one
watt
and
the
excess
energy
is
measured
in
tenths
of
a
watt
.
<END>
<START>
One
exception
is
a
continuing
experiment
at
Stanford
University
where
as
much
as
10
watts
of
energy
are
being
put
into
the
electrolytic
cells
.
<END>
<START>
One
of
the
few
hints
the
excess
heat
might
be
produced
by
fusion
came
from
brief
remarks
by
chemist
John
Bockris
of
Texas
A&M
University
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bockris
previously
reported
getting
bursts
of
excess
heat
and
of
detecting
increasing
amounts
of
tritium
forming
in
the
heavy
water
.
<END>
<START>
Increasingly
careful
attempts
to
measure
neutrons
,
which
would
be
strong
evidence
of
fusion
reactions
,
continue
to
be
negative
.
<END>
<START>
Messrs.
Fleischmann
and
Pons
initially
reported
indirect
evidence
of
neutrons
being
produced
in
their
experiment
but
later
conceded
the
measurements
were
questionable
.
<END>
<START>
In
subsequent
experiments
,
one
of
two
neutron
detectors
occasionally
indicated
a
burst
of
neutrons
but
neutron
bursts
were
never
recorded
in
both
detectors
at
the
same
time
.
<END>
<START>
They
concluded
the
indications
of
neutrons
stemmed
from
faults
in
the
detectors
rather
than
from
the
cold
fusion
experiment
.
<END>
<START>
Dow
Jones
&
Co.
announced
Wall
Street
Journal
advertising
rates
for
1990
.
<END>
<START>
The
rates
,
which
take
effect
Jan.
2
,
include
a
4
%
increase
for
national
edition
advertising
.
<END>
<START>
The
Journal
also
will
offer
expanded
volume
and
frequency
discounts
.
<END>
<START>
The
increase
for
national
edition
advertising
is
less
than
the
inflation
rate
and
compares
with
a
6.5
%
increase
in
1989
.
<END>
<START>
``
Newsprint
and
postage
prices
this
year
have
not
gone
up
,
''
said
Peter
R.
Kann
,
president
of
Dow
Jones
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
have
invested
in
improved
editorial
quality
and
expanded
our
quality
audience
without
substantially
increasing
our
costs
.
<END>
<START>
Fundamental
fairness
and
a
sense
of
responsibility
lead
us
to
share
operating
efficiencies
with
our
customers
.
''
<END>
<START>
Advertising
rates
for
the
Eastern
,
Midwest
,
Western
and
Southwest
editions
will
increase
an
average
5.5
%
,
and
rates
for
localized
advertising
editions
will
increase
7.5
%
.
<END>
<START>
Rates
for
the
Wall
Street
Journal
Reports
will
remain
unchanged
.
<END>
<START>
A
one-time
noncontract
full-page
advertisement
in
The
Wall
Street
Journal
national
edition
will
cost
$
99,385
.
<END>
<START>
Advertising
rates
for
The
Wall
Street
Journal/Europe
,
published
in
Brussels
and
printed
in
the
Netherlands
and
Switzerland
,
will
increase
9
%
.
<END>
<START>
Rates
for
The
Asian
Wall
Street
Journal
,
published
and
printed
in
Hong
Kong
and
also
printed
in
Singapore
and
Tokyo
,
will
rise
8
%
.
<END>
<START>
Rates
for
The
Asian
Wall
Street
Journal
Weekly
,
published
in
New
York
for
North
American
readers
,
will
rise
6
%
.
<END>
<START>
Dow
Jones
also
publishes
Barron
's
magazine
,
other
periodicals
and
community
newspapers
and
operates
electronic
business
information
services
.
<END>
<START>
It
owns
67
%
of
Telerate
Inc.
,
a
leading
supplier
of
computerized
financial
information
on
global
markets
.
<END>
<START>
Reflecting
the
impact
of
lower
semiconductor
prices
and
cuts
in
defense
spending
,
Texas
Instruments
Inc.
said
third-quarter
net
income
fell
31
%
and
sales
dropped
slightly
from
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Net
fell
to
$
65
million
,
or
67
cents
a
common
share
,
from
$
93.7
million
or
$
1.03
a
share
,
a
year
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
fell
2.5
%
to
$
1.54
billion
from
$
1.58
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
were
$
4.66
billion
,
up
1.3
%
from
$
4.6
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Jerry
Junkins
,
chairman
,
president
and
chief
executive
officer
,
said
sluggish
consumer-electronics
sales
reduced
demand
for
semiconductors
.
<END>
<START>
That
,
coupled
with
lower
semiconductor
prices
and
higher
semiconductor-depreciation
expense
,
contributed
to
the
decline
in
sales
and
profit
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
cost
increases
related
to
fixed-price
defense
contracts
and
a
$
10
million
charge
to
reduce
the
work
force
of
Texas
Instruments
'
defense-electronics
division
also
reduced
net
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
the
quarter
results
included
$
28
million
in
royalty
income
from
patent
licenses
,
up
from
$
21
million
in
the
year-earlier
period
.
<END>
<START>
The
nine
months
include
$
125
million
of
royalty
income
,
up
from
$
98
million
last
year
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Junkins
was
n't
optimistic
about
the
short-term
outlook
,
hinting
that
further
workforce
reductions
may
be
needed
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
expect
near-term
sluggishness
in
the
electronics
market
,
''
he
said
,
``
and
we
will
take
ongoing
cost-reduction
actions
as
necessary
to
keep
operations
aligned
with
demand
.
''
<END>
<START>
Further
,
he
said
,
an
internal
reorganization
to
combine
several
divisions
into
the
Information
Technology
Group
is
expected
to
affect
fourth-quarter
results
by
an
undisclosed
amount
.
<END>
<START>
Lynch
Corp.
said
its
Lynch
Telephone
Corp.
subsidiary
completed
the
acquisition
of
Western
New
Mexico
Telephone
Co.
for
$
20
million
plus
assumption
of
$
24
million
of
debt
.
<END>
<START>
Western
New
Mexico
Telephone
,
Silver
City
,
had
net
income
of
$
1.9
million
on
revenue
of
about
$
10
million
last
year
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
an
independent
phone
company
with
a
service
area
of
15,000
square
miles
in
southwest
New
Mexico
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
also
a
partner
in
the
wireline
cellular
franchise
covering
most
of
western
New
Mexico
.
<END>
<START>
The
transaction
represents
Lynch
's
entry
into
the
telephone
business
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
,
which
has
interests
in
television
,
trucking
services
,
and
glass-making
and
food-processing
equipment
,
said
it
plans
to
make
other
acquisitions
in
the
telephone
industry
.
<END>
<START>
Nelson
Bunker
Hunt
's
attempted
corner
on
silver
a
decade
ago
is
still
haunting
the
market
in
this
metal
.
<END>
<START>
Silver
,
now
trading
around
$
5
an
ounce
,
surged
to
an
all-time
peak
of
$
50
an
ounce
in
January
1980
from
around
$
9
in
mid-1979
.
<END>
<START>
Photographic
developers
,
for
example
,
bought
equipment
to
recover
silver
from
spent
photographs
,
negatives
and
processing
solutions
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
the
photographic
industry
,
which
accounts
for
44
%
of
silver
consumption
,
continues
to
look
for
substitutes
.
<END>
<START>
Japanese
and
U.S.
photographic
firms
are
beginning
to
produce
electronic
cameras
and
X-rays
that
do
n't
require
silver
,
dealers
say
.
<END>
<START>
Silver
's
history
of
volatility
is
also
discouraging
investors
,
dealers
say
.
<END>
<START>
Even
in
the
present
uncertain
investment
climate
,
investors
are
preferring
``
quality
assets
''
such
as
Treasury
bills
and
bonds
to
gold
,
silver
and
platinum
,
dealers
say
.
<END>
<START>
Silver
,
however
is
in
a
deeper
slump
than
are
gold
and
platinum
.
<END>
<START>
Some
analysts
contend
that
silver
is
cheap
now
that
prices
are
languishing
at
levels
last
seen
in
the
mid-1970s
.
<END>
<START>
``
Bargain
hunters
believe
that
silver
offers
the
best
value
amongst
precious
metals
,
''
says
Frederick
R.
Demler
,
analyst
at
Drexel
Burnham
Lambert
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
A
further
decline
in
prices
will
lead
to
mine
production
cuts
in
the
U.S.
,
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Scrap
merchants
are
converting
smaller
quantities
of
metal
into
silver
,
while
low
prices
are
discouraging
exports
from
India
and
the
Soviet
Union
.
<END>
<START>
Silver
prices
could
also
be
boosted
by
strikes
in
leading
producing
nations
Peru
and
Mexico
,
Mr.
Demler
says
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
total
fabrication
demand
for
silver
has
risen
six
years
in
a
row
,
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Japanese
demand
grew
by
70
%
in
the
first
half
of
this
year
and
the
nation
plans
an
issue
of
a
silver
commemorative
coin
that
will
require
4.5
million
ounces
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
intermittent
rallies
in
the
past
few
years
,
improvements
in
the
supply-demand
balance
have
n't
managed
to
push
silver
prices
into
a
higher
range
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
's
just
too
much
silver
around
,
''
says
Tom
Butler
,
an
analyst
at
Samuel
Montagu
&
Co.
,
a
London
bullion
house
.
<END>
<START>
``
Silver
production
is
also
in
an
inexorable
upward
trend
,
''
Ms.
O'Connell
says
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
while
Asian
and
Middle
Eastern
investors
hoard
gold
and
help
underpin
its
price
,
silver
does
n't
have
the
same
mystique
,
dealers
say
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
have
gotten
burned
on
silver
so
often
that
they
are
far
more
partial
to
gold
,
says
Urs
Seiler
,
senior
vice
president
at
Union
Bank
of
Switzerland
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
if
gold
prices
improve
,
silver
prices
could
rally
sharply
,
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
dealers
caution
that
any
increase
would
be
$
1
to
$
2
at
most
.
<END>
<START>
Looking
ahead
to
other
commodity
markets
this
week
:
<END>
<START>
Livestock
and
Meats
<END>
<START>
Analysts
expect
the
prices
of
live
cattle
futures
contracts
to
rise
in
trading
today
in
the
wake
of
a
government
quarterly
census
that
found
fewer-than-expected
cattle
on
feedlots
.
<END>
<START>
Most
analysts
had
expected
the
government
to
report
a
4
%
decline
.
<END>
<START>
Feedlots
fatten
young
cattle
for
slaughter
,
so
a
decline
signals
a
tightening
supply
of
beef
.
<END>
<START>
The
government
reported
that
the
number
of
young
cattle
placed
on
feedlots
during
the
quarter
dropped
5
%
compared
with
the
year-earlier
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Many
industry
analysts
had
been
projecting
a
3
%
decline
in
placements
for
the
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
1988
quarter
,
many
farmers
were
forced
to
sell
their
cattle
to
feedlot
operators
because
the
drought
dried
out
the
pasture
on
their
ranches
.
<END>
<START>
The
number
of
cattle
moving
onto
feedlots
in
the
recent
quarter
was
also
lower
because
fattening
cattle
is
less
profitable
.
<END>
<START>
A
shortage
of
young
cattle
has
made
them
more
expensive
for
feedlot
operators
to
buy
.
<END>
<START>
The
Agriculture
Department
also
said
that
the
number
of
fattened
cattle
slaughtered
in
the
quarter
dropped
by
5
%
from
the
1988
quarter
,
which
was
in
line
with
projections
by
analysts
.
<END>
<START>
Energy
<END>
<START>
Most
traders
and
analysts
attributed
the
decline
to
technical
factors
associated
with
the
contract
's
going
off
the
board
.
<END>
<START>
Others
said
that
the
drop
continued
the
downward
correction
that
's
been
due
in
the
petroleum
pits
and
that
such
a
trend
could
well
continue
in
the
next
several
trading
sessions
.
<END>
<START>
Barring
any
petroleum-related
news
events
,
trading
in
the
days
ahead
should
further
test
recent
projections
by
oil
economists
and
other
market
watchers
that
strong
fourth-quarter
demand
will
keep
prices
firm
.
<END>
<START>
Copper
<END>
<START>
Copper
prices
fell
sharply
Friday
afternoon
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
copper
for
December
delivery
settled
4.5
cents
lower
at
$
1.2345
a
pound
.
<END>
<START>
Pressure
came
from
several
developments
including
the
settlement
of
two
long-term
strikes
.
<END>
<START>
On
Friday
,
one
analyst
said
,
rank-and-file
workers
ratified
a
new
labor
agreement
ending
a
three-month
strike
at
the
Highland
Valley
mine
in
British
Columbia
.
<END>
<START>
The
mine
is
expected
to
return
to
production
in
about
a
week
.
<END>
<START>
On
Friday
,
selling
dominated
the
afternoon
``
curb
''
session
in
London
,
which
takes
place
at
noon
EDT
.
<END>
<START>
The
premium
of
cash
copper
to
the
three-month
forward
offerings
narrowed
,
indicating
weaker
demand
for
cash
copper
.
<END>
<START>
Long-term
support
for
the
December
contract
was
believed
to
be
at
$
1.25
a
pound
.
<END>
<START>
A
technical
analyst
said
there
were
a
number
of
stop-loss
orders
under
that
level
that
were
touched
off
when
the
contract
's
price
fell
below
it
.
<END>
<START>
That
brought
in
considerable
fund
selling
,
which
continued
until
the
close
of
trading
.
<END>
<START>
``
In
general
,
it
was
a
bearish
close
,
''
said
Ben
Hanauer
,
a
copper
trader
at
Rudolph
Wolff
&
Co.
,
a
major
commodities
trading
and
brokerage
firm
.
<END>
<START>
But
whether
this
price
break
has
implications
for
this
week
,
he
said
,
``
we
will
know
more
when
the
London
Metal
Exchange
copper
stock
levels
are
released
Monday
morning
.
''
<END>
<START>
Another
analyst
said
he
expected
LME
inventories
to
be
down
by
about
15,000
tons
when
the
weekly
report
is
issued
.
<END>
<START>
He
also
noted
that
the
Japanese
,
who
had
been
buying
at
prices
just
above
the
$
1.25
level
,
apparently
pulled
back
from
the
market
on
Friday
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Savaiko
said
he
sees
a
possibility
of
the
December
contract
dropping
to
$
1.05
a
pound
.
<END>
<START>
Hewlett-Packard
Co.
will
announce
today
a
software
program
that
allows
computers
in
a
network
to
speed
up
computing
tasks
by
sending
the
tasks
to
each
other
.
<END>
<START>
Called
Task
Broker
,
the
program
acts
something
like
an
auctioneer
among
a
group
of
computers
wired
together
.
<END>
<START>
If
a
machine
has
a
big
computing
task
,
Task
Broker
asks
other
computers
in
the
network
for
``
bids
''
on
the
job
.
<END>
<START>
It
then
determines
which
machine
is
free
to
do
the
task
most
quickly
and
sends
the
task
to
that
machine
.
<END>
<START>
Hewlett-Packard
claims
that
the
software
allows
a
network
to
run
three
times
as
many
tasks
as
conventional
networks
and
will
run
each
task
twice
as
fast
.
<END>
<START>
In
today
's
computer
networks
,
some
machines
often
sit
idle
while
others
are
overtaxed
.
<END>
<START>
With
the
Hewlett-Packard
program
,
he
said
,
``
You
get
more
bang
for
the
buck
you
've
spent
on
computers
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
program
,
which
will
be
shipped
in
January
1990
,
runs
on
the
Unix
operating
system
.
<END>
<START>
Hewlett-Packard
will
charge
$
5,000
for
a
license
covering
10
users
.
<END>
<START>
The
program
now
works
on
all
Hewlett-Packard
and
Apollo
workstations
and
on
computers
made
by
Multiflow
Computer
Inc.
of
Branford
,
Conn
.
<END>
<START>
Hewlett-Packard
said
it
will
sell
versions
later
next
year
that
run
on
Sun
Microsystems
Inc.
and
Digital
Equipment
Corp.
machines
.
<END>
<START>
The
Task
Broker
differs
from
other
programs
that
spread
computing
tasks
around
a
network
.
<END>
<START>
But
programs
in
individual
computers
must
be
revised
in
order
to
work
with
that
system
.
<END>
<START>
Price
wars
between
the
fast-food
giants
are
starting
to
clobber
the
fast-food
little
guys
:
the
franchisees
.
<END>
<START>
As
hamburger
and
pizza
outlets
saturate
one
area
after
another
,
franchisers
are
struggling
desperately
for
market
share
,
slashing
prices
and
stepping
up
costly
promotions
.
<END>
<START>
The
fight
is
putting
a
tight
squeeze
on
profits
of
many
,
threatening
to
drive
the
smallest
ones
out
of
business
and
straining
relations
between
the
national
fast-food
chains
and
their
franchisees
.
<END>
<START>
Though
Charisma
's
sales
are
up
slightly
this
year
,
Mr.
Harty
says
profits
will
be
flat
or
lower
.
<END>
<START>
Until
recently
,
the
huge
fast-food
industry
,
with
sales
of
about
$
60.1
billion
last
year
,
kept
price-skirmishing
to
a
minimum
.
<END>
<START>
That
brought
a
chain
reaction
in
the
industry
.
<END>
<START>
The
situation
was
further
aggravated
early
this
month
,
when
McDonald
's
set
plans
to
heat
up
the
discounting
by
offering
coupons
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
decided
to
go
national
with
pizza
,
which
it
has
been
test-marketing
.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
two-for-one
deals
on
pizza
are
common
;
so
are
99-cent
specials
on
sandwiches
normally
priced
twice
as
high
.
<END>
<START>
The
discounting
,
say
fast-food
operators
,
occurs
on
a
scale
and
with
a
frequency
they
have
n't
seen
before
.
<END>
<START>
The
result
is
that
some
franchisees
are
running
hard
just
to
stay
even
,
laying
off
middle
managers
and
working
harder
to
make
less
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
almost
as
if
you
're
doing
extra
work
to
give
away
the
food
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
battle
continues
much
longer
,
many
fast-food
businesses
will
close
or
merge
,
predicts
Vincent
Morrissey
,
who
owns
a
string
of
Kentucky
Fried
Chicken
stores
in
the
Midwest
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
industry
is
overbuilt
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
Fast-food
franchisers
have
managed
to
squeeze
in
stores
into
every
corner
available
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
National
Restaurant
Association
says
quick-service
restaurant
units
in
the
U.S.
rose
14
%
to
131,146
between
1983
and
1987
,
the
last
year
for
which
figures
are
available
.
<END>
<START>
Simply
put
,
there
is
n't
enough
business
for
every
store
to
grow
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
Mr.
Rohs
,
inflation-adjusted
,
same-store
sales
at
company-owned
Wendy
's
units
in
the
U.S.
have
trailed
year-earlier
levels
throughout
1989
,
except
for
August
.
<END>
<START>
``
McDonald
's
has
also
been
running
negative
all
year
,
''
the
analyst
says
.
<END>
<START>
Spokesmen
for
Wendy
's
and
McDonald
's
criticized
Mr.
Rohs
's
calculations
.
<END>
<START>
Jack
Greenberg
,
executive

and
chief

officer
of
McDonald
's
,
says
the
company
does
n't
compute
,
much
less
disclose
,
inflation-adjusted
,
same-store
sales
.
<END>
<START>
He
adds
that
short-term
comparisons
``
can
be
very
misleading
because
of
differences
in
timing
of
marketing
programs
from
year
to
year
.
''
<END>
<START>
Profit
margins
at
company-owned
McDonald
's
outlets
in
the
U.S.
``
are
holding
up
quite
nicely
,
''
says
Mr.
Greenberg
.
<END>
<START>
Profits
of
franchisees
have
n't
been
higher
since
the
mid-1970s
,
he

.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Greenberg
's
sanguine
outlook
is
n't
matched
by
many

industry

.
<END>
<START>
Smaller
chains
and

operators
will
be
the

to

,
many
in
the
industry
predict
.
<END>
<START>
Big

groups
``
can
ride
out

storm
a

,
''

Harty
,
the
Burger
King
operator
in

.
<END>
<START>
The
prolonged
price
pressures
are
driving
a

some

and

.
<END>
<START>
Franchisees
ca
n't

go

with
a

's

.
<END>
<START>
He
says

have

are

in
such
cases
by
the
need

.
<END>
<START>
In
any

,
many

,
in
order
to
stay

,
routinely

.
<END>
<START>
Says
Mr.
Riese

``

resisted
on

,
maybe

.
<END>

Companies

<END>
<START>

.

.
<END>
<START>
Otherwise

.
<END>
<START>
Companies

.

And

.

<START>

Mr.
Jackson

.

<START>

's

.

<START>

.

<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>
``
Maybe

,

-LCB-
Ty
-RCB-
Cobbs

,

awhile

Babe
Ruth

,
''

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

,

,
''

.
<END>
<START>

Who

?
''
<END>
<START>
And

.
<END>
<START>

I

n't

15

,
''
he

.
<END>
<START>
Why
Mr.
Jackson
,

n't

,
has

available

is
n't

.
<END>
<START>
He

n't

for

.
<END>
<START>
``
I

,
''

,

's

.
<END>
<START>
``
He
has

.
''
<END>
<START>
And
Mr.
Jackson
probably
has
opened
new
checking
accounts
,
too
.
<END>
<START>
Or
at
least
he
should
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
assume
those
accounts
are
closed
,
''
says
Mr.
Smalling
,
referring
to
the
accounts
of
the
canceled
checks
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
do
n't
think
he
'd
want
to
give
out
his
current
account
numbers
.
<END>
<START>
Terms
were
n't
disclosed
for
the
plant
,
which
will
have
annual
capacity
of
600,000
tons
.
<END>
<START>
The
move
by
the
nation
's
largest
steelmaker
follows
a
string
of
earlier
announcements
by
other
major
steel
companies
.
<END>
<START>
Bethlehem
Steel
Corp.
,
LTV
Corp.
and
Armco
Inc.
all
have
plans
to
build
additional
lines
for
such
coated
corrosion-resistant
steel
.
<END>
<START>
The
surge
in
production
,
analysts
say
,
raises
questions
about
capacity
outpacing
demand
.
<END>
<START>
They
note
that
most
of
the
new
plants
will
come
on
line
in
1992
,
when
the
current
import
trade
restraint
program
ends
,
which
could
result
in
more
imports
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
's
too
much
capacity
,
''
contended
Charles
Bradford
,
an
analyst
with
Merrill
Lynch
Capital
Markets
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
do
n't
think
there
's
anyone
not
building
one
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
does
add
,
however
,
that
transplanted
Japanese
car
makers
are
boosting
the
levels
of
U.S.-made
steel
in
their
autos
,
instead
of
relying
heavily
on
imported
steel
.
<END>
<START>
That
trend
could
increase
demand
for
hot-dipped
galvanized
sheet
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
USX
said
it
expects
the
market
for
coated
sheet
steel
to
reach
12
million
tons
annually
by
1992
,
compared
with
10.2
million
tons
shipped
in
1988
.
<END>
<START>
USX
already
has
six
lines
in
existing
plants
producing
hot-dipped
galvanized
steel
,
but
this
marks
the
first
so-called
greenfield
plant
for
such
production
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
it
will
boost
by
50
%
USX
's
current
hot-dipped
capacity
of
1,275,000
tons
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
it
does
n't
expect
the
new
line
's
capacity
to
adversely
affect
the
company
's
existing
hot-dipped
galvanizing
lines
.
<END>
<START>
Steelmakers
have
also
been
adding
capacity
of
so-called
electrogalvanized
steel
,
which
is
another
way
to
make
coated
corrosion-resistant
steel
.
<END>
<START>
One
of
the
advantages
of
the
hot-dipped
process
is
that
it
allows
the
steel
to
be
covered
with
a
thicker
coat
of
zinc
more
quickly
.
<END>
<START>
ONCE
YOU
MAKE
UP
your
mind
about
an
investment
,
the
rest
is
easy
,
right
?
<END>
<START>
You
just
call
your
broker
and
say
``
buy
''
or
``
sell
.
''
<END>
<START>
Dream
on
.
<END>
<START>
So
here
's
a
rundown
of
the
most
common
types
of
market
orders
permitted
by
the
stock
and
commodity
exchanges
.
<END>
<START>
Two
things
to
keep
in
mind
:
Not
all
exchanges
accept
every
type
of
order
.
<END>
<START>
And
even
when
a
specific
order
is
acceptable
to
an
exchange
,
a
brokerage
firm
can
refuse
to
enter
it
for
a
customer
.
<END>
<START>
Market
Order
:
This
is
probably
the
most
widely
used
order
--
and
the
one
most
open
to
abuse
by
unscrupulous
floor
brokers
,
since
it
imposes
no
price
restrictions
.
<END>
<START>
With
a
market
order
,
an
investor
tells
a
broker
to
buy
or
sell
``
at
the
market
.
''
<END>
<START>
It
's
like
saying
,
``
get
me
in
now
''
or
``
get
me
out
now
.
''
<END>
<START>
A
recent
indictment
alleges
that
some
floor
brokers
at
the
two
largest
Chicago
commodity
exchanges
used
market
orders
to
fill
customers
'
orders
at
unfavorable
prices
by
arranging
trades
with
fellow
brokers
.
<END>
<START>
Profits
realized
from
these
trades
would
then
be
shared
by
the
conspiring
brokers
.
<END>
<START>
Limit
Order
:
Limit
orders
are
used
when
investors
want
to
restrict
the
amount
they
will
receive
or
pay
for
an
investment
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
do
this
by
specifying
a
minimum
price
at
which
the
investment
may
be
sold
or
the
maximum
price
that
may
be
paid
for
it
.
<END>
<START>
Suppose
an
investor
wants
to
sell
a
stock
,
but
not
for
less
than
$
55
.
<END>
<START>
A
limit
order
to
sell
could
be
entered
at
that
price
.
<END>
<START>
One
risk
:
Investors
may
regret
the
restriction
if
the
stock
reaches
54
and
then
falls
.
<END>
<START>
Stop
Order
:
Stop
orders
tell
a
floor
broker
to
buy
or
sell
an
investment
once
the
price
reaches
a
certain
level
.
<END>
<START>
Once
the
price
reaches
that
level
,
a
stop
order
turns
into
a
market
order
,
and
the
order
is
filled
at
whatever
price
the
broker
can
get
.
<END>
<START>
Stop
orders
are
sometimes
called
``
stop-loss
''
orders
because
they
are
frequently
used
to
protect
profits
or
limit
losses
.
<END>
<START>
While
stop
orders
sound
similar
to
limit
orders
,
there
is
a
difference
:
Sell
stops
must
be
entered
at
a
price
below
the
current
market
price
and
buy
stops
above
.
<END>
<START>
In
contrast
,
sell
limit
orders
must
be
placed
above
the
market
price
and
buy
limit
orders
are
placed
below
.
<END>
<START>
The
crash
in
October
1987
and
last
Friday
's
sell-off
painfully
taught
some
investors
exactly
what
stop
orders
will
and
wo
n't
do
.
<END>
<START>
Stop-Limit
Order
:
Stop-limit
orders
turn
into
limit
orders
when
an
investment
trades
at
the
price
specified
in
the
order
.
<END>
<START>
Unlike
stop
orders
--
which
are
filled
at
the
market
price
when
the
stop
price
is
hit
--
stop-limit
orders
demand
that
the
trades
be
made
only
at
the
specified
price
.
<END>
<START>
If
it
ca
n't
be
made
at
that
price
,
it
does
n't
get
filled
.
<END>
<START>
But
if
the
market
moves
quickly
enough
,
it
may
be
impossible
for
the
broker
to
carry
out
the
order
because
the
investment
has
passed
the
specified
price
.
<END>
<START>
Market-If-Touched
Order
:
Market-if-touched
orders
are
like
stop
orders
in
that
they
become
market
orders
if
a
specified
price
is
reached
.
<END>
<START>
As
soon
as
the
market
trades
at
the
specified
price
the
floor
broker
will
fill
it
at
the
best
possible
price
.
<END>
<START>
Fill-Or-Kill
Order
:
The
fill-or-kill
order
is
one
of
several
associated
with
the
timing
of
trades
.
<END>
<START>
It
instructs
a
broker
to
buy
or
sell
an
investment
at
the
specified
price
or
better
.
<END>
<START>
But
if
the
investment
ca
n't
be
bought
or
sold
immediately
,
the
order
is
automatically
canceled
.
<END>
<START>
Gregory
Bessemer
,
who
came
in
second
in
the
stock
division
of
the
recently
completed
U.S.
Trading
Championship
,
says
he
uses
fill-or-kill
orders
almost
exclusively
when
trading
options
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
like
to
use
them
to
feel
out
the
market
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
they
do
n't
fill
it
immediately
,
then
I
can
start
over
at
a
new
price
or
try
again
with
the
same
price
.
''
<END>
<START>
Not-Held
Order
:
This
is
another
timing
order
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
a
market
order
that
allows
floor
brokers
to
take
more
time
to
buy
or
sell
an
investment
,
if
they
think
they
can
get
a
better
price
by
waiting
.
<END>
<START>
Not-held
orders
,
which
are
also
known
as
``
disregard
the
tape
''
orders
,
are
always
done
at
the
customer
's
risk
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
fast-moving
market
,
it
prevents
an
investor
from
getting
stuck
with
having
made
two
trades
on
the
same
security
.
<END>
<START>
Specific-Time
Order
:
This
type
of
order
couples
many
of
the
orders
described
above
with
instructions
that
the
order
must
be
carried
out
at
or
by
a
certain
time
.
<END>
<START>
``
On
the
close
''
can
be
added
to
many
types
of
orders
.
<END>
<START>
``
Stop-close-only
orders
''
are
stop
orders
that
only
become
active
during
the
closing
minutes
of
trading
.
<END>
<START>
``
Day
orders
''
expire
at
the
end
of
the
day
on
which
they
are
entered
,
``
good-till-canceled
orders
''
have
no
expiration
date
.
<END>
<START>
Most
brokers
assume
that
all
orders
are
day
orders
unless
specified
otherwise
.
<END>
<START>
On
Oct.
19
,
1987
,
some
investors
learned
the
consequences
of
entering
``
good-til-canceled
limit
orders
''
and
then
forgetting
about
them
.
<END>
<START>
They
found
they
had
bought
stock
from
limit
orders
that
they
might
have
entered
weeks
or
months
earlier
and
had
forgotten
to
cancel
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
always
the
responsibility
of
investors
to
keep
track
of
the
orders
they
have
placed
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
who
change
their
mind
about
buying
or
selling
after
an
order
has
been
filled
are
,
usually
,
stuck
with
the
consequences
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Angrist
writes
on
the
options
and
commodities
markets
for
The
Wall
Street
Journal
.
<END>
<START>
IN
SIZING
UP
the
risks
of
stock-market
investments
,
there
's
probably
no
starting
place
better
than
``
beta
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
investors
better
not
ignore
its
limitations
,
either
.
<END>
<START>
Beta
is
a
handy
gauge
that
measures
the
volatility
of
a
stock
or
stock
mutual
fund
.
<END>
<START>
For
any
given
move
in
the
overall
market
,
it
suggests
how
steeply
that
particular
issue
might
rise
or
fall
.
<END>
<START>
Beta
figures
are
widely
available
and
easy
to
interpret
.
<END>
<START>
The
beta
of
the
broad
market
,
typically
defined
as
the
Standard
&
Poor
's
500-stock
index
,
is
always
1.0
.
<END>
<START>
So
a
stock
with
a
beta
of
0.5
is
half
as
volatile
,
one
at
1.5
is
50
%
more
volatile
,
and
so
on
.
<END>
<START>
Cautious
investors
should
generally
go
with
stocks
that
have
low
betas
.
<END>
<START>
Go
with
high-beta
stocks
to
get
the
biggest
payoff
from
a
bet
on
a
bull
market
.
<END>
<START>
Remember
,
though
,
that
beta
also
has
important
limitations
.
<END>
<START>
``
Beta
is
only
part
of
the
risk
in
a
stock
,
''
says
William
F.
Sharpe
,
the
Stanford
University
emeritus
professor
who
developed
the
measure
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
is
risk
that
is
not
associated
with
market
moves
,
and
the
beta
does
n't
tell
you
the
magnitude
of
that
.
''
<END>
<START>
In
particular
,
beta
does
n't
measure
the
company
-
and
industry-specific
risk
associated
with
an
individual
stock
.
<END>
<START>
That
``
business
''
risk
is
very
significant
for
an
investor
with
only
a
few
stocks
,
but
it
virtually
disappears
in
a
large
and
well-diversified
portfolio
.
<END>
<START>
Beta
is
also
a
poor
indicator
of
the
risk
in
stock
groups
that
march
to
their
own
drummer
.
<END>
<START>
In
particular
,
the
prices
of
gold
and
other
precious-metals
stocks
shoot
up
and
down
,
but
the
stocks
tend
to
have
low
betas
because
their
moves
are
not
market-inspired
.
<END>
<START>
Concern
that
investors
could
misinterpret
such
readings
led
the
American
Association
of
Individual
Investors
to
eliminate
beta
figures
for
precious-metals
funds
in
the
1989
edition
of
its
mutual-fund
guide
.
<END>
<START>
``
In
reality
it
's
very
volatile
,
but
the
movements
are
not
because
of
market
movements
.
<END>
<START>
READY
TO
REVIEW
the
riskiness
of
your
investment
portfolio
?
<END>
<START>
First
,
a
pop
quiz
.
<END>
<START>
When
you
think
of
the
words
``
risk
''
and
``
investment
,
''
what
's
the
specific
peril
that
comes
to
mind
?
<END>
<START>
Pencils
down
.
<END>
<START>
``
People
tend
to
see
risk
primarily
on
that
one
dimension
,
''
says
Timothy
Kochis
,
national
director
of
personal
financial
planning
for
accountants
Deloitte
,
Haskins
&
Sells
.
<END>
<START>
But
therein
lies
another
aspect
of
investment
risk
:
the
hazard
of
shaping
your
portfolio
to
avoid
one
or
more
types
of
risk
and
being
blind-sided
by
others
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
clearly
not
good
news
to
all
you
people
who
sleep
like
babies
every
night
,
lulled
by
visions
of
your
money
sitting
risk-free
in
six-month
CDs
.
<END>
<START>
Risk
wears
many
disguises
,
and
investments
that
are
low
in
one
type
of
obvious
risk
can
be
distressingly
high
in
other
,
less
obvious
kinds
.
<END>
<START>
U.S.
Treasury
bonds
,
for
example
,
are
supersafe
when
it
comes
to
returning
money
at
maturity
.
<END>
<START>
But
their
value
as
investments
can
be
decimated
by
inflation
,
which
erodes
the
purchasing
power
of
bonds
'
fixed-dollar
interest
payments
.
<END>
<START>
Risk
is
also
a
function
of
time
.
<END>
<START>
When
financial
professionals
measure
risk
mathematically
,
they
usually
focus
on
the
volatility
of
short-term
returns
.
<END>
<START>
Stocks
are
much
riskier
than
Treasury
bills
,
for
example
,
because
the
range
in
performance
from
the
best
years
to
the
worst
is
much
wider
.
<END>
<START>
That
is
usually
measured
by
the
standard
deviation
,
or
divergence
,
of
annual
results
from
the
average
return
over
time
.
<END>
<START>
But
investors
who
are
preoccupied
with
short-term
fluctuations
may
be
paying
too
little
attention
to
another
big
risk
--
not
generating
enough
money
to
meet
long-term
financial
and
life-style
goals
.
<END>
<START>
For
instance
,
some
investors
have
sworn
off
stocks
since
the
1987
market
crash
;
last
Friday
's
debacle
only
reinforced
those
feelings
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
stock
market
,
despite
some
stomach-churning
declines
,
has
far
outperformed
other
securities
over
extended
periods
.
<END>
<START>
By
retreating
to
the
apparent
security
of
,
say
,
money-market
funds
,
investors
may
not
be
earning
enough
investment
return
to
pay
for
a
comfortable
retirement
.
<END>
<START>
``
That
's
the
biggest
risk
of
all
--
the
risk
of
not
meeting
your
objectives
,
''
says
Steven
B.
Enright
,
a
New
York
financial
planner
with
Seidman
Financial
Services
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
financial
advisers
say
they
take
several
steps
when
evaluating
the
riskiness
of
clients
'
portfolios
.
<END>
<START>
They
estimate
the
return
a
person
's
current
portfolio
is
likely
to
generate
over
time
,
along
with
a
standard
deviation
that
suggests
how
much
the
return
will
vary
year
by
year
.
<END>
<START>
They
try
to
figure
out
the
long-term
results
the
person
needs
to
meet
major
goals
.
<END>
<START>
And
they
eyeball
types
of
risk
that
are
not
easily
quantified
.
<END>
<START>
The
portfolios
of
two
hypothetical
families
,
one
a
couple
at
retirement
age
and
another
a
two-income
couple
at
age
45
,
illustrate
several
types
of
risk
that
investors
need
to
consider
.
<END>
<START>
For
instance
,
the
insured
municipal
bonds
that
dominate
the
older
couple
's
portfolio
were
probably
selected
in
large
part
for
their
low
repayment
risk
.
<END>
<START>
But
they
expose
the
holders
to
a
lot
of
inflation
risk
and
interest-rate
risk
.
<END>
<START>
The
younger
couple
's
stockholdings
involve
more
risk
than
a
diversified
stock
portfolio
because
the
bulk
of
the
money
is
in
a
single
issue
.
<END>
<START>
That
largely
reflects
the
heavy
stockholdings
.
<END>
<START>
But
one
price
paid
for
the
higher
expected
return
is
greater
short-term
volatility
,
as
reflected
in
the
higher
standard
deviation
that
Seidman
estimates
for
the
younger
couple
's
portfolio
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Here
's
how
to
interpret
a
standard
deviation
figure
:
Take
the
expected
return
and
add
one
standard
deviation
to
it
.
<END>
<START>
Then
take
the
expected
return
and
subtract
one
standard
deviation
.
<END>
<START>
In
two
of
three
years
,
the
actual
result
should
fall
within
that
range
if
all
the
assumptions
were
accurate
.
<END>
<START>
Then
add
and
subtract
two
standard
deviations
to
get
a
wider
range
.
<END>
<START>
There
's
a
95
%
probability
any
year
's
result
will
fall
in
the
range
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Of
course
,
the
greater
volatility
of
the
younger
couple
's
portfolio
does
n't
necessarily
mean
those
investments
are
riskier
in
terms
of
meeting
the
holders
'
long-term
goals
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
the
older
couple
's
portfolio
could
actually
be
riskier
in
that
sense
if
the
expected
return
wo
n't
generate
enough
dollars
to
meet
their
spending
plans
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
they
may
pay
a
price
10
or
20
years
in
the
future
.
''
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Slater
reports
on
personal
finance
from
The
Wall
Street
Journal
's
New
York
bureau
.
<END>
<START>
Looking
to
the
past
can
provide
some
clues
.
<END>
<START>
But
while
history
can
suggest
what
is
reasonable
to
expect
there
's
no
guarantee
that
the
past
will
repeat
itself
.
<END>
<START>
For
instance
,
some
analysts
believe
bond
returns
and
volatility
have
moved
permanently
closer
to
those
of
the
stock
market
.
<END>
<START>
And
returns
on
cash
investments
may
continue
to
exceed
inflation
by
a
wider
margin
than
they
did
over
the
long-term
past
.
<END>
<START>
Portfolio
A
:
Retired
couple
,
age
65
;
$
400,000
portfolio
.
<END>
<START>
Portfolio
B
:
Two-income
couple
,
age
45
;
$
150,000
portfolio
.
<END>
<START>
A
letter
from
Senator
John
Kerry
chides
us
today
for
implying
that
he
had
``
flip-flopped
''
on
Manuel
Noriega
.
<END>
<START>
He
correctly
says
he
has
been
down
on
Noriega
for
some
time
,
hence
his
criticism
of
administration
mishandling
of
the
attempted
coup
.
<END>
<START>
Our
October
12
editorial
should
have
been
more
precise
.
<END>
<START>
It
meant
to
convey
our
hope
that
the
Senator
and
other
members
of
the
congressional
left
are
broadening
their
dislike
of
Noriega
to
include
other
notorious
Central
American
drug
runners
.
<END>
<START>
The
Sandinistas
of
Nicaragua
,
for
example
,
also
are
part
of
the
Castro-Medellin
cartel
nexus
.
<END>
<START>
In
his
letter
and
on
the
basis
of
his
losing
vote
Tuesday
against
U.S.
aid
for
the
Nicaraguan
opposition
,
Senator
Kerry
makes
clear
he
has
not
made
that
intellectual
leap
.
<END>
<START>
We
were
wrong
.
<END>
<START>
THROUGHOUT
THE
1980s
,
investors
have
been
looking
for
creative
alternatives
to
traditional
modes
of
financial
planning
.
<END>
<START>
Capital
has
been
democratized
,
and
people
want
in
.
<END>
<START>
Too
often
,
however
,
small
investors
are
left
with
the
same
stale
solutions
that
appealed
to
previous
generations
of
fiduciary
strategists
.
<END>
<START>
Now
a
startling
new
approach
is
available
to
building
your
financial
portfolio
without
undue
risk
,
without
extensive
planning
and
without
hurting
your
life
style
one
bit
!
<END>
<START>
This
is
particularly
good
news
for
those
who
hate
risk
,
who
are
incapable
of
doing
extensive
amounts
of
planning
and
who
refuse
to
see
their
life
styles
hurt
in
any
way
.
<END>
<START>
You
know
who
you
are
.
<END>
<START>
My
revolutionary
system
is
also
useful
for
those
who
have
tried
customary
forms
of
growing
their
currency
cushion
.
<END>
<START>
Return
on
this
fine
portfolio
has
been
modest
when
it
has
not
been
negative
.
<END>
<START>
Figure
1
demonstrates
the
performance
of
those
businesses
I
've
invested
in
during
this
prosperous
decade
-LRB-
see
accompanying
illustration
--
WSJ
Oct.
20
,
1989
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
Likewise
,
mutual
funds
remained
relatively
flat
until
I
made
what
was
,
for
me
,
a
serious
investment
.
<END>
<START>
By
1987
,
these
properties
were
in
a
tailspin
,
causing
my
broker
at
Pru-Bache
to
remark
that
she
'd
``

.
''

<END>
<START>
Mr.

<START>

<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

.

.

.

.

<START>

to
