uses
,
the
indictment
charges
.
<END>
<START>
Douglas
Jones
,
an
attorney
representing
Richard
O.
Kelly
Sr.
,
the
chairman
and
president
of
Capital
Trust
,
says
his
client
denies
that
there
was
any
attempt
to
defraud
investors
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
were
some
business
deals
that
went
bad
,
''
Mr.
Jones
says
,
``
but
no
intent
to
defraud
.
''
<END>
<START>
Newport
Beach
operations
differ
from
the
Hollywood
boiler
rooms
in
style
as
well
as
in
dollars
.
<END>
<START>
Traditionally
,
boiler
rooms
operate
on
the
cheap
,
since
few
,
if
any
,
customers
ever
visit
their
offices
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
the
name
derives
from
the
tendency
among
telemarketing
scammers
to
rent
cheap
basement
space
,
near
the
boiler
room
.
<END>
<START>
But
,
says
Mr.
Katz
,
the
U.S.
attorney
,
``
the
interesting
thing
about
Newport
Beach
operations
is
that
they
give
themselves
the
indulgence
of
beautiful
offices
,
with
plush
furnishings
.
<END>
<START>
When
we
go
there
,
it
's
quite
different
from
these
Hollywood
places
where
the
sandwiches
are
spread
out
on
the
table
and
the
people
are
picking
their
noses
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
Newport
Beach
operators
also
tend
to
indulge
themselves
privately
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
amazing
the
amount
of
money
that
goes
up
their
nose
,
out
to
the
dog
track
or
to
the
tables
in
Las
Vegas
,
''
Mr.
Katz
says
.
<END>
<START>
All
this
talk
of
boiler
rooms
and
fraud
is
unnerving
to
the
city
's
legitimate
business
element
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Ciavarella
has
rejected
a
few
prospective
tenants
who
provided
``
incomplete
''
financial
information
and
acknowledges
that
illegitimate
operators
``
are
not
easily
detectable
.
<END>
<START>
''
-LRB-
Investigators
stress
that
building
owners
are
victims
,
too
,
since
boiler
rooms
often
leave
without
paying
rent
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Richard
Luehrs
,
president
of
the
Newport
Harbor
Area
Chamber
of
Commerce
,
calls
boiler
rooms
a
``
negative
we
wish
we
could
get
rid
of
.
''
<END>
<START>
Actually
,
``
we
do
n't
get
much
negative
publicity
about
this
,
''
he
insists
,
``
except
for
the
press
who
write
about
it
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lancaster
is
deputy
chief
of
The
Wall
Street
Journal
's
Dallas
bureau
.
<END>
<START>
YOU
WENT
to
college
and
thought
you
got
an
education
.
<END>
<START>
Now
you
discover
that
you
never
learned
the
most
important
lesson
:
How
to
send
your
kids
to
college
.
<END>
<START>
True
,
when
you
went
to
college
,
there
was
n't
that
much
to
learn
.
<END>
<START>
Stick
some
money
in
an
interest-bearing
account
and
watch
it
grow
.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
investment
salesmen
say
it
's
time
to
take
some
risks
if
you
want
the
kind
of
returns
that
will
buy
your
toddler
a
ticket
to
Prestige
U.
in
18
years
.
<END>
<START>
In
short
,
throw
away
the
passbook
and
go
for
the
glory
.
<END>
<START>
The
reason
is
cost
.
<END>
<START>
Nothing
in
the
annals
of
tuition
readied
parents
for
the
1980s
.
<END>
<START>
Tuitions
at
private
colleges
rose
154
%
in
the
10
years
ended
in
June
of
this
year
;
that
's
twice
the
77
%
increase
in
consumer
prices
for
the
same
period
.
<END>
<START>
A
year
at
Harvard
now
goes
for
$
19,395
.
<END>
<START>
By
2007
,
when
this
year
's
newborns
hit
campus
,
a
four-year
Ivy
League
sheepskin
will
cost
$
300,000
,
give
or
take
a
few
pizzas-with-everything
at
exam
time
.
<END>
<START>
Stanford
,
MIT
and
other
utmosts
will
cost
no
less
.
<END>
<START>
So
what
's
a
parent
to
do
?
<END>
<START>
Some
investment
advisers
are
suggesting
,
in
effect
,
a
bet
on
a
start-up
investment
pool
--
maybe
even
on
margin
.
<END>
<START>
Others
prefer
deep-discount
zero-coupon
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
Still
others
say
,
Why
not
take
a
chance
on
a
high-octane
growth
fund
?
<END>
<START>
``
You
're
not
going
to
make
it
in
a
5
%
bank
account
,
''
says
James
Riepe
,
director
of
mutual
funds
at
T.
Rowe
Price
.
<END>
<START>
To
get
the
necessary
growth
,
adds
Murray
Ruffel
,
a
marketing
official
at
the
Financial
Programs
mutual-fund
group
,
``
you
need
to
go
to
the
stock
market
.
''
<END>
<START>
In
other
words
,
a
little
volatility
never
hurt
.
<END>
<START>
It
never
hurt
anyone
,
that
is
,
unless
the
growth
funds
do
n't
grow
when
you
need
them
to
.
<END>
<START>
Or
the
zero-coupon
bonds
turn
out
not
to
have
been
discounted
deeply
enough
to
pay
your
kid
's
tuition
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
the
dilemma
for
today
's
parent
.
<END>
<START>
Although
many
experts
are
advising
risk
,
no
one
has
a
good
answer
for
you
if
the
risk
does
n't
pay
off
.
<END>
<START>
Help
may
be
on
the
way
.
<END>
<START>
The
antitrust
division
of
the
Justice
Department
is
investigating
the
oddly
similar
tuition
charges
and
increases
among
the
top
schools
.
<END>
<START>
Fear
of
the
price
police
could
help
cool
things
off
in
the
1990s
.
<END>
<START>
And
then
there
's
always
State
U
.
<END>
<START>
But
parents
'
craving
for
a
top-rated
education
for
their
children
is
growing
like
their
taste
for
fancy
wheels
and
vintage
wine
.
<END>
<START>
Belatedly
aware
of
public
concern
,
lawmakers
and
financial
middlemen
are
working
overtime
to
create
and
sell
college
savings
and
investment
schemes
.
<END>
<START>
Their
message
,
explicit
or
implicit
,
is
that
a
good
college
will
cost
so
much
by
whenever
you
want
it
that
the
tried
and
true
wo
n't
do
anymore
.
<END>
<START>
Forget
about
Treasury
bills
or
a
money-market
fund
.
<END>
<START>
The
latest
wave
of
marketing
is
instructive
.
<END>
<START>
The
calculations
generally
rely
on
an
after-tax
rate
of
return
of
8
%
annually
--
a
rate
historically
obtainable
by
the
individual
in
only
one
place
,
the
stock
market
.
<END>
<START>
Most
of
the
mailers
are
free
,
but
Denver-based
Financial
Programs
sells
,
for
$
15
,
a
version
customized
to
the
age
of
the
child
and
the
college
of
choice
.
<END>
<START>
The
figures
are
shocking
.
<END>
<START>
To
build
a
nest
egg
that
would
pay
for
Stanford
when
a
current
first-grader
reaches
college
age
,
parents
would
need
to
set
aside
$
773.94
a
month
--
for
12
years
.
<END>
<START>
They
can
cut
this
to
$
691.09
a
month
if
the
investing
keeps
up
through
college
.
<END>
<START>
And
they
can
further
reduce
the
monthly
amount
if
they
start
saving
earlier
--
when
mother
and
child
come
home
from
the
hospital
.
<END>
<START>
Plugging
a
cheaper
college
into
the
formulas
still
does
n't
generate
an
installment
most
people
can
live
with
.
<END>
<START>
Using
a
recent
average
private-school
cost
of
about
$
12,500
a
year
,
T.
Rowe
Price
's
planner
prescribes
$
450
monthly
if
the
plan
begins
when
the
child
is
six
.
<END>
<START>
Since
the
formula
assumes
an
8
%
before-tax
return
in
a
mutual
fund
,
there
would
also
be
$
16,500
in
taxes
to
pay
over
the
12
years
.
<END>
<START>
Not
everyone
is
so
pessimistic
.
<END>
<START>
``
People
are
basically
peddling
a
lot
of
fear
,
''
says
Arthur
Hauptman
,
a
consultant
to
the
American
Council
on
Education
in
Washington
.
<END>
<START>
He
takes
issue
with
projections
that
do
n't
factor
in
students
'
own
contribution
,
which
reduces
most
parents
'
burden
substantially
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
he
says
,
``
it
's
no
bad
thing
''
if
all
the
marketing
prods
people
into
putting
aside
a
little
more
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
situation
you
want
to
avoid
is
having
somebody
not
save
anything
and
hope
they
'll
be
able
to
do
it
out
of
current
income
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
That
's
crazy
.
''
<END>
<START>
His
advice
:
Do
n't
panic
.
<END>
<START>
Parents
,
he
says
,
should
aim
at
whatever
regular
investment
sum
they
can
afford
.
<END>
<START>
Half
the
amount
that
the
investment
tables
suggest
might
be
a
good
goal
,
he
adds
.
<END>
<START>
That
way
,
parents
will
reduce
borrowings
and
outlays
from
current
income
when
the
time
comes
to
pay
tuition
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Hauptman
reckons
that
the
best
investment
choice
is
mutual
funds
because
they
are
managed
and
over
time
have
nearly
kept
up
with
the
broad
stock
averages
.
<END>
<START>
He
favors
either
an
all-stock
fund
or
a
balanced
fund
that
mixes
both
stocks
and
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
In
their
anxiety
,
however
,
parents
and
other
student
benefactors
are
flocking
to
new
schemes
.
<END>
<START>
They
have
laid
out
about
$
1
billion
for
so-called
baccalaureate
zero-coupon
municipal
bonds
--
so
far
offered
by
Connecticut
,
Illinois
,
Virginia
and
eight
other
states
.
<END>
<START>
And
they
have
bought
about
$
500
million
in
prepaid-tuition
plans
,
offered
in
Michigan
,
Florida
and
Wyoming
.
<END>
<START>
The
prepaid
plans
take
payment
today
--
usually
at
current
tuitions
or
at
a
slight
discount
--
for
a
promise
that
tuition
will
be
covered
tomorrow
.
<END>
<START>
The
baccalaureate
bonds
--
tax-free
,
offered
in
small
denominations
and
usually
containing
a
provision
that
they
wo
n't
be
called
before
maturity
--
seem
to
be
tailor-made
for
college
savers
.
<END>
<START>
Like
other
zeros
,
they
pay
all
their
interest
at
maturity
,
meaning
that
buyers
can
time
things
so
that
their
bonds
pay
off
just
when
Junior
graduates
from
high
school
.
<END>
<START>
Their
compounding
effect
is
also
alluring
.
<END>
<START>
In
June
,
Virginia
sold
bonds
for
$
268.98
that
will
pay
$
1,000
in
2009
.
<END>
<START>
But
Richard
Anderson
,
head
of
the
Forum
for
College
Financing
Alternatives
,
at
Columbia
University
,
a
research
group
partly
financed
by
the
federal
government
,
says
zeros
are
particularly
ill-suited
.
<END>
<START>
Their
price
falls
further
than
that
of
other
bonds
when
inflation
and
interest
rates
kick
up
.
<END>
<START>
Most
other
bonds
,
however
,
would
probably
not
have
fared
much
better
.
<END>
<START>
The
prepaid
plans
may
be
a
good
bet
,
provided
the
guarantee
of
future
tuition
is
secure
.
<END>
<START>
Issuing
states
generally
limit
the
guarantees
to
in-state
institutions
,
however
,
and
buyers
get
refunds
without
much
interest
if
the
children
do
n't
attend
the
specified
schools
.
<END>
<START>
Two
private
groups
are
seeking
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
approval
for
plans
that
could
be
more
broadly
transferable
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Anderson
wants
the
prestige
colleges
to
sponsor
such
a
plan
.
<END>
<START>
The
issue
here
may
be
the
soundness
of
the
guarantee
.
<END>
<START>
Prepayments
,
much
like
mutual-fund
purchases
,
are
pooled
for
investment
.
<END>
<START>
Sponsors
are
naturally
counting
on
their
ability
to
keep
ahead
of
tuition
inflation
with
investment
returns
.
<END>
<START>
But
buyers
are
essentially
betting
on
a
start-up
investment
fund
with
no
track
record
--
and
some
have
been
encouraged
to
borrow
to
do
so
.
<END>
<START>
One
problem
is
that
the
Internal
Revenue
Service
has
decided
that
the
investment
earnings
and
gains
of
the
sponsors
'
funds
are
taxable
.
<END>
<START>
The
colleges
,
as
educational
institutions
,
had
hoped
that
would
n't
be
the
case
.
<END>
<START>
But
sponsors
might
not
pick
the
stocks
that
will
match
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
And
they
're
leaning
more
toward
fixed
income
,
whose
returns
after
tax
have
trailed
tuition
increases
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
'm
not
sure
they
're
going
to
make
it
work
,
''
says
Mr.
Anderson
.
<END>
<START>
What
happens
if
the
sponsors
do
n't
have
the
cash
to
pay
the
tuitions
?
<END>
<START>
Florida
and
Wyoming
have
backed
up
their
guarantees
with
the
full
faith
and
credit
of
the
state
governments
,
meaning
that
taxpayers
will
pick
up
any
slack
.
<END>
<START>
Not
so
Michigan
.
<END>
<START>
Its
plan
is
set
up
as
an
independent
agency
.
<END>
<START>
The
state
says
there
's
no
worry
--
investment
returns
,
combined
with
fees
and
the
gains
from
unused
plans
,
will
provide
all
the
cash
it
needs
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Putka
covers
education
from
The
Wall
Street
Journal
's
Boston
bureau
.
<END>
<START>
Figures
assume
a
7
%
annual
rise
in
tuition
,
fees
,
room
and
board
and
an
8
%
annual
investment
return
.
<END>
<START>
Note
:
These
figures
are
only
for
mandatory
charges
and
do
n't
include
books
,
transportation
etc
.
<END>
<START>
*
For
in-state
students
<END>
<START>
Source
:
PaineWebber
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
AMONG
THE
CATFISH
farmers
in
the
watery
delta
land
of
Humphreys
County
,
Miss.
,
Allen
D.
Tharp
of
Isola
was
one
of
the
best
known
and
most
enterprising
.
<END>
<START>
He
sold
quarter-inch
fingerlings
to
stock
other
farmers
'
ponds
,
and
he
bought
back
one-pound-or-so
food-fish
that
he
``
live-hauled
''
to
market
along
with
his
own
whiskery
crop
.
<END>
<START>
And
he
nearly
always
bought
and
sold
for
cash
.
<END>
<START>
Along
the
way
,
Mr.
Tharp
omitted
a
total
of
$
1.5
million
from
his
receipts
reported
on
federal
tax
returns
for
three
years
.
<END>
<START>
The
returns
landed
in
the
hands
of
an
Internal
Revenue
Service
criminal
investigator
,
Samuel
James
Baker
.
<END>
<START>
Unknown
to
Mr.
Tharp
,
he
had
fouled
his
net
on
a
special
IRS
project
to
catch
catfish
farmers
and
haulers
inclined
to
cheat
on
their
taxes
.
<END>
<START>
Confronted
with
the
evidence
,
Mr.
Tharp
pleaded
guilty
to
one
charge
of
filing
a
false
return
and
was
fined
$
5,000
and
sentenced
to
18
months
in
prison
.
<END>
<START>
He
also
owes
a
lot
of
back
taxes
,
interest
and
civil
fraud
penalties
.
<END>
<START>
A
lot
of
taxpayers
out
there
are
n't
as
paranoid
as
one
might
think
.
<END>
<START>
Mail-order
ministers
have
been
squelched
.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
television
and
radio
evangelists
are
under
scrutiny
.
<END>
<START>
IRS
statistics
show
that
the
more
persistent
hiders
of
income
among
sole
proprietors
of
businesses
include
used-car
dealers
,
entertainment
producers
,
masons
,
roofers
,
and
taxi
owners
.
<END>
<START>
Small
businesses
in
general
account
for
almost
40
%
of
unreported
personal
income
,
the
IRS
has
said
.
<END>
<START>
Once
such
abuses
become
so
pervasive
,
the
IRS
builds
another
factor
into
its
secret
computer
formula
for
selecting
returns
for
audit
and
does
n't
need
special
projects
for
them
.
<END>
<START>
San
Franciscans
have
a
much
higher
incidence
of
audits
than
average
because
more
of
them
score
high
under
that
formula
,
not
because
IRS
agents
envy
their
life
styles
.
<END>
<START>
Many
openings
for
mass
cheating
,
such
as
questionable
tax
shelters
and
home
offices
,
have
gaped
so
broadly
that
Congress
has
passed
stringent
laws
to
close
them
.
<END>
<START>
Deductions
of
charitable
gifts
of
highly
valued
art
now
must
be
accompanied
by
appraisals
.
<END>
<START>
And
laws
requiring
the
reporting
of
more
varieties
of
transactions
have
enabled
the
IRS
to
rely
on
computers
to
ferret
out
discrepancies
with
returns
and
to
generate
form-letter
inquiries
to
taxpayers
.
<END>
<START>
Unreported
alimony
income
can
be
spotted
by
computer
because
a
payer
of
alimony
-LRB-
who
gets
a
deduction
-RRB-
must
report
the
former
spouse
's
Social
Security
number
.
<END>
<START>
Passport
applicants
now
must
give
Social
Security
numbers
,
enabling
the
IRS
to
see
whether
Americans
living
abroad
are
filing
required
U.S.
returns
.
<END>
<START>
But
while
IRS
computers
focus
routinely
on
target
groups
like
these
,
the
agency
has
assigned
many
agents
to
special
projects
that
need
more
personal
attention
.
<END>
<START>
The
national
office
currently
has
21
noncriminal
audit
projects
,
according
to
Marshall
V.
Washburn
,
deputy
assistant
commissioner
for
examination
.
<END>
<START>
Impetus
for
the
direct-seller
project
came
from
a
congressional
hearing
some
years
back
.
<END>
<START>
It
prompted
an
IRS
study
that
found
many
sellers
were
concealing
income
and
treating
large
amounts
of
nondeductible
travel
and
other
personal
expenses
as
business
costs
,
Mr.
Washburn
says
.
<END>
<START>
The
study
provided
criteria
for
singling
out
returns
of
``
potentially
noncompliant
''
taxpayers
who
report
low
income
and
large
expenses
from
a
part-time
business
.
<END>
<START>
The
independent-contractor
project
,
which
began
in
1988
,
involves
about
350
IRS
agents
.
<END>
<START>
The
number
of
misclassified
workers
may
be
in
the
millions
,
mostly
paid
by
small
firms
.
<END>
<START>
Many
workers
,
especially
professionals
,
want
to
remain
independent
to
avoid
tax
withholding
and
to
continue
to
deduct
many
expenses
that
employees
ca
n't
.
<END>
<START>
Firms
that
are
paying
employment
taxes
also
provide
leads
to
competitors
that
are
n't
,
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
In
his
area
,
Mr.
Lackey
continues
,
the
miscreant
employers
most
commonly
are
in
construction
--
doing
framing
,
drywall
,

and
similar
work
.
<END>
<START>
But
a
medical
clinic
with
about
20
employees
wrongly
listed
all
of
them
--
including
physicians
and
receptionists
--
as
independent

.
<END>
<START>
The
IRS
assessed
the
clinic
$
350,000
in
back

.
<END>
<START>
It
assessed
nearly
$
500,000
against
a

that
carried
about
100
deckhands
,
cooks
,

,

and
other
employees
as

.
<END>
<START>
Thus
armed
for
massive
matching
of
documents
by

,
they
single
out
high-income
groups
,
looking
primarily
for
people
who
have
n't
filed
New
York

.
<END>
<START>
The
department
has
collected
over
$
6.5

from
brokers
so

and
recommended
more

.
<END>
<START>
``

can

of

just
through
the
nonresident
project
,
''
Mr.
Hicks

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Schmedel
is
editor
of
The
Wall
Street
Journal
's
Tax
Report
column
.
<END>
<START>
The
plan
indeed
raises
from
40
%
to
50
%
the
number
of
freshmen
applicants
admitted
strictly
by

criteria
.
<END>
<START>
But
that
does
n't

``
half
of
the

attending
Berkeley
''
will
be
admitted
this
way
.
<END>
<START>
The
plan
is
talking
about
applicants
admitted
,
not
students
who
enroll
.
<END>
<START>
In

,

will

from

consisting
of

whose

``

''
gaining

in

.
<END>
<START>
This
category
now
accounts
for
about
19
%
of

and
22
%
of

.
<END>
<START>
The
plan
thus
will
decrease
by
22
%
,
for

net
loss
of
10
%
,
the
number
of
students
admitted

by

criteria
.
<END>
<START>
Who
will
take
over
these
places
?
<END>
<START>
The
plan
creates
a
new
category
of
students
from
``
socioeconomically
disadvantaged
backgrounds
,
''
a
concept
not
yet

,
and
gives

about
10
%
of

class
.
<END>
<START>
One

's

has

``
socioeconomic

''
category
as
perhaps

more

than

based

.
<END>
<START>
Perhaps

.
<END>
<START>

's

.
<END>
<START>
Nor

``

''
for

.
<END>
<START>
The
plan
thus
places

,
based
on
``
socioeconomic
disadvantage
,
''
on

of
the
existing
program
based
on
race
.
<END>
<START>
The
role
of

criteria
in
choosing

's

can
only

as
a
result
.
<END>
<START>
Stephen
R.
Barnett
Professor
of
Law
University
of
California
Berkeley
,
Calif
.
<END>
<START>
FOR
THOSE
WHO
DELIGHT
in
the
misfortune
of
others
,
read
on
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
a
story
about
suckers
.
<END>
<START>
Most
of
us
know
a
sucker
.
<END>
<START>
Many
of
us
are
suckers
.
<END>
<START>
But
what
we
may
not
know
is
just
what
makes
somebody
a
sucker
.
<END>
<START>
What
makes
people
blurt
out
their
credit-card
numbers
to
a
caller
they
've
never
heard
of
?
<END>
<START>
Do
they
really
believe
that
the
number
is
just
for
verification
and
is
simply
a
formality
on
the
road
to
being
a
grand-prize
winner
?
<END>
<START>
What
makes
a
person
buy
an
oil
well
from
some
stranger
knocking
on
the
screen
door
?
<END>
<START>
Or
an
interest
in
a
retirement
community
in
Nevada
that
will
knock
your
socks
off
,
once
it
is
built
?
<END>
<START>
Because
in
the
end
,
these
people
always
wind
up
asking
themselves
the
same
question
:
``
How
could
I
be
so
stupid
?
''
<END>
<START>
There
are
,
unfortunately
,
plenty
of
answers
to
that
question
--
and
scam
artists
know
all
of
them
.
<END>
<START>
``
Once
they
size
them
up
,
then
they
know
what
buttons
to
push
.
''
<END>
<START>
John
Blodgett
agrees
--
and
he
ought
to
know
.
<END>
<START>
He
used
to
be
a
boiler-room
salesman
,
peddling
investments
in
oil
and
gas
wells
and
rare
coins
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
's
a
definite
psychology
of
the
sale
and
different
personalities
you
pitch
different
ways
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
The
most
obvious
pitch
,
of
course
,
is
the
lure
of
big
returns
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're
all
a
little
greedy
.
<END>
<START>
Everyone
is
vulnerable
,
''
says
Charles
Harper
,
associate
regional
administrator
for
the
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
in
Miami
.
<END>
<START>
``
These
guys
prey
on
human
frailties
.
''
<END>
<START>
While
the
promises
of
big
profits
ought
to
set
off
warning
bells
,
they
often
do
n't
,
in
part
because
get-rich-quick
tales
have
become
embedded
in
American
folklore
.
<END>
<START>
``
Other
people
are
making
it
overnight
,
and
the
rest
who
toil
daily
do
n't
want
to
miss
that
opportunity
when
it
seems
to
come
along
.
''
<END>
<START>
Adds
Spencer
Barasch
,
branch
chief
for
enforcement
at
the
SEC
in
Fort
Worth
,
Texas
:
``
Why
do
people
play
the
lottery
when
the
odds
are
great
against
them
?
<END>
<START>
People
are
shooting
for
a
dream
.
''
<END>
<START>
Clearly
,
though
,
scam
artists
have
to
be
a
bit
more
subtle
than
simply
promising
millions
;
the
psychology
of
suckers
is
n't
simply
the
psychology
of
the
greedy
.
<END>
<START>
There
's
also
,
for
instance
,
the
need
to
be
part
of
the
in-crowd
.
<END>
<START>
So
one
popular
ploy
is
to
make
a
prospective
investor
feel
like
an
insider
,
joining
an
exclusive
group
that
is
about
to
make
a
killing
.
<END>
<START>
Neither
the
Amoco
agreement
nor
the
wells
existed
,
the
suit
alleged
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
adds
to
the
mystery
of
the
venture
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Blodgett
,
the
boiler-room
veteran
,
believes
that
for
many
investors
,
the
get-rich-quick
scams
carry
a
longed-for
element
of
excitement
.
<END>
<START>
``
Once
people
got
into
it
,
I
was
allowing
them
to
live
a
dream
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
He
phoned
them
with
updates
on
the
investment
,
such
as
``
funny
things
that
happened
at
the
well
that
week
,
''
he

.
<END>
<START>
``
You
gave
them
some

that
they
did
n't
have
in
their
lives
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
says
he
has
quit
the
business
and
is
back
in
school
,
majoring
in
psychology
with
aspirations
to
go
into
industrial

.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
For
some
investors
,
it
's
the
appearances
that
leave
them

.
<END>
<START>
``
The

of

go

--

,

,
''

,

.
<END>
<START>
Conservative

make

's

.
<END>
<START>
``
People
honestly
lose
money
on
risky

that
they
did

realize
were
a

,
''
he

.
<END>
<START>
Paul
Wenz
,

,
Ariz.
,
attorney
,

a

of
unrealistic
returns
would
have

.
<END>
<START>
When
he
visited
the
company
's
office
,
he
says
,

had
``
all
the

of

.
''
<END>
<START>
Still

are

by

,

Douglas
Watson
,

.
<END>
<START>
Born-again
Christians
are
the
most
visible
targets
of
unscrupulous
do-gooder
investment
pitches
.
<END>
<START>
But
hardly
the
only
ones
:
The
scams
promise
--
among
other
things
--
to
help
save
the
environment
,
feed
starving
families
and
prevent
the
disappearance
of
children
.
<END>
<START>
Psychologists
say
isolated
people
who
do
n't
discuss
their
investments
with
others
are
particularly
at
risk
for
fraud
.
<END>
<START>
Scam
artists
seek
out
such
people
--
or
try
to
make
sure
that
their
victims
isolate
themselves
.
<END>
<START>
For
instance
,
salesmen
may
counter
a
man
's
objection
that
he
wants
to
discuss
an
investment
with
his
wife
by

,
``
Who
wears
the
pants
in
your

?
''
<END>
<START>
Or
an

who
wants

's

may
be
told
,
``
You
seem
like
a
guy
who
can
make
up
his
own
mind
.
''
<END>
<START>
Often
con
artists
will
try
to
disarm
their
victims
by
emphasizing
similarities
between
them
.
<END>
<START>
The
Lyneses
,
of
Powder
Springs
,
Ga.
,
have
filed
suit
in
Georgia

against
Stuart
James
,

.
<END>
<START>
They

.
<END>
<START>
They
say
the
broker
took

out
for

.
<END>
<START>
He
urged
them
to
refer
their
friends
,
who
also
lost

.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Donald
Trinen
,
an

for
the

firm
,

the

and
says

fully

.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
``
We
've
seen

where
salesmen
will
affect
the
accent
of
the
region
of
the
country
they

.
<END>
<START>
Anything
to

.
''
<END>
<START>
Experts
say
that

person

,

.
<END>
<START>
People

.
<END>
<START>
``
They
may

.
''
<END>
<START>
``
These

.
<END>
<START>
Almost

,
''

Jerald

,

.
<END>
<START>
Nick
Cortese
thinks
that
's
what
happened
to
him
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Cortese
,
a

Delta
Air

engineer
,
invested
some
$
2,000
in
penny

through
a

who
promised
quick

.
<END>
<START>
``
We
were

,

was

,
''
says
Mr.
Cortese
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
was
just
before
the
Christmas
holidays
,
and
I
figured
we
could
use
some
extra
cash
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
investment
is
worth
about
$
130
today
.
<END>
<START>
``
Maybe
it
was
just
a
vulnerable
time
,
''
says
Mr.
Cortese
.
<END>
<START>
``
Maybe
the
next
day
or
even
an
hour
later
,
I
would
n't
have
done
it
.
''
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Brannigan
is
a
staff
reporter
in
The
Wall
Street
Journal
's
Atlanta
bureau
.
<END>
<START>
Prices
for
seats
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
are
recovering
a
bit
after
hitting
a
four-year
low
earlier
this
month
.
<END>
<START>
Two
seats
on
the
Big
Board
were
sold
yesterday
for
$
455,000
,
and
then
$
500,000
.
<END>
<START>
The
previous
sale
was
$
436,000
on
Oct.
17
;
the
last
time
prices
were
that
low
was
November
1985
,
when
a
seat
sold
for
$
425,000
.
<END>
<START>
Prices
peaked
at
$
1,150,000
in
September
1987
.
<END>
<START>
Seats
are
currently
quoted
at
$
430,000
bid
and
$
525,000
asked
.
<END>
<START>
FOX
HUNTING
HAS
been
defined
as
the
unspeakable
in
pursuit
of
the
inedible
,
but
at
least
it
's
exercise
.
<END>
<START>
At
least
it
has
a
little
dash
.
<END>
<START>
Most
of
us
have
to
spend
our
time
on
pursuits
that
afford
neither
,
drab
duties
rather
than
pleasures
.
<END>
<START>
Like
trying
to
buy
life
insurance
,
for
instance
,
an
endeavor
notably
lacking
in
dash
.
<END>
<START>
Call
it
the
uninformed
trudging
after
the
incomprehensible
.
<END>
<START>
But
sooner
or
later
,
most
of
us
have
to
think
about
life
insurance
,
just
as
we
often
have
to
think
about
having
root-canal
work
.
<END>
<START>
And
my
time
has
come
.
<END>
<START>
I
'm
33
,
married
,
no
children
,
and
employed
in
writing
stories
like
this
one
.
<END>
<START>
In
times
past
,
life-insurance
salesmen
targeted
heads
of
household
,
meaning
men
,
but
ours
is
a
two-income
family
and
accustomed
to
it
.
<END>
<START>
What
to
do
?
<END>
<START>
First
,
generalize
.
<END>
<START>
If
all
you
want
is
death-benefit
coverage
,
pure
insurance
--
a
term
policy
--
gives
you
maximum
bang
for
your
buck
,
within
limits
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
much
cheaper
than
permanent
insurance
bought
at
the
same
age
.
<END>
<START>
But
``
term
''
means
just
that
;
the
policy
is
written
for
a
specific
time
period
only
and
must
be
renewed
when
it
expires
.
<END>
<START>
Even
if
you
're
healthy
and
can
renew
,
your
premium
will
go
up
sharply
because
you
're
that
much
older
.
<END>
<START>
So
term
insurance
may
not
be
as
cheap
as
it
looks
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
all
sorts
of
variations
on
term
insurance
:
policies
structured
to
pay
off
your
mortgage
debt
,
term
riders
tacked
on
to
permanent
insurance
,
and
many
others
.
<END>
<START>
Upon
examination
,
however
,
I
wondered
whether
the
plan
made
a
lot
of
sense
.
<END>
<START>
Sounds
great
--
or
does
it
?
<END>
<START>
First
,
if
I
canceled
,
I
'd
have
no
more
insurance
,
a
not
insignificant
consideration
.
<END>
<START>
That
would
be
all
right
with
Amex
,
which
could
then
lock
in
its
investment
profit
,
but
it
does
n't
add
up
to
a
``
smart
money
''
move
for
me
.
<END>
<START>
Which
goes
to
show
that
the
First
Law
applies
in
insurance
as
in
anything
else
:
There
is
no
free
lunch
,
there
is
only
marketing
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
Second
Law
,
unique
to
insurance
?
<END>
<START>
If
I
die
early
,
I
win
--
a
hollow
victory
,
since
I
ca
n't
enjoy
it
--
and
if
I
live
long
,
the
insurer
wins
.
<END>
<START>
Always
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
worth
remembering
when
insurers
and
their
salesmen
try
to
sell
you
permanent
insurance
,
the
kind
that
amasses
cash
value
.
<END>
<START>
The
implication
is
that
your
permanent-insurance
policy
is
really
some
kind
of
CD
or
mutual-fund
account
with
an
added
feature
.
<END>
<START>
That
is
gilding
the
lily
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
because
you
have
to
pay
for
the
insurance
portion
of
the
policy
and
the
effort
required
to
sell
and
service
the
whole
package
.
<END>
<START>
Again
,
no
free
lunch
.
<END>
<START>
So
view
permanent
insurance
for
what
it
is
--
a
compromise
between
pure
insurance
and
direct
investment
.
<END>
<START>
The
simplest
,
most
traditional
form
of
permanent
insurance
is
the
straight
whole
life
policy
.
<END>
<START>
Congress
closed
this
loophole
last
year
,
or
thought
it
did
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
percentage
of
your
cash
reserve
that
you
can
borrow
tax-free
is
very
small
.
<END>
<START>
I
'm
not
prepared
in
any
case
to
put
that
much
money
into
a
policy
immediately
,
so
I
look
into
the
broad
category
called
universal
life
.
<END>
<START>
Hugely
popular
,
it
is
far
more
flexible
than
straight
whole
life
.
<END>
<START>
Projecting
the
latter
over
several
decades
,
I
find
my
cash
buildup
is
impressive
--
but
can
any
high
interest
rate
prevail
for
that
long
?
<END>
<START>
Not
likely
,
I
think
.
<END>
<START>
Also
,
some
policy
illustrations
assume
that
mortality
costs
will
decline
or
that
I
will
get
some
sort
of
dividend
bonus
after
the
10th
year
.
<END>
<START>
These
are
not
certain
,
either
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
seemingly
endless
twists
to
universal
life
,
and
it
pays
to
ask
questions
about
all
of
them
.
<END>
<START>
I
call
her
agent
,
David
Dominici
.
<END>
<START>
If
interest
rates
plunge
,
the
insurer
may
be
knocking
on
my
door
,
asking
for
steeper
premium
payments
to
maintain
the
same
amount
of
protection
.
<END>
<START>
I
do
n't
like
the
sound
of
that
.
<END>
<START>
Some
insurers
have
also
started
offering
``
persistency
bonuses
,
''
such
as
extra
dividends
or
a
marginally
higher
interest
yield
,
if
the
policy
is
maintained
for
10
years
.
<END>
<START>
But
Glenn
Daily
,
a
New
York-based
financial
consultant
,
warns
that
many
of
these
bonuses
are
``
just
fantasies
,
''
because
most
are
n't
guaranteed
by
the
companies
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
feature
is
so
new
,
he
adds
,
that
no
insurer
has
yet
established
a
track
record
for
actually
making
such
payments
.
<END>
<START>
So-called
living-benefits
provisions
also
merit
a
close
inspection
.
<END>
<START>
Also
,
financial
planners
advising
on
insurance
say
that
to
their
knowledge
there
has
not
yet
been
a
tax
ruling
exempting
these
advance
payments
from
taxes
.
<END>
<START>
I
'm
more
favorably
impressed
by
``
no-load
life
,
''
even
though
it
turns
out
to
be
low-load
life
.
<END>
<START>
After
one
year
I
could
walk
away
from
the
Ameritas
policy
with
$
792
,
but
Id
get
only
$
14
from
the
Equitable
.
<END>
<START>
The
difference
is
magnified
by
time
,

.
<END>
<START>
Did

?
<END>
<START>
Well
,

.
<END>
<START>
I
'm

$
871

Paris

.
<END>
<START>
A

insurance
there

.

<START>
Mr.
Cawthorn
said
in

that

will

``
somewhat

10
%
.
''
<END>
<START>
Through

,

12

.
<END>
<START>

for

$

,

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Cawthorn
said

in

was

Rorer

.

,

.

,

,

,

.

sold

``

''
and

record

.
<END>
<START>

``

''

,

.

in

.

<START>

,

.
''
<END>
<START>

,
''
he

,

.

<START>
A

''

,

.

<START>
Hoechst
AG
said

stop

in

and

.

<START>
The

said

in

.
<END>
<START>

said

faces

in
Western

,

from
East

and

,

.

<START>
HomeFed
Corp.
said
its
main
subsidiary
,
Home
Federal
Savings
&
Loan
,
converted
from
a
federal
savings
and
loan
to
a
federal

bank
and
changed
its
name
to
HomeFed
Bank
.
<END>
<START>
The
federal
Office
of
Thrift
Supervision
approved
the
conversion
last
Friday
,
HomeFed
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
change
in
charter
does
n't
alter
the
federal
insurance
of
deposits
,
federal
regulatory
powers
or
company
operations
,
a
spokesman
said
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
the
second
anniversary
of
the
1987
crash
,
but
this
time
it
was
different
.
<END>
<START>
Stocks
rallied
on
good
earnings
reports
and
on
data
that
showed
less
inflation
than
expected
.
<END>
<START>
Blue
chips
led
the
march
up
in
heavy
trading
.
<END>
<START>
The
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
rose
39.55
points
to
2683.20
.
<END>
<START>
The
30
industrials
led
the
market
higher
from
the
opening
bell
as
foreign
buyers
stepped
in
.
<END>
<START>
By
afternoon
,
the
broader
market
joined
the
advance
in
full
strength
.
<END>
<START>
Standard
&
Poor
's
500-stock
Index
rose
5.37
to
347.13
and
the
Nasdaq
composite
index
jumped
7.52
to
470.80
.
<END>
<START>
New
York
Stock
Exchange
volume
swelled
to
198,120,000
shares
.
<END>
<START>
The
industrials
were
up
about
60
points
in
the
afternoon
,
but
cautious
investors
took
profits
before
the
close
.
<END>
<START>
Traders
said
a
variety
of
factors
triggered
the
rally
.
<END>
<START>
The
consumer
price
index
rose
0.2
%
in
September
,
while
many
economists
were
looking
for
a
0.4
%
increase
.
<END>
<START>
Stock-index
arbitrage
buy
programs
--
in
which
traders
buy
stock
against
offsetting
positions
in
futures
to
lock
in
price
differences
--
helped
the
rally
's
momentum
.
<END>
<START>
The
euphoria
was
such
that
investors
responded
to
good
earnings
reports
of
companies
such
as
American
Express
,
while
ignoring
the
disappointing
profits
of
companies
such
as
Caterpillar
,
analysts
said
.
<END>
<START>
Stock-index
arbitrage
trading
was
a
minor
influence
in
yesterday
's
rally
,
traders
said
.
<END>
<START>
Institutional
buyers
were
the
main
force
pushing
blue
chips
higher
.
<END>
<START>
To
the
amazement
of
some
traders
,
takeover
stocks
were
climbing
again
.
<END>
<START>
Hilton
rose
2
7/8
to
100
,
for
example
.
<END>
<START>
Last
Friday
,
takeover
traders
spilled
out
of
Hilton
,
knocking
the
stock
down
21
1/2
to
85
.
<END>
<START>
Among
other
stocks
involved
in
restructurings
or
rumored
to
be
so
:
Holiday
Corp.
gained
1
7/8
to
73
and
Honeywell
rose
2
7/8
to
81
1/2
.
<END>
<START>
One
floor
trader
noted
in
astonishment
that
nobody
seemed
to
mind
the
news
that
British
Airways
is
n't
making
a
special
effort
to
revive
the
UAL
buy-out
.
<END>
<START>
The
announcement
of
the
buy-out
's
troubles
triggered
the
market
's
nose
dive
a
week
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Takeover
enthusiasm
may
have
been
renewed
when
an
investor
group
disclosed
yesterday
that
it
had
obtained
all
the

to
complete

$
1.6

of
American
Medical
International
.
<END>
<START>
``
That
's

back

,
''

Peter
VandenBerg
,
a

.
<END>
<START>
But

traders
thought

was
less
to
the
rally
than

the
eye
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
is
no
strength
behind

rally
,
''

Chung

,

North

.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
traders
squaring
positions
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
not
good
;
the
market
is
setting
up
for
another
fall
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
number
of
outstanding
contracts
in
the
October
Major
Market
Index
jumped
from
5,273
on
Friday
to
9,023
on
Monday
.
<END>
<START>
The
MMI
is
a
20-stock
index
that
mimics
the
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
.
<END>
<START>
Outstanding
contracts
are
those
that
remain
to
be
liquidated
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
has
been
a
tremendous
increase
''
in
MMI
positions
,
Mr.
Selkin
said
.
<END>
<START>
Consumer
stocks
once
again
set
the
pace
for
blue-chip

If

<END>
<START>
You

,

.

<START>
The
study
surveyed
a
national
group
of

directors
,

and

about

on

York
Business
Group
,

.
<END>
<START>

was
undertaken
because

related
to

``
are
much
more

than

seem
,
''

J.

,

.
<END>
<START>
In
presenting
the
study
late
last
week
,
Dr.
Warshaw
estimated
the
cost
of
these
types
of
disorders
to
business
is
substantial
.
<END>
<START>
Occupational
disability
related
to
anxiety
,
depression
and
stress
costs
about
$
8,000
a
case
in
terms
of
worker
's
compensation
.
<END>
<START>
In
terms
of
days
lost
on
the
job
,
the
study
estimated
that
each
affected
employee
loses
about
16
work
days
a
year
because
of
stress
,
anxiety
or
depression
.
<END>
<START>
He
added
that
the
cost
for
stress-related
compensation
claims
is
about
twice
the
average
for
all
injury
claims
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
hope
to
sensitize
employers
''
to
recognize
the
problems
so
they
can
do
something
about
them
,
Dr.
Warshaw
said
.
<END>
<START>
Early
intervention
into
these
types
of
problems
can
apparently

long-term
expense
associated
with
hospitalization
,
which
sometimes
results
when
these
problems
go
untreated
for
too
long
.
<END>
<START>
Even

are

in

,

.

<START>

,

.

<START>

poll

.

<START>

.

.
<END>
<START>
Rep.
J.
Dennis

-LRB-

,

.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
When
his
Seventh
Avenue
fur
business
here
was
flying
high
20
years
ago
,
Jack
Purnick
had
25
workers
and
a
large
factory
.
<END>
<START>
Now
his
half-dozen
employees
work
in
an
eighth-floor
shop
that
he
says
is
smaller
than
his
old
storage
room
.
<END>
<START>
He
also
says
he
is
losing
money
now
.
<END>
<START>
He
blames
imports
.
<END>
<START>
He
credits
imports
.
<END>
<START>
The
difference
lies
in
how
the
two
entrepreneurial
furriers
reacted
to
the
foreign
competition
and
transformation
of
their
industry
over
the
past
10
years
.
<END>
<START>
One
stuck
to
old-line
business
traditions
,
while
the
other
embraced
the
change
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
small
,
good
fur
salon
is
not
what
it
used
to
be
,
''
says
Mr.
Purnick
,
75
years
old
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
make
the
finest
product
in
the
world
,
and
the
Americans
are
being
kicked
around
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Rosen
,
though
,
believes
imports
have
reinvigorated
the
industry
in
which
he
has
worked
for
most

57

.
<END>
<START>
``
You
've
got
some
minds
here
that
wo
n't
think
progressively
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Import
competition
for
U.S.
furs
has
risen

since
furriers
started
aggressively
marketing
``
working-girl
mink
''
and
similar
lower-priced
imported
furs
in
recent
years
.
<END>
<START>
Merchants
discovered
a
consumer
largely
ignored
by
higher-priced
furriers
:
the
younger
woman
--
even
in
her
late
20s
--
who
never
thought
she
could
buy
a
mink
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
market
helped
boost
U.S.
fur
sales
to
about
$
1.8
billion
a
year
now
,
triple
the
level
in
the
late
1970s
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
opened
the
door
to
furs
made
in
South
Korea
,
China
,
Hong
Kong
and
other
countries
.
<END>
<START>
Jindo
Furs
,
a
large
South

maker
,
says
it
operates
35
retail
outlets
in
the
U.S.
and
plans
to
open
15
more
by
the
end

next

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Purnick
and
other
old-line
furriers
call
many
of
the
the
imports
unstylish
and
poorly
made
.
<END>
<START>
High-end
U.S.
furriers
say
these
imports
have
n't
squeezed

.
<END>
<START>
But
low-priced
and

like
Mr.
Purnick
,
who
once
saturated
the
five-block
Seventh
Avenue
fur

,
say
imports
have
cut
their
sales
.
<END>
<START>
A
woman
who
once
would
have
saved
for
two
or
three

to
buy
a
U.S.-made
mink
can
now
get
an
imported
mink
right
away
for
less
than
$
2,000
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
Mr.
Rosen
has
turned
the
import
phenomenon
to
his
advantage
.
<END>
<START>
Early
in
the
decade
he
saw
that
fur
workers
in
many
foreign
countries
were
willing
to
work
longer
hours
at
lower
wages
than
their
American
counterparts
and
were
more
open
to
innovation
.
<END>
<START>
In
1982
,
he
started
a
factory
in
Greece
.
<END>
<START>
Two
years
later
,
he
opened
one
in
West
Germany
.
<END>
<START>
He
also
noticed
that
foreign
makers
were
introducing
many
variations
on
the
traditional
fur
,
and
he
decided
to
follow
suit
.
<END>
<START>
By
combining
his
strengths
in
innovation
and
quality
control
with
the
lower
costs
of
production
abroad
,
he
says
he
has
been
able
to
produce
high-quality
goods
at
low
cost
.
<END>
<START>
To
maintain
control
over
production
and
avoid
overdependence
on
foreign
sources
,
he
says
he
still
makes
most
of
his

in
the
U.S.
.
<END>
<START>
But
six
years
ago
he
also
began
importing
from
the
Far
East
.
<END>
<START>
Inspired
by
imports
,
Mr.
Rosen
now
makes
fur

,

and

.
<END>
<START>
This
year
he
produced
a
men
's
line
and
offers
dyed
furs
in
red
,
cherry

,
violet
,

and

.
<END>
<START>
He
has
leather
jackets
from
Turkey
that
are
lined
with
eel
skin
and
topped
off
with
raccoon-skin

.
<END>
<START>
From
Asia
,
he
has
mink

with

made
by
using
different
colored
furs
.
<END>
<START>
Next

will
be
testing
pictured

-LRB-
called
kalega
-RRB-
made
in
the
Far
East
.
<END>
<START>
He
plans
to
attach

to

and

.
<END>
<START>
Besides
adding
to

,

also
attract
retailers
who
may
buy
furs
later
,
he

.
<END>
<START>
Other

have
also
benefited
from

.
<END>
<START>
Seymour

,

,

to

.
<END>
<START>
He

for
25

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Rosen
is
also

.
<END>
<START>
This

bought
two

,

in

and

.
<END>
<START>
Other

have
also

.
<END>
<START>
Golden

Furs

began

eight

ago
,

now

account
for
about
20

.
<END>
<START>
In

,

Rosen

three

to

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>
Small

ca

.
<END>
<START>
Such

.
<END>
<START>

.

,

.

.
<END>

,

has

skins

,

.
<END>
<START>

.

.

.

.

.

.

.

<START>

.

<START>

&

,

.

<START>

's

486tm

,

.

<START>

Americans
do
,
''
the
spokesman
said
.
<END>
<START>
Executives
at
Olivetti
,
whose
earnings
have
been
steadily
sliding
over
the
past
couple
of
years
,
have
acknowledged
that
in
the
past
they
have
lagged
at

to

.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Davis
said
the
new
machines
could

some

away
from
Olivetti
's
own

,
but
would

among

,

.
<END>
<START>
``
We
think
the
worst
is
over
''
in
the
European

market
,

.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's

''
in

's

between

and

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
The
machines
will
cost
around
$
16,250
on
average
in
Europe
.
<END>
<START>
The
Intel
486
chip
can
process
15
million
instructions
per
second
,
or
MIPS
,
while
Intel
's
previous
386
chip
could
handle
only
3

6

.
<END>
<START>

also

CP486

in

starting
next

through
Olivetti
USA
and

,

.

<START>
Viatech
Inc.
said

received

from

for

44.7
million

of

S.A
.
<END>
<START>

satisfies

conditions
of

,

expected

within

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

.

makes

,
and

.

<START>
The
higher

will

3
,

.
<END>
<START>

,

will

to
7.65
%
in
1990
from
7.51
%
and
wo

any
further
in

.
<END>
<START>
This

that

yearly

will
rise
$
250.80
next

3,855.60
.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.

.

<START>
Health-care
companies
should
get

in
the
third
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Medical-supply
houses
are
expected
to

of
about
15
%
on

for
the
third

,

of

10

,

.
<END>
<START>
To

sales

,

have
been
cutting
staff
,
mostly
through
attrition
,
and
slowing
the
growth
in
research
and
development

.
<END>
<START>
Sales
growth
in
the
quarter
was
slowed
by
mounting
pressure
from
groups
of
buyers
,
such
as

,
to
hold
down

.
<END>
<START>
Suppliers
were
also
hurt
by
the
stronger
U.S.
dollar
,
which
makes
sales
abroad
more
difficult
.
<END>
<START>
In
some
cases
,
competition
has
squeezed

.
<END>
<START>
Becton
,
Dickinson
&
Co.
,
for

,
faces
stiff

from
a
Japanese
supplier
in

important

market
.
<END>
<START>

for
the
company
,
based
in

Park
,

,

8.3
%
to

1.31
billion
from

.

,

,

5.8
%
to

billion
from

.
<END>
<START>
But

.
<END>
<START>
Sales
fell
1.2
%
to
$
190.1

from

192.5
million
.
<END>

,

33

.

,

.

<START>
The

.

,
''

.

.

.

,

.

.

<START>
Colgate
Palmolive
Co.
reported
third-quarter
net
income
rose
27
%
,
bolstered
by
strong
sales
in
its
Latin
American
business
and
surprisingly
healthy
profits
from
U.S.
operations
.
<END>
<START>

said

income
for
the
quarter
rose
to
$
76.7
million
,
or
$
1.06
a
share
,
on
sales
that
increased
6
%
to
$
1.3
billion
.
<END>
<START>

the
year-earlier
period
,
Colgate
posted
net
income
of
$
60.2
million
,
or
88
cents
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Last
year
's

included

from

operations
of
$
13.1
million
,

19
cents
a

.
<END>

Mark
,

and

,

was

,

.

at

's

,
''

.

,

's

.

<START>

've

.
-RRB-

,
''

.

<START>

.
''

's

.

.

.

,

<START>

competitive
market
,
rose
6.4
%
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
growth
was
partly
offset
by
lower
equipment
sales
and
rentals
and
price
cuts
on
some
products
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
amended
pension
program
,
AT&T
managers
who
have
at
least
five
years
of
service
will
have
five
years
added
to
their
age
and
length
of
service
for
pension
purposes
.
<END>
<START>
Managers
who
retire
Dec.
30
will
have
an
additional
15
%
added
to
their
monthly
pension
for
as
long
as
five
years
or
age
65
,
whichever
comes
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
An
AT&T
spokeswoman
said
the
company
would
likely
replace
about
one-third
of
its
managers
who
choose
to
retire
with
new
employees
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
hailed
the
sweetened
pension
package
,
which
they
said
had
been
the
subject
of
rumors
for
several
months
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
tells
you
AT&T
is
serious
about
continuing
to
manage
their
cost
structure
and
is
committed
to
20%-a-year
earnings
growth
,
''
said
Jack
Grubman
,
an
analyst
with
PaineWebber
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
But
other
analysts
expressed
disappointment
that
the
cost-cutting
move
wo
n't
result
in
even
greater
earnings
growth
.
<END>
<START>
AT&T
said
the
special
retirement
option
will
increase
fourth-quarter
expenses
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
company
said
the
amount
ca
n't
be
determined
until
it
knows
how
many
managers
opt
to
retire
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
gained
3.1
%
to
$
26.81
billion
from
$
26
billion
.
<END>
<START>
In
composite
trading
yesterday
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
,
AT&T
shares
closed
at
$
43.375
,
up
87.5
cents
.
<END>
<START>
When
it
comes
to
buying
and
selling
shares
,
Westridge
Capital
Management
Inc.
takes
a
back
seat
to
no
one
.
<END>
<START>
Every
dollar
's
worth
of
stock
in
the
Los
Angeles
money
manager
's
portfolio
is
traded
seven
or
eight
times
a
year
,
the
firm
estimates
.
<END>
<START>
That
makes
it
the
most
active
trader
among
all
the
nation
's
investment
advisers
,
according
to
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
filings
.
<END>
<START>
But
wait
a
second
.
<END>
<START>
Westridge
Capital
is
an
index
fund
--
the
type
of
stolid
long-term
investor
whose
goal
is
to
be
nothing
more
than
average
.
<END>
<START>
Westridge
Capital
's
frenetic
trading
reflects
the
changes
sweeping
through
the
previously
sleepy
world
of
indexing
.
<END>
<START>
Institutional
investors
have
poured
$
210
billion
into
stock
and
bond
indexing
as
a
cheap
and
easy
form
of
investment
management
that
promises
to
post
average
market
returns
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
fees
investors
pay
for
indexing
run
a
few
pennies
for
each
$
100
of
assets
--
a
fraction
of
the
cost
of
active
managers
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
because
computers
do
most
of
the
work
,
and
low
trading
activity
keeps
a
lid
on
commission
costs
.
<END>
<START>
But
today
,
indexing
is
moving
from
a
passive
investment
strategy
to
an
increasingly
active
one
.
<END>
<START>
``
Now
the
interest
is
in
what
else
can
I
do
with
that
money
.
''
<END>
<START>
Among
the
souped-up
indexing
strategies
:
Indexed
portfolios
can
be
built
around
thousands
of
stocks
,
or
just
a
few
dozen
,
rather
than
being
restricted
to
the
S&P
500
companies
.
<END>
<START>
With
today
's
computer-driven
program
trading
techniques
,
index
funds
can
trade
back
and
forth
between
stock-index
futures
and
the
actual
stocks
making
up
indexes
such
as
the
S&P
500
.
<END>
<START>
One
reason
for
these
hybrids
is
that
indexing
's
rapid
growth
is
slowing
,
particularly
for
those
``
plain
vanilla
''
funds
that
mirror
the
S&P
500
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
After
tripling
in
size
in
the
past
five
years
,
index
funds
now
hold
about
20
%
of
the
stock
owned
by
pension
funds
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
A
further
problem
is
razor-thin
profits
.
<END>
<START>
Plain-vanilla
funds
have
become
so
commonplace
that
fees
they
can
charge
have
plunged
to
almost
nothing
,
and
in
some
cases
are
just
that
.
<END>
<START>
To
land
customers
for
their
well-paying
stock
custodial
business
,
big
banks
sometimes
will
throw
in
basic
indexing
services
for
free
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
like
getting
a
free
toaster
when
you
open
an
account
,
''
says
Axe
Core
's
Mr.
Lynn
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
indexers
have
been
looking
for
ways
to
give
investors
something
more
than
the
average
for
their
money
.
<END>
<START>
And
many
have
been
successful
,
as
in
the
case
of
the
index
fund
operated
by
hyper-trader
Westridge
Capital
.
<END>
<START>
Strategies
vary
for
Westridge
Capital
,
which
has
$
300
million
under
management
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Carder
also
goes
through
periods
when
he
buys
stocks
in
conjunction
with
options
to
boost
returns
and
protect
against
declines
.
<END>
<START>
And
in
some
months
,
he
buys
stock-index
futures
and
not
stocks
at
all
.
<END>
<START>
``
By
their
nature
,
our
trades
are
very
short-term
and
are
going
to
create
high
turnover
,
''
Mr.
Carder
adds
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
more
turnover
,
the
better
for
our
clients
.
''
<END>
<START>
Big
indexer
Bankers
Trust
Co.
also
uses
futures
in
a
strategy
that
on
average
has
added
one
percentage
point
to
its
enhanced
fund
's
returns
.
<END>
<START>
J.
Thomas
Allen
,
president
of
Pittsburgh-based
Advanced
Investment
Management
Inc.
,
agrees
it
's
a
good
idea
to
jump
between
the
S&P
500
stocks
and
futures
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
're
buying
the
S&P
,
and
you
always
want
to
hold
the
cheapest
form
of
it
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
But
some
indexers
make
little
or
no
use
of
futures
,
saying
that
these
instruments
present
added
risks
for
investors
.
<END>
<START>
Prudential
currently
is
seeking
approval
to
offer
a
new
fund
offering
a
return
equal
to
the
S&P
500
index
plus
5/100
of
a
percentage
point
.
<END>
<START>
An
added
feature
is
that
the
slighty
improved
return
would
be
guaranteed
by
Prudential
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
many
other
strategies
to
bolster
the
returns
of
index
funds
.
<END>
<START>
They
include
:
<END>
<START>
LIMITED
RISK
FUNDS
:
<END>
<START>
These
guarantee
protection
against
stock
market
declines
while
still
passing
along
most
gains
.
<END>
<START>
Here
a
fund
may
promise
to
pay
back
,
say
,
$
95
of
every
$
100
invested
for
a
year
,
even
if
the
market
goes
much
lower
.
<END>
<START>
The
fund
could
invest
$
87
for
one
year
in
Treasury
bills
yielding
8
%
to
return
the
guaranteed
$
95
.
<END>
<START>
That
leaves
$
13
,
which
could
be
used
to
buy
S&P
500
options
that
will
nearly
match
any
gain
in
the
S&P
index
.
<END>
<START>
MANAGER
REPLICATION
FUNDS
:
<END>
<START>
Say
a
big
investor
is
interested
in
growth
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
see
a
lot
of
interest
in
those
kind
of
things
,
''
says
Frank
Salerno
,
a
vice
president
of
Bankers
Trust
.
<END>
<START>
``
People
comfortable
with
the
passive
approach
are
using
them
for
other
strategies
.
''
<END>
<START>
TILT
FUNDS
:
<END>
<START>
This
is
an
index
fund
with
a
bet
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
of
replicating
the
S&P
500
or
some
other
index
exactly
,
some
stocks
are
overweighted
or
underweighted
in
the
portfolio
.
<END>
<START>
One
simple
approach
is
to
exclude
S&P
500
companies
considered
bankruptcy
candidates
;
this
can
avoid
weak
sisters
,
but
also
can
hurt
when
a
company
like
Chrysler
Corp.
rebounds
.
<END>
<START>
SPECIALIZED
FUNDS
:
<END>
<START>
Indexes
can
be
constructed
to
serve
social
goals
,
such
as
eliminating
the
stocks
of
companies
doing
business
in
South
Africa
.
<END>
<START>
Other
funds
have
been
designed
to
concentrate
on
stocks
in
a
geographic
area
in
order
to
encourage
local
investment
.
<END>
<START>
The
Big
Board
reported
that
short
interest
dropped
to
523,920,214
shares
as
of
Oct.
13
from
547,347,585
shares
in
mid-September
.
<END>
<START>
Amex
short
interest
climbed
3
%
to
53,496,665
shares
from
51,911,566
shares
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
year-earlier
month
,
the
Big
Board
reported
461,539,056
shares
,
indicating
a
13.5
%
year-to-year
rise
,
while
the
Amex
reported
36,015,194
shares
,
a
48
%
leap
.
<END>
<START>
Amex
short
interest
has
been
heading
upward
since
mid-December
,
with
increases
in
each
month
since
then
except
at
mid-July
.
<END>
<START>
Short
interest
is
the
number
of
shares
that
have
n't
yet
been
purchased
for
return
to
lenders
.
<END>
<START>
Fluctuation
in
short
interest
of
certain
stocks
also
may
be
caused
partly
by
arbitraging
.
<END>
<START>
The
figures
occasionally
include
incomplete
transactions
in
restricted
stock
.
<END>
<START>
The
level
of
negative
sentiment
measured
by
the
Big
Board
short
interest
ratio
slipped
to
3.36
from
last
month
's
3.38
.
<END>
<START>
The
ratio
is
the
number
of
trading
days
,
at
the
exchange
's
average
trading
volume
,
that
would
be
required
to
convert
the
total
short
interest
position
.
<END>
<START>
Some
analysts
suggest
,
however
,
that
the
ratio
has
weakened
in
value
as
an
indicator
because
options
and
other
products
can
be
used
to
hedge
short
positions
.
<END>
<START>
Varity
Corp.
led
the
Big
Board
list
of
largest
short
volumes
with
12,822,563
shares
.
<END>
<START>
Varity
has
proposed
to
acquire
K-H
Corp.
,
consisting
of
the
auto
parts
division
and
some
debt
of
Fruehauf
Corp.
,
for
$
577.3
million
of

and

.

Waste

,

3,383,477

.
<END>
<START>
Bristol-Myers

.

.

.

.

.

.

Bolar

.

.

The

.

First

.

Nelson
Holdings
International
Ltd.
dropped
the
most
on

basis
,
to
1,000
shares
from

.
<END>
<START>
You
are
absolutely
wrong
,
however
,
in
opining
that
this
position
is
some
kind
of
``
flip-flop
,
''
something
newly
arrived
at
as
a
result
of
reading
the
opinion
polls
.
<END>
<START>
My
position
is
one
founded
on
both
the
facts
and
the
law
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
during
those
hearings
that
the
nation
first
learned
the
breadth
and
depth
of
Gen.
Noriega
's
criminality
,
and
of
his
enduring
relationships
with
a
variety
of
U.S.
government
agencies
.
<END>
<START>
As
the
report
issued
by
the
subcommittee
concluded
,
``
Our
government
did
nothing
regarding
Gen.
Noriega
's
drug
business
and
substantial
criminal
involvement
because
the
first
priority
was
the
Contra
war
.
<END>
<START>
This
decision
resulted
in
at
least
some
drugs
entering
the
United
States
as
a
hidden
cost
of
the
war
.
''
<END>
<START>
Unfortunately
,
this
problem
continued
even
after
Gen.
Noriega
's
indictment
.
<END>
<START>
Throughout
1988
and
this
year
,
I
and
others
in
Congress
have
pressed
the
U.S.
to
develop
a
plan
for
pushing
this
``
narcokleptocrat
''
out
of
Panama
.
<END>
<START>
Regrettably
,
two
administrations
in
a
row
have
been
unwilling
and
unable
to
develop
any
plan
,
military
or
economic
,
for
supporting
the
Panamanian
people
in
their
attempts
to
restore
democracy
.
<END>
<START>
Sen.
John
Kerry
-LRB-
D.
,
Mass
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
For
Vietnamese
,
these
are
tricky
,
often
treacherous
,
times
.
<END>
<START>
After
years
of
hesitation
,
economic
and
political
reform
was
embraced
at
the
end
of
1986
,
but
ringing
declarations
have
yet
to
be
translated
into
much
action
.
<END>
<START>
Vietnam
is
finding
that
turning
a
stagnant
socialist
order
into
a
dynamic
free
market
does
n't
come
easy
.
<END>
<START>
Here
is
how
three
Vietnamese
are
coping
with
change
:
<END>
<START>
The
Tire
King
<END>
<START>
Nguyen
Van
Chan
is
living
proof
that
old
ways
die
hard
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Chan
used
to
be
an
oddity
in
Hanoi
:
a
private
entrepreneur
.
<END>
<START>
His
business
success
made
him
an
official
target
in
pre-reform
days
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Chan
,
now
64
years
old
,
invented
a
fountain
pen
he
and
his
family
produced
from
plastic
waste
.
<END>
<START>
Later
,
he
marketed
glue
.
<END>
<START>
Both
products
were
immensely
popular
.
<END>
<START>
For
his
troubles
,
Mr.
Chan
was
jailed
three
times
between
1960
and
1974
.
<END>
<START>
Though
his
operation
was
registered
and
used
only
scrap
,
he
was
accused
of
conducting
illegal
business
and
possessing
illegal
materials
.
<END>
<START>
Once
he
was
held
for
three
months
without
being
charged
.
<END>
<START>
Things
were
supposed
to
change
when
Vietnam
's
economic
reforms
gathered
pace
,
and
for
awhile
they
did
.
<END>
<START>
After
years
of
experimenting
,
Mr.
Chan
produced
a
heavy-duty
bicycle
tire
that
outlasted
its
state-produced
rival
.
<END>
<START>
By
1982
,
he
was
selling
thousands
of
tires
.
<END>
<START>
Newspapers
published
articles
about
him
,
and
he
was
hailed
as
``
the
tire
king
.
''
<END>
<START>
His
efforts
earned
a
gold
medal
at
a
national
exhibition
--
and
attracted
renewed
attention
from
local
authorities
.
<END>
<START>
District
police
in
1983
descended
on
his
suburban
home
,
which
he
and
his
large
family
used
as
both
residence
and
factory
,
and
demanded
proof
the
house
and
equipment
were
his
.
<END>
<START>
He
produced
it
.
<END>
<START>
``
That
was
the
first
time
they
lost
and
I
won
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
He
was
further
questioned
to
determine
if
he
was
``
a
real
working
man
or
an
exploiter
.
''
<END>
<START>
Says
Mr.
Chan
:
``
When
I
showed
it
was
from
my
own
brain
,
they
lost
for
the
second
time
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
a
few
days
later
the
police
accused
him
of
stealing
electricity
,
acquiring
rubber
without
permission
and
buying
stolen
property
.
<END>
<START>
Warned
he
was
to
be
jailed
again
,
he
fled
to
the
countryside
.
<END>
<START>
His
family
was
given
three
hours
to
leave
before
the
house
and
contents
were
confiscated
.
<END>
<START>
With
only
the
clothes
they
were
wearing
,
family
members
moved
to
a
home
owned
by
one
of
Mr.
Chan
's
sons
.
<END>
<START>
After
six
months
on
the
run
,
Mr.
Chan
learned
the
order
for
his
arrest
had
been
canceled
.
<END>
<START>
He
rejoined
his
family
in
January
1984
and
began
the
long
struggle
for
justice
,
pressing
everyone
from
Hanoi
municipal
officials
to
National
Assembly
deputies
for
restoration
of
his
rights
.
<END>
<START>
He
and
his
family
kept
afloat
by
repairing
bicycles
,
selling
fruit
and
doing
odd
jobs
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Chan
achieved
a
breakthrough
in
1987
--
and
became
a
minor
celebrity
again
--
when
his
story
was
published
in
a
weekly
newspaper
.
<END>
<START>
In
1988
,
18
months
after
the
sixth
congress
formally
endorsed
family-run
private
enterprise
,
district
authorities
allowed
Mr.
Chan
to
resume
work
.
<END>
<START>
By
late
last
year
he
was
invited
back
as
``
the
tire
king
''
to
display
his
products
at
a
national
exhibition
.
<END>
<START>
National
leaders
stopped
by
his
stand
to
commend
his
achievements
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Chan
now
produces
1,000
bicycle
and
motorbike
tires
a
month
and
1,000
tins
of
tire-patching
glue
in
the
son
's
small
house
.
<END>
<START>
Eighteen
people
pack
the
house
's
two
rooms
--
the
Chans
,
four
of
their
10
children
with
spouses
,
and
eight
of
22
grandchildren
.
<END>
<START>
Most
sleep
on
the
floor
.
<END>
<START>
Come
daybreak
,
eight
family
members
and
two
other
workers
unroll
a
sheet
of
raw
rubber
that
covers
the
floor
of
the
house
and
spills
out
onto
the
street
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Chan
talks
optimistically
of
expanding
,
maybe
even
moving
into
the
import-export
field
.
<END>
<START>
First
,
however
,
he
has
unfinished
business
.
<END>
<START>
When
district
authorities
allowed
him
to
resume
manufacturing
,
they
released
only
one
of
his
machines
.
<END>
<START>
They
did
n't
return
the
rubber

that
represent

.
<END>
<START>
Nor

return
his
house
and
contents
,
which
he
values
at
about
$
44,000
.
<END>
<START>
He
wants
to
recover
more
than
just
his
property
,
though
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
want
my
dignity
back
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
The
Editor
<END>
<START>
Nguyen
Ngoc
seemed
an
obvious
choice
when
the
Vietnamese
Writers
Association
was
looking
for
a
new
editor
to
reform
its
weekly
newspaper
,
Van
Nghe
.
<END>
<START>
After
the
sixth
congress
,
journalists
seized
the
opportunity
provided
by
the
liberalization
to
probe
previously
taboo
subjects
.
<END>
<START>
Appointed
editor
in
chief
in
July
1987
,
Mr.
Ngoc
rapidly
turned
the
staid
Van
Nghe
into
Vietnam
's
hottest
paper
.
<END>
<START>
Circulation
soared
as
the
weekly
went
way
beyond
standard
literary
themes
to
cover
Vietnamese
society
and
its
ills
.
<END>
<START>
Readers
were
electrified
by
the
paper
's
audacity
and
appalled
by
the
dark
side
of
life
it
uncovered
.
<END>
<START>
One
article
recounted
a
decade-long
struggle
by
a
wounded
soldier
to
prove
,
officially
,
he
was
alive
.
<END>
<START>
Another
described
how
tax-collection
officials
in
Thanh
Hoa
province
one
night
stormed
through
homes
and
confiscated
rice
from
starving
villagers
.
<END>
<START>
Van
Nghe
quickly
made
influential
enemies
.
<END>
<START>
``
Those
who
manage
ideology
and
a
large
number
of
writers
reacted
badly
''
to
the
restyled
paper
,
says
Lai
Nguyen
An
,
a
literary
critic
.
<END>
<START>
After
months
of
internal
rumblings
,
Mr.
Ngoc
was
fired
last
December
.
<END>
<START>
His
dismissal
triggered
a
furor
among
intellectuals
that
continues
today
.
<END>
<START>
``
Under
Mr.
Ngoc
,
Van
Nghe
protected
the
people
instead

the
government
,
''
says
Nguyen
Duy
,
a

is

's

for
southern

.
<END>
<START>
``
The
paper
reflected
the
truth
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
leadership
,
that
was
too
painful
to
bear
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
`
Billionaire
'
<END>
<START>
Nguyen
Thi
Thi
is
Vietnam
's
entrepreneur
of
the
1980s
.
<END>
<START>
Her
challenge
is
to
keep
her
fledgling
empire
on
top
in
the
1990s
.
<END>
<START>
Mrs.
Thi
did
n't
wait
for
the
reforms
to
get
her
start
.
<END>
<START>
She
charged
ahead
of
the
government
and
the
law
to
establish
Hochiminh
City
Food
Co.
as
the
biggest
rice
dealer
in
the
country
.
<END>
<START>
Her
success
,
which
included
alleviating
an
urban
food
shortage
in
the
early
1980s
,
helped
persuade
Hanoi
to
take
the
reform
path
.
<END>
<START>
Her
story
is
becoming
part
of
local
folklore
.
<END>
<START>
A
lifelong
revolutionary
with
little
education
who
fought
both
the
French
and
the
U.S.-backed
Saigon
regime
,
she
switched
effortlessly
to
commerce
after
the
war
.
<END>
<START>
Her
instincts
were
capitalistic
,
despite
her
background
.
<END>
<START>
As
she
rode
over
regulations
,
only
her
friendship
with
party
leaders
,
including
Nguyen
Van
Linh
,
then
Ho
Chi
Minh
City
party
secretary
,
kept
her
out
of
jail
.
<END>
<START>
Following
Mr.
Linh
's
appointment
as
secretary-general
of
the
party
at
the
sixth
congress
,
Mrs.
Thi
has
become
the
darling
of
``
doi
moi
''
,
the
Vietnamese
version
of
perestroika
.
<END>
<START>
The
authorities
have
steered
foreign
reporters
to
her
office
to
see
an
example
of
``
the
new
way
of
thinking
.
''
<END>
<START>
Foreign
publications
have
responded
with
articles
declaring
her
Vietnam
's
richest
woman
.
<END>
<START>
``
Some
people
call
me
the
communist
billionaire
,
''
she
has
told
visitors
.
<END>
<START>
Actually
,
67-year-old
Mrs.
Thi
is
about
as
poor
as
almost
everyone
else
in
this
impoverished
land
.
<END>
<START>
She
has
indeed
turned
Hochiminh
City
Food
into
a
budding
conglomerate
,
but
the
company
itself
remains
state-owned
.
<END>
<START>
She
manages
it
with
the
title
of
general-director
.
<END>
<START>
Last
year
,
Hochiminh
City
Food
says
it
bought
two
million
metric
tons
of
unhusked
rice
,
more
than
10
%
of
the
country
's
output
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
operates
a
fleet
of
trucks
and
boats
to
transport
the
commodities
to
its
warehouses
.
<END>
<START>
A
subsidiary
company
processes
commodities
into
foods
such
as
instant
noodles
that
are
sold
with
the
rice
through
a
vast
retail
network
.
<END>
<START>
Mrs.
Thi
says
Hochiminh
City
Food
last
year
increased
pretax
profit
60
%
to
the
equivalent
of
about
$
2.7
million
on
sales
of
$
150
million
.
<END>
<START>
She
expects
both
revenue
and
profit
to
gain
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
She
is
almost
cavalier
about
the
possibility
Vietnam
's
reforms
will
create
rivals
on
her
home
turf
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
do
n't
mind
the
competition

,
''
she

.
<END>
<START>
``
I

only

that
with

's

products
we
ca

with

.

<START>
Thomas

.

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>

,

.

<START>

<START>

,

.

<START>
Western

.
<END>
<START>
An

''

.
''
<END>
<START>

,

8

.
<END>
<START>
Graphics
,

and

were
combined
because
,
increasingly
,

functions
are
being

by

.
<END>
<START>
Storage
,
which
includes
computer

and
3.5-inch

,
represents
nearly
two-thirds
of
the
company
's
business
.
<END>
<START>
Disk
drives
,
which
allow
a
computer
to
access
its
memory
,
generated
38
%
more
revenue
in
the
most
recent
period
compared
with
the
fiscal
first
quarter
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Computer
parts
are
getting
ever

,
Mr.
Johnson
said
,
a
shrinking
that
has
propelled
laptops
into

as
the
fastest-growing
segment
of
the
computer
business
.
<END>
<START>
As
smaller
and

continue
to

,

,
Western

is

.
<END>
<START>
The
plan
will
help
the
company
in

.
<END>
<START>
About

of

's

,

Johnson

to

.

<START>
Plans

within

creates

for

company
,

,

already

.
<END>
<START>
Capitalizing

,
Western

.
<END>
<START>
Directors

's

.

<START>

,

.

<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

<START>

.

<START>

.
<END>
<START>
Consumer
prices
rose
a
surprisingly
moderate
0.2
%
in
September
,
pushed
up
mostly
by
a
jump
in
clothing
costs
,
the
Labor
Department
reported
.
<END>
<START>
Energy
costs
,
which
drove
wholesale
prices
up
sharply
during
the
month
,
continued
to
decline
at
the
retail
level
,
pulling
down
transportation
and
helping
to
ease
housing
costs
.
<END>
<START>
The
report
was
the
brightest
news
the
financial
markets
had
seen
since
before
the
stock
market
plunged
more
than
190
points
last
Friday
.
<END>
<START>
The
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
rallied
on
the
news
,
closing
39.55
points
higher
at
2683.20
.
<END>
<START>
Bond
prices
also
jumped
as
traders
appeared
to
read
the
data
as
a
sign
that
interest
rates
may
fall
.
<END>
<START>
But
many
economists
were
not
nearly
as
jubilant
.
<END>
<START>
The
climb
in
wholesale
energy
prices
is
certain
to
push
up
retail
energy
prices
in
the
next
few
months
,
they
warned
.
<END>
<START>
They
also
said
the
dollar
is
leveling
off
after
a
rise
this
summer
that
helped
to
reduce
the
prices
of
imported
goods
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
think
inflation
is
going
to
pick
up
through
the
fall
,
''
said
Joel
Popkin
,
a
specialist
on
inflation
who
runs
an
economic
consulting
firm
here
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
has
been
in
what
I
would
describe
as
a
lull
for
the
past
several
months
.
''
<END>
<START>
Because
wholesale
energy
prices
shot
up
by
a
steep
6.5
%
last
month
,
many
analysts
expected
energy
prices
to
rise
at
the
consumer
level
too
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
many
economists
were
expecting
the
consumer
price
index
to
increase
significantly
more
than
it
did
.
<END>
<START>
But
retail
energy
prices
declined
0.9
%
in
September
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
some
analysts
insisted
that
the
worst
of
the
inflation
is
behind
.
<END>
<START>
In
both
1987
and
1988
,
consumer
prices
rose
4.4
%
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Yardeni
predicted
that
world
business
competition
will
continue
to
restrain
prices
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
bottom
line
is
,
it
seems
to
me
that
the
economic
environment
has
become
very
,
very
competitve
for
a
lot
of
businesses
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
Back
in
1987-88
,
business
was
operating
at
fairly
tight
capacity
,
so
businesses
felt
they
could
raise
prices
.
''
<END>
<START>
Now
,
he
said
,
a
slowdown
in
economic
activity
has
slackened
demand
.
<END>
<START>
The
mild
inflation
figures
renewed
investors
'
hopes
that
the
Federal
Reserve
will
ease
its
interest-rate
stance
.
<END>
<START>
The
steep
climb
in
producer
prices
reported
last
Friday
fostered
pessimism
about
lower
interest
rates
and
contributed
to
the
stock
market
's
6.9
%
plunge
that
day
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
past
several
days
,
however
,
the
U.S.
's
central
bank
has
allowed
a
key
interest
rate
to
fall
slightly
to
try
to
stabilize
the
markets
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
say
Fed
policy
makers
have
been
wary
of
relaxing
credit
too
much
because
they
were
still
uncertain
about
the
level
of
inflation
in
the
economy
.
<END>
<START>
Excluding
the
volatile
categories
of
energy
and
food
--
leaving
what
some
economists
call
the
core
inflation
rate
--
consumer
prices
still
rose
only
0.2
%
in
September
.
<END>
<START>
Transportation
costs
actually
fell
0.5
%
,
and
housing
costs
gained
only
0.1
%
.
<END>
<START>
Apparel
prices
rocketed
up
1.7
%
,
but
that
was
after
three
months
of
declines
.
<END>
<START>
Medical
costs
continued
their
steep
ascent
,
rising
0.8
%
after
four
consecutive
months
of
0.7
%
increases
.
<END>
<START>
Car
prices
,
another
area
that
contributed
to
the
steep
rise
in
the
wholesale
index
last
month
,
still
showed
declines
at
the
consumer
level
.
<END>
<START>
They
dropped
0.4
%
as
dealers
continued
to
offer
rebates
to
attract
customers
.
<END>
<START>
Food
prices
rose
0.2
%
for
the
second
month
in
a
row
,
far
slower
than
the
monthly
rises
earlier
in
the
year
.
<END>
<START>
Separately
,
the
Labor
Department
reported
that
average
weekly
earnings
rose
0.3
%
in
September
,
after
adjusting
for
inflation
,
following
a
0.7
%
decline
in
August
.
<END>
<START>
All
the
numbers
are
adjusted
for
seasonal
fluctuations
.
<END>
<START>
Here
are
the
seasonally
adjusted
changes
in
the
components
of
the
Labor
Department
's
consumer
price
index
for
September
.
<END>
<START>
After
watching
interest
in
the
sport
plummet
for
years
,
the
ski
industry
is
trying
to
give
itself
a
lift
.
<END>
<START>
Across
the
country
,
resorts
are
using
everything
from
fireworks
to
classical-music
concerts
to
attract
new
customers
.
<END>
<START>
Some
have
built
health
spas
,
business
centers
and
shopping
villages
so
visitors
have
more
to
do
than
ski
.
<END>
<START>
And
this
week
,
the
industry
's
efforts
will
go
national
for
the
first
time
when
it
unveils
a
$
7
million
advertising
campaign
.
<END>
<START>
Such
efforts
--
unheard
of
only
a
few
years
ago
--
are
the
latest
attempts
to
revive
the
sagging
$
1.76
billion
U.S.
ski
industry
.
<END>
<START>
Since
the
start
of
the
decade
,
lift-ticket
sales
have
grown
only
3
%
a
year
on
average
,
compared
with
16
%
annual
growth
rates
in
the
'60s
and
'70s
.
<END>
<START>
Last
season
,
lift-ticket
sales
fell
for
the
first
time
in
seven
years
.
<END>
<START>
By
some
estimates
,
nearly
a
fourth
of
all
U.S.
ski
areas
have
been
forced
to
shut
down
since
the
early
'80s
.
<END>
<START>
Competition
and
mounting
insurance
and
equipment
costs
have
been
the
undoing
of
many
resorts
.
<END>
<START>
But
another
big
problem
has
been
the
aging
of
baby
boomers
.
<END>
<START>
Skiing
,
after
all
,
has
mainly
been
for
the
young
and
daring
and
many
baby
boomers
have
outgrown
skiing
or
have
too
many
family
responsibilities
to
stick
with
the
sport
.
<END>
<START>
One
60-second
TV
spot
features
a
diverse
group
of
skiers
gracefully
gliding
down
sun-drenched
slopes
:
senior
citizens
,
minorities
,
families
with
children
--
even
a
blind
skier
.
<END>
<START>
``
Ski
school
is
great
,
''
cries
out
a
tot
,
bundled
in
a
snowsuit
as
he
plows
down
a
bunny
slope
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
'll
never
know
'til
you
try
,
''
says
a
black
skier
.
<END>
<START>
Ski
promotions
have
traditionally
avoided
the
touchy

of
safety
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
new
commercials
deal
with
it
indirectly
by
showing
a
woman
smiling
as
she
tries
to
get
up
from
a
fall
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
wanted
to
show
it
's
okay
if
you
fall
,
''
says
Ms.
Dillmann
.
<END>
<START>
``
Most
people
think
if
you
slip
,
you
'll
wind
up
in
a
body
cast
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
ad
campaign
represents
an
unusual
spirit
of
cooperation
among
resorts
and
ski
equipment
makers
;
normally
,
they
only
run
ads
hyping
their
own
products
and
facilities
.
<END>
<START>
Many
resorts
also
are
focusing
more
on
the
service
side
of
their
business
.
<END>
<START>
Since
40
%
of
skiers
are
parents
,
many
slopes
are
building
nurseries
,
expanding
ski
schools
and
adding
entertainment
for
kids
.
<END>
<START>
Vail
,
Colo.
,
now
has
a
playland
that
looks
like
an
old
mining
town
;
kids
can
ski
through
and
pan
for
fool
's
gold
.
<END>
<START>
For
$
15
,
they
can
enjoy
their
own
nightly
entertainment
,
with
dinner
,
without
mom
and
dad
.
<END>
<START>
A
few
years
ago
,
parents
usually
had
to
hire
a
sitter
or
take
turns
skiing
while
one
spouse
stayed
with
the
children
.
<END>
<START>
To
make
skiing
more
convenient
for
time-strapped
visitors
,
several
resorts
are
buying
or
starting
their
own
travel
agencies
.
<END>
<START>
In
one
phone
call
,
ski
buffs
can
make
hotel
and
restaurant
reservations
,
buy
lift
tickets
,
rent
ski
equipment
and
sign
up
for
lessons
.
<END>
<START>
And
resorts
are
adding
other
amenities
,
such
as
pricey
restaurants
,
health
spas
and
vacation
packages
with
a
twist
.
<END>
<START>
During
Winter
Carnival
week
,
for
example
,
visitors
at
Sunday
River
in
Maine
can
take
a
hot-air
balloon
ride
.
<END>
<START>
The
ski
industry
hopes
to
increase
the
number
of
skiers
by
3.5
million
to
about
21.7
million
in
the
next
five
years
with
its
latest
ads
and
promotions
.
<END>
<START>
But
some
think
that
's
being

optimistic
.
<END>
<START>
And
most

still
prefer
a
warm
climate
for
their
winter

.
<END>
<START>
``
Most
people
will
come
on
the
weekend
,

slopes
will
be
overcrowded
and
then
these
-LCB-
new
skiers
-RCB-
wo
n't
come
back
.
<END>
<START>
They
did
n't
play
the
third
game
of
the
World
Series
on
Tuesday
night
as

,
and
they
did

.

<START>

<START>
Inland
Steel
Industries
Inc.
,
battered
by
lower

and

,

75

in

.
<END>
<START>

fell
to
$
981.2
million
from
$
1.02

.
<END>
<START>

also
mark
a
significant
drop
from

's
$
45.3
million
or
$
1.25
a

.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
the
earnings
were
well
below
analysts
'
expectations
of
about
$
1.16
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
In
composite
trading
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
,
Inland
closed
yesterday
at
$
35.875
a
share
,
down
$
1
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
attributed
the
earnings
drop
to
lower
volume
related
to

demand
and
the
soft
consumer
durable
market
,
especially
in
the

.
<END>
<START>
However
,
the
company
also
lost

because

in

.
<END>
<START>

slipped
7
%
from
the
year-ago
period
,
and
17
%
from
this
year
's

quarter
.
<END>
<START>

noted
that
the

results
do
n't

for

products
.
<END>
<START>
Charles
Bradford
,
an

with

Lynch
Capital
Markets
,
said
higher
prices
for
galvanized
and

for
bar
,

.
<END>
<START>

,

primarily
serves
the

market
,
was

hurt
by
a
15
%
price
drop
,

said
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
its
integrated
steel
sector
was
also

by
higher
raw

,

and

,
and

costs
.
<END>
<START>
The
increased
labor
costs
became
effective
Aug.
1
under
terms
of
the
four-year
labor
agreement
with
the
United
Steelworkers
union
.
<END>
<START>
Inland
Chairman
Frank
W.
Luerssen
said
the
company
's
short-term
outlook
is
``
clouded
by
uncertainties
in

and

.
''
<END>
<START>

,

are
up
from
early
summer

,
and
that
