expects
the
company
to
improve
its
cost
performance
in
the
fourth
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
The
``
seismic
''
activity
of
a
financial
market
bears
a
resemblance
to
the
seismic
activity
of
the
earth
.
<END>
<START>
When
things
are
quiet
-LRB-
low
volatility
-RRB-
,
the
structures
on
which
markets
stand
can
be
relatively
inefficient
and
still
perform
their
functions
adequately
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
when
powerful
forces
start
shaking
the
market
's
structure
,
the
more
``
earthquake-resistant
''
it
is
,
the
better
its
chance
for
survival
.
<END>
<START>
America
's
financial
markets
do
not
yet
have
all
the
required
modern
features
required
to
make
them
fully
``
aftershock-resistant
.
''
<END>
<START>
Investors
lack
equal
access
to
the
markets
'
trading
arena
and
its
information
.
<END>
<START>
That
structural
lack
is
crucial
because
investors
are
the
only
source
of
market
liquidity
.
<END>
<START>
And
liquidity
is
what
markets
need
to
damp
quakes
and
aftershocks
.
<END>
<START>
When
they
halt
trading
,
all
market
liquidity
is
gone
.
<END>
<START>
Last
Friday
the
13th
-LRB-
as
well
as
two
years
ago
this
week
-RRB-
the
markets
became
unlinked
.
<END>
<START>
When
that
happened
,
``
seismic
''
tremors
of
fear
--
much
like
the
shock
waves
created
by
an
earthquake
--
coursed
through
the
market
and
increased
the
market
's
volatility
.
<END>
<START>
Lack
of
important
,
needed
information
can
cause
fear
.
<END>
<START>
Fear
is
the
father
of
panic
.
<END>
<START>
Panic
frequently
results
in
irrational
behavior
.
<END>
<START>
And
in
financial
markets
,
irrational
behavior
is
sometimes
translated
into
catastrophe
.
<END>
<START>
Contrary
to
some
opinions
,
the
trading
activities
of
specialists
and
other
market
makers
do
not
provide
liquidity
to
the
market
as
a
whole
.
<END>
<START>
What
market
makers
provide
is
immediacy
,
a
very
valuable
service
.
<END>
<START>
Liquidity
is
not
a
service
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
a
market
attribute
--
the
ability
to
absorb
selling
orders
without
causing
significant
price
changes
in
the
absence
of
news
.
<END>
<START>
Market
makers
buy
what
investors
wish
to
sell
;
their
business
is
reselling
these
unwanted
positions
as
quickly
as
possible
to
other
investors
,
and
at
a
profit
.
<END>
<START>
Current
quotations
would
reflect
the
combined
financial
judgment
of
all
market
participants
--
not
just
those
of
intermediaries
who
become
extremely
risk-averse
during
times
of
crisis
.
<END>
<START>
Last
Friday
's
market
gyrations
did
not
result
in
severe
``
aftershocks
.
''
<END>
<START>
Were
we
smart
or
just
lucky
?
<END>
<START>
I
'm
not
certain
.
<END>
<START>
But
I
am
sure
we
need
to
maximize
our
``
earthquake
''
protection
by
making
certain
that
our
market
structures
let
investors
add
their
mighty
shock-damping
power
to
our
nation
's
markets
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Peake
is
chairman
of
his
own
consulting
company
in
Englewood
,
N.J
.
<END>
<START>
NOW
YOU
SEE
IT
,
now
you
do
n't
.
<END>
<START>
The
recession
,
that
is
.
<END>
<START>
The
economy
's
stutter
steps
leave
investors
wondering
whether
things
are
slowing
down
or
speeding
up
.
<END>
<START>
So
often
are
government
statistics
revised
that
they
seem
to
resemble
a
spinning
weather
vane
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
past
seven
years
,
investors
have
had
the
wind
at
their
backs
,
in
the
form
of
a
generally
growing
economy
.
<END>
<START>
Some
may
have
forgotten
--
and
some
younger
ones
may
never
have
experienced
--
what
it
's
like
to
invest
during
a
recession
.
<END>
<START>
Different
tactics
are
called
for
,
as
losing
money
becomes
easier
and
making
money
becomes
tougher
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
nutshell
,
pros
advise
investors
who
expect
a
slowdown
to
hold
fewer
stocks
than
usual
and
to
favor
shares
of
big
companies
in
``
defensive
''
industries
.
<END>
<START>
A
heavy
dose
of
cash
is
prescribed
,
along
with
a
heavier-than-usual
allotment
to
bonds
--
preferably
government
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
tempting
to
think
these
defensive
steps
can
be
delayed
until
a
recession
is
clearly
at
hand
.
<END>
<START>
But
that
may
not
be
possible
,
because
recessions
often
take
investors
by
surprise
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
always
seem
to
come
a
bit
later
than
you
expect
.
<END>
<START>
When
they
do
hit
,
they
hit
fast
,
''
says
David
A.
Wyss
,
chief
financial
economist
at
the
Data
Resources
division
of
McGraw-Hill
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
The
reason
is
simple
,
Mr.
Wyss
says
:
``
Interest
rates
almost
always
decline
during
recession
.
''
<END>
<START>
As
surely
as
a
seesaw
tilts
,
falling
interest
rates
force
up
the
price
of
previously
issued
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
They
are
worth
more
because
they
pay
higher
interest
than
newly
issued
bonds
do
.
<END>
<START>
That
effect
holds
true
for
both
short-term
and
long-term
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
But
short-term
bonds
ca
n't
rise
too
much
,
because
everyone
knows
they
will
be
redeemed
at
a
preset
price
fairly
soon
.
<END>
<START>
Long-term
bonds
,
with
many
years
left
before
maturity
,
swing
more
widely
in
price
.
<END>
<START>
But
not
just
any
bonds
will
do
.
<END>
<START>
Corporate
bonds
``
are
usually
not
a
good
bet
in
a
recession
,
''
Mr.
Wyss
says
.
<END>
<START>
As
times
get
tougher
,
investors
fret
about
whether
companies
will
have
enough
money
to
pay
their
debts
.
<END>
<START>
This
hurts
the
price
of
corporate
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
Also
,
he
notes
,
``
most
corporate
bonds
are
callable
.
''
<END>
<START>
When
interest
rates
have
dropped
,
it
makes
sense
for
corporations
to
do
just
that
;
they
then
save
on
interest
costs
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
investors
are
left
stranded
with
money
to
reinvest
at
a
time
when
interest
rates
are
puny
.
<END>
<START>
If
corporate
bonds
are
bad
in
recessions
,
junk
bonds
are
likely
to
be
the
worst
of
all
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
an
``
absolute
necessity
''
to
get
out
of
junk
bonds
when
a
recession
is
in
the
offing
,
says
Avner
Arbel
,
professor
of
finance
at
Cornell
University
.
<END>
<START>
``
Such
bonds
are
very
sensitive
to
the
downside
,
and
this
could
be
a
disaster
.
''
<END>
<START>
Municipal
bonds
are
generally
a
bit
safer
than
corporate
bonds
in
a
recession
,
but
not
as
safe
as
bonds
issued
by
the
federal
government
.
<END>
<START>
During
an
economic
slump
,
local
tax
revenues
often
go
down
,
raising
the
risks
associated
with
at
least
some
municipals
.
<END>
<START>
And
,
like
corporates
,
many
municipal
bonds
are
callable
.
<END>
<START>
But
a
few
experts
,
going
against
the
consensus
,
do
n't
think
bonds
would
help
investors
even
if
a
recession
is
in
the
offing
.
<END>
<START>
What
's
more
,
he
thinks
this
could
be
a
nastier
recession
than
usual
:
``
Once
the
downturn
comes
,
it
's
going
to
be
very
hard
to
reverse
.
''
<END>
<START>
Investors
,
he
advises
,
``
should
be
cautious
,
''
holding
fewer
stocks
than
usual
and
also
shunning
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
Because
he
sees
a
``
5
%
to
6
%
base
rate
of
inflation
in
the
economy
,
''
he
doubts
that
interest
rates
will
fall
much
any
time
soon
.
<END>
<START>
Greg
Confair
,
president
of
Sigma
Financial
Inc.
in
Allentown
,
Pa.
,
also
recommends
that
investors
go
heavily
for
cash
.
<END>
<START>
He
is
n't
sure
a
recession
is
coming
,
but
says
the
other
likely
alternative
--
reignited
inflation
--
is
just
as
bad
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
late
in
an
expansion
,
''
the
economy
tends
to
veer
off
either
into
damaging
inflation
or
into
a
recession
,
Mr.
Confair
says
.
<END>
<START>
The
Federal
Reserve
Board
's
plan
for
a
``
soft
landing
,
''
he
says
,
requires
the
Fed
to
navigate
``
an
ever-narrowing
corridor
.
''
<END>
<START>
A
soft
landing
is
n't
something
that
can
be
achieved
once
and
for
all
,
Mr.
Confair
adds
.
<END>
<START>
It
has
to
be
engineered
over
and
over
again
,
month
after
month
.
<END>
<START>
He
believes
that
the
task
facing
Fed
Chairman
Alan
Greenspan
is
so
difficult
that
it
resembles
``
juggling
a
double-bladed
ax
and
a
buzz
saw
.
''
<END>
<START>
And
,
in
a
sense
,
that
's
the
kind
of
task
individuals
face
in
deciding
what
to
do
about
stocks
--
the
mainstay
of
most
serious
investors
'
portfolios
.
<END>
<START>
It
comes
down
to
a
question
of
whether
to
try
to
``
time
''
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
For
people
who
can
ride
out
market
waves
through
good
times
and
bad
,
stocks
have
been
rewarding
long-term
investments
.
<END>
<START>
Most
studies
show
that
buy-and-hold
investors
historically
have
earned
an
annual
return
from
stocks
of
9
%
to
10
%
,
including
both
dividends
and
price
appreciation
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
well
above
what
bonds
or
bank
certificates
have
paid
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
because
no
one
knows
for
sure
just
when
a
recession
is
coming
,
some
analysts
think
investors
should
n't
even
worry
too
much
about
timing
.
<END>
<START>
``
Trying
to
time
the
economy
is
a
mistake
,
''
says
David
Katz
,
chief
investment
officer
of
Value
Matrix
Management
Inc.
in
New
York
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Katz
notes
that
some
economists
have
been
predicting
a
recession
for
at
least
two
years
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
who
listened
,
and
lightened
up
on
stocks
,
``
have
just
hurt
themselves
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Katz
adds
that
people
who
jump
in
and
out
of
the
stock
market
need
to
be
right
about
70
%
of
the
time
to
beat
a
buy-and-hold
strategy
.
<END>
<START>
Frequent
trading
runs
up
high
commission
costs
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
in-and-outer
might
miss
the
sudden
spurts
that
account
for
much
of
the
stock
market
's
gains
over
time
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
few
investors
are
able
to
sit
tight
when
they
are
convinced
a
recession
is
coming
.
<END>
<START>
After
all
,
in
all
five
recessions
since
1960
,
stocks
declined
.
<END>
<START>
About
six
months
before
a
recession
ends
,
stocks
typically
begin
to
rise
again
,
as
investors
anticipate
a
recovery
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
recession
lasts
about
a
year
.
<END>
<START>
Unfortunately
,
though
,
recessions
vary
enough
in
length
so
that
the
average
ca
n't
reliably
be
used
to
guide
investors
in
timing
stock
sales
or
purchases
.
<END>
<START>
But
whatever
their
advice
about
timing
,
none
of
these
experts
recommend
jettisoning
stocks
entirely
during
a
recession
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
portion
of
an
investor
's
portfolio
that
stays
in
stocks
,
professionals
have
a
number
of
suggestions
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Katz
advocates
issues
with
low
price-earnings
ratios
--
that
is
,
low
prices
in
relation
to
the
company
's
earnings
per
share
.
<END>
<START>
``
Low
P-E
''
stocks
,
he
says
,
vastly
outperform
others
``
during
a
recession
or
bear
market
.
''
<END>
<START>
In
good
times
,
he
says
,
they
lag
a
bit
,
but
overall
they
provide
superior
performance
.
<END>
<START>
Prof.
Arbel
urges
investors
to
discard
stocks
in
small
companies
.
<END>
<START>
Small-company
shares
typically
fall
more
than
big-company
stocks
in
a
recession
,
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
And
in
any
case
,
he
argues
,
stocks
of
small
companies
are
``
almost
as
overpriced
as
they
were
Sept.
30
,
1987
,
just
before
the
crash
.
''
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
Mr.
Arbel
says
,
stocks
of
small
companies
are
selling
for
about
19
times
cash
flow
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Cash
flow
,
basically
earnings
plus
depreciation
,
is
one
common
gauge
of
a
company
's
financial
health
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
That
ratio
is
dangerously
close
to
the
ratio
of
19.7
that
prevailed
before
the
1987
stock-market
crash
,
Mr.
Arbel
says
.
<END>
<START>
And
it
's
way
above
the
ratio
-LRB-
7.5
times
cash
flow
-RRB-
that
bigger
companies
are
selling
for
.
<END>
<START>
Another
major
trick
in
making
a
portfolio
recession-resistant
is
choosing
stocks
in
``
defensive
''
industries
.
<END>
<START>
Food
,
tobacco
,
drugs
and
utilities
are
the
classic
examples
.
<END>
<START>
Recession
or
not
,
people
still
eat
,
smoke
,
and
take
medicine
when
they
're
sick
.
<END>
<START>
George
Putnam
III
,
editor
of
Turnaround
Letter
in
Boston
,
offers
one
final
tip
for
recession-wary
investors
.
<END>
<START>
``
Keep
some
money
available
for
opportunities
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
the
recession
does
hit
,
there
will
be
some
great
investment
opportunities
just
when
things
seem
the
blackest
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Dorfman
covers
investing
issues
from
The
Wall
Street
Journal
's
New
York
bureau
.
<END>
<START>
Some
industry
groups
consistently
weather
the
storm
better
than
others
.
<END>
<START>
The
following
shows
the
number
of
times
these
industries
outperformed
the
Standard
&
Poor
's
500-Stock
Index
during
the
first
six
months
of
the
past
seven
recessions
.
<END>
<START>
Bond
prices
posted
strong
gains
as
investors
went
on
a
bargain
hunt
.
<END>
<START>
But
while
the
overall
market
improved
,
the
new-issue
junk-bond
market
continued
to
count
casualties
,
even
as
junk-bond
prices
rose
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
,
Prudential-Bache
Securities
Inc.
said
it
postponed
a
$
220
million
senior
subordinated
debenture
offering
by
York
International
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
The
issue
by
Chicago
&
North
Western
is
one
of
the
so-called
good
junk-bond
offerings
on
the
new-issue
calendar
.
<END>
<START>
Since
last
week
's
junk-bond
market
debacle
,
many
new
issues
of
high-yield
,
high-risk
corporate
bonds
have
either
been
scaled
back
,
delayed
or
dropped
.
<END>
<START>
On
Wednesday
,
Drexel
Burnham
Lambert
Inc.
had
to
slash
the
size
of
Continental
Airlines
'
junk-bond
offering
to
$
71
million
from
$
150
million
.
<END>
<START>
Salomon
Brothers
Inc.
has
delayed
Grand
Union
Co.
's
$
1.16
billion
junk-bond
offering
while
it
restructures
the
transaction
.
<END>
<START>
Last
week
,
the
Grand
Union
offering
was
sweetened
to
include
warrants
that
allow
bondholders
to
acquire
common
stock
.
<END>
<START>
Prudential-Bache
said
the
York
issue
was
delayed
because
of
market
conditions
.
<END>
<START>
Portfolio
managers
say
sweeteners
like
equity
kickers
and
stricter
protective
covenants
may
increasingly
be
required
to
sell
junk-bond
deals
.
<END>
<START>
If
you
're
going
to
take
the
risk
in
this
market
,
you
want
something
extra
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Baldwin
likes
the
offering
.
<END>
<START>
While
they
consider
the
Chicago
&
North
Western
issue
to
be
good
,
they
do
n't
view
it
as
the
best
.
<END>
<START>
The
bonds
are
expected
to
have
a
14
1/2
%
coupon
rate
.
<END>
<START>
The
equity
arrangement
apparently
would
allow
bondholders
to
buy
a
total
of
10
%
of
the
stock
of
CNW
Corp.
,
Chicago
&
North
Western
's
parent
company
.
<END>
<START>
Donaldson
Lufkin
declined
to
comment
on
the
restructuring
.
<END>
<START>
That
would
leave
the
Blackstone
fund
with
a
60
%
stake
and
Donaldson
Lufkin
with
15
%
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
the
problems
with
new
issues
,
high-yield
bonds
showed
gains
in
the
secondary
,
or
resell
,
market
.
<END>
<START>
Junk
bonds
ended
about
one-half
point
higher
with
so-called
high-quality
issues
from
RJR
Capital
Holdings
Corp.
and
Petrolane
Gas
Service
Limited
Partnership
rising
one
point
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
Treasury
market
,
the
benchmark
30-year
bond
rose
seven-eighths
point
,
or
$
8.75
for
each
$
1,000
face
amount
.
<END>
<START>
The
gain
reflects
fresh
economic
evidence
that
inflation
is
moderating
while
the
economy
slows
.
<END>
<START>
That
raised
hopes
that
interest
rates
will
continue
to
move
lower
.
<END>
<START>
The
Labor
Department
reported
that
consumer
prices
rose
just
0.2
%
last
month
,
slightly
lower
than
some
economists
had
expected
.
<END>
<START>
But
there
were
also
rumors
yesterday
that
several
Japanese
institutional
investors
were
shifting
their
portfolios
and
buying
long-term
bonds
while
selling
shorter-term
Treasurys
.
<END>
<START>
Short-term
Treasury
securities
ended
narrowly
mixed
,
with
two-year
notes
posting
slight
declines
while
three-year
notes
were
slightly
higher
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
,
the
Fed
executed
four-day
matched
sales
,
a
technical
trading
operation
designed
to
drain
reserves
from
the
banking
system
.
<END>
<START>
The
closely
watched
funds
rate
is
what
banks
charge
each
other
on
overnight
loans
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
considered
an
early
signal
of
Fed
credit
policy
changes
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
fact
that
they
did
four-day
matched
sales
means
they
are
not
in
a
mood
to
ease
aggressively
.
<END>
<START>
They
are
telling
us
that
-LCB-
8
3/4
%
-RCB-
is
as
low
as
they
want
to
see
the
fed
funds
rate
,
''
said
Robert
Chandross
at
Lloyds
Bank
PLC
.
<END>
<START>
Treasury
Securities
<END>
<START>
The
benchmark
30-year
bond
was
quoted
late
at
a
price
of
101
25/32
to
yield
7.955
%
,
compared
with
100
29/32
to
yield
8.032
%
Wednesday
.
<END>
<START>
The
latest
10-year
notes
were
quoted
late
at
100
9/32
to
yield
7.937
%
,
compared
with
99
26/32
to
yield
8.007
%
.
<END>
<START>
Short-term
rates
rose
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
The
discount
rate
on
three-month
Treasury
bills
rose
to
7.56
%
from
7.51
%
Wednesday
,
while
the
rate
on
six-month
bills
rose
to
7.57
%
from
7.53
%
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
the
Treasury
sold
$
9.75
billion
of
52-week
bills
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
yield
on
the
bills
was
7.35
%
,
down
from
7.61
%
at
the
previous
52-week
bill
auction
Sept.
21
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
's
yield
was
the
lowest
since
7.22
%
on
July
27
.
<END>
<START>
Here
are
details
of
the
auction
:
<END>
<START>
Rates
are
determined
by
the
difference
between
the
purchase
price
and
face
value
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
,
higher
bidding
narrows
the
investor
's
return
while
lower
bidding
widens
it
.
<END>
<START>
The
percentage
rates
are
calculated
on
a
360-day
year
,
while
the
coupon-equivalent
yield
is
based
on
a
365-day
year
.
<END>
<START>
Corporate
Issues
<END>
<START>

.

<START>
THE
PANHANDLER
approaches
,
makes
his
pitch
.
<END>
<START>
No
?
<END>
<START>
Well
,
how
about
a
loan
,
he
'll
take
your
name
and
address
...
<END>
<START>
Figuring
that
their
money
would
more
likely
go
toward
a
bottle
of
Night
Train
Express
,
most
people
have
little
trouble
saying
no
to
propositions
like
this
.
<END>
<START>
But
healthy
skepticism
vanishes
when
they
are
solicited
by
an
organized
charity
to
help
fight
cancer
,
famine
,
child
abuse
,
or
what
have
you
.
<END>
<START>
Most
see
little
reason
to
doubt
that
their
cash
will
go
toward
these
noble
goals
.
<END>
<START>
But
will
it
?
<END>
<START>
In
a
distressing
number
of
cases
,
no
.
<END>
<START>
In
fact
,
the
donors
sometimes
might
be
better
off
giving
the
money
to
the
panhandler
:
at
least
he
has
no
overhead
,
and
he
might
even
be
telling
the
truth
.
<END>
<START>
Last
year
,
more
than
$
100
billion
was
donated
to
the
nation
's
400,000
charities
.
<END>
<START>
In
many
cases
the
costs
claimed
were
so
high
that
only
a
dribble
of
cash
was
left
for
the
purported
beneficiaries
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
impossible
to
say
exactly
how
much
of
the
total
charity
intake
is
devoured
by
stratospheric
fund-raising
costs
,
high-living
operators
,
and
downright
fraud
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
problem
clearly
is
widespread
and
persistent
.
<END>
<START>
State
law
enforcers
can
barely
keep
up
with
charity
scams
,
and
reports
from
watchdog
groups
such
as
the
Council
of
Better
Business
Bureaus
are
not
encouraging
.
<END>
<START>
The
Service
figures
at
least
half
of
the
money
taken
in
should
be
spent
on
program
.
<END>
<START>
Roughly
a
third
of
the
charities
reviewed
flunk
the
test
.
<END>
<START>
Which
,
it
should
be
added
,
does
n't
prevent
the
charities
from
raking
in
a
lot
of
money
anyway
.
<END>
<START>
Without
a
microscope
and
a
subpoena
,
it
's
often
hard
to
sort
out
worthwhile
causes
from
ripoffs
if
all
you
've
got
to
go
on
is
the
solicitation
itself
.
<END>
<START>
``
A
lot
of
donors
just
get
taken
.
''
<END>
<START>
Including
those
,
he
contends
,
who
put
about
$
1
million
into
the
kitty
for
the
Connecticut
Association
of
Concerned
Veterans
and
the
Vietnam
Veterans
Service
Center
.
<END>
<START>
The
telephone
number
for
the
charity
in
Shelton
,
Conn.
,
has
been
disconnected
,
and
the
former
officials
could
n't
be
located
.
<END>
<START>
Running
a
charity
does
cost
money
,
but
reputable
organizations
manage
to
get
the
lion
's
share
of
donations
out
to
where
they
are
really
needed
.
<END>
<START>
The
Arthritis
Foundation
,
the
American
Cancer
Society
and
the
United
Way
of
America
all
say
that
they
spend
roughly
90
%
of
their
income
on
programs
,
not
overhead
.
<END>
<START>
With
some
other
charities
,
however
,
it
s
the
other
way
around
.
<END>
<START>
The
fledgling
National
Children
's
Cancer
Society
,
for
example
,
took
in
$
2.5
million
last
year
to
finance
bone-marrow
transplants
for
children
.
<END>
<START>
By
the
time
it
paid
its
expenses
it
only
had
$
120,000
left
--
not
enough
to
treat
even
one
child
.
<END>
<START>
The
state
of
Illinois
is
suing
the
charity
for
fraud
in
Chicago
,
along
with
Telesystems
Marketing
Inc.
,
its
Houston-based
fund
raiser
.
<END>
<START>
Both
deny
wrongdoing
.
<END>
<START>
The
charity
admits
spending
a
lot
on
fund
raising
,
but
says
that
was
necessary
to
establish
a
donor
base
it
can
tap
at
much
lower
cost
in
years
to
come
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
a
state
court
judge
has
allowed
the
charity
to
go
on
soliciting
funds
.
<END>
<START>
Enforcers
ca
n't
put
charities
out
of
business
simply
because
they
spend
the
lion
's
share
of
their
income
on
fund
raising
.
<END>
<START>
It
has
ruled
that
such
laws
might
work
to
stifle
fund
raising
,
which
would
amount
to
limiting
the
charities
'
first-amendment
right
to
freedom
of
expression
.
<END>
<START>
This
puts
upon
enforcers
the
burden
of
proving
outright
fraud
or
misrepresentation
,
and
such
actions
have
been
brought
against
hundreds
of
charities
recently
.
<END>
<START>
The
attorney
general
's
office
in
Connecticut
alone
has
put
seven
of
them
out
of
business
over
the
past
couple
of
years
,
and
the
enforcement
drive
is
continuing
there
and
elsewhere
.
<END>
<START>
In
making
cases
,
the
authorities
frequently
zero
in
on
alleged
misrepresentations
made
by
the
charities
'
fund
raisers
.
<END>
<START>
Illinois
,
for
instance
,
currently
has
under
investigation
10
of
the
30
companies
drumming
up
funds
for
charities
soliciting
there
.
<END>
<START>
Enforcers
pay
special
attention
to
operators
using
sweepstakes
prizes
as
an
additional
inducement
to
give
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
total
value
of
the
prizes
was
only
$
5,000
and
most
``
winners
''
will
receive
just
10
cents
,
according

's

.
<END>
<START>
The
suit
is
still
pending
in
Illinois
state
court
.
<END>
<START>
Watson
&
Hughey
has
denied
the
allegations
in
court
;
officials
decline
to
comment
further
.
<END>
<START>
While
they
can
target
some
of
the
most
obvious
miscreants
,
enforcers
concede
that
they
are
only
scratching
the
surface
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
so
many
cunning
ploys
used
by
so
many
dubious
operators
,
they
say
,
that
it
is
probably
impossible
to
stop
them
all
.
<END>
<START>
One
maneuver
:
the
``
public
education
''
gambit
.
<END>
<START>
The
solicitation
material
indicates
that
donations
will
go
toward
a
campaign
alerting
and
informing
the
public
about
some
health

.
<END>
<START>
What

does
n't
say
is
that
the
entire
``
campaign
''
may
be
the
fund-raising
letter
itself
.
<END>
<START>
``
A
few
boilerplate
warnings
about
cancer
appear
but
that
's
only
two
inches
in
all
four
pages
.
<END>
<START>
Officials
at
the
Washington
D.C.-based
charity
did
n't
return
repeated
phone
calls
.
<END>
<START>
Many
fly-by-night
charities
ride
the
coattails
of
the
biggest
,
best-known
and
most
reputable
ones
by

.
<END>
<START>
The

are

but

.
<END>
<START>
``
We
ca
n't

many

that

in

years
using

.
<END>
<START>

.

,

,

.

,

.

.
''

<START>
Mr.
Johnson
is
a

's

.

<START>
Overhead

,

<END>
<START>

.

.

''

,

.

,

's
participation
.
<END>
<START>
UAL
declined
to
comment
on
British
Air
's
statement
.
<END>

,

.

<START>

,

's

to

.

,

.
<END>
<START>

.

.

<START>
UAL

190.125
on

923,500

in

on

.
<END>
<START>
UAL

British
Air
's

.
<END>
<START>

,
``
We

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

party
to

.
''
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,

Air
seemed
to
be
distancing
itself
from
the
troubled

early
in

effort
to

.
<END>
<START>
The
original
transaction
fell
through
on
the
same
day
British
Air
shareholders
approved
the
plan
at
a
special

after
the
British
succeeded
in

the
financing
for

contribution
.
<END>
<START>
The
carrier
also
seemed

to
place

on

.
<END>
<START>
``
The
-LCB-
buy-out
-RCB-
consortium
ceased
to
exist
because
our
American
partners
were
not
capable
of
organizing
the

,
''
a
British
Air

said
.
<END>
<START>
Most
of
the
department
's
statements
since
the
Northwest
transaction
indicated
it
planned
to

foreign

in

.

,

.

.

<START>
Italy
's
industrial
wholesale
sales
index
rose
13.2
%
in
June
from
a
year
earlier
,
the
state
statistical
institute
Istat
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
June
increase
compared
with
a
rise
of
10.5
%
in
May
from
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Domestic
wholesale
sales
rose
11.9
%
from
a
year
earlier
,
while
foreign
sales
jumped
17.3
%
,
Istat
said
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
of
capital
goods
to
foreign
and
domestic
destinations
increased
16.6
%
in
the
January-June
period
from
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
of
consumer
goods
rose
6.9
%
in
the
same
period
,
while
sales
of
intermediate
goods
were
up
13.8
%
from
a
year
ago
.
<END>
<START>
A
core
group
of
six
or
so
Democratic
senators
has
been
working
behind
the
scenes
to
develop
a
proposal
to
reduce
the
tax
on
the
gain
from
the
sale
of
assets
.
<END>
<START>
The
plan
was
complete
except
for
finishing
touches
,
and
there
was
talk
that
it
would
be
unveiled
as
early
as
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
Sen.
Mitchell
urged
them
to
desist
.
<END>
<START>
Afterward
,
leaders
of
the
dissident
Democrats
relented
,
and
said
they
would
n't
offer
their
own
proposal
as
they
had
planned
.
<END>
<START>
The
decision
is
a
setback
for
President
Bush
,
who
needs
the
support
of
Democrats
to
pass
the
tax
cut
through
the
Democratic-controlled
Senate
.
<END>
<START>
Having
a
proposal
sponsored
by
Democrats
would
have
given
the
president
an
advantage
.
<END>
<START>
Having
only
a
Republican
measure
makes
the
task
harder
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
Sen.
Bob
Packwood
-LRB-
R.
,
Ore.
-RRB-
,
the
lead
sponsor
of
the
Republican
capital-gains
amendment
,
predicted
that
the
tax
cut
would
be
enacted
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
a
clear
majority
of
senators
back
the
tax
reduction
and
that
ultimately
there
would
be
enough
senators
to
overcome
any
procedural
hurdle
the
Democratic
leadership
might
erect
.
<END>
<START>
But
Sen.
Mitchell
,
buoyed
by
his
victory
among
fellow
Democrats
,
strongly
disagreed
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Mitchell
has
been
predicting
that
the
president
's
initiative
would
fail
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
,
in
an
interview
,
he
added
that
the
Democrats
'
decision
``
increases
the
likelihood
that
a
capital-gains
tax
cut
will
not
pass
this
year
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Mitchell
's
first
victory
came
last
week
,
when
the
Senate
passed
a
deficit-reduction
bill
that
did
n't
contain
a
capital-gains
provision
.
<END>
<START>
That
vote
made
it
unlikely
that
a
capital-gains
tax
cut
would
be
included
in
the
final
bill
,
now
being
drafted
by
House
and
Senate
negotiators
.
<END>
<START>
The
House
version
of
the
bill
does
include
the
tax
cut
.
<END>
<START>
The
president
apparently
will
have
only
one
bill
to
push
,
Sen.
Packwood
's
,
and
at
least
some
of
the
dissident
Democrats
plan
to
support
it
.
<END>
<START>
The
Packwood
plan
,
as
expected
,
would
allow
individuals
to
exclude
from
income
5
%
of
the
gain
from
the
sale
of
a
capital
asset
held
for
more
than
one
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
exclusion
would
rise
five
percentage
points
for
each
year
the
asset
was
held
,
until
it
reached
a
maximum
of
35
%
after
seven
years
.
<END>
<START>
The
exclusion
would
apply
to
assets
sold
after
Oct.
1
.
<END>
<START>
As
an
alternative
,
taxpayers
could
chose
to
reduce
their
gains
by
an
inflation
index
.
<END>
<START>
For
corporations
,
the
top
tax
rate
on
the
sale
of
assets
held
for
more
than
three
years
would
be
cut
to
33
%
from
the
current
top
rate
of
34
%
.
<END>
<START>
That
rate
would
gradually
decline
to
as
little
as
29
%
for
corporate
assets
held
for
15
years
.
<END>
<START>
The
Packwood
plan
also
would
include
a
proposal
,
designed
by
Sen.
William
Roth
-LRB-
R.
,
Del.
-RRB-
,
that
would
create
new
tax
benefits
for
individual
retirement
accounts
.
<END>
<START>
Current
IRAs
could
be
rolled
over
into
the
new
IRAs
,
but
would
be
subject
to
tax
though
no
penalty
.
<END>
<START>
Westmoreland
Coal
Co.
,
realizing
benefits
of
a
sustained
effort
to
cut
costs
and
boost
productivity
,
reported
sharply
improved
third-quarter
results
.
<END>
<START>
The
producer
and
marketer
of
low-sulfur
coal
said
net
income
for
the
quarter
was
$
5.9
million
,
or
71
cents
a
share
,
on
revenue
of
$
145.4
million
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
year-earlier
period
,
the
company
reported
a
loss
of
$
520,000
or
six
cents
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
latest
nine
months
,
the
company
earned
$
8.5
million
,
or
$
1.03
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Last
year
's
net
loss
of
$
3,524,000
included
a
benefit
of
$
1,640,000
from
an
accounting
change
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
for
the
nine
months
rose
to
$
449
million
from
$
441.1
million
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
latest
nine
months
,
Mr.
Hutchinson
said
,
total
coal
sales
rose
to
about
14.6
million
tons
from
about
14.3
million
tons
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
long-term
debt
has
been
trimmed
to
about
$
72
million
from
$
96
million
since
Jan.
1
.
<END>
<START>
He
predicted
the
debt
ratio
will
improve
further
in
coming
quarters
.
<END>
<START>
Westmoreland
's
strategy
is
to
retain
and
expand
its
core
business
of
mining
and
selling
low-sulphur
coal
in
the
Appalachia
region
.
<END>
<START>
The
operating
territory
includes
coal
terminals
on
the
Ohio
River
and
in
Newport
News
,
Va
.
<END>
<START>
Westmoreland
exports
about
a
fourth
of
its
coal
tonnage
,
including
a
significant
amount
of
metallurgical
coal
produced
by
others
that
is
used
by
steelmakers
overseas
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
past
couple
of
years
,
Westmoreland
has
undertaken
an
aggressive
streamlining
of
all
aspects
of
its
business
.
<END>
<START>
Marginal
operations
and
assets
have
been
sold
.
<END>
<START>
The
size
of
the
company
's
board
has
been
reduced
to
eight
directors
from
13
.
<END>
<START>
About
140
salaried
management
jobs
and
hundreds
of
hourly
wage
positions
have
been
eliminated
.
<END>
<START>
Even
perks
have
been
reduced
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
the
chief
executive
himself
now
pays
20
%
of
the
cost
of
his
health
benefits
;
the
company
used
to
pay
100
%
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
think
the
ship
is
now
righted
,
the
bilges
are
pumped
and
we
are
on
course
,
''
Mr.
Hutchinson
said
of
the
restructuring
program
.
<END>
<START>
``
Much
of
what
we
set
out
to
do
is
completed
.
''
<END>
<START>
One
difference
,
he
said
,
is
that
the
fourth
quarter
has
significantly
fewer
workdays
because
of
holidays
and
the
hunting
season
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
do
n't
want
to
give
the
impression
that
everybody
can
relax
now
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
have
to
keep
working
at
improving
our
core
business
to
stay
efficient
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
a
process
that
never
really
ends
.
''
<END>
<START>
Nevertheless
,
Mr.
Hutchinson
predicted
that
1989
would
be
``
solidly
profitable
''
for
Westmoreland
and
that
1990
would
bring
``
more
of
the
same
.
''
<END>
<START>
For
all
of
1988
,
the
company
reported
an
after-tax
operating
loss
of
$
134,000
on
revenue
of
$
593.5
million
.
<END>
<START>
An
accounting
adjustment
made
net
income
$
1.5
million
,
or
18
cents
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
move
that
complements
the
company
's
basic
strategy
,
its
Westmoreland
Energy
Inc.
unit
is
developing
four
coal-fired
cogeneration
plants
with
a
partner
in
Virginia
.
<END>
<START>
Some
of
the
coal
the
plants
buy
will
come
from
Westmoreland
mines
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Hutchinson
predicted
that
the
unit
's
contribution
to
company
results
in
the
1990s
``
will
be
exciting
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
said
Westmoreland
is
looking
at
investment
stakes
in
other
cogeneration
plants
east
of
the
Mississippi
River
.
<END>
<START>
Westmoreland
expects
energy
demand
to
grow
annually
in
the
2.5
%
range
in
the
early
1990s
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
see
coal
's
piece
of
the
action
growing
,
''
Mr.
Hutchinson
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
Coal
prices
,
while
not
skyrocketing
,
will
grow
modestly
in
real
terms
,
we
think
.
<END>
<START>
Chase
Manhattan
Corp.
,
after
trying
unsuccessfully
to
sell
its
interest
in
its
lower
Manhattan
operations
building
,
has
exercised
its
option
to
purchase
the
50-story
office
tower
.
<END>
<START>
Chase
had
purchased
an
option
to
buy
the
building
at
One
New
York
Plaza
for
an
undisclosed
sum
from
the
late
Sol
Atlas
as
part
of
its
original
lease
in
1970
.
<END>
<START>
The
current
transaction
cost
the
bank
approximately
$
140
million
.
<END>
<START>
Of
that
amount
,
$
20
million
was
payment
for
the
land
underneath
the
building
and
the
rest
was
for
the
building
itself
.
<END>
<START>
The
building
houses
about
4,500
Chase
workers
,
most
of
whom
will
be
moved
to
downtown
Brooklyn
after
the
bank
's
new
back
office
center
is
completed
in
1993
.
<END>
<START>
The
move
is
part
of
Chase
's
strategy
to
consolidate
its
back
offices
under
one
roof
.
<END>
<START>
The
headquarters
is
located
a
few
blocks
away
at
1
Chase
Manhattan
Plaza
.
<END>
<START>
Chase
Senior
Vice
President
George
Scandalios
said
the
bank
decided
to
exercise
its
option
after
bids
fell
short
of
expectations
.
<END>
<START>
As
the
building
's
new
owner
,
Chase
will
have
its
work
cut
out
for
it
.
<END>
<START>
Chase
is
vacating
1.1
million
square
feet
of
space
,
and
Salomon
Brothers
Inc.
,
whose
headquarters
is
in
the
building
,
also
plans
to
move
shortly
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
another
major
building
tenant
,
Thomson
McKinnon
Inc.
's
Thomson
McKinnon
Securities
,
likely
will
vacate
the
premises
as
part
of
its
liquidation
.
<END>
<START>
New
York
real
estate
brokerage
Edward
S.
Gordon
Co.
will
have
the
difficult
task
of
finding
new
tenants
.
<END>
<START>
Even
with
its
striking
views
of
the
New
York
harbor
,
the
building
is
considered
antiquated
by
modern
office
standards
.
<END>
<START>
And
Chase
will
have
to
spend
approximately
$
50
million
to
remove
asbestos
from
the
premises
.
<END>
<START>
WALL
STREET
,
SHAKE
hands
with
George
Orwell
.
<END>
<START>
Wall
Street
has
n't
gotten
that
far
yet
,
but
it
has
made
a
promising
start
.
<END>
<START>
Its
language
--
call
it
Streetspeak
--
is
increasingly
mellifluous
,
reassuring
,
and
designed
to
make
financial
products
and
maneuvers
appear
better
,
safer
or
cheaper
than
they
really
are
.
<END>
<START>
When
something
undeniably
nasty
happens
,
a
few
euphemisms
are
deployed
to
simply
make
it
disappear
,
much
as
a
fresh
grave
may
be
covered
by
a
blanket
of
flowers
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
we
'll
bet
you
thought
that
the
stock
market
crashed
two
years

.

<START>

and

Mr.
Peters
stay
on
to
fulfill
the
Warner
contract
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
business
is
n't
about
personalities
at
the
end
of
the
day
--
it
s
about
whether
the
ink
is
red
or
black
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
case
of
Peter
and
Jon
,
the
ink
has
been
very
,
very
black
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Guber
got
his
start
in
the
movie
business
at
Columbia
two
decades
ago
.
<END>
<START>
In
1980
,
Mr.
Guber
got
together
with
Mr.
Peters
,
by
then
a
successful
producer
in
his
own
right
,
after
the
death
of
Mr.
Bogart
.
<END>
<START>
While
Guber
Peters
produced
a
number
of
hits
for
Warner
and
others
,
their
record
was
n't
always
so
impressive
.
<END>
<START>
Among
their
clinkers
were
``
The
Legend
of
Billie
Jean
,
''
``
VisionQuest
,
''
``
Clue
''
and
``
Clan
of
the
Cave
Bear
.
''
<END>
<START>
And
the
failures
make
it
possible
for
Warner
in
its
current
lawsuit
to
paint
the
producers
as
ingrates
.
<END>
<START>
The
studio
says
it
stuck
with
them
``
even
in
the
early
years
when
the
creative
partnership
was
not
particularly
profitable
for
Warner
.
''
<END>
<START>
``
From
the
beginning
,
-LCB-
they
-RCB-
knew
we
had
a
goal
and
a
dream
,
''
says
Mr.
Guber
.
<END>
<START>
On
a
number
of
occasions
,
he
adds
,
he
tried
to
get
Warner
to
buy
Guber
Peters
outright
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
always
listened
,
but
they
never
acted
,
''
Mr.
Guber
says
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
MGM
plan
collapsed
just
two
weeks
later
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Guber
and
Mr.
Peters
say
they
got
a
look
at
the
books
and
balked
at
the
price
.
<END>
<START>
Their
relationship
with
Mr.
Sugarman
soured
shortly
thereafter
.
<END>
<START>
Last
May
,
he
sold
his
24
%
stake
in
Barris
to
a
passive
Australian
investor
and
Barris
was
renamed
Guber
Peters
Entertainment
Co
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
Mr.
Guber
and
Mr.
Peters
had
agreed
to
extend
their
Warner
agreement
with
the
new
five-year
exclusive
contract
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
deal
was
considered
the
most
generous
of
its
kind
,
both
financially
and
in
terms
of
creative
freedom
.
<END>
<START>
The
producers
'
28
%
share
of
publicly
held
Guber
Peters
would
net
them
an
additional
$
50
million
.
<END>
<START>
Sony
also
agreed
to
indemnify
the
producers
against
any
liability
to
Warner
.
<END>
<START>
Sony
is
paying
a
hefty
price
for
a
company
that
had
revenue
of
only
$
42
million
last
year
.
<END>
<START>
And
earnings
have
been
erratic
.
<END>
<START>
Guber
Peters
stock
,
which
traded
as
low
as
$
6
a
share
last
year
,
closed
yesterday
at
$
16.625
.
<END>
<START>
The
two
sides
now
are
accusing
each
other
of
lying
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Guber
and
Mr.
Peters
claim
they
have
an
oral
agreement
with
Warner
executives
that
allows
them
to
terminate
their
contract
should
the
opportunity
to
run
a
major
studio
arise
.
<END>
<START>
But
in
affidavits
filed
yesterday
in
the
Los
Angeles
court
,
Mr.
Ross
,
Warner
Bros.
Chairman
Robert
Daly
and
President
Semel
deny
that
such
an
oral
agreement
was
ever
made
.
<END>
<START>
Warner
,
in
its
court
filings
,
calls
it
``
a
piece
of
fiction
created
for
this
litigation
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Daly
in
his
affidavit
acknowledges
that
Warner
agreed
to
release
the
producers
last
year
to
take
over
MGM
but
says
that
situation
was
altogether
different
.
<END>
<START>
For
one
thing
,
according
to
Mr.
Daly
,
the
producers
requested
a
release
in
advance
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
the
old
contract
was
about
to
expire
,
and
the
lineup
of
Guber
Peters
pictures
for
Warner
was
n't
as
strong
as
it
is
now
.
<END>
<START>
Warner
obviously
does
n't
think
that
it
is
in
its
own
interests
to
let
Mr.
Guber
and
Mr.
Peters
go
off
to
Columbia
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
very
least
,
Mr.
Ross
clearly
sees
an
opportunity
to
use
the
two
men
to
get
a
pound
of
flesh
from
Sony
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Guber
and
Mr.
Peters
refuse
to
concede
that
they
may
have
made
a
tactical
error
in
accepting
the
Sony
offer
before
taking
it
up
with
Warner
.
<END>
<START>
And
they
say
there
are
plenty
of
precedents
in
Hollywood
for
letting
people
out
of
contracts
.
<END>
<START>
THE
SALES
PITCH
could
n't
sound
better
.
<END>
<START>
First
,
there
's
the
name
:
``
asset-backed
securities
.
''
<END>
<START>
Better
than
all
those
offers
you
get
to
buy
securities
backed
by
nothing
.
<END>
<START>
And
there
's
more
.
<END>
<START>
The
assets
backing
the
securities
come
from
some
of
the
country
's
biggest
--
and
most
secure
--
institutions
.
<END>
<START>
Most
earn
high
ratings
from
credit
agencies
.
<END>
<START>
Their
yields
are
higher
than
those
of
U.S.
Treasury
issues
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
booming
market
has
already
attracted
many
of
the
nation
's
biggest
institutional
investors
.
<END>
<START>
Ready
to
jump
?
<END>
<START>
Well
,
think
twice
.
<END>
<START>
The
concept
may
be
simple
:
Take
a
bunch
of
loans
,
tie
them
up
in
one
neat
package
,
and
sell
pieces
of
the
package
to
investors
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
simplicity
may
be
misleading
.
<END>
<START>
Skeptics
say
the
slightly
higher
returns
are
n't
enough
to
compensate
for
the
extra
risk
.
<END>
<START>
They
warn
that
asset-backed
securities
are
only
as
good
as
the
assets
and
credit
backing
that
support
them
--
and
those
are
hard
to
evaluate
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
the
securities
were
introduced
only
about
4
1/2
years
ago
;
the
biggest
unknown
is
how
they
will
fare
in
a
recession
.
<END>
<START>
``
A
lot
of
this
stuff
really
is
in
untested
waters
,
''
says
Owen
Carney
,
director
of
the
investment
securities
division
of
the
U.S.
comptroller
of
the
currency
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
do
n't
know
how
this
whole
market
will
work
in
a
serious
economic
downturn
.
''
<END>
<START>
Such
concerns
,
however
,
have
n't
stopped
asset-backed
securities
from
becoming
one
of
Wall
Street
's
hottest
new
products
.
<END>
<START>
Since
the
spring
of
1985
,
financial
alchemists
have
transformed
a
wide
variety
of
debt
into
these
new
securities
.
<END>
<START>
They
have
sold
issues
backed
by
car
loans
,
boat
loans
and
recreational-vehicle
loans
.
<END>
<START>
They
have
offered
bundles
of
homeequity
loans
,
as
well
as
packages
of
loans
used
to
buy
vacation
time-shares
.
<END>
<START>
Last
year
,
there
was
an
issue
of
``
death-backed
bonds
''
--
securities
backed
by
loans
to
life-insurance
policyholders
.
<END>
<START>
Some
predict
there
will
be
``
Third
World
bonds
,
''
backed
by
loans
to
Brazil
,
Argentina
and
other
debt-ridden
nations
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
biggest
volume
this
year
has
been
on
securities
backed
by
credit-card
receivables
,
sometimes
known
as
``
plastic
bonds
.
''
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
the
heyday
of
debt
,
''
says
James
Grant
,
editor
of
Grant
's
Interest
Rate
Observer
,
a
newsletter
.
<END>
<START>
``
Before
the
sun
sets
on
the
'80s
,
it
seems
nothing
will
be
left
unhocked
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
result
is
a
$
45
billion
market
,
according
to
Securities
Data
Co
.
<END>
<START>
Most
issues
have
been
sold
to
professional
money
managers
,
pension
funds
,
bank
trust
departments
and
other
institutions
.
<END>
<START>
But
wealthy
individuals
also
have
been
jumping
in
,
and
lately
brokers
have
been
pushing
smaller
investors
into
the
asset-backed
market
.
<END>
<START>
The
entry
fee
is
affordable
:
Issues
typically
are
sold
in
minimum
denominations
of
$
1,000
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
expect
additional
offerings
''
of
asset-backed
securities
targeted
toward
individual
investors
,
says
Bill
Addiss
,
a
senior
vice
president
at
Shearson
Lehman
Hutton
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
The
trust
then
issues
securities
--
generally
due
in
five
years
or
less
--
that
are
underwritten
by
Wall
Street
brokerage
firms
and
offered
to
investors
.
<END>
<START>
Issues
typically
come
with
``
credit
enhancements
,
''
such
as
a
bank
letter
of
credit
,
and
thus
have
received
high
credit
ratings
.
<END>
<START>
Enthusiasts
say
the
booming
market
has
opened
up
a
valuable
new
source
of
funds
to
issuers
,
while
providing
a
valuable
new
investment
for
individuals
and
institutions
.
<END>
<START>
But
skeptics
question
whether
asset-backed
bonds
offer
sufficient
rewards
to
compensate
for
the
extra
risks
.
<END>
<START>
Consider
a
$
500
million
offering
of
9
%
securities
issued
last
spring
and
backed
by
Citibank
credit-card
receivables
.
<END>
<START>
The
triple-A-rated
issue
offered
a
yield
of
only
about
0.5
percentage
point
above
four-year
Treasury
issues
.
<END>
<START>
On
a
$
10,000
investment
,
that
's
a
difference
of
only
$
50
a
year
.
<END>
<START>
That
kind
of
spread
can
be
critical
for
money
managers
who
buy
bonds
in
large
quantities
and
whose
livelihood
depends
on
outperforming
the
money
manager
across
the
street
.
<END>
<START>
But
for
individuals
who
buy
much
smaller
amounts
and
care
less
about
relative
performance
than
in
preserving
what
they
have
,
that
margin
is
meaningless
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
if
you
're
an
individual
investing
money
and
trying
to
get
it
back
again
,
then
that
is
n't
of
overwhelming
importance
.
''
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
the
interest
on
asset-backed
securities
is
fully
taxable
,
while
interest
on
Treasury
issues
is
tax-free
at
the
state
and
local
level
.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Powers
has
purchased
asset-backed
issues
for
individuals
with
tax-deferred
accounts
,
such
as
retirement
plans
.
<END>
<START>
He
points
out
that
institutions
buying
asset-backed
issues
in
large
quantities
can
earn
higher
spreads
over
Treasurys
than
individuals
buying
smaller
amounts
.
<END>
<START>
Another
concern
is
liquidity
,
or
how
easily
a
security
can
be
converted
into
cash
.
<END>
<START>
The
secondary
,
or
resale
,
market
for
asset-backed
securities
is
relatively
new
and
much
less
active
than
for
Treasury
issues
.
<END>
<START>
That
could
make
it
tricky
for
investors
who
need
to
sell
their
holdings
quickly
before
the
securities
mature
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
particularly
true
,
analysts
say
,
for
certain
of
the
securities
,
such
as
those
backed
by
time-share
loans
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
an
investor
who
wants
to
know
the
daily
value
of
Treasury
bonds
,
or
corporate
bonds
traded
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
,
can
simply
check
newspaper
listings
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
n't
any
such
listings
for
asset-backed
securities
.
<END>
<START>
Evaluating
asset-backed
securities
poses
another
problem
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
,
for
instance
,
may
mistakenly
assume
that
the
bank
or
company
that
originally
held
the
assets
is
guaranteeing
the
securities
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
n't
.
<END>
<START>
In
other
words
,
if
there
's
a
problem
,
do
n't
expect
Citibank
to
come
to
the
rescue
.
<END>
<START>
The
prospectus
also
notes
that
the
securities
are
not
guaranteed
by
any
government
agency
.
<END>
<START>
That
also
is
n't
easy
.
<END>
<START>
Take
the
``
credit
enhancements
,
''
which
typically
include
a
bank
letter
of
credit
or
insurance
from
a
bond-insurance
company
.
<END>
<START>
The
letter
of
credit
typically
is
not
offered
by
the
bank
selling
the
assets
to
back
the
securities
.
<END>
<START>
Nor
does
it
cover
the
entire
portfolio
.
<END>
<START>
Details
of
credit
enhancements
vary
widely
from
issue
to
issue
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
they
play
a
crucial
role
in
winning
top
ratings
for
most
asset-backed
issues
--
which
in
turn
is
why
the
yield
above
Treasurys
is
so
slim
.
<END>
<START>
But
skeptics
ask
why
you
should
bother
buying
this
stuff
when
you
can
get
only
slightly
lower
yields
on
government-guaranteed
paper
.
<END>
<START>
When
you
buy
an
asset-backed
issue
,
you
take
the
risk
that
a
bank
or
an
insurer
could
run
into
unexpected
difficulties
.
<END>
<START>
Underwriters
insist
these
issues
are
constructed
to
withstand
extremely
tough
economic
conditions
.
<END>
<START>
But
despite
the
credit
enhancements
,
despite
the
high
ratings
,
some
money
managers
still
worry
that
a
recession
could
wreak
havoc
on
the
underlying
assets
.
<END>
<START>
At
a
time
when
Americans
are
leveraged
to
their
eyeballs
,
asset-backed
investors
may
be
taking
a
heady
gamble
that
consumers
will
be
able
to
repay
loans
in
hard
times
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
very
least
,
a
recession
would
prompt
investors
to
buy
the
highest-quality
bonds
they
can
find
--
that
is
,
Treasurys
.
<END>
<START>
That
could
widen
the
yield
spread
between
Treasurys
and
asset-backed
securities
,
as
well
as
make
it
tougher
to
unload
the
latter
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
could
be
much
worse
.
<END>
<START>
Some
analysts
are
especially
wary
of
credit-card
issues
.
<END>
<START>
For
one
thing
,
credit-card
loans
are
unsecured
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
they
fear
that
banks
have
been
overeager
to
issue
cards
to
the
public
--
giving
cards
to
too
many
big
spenders
who
will
default
during
a
recession
.
<END>
<START>
What
about
triple-A-rated
asset-backed
issues
?
<END>
<START>
``
Nope
,
we
still
say
to
stick
with
Treasurys
,
''
Mr.
Corcoran
replies
.
<END>
<START>
Ratings
,
he
notes
,
``
are
subject
to
change
.
''
<END>
<START>
All
this
makes
asset-backed
securities
seem
too
risky
for
many
people
.
<END>
<START>
And
it
reminds
Raymond
F.
DeVoe
Jr.
,
a
market
strategist
at
Legg
Mason
Wood
Walker
Inc.
,
of
what
he
calls
``
DeVoe
's
Unprovable
but
Highly
Probable
Theory
No.
1
:
<END>
<START>
``
More
money
has
been
lost
reaching
for
yield
than
in
all
the
stock
speculations
,
scams
and
frauds
of
all
time
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Herman
is
a
staff
reporter
in
The
Wall
Street
Journal
's
New
York
bureau
.
<END>
<START>
Volume
of
asset-backed
securities
issued
annually
<END>
<START>
*
Principal
amount
<END>
<START>
**
As
of
August
30
<END>
<START>
*
Principal
amount
<END>
<START>
Source
:
Securities
Data
Co
.
<END>
<START>
IF
YOU
FORCE
financial
planners
to
sum
up
their
most
important
advice
in
a
single
sentence
,
it
would
probably
be
a
one-word
sentence
:
Diversify
.
<END>
<START>
Judging
by
a
poll
of
Wall
Street
Journal
readers
conducted
this
summer
by
Erdos
&
Morgan
Inc.
,
serious
investors
have
taken
that
advice
to
heart
.
<END>
<START>
Nearly
1,000
investors
responded
to
the
Journal
's
poll
,
providing
an
in-depth
look
at
their
portfolios
.
<END>
<START>
Those
portfolios
are
remarkably
diversified
.
<END>
<START>
By
spreading
their
wealth
among
several
investment
alternatives
,
the
respondents
have
protected
themselves
against
squalls
in
any
one
area
,
be
it
stocks
,
bonds
or
real
estate
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
about
88
%
of
Journal
readers
owned
stock
-LRB-
down
slightly
from
91
%
in
a
similar
poll
last
year
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
But
only
17.5
%
said
they
had
more
than
half
their
money
in
the
stock
market
.
<END>
<START>
Similarly
,
57
%
of
respondents
own
shares
in
a
money-market
mutual
fund
,
and
33
%
own
municipal
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
But
only
6
%
to
7
%
of
the
investors
were
committing
more
than
half
their
funds
to
either
of
those
alternatives
.
<END>
<START>
The
poll
,
conducted
Aug.
7-28
,
also
provides
a
glimpse
into
the
thinking
of
serious
investors
on
a
variety
of
other
topics
.
<END>
<START>
It
found
them
in
a
cautious
,
but
not
downbeat
,
mood
.
<END>
<START>
Of
1,500
people
sent
a
questionnaire
,
951
replied
.
<END>
<START>
The
response
rate
,
more
than
63
%
,
allows
the
results
to
be
interpreted
with
a
high
degree
of
confidence
.
<END>
<START>
The
results
ca
n't
be
extrapolated
to
all
investors
,
though
.
<END>
<START>
Journal
readers
are
relatively
affluent
,
with
a
median
household
income
of
between
$
75,000
and
$
99,000
.
<END>
<START>
Nearly
half
of
the
respondents
-LRB-
47
%
-RRB-
said
their
investment
portfolio
was
worth
$
250,000
or
more
,
and
17
%
said
it
was
worth
$
1
million
or
more
.
<END>
<START>
The
respondents
were
mildly
optimistic
about
the
economy
and
investment
markets
,
but
their
collective
judgments
were
a
notch
more
sober
than
they
were
a
year
ago
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
12
%
of
this
year
's
respondents
said
they
expect
a
recession
within
12
months
.
<END>
<START>
Last
year
,
only
8
%
were
expecting
a
recession
.
<END>
<START>
An
additional
56
%
of
this
year
's
respondents
expect
the
economy
to
slow
down
during
the
next
12
months
.
<END>
<START>
Only
42
%
of
last
year
's
respondents
anticipated
slowing
growth
.
<END>
<START>
Apparently
,
the
respondents
do
n't
think
that
an
economic
slowdown
would
harm
the
major
investment
markets
very
much
.
<END>
<START>
A
slim
majority
-LRB-
51
%
-RRB-
think
stock
prices
will
be
higher
in
August
1990
than
they
were
in
August
1989
.
<END>
<START>
Their
verdict
on
real
estate
is
almost
the
same
.
<END>
<START>
Some
50
%
expect
real
estate
in
their
local
area
to
increase
in
value
over
the
next
12
months
.
<END>
<START>
By
contrast
,
only
32
%
expect
an
increase
in
the
price
of
gold
.
<END>
<START>
Since
gold
tends
to
soar
when
inflation
is
high
,
that
finding
suggests
that
people
believe
inflation
remains
under
control
.
<END>
<START>
Even
though
only
12
%
actually
predicted
a
recession
,
many
respondents
were
taking
a
better-safe-than
sorry
investment
stance
.
<END>
<START>
Nearly
a
third
said
they
have
made
some
portfolio
changes
to
anticipate
a
possible
recession
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
most
part
,
the
changes
were
``
slight
.
''
<END>
<START>
A
buy-and-hold
approach
to
stocks
continues
to
be
the
rule
among
respondents
.
<END>
<START>
Most
own
two
to
10
stocks
,
and
buy
or
sell
no
more
than
three
times
a
year
.
<END>
<START>
Some
71
%
had
bought
some
stock
in
the
past
year
;
only
57
%
had
sold
any
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
lurking
shadow
of
1987
's
stock-market
crash
still
seems
dark
.
<END>
<START>
About
33
%
considered
another
crash
``
likely
,
''
while
about
63
%
said
one
is
``
unlikely
.
''
<END>
<START>
Those
percentages
hardly
changed
from
the
previous
year
's
poll
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
respondents
'
commitment
to
the
stock
market
remains
somewhat
lighter
than
usual
.
<END>
<START>
About
60
%
of
them
said
they
would
``
ordinarily
''
have
at
least
25
%
of
their
money
in
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
But
as
of
August
,
only
50
%
actually
had
stock-market
investments
of
that
size
.
<END>
<START>
Most
stock-market
indexes
were
hitting
all-time
highs
at
around
the
time
of
the
poll
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
appears
that
many
Journal
readers
were
taking
that
news
as
a
sign
to
be
cautious
,
rather
than
a
signal
to
jump
on
the
bandwagon
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Dorfman
covers
investing
issues
from
The
Wall
Street
Journal
's
New
York
bureau
.
<END>
<START>
The
week
's
total
was
down
7.1
%
from
297,446
tons
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
A
metric
ton
is
equal
to
2,204.62
pounds
.
<END>
<START>
The
cumulative
total
in
1989
was
12,283,217
tons
,
up
7.5
%
from
11,429,243
tons
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Health
Care
Property
Investors
Inc.
said
it
acquired
three
long-term
care
facilities
and
one
assisted-living
facility
in
a
purchase-and-lease
transaction
valued
at
$
15
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
real
estate
investment
trust
said
that
it
leased
the
three
Florida
facilities
to
National
Health
Care
Affiliates
Inc.
of
Buffalo
,
N.Y
.
<END>
<START>
Health
Care
Property
holds
an
interest
in
139
facilities
in
30
states
.
<END>
<START>
It
said
the
reduction
reflects
impaired
business
prospects
and
reduced
financial
flexibility
caused
by
continuing
losses
at
the
maker
of
Winchester
disk
drives
.
<END>
<START>
VALLEY
National
Corp.
--
<END>
<START>
Moody
's
Investors
Service
Inc.
said
it
lowered
its
rating
on
about
$
400
million
of
this
bank
holding
company
's
senior
debt
to
B2
from
Ba3
.
<END>
<START>
Electronic
theft
by
foreign
and
industrial
spies
and
disgruntled
employees
is
costing
U.S.
companies
billions
and
eroding
their
international
competitive
advantage
.
<END>
<START>
That
was
the
message
delivered
by
government
and
private
security
experts
at
an
all-day
conference
on
corporate
electronic
espionage
.
<END>
<START>
The
conference
was
jointly
sponsored
by
the
New
York
Institute
of
Technology
School
of
Management
and
the
Armed
Forces
Communications
and
Electronics
Association
,
a
joint
industry-government
trade
group
.
<END>
<START>
Any
secret
can
be
pirated
,
the
experts
said
,
if
it
is
transmitted
over
the
air
.
<END>
<START>
Even
rank
amateurs
can
do
it
if
they
spend
a
few
thousand
dollars
for
a
commercially
available
microwave
receiver
with
amplifier
and
a
VCR
recorder
.
<END>
<START>
They
need
only
position
themselves
near
a
company
's
satellite
dish
and
wait
.
<END>
<START>
The
only
way
to
catch
an
electronic
thief
,
he
said
,
is
to
set
him
up
with
erroneous
information
.
<END>
<START>
Even
though
electronic
espionage
may
cost
U.S.
firms
billions
of
dollars
a
year
,
most
are
n't
yet
taking
precautions
,
the
experts
said
.
<END>
<START>
By
contrast
,
European
firms
will
spend
$
150
million
this
year
on
electronic
security
,
and
are
expected
to
spend
$
1
billion
by
1992
.
<END>
<START>
Already
many
foreign
firms
,
especially
banks
,
have
their
own
cryptographers
,
conference
speakers
reported
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
encrypting
corporate
communications
is
only
a
partial
remedy
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
he
said
,
technology
now
exists
for
stealing
corporate
secrets
after
they
've
been
``
erased
''
from
a
computer
's
memory
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
that
Oliver
North
of
Iran-Contra
notoriety
thought
he
had
erased
his
computer
but
that
the
information
was
later
retrieved
for
congressional
committees
to
read
.
<END>
<START>
No
personal
computer
,
not
even
the
one
on
a
chief
executive
's
desk
,
is
safe
,
this
speaker
noted
.
<END>
<START>
Under
Mr.
Gorbachev
,
Mr.
Goode
said
,
the
Soviets
are
openly
stealing
Western
corporate
communications
.
<END>
<START>
He
cited
the
case
of
a
Swiss
oil
trader
who
recently
put
out
bids
via
telex
for
an
oil
tanker
to
pick
up
a
cargo
of
crude
in
the
Middle
East
.
<END>
<START>
Among
the
responses
the
Swiss
trader
got
was
one
from
the
Soviet
national
shipping
company
,
which
had
n't
been
invited
to
submit
a
bid
.
<END>
<START>
The
Soviets
'
eavesdropping
paid
off
,
however
,
because
they
got
the
contract
.
<END>
<START>
The
University
of
Toronto
stepped
deeper
into
the
contest
for
Connaught
BioSciences
Inc.
by
reaching
an
unusual
agreement
with
Ciba-Geigy
Ltd.
and
Chiron
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
It
said
$
10
million
would
go
to
the
University
of
Toronto
.
<END>
<START>
Ciba-Geigy
and
Chiron
have
made
a
joint
bid
of
C$
866
million
for
Connaught
,
and
Institut
Merieux
S.A.
of
France
has
made
a
rival
bid
of
C$
942
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
University
is
seeking
an
injunction
against
the
Merieux
bid
,
arguing
that
Connaught
's
predecessor
company
agreed
in
1972
that
Connaught
's
ownership
would
n't
be
transferred
to
foreigners
.
<END>
<START>
The
university
implied
that
it
would
drop
its
opposition
to
foreign
ownership
if
Ciba-Geigy
and
Chiron
are
successful
with
their
lower
bid
.
<END>
<START>
It
said
the
new
agreement
would
``
replace
''
the
old
one
that
forms
the
basis
of
its
suit
against
the
Merieux
takeover
.
<END>
<START>
``
Notwithstanding
foreign
ownership
of
Connaught
,
this
accord
would
enhance
research
and
development
in
Canada
,
''
said
James
Keffer
,
the
university
's
vice
president
of
research
.
<END>
<START>
Ciba-Geigy
is
a
Swiss
pharmaceutical
company
and
Chiron
is
based
in
Emeryville
,
Calif
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
statement
,
Jacques-Francois
Martin
,
director
general
of
Merieux
,
said
the
French
company
is
still
determined
to
acquire
Connaught
.
<END>
<START>
In
national
over-the-counter
trading
yesterday
,
Connaught
closed
at
$
28.625
,
up
$
1.25
.
<END>
<START>
Microsoft
and
other
software
stocks
surged
,
leading
the
Nasdaq
composite
index
of
over-the-counter
stocks
to
its
biggest
advance
of
the
year
on
breathtaking
volume
.
<END>
<START>
Leading
the
pack
,
Microsoft
soared
3
3/4
,
or
4
%
,
to
a
record
price
of
84
1/4
on
1.2
million
shares
.
<END>
<START>
On
the
other
hand
,
Valley
National
tumbled
24
%
after
reporting
a
sizable
third-quarter
loss
.
<END>
<START>
The
Nasdaq
composite
leaped
7.52
points
,
or
1.6
%
,
to
470.80
.
<END>
<START>
Its
largest
previous
rise
this
year
came
Aug.
7
,
when
it
gained
4.31
.
<END>
<START>
The
OTC
market
's
largest
stocks
soared
as
well
,
as
the
Nasdaq
100
Index
jumped
10.01
,
or
2
%
,
to
463.06
.
<END>
<START>
The
Nasdaq
Financial
Index
rose
5.04
,
or
1.1
%
,
to
460.33
.
<END>
<START>
By
comparison
,
the
Dow
Jones
Industrials
and
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
Composite
each
rose
1.5
%
.
<END>
<START>
Volume
totaled
173.5
million
shares
,
30
%
above
this
year
's
average
daily
turnover
on
Nasdaq
.
<END>
<START>
Among
broader
Nasdaq
industry
groups
,
the
utility
index
gained
18.11
to
761.38
.
<END>
<START>
The
transportation
and
insurance
sectors
each
posted
gains
of
8.59
,
with
the
transports
finishing
at
486.74
and
the
insurers
at
537.91
.
<END>
<START>
The
index
of
smaller
banks
improved
1.97
.
<END>
<START>
Of
the
4,346
issues
that
changed
hands
,
1,435
rose
and
629
fell
.
<END>
<START>
Jeremiah
Mullins
,
head
of
OTC
trading
at
Dean
Witter
Reynolds
,
said
both
institutional
and
retail
investors
were
buying
.
<END>
<START>
But
there
was
a
dearth
of
sellers
,
traders
said
,
so
buyers
had
to
bid
prices
up
to
entice
them
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
's
no
pressure
on
OTC
stocks
at
this
point
,
''
said
Mr.
Mullins
,
who
said
some
buyers
are
beginning
to
shop
among
smaller
OTC
issues
.
<END>
<START>
Microsoft
's
surge
followed
a
report
this
week
of
substantially
improved
earnings
for
its
first
quarter
,
ended
Sept.
30
.
<END>
<START>
The
stock
was
trading
at
69
just
two
weeks
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Rick
Sherlund
,
a
Goldman
Sachs
analyst
,
has
raised
his

estimates
for

company
twice
in

,

.

<START>

,

to

4
a

.
<END>
<START>
Microsoft
earned
$
3.03
a
share
in

1989
.
<END>
<START>
Caere
,
a
new

to

1/8
.
<END>
<START>
The

.
<END>
<START>
Caere
was
underwritten
by
Alex
.
Brown

.
<END>
<START>
Another
recently
offered
Alex
.
Brown
issue
,
Rally
's
,
surged
3
1/8
to
23
.
<END>
<START>
The
operator
of
fast-food
restaurants
,
whose
shares
began
trading
last
Friday
,
climbed
3
1/8
to
23
on
944,000
shares
.
<END>
<START>
Its
1.7
million-share
offering
was
priced
at
15
.
<END>
<START>
Valley
National
's
slide
of
5
3/4
points
to
18
1/2
on
4.2
million
shares
followed
its
report
late
Wednesday
of
a
$
72.2
million
third-quarter
loss
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
1988
quarter
,
the
Phoenix
,
Ariz.
,
commercial
banking
concern
earned
$
18.7
million
.
<END>
<START>
Valley
National
said
its
$
110
million
provision
for
credit
losses
and
$
11
million
provision
for
other
real
estate
owned
is
related
to
weakness
in
the
Arizona
real
estate
market
.
<END>
<START>
Additionally
,
Moody
's

Service
said
it
downgraded
Valley
National
's
senior
debt
and
confirmed
the
company
's
commercial
paper
rating
of
``
not
prime
.
''
<END>
<START>
A
new
issue
,
Exabyte
,
surged
2
1/8
from

to

12
1/8
.

;

.

.

.

,

.

.
<END>
<START>
Row
21
of
Section
9
of
the
Upper
Reserved
at
Candlestick
Park
is
a
lofty
perch
,
only
a
few
steps
from
the
very
top
of
the
stands
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
five
in
the
afternoon
,
but
that
was
Pacific
time
.
<END>
<START>
Back
in
New
York
the
work
day
was
already
over
,
so
I
did
n't
have
to
feel
guilty
.
<END>
<START>
This
ballpark
,
the
Stick
,
was
not
a
classic
baseball
stadium
--
too
symmetrical
,
too
much
bald
concrete
.
<END>
<START>
And
it
did
n't
have
the
crowded
wild
intimacy
of
Yankee
Stadium
.
<END>
<START>
Maybe
it
was
their
peculiar
sense
of
history
.
<END>
<START>
The
broadcasters
were
,
after
all
,
documenting
the
game
,
ratifying
its
occurrence
for
millions
outside
the
Stick
.
<END>
<START>
Why
not
watch
or
hear
your
experience
historicized
while
you
were
living
it
?
<END>
<START>
The
day
was
saturated
with
the
weight
of
its
own
impending
history
.
<END>
<START>
Long
lines
of
people
waited
to
buy
special
souvenir
World
Series
postcards
with
official
postmarks
.
<END>
<START>
Pitcher
=
lanzador
.
<END>
<START>
Homerun
=
jonron
.
<END>
<START>
Players
ran
out
on
the
field
way
below
,
and
the
stands
began
to
reverberate
.
<END>
<START>
It
must
be
a
local
custom
,
I
thought
,
stamping
feet
to
welcome
the
team
.
<END>
<START>
But
then
the
noise
turned
into
a
roar
.
<END>
<START>
And
no
one
was
shouting
.
<END>
<START>
No
one
around
me
was
saying
anything
.
<END>
<START>
Because
we
all
were
busy
riding
a
wave
.
<END>
<START>
Sixty
thousand
surfers
atop
a
concrete
wall
,
waiting
for
the
wipeout
.
<END>
<START>
Only
at
the
moment
of
maximum
roll
did
I
grasp
what
was
going
on
.
<END>
<START>
Then
I
remembered
the
quake
of
'71
,
which
I
experienced
in
Santa
Barbara
in
a
second-story
motel
room
.
<END>
<START>
Then
I
noticed
the
overhead
light
was
swaying
on
its
cord
and
realized
what
had
happened
.
<END>
<START>
What
should
I
do
?
<END>
<START>
Get
out
of
the
possibly
collapsing
building
to
the
parking
lot
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
lot
might
split
into
crevasses
,
so
I
had
better
stand
on
my
car
,
which
probably
was
wider
than
the
average
crevasse
.
<END>
<START>
Fortunately
,
the
quake
was
over
before
I
managed
to
run
out
and
stand
naked
on
the
hood
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
Stick
,
while
the
world
shook
,
I
thought
of
that
morning
and
then
it
struck
me
that
this
time
was
different
.
<END>
<START>
If
I
survived
,
I
would
have
achieved
every
journalist
's
highest
wish
.
<END>
<START>
I
was
an
eyewitness
of
the
most
newsworthy
event
on
the
planet
at
that
moment
.
<END>
<START>
What
was
my
angle
?
<END>
<START>
How
would
I
file
?
<END>
<START>
All
these
thoughts
raced
through
my
head
in
the
15
seconds
of
the
earthquake
's
actual
duration
.
<END>
<START>
The
rest
is
,
of
course
,
history
.
<END>
<START>
The
Stick
did
n't
fall
.
<END>
<START>
The
real
tragedies
occurred
elsewhere
,
as
we
soon
found
out
.
<END>
<START>
But
for
a
few
minutes
there
,
relief
abounded
.
<END>
<START>
A
young
mother
found
her
boy
,
who
had
been
out
buying
a
hotdog
.
<END>
<START>
The
wall
behind
me
was
slightly
deformed
,
but
the
center
had
held
.
<END>
<START>
And
most
of
us
waited
for
a
while
for
the
game
to
start
.
<END>
<START>
Then
we
began
to
file
out
,
to
wait
safely
on
terra
firma
for
the
opening
pitch
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
during
the
quiet
exodus
down
the
pristine
concrete
ramps
of
the
Stick
that
I
really
understood
the
point
of
all
those
Walkmen
and
Watchmen
.
<END>
<START>
The
crowd
moved
in
clumps
,
clumps
magnetized
around
an
electronic
nucleus
.
<END>
<START>
In
this
way
,
while
the
Stick
itself
was
blacked
out
,
we
kept
up
to
date
on
events
.
<END>
<START>
Within
15
minutes
of
the
quake
itself
,
I
was
able
to
see
pictures
of
the
collapsed
section
of
the
Bay
Bridge
.
<END>
<START>
Increasingly
accurate
estimates
of
the
severity
of
the
quake
became
available
before
I
got
to
my
car
.
<END>
<START>
Darkness
fell
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
broadcasts
continued
through
the
blacked-out
night
,
with
pictures
of
the
sandwiched
highway
ganglion
in
Oakland
and
firefighting
in
the
Marina
district
.
<END>
<START>
By
then
,
our
little
sand
village
of
cars
had
been
linked
with
a
global
village
of
listeners
and
viewers
.
<END>
<START>
Everyone
at
the
Stick
that
day
had
started
out
as
a
spectator
and
ended
up
as
a
participant
.
<END>
<START>
In
fact
,
the
entire
population
of
the
Bay
Area
had
ended
up
with
this
dual
role
of
actor
and
audience
.
<END>
<START>
The
reporters
were
victims
and
some
of
the
victims
turned
into
unofficial
reporters
.
<END>
<START>
The
tape
was
on
tv
before
the
night
was
out
.
<END>
<START>
Marshall
McLuhan
,
you
should
have
been
there
at
that
hour
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
who
received
Shearson
Lehman
Hutton
Inc.
's
latest
stock
commentary
may
be
left
with
blank
expressions
.
<END>
<START>
The
first
10
pages
of
the
76-page
Weekly
Portfolio
Perspective
are
completely
blank
,
except
for
the
page
numbers
.
<END>
<START>
Rather
than
printing
devils
,
Shearson
puts
all
the
blame
on
the
unpredictable
stock
market
.
<END>
<START>
The
plunge
made
Shearson
's
market
commentary
instantly
out
of
date
.
<END>
<START>
The
first
thought
some
investors
had
was
that
a
red-faced
Shearson
must
have
been
wildly
bullish
on
stocks
in
its
original
commentary
,
and
that
's
why
it
purged
its
pages
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
recalled
that
Shearson
last
week
had
been
advising
that
``
the
market
is
still
exhibiting
all
the
signs
of
a
further
advance
.
''
<END>
<START>
Many
other
brokerage
firms
had
similarly
bullish
views
.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Rivkin
insists
that
the
10
pages
were
n't
pulled
because
they
were
too
bullish
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
,
he
says
,
``
they
were
cautious
,
and
that
was
n't
the
message
we
wanted
to
deliver
''
on
Monday
.
<END>
<START>
As
Mr.
Rivkin
explains
it
,
``
We
were
raising
some
caution
flags
about
rate
rises
in
Europe
and
concerns
about
the
LBO
market
.
<END>
<START>
And
by
late
Friday
afternoon
,
actually
after
the
close
,
we
decided
that
was
the
wrong
tone
to
take
.
<END>
<START>
With
the
market
down
,
we
wanted
to
tell
people
to
put
their
orders
in
on
the
opening
.
''
<END>
<START>
Both
before
and
after
the
Friday
plunge
,
Shearson
has
maintained
a
recommended
portfolio
weighting
of
65
%
stocks
,
20
%
bonds
and
15
%
cash
.
<END>
<START>
Sheldon
B.
Lubar
,
chairman
of
Lubar
&
Co.
,
and
John
L.
Murray
,
chairman
of
Universal
Foods
Corp.
,
were
elected
to
the
board
of
this
engine
maker
.
<END>
<START>
They
succeed
Robert
W.
Kasten
and
John
R.
Parker
,
who
reached
the
mandatory
retirement
age
.
<END>
<START>
China
's
slide
toward
recession
is
beginning
to
look
like
a
free
fall
.
<END>
<START>
Retail
sales
are
plummeting
,
while
consumer
prices
still
are
rising
.
<END>
<START>
Chinese
and
foreign
economists
now
predict
prolonged
stagflation
:
low
growth
and
high
inflation
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
economy
is
crashing
hard
,
''
says
an
Asian
economist
in
Beijing
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
slowdown
is
taking
hold
a
lot
more
quickly
and
devastatingly
than
anyone
had
expected
.
''
<END>
<START>
A
lengthy
recession
,
if
it
materializes
,
would
drain
state
coffers
and
create
severe
hardships
for
urban
workers
.
<END>
<START>
Experts
predict
the
coming
year
will
be
characterized
by
flat
or
negative
industrial
growth
,
rising
unemployment
and
a
widening
budget
deficit
.
<END>
<START>
Unless
the
government
suddenly
reverses
course
,
wages
for
most
workers
wo
n't
keep
pace
with
inflation
,
creating
a
potential
source
of
urban
unrest
.
<END>
<START>
The
economy
's
slowdown
is
due
only
partly
to
the
austerity
program
launched
in
September
1988
to
cool
an
overheated
economy
and
tame
inflation
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Industrial
output
surged
21
%
in
1988
,
while
inflation
peaked
last
February
at
nearly
30
%
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
The
slowdown
also
results
from
chronic
energy
and
raw-materials
shortages
that
force
many
factories
to
restrict
operations
to
two
or
three
days
a
week
.
<END>
<START>
In
Western
,
market-driven
countries
,
recessions
often
have
a
bright
side
:
prodding
the
economy
to
greater
efficiency
.
<END>
<START>
In
China
,
however
,
there
is
n't
likely
to
be
any
silver
lining
because
the
economy
remains
guided
primarily
by
the
state
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
,
China
is
likely
to
shell
out
ever-greater
subsidies
to
its
coddled
state-run
enterprises
,
which
ate
up
$
18
billion
in
bailouts
last
year
.
<END>
<START>
Nor
are
any
of
these
inefficient
monoliths
likely
to
be
allowed
to
go
bankrupt
.
<END>
<START>
``
When
the
going
gets
rough
,
China
penalizes
the
efficient
and
rewards
the
incompetent
,
''
says
a
Western
economist
.
<END>
<START>
Reports
of
an
economy
near
recession
come
as
officials
prepare
a
major
Communist
Party
plenum
for
sometime
in
the
next
few
weeks
.
<END>
<START>
The
meeting
is
expected
to
call
for
heightened
austerity
for
two
years
.
<END>
<START>
But
with
industrial
growth
stagnant
and
inflation
showing
signs
of
easing
,
some
voices
may
call
for
measures
to
pump
new
life
into
the
economy
.
<END>
<START>
Some
analysts
believe
China
soon
will
begin
relaxing
economic
controls
,
particularly
by
loosening
credit
.
<END>
<START>
That
would
benefit
Chinese
enterprises
as
well
as
Sino-foreign
joint
ventures
,
both
of
which
have
been
plagued
by
shortages
of
working
capital
.
<END>
<START>
A
dangerous
buildup
this
year
of
billions
of
dollars
in
inter-company
debts
threatens
,
if
unchecked
,
to
bring
the
economy
to
a
collapse
.
<END>
<START>
But
while
pumping
more
money
into
the
economy
would
bring
relief
to
many
industries
,
it
also
runs
the
risk
of
triggering
another
period
of
runaway
growth
and
steep
inflation
.
<END>
<START>
The
cycle
has
been
repeated
several
times
since
China
began
reforming
its
planned
economy
in
1979
.
<END>
<START>
And
,
because
China
's
leaders
have
abandoned
plans
to
drastically
reform
the
economy
,
it
is
likely
to
continue
,
analysts
say
.
<END>
<START>
The
statistical
bureau
's
report
,
cited
in
China
Daily
,
notes
that
industrial
output
in
September
totaled
$
29.4
billion
,
a
rise
of
just
0.9
%
from
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Output
declined
in
several
provinces
,
including
Jiangsu
and
Zhejiang
,
two
key
coastal
areas
,
and
Sichuan
,
the
nation
's
agricultural
breadbasket
.
<END>
<START>
Production
in
Shanghai
,
China
's
industrial
powerhouse
and
the
largest
source
of
tax
revenue
for
the
central
government
,
fell
1.8
%
for
the
month
.
<END>
<START>
Nationwide
,
output
of
light
industrial
products
declined
1.8
%
--
``
the
first
decline
in
10
years
,
''
a
bureau
spokesman
told
China
Daily
.
<END>
<START>
In
an
unusually
direct
statement
,
the
bureau
spokesman
recommended
that
state
banks
extend
more
credit
to
shopkeepers
so
that
they
can
purchase
manufacturers
'
goods
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
will
prevent
a
slide
in
industrial
production
,
which
will
otherwise
cause
new
panic
buyings
,
''
the
spokesman
said
.
<END>
<START>
Real-estate
executives
are
lobbying
to
ease
anti-tax-shelter
rules
.
<END>
<START>
Charitable
groups
are
trying
to
reinstate
the
write-off
for
contributions
made
by
individuals
who
do
n't
itemize
their
deductions
.
<END>
<START>
Big
auction
houses
want
to
make
collectibles
eligible
for
lower
capital-gains
taxes
.
<END>
<START>
And
heavy-industry
lobbyists
are
quietly
discussing
the
possibility
of
reinstating
the
investment
tax
credit
.
<END>
<START>
``
Everything
is
up
for
grabs
,
''
says
Theodore
Groom
,
a
lobbyist
for
mutual
life-insurance
companies
.
<END>
<START>
The
catalyst
has
been
the
congressional
move
to
restore
preferential
tax
treatment
for
capital
gains
,
an
effort
that
is
likely
to
succeed
in
this
Congress
.
<END>
<START>
Other
fundamental
``
reforms
''
of
the
1986
act
have
been
threatened
as
well
.
<END>
<START>
The
House
seriously
considered
raising
the
top
tax
rate
paid
by
individuals
with
the
highest
incomes
.
<END>

<START>

.

<START>
Denver-based
U
S
West
said
net
income
dropped
8.9
%
,
noting
that
the
year-ago
quarter
included
the
sale
of
a
building
by

BetaWest

.
<END>
<START>

4.3

2.3
billion
from

2.4
billion
,
reflecting
declines
in

,

.
<END>
<START>

a

.

.

.

.

out
by
U.S.
legislators
adds
to
a
confusing
U.S.
performance
that
has
emboldened
Soviet
initiatives
in
Central
America
.
<END>
<START>
On
Oct.
3
,
following
conversations
with
Secretary
of
State
James
Baker
,
Soviet
Foreign
Minister
Eduard
Shevardnadze
arrived
in
Managua
to
acclaim
``
Nicaragua
's
great
peace
efforts
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
also
called
on
Nicaragua
's
neighbors
to
accept
a
``
military
equilibrium
''
guaranteed
by
both
superpowers
.
<END>
<START>
The
Pentagon
claims
that
in
spite
of
Moscow
's
words
,
East
bloc
weapons
continue
to
flow
into
Nicaragua
through
Cuba
at
near-record
levels
.
<END>
<START>
Since
Mr.
Shevardnadze
's
proposals
followed
discussions
with
Mr.
Baker
,
speculations
arose
that
the
Bush
administration
was
seeking
an
accommodation
with
the
Soviets
in
Central
America
.
<END>
<START>
This
scheme
would
fit
the
Arias
Plan
,
which
declared
a
false
symmetry
between
Soviet
military
aid
to
the
Sandinista
dictatorship
and
that
provided
by
Washington
to
freely
elected
governments
.
<END>
<START>
The
sad
condition
of
U.S.
policy
in
Central
America
is
best
depicted
by
the
recent
end
to
U.S.
sponsorship
of
Radio
Costa
Rica
.
<END>
<START>
In
1984
,
the
Costa
Rican
government
requested
help
to
establish
a
radio
station
in
the
northern
part
of
the
country
,
flooded
by
airwaves
of
Sandinista
propaganda
.
<END>
<START>
Recovering
radiophonic
sovereignty
was
the
purpose
of
Radio
Costa
Rica
,
funded
by
the
U.S.
and
affiliated
with
the
Voice
of
America
-LRB-
VOA
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
A
few
months
ago
,
the
Bush
administration
decided
to
stop
this
cooperation
,
leaving
Radio
Costa
Rica
operating
on
a
shoestring
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
news
reports
,
the
abrupt
termination
was
due
to
fears
that
VOA
transmissions
could
interfere
with
the
peace
process
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
meantime
,
Russia
gave
Nicaragua
another
powerful
radio
transmitter
,
which
has
been
installed
in
the
city
of
Esteli
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
capable
of
reaching
the
entire
Caribbean
area
and
deep
into
North
America
.
<END>
<START>
Perhaps
its
loud
signal
may
generate
some
awareness
of
the
Soviet
condominium
being
created
in
the
isthmus
thanks
to
U.S.
default
.
<END>
<START>
The
Soviet
entrenchment
in
Nicaragua
is
alarming
for
Costa
Rica
,
a
peaceful
democracy
without
an
army
.
<END>
<START>
Questioned
in
Washington
about
what
would
happen
if
his
much-heralded
peace
plan
would
fail
,
President
Arias
voiced
expectations
of
direct
U.S.
action
.
<END>
<START>
But
in
the
light
of
events
in
Panama
,
where
the
U.S.
has
such
clear
strategic
interests
,
waiting
for
the
Delta
Force
may
prove
to
be
a
dangerous
gambit
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Daremblum
is
a
lawyer
and
a
columnist
for
La
Nacion
newspaper
.
<END>
<START>
Holiday

,

.

,

,

.

.

.

.

.

<START>
The

Inc.

to
independent

two

,

.

.

,

,

to

.
<END>
<START>

.

.

.

.

,

.

<START>
Banco
Popular
de
Puerto
Rico
and
BanPonce
Corp.
--
agreed
to
merge
in
a
transaction
valued
at
$
324
million
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
agreement
,
BanPonce
stockholders
will
be
able
to
exchange
each
of
their
shares
for
either
shares
in
the
new
entity
or
cash
.
<END>
<START>
In
each
case
,
the
exchange
is
valued
at
$
56.25
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
The
two
companies
,
both
based
in
San
Juan
,
will
form
a
bank
holding
company
with
assets
of
just
over
$
9
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
holding
company
will
be
called
BanPonce
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
The
primary
subsidiary
will
be
the
combined
banking
operations
of
the
two
companies
and
will
be
known
as
Banco
Popular
de
Puerto
Rico
.
<END>
<START>
Rafael
Carrion
Jr.
,
chairman
of
Banco
Popular
,
will
be
the
chairman
of
the
holding
company
.
<END>
<START>
Alberto
M.
Paracchini
,
currently
chairman
of
BanPonce
,
will
serve
as
president
of
the
bank
holding
company
and
chairman
of
the
subsidiary
.
<END>
<START>
Banco
Popular
originally
proposed
the
merger
in
July
,
in
a
cash
and
stock
transaction
valued
at
$
50
a
share
,
or
about
$
293
million
.
<END>
<START>
BanPonce
reacted
cooly
at
first
,
but
appeared
to
be
won
over
,
analysts
said
,
by
Banco
Popular
's
assurances
that
it
wanted
only
a
friendly
transaction
.
<END>
<START>
``
Banco
Popular
just
kept
waiting
,
''
said
Edward
Thompson
,
a
vice
president
and
analyst
at
Thomson
BankWatch
Inc.
in
New
York
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
got
a
transaction
that
's
good
for
both
companies
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
two
banks
appear
to
be
a
good
fit
.
<END>
<START>
BanPonce
caters
to
a
more
affluent
customer
,
while
Banco
Popular
has
always
had
a
large
presence
among
middle-income
and
lower-income
markets
.
<END>
<START>
The
merger
should
also
allow
the
companies
to
reduce
costs
by
combining
operations
in
many
locations
in
Puerto
Rico
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
're
often
right
across
the
street
from
one
another
,
''
Mr.
Thompson
said
.
<END>
<START>
Richard
Carrion
,
who
is
currently
president
and
chief
executive
officer
of
Banco
Popular
,
said
the
merger
will
result
in
a
``
larger
and
stronger
locally
based
bank
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Carrion
,
who
will
now
serve
as
president
and
chief
executive
officer
of
the
subsidiary
bank
,
added
:
``
We
'll
be
able
to
better
compete
with
large
foreign
banks
.
<END>
<START>
It
makes
sense
from
a
strategic
standpoint
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
newly
merged
company
will
have
165
branches
in
Puerto
Rico
and
27
branches
outside
of
the
island
.
<END>
<START>
The
banks
said
they
do
n't
expect
the
merger
to
face
any
regulatory
hurdles
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Carrion
said
the
merger
should
be
completed
in
six
to
nine
months
.
<END>

.

.

's

.

''

.

.

.
''

.

<START>

,

.
