<START>
Union
Pacific
Corp
.
third-quarter
net
income
fell
17
%
.
<END>
<START>
Excluding
earnings
from
discontinued
operations
a
year
earlier
,
net
fell
only
2
%
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
1988
third
quarter
,
profit
from
continuing
operations
totaled
$
140.1
million
.
<END>
<START>
A
year
earlier
,
the
company
had
profit
from
discontinued
operations
of
$
24.9
million
from
sale
of
a
pipeline
,
a
refinery
and
an
interest
in
a
second
refinery
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
rose
2
%
to
$
1.58
billion
from
$
1.54
billion
.
<END>
<START>
In
composite
trading
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
,
Union
Pacific
jumped
$
1.375
to
$
75
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
its
Union
Pacific
Railroad
had
a
3
%
profit
increase
,
despite
a
14
%
rise
in
fuel
costs
and
a
4
%
drop
in
car
loadings
.
<END>
<START>
Most
of
the
commodity
traffic
was
off
,
the
company
said
.
<END>
<START>
Earnings
from
continuing
operations
of
the
Union
Pacific
Resources
unit
almost
doubled
,
the
company
said
.
<END>
<START>
It
added
that
higher
revenue
,
strong
crude
oil
prices
and
higher
natural
gas
prices
offset
declines
in
production
of
oil
,
gas
and
plant
liquids
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
the
company
cited
cost-reduction
moves
and
interest
income
.
<END>
<START>
Earnings
from
Union
Pacific
Realty
dropped
50
%
to
$
3
million
.
<END>
<START>
Before
good
will
,
Overnite
Transportation
earnings
fell
11
%
to
$
15
million
,
Union
Pacific
said
.
<END>
<START>
Profit
from
continuing
operations
in
the
year-earlier
period
was
$
402.7
million
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
was
$
4.75
billion
,
up
6
%
from
$
4.49
billion
.
<END>

<END>

.

.

.

.

.

<START>
First
they
get
us
to
buy
computers
so
we
can
get
more
information
.
<END>
<START>
Then
the
computers
give
us
more
information
than
we
can
ever
read
.
<END>
<START>
Now
they
plan
to
sell
us
products
that
sift
through
all
the
information
to
give
us
what
we
really
want
to
know
.
<END>
<START>
The
products
range
from
computer-edited
,
personal
newsletters
to
systems
that
sit
inside
a
personal
computer
and
pick
stories
on
selected
topics
off
news
wires
.
<END>
<START>
``
Filtered
news
is
what
people
want
,
''
says
Esther
Dyson
,
editor
of
Release
1.0
,
an
industry
newsletter
that
spots
new
developments
.
<END>
<START>
``
Most
people
read
10
times
more
than
necessary
in
order
to
find
out
what
they
really
need
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Goodfellow
has
started
a
Menlo
Park
,
Calif.
,
company
called
Anterior
Technology
that
provides
human
editors
for
public
electronic
networks
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
see
it
as
a
sewage
treatment
plant
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
A
new
product
,
NewsEdge
,
carries
five
business
news
wires
simultaneously
into
a
user
's
computer
and
beeps
and
flashes
whenever
an
article
appears
that
is
of
interest
to
the
user
.
<END>
<START>
The
product
,
developed
by
Desktop
Data
Corp.
,
a
new
company
based
in
Waltham
,
Mass.
,
scans
the
wires
looking
for
articles
that
contain
key
words
specified
by
the
user
.
<END>
<START>
One
early
user
,
David
Semmel
,
a
Chicago
venture
capitalist
and
investor
in
Desktop
Data
,
says
he
uses
it
to
track
takeover
developments
.
<END>
<START>
He
says
he
told
NewsEdge
to
look
for
stories
containing
such
words
as
takeover
,
acquisition
,
acquire
,
LBO
,
tender
,
merger
,
junk
and
halted
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
'm
pretty
confident
I
'm
catching
everything
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
NewsEdge
is
pricey
:
$
7,500
a
year
for
a
limited
version
,
$
40,000
a
year
if
the
cost
of
all
the
news
wires
is
included
.
<END>
<START>
And
it
works
best
in
high-powered
personal
computers
.
<END>
<START>
But
some
investors
and
consultants
who
have
tried
it
are
enthusiastic
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
the
first
time
I
've
seen
something
I
could
imagine
a
lot
of
people
using
.
''
<END>
<START>
NewsEdge
uses
an
FM
radio
band
to
carry
news
wires
provided
by
Reuters
,
McGraw-Hill
and
Dow
Jones
&
Co.
,
as
well
as
PR
Newswire
,
which
carries
corporate
press
releases
.
<END>
<START>
An
FM
receiver
attached
to
a
user
's
personal
computer
receives
the
information
.
<END>
<START>
Some
organizations
have
devised
their
own
systems
to
sort
through
news
wire
items
as
they
come
in
.
<END>
<START>
George
Goodwin
,
an
account
manager
at
Royal
Bank
of
Canada
,
adapted
a
Lotus
Development
Corp.
program
called
Agenda
to
sort
through
international
news
wires
.
<END>
<START>
It
automatically
selects
stories
from
particular
countries
for
reading
by
the
international
bankers
responsible
for
lending
in
those
areas
.
<END>
<START>
For
those
who
do
n't
need
their
personalized
information
moment
by
moment
,
some
services
are
offering
overnight
newsletters
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
are
operating
an
information
refinery
that
takes
a
broad
stream
of
raw
data
and
turns
it
into
actionable
knowledge
,
''
says
Yosi
Amram
,
founder
and
president
.
<END>
<START>
One
early
user
is
NEC
Corp.
's
U.S.
printer
marketing
arm
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
want
the
full
press
releases
on
printer
announcements
by
their
competition
,
''
Mr.
Amram
says
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
tracks
personnel
and
financial
announcements
by
NEC
's
distributors
and
customers
.
<END>
<START>
Individual
Inc.
's
technology
goes
beyond
word
searches
by
using
a
computerized
thesaurus
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
Individual
Inc.
's
computers
can
weigh
the
value
of
an
article
based
on
how
closely
the
story
matches
the
subscriber
's
interest
area
.
<END>
<START>
It
compares
the
position
of
key
words
in
the
story
;
words
in
the
headline
or
first
paragraph
get
a
higher
value
.
<END>
<START>
And
it
calculates
how
often
the
words
appear
in
the
story
compared
with
how
often
they
appear
in
the
entire
data
base
.
<END>
<START>
The
higher
the
ratio
of
hits
to
total
words
,
the
higher
the
presumed
value
to
the
reader
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
computers
find
all
the
key
words
they
can
,
but
the
editors
confirm
every
one
.
<END>
<START>
Computer
picking
is
n't
perfect
,
''
says
Harvey
Golomb
,
president
and
founder
of
Pinpoint
.
<END>
<START>
The
humans
also
write
abstracts
of
articles
from
some
200
computer
industry
publications
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Golomb
says
each
of
his
computers
can
produce
and
send
about
75
unique
newsletters
a
night
.
<END>
<START>
Many
computer
network
users
who
never
see
news
wires
would
like
to
sort
through
their
electronic
mail
automatically
.
<END>
<START>
So-called
E-mail
is
the
collection
of
inter-office
memos
,
gossip
,
technical
data
,
schedules
and
directives
distributed
over
local
and
national
computer
networks
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Digate
says
his
firm
,
Beyond
Inc.
,
has
licensed
technology
known
as
Information
Lens
from
Massachusetts
Institute
of
Technology
and
plans
to
develop
it
for
commercial
use
.
<END>
<START>
The
MIT
project
devised
ways
for
E-mail
to
be
automatically
categorized
as
top
priority
if
it
comes
from
certain
designated
senders
or
requires
action
in
the
next
couple
of
days
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Digate
says
that
Beyond
will
refine
the
product
``
so
the
message
will
be
smart
enough
to
know
to
come
back
and
bother
you
again
next
week
.
''
<END>
<START>
And
if
a
user
is
busy
,
``
he
can
set
it
for
crisis
mode
:
`
Do
n't
bother
me
with
reports
until
Monday
.
'
''
<END>
<START>
A
program
called
Notes
,
which
is
under
development
by
Lotus
,
also
is
designed
to
sort
E-mail
sent
within
work
groups
.
<END>
<START>
One
thing
that
makes
E-mail
difficult
to
sift
through
is
that
each
item
looks
the
same
.
<END>
<START>
Notes
,
which
is
designed
for
advanced
computers
that
display
graphics
,
allows
mail
senders
to
put
different
logos
on
their
mail
.
<END>
<START>
A
daily
news
briefing
from
the
company
librarian
,
for
example
,
would
have
a
distinctive
format
on
the
screen
,
just
as
a
paper
version
would
have
.
<END>
<START>
``
With
E-mail
,
you
do
n't
have
the
visual
clues
of
paper
,
''
says
Mr.
Tarter
,
the
editor
of
SoftLetter
.
<END>
<START>
``
With
Notes
,
they
're
visually
distinct
.
<END>
<START>
Dean
Witter
Reynolds

lost

recent

a

.

<START>
American
Brands
Inc.
said

net
income
rose
13
%
,
reflecting
strong
gains
in
its
tobacco
and
distilled
spirits
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
Year-earlier
results
for
the
quarter
and
the
nine
months
were
restated
to
reflect
a
change
in
accounting
standards
.
<END>
<START>
Operating
profit
for
world-wide
tobacco
products
rose
10
%
to
$
247.6
million
.
<END>
<START>
For
distilled
spirits
,
operating
profit
rose
36
%
,
to
$
24.8
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
year-earlier
period
included
$
40.1
million
,
or
41
cents
a
share
,
from
discontinued
operations
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
rose
to
$
9.03
billion
from
$
8.98
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
number
of
shares
outstanding
rose
2
%
in
the
third
quarter
but
was
down
4
%
for
the
nine
months
.
<END>
<START>
In
composite
trading
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
,
American
Brands
shares
rose
$
1.75
to
$
73
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
is
an
independent
refined-petroleum-products
pipeline
serving
six
Western
states
.

<START>
Missouri
farmer
Blake
Hurst
writing
in
the
fall
issue
of
the
Heritage
Foundation
's
Policy
Review
about
the
proposed

of
a

incinerator
in
his

:
<END>
<START>
Of
course
I
'd
rather
have
a
computer
software
firm
in
my
backyard
than
a
hazardous
waste
incinerator
.
<END>
<START>
But
I
'd
also
rather
live
next
door
to
an
incinerator
than
to
some
of
the
hog
farms
I
've
seen
-LRB-
and
smelt
-RRB-
in
these
parts
.
<END>
<START>
An
incinerator
is
also
probably
better
than
having
nobody
next
door
--
on
our
farm
there
are
four
unoccupied
houses
.
<END>
<START>
On
my
four-mile
drive
to
farm
headquarters
each
morning
,
I
drive
by
another
four
empty
houses
.
<END>
<START>
A
community
of
abandoned
farmsteads
,
failing
businesses
,
and
crumbling
roads
and
bridges
is
hardly
a
desirable
one
...
.
<END>
<START>
After
all
,
farmers
here
work
with
``
hazardous
''
chemicals
every
day
,
many
of
them
the
same
chemicals
that
would
have
been
destroyed
in
the
incinerator
.
<END>
<START>
We
know
they
are
dangerous
,
but
if
handled
with
care
,
their
benefits
far
outweigh
any
risk
to
the
environment
.
<END>
<START>
The
mural
,
now
valued
at
$
1.3
million
according
to
appraisers
,
was
tossed
in
a
trash
heap
in
1971
by
workers
who
were
renovating
the
building
.
<END>
<START>
The
100-foot-long
mural
,
painted
by
James
Daugherty
in
1934
,
was
commissioned
by
the
federal
Works
Project
Administration
.
<END>
<START>
After
the
discarded
mural
was
found
outside
the
school
by
a
concerned
Stamford
graduate
,
it
eventually
was
turned
over
to
Hiram
Hoelzer
,
a
professional
art
restorer
.
<END>
<START>
Throughout
the
1970s
,
Stamford
school
and
city
officials
made
no
effort
to
locate
the
mural
.
<END>
<START>
In
1986
,
Stamford
officials
thanked
Mr.
Hoelzer
for
taking
care
of
the
mural
--
and
demanded
he
return
it
as
soon
as
possible
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Hoelzer
,
however
,
sued
Stamford
,
claiming
that
the
city
had
abandoned
the
artwork
and
that
it
had
waited
too
long
to
reclaim
it
.
<END>
<START>
The
judge
also
ruled
that
the
painting
was
n't
abandoned
because
officials
did
n't
intend
for
it
to
be
thrown
away
and
were
unaware
that
the
workmen
had
discarded
it
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Hoelzer
did
n't
return
phone
calls
seeking
comment
on
the
judge
's
decision
.
<END>
<START>
The
judge
ordered
that
a
hearing
be
held
Nov.
17
to
determine
how
much
the
city
should
pay
Mr.
Hoelzer
for
his
services
.
<END>
<START>
Mary
E.
Sommer
,
corporate
counsel
for
Stamford
,
said
the
city
has
discussed
several
possible
plans
for
displaying
the
mural
,
which
portrays
various
scenes
from
the
Great
Depression
.
<END>
<START>
She
said
the
mural
``
preserves
an
era
in
Stamford
and
in
our
country
when
this
type
of
work
was
being
done
.
<END>
<START>
The
prices
of
corn
futures
contracts
jumped
amid
rumors
that
the
Soviet
Union
is
keeping
up
its
dizzying
October
buying
binge
of
U.S.
corn
.
<END>
<START>
In
trading
at
the
Chicago
Board
of
Trade
,
the
corn
contract
for
December
delivery
jumped
5.75
cents
a
bushel
to
settle
at
$
2.44
a
bushel
.
<END>
<START>
That
pace
is
causing
some
analysts
to
speculate
that
the
Soviet
Union
might
soon
purchase
as
much
as
another
two
million
metric
tons
.
<END>
<START>
One
sign
that
more
Soviet
purchases
are
possible
is
that
U.S.
grain
companies
yesterday
bought
an
unusually
large
amount
of
corn
futures
contracts
.
<END>
<START>
That
sometimes
signals
that
they
are
laying
plans
to
export
corn
.
<END>
<START>
By
some
estimates
,
several
grain
companies
combined
bought
contracts
for
the
possession
of
roughly
one
million
metric
tons
of
corn
.
<END>
<START>
By
buying
futures
contracts
,
these
companies
attempt
to
protect
themselves
from
swings
in
the
price
of
the
corn
that
they
are
obligated
to
deliver
.
<END>
<START>
Rumors
of
Soviet
interest
also
pushed
up
the
prices
of
soybean
futures
contracts
.
<END>
<START>
Among
other
things
,
the
Agriculture
Department
is
widely
thought
to
be
mulling
whether
to
subsidize
the
sale
of
soybean
oil
to
the
Soviet
Union
.
<END>
<START>
The
harvest
delays
,
however
,
are
expected
to
be
temporary
.
<END>
<START>
Balmy
temperatures
are
forecast
for
next
week
,
said
Robert
Lekberg
,
an
analyst
at
Farmers
Grain
&
Livestock
Corp.
,
Chicago
.
<END>
<START>
Many
farmers
used
the
jump
in
prices
to
sell
their
recently
harvested
crop
to
grain
elevator
companies
.
<END>
<START>
The
heavy
selling
by
farmers
helped
to
damp
the
price
rally
.
<END>
<START>
Wheat
futures
prices
rose
slightly
.
<END>
<START>
In
other
commodity
markets
yesterday
:
<END>
<START>
PRECIOUS
METALS
:
<END>
<START>
Futures
prices
declined
.
<END>
<START>
A
number
of
developments
were
negatively
interpreted
by
traders
.
<END>
<START>
December
delivery
gold
fell
$
1.80
an
ounce
to
$
370.60
.
<END>
<START>
December
silver
eased
2.7
cents
an
ounce
to
$
5.133
.
<END>
<START>
January
platinum
was
down
$
3.60
an
ounce
at
$
491.10
.
<END>
<START>
One
price-depressing
development
was
the
lower-than-expected
increase
of
only
0.2
%
in
the
consumer
price
index
for
September
,
an
analyst
said
.
<END>
<START>
He
noted
that
the
``
core
inflation
rate
,
''
which
excludes
food
and
energy
,
was
also
low
at
0.2
%
.
<END>
<START>
Both
are
in
great
need
of
foreign
exchange
,
and
South
Africa
is
also
under
pressure
to
meet
foreign
loan
commitments
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
Putting
it
all
together
,
we
have
a
negative
scenario
that
does
n't
look
like
it
will
improve
overnight
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
COPPER
:
<END>
<START>
Futures
prices
recovered
in
quiet
trading
.
<END>
<START>
The
December
contract
rose
1.50
cents
a
pound
to
$
1.2795
.
<END>
<START>
In
recent
days
,
however
,
there
has
been
increased
purchasing
of
copper
in
London
,
an
analyst
said
.
<END>
<START>
ENERGY
:
<END>
<START>
Crude
oil
prices
ended
mixed
.
<END>
<START>
West
Texas
Intermediate
for
November
delivery
fell
14
cents
a
barrel
to
$
20.42
.
<END>
<START>
But
so-called
outer
month
contracts
finished
higher
.
<END>
<START>
For
instance
,
December
contracts
for
WTI
rose
17
cents
to
$
20.42
.
<END>
<START>
Most
energy
futures
opened
lower
,
following
Wednesday
's
market
downturn
.
<END>
<START>
But
a
flurry
of
late
trading
yesterday
beefed
up
prices
.
<END>
<START>
Heating
oil
and
gasoline
futures
ended
higher
as
well
.
<END>
<START>
Melvin
Belli
's
San
Francisco
law
offices
may
have
been
the
epicenter
of
legal
activity
after
Tuesday
's
earthquake
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
first
25
minutes
after
his
office
's
telephone
service
was
restored
yesterday
morning
,
17
potential
clients
had
called
seeking
the
services
of
the
self-proclaimed
King
of
Torts
.
<END>
<START>
Suits
are
likely
to
be
filed
against
engineering
firms
,
contractors
and
developers
,
as
well
as
against
local-government
agencies
.
<END>
<START>
But
lawyers
looking
to
cash
in
on
the
quake
may
have
a
tough
time
once
their
cases
reach
a
judge
.
<END>
<START>
Experts
on
California
tort
law
say
protections
afforded
government
agencies
in
such
cases
are
pretty
ironclad
.
<END>
<START>
Even
claims
against
individuals
and
companies
face
significant
roadblocks
.
<END>
<START>
The
major
legal
barrier
is
the
principle
that
no
one
can
be
held
liable
for
an
``
act
of
God
.
''
<END>
<START>
We
still
have
people
wandering
around
in
a
daze
in
San
Francisco
worrying
about
whether
it
's
going
to
rain
tonight
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
that
wo
n't
stop
plaintiffs
'
lawyers
from
seeking
a
little
room
for
maneuvering
.
<END>
<START>
In
San
Francisco
,
they
argue
,
an
earthquake
was
a
near
certainty
.
<END>
<START>
``
My
prediction
is
there
will
be
mass
litigation
over
errors
and
omissions
in
engineering
and
contracting
,
''
says
Stanley
Chesley
,
a
well-known
Cincinnati
plaintiffs
lawyer
.
<END>
<START>
He
adds
that
``
they
were
aware
of
the
propensity
for
earthquakes
and
the
San
Andreas
Fault
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
flamboyant
and
publicity-conscious
Mr.
Belli
says
he
already
has
investigators
looking
into
who
could
be
held
liable
for
the
damage
on
the
Bay
Bridge
and
the
interstate
approaching
it
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
wo
n't
know
until
the
smoke
clears
--
but
yes
,
we
're
looking
into
it
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Belli
says
he
wants
to
know
whether
state
or
federal
engineers
or
private
companies
could
have
prevented
the
damage
.
<END>
<START>
Plaintiffs
,
he
says
,
will
argue
that
damaged
structures
were
n't
built
to
proper
design
standards
.
<END>
<START>
But
if
defendants
can
prove
that
they
met
San
Francisco
's
stringent
building
codes
,
``
that
's
probably
going
to
protect
them
,
''
Mr.
Ruvolo
says
.
<END>
<START>
Government
entities
,
continues
Mr.
Ruvolo
,
could
be
protected
by
the
California
Government
Tort
Liability
Act
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
statute
,
agencies
are
provided
``
defenses
that
normally
are
n't
available
in
the
private
sector
,
''
Mr.
Ruvolo
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
legislature
does
not
want
to
inhibit
the
unique
government
activities
by
exposing
public
entities
to
liability
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
state
is
protected
when
plans
and
designs
for
public
structures
were
approved
ahead
of
time
or
when
structures
met
previously
approved

,
says
Mr.
Covert
.
<END>
<START>
He
believes
those
defenses
might
well
apply
to
the
Bay
Bridge
collapse
.
<END>
<START>
Nevertheless
,
he
adds
,
``
I
would
n't
get

if
we
get
lawsuits
out

the
Bay

.
''
<END>
<START>
If
there
's
going

be
a
race
to
the

,

has
n't

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Covert

to

yesterday
,

.

<START>
Wednesday

.

<START>

.

<START>

,

.

.
<END>
<START>
What
's
in
a
name
?
<END>
<START>
Apparently
a
lot
,
according
to
the
British
firm
of
Deloitte
,
Haskins
&
Sells
.
<END>
<START>
The
British
Deloitte
firm
recently
withdrew
from
the
merger
of
Deloitte
and
Touche
world-wide
and
joined
Coopers
&
Lybrand
.
<END>
<START>
John
Bullock
,
senior
partner
of
Deloitte
in
the
U.K.
,
said
``
the
decision
to
start
these
proceedings
has
n't
been
taken
lightly
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bullock
said
the
British
firm
has
used
the
name
``
Deloitte
''
since
1845
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
U.S.
,
Deloitte
,
Haskins
&
Sells
was
known
as
Haskins
&
Sells
until
1978
,
when
it
added
the
``
Deloitte
''
name
of
its
British
affiliate
.
<END>
<START>
Although
accountants
are
n't
noted
as
``
being
deeply
emotional
,
they
really
hold
it
all
in
,
''
said
Mr.
Burton
,
former
chief

of
the

and
Exchange
Commission
.
<END>
<START>
J.
Michael
Cook
,

of

,
Haskins
&
Sells
International
,
said
he
believes
the
legal
action
by
the
British
firm
``
to
be
without
merit
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Cook
said
that
last
June
,
the
international
executive
committes
of
Deloitte
and
Touche
agreed
to
a

.
<END>
<START>
``
The
merger
is
proceeding
according
to
plan
,
except
as
to
the
withdrawal
of
the
Deloitte
U.K.
firm
,
''

.
<END>
<START>
Partners
at
other

say
that
the
Deloitte
firm
in
the
U.K.
is
filing
the
suit
to
get
even
with
the
merged
Deloitte-Touche
firm
for
keeping
major

work
in
England
.
<END>
<START>
In
England
,
this
would
mean
that
the
British
Deloitte
would
lose

for
its
audit
of
GM
's
Vauxhill
unit
.
<END>
<START>
The
defection
of
Deloitte
's

in
Britain
and
the
Netherlands
to
Coopers
&
Lybrand
will
make
Coopers
one
of
the
biggest

firms
in
Europe
,
rivaling
KPMG
Peat
Marwick
there
.
<END>
<START>
Although
Coopers
has
n't
been
courted
by
other
major
accounting
firms
for
a
merger
,
it
is
benefiting
greatly
from
fallout
from
the
Deloitte-Touche
merger
.
<END>
<START>
In

,
Harris
Amhowitz
,

of

,
said

``
was
aware
of
the

,
''
but

.
<END>
<START>

UK

.
<END>
<START>
Coopers
uses
the
Coopers
&
Lybrand
name
world-wide
.
<END>
<START>
William
Bennett
,
the
White
House
drug-policy
director
,
accused
local
officials
in
the
Washington
area
of
blocking
construction
of

to
house

.
<END>
<START>
Without

to

,
he

,
``
we
will
not

.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bennett
declared

that

a
``

''
for
how

Bush

would

.
<END>
<START>

here
,
``

.
''
<END>
<START>

,

,

``

is

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
Drugs

,

.

<END>
<START>

.

,

that

have

375

.

<START>

lent

10

,

Federal

of
Investigation

and

,

.
<END>
<START>
What
if
it
happened
to
us
?
<END>
<START>
In
the
wake
of
the
earthquake
in
California
and
the
devastation
of
Hurricane
Hugo
,
many
companies
in
disaster-prone
areas
are
pondering
the
question
of
preparedness
.
<END>
<START>
Some
,
particularly
in
West
Coast
earthquake
zones
,
are
dusting
off
their
evacuation
plans
,
checking
food
stocks
and
reminding
employees
of
what
to
do
if
emergency
strikes
.
<END>
<START>
Others
say
they
feel
confident
that
steps
they
've
already
taken
would
see
them
through
a
disaster
.
<END>
<START>
Preparedness
involves
more
than
flashlights
and
fire
alarms
these
days
.
<END>
<START>
Some
big
companies
have
teams
of
in-house
experts
focusing
on
safety
and
business
resumption
.
<END>
<START>
Many
companies
in
the
path
of
potential
disaster
have
set
up
contingency
offices
in
safe
regions
,
hoping
they
can
transport
employees
there
and
resume
operations
quickly
.
<END>
<START>
That
means
making
sure
that
copies
of
vital
computer
software
and
company
records
are
out
of
harm
's
way
.
<END>
<START>
``
Self-sufficiency
has
to
be
the
cornerstone
of
your
plan
,
''
says
Stephanie
Masaki-Schatz
,
manager
of
corporate
emergency
planning
at
Atlantic
Richfield
Co.
in
Los
Angeles
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
you
do
n't
save
your
critical
people
,
you
wo
n't
be
able
to
bring
up
your
vital
business
functions
.
''
<END>
<START>
``
You
need
to
capitalize
on
these
moments
when
you
have
everyone
's
attention
,
''
she
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
was
a
good
reminder
that
we
all
need
to
prepare
prior
to
an
event
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
ARCO
memo
urges
employees
to
keep
certain
supplies
at
work
,
such
as
solid
shoes
and
``
heavy
gloves
to
clear
debris
.
''
<END>
<START>
It
also
recommends
that
employees
be
aware
of
everyday
office
items
that
could
be
used
for
emergency
care
or
shelter
.
<END>
<START>
Among
the
suggestions
:
Pantyhose
and
men
's
ties
could
be
used
for
slings
,
while
removable
wooden
shelves
might
aid
in
``
breaking
through
office
walls
.
''
<END>
<START>
ARCO
maintains
an
office
in
Dallas
that
would
take
over
if
payroll
operations
in
Pasadena
were
disrupted
.
<END>
<START>
The
ARCO
plan
takes
into
account
such
details
as
which
aspects
of
business
are
busier
at
certain
times
of
the
year
.
<END>
<START>
This
way
,
depending
on
when
a
quake
might
strike
,
priorities
can
be
assigned
to
departments
that
should
be
brought
back
on
line
first
.
<END>
<START>
At
Hewlett-Packard
Co.
,
the
earthquake
came
just
as
the
company
was
reviewing
its
own
emergency
procedures
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
were
talking
about
scheduling
a
practice
drill
for
November
,
''

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
''

.

<START>
MAITRE'D
CLAIMS
in
suit
that
restaurant
fired
her
because
she
was
pregnant
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
suit
filed
in
state
court
in
Manhattan
,
the
American
Civil
Liberties
Union
is
representing
the
former
maitre
'd
of
the
chic
Odeon
restaurant
.
<END>
<START>
The
suit
,
which
seeks
compensatory
and
punitive
damages
of
$
1
million
,
alleges
that
the
firing
of
Marcia
Trees
Levine
violated
New
York
state
's
human-rights
law
.
<END>
<START>
Among
other
things
,
the
law
prohibits
discrimination
on
the
basis
of
sex
and
pregnancy
.
<END>
<START>
The
suit
alleges
that
Ms.
Levine
was
fired
after
she
refused
to
accept
a
lower
paying
,
less
visible
job
upon
reaching
her
sixth
month
of
pregnancy
.
<END>
<START>
Kary
Moss
,
an
attorney
with
the
ACLU
's
Women
's
Rights
Project
,
said
,
``
They
wanted
a
svelte-looking
woman
,
and
a
pregnant
woman
is
not
svelte
.
<END>
<START>
They
told
her
,
`
We
do
n't
hire
fat
people
and
we
do
n't
hire
cripples
.
<END>
<START>
And
pregnant
women
are
fat
.
'
''
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Moss
said
Ms.
Levine
secretly
taped
many
conversations
with
her
bosses
at
the
Odeon
in
which
they
told
her
she
was
being
fired
as
maitre
'd
because
she
was
pregnant
.
<END>
<START>
Paul
H.
Aloe
,
an
attorney
for
Odeon
owner
Keith
McNally
,
denied
the
allegations
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
Ms.
Levine
had
never
been
fired
,
although
she
had
stopped
working
at
the
restaurant
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Aloe
said
the
Odeon
``
has
no
policy
against
hiring
pregnant
people
.
''
<END>
<START>
LAWYERS
IN
Texas
's
biggest
bank-fraud
case
want
out
in
face
of
retrial
.
<END>
<START>
Lawyers
representing
five
of
the
seven
defendants
in
the
case
say
their
clients
can
no
longer
afford
their
services
.
<END>
<START>
The
trial
of
the
case
lasted
seven
months
and
ended
in
September
with
a
hung
jury
.
<END>
<START>
The
defense
lawyers
,
three
of
whom
are
solo
practitioners
,
say
they
ca
n't
afford
to
put
their
law
practices
on
hold
for
another
seven-month
trial
.
<END>
<START>
Some
of
the
lawyers
say
they
would
continue
to
represent
their
clients
if
the
government
pays
their
tab
as
court-appointed
lawyers
.
<END>
<START>
Assistant
U.S.
Attorney
Terry
Hart
of
Dallas
says
the
government
will
oppose
any
efforts
to
bring
in
a
new
defense
team
because
it
would
delay
a
retrial
.

<START>
New
York
Times
Co.
's
third-quarter
earnings
report
is
reinforcing
analysts
'
belief
that
newspaper
publishers
will
be
facing
continued
poor
earnings
comparisons
through
1990
.
<END>
<START>
The
publisher
was
able
to
register
soaring
quarter
net
income
because
of
a
onetime
gain
on
the
sale
of
its
cable-TV
system
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
operating
profit
fell
35
%
to
$
16.4
million
.
<END>
<START>
In
composite
trading
on
the
American
Stock
Exchange
,
New
York
Times
closed
at
$
28.125
a
share
,
down
37.5
cents
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
said
the
company
's
troubles
mirror
those
of
the
industry
.
<END>
<START>
Retail
advertising
,
which
often
represents
half
of
the
advertising
volume
at
most
daily
newspapers
,
largely
is
n't
rebounding
in
the
second
half
from
extended
doldrums
as
expected
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
same
time
,
newspapers
are
bedeviled
by
lagging
national
advertising
,
especially
in
its
financial
component
.
<END>
<START>
Dow
Jones
&
Co.
recently
reported
net
fell
9.9
%
,
a
reflection
,
in
part
,
of
continued
softness
in
financial
advertising
at
The
Wall
Street
Journal
and
Barron
's
magazine
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
expect
next
year
to
be
a
fairly
soft
year
in
newspaper-industry
advertising
,
''
said
John
Morton
,
an
analyst
for
Lynch
,
Jones
&
Ryan
.
<END>
<START>
``
Next
year
,
earnings
will
hold
steady
,
but
we
just
do
n't
see
a
big
turnaround
in
the
trend
in
advertising
.
''
<END>
<START>
John
S.
Reidy
,

Drexel
Burnham
Lambert
Inc.
,
said
,
``
The
Times
faces
the
same
problem
of
other
publishers
:
linage
is
down
.
<END>
<START>
It
will
be
hard
to
do
handstands
until
real
linage
starts
heading
back
up
.
''
<END>
<START>

,
Arthur

,

Times
Co.

and

,

.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
agreed
with

that
operating

will

down
this
year
and
in
1990
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.

said

new

plant
in
Edison
,
N.J.
,
in
1990
would

heavy

costs
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
many
newspapers
are
facing
similar
comparisons
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
sale
of
the
company
's
cable
franchise
brought
an
after-tax
gain

$
193.3

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
Drexel

``
profits

.
<END>
<START>
That
's
a

sign
when

.
<END>
<START>
Investors
celebrated
the
second
anniversary
of
Black
Monday
with
a
buying
spree
in
both
stocks
and
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
dollar
was
mixed
.
<END>
<START>
Stock
and
bond
investors
were
cheered
by
last
month
's
encouragingly
low
inflation
rate
.
<END>
<START>
This
news
raised
hopes
for
further
interest-rate
cuts
.
<END>
<START>
Treasury-bond
prices
immediately
rallied
,
setting
the
stock
market
rolling
from
the
opening
bell
.
<END>
<START>
The
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
,
up
about
60
points
in
mid-afternoon
,
finished
with
a
gain
of
39.55
points
,
to
2683.20
.
<END>
<START>
That
brought
the
average
's
cumulative
gain
this
week
to
about
114
points
.
<END>
<START>
Since
the
1987
crash
,
the
industrials
have
soared
more
than
54
%
,
and
the
widely
watched
market
barometer
is
about
4
%
below
its
record
high
set
earlier
this
month
.
<END>
<START>
The
stock-market
rally
was
led
by
blue-chip
issues
,
but
,
unlike
Monday
's
rebound
,
was
broadly
based
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
over-the-counter
stocks
,
led
by
technology
issues
,
outleaped
the
industrial
average
.
<END>
<START>
The
Nasdaq
Composite
Index
soared
7.52
,
or
1.6
%
,
to
470.80
,
its
highest
one-day
jump
in
points
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Many
takeover-related
stocks
rose
after
news
that
a
group
obtained
financing
commitments
for
the
proposed
buy-out
of
American
Medical
International
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
Among
the
biggest
winners
were
brokerage-house
stocks
,
responding
to
heavy
trading
volume
.
<END>
<START>
The
government
said
consumer
prices
rose
only
0.2
%
last
month
.
<END>
<START>
Economists
expected
twice
as
large
an
increase
.
<END>
<START>
Fed
officials
probably
wo
n't
drive
down
rates
immediately
,
Mr.
Keith
said
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
the
inflation
news
,
several
Fed
officials
still
fear
consumer-price
pressures
will
intensify
because
they
insist
the
economy
is
stronger
than
generally
believed
.
<END>
<START>
But
Wall
Street
analysts
expect
further
signs
of
economic
weakness
in
government
reports
during
the
next
few
weeks
.
<END>
<START>
If
so
,
that
will
cinch
the
case
for
another
shot
of
credit-easing
within
a
month
or
so
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're
not
out
of
the
woods
yet
by
any
means
,
''
said
George
R.
Mateyo
,
president
and
chief
executive
of
Carnegie
Capital
Management
Co.
,
Cleveland
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
economy
``
is
slowing
enough
to
give
the
Federal
Reserve
leeway
to
reduce
interest
rates
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
many
individual
investors
are
leery
about
stocks
because
of
fresh
signs
of
fragility
in
the
huge
junk-bond
market
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
also
are
anxious
about
today
's
``
witching
hour
,
''
the
monthly
expiration
of
stock-index
futures
and
options
,
and
options
on
individual
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
This
phenomenon
often
makes
stock
prices
swing
wildly
at
the
end
of
the
trading
session
.
<END>
<START>
In
major
market
activity
:
Stock
prices
surged
in
heavy
trading
.
<END>
<START>
Volume
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
rose
to
198.1
million
shares
from
166.9
million
Wednesday
.
<END>
<START>
Gaining
Big
Board
issues
outnumbered
decliners
by
1,235
to
355
.
<END>
<START>
The
dollar
was
mixed
.
<END>
<START>
In
New
York
late
yesterday
,
it
was
at
141.70
yen
,
up
from
141.45
yen
late
Wednesday
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
fell
to
1.8470
marks
from
1.8485
.
<END>
<START>
Now
that
percentage
routinely
equals
a
third
and
twice
has
been
above
40
%
.
<END>
<START>
As
we
know
,
voters
tend
to
favor
Republicans
more
in
races
for
president
than
in
those
for
Congress
.
<END>
<START>
Prior
to
1932
,
the
pattern
was
nearly
the
opposite
.
<END>
<START>
What
accounts
for
the
results
of
recent
decades
?
<END>
<START>
A
simple
economic
theory
may
provide
at
least
a
partial
explanation
for
the
split
personality
displayed
by
Americans
in
the
voting
booth
.
<END>
<START>
The
theory
relies
on
three
assumptions
:
<END>
<START>
3
-RRB-
Republican
congressional
representatives
,
because
of
their
belief
in
a
minimalist
state
,
are
less
willing
to
engage
in
local
benefit-seeking
than
are
Democratic
members
of
Congress
.
<END>
<START>
Each
legislator
,
after
all
,
is
only
one
out
of
535
when
it
comes
to
national
policy
making
.
<END>
<START>
In
races
for
the
White
House
,
a
voter
's
incentive
,
at
the
margin
,
is
to
lean
Republican
.
<END>
<START>
The
individual
voter
's
standing
consequently
will
be
enhanced
through
lower
taxes
.
<END>
<START>
While
this
theory
is
exceedingly
simple
,
it
appears
to
explain
several
things
.
<END>
<START>
Third
,
the
theory
suggests
why
legislators
who
pay
too
much
attention
to
national
policy
making
relative
to
local
benefit-seeking
have
lower
security
in
office
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
first-term
members
of
the
House
,
once
the
most
vulnerable
of
incumbents
,
have
become
virtually
immune
to
defeat
.
<END>
<START>
The
one
exception
to
this
recent
trend
was
the
defeat
of
13
of
the
52
freshman
Republicans
brought
into
office
in
1980
by
the
Reagan
revolution
and
running
for
re-election
in
1982
.
<END>
<START>
Because
these
freshmen
placed
far
more
emphasis
on
their
partisan
role
--
spreading
the
Reagan
revolution
--
in
national
policy
making
,
they
were
more
vulnerable
to
defeat
.
<END>
<START>
Fourth
,
the
theory
indicates
why
the
Republican
Party
may
have
a
difficult
time
attracting
viable
candidates
for
congressional
office
.
<END>
<START>
Potential
candidates
may
be
discouraged
from
running
less
by
the
congressional
salary
than
by
the
prospect
of
defeat
at
the
hands
of
a
Democratic
opponent
.
<END>
<START>
Fifth
,
the
theory
may
provide
at
least
a
partial
reason
for
why
ticket
splitting
has
been
particularly
pronounced
in
the
South
.
<END>
<START>
Finally
,
the
theory
suggests
why
Republicans
generally
have
fared
better
in
Senate
races
than
in
campaigns
for
the
House
.
<END>
<START>
Is
there
any
empirical
support
for
this
theory
?
<END>
<START>
Three
pieces
of
evidence
corroborate
the
key
assumption
that
Democratic
legislators
are
more
willing
to
engage
in
local
benefit-seeking
than
their
Republican
colleagues
.
<END>
<START>
First
,

James

that
GOP

turn
back

10
%

than

do
.
<END>
<START>

the

of

involves
local

,
this
indicates
that
political

leads

to
pay
less

to

.
<END>
<START>
This

what
the
data
indicate
,

House
.
<END>
<START>
The

rate
has

.
<END>
<START>

than

when

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.

.

.
<END>
<START>
A
good
place
to
start
the
rehabilitation
is
a
``
legislative
line-item
veto
''
bill
now
being
offered
by
Indiana
Senator
Dan
Coats
.
<END>
<START>
The
Coats
bill
,
which
already
has
32
Senate
co-sponsors
,
is
n't
a
pure
line-item
veto
because
it
would
apply
only
to
spending
bills
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
it
's
a
form
of
``
enhanced
rescission
,
''
giving
a
President
a
chance
to
rescind
,
or
strike
,
specific
spending
items
that
just
go
too
far
.
<END>
<START>
Congress
would
have
20
days
to
reject
the
package
with
a
50
%
majority
,
but
then
a
President
could
veto
that
rejection
.
<END>
<START>
Congress
would
then
need
the
usual
two-thirds
majority
to
override
any
veto
.
<END>
<START>
The
proposal
would
restore
some
discipline
erased
from
the
budget
process
by
the
1974
Budget
``
Reform
''
Act
.
<END>
<START>
Before
1974
,
a
President
could
``
impound
,
''
or
refuse
to
spend
,
funds
appropriated
by
Congress
.
<END>
<START>
Presidents
Kennedy
and
Johnson
were
both
big
users
of
the
impoundment
power
,
but
Congress
saw
its
chance
against
a
weakened
President
Nixon
and
stripped
it
away
.
<END>
<START>
Today
a
President
can
still
send
up
spending
rescissions
,
but
they
're
meaningless
unless
Congress
has
a
guilty
conscience
and
changes
its
mind
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
like
asking
foxes
to
feel
remorse
about
chickens
,
and
naturally
rescissions
are
almost
never
approved
.
<END>
<START>
In
1987
,
President
Reagan
sent
73
rescissions
back
to
the
Hill
,
but
only
3
%
of
the
spending
total
was
approved
by
Congress
.
<END>
<START>
Senator
Coats
's
proposal
would
let
the
proposed
spending
cuts
take
place
automatically
unless
Congress
acts
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Coats
plans
to
offer
his
proposal
as
an
amendment
to
a
bill
to
raise
the
federal
debt
limit
before
the
end
of
the
month
.
<END>
<START>
President
Bush
has
endorsed
the
idea
,
and
at
least
50
sitting
Senators
have
voted
to

enhanced

in
the
past
.
<END>
<START>
We

<START>
Is
an
American
Secretary
of
State
seriously
suggesting
that
the
Khmer
Rouge
should
help
govern
Cambodia
?
<END>
<START>
Apparently
so
.
<END>
<START>
The
coalition
would
include
the
current
Vietnamese-backed
Hun
Sen
regime
,
the
two
non-communist
resistance
groups
led
by
Son
Sann
and
Prince
Sihanouk
,
and
the
Khmer
Rouge
.
<END>
<START>
The
aim
would
be
to
end
the
guerrilla
war
for
control
of
Cambodia
by
allowing
the
Khmer
Rouge
a
small
share
of
power
.
<END>
<START>
The
State
Department
says
that
any
Khmer
Rouge
participation
would
have
to
be
``
minimal
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
usual
problem
with
including
communists
in
``
interim
''
coalition
governments
is
that
their
ideology
and
methods
require
they
squeeze
out
everyone
else
.
<END>
<START>
Recall
that
Nicaragua
's
Sandinistas
came
into
Managua
as
partners
in
a
coalition
government
with
anti-Somoza
moderates
.
<END>
<START>
In
Laos
,
when
the
Western
powers
bowed
to
pressure
for
such
a
coalition
it
turned
out
they
were
opening
the
door
to
communist
domination
.
<END>
<START>
Even
Mao
Tse-tung
's
China
began
in
1949
with
a
partnership
between
the
communists
and
a
number
of
smaller
,
non-communist
parties
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
not
clear
which
crew
of
communists
might
prevail
in
a
coalition
government
,
but
the
one
good
bet
is
that
the
non-communists
would
disappear
.
<END>
<START>
That
would
leave
Hun
Sen
and
the
Khmer
Rouge
.
<END>
<START>
The
Hun
Sen
regime
has
sent
thousands
of
conscript
laborers
to
die
of
malaria
and

while
building
Cambodia
's
equivalent
of
the
Berlin
Wall
near
the
Thai
border
.
<END>
<START>
The
Khmer
Rouge
,
however
,
carry
an
unsurpassed
record
for
Cambodian
tyranny
.
<END>
<START>
These
utopians
caused
the
deaths
--
by
starvation
,
disease
or
execution
--
of
well
over
one
million
Cambodians
.
<END>
<START>
The
Cambodian
horror
was
so
bad
that
the
Vietnamese
occupation
in
1978
was
a
perverse
form
of
relief
.
<END>
<START>
But
there
is
no

Rouge
have

.
<END>
<START>

COKE
ADS
:
<END>
<START>
Coca-Cola
Co.
said
it
produced
a
new
version
of
its
1971
``
I
'd
like
to
teach
the
world
to
sing
''
commercial
.
<END>
<START>
The
ad
is
part
of
Classic
Coke
's
1990
ad
campaign
,
with
the
tag
line
,
``
Ca
n't
beat
the
Real
Thing
.
''
<END>
<START>
Basketball
star
Michael
Jordan
and
singer
Randy
Travis
have
also
agreed
to
appear
in
ads
.
<END>
<START>
Earnings
for
fiscal
1989
were
$
14.4
million
,
or
80
cents
a
share
,
on
sales
of
$
257.8
million
.
<END>
<START>
Results
for
the
third
quarter
ending
Oct.
31
,
are
expected
to
be
released
the
third
week
of
November
,
according
to
Michael
Dell
,
chairman
and
chief
executive
officer
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Dell
said
he
does
n't
expect
a
loss
in
either
the
third
or
fourth
quarter
,
but
said
third-quarter
earnings
could
be
as
low
as
four
cents
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
third
quarter
last
year
,
Dell
had
net
income
of
$
5
million
,
or
26
cents
a
share
,
on
sales
of
$
75.2
million
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Dell
attributed
the
earnings
slide
to
new
product
delays
,
such
as
a
laptop
scheduled
for
September
that
wo
n't
be
introduced
until
early
November
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Dell
,
meanwhile
,
concedes
the
company
was
``
definitely
too
optimistic
''
in
its
expectations
.
<END>
<START>
The
result
has
been
thinner
margins
,
which
have
been
further
eroded
by
an
ambitious
research
and
development
effort
and
rapid
overseas
expansion
.
<END>
<START>
In
national
over-the-counter
trading
,
Dell
closed
yesterday
at
$
6
a
share
,
down
87.5
cents
.
<END>

<START>
Schlumberger
Ltd.
,
New
York
,
reported
third-quarter
net
income
edged
up
as
growth
in
its
oil-field
services
sector
offset
a
decline
in
interest
income
.
<END>
<START>
The
lower
interest
income
occurred
because
Schlumberger
spent
$
1.2
billion
buying
back
its
stock
last
year
.
<END>
<START>
Per-share
earnings
advanced
14
%
because
of
the
buy-back
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
declined
6.3
%
to
$
1.11
billion
from
$
1.18
billion
.
<END>
<START>
But
excluding
businesses
acquired
or
sold
,
revenue
was
flat
at
about
$
1.24
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Nine-month
net
fell
9.5
%
to
$
323.4
million
,
or
$
1.36
a
share
,
from
$
357.2
million
,
or
$
1.32
a
share
,
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
dropped
5.4
%
to
$
3.48
billion
from
$
3.68
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
year-earlier
nine
months
include
a
gain
of
$
35
million
,
or
13
cents
a
share
,
from
sale
of
the
company
's
Electricity
Control
&
Transformers
division
.

<START>
Few
specialists
said
they
expect
the
quake
to
have
much
of
an
effect
on
most
California
property
values
.
<END>
<START>
But
real-estate
experts
and
brokers
said
the
quake
undoubtedly
will
drag
down
prices
in
neighborhoods
built
on
less
stable
ground
,
especially
in
the
Bay
Area
.
<END>
<START>
``
California
prices
were
already
coming
down
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
n't
going
to
help
,
''
said
Kenneth
T.
Rosen
,
chairman
of
the
Center
for
Real
Estate
and
Urban
Economics
at
the
University
of
California
at
Berkeley
.
<END>
<START>
State
housing
prices
,
at
a
median
$
201,028
,
have
declined
in
recent
months
because
of
potential
buyers
'
inability
to
afford
homes
.
<END>
<START>
One
San
Francisco
neighborhood
likely
to
test
Mr.
Rosen
's
theory
soon
is
the
city
's
fashionable
Marina
district
,
which
boasts
some
of
the
highest
home
prices
in
the
state
.
<END>
<START>
The
district
,
built
on
landfill
,
suffered
heavy
quake
damage
,
including
collapsed
buildings
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
,
the
city
demolished
two
dwellings
in
the
district
because
of
severe
structural
damage
and
said
as
many
as
19
of
the
district
's
350
dwellings
might
have
to
be
razed
.
<END>
<START>
Brokers
agreed
with
the
two-tier
price
theory
.
<END>
<START>
``
My
gut
feeling
is
that
the
Marina
properties
will
be
affected
,
''
said
Grace
Perkins
,
senior
vice
president
at
Grubb
&
Ellis
Residential
Brokerage
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Rosen
said
the
quake
will
revive
consumer
interest
in
a
little-publicized
1972
state
law
that
requires
brokers
to
disclose
to
potential
buyers
how
close
a
property
sits
to
a
fault
line
.
<END>
<START>

of

size
of

California

,

.

.

<START>
Aussedat
Rey
is
a
leading
French
maker
of
copying
and
electronic
printing
paper
.
<END>
<START>
Thermal
paper
is
used
in
facsimile
machines
.
<END>
<START>
Terms
of
the
agreement
were
n't
disclosed
.
<END>
<START>
Aussedat
Rey
's
move
follows
similar
technology-licensing
agreements
between
Japanese
producers
of
thermal
paper
and
European
paper
groups
.
<END>
<START>
Net
income
rose
to
$
97.9
million
,
or
$
1.15
a
share
,
from
$
50.5
million
,
or
60
cents

,

earlier
.
<END>
<START>

increased
7
%

1.49
billion
from

.

<START>

,

.

.

Doman

<START>
The
Canadian
government
introduced
in
the
House
of
Commons
legislation
to
extend
federal
regulatory
authority
over
provincial
government-owned
telephone
utilities
in
Alberta
,
Saskatchewan
and
Manitoba
.
<END>
<START>
The
legislation
would
open
the
way
for
more
telephone
services
and
more
competition
in
the
telephone
business
in
the
three
provinces
,
federal
officials
said
.
<END>
<START>
Prior
to
the
ruling
the
federal
government
had
regulated
only
the
telephone
companies
in
Quebec
,
Ontario
,
British
Columbia
and
the
Northwest
Territories
.
<END>
<START>
The
governments
of
Alberta
,
Saskatchewan
and
Manitoba
have
strongly
opposed
federal
regulation
of
their
telephone
companies
.
<END>
<START>
The
extension
of
federal
regulatory
authority
over
telephone
utilities
in
the
Atlantic
provinces
has
n't
required
special
legislation
because
they
are
investor-owned
.
<END>

<START>
Three
savings-and-loan
institutions
in
Kansas
and
Texas
were
added
to
the
Resolution
Trust
Corp.
's
conservatorship
program
after

insolvent
and

their

.
<END>

,

and

were

to

.

three
insolvent

will
maintain
normal

hours
and
operations
under
RTC-appointed
managing
agents
,
while
the
RTC
tries
to
negotiate
permanent
resolutions
.

<START>
Separately
,
Century
Bank
,

,

,
was
closed
by
Arizona

officials
.
<END>
<START>

Federal
Deposit
Insurance
Corp.
approved
the

of
Century
's

and

by

of

,

.

,

bank
's
five
offices
will
reopen
today
.
<END>
<START>

failed
bank
had
assets
of
about
$
129.6
million
.
<END>
<START>

newly

bank
will

about

125.7
million
in
10,300

and

a

of
$
2.9

.

91.7

of

,

will

$
31.8
million
to

.

<START>
International
Business
Machines
Corp.
and
MCA
Inc.
said
they
agreed
to
sell
their
Discovision
Associates
joint
venture
to
U.S.
units
of
Pioneer
Electronic
Corp.
for
$
200
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
joint
venture
licenses
a
portfolio
of
about
1,400
patents
and
patent
applications
relating
to
optical-disk
recording
technology
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
and
MCA
formed
Discovision
in
1979
to
make
laser-read
optical
products
.
<END>
<START>
But
the

did
n't

was

.
<END>
<START>
After
reportedly

$
100
million
in
the
business
,
Discovision
ceased
manufacturing
operations
in
1982
and
sold
many
of

to

Pioneer
,

others
.
<END>
<START>
Discovision
now

with
major
manufacturers
covering

audio
disks
,
audio

,

and

.
<END>
<START>
It
also

and

.
<END>
<START>
He
said
it
is
n't

whether

's

will

when

buys
the
company
.
<END>
<START>
The
agreement
is

on

and
should
be
completed
later
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Tokyo

.

.

.

.

,

,

.

,

.

.
<END>
<START>
This

,

,

.

<START>
The

's

.
<END>
<START>
Fannie

,

,

in

.
<END>
<START>
Prudential
Insurance
is
based
in
Newark
,

.
<END>
<START>
The

can
be
for

,
for

built
in

's

,

or

.
<END>
<START>
Fannie
Mae
makes
a
secondary
market
in
home
loans
.
<END>
<START>
It
buys
loans
from
lenders
,
packages
some
into
securities
for
sale
to
investors
and
holds
the
remainder
in
a
portfolio
.

<START>
H&R
Block
is
one
of

.
<END>
<START>

,

.

<START>
Some

Block
because

's

,

.

,

.

-LRB-

<END>
<START>
Options
lost
some
of
their
mystery
in
1973
when
the
Chicago
Board
of
Trade
set
up
a
special
exchange
to
deal
in
them
.
<END>
<START>
Until
then
,
options
had
been
traded
only
in
the
over-the-counter
market
,
mostly
in
New
York
,
and
in
an
almost
invisible
secondary
market
operating
chiefly
by
telephone
.
<END>
<START>
The
Chicago
Board
of
Trade
,
the
No.
1
U.S.
grain
market
,
had
long
chafed
under
the
attention
won
by
its
innovative
archrival
,
the
livestock-dealing
Mercantile
Exchange
.
<END>
<START>
So
the
men
who
ran
the
grain
pits
listened
when
Joseph
Sullivan
,
a
35-year-old
former
Wall
Street
Journal
newsman
,
offered
them
the
idea
of
all-options
trading
.
<END>
<START>
The
beginnings
were
modest
.
<END>
<START>
The
CBOE
opened
for
business
on
April
26
,
1973
,
in
what
had
been
a
Board

.
<END>
<START>
It
listed
just
16
options
to
buy
a
``
pilot
list
''
of
stocks
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Puts
,
or
sell
options
,
would
not
be
added
until
1977
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>

282

$
10,000

.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-

1989

:
$
250,000
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>

911
contracts

-RRB-
.

.

.

,

.

.

<START>
China
said
the
question
of
Taiwan
's
membership
in
the
General
Agreement
on
Tariffs
and
Trade
should
be
considered
only
after
China
's
own
membership
in
the
97-nation
organization
is
restored
.
<END>
<START>
Both
China
and
Taiwan
are
seeking
seats
in
GATT
,
which
sponsors
trade-liberalizing
agreements
and
sets
world-commerce
rules
.
<END>
<START>
``
As
one
of
China
's
provinces
,
Taiwan
has
no
right
to
join
GATT
on
its
own
,
''
Foreign
Ministry
spokesman
Li
Zhaoxing
said
.
<END>
<START>
China
,
under
the
Nationalist
government
of
Chiang
Kai-shek
,
was
a
founding
member
of
GATT
in
1947
.
<END>
<START>
The
Nationalists
withdrew
in
1950
,
after
their
flight
to
Taiwan
,
and
the
Communist
government
in
Beijing
applied
for
restoration
of
China
's
membership
in
July
1986
.
<END>
<START>
The
U.S.
has
voiced
opposition
to
China
's
bid
for
GATT
membership
,
saying
China
has
yet
to
undertake
needed
economic
reforms
.
<END>
<START>

's
biggest

's

,

,

that

that

.

''

A
Canadian

agency
conditionally
approved

exports
to
the
U.S.
of
natural
gas
from
big
,
untapped
fields
in
the
Mackenzie
River
delta
area
of
the
western
Canadian
Arctic
.
<END>
<START>
To
be

feasible
,
the
11
billion
Canadian
dollar
-LRB-
US$
9.37
billion
-RRB-
project
requires

of

.
<END>
<START>
It
also
faces

other

on
a

for
the
gas
.
<END>
<START>
U.S.

have

.
<END>
<START>

include
Enron
Corp.
,
Texas
Eastern
Corp.
,
Pacific
Interstate
Transmission
Co.
and
Tennessee
Gas
Pipeline
Co
.
<END>
<START>

project
could
result
in
the
U.S.
taking
more
than
10
%
of
its
natural
gas
supplies
from
Canada
,
up
from
about
5
%
currently
.
<END>
<START>
It
would
bring
13
gas
fields
into
production
at
a

rate
of
about
1.2
billion
cubic
feet
a
day
.
<END>
<START>

board

that

of

a

from
the
Mackenzie
delta
to
Alberta
would
be

C$
5.9
million
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
said

for

and

of
C$
5.25
per

cubic
feet
by
2005
would
make
the
project

viable
.
<END>

sold

a
unit
of
Unimin
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
Where
do
Americans
put
their
money
?
<END>
<START>
It
depends
on
when
you
look
.
<END>
<START>
In
1900
,
for
instance
,
less
than
8
%
of
assets
went
into
bank
deposits
.
<END>
<START>
That
rose
to
nearly
18
%
during
the
Depression
,
and
has
n't
changed
much
since
.
<END>
<START>
Pension
reserves
,
on
the
other
hand
,
made
up
a
relatively
small
part
of
household
assets
until
the
last
decade
,
when
they
skyrocketed
.
<END>
<START>
And
there
has
been
a
drastic
decline
in
the
importance
of
unincorporated
business
assets
--
thanks
to
industry
consolidation
and
a
decline
in
family
farms
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
some
of
what
emerges
from
the
following
charts
,
which
show
how
Americans
have
changed
their
investment
patterns
over
the
past
90
years
.
<END>
<START>
Some
results
are
self-explanatory
.
<END>
<START>
But
other
figures
are
surprising
.
<END>
<START>
Housing
,
for
instance
,
has
remained
a
fairly
steady
component
of
household
assets
over
the
past
decade
--
although
common
wisdom
would
have
expected
an
increase
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
is
a
lot
of
attention
paid
to
housing
as
a
form
of
household
wealth
,
''
says
Edward
N.
Wolff
,
professor
of
economics
at
New
York
University
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
it
has
n't
increased
much
relative
to
other
assets
.
<END>
<START>
It
suggests
that
households
accumulate
wealth
across
a
broad
spectrum
of
assets
.
<END>
<START>
And
housing
though
it
appears
in
the
popular
mind
as
being
the
major
-LCB-
growing
-RCB-
household
asset
,
is
n't
.
''
<END>
<START>
``
Stocks
have
not
spread
to
the
general
public
,
despite
the
fact
that
the
environment
is
much
different
,
''
concludes
Robert
Avery
,
an
economist
at
Cornell
University
.
<END>
<START>
--
The
charts
show
how
househld
assets
have
been
distributed
over
time
.
<END>
<START>
The
main
components
of
the
various
asseet
categories
:
Housing
:
Primary
home
,
but
not
the
land
it
's
on
.
<END>
<START>
Land
and
Other
Real
Estate
:
Land
on
which
primary
home
is
built
,
investment
property
.
<END>
<START>
Consumer
Durables
:
Automobiles
,
appliances
,
furniture
.
<END>
<START>
Bank
Deposits
:
Currency
,
checking-account
deposits
,
small
savings
and
time
deposits
,
certificates
of
deposits
,
money-market
fund
shares
.
<END>
<START>
Bonds
:
Excludes
bond
funds
.
<END>
<START>
Stocks/Mutual
Funds
:
Stocks
and
mutual
funds
other
than
money-market
funds
.
<END>
<START>
Unincorporated
Business
:
Partnerships
and
sole
proprietorships
,
professional
corporations
.
<END>
<START>
Pension
Reserves
:
Holdings
by
pension
funds
.
<END>
<START>
McCaw
Cellular

Bell

.

<START>

.

,

''

.

.

Past

Impasse

<START>
I

;

less

.

,
It

:

Am

.

<START>
Helmsley
Enterprises
Inc.
plans
to
close

and
is
seeking
other
brokers
to

,

the
New

firm
.
<END>
<START>
Helmsley
Enterprises
is
the

for
companies
controlled
by
Harry
B.
Helmsley
.
<END>
<START>
These
include
office
and
residential

giant
,
HelmsleySpear
Inc.
,
and
Helmsley
Hotels
.
<END>
<START>
The
insurance
firm
acts
as
a
broker
on
policies
covering
buildings
managed
by
HelmsleySpear
and
others
.
<END>
<START>
Many
of
the
properties
are
owned
through
limited
partnerships
controlled
by
Mr.
Helmsley
.
<END>
<START>
New
York
State
law
prohibits
insurance
brokerages
from
deriving
more
than
10
%
of
revenue
from
insuring
affiliated
companies
.
<END>
<START>
Adverse

from

its

's

and
related
management

have
put

on

.

's

companies
.

of

.
<END>
<START>
Officials
there

to
comment
,

.
<END>
<START>
Outside
the
white-walled
headquarters
of
the
socalled
Society
of
Orange
Workers
,
all
seems
normal
in
South
Africa
's
abnormal
society
.
<END>
<START>
A
pickup
truck
driven
by
a
white
farmer
rumbles
past
with
a
load
of
black
workers
bouncing
in
the
back
.
<END>
<START>
Over
at
Conradies
,
the
general
store
,
a
black
stock
boy
scurries
to
help
an
elderly
white
woman
with
her
packages
.
<END>
<START>
Down
the
street
,
a
car
pulls
into
the
Shell
station
and
is
surrounded
by
black
attendants
.
<END>
<START>
A
dozen
white
office
workers
fold
newsletters
and
stuff
them
into
envelopes
.
<END>
<START>
White
women
serve
tea
and
coffee
,
and
then
wash
the
cups
and
saucers
afterwards
.
<END>
<START>
White
children
empty
the
wastepaper
baskets
and
squeegee
the
windows
.
<END>
<START>
There
is
n't
a
black
worker
in
sight
.
<END>
<START>
Not
in
the
kitchen
,
or
the
storeroom
or
the
book
shop
.
<END>
<START>
They
do
indeed
want
their
own
nation
.
<END>
<START>
But
here
in
Morgenzon
,
a
sleepy
town
amid
the
corn
fields
of
the
eastern
Transvaal
,
the
Orange
Workers
are
holding
the
pillars
steady
.
<END>
<START>
Here
,
then
,
is
where
the
Orange
Workers
have
come
to
make
apartheid
's
last
stand
.
<END>
<START>
Their
idea
is
to
create
a
city
,
first
,
and
then
an
entire
nation
--
without
blacks
.
<END>
<START>
This
may
seem
to
be
a
preposterous
and
utterly
futile
effort
in
Africa
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
fact
that
there
are
only
3,000
card-carrying
Orange
Workers
may
put
them
on
the
loony
fringe
.
<END>
<START>
Afrikaner
philosophers
and
theologians
have
long
ruminated
on
the
need
for
a
white
homeland
.
<END>
<START>
The
Orange
Workers
are
just
putting
this
preaching
into
practice
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
,
farmer
Johan
Fischer
,
his
T-shirt
and
jeans
covered
in
grease
,
crawls
around
under
his
planter
,
tightening
bolts
and
fixing
dents
.
<END>
<START>
On
almost
every
other
farm
in
South
Africa
,
black
workers
do
the
repairs
.
<END>
<START>
But
not
here
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Fischer
plows
his
own
fields
,
sows
his
own
corn
and
sunflowers
,
and
feeds
his
own
sheep
.
<END>
<START>
Over
at
the
fiberglass
factory
,
four
white
workers
assemble
water
tanks
on
their
own
,
and
in
their
spare
time
they
build
townhouses
across
the
road
.
<END>
<START>
On
Main
Street
,
Alida
Verwoerd
and
her
daughters
look
after
the
clothes
and
fabric
shop
,
then
hurry
home
to
fix
lunch
for
the
rest
of
the
family
.
<END>
<START>
Down
by
the
stream
,
a
group
of
Orange
Workers
puts
the
finishing
touches
on
a
golf
course
.
<END>
<START>
If
whites
want
to
play
there
by
themselves
,
says
consulting
engineer
Willem
van
Heerden
,
whites
should
also
build
it
by
themselves
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
we
want
to
survive
as
a
people
,
''
he
says
,
``
we
have
to
change
our
way
of
life
.
<END>
<START>
The
Afrikaner
must
end
his
reliance
on
others
.
''
<END>
<START>
Somewhere
,
the
son
sighs
,
things
went
terribly
wrong
with
apartheid
;
today
,
whites
even
rely
on
blacks
to
police

.
<END>
<START>
``
People
took
separate
development
as
an

to
use
black
labor
without

.
<END>
<START>
But
my
father
meant

to
mean
real
separation
,
''
says
the
son
.
<END>
<START>
The
Orange
Workers
speak
sincerely
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
agree
with
world
opinion
that
the
status
quo
in
South
Africa
is
morally
wrong
,
''
says
Pieter
Bruwer
,
the
Orange
Workers
'

scribe
and

.
<END>
<START>
``
We
must
either
integrate
honestly
or
segregate
honestly
.
''
<END>
<START>
Morgenzon
has
long
been
a
special
domain
of
Afrikanerdom
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
Mr.
Verwoerd
,
the
early
Afrikaner
pioneers
were
the
first
people
to
settle
in
the
eastern
Transvaal
,
even
before
the
blacks
.
<END>
<START>
Today
,
Morgenzon
is
a
town
of
800
whites
and
two
paved
roads
.
<END>
<START>
Weeds
push
up
through
the
cracks
in
the
sidewalks
,
and
many
houses
and
storefronts
are
empty
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
few
factories
and
no
mines
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
an
ideal
place
for
the
Orange
Workers
to
start
their
new
nation
,
unencumbered
by
the
demographics
that
have
undermined
apartheid
elsewhere
in
South
Africa
.
<END>
<START>
So
far
,
about
150
Orange
Workers
have
moved
here
,
spending
nearly
$
1
million
buying
up
property
over
the
past
three
years
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
complete
and
total
segregation
remains
elusive
.
<END>
<START>
Just
beyond
the
city
limits
is
a
shantytown
of
2,000
blacks
who
are
employed
throughout
the
area
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
the
Orange
Workers
'
intention
to
put
them
all
out
of
work
,
they
are
in
no
hurry
to
leave
.
<END>
<START>
The
650-or-so
local
whites
who
are
n't
Orange
Workers
are
more
troubled
.
<END>
<START>
Try
as
they
might
,
they
just
ca
n't
conceive
of
life
without
black
workers
.
<END>
<START>
``
Impossible
,
impossible
,
''
say
the
Conradies
,
an
elderly
couple
who
have
run
the
general
store
for

.
<END>
<START>
``
We
ca
n't
do
without
their
help
,
''
says
Mrs.
Conradie
.
<END>
<START>
``
Oh
no
.
<END>
<START>
We
need
them
and
I
thank
God
for
them
.
''
<END>
<START>
Over
at
the
Shell
station
,
owner
Rudi
van
Dyk
,
who
doubles
as
Morgenzon
's
mayor
,
worries
that
the
Orange
Workers
have
made
his
town
the
laughingstock
of
the
nation
.
<END>
<START>
``
What
they
want
us
to
do
just
is
n't
practical
,
''
he
says
,
noting
that
he
employs
16
blacks
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
could
n't
afford
to
hire
16
whites
.
<END>
<START>
The
only
Afrikaners
who
would
be
willing
to
work
for
this
salary
would
n't
know
how
to
handle
money
.
''
<END>
<START>
Back
at
the
Verwoerd
house
,
Hendrik
Sr.
peers
down
over
the
shoulder
of
Hendrik
Jr
.
<END>
<START>
The
son
believes
that
when
the
Afrikaners
finally
realize
there
is
no
turning
back
the
integration
of
South
African
society
and

,
Morgenzon
will
boom
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
urge
our
people
not
to
wait
until
they
have
to
fight
for
their
own
nation
,
''
says
Mr.
Verwoerd
.
<END>
<START>
``
By
populating
a
place
now
,
we
make
ourselves
a
power
any
new
government
will
have
to
take
into
account
.
''
<END>
<START>

<END>
<START>

.
''
<END>
<START>

?
<END>
<START>

stocks
,

Goldman
.
<END>
<START>
WATCH
FOR

.
<END>
<START>

<START>

<START>

.

.

`

'

,

.
<END>
<START>

ratios
-LRB-

's

.

.

.

.

<START>
International
Business
Machines
Corp.
will
announce
on
Tuesday
a
slew
of
software
products
aimed
at
eliminating
some
of
the
major
problems
involved
in
computerizing
manufacturing
operations
,
industry
executives
said
.
<END>
<START>
Many
plant
floors
currently
resemble
a
Tower
of
Babel
,
with
computers
,
robots
and
machine
tools
that
generally
speak
their
own
language
and
have
trouble
talking
to
each
other
.
<END>
<START>
So
IBM
will
be
announcing
more
than
50
products
that
will
be
aimed
at
letting
even
the
dumbest
machine
tool
talk
to
the
smartest
mainframe
,
or
anything
in
between
.
<END>
<START>
In
an
unusual
display
of
openness
,
IBM
also
will
be
helping
customers
tie
together
operations
that
include
lots
of
equipment
made
by
IBM
's
competitors
.
<END>
<START>
In
Armonk
,
N.Y.
,
an
IBM
spokeswoman
confirmed
that
IBM
executives
will
be
announcing
some
computer-integrated-manufacturing
plans
next
week
but
declined
to
elaborate
.
<END>
<START>
The
industry
executives
said
that
,
as
usual
with
such
broad
announcements
from
IBM
,
this
one
will
be
part
reality
and
part
strategy
.
<END>
<START>
So
it
will
take
many
quarters
for
IBM
to
roll
out
all
the
products
that
customers
need
,
and
it
will
take
years
for
customers
to
integrate
the
products
into
their
operations
.
<END>
<START>
Also
as
usual
,
the
products
will
appeal
mostly
to
heavy
users
of
IBM
equipment
,
at
least
initially
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
a
step
in
the
right
direction
,
''
said
Martin
Piszczalski
,
a
Yankee
Group
analyst
.
<END>
<START>
He
added
,

,
that
``
a
lot
of
this
is
intentions
...
.
<END>
<START>
We
'll
have
to
wait
and
see
''
how
the
plan
develops
.
<END>
<START>
The
announcements
also
should
help
IBM
go
on
the
offensive
against
Digital
Equipment
Corp.
on
the
plant
floor
.
<END>
<START>
While
IBM
has
traditionally
dominated
the
market
for
computers
on
the
business
side
of
manufacturing
operations
and
has
done
well
in
the
market
for
design
tools
,
Digital
has
dominated
computerized
manufacturing
.
<END>
<START>
Hewlett-Packard
Co.
also
has
begun
to
gain
share
in
the
whole
computer-integrated-manufacturing
arena
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
will
face
an
uphill
climb
against
Digital
,
given
Digital
's
reputation
for
being
better
than
IBM
at
hooking
together
different
manufacturers
'
computers
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
Hewlett-Packard
,
while
a
much
smaller
player
,
has
made
a
big
commitment
to
the
sorts
of
industry
standards
that
facilitate
those
hookups
and
could
give
IBM
some
problems
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
,
which
Gartner
Group
said
generates
22
%
of
its
revenue
in
this
market
,
should
be
able
to
take
advantage
of
its
loyal
following
among
buyers
of
equipment
.
<END>
<START>
That
is
because
many
companies
will
standardize
on
certain
types
of
equipment
as
the
various
parts
of
the
manufacturing
market
merge
,
and
IBM
is
the
biggest
player
.
<END>
<START>
But
much
will
depend
on
how
quickly
IBM
can
move
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
said
a
system
such
as
IBM
's
should
help
significantly
.
<END>
<START>
In
making
polyethylene
sheets
out
of
plastic
chips
,
for
instance
,
a
chip
sometimes
does
n't
melt
,
gets
caught
in

and
creates
a
run
in

sheets
.
<END>
<START>
That
can
be
expensive
,
because
the
problem
may
not

noticed
for
a
while
,
and
the
sheets
are
typically

.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Keller
said
that
,
if
computers
can
be
integrated
into
the
process
,
they
could
alert
an
operator
as
soon
as
the
problem
occurred
.
<END>
<START>
They
could
also

orders
on

to

that
was

to
accept
a
lower

of

.
<END>
<START>
The
computer
would
let
the
machine
run
just
until
that
order
was
filled
,

waste
.
<END>
<START>
This
sort

improved
link
figures
to

for
some

.
<END>
<START>
Companies
might

able

tell

daily
,
for

,
about
idle
equipment
,
so

could

on
whatever
that

.

.
<END>
<START>
Merkur
's
death
is
n't
nearly
as
costly
to
Ford
as
was
the
Edsel
debacle
,
because
Merkur
was
a
relatively
low-budget
project
with
limited
sales
goals
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
Merkur
's
demise
is
a
setback
for
Ford
at
a
time
when
the
company
's
image
as
the
U.S.
auto
maker
with
the
golden
touch
is
showing
signs
of
strain
.
<END>
<START>
This
fall
,
Ford
introduced
only
one
new
product
:
A
restyled
version
of
its
hulking
Lincoln
Town
Car
luxury
model
.
<END>
<START>
The
demise
of
Merkur
-LRB-
pronounced
mare-COOR
-RRB-
comes
after
a
September
in
which
670
Merkur
dealers
managed
to
sell
only
93
Scorpios
.
<END>
<START>
Total
Merkur
sales
for
the
first
nine
months
dropped
46
%
from
a
year
ago
to
just
6,320
cars
.
<END>
<START>
Merkur
is
n't
the
only
European
luxury
brand
having
problems
in
the
U.S.
.
<END>
<START>
The
Japanese
assault
on
the
luxury
market
is
rapidly
overshadowing
such
European
makes
as
Audi
and
Saab
,
which
at
least
have
clear
brand
images
.
<END>
<START>
Merkur
,
as
an
import
on
domestic
car
lots
,
suffered
from
the
same
sort
of
image
confusion
that
is
hobbling
sales
of
imports
at
General
Motors
Corp.
and
Chrysler
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
brand
had
trouble
from
the
start
.
<END>
<START>
The
first
Merkur
,
the
XR4Ti
,
went
on
sale
in
early
1985
.
<END>
<START>
The
sporty
coupe
foundered
in
part
because
American
buyers
did
n't
go
for
the
car
's
unusual
double-wing
rear
spoiler
.
<END>
<START>
In
May
1987
,
Ford
began
importing
the
Scorpio
sedan
from
West
Germany
to
sell
next
to
a
redesigned
XR4Ti
in
showrooms
.
<END>
<START>
Ford
officials
said
they
expected
the
two
Merkurs
would
sell
about
15,000
cars
a
year
,
and
in
1988
they
reached
that
goal
,
as
sales
hit
15,261
cars
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
downhill
from
there
,
however
.
<END>
<START>
One
major
factor
was
the
decline
of
the
dollar
against
the
mark
,
which
began
less
than
a
year
after
Merkur
's
1985
launch
.
<END>
<START>
As
the
West
German
currency
rose
,
so
did
Merkur
prices
.
<END>
<START>
The
Merkur
cars
also
suffered
from
spotty
quality
,
some
dealers
say
.
<END>
<START>
But
by
the
third
quarter
of
1988
,
Scorpios
had
a
high
satisfaction
rating
in
internal
Ford
studies
,
a
spokesman
said
.
<END>
<START>
Apparently
,
however
,
the
improvement
came
too
late
.
<END>
<START>
Last
fall
,
Ford
announced
it
would
discontinue
the
XR4Ti
in
the
U.S.
at
the
end
of
the
1989
model
year
.
<END>
<START>
Ford
said
then
it
would
keep
the
Scorpio
.
<END>
<START>
This
year
,
Scorpio
sales
plummeted
,
and
at
the
current
sales
pace
it
would
take
Ford
242
days
to
sell
off
the
current
Scorpio
inventory
of
about
4,600
cars
.
<END>
<START>
Soo
Line
said
its
board
appointed
a
special
committee
of
independent
directors
to
study
the
proposal
.
<END>
<START>
The
troubled
Minneapolis-based
railroad
concern
said
the
committee
has
the
authority
to
hire

and

to

.

<START>

will

,
Soo
Line

.
<END>

shares
jumped
well
above
the

,

at
$
20.25
,

$
2.75
.
<END>
<START>
Canadian
Pacific
put
its
56
%

in
Soo
Line
up
for

last
year
but
could
n't

any
takers
.
<END>
<START>
Canadian
Pacific
,
which
has

in

,

,
forest

,
energy
and

,

majority
block
off

this
spring
.
<END>
<START>

Pacific
is
Soo

's

.

<START>

.

<START>
Revenue
fell
5.8
%

407.9
million
from

.
<END>
<START>
The
company
had
a
loss

of
$
1.7
million
.
<END>
<START>
Golden
Nugget
Inc.
reported
a

loss
of
$
13.1
million
,
or
76
cents
a

,

17.2

.

,

.

a

.

,

.

,

,

,

.

,

,

.

.

.

,

.

<START>

Holding
Corp.
said

A.
Franco
,
its

,
as

.

Franco

that

with

,

.
<END>

W.
Bailey
II
,

,

,

,

.

,

.

.

.

,

<START>
PLASTIC
PENCILS
,
CODE-NAMED
E-71
,
made
their
hush-hush
debut
in
children
's
pencil
boxes
at
five-and-dime
stores
in
1973
.
<END>
<START>
But
few
knew
it
then
and
most
still
think
all
pencils
are
wooden
.
<END>
<START>
Eagle
Pencil
of
Shelbyville
,
Tenn.
,
``
Pencil
City
U.S.A.
,
''
had
made
its
earliest
pilot
plastic
pencils
in
1971
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
was
n't
until
after
it
hired
Arthur
D.
Little
,
a
Cambridge
,
Mass.
,
research
concern
,
that
its
new
product
was
refined
for
commercial
sale
in
1973
.
<END>
<START>
Three
A.D.L.
inventors
applied
April
6
,
1973
,
for
the
patent
,
which
was
assigned
and
awarded
in
1976
to
Hasbro
Industries
,
then
Eagle
's
parent
.
<END>
<START>
Pencil
pushers
chew
and
put
the
plastic
models
behind
their
ears
just
like
traditional
pencils
made
of
glued
strips
of
California
incense
cedar
filled
with
ceramic
lead
.
<END>
<START>
It
takes
five
steps
to
make
standard
pencils
,
just
one
for
the
plastic
type
.
<END>
<START>
Automated
machines
coextrude
long
plastic
sheaths
with
graphite-plastic
cores
that
are
printed
,
cut
,
painted
and
eraser-fitted
.
<END>
<START>
``
After
more
than
200
years
,
something
new
has
happened
to
pencils
,
''
said
Arthur
D.
Little
in
a
1974
report
that
publicly
described
the
previously
secret
item
.
<END>
<START>
Eagle
's
plastic
type
sharpens
and
looks
like
a
wooden
pencil
.
<END>
<START>
A
major
difference
is
that
a
snapped
wooden
pencil
will
have
a
slivered
break
while
a
plastic
model
will
break
cleanly
.
<END>
<START>
The
softness
of
the
core
constrains
the
plastic
models
to
No.
1
,
No.
2
or
No.
3-type
pencils
,
which
account
for
the
bulk
of
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
Artists
and
draftsmen
need
harder
``
leads
.
''
<END>
<START>
Eagle
,
now
called
Eagle-Berol
,
remains
a
leading
company
among
the
10
in
the
U.S.
that
produced
about
2.3
billion
pencils
last
year
,
according
to
the
Pencil
Makers
Association
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
a
trade
secret
how
many
were
plastic
,
and
most
writers
still
do
n't
know
what
they
're
using
.
<END>
<START>
Pretax
earnings
declined
1.3
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
the
decline
was
attributable
to
a
79
%
reduction
in
net
gains
on
loan
sales
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Third-quarter
spreads
widened
to
the
highest
level
in
two
years
as
loan
portfolio
yields
rose
and
money
costs
declined
,
the
company
said
.
<END>
<START>
Great
Western
,
based
in
Beverly
Hills
,
Calif.
,
is
a
financial
services
firm
and
parent
to
Great
Western
Bank
,
an
S&L
.
<END>
<START>
Great
Western
said
it
had
a
sharp
increase
in
margins
in
the
recent
third
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Margins
are
the
difference
between
the
yield
on
the
company
's
earning
assets
and
its
own
cost
of
funds
.
<END>
<START>
But
a
reduction
in
one-time
gains
on
the
sale
of
various
assets
and
an
increase
in
the
company
's

loan
losses
held
down

gain
,
the
company

.

<START>
Dun
&
Bradstreet
Corp.
posted
a
15
%
rise
in
third-quarter
earnings
.
<END>
<START>
But
revenue
declined
more
than
2
%
,
reflecting
in
part
a
continuing
drop
in
sales
of

in

over

's

.

<START>

information

cited
the
stronger
dollar
,
the

of

former
Official
Airline
Guides
unit
and

.
<END>
<START>
Net

rose

$
155.3
million
,
or
83
cents
a

,
from
$
134.8
million
,

72
cents
a

.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
fell
to
$
1.04
billion
from
$
1.07
billion
.
<END>
<START>
In
composite
trading
on
the
New
York

Exchange
,
Dun
&
Bradstreet
closed
yesterday
at
$
53.75
,

25
cents
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
said
the
results
were
as
expected
,
but
several
added
that
the
earnings
masked
underlying
weaknesses
in
several

.
<END>
<START>
``
The
quality
of
earnings
was
n't
as
high
as
I
expected
,
''
said
Eric
Philo
,
an

for

,
Sachs
&
Co
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
he
noted
,

was
weaker
than
he
had

,
but

earnings
of
$
14.6
million
and
a
lower
tax
rate
helped
boost
net
income
.
<END>
<START>
Dun
&
Bradstreet
said
operating
earnings
rose
8
%
,
excluding
the
sale
of
Official
Airline
Guides
.
<END>
<START>
Third-quarter
sales
of
U.S.
credit
services
were
``
disappointingly
below
sales
''
of
a
year
earlier
,
Dun
&
Bradstreet
said
.
<END>
<START>
As

,
those
sales
have
been
declining
this
year
in
the

of
allegations
that
the
company

in

that
encouraged

to

.
<END>
<START>
The
company
has
denied
the

but
has
negotiated
a

$
18
million
settlement
of

.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
predict
the
sales
impact
will
linger
.
<END>
<START>
``

n't

question

will

,
''

John
Reidy
,

.
<END>
<START>
Dun
&
Bradstreet
noted

in
its
Nielsen
Marketing
Research
,
Nielsen

House
and
Donnelley

also
restrained

.

<START>
It
cited
cyclical

in
its
Moody
's
Investors
Service
Inc.
and
D&B
Plan
Services
units
.
<END>
<START>
Year-earlier

reflected

of
$
14.3

IMS

.
<END>
<START>

.

Allenport
,
Pa
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
equipment
,
which
will
produce
steel
sheet
with
more
uniform
thickness
and
flatness
,
is
likely
to
cost
more
than
$
20
million
,
the
company
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
time

for
installing
the
equipment
also
will
be
developed
by
the
task
force
,
the
company
said
.
<END>
<START>
Sir
Richard
succeeds
John
Plastow
,
who
resigned
in
July
.
<END>
<START>
Sir
Richard
is
also
a
non-executive
director
at
National
Westminister
Bank
and
NatWest
Investment
Bank
Ltd
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
long
,
frightening
night
after
Tuesday
's
devastating
earthquake
,
Bay
Area
residents
searched
for
comfort
and
solace
wherever
they
could
.
<END>
<START>
Some
found
it
on
the
screen
of
a
personal
computer
.
<END>
<START>
Hundreds
of
Californians
made
their
way
to
their
computers
after
the
quake
,
and
checked
in
with
each
other
on
electronic

boards
,
which
link
computers
CB-radio-style
,
via
phone
lines
.
<END>
<START>
Some
of
the
most

came
over
The
Well
,
a
Sausalito
,
Calif.
,
board
that
is
one
of
the
liveliest
outposts
of
the
electronic
underground
.
<END>
<START>
About
two-thirds
of

's
3,000

live

Bay

.
<END>
<START>
The
quake
knocked
The
Well
out
for
six
hours
,

came

up
,

teemed
with

.

,

.

PANDA
:

<START>

to

.
<END>
<START>

seems
a

.
<END>
<START>
Berkeley
very
quiet
right
now
.
<END>
<START>
I
walked
along
Shattuck
between
Delaware
and
Cedar
at
a
few
minutes
before
eight
this
morning
.
<END>
<START>
I
agreed
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
.
<END>
<START>
Great
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
increased
10
%
to
$
2.65
billion
from
$
2.41
billion
.
<END>
<START>
With
strong
prices
in
the
company
's
two
major
areas
--
building
products
as
well
as
pulp
and
paper
--
analysts
had
expected
a
roaring
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
performance
exceeded
some
estimates
of
around
$
1.90
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Fueling
the
growth
,
among
other
things
,
were
higher-than-expected
prices
for
certain
building
products
.
<END>
<START>
One
reason
:
efforts
to
protect
the
spotted
owl
led
to
restrictions
on
logging
in
the
Pacific
Northwest
,
constricting
supply
and
forcing
prices
up
.
<END>
<START>
Another
reason
:
strikes
,
both
at
Georgia-Pacific
and
other
lumber
companies
also
cut
supplies
and
raised
prices
,
analysts
said
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
nine
months
,
Georgia-Pacific
's
earnings
increased
49
%
to
$
504
million
,
or
$
5.58
a
share
,
from
$
338
million
,
or
$
3.41
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
rose
11
%
to
$
7.73
billion
from
$
6.94
billion
.
<END>
<START>
In
composite
New
York
Stock
Exchange
Trading
,
Georgia-Pacific
stock
rose
$
1.25
a
share
yesterday
to
close
at
$
58
.
<END>
<START>
The
House
Public
Works
and
Transportation
Committee
approved
a
bill
that
would
give
the
Transportation
Department
power
to
block
airline
leveraged
buy-outs
,
despite
a
clear
veto
threat
from
the
Bush
administration
.
<END>
<START>
The
23-5
vote
clears
the
way
for
consideration
on
the
House
floor
next
week
or
the
week
after
.
<END>
<START>
Transportation
Secretary
Samuel
Skinner
,
in
a
letter
to
the
committee
,
warned
that
he
would
urge
President
Bush
to
veto
the
legislation
if
it
passed
Congress
.
<END>
<START>
The
Senate
Commerce
Committee
already
has
approved
similar
legislation
.
<END>
<START>
On
Monday
,
a
letter
from
Mr.
Skinner
's
deputy
,
Elaine
Chao
,
said
the
administration
opposed
the
legislation
``
in
its
present
form
.
''
<END>
<START>
Some
of
the
bill
's
supporters
had
taken
heart
from
the
fact
that
the
letter
was
n't
signed
by
Mr.
Skinner
and
that
it
did
n't
contain
a
veto
threat
.
<END>
<START>
The
stepped-up
administration
warnings
annoyed
some
lawmakers
,
especially
senior
Republicans
who
supported
the
bill
because
they
thought
the
Transportation
Department
favored
it
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
backed
this
bill
because
we
thought
it
would
help
Skinner
,
''
one
Republican
said
,
``
and
now
we
're
out
there
dangling
in
the
wind
.
''
<END>
<START>
A
few
weeks
ago
,
Mr.
Skinner
testified
before
Congress
that
it
would
be
``
cleaner
,
more
efficient
''
if
he
had
authority
to
block
buy-outs
in
advance
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
never
took
an
official
position
on
the
bill
and
has
steadfastly
maintained
that
he
already
has
enough
authority
to
deal
with
buy-outs
.
<END>
<START>
Although
the
legislation
would
apply
to
any
acquisition
of
a
major
airline
,
it
is
aimed
at
transactions
financed
by
large
amounts
of
debt
.
<END>
<START>
Supporters
of
the
bill
are
concerned
an
airline
might
sacrifice
costly
safety
measures
in
order
to
repay
debt
.
<END>
<START>
The
panel
's
action
occurs
in
a
politically
charged
atmosphere
surrounding
recent
buy-out
proposals
,
their
apparent
collapse
and
the
volatile
conditions
in
the
stock
market
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
do
n't
believe
in
the
airline
business
you
can
be
totally
laissez-faire
because
of
the
high
degree
of
public
interest
''
at
stake
.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Skinner
disagreed
,
calling
the
legislation
``
a
retreat
from
the
policy
of
deregulaton
of
the
airline
industry
.
''
<END>
<START>
Currently
,
the
Transportation
Department
does
n't
have
the
authority
to
block
a
takeover
in
advance
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
if
the
secretary
concludes
that
a
transaction
has
made
a
carrier
unfit
to
operate
,
the
department
may
revoke
its
certificate
,
grounding
the
airline
.
<END>
<START>
Such
authority
is
more
than
adequate
,
say
opponents
of
the
legislation
.
<END>
<START>
But
supporters
argue
that
grounding
an
airline
is
so
drastic
that
the
department
would
hesitate
doing
it
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
voted
down
proposals
to
give
the
secretary
much
more
discretion
on
whether
to
block
a
buy-out
and
to
require
the
department
to
consider
the
impact
of
a
buy-out
on
workers
.
<END>
<START>
London
shares
rallied
to
post
strong
gains
after
initial
fears
evaporated
that
the
California
earthquake
would
depress
Wall
Street
prices
.
<END>
<START>
Tokyo
stocks
,
which
rebounded
strongly
Tuesday
,
extended
their
gains
yesterday
,
but
most
other
Asian
and
Pacific
markets
closed
sharply
lower
.
<END>
<START>
In
London
,
the
Financial
Times-Stock
Exchange
100-share
index
jumped
34.6
points
to
close
at
its

high
of
2170.1
.
<END>
<START>
The
index
was
under
pressure
for

morning
over

that
the
effects
of
Tuesday
night
's
major

in

would

.
<END>
<START>
The

changed
after

the

of

on
shares
and

Street
rebounded
from

.
<END>
<START>

30-share

settled
27.8

at
1758.5
.
<END>
<START>
Volume
was
449.3
million
shares
,
the
slowest
of
a
hectic

,
compared
with
643.4

Tuesday
.
<END>
<START>
The

gave

to

on

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.

,

.

5

,

.

.

.

.

<START>
Tokyo
's

225

,

,
to
35107.56
.
<END>
<START>
The

gained
527.39
Tuesday
.
<END>
<START>
Volume
was

at
800
million

,

678

Tuesday
.
<END>
<START>
Declining

outnumbered

505-455
,

172

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

,

%
,
at
2642.88
.
<END>
<START>
In

in

Thursday
,
the

rose
135.09
points
to
35242.65
.
<END>
<START>
On

,

were

by

on
the

of

as
well

from

and

,

.
<END>
<START>
Institutions
,

,

as

.
<END>
<START>
Traders

n't

.
<END>
<START>

on

and

is

,

.
<END>
<START>
Buying
was

,

fairly

,
traders
said
.
<END>
<START>
With

still

over

rates
and

,
the
market
failed
to
find
a

that
might

,

.
<END>
<START>

said

that
gained
yesterday
wo
n't

,
as

.

<START>

,

,

,

.

to

,
so

are
n't

.

a

.

.

.

.

,

<START>
Here
are
price

on

world
's

markets
,
as

by
Morgan
Stanley

International

,

,

close
