1969
equaling
100
.
<END>
<START>
The
percentage
change
is
since
year-end
.
<END>
<START>
Housing
construction
sank
in
September
to
its
lowest
level
since
the
last
recession
,
the
Commerce
Department
reported
.
<END>
<START>
Work
began
on
homes
and
apartments
at
an
annual
rate
of
1,263,000
units
last
month
,
down
5.2
%
from
August
,
the
department
said
.
<END>
<START>
Originally
the
department
had
reported
the
August
decline
as
5
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
numbers
suggest
that
the
housing
industry
is
still
suffering
the
effects
of
the
Federal
Reserve
's
battle
against
inflation
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
of
new
homes
rose
and
inventories
of
houses
,
which
had
been
climbing
,
dropped
.
<END>
<START>
But
last
month
new
construction
in
all
types
of
homes
waned
,
from
single-family
houses
to
large
apartment
complexes
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
pretty
much
weak
across
the
board
,
''
said
Martin
Regalia
,
chief
economist
of
the
National
Council
of
Savings
Institutions
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Regalia
said
the
industry
may
be
reluctant
to
step
up
building
at
the
moment
for
fear
the
inventories
of
unsold
homes
will
increase
again
.
<END>
<START>
Another
reason
for
the
weakness
,
he
said
,
may
be
that
mortgage
rates
have
hit
a
plateau
since
they
began
edging
down
after
a
peak
in
March
.
<END>
<START>
In
August
,
rates
on
30-year
fixed-rate
mortgages
started
creeping
up
a
bit
,
but
they
inched
down
again
through
September
.
<END>
<START>
``
Rates
have
n't
really
peeled
off
that
much
,
''
Mr.
Regalia
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
've
kind
of
settled
now
into
an
interest-rate
environment
that
's
fairly
high
.
''
<END>
<START>
That
followed
a
3.3
%
decline
in
August
.
<END>
<START>
Construction
of
apartments
and
other
multi-family
dwellings
slipped
2.2
%
to
an
annual
rate
of
1,022,000
following
a
3.5
%
decline
in
August
.
<END>
<START>
The
number
of
building
permits
issued
for
future
construction
dropped
2.4
%
to
a
1,296,000
annual
rate
after
rising
3.7
%
in
August
.
<END>
<START>
All
the
numbers
were
adjusted
for
normal
seasonal
variations
in
building
activity
.
<END>
<START>
The
housing
starts
numbers
,
however
,
are
one
of
the
least
precise
of
the
government
's
economic
indicators
and
are
often
revised
significantly
as
more
information
is
collected
.
<END>
<START>
Shearson
Lehman
Hutton
Holdings
Inc.
posted
a
sharp
third-quarter
turnaround
from
a
year
earlier
,
but
net
income
would
have
dropped
from
the
second
quarter
without
a
$
37

after-tax
gain
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
climbed
25
%
to
$
3.3
billion
from
$
2.6
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
latest
period
included
the
gain
,
which
was
$
77
million
before
tax
,
from
the
previously
announced
sale
of
the

of
Lehman
Management
Co
.
<END>
<START>
The
1988
period
was
restated
from
net
income
of

8
million
to

in

company
's
Boston
Co.

.
<END>
<START>
In

1989
second
quarter
,

had
net
income
of
$
55
million
,
or
54
cents
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
An
average
102.5
million
common

were
outstanding
in

latest

,
up
from
87.1
million
.
<END>
<START>
In
New
York
Stock
Exchange
composite
trading
yesterday
,
Shearson
shares
lost
37.5
cents
to
$
18.125
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
the
improved
performance
from
a
year
ago
reflects
higher
commissions
and
revenue
from
marketmaking
and
trading
for
its
own

.
<END>
<START>
Commission
revenue
was
$
522
million
,
up
49
%
.
<END>
<START>
But
industrywide
trading
activity
slowed
in
September
as
institutional
investors
turned
cautious
and
individuals
continued
to
shy
away
from
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
Investment
banking
revenue
fell
32
%
to
$
205
million
,
in
part
reflecting
the
continued
slowdown
of
the
underwriting
business
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
nine
months
,
net
fell
3
%
to
$
106
million
,
or
98
cents
a
share
,
from
$
110
million
,
or
$
1.05
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
advanced
26
%
to
$
9.6
billion
from
$
7.6
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Two

drug

posted
strong

,
in

already

and

'

.
<END>
<START>
But

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

as

.

<START>
American

Products
<END>
<START>

.

.

,
''

,

.

<START>
Pfizer
<END>
<START>
Pfizer
said

4
%
to

from

.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
net
income
was
flat
because
of
investment
in
research
and
development
and
costs
related
to
launches
of
several
products
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
the
dollar
's
continued
strengthening
reduced
world-wide
sales
growth
by
three
percentage
points
.
<END>
<START>
Pfizer
posted
its
largest
gains
in
healthcare
sales
,
up
3
%
,
and
consumer
products
,
up
23
%
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
by
the
specialty
chemicals
and
materials
science
segments
were
flat
,
and
sales
by
the
agriculture
segment
declined
5
%
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
health-care
segment
,
pharmaceutical
sales
increased
4
%
and
sales
of
hospital
products
increased
1
%
.
<END>
<START>
In
New

Exchange
composite
trading

,
Pfizer
closed
at
$
67.75
a

,
up
75

.
<END>
<START>
Schering-Plough
<END>
<START>

said
sales
gained
2.7
%
to
$
743.7
million
from
$
724.4
million
.
<END>
<START>
These
actions
did
n't

because

.

;

.

.

.

.

.
<END>
<START>

's

.
<END>
<START>
Brawls
between

still

.
<END>
<START>
The
61-year-old
Mr.
Guzman
Cabrera
takes

in

.
<END>
<START>
``
This
is

a
new

union

,

's

new
Mexico
.
<END>
<START>
We
're
no
longer

of

with

,
''
he

.
<END>
<START>
Pemex
,
which
produces
40
%
of
government
revenue
,
desperately
needs
new
investment
.
<END>
<START>
Since
world

collapsed
in
1982
,
the
government
has
siphoned
Pemex
's
coffers
to
make

on
Mexico
's
$
97
billion
foreign
debt
.
<END>
<START>
Little
money
has
been
returned
to
upgrade
Pemex
's
aging
facilities
.
<END>
<START>
While
the
government
drains
Pemex
from
above
,
the
union
has
drained
it
from
below
.
<END>
<START>
A
bloated
payroll
and
pervasive
graft
caused

's
operating
costs
to
balloon
to
95
cents
of
each
$
1
in
sales
,
far
above
the
industry

.
<END>
<START>
The
declines
in

and
efficiency
explain
in

why
Mexico
has
been

this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Some

show

crude
by

,

of

.
<END>
<START>
``

,

,

.

-LRB-

<START>
Couple
Counseling
Grows
to
Defuse
Stress
<END>
<START>
MORE
EXECUTIVES
and
their
spouses
are
seeking
counseling
as
work
and
family
pressures
mount
.
<END>
<START>
Some
employers
initiate
referrals
,
especially
if
work
problems
threaten
a
top
manager
's
job
.
<END>
<START>
Many
couples
``
are
like
ships
passing
in
the
night
,
''
a
communications
gulf
that
sparks
problems
on
the
job
and
at
home
,
says
psychologist
Harry
Levinson
.
<END>
<START>
His
Levinson
Institute
in
Belmont
,
Mass.
,
has
seen
in
recent
years
a
doubling
in
the
number
of
executives
and
spouses
at
its
weeklong
counseling
program
.
<END>
<START>
Employers
foot
the
bill
,
he
says
,
figuring
what
's
good
for
the
couple
is
good
for
the
company
.
<END>
<START>
One
East
Coast
manufacturing
executive
,
faced
with
a
job
transfer
his
wife
resented
,
found
that
counseling
helped
them
both
come
to
grips
with
the
move
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
vice
president
of
a
large
Midwestern
company
realized
that
an
abrasive
temperament
threatened
his
career
when
his
wife
confided
that
similar
behavior
at
home
harmed
their
marriage
.
<END>
<START>
More
dual-career
couples
also
are
getting
help
,
with
men
increasingly
bringing
their
working
wives
for
joint
counseling
.
<END>
<START>
Her
Institute
for
Family
and
Work
Relationships
in
La
Jolla
,
Calif.
,
has
noted
a
doubling
in
the
number
of
couples
seeking
help
the
past
two
years
.
<END>
<START>
She
urges
client
couples
to
begin
a
``
detoxification
''
period
,
purging
social
and
other
nonproductive
activities
and
setting
time
apart
for

.
<END>
<START>
``
Putting
those
times
on
the
calendar
,
''
she
says
,
``
is
as
important
as
remembering
business
appointments
.
''
<END>
<START>
Power
of
Suggestion
Stronger
in
Japan
<END>
<START>
And
the
Japanese
make
far
more
suggestions
--
2,472
per
100
eligible
employees
vs.
only
13
per
100
employees
in
the
<END>
<START>
In
Japan
,
small
suggestions
are
encouraged
.
<END>
<START>
Each
new
employee
is
expected
to
submit
four
daily
in
the
first
few
months
on
the
job
.
<END>
<START>
U.S.
companies
tend
to
favor
suggestions
``
that
go
for
the
home
runs
,
''
says
Gary
Floss
,
vice
president
of
corporate
quality
at
Control
Data
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
That
helps
explain
why
American
employers
grant
an
average
award
of
$
604.72
per
suggestion
,
while
Japan
's
payment
is
$
3.23
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
suggestions
'
net
savings
per
100
employees
is
$
274,475
in
Japan
vs.
$
24,891
in
the
U.S.
.
<END>
<START>
U.S.
companies
developing
management
teams
are

with

suggestion
systems
.
<END>

Control
Data
,

,
plays
down

employee

because
it
favors
the
team-management
focus
.
<END>
<START>
Merger
Fallout
:
Beware
Employee
Dishonesty
<END>
<START>
CORPORATE
security
directors
increasingly
worry
that
merger
mania
spawns
a
rise
in
employee
dishonesty
.
<END>
<START>
A
Security
magazine
survey
places
the
effect
of
takeovers
and
buy-outs
among
the
industry
's
10
biggest
challenges
.
<END>
<START>
A
separate
study
of
the
extent
of
employee
misconduct
linked
general
job
satisfaction
to
property
loss
.
<END>
<START>
Co-author
Richard
Hollinger
cites
what
happened
at
one
family-owned
company
absorbed
by
a
foreign
giant
.
<END>
<START>
Pilferage
climbed
dramatically
as
many
angry
employees
``
felt
abandoned
by
the
former
owners
,
''
says
the
University
of
Florida
sociologist
.
<END>
<START>
But
top
management
should
watch
for
other
tell-tale
signs
of
employee
misdeeds
,
like
expense-account
fudging
and
phone
misuse
.
<END>
<START>
Security
consultant
Dennis
Dalton
of
Ventura
,
Calif.
,
thinks
mergers
often
trigger
longer
lunch
hours
and
increased
absenteeism
,
conduct
which
can
sap
the
bottom
line
more
than
thefts
.
<END>
<START>
New
management
can
take
several
steps
to
reduce
dishonesty
.
<END>
<START>
Most
important
,
experts
say
,
is
to
show
that
a
company
's
ethical
tone
is
set
at
the
top
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Dalton
also
recommends
that
the
chief
executive
establish
a
rumor
control
center
and
move
swiftly
to
bolster
morale
.
<END>
<START>
Consultant
John
Keller
of
Southlake
,
Texas
,
urges
that
top
management
adopt
a
``
tough
hands-on
approach
''
with
very
tight
controls
and
monitoring
.
<END>
<START>
And
security
authority
Robert
L.
Duston
favors
disciplining
all
employees
who
cheat
.
<END>
<START>
Firms
Walk
Fine
Line
In
Distributing
Profits
<END>
<START>
ARE
CORPORATE
profits
distributed
fairly
?
<END>
<START>
A
survey
by
Sirota
,
Alper
&
Pfau
,
a
New
York
consulting
firm
,
underscores
the
difficulty
for
top
management
in
satisfying
employees
and
investors
on
that
score
.
<END>
<START>
Nearly
seven
of
10
investors
think
companies
reinvest
``
too
little
''
of
their
profits
in
the
business
.
<END>
<START>
And
half
the
employees
surveyed
think
companies
dole
out
too
little
to
them
.
<END>
<START>
But
both
see
a
common
enemy
:
About
66
%
of
employees
and
73
%
of
investors
think
senior
managers
get
too
big
a
slice
of
the
profit
pie
.
<END>
<START>
Bank
of
New
York
Co.
said
it
agreed
in
principle
to
acquire
the
credit-card
business
of
Houston-based
First
City
Bancorp.
of
Texas
for
between
$
130
million
and
$
134
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
move
,
subject
to
a
definitive
agreement
,
is
part
of
a
trend
by
big-city
banks
that
have
been
buying
up
credit-card
portfolios
to
expand
their
business
.
<END>
<START>
First
City
's
portfolio
includes
approximately
640,000
accounts
with
about
$
550
million
in
loans
outstanding
.
<END>
<START>
First
City
,
which
issues
both
MasterCard
and
Visa
cards
,
has
agreed
to
act
as
an
agent
bank
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
end
of
the
third
quarter
,
Bank
of
New
York
's
credit-card
business
consisted
of
2.4
million
accounts
with
$
3.6
billion
in
loans
outstanding
.
<END>
<START>
Bank
of
New
York
is
currently
the
seventh-largest
issuer
of
credit
cards
in
the
<END>
<START>
First
City
said
that
because
of
increased

in
the
credit-card
business
,

had
decided
it
either

or

.
<END>
<START>
``
We
think
there
's
a
good
prospect
that
competition
is
going
to
get
pretty

in
this
market
,
''

,

.
<END>
<START>
``
We
see
it
becoming
a
bargain-basement
kind

.
''
<END>
<START>
The
company
also
said
the
transaction
would
bolster

by
$
3.25
a
share
when
completed
and
boost
its

capital
ratio
to
7
%
from
6.63

.
<END>
<START>
First

,

,

would
use

to

in

Southwest
and

.
<END>
<START>
With

in

,

for

.
<END>
<START>

,
''

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
``
That
's

.
<END>
<START>
He

is

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

,
''
he

,
adding

revised

could

.
<END>
<START>
UAL
management
was
to
pay
$
15
million
for
10
%
,
and

Air
was
to

15

.
<END>
<START>

fell
through

and

.
<END>
<START>
Since

,

has

33
%
in
what
may

as
the
largest

of

.
<END>
<START>

's

.

.

<START>

,

,

.

,

.

,

<START>

220

hired
during

's
1985
strike
filed
suit
Friday
in
Chicago
federal

to
block
the

.
<END>
<START>
The
dissident
pilots
oppose
the
plan
because
it
would
cause
them
to
lose
their
seniority
.
<END>
<START>
UAL
's

agreed

of
those
pilots
in
exchange
for
the
support
of

United

.

n't

of

.
<END>

airline
had
allowed

to

of
some
union
members
in

following
the
1985
strike
,
a
move
the
union
had
contested
in
a
previous

.
<END>
<START>
Judith
Valente
contributed
to
this
article
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
last
decade
,
many
corporations
have
embraced
the
``
utilization
management
''
cost
containment
strategy
as
a
way
to
control
health-care
costs
for
employees
.
<END>
<START>
These
programs
vary
widely
,
but
often
require
second
opinions
on
proposed
surgery
,
preadmission
reviews
of
elective
hospitalizations
and
reviews
of
treatment
during
illnesses
or
recovery
periods
.
<END>
<START>
Between
50
%
and
75
%
of
today
's
workers
are
covered
by
such
plans
,
up
from
5
%
five
years
ago
.
<END>
<START>
``
Employers
who
saw
a
short-term
moderation
in
benefit
expenditures
are
seeing
a
return
to
previous
trends
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
report
suggested
that
current
review
programs
are
too
narrow
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
unnecessary
and
inappropriate
use
of
the
hospital
,
and
not
the
actual
need
for
a
particular
procedure
,
has
been
the
main
focus
,
''
the
panel
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
As
a
general
rule
,
prior-review
programs
have
not
made
case-by-case
assessments
of
the
comparative
costs
of
alternative
treatments
or
sites
of
care
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
report
said
that
utilization
management
should
have
more
of
an
impact
as
federal
research
on
the
effectiveness
of
medical
treatments
helps
lead
to
medical
practice
guidelines
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
's
pretty
good
evidence
that
utilization
management
has
reduced
inappropriate
hospitalization
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
But
at
the
same
time
,
spending
on
physician
services
and
ambulatory
care
have
mushroomed
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
like
squeezing
a
balloon
,
''
Dr.
Bailit
said
.
<END>
<START>
Jerome
Grossman
,
chairman
of
the
panel
,
agrees
that
administrative
costs
of
utilization
management
programs
can
be
high
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
have
a
whole
staff
standing
ready
''
to
evaluate
the
appropriateness
of
recommended
treatment
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
panel
urged
greater
efforts
to
reduce
the
complexity
,
paperwork
and
cost
of
utilization
review
.
<END>
<START>
Renault
and
DAF
Trucks
NV
announced
a
preliminary
agreement
to
jointly
manufacture
a
line
of
trucks
in
Britain
and
France
.
<END>
<START>
The
French
state-controlled
auto
group
and
the
Dutch
truck
maker
plan
to
incorporate
the
new
trucks
into
their
product
lines
when
they
begin
production
toward
the
middle
of
the
1990s
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Gras
said
he
expects
a
definitive
agreement
between
the
two
companies
to
be
completed
in
the
next
few
months
.
<END>
<START>
The
venture
is
the
latest
example
of
the
trend
toward
cooperative
projects
in
Europe
ahead
of
the
1992
deadline
for
eliminating
trade
barriers
within
the
European
Community
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
the
companies
will
each
spend
about
FFr
1
billion
on
tooling
up
their
plants
.
<END>
<START>
By
pooling
their
resources
,
the
two
groups
have
effectively
halved
the
design
and
development
costs
that
would
otherwise
have
been
entailed
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Both
Renault
and
DAF
will
have
world-wide
marketing
rights
for
the
new
range
of
vans
and
light
trucks
.
<END>
<START>
DAF
is
16%-owned
by
British
Aerospace
,
with
a
further
6.5
%
held
by
the
Dutch
state-owned
chemical
group
NV
DSM
.
<END>
<START>
The
van
Doorne
family
of
the
Netherlands
holds
an
additional
11
%
of
DAF
's
capital
.
<END>
<START>
The
Federal
Reserve
System
is
the
standard
object
of
suggestions
for
organizational
and
institutional
changes
,
for
two
reasons
.
<END>
<START>
First
,
its
position
in
the
government
is
anomalous
.
<END>
<START>
It
has
an
unusual
kind
of
independence
from
elected
officials
and
still
has
authority
over
one
of
the
most
powerful
of
government
's
instruments
--
the
control
of
the
money
supply
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
we
have
a
condition
that
is
easily
described
as
undemocratic
.
<END>
<START>
As
former
Fed
Chairman
William
McChesney
Martin
used
to
say
,
they
would
have
to
take
the
punch
bowl
away
just
as
the
party
is
getting
interesting
.
<END>
<START>
So
the
Federal
Reserve
is
an
attractive
target
for
complaint
by
politicians
.
<END>
<START>
The
Fed
is
easily
assigned
the
blame
for
unpleasantness
,
like
high
interest
rates
or
slow
economic
growth
,
while
the
politicians
can
escape
responsibility
by
pointing
to
the
Fed
's
independence
.
<END>
<START>
Some
of
these
ideas
are
again
under
consideration
in
Congress
.
<END>
<START>
But
these
proposals
do
not
rest
on
a
view
of
what
the
Fed
's
problem
is
or
,
if
they
do
,
they
rest
on
an
incorrect
view
.
<END>
<START>
They
would
not
solve
the
problem
;
they
would
make
it
worse
.
<END>
<START>
The
problem
is
not
that
the
Fed
is
too
unresponsive
to
the
public
interest
.
<END>
<START>
On
the
contrary
,
it
is
too
responsive
to
an
incorrect
view
of
the
public
interest
.
<END>
<START>
The
price
level
in
the
U.S.
is
now
about
4
1/4
times
as
high
as
it
was
30
years
ago
.
<END>
<START>
On
average
,
something
that
cost
$
100
30
years
ago
now
costs
$
425
.
<END>
<START>
Or
,
a
wage
that
was
$
100
30
years
ago
would
buy
only
$
23.53
worth
of
stuff
today
.
<END>
<START>
On
two
occasions
the
inflation
rate
rose
to
more
than
10
%
a
year
.
<END>
<START>
In
each
case
the
ending
of
this
unsustainable
inflation
caused
a
severe
recession
--
the
two
worst
of
the
postwar
period
.
<END>
<START>
The
enormous
inflation
over
the
past
30
years
was
largely
due
to
monetary
policy
.
<END>
<START>
At
least
,
it
would
not
have
happened
without
the
support
of
monetary
policy
that
provided
for
a
10-fold
increase
in
the
money
supply
during
the
same
period
.
<END>
<START>
And
that
increase
in
the
money
supply
would
not
have
happened
without
the
consent
of
the
Federal
Reserve
.
<END>
<START>
The
basic
problem
of
monetary
policy
,
to
which
reform
of
the
Fed
should
be
addressed
,
is
to
prevent
a
recurrence
of
this
experience
.
<END>
<START>
There
were
two
general
reasons
for
the
mistaken
monetary
policy
of
the
past
30
years
:
<END>
<START>
1
.
To
some
extent
the
Federal
Reserve
shared
the
popular
but
incorrect
view
that
expansionary
monetary
policy
could
yield
a
net
improvement
in
employment
and
output
.
<END>
<START>
2
.
Even
where
the
Fed
did
not
share
this
view
it
felt
the
need
to
accommodate
to
it
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
all
the
formal
provisions
for
its
independence
,
the
Fed
seems
constantly
to
feel
that
if
it
uses
its
independence
too
freely
it
will
lose
it
.
<END>
<START>
The
common
proposals
for
reforming
the
Fed
would
only
make
the
situation
worse
,
if
they
had
any
effect
at
all
.
<END>
<START>
Putting
the
Secretary
of
the
Treasury
on
the
Board
of
Governors
,
one
of
the
leading
proposals
today
,
is
an
example
.
<END>
<START>
The
secretary
is
the
world
's
biggest
borrower
of
money
.
<END>
<START>
He
has
a
built-in
,
constant
longing
for
lower
interest
rates
.
<END>
<START>
How
should
a
reasonable
member
of
the
Federal
Reserve
Board
interpret
a
congressional
decision
to
put
the
secretary
on
the
board
?
<END>
<START>
Could
he
plausibly
interpret
it
as
encouragement
for
the
Fed
to
give
primary
emphasis
to
stabilizing
the
price
level
?
<END>
<START>
The
answer
seems
perfectly
clear
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
True
,
a
succession
of
Fed
chairmen
has
given
color
to
the
notion
that
the
Secretary
of
the
Treasury
belongs
on
the
Fed
.
<END>
<START>
The
Fed
's
case
for
its
own
independence
would
be
a
little
stronger
if
it
were
more
solicitous
of
the
independence
of
the
rest
of
the
government
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
The
Fed
's
problem
is
not
that
it
is
too
independent
,
or
too
unpolitical
.
<END>
<START>
The
Fed
is
responsive
to
,
and
can
not
help
being
responsive
to
,
the
more
overtly
political
part
of
the
government
.
<END>
<START>
The
Fed
exercises
a
power
given
to
it
by
Congress
and
the
president
.
<END>
<START>
But
Congress
and
the
president
accept
no
responsibility
for
the
exercise
of
the
power
they
have
given
the
Fed
.
<END>
<START>
Critics
of
the
present
arrangement
are
correct
to
say
that
it
is
undemocratic
.
<END>
<START>
To
leave
this
decision
to
an
``
independent
''
agency
is
not
only
undemocratic
.
<END>
<START>
The
greatest
contribution
Congress
could
make
at
this
time
would
be
to
declare
that
stabilizing
the
price
level
is
the
primary
responsibility
of
the
Federal
Reserve
System
.
<END>
<START>
Legislation
to
this
effect
has
been
introduced
in
Congress
in
this
session
by
Rep.
Stephen
Neal
-LRB-
D.
,
N.C
.
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
not
the
kind
of
thing
that
is
likely
to
be
enacted
,
however
.
<END>
<START>
Congress
would
be
required
to
make
a
hard
decision
,
and
Congress
would
much
prefer
to
leave
the
hard
decision
to
the
Fed
and
retain
its

of

fact
.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.

to
resume
travel
.
<END>
<START>
While
the
airport
was
closed
,
flights
were
diverted
to
airports
in
Sacramento
and
Stockton
,
Calif.
;
Reno
and
Las
Vegas
,
Nev.
;
and
Los
Angeles
.
<END>
<START>
A
United
spokesman
said
14
of
its
21
gates
were
unusable
,
mainly
because
of
water
damage
caused
when
a
sprinkler
system
was
triggered
by
the
tremors
.
<END>
<START>
The
United
spokesman
said
none
of
its
people
were
injured
at
the
airport
;
in
fact
,
as
the
airport
was
being
evacuated
Tuesday
night
,
two
babies
were
born
.
<END>
<START>
The
airports
in
San
Jose
and
Oakland
were
both
fully
operational
by
noon
yesterday
,
the
Federal
Aviation
Administration
said
.
<END>
<START>
In
terms
of
diversions
,
Denver
's
Stapleton
International
may
have
experienced
the
most
far-flung
:
A
United
flight
from
Japan
was
rerouted
there
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
think
that
's
the
first

from

to

,
''

.
<END>
<START>

into

,

.
<END>
<START>

in

,

,

the

.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're
in
the
dark
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Whitbread
&
Co.
put
its
spirits
division
up
for
sale
,
triggering
a
scramble
among
global
groups
for
the
British
company
's
brands
.
<END>
<START>
Whitbread
already
has
been
approached
by
``
about
half
a
dozen
''
companies
interested
in
buying
all
or
part
of
the
spirits
business
,
a
spokesman
said
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
expect
the
spirits
operations
and
some
California
vineyards
that
also
are
being
sold
to
fetch
about
#
500
million
-LRB-
$
788.8
million
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
Among
the
brands
for
sale
are
Beefeater
gin
,
the
No.
2
imported
gin
in
the
U.S.
,
and
Laphroaig
single-malt
whiskey
.
<END>
<START>
Also
for
sale
are
Buckingham
Wile
Co.
,
which
distributes
Cutty
Sark
blended
whiskey
in
the
U.S.
,
and
Whitbread
's
Atlas
Peak
Vineyards
in
California
's
Napa
Valley
.
<END>
<START>
Beefeater
alone
is
worth
as
much
as
#
300
million
,
analysts
said
.
<END>
<START>
Whitbread
bought
the
Beefeater
distillery
two
years
ago
for
#
174.5
million
.
<END>
<START>
That
purchase
represented
an
attempt
by
Whitbread
,
a
venerable
British
brewer
,
to
become
a
major
player
in
the
global
liquor
business
.
<END>
<START>
But
Whitbread
has
been
squeezed
by
giant
rivals
amid
widespread
consolidation
in
the
industry
.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
it
wants
to
concentrate
on
beer
and
its
newer
hotel
and
restaurant
operations
.
<END>
<START>
For
rival
liquor
companies
,
the
Whitbread
auction
is
a
rare
opportunity
to
acquire
valuable
brands
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
not
very
often
something
like
this
comes
up
,
''
said
Ron
Littleboy
,
a
liquor
company
analyst
at
Nomura
Research
Institute
in
London
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
division
will
be
sold
off
quite
rapidly
,
''
predicted
Neill
Junor
,
an
analyst
at
London
brokers
County
NatWest
WoodMac
.
<END>
<START>
Among
possible
buyers
,
Grand
Metropolitan
PLC
might
find
Beefeater
a
useful
addition
to
its
portfolio
.
<END>
<START>
Grand
Met
owns
Bombay
gin
,
the
No.
3
imported
gin
in
the
U.S.
;
rival
Guinness
PLC
has
the
No.
1
imported
brand
,
Tanqueray
.
<END>
<START>
The
Whitbread
spirits
auction
``
is
an
extremely
interesting
development
...
and
naturally
we
'll
be
considering
it
carefully
,
''
a
Grand
Met
spokesman
said
.
<END>
<START>
Guinness
,
which
owns
several
leading
whiskey
brands
plus
Gordon
's
gin
,
the
world
's
No.
1
gin
,
is
considered
less
likely
to
bid
for
the
Whitbread
spirits
.
<END>
<START>
A
Guinness
spokesman
declined
to
comment
.
<END>
<START>
Two
other
global
liquor
giants
,
Canada
's
Seagram
Co.
and
Britain
's
Allied-Lyons
PLC
,
also
are
possible
buyers
.
<END>
<START>
Seagram
's
gin
is
the
world
's
No.
2
gin
brand
,
but
the
company
does
n't
own
any
of
the
major
gin
brands
imported
in
the
U.S.
.
<END>
<START>
Allied-Lyons
,
while
powerful
in
whiskey
,
does
n't
own
any
major
white-spirit
brands
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
will
certainly
have
to
take
a

at
''
the
Whitbread
spirits
business
,
an

.
<END>
<START>
``
We
would
certainly

brand
in

.
''
<END>
<START>
A

spokesman
in
New

would
n't

.
<END>
<START>
Smaller
liquor
companies
,
such
as
Brown-Forman
Corp.
and
American
Brands
Inc.
of
the

,

are

to
be

.
<END>
<START>
Such

``
are
increasingly
being
left

''
in

global

,

.
<END>
<START>
In

,

.
<END>
<START>
Brown-Forman
,
a
Louisville
,
Ky.

,

to
comment
.
<END>
<START>
Whitbread
's
wine
,
spirits
and
soft-drink
operations
had
trading
profit
of
#
35.4
million
on
sales
of
#
315.5
million
in
the
year
ended
Feb.
25
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
,
which
is
retaining
most
of
its
wine
and
all
of
its
soft-drink
interests
,
did
n't

for

to
sell
.
<END>
<START>
But
analysts
estimate
their
trading
profit
at
#
30
million
.
<END>
<START>
Whitbread
had
total
pretax
profit
in
the
year
ended
Feb.
25
of
#
223.2
million
,
on
sales
of
#
2.26
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Whitbread
's
spirits
auction
occurs
amid
a
parallel
shakeup
in
the
British
beer
industry
.
<END>
<START>
Earlier
this
year
,
the
government
announced
plans
to
foster
increased
competition
in
the
industry
.
<END>
<START>
British
brewers
currently
own
thousands
of
pubs
,
which
in
turn
sell
only
the
breweries
'
beer
and
soft
drinks
.
<END>
<START>
Under
new
rules
,
many
of
the
country
's
pubs
would
become
``
free
houses
,
''
selling
beers
of
their
choice
.
<END>
<START>
Whitbread
now
intends
to
bolster
its
brewing
interests
,
in
an
effort
to
grab
a
share
of
sales
to
free
houses
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
,
which
last
month
paid
#
50.7
million
for
regional
British
brewer
Boddington
Group
PLC
,
has
about
13
%
of
the
British
beer
market
.
<END>
<START>
Whitbread
also
owns
the
license
to
brew
and
distribute
Heineken
and
Stella
Artois
beers
in
Britain
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
Whitbread
intends
to
focus
on
its
newer
hotel
,
liquor
store
and
restaurant
businesses
in
Europe
and
North
America
.
<END>
<START>
In
Britain
,
those
interests
include
the
Beefeater
steakhouse
chain
and
joint
ownership
with
PepsiCo
Inc.
of
the
country
's
Pizza
Hut
chain
.
<END>
<START>
In
Canada
and
the
U.S.
,
Whitbread
owns
The
Keg
chain
of
steak
and
seafood
restaurants
.
<END>
<START>
Focusing
on
beer
,
restaurants
and
hotels
means
``
we
can
concentrate
our
skills
and
resources
more
effectively
,
''
Peter
Jarvis
,
Whitbread
's
managing
director
,
said
in

.
<END>
<START>
The
spirits
business
``
would
require
substantial
additional
investment
to
enable
it
to
compete
effectively
in
the
first
division
of
global
players
.
''
<END>
<START>
Whitbread

Jarvis
,

48
,

company
's

.

,

.

Champion

,

,

,

.

.

,

25

.
<END>
<START>
Digital
Equipment
Corp.
is
planning
a
big
coming-out
party
on
Tuesday
for
its
first
line
of
mainframe
computers
.
<END>
<START>
But
an
uninvited
guest
is
expected
to
try
to
crash
the
party
.
<END>
<START>
On
the
morning
of
the
long-planned
announcement
,
International
Business
Machines
Corp.
is
to
introduce
its
own
new
mainframe
.
<END>
<START>
``
Their
attitude
is
,
`
You
want
to
talk
mainframes
,
we
'll
talk
mainframes
,
'
''
says
one
computer
industry
executive
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
're
deliberately
trying
to
steal
our
thunder
,
''
a
Digital
executive
complains
.
<END>
<START>
``
Maybe
we
should
take
it
as
a
compliment
.
''
<END>
<START>
Digital
's
target
is
the
$
40
billion
market
for
mainframe
computers
,
the
closet-sized
number-crunchers
that
nearly
every
big
company
needs
to
run
its
business
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
,
based
in
Armonk
,
N.Y.
,
has
dominated
the
market
for
decades
.
<END>
<START>
That
does
n't
scare
Digital
,
which
has
grown
to
be
the
world
's
second-largest
computer
maker
by
poaching
customers
of
IBM
's
mid-range
machines
.
<END>
<START>
Digital
,
based
in
Maynard
,
Mass.
,
hopes
to
stage
a
repeat
performance
in
mainframes
,
and
it
has
spent
almost
$
1
billion
developing
the
new
technology
.
<END>
<START>
A
spoiler
,
nimble
Tandem
Computers
Inc.
in
Cupertino
,
Calif.
,
jumped
into
the
fray
earlier
this
week
with
an
aggressively
priced
entry
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
appears
more
worried
about
Digital
,
which
has
a
broad
base
of
customers
waiting
for
the
new
line
,
dubbed
the
VAX
9000
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
going
to
be
nuclear
war
,
''
says
Thomas
Willmott
,
a
consultant
with
Aberdeen
Group
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
The
surge
in
competition
is
expected
to
stir
new
life
into
the
huge
mainframe
market
,
where
growth
has
slowed
to
single
digits
in
recent
years
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
's
traditional
mainframe
rivals
,
including
Unisys
Corp.
,
Control
Data
Corp.
and
NCR
Corp.
,
have
struggled
recently
.
<END>
<START>
Digital
is
promising
a
new
approach
.
<END>
<START>
And
unlike
IBM
's
water-cooled
mainframes
,
it
does
n't
need
any
plumbing
.
<END>
<START>
The
challengers
will
have
a
big
price
advantage
.
<END>
<START>
Digital
is
expected
to
tag
its
new
line
from
about
$
1.24
million
to
$
4.4
million
and
up
,
depending
on
configuration
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
about
half
the
price
of
comparably
equipped
IBM
mainframes
.
<END>
<START>
Tandem
's
pricing
is
just
as
aggressive
.
<END>
<START>
The
heightened
competition
will
hit
IBM
at
a
difficult
time
.
<END>
<START>
The
computer
giant
's
current
mainframe
line
,
which
has
sold
well
and
has
huge
profit
margins
,
is
starting
to
show
its
age
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
3090s
due
next
week
will
boost
performance
by
only
about
8
%
to
10
%
.
<END>
<START>
And
IBM
is
n't
expected
to
deliver
a
new
generation
of
mainframes
until
1991
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
no
one
expects
IBM
's
rivals
to
deliver
a
knockout
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
has
a
near-monopoly
on
mainframes
,
with
an
estimated
70
%
share
of
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
is
five
times
the
size
of
Digital
--
and
40
times
the
size
of
Tandem
--
and
wields
enormous
market
power
.
<END>
<START>
It
counts
among
its
customers
a
majority
of
the
world
's
largest
corporations
,
which
entrust
their
most
critical
business
information
to
IBM
computers
.
<END>
<START>
He
says
Digital
will
target
faster-growing
market
segments
such
as
on-line
transaction
processing
,
which
includes
retail-sales
tracking
,
airline
reservations
and
bank-teller
networks
.
<END>
<START>
Tandem
,
which
already
specializes
in
on-line
transaction
processing
,
is
a
potent
competitor
in
that
market
.
<END>
<START>
A
key
marketing
target
for
Digital
will
be
the
large
number
of
big
customers
who
already
own
both
Digital
and
IBM
systems
.
<END>
<START>
One
such
company
is
Bankers
Trust
Co
.
<END>
<START>
The
software
conversion
costs
would
dwarf
any
savings
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Rose
is
still
looking
seriously
at
the
9000
.
<END>
<START>
Bankers
Trust
uses
Digital
's
VAX
to
run
its
huge
money-transfer
and
capital
markets
accounts
,
juggling
hundreds
of
billions
of
dollars
each
day
,
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
As
that
system
grows
,
larger
computers
may
be
needed
.
<END>
<START>
``
In
the
past
,
customers
had
to
go
to
IBM
when
they
outgrew
the
VAX
.
<END>
<START>
Now
they
do
n't
have
to
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
That
's
going
to
cost
IBM
revenue
.
''
<END>
<START>
Analysts
say
Digital
can
expect
this
pent-up
demand
for
the
new
VAX
to
fuel
strong
sales
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
Barry
F.
Willman
,
an
analyst
at
Sanford
C.
Bernstein
&
Co.
,
estimates
the
9000
could
boost
sales
by
more
than
$
1
billion
in
the
fiscal
year
beginning
in
July
.
<END>
<START>
He
bases
the
estimate
on
a
survey
of
hundreds
of
Digital
's
largest
customers
.
<END>
<START>
Although
Digital
will
announce
a
full
family
of
mainframes
next
week
,
it
is
n't
expected
to
begin
shipping
in
volume
until
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
Four
more
models
,
aimed
squarely
at
IBM
's
commercial
customers
,
are
expected
to
begin
shipping
in
late
June
.
<END>
<START>
Most
analysts
do
n't
expect
the
new
mainframes
to
begin
contributing
significantly
to
revenue
before
the
fiscal
first
quarter
,
which
begins
next
July
1
.
<END>
<START>
Digital
's
new
line
has
been
a
long
time
coming
.
<END>
<START>
Digital
's
failure
to
deliver
a
true
mainframe-class
machine
before
now
may
have
cost
the
company
as
much
as
$
1
billion
in
revenue
in
fiscal
1989
,
Mr.
Willman
says
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
will
face
still
more
competition
in
coming
months
.
<END>
<START>
Amdahl
Corp.
,
backed

Japan
's
Fujitsu
Ltd.
,
has
a
growing
share
of
the
market
with
its
low-priced
,

.

<START>
The
frenetic
stock
and
bond
markets
cooled
off
,
but
the
dollar
slumped
.
<END>
<START>
Stocks
rose
slightly
as
trading
activity
slowed
from
the
frenzied
pace
earlier
this
week
.
<END>
<START>
Helped
by
futures-related
program
buying
,
the
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
gained
4.92
points
to
close
at
2643.65
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
Dow
Jones
Transportation
Average
fell
for
the
seventh-consecutive
session
as
more
investors
dumped
UAL
shares
.
<END>
<START>
Bond
prices
rallied
early
yesterday
morning
as
traders
scrambled
to
buy
Treasury
issues
on
fears
that
the
Northern
California
earthquake
might
lead
to
a
stock-market
debacle
.
<END>
<START>
But
when
stocks
held
steady
,
Treasury
bonds
later
retreated
.
<END>
<START>
Speculation
that
the
Federal
Reserve
will
lower
interest
rates
in
coming
weeks
helped
push
the
dollar
down
while
boosting
stocks
,
traders
said
.
<END>
<START>
But
many
investors
remain
wary
about
stocks
,
partly
because
they
expect
continued
turbulence
in
the
junk-bond
market
that
would
make
it
more
difficult
to
finance
corporate
takeovers
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
'm
surprised
we
did
n't
see
more
volatility
''
in
stocks
,
said
Raymond
F.
DeVoe
Jr.
,
market
strategist
at
Legg
Mason
Wood
Walker
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
think
the
problems
in
the
junk-bond
area
are
just
beginning
,
and
this
will
be
very
unsettling
for
companies
that
have
issued
junk
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
bull
market
,
credit
does
not
matter
,
''
Mr.
DeVoe
added
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
when
it
does
matter
,
then
it
's
the
only
thing
that
matters
.
''
<END>
<START>
``
Things
are
beginning
to
settle
down
.
<END>
<START>
The
markets
are
returning
to
normalcy
.
''
<END>
<START>
Oil
prices
initially
rose
on
fears
that
the
massive
earthquake
in
Northern
California
would
disrupt
production
.
<END>
<START>
But
prices
later
reversed
course
,
finishing
slightly
lower
,
as
investors
concluded
that
any
cuts
would
n't
be
large
and
that
foreign
oil
producers
would
quickly
pick
up
the
slack
.
<END>
<START>
In
major
market
activity
:
<END>
<START>
Stock
prices
rose
.
<END>
<START>
New
York
Stock
Exchange
volume
shrank
to
166.9
million
shares
from
224.1
million
Tuesday
.
<END>
<START>
Advancers
on
the
Big
Board
outpaced
decliners
by
822
to
668
.
<END>
<START>
Bond
prices
were
little
changed
in
sluggish
activity
.
<END>
<START>
The
yield
on
the
Treasury
's
30-year
issue
fell
slightly
to
8.03
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
dollar
dropped
.
<END>
<START>
In
New
York
late
yesterday
,
the
currency
was
at
141.45
yen
and
1.8485
marks
,
down
from
142.75
yen
and
1.8667
marks
late
Tuesday
.

L.

.

<START>
AMR
's
earnings
decline
comes
a
year
after
the
parent
company
of
American
Airlines
and
the
rest
of
the
airline
industry
set
profit
records
.
<END>
<START>
Some
analysts
say
the
latest
results
only
seem
pale
by
comparison
with
a
spectacular
second
half
of
1988
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
AMR
's
stumble
does
n't
bode
well
for
the
rest
of
the
industry
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
third
quarter
,
AMR
said
,
net
fell
to
$
137
million
,
or
$
2.16
a
share
,
from
$
150.3
million
,
or
$
2.50
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
rose
17
%
to
$
2.73
billion
from
$
2.33
billion
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
think
these
trends
will
continue
and
will
produce
a
very
disappointing
fourth
quarter
as
well
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Tim
Pettee
,
an
analyst
with
Merrill
Lynch
&
Co.
,
said
:
``
The
business
turned
faster
than
expected
.
<END>
<START>
Costs
are
giving
them
a
little
bit
of
trouble
,
and
the
whole
industry
is
having
a
pricing
problem
.
''
<END>
<START>
For
the
nine
months
,
AMR
's
net
rose
15
%
to
$
415.9
million
,
or
$
6.59
a
share
,
from
$
360.1
million
,
or
$
5.99
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
jumped
22
%
to
$
7.89
billion
from
$
6.46
billion
.
<END>
<START>
AMR
has
not
been
,
and
is
not
,
for
sale
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Crandall
said
the
company
's
current
decline
in
earnings
is
exactly
the
kind
of
situation
that
an
excessively
leveraged
company
laden
with
debt
from
a
takeover
would
find
difficult
to
weather
.
<END>
<START>
``
Our
very
disappointing
third-quarter
results
and
the
discouraging
outlook
for
the
fourth
quarter
underscore
the
importance
of
an
adequate
capital
base
,
''
he
said
.
<END>

<START>
Congress
should
stop
throwing
tax
dollars
out
to
sea
by
subsidizing
the
development
of
beach
communities
on
ecologically
fragile
coastal
barrier
islands
,
such
as
the
hard-hit
Isle
of
Palms
near
Charleston
.
<END>
<START>
As
you
mentioned
,
subsidies
for
development
on
a
number
of
barrier
islands
were
curtailed
in
1982
by
the
Coastal
Barrier
Resource
System
.
<END>
<START>
The
National
Taxpayers
Union
would
like
Congress
to
add
800,000
acres
to
the
453,000
of
shoreline
in
the
system
by
enacting
``
The
Coastal
Barrier
Improvement
Act
of
1989
.
''
<END>
<START>
This
bill
simply
says
that
if
you
want
to
develop
property
on
a
barrier
island
you
have
to
do
so
without
taxpayer
support
.
<END>
<START>
Private-property
rights
would
be
upheld
because
the
legislation
would
not
ban
coastal
development
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
home
builders
would
have
to
bear
the
full
costs
of
such
beach-house
construction
.
<END>
<START>
A
Taxpayers
Union
study
concluded
the
bill
would
save
taxpayers
up
to
$
9.3
billion
in
barrier-island
subsidies
over
20
years
.
<END>
<START>
Already
,
the
1982
legislation
has
saved
an
estimated
$
800
million
.
<END>
<START>
Marshall
Y.
Taylor
<END>
<START>
Communications
Director
<END>
<START>
National
Taxpayers
Union
<END>
<START>
The
government
said
13.1
%
of
Americans
,
or
31.9
million
people
,
were
living
in
poverty
in
1988
.
<END>
<START>
But
,
he
added
,
``
Since
the
late
1960s
,
the
distribution
of
income
has
been
slowly
getting
less
equal
.
<END>
<START>
There
was
no
reversal
-LCB-
of
that
trend
-RCB-
between
1987
and
1988
.
''
<END>
<START>
Per
capita
income
,
a
widely
used
measure
of
a
nation
's
economic
health
,
hit
a
record
in
1988
,
rising
1.7
%
after
inflation
adjustment
to
$
13,120
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
median
income
of
American
families
fell
0.2
%
,
the
first
time
it
has
failed
to
rise
since
1982
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
of
last
year
's
decline
,
the
government
's
estimate
for
the
number
of
people
living
below
the
poverty
line
declined
by
about
500,000
.
<END>
<START>
The
poverty
threshold
,
defined
as
three
times
food
expenses
as
calculated
by
the
Agricultural
Department
,
last
year
was
$
12,092
for
a
family
of
four
.
<END>
<START>
The
Census
Bureau
counts
all
cash
income
in
determining
whether
families
are
below
the
line
,
but
it
does
n't
consider
other
government
benefits
,
such
as
Medicare
.
<END>
<START>
Poverty
remains
far
more
widespread
among
blacks
than
other
Americans
.
<END>
<START>
In
1988
,
31.6
%
of
blacks
lived
in
poverty
,
compared
with
10.1
%
for
whites
and
26.8
%
for
Hispanics
.
<END>
<START>
But
two-thirds
of
all
poor
Americans
were
white
.
<END>
<START>
More
than
half
of
poor
families
were
headed
by
women
living
without
men
,
the
bureau
said
.
<END>
<START>
More
than
three-fourths
of
poor
black
families
were
headed
by
women
.
<END>
<START>
The
poverty
rate
of
children
under
18
years
old
dropped
last
year
to
19.7
%
from
20.5
%
in
1987
,
but
remained
far
higher
than
a
decade
ago
.
<END>
<START>
The
rate
among
the
elderly
--
12
%
in
1988
--
was
n't
significantly
lower
than
the
year
before
.
<END>
<START>
If
it
were
n't
for
Social
Security
payments
,
more
than
three
times
as
many
elderly
would
be
below
the
poverty
line
,
Mr.
Butz
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
Census
Bureau
also
said
:
<END>
<START>
--
Some
17.2
%
of
all
money
income
received
by
families
in
1988
went
to
the
wealthiest
5
%
of
all
families
,
up
from
16.9
%
in
1987
.
<END>
<START>
That
is
the
greatest
share
reported
for
any
year
since
1950
,
although
changing
definitions
over
the
years
distort
the
comparison
.
<END>
<START>
--
The
top
fifth
of
all
families
got
44
%
of
the
income
,
up
from
41.5
%
a
decade
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
The
bottom
fifth
of
all
families
got
4.6
%
of
the
income
,
down
from
5.2
%
a
decade
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Earnings
of
female
workers
were
unchanged
.
<END>
<START>
--
Women
working
full-time
earned
66
cents
for
every
dollar
earned
by
men
,
a
penny
more
than
in
1987
and
seven
cents
more
than
in
1978
.
<END>
<START>
--
Median
household
income
--
which
includes
both
those
living
in
families
and
those
who
are
n't
--
rose
0.3
%
last
year
to
$
27,225
after
inflation
.
<END>
<START>
It
rose
sharply
in
the
Northeast
and
Midwest
and
fell
slightly
in
the
South
and
West
.
<END>
<START>
Median
family
income
was
$
32,191
,
down
0.2
%
.
<END>
<START>
--
Per
capita
income
of
blacks
,
though
still
only
60
%
that
of
whites
,
rose
3.9
%
in
1988
,
while
per
capita
income
of
whites
rose
only
1.5
%
.
<END>
<START>
--
Among
married
couples
,
the
gap
between
blacks
and
whites
narrowed
sharply
,
as
income
of
black
families
shot
up
6.8
%
while
income
of
whites
did
n't
budge
.
<END>
<START>
Critics
on
the
left
and
right
have
been
calling
for
all
sorts
of
revisions
to
the
measure
for
years
.
<END>
<START>
A
report
by
the
staff
of
the
Joint
Economic
Committee
of
Congress
released
yesterday
concluded
,
``
It
is
misleading
to
make
this
change
without
adjusting
for
other
changes
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
official
poverty
threshold
is
set
by
the
Office
of
Management
and
Budget
.
<END>
<START>
John
E.
Hayes
Jr.
was
elected

,
president
and

,

S.

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
Kansas
Power
said
Mr.
Black
,
61
,
chose

.

<START>
The
space
shuttle
Atlantis
boosted
the
Galileo
spacecraft
on
its
way
to
Jupiter
,
giving
a
big
lift
as
well
to
an
ambitious
U.S.
program
of
space
exploration
.
<END>
<START>
But
yesterday
,
as
Atlantis
rumbled
into
a
patch
of
clear
sky
above
Florida
with
storm
clouds
closing
in
on
it
,
NASA
sought
to
turn
Galileo
into
a
symbol
of
triumph
.
<END>
<START>
``
NASA
did
it
right
;
that
's
the
message
,
''
said
J.R.
Thompson
,
the
agency
's
deputy
administrator
.
<END>
<START>
The
$
1.4
billion
robot
spacecraft
faces
a
six-year
journey
to
explore
Jupiter
and
its
16
known
moons
.
<END>
<START>
Jupiter
is
so
enormous
--
its
mass
is
318
times
that
of
Earth
--
that
its
gravity
may
have
trapped
these
primordial
gases
and
never
let
them
escape
.
<END>
<START>
Some
scientists
have
suggested
that
comets
and
asteroids
may
have
brought
enough
of
this
kind
of
material
from
the
outer
solar
system
to
Earth
to
spawn
life
.
<END>
<START>
Beginning
in
December
1995
,
Galileo
will
begin
a
two-year
tour
of
the
Jovian
moons
.
<END>
<START>
In
1979
,
two
Voyager
spacecraft
sent
back
stunning
photos
of
Jovian
moons
Io
and
Europa
that
showed
them
to
be
among
the
most
intriguing
bodies
in
the
solar
system
.
<END>
<START>
The
photos
showed
active
geysers
on
Io
spewing
sulfurous
material
190
miles
into
its
atmosphere
and
indicated
that
Europa
may
have
an
ocean
hidden
under
a
thick
sheet
of
ice
.
<END>
<START>
Atlantis
lifted
Galileo
from
the
launch
pad
at
12:54
p.m.
EDT
and
released
the
craft
from
its
cargo
bay
about
six
hours
later
.
<END>
<START>
``
Galileo
is
on
its
way
to
another
world
in
the
hands
of
the
best
flight
controllers
in
this
world
,
''
Atlantis
Commander
Donald
Williams
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
Fly
safely
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
five-member
Atlantis
crew
will
conduct
several
experiments
,
including
growing
plants
and
processing
polymeric
materials
in
space
,
before
their
scheduled
landing
at
Edwards
Air
Force
Base
,
Calif.
,
Monday
.
<END>
<START>
The
Galileo
project
started
in
1977
,
and
a
number
of
project
veterans
were
on
hand
to
watch
the
launch
.
<END>
<START>
An
ebullient
Mr.
Johnson
,
wearing
a
NASA
baseball
cap
and
carrying
a
camera
and
binoculars
,
called
the
launch
``
fantastic
.
''
<END>
<START>
Benny
Chin
,
manager
of
the
Galileo
probe
,
compared
it
to
watching
a
child
leave
home
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
'm
happy
and
sad
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Anti-nuclear
activists
took
a
less
positive
view
.
<END>
<START>
Having
argued
that
Galileo
's
plutonium
power
source
could
have
released
lethal
doses
of
radiation
if
the
shuttle
exploded
yesterday
,
they
were
n't
quieted
by
yesterday
's
successful
launch
.
<END>
<START>
Galileo
will
skim
past
Earth
in
1990
and
1992
,
collecting
energy
from
the
planet
's
gravitational
field
to
gain
momentum
for
its
trip
to
Jupiter
.
<END>
<START>
The
protesters
point
out
that
Galileo
also
could
crash
to
Earth
then
.
<END>
<START>
They
said
they
dropped

to

the
Kennedy
Space
Center
after
NASA
beefed
up

.
<END>
<START>
One
protest
did
get
past
NASA
's
guard
,
though
;
a
computer
virus
caused
anti-Galileo
messages
to
flash
onto
some
computer

NASA

.
<END>
<START>
The
successful
launch
continues
a
remarkable
recovery
in
the
U.S.
space-science
program
.
<END>
<START>
An

,

,
already
is

and

.
<END>
<START>
Voyager
2
sent

of
Neptune
and

,

,
this
summer
.
<END>
<START>
Next

,

to

a

to

dating
from
the

.
<END>
<START>
In
December
,

Columbia
will

to
retrieve
a
satellite
that
's
been
in
orbit
for
nearly
five
years
measuring
the
deleterious

of

on

and

.
<END>
<START>

,

Discovery
will

,
a
$
1.5

designed
to

.
<END>
<START>
Not

's

,

.
<END>
<START>
Around

,

Max

,

NASA

,
will

back
into

Earth
's

.
<END>
<START>
NASA
wo
n't
attempt

;
instead
,

will

to
predict

any
of

rubble
will

to

.

<START>
The
Associated
Press
's

to

.
<END>
<START>
Private

,

,

,

``

.
''
<END>
<START>
One

even
displayed
25

.
<END>
<START>

recall

Charleston

about

's

to

.
<END>
<START>
The
sense
grows
that
modern

simply
do
n't
perform

functions
well
.
<END>
<START>
Bally
Manufacturing
Corp.
and
New
York
developer
Donald
Trump
have
agreed
in
principle
to
a
$
6.5
million
settlement
of
shareholder
litigation
stemming
from
Bally
's
alleged
greenmail
payment
to
Mr.
Trump
.
<END>
<START>
The
term
greenmail
refers
to
a
situation
where
a
company
pays
a
premium
over
market
value
to
repurchase
a
stake
held
by
a
potential
acquirer
.
<END>
<START>
That
settlement
represented
the
first
time
shareholders
were
granted
a
major
payment
in
a
greenmail
case
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Steinberg
made
a
$
59.7
million
profit
on
the
sale
to
Disney
of
his
investment
in
the
company
in
1984
.
<END>
<START>
But
lawyers
said
Mr.
Steinberg
probably
faced
much
more
potential
liability
because
,
when
he
sued
Disney
during
his
takeover

,
he
filed
on

all

.
<END>
<START>
When

to
pay
Mr.
Steinberg
a

,
the
New
York
investor
did
n't
demand
the
company
also
pay
a
premium
to
other

.
<END>
<START>
When
Mr.
Trump
sued
Bally
,
he
sued
only
on
behalf
of
himself
.
<END>
<START>
That
rule
gives
boards
of
directors
wide
latitude
in
deciding
how

deal
with
dissident
shareholders
.

<START>
SENATE
HEARS
final
arguments
in
impeachment
trial
of
federal
judge
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
,
U.S.
Judge
Alcee
Hastings
faced
his
jury
--
the
full
U.S.
Senate
--
and
said
,
``
I
am
not
guilty
of
having
committed
any
crime
.
''
<END>
<START>
Seventeen
articles
of
impeachment
against
the
Florida
judge
,
one
of
the
few
blacks
on
the
U.S.
bench
,
were
approved
by
the
House
in
August
1988
.
<END>
<START>
He
is
also
accused
of
lying
under
oath
and
of
leaking
information
obtained
from
a
wiretap
he
supervised
.
<END>
<START>
The
Senate
's
public
gallery
was
packed
with
Judge
Hastings
'
supporters
,
who
erupted
into
applause
after
he
finished
his
argument
.
<END>
<START>
Judge
Hastings
,
who
was
acquitted
of
similar
charges
by
a
federal
jury
in
1983
,
claims
he
is
being
victimized
and
that
the
impeachment
proceedings
against
him
constitute
double
jeopardy
.
<END>
<START>
The
Senate
will
deliberate
behind
closed
doors
today
and
is
scheduled
to
vote
on
the
impeachment
tomorrow
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
judge
is
impeached
,
as
is
thought
likely
,
he
will
be
removed
from
office
immediately
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
Judge
Hastings
has
said
he
will
continue
to
fight
and
is
contemplating
an
appeal
of
any
impeachment
to
the
U.S.
Supreme
Court
.
<END>
<START>
COMPANIES
SEEKING
to
make
insurers
pay
for
pollution
cleanup
win
court
victory
.
<END>
<START>
Travelers
and
other
insurers
have
maintained
that
cleanup
costs
are
n't
damages
and
thus
are
n't
covered
under
commercial
policies
.
<END>
<START>
The
appeals
court
disagreed
on
both
counts
.
<END>
<START>
Avondale
was
notified
by
Louisiana
officials
in
1986
that
it
was
potentially
responsible
for
a
cleanup
at
an
oil-recycling
plant
.
<END>
<START>
Avondale
asked
Travelers
to
defend
it
in
the
state
proceeding
,
but
the
insurer
did
n't
respond
.
<END>
<START>
The
appeals
court
upheld
a
district
judge
's
ruling
that
the
insurer
had
to
defend
the
company
in
such
proceedings
.
<END>
<START>
The
appeals
court
also
said
,
``
We
think
an
ordinary
businessman
reading
this
policy
would
have
believed
himself
covered
for
the
demands
and
potential
damage
claims
''
stemming
from
any
cleanup
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
the
decision
was
the
first
in
which
a
federal
appeals
court
has
ruled
whether
administrative
government
proceedings
qualify
as
litigation
.
<END>
<START>
Barry
R.
Ostrager
,
an
attorney
for
Travelers
,
said
,
``
there
are
procedural
bases
on
which
this
case
will
be
appealed
further
.
''
<END>
<START>
NEW
YORK
'S
poor
face
nearly
three
million
legal
problems
a
year
without
legal
help
.
<END>
<START>
That
is
the
conclusion
of
a
report
released
by
the
New
York
State
Bar
Association
.
<END>
<START>
The
report
was
based
on
a
telephone
survey
of
1,250
low-income
households
across
the
state
,
a
mail
survey
of
major
legal-services
programs
and
on-site
interviews
with
individuals
in
the
field
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
the
study
,
slightly
more
than
34
%
of
those
surveyed
reported
having
at
least
one
housing
problem
every
year
for
which
they
had
no
legal
help
.
<END>
<START>
Nearly
36
%
ranked
housing
problems
as
their
most
serious
unmet
legal
need
.
<END>
<START>
During
the
15-month
survey
,
43
%
of
all
legal-services
programs
said
that
at
some
period
they
were
unable
to
accept
new
clients
unless
they
had
an
emergency
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Genova
said
the
committee
may
meet
to
propose
solutions
to
the
problems
identified
in
the
study
.
<END>

.

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
proposed
agreement
involving
the
world
's
tallest
building
,
Chicago-based
Sears
would
receive
about
half
the
money
through
conventional
mortgage
financing
and
the
other
half
as
a
convertible
mortgage
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
end
of
the
term
of
the
convertible
loan
,
Sears
could
still
own
half
the
building
,
and
AEW
could
own
the
other
half
.
<END>
<START>
Neither
side
would
comment
.
<END>
<START>
The
parties
are
currently
negotiating
over
who
would
manage
the
building
,
which
will
be
emptied
of
6,000
employees
from
Sears
'
merchandise
group
,
which
is
moving
elsewhere
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
manager
will
face
the
daunting
task
of
leasing
1.8
million
square
feet
in
a
relatively
soft
Chicago
real
estate
market
.
<END>
<START>
Also
,
it
has
not
yet
been
decided
exactly
how
much
of
the
mortgage
AEW
will
be
able
to
convert
into
equity
.
<END>
<START>
Convertible
mortgages
have
become
an
increasingly
popular
way
to
finance
prestigious
buildings
of
late
.
<END>
<START>
During
the
term
,
the
lender
can
either
receive
a
percentage
of
cash
flow
,
a
percentage
of
the
building
's
appreciation
or
a
fixed
return
.
<END>
<START>
The
main
advantage
of
a
convertible
mortgage
is
that
it
is
not
a
sale
and
therefore
does
not
trigger
costly
transfer
taxes
and
reappraisal
.
<END>
<START>
Sears
said
it
would
put
the
110-story
tower
on
the
block
almost
a
year
ago
as
part
of
its
anti-takeover

.
<END>
<START>
But
Japanese

shied

out

fear

of

.

.
<END>

,

,

.

<START>
However
,

also

.

AEW
,

AEW

$
3.5

,

.

<START>
Tandy
Corp.
said
it
signed
a
definitive
agreement
to
acquire
two
units
of
Datatronic
AB
of
Stockholm
for
cash
.
<END>
<START>
The
amount
was
n't
disclosed
.
<END>
<START>
The
electronics
maker
and
retailer
previously
estimated
the
sale
price
at
between
$
100
million
and
$
200
million
for
Datatronic
's
Victor
microcomputer
and
Micronic
hand-held
computer
subsidiaries
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
Tandy
will
acquire
rights
to
the
Victor
and
Micronic
names
for
computers
.
<END>
<START>
During
1988
,
the
Datatronic
subsidiaries
had
combined
sales
in
excess
of
$
200
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
transaction
will
give
Tandy
a
well-known
European
computer
brand
that
includes
2,700
dealers
and
distributors
marketing
to
medium-sized
business
and
educational
institutions
.
<END>
<START>
Closing
of
the
transaction
is
subject
to
certain
conditions
and
regulatory
approvals
,
the
company
said
.
<END>
<START>
Two
rules
in
pending
congressional
legislation
threaten
to
hinder
leveraged
buy-outs
by
raising
the
price
tags
of
such
deals
by
as
much
as
10
%
.
<END>
<START>
Wall
Street
is
seething
over
the
rules
,
which
would
curtail
the
tax
deductibility
of
debt
used
in
most
LBOs
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
some
investment
bankers
have
already
started
restructuring
deals
to
cope
with
the
expected
rules
.
<END>
<START>
Wall
Street
has
all
but
conceded
on
the
issue
and
is
now
lobbying
for
the
less
onerous
Senate
version
of
one
of
the
provisions
.
<END>
<START>
At
issue
is
the
deductibility
of
certain
junk
bonds
that
are
used
in
most
LBOs
.
<END>
<START>
Such
high-yield
debt
is
similar
to
a
zero-coupon
bond
in
that
it
is
sold
at
a
discount
to
face
value
,
with
interest
accruing
instead
of
being
paid
to
the
holder
.
<END>
<START>
Under
current
rules
,
that
accrued
interest
is
deductible
by
the
company
issuing
the
debt
.
<END>
<START>
The
House
version
of
the
legislation
would
kill
that
deduction
,
and
label
any
such
debt
as
equity
,
which
is
n't
deductible
.
<END>
<START>
The
less-rigorous
Senate
version
would
defer
the
deductibility
for
roughly
five
years
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
see
these
in
just
about
every
LBO
,
''
said
Robert
Willens
,
senior
vice
president
in
charge
of
tax
issues
at
Shearson
Lehman
Hutton
Inc.
in
New
York
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
becomes
a
source
of
cash
''
for
the
company
making
the
LBO
because
it
gets
a
deduction
and
does
n't
have
to
repay
the
debt
for
several
years
.
<END>
<START>
Typically
,
Mr.
Willens
estimates
,
this
type
of
debt
makes
up
15
%
to
20
%
of
the
financing
for
LBOs
.
<END>
<START>
These
types
of
bonds
have
been
used
in
buy-outs
of
companies
such
as
RJR
Nabisco
Inc.
,
Storer
Communications
Inc.
and
Kroger
Co
.
<END>
<START>
But
that
rule
is
being
virtually
overlooked
by
Wall
Street
,
which
is
concentrating
on
coping
with
the
deduction
issue
.
<END>
<START>
Several
Wall
Street
officials
say
the
proposed
legislation
already
is
having
an
impact
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
would
have
paid
more
if
we
thought
that
law
was
n't
going
to
pass
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
That
would
force
the
buy-out
firm
and
the
target
company
's
management
to
reduce
their
level
of
ownership
.
<END>
<START>
Another
solution
,
said
a
tax
lawyer
who
requested
anonymity
,
is
for
firms
to
use
convertible
bonds
that
sell
at
a
discount
.
<END>
<START>
Since
they
have
a
lower
interest
rate
,
they
would
n't
fall
under
the
junk-bond
category
that
would
lose
its
deductibility
.
<END>
<START>
The
bill
would
then
declare
that
the
debt
is
equity
and
therefore
is
n't
deductible
.
<END>
<START>
The
Senate
bill
would
only
deny
the
deduction
until
interest
is
actually
paid
.
<END>
<START>
Currently
,
even
though
the
issuer
does
n't
pay
tax
,
the
debt
holder
is
taxed
on
the
accrued
interest
.
<END>
<START>
But
those
holders
are
often
foreign
investors
and
tax-exempt
pension
funds
that
do
n't
pay
taxes
on
their
holdings
.
<END>
<START>
The
Senate
estimates
that
its
version
of
the
provision
would
yield
$
17
million
the
first
year
and
a
total
of
$
409
million
over
five
years
.
<END>
<START>
The
House
version
would
raise
slightly
more
.
<END>
<START>
Even
if
Wall
Street
finds
ways
around
the
new
rules
,
a
Senate
aide
contends
LBOs
will
become
somewhat
more
difficult
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
's
no
question
it
will
make
LBOs
more
expensive
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
interest
deduction
was
the
engine
that
made
these
things
more
productive
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
publicly
offered
commodity
fund
fell
4.2
%
in
September
,
largely
because
of
the
volatile
markets
in
foreign
currencies
,
according
to
Norwood
Securities
.
<END>
<START>
The
firm
said
that
losers
outnumbered
gainers
by
more
than
three
to
one
among
the
122
funds
it
tracks
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
first
nine
months
of
the
year
,
Norwood
said
the
average
fund
has
lost
3.3
%
.
<END>
<START>
President
Bush
signed
a
disaster
declaration
covering
seven
Northern
California
counties
.
<END>
<START>
The
declaration
immediately
made
the
counties
eligible
for

,

to

.
<END>

.
<END>
<START>

,

.

``

I
think

,

required

.
''
<END>
<START>
In

.
<END>
<START>
Money

bill

Federal

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
But

;

.
<END>
<START>
FEMA

,

.

<END>

<START>
FARMERS

.

?
<END>
<START>
The

arrives

after

's

effort
:

output
at

,

51
%
from

.
<END>
<START>

24
%
.
<END>
<START>

,

paid

for

,

in

,

20

.

<START>

do

in

way

soon

.

this

and

.

.

,

``

,
''

.

.

<START>
John
R.
Wilke
contribued
to
this
article
.
<END>
<START>
Michael
Maynard
offered
the
world
a
faster
way
to
break
eggs
.
<END>
<START>
As
thanks
,
the
egg
industry
tried
to
break
him
.
<END>
<START>
And
the
egg
producers
have
done
a
pretty
good
job
.
<END>
<START>
They
tried
to
put
Mr.
Maynard
out
of
business
by
an
act
of
Congress
.
<END>
<START>
Egg-industry
lobbying
helped
persuade
six
states
to
ban
Mr.
Maynard
's
automatic
egg-breaking
machine
because
of
fears
over
salmonella
.
<END>
<START>
His
company
,
Misa
Manufacturing
Inc.
,
was
forced
to
seek
protection
from
creditors
under
federal
bankruptcy
law
in
1987
and
has
since
been
liquidated
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Maynard
is
n't
the
first
entrepreneur
to
bump
up
against
entrenched
interests
.
<END>
<START>
Now
one
might
ask
why
people
who
sell
eggs
would
fight
someone
who
is
trying
to
make
it
easier
to
crack
them
.
<END>
<START>
Part
of
the
answer
lies
in
the
nature
of
the
industry
.
<END>
<START>
Many
larger
egg
producers
are
also
egg
processors
,
who
crack
,
inspect
,
and
sanitize
billions
of
eggs
,
turning
them
into
powdered
,
liquified
or
frozen
egg
products
.
<END>
<START>
But
for
companies
that
use
hundreds
of
eggs
a
day
,
breaking
them
by
hand
can
get
,
well
,
out
of
hand
.
<END>
<START>
One
Egg
King
--
which
at
just
under
four
feet
tall
and
two
feet
wide
has
been
likened
to
the
robot
R2-D2
--
can
crack
about
20,000
eggs
an
hour
.
<END>
<START>
Because
fresh
eggs
are
less
expensive
than
processed
ones
,
a
big
egg
user
can
recover
the
Egg
King
's
$
3,390
cost
in
a
few
months
,
says
Mr.
Maynard
.
<END>
<START>
Such
centrifugal
egg
breakers
have
been
around
since
the
1890s
.
<END>
<START>
But
when
Mr.
Maynard
came
forward
with
his
machine
in
the
early
1970s
nobody
else
was
offering
them
in
the
U.S.
.
<END>
<START>
The
main
reason
:
salmonella
.
<END>
<START>
Chickens
carry
this
bacteria
,
which
can
cause
upset
stomachs
and
,
in
rare
cases
,
death
among
people
.
<END>
<START>
Hens
sometimes
pass
salmonella
to
the
eggs
,
and
it
can
also
be
found
on
unclean
shells
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
,
any
machine
that
breaks
large
amounts
of
eggs
at
once
has
the
potential
to
spread
salmonella
if
a
bad
egg
gets
in
with
the
good
ones
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Maynard
claims
this
is
a
manageable
problem
.
<END>
<START>
With
nearly
4,000
machines
in
use
,
there
have
been
no
salmonella
problems
as
long
as
instructions
were
followed
,
Mr.
Maynard
boasts
.
<END>
<START>
He
says
the
handful
of
salmonella
cases
involving
products
that
may
have
used
eggs
broken
by
an
Egg
King
stemmed
from
a
failure
to
adequately
cook
the
products
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
says
that
's
no
more
a
reason
for
banning
Egg
Kings
than
bad
drivers
are
a
reason
for
banning
cars
.
<END>
<START>
Opponents
do
n't
buy
such
arguments
.
<END>
<START>
``
Human
nature
being
what
it
is
,
people
do
n't
always
follow
instructions
,
''
says
Jack
Guzewich
,
chief
of
food
protection
for
the
New
York
state
Health
Department
.
<END>
<START>
Leading
the
assault
against
the
Egg
King
has
been
United
Egg
Producers
.
<END>
<START>
The
UEP
declines
to
comment
,
but
the
group
's
attorney
,
Alfred
Frawley
,
says
the
group
's
actions
are
motivated
solely
by
``
health
concerns
.
''
<END>
<START>
An
early
battleground
was
the
U.S.
Department
of
Agriculture
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Maynard
initially
won

for
his
machine
to
be
used
at
egg-processing
facilities
regulated
by
the
USDA
's

Inspection

.
<END>
<START>
Unfortunately
for
Mr.
Maynard
,
another
branch
of
the
USDA
,
the
Agricultural
Marketing
Service
,
was
in

of

.
<END>
<START>
The
egg

also
lobbied
the
Food
and
Drug
Administration
.
<END>
<START>
But
the

in
a
1985

to
the
United

said
that
there
was
``
little

''

as

.
<END>
<START>

to

,

from

a

to
ban

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Maynard
,

at

,

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

's

,

.
<END>
<START>

``

''

.
<END>
<START>

,

to

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

,

have

's

,

.
<END>
<START>
An

that
Mr.

in

against

and

.
<END>

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.

pushed

into

.
<END>
<START>
Now

where

.

.

<START>
Money-market
mutual
fund
assets
grew
at
nearly
three
times
their
usual
rate
in
the
latest
week
,
as

opted
for
safety
instead

.
<END>
<START>
Money-fund
assets
soared
$
4.5
billion
in

,
to

$
348.4
billion
,

,

,

.

<START>

,
''

,

.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
the
proverbial
flight
to
safety
.
''
<END>
<START>
Despite
recent
declines
in
interest
rates
,
money
funds
continue
to
offer
better
yields
than
other
comparable
investments
.
<END>
<START>

average
seven-day

yield
on
the
400

tracked
by
IBC/Donoghue
's
was
8.55
%
in
the
latest
week
,
down

8.60
%
.
<END>
<START>
Compound
yields
assume
reinvestment
of
dividends
and
that
current
yields
continue
for
a
year
.
<END>
<START>
Money-fund
assets
have
been
rising
at
an
average
rate
of
$
1.6
billion
a
week
in
recent
months
,
Ms.
Negus
said
,
reflecting
the
relatively
high
yields
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
latest
week
,
funds
open
to
institutions
alone
grew
by
$
1.8
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Some
fund
managers
say
inflows
could
increase
in
coming
days
as
a
result
of
stock
selling
in
the
wake
of
Friday
's
190.58
point
drop
in
the
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
you
're
selling
equities
,
you
do
n't
start
getting
proceeds
for
five
to
seven
days
,
''
said
Frank
Rachwalski
,
who
manages
the
Kemper
Money
Market
Fund
.
<END>
<START>
Monday
and
Tuesday
``
were
lackluster
in
comparison
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
People
are
n't
necessarily
running
scared
,
''
Mr.
Litvack
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
're
maintaining
their
attitude
toward
investing
,
which
has
leaned
toward
the
conservative
recently
.
''
<END>
<START>
Money-fund
yields
tend
to
lag
interestrate
trends
as
portfolio
managers
adjust
the
maturities
of
their
investments
--
short-term
Treasury
securities
,
commercial
paper
and
the
like
--
to
capture
the
highest
yields
.
<END>
<START>
Maturities
usually
are
shorter
when
rates
are
rising
and
longer
when
they
are
falling
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
maturity
of
the
funds
tracked
by
IBC/Donoghue
's
remained
at
38
days
for
the
third
consecutive
week
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
as
short
as
29
days
at
the
start
of
this
year
,
when
rates
were
marching
steadily
upward
,
and
hit
42
days
in
August
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
seven-day
simple
yield
of
the
funds
fell
to
8.21
%
this
week
from
8.26
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
average
30-day
simple
yield
was
8.26
%
,
compared
with
8.27
%
the
week
before
,
and
the
30-day
compound
yield
slid
to
8.60
%
from
8.61
%
.
<END>
<START>
Some
funds
are
posting
yields
far
higher
than
the
average
.
<END>
<START>
The
highest
yielding
taxable
fund
this
week
was
Harbor
Money
Market
Fund
,
with
a
seven-day
compound
yield
of
12.75
%
.
<END>
<START>
That
included
capital
gains
that
were
passed
along
to
customers
.
<END>
<START>
Among
the
other
high-yielding
funds
,
Fidelity
's
Spartan
Fund
had
a
seven-day
compound
yield
of
9.33
%
in
the
latest
week
.
<END>
<START>
The
seven-day
compound
yield
of
the
Dreyfus
Worldwide
Dollar
Fund
was
9.51
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
complex
restructuring
,
which
was
long
expected
,
transforms
London-based
WCRS
from
primarily
a
creator
of
advertising
into
one
of
Europe
's
largest
buyers
of
advertising
time
and
space
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
creates
a
newly
merged
world-wide
ad
agency
controlled
by
Eurocom
and
headed
jointly
by
New
York
ad
man
Jerry
Della
Femina
and
two
top
WCRS
executives
.
<END>
<START>
The
merged
agency
's
admittedly
ambitious
goal
:
to
become
one
of
the
world
's
10
largest
agencies
,
while
attracting
more
multinational
clients
than
the
agencies
were
able
to
attract
alone
.
<END>
<START>
For
Eurocom
,
meanwhile
,
the
move
gives
it
a
strong
U.S.
foothold
in
Della
Femina
,
and
more
than
quadruples
the
size
of
its
ad
agency
business
world-wide
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
Eurocom
,
which
had
held
20
%
of
WCRS
's
ad
unit
,
will
pay
#
43.5
million
-LRB-
$
68.5
million
-RRB-
to
raise
its
stake
to
60
%
.
<END>
<START>
That
price
also
covers
Eurocom
raising
to
60
%
its
51
%
stake
in
Europe
's
Belier
Group
,
a
joint
venture
ad
agency
network
it
owns
with
WCRS
.
<END>
<START>
Eurocom
will
also
have
the
right
to
buy
the
remaining
40
%
of
the
merged
ad
agency
group
in
six
years
.
<END>
<START>
The
transaction
places
the
three
executives
squarely
at
the
helm
of
a
major
agency
with
the
rather
unwieldy
name
of
Eurocom
WCRS
Della
Femina
Ball
Ltd.
,
or
EWDB
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Della
Femina
will
be
joint
chairman
with
former
WCRS
executive
Robin
Wight
.
<END>
<START>
Both
will
report
to
Tim
Breene
,
a
former
WCRS
executive
who
will
be
chief
executive
officer
at
the
new
agency
.
<END>
<START>
``
Our
goal
is
to
develop
quite
rapidly
to
a
top-10
position
...
by
the
end
of
three
years
from
now
.
<END>
<START>
It
implies
very
dramatic
growth
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
He
added
that
Eurocom
and
WCRS
had
agreed
to
provide
a
development
fund
of
#
100
million
for
acquisitions
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
agency
group
is
already
in
discussions
about
a
possible
purchase
in
Spain
,
while
Mr.
Breene
said
it
also
plans
to
make
acquisitions
in
Scandinavia
,
Germany
and
elsewhere
.
<END>
<START>
Cracking
the
top
10
within
three
years
will
be
difficult
at
best
.
<END>
<START>
Della
Femina
had
billings
of
just
$
660
million
last
year
and
ranked
as
the
U.S.
's
24th-largest
ad
agency
.
<END>
<START>
The
merged
company
that
it
now
becomes
part
of
will
have
billings
of
just
more
than
$
2.6
billion
--
most
of
that
in
Europe
--
bringing
it
to
about
14th
world-wide
.
<END>
<START>
To
make
it
to
top-10
status
,
it
would
have
to
leapfrog
over
such
formidable
forces
as
Grey
Advertising
,
D'Arcy
Masius
Benton
&
Bowles
and
Omnicom
's
DDB
Needham
.
<END>
<START>
The
merged
agency
's
game
plan
to
attract
multinational
packaged-goods
advertisers
may
prove
equally
difficult
.
<END>
<START>
Since
then
,
Della
Femina
won
Pan
Am
as
an
international
client
and
also
does
work
for
a
few
packaged-goods
clients
,
including
Dow
Chemical
Co.
's
Saran
Wrap
.
<END>
<START>
But
major
packaged-goods
players
of
the
world
--
such
as
Procter
&
Gamble
,
Colgate-Palmolive
and
Unilever
--
have
steadfastly
eluded
the
agency
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
the
restructuring
could
create
one
of
the
most
powerful
alliances
between
advertising
and
media-buying
firms
that
Europe
has
seen
.
<END>
<START>
As
part
of
the
restructuring
,
WCRS
and
Eurocom
said
they
will
look
for
ways
to
combine
their
media
buying
across
Europe
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Della
Femina
says
he
plans
to
remain
heavily
involved
in
the
creative
product
at
the
world-wide
agency
,
serving
as
a
sort
of
``
creative
conscience
.
''
<END>
<START>
Louise
McNamee
,
Della
Femina
's
president
,
will
continue
running
the
U.S.
agency
day-to-day
.
<END>
<START>
They
and
other
top
executives
signed
long-term
employment
contracts
and
Mr.
Della
Femina
will
receive
an
additional
multimillion-dollar
sum
,
which
some
industry
executives
pegged
at
about
$
10
million
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
to
Carat
,
WCRS
will
hold
onto
its
public
relations
,
TV
programming
and
other
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
WCRS
says
its
debt
will
be
cut
to
#
24
million
from
#
66
million
as
a
result
of
the
transaction
.
<END>
<START>
For
Carat
,
meanwhile
,
the
alliance
with
Eurocom
and
WCRS
is
intended
to
strengthen
its
own
push
outside
France
.
<END>
<START>
Carat
's
Gross
brothers
invented
the
idea
of
large-scale
buying
of
media
space
.
<END>
<START>
By
buying
the
space
in
bulk
,
they
obtain
discounts
as
high
as
50
%
,
which
they
can
pass
on
to
customers
.
<END>
<START>
They
thus
have
won
the
French
space-buying
business
of
such

giants
as
Coca-Cola
Co.
,
Fiat
S.p
.
A.
,

and

.
<END>
<START>
But
now
,

agencies
are
getting

business
with
their
own
competing
media-buying
groups
--
and
Carat
wants
to
expand
to
the
rest
of
Europe
.
<END>
<START>
To

,

of

.

's

,

.

,

.

.

:

.

,

,

's

.
<END>
<START>
Diamond-Star
said
it
will
export
about
1,500
Eclipse
cars
to
Japan
by
year
's
end
.
<END>
<START>
One
of
the
most
remarkable
features
of
the
forced
marches
of
the
ethnic
Turks
out
of
Bulgaria
over
the
past
five
months
has
been
the
lack
of
international
attention
.
<END>
<START>
The
deportation
of
more
than
315,000
men
,
women
and
children
by
the
Bulgarian
regime
adds
up
to
one
of
the
largest
migrations
seen
in
the
postwar
years
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
some
people
are
advancing
a
chilling
casuistry
:
that
what
we
are
seeing
is
somehow
the
understandable
result
of
the
historical
sins
committed
by
the
Turks
in
the
16th
century
.
<END>
<START>
Today
's
Turks
in
Bulgaria
,
in
other
words
,
deserve
what
is
coming
to
them
four
centuries
later
.
<END>
<START>
As
if
this
were
n't
enough
,
the
Senate
Judiciary
Committee
is
getting
into
the
act
.
<END>
<START>
There
can
be
no
quibbling
that
the
Armenians
endured
terrible
suffering
,
but
one
has
to
wonder
what
possible
good
such
a
resolution
will
achieve
.
<END>
<START>
It
puts
great
strain
on
a
longstanding
U.S.
friendship
with
Turkey
,
a
country
that
has
been
one
of
America
's
strongest
allies
in
NATO
.
<END>
<START>
Turkey
has
been
fighting
its
past
for
years
,
and
thus
far
has
been
only
partially
successful
.
<END>
<START>
Must
it
now
accept
that
one
of
its
strongest
allies
blames
it
for
the
genocide
of
another
people
?
<END>
<START>
Such
sentiment
only
encourages
the
adverse
feelings
toward
Turkey
that
surfaced
when
Turkey
asked
for
assistance
in
dealing
with
its
Bulgarian
emigration
crisis
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Dole
's
odd
effort
notwithstanding
,
most
of
Turkey
's
political
problems
lie
with
the
Europeans
.
<END>
<START>
Part
of
the
problem
some
Europeans
have
with
Turkey
seems
to
stem
from
its
location
--
Turkey
is
n't
really
part
of
Europe
.
<END>
<START>
Why
,
they
wonder
,
should
it
belong
to
the
EC
?
<END>
<START>
It
's
when
these
rationalizations
fall
on
deaf
ears
that
the
old
standby
of
retribution
for
treatment
at
the
hands
of
the
Ottoman
Empire
comes
to
the
fore
.
<END>
<START>
No
one
has
to
accept
the
sins
of
the
Ottoman
Empire
to
reject
that
argument
.
<END>
<START>
Turkey
in
any
event
is
long
past
it
.
<END>
<START>
The
country
has
in
recent
years
accepted
more
than
500,000
refugees
from
at
least
four
bordering
nations
.
<END>
<START>
Kurds
,
suffering
what
many
people
consider
to
be
a
current
extermination
campaign
at
the
hands
of
Syria
,
Iran
and
Iraq
have
inundated
eastern
Turkey
.
<END>
<START>
Now
it
is
their
fellow
Turks
arriving
as
refugees
from
Bulgaria
.
<END>
<START>
The
Turkish
refugee
tragedy
and
the
ongoing
crisis
can
not
be
ignored
and
shuttled
off
to
that
notorious
dustbin
of
history
that
has
become
so
convenient
recently
.
<END>
<START>
Surely
,
the
past
suffering
of
any
people
at
any
time
can
not
be
simply
filed
away
and
forgotten
.
<END>
<START>
But
what
the
Senate
Judiciary
Committee
has
done
in
supporting
the
strongly
worded
Armenian
resolution
achieves
no
useful
end
;
it
merely
produces
more
controversy
and
embittered
memories
.
<END>
<START>
Congress
has
enough
difficulty
dealing
with
the
realities
of
the
world
as
it
currently
exists
.
<END>
<START>
Bulgaria
's
government
has
been
behaving
beyond
the
pale
for
months
,
and

<START>
Natural

,
and
most
particularly
earthquakes
,
are
not
only
horrible
realities
in
and
of
themselves
,
but
also
symbols
through
which
the
state
of
a

can
be
construed
.
<END>
<START>
The
rubble
after
the
Armenian
earthquake
a
year
ago
disclosed
,
quite
literally
,
a
city
whose
larger
structures
had
been
built
with
sand
.
<END>
<START>
The
extent
of
the
disaster
stemmed
from
years
of
chicanery
and
bureaucratic
indifference
.
<END>
<START>
The
larger
parallel
after
the
earthquake
centered
south
of
San
Francisco
is
surely
with
the
state
of
the
U.S.

.
<END>
<START>
Did
the
stock-market
tremors
of
Friday
,
Oct.
13
,
presage
larger
fragility
,
far
greater
upheavals
?
<END>
<START>
Are
the
engineering
and
architecture
of
the
economy
as
vulnerable
as
the
spans
of
the
Bay
Bridge
?
<END>
<START>
The
eerie
complacency
of
the
Reagan-Bush
era
has
produced
Panglossian
paeans
about
the
present
perfection
of
U.S.
economic
and
social
arrangements
.
<END>
<START>
His
observations
were
taken
seriously
.
<END>
<START>
But
we
are
,
in
reality
,
witnessing
the
continuing
decline
of
the
political
economy
of
capitalism
:
not
so
much
the
end
of
history
but
the
history
of
the
end
.
<END>
<START>
The
financial
equivalent
of
the
sand
used
by
those
Armenian
contractors
is
junk
bonds
and
the
leveraged
buy-outs
associated
with
them
.
<END>
<START>
Builders
get
away
with
using
sand
and
financiers
junk
when
society
decides
it
's
okay
,
necessary
even
,
to
look
the
other
way
.
<END>
<START>
And
by
the
early
1980s
U.S.
capitalists
had
ample
reason
to
welcome
junk
bonds
,
to
look
the
other
way
.
<END>
<START>
By
that
time
they
found
extremely
low
profit
rates
from
non-financial
corporate
investment
.
<END>
<START>
Government
statistics
in
fact
show
that
the
profit
rate
--
net
pretax
profits
divided
by
capital
stock
--
peaked
in
1965
at
17.2
%
.
<END>
<START>
In
theory
,
the
value
attached
to
a
firm
by
the
market
and
the
cost
of
replacing
its
assets
should
be
the
same
.
<END>
<START>
But
of
course
the
market
could
decide
that
the
firm
's
capital
stock
--
its
assets
--
means
nothing
if
the
firm
is
not
producing
profits
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
indeed
what
the
market
decided
.
<END>
<START>
By
1982
the
ratio
was
43.5
%
,
meaning
that
the
market
was
valuing
every
dollar
's
worth
of
the
average
firm
's
assets
at
43
cents
.
<END>
<START>
Hence
the
LBO
craze
.
<END>
<START>
But
here
is
where
the
entrepreneur
made
a
very
risky
bet
,
and
where
society
was
maybe
foolish
to
look
the
other
way
.
<END>
<START>
The
profit
rate
is
still
low
and
the
Q
ratio
was
only
65
%
in
1987
and
68.9
%
in
1988
.
<END>
<START>
Result
:
a
landscape
littered
with
lemons
,
huge
debt
burdens
crushing
down
upon
the
arch
and
spans
of
corporate
America
.
<END>
<START>
The
mounting
risks
did
not
go
unobserved
,
even
in
the
mid-1980s
.
<END>
<START>
But
there
were
enough
promoters
announcing
the
end
of
history
-LRB-
in
this
case
suspension
of
normal
laws
of
economic
gravity
-RRB-
for

to
continue

.
<END>
<START>
But

rewards
of

.
<END>
<START>
The

whose

the
topic
figure
of
'80s

,
Michael
Milken
's

517

.
<END>
<START>
All

and

.
<END>
<START>
Profit

after
the
great

wave
are
no
higher
,
and
now

an

high-interest
burden
relative

.
<END>
<START>
The

of

with

are

up
.
<END>
<START>
What
is
the
consequence
of
a
high-interest

,
high

rates
and
continued
low

?
<END>
<START>
Corporations
need

,
in

.
<END>
<START>
The
consequence
can
be
inflation
,
brought
on
as
the
effect
of
a
desperate
bid
to
avoid
the

of

.
<END>
<START>
Attacks
on

come
with
another

of
capital
of
a

traditional

:
an

on

.
<END>
<START>

Fukuyama
,

,

``

way
.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>
International
Business
Machines
Corp.
said
its
board
approved
the
purchase
of
$
1
billion
of
its
common
shares
,
a
move
that
should
help
support
its
battered
stock
.
<END>
<START>
Even
as
the
stock
market
has
generally
done
well
this
year
,
IBM
's
shares
have
slipped
steadily
from
its
52-week
high
of
$
130.875
.
<END>
<START>
The
announcement
came
after
the
market
's
close
.
<END>
<START>
The
move
by
IBM
was
n't
exactly
a
surprise
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
has
spent
some
$
5
billion
over
the
past
3
1/2
years
to
buy
back
42
million
common
shares
,
or
roughly
7
%
of
those
outstanding
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
despite
IBM
's
well-publicized
recent
problems
,
the
computer
giant
still
generates
enormous
amounts
of
cash
.
<END>
<START>
As
of
the
end
of
the
second
quarter
,
it
had
$
4.47
billion
of
cash
and
marketable
securities
on
hand
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
some
securities
analysts
had
predicted
in
recent
days
that
IBM
would
authorize
additional
purchases
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
view
it
as
a
good
long-term
investment
,
''
the
spokesman
said
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
short
term
,
the
move
is
likely
to
have
little
effect
.
<END>
<START>
At
yesterday
's
closing
price
,
$
1
billion
would
buy
back
about
10
million
shares
,
or
less
than
2
%
of
the
roughly
580
million
outstanding
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
as
of
Sept.
30
,
the
company
still
had
authorization
to
buy
$
368
million
of
stock
under
a
prior
repurchase
program
.
<END>
<START>
Although
IBM
last
year
produced
its
first
strong
results
in
four
years
and
was
expected
to
continue
to
roll
this
year
,
it
began
faltering
as
early
as
January
.
<END>
<START>
First
,
it
had
trouble
manufacturing
a
chip
for
its
mainframes
,
IBM
's
bread-and-butter
business
.
<END>
<START>
Then
it
had
a
series
of
smaller
glitches
,
including
problems
manufacturing
certain
personal
computers
and
the
delay
in
the
announcement
of
some
important
workstations
.
<END>
<START>
Finally
,
IBM
had
to
delay
the
introduction
of
some
high-end
disk
drives
,
which
account
for
10
%
of
its
$
60
billion
of
annual
revenue
.
<END>
<START>
None
of
the
problems
is
necessarily
fatal
,
and
they
are
n't
all
necessarily
even
related
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
also
other
factors
at
work
that
are
outside
IBM
's
control
,
such
as
currency
exchange
rates
.
<END>
<START>
Without
that
problem
,
IBM
might
have
matched
last
year
's
earnings
of
$
5.81
billion
,
or
$
9.80
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
investors
will
take
some
convincing
before
they
get
back
into
IBM
's
stock
in
a
big
way
.
<END>
<START>
On

,

's

was

to

.
<END>
<START>
``

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
However
,

,

last

and
are

.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
,

.
<END>

,

,

that

.

.
