-RCB-
<END>
<START>
Betty
Lombardi
is
a
mild-mannered
homemaker
and
grandmother
in
rural
Hunterdon
County
,
N.J
.
<END>
<START>
But
put
her
behind
a
shopping
cart
and
she
turns
ruthless
.
<END>
<START>
If
Colgate
toothpaste
offers
a
tempting
money-saving
coupon
,
she
'll
cross
Crest
off
her
shopping
list
without
a
second
thought
.
<END>
<START>
Never
mind
that
her
husband
prefers
Crest
.
<END>
<START>
Some
weeks
when
her
supermarket
runs
a
double-coupon
promotion
,
she
boasts
that
she
shaves
$
22
off
her
bill
.
<END>
<START>
Money
is
n't
the
only
thing
that
makes
her
dump
once
favorite
brands
.
<END>
<START>
After
she
heard
about
the
artery-clogging
hazards
of
tropical
oils
in
many
cookies
,
she
dropped
Pepperidge
Farm
and
started
buying
brands
free
of
such
oils
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
always
thought
Pepperidge
Farm
was
tasty
and
high
quality
,
''
Mrs.
Lombardi
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
I
do
n't
want
any
of
that
oil
for
my
grandkids
.
''
<END>
<START>
Clearly
,
people
like
Mrs.
Lombardi
are
giving
marketers
fits
.
<END>
<START>
She
represents
a
new
breed
of
savvy
consumer
who
puts
bargain
prices
,
nutritional
and
environmental
concerns
,
and
other
priorities
ahead
of
old-fashioned
brand
loyalty
.
<END>
<START>
While
brand
loyalty
is
far
from
dead
,
marketing
experts
say
it
has
eroded
during
the
1980s
.
<END>
<START>
Marketers
themselves
are
partly
to
blame
:
They
've
increased
spending
for
coupons
and
other
short-term
promotions
at
the
expense
of
image-building
advertising
.
<END>
<START>
What
's
more
,
a
flood
of
new
products
has
given
consumers
a
dizzying
choice
of
brands
,
many
of
which
are
virtually
carbon
copies
of
one
other
.
<END>
<START>
``
Marketers
have
brought
this
on
themselves
with
their
heavy
use
''
of
promotions
,
contends
Joe
Plummer
,
an
executive
vice
president
at
the
D'Arcy
Masius
Benton
&
Bowles
ad
agency
.
<END>
<START>
``
Without
some
real
product
improvements
,
it
's
going
to
be
difficult
to
win
that
loyalty
back
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
Wall
Street
Journal
's
``
American
Way
of
Buying
''
survey
this
year
found
that
most
consumers
switch
brands
for
many
of
the
products
they
use
.
<END>
<START>
More
than
half
the
users
of
17
of
the
25
products
included
in
the
survey
said
they
're
brand
switchers
.
<END>
<START>
Overall
,
12
%
of
consumers
are
n't
brand
loyal
for
any
of
the
25
product
categories
.
<END>
<START>
About
47
%
are
loyal
for
one
to
five
of
the
products
.
<END>
<START>
Only
2
%
are
brand
loyal
in
16
to
20
of
the
categories
,
and
no
one
is
loyal
for
more
than
20
types
of
products
.
<END>
<START>
For
such
products
as
canned
vegetables
and
athletic
shoes
,
devotion
to
a
single
brand
was
quite
low
,
with
fewer
than
30
%
saying
they
usually
buy
the
same
brand
.
<END>
<START>
Only
for
cigarettes
,
mayonnaise
and
toothpaste
did
more
than
60
%
of
users
say
they
typically
stick
with
the
same
brand
.
<END>
<START>
People
tend
to
be
most
loyal
to
brands
that
have
distinctive
flavors
,
such
as
cigarettes
and
ketchup
.
<END>
<START>
Kathie
Huff
,
a
respondent
in
the
Journal
survey
from
Spokane
,
Wash.
,
says
her
husband
is
adamant
about
eating
only
Hunt
's
ketchup
.
<END>
<START>
He
simply
ca
n't
stomach
the
taste
of
Heinz
,
she
says
.
<END>
<START>
The
31-year-old
homemaker
adds
,
``
The
only
other
thing
I
'm
really
loyal
to
is
my
Virginia
Slims
cigarettes
.
<END>
<START>
Coke
and
Pepsi
are
all
the
same
to
me
,
and
I
usually
buy
whichever
brand
of
coffee
happens
to
be
on
sale
.
''
<END>
<START>
Brand
imagery
plays
a
significant
role
in
loyalty
to
such
products
as
cigarettes
,
perfume
and
beer
.
<END>
<START>
People
often
stay
with
a
particular
brand
because
they
want
to
be
associated
with
the
image
its
advertising
conveys
,
whether
that
's
macho
Marlboro
cigarettes
or
Cher
's
Uninhibited
perfume
.
<END>
<START>
Loyalty
lags
most
for
utilitarian
products
like
trash
bags
and
batteries
.
<END>
<START>
Only
23
%
of
trash-bag
users
in
the
Journal
survey
usually
buy
the
same
brand
,
and
just
29
%
of
battery
buyers
stick
to
one
brand
.
<END>
<START>
Underwear
scored
a
middling
36
%
in
brand
loyalty
,
but
consumer
researchers
say
that
's
actually
quite
high
for
such
a
mundane
product
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
high
score
reflects
the
attempts
to
make
underwear
more
of
a
fashion
image
business
for
both
men
and
women
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
believes
there
's
opportunity
for
a
smart
gasoline
marketer
to
create
a
strong
brand
image
and
more
consumer
loyalty
.
<END>
<START>
What
loyalty
there
is
to
gas
brands
,
he
believes
,
is
a
matter
of
stopping
at
the
most
conveniently
located
service
stations
.
<END>
<START>
Brand
loyalty
was
stronger
among
older
consumers
in
the
Journal
survey
.
<END>
<START>
Higher-income
people
also
tend
to
be
more
brand
loyal
these
days
,
the
Journal
survey
and
other
research
studies
indicate
.
<END>
<START>
Marketers
speculate
that
more
affluent
people
tend
to
lead
more
pressured
lives
and
do
n't
have
time
to
research
the
products
they
buy
for
the
highest
quality
and
most
reasonable
price
.
<END>
<START>
An
established
brand
name
is
insurance
that
at
least
the
product
will
be
of
acceptable
quality
,
if
not
always
the
best
value
for
the
money
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
sort
of
loyalty
by
default
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
``
the
bottom
end
of
the
market
is
becoming
less
loyal
,
''
says
Laurel
Cutler
,
vice
chairman
of
the
ad
agency
FCB/Leber
Katz
Partners
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
're
buying
whatever
's
cheaper
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
biggest
wild
card
in
the
brand
loyalty
game
:
How
those
hotly
pursued
but
highly
unpredictable
baby
boomers
will
behave
as
they
move
into
middle
age
.
<END>
<START>
They
grew
up
with
more
brand
choices
than
any
generation
and
have
shown
less
allegiance
so
far
.
<END>
<START>
But
now
that
they
're
settling
down
and
raising
families
,
might
they
also
show
more
stability
in
their
brand
choices
?
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Kim
of
J.
Walter
Thompson
does
n't
think
so
.
<END>
<START>
He
believes
baby
boomers
will
continue
to
be
selective
in
their
brand
loyalties
.
<END>
<START>
While
not
as
brand
loyal
as
in
the
past
,
consumers
today
do
n't
buy
products
capriciously
,
either
.
<END>
<START>
Rather
,
they
tend
to
have
a
set
of
two
or
three
favorites
.
<END>
<START>
Sometimes
,
they
'll
choose
Ragu
spaghetti
sauce
;
other
times
,
it
will
be
Prego
.
<END>
<START>
Advertisers
attribute
this
shared
loyalty
to
the
striking
similarity
among
brands
.
<END>
<START>
If
a
more
absorbent
Pampers
hits
the
market
,
you
can
be
sure
a
new
and
improved
Huggies
wo
n't
be
far
behind
.
<END>
<START>
``
Too
often
,
advertising
imagery
has
n't
done
a
good
job
of
forging
a
special
emotional
bond
between
a
brand
and
the
consumer
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
given
such
strong
brand
disloyalty
,
some
marketers
are
putting
renewed
emphasis
on
image
advertising
.
<END>
<START>
A
small
but
growing
number
of
companies
are
also
trying
to
instill
more
fervent
brand
loyalty
through
such
personalized
direct-marketing
ploys
as
catalogs
,
magazines
and
membership
clubs
for
brand
users
.
<END>
<START>
While
discount
promotions
are
essential
for
most
brands
,
some
companies
concede
they
went
overboard
in
shifting
money
from
advertising
to
coupons
,
refunds
and
other
sales
incentives
.
<END>
<START>
Some
people
argue
that
strong
brands
can
afford
to
stop
advertising
for
a
time
because
of
the
residual
impact
of
hundreds
of
millions
of
dollars
spent
on
advertising
through
the
years
.
<END>
<START>
But
most
companies
are
too
afraid
to
take
that
chance
.
<END>
<START>
And
perhaps
with
good
reason
.
<END>
<START>
Consider
,
for
example
,
what
happened
to
Maxwell
House
coffee
.
<END>
<START>
The
Kraft
General
Foods
brand
stopped
advertising
for
about
a
year
in
1987
and
gave
up
several
market
share
points
and
its
leadership
position
in
the
coffee
business
.
<END>
<START>
But
since
returning
to
advertising
,
Maxwell
House
has
regained
the
lost
share
and
is
running
neck
and
neck
with
archrival
Folgers
.
<END>
<START>
``
Even
though
brand
loyalty
is
rather
strong
for
coffee
,
we
need
advertising
to
maintain
and
strengthen
it
.
''
<END>
<START>
Campbell
Soup
Co.
,
for
one
,
has
concluded
that
it
makes
good
sense
to
focus
more
on
its
most
loyal
customers
than
on
people
who
buy
competitive
brands
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
probability
of
converting
a
non-user
to
your
brand
is
about
three
in
1,000
,
''
says
Tony
Adams
,
the
company
's
vice
president
for
marketing
research
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
best
odds
are
with
your
core
franchise
.
<END>
<START>
Our
heavy
users
consume
two
to
three
cans
of
soup
a
week
,
and
we
'd
like
to
increase
that
.
''
<END>
<START>
So
Campbell
is
talking
to
its
``
brand
enthusiasts
,
''
probing
their
psychological
attachment
to
its
soup
.
<END>
<START>
In
one
consumer
focus
group
,
a
fan
declared
that
,
``
Campbell
's
soup
is
like
getting
a
hug
from
a
friend
.
''
<END>
<START>
That
helped
persuade
the
company
to
introduce
a
new
advertising
slogan
:
``
A
warm
hug
from
Campbell
's
.
''
<END>
<START>
Insurers
face
the
prospect
of
paying
out
billions
of
dollars
for
damages
caused
by
this
week
's
California
earthquake
.
<END>
<START>
Getting
a
grip
on
the
extent
of
the
damages
is
proving
a
far
more
difficult
task
than
what
insurers
faced
after
Hurricane
Hugo
ripped
through
the
Caribbean
and
the
Carolinas
last
month
.
<END>
<START>
Reflecting
that
logic
,
insurance-company
stocks
posted
strong
gains
.
<END>
<START>
Aetna
and
other
insurers
are
hiring
engineers
and
architects
to
help
them
assess
structural
damage
.
<END>
<START>
Most
insurers
already
have
mobilized
their
``
catastrophe
''
teams
to
begin
processing
claims
from
their
policyholders
in
northern
California
.
<END>
<START>
About
25
adjusters
were
dispatched
yesterday
afternoon
,
along
with
laptop
computers
,
cellular
phones
and
blank
checks
.
<END>
<START>
Some
adjusters
,
already
in
other
parts
of
California
,
drove
to
the
disaster
area
with
recreational
vehicles
and
mobile
homes
that
could
be
used
as
makeshift
claims-processing
centers
.
<END>
<START>
Insurers
will
be
advertising
800
numbers
--
probably
on
the
radio
--
that
policyholders
can
call
to
get
assistance
on
how
to
submit
claims
.
<END>
<START>
State
Farm
,
based
in
Bloomington
,
Ind.
,
is
also
the
largest
writer
of
personal-property
earthquake
insurance
in
California
.
<END>
<START>
Earthquake
insurance
is
sold
as
a
separate
policy
or
a
specific
endorsement
``
rider
''
on
a
homeowner
's
policy
in
California
,
because
of
the
area
's
vulnerability
to
earthquakes
.
<END>
<START>
State
Farm
said
about
25
%
of
its
policyholders
in
California
have
also
purchased
earthquake
insurance
.
<END>
<START>
The
Association
of
California
Insurance
Companies
estimated
damage
to
residential
property
could
total
$
500
million
,
but
only
$
100
million
to
$
150
million
is
insured
,
it
said
.
<END>
<START>
They
expect
to
have
a
preliminary
estimate
of
the
damages
in
a
day
or
two
.
<END>
<START>
Roads
and
bridges
in
the
Bay
area
appear
to
have
suffered
some
of
the
most
costly
damage
.
<END>
<START>
Highways
,
such
as
the
section
of
Interstate
880
that
collapsed
in
Oakland
,
generally
do
n't
have
insurance
coverage
.
<END>
<START>
That
coverage
is
provided
by
a
syndicate
of
insurance
companies
including
Fireman
's
Fund
Corp.
,
based
in
Novato
,
Calif.
,
and
Cigna
Corp.
,
based
in
Philadelphia
.
<END>
<START>
Earthquake-related
claims
are
n't
expected
to
cause
significant
financial
problems
for
the
insurance
industry
as
a
whole
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
the
earthquake
could
contribute
to
a
turnaround
in
the
insurance
cycle
in
a
couple
of
ways
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
insurers
may
seek
to
limit
their
future
exposure
to
catastrophes
by
increasing
the
amount
of
reinsurance
they
buy
.
<END>
<START>
Reinsurance
is
protection
taken
out
by
the
insurance
firms
themselves
.
<END>
<START>
His
firm
,
along
with
some
others
,
issued
new
buy
recommendations
on
insurer
stocks
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
a
few
individual
companies
,
most
likely
smaller
ones
,
could
be
devastated
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
think
there
is
a
damned
good
chance
someone
is
going
to
hit
the
skids
on
this
,
''
said
Oppenheimer
&
Co.
analyst
Myron
Picoult
.
<END>
<START>
He
suspects
some
insurers
who
had
purchased
reinsurance
to
limit
their
exposure
to
catastrophes
will
discover
that
reinsurance
was
used
up
by
Hurricane
Hugo
.
<END>
<START>
British
,
West
German
,
Scandinavian
and
other
overseas
insurers
are
bracing
for
big
claims
from
the
San
Francisco
earthquake
disaster
.
<END>
<START>
Although
it
's
unclear
how
much
exposure
the
London
market
will
face
,
U.K.
underwriters
traditionally
have
a
large
reinsurance
exposure
to
U.S.
catastrophe
coverage
.
<END>
<START>
Jack
Byrne
,
chairman
of
Fireman
's
Fund
,
said
this
disaster
will
test
the
catastrophe
reinsurance
market
,
causing
these
rates
to
soar
.
<END>
<START>
The
catastrophe
losses
sustained
by
insurers
this
year
will
probably
be
the
worst
on
an
inflation-adjusted
basis
since
1906
--
when
another
earthquake
sparked
the
Great
San
Francisco
Fire
.
<END>
<START>
Orin
Kramer
,
an
insurance
consultant
in
New
York
,
estimates
that
the
1906
San
Francisco
destruction
,
on
an
inflation-adjusted
basis
,
included
insured
losses
of
$
5.8
billion
.
<END>
<START>
He
is
estimating
this
week
's
disaster
will
generate
insured
losses
of
$
2
billion
to
$
4
billion
,
following
about
$
4
billion
in
costs
to
insurers
from
Hurricane
Hugo
.
<END>
<START>
The
maker
of
computer
workstations
said
a
surge
of
government
orders
contributed
to
the
increase
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
rose
95
%
to
$
86.4
million
from
$
44.3
million
the
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
In
national
over-the-counter
trading
,
the
company
closed
yesterday
at
$
23.25
a
share
,
down
25
cents
.
<END>
<START>
Hunter
Environmental
Services
Inc.
said

its
environmental

and

for

40

and

.
<END>
<START>
The

was
n't

.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
it
also
is
making
progress
in

of
its
design
division
by

.
<END>
<START>
Hunter
wants
to
concentrate
its
resources
on

and

to
store

wastes
in

.
<END>
<START>
Jaguar
PLC
's
chairman
said
he
hopes
to
reach
a
friendly
pact
with
General
Motors
Corp.
within
a
month
that
may
involve
the
British
luxury-car
maker
's
producing
a
cheaper
executive
model
.
<END>
<START>
Sir
John
Egan
told
reporters
at
London
's
Motorfair
yesterday

``
would
be
disappointed
if
we
could
n't
do
-LCB-
the
deal
-RCB-
within
a
month
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
said
the
tie-up
would
mean
Jaguar
could
``
develop
cars
down
range
-LCB-
in
price
-RCB-
from
where
we
are
''
by

access
to
GM
's
high-volume
parts
production
.
<END>
<START>
Besides
creating
joint

ventures
,
the
accord
is
expected
to
give
GM
about
a
15
%

that

would
rise
to
about
30
%
.
<END>
<START>
Jaguar
figures
a
friendly
alliance
with
GM
will
fend
off
unwelcome
advances
from
Ford
Motor
Co
.
<END>
<START>
But
Ford
,
Jaguar
's
biggest

since
lifting

stake
to
10.4
%
this
week
,
is
pressing
harder
for

Sir
John
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're
getting
to
the
point
where
we
are
going
to
have
to
meet
''
with
him
,

Ford
official

.
<END>
<START>
Ford
probably
will
renew
its
request
for
such
a
meeting
soon
,
he

.
<END>
<START>
Sir
John
has
spurned
Ford
's
advances
since
the
U.S.
auto
giant
launched
a
surprise
bid
for
as
much
as
15
%
of

last

.

<START>
Developing

range

's

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
It

25,000
-LRB-

,

<START>
Although

.

<START>
Ameritech
Corp.
's

%
,

were

.

,

and

and

.

<START>
BellSouth
<END>
<START>
At
BellSouth
,
based
in
Atlanta
,
customer
access
lines
grew
by
162,000
,
or
3.5
%
,
during
the
12-month
period
ended
Sept
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
third
quarter
,
total
operating
revenue
grew
2.6
%
to
$
3.55
billion
from
$
3.46
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Total
operating
expenses
increased
3.5
%
to
$
2.78
billion
from
$
2.69
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Overall
access
minutes
of
use
increased
10.3
%
and
toll
messages
jumped
5.2
%
.
<END>
<START>
BellSouth
Chairman
and
Chief

Officer
John
L.
Clendenin
said
three
factors
accounted
for
the
drop
in

.
<END>
<START>
The
company
previously
said
that
the
recent
acquisition
of
Mobile

Corp.
of

would
dilute
1989

by
about
3

.
<END>
<START>

,

were

by

,

,

,

.

<START>
Ameritech
<END>
<START>

the
third
quarter
,
revenue
increased
1.9
%
to
$
2.55
billion
from
$
2.51
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Operating
expenses
increased
2.6
%
to
$
2.04
billion
,

of
$
40

for

.
<END>
<START>

service

3.5
%
and

9.5
%
.
<END>
<START>
But
network
access
revenue
dropped
4
%
and

revenue

1.4
%
.
<END>
<START>
a
-
reflects
2-for-1
stock
split
effective
Dec.
30
,
1988
.
<END>
<START>
b
-
reflects

for

.
<END>
<START>

of
14

a

.
<END>
<START>
The
two
surveys
,
which
asked
different
questions
,
were
conducted
using
national
random
probability
samples
.
<END>
<START>
The
poll
conducted
by
Peter
D.
Hart
Research
Associates
interviewed
2,064
adults
age
18
and
older
from
June
15
to
June
30
,
1989
.
<END>
<START>
The
poll
conducted
by
the
Roper
Organization
interviewed
2,002
adults
age
18
and
older
from
July
7
to
July
15
,
1989
.
<END>
<START>
Responses
were
weighted
on
the
basis
of
age
and
gender
to
conform
with
U.S.
Census
data
.
<END>
<START>
The
margin
of
error
for
subgroups
--
for
example
,
married
women
with
children
at
home
--
would
be
larger
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
in
any
survey
,
there
is
always
the
chance
that
other
factors
such
as
question
wording
could
introduce
errors
into
the
findings
.
<END>
<START>
Program
traders
were
buying
and
selling
at
full
steam
Monday
,
the
first
trading
session
after
the
stock
market
's
190.58-point
plunge
Friday
.
<END>
<START>
They
accounted
for
a
hefty
16
%
of
New
York
Stock
Exchange
volume
Monday
,
the
fourth
busiest
session
ever
.
<END>
<START>
On
Friday
,
13
%
of
volume
was
in
computer-guided
program
trades
.
<END>
<START>
In
August
,
by
contrast
,
program
trading
averaged
10.3
%
of
daily
Big
Board
turnover
.
<END>
<START>
Program
traders
were
publicly
castigated
following
the
508-point
crash
Oct.
19
,
1987
,
and
a
number
of
brokerage
firms
pulled
back
from
using
this
strategy
for
a
while
.
<END>
<START>
But
as
the
outcry
faded
by
the
spring
of
1988
,
they
resumed
.
<END>
<START>
Some
observers
thought
that
after
Friday
's
sharp
drop
,
the
firms
would
rein
in
their
program
traders
to
avoid
stoking
more
controversy
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
statistics
released
yesterday
show
the
firms
did
nothing
of
the
sort
.
<END>
<START>
One
reason
,
they
said
,
was
that
the
official
reports
on
the
1987
crash
exonerated
program
trading
as
a
cause
.
<END>
<START>
Stock-index
arbitrage
is
the
most
controversial
form
of
program
trading
because
it
accelerates
market
moves
,
if
not
actually
causing
them
.
<END>
<START>
In
it
,
traders
buy
or
sell
stocks
and
offset
those
positions
in
stock-index
futures
contracts
to
profit
from
fleeting
price
discrepancies
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
exchange
's
definitions
,
program
trading
also
describes
a
number
of
other
strategies
that
,
in
the
opinion
of
some
traders
,
do
n't
cause
big
swings
in
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
The
Big
Board
's
disclosure
of
program
trading
activity
on
these
two
days
was
unusual
.
<END>
<START>
Though
it
collects
such
data
daily
,
its
monthly
reports
on
program
trading
usually
come
out
about
three
weeks
after
each
month
ends
.
<END>
<START>
The
September
figures
are
due
to
be
released
this
week
.
<END>
<START>
The
Big
Board
declined
to
name
the
Wall
Street
firms
involved
in
the
activity
Friday
and
Monday
,
or
the
type
of
strategies
used
.
<END>
<START>
But
traders
on
the
exchange
floor
,
who
can
observe
the
computer-guided
trading
activity
on
monitor
screens
,
said
most
of
the
top
program-trading
firms
were
active
both
days
.
<END>
<START>
Though
brokerage
officials
defended
their
use
of
program
trading
,
one
sign
of
what
an
issue
it
remains
was
that
few
executives
would
comment
on
the
record
.
<END>
<START>
Besides
reciting
the
pardon
for
program
trading
contained
in
the
Brady
Commission
report
,
they
said
stock-index
arbitrage
was
actually
needed
Monday
to
restore
the
markets
'
equilibrium
.
<END>
<START>
Futures
trading
resumed
a
half-hour
later
,
but
the
session
ended
shortly
thereafter
,
leaving
the
stock
market
set
up
for
more
sell
programs
,
traders
said
.
<END>
<START>
By
Monday
morning
,
they
said
,
stock-index
arbitrage
sell
programs
helped
re-establish
the
link
between
stocks
and
futures
.
<END>
<START>
But
stunning
volatility
was
produced
in
the
process
.
<END>
<START>
The
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
plunged
a
breathtaking
63.52
points
in
the
first
40
minutes
of
trading
Monday
as
stock-index
arbitrage
sell
programs
kicked
in
.
<END>
<START>
At
about
10:10

EDT
,

upward
on
stock-index
arbitrage
buy
programs
.
<END>
<START>
By
day
's
end
,
the
Dow

had
rebounded
88.12

,
or
nearly
half
of
Friday
's

.

the
deck
is
stacked
against
them
.
<END>
<START>
But
``
these
wide
swings
scare
them
to
death
.
''
<END>
<START>
All
of
this
is
bad
news
for
the
big
brokerage
firms
such
as
Shearson
and
Merrill
Lynch
&
Co.
that
have
big
``
retail
,
''
or
individual-investor
,
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
After
expanding
rapidly
during
the
bull-market
years
up
to
the
1987
crash
,
retail
brokerage
operations
these
days
are
getting
barely
enough
business
to
pay
the
overhead
.
<END>
<START>
True
,
the
amount
of
money
investors
are
willing
to
entrust
to
their
brokers
has
been
growing
lately
.
<END>
<START>
But
those
dollars
have
been
going
into
such
``
safe
''
products
as
money
market
funds
,
which
do
n't
generate
much
in
the
way
of
commissions
for
the
brokerage
firms
.
<END>
<START>
At
discount
brokerage
Charles
Schwab
&
Co.
,
such
``
cash-equivalent
''
investments
recently
accounted
for
a
record
$
8
billion
of
the
firm
's
$
25
billion
of
client
's
assets
.
<END>
<START>
The
brokers
'
hope
has
been
that
they
could
soon
coax
investors
into
shifting
some
of
their
hoard
into
the
stock
market
.
<END>
<START>
And
before
last
Friday
,
they
were
actually
making
modest
progress
.
<END>
<START>
A
slightly
higher
percentage
of
New
York
Stock
Exchange
volume
has
been
attributed
to
retail
investors
in
recent
months
compared
with
post-crash
1988
,
according
to
Securities
Industry
Association
data
.
<END>
<START>
In
1987
,
an
average
19.7
%
of
Big
Board
volume
was
retail
business
,
with
the
monthly
level
never
more
than
21.4
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
retail
participation
dropped
to
an
average
18.2
%
in
1988
,
and
shriveled
to
barely
14
%
some
months
during
the
year
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
in
1989
,
retail
participation
has
been
more
than
20
%
in
every
month
,
and
was
23.5
%
in
August
,
the
latest
month
for
which
figures
are
available
.
<END>
<START>
But
there
did
seem
to
be
a
retail
activity
pickup
.
<END>
<START>
But
``
Friday
did
n't
help
things
,
''
says
Mr.
Schaefer
.
<END>
<START>
Joseph
Grano
,
president
of
retail
sales
and
marketing
at
PaineWebber
Group
Inc.
,
still
thinks
that
individual
investors
will
eventually
go
back
into
the
stock
market
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
will
develop
``
thicker
skins
,
''
and
their
confidence
will
return
,
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Friday
's
plunge
,
he
is
telling
PaineWebber
brokers
,
was
nothing
more
than
a
``
tremendous
reaction
to
leveraged
buy-out
stocks
.
''
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
PaineWebber
remains
among
the
leaders
in
efforts
to
simply
persuade
investors
to
keep
giving
Wall
Street
their
money
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
equity
decision
will
come
when
the
client
is
ready
and
when
there
's
a
semblance
of
confidence
.
''
<END>
<START>
It
could
be
a
long
wait
,
say
some
industry
observers
.
<END>
<START>
``
Some
investors
will
tiptoe
back
in
,
''
says
Richard
Ross
,
a
market
research
director
for
Elrick
&
Lavidge
in
Chicago
.
<END>
<START>
``
Then
there
'll
be
another
swing
.
<END>
<START>
Given
enough
of
these
,
this
will
drive
everyone
out
except
the
most
hardy
,
''
he
adds
.
<END>
<START>
The
long-term
outlook
for
the
retail
brokerage
business
is
``
miserable
,
''
Mr.
Ross
declares
.
<END>

<START>
John
V.
Holmes
,
an
investment-newsletter
publisher
,
and
three
venture-capital
firms
he
organized
were
enjoined
from
violating
the
registration
provisions
of
the
securities
laws
governing
investment
companies
.
<END>
<START>
As
part
of
an
agreement
that
settled
charges
brought
by
the
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
,
a
receiver
was
also
appointed
for
the
three
venture-capital
firms
.
<END>
<START>
In
1986
,
in
another
consent
agreement
with
the
SEC
,
Mr.
Holmes
was
enjoined
from
violating
the
stock-registration
and
anti-fraud
provisions
of
the
securities
laws
.
<END>
<START>
Without
any
admission
or
denial
of
guilt
by
Mr.
Holmes
,
that
agreement
settled
SEC
charges
that
Mr.
Holmes
sold
unregistered
securities
and
misled
investors
.
<END>
<START>
The
SEC
also
charged
that
Mr.
Holmes
acted
as
an
officer
or
director
of
New
Ventures
,
in
violation
of
his
previous
consent
agreement
.
<END>
<START>
``
Some
companies
were
delinquent
in
filings
and
other
actions
,
all
of
which
cost
money
,
''
Mr.
Holmes
said
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Smith
also
agreed
to
a
permanent
injunction
barring
her
from
acting
as
an
officer
,
director
or
investment

of
any

,
unit

or

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Byrum
and
Ms.
Smith
could
n't

reached
for
comment
.
<END>
<START>
In
consenting
to
the
injunctions
,
none
of
the
individuals
or
companies
admitted
or
denied
the
allegations
.
<END>
<START>
Senate
Republicans
have
settled
on
a
proposal
that
would
cut
the
capital-gains
tax
for
individuals
and
corporations
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
same
time
,
a
small
group
of
Senate
Democrats
are
working
on
a
similar
plan
and
may
introduce
it
soon
.
<END>
<START>
He
gave
10-to-1
odds
that
a
capital-gains
tax
cut
of
some
sort
would
be
approved
this
year
,
though
it
probably
wo
n't
be
included
in
the
pending
deficit-reduction
bill
.
<END>
<START>
He
added
that
he
expects
to
talk
to
the
Democrats
who
also
wanted
to
cut
the
gains
tax
about
drafting
a
joint
proposal
.
<END>
<START>
For
individuals
,
the
Packwood
plan
would
exclude
from
income
5
%
of
the
gain
from
the
sale
of
a
capital
asset
held
for
more
than
one
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
exclusion
would
rise
five
percentage
points
for
each
year
the
asset
was
held
until
it
reached
a
maximum
of
35
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
exclusion
would
apply
to
assets
sold
after
Oct.
1
,
1989
.
<END>
<START>
As
an
alternative
,
he
said
,
taxpayers
could
chose
to
reduce
their
gains
by
an
inflation
index
.
<END>
<START>
For
corporations
,
the
top
tax
rate
on
the
sale
of
assets
held
for
more
than
three
years
would
be
cut
to
33
%
from
the
current
top
rate
of
34
%
.
<END>
<START>
That
rate
would
gradually
decline
to
as
little
as
29
%
for
corporate
assets
held
for
15
years
.
<END>
<START>
The
Packwood
plan
would
also
include
a
proposal
,
designed
by
Sen.
William
Roth
-LRB-
R.
,
Del.
-RRB-
,
that
would
expand
and
alter
the
deduction
for
individual
retirement
accounts
.
<END>
<START>
Current
IRAs
could
be
rolled
over
into
the
new
IRAs
but
would
be
subject
to
tax
.
<END>
<START>
Newly
acquired
assets
would
get
a
bigger
break
than
those
currently
held
.
<END>
<START>
An
extra
exclusion
would
be
given
to
long-held
stock
in
small
and
medium-size
corporations
just
starting
up
.
<END>
<START>
No
one
in
the
Senate
is
considering
the
capital-gains
plan
passed
by
the
House
.
<END>
<START>
That
plan
would
provide
a
30
%
exclusion
to
assets
sold
over
a
2
1/2-year
period
ending
Dec.
31
,
1991
.
<END>
<START>
After
then
,
the
House
measure
would
boost
the
tax
rate
to
28
%
and
exclude
from
tax
the
gain
attributable
to
inflation
.
<END>
<START>
Senators
are
focusing
on
making
a
capital-gains
differential
permanent
.
<END>
<START>
The
current
debt
limit
expires
Oct.
31
.
<END>
<START>
He
also
urged
House
and
Senate
negotiators
to
rid
the
deficit-reduction
bill
of
all
provisions
that
increase
the
budget
deficit
,
including
the
House-passed
capital-gains
provision
.
<END>
<START>
But
this
quake
was
n't
the
big
one
,
the
replay
of
1906
that
has
been
feared
for
so
many
years
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
the
tragic
loss
of
more
than
270
lives
,
and
damage
estimated
in
the
billions
,
most
businesses
and
their
plants
and
offices
in
the
Bay
area
were
n't
greatly
affected
.
<END>
<START>
The
economic
life
of
the
region
is
expected
to
revive
in
a
day
or
two
,
although
some
transportation
problems
may
last
weeks
or
months
.
<END>
<START>
Also
,
the
region
's
insistence
on
strict
building
codes
helped
prevent
wider
damage
.
<END>
<START>
Of
course
,
the
quake
was
the
worst
since
the
emergence
of
the
computer
era
turned
Silicon
Valley
into
the
nation
's
capital
of
high
technology
.
<END>
<START>
When
the
tremors
struck
,
the
region
's
largely
unseen
high-tech
fabric
held
up
surprisingly
well
despite
the
devastation
visible
from
the
air
.
<END>
<START>
The
battery
packs
have
enough
power
for
only
three
hours
,
but
that
gave
emergency
crews
time
to
turn
on
an
emergency
system
that
runs
primarily
on
diesel
fuel
.
<END>
<START>
Of
some
160
switches
in
Pacific
Bell
's
network
,
only
four
went
down
.
<END>
<START>
One
of
those
was
in
Hollister
,
Calif.
,
near
the
earthquake
's
epicenter
.
<END>
<START>
Few
telephone
lines
snapped
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
because
the
widely
used
fiber-optic
cable
has
been
installed
underground
with
25
extra
feet
of
cable
between
junction
points
.
<END>
<START>
The
slack
absorbs
the
pulling
strain
generated
by
an
earthquake
.
<END>
<START>
Nevertheless
,
phone
service
was
sporadic
;
many
computer
terminals
remained
dark
,
and
by
late
yesterday
a
third
of
San
Francisco
remained
without
power
.
<END>
<START>
Business
in
the
nation
's
fourth-largest
metropolitan
region
was
nearly
paralyzed
;
an
estimated
one
million
members
of
the
work
force
stayed
at
home
.
<END>
<START>
The
economic
dislocation
was
as
abrupt
as
the
earthquake
itself
,
as
virtually
all
businesses
shut
down
.
<END>
<START>
In
high-tech
,
the
Bay
area
accounts
for
15
%
to
20
%
of
the
U.S.
computer-related
industry
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
has
been
a
major
disruption
for
the
Bay
area
economy
,
''
says
Pauline
Sweezey
,
the
chief
economist
at
the
California
Department
of
Finance
.
<END>
<START>
``
Obviously
,
things
are
going
to
have
to
go
on
hold
for
many
companies
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
damage
to
the
Bay
area
's
roadways
could
cause
significant
economic
hardship
.
<END>
<START>
California
state
transportation
officials
interviewed
by
telephone
say
they
nevertheless
do
n't
expect
serious
problems
for
commerce
in
and
out
of
the
Bay
area
.
<END>
<START>
All
major
roadways
except
Interstate
880
,
known
as
the
Nimitz
Freeway
,
and
the
Bay
Bridge
were
open
by
1
p.m.
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
Officials
expect
difficulty
routing
traffic
through
downtown
San
Francisco
.
<END>
<START>
The
earthquake
caused
many
streets
to
buckle
and
crack
,
making
them
impassible
.
<END>
<START>
Other
roads
were
obstructed
by
collapsed
buildings
and
damaged
water
and
power
lines
,
an
emergency
relief
spokesman
says
.
<END>
<START>
San
Francisco
Mayor
Art
Agnos
estimated
the
damage
to
his
city
alone
at
$
2
billion
.
<END>
<START>
But
many
predicted
that
the
commercial
disruption
would
be
short-lived
.
<END>
<START>
Of
the
scores
of
companies
contacted
by
this
newspaper
,
few
reported
any
damage
that
they
did
n't
expect
to
have
remedied
within
a
day

two
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
possible
,
of
course
,
that
some
of
the
most
seriously
damaged
companies
could
n't
be
reached
,
particularly
in

nearest
the
epicenter
.
<END>
<START>
Typical
,
perhaps
,
was
the

at
New
United
Motor
Manufacturing
Inc.
,
the
General
Motors
Corp.-Toyota
joint-venture

in

,
about
35

.
<END>
<START>
Ten
of
the
plant
's
workers
were
injured
when
the
quake
hit
about
a
half-hour
into
the
afternoon
shift
;
seven
were

.
<END>
<START>
Metal
racks
on
the
plant
floor
fell
over
,
and
water

ruptured
,
a
spokeswoman
says
.
<END>
<START>
The
plant
was

and
workers
sent
home
.
<END>
<START>
Computer
maker
Hewlett-Packard
Co.
,

,

its

sustained

was

off

.
<END>
<START>
Other

had
broken

,

and

,
a

says
,
estimating

cost
of

``
in

millions
.
''
<END>
<START>
Most
banks
were
closed
but
were
expected
to
reopen
today
with
few

anticipated
.
<END>
<START>
At

Federal

Bank
of
San

,
Vice
President
Robert
Fienberg
says
operations
were
``
steaming
along
as

''
yesterday

.
<END>
<START>
`
When
the
quake
hit
,
we
turned
on
our
emergency
generator
and
brought
our
computers
up
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
The
Fed
serves
as

for
banks
,
taking
checks
from
one
bank
and
sending
them
to
another
,
an
operation
that
it
handled
smoothly
Tuesday

after
the
quake
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
volume
we
received
from
the
banks
was
a

lower
than

,
''
he

.
<END>
<START>
A

the
Los

would
come
to

Francisco
's

was
n't

,

.
<END>
<START>
Most

in
the

stemmed

.
<END>
<START>
The
telephone
network
simply
could
n't
handle
the
large
number
of
people

to

.
<END>
<START>
The
volume
resulted
in
dial-tone
delays
that
were
as
short
as
15

and
as
long
as
five
minutes
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bandler
puts
traffic
volume
at
10
to
50
times
normal
.
<END>
<START>
American
Telephone
&
Telegraph
Co.
,

Inc.
and

Telecommunications
'
U
S
Sprint
unit
were
blocking
phone

into
the
Bay
area
to
alleviate

.
<END>
<START>
The
companies
block
traffic
much
as

are

when

up
.
<END>
<START>
William
E.

,

,

were
blocking
about
50
%

.
<END>
<START>
Pacific
Telesis
says
its

unit
also
was

.
<END>
<START>
Ironically
,

of

may
be
to

Bay

's

and
,

,
the

's

.
<END>
<START>
It

.
<END>
<START>
The
construction

is

.
<END>
<START>
``
There
will

,

,
''

<START>

``

,

.
''
<END>
<START>
Wall

reacted

by

.
<END>
<START>
Shares

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

wo

.
''

<START>
Lone
Star
's

Francisco

were
n't

in

.
<END>
<START>
The
earthquake
is
likely

reduce
GNP
negligibly
in
the

and
then
could
raise

a

as

.
<END>
<START>
The

are
,

,
negative
as

and

.
<END>
<START>
Corporate

.
<END>
<START>
Many

wo
n't

;

never

.
<END>
<START>
Subsequently
,

,

ill

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
Because

,

,

,
wo
n't

.
<END>
<START>
The

.
<END>
<START>
``
You

's

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
''

<START>
Mr.
Goldberg
says
the

the

will

$
1

and

4

.
<END>
<START>
He

that
early

are
often

;
the

in

Hugo
increased

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.

.

<START>
Jack

,

's

.
<END>
<START>
The

was

Northern

.

<START>
Fireman
's

and

.
<END>
<START>
Fireman
's
Fund
insures
37,300

in

.
<END>
<START>

,

and

.

<START>

.

<START>

.

<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>
Earthquake

.
<END>
<START>
Whatever
the

,

from
the

above

is

.
<END>
<START>
Gargantuan
sections
of
a

have

about

.
<END>
<START>
Atop

and

to
safety
the

.
<END>
<START>
In

where

made

itself

that

say
have

into

.
<END>
<START>
On

,

workers
seem
,
from

air
,
to

in

.
<END>
<START>
They
peck
away
at

1
1/2-mile

,

for
more
of

250

thought

.
<END>
<START>
About
20

.
<END>
<START>
Onlookers
say
three

exploded
into

shortly

.
<END>
<START>
Efforts

.
<END>
<START>

,

.

<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>
In

District
,

,

.

<START>

,

,

.

.

<START>
PRINCE
HENRI
is

.

<START>

,

,

.

<START>
Resolution
Funding
Corp.
plans
to
sell
$
4.5
billion
of
30-year
bonds
Wednesday
in
the
agency
's
first
sale
of
securities
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
bonds
will
be
dated
Oct.
30
and
mature
Oct.
15
,
2019
.
<END>
<START>
Tenders
for
the
bonds
,
available
in
minimum
denominations
of
$
1,000
,
must
be
received
by
1
p.m.
EDT
Wednesday
at
Federal
Reserve
banks
.
<END>
<START>
Refcorp
,
created
by
the
thrift-overhaul
law
enacted
in
August
,
will
use
the
proceeds
to
merge
or
sell
off
ailing
savings-and-loan
institutions
.
<END>
<START>
Congress
authorized
$
50
billion
to
be
borrowed
to
pay
for
the
thrift
bailout
.
<END>
<START>
Of
that
amount
,
$
20
billion
has
already
been
borrowed
by
the
Treasury
Department
.
<END>
<START>
Unless
otherwise
specified
in
a
particular
offer
,
the
bonds
wo
n't
be
subject
to
redemption
prior
to
maturity
.
<END>
<START>
Interest
payments
on
the
bonds
will
be
payable
semiannually
.
<END>
<START>
The
bonds
are
subject
to
federal
taxation
in
the
U.S.
,
including
income
taxes
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
state
and
local
level
,
the
bonds
are
subject
to
surtaxes
and
estate
,
inheritance
and
gift
taxes
,
but
exempt
from
taxation
as
to
principal
and
interest
.
<END>
<START>
G.D.
Searle
&
Co.
,
a
Monsanto
Co.
unit
,
is
launching
a
program
to
give
consumers
more
information
about
its
drugs
when
doctors
prescribe
them
.
<END>
<START>
Called
Patients
in
the
Know
,
the
program
features
fact
sheets
designed
to
be
easy
to
understand
.
<END>
<START>
The
sheets
tell
how
the
medicine
works
,
describe
how
to
use
it
and
list
its
possible
side
effects
.
<END>
<START>
They
are
designed
to
be
given
to
patients
by
their
doctors
when
the
medicines
are
prescribed
and
include
space
for
the
doctor
to
write
special
instructions
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
Searle
will
give
pharmacists
brochures
on
the
use
of
prescription
drugs
for
distribution
in
their
stores
.
<END>
<START>
Consumer
groups
have
long
advocated
that
drug
companies
and
doctors
make
more
information
available
to
patients
.
<END>
<START>
Dr.
Teich
said
Searle
is
``
the
only
company
I
know
that
voluntarily
''
will
make

information
available
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
think

's

as

as
possible
on
the
drugs
consumers
take
,
''
said
Searle
Chairman
Sheldon
Gilgore
.
<END>
<START>
Bond
prices
rambled
yesterday
as
investors
kept
close
watch
on
the
stock
market
and
worried
about
a
wave
of
new
supply
.
<END>
<START>
Early
yesterday
,
bonds
rose
as
investors
rushed
to
buy
Treasury
securities
on
the
prospect
that
stocks
would
plummet
in
the
aftermath
of
the
massive
California
earthquake
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
some
securities
analysts
warned
that
stocks
of
certain
insurance
companies
,
which
face
massive
damage
claims
,
would
get
hit
hard
.
<END>
<START>
But
when
the
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
rose
instead
,
bonds
drifted
lower
.
<END>
<START>
With
stocks
not
a
major
focus
,
``
we
're
waiting
for
the
next
guiding
light
,
''
said
Brian
J.
Fabbri
,
chief
economist
at
Midland
Montagu
Securities
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
Interest
rates
barely
budged
from
Tuesday
's
levels
.
<END>
<START>
Most
junk
bonds
,
which
have
been
battered
in
recent
weeks
,
continued
a
slow
recuperation
and
ended
unchanged
to
slightly
higher
.
<END>
<START>
But
some
so-called
high-quality
junk
issues
fell
as
some
mutual
funds
sold
their
most
liquid
issues
to
raise
cash
.
<END>
<START>
RJR
Holdings
Capital
Corp.
's
14.7
%
bonds
due
2009
fell
one
point
.
<END>
<START>
Other
RJR
issues
fell
between
1/2
point
and
1
1/2
point
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
latest
sign
of
how
difficult
it
is
to
place
certain
junk
bonds
,
Continental
Airlines
said
it
was
forced
to
scale
back
the
size
of
its
latest
offering
.
<END>
<START>
Continental
,
a
unit
of
Texas
Air
Corp.
,
slashed
the
size
of
its
note
offering
from
$
150
million
to
$
71
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
move
had
been
widely
expected
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
multipart
offering
,
the
company
sold
a
portion
of
secured
notes
but
shelved
all
the
unsecured
notes
.
<END>
<START>
A
Continental
spokeswoman
said
the
notes
may
be
offered
at
a
later
date
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
was
not
a
do-or-die
deal
,
''
she
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
think
this
is
a
market
that
required
some
level
of
security
.
<END>
<START>
It
did
not
make
sense
to
offer
unsecured
paper
in
an
unsettling
market
.
''
<END>
<START>
Investors
have
been
speculating
for
weeks
about
the
market
's
ability
to
place
the
$
7
billion
to
$
10
billion
of
new

scheduled
to
be
sold
by
year

.
<END>
<START>
Supply

were
also

of
Treasury
investors
yesterday
,
who
worried
about
the
flood

coming

.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're
being

by

,
''

William
Sullivan

,

.
<END>
<START>
``
The

is

all

debt
at
current

.
''
<END>
<START>
And
Resolution
Funding
Corp.
said
late
yesterday
that
it
will
sell
$
4.5
billion
of
30-year

Wednesday
.
<END>
<START>
Refcorp
is

Corp.
,

created
to

.
<END>
<START>
Its

have
been

``

''

.
<END>
<START>
In
when-issued
trading
,
the

Treasurys
had
a
yield
of
about
7.88
%
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
municipal
market
,
all

were
on
California
debt
as

tried
to
gauge
the
financial
ramifications
of
Tuesday
's

.
<END>
<START>
But

said
the
quake
had
only

California

.
<END>
<START>
Since

already
pay
a

yield
,
an
extra

the

risk
,

n't

.
<END>
<START>
But

.

.

<START>
Treasury
Securities
<END>
<START>
Treasury

ended

in

.
<END>
<START>

of
100
29/32
to

8.03
%
,

100
28/32

8.04

.

<START>

99
26/32
to

8
%
,

99
25/32
to

8.01
%
.
<END>
<START>
Short-term
rates
were
little
changed
.
<END>
<START>
Corporate
Issues
<END>
<START>
Investment-grade
corporate
bonds
ended
1/4
point
lower
.
<END>
<START>
The
Continental
junk

,

Burnham
Lambert
Inc.
,

.
<END>
<START>

,

$
71

of

to

13.75
%

.
<END>
<START>
Municipals
<END>
<START>

ended
about
1/8
to
3/8
point
lower
,
hurt
by

of
two
``
bid-wanted
''
lists
totaling
$
655

.
<END>
<START>
Chemical
Securities
Inc.
is
acting
as
agent
for
the
seller
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
some
California
issues
were
down
a

than

broad
market
,
but

said

.
<END>
<START>
But

.
<END>
<START>
Traders

was

yesterday
,

for

0.05

.
<END>
<START>
Traders

on

's

and

ahead

.
<END>

,

200

.

98

.

The

,

.

<START>
Mortgage-Backed
Securities
<END>
<START>
Mortgage
securities
ended
little
changed
after
light
dealings
.
<END>
<START>
There
was
no
appreciable
market

from
the
California
earthquake
.
<END>
<START>
Dealers
said
there
was
some

that

might
be
forced
to
sell
mortgage
securities
to
help

claims
,
but
no

materialized
.
<END>
<START>
The
Federal
Home
Loan
Mortgage
Corp.
and
Federal

Association
,
two

of

,

California

in

.
<END>
<START>
But
their
potential
quake
exposure
is
seen
as
small
given
that
they
require
a

on
all

they

.
<END>
<START>
And

Northern
California

are

high
,

from
the
region
often
are
too
large
to
be

in
Freddie

.

,

9

97
29/32
,

.
<END>
<START>
Freddie
Mac
9
%

were
at
97
4/32
,
down
1/32
.

<START>

,

400

.

Foreign

<END>
<START>

,

,

as

from

's

.
<END>
<START>
Traders
said

may

.
<END>
<START>
Several

are
due
out
and

Nigel
Lawson
is

to

``
Mansion

''

to

.
<END>
<START>
The

sometimes

to

.
<END>
<START>
Economists
do

's

,

's

.

<START>
Meanwhile
,
Japanese
government
bonds
retreated
in

,

by

's

.
<END>
<START>
Japan
's

4.6
%

1998
ended
on

'

at
95.75
to
yield
5.315
%
.
<END>
<START>
In
West
Germany
,

stayed

as
the
bond
market
searched
for

.
<END>
<START>
The
government
's
7
%
issue
due
October
1999
fell
0.05
point
to
99.90
to
yield
7.01
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
Berlin
Wall
still
stands
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
man
who
built
it
has
fallen
.
<END>
<START>
But
while
it
was
a
move
that
stunned
the
East
bloc
,
it
hardly
ushers
in
an
era
of
reform
--
at
least
anytime
soon
.
<END>
<START>
East
Germany
,
it
is
clear
,
is
no
Poland
,
where
the
Communist
Party
now
shares
power
with
the

Solidarity
union
.
<END>
<START>
Nor
is
it
a
Hungary
,
where
yesterday
the
parliament
approved
constitutional
changes
meant
to
help
turn
the
Communist
nation
into

.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
any
change
in
East
Germany
has
enormous
implications
,
for
both
East
and
West
.
<END>
<START>
It
raises
the
long-cherished
hopes
of
many
Germans
for
reunification
--
a
prospect
that
almost
equally
alarms
political
leaders
in
Moscow
,

and
Western
Europe
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Krenz
,
52
,
was
named
the
new
party
chief
just
minutes
after
the
Party
's
163-member
Central
Committee
convened
in
East
Berlin
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Mr.
Honecker
was
twice
hospitalized
this
summer
for
a
gall
bladder
ailment
and
his
physical
condition
has
been
the
subject
of
intense
speculation
in
the
Western
media
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Krenz
is
expected
to
be
formally
named
to
all
three
positions
once
the
nation
's
parliament
convenes
later
this
week
.
<END>
<START>
His
grip
on
power
unraveled
this
summer
as
thousands
of
his
countrymen
,
dissatisfied
by
the
harshness
of
his
rule
,
fled
to
the
West
.
<END>
<START>
Thousands
more
have
taken
to
the
streets
in
the
last
month
in
East
Germany
's
largest
wave
of
domestic
unrest
since
a
workers
'
uprising
in
1953
.
<END>
<START>
In
Washington
,
the
Bush
administration
took
a
characteristically
cautious
and
skeptical
view
of
the
leadership
change
.
<END>
<START>
The
official
line
was
to
offer
warmer
ties
to
Mr.
Krenz
,
provided
he
is
willing
to
institute
reforms
.
<END>
<START>
But
U.S.
officials
have
strong
doubts
that
he
is
a
reformer
.
<END>
<START>
President
Bush
told

:
``
Whether
that
-LCB-
the
leadership
change
-RCB-
reflects
a
change

East-West

,
I
do
n't

.
<END>
<START>
Because
Mr.
Krenz
has
been

much
in

Honecker
.
''
<END>
<START>
One

:
``
There
is
no

champion
of

,

,

East

.
''
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
Mr.
Krenz
said
on
East
German
television
last
night
that
there
will
be
no
sharing
of
power
with
pro-democracy
groups
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
,
while
dialogue
is
important
,
enough
forums
already
exist
``
in
which
different
interests
''
can
express

.
<END>
<START>
The
removal
of
Mr.
Honecker
was
apparently
the
result
of
bitter
infighting
within
the
top
ranks
of
the
Communist
party
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
West
German
government
sources
,
Mr.
Honecker
and
several
senior
Politburo
members
fought
over
the
last
week
to
delay
any

about
a

change
.
<END>
<START>
But
,
with
public
demonstrations
in
the
country
growing
in
size
and
intensity
,
Mr.
Honecker
and
several
key
allies
lost
out
in
this

,

say
.
<END>
<START>
Those
allies
included
Politburo
members
Guenter
Mittag
,
who
has
long
headed
economic

,
and
Joachim
Hermann
,
chief
of

.
<END>
<START>
Both
men
were
also
relieved
of
their
duties
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
Although
other
resignations
may
follow
,
it
's
still
not
clear
to
what
extent
the
change
in
party

will
alter
the
government
's
resistance
to

change
.
<END>
<START>
Clearly
,
the
central
figure
in
this
process
is
Egon
Krenz
.
<END>
<START>
Born
in
1937
in
a
Baltic
Sea
town
now
part
of
Poland
,
he
was
eight
years
old
when
World
War
II
ended
.
<END>
<START>
Like
West
German
Chancellor
Helmut
Kohl
,
he
represents
the
postwar
generation
that
has
grown
up
during
Germany
's
division
.
<END>
<START>
In
fact
,
the
two
men
have
had
strikingly
similar
career
paths
,
both
having
served
as
chief
of
internal
security
before
their
rise
to
the
top
party
position
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
both
men
have
hewn
to
a
similar
hard-line
philosophy
.
<END>
<START>
Notably
,
one
of
Mr.
Krenz
's
few
official
visits
overseas
came
a
few
months
ago
,
when
he
visited
China
after
the
massacre
in
Beijing
.
<END>
<START>
He
later
defended
the
Chinese
government
's
response
during
a
separate
visit
to
West
Germany
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
Mr.
Krenz
also
has
a
reputation
for
being
politically
savvy
.
<END>
<START>
His
shrewd
ability
to
read
the
shifting
popular
mood
in
East
Germany
is
best
illustrated
by
his
apparent
break
with
his
old
mentor
,
Mr.
Honecker
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
according
to
West
German
government
sources
,
he
was
one
of
the
leaders
in
the
power
struggle
that
toppled
Mr.
Honecker
.
<END>
<START>
In
recent
days
,
Mr.
Krenz
has
sought
to
project
a
kinder
image
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
a
report
widely
circulating
in
East
Berlin
,
it
was
Mr.
Krenz
who
ordered
police
to
stop
using
excessive
force
against
demonstrators
in
Leipzig
.
<END>
<START>
``
He
's
not
a
reformer
--
he
wants
to
have
the
image
of
a
reformer
.
''
<END>
<START>
As
part
of
his
image
polishing
,
Mr.
Krenz
is
expected
to
take
modest
steps
toward
reform
to
rebuild
confidence
among
the
people
and
reassert
the
party
's
authority
.
<END>
<START>
But
will
it
be
enough
?
<END>
<START>
West
German
government
officials
and
Western
analysts
are
doubtful
.
<END>
<START>
``
He
does
n't
signify
what
people
want
,
so
the
unrest
will
go
on
,
''
Mr.
Oldenburg
predicts
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
same
time
,
the
expectations
of
the
East
German
people
are
great
and
will
continue
to
grow
.
<END>
<START>
Says
one
West
German
official
:
``
What
's
necessary
now
is
the
process
of
democratization
.
<END>
<START>
Not
just
that
people
are
being
heard
but
that
their
interests
are
being
taken
seriously
.
''
<END>
<START>
Chancellor
Kohl
,
meanwhile
,
has
invited
Mr.
Krenz
to
open
discussions
with
Bonn
on
a
wide
range
of
subjects
.
<END>
<START>
Reports
in
the
West
German
press
,
citing
sources
in
East
Germany
,
suggest
Mr.
Krenz
may
serve
only
as
a
bridge
between
Mr.
Honecker
and
a
genuine
reform
leader
.
<END>
<START>
Adding
to
that
speculation
is
Mr.
Krenz
's
reputation
as
a
heavy
drinker
,
who
is
said
to
also
suffer
from
diabetes
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
a
dynamic
process
and
we
're
experiencing
the
first
step
,
''
the
Bonn
official
adds
.
<END>
<START>
The
selection
of
Mr.
Krenz
may
also
disappoint
Moscow
.
<END>
<START>
Soviet
leader
Mikhail
Gorbachev
has
pressed
hard
for
a
change
in
East
Germany
's
rigid
stance
.
<END>
<START>
Two
reform-minded
party
leaders
favored
by
Moscow
as
possible
successors
to
Mr.
Honecker
,
Dresden
party
secretary
Hans
Modrow
and
Politburo
member
Guenter
Schabowski
,
were
passed
over
.
<END>
<START>
If
Mr.
Krenz
sticks
to
rigid
policies
the
pressure
from
the
Soviet
Union
could
intensify
.
<END>
<START>
In
Moscow
,
Mr.
Gorbachev
sent
Mr.
Krenz
a
congratulatory
telegram
that
appeared
to
urge
the
new
leadership
to
heed
growing
calls
for
change
.
<END>
<START>
A
force
of
younger
pro-Gorbachev
members
in
the
East
German
bureaucracy
has
for
some
time
been
pushing
for
relaxation
within
their
country
.
<END>
<START>
The
older
generation
has
been
torn
between
a
fear
of
tampering
with
the
status
quo
and
a
fear
of
what
might
happen
if
they
did
n't
.
<END>
<START>
From
the
perspective
of
East
Germany
's
old
guard
,
reforms
that
smack
of
capitalism
and
Western-style
democracy
could
eliminate
their
country
's
reason
for
being
.
<END>
<START>
Unlike
the
other
nations
of
the
bloc
,
East
Germany
is
a
creature
of
the
Cold
War
.
<END>
<START>
Erasing
the
differences
still
dividing
Europe
,
and
the
vast
international
reordering
that
implies
,
wo
n't
endanger
the
statehood
of
a
Poland
or
a
Hungary
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
could
ultimately
lead
to
German
reunification
and
the
disappearance
of
East
Germany
from
the
map
.
<END>
<START>
Which
is
what
the
Old
Guard
fears
.
<END>
<START>
Neither
man
achieved
perfection
.
<END>
<START>
Early
in
1987
,
Mr.
Honecker
and
his
team
stopped
paying
thin
compliments
to
Mr.
Gorbachev
and
joined
with
Romania
in
rejecting
any
necessity
for
adjustments
in
their
systems
.
<END>
<START>
The
less-self-confident
Czechoslovaks
and
Bulgarians
,
in
contrast
,
declared
their
intentions
to
reform
,
while
doing
nothing
concrete
about
it
.
<END>
<START>
The
East
German
media
soon
began
presenting
Mr.
Gorbachev
's
speeches
only
as
sketchy
summaries
,
and
giving
space
to
his
opponents
.
<END>
<START>
By
late
1988
,
they
were
banning
Soviet
publications
.
<END>
<START>
The
country
abandoned
its
former
devotion
to
socialist
unity
and
took
to
insisting
instead
that
each
country
in
the
bloc
ought
to
travel
its
own
road
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Honecker
spoke
of
``
generally
valid
objective
laws
of
socialism
''
and
left
no
room
for
debate
.
<END>
<START>
With
this
year
's
dislocations
in
China
and
the
Soviet
Union
,
and
the
drive
to
democracy
in
Poland
and
Hungary
,
the
East
German
leadership
grew
still
more
defensive
.
<END>
<START>
Politburo
member
Joachim
Herrman
confessed
to
a
``
grave
concern
''
over
Hungarian
democracy
.
<END>
<START>
``
Under
the
banner
that
proclaims
the
`
renewal
of
socialism
,
'
''
he
said
,
``
forces
are
at
work
that
are
striving
to
eliminate
socialism
.
''
<END>
<START>
Some
loyal
voices
,
in
and
out
of
the
East
German
Communist
party
,
saw
the
nation
's
unrest
coming
.
<END>
<START>
The
first
signs
were
economic
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
heavily
subsidized
consumer
industries
,
East
Germans
have
for
years
watched
the
West
pull
farther
out
ahead
.
<END>
<START>
In
1988
,
for
the
first
time
,
economic
growth
came
to
a
dead
stop
.
<END>
<START>
Gingerly
,
some
economists
began
to
blame
central
planning
.
<END>
<START>
Some
writers
in
theoretical
journals
even
raised
the
notion
of
introducing
democracy
,
at
least
in
the
workplace
.
<END>
<START>
By
summer
,
an
independent
reform
movement
was
saying
out
loud
what
it
had
only
whispered
before
.
<END>
<START>
But
they
are
stalwart
socialists
.
<END>
<START>
Their
proclaimed
purpose
is
to
cleanse
East
Germany
of
its
Stalinist
muck
,
not
to
merge
with
the
West
.
<END>
<START>
One
of
their
pastors
has
envisioned
a
``
new
utopia
''
of
``
creative
socialism
.
''
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
the
man
Mr.
Krenz
replaces
has
left
an
indelible
mark
on
East
German
society
.
<END>
<START>
Imprisoned
by
the
Nazis
during
World
War
II
for
his
political
beliefs
,
Mr.
Honecker
typified
the
postwar
generation
of
committed
Communist
leaders
in
Eastern
Europe
who
took
their
cues
from
Moscow
.
<END>
<START>
He
was
a
``
socialist
warrior
''
who
felt
rankled
by
West
Germany
's
enormous
postwar
prosperity
and
the
Bonn
government
's
steadfast
refusal
to
recognize
the
legitimacy
of
his
state
.
<END>
<START>
Finally
,
during
his
first
and
only
state
visit
to
Bonn
two

ago
,
he
won
some
measure
of
the
recognition
he
had

.
<END>
<START>
But
ultimately
he
was
undone
by
forces

by
his
own
comrade
,
Mr.
Gorbachev
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Honecker
's

``
was
bound
to
happen
,
''
says
one

to
Chancellor
Kohl
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
was
only
a
matter
of
time
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
European
Community
Commission
increased
its
forecast
for
economic
growth
in
the
EC
in
1989
to
3.5
%
,
slightly
higher
than
its
June
projection
of
3.25
%
.
<END>
<START>
In
its
annual
economic
report
for
1989-1990
,
the
commission
also
projected
1990
gross
domestic
product
growth
for
the
12
EC
members
at
3
%
.
<END>
<START>
EC
inflation
was
seen
at
4.8
%
in
1989
,
higher
than
1988
's
3.6
%
price
rise
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
inflation
for
1990
was
seen
slowing
to
4.5
%
.
<END>
<START>
Leading
EC
growth
forecasts
in
1989
was
Ireland
,
seen
growing
5
%
at
constant
prices
.
<END>
<START>
Slower
growth
countries
included
Greece
,
at
2.5
%
,
the
U.K.
,
at
2.25
%
,
and
Denmark
,
at
1.75
%
.
<END>
<START>
Inflation
is
expected
to
be
highest
in
Greece
,
where
it
is
projected
at
14.25
%
,
and
Portugal
,
at
13
%
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
other
end
of
the
spectrum
,
West
German
inflation
was
forecast
at
3
%
in
1989
and
2.75
%
in
1990
.

<START>
FEDERAL
HOME

MORTGAGE

<START>
A

Norton

's

,

.

<START>

,

.

.

.

.

<START>
Pinnacle
West
Capital
Corp.
said
it
suspended
indefinitely
its
common
stock
dividend
and
reported
a
91
%
plunge
in
third-quarter
net
income
.
<END>
<START>
The
announcement
,
made
after
the
close
of
trading
,
caught
analysts
by
surprise
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
closed
at
$
12
a
share
,
down
62.5
cents
,
in
composite
trading
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
.
<END>
<START>
A
company
spokesman
said
the
decision
to
eliminate
the
dividend
resulted
from
a
quarterly
appraisal
and
that
circumstances
had
changed
since
the
December
announcement
.
<END>
<START>
He
declined
to
elaborate
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
have
estimated
that
Pinnacle
West
may
have
to
inject
between
$
300
million
and
$
400
million
into
the
MeraBank
unit
before
turning
the
thrift
over
to
federal

.
<END>
<START>
Third-quarter
net
income
slid
to
$
5.1
million
,
or
six
cents
a
share
,
from
$
56
million
,
or
65
cents
,
a

.
<END>
<START>
In

,

at
MeraBank
totaled
$
85.7
million
in
the
latest
quarter
,
compared
with
a
$
2.5
million
profit
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
The
latest
quarter
includes
a
$
42.7
million

to
loan-loss

.
<END>
<START>
As
recently
as
August
,
the
company
said

did
n't

a
need
for
substantial

to
reserves
.
<END>
<START>
Pinnacle
's

.

's

13.8

$
78.4

.
<END>
<START>

latest

9

.

.

<START>
Under
the
proposal
by
Equitec
,
a

syndicator
,
New
York-based
Hallwood
Group
Inc.
would
replace
Equitec
as
the
newly
formed
master
limited

's

and
manager
.
<END>
<START>
Shares
of
the
new
partnership
would
trade
on
an
exchange
like
a
stock
.
<END>
<START>
Hallwood
is
a
merchant
bank
whose
activities
include
the
ownership
,
management
and
financial
restructuring
of
shopping
centers
,
office

,

and
other

.
<END>
<START>
In

,

Richard
L.
Saalfeld
said

transfer
will
benefit
both

company
and
investors
in
the
12
limited

included
in
the
proposed
rollup
.
<END>
<START>
While
he
did
n't
describe
the
partnerships
'
financial
condition
,
he
said
their
operations
``
continue
to
drain
the
resources
of
Equitec
.
''
<END>
<START>

New
York
Stock
Exchange
composite

,
Equitec
closed
at
$
2.625
a
share
,
unchanged
.
<END>
<START>
Because
of
Tuesday
's

in
Northern
California
,
company

could
n't

for
additional

.
<END>
<START>

said

12

,

by

and

1979

1984
,
raised

from
investors
.

<START>
With
airline
deals
in
a
tailspin
,
legendary
Wall
Street
trader
Michael
Steinhardt
could
have
trouble
parachuting
out
of
USAir
Group
,
traders
say
.
<END>
<START>
Only
a
week
ago
,
when
airline
buy-out
fever
was
already
winding
down
,
Mr.
Steinhardt
was
engaged
in
a
duel
with
USAir
.
<END>
<START>
He
was
threatening
to
take
over
the
carrier
,
after
spending
an
estimated
$
167
million
to
build
an
8.4
%
USAir
stake
for
his
investment
clients
.
<END>
<START>
In
fighting
USAir
,
Mr.
Steinhardt
was
pitted
against
another
investor
,
billionnaire
Warren
Buffett
,
who
bought
into
USAir
to
help
fend
off
Mr.
Steinhardt
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Buffett
's
firm
,
Berkshire
Hathaway
,
holds
a
much
bigger
stake
in
the
carrier
than
Mr.
Steinhardt
's
firm
,
Steinhardt
Partners
.
<END>
<START>
Now
,
in
the
wake
of
UAL
's
troubles
in
financing
its
buy-out
,
the
airline
raiding
game
has
been
grounded
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
current
price
,
the
USAir
holding
represents
9
%
of
all
the
assets
that
Mr.
Steinhardt
manages
.
<END>
<START>
Traders
say
this
all
goes
to
show
that
even
the
smartest
money
manager
can
get
infected
with
crowd
passions
.
<END>
<START>
In
trying
to
raid
USAir
,
Mr.
Steinhardt
abandoned
his
usual
role
as
a
passive
investor
,
and
ran
into
snags
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
unlike
Mr.
Buffett
,
who
often
holds
big
stakes
in
companies
for
years
,
Mr.
Steinhardt
has
n't
in
the
past
done
much
long-term
investing
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
his
big
losses
,
for
instance
in
1987
's
crash
,
generally
have
been
trading
losses
.
<END>
<START>
So
,
some
see
a
special
irony
in
the
fact
that
Mr.
Steinhardt
,
the
trader
,
now
is
encumbered
with
a
massive
,
illiquid
airline
holding
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
say
USAir
stock
might
lose
four
or
five
points
if
the
Steinhardt
stake
was
dumped
all
at
once
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
Mr.
Steinhardt
must
reconcile
himself
to
selling
USAir
at
a
loss
,
or
to
holding
the
shares
as
an
old-fashioned
investment
.
<END>
<START>
``
Long-term
investing
--
that
's
not
Steinhardt
's
style
,
''
chuckles
an
investor
who
once
worked
at
Steinhardt
Partners
.
<END>
<START>
``
He
does
n't
usually
risk
that
much
unless
he
thinks
he
has
an
ace
in
the
hole
,
''
adds
another

Partners
alumnus
.
<END>
<START>
If
USAir
stepped
up

,
that
might
be
a
way
for
Mr.
Steinhardt
to
get
out
,

Timothy

,
a
Merrill

.
<END>
<START>
But
USAir
might
not
want
to
help
Mr.
Steinhardt
,
he
adds
.
<END>
<START>
In
1987
,
USAir
Chairman
Edwin
Colodny
stonewalled
when
Trans
World
Airlines
Chairman
Carl
Icahn
threatened
to
take
over
the
carrier
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Icahn
,
a
much
more
practiced
raider
than
Mr.
Steinhardt
,
eventually
sold
a
big
USAir
stake
at
a
tiny
profit
through
Bear
,
Stearns
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Steinhardt
also
could
take
that
route
.
<END>
<START>
He
confers
big
trading
commissions
on
Wall
Street
firms
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
with
airline
stocks
cratering
,
he
might
not
get
a
very
good
price
for
his
shares
,
traders
say
.
<END>
<START>
Especially
galling
for
Mr.
Steinhardt
,
say
people
close
to
him
,
is
that
USAir
's
Mr.
Colodny
wo
n't
even
take
his
telephone
calls
.
<END>
<START>
USAir
's
deal
with
Mr.
Buffett
``
was
n't
exactly
a
shining
example
of
shareholder
democracy
,
''
Mr.
Steinhardt
says
.
<END>
<START>
Since
last
April
,
the
investor
has
made
seven
so-called
13D
filings
in
USAir
,
as
he
bought
and
sold
the
company
's
stock
.
<END>
<START>
Such
disclosures
of
big
holdings
often
are
used
by
raiders
to
try
to
scare
a
company
's
managers
,
and
to
stir
interest
in
the
stock
.
<END>
<START>
But
of
course

would
be
highly
unusual
for
an
investment
fund
such
as
Steinhardt
Partners
to
take
over
a
company
.
<END>
<START>
USAir
and
Mr.
Buffett
wo
n't
talk
about
Mr.
Steinhardt
at
all
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
say
USAir
has
great
promise
.
<END>
<START>
By
the
second
half
of
1990
,
USAir
stock
could
hit
60
,
says
Helane
Becker
of
Shearson
Lehman
Hutton
.
<END>
<START>
She
thinks
traders
should
buy
the
stock
if
it
tumbles
to
35
.
<END>
<START>
But
meanwhile
,
USAir
is
expected
to
show
losses
or
lackluster
profit
for
several
quarters
as
it
tries
to
digest
Piedmont
Airlines
,
which
it
acquired
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
some
investors
think
a
recession
or
renewed
airfare
wars
will
pummel
airline
stocks
in

months
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
Mr.
Steinhardt
says
he
's
``
comfortable
holding
USAir
as
an
investment
.
''
<END>
<START>
While

has
bought
and

some
USAir
shares
in

days
,
he
says
that
contrary
to
rumors
,

has
n't

unload
his

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Steinhardt
adds
that

USAir

earlier
this

as
``

.
''
<END>
<START>
In
1989
,
Mr.
Steinhardt
says
he
made

trading
in
Texas
Air
,
AMR
and
UAL
.
<END>
<START>
Overall
,
his
investments
so
far
this
year
are

of
about
20
%
,

.
<END>
<START>
Does
Mr.
Steinhardt

game
?
<END>
<START>
People

the

he

.
<END>
<START>
``
I

n't

'll

in

,
''

.

21

.

,

.

<START>
Commodore
International
Ltd.
said
it
will
report
a
loss
for
the
first
quarter
ended
Sept.
30
because
sales
of
personal
computers
for
the
home
market
remained
weak
in
some
major
countries
.
<END>
<START>
That
will
mark
the
second
consecutive
quarterly
loss
for
Commodore
and
will
raise
additional
questions
about
whether
it
can
sustain
the
turnaround
it
had
seemed
to
be
engineering
.
<END>
<START>
Commodore
,
West
Chester
,
Pa.
,
had
said
in
August
that
it
was
consolidating
manufacturing
to
cut
costs
and
expected
to
be
profitable
in
the
fiscal
first
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Commodore
said
that
its
announcement
is
based
on
preliminary
information
and
that
the
situation
could
look
different
by
the
time
final
results
are
announced
early
next
month
.
<END>
<START>
In
fact
,
Commodore
's
fiscal
fourth-quarter
loss
was
$
2
million
narrower
than
Commodore
had
expected
a
few
weeks
after
the
quarter
closed
.
<END>
<START>
The
price
can
be
expected
to
erode
further
,
because
the
loss
estimate
came
after
the
market
closed
.
<END>
<START>
Commodore
has
assembled
an
experienced
management
team
,
it
has
persuaded
many
more
dealers
to
carry
its
products
and
it
has
unleashed
a
slick
advertising
campaign
.
<END>
<START>
But
those
represent
long-term
strategies
that
probably
wo
n't
succeed
quickly
,
even
if
they
turn
out
to
be
the
right
ones
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
meantime
,
the
strategies
will
increase
expenses
.
<END>
<START>
But
sales
to
consumers
have
become
difficult
during
the
past
several
months
,
even
in
West
Germany
,
which
has
been
by
far
Commodore
's
strongest
market
.
<END>
<START>
Commodore
has
said
it
expects
sales
to
rebound
,
but
market
researchers
have
said
that
sales
of
the
low-end
products
may
finally
be
trailing
off
.
<END>
<START>
Stock

's

.
<END>
<START>
Some

in

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>

.

.

,

.

``

.

<START>
Dayton
Hudson
Corp.
said
it
accepted
for
purchase
seven
million
common
shares
at
$
62.875
each
,
under
the
terms
of
a
Dutch
auction
self-tender
offer
.
<END>
<START>
The
offer
expired
at
12:01
a.m.
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
In
a
Dutch
auction
,
the
buyer
sets
a
price
range
and
holders
give
a
price
in
that
range
at
which
they
're
willing
to
sell
their
shares
.
<END>
<START>
The
buyer
then
picks
a
price
and
buys
shares
at
that
price
from
holders
who
offered
to
sell
at
that
price
or
lower
.
<END>
<START>
Dayton
Hudson
's
repurchase
offer
,
representing
about
9
%
of
its
common
shares
outstanding
,
had
established
a
range
of
between
$
60
and
$
65
for
the
buy-back
.
<END>
<START>
The
Minneapolis-based
retailer
said
it
expects
to
pay
for
the
seven
million
shares
next
Thursday
.
<END>
<START>
Tendered
shares
not
purchased
will
be
returned
to
holders
.
<END>
<START>
In
New
York
Stock
Exchange
composite

,

1
to
$
61.125
.

Tuesday
's
catastrophic

.
<END>
<START>
``
The
press
has
been
doing
an
excellent
job
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Ball
noted
that
television

people

up

,
explaining
where
to
call

.
<END>
<START>
Radio

an

for
people
who
smelled
gas
but
did
n't

how
to
turn

.

.

<START>
Sterling
Software
Inc.
said

to
supply
software
services
to
the
National
Aeronautics
and
Space
Administration
's
Ames
Research
Center
at
Moffett
Field
,
Calif
.
<END>
<START>
Sterling
,
which
estimated
the
value
of
the
contract
at
$
150
million
,
said
NASA
selected
another
bidder
for
final
negotiations
.
<END>
<START>
In
1988
,
Dallas-based
Sterling
protested
a
similar
decision
by
NASA
involving
the
same
contract
,
claiming

had
submitted

.
<END>
<START>
As

result
,

March

directed

to

on

.
<END>
<START>

had

by
NASA
but
had
not

whether
to
protest
the

's
latest

.
<END>
<START>
Consolidated
Rail
Corp.
,
New
York
,
reported
that

net

climbed
4.8
%
to
$
87
million
,
or
$
1.27
a

,

'

.
<END>
<START>
In

,

$
83

,

$
1.21
a

.
<END>
<START>

A.

,

,

``

,

.
''
<END>
<START>
Revenue

4.6

$
835
million
from

876

.
<END>
<START>

,

0.4

229

,

3.34

,

228
million
,

$
3.31
a

.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
was

at
$
2.59
billion
.
<END>
<START>

,

13

53.1

in

.
<END>
<START>

10

.

<START>

.

<START>

,

<START>

,

again
,

's

level
against

``
appropriate
.
''
<END>
<START>

wants
a
higher
won
to

more

and

's

.
<END>
<START>

a
devaluation
instead
,
arguing
that
the
won
's
recent
gains
already
have
weakened

country
's

performance
.
<END>
<START>

Roh
also
said

to

.

as

won
's

remains

.

''

.

ca

on

``
without

.

<START>
Great
American
Bank
said

approved
the

of
a
holding
company
enabling
the
savings
bank
to
pursue
nontraditional
banking
activities
under
a
new
federal
law
.
<END>
<START>
The
proposed
holding
company
's
primary
purpose
would
be
to
allow
Great
American
to
continue
engaging
in
real
estate
development
activities
,
it
said
.
<END>
<START>
Those
activities
generated
$
26.1
million
in
operating
profit
last
year
.
<END>
<START>
But
according
to
Great
American
,
such
profits
do
n't
count
toward
meeting
the
San
Diego
savings
bank
's
new
capitalization
requirements
under
1989
federal
law
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
real
estate
unit
would
have
a
separate
capital
structure
to
comply
with
the
law
.
<END>
<START>
The
proposed
holding
company
would
also
consolidate
Great
American
Bank
in
San
Diego
and
its
Tucson
,
Ariz.
,
savings
bank
into
a
single
,
federally
chartered
institution
in
San
Diego
.
<END>
<START>
The
consolidation
is
expected
to
save
$
1
million
a
year
in
administrative
costs
,
a
Great
American
spokesman
said
.
<END>
<START>
Dale
Lang
,
who
this
week
completed
the
acquisition
of
the
publisher
of
Ms.
and
Sassy
,
is
candid
about
the
challenge
he
is
taking
on
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lang
admits
that
Ms.
is
``
in
dire
straits
''
and
that
Sassy
needs
big
promotional
dollars
to
keep
it
alive
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
57-year-old
publisher
has
moved
quickly
and
boldly
to
deal
with
the
magazines
'
problems
.
<END>
<START>
Last
Friday
,
he
told
the
staff
of
Ms.
that
the
magazine
in
January
would
begin
publishing
without
advertising
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lang
will
do
away
with
expensive
circulation
drives
,
not
to
mention
sales
staff
,
and
attempt
to
publish
the
17-year-old
magazine
supported
by
circulation
revenue
alone
.
<END>
<START>
``
Any
fool
can
publish
a
money-losing
magazine
.
<END>
<START>
I
want
to
publish
one
that
succeeds
,
''
said
Mr.
Lang
.
<END>
<START>
``
For
Ms.
,
it
's
time
to
publish
for
the
reader
,
not
the
advertiser
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lang
said
the
former
Australian
owners
of
Sassy
were
``
blind-sided
by
the
Moral
Majority
...
.
<END>
<START>
Their
reaction
was
to
do
nothing
and
ride
it
out
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
said
Sassy
will
keep
its
irreverent
tone
,
but
added
,
``
We
will
keep
a
close
watch
on
the
editorial
content
of
the
magazine
.
''
<END>
<START>
Sassy
already
has
recovered
;
circulation
has
quickly
passed
the
500,000
mark
and
advertising
pages
have
stabilized
this
year
at
more
than
300
.
<END>
<START>
What
's
more
,
Mr.
Lang
says
he
has
what
all
publishers
wish
for
:
a
bona
fide
niche
.
<END>
<START>
``
Seventeen
is
written
more
for
mothers
,
not
their
daughters
,
''
said
Mr.
Lang
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
Sassy
has
a
different
spirit
.
<END>
<START>
It
gets
more
mail
in
a
month
than
McCall
's
got
in
a
year
,
and
it
's
not
from
mothers
.
<END>
<START>
I
feel
about
Sassy
like
I
did
about
Working
Woman
10
years
ago
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lang
took
on
Ms.
and
Sassy
with
the
acquisition
of
Matilda
Publications
Inc.
by
his
newly
formed
Lang
Communications
.
<END>
<START>
Lang
owns
70
%
of
Matilda
,
while
Citicorp
owns
the
rest
through
its
Citicorp
Venture
Capital
Partners
.
<END>
<START>
Two
weeks
ago
,
Citicorp
and
Mr.
Lang
pumped
$
800,000
into
Matilda
just
to
keep
the
doors
open
.
<END>
<START>
Industry
observers
have
congratulated
Mr.
Lang
on
what
some
call
his
``
courageous
''
handling
of
Ms.
,
but
his
track
record
in
magazine
publishing
in
general
has
gotten
mixed
reviews
.
<END>
<START>
Besides
Ms.
and
Sassy
,
closely
held
Lang
Communications
includes
Success
,
a
magazine
for
entrepreneurs
and
small
businesses
,
and
Working
Woman
and
Working
Mother
,
two
monthly
magazines
.
<END>
<START>
Working
Woman
,
with
circulation
near
one
million
,
and
Working
Mother
,
with
625,000
circulation
,
are
legitimate
magazine
success
stories
.
<END>
<START>
The
magazine
Success
,
however
,
was
for
years
lackluster
and
unfocused
.
<END>
<START>
Only
recently
has
it
been
attractively
redesigned
and
its
editorial
product
improved
.
<END>
<START>
Success
is
expected
to
gain
at
least
because
of
the
recent
folding
of
rival
Venture
,
another
magazine
for
growing
companies
.
<END>
<START>
Working
Woman
and
Working
Mother
have
operated
as
part
of
Working
Woman/McCall
's
Group
,
a
less-than-successful
joint
venture
between
Mr.
Lang
and
Time
Warner
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
Executives
at
Time
Inc
.
Magazine
Co.
,
a
subsidiary
of
Time
Warner
,
have
said
the
joint
venture
with
Mr.
Lang
was
n't
a
good
one
.
<END>
<START>
The
venture
,
formed
in
1986
,
was
supposed
to
be
Time
's
low-cost
,
safe
entry
into
women
's
magazines
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lang
surprised
Time
soon
after
joining
forces
when
he
said
he
would
negotiate
rates
individually
with
advertisers
,
a
practice
common
in
broadcasting
but
considered
taboo
by
magazine
publishers
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
McCall
's
put
in
a
less
than
stellar
performance
.
<END>
<START>
Until
a
recent
comeback
,
it
saw
steep
losses
in
ad
pages
and
circulation
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lang
feels
that
Time
's
priorities
changed
.
<END>
<START>
``
Their
management
changed
right
after
-LCB-
the
venture
was
formed
-RCB-
,
and
I
do
n't
think
they
were
comfortable
getting
into
the
competitive
wars
of
women
's
service
magazines
.
''
<END>
<START>
Today
,
Mr.
Lang
believes
his
magazines
will
offer
what
many
women
's
magazines
do
n't
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
write
straight
for
women
on
their
level
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
do
n't
have
passive
readers
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lang
points
out
that
even
Success
,
in
part
,
fits
the
company
's
image
,
since
about
30
%
of
its
readership
is
female
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lang
has
named
Carol
Taber
,
43
,
as
group
publisher
of
New
York-based
Lang
Communications
.
<END>
<START>
She
will
oversee
Working
Woman
,
Working
Mother
and
Success
magazines
,
and
retain
her
post
as
publisher
of
Working
Woman
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lang
says
he
is
n't

,
at

.
<END>
<START>
``
We
would
have
to
go
outside
to
banks
to

and

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
``
Besides
,

have
enough
on

.
<END>
<START>
There
is
plenty
of
work
to
be

on

we
have
.
<END>

The

,

.

,

,

.

a

,

,

.

.

.

.

.

<START>

officially

Bates
-LRB-

,

.
-RRB-
for

two

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

``
absurd
.
''
<END>
<START>
It
ordered
Rep.
Bates
to
write
letters
of
apology
to
Ms.
Bertussi
and
to
a
second
complainant
,
Karen
Dryden
.
<END>
<START>
Rep.
Bates
said
he
would
write
the
letters
as
ordered
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
accept
the
resolution
of
the
matter
by
the
Ethics
Committee
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
panel
also
warned
Rep.
Bates
that
any
further
violations
``
may
result
in
a
recommendation
that
disciplinary
action
be
considered
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
Ms.
Bertussi
asked
,
``
Who
in
their
right
mind
is
going
to
file
another
complaint
with
the
Ethics
Committee
?
''
<END>
<START>
Rep.
Bates
has
publicly
begged
for
forgiveness
from
voters
and
was
re-elected
with
60
%
of
the
vote
last

.

<START>

Airlines

it
received
earlier
this
week
from
StatesWest
Airlines
is
for
a

of
cash
and

valued

StatesWest
at
$
10

.
<END>
<START>

in

Southwest
.
<END>
<START>

made

offer
,
StatesWest
declined
to
disclose

and
asked
Mesa
to
do

same
.
<END>
<START>
But
Farmington
,
N.M.-based
Mesa
said
the
offer
was
for
$
7
in
cash
and
unspecified
StatesWest

valued
at
$
3
a
share
.
<END>
<START>

Mesa

StatesWest
,

proposed

would

a

of
about

15.3
million
.
<END>
<START>
StatesWest
owns
7.25
%

Mesa
.
<END>
<START>

,

rejected
a

from

that
the

.

.

,

,

<START>
Arkla
Inc.
said

it
will
take
a
total
of
$
189
million
in

by

.
<END>
<START>

also

of
18
%
of

.
<END>
<START>

Shreveport
,
La.
,

gas
company
said

,
though
partially
offset
by
a
one-time
gain
from
the

,
will
result
in
a
full-year
after-tax
loss
.
<END>
<START>
Last
year
,
the
company
had
net
income
of
$
117.3
million
,
or
$
1.30
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Arkla
said
it
will
report
$
179
milllion
in
one-time
charges
against
continuing
operations
for
the
third
quarter
,
reflecting
settlement
of
certain
natural
gas
contracts
.
<END>
<START>
It
said
it
will
take
a
$
10
million
fourth-quarter
charge
against
discontinued
operations
,
reflecting
certain
write-downs
and
the
planned
sale
of
a
unit
.
<END>
<START>
Arkla
Exploration
owns
sizable
gas
and
crude-oil
reserves
in
the
South
and
Southwest
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
agreement
will
last
for
3
1/2
years
starting
July
1
,
1990
,
when
the
current
agreement
expires
.
<END>
<START>
The
agreement
calls
for
South
African
debtors
to
make
repayments
in
eight
installments
,
starting
in
December
of
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
redemption
then
would
be
at
1.5
%
of
the
total
debt
,
increasing
to
2.5
%
in
February
1991
,
and
to
3
%
at
six-month
intervals
thereafter
.
<END>
<START>
A
revised
provision
would
be
included
for
the
conversion
of
short-term
claims
inside
the
net
to
long-term
loans
outside
the
net
.
<END>
<START>
These
claims
would
be
repayable
over
a
10-year
period
.
<END>
<START>
Foreign
debt
falling
outside
the
net
of
affected
indebtedness
--
which
Mr.
Stahl
estimated
at
$
12
billion
--
would
remain
not
subject
to
the
debt
arrangements
.
<END>

<START>
The

--
rated

6.9
on

--

,

.
<END>
<START>

ground

,

.

,

.
<END>

,

--

.

``

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
''

,

,

``

can

.
<END>
<START>

.
''
<END>

<START>
Coca-Cola
Co.
may
be
about
to
intensify
the
cola
wars
.
<END>
<START>
Coke
said
it
will
test
market
a
caffeine-free
version
of
its
flagship
brand
,
Coca-Cola
Classic
,
beginning
next
week
in
Charlotte
,
N.C
.
<END>
<START>
Other
,
as
yet
unnamed
,
cities
will
follow
.
<END>
<START>
If
all
goes
well
,
the
product
will
be
rolled
out
for
national
sales
sometime
next
year
,
a
Coke
spokesman
said
.
<END>
<START>
After
the
confusion
surrounding
the
change
of
the
Coke
formula
in
1985
,
Coca-Cola
was
reluctant
to
clutter
the
Classic
name
with
a
brand
extension
.
<END>
<START>
But
now
,
the
soft-drink
giant
appears
willing
to
take
the
risk
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
name
Classic
Coke
has
tremendous
value
,
and
they
have
n't
merchandised
that
name
before
,
''
says
Jesse
Meyers
,
publisher
of
the
trade
journal
Beverage
Digest
.
<END>
<START>
The
Coke
spokesman
said
a
caffeine-free
Classic
should
help
increase
volume
of
the
original
brand
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
analysts
have
said
that
the
absence
of
new
products
,
among
other
factors
,
has
limited
sales
growth
throughout
the
industry
.
<END>
<START>
Coke
now
leads
Pepsi
in
market
share
in
caffeine-free
diet
colas
but
trails
Pepsi
in
sales
of
caffeine-free
sugared
colas
,
according
to
Beverage
Digest
.
<END>
<START>
Coke
introduced
a
caffeine-free
sugared
cola
based
on
its
original
formula
in
1983
.
<END>
<START>
It
switched
to
a
caffeine-free
formula
using
its
new
Coke
in
1985
.
<END>
<START>
Coke
has
been
studying
the
possibility
of
introducing
a
caffeine-free
Classic
for
a
year
,
a
company
spokesman
said
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
large
increases
in
sales
of
other
non-caffeine
soft
drinks
make
the
timing
right
now
.
<END>
<START>
CALIFORNIA
STRUGGLED

the
aftermath
of
a

area

.
<END>
<START>
As

Francisco

,

through

for

of

's

,

.

,

within

and

from

.

<START>

least

reported

and

in

that
caused

of
dollars
of

along
100
miles
of
the
San
Andreas
fault
.
<END>
<START>
Bush
declared
the
region
a
major

and

was

to
prevent

.
<END>

in

Park
.
<END>
<START>
HONECKER
WAS
OUSTED
as

.
<END>
<START>
The

,

,

during

.
<END>
<START>
Honecker
,

ill
following

in
August
,
said
he
was
resigning
for
health

make
serious
efforts
at
reform
,
he
will
face
a
challenge
just
as
fundamental
.
<END>
<START>
Abandoning
socialism
means
abandoning
the
East
German
state
's
reason
for
existence
,
and
with
it
the
justification
for
its
watchdogs
and
its
Wall
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Krenz
may
need
a
bit
of
time
to
consolidate
his
empire
,
which
would
do
a
lot
to
promote
Reunification
Scenario
One
.
<END>
<START>
Cartoonists
in
West
Germany
have
already
mocked
the
exodus
by
imagining
an
advertisement
placed
by
Mr.
Honecker
:
``
Wanted
:
one
people
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
West
German
embassies
in
Prague
,
Budapest
and
Warsaw
are
continuing
to
find
refugees
at
their
gates
.
<END>
<START>
Of
course
East
Germany
,
true
to
its
tradition
,
could
tighten
its
borders
yet
further
.
<END>
<START>
Two
of
the
last
gestures
of
the
Honecker
regime
were
to
close
the
border
to
Czechoslovakia
and
install
halogen
lights
in
some
spots
along
the
frontier
.
<END>
<START>
But
with
world-wide
opinion
--
even
,
apparently
in
Moscow
--
against
East
Germany
,
the
country
would
have
to
turn
itself
into
an
Albania
to
clamp
down
further
on
refugees
.
<END>
<START>
But
even
if
he
effects
a
Hyde-to-Jekyll
transformation
,
he
will
face
a
serious
ideological
crisis
and
Reunification
Scenario
Two
.
<END>
<START>
The
problem
is
one
that
East
Germany
shares
with
other
half-states
,
such
as
North
Korea
,
but
one
it
must
shoulder
alone
in
the
East
Bloc
.
<END>
<START>
When
Poland
moves
to
reform
,
it
can
at
least
lean
on
its
past
:
However
flawed
and
short-lived
Joseph
Pilsudski
's
interwar
republic
,
it
was
a
nonsocialist
democracy
.
<END>
<START>
Czech
reformers
can
recall
the
Wilsonian
ideals
of
the
same
period
in
their
country
.
<END>
<START>
Even
the
Soviet
Union
has
Peter
the
Great
to
rediscover
,
should
it
choose
to
.
<END>
<START>
But
East
Germany
is
merely
``
the
land
of
truly
existing
socialism
.
''
<END>
<START>
Beyond
that
,
it
has
to
compete
with
West
Germany
for
a
claim
to
the
German
identity
.
<END>
<START>
Up
to
now
,
the
main
weapon
of
the
``
worker
and
peasant
state
''
has
been
the
ideology
of
socialism
.
<END>
<START>
With
talk
today
of
a
second
economic
miracle
in
West
Germany
,
East
Germany
no
longer
can
content
itself
with
being
the
economic
star
in
a
loser
league
.
<END>
<START>
Without
Moscow
's
military
and
party
behind
it
,
East
Germany
runs
the
risk
of
disintegrating
.
<END>
<START>
If
it
goes
capitalist
,
and
increases
trade
with
West
Germany
,
it
will
convert
itself
,
willy-nilly
,
into
an
economic
annex
of
the
Federal
Republic
.
<END>
<START>
There
may
be
forces
that
would
delay
this
scenario
.
<END>
<START>
Ideologues
are
the
last
to
surrender
,
and
Germans
are
an
ideological
people
.
<END>
<START>
The

Mikhail
Gorbachev
at
East
Berlin
's

earlier
this
month
were
n't
shouting
``

U.S.A
''
--

were

``
Gorby
,
Help
Us
.
''
<END>
<START>
Ideologues
on
the
other
side
of
the
border
can
also
slow
the
process
.
<END>
<START>
Helmut
Kohl
's

is
proving

true
to
the
West
German
constitution
by
making
more

500,000
people
of
German
descent
automatic
citizens
this

alone
.
<END>
<START>
But

,

.
<END>

--

.

<START>

,

''

.

,

.

Miss
Shlaes

.

<START>
INSURERS
ARE
FACING

in

from

California

.
<END>
<START>
But

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

in

.
<END>
<START>
Also
,

quickly

of
