.
<END>
<START>

may

by

.
<END>
<START>
The

,

,
could

up

10

.

.

.

<START>

.

<START>

.

<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>
Most
said

operations
as

n't

.

<START>

were

,

.

<START>

,

.

1.26

to

.

<START>

,

.

.

issue
all
along
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Nevertheless
,
the
increasing
likelihood
that
these
two
major
supply
disruptions
will
be
resolved
weighed
on
the
market
,
the
analysts
agreed
.
<END>
<START>
Both
of
these
mines
are
normally
major
suppliers
of
copper
to
Japan
,
which
has
been
buying
copper
on
the
world
market
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
focus
for
some
time
has
been
on
the
copper
supply
,
and
good
demand
has
been
taken
for
granted
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
Now
that
the
supply
situation
seems
to
be
improving
,
it
would
be
best
for
traders
to
switch
their
concentration
to
the
demand
side
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
noted
the
Commerce
Department
report
yesterday
that
housing
starts
in
September
dropped
5.2
%
from
August
to
1.26
million
units
on
an
annualized
basis
,
the
lowest
level
in
seven
years
.
<END>
<START>
``
Along
with
these
factors
,
other
economic
reports
suggest
a
slowing
of
the
economy
,
which
could
mean
reduced
copper
usage
,
''
he
said
.

<START>
SUGAR
:
<END>
<START>
Futures
prices
extended
Tuesday
's
gains
.
<END>
<START>
The
March
delivery
ended
with
an
advance
of
0.16
cent
a
pound
to
14.27
cents
,
for
a
two-day
gain
of
0.3
cent
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
one
dealer
,
Japan
said
it
has
only
40,000
tons
of
sugar
remaining
to
be
shipped
to
it
this
year
by
Cuba
under
current
commitments
.
<END>
<START>
The
announcement
was
made
because
of
reports
Tuesday
that
Cuba
would
delay
shipments
to
Japan
scheduled
for
later
this
year
,
into
early
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
dealer
said
the
quantity
mentioned
in
the
Japanese
announcement
is
so
small
that
it
's
meaningless
.
<END>
<START>
One
analyst
said
he
thought
the
market
continued
to
be
supported
to
some
degree
by
a
delay
in
the
Cuban
sugar
harvest
caused
by

weather
.
<END>
<START>
The
dealer
said
India
might
be
the
real
factor
that
is
keeping

prices
firm
.
<END>
<START>
That
country
recently
bought
200,000
tons
of
sugar
and
had
been
expected
to
seek
a
like
quantity
last
week
but
did
n't
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
known
they
need
the
sugar
,
and
the
expectation
that
they
will
come
in
is
apparently
giving
the
market
its
principal
support
,
''
the
dealer
said
.

LIVESTOCK
AND

:
<END>
<START>
Cattle
prices
have
risen
in
recent
weeks
on
speculation
that
the
government
's
quarterly
report
will
signal
tighter
supplies
of
beef
.
<END>
<START>
Among
other
things
,
the
government
is
expected
to
report
that
the
number
of
young
cattle
placed
on
feedlots
during
the
quarter
slipped
3
%
.
<END>
<START>
Feedlots
fatten
cattle
for
slaughter
,
so
a
drop
indicates
that
the
production
of
beef
will
dip
this
winter
.

The

:

.
<END>
<START>
A
new
drug
to
prevent
the
rejection
of
transplanted
organs
has
been
successfully
used
on
more
than
100
patients
at
the
University
of
Pittsburgh
,
according
to
researchers
.
<END>
<START>
The
drug
,
which
is
still
in
the
experimental
phase
,
has
n't
been
approved
yet
by
the
Food
and
Drug
Admistration
,
and
its
long-term
effects
are
unknown
.
<END>
<START>
But
researchers
say
the
drug
,
called
FK-506
,
could
revolutionize
the
transplantation
field
by
reducing
harmful
side
effects
and
by
lowering
rejection
rates
.
<END>
<START>
Rejection
has
been
the
major
obstacle
in
the
approximately
30,000
organ
transplants
performed
world-wide
each
year
.
<END>
<START>
Researchers
began
using
the
drug
in
February
on
patients
who
had
received
kidney
,
liver
,
heart
and
pancreas
transplants
.
<END>
<START>
Only
two
of
111
transplants
have
been
rejected
.
<END>
<START>
The
drug
,
discovered
in
1984
,
is
metabolized
from
soil
fungus
found
in
Japan
.
<END>
<START>
The
Pittsburgh
patients
are
the
first
humans
to
be
given
the
drug
,
which
is
made
by
Fujisawa
Pharmaceutical
Co
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
consider
it
a
life-saving
drug
,
like
one
for
AIDS
,
''
said
Dr.
John
Fung
,
an
immunologist
at
the
University
of
Pittsburgh
.
<END>
<START>
Researchers
say
they
believe
FK-506
is
100
times
more
effective
than
the
traditional
anti-rejection
drug
,
cyclosporine
,
made
by
Swiss
pharmaceutical
giant
Sandoz
Ltd
.
<END>
<START>
They
are
also
encouraged
by
the
relatively
mild
side
effects
of
FK-506
,
compared
with
cyclosporine
,
which
can
cause
renal
failure
,
morbidity
,
nausea
and
other
problems
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
side
effects
-LCB-
of
cyclosporine
-RCB-
have
made
the
penalty
for
its
success
rather
high
,
''
Dr.
Starzl
said
.
<END>
<START>
Dr.
Fung
said
that
FK-506
would
not
be
available
in
the
market
for
at
least
a
year
,
and
that
the
FDA
approval
process
usually
takes
three
years
to
five
years
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
no
firm
plans
to
expand
the
experimental
program
beyond
the
University
of
Pittsburgh
,
whose
hospital
performs
the
most
transplants
in
the
world
.
<END>
<START>
Dr.
Starzl
said
the
research
has
been
largely
financed
by
the
National
Institute
of
Health
and
by
university
funds
,
and
that
Fujisawa
did
n't
give
the
hospital
any
grants
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
that
the
research
team
had
no
financial
stake
in
the
drug
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
Mr.
Laband
,
``
screaming
''
for
price
controls
occurs
when
income
redistribution
``
threatens
to
hit
home
.
''
<END>
<START>
To
be
sure
,
the
threat
has
hit
home
down
here
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
in
Mr.
Laband
's
rehash
of
free-market
logic
,
human
greed
and
self-interest
are
the
only
permissible
psychological
reactions
.
<END>
<START>
Allowing
uncontrolled
prices
for
necessities
would
indeed
shorten
the
lines
at
stores
,
as
he
contends
.
<END>
<START>
But
not
because
resources
are
going
to
their
most
efficient
use
,
leaving
scarce
goods
``
allocated
to
those
buyers
who
place
the
highest
value
on
them
.
''
<END>
<START>
Rather
,
lines
would
diminish
because
at
higher
prices
many
victims
could
not
afford
necessities
such
as
food
and
medical
supplies
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
essential
relief
supplies
such
as
ice
must
be
distributed
throughout
the
population
because
of
potential
health
problems
from
spoiled
food
and
possible
outbreak
of
disease
.
<END>
<START>
Such
spillover
effects
give
the
state
a
right
to
intervene
in
the
marketplace
and
temporarily
coordinate
allocation
of
resources
.
<END>
<START>
Fortunately
,

and

are
not
motivated
by
self-interest
,
but
by
altruism
.
<END>
<START>
Why
should
they
have
to
co-exist
with
opportunists
rushing
in
to
turn
a
quick
profit
?
<END>
<START>
These
latter-day

would

to

of
the

,
if

.
<END>
<START>
The

.
<END>
<START>
South

A

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

for

rote

.
<END>
<START>
Give

.
<END>
<START>
Signed
by
25

<END>
<START>

,
<END>
<START>

<START>

.
<END>

<START>
Chris
Edgar
<END>
<START>
Myrtle
Beach
,
S.C
.
<END>
<START>
This
seems
to
be
the
season
for
revivals
in
Chicago
.
<END>
<START>
Revivals
of
a
different
sort
also
are
being
offered
by
our
two
major
theater
troupes
,
the
Goodman
and
Steppenwolf
.
<END>
<START>
Each
is
more
problematic
than
an
unexpected
divisional
baseball
championship
,
but
both
help
explain
why
Chicago
remains
a
vital
center
of
this
country
's
regional
theater
movement
.
<END>
<START>
The
Goodman
is
offering
a
modernized
version
of
Moliere
's
``
The
Misanthrope
''
through
Nov.
4
.
<END>
<START>
The
original
is
a
comedy
about
Alceste
,
a
man
who
sees
falseness
and
vanity
in
everyone
except
himself
.
<END>
<START>
He
is
the
jealous
friend
of
Philinte
,
and
the
jealous
lover
of
Celimene
.
<END>
<START>
The
play
is
filled
with
intrigue
,
dishonesty
and
injustice
.
<END>
<START>
Twenty-five
years
ago
the
poet
Richard
Wilbur
modernized
this
17th-century
comedy
merely
by
avoiding
``
the
zounds
sort
of
thing
,
''
as
he
wrote
in
his
introduction
.
<END>
<START>
Otherwise
,
the
scene
remained
Celimene
's
house
in
1666
.
<END>
<START>
The
Wilbur
translation
is
remarkable
--
well
worth
a
read
and
even
better
seen
in
the
theater
if
you
ever
have
the
opportunity
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Falls
,
the
Goodman
's
artistic
director
,
took
a
recent
adaptation
by
Neil
Bartlett
and
significantly
adapted
it
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bartlett
had
slimmed
Moliere
's
cast
of
characters
to
six
and
set
them
in
the
London
media
world
of
Thatcherite
Britain
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Falls
transfers
the
setting
to
Hollywood
,
and
transforms
the
characters
into
what
passes
for
aristocracy
there
--
agents
,
producers
,
actors
,
writers
and
sycophants
.
<END>
<START>
It
works
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bartlett
managed
to
more
or
less
maintain
Moliere
's
Alexandrine
verse
form
,
12
syllable
lines
in
rhyming
couplets
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Falls
kept
the
form
,
but
Americanized
it
with
Mr.
Bartlett
's
further
help
.
<END>
<START>
A
300-year-old
play
may
be
easier
to
revive
than
one
merely
25
.
<END>
<START>
When
``
The
Homecoming
''
was
first
produced
on
this
side
of
the
Atlantic
,
actors
and
directors
were
reverential
.
<END>
<START>
Silences
were
lengthy
--
nobody
moved
or
gestured
.
<END>
<START>
Nobody
smiled
onstage
,
and
nobody
in
the
audience
was
encouraged
to
laugh
.
<END>
<START>
This
kind
of
theater
was
new
to
us
.
<END>
<START>
Also
,
it
was
not
a
funny
time
over
here
,
what
with
the
Vietnam
War
,
the
'68
Democratic

,

and

.
<END>
<START>
But

Jerry
Perry
's
direction
the
current
Steppenwolf
production
,
scheduled
to
play
through
Nov.
19
,
breaks
through
the
flat
and

ritual
that
``
The
Homecoming
''
had
become
.
<END>
<START>

by

,

.
<END>
<START>
Sam
,

's

,

.

<START>
After
enduring
three
days
of
heavy
selling
,
the
beleaguered
Nasdaq
over-the-counter
market
finally
rebounded
,
rising
sharply
in

trading
.
<END>
<START>
The
Nasdaq
Composite
Index
jumped
0.7
%
,
or
3.35
,
to
463.28
.
<END>
<START>

rose
more
than

Exchange
Composite
,

0.2
%
.
<END>
<START>

,

100

1

,
or
4.56
,
to
453.05
,

Average
was

0.2

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.

,

,

.

,
''

.

.
<END>
<START>

.
''
<END>
<START>
The
trading
pace
was

,
with
4,343
issues
and
147.6
million
shares
changing
hands
.
<END>
<START>
Advancing
issues
beat
declining
ones
,
1,271
to
811
.
<END>
<START>
Much

the

by

and

centered
on
shares
of
companies
that
might
be

by

from
the

in

.
<END>
<START>
As

,

of
a

of
companies
that
might

or

because

were

.
<END>
<START>
Heading
the
list
:

,

and

companies
located
in
the
San
Francisco

.
<END>
<START>

as

of

and

on

.
<END>
<START>

's

.

.

,

.

,

Mr.

's

.
<END>
<START>
The

,

,
represents
the

about
the

of
the
future

of

's

,

to

.
<END>
<START>
Why
should
it
be
so
surprising
that
a
30
%
cut
in
the
capital-gains
tax
would
have
such
an
enormous
impact
on
the
value
of
the
nation
's

?
<END>
<START>
The

of

held
assets
is
easily
more
than
$
15
trillion
.
<END>
<START>
The
value
traded
on
the

is
close
to
$
3
trillion
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
tax
on
any
gain
to
those
assets
was
doubled
,
would
n't
the
value
fall
to
the
owners
of
the
assets
?
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
the
stock
market
's
steady
advance
this
year
tracked
with
President
Bush
's
success
in
advancing
his

proposal
.
<END>
<START>
A
30
%
cut
in
this
year
's

gains
alone
amounts
to
roughly
$
50
billion
.
<END>
<START>
We
're
talking
real
money
.
<END>
<START>
When
Richard
Rahn
advised

press
that
the
market

was
caused
by
the

to
capital
gains
,

was

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Rahn
was

out
an

rumbling

Street
while

had
fastened
on

UAL

.
<END>
<START>
Why
is
this
happening
?
<END>
<START>
They
are

and

who
sympathize
with

view
that
a

tax
cut
benefits

.
<END>

is

.

<START>

Monday

Darman
that

administration
has
other

to
win

,

.

<START>

Bradley
's

is
that

tax
cut
would
be

in

.
<END>
<START>
It
would

lead
to
an
increase
in
marginal
income-tax
rates
in
1990
,
he
thinks
,
when
the
White
House
is
forced
to
ask
for
higher
taxes
to
meet
budget
targets
.
<END>
<START>
That
is
,
with
capital
gains
cut
,
the
glue
of
the
1986
accord
will
be
gone
,
and
political
realities
will
push
up
income-tax
rates
.
<END>
<START>
In
this
atmosphere
,
there
would
be
no
serious
consideration
of
tax
increases
.
<END>
<START>
No
tax
increases
would
be
necessary
.
<END>
<START>
The
struggle
over
capital
gains
is
the
most
important
game
in
town
.
<END>
<START>
In
Washington
and
on
Wall
Street
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Wanniski
is
president
of
Polyconomics
Inc.
,
of
Morristown
,
N.J
.
<END>
<START>
Federal
prosecutors
said
they
have

a
guilty
plea
from
another
person
in
the
government
's
ongoing
probe
of
illegal
payments
in
the
record
industry
.
<END>
<START>
William
Craig
,
an
independent
record
promoter
,
pleaded
guilty
to
payola
and
criminal
tax
charges
,
according
to
a
statement
issued
by
Gary
Feess
,
the
U.S.
attorney
here
.
<END>
<START>
Payola
is
the
practice
of
making
illegal
,
undisclosed
payments
to
radio
station
personnel
in
return
for
getting
the
stations
to
play
certain
songs
over
the
air
.
<END>
<START>
As

of
his
plea
agreement
with
the
government
,
the
44-year-old
Mr.
Craig
faces
a
maximum
of
three
years
in
prison
.
<END>
<START>
In
return
,
Mr.
Craig
agreed
to
cooperate
in
the
government
's
continuing
payola
probe
,

a
spokeswoman
for
the
U.S.
attorney
's
office
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Craig
and
three
others
were
indicted
last
year
as
part
of
that
payola
probe
.
<END>
<START>
Two
other
defendants
previously
pleaded

,
and
charges
against
the
third
were
dropped
.
<END>

.

.

.

.
<END>

.

.

.

<START>
In
one
of
the
first
indoor
air-pollution
cases
to
go
to
trial
,
a
state-court
jury
decided
in
favor
of
the
defendant
,
Burlington
Industries
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
The
verdict
,
reached
late
last
week
in
Cincinnati
,
may
end
an
eight-year
legal
battle
for
the
Greensboro
,
N.C.
,
carpet
maker
.
<END>
<START>
Glenn
and
Sharon
Beebe
of
Cincinnati
had
sued
the
com
-
pany
in
1981
after
installing
Burlington
carpets
in
their
office
.
<END>
<START>
The
Beebes
alleged
that
toxic
fumes
from
the
carpets
made
them
sick
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
of
their
illness
,
the
Beebes
said
,
they
lost
$
1.8
million
in
wages
and
earnings
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
they
said
that
months
of
exposure
to
the
chemicals
has
left
them
sensitive
to
a
wide
range
of
commonly
used
substances
.
<END>
<START>
The
case
had
been
closely
watched
because
attorneys
anticipate
increasing
litigation
nationally
over
the
so-called
sick-building
syndrome
.
<END>
<START>
Plaintiffs
'
lawyers
say
that
buildings
become
``
sick
''
when
inadequate
fresh
air
and
poor
ventilation
systems
lead
pollutants
to
build
up
inside
.
<END>
<START>
Anthony
J.
Iaciofano
,
a
lawyer
for
Burlington
,
said
the
company
believes
the
Beebes
'
symptoms
were
not
related
to
the
carpeting
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
that
ill
effects
from
new
carpets
manifest
themselves
immediately
but
that
the
Beebes
'
symptoms
appeared
months
later
.
<END>
<START>
Catherine
Adams
,
the
Beebes
'
lawyer
,
said
the
verdict
would
not
discourage
other
plaintiffs
from
filing
such
suits
.
<END>
<START>
Scientists
are
only
beginning
to
understand
what
causes
sick-building
syndrome
and
much
of
that
research
was
unavailable
when
the
Beebes
filed
the
case
,
she
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
Beebes
now
believe
that
a
prime
culprit
for
their
injuries
was
fumes
from
an
adhesive
used
in
the
carpeting
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
Beebes
did
n't
come
to
that
conclusion
until
time
limits
had
elapsed
for
adding
the
adhesives
maker
as
a
defendant
in
the
case
,
Ms.
Adams
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
Beebes
have
not
yet
decided
whether
to
appeal
.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>
The

planned
for
42nd
Street
in

.
<END>
<START>
Opponents
of

had

that

city
and

state
of
New
York
,
which
are

the
project
,
had
failed
to

to

guidelines
.
<END>
<START>
All
but
two
of
the
40
or
so

that
have
been

since

's
1984

have
been

stage
.
<END>
<START>

two
that
remain
have

yet

stage
.
<END>
<START>
State

said

's
ruling
clears

way
for

to
condemn

in

.
<END>
<START>
``
This
project
is
ready
to

,
''

Vincent
Tese
.
<END>
<START>

still
remain
.
<END>
<START>

General

Matthew
Mayer
said

team
will

to
review
two
additional
lawsuits
before
putting
up

$
155
million
letter
of
credit
to
cover

costs
.
<END>
<START>
Also
,
he
said
,
the
partnership
is
waiting
to
see
whether
the
appellate
division
's
ruling
will
be
appealed
.
<END>
<START>
The
plan
,
which
has
been

,

.
<END>
<START>

and

.

<START>
FEDERAL
JUDGE
EXPANDS
role
of
U.S.
courts
in
extradition
decisions
.
<END>
<START>
A
magistrate
had
initially
refused
the
request
,
ruling
that
the
attack
had
been
a
political
act
for
which
the
man
,
Mahmoud
El-Abed
Ahmad
,
would
be
exempt
from
extradition
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
Judge
Weinstein
wrote
in
his
opinion
late
last
month
that
terrorism
and
acts
of
war
against
civilians
can
not
be
defined
as
political
acts
.
<END>
<START>
Judge
Weinstein
also
ruled
that
judges
must
consider
prior
to
extradition
whether
the
defendant
will
be
treated
fairly
in
a
foreign
court
.
<END>
<START>
To
do
so
,
the
judge
said
,
the
U.S.
courts
must
review
the
judicial
process
in
the
foreign
country
independently
of
the
State
Department
's
assessment
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
that
in
this
case
he
concurred
with
the
State
Department
's
decision
that
Mr.
Ahmad
should
be
extradited
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Ahmad
's
lawyer
said
he
would
appeal
.
<END>
<START>
Lawyers
close
to
the
case
said
they
believed
the
ruling
was
unprecedented
.

QUOTABLE
:
<END>
<START>
I
take
these
pronouncements
,
like
many
that
have
preceded
them
in
past
years
,
with
a
grain
of
salt
.
<END>
<START>
In
an
era
of
`
sound
bites
'
and
instant
opinion
polls
it
is
dangerous
to
apply
broad
labels
to
a
single
term
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
During
its
centennial
year
,
The
Wall
Street
Journal
will
report
events
of
the
past
century
that
stand
as
milestones
of
American
business
history
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
THE
YOM
KIPPUR
WAR
,
WHEN
EGYPT
CRASHED
into
Israel
on
Oct.
6
,
1973
,
the
holiest
day
in
the
Jewish
calendar
,
lasted
barely
a
month
.
<END>
<START>
But
one
far-afield
effect
is
still
with
us
.
<END>
<START>
The
Arab
states
,
always
bitterly
resentful
of
U.S.
support
toward
Israel
,
realized
they
held
an
irresistable
weapon
--
oil
.
<END>
<START>
Early
in
October
,
six
Arab
nations
in
the
Persian
Gulf
jacked
up
prices
sharply
.
<END>
<START>
On
Oct.
22
,
led
by
Saudi
Arabia
,
the
world
's
largest
exporter
,
they
embargoed
oil
shipments
to
the
U.S.
and
to
the
Netherlands
,
Israel
's
staunchest
European
ally
.
<END>
<START>
The
timing
was
perfect
.
<END>
<START>
The
Arabs
had
tried
embargos
before
.
<END>
<START>
In
1956
,
when
Britain
,
France
and
Israel
invaded
Egypt
to
seize
the
Suez
Canal
,
Arab
producers
cut
off
supplies
to
Europe
.
<END>
<START>
Texas
simply
pumped
harder
.
<END>
<START>
U.S.
oil
supplies
,
however
,
had
peaked
in
1970
and
1971
and
by
1973
were
declining
.
<END>
<START>
Imports
,
then
six
million
barrels
a
day
,
came
primarily
from
Venezuela
and
Canada
.
<END>
<START>
But
Middle
East
supplies
were
growing
in
importance
.
<END>
<START>
By
1973
,
the
U.S.
was
bringing
in
two
million
barrels
of
Arab
oil
a
day
,
more
than
10
%
of
the
17.3
million
barrels
consumed
daily
.
<END>
<START>
Politics
and
economics
conspired
.
<END>
<START>
Japan
and
Europe
,
far
more
dependent
on
Mideast
oil
than
the
U.S.
,
would
n't
offend
the
Arabs
or
trade
off
their
precious
supplies
.
<END>
<START>
The
U.S.
did
manage
to
supply
the
Dutch
with
oil
by
relabeling
supplies
;
once
oil
is
shipped
,
no
one
can
tell
its
source
.
<END>
<START>
But
car-happy
Americans
panicked
,
and
so
did
the
U.S.
and
other
oil-consuming
governments
.
<END>
<START>
``
Shortage
''
and
``
crisis
''
became
buzz
words
,
although
neither
really
applied
.
<END>
<START>
The
embargo
lasted
only
six
months
,
but
the
price
hikes
became
a
fact
of
life
.
<END>
<START>
What
the
Arabs
started
,
inflation
finished
.
<END>
<START>
Once
and
for
all
,
$
5-a-barrel
crude
oil
and
35-cents-a-gallon
gasoline
were
history
.
<END>
<START>
Times
may
be
tough
on
Wall
Street
for
some
,
but
a
few
bosses
are
making
as
much
as
ever
--
or
more
.
<END>
<START>
The
figures
do
n't
include
substantial
dividends
on
holdings
of
Bear
Stearns
stock
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Greenberg
himself
was
paid
$
4.5
million
,
before
an
estimated
$
1.5
million
in
dividends
,
up
from
$
2.4
million
the
year
before
.
<END>
<START>
The
increase
is
noted
in
the
brokerage
firm
's
latest
proxy
statement
filed
with
the
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
.
<END>
<START>
Because
it
operates
on
a
fiscal
year
,
Bear
Stearns
's
yearly
filings
are
available
much
earlier
than
those
of
other
firms
.
<END>
<START>
The
latest
period
includes
14
months
instead
of
12
because
Bear
Stearns
changed
to
a
fiscal
year
ending
in
June
instead
of
April
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
Bear
Stearns
on
Monday
reported
improved
earnings
for
its
first
quarter
,
ended
Sept.
29
,
partly
because
of
a
31
%
increase
in
commissions
during
the
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
William
J.
Montgoris
,
chief
financial
officer
,
defended
the
lofty
salaries
at
Bear
Stearns
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
Bear
Stearns
has
never
had
an
unprofitable
year
since
its
founding
65
years
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Four
Bear
Stearns
executives
besides
the
62-year-old
Mr.
Greenberg
were
paid
$
3
million
or
more
before
dividends
for
the
14
months
ended
in
June
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Montgoris
said
the
firm
has
a
``
straight
mathematical
formula
''
for
determining
compensation
,
based
on
the
firm
's
earnings
.
<END>
<START>
``
Just
because
a
particular
element
of
the
firm
is
down
,
''
such
as
stockbrokerage
,
``
does
n't
mean
the
executive
committee
should
be
paid
less
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
Morgan
Grenfell
Group
PLC
said
John
Craven
,
group
chief
executive
officer
,
is
taking
over
the
chairmanship
of
the
merchant
banking
group
from
Sir
Peter
Carey
,
who
is
retiring
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Carey
will
remain
a
member
of
the
merchant
bank
's
board
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Craven
is
widely
credited
with
refocusing
Morgan
Grenfell
's
energies
on
its
core
corporate
finance
,
fund
management
and
banking
activities
over
the
past
year
.
<END>
<START>
Last
year
,
Morgan
Grenfell
shut
down
its
ailing
U.K.
securities
operations
.
<END>
<START>
Morgan
Grenfell
had
advised
Guinness
on
the
bid
,
which
was
surrounded
by
allegations
that
Guinness
used
artificial
means
to
support
the
bid
's
value
.
<END>
<START>
Morgan
Grenfell
said
Michael
Dobson
,
currently
group
deputy
chief
executive
,
will
assume
the
chief
executive
position
.
<END>
<START>
The
merchant
bank
also
announced
that
finance
director
David
Eward
is
taking
early
retirement
for
personal
reasons
.
<END>
<START>
His
duties
will
be
taken
over
by
Anthony
Richmond-Watson
,
who
has
been
elected
deputy
chairman
.
<END>
<START>
News
of
Mr.
Eward
's

comes
one
day
after
Morgan
said
that
Christopher
Whittington
resigned
as
chairman
of
Morgan
's

to
join
a
financial
services
firm
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Craven
said
both
Messrs.
Eward
and
Whittington
had
planned
to
leave
the
bank
earlier
,
but
Mr.
Craven
had
persuaded
them
to

until
the

was
in

.
<END>
<START>
``
If

's

about

it

leaving
at

very

.
''
<END>

,

9.39

.

.
<END>
<START>

.

.

.

.

<START>
Par
Pharmaceutical
Inc.
said

and

,

I.
Sawyer
,
to

,

.

in

in

,

.

,

.

.

.

'

.

<START>
Just
after

Monday
,
federal
spending
started
to
drop
by
$
16
billion
.
<END>
<START>
What

,

?

,

--

.

,

.

,

of

16

would

.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
We
suspect

fed

with

.
<END>
<START>
Consider
,

,
that

's

is

if

.

<START>
Under

law
,

's

in

are
supposed
to
be

.
<END>
<START>

Security
and

for

.

<START>
However
,

's

:

.

.
<END>
<START>

in

.
''
<END>
<START>

.

all

.

<START>
Ask
Tommy
Lasorda
;
thin
is
in
.
<END>
<START>
Another
major

in
this

was

's

to

<END>
<START>
If

's
elites
ever
succeed
in
bursting
the
tax
dam
,
Americans
will
be
engulfed
in
a
red
sea
of
new
spending
programs
,
such
as
federalized
child
care
.
<END>
<START>
Child
care
was
one
of
the
many
``
extraneous
''
bills
pulled
out
of
the
Senate
's
reconciliation
bill
last
Friday
.
<END>
<START>
Others
were
the
capital-gains
cut
,
Section
89
repeal
,
the
disabled
workers
bill
,
and
the
unprecedented
reconsideration
of
the
catastrophic
health
act
.
<END>
<START>
All
this
stuff
still
is
in
the
House
's
1,878-page
reconciliation
bill
,
and
many
Members
say
they
're
reluctant
to
pull
out
cherished
bills
,
just
to
see
them
die
.
<END>
<START>
Republicans
especially
want
a
guarantee
from
the
House
leadership
that
they
'll
get
an
up-or-down
vote
on
the
bills
.
<END>
<START>
House
Speaker
Foley
ought
to
deliver
that
promise
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
the
way
government
is
supposed
to
work
,
with
politicians
taking
responsibility
for
votes
that
their
constituents
can
identify
,
instead
of
concealing

in
the
great

garbage
truck
.
<END>
<START>
Those
days
are
gone
.
<END>
<START>
Save
the
sequester
,
and
let
Washington
scream
.
<END>

.

,

.

<START>

.

<START>
Tokyo
's

Index
of
225

34996.08
.
<END>
<START>
In

Wednesday
in

,

rose
19.30

to
35015.38
.
<END>
<START>

,

,

,

,

,

2642.64
.
<END>
<START>
Trading
was
relatively

at

650

,

than

's
526

.
<END>
<START>
Advancing
issues
outnumbered

821-201
,
with
103
unchanged
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're
back

,
''

Smithson
,

.

<START>
Japanese

,

,

during

were

,

.
<END>
<START>
Foreign

but

.

<START>

,
''

.

<START>

.
''
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>

to

's
88.12-point

.
<END>
<START>
``

.
<END>
<START>

,
''

,

.

.
''
<END>
<START>

's

,

.
<END>
<START>

643.3

,

but

the

,

``
Manic

.
''
<END>
<START>
Prices

on

and

.

<START>

.
<END>
<START>
The

deficit
of
$
10.77
billion
hit
an

U.K.

in

.
<END>
<START>
Michael
Hicks
,

,

:
``

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

,

had
n't
.
''

,

90

anxiety

.
''

Britain
's

,

,
``
do

.
''

<START>

,

.

.

,

.

<START>

.

.

<START>

,

.

<START>

,

,

.

<START>
In

,

in

and

and

in

,

and

.
<END>
<START>
Paris

lower
,
and
most

shares
were
unable
to
trade
for
a
second
consecutive
day
because

.
<END>
<START>
South
African
gold
stocks
closed
higher
.
<END>
<START>
Elsewhere
,
share
prices
rebounded
in
Hong
Kong
,
Sydney
,
Singapore
,
Wellington
,
Taipei
,
Manila
and
Seoul
.
<END>
<START>
Here
are
price
trends
on
the
world
's
major
stock
markets
,
as
calculated
by
Morgan
Stanley
Capital
International
Perspective
,
Geneva
.
<END>
<START>
To
make
them
directly
comparable
,
each
index
is
based
on
the
close
of
1969
equaling
100
.
<END>
<START>
The
percentage
change
is
since
year-end
.
<END>
<START>
Zurn
Industries
Inc.
said
it
received
approval
to
proceed
on
four
separate
projects
with
a
total
contract
value
of
$
59
million
.
<END>
<START>
AVX
Corp.
and
Unitrode
Corp.
said
they
completed
the
previously
reported
sale
of
Unitrode
's
San
Diego-based
Passive
Components
division
to
AVX
.
<END>
<START>
AVX
,
a
New
York-based
maker
of
passive
electronic
products
,
paid
$
11
million
in
cash
to
Unitrode
,
a
Lexington-based
maker
of
semiconductor
products
.
<END>
<START>
Passive
Components
makes
capacitors
and
filters
used
to
protect
electronics
.
<END>
<START>
Consolidated
Papers
Inc.
said
it
plans
to
spend
$
495
million
on
new
paper-manufacturing
equipment
and
facilities
.
<END>
<START>
The
producer
of
paper
used
in
magazines
and
by
commercial
printers
said
spending
on
the
expansion
is
planned
to
begin
in
the
first
quarter
of
1990
.
<END>
<START>
The
expansion
is
subject
to
approval
by
federal
and
Wisconsin
environmental
regulators
.
<END>
<START>
THE
STOCK
of
Applied
Power
Inc.
,
which
split
2-for-1
in
May
,
has
risen
since
August
1988
.
<END>
<START>
In
yesterday
's
edition
,
it
was
incorrectly
stated
that
the
company
's
share
price
has
softened
since
August
1988
.
<END>
<START>
The
stock
market
's
dizzying
gyrations
during
the
past
few
days
have
made
a
lot
of
individual
investors
wish
they
could
buy
some
sort
of
insurance
.
<END>
<START>
After
all
,
they
wo
n't
soon
forget
the
stock
bargains
that
became
available
after
the
October
1987
crash
.
<END>
<START>
But
while
they
want
to
be
on
the
alert
for
similar
buying
opportunities
now
,
they
're
afraid
of
being
hammered
by
another
terrifying
plunge
.
<END>
<START>
The
solution
,
at
least
for
some
investors
,
may
be
a
hedging
technique
that
's
well
known
to
players
in
the
stock-options
market
.
<END>
<START>
Called
a
``
married
put
,
''
the
technique
is
carried
out
by
purchasing
a
stock
and
simultaneously
buying
a
put
option
on
that
stock
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
like
``
fire
insurance
,
''
says
Harrison
Roth
,
the
senior
options
strategist
at
Cowen
&
Co
.
<END>
<START>
But
most
investment
advisers
do
n't
recommend
using
married
puts
all
the
time
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
because
the
cost
of
buying
put
options
eats
into
an
investor
's
profit
when
stock
prices
rise
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
the
type
of
fire
insurance
you
only
buy
when
the
nearby
woods
are
on
fire
,
''
says
Mr.
Roth
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
always
want
your
house
insured
,
but
you
do
n't
always
feel
the
need
for
your
investments
to
be
insured
.
''
<END>
<START>
In
addition
to
hedging
new
stock
purchases
,
the
married-put
technique
can
be
used
to
protect
stocks
that
an
investor
already
owns
.
<END>
<START>
In
either
case
,
the
investor
faces
three
possible
outcomes
:
<END>
<START>
--
If
the
stock
goes
up
in
price
between
now
and
the
put
's
expiration
date
,
the
put
will
probably
expire
worthless
.
<END>
<START>
The
investor
will
be
out
the
cost
of
the
put
,
which
is
called
the
``
premium
,
''
and
this
loss
will
reduce
the
stock-market
profit
.
<END>
<START>
The
worst-case
scenario
would
be
if
the
put
expires
worthless
.
<END>
<START>
--
If
the
price
of
the
stock
declines
,
the
put
will
increase
in
value
.
<END>
<START>
The
put
establishes
a
minimum
selling
price
for
the
stock
during
its
life
.
<END>
<START>
When
a
stock
falls
below
the
put
's
strike
price
,
the
investor
simply
sells
the
stock
at
a
loss
and
simultaneously
sells
the
put
at
a
profit
.
<END>
<START>
Brokers
handle
such
transactions
through
the
Options
Clearing
Corp.
,
which
guarantees
all
option
trades
.
<END>
<START>
The
accompanying
table
shows
how
this
strategy
would
work
for
three
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
Though
not
reflected
in
the
table
,
an
investor
should
know
that
the
cost
of
the
option
insurance
can
be
partially
offset
by
any
dividends
that
the
stock
pays
.
<END>
<START>
In
this
case
,
the
investor
's
risk
would
n't
exceed
3.6
%
of
the
total
investment
.
<END>
<START>
To
simplify
the
calculations
,
commissions
on
the
option
and
underlying
stock
are
n't
included
in
the
table
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
more
than
650
stocks
on
which
options
may
be
bought
and
sold
,
including
some
over-the-counter
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
But
some
investors
might
prefer
a
simpler
strategy
then
hedging
their
individual
holdings
.
<END>
<START>
They
can
do
this
by
purchasing
``
index
puts
,
''
which
are
simply
put
options
on
indexes
that
match
broad
baskets
of
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
For
instance
,
the
most
popular
index
option
is
the
S&P
100
option
,
commonly
called
the
OEX
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
based
on
the
stocks
that
make
up
Standard
&
Poor
's
100-stock
index
.
<END>
<START>
Unlike
options
on
individual
issues
,
index
options
are
settled
only
in
cash
,
and
no
stock
is
ever
tendered
.
<END>
<START>
But
while
index
options
are
convenient
,
they
have
several
disadvantages
.
<END>
<START>
For
one
thing
,
an
investor
's
portfolio
might
not
closely
match
the
S&P
100
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
the
OEX
insurance
may
or
may
not
fully
protect
an
investor
's
holdings
in
the
event
of
a
market
decline
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
OEX
options
were
suspended
from
trading
last
Friday
afternoon
,
after
the
stock-market
sell-off
got
under
way
and
trading
in
the
S&P-500
futures
contract
was
halted
.
<END>
<START>
So
an
investor
who
wanted
to
realize
a
profit
on
OEX
puts
after
the
trading
suspension
would
have
been
out
of
luck
.
<END>
<START>
On
the
other
hand
,
only
a
handful
of
individual
issues
were
suspended
from
trading
on
Friday
.
<END>
<START>
Normally
,
once
the
underlying
investment
is
suspended
from
trading
,
the
options
on
those
investments
also
do
n't
trade
.
<END>
<START>
Ultimately
,
whether
the
insurance
provided
by
purchasing
puts
is
worthwhile
depends
on
the
cost
of
the
options
.
<END>
<START>
That
cost
rises
in
times
of
high
market
volatility
.
<END>
<START>
But
it
still
might
be
cheaper
than
taking
a
major
hit
.
<END>
<START>
The
protection
from
using
married
puts
is
clearly
superior
to
that
afforded
by
another
options
strategy
some
investors
consider
using
during
troubled
times
:
selling
call
options
on
stocks
the
investor
owns
.
<END>
<START>
A
call
option
is
similar
to
a
put
,
except
that
it
gives
its
owner
the
right
to
buy
shares
at
a
stated
price
until
expiration
.
<END>
<START>
Selling
a
call
option
gives
an
investor
a
small
buffer
against
a
stock-market
decline
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
because
it
reduces
the
cost
of
the
stock
by
the
amount
of
premium
received
from
the
sale
of
the
call
.
<END>
<START>
But
if
the
price
of
the
stock
rises
above
the
strike
price
of
the
option
,
the
stock
is
almost
certain
to
be
called
away
.
<END>
<START>
And
in
that
case
,
the
investor
misses
out
on
any
major
upside
gain
.
<END>
<START>
These
calculations
exclude
the
effect
of
commissions
paid
and
dividends
received
from
the
stock
.
<END>
<START>
All
prices
are
as
of
Monday
's
close
.
<END>
<START>
Hopes
for
quick
enactment
of
pending
deficit-reduction
legislation
faded
as
efforts
to
streamline
the
House
version
in
advance
of
a
House-Senate
conference
broke
down
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
effort
became
snagged
on
the
question
of
what
would
become
of
other
issues
,
ranging
from
cutting
the
capital-gains
tax
to
child
care
to
repeal
of
catastrophic-illness
insurance
.
<END>
<START>
``
Many
members
feel
there
are
important
features
of
the
House
bill
that
should
be
enacted
,
''
Speaker
Thomas
Foley
-LRB-
D.
,
Wash
.
-RRB-
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
there
is
any
support
for
reducing
the
bill
,
it
is
conditioned
on
their
desire
to
see
them
passed
in
another
form
.
''
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
a
democratic
process
--
you
ca
n't
slam-dunk
anything
around
here
.
''
<END>
<START>
Failure
to
pass
the
bill
meant
that
$
16.1
billion
in
across-the-board
spending
cuts
took
effect
Monday
under
the
Gramm-Rudman
budget
law
.
<END>
<START>
The
bill
must
be
enacted
before
the
cuts
can
be
restored
.
<END>
<START>

.

500

.

.

amount

.

The

.

.

.

Gold
Corp.
to
42
%
from
26
%
.
<END>
<START>
Northgate

will
own
about
50
%
of
the
equity
and
81
%
of
the
votes
of
ABM
after
the
amalgamation
.
<END>
<START>
The
amalgamations
are
subject
to
regulatory
approval
and
require
approval
by
shareholders
of
ABM
,
Inca
,
United
and
Neptune
at
special
meetings
on
Nov.
10
.

<START>
Steven
C.
Walker
,
senior
vice

of
this
bank
holding
company
,
was

president
,
chief

and
a
director
of

Commercial
National
and

.
<END>
<START>
He

James
E.

III
,
who

from

three
posts
to

other
interests
.
<END>
<START>
Cincinnati
Microwave
Inc.
said
it
introduced
two
radar
detectors
.
<END>
<START>
One
unit
,
called
the
Escort
,
uses
a
new
digital
signal-processing
technology
to
detect
radar
signals
much
sooner
than
was
previously
possible
,
the
company
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
other
,
called
the
Solo
,
is
battery
operated
and
is
the
first
high-performance
radar
detector
that
does
n't
need
a
power
cord
,
the
company
said
.
<END>
<START>
A
surprising
surge
in
the
U.S.
trade
deficit
raised
fears
that
the
nation
's
export
drive
has
stalled
,
and
caused
new
turmoil
in
financial
markets
.
<END>
<START>
Exports
fell
for
the
second
month
in
a
row
,
while
imports
rose
to
a
record
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
one
of
the
worst
trade
releases
we
've
had
since
the
dollar
troughed
out
in
1987
,
''
said
Geoffrey
Dennis
,
chief
international
economist
at
James
Capel
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
The
number
had
a
troubling
effect
on
Wall
Street
,
suggesting
that
more
fundamental
economic
problems
may
underlie
last
Friday
's
stock
market
slide
.
<END>
<START>
The
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
tumbled
more
than
60
points
after
the
report
's
release
,
before
recovering
to
close
18.65
points
lower
at
2638.73
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
bad
trade
number
raises
some
deeper
issues
about
the
market
decline
,
''
said
Norman
Robertson
,
chief
economist
for
Mellon
Bank
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
raises
questions
about
more
deep-seated
problems
,
the
budget
deficit
and
the
trade
deficit
and
the
seeming
lack
of
ability
to
come
to
grips
with
them
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
trade
report
drew
yet
another
unsettling
parallel
to
October
1987
.
<END>
<START>
On
Oct.
14
of
that
year
,
the
announcement
of
an
unusually
large
August
trade
deficit
helped
trigger
a
steep
market
decline
.
<END>
<START>
The
slide
continued
until
the
record
508-point
market
drop
on
Oct.
19
.
<END>
<START>
In
1987
,
however
,
the
news
was
the
latest
in
a
string
of
disappointments
on
trade
,
while
the
current
report
comes
after
a
period
of
improvement
.
<END>
<START>
The
bleak
trade
report
was
played
down
by
the
Bush
administration
.
<END>
<START>
Commerce
Secretary
Robert
Mosbacher
called
the
worsening
trade
figures
``
disappointing
after
two
very
good
months
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
the
figures
reinforced
the
view
of
many
private
analysts
that
the
improvement
in
the
U.S.
trade
deficit
has
run
out
of
steam
.
<END>
<START>
Exports
declined
for
the
second
consecutive
month
in
August
,
slipping
0.2
%
to
$
30.41
billion
,
the
Commerce
Department
reported
.
<END>
<START>
Imports
,
on
the
other
hand
,
leaped
6.4
%
to
a
record
$
41.18
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Not
only
was
August
's
deficit
far
worse
than
July
's
,
but
the
government
revised
the
July
figure
substantially
from
the
$
7.58
billion
deficit
it
had
initially
reported
last
month
.
<END>
<START>
Many
economists
contend
that
deep
cuts
in
the
U.S.
budget
deficit
are
needed
before
further
trade
improvement
can
occur
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
because
the
budget
deficit
feeds
an
enormous
appetite
in
this
country
for
both
foreign
goods
and
foreign
capital
,
overwhelming
the
nation
's
capacity
to
export
.
<END>
<START>
``
People
are
sick
and
tired
of
hearing
about
these
deficits
,
but
the
imbalances
are
still
there
and
they
are
still
a
problem
,
''
said
Mr.
Robertson
.
<END>
<START>
Since
March
,
exports
have
been
virtually
flat
.
<END>
<START>
Most
economists
expect
the
slowing
U.S.
economy
to
curb
demand
for
imports
.
<END>
<START>
But
they
foresee
little
substantial
progress
in
exports
unless
the
dollar
and
the
federal
budget
deficit
come
down
.
<END>
<START>
``
That
must
start
with
cutting
the
federal
budget
deficit
.
''
<END>
<START>
August
's
decline
in
exports
reflected
decreases
in
sales
of
industrial
supplies
,
capital
goods
and
food
abroad
and
increases
in
sales
of
motor
vehicles
,
parts
and
engines
.
<END>
<START>
The
jump
in
imports
stemmed
from
across-the-board
increases
in
purchases
of
foreign
goods
.
<END>
<START>
The
numbers
were
adjusted
for
usual
seasonal
fluctuations
.
<END>
<START>
Alan
Murray
contributed
to
this
article
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
In
billions
of
U.S.
dollars
,
not
seasonally
adjusted
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
*
Newly
industrialized
countries
:
Singapore
,
Hong
Kong
,
Taiwan
,
South
Korea
<END>
<START>
Steve
Jobs
took
a
step
back
from
the
frontier
of
personal-computer
technology
in
an
effort
to
spur
sales
of
Next
Inc.
's
new
machine
.
<END>
<START>
The
hard
drive
,
which
is
the
storage
device
of
choice
for
virtually
every
desktop
computer
user
,
also
now
will
supplement
Next
's
futuristic
optical
device
if
buyers
pay
full
price
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Jobs
,
co-founder
of
Apple
Computer
Inc.
,
founded
Next
four
years
ago
in
the
hopes
of
fomenting
a
revolution
in
the
way
desktop
computers
are
designed
and
used
.
<END>
<START>
His
Next
computer
,
introduced
about
a
year
ago
and
aimed
primarily
at
university
computer
users
,
sports
snazzy
graphics
,
digital
sound
,
built-in
networking
and
a
sleek
black
design
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
computer
was
proving
a
hard
sell
because
of
its
high
price
,
a
lack
of
software
and
an
optical
data-storage
device
that
was
too
slow
.
<END>
<START>
The
machine
began
shipping
at
the
end
of
last
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
closely
held
company
has
n't
disclosed
sales
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
most
universities
that
have
bought
the
machines
say
they
are
buying
small
numbers
for
evaluation
purposes
.
<END>
<START>
Universities
can
now
buy
a
Next
computer
without
an
optical
storage
device
for
$
4,995
.
<END>
<START>
Commercial
customers
can
purchase
the
same
system
through
Businessland
Inc.
,
a
computer
retailer
based
in
San
Jose
,
Calif.
,
for
roughly
$
3,000
more
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Jobs
said
the
changes
were
prompted
by
requests
from
customers
who
are
frustrated
with
the
performance
of
the
optical
device
,
which
is
n't
offered
as
standard
equipment
by
any
rivals
.
<END>
<START>
Another
factor
was
that
customers
were
asking
,
``
Why
do
n't
you
give
us
a
cheaper
system
?
''
Mr.
Jobs
said
at
a
conference
on
university
computing
here
.
<END>
<START>
Optical-storage
devices
can
handle
very
large
amounts
of
data
and
make
it
far
easier
to
edit
film
clips
or
audio
recordings
with
a
computer
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
technology
,
while
reliable
,
is
far
slower
than
the
widely
used
hard
drives
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're
extremely
committed
to
optical
storage
technology
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
think
everything
will
go
this
way
in
a
few
years
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
said
that
the
next
generation
of
optical
drives
will
be
as
fast
as
hard
drives
,
but
he
depends
on
outside
suppliers
for
the
devices
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
it
will
definitely
boost
Next
's
sales
.
''
<END>
<START>
Universities
,
however
,
say
Next
's
prices
must
go
even
lower
before
large
numbers
of
students
purchase
the
machine
.
<END>
<START>
Broad
acceptance
of
Next
's
computer
also
is
hindered
by
difficulty
in
distributing
software
for
it
.
<END>
<START>
Most
software
is
distributed
on
cheap
floppy
disks
,
but
the
Next
computer
does
n't
come
with
a
device
that
reads
them
.
<END>
<START>
Next
's
computer
also
needs
more
software
applications
,
but
Mr.
Jobs
said
he
expects
more
soon
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
he
expects
Lotus
Development
Corp.
to
introduce
a
Next
version
of
its
popular
1-2-3
spreadsheet
program
in
1990
.
<END>
<START>
Educators
added
that
Next
needs
to
soon
offer
a
color
version
of
its
computer
.
<END>
<START>
Every
major
maker
offers
computers
with
color
displays
.
<END>
<START>
Next
wo
n't
comment
on
when
it
will
do
the
same
,
but
is
believed
to
have
a
color
model
under
development
.
<END>

<START>
Ethyl
Corp.
reported
that
third-quarter
net
income
fell
12
%
from
a
year-earlier
quarter
helped
by
a
gain
from
discontinued
operations
.
<END>
<START>
Profit
from
continuing
operations
rose
19
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
chemicals
and
insurance
company
said
net
in
the
latest
quarter
was
$
54.8
million
,
or
45
cents
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
year-earlier
quarter
,
net
was
$
62.2
million
,
or
51
cents
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
The
previous-year
quarter
included
$
16.1
million
from
businesses
spun
off
as
Tredegar
Industries
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
was
$
613.7
million
,
up
18
%
from
$
521.2
million
a
year
ago
.
<END>
<START>

said

from
its
insurance

,

,
rose
28
%
in

$
28.6

from

22.4

.
<END>
<START>

chemicals
segment
,

rose
7
%
to
$
69.2
million
from
$
64.9
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
's

,

,

,

and

.

in

included
$
11.9
million
from

and

of
$
6.2
million
from

closing
.
<END>
<START>

,

included
$
32.7
million
from
discontinued
operations
.
<END>
<START>

was

1.79
billion
,

18

1.52

.

,

.

been

with

.

.

<START>

,
''

<START>
U.S.
exports
to
Canada
jumped
11.2
%
in
August
from
July
while
U.S.
imports
from
Canada
rose
only
2.7
%
.
<END>
<START>
U.S.
exports
benefited
in
August
from
heavy
Canadian
spending
on
new
plant
and
equipment
and
a
pickup
in
Canadian
auto
demand
,
Canadian
officials
said
.
<END>
<START>
Industries
in
both
countries
have
requested
a
speedup
of
tariff
cuts
on
hundreds
of
products
.
<END>
<START>
Some
tariffs
were
eliminated
when
the
trade
pact
took
effect
Jan.
1
.
<END>
<START>
The
remainder
were
to
be
phased
out
in
five
or
10
annual
installments
,
with
all
tariffs
eliminated
by
January
1998
.
<END>
<START>
The
two
countries
aim
to
reach
an
agreement
by
early
December
on
a
package
of
accelerated
tariff
cuts
that
would
take
effect
early
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
Canadian
officials
said
the
trade
pact
has
kindled
an
export
interest
among
many
small
Canadian
companies
that
previously
had
little
or
no

.

<START>

,

is

.

<START>

.
<END>
<START>

and

jamming
capabilities
.
<END>
<START>
The
defense
electronics
maker
said
delivery
will
begin
in
October
1991
and
run
through
mid-1995
.
<END>
<START>
Loral
said
the
contract
with
Turkey
will
provide
opportunities
for
Loral
to
supply
that
country
with
other
defense
systems
.
<END>
<START>

.

.

.

.

yesterday
at

2
bid
.
<END>
<START>
Among

,

.

,

from

.

,

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Connolly
noted

third-quarter

,
at

63

,

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>

$
354

.
<END>

to

,

.

.

<START>

14

,

.

,

.

.

.

%
of

,

.

,

<START>
How

will

,

,
are

.
<END>
<START>
But
Wang
salespeople
are
trying
to
cope
with
the
biggest
challenge
any
marketer
can
face
:
selling
the
products
of
a
company
that
is
on
the
ropes
.
<END>
<START>
It
can
happen
in
any
industry
.
<END>
<START>
Consider
the
difficulties
faced
by
Audi
salespeople
when
the
car
was
tainted
by
false
charges
of
sudden
acceleration
,
or
Exxon
dealers
'
problems
in
the
wake
of
the
Valdez
oil
spill
.
<END>
<START>
Like
thousands
of
salespeople
before
them
,
Wang
's
are
finding
ways
to
combat
the
bad
news
.
<END>
<START>
Wang
got
into
financial
trouble
because
of
bloated
overhead
and
overly
optimistic
sales
forecasts
.
<END>
<START>
Its
mainline
minicomputers
and
word
processors
have
lost
ground
to
cheaper
personal
computers
.
<END>
<START>
Last
year
it
funded
its
high
employment
by
heavy
borrowing
,
and
it
suffered
huge
losses
when
sales
turned
down
instead
of
rising
.
<END>
<START>
Salespeople
try
to
push
their
products
and
avoid
discussions
of
finances
.
<END>
<START>
Responding
to
such
questions
is
``
defensive
,
''
says
Kenneth
Olissa
,
Wang
's
vice
president
,
marketing
.
<END>
<START>
``
That
's
antithetical
to
the
art
of
selling
.
''
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
he
notes
that
analyzing
financial
results
``
poses
a
problem
for
a
salesman
who
is
n't
particularly
familiar
with
a
balance
sheet
.
''
<END>
<START>
At
one
sales
strategy
meeting
,
an
executive
suggested
ordering
salespeople
to
become
experts
on
the
annual
report
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Miller
vetoed
that
:
``
Even
I
ca
n't
understand
all
the
footnotes
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
We
tell
them
all
the
major
companies
are
having
financial
difficulties
.
''
<END>
<START>
Numerous
computer
companies
are
having
sales
slumps
and
earnings
declines
,
but
very
few
have
had
losses
comparable
to
Wang
's
or
are
carrying
such
a
large
debt
load
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Miller
says
that
after
a
sharp
sales
slump
in
July
and
August
,
sales
stabilized
in
September
.
<END>
<START>
Experts
on
sales
technique
say
anyone
representing
a
troubled
company
must
walk
a
fine
line
.
<END>
<START>
Ignore
the
present
condition
.
<END>
<START>
Show
it
's
business
as
usual
.
''
<END>
<START>
That
is
n't
easy
.
<END>
<START>
For
buyers
,
``
these
are
career-risking
decisions
,
''
says
Jean
Conlin
,
who
supervises
a
network
of
Wang
computers
in
the
admissions
department
at
Boston
University
.
<END>
<START>
The
university
is
considering
installing
a
$
250,000
system
to
store
applications
electronically
.
<END>
<START>
``
Before
the
really
bad
news
,
we
were
looking
at
Wang
fairly
seriously
,
''
she
says
.
<END>
<START>
But
``
their
present
financial
condition
means
I
'd
have
a
hard
time
convincing
the
vice
president
in
charge
of
purchasing
.
''
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Conlin
adds
:
``
At
some
point
we
'd
have
to
ask
,
`
How
do
we
know
that
in
three
years
you
wo
n't
be
in
Chapter
11
?
'
''
<END>
<START>
During
the
past
year
,
Wang
has
developed
new
products
and
a
new
strategy
and
hired
a
new
president
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
were
on
the
road
to
recovery
in
terms
of
customer
attitudes
until
this
bad
quarter
happened
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
first
priority
for
Wang
's
sales
force
is
to
make
sure
it
holds
on
to
existing
customers
.
<END>
<START>
Wang
's
installed
base
is
one
of
its
greatest
assets
,
and
many
of
those
customers
remain
extremely
loyal
.
<END>
<START>
The
more
recent
losses
were
really
devastating
.
''
<END>
<START>
New
customers
,
the
source
of
higher
commissions
for
salespeople
and
the
key
to
Wang
's
long-term
viability
,
are
even
tougher
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Lynch
left
Wang
this
summer
for
Oracle
Systems
Inc.
,
a
software
vendor
.
<END>
<START>
The
financial
problems
are
particularly
frustrating
for
salespeople
pushing
Wang
's
image
systems
,
which
convert
paper
forms
to

documents
.
<END>
<START>
Consultants
say
that
Wang
's
technology
is
among
the
best
available
in
the
image
market
.
<END>
<START>
But
salespeople
often
found
that
news
of
Wang
's
problems
superseded
their
sales
efforts
.
<END>
<START>
William
Tait
,
a
former

manager
in
Indianapolis
,

that
his
office
had
all
but
sold
a
$
1.5
million

system
to

maker
Eli
Lilly
&
Co
.
<END>
<START>
``
When
they
were
making
the
decision
,
all
hell
broke
loose
with
the
finances
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
says
the
Lilly
executives
told
him
they
could
n't
take
the
risk
with
Wang
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Tait
say
he
does
n't
blame
Lilly
.
<END>
<START>
Buyers
have
to
rely
on
a
supplier
``
continually
upgrading
and
replacing
the
product
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
When
a
company
realizes
that
,
it
's
hard
to
go
with
Wang
.
''
<END>
<START>
For
Mr.
Tait
,
who
says
he
used
to
earn
as
much
as
$
150,000
a
year
at
Wang
,

was

more
reason
to
quit
.
<END>
<START>
He
is
now
president
of
Eastate
Homes
Inc.
,
an
Indianapolis
contractor
.
<END>
<START>
It
can
be
hard
for
a
salesperson
to
fight
off
feelings
of
discouragement
.
<END>
<START>
Brian
Petre
,
a
former
Wang
salesman
in
upstate
New
York
,
says
:
``
You
have
pride
in
your
job
.
<END>
<START>
You
think
you
can
go
out
and
turn
things
around
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
a
tough
thing
when
you
ca
n't
.
<END>
<START>
The
reason
does
n't
relate
to
your
selling
skills
.
''
<END>
<START>
Discouragement
feeds
on
itself
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
problem
is
,
if
people
get
down
in
the
dumps
,
they
stop
selling
,
''
says
Mike
Durcan
,

manager
in
Wang
's
Austin
office
.
<END>
<START>
One
key
for
salespeople
is
to
boost
their
own
morale
.
<END>
<START>
The
good
news
is
,
it
's
not
your
fault
.
''
<END>
<START>
So
,
he
advises
,
make

achievable
.
<END>
<START>
For

,
he
suggests
that

making

calls
should
say

:
``
All
I
want

50

.
''
<END>
<START>
But

Miller
,
Wang
's

,

.

<START>
``
Our

,
''

.

<START>
``

,
`

.
<END>
<START>

<START>
Olin
Corp.
said
third-quarter
net
income
rose
26
%
on
the
strength
of
its
chemical
business
.
<END>
<START>
Net
was
$
24
million
,
or
$
1.15
a
share
,
up
from
$
19
million
,
or
90
cents
a
share
,
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
rose
7.4
%
to
$
580
million
from
$
540
million
.
<END>
<START>
Olin
said
its
chemical
segment
had
profit
of
$
22
million
,
up
from
$
15
million
a
year
ago
,
largely
because
of
gains
in
electrochemicals
such
as
caustic
soda
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
the
gains
were
tied
to
volume
increases
and
higher
prices
.
<END>
<START>
The
market
for
electrochemicals
include
the
paper
,
water-purification
and
textile
industries
.
<END>
<START>
The
chemical
segment
had
a
$
6
million
gain
on
the
sale
of
ammonia
and
urea
businesses
,
which
was
offset
by
a
$
6
million
charge
for
future
environmental
expenditures
.
<END>
<START>
Profit
in
Olin
's
defense
and
ammunition
segment
rose
to
$
8
million
from
$
7
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
metals
segment
,
hurt
by
a
strike
,
had
break-even
results
,
against
$
3
million
a
year
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
rose
13
%
to
$
1.91
billion
from
$
1.69
billion
.
<END>
<START>
In
New
York
Stock
Exchange
composite
trading
,
Olin
closed
at
$
58.50
a
share
,
down
25
cents
.
<END>
<START>
GTE
Corp.
and
MCI
Communications
Corp.
reported
strong
earnings
gains
to
record
levels
for
the
third
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Southwestern
Bell
Corp.
and
Cincinnati
Bell
posted
slight
declines
.
<END>
<START>
GTE
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
GTE
said
net
income
rose
18
%
,
aided
by
higher
long-distance
calling
volumes
and
an
increase
in
telephone
lines
in
service
.
<END>
<START>
Pretax
operating
profit
from
telephone
operations
rose
8.2
%
but
profits
from
telecommunications
products
and
electrical
products
were
flat
.
<END>
<START>
Revenues
rose
8.8
%
to
$
4.35
billion
from
$
4.0
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
the
quarter
included
a
10
%
increase
in
local-exchange
usage
for
long-distance
calling
and
a
5
%
increase
in
the
number
of
access
lines
in
service
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
in
the
telecommunications
products
and
services
unit
rose
27
%
to
$
728.8
million
,
but
operating
profit
was
unchanged
at
$
26.3
million
,
partly
because
of
start-up

.
<END>
<START>
Operating
profit
of
$
37.2
million
was
unchanged
.
<END>
<START>
In
composite
trading
on
the

,
GTE
rose
$
1.25
to
$
64.125
.

<START>
MCI
Communications
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
MCI
,

up

to
sell
long-distance
telephone
service
to

,
reported
a
59
%
jump
in
earnings
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
rose
23
%
to
$
1.67
billion
from
$
1.36
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Daniel
Akerson
,

.
<END>
<START>
``

to

18
%

18

,
''

.
<END>
<START>

trading
,

fell
$
2.625
to
$
42.375
.
<END>
<START>
Charles
Schellke
,
an

with
Smith
Barney
,
Harris
Upham
&
Co.
,
said

apparently
expected

better

growth
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
that

grew
faster
than

and

to
its
new
PrimeTime
calling
plan
that
competes
with
American

&
Telegraph
's
Reach
Out

plan
.
<END>
<START>
MCI
claims
about
12
%
of
the
overall
long-distance
telephone
market
but
just
under
10
%
of
the
$
23
billion
residential
market
.
<END>
<START>
It
has
been
trying
to
improve
its
share
of
the
residential
market
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
wants
its

mix
to
more
closely
match
that
of
AT&T
--
a
step
it
says
will
help
prevent
cross
subsidization
.
<END>
<START>
The
current
quarter
,
he
said
,
``
looks
fine
.
<END>
<START>
We
think
revenue
will
continue
to
grow
and
that
we
can
control
costs
and
thus
improve
profitability
.
''
<END>

.

Co.
to

's

.
<END>

.
<END>

,

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

to

.

,

.

<START>
Arbitragers
were
n't

.
<END>
<START>

's

,

.

.

.

,

.

<START>

,

.

,

,

,

.

.

.

,

.

.

,

.

<START>

.
<END>
<START>

,
''

.

.

,

's

calls
for

to

.

,

said
,

on
any

.

Percival
will

,

.

.

.

3
%

's

,

.

,

at
$
3.625
,

.
<END>
<START>
Three
leading
drug
companies
reported
robust
third-quarter
earnings
,
bolstered
by
strong
sales
of
newer
,
big-selling
prescriptions
drugs
that
provide
hefty
profit
margins
.
<END>
<START>
Merck
&
Co.
reported
a
25
%
increase
in
earnings
;
Warner-Lambert
Co.
's
profit
rose
22
%
and
Eli
Lilly
&
Co.
's
net
income
rose
24
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
results
were
in
line
with
analysts
'
expectations
.
<END>
<START>
Merck
&
Co
.
<END>
<START>
Merck
,
Rahway
,
N.J.
,
continued
to
lead
the
industry
with
a
strong
sales
performance
in
the
human
and
animal
health-products
segment
.
<END>
<START>
A
stronger
U.S.
dollar
reduced
third-quarter
and
first-nine-month
sales
growth
2
%
and
3
%
,
respectively
.
<END>
<START>
International
sales
accounted
for
47
%
of
total
company
sales
for
the
nine
months
,
compared
with
50
%
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
for
the
quarter
rose
to
$
1.63
billion
from
$
1.47
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Mevacor
,
Merck
's
new
cholesterol-lowering
drug
,
had
higher
sales
than
any
other
prescription
medicine
has
ever
achieved
in
the
U.S.
in
the
year
following
introduction
,
the
company
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
drug
was
introduced
in
West
Germany
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Intense
competition
,
however
,
led
to
unit
sales
declines
for
a
group
of
Merck
's
established
human
and
animal-health
products
,
including
Aldomet
and
Indocin
.
<END>
<START>
In
New
York
Stock
Exchange
composite
trading
yesterday
,
Merck
shares
closed
at
$
75.25
,
up
50
cents
.
<END>
<START>
Warner-Lambert
Co
.
<END>
<START>
Warner-Lambert
,
Morris
Plains
,
N.J.
,
reported
sales
that
were
a
record
for
any
quarter
and
the
eighth
quarter
in
a
row
of
20
%
or
more
per-share
earnings
growth
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
for
the
quarter
rose
to
$
1.11
billion
from
$
1.03
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Prescription-drug
world-wide
sales
rose
9
%
in
the
quarter
to
$
340
million
;
U.S.
sales
rose
15
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
segment
's
growth
was
led
by
sales
of
the
cardiovascular
drugs
Lopid
,
a
lipid
regulator
,
and
Dilzem
,
a
calcium
channel
blocker
.
<END>
<START>
Confectionery
products
sales
also
had
strong
growth
in
the
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
World-wide
sales
of
Trident
gum
,
Certs
breath
mints
,
and
Clorets
gum
and
breath
mints
,
increased
12
%
to
$
277
million
.
<END>
<START>
Warner-Lambert
shares
closed
at
$
109.50
a
share
,
up
$
1.50
,
in
Big
Board
composite
trading
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
Eli
Lilly
&
Co
.
<END>
<START>
Lilly
attributed
record
third-quarter
and
nine-month
results
to
world-wide
gains
for
pharmaceuticals
,
medical
instruments
and
plant-science
products
despite
poor
exchange
rates
for
the
dollar
that
slowed
sales
abroad
.
<END>
<START>
Third-quarter
sales
of
the
Indianapolis
,
Ind.
,
company
rose
11
%
to
$
1.045
billion
from
$
940.6
million
.
<END>
<START>
Nine-month
sales
grew
12
%
to
$
3.39
billion
from
$
3.03
billion
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
of
Prozac
,
an
anti-depressant
,
led
drug-sales
increases
.
<END>
<START>
Higher
sales
of
pesticides
and
other
plant-science
products
more
than
offset
a
slight
decline
in
the
sales
of
animal-health
products
to
fuel
the
increase
in
world-wide
agricultural
product
sales
,
Lilly
said
.
<END>
<START>
Advanced
Cardiovascular
Systems
Inc.
and
Cardiac
Pacemakers
Inc.
units
led
growth
in
the
medical-instrument
systems
division
.
<END>
<START>
Lilly
shares
closed
yesterday
in
composite
trading
on
the
Big
Board
at
$
62.25
,
down
12.5
cents
.
<END>
<START>

Mark
,

''

;

,

.

the

.

Colgate
's

rose

8
%

.

<START>
Mr.
Mark
attributed

growth
to

,

.

``

''

's

,

said
.
<END>
<START>
Operating
profit
at
Colgate
's
U.S.

products
and

<START>

<START>
The

<END>
<START>
A

was
born
.
<END>
<START>
It

for

,

<START>

.

<START>
Tony

,

.

<START>

<START>

's

,

.

<START>

,

.

<START>
United

.
<END>
<START>
Satisfying

.

's

.

<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
He

,

.
<END>
<START>
This

<START>
Mr.

<START>
Mr.

<START>

,

.

<START>

,

,

.

,

<START>
Industrial
production
declined
0.1
%
in
September
,
reinforcing
other
signs
that
the
manufacturing
sector
continues
its
slowing
trend
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
need
to
do

about
this
,
''

,

.
<END>
<START>
The

said

operated
at
83.6
%
of

last
month
,
down
from
83.8

in
August
.
<END>
<START>
Measures
of

more
than

.
<END>
<START>
Factory
output
dropped
0.2
%
,
its
first

since
February
,
after
having
been
unchanged
in
October
.
<END>
<START>
Factories
operated
at
83.7
%
of
capacity
,
the
lowest

in
more
than
a
year
and
down
from
84.1
%
in
September
.
<END>
<START>
The
declines
mainly
reflected
widespread

in
durable

,
those
intended
to
last
more
than
three

.
<END>
<START>
The

was

by

,
a

that
includes
the
steel
industry
.
<END>
<START>
Output
of
business

was
unchanged
in
September
.
<END>
<START>
Production
of
factory
equipment
,
one
indication
of
the
strength
of
manufacturers
'
investment
spending
,
fell
0.3
%
.
<END>
<START>
Some
economists
expect
further

in

spending
.
<END>
<START>
``

are

that

,
''

Harris

.
<END>
<START>
``

.
''

.

<START>
Lung-cancer
mortality
rates
for
people
under
45
years
of
age
have
begun
to
decline
,
federal
researchers
report
.
<END>
<START>
The
drop
is
particularly
large
for
white
males
,
although
black
males
and
white
and
black
women
also
show
lower
mortality
rates
.
<END>
<START>
The
National
Cancer
Institute
report
compares
mortality
rates
of
two
groups
of
people
between
the
ages
of
35
and
44
a
decade
apart
.
<END>
<START>
Measured
the
same
way
,
the
decline
for
black
males
was
14.2
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
drop
in
mortality
rates
for
women
was
less
steep
--
8.9
%
for
blacks
and
5.3
%
for
whites
.
<END>
<START>
Lung-cancer
mortality
rates
increase
with
age
and
are
continuing
to
rise
for
all
age
groups
over
55
,
with
sharp
increases
for
everybody
but
white
men
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
he
stressed
that
the
improvement
depends
on
a
continued
reduction
in
smoking
.
<END>
<START>
``
Even
though
these
favorable
trends
in
lung-cancer
mortality
affect
all
sex
and
race
groups
,
they
ca
n't
be
taken
for
granted
,
''
the
report
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
Smoking
prevention
programs
should
reach
larger
segments
of
the
population
,
especially
children
,
adolescents
and
minorities
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
the
editorial
,
by
Jan
Stjernsward
of
the
World
Health
Organization
,
notes
that
tobacco
consumption
and
lung-cancer
mortality
rates
are
rising
in
developing
countries
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
the
American
Cancer
Society
,
smoking
is
responsible
for
85
%
of
the
lung-cancer
cases
among
men
and
75
%
among
women
.
<END>
<START>
The
NCI
report
attributes
the
differences
in
mortality
rates
by
race
to
different
smoking
patterns
.
<END>
<START>
A
higher
proportion
of
black
men
smoke
than
white
men
.
<END>
<START>
While
nearly
equal
percentages
of
black
and
white
women
currently
smoke
,
in
both
sexes
more
whites
have
given
up
smoking
than
blacks
.
<END>
<START>
In
comparing
changes
in
mortality
rates
over
the
past

,
the
NCI
study
looked
only

and
whites
.
<END>
<START>
Asians
and
native
Americans
were
n't

;

were

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
White
Males
<END>
<START>
White

<END>
<START>
Black

<START>

<END>

<START>

profit
from
the
recent
volatility
in
financial
markets
invaded
the
Nasdaq
over-the-counter
market
,
prompting
even
more
swings
in
stock
prices
.
<END>
<START>
After
gaining
strength
during
a
brief
run-up
when
trading
began
,
the
Nasdaq
Composite
Index
weakened
under
selling
pressure
.
<END>
<START>
The
forces
at
work
included
computer-guided
trading
,
as
well
as
profit-driven
market
makers
and
institutional
investors
who
had
bought
stock
on
the
cheap
during
the
recent
correction
.
<END>
<START>
During
the
last
two
hours
of
trading
,
the
composite
almost
drew
even
on
the
day
before
slipping
again
.
<END>
<START>
The
Nasdaq
Composite
closed
down
1.05
,
or
0.2
%
,
to
459.93
.
<END>
<START>
The
action
was
confined
to
Nasdaq
's
biggest
and
most
liquid
stocks
,
traders
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
Nasdaq
100
Index
began
the
day
at
449.89
,
lost
2
%
at
one
point
,
and
was
up
0.4
%
at
another
.
<END>
<START>
The
barometer
of
the
biggest
nonfinancial
stocks
settled
at
448.49
,
off
1.40
.
<END>
<START>
Its
counterpart
,
the
Nasdaq
Financial
Index
,
was
weak
for
most
of
the
day
,
sliding
2.51
to
453.57
by
the
end
of
trading
.
<END>
<START>
The
volatility
was
dizzying
for
traders
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
market
must
have
turned
up
and
down
15
different
times
,
''
commented
Lance
Zipper
,
head
of
OTC
trading
at
Kidder
Peabody
.
<END>
<START>
``
Every
time
you
thought
it
was
going
into
a
rally
it
gave
up
,
and
every
time
you
thought
it
would
rally
it
came
down
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
a
tough
market
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Zipper
said
the
market
is
still
settling
down
after
the
recent
correction
.
<END>
<START>
Most
of
trading
action
now
is
from
professional
traders
who
are
trying
to
take
advantage
of
the
price
swings
to
turn
a
quick
profit
,
he
and
other
traders
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
Everybody
's
confused
and
no
one
has
an
opinion
that
lasts
longer
than
30
seconds
,
''
said
Mr.
Zipper
.
<END>
<START>
``
A
lot
of
the
professional
traders
are
just
going
back
and
forth
.
<END>
<START>
They
're
just
as
confused
.
''
<END>
<START>
William
Rothe
,
head
of
OTC
trading
at
Alex
.
Brown
&
Sons
,
in
Baltimore
,
said
program
trading
is
keeping
the
markets
unsettled
.
<END>
<START>
He
believes
that
the
volatile
conditions
created
by
program
trading
has
``
thoroughly
confused
''
investors
about
where

market

.
<END>
<START>
Program
trading
is
``
benefiting
a
few
to
the
detriment
of
many
and
I
wish
someone
would
do
something
about
it
,
''
he

.
<END>
<START>
Trading
activity
cooled
off
from
Monday
's

pace
.
<END>
<START>
Share

subsided
to
161.5
million
.
<END>
<START>
Advancing
and

issues
finished
about
even
.
<END>
<START>
Of

4,345

that

,
1,174

and
1,040

.
<END>
<START>
One

,
Novell
,

.
<END>

The
stock
,

at
29
1/2
,

as

as
29
3/4
and

as
28
3/4
before

1/4
,

.

The

,

.

.

,

.

.

,

,

B.

,

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
Michael
Applebaum
resigned
after
less
than
a
year
in
the
posts
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Clifton
had
been
executive
financial
assistant
to
the
chairman
.
<END>
<START>
Old
Environmentalism
involved
microbe
hunters
and
sanitationists
.
<END>
<START>
It
started
with
improvements
in
hygiene
made
possible
by
affordable
soap
and
washable
underwear
during
the
Industrial
Revolution
.
<END>
<START>
Then
cast-iron
sewer
pipe
and
the
flush
toilet
were
followed
by
sewage
-
and
water-treatment
plants
toward
the
end
of
the
19th
century
.
<END>
<START>
Medicine
in
the
19th
century
was
dedicated
mostly
to
combating
sepsis
and
diagnostic
analysis
.
<END>
<START>
Then
the
20th
century
saw
the
evolution
of
private-sector
wonder
drugs
,
which
promulgated
medical
therapy
.
<END>
<START>
The
process
dramatically
increased
our
average
life
expectancy
,
eliminated
much
pain
and
constantly
improved
health
and
well-being
.
<END>
<START>
Most
public-health
measures
were
handled
at
the
local
level
.
<END>
<START>
New
Environmentalism
probably
started
in
1962
with
the
publication
of
Rachel
Carson
's
book
``
Silent
Spring
.
''
<END>
<START>
Shortly
thereafter
,
hysterical
articles
began
to
appear
predicting
that
advanced
industrial
societies
would
produce
a
blackened
,
uninhabitable
planet
possibly
by
the
turn
of
the
century
.
<END>
<START>
These
apocalyptic
predictions
were
advanced
by
such
stalwarts
as
Paul
Ehrlich
,
Barry
Commoner
,
Rene
Dubois
and
George
Wald
.
<END>
<START>
Writing
in
the
1960s
Ms.
Carson
suggested
that
the
human
race
could
be
eliminated
in
20
years
,
and
Mr.
Wald
suggested
that
life
on
earth
might
end
by
1985
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Ehrlich
predicted
unprecedented
famine
by
1980
.
<END>
<START>
There
were
many
more
.
<END>
<START>
Thousands
of
chemical
products
were
categorized
as
carcinogenic
,
with
recommendations
that
they
be
banned
from
industrial
use
because
they
produced
malignant
tumors
in
overdosed
rats
.
<END>
<START>
Unknown
before
1960
were
the
inconclusive
effects
of
acid
rain
,
greenhouse
warming
and
ozone
depletion
,
all
of
which
required
burgeoning
political
power
and
gargantuan
expense
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
the
New
Environmentalists
systematically
opposed
the
methods
of
the
Old
Environmentalists
.
<END>
<START>
Local
pollution
problems
require
cheap
energy
and
capital
for
their
solution
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
New
Environmentalists
oppose
private
wealth
creation
-LRB-
which
,
they
claim
,
depletes
natural
resources
-RRB-
and
nuclear
power
-LRB-
even
though
it
would
counteract
the
greenhouse
effect
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
They
are
in
the
forefront
of
opposing
the
search
for
new
landfills
and
methods
of
incineration
and
even
oppose
new
methods
of
research
such
as
genetic
engineering
.
<END>
<START>
New
Environmentalism
is
an
emotional
attack
on
proven
methods
of
improving
our
quality
of
life
and
a
bid
for
political
power
.
<END>
<START>
Let
's
rationalize
our
priorities
by
solving
pollution
problems
at
the
local
level
as
heretofore
.
<END>
<START>
Harry
Lee
Smith
Alpharetta
,
Ga
.
<END>
<START>
Your
story
missed
some
essential
points
of
the
conference
on
``
The
Global
Environment
:
Are
We
Overreacting
?
''
<END>
<START>
First
and
foremost
,
the
vignettes
presented
by
the
various
scientists
represent
a
general
consensus
among
specialists
working
in
the
respective
aspects
of
the
global
environment
.
<END>
<START>
The
point
was
to
answer
the
question
in
the
conference
title
,
not
to
try
to
create
news
stories
for
the
event
itself
.
<END>
<START>
Nor
was
it
intended
to
dictate
a
set
of
prescriptive
solutions
,
although
various
points
were
raised
.
<END>
<START>
Each
speaker
was
asked
to
address
a
specific
topic
,
not
deliver
a
point
of
view
.
<END>
<START>
Each
scientist
independently
concluded
society
and
government
are
underreacting
when
it
comes
to
substantive
policy
change
.
<END>
<START>
This
leads
to
a
very
special
sense
of
urgency
.
<END>
<START>
If
the
media
decide
to
work
harder
at
educating
the
public
about
these
complex
and
technical
issues
,
that
hardly
can
be
termed
non-objective
journalism
.
<END>
<START>
The
environment
can
no
longer
be
a
normal
issue
,
to
be
dealt
with
on
a
business-as-usual
basis
with
comfortable
increments
of
change
.
<END>
<START>
We
have
literally
altered
the
chemistry
and
physics
of
our
planet
's
atmosphere
.
<END>
<START>
This
portends
consequences
from
what
we
have
already
done
that
will
be
very
destabilizing
to
social
and
economic
systems
.
<END>
<START>
The
consensus
from
the
scientific
community
is
that
there
is
sufficient
evidence
to
advise
major
policy
changes
.
<END>
<START>
No
,
we
are
not
overreacting
.
<END>
<START>
Thomas
E.
Lovejoy
Assistant
Secretary
for
External
Affairs
Smithsonian
Institution
<END>
<START>
Coca-Cola
Enterprises
Inc.
,
fulfilling
its
dismal
earnings
forecast
for
1989
,
said
its
third-quarter
net
income
fell
68
%
on
flat
revenue
.
<END>
<START>
The
results
met
estimates
of
analysts
,
who
had
already
slashed
their
projections
after
the
company
said
in
late
August
that
its
1989
earnings
could
tumble
as
much
as
37
%
.
<END>
<START>
A
company
spokesman
said
yesterday
that
Coca-Cola
Enterprises
sticks
by
its
1989
forecast
.
<END>
<START>
Third-quarter
revenue
was
flat
at
$
1.02
billion
.
<END>
<START>
The
year-ago
results
,
however
,
included
the
operations
of
a
bottling
business
,
which
was
sold
last
December
.
<END>
<START>
Excluding
that
bottling
business
,
Coca-Cola
Enterprises
'
volume
,
measured
by
cases
of
soda
,
rose
only
1
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
volume
is
well
below
the
industry
's
4
%
to
5
%
growth
rate
of
recent
years
,
but
in
line
with
other
soft-drink
companies
for
the
third
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
The
latest
third-quarter
volume
also
compares
with
a
very
strong
10
%
growth
in
the
year-ago
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Coca-Cola
Enterprises
blamed
the
lower
volume
on
its
soft-drink
prices
,
which
were
about
3
%
higher
in
the
third
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Consumers
have
been
accustomed
to
buying
soft-drinks
at
discounted
prices
for
several
years
.
<END>
<START>
Coca-Cola
Enterprises
said
it
had
to
boost
spending
for
trade
and
dealer
incentives
to
try
to
keep
volumes
from
slipping
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
it
expects
consumers
will
adjust
to
higher-priced
soft
drinks
.
<END>
<START>
A
spokesman
attributed
the
bulk
of
a
14
%
increase
in
selling
,
administrative
and
general
expenses
--
to
$
324.9
million
--
to
marketing
costs
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
're
out
there
promoting
like
crazy
,
trying
to
get
prices
up
by
promotion
,
''
said
Roy
Burry
,
an
analyst
with
Kidder
,
Peabody
&
Co
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
was
flat
at
about
$
2.97
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Coca-Cola
Enterprises
,
which
is
49%-owned
by
Coca-Cola
Co.
,
also
said
it
repurchased
about
1.2
million
of
its
common
shares
during
the
third
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
The
buy-back
is
part
of
a
25-million-share
repurchase
plan
,
under
which
Coca-Cola
Enterprises
so
far
has
acquired
a
total
of
9.7
million
shares
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
rose
25
%
to

3.90
billion
from

3.13

.
<END>
<START>
The

's

.

,

.

.
<END>
<START>
L.J.
Hooker
Corp.
is
expected
to
reach
an
agreement
in
principle
this
week
to
sell
Merksamer
Jewelers
Inc.
to
management
,
say
executives
familiar
with

.
<END>
<START>
L.J.
Hooker
,
based
in
Atlanta
,
filed
for
Chapter
11
bankruptcy
protection
earlier
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Currently
,
its
parent
company
,
Hooker
Corp.
of
Sydney
,
Australia
,
is
being
managed
by
a
court-appointed
liquidator
.
<END>
<START>
A
spokesman
for
GE
Capital
declined
to
comment
.
<END>
<START>
GE
Capital
has
a
working
relationship
with
L.J.
Hooker
.
<END>
<START>
Sam
Merksamer
,
chief
executive
officer
of
the
nationwide
jewelry
chain
,
and
Sanford
Sigoloff
,
chief
executive
of
L.J.
Hooker
Corp.
,
both
declined
to
comment
.
<END>
<START>
Currently
,
Mr.
Merksamer
owns
20
%
of
the
company
;
L.J.
Hooker
acquired
its
80
%
interest
in
the
firm
in
May
1986
.
<END>
<START>
At
the
time
,
the
Merksamer
chain
had
11
stores
in
operation
.
<END>
<START>
Today
,
there
are
77
units
,
all
located
in
shopping
malls
.
<END>
<START>
This
year
,
a
number
of
retail
leveraged
buyouts
have
failed
,
causing
jitters
among
suppliers
,
and
Mr.
Merksamer
apparently
wanted
assurances
that
he
wo
n't
have
delivery
problems
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
year
ended
June
30
,
1989
,
Merksamer
Jewelers
had
$
62
million
of
revenue
and
operating
profit
of
$
2.5
million
.
<END>
<START>
The
jewelery
chain
was
put
up
for
sale
in
June
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
those
familiar
with
the
situation
,
other

included
Ratners
Group
PLC
of
London
and
Kay
Jewelers
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
First
Boston
Corp.
is
advising
L.J.
Hooker
on
the
sale
of
the
Merksamer
business
.
<END>
<START>
Merksamer
was
the
first
in
a
series
of
retail
acquisitions
made
by
L.J.
Hooker
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
was
founded
in
Sacramento
in
1929
by
two
brothers
,
Ralph
and
Walter
Merksamer
,
who
operated
as
DeVon
's
Jewelers
.
<END>
<START>

1979
,

pair
split
the
company
in
half
,
with
Walter
and
his
son
,
Sam
,
agreeing
to
operate
under
the
Merksamer
Jewelery
name
.
<END>
<START>

of

Jewelers
is
subject
to
approval
by
Judge
Tina
Brozman
of
U.S.

.
<END>
<START>
The
offer
,
which
did
n't
include
the
Merksamer
chain
,
is
being
reviewed
by
Mr.
Sigoloff
.

<START>
Rohm
&

Co.
said

35

32.6
million
,
or
49

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

75

.
<END>
<START>

were
$
623

,

million
a

ago
.
<END>
<START>

&

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

stronger
dollar
,

when

.
<END>
<START>

for

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>
Sales
rose
5.2
%

$
2.04

from

1.94

the

.

<START>

,

closed

33

,

.

<START>
This
is
written
to
correct
a
misquotation
in
your
Oct.
3
article
``
Deaths
From
Advanced
Colon
Cancer
Can
Be
Reduced
by
Using
Two
Drugs
.
''
<END>
<START>
In
this
article
,
I
was
alleged
to
have
said
,
``
Any
patient
with
high-risk
colon
cancer
is
really
getting
short
shrift
if
he
's
not
getting
this
therapy
.
''
<END>
<START>
I
did
n't
say
this
,
and
I
'm
totally
opposed
to
the
philosophy
expressed
by
the
quote
.
<END>
<START>
I
have
not
offered
and
will
not
offer
routine
therapy
with
the
two
drugs
,
levamisole
and
5-fluorouracil
,
to
any
of
my
colon-cancer
patients
.
<END>
<START>
With
this
treatment
we
have
reduced
deaths
in
high-risk
colon
cancer
by
one-third
--
but
this
leaves
the
two-thirds
who
are
dying
of
cancer
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
not
nearly
good
enough
.
<END>
<START>
I
believe
any
physician
who
truly
cares
about
cancer
patients
,
both
today
and
tomorrow
,
should
offer
the
hope
of
something
better
than
that
.
<END>
<START>
These
research
protocols
offer
to
the
patient
not
only
the
very
best
therapy
which
we
have
established
today
but
also
the
hope
of
something
still
better
.
<END>
<START>
I
feel
any
patient
with
high-risk
cancer
is
getting
short
shrift
if
he
is
not
offered
this
opportunity
.
''
<END>
<START>
We
have
very
exciting
prospects
for
far
more
impressive
advances
in
the
treatment
of
colon
cancer
during
the
years
immediately
ahead
.
<END>
<START>
This
hope
,
however
,
will
never
be
realized
if
we
use
levamisole
and
5-fluorouracil
as
a
stopping
point
.
<END>
<START>
Charles
G.
Moertel
M.D
.
Mayo
Clinic
Rochester
,
Minn
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
their
search
notably
wo
n't
include
natural
gas
or
pure
methanol
--
the
two
front-running
alternative
fuels
--
in
tests
to
be
completed
by
next
summer
.
<END>
<START>
Environmentalists
criticized

as

to
head

a

to

.

<START>

have

for

,

Atlantic
Richfield
Co.
is
now

for

.
<END>
<START>

21

85
%

.
<END>
<START>

on

1992

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>
But
after
selling
off
pieces
such
as
its
East

,
its
Philadelphia
hub
and

,

.
<END>
<START>
It
could
n't

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

's

.
<END>
<START>
A

over

and

.
<END>
<START>

<START>

would

.
<END>
<START>
Experts
from
Goldman
Sachs

would
miss
the
same
mark
by
$
120

to

135

,

.
<END>
<START>
The

said
they
expected

would
have
to

to

,
and
that

would

far
less

.
<END>
<START>
Other

would

,

,
because

.
<END>
<START>
At

,

.

.

,

.

.
<END>
<START>

,

.

Eastern

<START>

.
<END>

<START>

<START>
HUGO
'S
RAVAGES
may

for

.
<END>
<START>

;

's

.

.
<END>
<START>

relief

Hugo
's

.
<END>
<START>

:
Fiscal-year

wo

15
.

<START>

16
.
<END>
<START>
Extensions
ca

31

,

.

;

<START>
In

,

,

<START>

.

<START>
From

six

,

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
The

kicked
up
by
the

of
these

is
one
of

most
divisive

to

.
<END>
<START>
Key
to

is
that
the

,
in

,
can
go
virtually
anywhere
,
and

can

.
<END>
<START>
An

can
leap
from
a

to

top

without

.
<END>
<START>
For

,

is

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

that

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>

<START>

<START>

<START>
Even

<START>
``
I
think

.
''
<END>
<START>
Few

County

.
<END>
<START>
They

<END>
<START>

<START>
When

,

.
<END>
<START>

25

.
<END>
<START>
In
California
,
a

,

.
<END>
<START>
The

.

<START>
City

and

.
<END>
<START>
Crested
Butte
,

1,200
,

.
<END>
<START>
By

,

.
<END>
<START>
The

Fame
and
it
hosts
the
annual
Fat
Tire
Bike
Week
.
<END>
<START>
This
summer
,
the
jamboree
attracted
more
visitors
than
the
busiest
week
of
the
town
's
winter
ski
season
.
<END>
<START>
David
Lindsey
,
chairman
of
the
Fat
Tire
Bike
celebration
,
muses
that
the
bike
's
popularity
may
be
a
combination
of
technology
and
nostalgia
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
mountain
bike
feels
as
comfortable
as
the
`
paperboy
'
bike
you
had
as
a
kid
,
but
it
can
do
so
much
more
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
The
following
issues
were
recently
filed
with
the
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
:
<END>
<START>
Canada
's
Province
of
Nova

,
shelf

of
up
to
$
550
million
of

.
<END>

,

.
