.
<END>
<START>
Stock-market
tremors
again
shook
bond
prices
,
while
the
dollar
turned
in
a
mixed
performance
.
<END>
<START>
Early
yesterday
,
investors
scrambled
to
buy
Treasury
bonds
for
safety
as
stock
prices
plummeted
and
fears
mounted
of
a
replay
of
Friday
.
<END>
<START>
But
stocks
later
recovered
,
erasing
most
of
their
early
declines
.
<END>
<START>
That
cut
short
the
rally
in
Treasury
bonds
and
depressed
prices
moderately
below
late
Monday
's
levels
.
<END>
<START>
The
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
,
down
more
than
60.25
points
early
in
the
day
,
finished
18.65
points
lower
at
2638.73
.
<END>
<START>
Long-term
Treasury
issues
declined
about
half
a
point
,
or
$
5
for
each
$
1,000
face
amount
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
stock
market
clearly
is
leading
the
bond
markets
,
''
said
Jack
Conlon
,
an
executive
vice
president
at
Nikko
Securities
.
<END>
<START>
``
People
are
breathing
a
major
sigh
of
relief
that
the
world
did
n't
end
Monday
morning
''
or
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
Gold
,
a
closely
watched
barometer
of
investor
anxiety
,
was
little
changed
.
<END>
<START>
The
dollar
initially
fell
against
other
major
currencies
on
news
that
the
U.S.
trade
deficit
surged
in
August
to
$
10.77
billion
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
dollar
later
rebounded
,
finishing
slightly
higher
against
the
yen
although
slightly
lower
against
the
mark
.
<END>
<START>
Federal
Reserve
officials
sent
another
signal
of
their
determination
to
shore
up
investor
confidence
.
<END>
<START>
In
an
apparent
attempt
to
keep
a
lid
on
short-term
interest
rates
,
the
Fed
once
again
pumped
money
into
the
banking
system
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
Fed
move
was
a
small
gesture
,
traders
said
.
<END>
<START>
Fed
officials
appear
reluctant
to
ease
their
credit
grip
any
further
because
a
bold
move
does
n't
appear
necessary
,
several
investment
managers
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
Fed
has
allowed
a
key
short-term
interest
rate
to
decline
about
one-quarter
percentage
point
.
<END>
<START>
The
federal
funds
rate
on
overnight
loans
between
banks
has
been
hovering
around
8
3/4
%
,
down
from
9
%
previously
.
<END>
<START>
Although
stocks
have
led
bonds
this
week
,
some
traders
predict
that
relationship
will
reverse
during
the
next
few
weeks
.
<END>
<START>
Nikko
's
Mr.
Conlon
fears
a
huge
wave
of
Treasury
borrowing
early
next
month
will
drive
down
Treasury
bond
prices
.
<END>
<START>
That
,
coupled
with
poor
third-quarter
corporate-earnings
comparisons
,
``
will
make
trouble
for
the
equity
market
for
the
next
two
to
three
months
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
But
several
other
traders
contend
investors
have
overreacted
to
junk-bond
jitters
,
and
that
stock
prices
will
continue
to
recover
.
<END>
<START>
In
major
market
activity
:
Treasury
bond
prices
fell
.
<END>
<START>
The
yield
on
30-year
Treasury
bonds
climbed
back
above
8
%
,
ending
the
day
at
8.03
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
dollar
was
mixed
.
<END>
<START>
Late
yesterday
in
New
York
,
the
dollar
rose
to
142.75
yen
from
141.80
yen
Monday
,
but
fell
to
1.8667
marks
from
1.8685
marks
.

<START>
The
Consumer
News
and
Business
Channel
cable
network
and
U.S.
News
&
World
Report
have
formed
a
joint
venture
to
produce
cable
program
versions
of
special
issues
of
the
magazine
.
<END>
<START>
The
programs
will
run
on
the
cable
network
the
Sunday
evening
immediately
prior
to
the
release
of
the
special
issue
of
U.S.
News
&
World
Report
.
<END>
<START>
CNBC
is
a
joint
venture
of
the
National
Broadcasting
Co.
,
a
unit
of
General
Electric
Co.
,
and
Cablevision
System
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
Advertisers
will
be
offered
an
advertising
package
,
which
for
a
single
price
,
will
include
time
on
the
CNBC
program
and
ad
pages
in
the
special
guides
.
<END>
<START>
CNBC
will
produce
six
,
one-hour
programs
,
beginning
in
April
1990
.
<END>
<START>
The
first
program
scheduled
in
the
joint
venture
is
``
The
1990
Homeowner
's
Guide
.
''
<END>
<START>
Other
programs
and
special
issues
will
be
based
on
themes
of
health
,
jobs
,
personal
finance
,
the
best
colleges
,
and
investments
.
<END>
<START>
The
programs
will
be
written
and
produced
by
CNBC
,
with
background
and
research
provided
by
staff
from
U.S.
News
&
World
Report
.

<START>
In
the
1988
third
quarter
,
the
forest-products
company
reported
profit
of
$
144.9
million
,
or
69
cents
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
rose
9
%
to
$
2.57
billion
from
$
2.36
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
rose
9
%
to
$
7.54
billion
from
$
6.95
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Forest-products
operations
strengthened
in
the
third
quarter
,
while
paper
operations
were
dogged
by
higher
costs
,
soft
newsprint
exports
and
a
strong
Japanese
yen
.
<END>
<START>
Some
competing
forest-products
firms
have
recently
reported
improved
results
due
to
strong
pulp
and
paper
business
.
<END>
<START>
Looking
ahead
to
the
fourth
quarter
,
the
company
said
export
log
and
lumber
markets
will
be
weak
,
while
panel
and
plywood
markets
will
be
stronger
.
<END>
<START>
Pulp
and
paper
performance
depends
on
cost
and
price
variables
,
the
company
said
.
<END>
<START>
Bankers
Trust
New
York
Corp.
became
the
latest
major
U.S.
bank
to
increase
reserves
for
its
loans
to
less-developed
countries
,
making
a
$
1.6
billion
third-quarter
addition
to
its
provision
.
<END>
<START>
The
bank
also
said
it
expects
to
report
a
$
1.42
billion
loss
for
the
third
quarter
and
a
loss
for
the
full
year
.
<END>
<START>
``
Step
up
to
the
plate
and
take
the
big
swing
.
<END>
<START>
Get
the
problem
behind
you
and
do
n't
look
back
,
''
said
James
J.
McDermott
,
analyst
at
Keefe
,

&

,
in

of
the
move
.
<END>
<START>
Bankers
Trust
``
has
had
the
capacity
to
do
this
for
some
time
,
''
the
analyst
said
.
<END>
<START>
He
expects
Citicorp
to
take
a
similar
step
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Three
other

posted
earnings
increases
.
<END>
<START>
Wells
Fargo
&
Co.
of

posted

17
%
jump
.
<END>
<START>

,

of

,

climbed
9.8
%
,
while

for

One
Corp.
of

,

,

3.8
%
.
<END>
<START>
Citicorp
<END>
<START>

were
only

by
Citicorp
's
numbers
.
<END>
<START>
Earnings
from
the
bank
's

business
grew
27
%
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
consumer
business
continues
to
drive
the
earnings
stream
,
''
said
Mr.
McDermott
of

,

&

.

<START>
Overall
,
the
portfolio
narrowed
its
quarterly
loss
to
$
70
million
from
$
80
million
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
``
People
were
waiting
to
see
if
we
would
take
an
additional
provision
''
for
medium-term
and

loans
to

.

.
''

,

,

is

in

.
<END>
<START>
Wells
Fargo
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
Wells
Fargo
's
net
interest
income
rose
$
36.3
million
,
or
7
%
,
to
$
537
million
for
the
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Non-interest
income
fell
slightly
to
$
191.9
million
from
$
193.3
million
,
while
Wells
Fargo
continued
to
rigorously
control
non-interest
expense
,
which
was
almost
flat
at
$
393.4
million
.
<END>
<START>

Fargo
's
return
on

increased
to
24.4
%
from
23.8
%
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
amount
was
still
39
%
higher
than
the
year-ago
level
,
and
25
%
higher
as

of

.
<END>
<START>
That

,
and

Fargo
's

,
are
about

's

.
<END>
<START>
Manufacturers
Hanover
<END>
<START>
The
comparable
year-earlier
number
was
$
56
million
,
a

said
.
<END>
<START>
The
bank
's

brought

for

to

to
$
2.4
billion
,

36
%
of

to

.
<END>
<START>
Fees
from

dropped
48
%
,
to
$
21
million
.
<END>
<START>
``
We

n't

''
in

``
because
their

,
''

.

rose
5.4
%
,

.

PNC

<END>
<START>
PNC
Financial
cited

from

and

.
<END>

,

.

15

,

.

,

<START>
Prime
Minister
Rajiv
Gandhi
set
a
date
next
month
for
general
elections
that
some
analysts
say
could
cost
him
and
his
ruling
Congress
-LRB-
I
-RRB-
Party
control
of
the
government
.
<END>
<START>
Other
analysts
say
the
Indian
leader
could
retain
control
with
a
slim
majority
or
be
forced
to
rule
as
the
dominant
partner
in
a
coalition
with
other
parties
.
<END>
<START>
Elections
in
this
large
,
diverse
and
passionate
nation
are
always
hard
to
predict
.
<END>
<START>
Much
depends
on
the
opposition
,
a
loose
group
of
regional
and
ideological
parties
led
by
former
Gandhi
cabinet
minister
Vishwanath
Pratap
Singh
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
,
four
days
after
an
unusual
parliamentary
defeat
for
the
ruling
party
,
Mr.
Gandhi
called
elections
for
the
lower
house
of
Parliament
on
Nov.
22
and
24
.
<END>
<START>
The
elections
will
be
held
in
different
states
on
one
of
the
two
days
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
The
lower
house
's
five-year
term
expires
in
January
;
the
Parliament
's
upper
house
is
appointed
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
After
a
landslide
win
in
1984
in
polls
held
after
the
assassination
of
his
mother
,
Indira
Gandhi
,
Mr.
Gandhi
saw
his
popularity
begin
a
roller
coaster
ride
.
<END>
<START>
His
early
promises
to
make
India
a
modern
nation
remain
bogged
down
in
bloated
bureaucracy
.
<END>
<START>
His
pledge
to
clean
up
local
administration
and
Indian
politics
,
including
his
own
party
,
went
unfulfilled
.
<END>
<START>
His
``
Mr.
Clean
''
image
was
muddied
by
an
arms-kickback
scandal
,
which
will
be
a
major
campaign
issue
.
<END>
<START>
Some
analysts
predict
that
disappointment
in
Mr.
Gandhi
's
spent
pledge
to
reduce
corruption
and
heavy-handed
local
government
will
crest
at
the
polls
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
's
a
wide
feeling
of
indignation
across
the
country
,
''
says
Bhabani
Sen
Gupta
of
the
Center
for
Policy
Research
,
in
New
Delhi
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
think
the
people
will
be
judging
the
regime
by
a
petty
policeman
,
by
a
corrupt
revenue
collector
.
<END>
<START>
This
could
be
a
big
protest
against
an
administrative
failure
.
''
<END>
<START>
Even
if
the
Congress
-LRB-
I
-RRB-
retains
control
of
the
government
,
Mr.
Gandhi
's
ability
to
push
through
major
initiatives
might
be
hobbled
by
a
thinner
majority
.
<END>
<START>
Economic
analysts
call
his
trail-blazing
liberalization
of
the
Indian
economy
incomplete
,
and
many
are
hoping
for
major
new
liberalizations
if
he
is
returned
firmly
to
power
.
<END>
<START>
The
Lok
Sabha
,
or
lower
house
of
Parliament
,
has
542
elected
and
two
appointed
seats
.
<END>
<START>
In
1984
,
the
Congress
-LRB-
I
-RRB-
captured
405
seats
,
the
largest
victory
in
the
history
of
Indian
democracy
.
<END>
<START>
The
landslide
was
fueled
by
panic
that
prevailed
in
India
at
the
time
.
<END>
<START>
Mrs.
Gandhi
had
been
assassinated
by
separatist
Sikhs
,
and
many
Indians
feared
their
country
might
split
apart
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
previous
three
general
elections
,
similar
national
issues
clinched
the
vote
.
<END>
<START>
In
1971
,
the
Congress
Party
won
after
India
's
victory
in
the
Bangladesh
war
.
<END>
<START>
Most
political
analysts
say
that
if
Mr.
Gandhi
's
opposition
unites
to
field
single
candidates
in
most
precincts
,
the
Congress
-LRB-
I
-RRB-
will
lose
big
.
<END>
<START>
But
if
the
opposition
remains
fractured
,
the
Congress
-LRB-
I
-RRB-
could
win
a
small
majority
,
or
lead
a
coalition
government
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
say
the
opposition
will
struggle
this
week
to
unite
,
and
its
success
will
be
clear
only
when
it
announces
its
final
list
of
parliamentary
candidates
.
<END>
<START>
The
arms-kickback
scandal
is
likely
to
be
one
of
the
big
talking
points
in
the
campaign
,
but
it
's
unclear
how
it
is
viewed
by
average
Indian
voters
.
<END>
<START>
In
1986
,
India
signed
a
$
1.4
billion
contract
with
AB
Bofors
,
a
unit
of
Nobel
Industries
Sweden
AB
,
to
purchase
400
artillery
pieces
.
<END>
<START>
The
contract
was
negotiated
by
the
countries
'
two
prime
ministers
,
and
was
supposed
to
be
free
of
commissions
or
agents
'
costs
.
<END>
<START>
In
April
1987
,
evidence
surfaced
that
commissions
were
paid
.
<END>
<START>
The
opposition
charged
that
the
money
was
used
to
bribe
Indian
government
officials
,
an
allegation
denied
by
Mr.
Gandhi
's
administration
.
<END>
<START>
But
many
of
his
statements
on
the
issue
in
Parliament
subsequently
were
proven
wrong
by
documentary
evidence
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
the
first
time
in
20
years
that
such
government
bills
were
defeated
.
<END>
<START>
That
illustrates
the
kind
of
disappointment
many
Indians
feel
toward
Mr.
Gandhi
,
whom
they
zestfully
elected
and
enthusiastically
supported
in
his
first
two
years
in
power
.
<END>
<START>
His
term
has
produced
no
spectacular
failures
in
politics
,
in
the
economy
or
on
the
military
front
,
and
has
chalked
up
some
successes
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
average
Indian
had
tremendous
hope
in
the
youthful
leader
and
his
promise
to
make
both
government
and
the
ruling
party
more
effective
and
less
corrupt
.
<END>
<START>
His
failures
in
those
two
areas
deeply
,
and
sometimes
bitterly
,
disappointed
many
Indians
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
do
n't
like
the
Congress
-LRB-
I
-RRB-
,
''
says
Sooraji
Jath
,
a
farmer
in
the
western
state
of
Gujarat
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
Congress
government
is
taking
the
farmers
'
bread
and
not
giving
us
any
support
.
<END>
<START>
When
there
are
well
problems
,
light
problems
,
road
problems
,
the
government
tells
us
to
forget
it
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
greatest
thing
going
for
Mr.
Gandhi
and
the
Congress
-LRB-
I
-RRB-
Party
is
the
poor
reputation
of
the
opposition
.
<END>
<START>
Even
if
it
unites
for
the
elections
,
its
coherence
is
likely
to
be
temporary
.
<END>
<START>
When
the
Congress
-LRB-
I
-RRB-
lost
the
1977
election
,
following
Mrs.
Gandhi
's
hated
emergency
rule
,
a
similar
coalition
took
power
and
then
disintegrated
.
<END>
<START>
Many
Indians
fear
a
repeat
of
that
experience
.
<END>
<START>
March
24
,
1986
:
<END>
<START>

,

,

with
India
's

to
supply
400
Bofors
FH-77B
155-mm
field

guns
.
<END>
<START>

,

,

,

have

.

16
,

:

Radio

that

40
million
--

3

contract
--

paid
by

as

to

.

<START>

,

:

releases

40

to

.
<END>
<START>
The
report
says
that

were
severely

by
lack

from

.
<END>
<START>
Bofors
says
it
ca
n't
disclose
the
names
of
the
middlemen
because
it
would
jeopardize
industrial

.
<END>
<START>
A
portion
of
the
report
containing
names
of
the
middlemen
is
withheld
by
officials
citing

secrecy

.

:

.

.

.

:

.

.

was

by

.

:

.

.
<END>
<START>
Parsow
Partnership
Ltd.
and
Elkhorn
Partners
L.P.
said
they
may
seek
proposals
from
third
parties
relating
to
a
sale
or
restructuring
of
CACI
International
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
CACI
,
based
in
Arlington
,
Va.
,
said
it
had
n't
seen
the
filing
by
Parsow
and
Elkhorn
and
therefore
had
no
comment
.
<END>
<START>
The
partnerships
said
they
may
seek
board
representation
,
and
they
may
seek
the
support
of
CACI
's
board
and
other
major
shareholders
in
connection
with
their
plans
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
the
filing
,
Parsow
and
Elkhorn
are
based
in
Elkhorn
,
Neb.
,
and
are
controlled
by
the
same
general
partner
,
Alan
S.
Parsow
.
<END>
<START>
Their
combined
stake
consists
of
880,500
CACI
common
shares
,
including
86,500
shares
bought
in
the
past
60
days
at
$
2.3125
to
$
2.4375
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Additional
shares
may
be
bought
or
sold
in
the
open
market
,
in
private
transactions
or
otherwise
,
depending
on
market
conditions
and
other
factors
.
<END>
<START>
The
inverse
trading
relationship
between
bonds
and
stocks
was
interrupted
yesterday
as
bonds
fell
despite
a
modest
decline
in
stock
prices
.
<END>
<START>
But
bond
investors
continue
to
keep
a
close
watch
on
the
jittery
stock
market
.
<END>
<START>
In
early
trading
,
investors
were
bidding
bond
prices
higher
as
stocks
tumbled
and
fears
mounted
that
Friday
's
stock
market
debacle
would
be
repeated
.
<END>
<START>
But
a
partial
recovery
in
the
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
,
which
had
been
down
more
than
60
points
in
midmorning
,
dashed
those
expectations
.
<END>
<START>
Treasury
bonds
also
were
hurt
late
in
the
day
by
a
$
4
billion
offering
by
the
Tennessee
Valley
Authority
and
the
prospect
of
a
huge
amount
of
new
agency
debt
.
<END>
<START>
``
Bond
investors
were
hoping
that
stock
prices
would
continue
to
fall
,
''
said
Roger
Early
,
a
vice
president
at
Federated
Investors
Inc.
,
Pittsburgh
.
<END>
<START>
``
When
stocks
stabilized
,
that
was
a
disappointment
.
''
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
for
the
second
straight
day
,
the
bond
market
paid
little
attention
to
the
Federal
Reserve
's
open
market
operations
.
<END>
<START>
Fed
officials
injected
more
cash
into
the
banking
system
by
arranging
$
1.5
billion
of
repurchase
agreements
during
the
usual
pre-noon
intervention
period
.
<END>
<START>
The
move
was
meant
to
keep
a
lid
on
interest
rates
and
to
boost
investor
confidence
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
intervention
has
been
friendly
,
meaning
that
they
really
did
n't
have
to
do
it
,
''
said
Maria
Fiorini
Ramirez
,
money-market
economist
at
Drexel
Burnham
Lambert
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
She
said
a
more
aggressive
move
was
n't
needed
.
<END>
<START>
The
Fed
also
appears
reluctant
to
ease
credit
conditions
further
.
<END>
<START>
It
already
has
allowed
the
closely
watched
federal
funds
rate
to
decline
1/4
percentage
point
to
about
8
3/4
%
from
its
previous
target
level
of
about
9
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
rate
,
which
banks
charge
each
other
on
overnight
loans
,
is
considered
an
early
signal
of
changes
in
Fed
policy
.
<END>
<START>
It
ended
at
about
8
11/16
%
yesterday
,
but
was
as
low
as
8
1/2
%
Monday
.
<END>
<START>
Investment-grade
corporate
,
municipal
and
mortgage-backed
securities
also
fell
.
<END>
<START>
But
most
junk
bonds
closed
unchanged
after
opening
slightly
higher
on
bargain-hunting
by
institutional
investors
.
<END>
<START>
Some
so-called
high-quality
junk
issues
,
such
as
R.H.
Macy
&
Co.
's
14
1/2
%
subordinated
debentures
,
rose
.
<END>
<START>
The
Macy
's
issue
closed
up
about
one
point
at
a
bid
price
of
97
.
<END>
<START>
The
TVA
's
public
debt
offering
was
its
first
in
15
years
.
<END>
<START>
Strong
investor
demand
prompted
it
to
boost
the
size
of
the
issue
from
$
3
billion
.
<END>
<START>
Traders
said
hedging
related
to
the
TVA
pricing
also
pressured
Treasury
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
Today
the
Treasury
will
announce
the
size
of
its
next
two-year
note
sale
and
Resolution
Funding
Corp.
will

.
<END>
<START>
Refcorp
was
created
to
help
fund
the
thrift
bailout
.
<END>
<START>
Another
agency
issue
came
to
market
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
The
Office
of
Finance
of

$
2.27

8.125

.
<END>
<START>
The
August
gap
was
expected

.
<END>
<START>
Treasury
Securities
<END>
<START>
Treasury
securities
were
essentially
flat
to
about
1/2
point
lower
.
<END>
<START>
The
benchmark
30-year
bond
was
quoted
late
at
100
28/32
to
yield
8.04
%
,
compared
with
101
19/32
to
yield
7.97
%
Monday
.
<END>
<START>
The
latest
10-year
notes
were
quoted
late
at
99
25/32
to
yield
8.01
%
,
compared
with
100
1/32
to
yield
7.97
%
.
<END>
<START>
Short-term
rates
increased
.
<END>
<START>
The
discount
rate
on
three-month
bills
rose
to
7.52
%
for
a
bond-equivalent
yield
of
7.75
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
rate
on
six-month
bills
rose
to
7.53
%
for
a
bond-equivalent
yield
of
7.92
%
.
<END>
<START>
Corporate
,
Other
Issues
<END>
<START>
Investment-grade
corporate
bonds
ended
1/4
to
1/2
point
lower
,
while
most
junk
bonds
ended
unchanged
.
<END>
<START>
The
TVA
's
huge
$
4
billion
offering
dominated
attention
in
the
new-issue
market
.
<END>
<START>
The
TVA
,
which
operates
one
of
the
nation
's
largest
electric
power
systems
,
is
a
corporation
wholly
owned
by
the
U.S.
government
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
's
bond
sale
was
part
of
a
$
6.7
billion
refinancing
plan
to
pay
off
high-interest
debt
the
TVA
owes
the
Federal
Financing
Bank
,
an
arm
of
the
Treasury
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
Lockheed
Corp.
priced
a
$
300
million
note
offering
to
yield
9.39
%
.
<END>
<START>
Mortgage-Backed
Securities
<END>
<START>
The
derivative
mortgage-backed
market
revived
after
a
brief
hiatus
as
two
new
Remics
totaling
$
850
million
were
offered
and
talk
circulated
about
two
more
issues
that
could
be
priced
today
.
<END>
<START>
The
revival
of
the
real
estate
mortgage
investment
conduit
market
reflected
the
relative
calm
in
the
mortgage
market
after
two
days
of
volatile
trading
.
<END>
<START>
Dealers
noted
that
it
's
difficult
to
structure
new
Remics
when
prices
are
moving
widely
.
<END>
<START>
The
Remic
issuance
supported
prices
of
Freddie
Mac
and
Fannie
Mae
securities
,
which
held
up
better
than
Government
National
Mortgage
Association
securities
during
an
afternoon
sell-off
.
<END>
<START>
Freddie
Mac
9
%
securities
were
at
97
5/32
,
down
3/32
.
<END>
<START>
The
Ginnie
Mae
9
%
issue
was
yielding
9.43
%
to
a
12-year
average
life
assumption
,
as
the
spread
above
the
Treasury
10-year
note
held
at
1.42
percentage
points
.
<END>
<START>
Municipals
<END>
<START>
Confusion
over
the
near-term
trend
for
rates
dominated
the
municipal
arena
,
as
gyrations
in
the
stock
market
continued
to
buffet
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
Long
tax-exempt
dollar
bonds
were
mostly
flat
to
3/8
point
lower
after
a
whipsaw
session
of
moving
inversely
to
stocks
in
modest
dealer-led
trading
.
<END>
<START>
The
lists
total
$
654.5
million
.
<END>
<START>
Pre-refunded
bonds
are
called
at
their
earliest
call
date
with
the
escrowed
proceeds
of
another
bond
issue
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
several
new
issues
were
priced
.
<END>
<START>
Underwriters
led
by
PaineWebber
Inc.
set
preliminary
pricing
for
$
144.4
million
of
California
Health
Facilities
Financing
Authority
revenue
bonds
for
Kaiser
Permanente
.
<END>
<START>

were

from
6.25
%
in
1993
to
7.227
%
in
2018
.

<START>

100

.
<END>
<START>
The
6
3/4
%

6.25
%
.
<END>
<START>
Foreign

<END>
<START>

7

,

0.10

,

7.01

.

7.31

.
<END>
<START>
British

on

.

10/32

.

.

,

.
<END>
<START>
The
current
ceiling
on

insured
by
the
Federal
Housing
Administration
would
be
increased
to
$
124,875
.
<END>
<START>
Separately
,

to

for

.

<START>

,

,
has
met

from

.
<END>
<START>
And

.
<END>

,

.

,
''

.

.

.

.

<START>
Markets
usually
get
noticed
because
they
soar
or
plunge
.
<END>
<START>
The
settlement
prices
of
the
December
,
February
and
April
gold
contracts
were
even
with
Monday
's
final
prices
.
<END>
<START>
The
December
1989
contract
,
which
has
the
greatest
trading
volume
,
ended
at
$
371.20
an
ounce
.
<END>
<START>
The
other
months
posted
advances
of
10
cents
to
20
cents
an
ounce
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
,
gold
traded
within
a
narrow
range
.
<END>
<START>
``
December
delivery
gold
is
trading
in
a
range
of
$
365
to
$
375
-LCB-
an
ounce
-RCB-
and
is
having
difficulty
breaking
out
above
that
,
''
Mr.
Savaiko
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
Producers
at
the
moment
regard
that
area
a
good
one
in
which
to
sell
gold
.
''
<END>
<START>
Jeffrey
Nichols
,
president
of
APMS
Canada
,
Toronto
precious
metals
advisers
,
said
there
is
little
to
motivate
gold
traders
to
buy
the
metal
.
<END>
<START>
There
is
n't
any
rush
on
the
part
of
investors
in
the
West
to
buy
gold
,
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
an
experience
they
do
n't
want
to
repeat
.
''
<END>
<START>
There
is
little
incentive
to
buy
gold
because
if
the
stock
market
goes
higher
,
it
may
be
just
a
false
alarm
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
keeping
the
gold
traders
handcuffed
.
''
<END>
<START>
Previously
,
he
noted
,
gold
producers
tended
to
back
off
from
a
rising
gold
market
,
letting
prices
rise
as
much
as
possible
before
selling
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
dollar
has
n't
reacted
much
to
it
,
so
gold
has
n't
either
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
In

yesterday
:
<END>
<START>
ENERGY
:
<END>
<START>
Crude
oil
prices
rose
slightly
in
lackluster
activity
as
traders
in
the
pits
tried
to
assess
action
in
the
stock
market
.
<END>
<START>
Since
stock
market
indexes
plummeted
last
Friday
,
participants
in
all
markets
have
been
wary
.
<END>
<START>
When
traders
become
confident
that
the
stock
market
has
stabilized
,
oil
prices
are
expected
to
rise
as
supply
and
demand
fundamentals
once
again
become
the
major
consideration
.
<END>
<START>
Crude
oil
for
November
delivery
edged
up
by
16
cents
a
barrel
to
$
20.75
a
barrel
.
<END>
<START>
Heating
oil
prices
also
rose
.
<END>
<START>
November
gasoline
slipped
slightly
.
<END>
<START>
SUGAR
:
<END>
<START>
Futures
prices
rose
on
a
report
that
Cuba
may
seek
to
postpone
some
sugar
shipments
.
<END>
<START>
The
March
contract
advanced
0.14
cent
a
pound
to
14.11
cents
.
<END>
<START>
``
Japan
is
perceived
as
a
wealthy
nation
that
can
turn
elsewhere
in
the
world
market
and
buy
the
sugar
,
''
the
analyst
said
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
the
possibility
of
this
demand
that
helped
firm
prices
,
the
analyst
said
.
<END>
<START>
Another
analyst
noted
that
Cuba
has
been
deferring
shipments
in
recent
years
.
<END>
<START>
``
To
the
professionals
in
the
trade
it
did
n't
cause
much
surprise
.
<END>
<START>
The
March
futures
contract
traded
as
high
as
14.24
cents
,
but
could
n't
sustain
the
advance
,
''
he
said
.

.

.

<START>

's

,

,

.

<START>
The
nations
of
southern
Africa
know
a
lot
about

;
their

are

.
<END>
<START>
But

Europe
and

have

know

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
A

delegate
argued

``
guarantee

.
''

Legitimate

,

,

.

<START>

.

.

<START>
HUGO'S
BLAST
generates
pleas
for
aid
from
South
Carolina
small
businesses
.
<END>
<START>
The
Small
Business
Administration
has
received
more
than
5,000
formal

for
disaster
loans
because
of
the
hurricane
.
<END>
<START>
About
45
%
of

for
SBA

,

also
are

to
homeowners
,
come
from

,

25

after

.
<END>
<START>

expects
to

1
billion
in
Hurricane
Hugo

.
<END>
<START>

is

.

<START>

.

.

<START>

,

.

,

<START>
PRISON-SHOP
BLUES
:
<END>
<START>
Sen.
Strom
Thurmond
-LRB-
R.
,
S.C
.
-RRB-
protests
pending
legislation
to
end
the
preference
that
the
federal
prison
system
gets
in
selling
prisoner-made
furniture
and
other
goods
to
government
agencies
.
<END>
<START>
Small-business
suppliers
want
prisons
to
stop
getting
high
priority
,
especially
as
prison
production
grows
with
swelling
inmate
populations
.
<END>
<START>
Last
year
,
the
prisons
'
sales
to
the
Pentagon
totaled
$
336
million
.
<END>
<START>
REPAIR
SHOPS
SCRAP
for
more
access
to
work
on
auto-emissions
systems
.
<END>
<START>
Groups
representing
some
independent
auto-repair
shops
join
a
compromise
on
the
Clean
Air
legislation
worked
out
between
environmentalists
and
Rep.
Henry
Waxman
-LRB-
D.
,
Calif
.
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
The
plan
would
increase
the
warranty
on
auto-emission
systems
to
eight
years
or
80,000
miles
from
five
years
or
50,000
for
major
parts
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
warranty
on
simpler
parts
would
be
lowered
to
two
years
or
24,000
miles
.
<END>
<START>
The
garage
owners
say
they
would
benefit
because
car
owners
would
be
less
likely
to
go
back
to
dealers
for
the
simpler
repairs
after
two
years
.
<END>
<START>
The
repair
shops
are
n't
united
,
however
.
<END>
<START>
Shops
represented
by
the
Automotive
Service
Industry
Association
and
the
Motor
Equipment
Manufacturers
Association
oppose
any
increase
in
warranty
length
.
<END>
<START>
They
say
the
longer
the
warranty
,
the
longer
customers
will
automatically
return
to
new-car
dealers
,
which
then
find
non-warranty
work
that
might
otherwise
go
to
repair
shops
.
<END>
<START>
The
House
Energy
Committee
will
debate
the
issue
later
this
month
.
<END>
<START>
Stan
Hathcock
,
an
Atlanta
garage
owner
who
opposes
a
longer
warranty
,
estimates
that
the
current
plan
costs
him
as
much
as
$
15,000
a
year
in
lost
business
.

TALK
:

<START>

's

.
<END>
<START>

''

,

,

.

,

,

,

``

.
''

.

<START>
The

plans

of

.

.

.
<END>
<START>
Moody
's
Investors
Service
Inc.
said
it
lowered
ratings
on
about
$
650
million
of
Beatrice
Co.
debt
,
citing
the
closely
held
Chicago
food
concern
's
proposed

.
<END>
<START>

said
it
downgraded
Beatrice
notes
,
Euronotes
and
certain
industrial

to
single-B-1
from
Ba-3
and
the
company
's
subordinated
debentures
to
single-B-3
from
single-B-2
.
<END>
<START>
A
Beatrice
spokesman
did
n't
return
calls
seeking
comment
.
<END>
<START>
When
the
Soviets
announced
their
last
soldier
had
left
Afghanistan
in
February
,
the
voices
of
skepticism
were
all
but
drowned
out
by
an
international
chorus
of
euphoria
.
<END>
<START>
It
was
``
the
Soviets
'
Vietnam
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
Kabul
regime
would
fall
.
<END>
<START>
Millions
of
refugees
would
rush
home
.
<END>
<START>
A
resistance
government
would
walk
into
Kabul
.
<END>
<START>
Those
who
bought
that
illusion
are
now
bewildered
.
<END>
<START>
But
there
never
was
a
chance
that
the
Afghan
resistance
would
overthrow
the
Kabul
regime
quickly
and
easily
.
<END>
<START>
Soviet
leaders
said
they
would
support
their
Kabul
clients
by
all
means
necessary
--
and
did
.
<END>
<START>
The
U.S.
said
it
would
fully
support
the
resistance
--
and
did
n't
.
<END>
<START>
With
the
February
1987
U.N.
accords
``
relating
to
Afghanistan
,
''
the
Soviet
Union
got
everything
it
needed
to
consolidate
permanent
control
.
<END>
<START>
But
as
soon
as
the
accords
were
signed
,
American
officials
sharply
reduced
aid
.
<END>
<START>
In
February
1989
,
when
the
Soviets
said
they
had
completed
their
pullout
,
the
U.S.
cut
it
further
.
<END>
<START>
Not
so
the
Soviets
.
<END>
<START>
Gen.
Gromov
himself
said
Soviet
troops
expected
to
leave
behind
more
than
$
1
billion
of
military
equipment
and
installations
for
the
Kabul
regime
.
<END>
<START>
This
includes
what
Deputy
Foreign
Minister
Yuli
Vorontsov
fetchingly
called
``
new
peaceful
long-range
weapons
,
''
including
more
than
800
SCUD
missiles
.
<END>
<START>
By
early
May
,
Moscow
had
delivered
,
for
example
,
1,000
trucks
,
about
100
tanks
,
artillery
and
hundreds
of
other
combat
vehicles
.
<END>
<START>
Later
that
month
,
it
added
an
entire
tank
brigade
,
including
120
T-72
tanks
and
more
than
40
BMP
state-of-the-art
infantry
fighting
vehicles
.
<END>
<START>
By
September
,
a
new
Reinforced
Motorized
Rifle
Brigade
with
an
additional
300
combat
vehicles
,
1,000
more
trucks
and
10,000
Soviet-trained
Afghan
troops
had
arrived
in
Kandahar
.
<END>
<START>
Moscow
claims
this
is
all
needed
to
protect
the
Kabul
regime
against
the
guerrilla
resistance
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
well-known
that
the
regular
Afghan
infantry
is
filled
with
reluctant
conscripts
.
<END>
<START>
But
this
is
not
the
entire
Afghan
army
,
and
it
is
no
longer
Kabul
's
only
military
force
.
<END>
<START>
Complete
units
have
been
trained
and
indoctrinated
in
the
U.S.S.R.
and
other
East
bloc
nations
;
30,000
to
40,000
of
these
troops
have
returned
.
<END>
<START>
Even
if
not
all
these
forces
are
committed
to
the
regime
,
they
are
now
dependent
on
it
.
<END>
<START>
And
thousands
of
Afghan
children
have
been
taken
to
the
Soviet
Union
,
where
they
are
hostage
for
the
behavior
of
their
families
.
<END>
<START>
Since
1981
,
Indian
military
advisers
have
been
assisting
the
Kabul
regime
.
<END>
<START>
In
preparation
for
the
withdrawal
,
Moscow
,
Kabul
and
New
Delhi
signed
two
agreements
for
several
hundred
newly
civilian
Indian
experts
to
replace
some
of
the
more
visible
Soviet
military
personnel
.
<END>
<START>
Cuban
military
personnel
also
have
been
active
in
Afghanistan
since
1979
.
<END>
<START>
The
Soviets
cut
a
deal
with
Iran
:
a
future
Iranian
role
in
Afghanistan
in
exchange
for
Iranian
support
of
Soviet
policy
.
<END>
<START>
The
deal
was
symbolized
by
the
restoration
of
the
Shi'ite
Sultan
Ali
Keshtmand
to
the
Afghan
prime
ministry
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
serious
questions
have
been
raised
about
the
claimed
withdrawal
of
Soviet
forces
.
<END>
<START>
Before
his
assassination
in
1988
,
President
Zia
of
Pakistan
repeatedly
stated
that
fresh
Soviet
troops
were
being
inserted
into
Afghanistan
even
as
others
were
ostentatiously
withdrawn
.
<END>
<START>
Rep.
Bill
McCollum
-LRB-
R.
,
Fla.
-RRB-
reports
that
these
included
20,000
to
30,000
Soviet
Central
Asian
KGB
Border
Guards
,
ethnically
indistinguishable
from
Afghans
and
wearing
unmarked
uniforms
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
the
Kabul
regime
is
increasingly
successful
at
portraying
the
resistance
as
bloody-minded
fanatics
.
<END>
<START>
This
heavy
outside
support
for
the
worst
has
undermined
better
,
moderate
leaders
.
<END>
<START>
In
autumn
last
year
,
for
example
,
the
regime
garrison
at
Kandahar
was
prepared
to
surrender
the
city
to
resistance
moderates
.
<END>
<START>
The
deal
fell
through
,
and
Kandahar
remains
a
major
regime
base
.
<END>
<START>
The
resistance
lacks
not
only
air
power
,
armor
and
expertise
but
often
such
essentials
as
maps
,
mine
detectors
,
or
even
winter
gloves
.
<END>
<START>
Experienced
resistance
commanders
wanted
to
use
guerrilla
action
and
siege
tactics
to
wear
down
the
regime
.
<END>
<START>
Instead
,
they
were
pressured
by
Pakistan
's
ISI
,
the
channel
for
their
support
,
into
attacking
Jalalabad
.
<END>
<START>
They
took
more
than
25
%
casualties
;
journalists
report
that
they
faced
minefields
without
mine
detectors
.
<END>
<START>
The
wonder
is
not
that
the
resistance
has
failed
to
topple
the
Kabul
regime
,
but
that
it
continues
to
exist
and
fight
at
all
.
<END>
<START>
For
months
the
resistance
has
been
defenseless
against
air
attack
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
far
there
is
no
indication
that
they
have
been
re-supplied
with
Stingers
or
other
anti-aircraft
weapons
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
U.S.
officials
have
indicated
to
the
press
that
the
continuation
of
aid
depends
on
what
success
the
weakened
resistance
achieves
by
the
end
of
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Moscow
and
Kabul
must
have
found
that
information
useful
.
<END>
<START>
For
a
decade
U.S.
policy
has
been
incoherent
,
based
on
miscalculation
and
the
defense
of
bureaucratic
and
political
turf
.
<END>
<START>
No
settlement
negotiated
by
others
can
force
the
Afghan
people
to
give
up
their
struggle
.
<END>
<START>
A
cutoff
of
U.S.
military
aid
would
merely
abandon
them
to
die
in
vain
.
<END>
<START>
Creation
of
a
new
,
realistic
U.S.
policy
is
long
overdue
.
<END>
<START>
Ms.
Klass
,
editor
and
co-author
of
``
Afghanistan
:
The
Great
Game
Revisited
''
-LRB-
Freedom
House
-RRB-
,
directs
the
Freedom
House
program
on
Afghanistan/Southwest
Asia
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
under
Mr.
Reagan
's
preferred
successor
,
President
Bush
,
those
two
cherished
national-security
causes
are
withering
on
the
vine
.
<END>
<START>
And
,
surprisingly
,
little
more
than
a
whimper
of
protest
is
being
heard
,
even
though
Reaganauts
once
breathed
fire
supporting
the
Contras
and
the
Strategic
Defense
Initiative
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
programs
have
arthritis
,
''
says
Rep.
Henry
Hyde
,
a
conservative
Republican
from
Illinois
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
,
he
asserts
,
``
you
look
around
...
and
you
say
,
`
Who
are
the
leaders
?
<END>
<START>
Who
is
going
to
carry
the
water
?
'
''
<END>
<START>
It
is
n't
surprising
that
President
Bush
has
n't
led
a
crusade
to
pump
up
the
Contras
or
SDI
.
<END>
<START>
Though
he
nominally
supports
both
programs
,
Mr.
Bush
has
n't
been
a
passionate
champion
of
either
cause
,
as
Mr.
Reagan
was
.
<END>
<START>
What
's
surprising
is
that
there
is
n't
more
of
a
conservative
outcry
as
the
Bush
administration
lets
the
programs
slip
down
the
national-priority
list
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
it
's
like
kicking
your
father
in
the
pants
.
<END>
<START>
You
hate
to
do
it
because
he
's
your
father
.
''
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Burton
says
conservatives
'
unhappiness
with
Mr.
Bush
's
cautious
handling
of
the
recent
unsuccessful
coup
in
Panama
will
make
them
more
willing
to
speak
out
.
<END>
<START>
Of
course
,
neither
President
Bush
nor
the
Congress
has
actually
abandoned
the
Contras
or
SDI
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Bush
has
struck
a
deal
with
congressional
leaders
to
provide
nonlethal
aid
to
the
Contras
until
Nicaragua
holds
national
elections
next
February
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
administration
has
dropped
any
effort
to
win
military
aid
for
the
rebels
.
<END>
<START>
The
administration
continues
to
support
SDI
,
or
Star
Wars
,
and
it
recently
lobbied
to
persuade
the
Senate
to
restore
some
of
the
funds
it
planned
to
cut
from
the
program
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
strong
pitch
by
Mr.
Cheney
may
be
too
little
too
late
to
prevent
damage
to
SDI
.
<END>
<START>
And
while
the
defense
secretary
is
speaking
out
,
President
Bush
himself
has
n't
launched
any
high-visibility
campaign
to
drum
up
support
,
as
President
Reagan
did
.
<END>
<START>
The
administration
also
acknowledges
that
it
is
n't
pursuing
Mr.
Reagan
's
original
vision
of
an
``
impenetrable
shield
''
protecting
the
whole
U.S.
,
but
rather
a
more
modest
version
.
<END>
<START>
More
ominous
to
SDI
supporters
,
the
Bush
administration
appears
to
have
tacitly
accepted
a
new
arms-control
proposal
from
the
Soviet
Union
that
spells
long-term
trouble
for
Star
Wars
.
<END>
<START>
The
Soviets
have
agreed
to
complete
a
treaty
cutting
strategic
weapons
without
including
restrictions
on
space-based
defenses
.
<END>
<START>
It
will
be
hard
down
the
road
to
persuade
Congress
to
approve
money
for
SDI
plans
if
lawmakers
fear
those
plans
could
scuttle
a
completed
treaty
.
<END>
<START>
Some
activists
are
toiling
to
raise
the
profile
of
the
two
causes
.
<END>
<START>
But
they
say
they
ca
n't
make
much
headway
because
of
a
lack
of
willing
leaders
in
a
position
to
turn
the
tide
.
<END>
<START>
One
longtime
champion
of
these
programs
in
Congress
,
Republican
whip
Newt
Gingrich
of
Georgia
,
is
distracted
by
questions
about
his
ethics
,
conservatives
note
.
<END>
<START>
Other
conservative
champions
,
like
Wyoming
Republican
Sen.
Malcolm
Wallop
,
a
longtime
SDI
advocate
,
do
n't
have
the
clout
with
the
Bush
White

that
they
enjoyed
with
President
Reagan
.
<END>
<START>
Above
all
,
though
,
proponents
say
neither
the
Contra
nor
the
SDI
cause
can
be
pushed
much
further
without
more
presidential
support
.
<END>
<START>
``
For
there
to
be
wind
in
the
sails
of
any
program
,
the
chief
executive
has
to
be
blowing
in
the
sails
,
''
says
Rep.
Burton
.
<END>
<START>
All
this
causes
Rep.
Hyde
to
muse
about
an
alternate
way
to
drum
up
more
enthusiasm
.
<END>
<START>
We
're
sorry
to
report
that
on
Monday
President
Bush
accepted
the
resignation
of
William
Allen
as
chairman
of
the
U.S.
Civil
Rights
Commission
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Allen
,
appointed
by
President
Reagan
,
grew
understandably
tired
of
dealing
with
the
guerrilla
tactics
of
his
enemies
.
<END>
<START>
His
recent
speech
,
provocatively
titled
``
Blacks
?
Animals
?
Homosexuals
?
What
is
a
Minority
?
''
caused
an
uproar
when
its
title
leaked
out
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Allen
's
commissioners
voted
to
call
his
unread
speech
``
thoughtless
,
disgusting
and
unnecessarily
inflammatory
.
''
<END>
<START>
Commissioner
Mary
Francis
Berry
said
it
was
``
another
sad
episode
in
the
saga
of
the
unguided
missile
who
is
chairman
.
''
<END>
<START>
Rep.
Don
Edwards
,
the
California
Democrat
,
warned
Mr.
Allen
that
the
speech
would
be
``
outside
the
scope
of
the

's

.
''
<END>
<START>
Thomas
Stoddard
,
head
of
the
Lambda
Legal
Defense
Fund
,
called
the
prospect
of
the
speech
``
frankly
shocking
.
''
<END>
<START>
We
've
actually
read
the
speech
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Allen
began
it
with
a
warning
to
his
hosts
,
a
California
church
group
that
opposes
rights
for

.
<END>
<START>
''
Mr.
Allen

``

project
of
charity
,
of
humaneness
.
''
<END>
<START>
Rights
on
such
a
basis
,
whether
for
blacks
or

,
are
``
mere
indulgences
,
''

,

.
<END>
<START>

.

.

,

,

that

of

,

the

$

.

<START>

,

,

's

.

''

n't

.
''

,

,

,

,

,

,

.

<START>
In
New
York
Stock
Exchange
composite
trading
,

closed
at
$
47
,
up
$
1.125
.
<END>
<START>
Why
is
the
stock
market
suddenly
so
volatile
?
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
,
the
Dow
Jones
Industrial
Average
did
a
now
familiar
dance
:
It
plunged
60.25
points
before
lunch
,
with
most
of
the
drop
occurring
in
25
minutes
.
<END>
<START>
Then
,
it
rebounded
to
finish
down
only
18.65
points
.
<END>
<START>
And
those
swings
paled
beside
Friday
's
190.58-point
plunge
and
Monday
's
88.12-point
recovery
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
madness
--
that
in
an
hour
you
can
whack
off
so
much
value
,
''
says
Stanford
Calderwood
,
chairman
of
Trinity
Investment
Management
Corp.
,
Boston
.
<END>
<START>
And
,
apparently
,
it
is
here
to
stay
.
<END>
<START>
Richard
Bernstein
,
senior
quantitative
analyst
at
Merrill
Lynch
&
Co
,
says
,
``
My
gut
feel
is
that
we
'll
live
with
those
swings
for
a
while
.
''
<END>
<START>
There
are
many
reasons
for
the
market
's
jumpiness
:
new
trading
vehicles
such
as
stock-index
futures
and
options
;
computer-driven
strategies
like
program
trading
;
and
crowd
psychology
.
<END>
<START>
But
most
are
linked
by
a
single
theme
:
liquidity
--
the
ability
to
get
in
and
out
of
the
market
quickly
.
<END>
<START>
Prices
are
moving
up
and
down
so
fast
because
investors
are
employing
ways
to
turn
over
shares
at
ever-faster
rates
and
increasingly
acting
in
concert
.
<END>
<START>
``
Institutions
are
herding
animals
,
''
says
Peter
Anderson
,
who
heads
the
pension-fund
management
arm
of
IDS
Financial
Services
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
watch
the
same
indicators
and
listen
to
the
same
prognosticators
.
<END>
<START>
Like
lemmings
,
we
tend
to
move
in
the
same
direction
at
same
time
.
''
<END>
<START>
And
that
,
naturally
,
exacerbates
price
movements
.
<END>
<START>
Institutions
--
who
now
account
for
most
trading
--
count
on
being
able
to
buy
and
sell
big
blocks
of
stock
at
an
eye-blink
.
<END>
<START>
But
when
they
discover
that
markets
are
n't
always
as
liquid
as
they
supposed
--
markets
jump
.
<END>
<START>
And
when
many
firms
had
to
``
pay
up
,
''
Monday
's
sudden
rally
was
sparked
.
<END>
<START>
Trading
in
futures
and
options
,
some
people
believe
,
can
add
to
volatility
.
<END>
<START>
These
and
other
modern
trading
methods
``
tend
to
promote
dramatic
shifts
in
assets
,
''
says
George
Douglas
,
first
vice
president
at
Drexel
Burnham
Lambert
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
the
idea
that
what
goes
in
easy
can
come
out
easy
''
--
so
that
bouts
of
higher
volatility
get
built
into
the
stock
market
.
<END>
<START>
One
new
investment
style
called
``
asset
allocation
''
shifts
portfolio
weightings
between
stocks
,
bonds
and
cash
when
computer
models
say
one
is
more
attractive
.
<END>
<START>
It
added
another
5
%
Monday
before
stocks
rallied
.
<END>
<START>
When
they
did
,
the
firm
reduced
those
stock
holdings
to
about
70
%
.
<END>
<START>
A
classic
example
of
institutions
'
hunger
for
liquidity
is
portfolio
insurance
,
now
widely
discredited
.
<END>
<START>
Before
the
1987
crash
,
an
estimated
$
60
billion
in
institutional
money
was
managed
under
this
hedging
technique
.
<END>
<START>
The
idea
was
to
``
insure
''
the
value
of
a
portfolio
by
selling
futures
when
stock
prices
dropped
--
eliminating
the
need
to
sell
the
stocks
themselves
.
<END>
<START>
But
in
October
1987
,
when
portfolio
insurers
rushed
to
sell
at
the
same
time
,
they
overwhelmed
both
the
stock
and
futures
markets
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
even
today
,
institutions
are
quietly
practicing
forms
of
portfolio
insurance
by
nervously
rushing
to
and
fro
in
the
markets
.
<END>
<START>
Others
are
doing
``
index
arbitrage
''
a
strategy
of
taking
advantage
of
price
discrepancies
between
stocks
and
futures
.
<END>
<START>
Unlike
traditional
buy-and-hold
strategies
,
all
of
the
above
require
that
market
makers
be
on
hand
to
provide
liquidity
by
buying
and
selling
stocks
in
a
crunch
.
<END>
<START>
But
institutions
say
Wall
Street
brokerage
firms
are
less
willing
to
make
markets
.
<END>
<START>
Brokers
do
n't
deny
that
.
<END>
<START>
Wall
Street
traders
say
that
,
with
institutional
brokerage
commissions
far
lower
than
in
the
1970s
,
securities
firms
ca
n't
afford
to
take
the
risk
of
buying
too
much
stock
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
think
everyone
's
a
little
more
leery
,
''
says
Jack
Baker
,
head
of
equity
trading
at
Shearon
Lehman
Hutton
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
``
Why
should
I
risk
money
for
a
guy
for
who
's
paying
me
five
cents
a
dance
?
<END>
<START>
All
you
get
is
risk
.
''
<END>
<START>
Lack
of
liquidity
can
also
result
from
exchange
``
reforms
.
''
<END>
<START>
Many

``

''

after

actually

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>

''

''

<START>
The

.
<END>
<START>
UAL

.
<END>
<START>

.

;

.
<END>
<START>
Presumably
,

.
<END>
<START>
By

,

.
<END>
<START>
Some

.

<START>
``

ca

,
''

.
<END>
<START>

less

.

<START>

.

.

.
<END>
<START>
James
A.
White

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Redmond
said
the

had

but

``

.
''
<END>
<START>
He

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

hardware

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>
In
the
lingo
of
computer
security
,
the
NASA
intruder
is
technically
a
computer
worm
,
Mr.
Redmond
said
.
<END>
<START>
A
worm
resides
in
the
operating
system
of
a
computer
and
spreads
by
boring
into
other
computers
contacted
through
networks
.
<END>
<START>
The
Galileo
worm
apparently
was
hatched
on
a
computer
in
France
hooked
up
to
NASA
's
Space
Physics
Analysis
Network
,
Mr.
Redmond
said
.
<END>
<START>
NASA
said
the
Galileo
worm
had
n't
affected
its
computers
or
the
computers
of
other
government
agencies
because
they
had
modified
their
systems
to
reject

.
<END>
<START>
But
Mr.
Redmond
said
the
worm
hit
universities
that
had
n't
elected
to
make
the
changes
.
<END>
<START>
If
it
finds
one
and
gets
into
the
system
,
it
will
display
a
screen
when
a
user
logs
on
that

,
``
Worms
Against
Nuclear
Killers
...
.
<END>
<START>
You
talk

times

,
and

prepare
for

.
''
<END>
<START>
The

that
confer

on

user
.
<END>
<START>
The

but
are
supposed

be

.
<END>
<START>
NASA

that
,

,

.
<END>
<START>

,

;

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>
Anti-nuclear

.

<START>
Mr.

.

,

.
<END>
<START>
It
is
now
a
commonplace
that
prosecutors
are
bringing
criminal
indictments
in
cases
where
until
a
few
years
ago
only
a
civil
action
at
most
would
have
been
brought
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
it
is
also
axiomatic
that
the
power
to
create
new
crimes
belongs
only
to
the
legislature
,
and
not
to
courts
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
the
conventional
theory
anyway
.
<END>
<START>
In
practice
,
however
,
the
line
between
interpretation
and
redefinition
of
the
criminal
law
long
ago
began
to
blur
.
<END>
<START>
In
particular
,
a
common
law
of
white-collar
crime
has
developed
with
surprising
rapidity
over
the
past
decade
.
<END>
<START>
For
example
,
although
insider
trading
has
long
been
criminal
,
it
has
never
been
statutorily
defined
.
<END>
<START>
Gradually
,
however
,
lower
courts
and
prosecutors
have
pushed
this
definition
to
its
breaking
point
.
<END>
<START>
Consider
the
facts
underlying
the
1989
conviction
of
Robert
Chestman
.
<END>
<START>
She
called
her
daughter
to
take
her
to
the
bank
,
who
,
in
turn
,
persuaded
her
husband
,
a
Mr.
Loeb
,
to
run
this
errand
.
<END>
<START>
Hearing
of
this
information
,
the
husband
discussed
it
with
his
broker
,
Mr.
Chestman
,
and
Mr.
Chestman
then
bought
for
his
own
account
and
other
clients
.
<END>
<START>
Basically
,
Mr.
Chestman
was
a
fourth-level
tippee
.
<END>
<START>
Did
Mr.
Loeb
,
his
tipper
,
breach
a
fiduciary
duty
-LRB-
and
,
if
so
,
to
whom
-RRB-
?
<END>
<START>
Did
Mr.
Loeb
seek
personal
gain
-LRB-
and
if
so
,
how
-RRB-
?
<END>
<START>
Or
did
Mr.
Chestman
only
hear
a
market
rumor
-LRB-
which
one
may
lawfully
trade
upon
-RRB-
?
<END>
<START>
The
line
seems
awfully
thin
for
criminal-law
purposes
.
<END>
<START>
A
second
illustration
is
supplied
by
the
recent
guilty
plea
entered
by
Robert
Freeman
,
formerly
head
of
arbitrage
at
Goldman
,
Sachs
&
Co
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Siegel
asked
Mr.
Freeman
who
his
source
was
and
,
on
hearing
that
it
was
Bunny
Lasker
,
responded
:
``
Well
,
your
bunny
has
a
good
nose
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
illegal
``
tip
''
of
the
bunny
's
good
nose
was
then
largely
a
confirmation
of
rumors
already
known
to
many
in
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
Had
the
case
gone
to
trial
the
same
issues
would
have
surfaced
:
<END>
<START>
Was
there
a
fiduciary
breach
in
order
to
obtain
personal
gain
?
<END>
<START>
Did
Mr.
Freeman
have
notice
of
this
?
<END>
<START>
Finally
,
was
the
information
material
?
<END>
<START>
Yet
,
all
these
issues
are
subsidiary
to
a
more
central
issue
:
Who
is
and
who
should
be
making
the
criminal
law
here
?
<END>
<START>
It
is
not
my
contention
that
either
Mr.
Chestman
or
Mr.
Freeman
was
an
innocent
victim
of
prosecutorial
overzealousness
.
<END>
<START>
Arguably
,
both
were
on
notice
that
their
behavior
was
at
least
risky
.
<END>
<START>
But
even
if
they
behaved
recklessly
,
reasons
still
exist
to
fear
and
resist
this
steady
process
of
case-by-case
judicial
extension
of
the
law
of
insider
trading
.
<END>
<START>
Courts
and
legislatures
make
decisions
in
very
different
ways
and
are
each
susceptible
to
very
different
kinds
of
errors
.
<END>
<START>
After-the-fact
judicial
examination
of
an
actor
's
conduct
has
always
been
the
common
law
's
method
.
<END>
<START>
When
only
civil
liability
is
involved
,
this
method
has
the
undeniable
strengths
of
factual
specificity
and
avoidance
of
overgeneralization
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
case-by-case
retrospective
decision
making
of
this
sort
is
vulnerable
to
the
tunnel
vision
caused
by
a
fixation
on
ad
hoc
-LRB-
and
usually
sleazy
-RRB-
examples
.
<END>
<START>
Thus
,
a
court
is
poorly
positioned
to
make
judgments
about
the
social
utility
of
the
expanded
rule
.
<END>
<START>
Can
a
security
analyst
call
an
investment
banker
to
make
certain
that
a
seemingly
improbable
rumor
is
in
fact
false
?
<END>
<START>
Today
,
after
Mr.
Freeman
's
plea
,
there
is
an
uncertainty
that
is
both
unfair
and
inefficient
.
<END>
<START>
At
least
when
the
stakes
are
high
,
uncertainty
in
turn
results
in
overinclusion
,
as
individuals
do
not
dare
to
approach
an
uncertain
line
closely
.
<END>
<START>
The
federal
mail
and
wire
fraud
statutes
provide
even
better
illustrations
of
the
rapid
evolution
of
a
federal
common
law
of
white-collar
crime
.
<END>
<START>
In
1987
,
the
Supreme
Court
attempted
in
McNally
v.
U.S.
to
halt
the
inexorable
expansion
of
these
statutes
by
adopting
a
rule
of
strict
construction
for
ambiguous
criminal
statues
.
<END>
<START>
At
a
stroke
,
this
may
criminalize
all
fiduciary
breaches
-LRB-
and
possibly
all
misrepresentations
by
an
agent
or
employee
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
We
are
confronted
less
with
a
judicial
power
grab
than
with
a
legislative
giveaway
.
<END>
<START>
Predictably
,
when
confronted
with
morally
dubious
behavior
,
prosecutors
will
exploit
the
latitude
such
openended
statutes
give
them
.
<END>
<START>
Over
the
long
run
,
however
,
sleazy
cases
will
make
bad
law
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Coffee
is
a
professor
at
Columbia
Law
School
.
<END>
<START>

<START>

jumped
3
3/8
to
127
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
``
are
buying
stocks
that
have
predictable
earnings
,
''
said
Edward
J.
Laux
,

.

<START>

<START>

.

<START>
-LRB-
In

,
traders
buy
or
sell
big
baskets
of
stocks
against
offsetting
positions
in
futures
.
-RRB-
<END>
<START>

's

.

<START>
Aside

.

<START>
Banks
are
continuing
to
go
after
individual
investors
,
despite
falling
interest
rates
.
<END>
<START>
Yields
on
small-denomination
certificates
of
deposit
fell
at
about
half
the
rate
of
so-called
jumbo
CDs
this
week
,
according
to
Banxquote
Money
Markets
,
an
information
service
based
here
.
<END>
<START>
Investors
can
get
slightly
higher
yields
on
deposits
below
$
50,000
than
they
can
on
deposits
of
$
90,000
and
up
.
<END>
<START>
``
Banks
want
to
remain
competitive
,
''
said
Norberto
Mehl
,

of
Banxquote
.
<END>
<START>
``
October
is
a
big
rollover
month
and
perhaps
they
anticipate
greater
demand
...
among
people
leaving
the
stock
market
.
''
<END>
<START>
Some
bankers
are
reporting
more

than
usual
about
CDs
since
Friday
.
<END>
<START>
``
Reports
from
branches
are
that
there
has
been
greater
interest
in
the
last
day
or
so
,
''
said
Steven
Braitman
,
a

at
Chemical
Bank
in

.
<END>
<START>
Chemical
said

Monday
were
about
$
5
million
higher
than
usual
and
it
expects
more
activity
as
investors
receive
the
proceeds
from
sales
of
stock
.
<END>
<START>
``
This
is
no
time
to
be
playing
in
the
street
...
<END>
<START>
the
Dow
has
more
ups
and
downs
than
an
elevator
,
''
proclaimed
an
advertisement
Monday
in
New
York
newspapers
,
touting
Lincoln
Savings
Bank
's
one-year
CD
.
<END>
<START>
Friday
's
market
rout
came
smack
in
the
middle
of
the
heaviest
month
for
CD
rollovers
,
when
a
number
of
banks
and
thrifts
already
have
promotions
under
way
.
<END>
<START>
First
National
Bank
of
Boston
,
for
example
,
is
offering
certain
new
depositors
an
extra
quarter
of
a
percentage
point
on
six-month
and
12-month
CDs
.
<END>
<START>
Some
banks
actually
boosted
yields
on
the
shortest
term
CDs
in
the
latest
week
.
<END>
<START>
New
York
's
Citibank
,
for
instance
,
increased
the
yield
on
small-denomination
three-month
CDs
to
8
%
from
7.9
%
.
<END>
<START>
On
average
,
however
,
three-month
CDs
at
major
banks
are
yielding
a
tenth
of
a
percentage
point
less
than
they
were
a
week
ago
.
<END>
<START>
Average
yields
on
CDs
aimed
at
individual
investors
fell
less
than
half
as
much
as
yields
on
Treasury
bills
sold
at
Monday
's
auction
.
<END>
<START>
Six-month
CDs
of
$
50,000
and
less
yielded
an
average
8.02
%
in
the
week
ended
Tuesday
,
down
from
8.10
%
,
according
to
Banxquote
.
<END>
<START>
The
yield
on
six-month
T-bills
fell
to
7.82
%
on
Monday
,
from
8.01
%
the
week
before
.
<END>
<START>
Meanwhile
,
the
average
yield
on
six-month
CDs
of
more
than
$
90,000
fell
to
7.93
%
in
the
latest
week
,
according
to
Banxquote
,
from
8.10
%
the
week
before
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Mehl
noted
that
actual
rates
are
almost
identical
on
small
and
large-denomination
CDs
,
but
yields
on
CDs
aimed
at
the
individual
investor
are
boosted
by
more
frequent
compounding
.
<END>
<START>
CDs
sold
by
major
brokerage
houses
,
which
like
jumbo
CDs
tend
to
closely
follow
interest
rate
trends
,
also
posted
larger
drops
in
yields
.
<END>
<START>
A
six-month
,
broker-sold
CD
,
for
example
,
was
yielding
an
average
8.09
%
in
the
latest
week
,
a
fifth
of
a
percentage
point
lower
than
the
week
before
.
<END>
<START>
In
late
April
,
when
interest
rates
were
at
their
recent
highs
,
short-term
CDs
sold
by
brokers
were
offering
yields
half
a
percentage
point
or
more
higher
than
banks
.
<END>
<START>
CD
yields
are
generally
expected
to
fall
further
in
coming
weeks
.
<END>
<START>
``
That
puts
pressure
on
CD
rates
.
<END>
<START>
Conservatives
have
an
important
decision
to
make
this
fall
.
<END>
<START>
This
would
be
consistent
with
its
unwavering
support
for
the
Brady
Plan
and
G-7
exchange-rate
intervention
,
and
with
its
financial
commitment
to
Mexico
,
Poland
and
others
.
<END>
<START>
The
IMF
has
several
reasons
for
requesting
the
increase
.
<END>
<START>
Its
role
in
the
economies
of
developing
countries
has
grown
steadily
since
the
1970s
.
<END>
<START>
The
size
and
pace
of
disbursements
will
accelerate
further
under
the
Brady
Plan
,
which
promises
larger
and
earlier
disbursements
to
approved
countries
.
<END>
<START>
At
least
three
other
factors
have
encouraged
the
IMF
to
insist
on
increased
capital
.
<END>
<START>
First
,
it
argues
that
its
capital
base
must
be
increased
in
order
to
maintain
its
size
relative
to
world
financial
markets
,
for
which
it
feels
some
responsibility
.
<END>
<START>
Third
,
the
IMF
would
like
to
meet
Japan
's
request
for
increased
ownership
-LRB-
currently
4.5
%
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
Japan
has
supported
a
larger
role
for
the
IMF
in
developing-country
debt
issues
,
and
is
an
important
financial
resource
for
IMF-guided
programs
in
developing
countries
.
<END>
<START>
While
international
politics
may
argue
for
the
capital
increase
,
there
is
a
clear
economic
case
against
it
.
<END>
<START>
Opponents
of
the
increase
argue
that
the
IMF
practices
central
planning
while
supporting
ineffective
governments
.
<END>
<START>
They
question
whether
the
IMF
has
any
role
in
developing
countries
,
given
its
original
mandate
to
assist
industrial
countries
in
balance-of-payments
emergencies
.
<END>
<START>
Opponents
show
that
there
are
already
more
funds
available
than
commendable
reform
efforts
.
<END>
<START>
They
worry
that
new
IMF
funding
of
developing
countries
will
simply
end
up
substituting
IMF
debt
for
reschedulable
commercial
bank
debt
,
a
bad
trade
all
around
.
<END>
<START>
They
point
at
the
numerous
developing-country
governments
that
have
inflated
,
taxed
and
regulated
themselves
into
despair
under
successive
IMF
programs
.
<END>
<START>
Decisions
on
increases
in
the
IMF
's
capital
base
traditionally
are
made
by
the
administration
,
with
subsequent
authorization
by
Congress
.
<END>
<START>
The
last
U.S.
congressional
authorization
,
in
1983
,
was
a
political
donnybrook
and
carried
a
$
6
billion
housing
program
along
with
it
to
secure
adequate
votes
.
<END>
<START>
The
politics
of
the
1990
congressional
authorization
are
likely
to
be
similar
to
those
of
previous
authorizations
.
<END>
<START>
Conservative
Republicans
will
be
given
the
choice
of
supporting
or
fighting
their
party
's
popular
president
in
an
election
year
.
<END>
<START>
Commentators
would
fret
over
the
implications
for
the
G-7
coordination
process
and
the
stability
of
world
financial
markets
.
<END>
<START>
Because
commercial
banks
and
the
developing-country
governments
believe
they
will
get
a
piece
of
any
capital
increase
,
a
scaled-down
IMF
mission
would
leave
both
feeling
shortchanged
.
<END>
<START>
Furthermore
,
a
U.S.
rejection
of
the
capital
increase
-LRB-
and
transfer
of
shares
to
Japan
-RRB-
would
give
Japan
an
argument
against
future
calls
for
economic
burden-sharing
.
<END>
<START>
On
the
other
hand
,
a
decision
to
increase
the
IMF
's
capital
would
reinforce
the
central
economic
role
of
multilateral
institutions
in
developing
countries
.
<END>
<START>
With
the
increase
,
even
more
developing-country
energy
and
talent
would
be
diverted
from
creating
profitable
economic
systems
to
setting
up
economic
planning
ministries
that
generate
IMF-approved
economic
plans
.
<END>
<START>
Upping
the
ante
could
slow
economic
development
even
further
,
as
countries
delay
market-opening
steps
in
anticipation
of
richer
multilateral
support
.
<END>
<START>
Conservatives
should
take
a
position
prior
to
the
administration
's
year-end
deadline
.
<END>
<START>
The
issues
are
too
important
to
be
left
to
the
financial
and
budget
ministries
fighting
over
the
size
of
the
capital
increase
,
rather
than
its
purpose
.
<END>
<START>
If
conservatives
do
n't
support
an
increase
in
the
IMF
's
capital
,
then
it
is
incumbent
on
them
to
speak
up
now
and
explain
the
alternative
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Malpass
directs
the
Republican
staff
of
the
Joint
Economic
Committee
of
Congress
.
<END>

<START>

Tuesday
,

.

.

,

<START>
An
experimental
vaccine
can
alter
the
immune
response
of
people
infected
with
the
AIDS
virus
,
a
prominent
U.S.
scientist
said
.
<END>
<START>
However
,
that
does
n't
mean
they
can
benefit
from
the
vaccine
.
<END>
<START>
The
vaccine
,
VaxSyn
HIV-1
,
has
been
safely
given
to
14
people
,
some
of
whom
are
experiencing
substantial
increases
in
certain
antibodies
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
conventional
wisdom
used
to
be
that
you
could
n't
modify
the
immune
response
of
an
infected
individual
''
by
innoculating
them
with
synthetic
viral
proteins
,
Dr.
Redfield
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
've
demonstrated
that
you
can
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
said
certain
volunteers
developed
kinds
of
antibodies
associated
with
early
AIDS
.
<END>
<START>
Other
antibodies
sparked
by
the
preparation
are
of
a
sort
rarely
present
in
large
quantities
in
infected
or
ill
individuals
,
he
added
.
<END>
<START>
One
of
the
mysteries
of
AIDS
remains
why
infected
people
produce
large
quantities
of
antibodies
,
but
deteriorate
nonetheless
.

<START>
Amstrad
PLC
,
a
British
maker
of
computer
hardware
and
communications
equipment
,
posted
a
52
%
plunge
in
pretax
profit
for
the
latest
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
slump
in
profit
,
which
came
despite
steady
sales
,
was
attributed
to
increased
costs
for
parts
and
problems
with
model
introductions
.
<END>
<START>
Amstrad
's
profit
after
taxes
fell
a
similarly
steep
51
%
,
to
#
51.1
million
from
#
105
million
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Sales
edged
up
fractionally
to
#
626.3
million
from
#
625.4
million
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
rose
to
$
235.2
million
,
from
$
176.4
million
.
<END>
<START>
Microsoft
previously
indicated
it
would
have
a
strong
quarter
by
forecasting
its
revenue
gain
on
Oct.
4
,
causing
a
$
6.50
a
share
jump
in
its
stock
.
<END>
<START>
But
its
stock
jumped
again
yesterday
as
it
disclosed
surprisingly
strong
margins
on
those
sales
.
<END>
<START>
Microsoft
's
stock
rose
$
2.875
a
share
in
national
over-the-counter
trading
to
$
78.625
.
<END>
<START>
The
stock
had
hit
a
high
of
$
81
a
share
early
last
week
but
collapsed
to
$
73.50
in
the
Friday
stock
plunge
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
had
been
experiencing
softening
margins
because
of
increased
sales
of
software
applications
,
which
have
lower
margins
than
do
operating
systems
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
company
said
that
trend
was
offset
in
the
first
quarter
by
better
economies
of
scale
and
efficiencies
in
manufacturing
.
<END>
<START>
As
a
result
,
Microsoft
's
cost
of
goods
,
as
a
percentage
of
sales
,
fell
17
%
from
the
year-ago
quarter
and
13
%
from
the
previous
period
.
<END>
<START>
The
trend
drove
up
the
aftertax
margin
--
net
income
as
a
percentage
of
revenues
--
to
21.1
%
in
the
quarter
,
compared
with
20.7
%
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
Microsoft
officials
said
the
strong
results
also
reflected
continuing
high
demand
for
its
software
applications
and
operating
systems
.
<END>
<START>
That
segment
continues
to
post
strong
quarter-to-quarter
gains
,
while
the
low-end
,
or
commodity
segment
,
of
the
industry
is
experiencing
sluggish
growth
or
even
sales
declines
.
<END>
<START>
Compared
with
its
previous
quarter
,
the
final
period
of
its
1989
fiscal
year
,
net
rose
9
%
,
and
sales
rose
7
%
.
<END>
<START>
Control
Data
Corp.
,
Minneapolis
,
signed
a
joint
development
agreement
with
MIPS
Computer
Systems
Inc.
to
incorporate
an
emerging
computing
architecture
in
future
machines
.
<END>
<START>
MIPS
is
a
leader
in
what
is
known
as
reduced-instruction
set
computing
,
or
RISC
,
a
technology
combining
microprocessors
and
sophisticated
software
.
<END>
<START>
In
joining
MIPS
,
Control
Data
follows
several
competitors
in
embracing
RISC
as
a
new
design
approach
.
<END>
<START>
Digital
Equipment
Corp.
,
Tandem
Computers
Inc.
,
NEC
Corp.
and
Group
Bull
,
among
others
,
have
similar
arrangements
with
MIPs
,
based
in
Sunnyvale
,
Calif
.
<END>
<START>
Control
Data
said
it
expects
its
first
RISC-based
mainframe
machine
to
be
introduced
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
accord
with
MIPS
calls
for
Control
Data
to
share
its
expertise
in
data
storage
,
the
companies
said
.
<END>
<START>
Control
Data
also
said
it
is
developing
what
it
called
a
``
supermainframe
''
computer
,
the
Cyber
2000
,
intended
for
scientists
,
engineers
and
other
users
of
generalpurpose
high-performance
computers
.
<END>

<START>
Interactive
telephone
technology
has
taken
a
new
leap
in
sophistication
,
and
television
programmers
are
racing
to
exploit
the
possibilities
.
<END>
<START>
Eventually
viewers
may
grow
bored
with
the
technology
and
resent
the
cost
.
<END>
<START>
But
right
now
programmers
are
figuring
that
viewers
who
are
busy
dialing
up
a
range
of
services
may
put
down
their
remote
control
zappers
and
stay
tuned
.
<END>
<START>
``
With
the
competitiveness
of
the
television
market
these
days
,
everyone
is
looking
for
a
way
to
get
viewers
more
excited
.
''
<END>
<START>
One
of
the
leaders
behind
the
expanded
use
of
900
numbers
is
Call
Interactive
,
a
joint
venture
of
giants
American
Express
Co.
and
American
Telephone
&
Telegraph
Co
.
<END>
<START>
Formed
in
August
,
the
venture
weds
AT&T
's
newly
expanded
900
service
with
200
voice-activated
computers
in
American
Express
's
Omaha
,
Neb.
,
service
center
.
<END>
<START>
Other
long-distance
carriers
have
also
begun
marketing
enhanced
900
service
,
and
special
consultants
are
springing
up
to
exploit
the
new
tool
.
<END>
<START>
Blair
Entertainment
,
a
New
York
firm
that
advises
TV
stations
and
sells
ads
for
them
,
has
just
formed
a
subsidiary
--
900
Blair
--
to
apply
the
technology
to
television
.
<END>
<START>

use
of

numbers

in

.

<START>
The

of

is
set
by

--
ABC
Sports
,
for
example
--
with
the
cheapest
starting
at
75
cents
.
<END>
<START>
Billing
is
included
in
a
caller
's
regular
phone
bill
.
<END>
<START>
In
recent
months
,
the
technology
has
become
more
flexible
and
able
to
handle
much
more
volume
.
<END>
<START>
Before
,
callers
of
900
numbers
would
just
listen
and
not
talk
,
or
they
'd
vote
``
yes
''
or
``
no
''
by
calling
one
of
two
numbers
.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
People
in
the
phone
business
call
this
technology
``
900
click
.
''
-RRB-
<END>
<START>
Now
,
callers
are
led
through
complex
menus
of
choices
to
retrieve
information
they
want
,
and
the
hardware
can
process
10,000
calls
in
90
seconds
.
<END>
<START>
Up
to
now
,
900
numbers
have
mainly
been
used
on
local
TV
stations
and
cable
channels
.
<END>
<START>
MTV
used
one
to
give
away
the
house
that
rock
star
Jon
Bon
Jovi
grew
up
in
.
<END>
<START>
The
newest
uses
of
the
900-interactive
technology
demonstrate
the
growing
variety
of
applications
.
<END>
<START>
Capital
Cities/ABC
Inc.
,
CBS
Inc.
and
General
Electric
Co.
's
National
Broadcasting
Co.
unit
are
expected
to
announce
soon
a
joint
campaign
to
raise
awareness
about
hunger
.
<END>
<START>
The
subject
will
be
written
into

plots

,
and

given

900

.
<END>
<START>

,

call
's

an

.
<END>

.

<START>
Right
away
you
notice
the
following
things
about
a
Philip
Glass

.
<END>
<START>
It
attracts

-LRB-
or

-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
Whoever

Bank
come

,

,
along
with
a
smattering
of
yuppies
who
want
to
be
on

cutting

.
<END>
<START>
People
in
Glass
houses
tend
to
look
stoned
.
<END>
<START>
Currently
in
the
middle
of
a
four-week
,
20-city

as
a

,
Mr.
Glass
has
left
behind
his

,

and

in
favor
of
going
it
alone
.
<END>
<START>
He
sits
down
at
the

and
plays
.
<END>
<START>
And
plays
.
<END>
<START>
Either
one
likes
it
or
one
does
n't
.
<END>
<START>
The
typical
Glass
audience
,
which
is
more
likely
to
be
composed
of
music
students
than
their
teachers
,
certainly
does
.
<END>
<START>
The
work
,
though
,
sounds
like
Muzak
for
spaceships
.
<END>
<START>
Philip
Glass
is
the
emperor
,
and
his
music
the
new
clothes
,
of
the
avant-garde
.
<END>
<START>
His
success
is
easy
to
understand
.
<END>
<START>
Softly
introducing
and
explaining
his
pieces
,
Mr.
Glass
looks
and
sounds
more
like
a
shaggy
poet
describing
his
work
than
a
classical
pianist
playing
a
recital
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
music
for
people
who
want
to
hear
something
different
but
do
n't
want
to
work
especially
hard
at
the
task
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
E-Z
listening
for
the
now
generation
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Glass
has
inverted
the
famous
modernist
dictum
``
less
is
more
.
''
<END>
<START>
His
more
is
always
less
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
music
has
its
charm
,
and
Mr.
Glass
has
constructed
his
solo
program
around
a
move
from
the
simple
to
the
relatively
complex
.
<END>
<START>
There
is
a
recognizable
musical
style
here
,
but
not
a
particular
performance
style
.
<END>
<START>
The
music
is
not
especially
pianistic
;
indeed
,
it
's
hard
to
imagine
a
bad
performance
of
it
.
<END>
<START>
Nothing
bravura
,
no
arpeggios
,
no
ticklish
fingering
problems
challenge
the
performer
.
<END>
<START>
We
hear
,
we
may
think
,
inner
voices
,
but
they
all
seem
to
be
saying
the
same
thing
.
<END>
<START>
With
``
Planet
News
,
''
music
meant
to
accompany
readings
of
Allen
Ginsberg
's
``
Wichita
Vortex
Sutra
,
''
Mr.
Glass
gets
going
.
<END>
<START>
His
hands
sit
farther
apart
on
the
keyboard
.
<END>
<START>
Seventh
chords
make
you
feel
as
though
he
may
break
into
a
-LRB-
very
slow
-RRB-
improvisatory
riff
.
<END>
<START>
The
chords
modulate
,
but
there
is
little
filigree
even
though
his
fingers
begin
to
wander
over
more
of
the
keys
.
<END>
<START>
Contrasts
predictably
accumulate
:
First
the
music
is
loud
,
then
it
becomes
soft
,
then
-LRB-
you
realize
-RRB-
it
becomes
louder
again
.
<END>
<START>
When
Mr.
Glass
decides
to

,
he
crosses
his
hands
and
hits
a
resonant
bass
note
with
his

.
<END>
<START>
He
does
this
in
at
least
three
of
his
solo

.
<END>
<START>
You
might
call
it
a
leitmotif
or
a

.
<END>
<START>
Not
only
is
the
typical
Glasswork
open-ended
,
it
is
also
often
multiple
in
its
context
-LRB-
s
-RRB-
.
<END>
<START>
Later
it
was
performed
on
Radio
Bremen
in
Germany
,
and
then
Lucinda
Childs
took
it
for
one
of
her

.
<END>
<START>
The
point
is
that
any

can
be
used
as

for
virtually
anything
.
<END>
<START>
The
evening
ended
with
Mr.
Glass
's
``
Metamorphosis
,
''
another
multiple
work
.
<END>
<START>
Served
up
as

,

,

a

within

.
<END>
<START>
But

,

.

''

.

''

.
''

,

<START>
Robert
J.
McManus
<END>
<START>
National
Geographic
,
the
sixth-largest
U.S.
magazine
,
is
attracting
more
readers
than
ever
and
offers
the
glossy
,
high-toned
pages
that
upscale
advertisers
love
.
<END>
<START>
So
why
did
advertising
pages
plunge
by
almost
10
%
and
ad
revenue
by
7.2
%
in
the
first
half
?
<END>
<START>
To
hear
advertisers
tell
it
,
the
magazine
just
has
n't
kept
up
with
the
times
.
<END>
<START>
Worse
,
it
lagged
behind
competitors
in
offering
now-standard
gimmicks
,
from
regional
editions
to
discounts
for
frequent
advertisers
.
<END>
<START>
But
now
,
the
magazine
is
attempting
to
fight
back
,
with
an
ambitious
plan
including
a
revamped
sales
strategy
and
a
surprisingly
aggressive
ad
campaign
.
<END>
<START>
Advertisers
do
n't
think
of
the
magazine
first
,
says
Joan
McCraw
,
who
joined
in
April
as
national
advertising
director
.
<END>
<START>
``
What
we
want
to
do
is
take
a
more
aggressive
stance
.
<END>
<START>
People
did
n't
believe
we
were
in
tune
with
the
marketplace
,
and
in
many
ways
we
were
n't
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
101-year-old
magazine
has
never
had
to
woo
advertisers
with
quite
so
much
fervor
before
.
<END>
<START>
The
magazine
had
its
best
year
yet
in
1988
,
when
it
celebrated
its
centennial
and
racked
up
a
17
%
gain
in
ad
pages
,
to
283
.
<END>
<START>
But
this
year
,
when
the
hullabaloo
surrounding
its
centennial
died
,
so
too
did
some
advertiser
interest
.
<END>
<START>
The
reason
,
ad
executives
say
,
is
that
the
entire
magazine
business
has
been
soft
--
and
National
Geographic
has
some
quirks
that
make
it
especially
unattractive
during
a
soft
market
.
<END>
<START>
When
ad
dollars
are
tight
,
the
high
page
cost
is
a
major
deterrent
for
advertisers
,
who
generally
want
to
appear
regularly
in
a
publication
or
not
at
all
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
magazine
was
slower
than
its
competitors
to
come
up
with
its
regional
editions
,
and
until
last
year
offered
fewer
of
them
than
did
competitors
.
<END>
<START>
Time
magazine
,
for
example
,
has
more
than
100
separate
editions
going
to
different
regions
,
top
management
,
and
other
groups
.
<END>
<START>
And
National
Geographic
's
smaller-than-average
size
means
extra
production
costs
for
advertisers
.
<END>
<START>
But
Ms.
McCraw
says
the
magazine
is
fighting
back
.
<END>
<START>
It
now
offers
30
regional
editions
,
it
very
recently
began
running
ads
adjacent
to
articles
,
and
it
has
been
beefing
up
its
sales
force
.
<END>
<START>
And
it
just
launched
a
promotional
campaign
to
tell
chief
executives
,
marketing
directors
,
and
media
executives
just
that
.
<END>
<START>
The
centerpiece
of
the
promotion
is
its
new
ad
campaign
,
into
which
the
magazine
will
pour
about
$
500,000
,
mostly
in
the
next
few
weeks
.
<END>
<START>
The
campaign
,
created
by
Omnicom
Group
's
DDB
Needham
agency
,
takes
advantage
of
the
eye-catching
photography
that
National
Geographic
is
known
for
.
<END>
<START>
Another
ad
pictures
a
tree
ant
,
magnified
80
times
,
with
the
headline
,
``
For
impact
far
beyond
your
size
consider

.
''
<END>
<START>
Ms.
McCraw
says
she

help

in
10
categories
,

,

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
Her
goal
:
to
top
300
ad
pages
in
1990
,
up
from
about
274
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Whether
she
can
meet
that
ambitious
goal
is
still
far
from
certain
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
ad
campaign
is
meant
to
contemporize
the
thought
of
National
Geographic
,
''
she
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
want
it
to
be
a
'90s
kind
of
image
.
''

firm
,
Boulet
Dru
Dupuy
Petit
,
or
BDDP
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
the
executive
,
BDDP
's
involvement
prompted
renewed
vigor
in
the
WCRS-Eurocom
talks
and
the
two
agencies
were
hoping
to
hammer
out
details
by
today
.
<END>
<START>
Executives
of
the
two
agencies
could
n't
be
reached
last
night
.
<END>
<START>
Ad
Notes
...
.
<END>
<START>
Billings
were
n't
disclosed
.
<END>
<START>
Professional
Crisco
products
are
specially
made
for
the
foodservice
industry
.
<END>
<START>
WHO
'S
NEWS
:
Stephen
Novick
,
49
,
was
named
executive
vice
president
,
deputy
creative
director
at
Grey
Advertising
,
New
York
.
<END>
<START>
He
was
executive
vice
president
,
director
of
broadcast
production
.
<END>
<START>
The
Commodity
Futures
Trading
Commission
plans
to
restrict
dual
trading
on
commodity
exchanges
,
a
move
almost
certain
to
infuriate
exchange
officials
and
traders
.
<END>
<START>
The
CFTC
said
it
will
propose
the
restrictions
after
the
release
of
a
study
that
shows
little
economic
benefit
resulting
from
dual
trading
and
cites
``
problems
''
associated
with
the
practice
.
<END>
<START>
Dual
trading
gives
an
exchange
trader
the
right
to
trade
both
for
his
own
account
and
for
customers
.
<END>
<START>
The
issue
exploded
this
year
after
a
Federal
Bureau
of
Investigation
operation
led
to
charges
of
widespread
trading
abuses
at
the
Chicago
Board
of
Trade
and
Chicago
Mercantile
Exchange
.
<END>
<START>
While
not
specifically
mentioned
in
the
FBI
charges
,
dual
trading
became
a
focus
of
attempts
to
tighten
industry
regulations
.
<END>
<START>
Critics
contend
that
traders
were
putting
buying
or
selling
for
their
own
accounts
ahead
of
other
traders
'
customer
orders
.
<END>
<START>
Traders
are
likely
to
oppose
such
restrictions
because
dual
trading
provides
a
way
to
make
money
in
slower
markets
where
there
is
a
shortage
of
customer
orders
.
<END>
<START>
The
exchanges
contend
that
dual
trading
improves
liquidity
in
the
markets
because
traders
can
buy
or
sell
even
when
they
do
n't
have
a
customer
order
in
hand
.
<END>
<START>
The
exchanges
say
liquidity
becomes
a
severe
problem
for
thinly
traded
contracts
such
as
those
with
a
long
time
remaining
before
expiration
.
<END>
<START>
The
CFTC
may
take
those
arguments
into
account
by
allowing
exceptions
to
its
restrictions
.
<END>
<START>
The
agency
did
n't
cite
specific
situations
where
dual
trading
might
be
allowed
,
but
smaller
exchanges
or
contracts
that
need
additional
liquidity
are
expected
to
be
among
them
.
<END>
<START>
The
study
,
by
the
CFTC
's
division
of
economic
analysis
,
shows
that
``
a
trade
is
a
trade
,
''
a
member
of
the
study
team
said
.
<END>
<START>
Whether
a
trade
is
done
on
a
dual
or
non-dual
basis
,
the
member
said
,
``
does
n't
seem
to
have
much
economic
impact
.
''
<END>
<START>
Currently
,
most
traders
on
commodity
exchanges
specialize
in
trading
either
for
customer
accounts
,
which
makes
them
brokers
,
or
for
their
own
accounts
as
socalled
locals
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
tests
indicate
that
dual
and
non-dual
traders
are
similar
in
terms
of
the
trade
executions
and
liquidity
they
provide
to
the
market
,
''
Mrs.
Gramm
told
the
Senate
panel
.
<END>
<START>
Members
of
Congress
have
proposed
restricting
dual
trading
in
bills
to
reauthorize
CFTC
operations
.
<END>
<START>
The
House
's
bill
would
prohibit
dual
trading
in
markets
with
daily
average
volume
of
7,000
contracts
or
more
,
comprising
those
considered
too
difficult
to
track
without
a
sophisticated
computer
system
.
<END>
<START>
The
Senate
bill
would
force
the
CFTC
to
suspend
dual
trading
if
an
exchange
ca
n't
show
that
its
oversight
system
can
detect
dual-trading
abuses
.
<END>
<START>
So
far
,
one
test
of
restricting
dual
trading
has
worked
well
.
<END>
<START>
The
Chicago
Merc
banned
dual
trading
in
its
Standard
&
Poor
's
500-stock
index
futures
pit
in
1987
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
rules
,
traders
decide
before
a
session
begins
whether
they
will
trade
for
their
own
account
or
for
customers
.
<END>
<START>
Traders
who
stand
on
the
pit
's
top
step
,
where
most
customer
orders
are
executed
,
ca
n't
trade
for
themselves
.
<END>
<START>
A
Merc
spokesman
said
the
plan
has
n't
made
much
difference
in
liquidity
in
the
pit
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
too
soon
to
tell
...
but
people
do
n't
seem
to
be
unhappy
with
it
,
''
he
said
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
he
would
n't
comment
on
the
CFTC
plan
until
the
exchange
has
seen
the
full
proposal
.
<END>
<START>
But
at
a
meeting
last
week
,
Tom
Donovan
,
the
Board
of
Trade
's
president
,
told
commodity
lawyers
:
``
Dual
trading
is
definitely
worth
saving
.
<END>
<START>
It
adds
something
to
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
Japanese
Firms
Push
Posh
Car
Showrooms
<END>
<START>
JAPANESE
luxury-car
makers
are
trying
to
set
strict
design
standards
for
their
dealerships
.
<END>
<START>
But
some
dealers
are
negotiating
looser
terms
,
while
others
decline
to
deal
at
all
.
<END>
<START>
Nissan
Motor
Co.
's
Infiniti
division
likes
to
insist
that
every
dealer
construct
and
furnish
a
building
in
a
Japanese
style
.
<END>
<START>
Specifications
include
a
polished
bronze
sculpture
at
the
center
of
each
showroom
and
a
tile
bridge
spanning
a
stream
that
flows
into

building
from
outside
.
<END>
<START>
``
Infiniti
has
it
down
to
the
ashtrays
,
''
says
Jay
Ferron
,
a
partner
at
J.D.
Power
&
Associates
,
an
auto
research
firm
.
<END>
<START>
Toyota
Motor
Corp.
's
Lexus
division
also
provides
specifications
.
<END>
<START>
But
only
two-thirds
of
Lexus
dealers
are
constructing
new
buildings
according
to
the
Lexus
specs
.
<END>
<START>
Some
are
even
coming
up
with
their
own
novel
designs
.
<END>
<START>
In
Louisville
,
Ky.
,
for
example
,
David
Peterson
has
built
a
Lexus
dealership
with
the
showroom
on
the

floor
.
<END>
<START>
Yet
some

have
turned
down
Infiniti
or
Lexus

because
they
were
unwilling
or
unable

meet

.
<END>
<START>
Lee
Seidman

Cleveland
says

``
was
a
bear
on
interiors
''
but
at
least

--
without
the

.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Seidman

in

``
the
building
was
gorgeous
but
very
expensive
.
''
<END>
<START>
To
head
off

,
Infiniti
offers
dealers
cash
bonuses
and
low-interest
construction
loans
.
