<START>
Dictation
Device
's
Saga
Plays
Back
a
Lesson
<END>
<START>
PRODUCTS
DON'T
have
to
be
first
to
be
winners
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
the
lesson
offered
through
one
case
study
featured
in
a
design
exhibit
.
<END>
<START>
Dictaphone
Corp.
was
caught
off
guard
in
1974
when
its
main
competitor
,
Lanier
Office
Products
of
Japan
,
introduced
a
microcassette
dictation
recorder
half
the
size
of
standard
cassette
devices
.
<END>
<START>
Blocked
by
patent
protection
from
following
suit
,
Dictaphone
decided
to
go
a
step
further
and
cut
the
cassette
in
half
again
--
down
to
the
length
of
a
paperclip
.
<END>
<START>
By
1979
,
designers
and
engineers
at
Dictaphone
,
a
Pitney
Bowes
subsidiary
,
had
produced
a
working
model
of
a
``
picocassette
''
recorder
.
<END>
<START>
By
1982
,
however
,
the
patent
status
of
the
Lanier
microcassette
had
changed
,
permitting
Dictaphone
to
develop
its
own
competitive
micro
system
,
which
it
did
.
<END>
<START>
Marketing
and
sales
departments
then
urged
abandonment
of
the
pico
project
.
<END>
<START>
But
others
said
pico
should
proceed
.
<END>
<START>
Both
were
right
.
<END>
<START>
Dictaphone
went
ahead
and
introduced
the
pico
in
1985
,
but
it
has
n't
sold
well
.
<END>
<START>
To
date
,
says
Emil
Jachmann
,
a
Dictaphone
vice
president
,
it
has
``
broken
even
or
shown
a
small
loss
.
''
<END>
<START>
Nevertheless
,
the
device
has
been
successful
in
other
ways
.
<END>
<START>
It
helped
Dictaphone
attract
better
engineers
,
and
it
provided
new
technology
for
other
company
products
.
<END>
<START>
The
picocassette
recorder
also
helped
transform
the
company
's
reputation
from
follower
to
leading-edge
innovator
.
<END>
<START>
Dictaphone
's
picocassette
recorder
is
one
of
13
case
studies
in
the
TRIAD
Design
Project
,
sponsored
by
the
Design
Management
Institute
of
Boston
and
Harvard
Business
School
.
<END>
<START>
The
studies
are
on
exhibit
at
Harvard
this
month
and
will
travel
to
Chicago
's
Institute
of
Design
and
the
University
of
California
at
Berkeley
.
<END>
<START>
A
Rake
's
Progress
Means
Branching
Out
<END>
<START>
ONE
DAY
Carl
Barrett
of
Mobile
,
Ala.
,
was
raking
some
sycamore
leaves
,
but
the
rake
kept
riding
up
over
the
piles
.
<END>
<START>
The
harder
he
tried
to
push
them
into
large
piles
,
the
closer
he
came
to
breaking
the
rake
and
straining
his
back
.
<END>
<START>
So
Mr.
Barrett
,
then
vice
president
of
the
Alabama
Steamship
Association
,
took
a
steel-toothed
garden
rake
and
taped
it
to
the
underside
of
a
leaf
rake
about
nine
inches
up
.
<END>
<START>
His
crude
device
worked
:
The
lower
teeth
gathered
the
leaves
into
a
pile
,
while
the
higher
,
harder
teeth
moved
the
top
of
the
pile
.
<END>
<START>
Now
incorporated
into
a
polypropylene
rake
,
the
four-inch
prongs
,
or
``
wonderbars
,
''
also
are
supposed
to
aid
in
picking
up
leaves
.
<END>
<START>
One
customer
,
Donald
Blaggs
of
Mobile
,
says
the
Barrett
Rake
allowed
him
to
do
his
lawn
in
2
1/2
hours
,
two
hours
less
than
usual
.
<END>
<START>
But
other
rake
makers
have
their
doubts
.
<END>
<START>
John
Stoner
,
marketing
director
for
True
Temper
Corp.
,
a
subsidiary
of
Black
&
Decker
,
says
people
do
n't
want
to
move
a
leaf
pile
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
either
pick
it
up
,
''
he
says
,
``
or
they
start
pulling
from
a
fresh
direction
.
''
<END>
<START>
Odds
and
Ends
<END>
<START>
NO
MORE
STUBBED
toes
or
bruised
shins
,
promises
Geste
Corp.
of
Goshen
,
Ind.
,
the
designer
of
a
bed
support
to
replace
traditional
frames
.
<END>
<START>
Four
tubular
steel
``
Bedfellows
,
''
each
roughly
in
the
shape
of
a
``
W
,
''
are
attached
to
the
bottom
of
the
box
spring
in
a
recessed
position
...
.
<END>
<START>
The
Pentagon
is
a
haunted
house
.
<END>
<START>
Living
there
for
six
years
was
really
scary
.
<END>
<START>
The
ghosts
of
the
past
are
everywhere
:
They
are
kept
at
bay
only
by
feeding
them
vast
quantities
of
our
defense
budget
.
<END>
<START>
Some
can
be
bought
off
relatively
cheaply
.
<END>
<START>
During
the
Korean
War
,
Gen.
Douglas
MacArthur
demanded
and
got
,
in
addition
to
his
U.N.
command
in
Korea
,
his
own
naval
command
in
Japan
,
NavforJapan
.
<END>
<START>
Those
obsolete
operations
cost
less
than
$
2
billion
a
year
,
and
keep
Mac
's
ghost
quiet
.
<END>
<START>
That
's
about
all
it
costs
to
appease
Adm.
Erich
Raeder
's
ghost
.
<END>
<START>
In
1941
,
Raeder
and
the
German
navy
threatened
to
attack
the
Panama
Canal
,
so
we
created
the
Southern
Command
in
Panama
.
<END>
<START>
The
Southern
Command
has
grown
even
bigger
since
the
war
because
Raeder
's
ghost
sometimes
runs
through
the
E
ring
dressed
like
Gen.
Noriega
.
<END>
<START>
So
far
no
one
has
.
<END>
<START>
The
brigade
has
n't
been
heard
from
since
,
but
we
keep
the
staff
around
just
in
case
.
<END>
<START>
George
Marshall
's
ghost
is
much
more
difficult
to
keep
happy
.
<END>
<START>
We
keep
a
lot
of
shrines
to
him
around
the
Pentagon
:
statues
,
busts
,
relics
and
such
.
<END>
<START>
The
Army
headquarters
on
the
third
deck
of
the
Pentagon
used
to
burn
a
lot
of
incense
to
him
,
but
the
Navy
headquarters
on
the
fourth
deck
made
them
stop
it
.
<END>
<START>
You
see
,
Marshall
had
this
thing
about
the
Navy
and
the
Marines
--
he
wanted
to
make
them
part
of
the
Army
but
Secretary
of
the
Navy
James
Forrestal
blocked
him
.
<END>
<START>
Now
his
ghost
wo
n't
let
up
till
it
's
done
.
<END>
<START>
To
keep
him
quiet
we
invent
a
new
unified
command
every
year
or
so
run
by
the
Army
or
the
Air
Force
and
put
more
of
the
Navy
and
Marines
under
it
.
<END>
<START>
Which
brings
up
the
worst
and
meanest
ghost
of
all
--
the
ghost
of
the
shah
of
Iran
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Carter
said
he
would
go
to
war
to
stop
anyone
from
trying
to
grab
Iran
.
<END>
<START>
But
that
ghost
would
n't
settle
for
words
,
he
wanted
money
and
people
--
lots
.
<END>
<START>
So
Mr.
Carter
formed
three
new
Army
divisions
and
gave
them
to
a
new
bureaucracy
in
Tampa
called
the
Rapid
Deployment
Force
.
<END>
<START>
After
Mr.
Carter
was
defeated
in
1980
,
the
shah
's
ghost
claimed
the
credit
and
then
went
after
President
Reagan
and
Cap
Weinberger
.
<END>
<START>
I
saw
what
he
did
to
them
firsthand
.
<END>
<START>
It
made
my
shoelaces
dance
with
terror
.
<END>
<START>
He
dedicated
all
these
new
forces
to
the
Persian
Gulf
.
<END>
<START>
One
night
both
Marshall
's
ghost
and
the
shah
's
ghost
together
caught
Cap
and
threw
him
to
the
ground
.
<END>
<START>
Before
they
let
him
go
he
added
a
thousand
bureaucrats
to
the
RDF
in
Tampa
and
renamed
it
Central
Command
.
<END>
<START>
He
gave
those
bureaucrats
charge
of
all
naval
operations
in
the
Persian
Gulf
and
Indian
Ocean
.
<END>
<START>
Marshall
figured
it
would
be
good
training
for
those
soldiers
--

art

.

<START>

.

Figures

.

<START>

substantially

.

,

.

.

.

,

.

<START>
-LCB-
During
its
centennial
year
,
The
Wall
Street
Journal
will
report
events
of
the
past
century
that
stand
as
milestones
of
American
business
history
.
-RCB-
<END>
<START>
CREATIVE
ACCOUNTING
,
mostly
by
conglomerates
,
forced
CPAs
to
change
their
way
of
setting
standards
to
be
followed
by
corporations
reporting
financial
results
,
standards
that
had
become
all
too
flexible
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
Financial
Accounting
Standards
Board
-LRB-
FASB
-RRB-
was
created
in
1972
to
replace
the
Accounting
Principles
Board
of
the
American
Institute
of
Certified
Public
Accountants
.
<END>
<START>
All
of
the
former
board
's
members
were
CPAs
,
provoking
conflict-of-interest
criticism
because
they
were
writing
rules
while
handling
clients
'
books
at
the
same
time
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
board
's
seven-member
structure
kept
four
CPAs
,
but
the
others
were
from
industry
and
academia
.
<END>
<START>
Francis
M.
Wheat
,
a
former
Securities
and
Exchange
Commission
member
,
headed
the
panel
that
had
studied
the
issues
for
a
year
and
proposed
the
FASB
on
March
30
,
1972
.
<END>
<START>
The
former
board
had
produced
``
21
opinions
and
1,000
critics
''
in
its
12-year
life
,
its
chairman
had
conceded
.
<END>
<START>
The
climate
was
right
for
the
new
FASB
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
late
1960s
some
CPAs
failed
to
correct
such
abuses
as
clients
picking
permissive
rules
that
hyped
earnings
and
stock
prices
.
<END>
<START>
And
in
November
1970
Congress
had
passed
a
special
act
to
overrule
one
board
rule
.
<END>
<START>
Keepers
of
the
books
,
dubbed
``
figure
filberts
,
''
loathed
the
threat
.
<END>
<START>
The
FASB
had
its
initial
meeting
on
March
28
,
1973
.
<END>
<START>
On
Dec.
13
,
1973
,
it
issued
its
first
rule
;
it
required
companies
to
disclose
foreign
currency
translations
in
U.S.
dollars
.
<END>
<START>
The
FASB
since
then
has
issued
102
rules
,
and
some
still
rile
industry
.
<END>
<START>
Since
late
1987
,
for
example
,
it
has
put
off
a
rule
dealing
with
deferred
income
taxes
because
of
the
continuing
controversy
over
the
issue
.
<END>
<START>
Amcast
Industrial

,

,

.

.

<START>

1

,

Co.

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

Aluminium
Ltd.

30

180

,

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

on

about

2.70
for

1
for

.
<END>
<START>
The
nation
's
No.
2
aluminum
company
said

were
hurt
by
lower
prices
for
certain
fabricated
aluminum
products
,
which
typically
follow
price
fluctuations
of
primary
ingots
.
<END>
<START>
The
base
metal
price
has
dropped
30.3
%
from
a
year
earlier
to
78
cents
a
pound
.
<END>
<START>
Much
of
the
price
decline
has
been
blamed
on
a

economy
and
the
third
quarter
is
typically
the
industry
's

.
<END>
<START>
But
William
O.
Bourke
,

,

``
appears

.
''
<END>
<START>
He
said

are
continuing
at

``
healthy
''

and
the
company
has
no

inventory
.
<END>
<START>
Aluminum
shipments
of
329,600

tons
were
nearly

to

period
,
the
company
said
.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.

.

<START>
No

,

.

<START>

houses
proclaiming
that
stocks
are
a
good
bargain
again
.
<END>
<START>
But
quite
a
few
money
managers
are
n't
buying
it
.
<END>
<START>
Weakening
corporate
earnings
,
they
say
,
are
no
prescription
for
a
bull
market
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
stock
market
ai
n't
going
to
do
much
of
anything
''
for
a
while
,
says
John
Neff
of
Wellington
Management
,
who
runs
the
$
8.3
billion
Windsor
Fund
.
<END>
<START>
He
suspects
that
Friday
's
market
decline
may
have
a
second
leg
,
perhaps
a
10
%
to
15
%
drop
later
on
.
<END>
<START>
After
sitting
with
20
%
of
his
fund
in
cash
before
Friday
's
sell-off
,
Mr.
Neff
says
he
bought
``
a
narrow
list
of
stocks
''
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
With
flat
corporate
profits
on
the
horizon
for
1990
,
money
managers
say
price-earnings
multiples
that
look
cheap
today
might
go
on
being
cheap
for
a
long
time
.
<END>
<START>
Bulls
say
the
market
is
an
incredible
bargain
,
priced
at
only
about
12
times
estimated
1989
earnings
for
stocks
in
the
Standard
&
Poor
's
500
index
.
<END>
<START>
Before
the
1987
crash
,
the
P/E
was
more
than
20
.
<END>
<START>
Our
view
is
that
we
may
see
a
profit
decline
.
''
<END>
<START>
Some
think
investors
should
sell
into
rallies
.
<END>
<START>
The
market
``
is
going
to
wind
down
,
''
says
Gerald
W.
Perritt
,
a
Chicago
money
manager
.
<END>
<START>
``
Things
are
a
little
less
overpriced
''
after
Friday
's
jolt
in
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
He
expects
stocks
to
decline
an
additional
5
%
to
30
%
,
with
the
Dow
perhaps
bottoming
out
between
2000
and
2100
``
between
now
and
June
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
found
85
still
overvalued
and
15
fairly
valued
.
<END>
<START>
Nicholas
Parks
,
a
New
York
money
manager
,
expects
the
market
to
decline
about
15
%
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
've
been
two-thirds
in
cash
since
July
,
and
I
continue
to
think
that
having
a
defensive
position
is
appropriate
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
Companies
that
piled
on
debt
in
leveraged
buy-outs
during
the
past
two
years
``
will
continue
to
surface
as
business
problems
.
''
<END>
<START>
``
Generalizations
about
value
are
n't
useful
,
''
says
New
York
money
manager
John
LeFrere
of
Delta
Capital
Management
.
<END>
<START>
There
are
still
bulls
out
there
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're
doing
a
little
buying
''
in
some
stocks
``
that
have
really
been
smashed
down
.
''
<END>
<START>
Many
brokerage
house
officials
also
are
optimistic
.
<END>
<START>
Yesterday
,
Goldman
Sachs
,
Merrill
Lynch
and
Dean
Witter
all
increased
the
proportion
of
assets
they
recommend
investors
commit
to
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
Dean
Witter
now
recommends
85
%
,
Goldman
65
%
and
Merrill
Lynch
50
%
.
<END>
<START>
Some
investors
say
Friday
's
sell-off
was
a
good
thing
,
because
it
deflated
a
lot
of
crazy
takeover
speculation
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
was
a
healthy
cleansing
,
''
says
Michael
Holland
,
who
runs
Salomon
Brothers
Asset
Management
in
New
York
.
<END>
<START>
From
here
out
,
these
investors
see
a
return
to
old-fashioned
investing
,
based
on
a
company
's
ability
to
show
profit
growth
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
fundamentals
are
pretty
strong
,
''
Mr.
Dreman
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
do
n't
see
this
as
a
bear
market
at
all
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
a
recognition
that
there
was
much
too
much
fluff
in
the
LBO
market
.
''
<END>
<START>
Friday
's
big
fall
was
``
just
a
blunder
by
the
stock
market
,
''
says
John
Connolly
,
chief
strategist
for
Dean
Witter
.
<END>
<START>
Many
investors
have
nagging
worries
,
however
.
<END>
<START>
Newspapers
are
full
of
headlines
about
companies
defaulting
on
their
debts
and
banks
writing
off
real
estate
loans
.
<END>
<START>
That
hurts
investors
'
confidence
in
the
economy
and
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
Not
even
all
the
brokerage
firms
see
clear
sailing
ahead
.
<END>
<START>
``
Disappointing
profits
are
likely
to
get
worse
in
the
next
two
quarters
,
''
says
Mary
Farrell
,
a
market
strategist
at
PaineWebber
.
<END>
<START>
She
thinks
the
market
could
drop
about
10
%
in
the
next
few
months
,
then
recover
and
go
higher
.
<END>
<START>
Companies
with
steady
earnings
growth
could
do
well
,
she
says
,
while
others
with
high
debt
or
poor
earnings
could
see
their
shares
decline
far
more
than
10
%
.
<END>
<START>
The
turmoil
on
Wall
Street
may
benefit
some
retailers
attempting
to
lead
leveraged
buy-outs
of
their
specialty
and
department-store
chains
,
investment
bankers
and
retailers
said
.
<END>
<START>
Managers
at
five
chains
have
said
in
recent
weeks
that
they
intend
to
bid
for
their
companies
.
<END>
<START>
Hooker
is
based
in
Sydney
,
Australia
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
pricing
will
become
more
realistic
,
which
should
help
management
,
''
said
Bruce
Rosenthal
,
a
New
York
investment
banker
with
Nathan
S.
Jonas
&
Co
.
<END>
<START>
``
Investors
are
n't
going
to
be
throwing
money
at
any
of
the
proposed
LBOs
,
but
doing
deals
on
the
basis
of
ridiculous
assumptions
never
made
sense
,
either
.
''
<END>
<START>
Earlier
this
year
,
bankers
and
other
investors
were
willing
to
provide
financing
because
they
assumed
there
would
be
major
gains
in
both
profitability
and
sales
,
Mr.
Rosenthal
added
.
<END>
<START>
Those
days
are
over
now
,
he
believes
.
<END>
<START>
``
Competition
from
third
parties
who
have
cash
and
are
prepared
to
buy
has
always
existed
and
will
continue
,
''
added
Mr.
Rosenthal
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
when
prices
were
crazy
,
it
was
even
harder
to
do
an
LBO
.
<END>
<START>
Bankers
believed
in
the
greater-fool
theory
that
says
somebody
else
is
always
willing
to
pay
more
.
<END>
<START>
This
is
no
longer
true
today
.
''
<END>
<START>
At
Saks
Fifth
Avenue
,
Paul
Leblang
,
senior
vice
president
,
marketing
,
agreed
that
lower
prices
will
help
his
management
team
in
their
proposed
LBO
.
<END>
<START>
``
Having
to
take
on
less
debt
would
certainly
be
an
advantage
,
''
said
Mr.
Leblang
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
would
also
help
us
in
our
search
for
equity
partners
.
<END>
<START>
To
make
an
LBO
work
,
now
we
are
going
to
need
more
than
just
junk
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
''
None
believe
the
proposed
management
LBOs
will
be
easy
to
complete
,
especially
at
B.
Altman
&
Co.
,
which
is
under
Chapter
11
bankruptcy
protection
.
<END>
<START>
Further
,
many
institutions
today
holding
troubled
retailers
'
debt
securities
will
be
reticent
to
consider
additional
retailing
investments
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
called
bad
money
driving
out
good
money
,
''
said
one
retailing
observer
.
<END>
<START>
``
Institutions
that
usually
buy
retail
paper
have
to
be
more
concerned
.
''
<END>
<START>
However
,
the
lower
prices
these
retail
chains
are
now
expected
to
bring
should
make
it
easier
for
managers
to
raise
the
necessary
capital
and
pay
back
the
resulting
debt
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
the
fall
selling
season
has
generally
been
a
good
one
,
especially
for
those
retailers
dependent
on
apparel
sales
for
the
majority
of
their
revenues
.
<END>
<START>
``
Retailers
who
had
good
track
records
of
producing
profits
will
have
a
better
chance
to
buy
back
their
companies
.
''
<END>
<START>
``
But
the
hurdle
of
financing
still
has
to
be
resolved
.
<END>
<START>
Potential
bondholders
will
either
look
for
greater
equity
participation
on
behalf
of
management
,
or
insist
the
equity
component
of
the
deals
be
substantially
greater
than
in
the
past
.
<END>
<START>
Sony
Corp.
won
a
pretrial
order
blocking
U.S.
sales
of
Justin
Products
Inc.
's
``
My
Own
''
line
of
portable
audio
players
for
children
.
<END>
<START>
Judge
John
E.
Sprizzo
issued
the
order
in
Manhattan
federal
court
,
where
Sony
has
accused
the
tiny
company
of
illegally
knocking
off
the
``
My
First
Sony
''
line
.
<END>
<START>
The
judge
held
that
the
combination
of
colors
used
for
the
Sony
products
is
distinctive
and
subject
to
protection
under
New
York
state
law
,
rather
than
federal
law
.
<END>
<START>
The
legal
fight
was
the
subject
of
a
Wall
Street
Journal
story
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
Justin
's
attorney
,
Charles
E.
Baxley
,
said
Justin
would
ask
an
appeals
court
to
set
aside
the
order
temporarily
,
pending
an
expedited
appeal
.
<END>
<START>
He
also
repeated
Justin
's
denial
of
Sony
's
charges
.
<END>
<START>
``
Their
likelihood
of
reversing
us
is
very
slim
,
''
said
Lewis
H.
Eslinger
,
Sony
's
attorney
,
who
said
he
doubts
Justin
will
go
ahead
with
a
trial
.
<END>
<START>
CONTINENTAL
MORTGAGE
&
EQUITY
TRUST
said
it
will
resume
dividend
payments
with
a
10-cent-a-share
payout
on
Nov.
6
to
shares
of
record
Oct.
25
.
<END>
<START>
The
Dallas
real
estate
investment
trust
last
paid
a
dividend
on
Dec.
31
,
1987
,
when
shareholders
received
$
1
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
continuing
troubles
with
problem
assets
and
nonperforming
loans
,
the
trust
said
it
expects
to
be
able
to
maintain
or
increase
the
rate
of
distributions
because
of
operations
of
joint-venture
properties
.
<END>
<START>
A
federal
appeals
court
struck
down
a
natural-gas
regulation
that
had
prevented
pipeline
companies
from
passing
to
customers
part
of
$
1
billion
in
costs
from
controversial
``
take-or-pay
''
contracts
.
<END>
<START>
A
majority
of
old
contracts
were
renegotiated
by
the
deadline
and
settled
at
steep
discounts
.
<END>
<START>
But
pipeline
companies
estimate
they
still
face
$
2.4
billion
in
liabilities
from
unresolved
disputes
,
including
$
1
billion
they
fear
they
wo
n't
be
able
to
pass
on
to
customers
.
<END>
<START>
According
to
industry
lawyers
,
the
ruling
gives
pipeline
companies
an
important
second
chance
to
resolve
remaining
disputes
and
take
advantage
of
the
cost-sharing
mechanism
.
<END>
<START>
The
court
left
open
whether
FERC
could
reimpose
a
new
deadline
later
.
<END>
<START>
The
court
ordered
FERC
to
justify
within
60
days
not
only
its
cost-sharing
deadline
,
but
other
major
elements
of
its
proposed
regulation
for
introducing
more
competition
into
natural-gas
transportation
.
<END>
<START>
The
court
also
questioned
a
crediting
mechanism
that
could
be
used
to
resolve
take-or-pay
liabilities
.
<END>
<START>
The
complex
regulation
,
known
in
the
industry
as
Order
500
,
has
been
hotly
contested
by
all
sides
,
including
natural-gas
producers
,
pipelines
,
local
distribution
companies
and
consumers
.
<END>
<START>
The
court
's
decision
would
allow
FERC
to
change
some
of
its
provisions
,
but
ensures
it
will
be
reviewed
again
quickly
by
the
court
.
<END>
<START>
MEDUSA
Corp.
said
it
voluntarily
prepaid
$
7
million
on
its
original
$
75
million
term
loan
,
bringing
the
total
debt
reduction
for
the
year
to
$
18
million
.
<END>
<START>

the
payment
,
the
Cleveland
company
owes
$
57
million
on
the
loan
.
<END>
<START>
The
cement
producer
said
the
payment
was
made
from
excess
cash
flow
.
<END>

.

,

.

.

<START>
MLX
Corp.
said
it
reached
a
preliminary
agreement
with
senior
lenders
to
its
refrigeration
and
air-conditioning
group
to
restructure
the
$
188.5
million
of
credit
facilities
the
lenders
provide
to
the
group
.
<END>
<START>
Among
other
things
,
the
restructured
facilities
will
substantially
reduce
the
group
's
required
amortization
of
the
term
loan
portion
of
the
credit
facilities
through
September
1992
,
MLX
said
.
<END>
<START>
Certain
details
of
the
restructured
facilities
remain
to
be
negotiated
.
<END>
<START>
The
agreement
is
subject
to
completion
of
a
definitive
amendment
and
appropriate
approvals
.
<END>

has

statement
with

and
Exchange
Commission
covering
a

of
$
120
million
in

.

<START>
Raw-steel
production
by
the
nation
's
mills
decreased
0.8
%
last
week
to
1,828,000
tons
from
1,843,000
tons
the
previous
week
,
the
American
Iron
and
Steel
Institute
said
.
<END>
<START>
Last
week
's
output
rose
1.4
%
from
the
1,802,000
tons
produced
a
year
earlier
.
<END>
<START>
The
industry
used
82.2
%
of
its
capability
last
week
,
compared
with
82.8
%
the
previous
week
and
84
%
a
year
ago
.
<END>
<START>
The
capability
utilization
rate
is
a
calculation
designed
to
indicate
at
what
percent
of
its
production
capability
the
industry
is
operating
in
a
given
week
.

<START>
Korean
car
exports
have
slid
about
40
%
so
far
this
year
,
but
auto
makers
here
are
n't
panicking
.
<END>
<START>
They
are
enjoying
domestic
sales
that
are
more
than
making
up
for
lost
overseas
sales
.
<END>
<START>
South
Korean
consumers
are
expected
to
buy
almost
500,000
passenger
cars
this
year
,
up
60
%
from
1988
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
are
very
lucky
to
easily
change
an
export
loss
to
domestic
plus
,
''
says
Hong
Tu
Pyo
,
managing
director
of
domestic
marketing
for
Hyundai
Motor
Co
.
<END>
<START>
As
it
is
,
waiting
lists
of
a
month
are
n't
unusual
for
popular
models
.
<END>
<START>
Demand
is
so
strong
that
all
of
the
domestic
makers
--
Hyundai
,
Kia
Motors
Corp.
,
Daewoo
Motor
Co.
and
even
upstart
SsangYong
Motor
Co.
--
plan
to
build
more
factories
.
<END>
<START>
Industry
analysts
predict
that
by
1995
,
South
Korea
will
be
building
three
million
cars
a
year
--
about
half
of
that
for
export
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
an
optimistic
move
in
a
industry
already
facing
world-wide
overcapacity
.
<END>
<START>
But
South
Korean
auto
makers
are
confident
that
the
export
market
will
bounce
back
and
that
demand
in
Korea
will
stay
strong
.
<END>
<START>
Currently
only
one
in
38
South
Koreans
owns
a
car
,
up
from
one
in
200
a
decade
ago
.
<END>
<START>
``
In
the
year
2000
it
will
be
one
car
per
family
.
<END>
<START>
At
that
point
domestic
sales
will
slow
down
,
''
says
Kim
Yoon
Kwon
,
director
of
marketing
for
Daewoo
Motor
.
<END>
<START>
The
reason
for
the
tremendous
demand
is
simple
:
South
Koreans
suddenly
have
a
lot
more
money
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
never
thought

'd
own
a
car
,
''
says
Kwang
Ok
Kyong
,
who
just
bought
a
Daewoo
LeMans
on

.
<END>
<START>
She
and

started
a
small
printing
business
and
need
the
car
for
work
as
well
as
for
weekend

.
<END>
<START>
Pay

of
60
%
over
the
past
three
years
have
given
many
South
Koreans
the
money
to
enjoy
the
things
they
were
supplying
the
rest

.
<END>
<START>
The

of
newcomer
SsangYong
Motor
shows
the
strength
of
the
auto

and
its
growing

.
<END>
<START>
A

construction-oriented
conglomerate

Group
,

took

Dong-A
Motor
Co.
in

.
<END>
<START>
SsangYong
began

Jeep-like
``
Korando
''

.
<END>
<START>
-LRB-
Dong-A
had

with
Jeep

American

Corp.
,

Corp
.
-RRB-
<END>

``

,
''

.

;

25,000
.

<START>
SsangYong
,

,

.

45

.
<END>
<START>

50

.
<END>

240

.
<END>
<START>

,

<END>
<START>

<START>

.

.
<END>

.

.

<START>
Many

.

,

.

,

.

.

<START>

,

.

<START>

reported

.

.
<END>
<START>
This
time
,
``
We

.
''
<END>
<START>
Of

,

could

if

.
<END>
<START>

,

.

,

%

--

--

.

<START>

.

<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>

.

,

Most

that
increase
came
in
the
first
hour
after
the
phone
lines
opened
at
8
a.m
.
<END>
<START>
As
stocks
rose
,
in
fact
,
some
investors
changed
course
and
reversed
their
sell
orders
.
<END>
<START>
Many
funds
allow
investors
to
void
orders
before
the
close
of
trading
.
<END>
<START>
Because
mutual
fund
trades
do
n't
take
effect
until
the
market
close
--
in
this
case
,
at
4
p.m.
--
these
shareholders
effectively
stayed
put
.
<END>
<START>
But
by
3:15
p.m.
,
with
the
market
comfortably
ahead
for
the
day
,

Sherman
was
preparing

switch
.
<END>
<START>

's

,
''

.
<END>
<START>

.

<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
This

.
<END>
<START>
That

,

<START>
SOFT
CONTACT
LENSES
WON
federal
blessing
on
March
18
,
1971
,
and
quickly
became
eye
openers
for
their
makers
.
<END>
<START>
The
Food
and
Drug
Administration
that
day
said
Bausch
&
Lomb
could
start
selling
them
in
the
U.S.
.
<END>
<START>
The
cornflake-size
product
was
more
comfortable
and
less
prone
to
falling
out
than
hard
contact
lenses
,
which
had
been
around
since
1939
.
<END>
<START>
Bausch
&
Lomb
sold
the
softies
under
a
sublicense
from
National
Patent
Development
,
which
had
gained
the
rights
from
the
Czechoslovakia
Academy
of
Sciences
.
<END>
<START>
Otto
Wichterle
,
a
Czech
,
invented
them
in
1962
.
<END>
<START>
The
plastic
lens
wraps
itself
over
the
cornea
,
absorbing
eye
moisture
while
permitting
oxygen
to
pass
through
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
new
lens
became
the
eye
of
a
storm
.
<END>
<START>
In
September
1971
California
officials
seized
``
bootlegged
''
lenses
--
made
by
unlicensed
companies
--
after
some
showed
traces
of
bacteria
.
<END>
<START>
In
October
doctors
were
debating
the
product
's
safety
,
some
claiming
it
caused
infections
.
<END>
<START>
And
there
were
Senate
hearings
on
the
questions
in
July
1972
.
<END>
<START>
The
product
overcame
the
bad
publicity
and
kept
evolving
.
<END>
<START>
The
early
soft
lenses
,
which
cost
$
300
a
set
,
were
expected
to
last
for
a
year
.
<END>
<START>
In
1983
``
extended
wear
''
versions
,
designed
to
be
worn
for
30
days
at
a
time
,
wree
offered
.
<END>
<START>
Eighteen
months
ago
a
``
disposable
''
seven-day
model
bowed
;
a
year
's
supply
costs
about
$
500
.
<END>
<START>
Last
month
the
FDA
and
Contact
Lens
Institute
cautioned
users
that
serious
eye
infections
could
result
from
wearing
lenses
more
than
seven

at
a

.
<END>
<START>
Today
20
million
of
the
25
million

using
contact
lenses
are
using
the
soft
type
.
<END>
<START>
Including
the
accesory
eye
care

,

account
for
$
2

.

that
the
landscape
of
our
country
alone
would
justify
the
use
of
this
lofty
adjective
...
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
the
very
lack
of
obvious
drama
or
spectacle
that
sets
the
beauty
of
our
land
apart
.
<END>
<START>
What
is
pertinent
is
the
calmness
of
that
beauty
,
its
sense
of
restraint
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
as
though
the
land
knows
of
its
own
beauty
,
of
its
own
greatness
,
and
feels
no

to

.
<END>
<START>
An
effusive
landscape
?
<END>
<START>
An
ill-mannered
mountain
?
<END>
<START>
His
answer
is
one
``
possessed
of
a
dignity
in
keeping
with
his
position
.
''
<END>
<START>
Such

``
has
to
do
crucially
with
a
butler
's
ability
not
to
abandon
the
professional

.
''
<END>
<START>
He
``

,

.
<END>
<START>
Continentals

as

.

<END>
<START>

;

``

.
''
<END>
<START>
You
see
,

to

.
''
<END>
<START>
We
note
the

word
used
to

rage

.
<END>
<START>
That
Stevens
himself
is

,

,
is
entirely

's

.
<END>
<START>
`
This

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

is

.
''
<END>
<START>

.

.
<END>
<START>

ca

.
<END>
<START>
Really
--

--
what

?
''
<END>
<START>
The
loyal

has
come

.
<END>
<START>
What
is

?
<END>
<START>
What
is

?
<END>
<START>
We

.

.

<END>
<START>
Hardly
.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>

.
<END>
<START>
Aer

.
<END>
<START>

<START>
An

.

<START>

.
<END>

,

,

.

<START>

.

.

<START>
When
Nucor
Corp.
begins
shipping
steel
from
the
world
's
first
thin-slab
plant
this
month
,
it
will
begin
testing
the
competitive
mettle
of
its
giant
competitors
.
<END>
<START>
The
new
technology
,
which
creates
a
very
thin
piece
of
steel
,
radically
reduces
the
costs
of
making
flat-rolled
sheets
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
've
had
the
Russians
and
Chinese
,
and
people
from
India
visiting
us
,
''
Mr.
Iverson
beams
.
<END>
<START>
``
Everyone
in
the
world
is
watching
us
very
closely
.
''
<END>
<START>
Especially
his
neighbors
,
the
major
U.S.
steelmakers
.
<END>
<START>
Already
,
USX
Corp.
and
Armco
Inc.
are
studying
Nucor
's
technology
to
see
if
they
can
adopt
it
.
<END>
<START>
Says
the
chief
executive
officer
of
a
major
Midwest
steel
company
:
``
It
's
damn
worrisome
.
''
<END>
<START>
The
once-staid
steel
industry
is
about
to
be
turned
topsy-turvy
by
a
1990s
technology
revolution
.
<END>
<START>
New
,
efficient
and
sophisticated
processes
make
it
easier
for
smaller
,
less
cash-rich
companies
to
make
steel
at
a
fraction
of
what
Big
Steel
paid
decades
ago
.
<END>
<START>
It
also
enables
minimills
finally
to
get
a
toehold
in
the
flat-rolled
steel
market
--
the
major
steelmakers
'
largest
,
most
prized
,
and
until
now
,
untouchable
,
market
.
<END>
<START>
But
such
thin-slab
technology
is
only
the
beginning
.
<END>
<START>
Eager
engineers
espouse
direct-steelmaking
and
direct
casting
,
which
by
the
end
of
the
1990s
will
enable
production
without
coke
ovens
and
blast
furnaces
.
<END>
<START>
Those
massive
structures
,
while
posing
cost
and
environmental
headaches
,
effectively
locked
out
all
but
deep-pocketed
giants
from
steelmaking
.
<END>
<START>
It
is
n't
that
major
steelmakers
have
blithely
ignored
high
technology
.
<END>
<START>
In
fact
,
they
've
spent
billions
of
dollars
to
boost
the
percentage
of
continously
cast
steel
to
60.9
%
in
1988
,
from
39.6
%
five
years
before
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
their
balance
sheets
are
rich
with
diversity
,
their
old
plants
shuttered
,
and
work
forces
lean
.
<END>
<START>
But
that
wo
n't
suffice
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
no
longer
enough
to
beat
the
guy
down
the
street
.
<END>
<START>
You
have
to
beat
everyone
around
the
world
,
''
says
Mr.
Dennis
.
<END>
<START>
He
wants
to
see
steelmakers
more
involved
in
computers
and
artificial
intelligence
.
<END>
<START>
The
problem
:
They
're
saddled
with
huge
plants
that
require
costly
maintenance
.
<END>
<START>
And
try
plying
new
dollars
free
in
a
market
that
is
softening
,
hurt
by
a
strong
dollar
and
concerned
about
overcapacity
--
the
industry
's
Darth
Vadar
.
<END>
<START>
``
The
technology
revolution
is
going
to
be
very
threatening
to
established
producers
,
''
says
Peter
Marcus
,
an
analyst
with
PaineWebber
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
've
got
too
much
invested
in
the
old
stuff
and
they
ca
n't
get
their
workers
to
be
flexible
.
''
<END>
<START>
No
one
expects
minimills
to
eclipse
major
integrated
steelmakers
,
who
remain
the
undisputed
kings
of
highest-quality
steel
used
for
autos
and
refrigerators
.
<END>
<START>
Still
,
flat-rolled
is
the
steel
industry
's
bread
and
butter
,
representing
about
half
of
the
80
million
tons
of
steel
expected
to
be
shipped
this
year
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
the
process
is
n't
without
its
headaches
.
<END>
<START>
Because
all
operations
are
connected
,
one
equipment
failure
forces
a
complete
plant
shutdown
.
<END>
<START>
On
some
days
,
the
Nucor
plant
does
n't
produce
anything
.
<END>
<START>
Indeed
,
with
demand
for
steel
not
growing
fast
enough
to
absorb
capacity
,
steelmakers
will
have
to
change
the
way
they
do
business
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
past
,
says
Armco
's
chief
economist
John
Corey
,
steelmakers
made
a
product
and
set
it
out
on
the
loading
dock
.
<END>
<START>
Armco
's
sales
representatives
visit
the
General
Motors
Corp.
's
Fairfax
assembly
plant
in
Kansas
City
,
Mo.
,
two

days
a
week
.
<END>
<START>
When
they
determined
that
GM
needed
parts
more
quickly
,
Armco
convinced
a
steel
service
center
to
build
a
processing
plant
nearby
so
shipments
could
be
delivered
within
15
minutes
.
<END>
<START>
But
steelmakers
must
also
find
new
markets
.
<END>
<START>
After
letting
aluminum-makers
take
the
recycling
lead
,
a
group
of
the
nation
's
largest
steelmakers
started
a

institute
to
promote
steel
cans
to
an
environmentally
conscious
nation
.
<END>
<START>
Battelle
's
Mr.
McCall
thinks
steelmakers
should
concentrate
more
on
construction
.
<END>
<START>
Other
steelmakers
envision
steel
roofs
covering
suburbia
.
<END>
<START>
Still
others
are
looking
at
overseas
markets
.
<END>
<START>
USX
is
funneling
drilling
pipe
to
steel-hungry
Soviet
Union
.
<END>
<START>
This
year
,
the
nation
's
largest
steelmaker
reactivated
its
overseas
sales
operation
.
<END>
<START>
Producers
also
are
trying
to
differentiate
by
concentrating
on
higher-profit
output
,
such
as
coated
and
electrogalvanized
products
,
which
remain
beyond
the
reach
of
minimills
.
<END>
<START>
Almost
all
capital-improvement
programs
announced
by
major
steelmakers
within
the
past
year
involve
building
electrogalvanizing
lines
,
used
to
produce
steel
for
such
products
as
household
appliances
and
car
doors
.
<END>
<START>
But
unfortunately
,
that
segment
is
much
smaller
than
the
bread-and-butter
flat-rolled
steel
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
like
everyone
climbing
out
of
the
QE
II
and
getting
into
a
lifeboat
,
''
says
John
Jacobson
,
an
analyst
with
AUS
Consultants
.
<END>
<START>
``
After
a
while
,
someone
has
to
go
over
the
side
.
''
<END>
<START>
Although
he
does
n't
expect
any
bankruptcies
,
he
does
see
more
plants
being
sold
or
closed
.
<END>
<START>
Robert
Crandall
,
with
the
Brookings
Institute
,
agrees
.
<END>
<START>
Not
to
mention
the
incursion
of
imports
.
<END>
<START>
Japanese
and
European
steelmakers
,
which
have
led
the
recent
technology
developments
,
are
anxiously
awaiting
the
lifting
of
trade
restraints
in
1992
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
the
U.S.
can
expect
more
competition
from
low-cost
producing
Pacific
Rim
and
Latin
American
countries
.
<END>
<START>
A
Taiwanese
steelmaker
recently
announced
plans
to
build
a
Nucor-like
plant
.
<END>
<START>
``
People
think
of
the
steel
business
as
an
old
and
mundane
smokestack
business
,
''
says
Mr.
Iverson
.
<END>
<START>
``
They
're
dead
wrong
.
''
<END>
<START>
*
USX
,
LTV
,
Bethlehem
,
Inland
,
Armco
,
National
Steel
<END>
<START>
**
Projected
<END>
<START>
Polaroid
Corp.
's
patent-infringement
damages
case
against
Eastman
Kodak
Co.
,
one
of
the
highest
stakes
corporate
trials
ever
,
is
getting
scant
attention
on
Wall
Street
.
<END>
<START>
After
78
days
of
mind-numbing
testimony
in
federal
court
in
Boston
,
the
trial
is
being
all
but
ignored
by
analysts
and
patent
attorneys
.
<END>
<START>
Most
have
read
the
pre-trial
documents
,
however
,
and
estimate
Kodak
will
be
ordered
to
pay
$
1
billion
to
$
1.5
billion
for
infringing
on
seven
Polaroid
patents
.
<END>
<START>
That
may
be
the
largest
patent
award
ever
,
but
it
is
well
below
the
$
12
billion
Polaroid
seeks
.
<END>
<START>
The
two
companies
later
agreed
to
settle
for
$
95
million
.
<END>
<START>
Few
analysts
think
it
is
worth
their
time
to
slog
through
the
Polaroid
trial
testimony
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
like
panning
for
gold
outside
of
Grand
Central
Station
.
<END>
<START>
You
might
find
something
,
but
the
chances
are
low
,
''
said
Michael
Ellman
,
an
analyst
at
Wertheim
Schroder
&
Co
.
<END>
<START>
A
75-day
trial
in
the
early
1980s
determined
that
Kodak
,
based
in
Rochester
,
N.Y.
,
infringed
on
patents
of
Polaroid
,
of
Cambridge
,
Mass
.
<END>
<START>
The
main
issues
remaining
are
how
to
calculate
damages
and
whether
the
infringement
was
``
willful
and
deliberate
.
''
<END>
<START>
If
so
,
the
damages
could
be
tripled
.
<END>
<START>
``
Carr
told
Kodak
on
many
occasions
to
avoid
various
features
because
of
Polaroid
's
patent
positions
,
''
and
Kodak
followed
his
advice
in
every
instance
,
Mr.
Crary
said
.
<END>
<START>
It
's
difficult
to
be
that
consistently
wrong
.
''
<END>
<START>
Observers
also
wonder
whether
Judge
Mazzone
will
use
the
lost-profits
method
of
determining
damages
,
which
Polaroid
favors
because
it
would
result
in
a
larger
award
,
or
the
reasonable
royalty
method
.
<END>
<START>
Polaroid
claims
it
could
have
manufactured
and
sold
all
the
instant
cameras
and
film
sold
by
Kodak
if
Kodak
had
n't
entered
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
Each
side
has
called
a
Harvard
Business
School
professor
to
testify
on
that
issue
.
<END>
<START>
Kodak
hired
Robert
Buzzell
and
Polaroid
brought
in
Robert
J.
Dolan
.
<END>
<START>
``
There
's
nothing
that
says
that
people
at
Harvard
Business
school
have
to
agree
with
each
other
,
''
said
Mr.
Buzzell
.
<END>
<START>
Testimony
is
expected
to
continue
until
early
December
.
<END>
<START>
A
decision
is
n't
expected
until
some
time
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
International
Business
Machines
Corp.
said
earnings
tumbled
30
%
in
the
third
quarter
,
even
a
bit
further
than
expected
,
rendering
the
outlook
doubtful
for
the
next
few
quarters
.
<END>
<START>
The
main
reason
was
a
delay
in
shipment
of
new
high-end
disk
drives
,
a
business
that
accounts
for
some
10
%
of
IBM
's
$
60
billion
of
annual
revenue
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
IBM
noted
that
the
stronger
dollar
has
cut
the
value
of
overseas
revenue
and
earnings
when
they
are
translated
into
dollars
.
<END>
<START>
Earnings
fell
to
$
877
million
,
or
$
1.51
a
share
,
somewhat
below
securities
analysts
'
revised
expectations
of
around
$
1.60
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
climbed
4.3
%
to
$
14.31
billion
from
$
13.71
billion
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
,
Armonk
,
N.Y.
,
remained
upbeat
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
in
a
statement
that
``
demand
for
IBM
products
and
services
continues
to
be
good
world-wide
.
<END>
<START>
We
do
not
see
anything
in
the
fundamentals
of
our
business
that
would
cause
us
to
change
our
strategy
of
investing
for
profitable
growth
.
''
<END>
<START>
Securities
analysts
,
however
,
remained
downbeat
.
<END>
<START>
``
I
think
1990
will
be
another
mediocre
year
,
''
said
Steve
Milunovich
of
First
Boston
.
<END>
<START>
Both
estimates
would
mark
declines
from
the
1988
net
of
$
5.81
billion
,
or
$
9.80
a
share
,
which
itself
was
well
below
the
record
IBM
set
in
1984
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Stevens
said
he
kept
a
``
buy/hold
''
recommendation
on
the
stock
only
because
``
all
the
damage
has
been
done
.
''
<END>
<START>
He
said
the
stock
has
n't
traded
below
1
1/2
times
book
value
over
the
past
10
years
,
which
at
the
moment
computes
to
a
stock
price
of
$
100
.
<END>
<START>
The
stock
closed
yesterday
at
$
103
a
share
,
up
just
$
1
in
composite
trading
on
the
New
York
Stock
Exchange
as
the
market
surged
.
<END>
<START>
Analysts
worry
that
the
disk-drive
and
leasing
problems
will
last
at
least
through
the
first
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
``
A
key

of

question
is
,
how
soon
does
this
disk-drive
come
and
how
soon
does
production
ramp
up
?
''
said
Steve
Cohen
at
SoundView
Financial
Group
.
<END>
<START>
``
And
the
input
I
've
had
from
customers
is
that
it
still
could
be
a
while
.
''
<END>
<START>
On
leasing
,
Bob
Djurdjevic
at
Annex
Research
said
he
thinks
IBM
has
hurt
itself
unnecessarily
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
IBM
has
priced
its
leases
aggressively
,
thinking
that
would
help
win
business
.
<END>
<START>
But
he
said
IBM
would
have
won
the
business
anyway
as
a
sale
to
a
third
party
that
would
have
then
leased
the
equipment
to
the
customer
.
<END>
<START>
He
said
IBM
has
not
only
hurt
its
short-term
revenue
outlook
but
has
also
been
losing
money
on
its
leases
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
is
expected
to
get
a
boost
soon
when
it
announces
some
new
versions
of
its
mainframes
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
basic
technology
in
the
line
is
almost
five
years
old
,
which
means
it
is
long
in
the
tooth
,
and
competitors
are
rolling
out
strong
products
of
their
own
.
<END>
<START>
IBM
is
gaining
momentum
in
the
personal-computer
market
,
and
is
expected
to
introduce
some
impressive
workstations
early
next
year
.
<END>
<START>
The
disk
drives
will
doubtless
sell
well
when
they
finally
become
available
.
<END>
<START>
But
the
AS/400
,
IBM
's
highly
successful
minicomputer
line
,
is
losing
its
momentum
,
and
some
analysts
said
sales
could
even
decline
in
the
fourth
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
And
expenses
,
up
7.9
%
in
the
quarter
,
have
stayed
stubbornly
high
.
<END>
<START>
In

nine
months
,
IBM
earned
$
3.17
billion
,
or
$
5.43
a
share
,
down
8.4
%
from
the

$
3.46
billion
,
or
$
5.83
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Revenue
increased
6.5
%
to
$
42.25
billion
from
$
39.68
billion
.
<END>
<START>
D.
Wayne
Calloway
,
also
chief

of
the
company
,
indicated
that
he
expects

to
raise

for
1989
after

company
releases
its

today
.
<END>
<START>
So
far
,
analysts
have
said
they
are

for
$
3.30
to
$
3.35
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
After
today
's

,
that
range
could
increase
to
$
3.35
to
$
3.40
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
The
official
said
he
also
would
be
comfortable
with
that
new
range
.
<END>
<START>
In
1988
,
the

giant
earned
$
2.90
a
share
.
<END>
<START>
Results
for
1989
will
include
about
40
cents
a
share
from
the
dilutive
effects
of

and

company

.
<END>
<START>
In

on

Exchange
,
the
company
closed
yesterday
at
$
57.125
a
share
,
up
$
3.125
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
said
third-quarter
sales
are
expected
to
increase
25
%
from
$
3.12
billion
of
last
year
's
third
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Calloway
blamed
the
slower

on
rainier

,
a

of
new
products
in
the
industry
and
--
to

--

.
<END>
<START>
PepsiCo
said
its

prices
were
about
2
%
higher
in
the
quarter
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Calloway
also

volume
rose
a

9
%
in
last
year
's
third
quarter
,
making
the
comparison
more
difficult
.
<END>
<START>
International
soft-drink
volume
was
up
about
6
%
.
<END>
<START>
Snack-food
tonnage
increased
a
strong
7
%
in
the
third
quarter
,
while
domestic
profit
increased
in
double

,
Mr.
Calloway
said
.
<END>
<START>
Excluding

business
acquired
in

,

international

jumped
40
%
,
with
sales
strong
in
Spain
,

and
Brazil
.
<END>
<START>
Total

profit
rose
30
%
.
<END>
<START>
Led

Hut
and
Taco
Bell
,

increased
about
25
%
in
the
third

on

22
%

.
<END>
<START>

for

rose
about
13
%
,

's

22
%
,

to

.

<START>

Bell
has

.

<START>

,

,

.

,

,

.

,
''

,
``

.

<START>
President
Bush
chose
Martin
Allday
,
a

friend
from
Texas
,
to
be

of

Federal

Regulatory
Commission
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Allday
would
succeed
Martha
Hesse
,
who
is
resigning
.
<END>
<START>
The
White
House
said
Ms.
Hesse
,
a
Chicago
businesswoman
who
previously
held
posts
at
the
Energy
Department
and
FERC
,
is
leaving
to
become
a

of
First
Chicago
Corp
.
<END>
<START>
Mr.
Allday
,
an
attorney
in

,

,
has

at
the

Department
.
<END>
<START>

,

in

.

FERC
is
a

that

.

<START>

.

.

<START>
Hydro-Quebec
said
it
notified
Central
Maine
Power
Co.
it
will
cancel
a
$
4
billion
contract
to
supply
electricity
to
the
Maine
utility
.
<END>
<START>
The
provincially
owned
utility
said
it
is
tearing
up
the
deal
because
``
the
contract
's
objectives
ca
n't
be
fulfilled
.
''
<END>
<START>
Hydro-Quebec
said
Maine
regulators
'
refusal
to
approve
the
contract
earlier
this
year
halted
work
on
transmission
lines
and
stopped
negotiations
for
resale
of
electricity
carried
through
Maine
to
other
utilities
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
would
now
be
physically
impossible
to
begin
deliveries
in
1992
,
''
a
Hydro-Quebec
official
said
.
<END>
<START>
The
contract
was
to
run
from
1992
to
2020
.
<END>
<START>
Under
the
contract
Hydro-Quebec
was
to
supply
400
megawatts
of
power
to
Central
Maine
Power
starting
in
1992
,
600
megawatts
starting
in
1995
and
900
megawatts
starting
in
<END>
<START>
Hydro-Quebec
said
Maine
regulators
'
refusal
to
approve
the
contract
means
Central
Maine
Power
has
lost
its
place
in
line
.
<END>
<START>
``
We
wo
n't
sign
any
new
contracts
-LCB-
with
deliveries
-RCB-
beginning
earlier
than
2000
,
''
the
Hydro-Quebec
official
said
.
<END>
<START>
He
said

<START>
The

,

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
But

,

,

,

<END>
<START>
Asia

and

to

.
<END>
<START>
The
decision
to
cancel
the
loan
exemplifies
the
tough
attitude
bankers
have
taken
toward
China
since
June
4
.
<END>
<START>
While
some

lending
has
resumed
,

lenders
remain
nervous
about
China
's
economic
troubles
and
foreign
debt
--
$
40
billion
at
the
end
of
1988
.
<END>
<START>
Many
loans
are
being
renegotiated
,
especially
those
tied
to
the
hotel
sector
,
which
has
been
hit
hard
by
a
post-June
4

.
<END>
<START>
Many
bankers
view
property-sector
loans
as
particularly

.
<END>
<START>
The
canceled
Shanghai
loan
leaves
Asia
Development
,
a
small

,
saddled
with
a
half-completed
32-story

and

.
<END>
<START>
The
project
,
known
as
Lotus

,
has

in

.
<END>
<START>
When

loan

was

,

was

as

.
<END>
<START>
Unlike
most

to
China
,

.
<END>
<START>
Instead
,

secured

from

Bank

that

would
lend
Asia
Development
the
entire
$
55
million
at

to

original

.
<END>
<START>
The
loan
was
to
have

in
just
two

,
as

.
<END>
<START>

,

,

.
<END>
<START>

's

,

.
<END>
<START>
The

is

,

's

.
<END>
<START>

11

because

.
<END>
<START>
The

comes
as

's

is

and

its

are

.
<END>
<START>
``
The
membership

concept
has
great

,
''

,

,

<START>

,

<START>

in
Makro
Inc
.
<END>
<START>
Six-year-old
Pace
,
based
in
Aurora
,
Colo.
,
operates
41
warehouse-club
stores
.
<END>
<START>
The
company
had
losses
for
several
years
before
turning
profitable
in
fiscal
1988
.
<END>
<START>
``
Warehouse
productivity
is
really
beginning
to
take
off
.
''
<END>
<START>
But
some

contend
K
mart
has
agreed

much
for
Pace
.
<END>
<START>
``
Even

as

,

's
expensive
,
''
said
Wayne
Hood
of

Inc
.
<END>
<START>
``
In
my
opinion
,
you
would
only
pay
that

if
you
were

a

in

.
''
<END>
<START>
Ms.

of

about

.
<END>
<START>
``
If
K

ca

,

?
''
<END>
<START>
At

,

.
''
<END>
<START>
But

's

.
<END>
<START>
For

,

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
It

,

<START>

,

at

36

,

.
<END>
<START>
Pace
rose

2.625

in

.
<END>
<START>
A

.
<END>

<END>
<START>
literally
.
<END>
<START>
Traders

.
<END>
<START>

.

.

.

?

<END>
<START>
After
two
years
of
drought
,
it
rained
money
in
the
stock-index
futures
markets
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
The
sudden
influx
of
liquidity
enabled
several
traders
to
reap
six-figure
windfalls
in
a
matter
of
minutes
as
prices
soared
,
traders
said
.
<END>
<START>
``
Guys
were
minting
money
in
there
today
,
''
said
John
Legittino
,
a
futures
broker
for
Elders
Futures
Inc.
in
Chicago
.
<END>
<START>
Each
index
point
represents
a
$
500
profit
for
each
S&P
500
contract
held
.
<END>
<START>
For
the
first
time
since
the
1987
crash
,
traders
said
that
they
were
able
to
trade
several
hundred
S&P
500
contracts
at
a
time
in
a
highly
liquid
market
.
<END>
<START>
Many
institutions
and
individual
investors
have
shied
away
from
stock-index
futures
,
blaming
them
for
speeding
the
stock
market
crash
on
Black
Monday
two
years
ago
.
<END>
<START>
More
than
400
traders
jammed
the
S&P
500
futures
pit
to
await
the
opening
bell
.
<END>
<START>
Traders
were
shouting
bids
and
offers
a
full
five
minutes
before
the
start
of
trading
at
8:30
am
<END>
<START>
The
contract
fell
five
points
at
the
open
to
323.85
,
the
maximum
opening
move
allowed
under
safeguards
adopted
by
the
Merc
to
stem
a
market
slide
.
<END>
<START>
But
several
traders
quickly
stepped
up
and
bid
for
contracts
,
driving
prices
sharply
higher
.
<END>
<START>
The
S&P
500
contract
that
expires
in
December
closed
up
a
record
15.65
points
on
volume
of
nearly
80,000
contracts
.
<END>
<START>
``
Traders
five
feet
from
each
other
were
making
bids
and
offers
that
were
a
full
point
apart
,
''
said
one
S&P
500
broker
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
could
buy
at
the
bid
and
sell
at
the
offer
and
make
a
fortune
,
''
he
marveled
.
<END>
<START>
Several
of
Wall

's
largest

,

Salomon
Brothers
Inc.
and
PaineWebber

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
Salomon
Brothers
was

last

,

.
<END>
<START>
Brokerage

.
<END>
<START>
Unlike

,

in

500

.
<END>
<START>
The

for
$
200
billion
of

regained

as

.
<END>
<START>

,

.
<END>
<START>
No

for

,

said
.
<END>
<START>
On

,

ground

as

fled
and

were

.

<START>
``

.
''
<END>
<START>

Now
,

.
''
<END>
<START>

,

,

,

.
<END>
<START>
``
Liquidity
has

,
''

.
<END>
<START>

,
''

.
<END>
<START>

.

<END>

.

.

''

.
<END>
<START>
``
You

,
''

.
<END>
<START>
``
It

in

,
because

.
<END>
<START>
I
'm

.
''
<END>
<START>
But
yesterday
's
rally
among
``
good
''
junk
was
a
badly
needed
tonic
for
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
Many
issues
``
bounced
off
the
floor
,
''
Mr.
Minella
said
,
and
benchmark
junk
issues
``
recovered
all
of
their
losses
''
from
Friday
and
early
yesterday
.
<END>
<START>
Traders
said
yesterday
's
rally
was
fueled
by
insurance
companies
looking
for
bargains
after
a
drastic
slide
in
prices
the
past
month
.
<END>
<START>
In
addition
,
mutual
funds
did
n't
appear
to
be
major
sellers
of
high-yield
securities
as
was
expected
.
<END>
<START>
``
Sometimes
a
shakeout
is
healthy
,
''
said
Drexel
's
Mr.
Feinman
.
<END>
<START>
``
People
will
learn
to
be
more
circumspect
.
<END>
<START>
If
they
do
good
credit
analysis
,
they
will
avoid
the
hand
grenades
.
<END>
<START>
I
think
the
market
is
in
good
shape
.
<END>
<START>
Should
you
really
own
stocks
?
<END>
<START>
That
's
a
question
a
lot
of
people
are
asking
,
following
the
stock
market
's
stunning
display
of
volatility
.
<END>
<START>
The
answer
,
say
academic
researchers
,
money
managers
and
investment
specialists
,
is
yes
--
as
long
as
you
approach
the
stock
market
as
an
investor
.
<END>
<START>
But
,
they
say
,
people
should
n't
try
to
be
traders
,
who
buy
and
sell
in
an
effort
to
ride
the
latest
economic
trend
or
catch
the
next
hot
stock
.
<END>
<START>
The
case
for
owning
stocks
over
the
long-term
is
compelling
.
<END>
<START>
But
a
dollar
invested
in
long-term
bonds
in
1926
would
have
grown
to
only
$
16.56
,
and
a
dollar
put
in
Treasury
bills
would
equal
a
meager
$
9.29
.
<END>
<START>
The
longer
the
time
period
,
the
less
risk
there
is
of
losing
money
in
the
stock
market
.
<END>
<START>
Over
time
,
the
odds
increasingly
favor
the
investor
with
a
diversified
portfolio
.
<END>
<START>
``
If
you
do
n't
need
the
money
for
10
years
,
there
's
a
clear-cut
case
for
sticking
to
a
steady
core
of
stocks
,
''
Mr.
Gregory
says
.
<END>
<START>
Stock-market
investments
also
help
balance
the
other
assets
an
individual
owns
,
says
John
Blankenship
Jr.
,
president
of
the
Institute
of
Certified
Financial
Planners
.
<END>
<START>
Stocks
have
a
place
in
an
investors
'
portfolio
along
with
real
estate
,
bonds
,
international
securities
and
cash
,
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
People
also
should
n't
invest
money
in
stocks
that
they
'll
need
in
the
near
future
--
for
example
,
for
college
tuition
payments
or
retirement
expenses
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
may
have
to
sell
your
stocks
at
a
time
when
the
market
takes
a
plunge
,
''
says
Mr.
Blankenship
,
a
Del
Mar
,
Calif.
financial
planner
.
<END>
<START>
He
says
individuals
should
consider
not
just
stocks
,
but
other
long-term
investments
,
such
as
high-quality
bonds
.
<END>
<START>
Despite
the
strong
case
for
stocks
,
however
,
most
pros
warn
that
individuals
should
n't
try
to
profit
from
short-term
developments
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
very
difficult
to
do
,
''
says
Donald
Holt
,
a
market
strategist
for
Wedbush
Morgan
Securities
,
a
Los
Angeles
brokerage
firm
.
<END>
<START>
``
Our
markets
move
so
fast
and
they
are
so
volatile
,
there
's
no
way
the
average
investor
can
compete
with
the
pros
.
''
<END>
<START>
Individual
investors
face
high
transaction
costs
of
moving
in
and
out
of
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
And
assuming
their
first
investment
is
successful
,
investors
will
have
to
pay
taxes
on
their
gains
.
<END>
<START>
That
can
reduce
returns
by
a
third
or
more
,
once
local
taxes
are
included
,
Mr.
Lipper
says
.
<END>
<START>
After
that
,
individual
traders
face
the
risk
that
the
new
investment
they
choose
wo
n't
perform
well
--
so
their
trading
costs
could
be
sustained
for
nothing
.
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
very
tough
for
most
individuals
to
out-trade
the
mutual
funds
or
the
market
,
''
says
Mr.
Lipper
.
<END>
<START>
``
You
should
really
think
twice
if
you
think
you
can
out-smart
the
system
.
''
<END>
<START>
Then
,
too
,
many
individual
investors
lack
the
sturdy
emotional
makeup
professionals
say
is
needed
to
plunge
in
and
out
of
the
market
.
<END>
<START>
So
what
's
the
best
way
to
buy
stocks
?
<END>
<START>
``
It
's
now
selling
at
a
multiple
about
even
with
the
market
,
''
says

Douglas
.
<END>
<START>
Moreover
,
Mr.
Douglas
sees

in

stocks
that
could

of
these

in

.
<END>
<START>
Many

in

of

a

of
this

,

.
<END>
<START>
``
We
're

a
real

in

in

stocks
,
''
he

.
<END>
<START>
The
pros
strenuously
advise

to
stay
away
from
the
latest

fad
.
<END>
<START>
They
say
that
's
especially
important
this
late
in
the
growth
phase
of
the
economic
cycle
,
when
there
's
no
robust

market
to
bail

out
of
their
mistakes
.
<END>
<START>
``
Buy
stocks
on
weakness
for
their
long-term
fundamentals
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
In
the
long
run
,
investment
advisers
say
,
most
investors
will
be
better
off
using
the
dollar-cost
averaging
method
of
buying
stocks
.
<END>
<START>
In
this
method
,
a
person
invests
a
regular
amount
every
month
or
quarter
into
the
stock
market
whether
the
market
is
up
or
down
.
<END>
<START>
That
cuts
the
risk
,
Mr.
Gregory
,
the
San
Francisco

manager
,
points
out
.
<END>
<START>
``
When
the
market
is
low
,
you
are
buying
more
shares
,
and
when
it
's
high
,
you
're
buying
fewer
shares
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
A
disciplined
program
will
work
the
best
,
Mr.
Boesel
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
One
of
the
hardest
things
to
do
is
to
buy
stocks
when
the
market
is
down
,
''
he
says
.
<END>
<START>
``
But
that
's
just
the
time
when
you
should
be
buying
them
.
''
<END>
<START>
Compound

,
